column2: Treasures of the house of Rothschild, noted for its role in the financial history of Europe, will be auctioned tomorrow while thousands of radio listeners hear the bidding.

Miss Lucy Pease Gay of this city will be married on May 8 to Harrison Brown, son of Mrs. Walter S. Brown and the late Mr. Brown. The ceremony will take place at the home of Miss Gay's mother, Mrs. Clara M. Gay in East Granbv.

Characterizing Paul the Apostle as the "greatest churchman that ever lived," the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill said in his sermon yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirtyseventh Street, that the church today would do well to recall some of his precepts.

Early in March it was being said in official circles in London and Paris that the longer the Spanish war lasted the less likely it was to spread and the less imminent was the danger of any other European war.

An investor purchased from the Maroom Holding Company the 51/2story apartment house for fortyeight families at 1,971 Grand Avenue, the Bronx. The property is 109 by 112 feet and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $119,400 held by the Union Square Sayings Bank.
Germany's shortage of wheat has led to new prohibitions against industrial use of the grain and to regulations designed to prevent accumulations to wheat stocks by bakeries.

The Knickerbocker Field Club, East Eighteenth Street and Tennis Court, Brooklyn, notable since 1889 for the fact that liquor has never been permitted in the clubhouse and a dogged fight to protect its acres, has capitulated at last in selling land for an apartment site.
Shrieking sirens and roars of cheering greeted Commander Armando Revoredo Iglesias when he arrived here this morning, completing a round-trip flight between Lima and Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Upsets were again in evidence in the international chess masters' tournament at the Casino today when, after two adjourned games from the sixth and seventh rounds had been finished, four of the five matches scheduled for the eighth round were decided.

A mother and six children were killed tonight when a blasting substance stored in the basement of their ten-room farm home exploded. Another child, a boy, was missing, and deputy sheriffs and neighbors joined the father in a search of the ruins for the body.

The special for the best in show at the close of the second annual exhibition of the Mahoning-Shenango Kennel Club tonight was awarded to the Sealyham Terrier, Ch. wolvey Noel of Clairedate, owned by Mr. and Mrs. W. O. Penney of Riverhead, L. I., and handled by Leonard Brumby of Hicksville.

For the privilege of using city streets, rural roads and national highways, commercial motor trucks and buses engaged in carrying freight and passengers paid to the various States and the District of Columbia in the calendar year 1935 a total of $286,043,508, plus $45,847,299 that went into the record as "Federal gasoline tax," which made the total reach $331,880,807.
All controversial opinion on the speed merits of the Class B OneDesign and Class X sailing dinghies went to the winds today in the final session of team racing off the Larchmont Yacht Club.
Prices of lard here dropped last week to new low levels. May lard closed at $11.40 a hundredweight, a net decline of 771/2 cents. July lard closed as $11.70 and September at $12, both off 75 cents.

Mayor La Guardia replied yesterday to attacks on his administration for the high cost of running the city and to criticism of salary increases for civil service employes. He declared that business and industry must realize that "there will be less taxes to pay" when higher wages and shorter hours have been established.

The first of several Staten Island functions marking the eighty-fifth birthday of one of the island's most distinguished citizens, Edward distinguished citizens, Edwin Markham, the poet, was held yesterday afternoon in the Veteran Firemen's Hall, West New Brighton. Markham was presented with a Bible by the Everyman's Bible Class.

Fabian Gaffke, outfielding rookie from Minneapolis, set the batting pace for the Red Sox today when Boston's American League representatives swept the two-game city series with the Bees with a 10-8 victory.

The Sampiro Realty Co., Inc., assigned to Ida Shapiro a mortgage for $15,000 on the southwest corner of Broadway and 187th St. On the north corner of Riverside Dr. and 161st St. the Rosecope Realty Corp., Samuel Ageloff, president gave to Ora Copel a third mortgage for $7,750, due next Oct. 9 at 6 per cent, subject to a first for $330,000 and to a second for $13,500.

Electric Bond and Share Company--Three months to March 31: Net income after expenses, taxes and preferred dividends, $351,566, compared with $72,453 last year. Twelve months to March 31: Net income, $1,185,604, compared with $833,334 for preceding twelve months.

The White Star Line announced today a net profit of [pound]546,659 for 1936 in marked contrast to the [pound]61,792 lost in 1935 and a deficit of not less than [pound]408,090 in slightly more than six months in 1934.

The early birds this morning will find "A Family Affair" in full swing at the Rialto, with the excite- d ment involving the "Ah Wilder- d ness" youngsters, Eric Linden and Cecelia Parker, with Julie Haydon, s: Spring Byingto . Charley Grapewin and Mickey Rooney....
A recruiting campaign for the Knickerbocker Greys, junior cadet corps, will start today and continue until Friday, April 30, it was announced yesterday by the Greys' board of directors.

Landon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, predicted yesterday that because of an unprecedented housing shortage facing this city rentals at all levels, particularly the lower ones, would rise considerably in the next six months.

Modified corporations may do as much to serve the general welfare in this country as the Scandinavian type of cooperatives now being studied and are probably better adapted to American needs, Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, said yesterday in an address at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

Harper Sibley, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, in writing to Congressional committees urging modification of the surtax on undistributed corporate earnings, today proposed, as "a simple but inadequate corrective measure," that 30 per cent of the taxable incomes of corporations be exempt from the surtax.

Sixty-six previous games having failed to produce a winner, the four men who finished all even in the world's pocket billiard championship started a round-robin play-off for top honors at Ponzi's Academy last night. Ralph Greenleaf of New York and Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia were victors before a gal lery of 500.

The reply the Jews made to Pontius Pilate, "We have no king but Caesar," is "one of the most tragic utterances" that has ever been made, the Rev. Dr. Philip S. Watters, pastor of Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church, White Plains, said yesterday at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

An extensive newspaper, magazine, poster and direct-mail campaign will be launched today by Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., for a seven weeks' "Spring Parade" in forty-eight States, according to David R. Wilson, president.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, issued a statement yesterday, giving his reasons for opposing the President's proposal on reorganization of the Supreme Court.
James Primrose Whyte, Professor of Oral English at Bucknell University, died of a heart attack tonight while listening to the radio at his home here. He was 68 years old.

Rosemarie Brancato, soprano; Grace Castagnetta, pianist; Yoichi Hiroaka, xylophonist, and the Phil-Sym Quartet presented a concert at the Town Hall last night for the benefit of the educators' division of the American ORT Federation.

Ohio has long been conspicuous among many competitors for her devotion to politics. This year she has more than upheld her reputation. For more than three months her Legislature and her Governor have been trying to do or not to do something about relief. Governor DAVEY, whose voice was loud for "no more taxes" when he was campaigning for re-election, has found in the Senate an unwelcome convert to a doctrine intended for the stump.
Eleven Federal agencies awarded 131 supply contracts for $4,679,241 under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, in the week ended April 15, the Department of Labor announced today.

Twelve new artists have been added to the roster for the Spring season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, it is announced by Lee Pattison, director. They are Margaret Daum, Nancy McCord and Helen Traubel, sopranos; Maria Matyas and Jennie Tourel, mezzosopranos; Donald Dickson, Ernst Fischer, Robert Nicholson, Rocco Pandiscio, Thomas L. Thomas and Robert Weede, baritones, and Leo Kopp, assistant conductor.
Current figures on employment in the United States may overestimate the jobless by as many as 5,000,000, Senator Vandenberg declared today.

In a speech dealing with internal and foreign political problems, delivered to supporters at a meeting in Szebedin today, Premier Koloman Daranyi indicated the terms on which Hungary is prepared to negotiate with the Little Entente [Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia] but did not say whether he would negotiate with the Little Entente as a whole or only with individuals.

Contrary to the expectations of the record crowd, the French champion, Mrs. Simone Mathieu, defeated Miss Helen Jacobs of the United States by 9-7, 6-0 in the final of the Eastern Mediterranean tournament at the Athens Tennis Club today.
Harvey William Partridge, retired investment broker, whose family has been identified with the growth of Western Massachusetts for 278 years, died here tonight at the age of 89.

The New York Hippodrome Opera Company presented "Aida" last night before a large and enthusiastic audience. There were two newcomers to Hippodrome casts, Jesus De Gaviria, who sang the role of Radames, and Mario Cozzi, who sang Amonasro. Both were well received.

Senator Byrd of Virginia, one of the leading advocates of Federal economy, virtually on the eve of the President's budget and relief message, made public today a summary of the introduction to a Brdokings Institution report on governmental reorganization, which has been sent to the Senate Select Committee to Investigate Executive Agencies.
President Roosevelt will draw back his sturdy right arm tomorrow and flip a shiny new ball to the infield to open the 1937 American League baseball season.
Mr. and Mrs. Walker Breckinridge Armstrong gave a buffet supper with dancing yesterday at Glenbreekin, their home in Darien, Conn.

Loew's, Inc., showed a net profit of $8,606,130 after depreciation, taxes and other deductions but before provision for surtaxes on undistributed income, according to the report for the twenty-eight weeks ended on March 11, to be announced today by David Bernstein, vice president and treasurer.

W. H. Coverdale, chairman and president of the Pierce Petroleum Corporation, the common stock of which was suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange on March 16, confirmed yesterday in a letter to stockholders the Exchange's statement on suspension that the sole assets of the company consist of 125,000 shares of common stock of the Consolidated Oil Corporation (formerly Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation) and approximately $375,000 in cash.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 91 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the two weeks preceding. Since about March 1 tonnage output has been at the highest rate in history, passing the previous peak rate, which was in June. 1929.

Before an audience consisting partly of Broadway managers and theatrical casting agents, the junior members of the George Pierce Baker Group of New York presented themselves last night in two one-act plays at Town Hall Club.

IN figuring out the chances of the various clubs in the big league campaigns that are about to start there are a few things to remember. As for instance: The Detroit Tigers looked great about this time last year. They were world champions. They had a fast club and a powerful club.
Two peasants were killed and several wounded today in a clash between peasants and police on the historic battleground of Raclawice where Tadeusz Kosciuszko defeated a Russian army in 1794.

The Rev. Dr. J. Newton Davies, Professor of New Testament Interpretation at Drew University, told the congregation of Metropolitan Methodist Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street, yesterday that care and worry are devitalizing and prevent us from realizing the best that is within us.

With the lifting of the ban by the Air Corps and Naval Aviation on information about a new engine development, some details of the world's largest aircraft. now under construction for the Atlantic service, became available yesterday.
The Naval Academy engaged in its first intercollegiate sailing regatta today and lost to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology team by 39 to 31 1/2.

Nearly 30,000 Chicagoans turned out today for a final preview of their big league baseball prospects and saw the White Sox defeat the Cubs, 7 to 6, in ten innings and win the intracity spring series for the third straight year, six games to five.

Major George Berry, president of Labor's Non-Partisan League, announced today that he and Attorney General Cummings would address a series of mass meetings in twenty-six cities tomorrow night in behalf of the Roosevelt court plan.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Artur Rodzinski directing, discoursed momentous matters at the final concert of the season at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The program was devoted lo to the three B's and contained the St two towering symphonies in C minor -- Beethoven's Fifth and Brahms's First.

Louis Kovach, 23 years old, of Roebling, a former lightweight boxing champion in the United States Navy, was killed early this morning when an automobile he was driving struck a telephone pole on Route 25 and overturned four times.
A fleet of eleven dinghies took part in the frostbite regatta at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today. Allan Clark won all the honors in Class D, and Egbert Moxham Jr. topped Class B.

The world's wheat markets are in the most unsettled condition that the trade ever has known. Fluctuations of prices last week were unusually wide, sharp breaks following bulges and similar rallies following breaks.

A slowdown strike in General Motors plants in the United States, followed by a walkout affecting 110,000 American workers, was predicted in union circles tonight if executives of General Motors of Canada, Ltd., refuse to recognize the Canadian local of the United Automobile Workers of America in collective bargaining negotiations by Tuesday.

The output of steel in Great Britain in March reached a new high record of 1,109,500 tons, which compares with 995,900 tons in February, the previous high record, and with 1,060,500 and 990,100 tons, respectively, in October and March, 1936.

Walter H. Chute nearly lost his life doing it, but he brought back 2,400 specimens of tropical fish for the John G. Shedd Aquarium, of which he is director. "Some people think fishing is fun," Mr. Chute said today as he rested from his twentieth expedition in behalf of the Lake Front aquarium. "They ought to have been along."

The Arts Students League announced yesterday the ten winners in its annual contest for out-oftown art students. Each winner is entitled to free tuition in any two classes of the school for eight and a half months.

Tom Henrich, the young outfielder who was declared a free agent by Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis last week after he found the Indians guilty of "covering up" by shifting the youngster from New Orleans to Milwaukee, has agreed to terms with the Yankees and will report to Manager Joe McCarthy today.

Little tent cities today dotted the shores of Kuskokwim Bay, where stampeders flocked by airplanes to search for fortunes in placer gold and platinum. The platinum rush centered on Goodnews Bay, where deposits were found on a narrow strip of beach.

The Right Rev. Frank W. Creighton, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, officiated at his last confirmation service in that capacity here this morning in St. John's Church, when he administered the rite to twenty-eight children of the parish.

An extensive new Italian naval program will be announced shortly in the Chamber of Deputies, well-informed sources said today. This was disclosed as the Official Gazette published a decree giving the State control of naval construction industries.

Dr. Edmund E. Day, director of the social science division of the Rockefeller Foundation and presidentelect of Cornell University, will be a speaker at the annual dinner of the Phi Beta Kappa Society of Princeton University in Proctor Hall of the Graduate College tomorrow evening.

In the members' stake at the third annual meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club, which was concluded today, highest honors were awarded to the Labrador dog Black Jack, owned and handled by Robert W. Morgan of New York.
Albino Hermogenes Arosemena, father of President Arosemena, died early today at the age of 85. He served in various public positions from 1885 until 1920, when he retired because of ill health.

A girl night-club violinist died in Roosevelt Hospital at 8 o'clock last night nine to eleven hours after she had been beaten with a claw-hammer in a third-floor rehearsal studio at 132-6 West Forty-third Street, just east of Times Square.

Playing nip-and-tuck ball all the way, the Reds loaded the bases in the ninth inning today and, with a rifleshot pinch hit by Kiki Cuyler, defeated the Tigers, 5 to 4. A rainsoaked crowd of 8,738 saw the first game on the Reds' home grounds this season.

A good demand for tenement houses in the Yorkville section of Manhattan was indicated in deals announced over the week-end. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, which recently reconditioned the five-story flat on a lot 25x100.8 feet at 343 East Eighty-sixth Street, sold it to the Rokraine Realty Corporation, Irving Friedman, president.

ETHEL BROWN, housewife, 573 South Broadway, Yonkers.-Liabilities $3,450, no assets except insurance. CHRISTIAN M. DANIELSEN, butcher and grocer, 1,519 Williamsbridge Road.-Liabilities $3,294. no assets.

For the first time in many years, setters outshone pointers in the closing event of the three-day meet of the Orange County Field Trial Club. Cicora Citation, a white and black setter owned by F. J. Frank of Madison, N. J., took first place in the stake for shooting dogs handled by amateurs.

The body of Mrs. Ruth Matteson Hartman, 28, wife of Adam J. Hartman of Watertown, was found this morning on Board Island, 500 feet from shore in the St. Lawrence River a mile below Clayton. A bar extending from the island to shore is two feet under water.
The further decline this week of [pound]4,276,000 in the Bank of England's circulation continued the movement which normally occurs after the holiday period.
Pennsylvanians by the thousands headed for rivers and creeks today to cast for trout as Sunday fishing became legal for the first time in the Commonwealth's history.

Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, executive director of the New York Catholic Charities, made an address last night on behalf of the annual appeal of the Catholic charities in the Archdiocese of New York which was opened yesterday and will continue all week. His talk was broadcast by Station WINS between 7 and 7:15 P. M.

Daniel J. Tompkins, former president of the United States Guarantee Company at 90 John Street, a large insurance firm, died yesterday at his residence, the Hotel Bossert, 98 Montague Street, Brooklyn. On Thursday he would have been 83 years old. A sister, Mrs. C. V. Hudson of Fulton, N. Y., survives.
The outlook for wheat supplies in Europe is not favorable and it is expected that the surplus by August will shrink to a minimum for the last ten years.

Alfred H. Kirchhofer, newly elected president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, expressed confidence today that the press is meeting its responsibilities "with a very sincere appreciation of the public obligation involved."

The Goldman Band, under the direction of Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, will inaugurate its twentieth Summer season on June 16 in Central Park, playing the eleven hundredth concert in its series, it was announced yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. John G. Meengs, since 1907 pastor of the Second Reformed Church of Schenectady and a past vice president of the General Synod of the Reformed Church in America, died today of pneumonia in a hospital here. His age was 63. He collapsed in the pulpit of his church last Sunday.

Orientation to the potentialities of life rather than to its myths and fables is one of the prime needs of the world today, Dr. Halford E. Luccock of Yale University Divinity School said in a sermon yesterday morning at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

Wholesale desertions across the Soviet Union's Far Eastern borders by Manchukuoan troops commanded by Japanese officers were alleged by the newspaper Izvestia today. It asserts that in some cases whole detachments together with their officers surrendered their arms at Soviet outposts.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

A head-on shot at the unprotected goal mouth by Substitute Freddy Ferreira midway in the second period gave the New York Americans a soccer victory over the St. Louis Shamrocks at Starlight Park yesterday, gave them the National Challenge Cup and also gave them the national championship.
A new issue of $1,000,000 city of Charleston (S. C.) waterworks 31/4 er cent bonds, due serially from 1938 to 1978, will be placed on the market today at prices to yield 1.50 to 3.40 per cent.
Professor Irving Fisher, Yale economist, will receive an honorary degree from Athens University, it was announced today during the colorful celebration of the university's centenary.

The downward movement of cotton prices, which began two weeks ago, continued last week. Prices for futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses last week of 27 to 54 points, following losses of 40 to 53 points in the previous week.

The Girls Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street, aided 1,652 girls during 1936, according to the annual report, made public yesterday. The league's guidance bureau held a total of 5,578 interviews and conferences with 1,013 girls. Two hundred and twenty-seven girls were under intensive care work during the year.

Lexington Av., n. w. cor. 87th St., 100.Sx 118.3: Julia 0., Inc., to Emanuel Ornstein, 296 Central Park West; mtg. $360,000. 127th St., s. s., 125 ft. e. of 7th Av., 60x 100; Minsay Realty Corp., to Julius K. Brody, 333 E. 86th St.; mtg. $38,000 ($1). 50th St., n. s., 275 ft. e. of 10th Av., 25x 100.5; William H. Bull Jr., to Otto H. Osenkop, 380 Riverside Dr. (quitclaim) ($1).

Members of the Stanwich Congregational Church, Greenwich, which has been without a pastor since the Rev. Lyman H. Merrill retired in August, extended a unanimous call today to Gayle Strickler, a student at the Union Theological Seminary, New York, to become their minister.
John Risley, Commissioner of Finance and former Mayor of Margate, N. J., died at his home in Margate today after a heart attack. His age was 64.

Dr. and Mrs. Robert H. Halsey of 17 East Eighty-ninth Street and the Cottage, Derby, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Halsey, to Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Whitfield of 28 East Sixty-third Street and Southampton, L. I.

A warning to employers to produce their witnesses and make a clear record in any proceedings before a regional labor board so that the appellate courts would not be round by "irrelevant or uncompetent evidence or finding of fact" was issued yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Blanche Haskell of Portland, Me., of the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Dorothy Haskell Chesley, to William Foster Lecraw, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Ross Lecraw of Plainfield. N. J.

Seven persons are leaving the rolls of the Emergency Relief Bureau for jobs in private industry for every four who quit the rolls of the Works Progress Administration in this city, an analysis of the extent to which relief recipients are finding private employment disclosed yesterday.
Olivar Asselin, prominent in French-Canadian journalism for many years, died today after a long illness. He was 62 years old.
The Retail Dairy, Grocery and Fruit Clerks Union, Local 338, was notified yesterday of its own suspension on charges of "insubordination."

Cheering lead and zinc miners, estimated at 6,000 in number, shouted defiance of the Committee for In-IN dustrial Organization and approval of affiliation with the American Federation of Labor at a mass meeting here today.
A Baptist pastor, victor in a bitter campaign for Mayor of this town of 400 inhabitants, promised an administration keyed to the golden rule with "no politics."

Senator Nye of North Dakota demanded today in a letter to President Federico Laredo Bru of Cuba that the Chase National Bank or any committee of its choosing be barred from representing American holders of defaulted Cuban public-works bonds at a conference this week in Havana at which the Cuban Government will seek to settle bondholders' claims.

Henry George Pickslay, who until he retired seven years ago was head of William Russell Co., coffee brokers, of 101 Front Street, New York, died today at his home here at the age of 79. Mr. Pickslay had been in the coffee business for forty-five years. He was born in Sharon, Pa., and was a member of the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

Allen Smith, 28 years old, of 351 Clifton Avenue, an unemployed theatrical press agent, shot and killed Mrs. Lois Duffy, 32, of 528 Summer Avenue today, and then shot himself fatally, according to the police. He died at City Hospital at 8:06 o'clock tonight.

Frank Rutter, one of the first English art critics to champion the French impressionists, died today. He was 61 years old. His early interest in painting was attributable perhaps to the fact that his father, the late Henry Rutter, was for years solicitor for John Ruskin.
Munster won the inter-provincial Gaelic football championship by defeating Leinster, 9 to 5, in an interesting battle before 2,000 fans at Innisfail Park yesterday.

That old police tradition, "Fight it out, even if your adversary has the drop on you," was decried by Mayor Frank Hague today when he addressed 800 policemen and firemen at the annual communion breakfast in Grandview Auditorium.
Clarence M. Lowes, for many years a leader in banking and civic circles on the North Shore of Queens, died yesterday morning at his home, 134-04 Franklin Avenue, Flushing. He was 64 years old.
William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company said in a radio address tonight that higher wages and lower prices are "a practical accomplishment wherever enlightened management has a free hand."

Dr. Thornwell Jacobs, president of Oglethorpe University, delivered an address yesterday afternoon which he hopes will be transmitted to the people of 8113 A. D. by means of a phonograph recording to be buried in a stainless steel crypt under the university's library at Atlanta, Ga.
Rules of the New York Stock Exchange requiring members and firms to be fully margined at all times during the trading day--the so-called "daylight trading" regulations--will take effect on May 17.
The French weekly wholesale price average as of April 10 was 541, compared with 539 on April 3 and with 404 on Sept. 26, 1936, or just before the franc was devalued.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota was the principal speaker last night at the launching of a "No Foreign War" crusade at a meeting of the Brooklyn division of the Emergency Peace Campaign. The meeting was held in the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Clinton and Montague Streets, Brooklyn.

The outlook for Premier Senjuro Hayashi's Cabinet in the coming general election became darker today when the Kokumin Domei, a minor party hitherto supporting the Cabinet, announced it would join forces with the major parties opposing it.

Herbert P. Haschke will manage the office opened in Houston, Texas, by Marwick, Mitchell Co. C. Milton Osborne has announced the change of his firm name and address to C. M. Osborne Co., 52 William Street. Herbert Filer has moved to 25 Broadway.

Dr. Walter Reynolds, a pioneer physician here, died at his home here today after a heart attack. He was 72 years old. Born in England, he came to the United States and was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Medical School.

Frank L. Marcelle, attached to the legal department of the B. M. T. for more than thirty-five years, died yesterday at his home, 1,449 Bath Avenue, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 69 years old.

The Rev. Theodore Parker Ferris, an assistant at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, at Tenth Street and Broadway, New York, has accepted a call as rector of Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church, Baltimore, and will take up his new work in September.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson in newspaper advertising tomorrow will invite utility-management enterprises to submit bids for operation of Philadelphia's city-owned gas plant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble and to petition the government for a redress of grievances."-The First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

The situation in the United States remains somewhat puzzling to Dutch observers. Still, after the various strike successes and passive government attitude, and the unexpected Wagner law decision and, not least, Henry Ford's considerably less indulgent attitude toward trade unions, it appears as if the American situation is assuming a more definite shape.
Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., defeated Bryan (Bitsy) Grant in the final of the Atlanta invitation tennis tournament today, 6-0, 6-0, 7-5.

John D. Rockefeller Sr., who is at his Winter home, The Casements, Ormond Beach, Fla., has sent word to Pocantico Hills, where he has a large Summer estate, to have the house ready for occupancy on June 1.

Macklin Marrow conducted the third and final program of the Spring series of "Continental Concerts" at the Plaza last night. The assisting artists were Deems Tayor, who led his own ballet music from "Casanova," and Colette D'Arville, soprano, who sang a group of songs by Debussy, Roussel, Faure and Obradors which Mr. Taylor had orchestrated.
The entire German press devotes considerable space today to the publication of further sweeping denials of rumors abroad of an impending Russo-German rapprochement along political and economic lines.

Miss Kathleen Keenan, chairman of the State Chapter of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, presided at a foreign-relations forum at the Good Counsel College this afternoon, attended by about 150 members and friends of the alumnae.
The Committee for Industrial Organization announced at a mass meeting today that a drive to organize about 18,000 textile workers here would get under way tomorrow.
A return in religion to the simplicity of Christ and His utterances was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, the chaplain, in his address at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.
While one union of the Committee for Industrial Organization was stalemated in Oshawa, another, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, today won a partial victory by its strike in Montreal.

An offering of $10,000,000 of tenyear 4 per cent convertible debentures of the Interlake Iron Corporation made to stockholders and to the public will be completed today when an underwriting group headed by Hayden, Stone Co. will offer publicly the debentures not taken by the stockholders. The debentures will be priced on application.
Mrs. H. Davidson Craig of Denver gave a dinner last night at the national headquarters of the Junior League in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Remarriage after divorce is condemned in a statement made public yesterday by a group of fifteen Episcopal clergymen from all parts of the United States. The statement was mailed to 160 Bishops and 6,200 priests of the communion with a request for additional signatures.

Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the Nazi party, who speaks for Chancellor Adolf Hitler, issued a warning to the churches today in an address at Karlsruhe. Catholics particularly were told to watch out for trouble.

Police are investigating an attempt on the life of Dr. Vicente Vita, managing director of the Nicaraguan National Bank. While driving his car at night Dr. Vita passed a man who turned a flashlight on the number of the car. On the return trip, a few minutes later, four shots were fired at Dr. Vita, but all missed.

Princeton University's polo team will play four outdoor matches next month against traditional rivals, it was announced today by the Princeton Polo Association. Two matches are arranged for the junior varsity and three for the yearling riders.

PARIS--The Socialist party council, upholding Premier Blum, voted to dissolve the extremist bloc that has been calling for intervention in Spain. But the debate indicated the party faces a crisis. Page 1.

Liquor tax returns have been far below the estimates of advocates of repeal, Fred A. Victor, State Superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, declared last night in an address assailing "false prophets" of repeal. He spoke before the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th Street.

Protesting that church attendance alone was not enough, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, the rector, urged the congregation at the Sunday morning services at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Nineteenth Street and Fifth Avenue.
A church roof crashed on several score persons gathered for prayer during earth tremors at the Andean city of Cajabamba, reports to Lima said today. In a rush for the doors several were injured.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn read a message from Pope Plus XI at the Church of Our Lady of the Presentation, Rockaway and St. Marks Avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, conveying his "most cordial felicitations and the assurance of his apostolic blessing," in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the parish.
Fire swept through the two upper floors of the ten-story New Secor Hotel here tonight, driving out guests and employes. Fire Chief Fred T. Schlorf estimated damage at $20,000.

A large piece of plaster ceiling fell with a crash onto diners in a wing of Lundy's Restaurant, Emmons and Ocean Avenues, Sheepshead Bay, early last night, causing slight injuries to five persons. The restaurant had a crowd of 2,000 at the time.

The Agfa Ansco Corporation has reported for 1936 a net profit of $157,486 after all charges, reserves and taxes, including provision for Federal surtax on undistributed profits. This is equal to 33 cents a share on 480,000 common shares. In 1935 the net profit was $15,377, or 3 cents a share.

Miss Ann Rossiter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. G. Rossiter of this place, will be married to Andrew Jefferson Berry Jr. of Scarsdale on May 14 in the Reformed Church here by the Rev. John H. Powell Jr., the pastor. The ceremony will be followed by a reception at the Siwanoy Country Club.

Argentina finished the financial year 1936 with a balanced budget, Roberto Ortiz, Minister of Finance, says in a preliminary report, according to cabled advices received here yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau.

Quoting the recent Brussels statement of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the German Economics Minister, that a European economic agreement presupposes a general political settlement, Yvon Delbos, the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, repeated at Carcassonne today that France was ready at any time to seek by every possible road peace and friendship with her neighbors; whatever re gimes they might prefer for their internal government.

The Princeton University Council on Athletics has sanctioned 186 awards to undergraduates for participation in Winter sports as either members or managers of fifteen Nassau teams, according to the list released today by Asa S. Bushnell, '21, graduate manager of athletics at the university.

Miss Ada Forbush Dewson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Dewson of Milton, Mass., will be married to Edward Goodridge Iselin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Iselin of The Chestnuts, Riverdale, on May 16.

No Sir, Miss Mary Hirsch's Kentucky Derby hopeful, picked up added admirers today after an impressive 1:40 3-5 mile over a none-too-fast track at Churchill Downs. The work-out was the most impressive for the 3-year-old son of Sortie since his arrival from Florida.

Doubly significant as evidence of the growing internal unity and as evidence of the national determination to use force to resist Japan is a secret agreement, Just concluded, providing for the formation of a new Chinese national defense council.
Back in 1854, John "Soda Ash" Horan asked for a job stacking cord wood for the Milwaukee Railroad. He said that he wanted something that would give him steady work.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Mae Cunningham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howell C. Cunningham of this city, to Donald H. Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Parker of Englewood, N. J., has been announced by her parents.
Funeral services for Brig. Gen. Jay Morrow, U.S.A. (retired), were held here today at the house where he had lived with his sister. He died early yesterday.

Dr. George Croft Cell, Professor of Historical Theology at the Boston University School of Theology since 1908, died here today. His age was 62. Born in St. Thomas, Pa., Dr. Cell was graduated from Baker University, Baldwin, Kan., in 1901.

Mrs. Sidney W. Fish, a prominent member of the East Hampton (L. I.) Summer colony and daughter-in-law of the late Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish, New York and Newport society leader, died at her Winter home here early today.

Dr. Roy L. Blackman and C. N. Calkins won the best-ball tournament which climaxed a golf outing of the New York Athletic Club at the Sea View Club today. The pair had a low gross of 70 for the eighteen holes.

The collapse of the security and the commodity markets here following the entirely unsupported rumors that the United States was contemplating a reduction in its buying price for gold gave place this week to some recovery and to the restoration of healthier conditions in the markets.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 86.8 on April 14, which compared with 87.2 a fortnight before, 85 on March 10 and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.
Three bandits invaded the Delmonico Hotel, Park Avenue near Sixtieth Street, early yesterday, held up four guests in an elevator and took about $15,000 in jewels and money.

The outstanding feature of the Bank of France's report, dated April 9, is the increase of 3,500,000,000 francs in Treasury deposits, which is the result of the payment by French banks of the balance of subscriptions to the recent national defense loan.

Six railway employes were dismissed and arrested on charges of criminal negligence and the reorganization of passenger service in the interests of safety was ordered as a result of an unusual accident on the outskirts of Moscow last Monday in which seven were killed and twelve others seriously injured.

American universities and colleges will send the largest delegation to the 200th anniversary ceremonies. of Goettingen University June 25 to 30, as they did last June to Heidelberg's 550th anniversary, which was turned into a propagandist demonstration for National Socialist science.

Announcing the appointment of Miss Henrietta Additon, former Deputy Police Commissioner, as Director of Welfare activities for the New York World's Fair, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, disclosed yesterday plans were being made for a welfare program to be carried on in connection with the exposition.

The Rev. Robert H. Kelley, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church at Hartsdale for the last eleven years, and who has served forty-five years in the ministry, nounced his retirement as active pastor tonight when he preached his final sermon.

Davidson Av. (11-3198), n. w. cor. Evelyn Pl., 100x25; Christian J. Osterholz to John G. H. Klemeyer, 2,323 Davidson Av.; mtg. $27,000. Jackson Av.. 534 (10-2579): Theresa Jesch to Helen Kowalsky, 551 Cauldwell Av.; mtg. $23,100. Taylor Av., 1.243 (14-3764): Michael Snyder to Minnie Sick, 867 Eagle Av.

The personnel of Klumpp, Glynn Co., 1,700 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, has become the yarn department of Bliss Fabyan Co., Inc. Joseph J. Klumpp and Martin P. Glynn Jr., and their associates have represented a number of spinning mills, which will continue with the new department, with sales activities centered in Philadelphia.
Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. tonight declared President Roosevelt's Court Reorganization Bill, if passed, would "establish a precedent which could be used to destroy this Republic."
The Spanish civil war was nine months old yesterday. At midnight tonight interna- tional non-intervention control of Spain's land and sea frontiers is scheduled to become fully effective.

After many hours spent questioning a neat, gray-haired watchman, Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx and high police officials expressed the belief yesterday that the man responsible for many of the incendiary fires that have terrorized residents of the lower east Bronx in the last two years had been apprehended.

Carleton Beals, well known writer who resigned yesterday as a member of the subcommission of inquiry into the Moscow charges that Leon Trotsky conspired with Germany and Japan against the Soviet Union, today charged Professor John Dewey, chairman of the inquiry, with distorting the meaning of his letter of resignation from that body.

Mrs. Eleanor Patterson, who for several years has been publisher of The Washington Herald, a daily and Sunday morning newspaper owned by William Randolph Hearst, announced today that she had leased the paper for a period of years.

Midwestern bowlers, following a custom which has prevailed on the previous five Sundays in the longdistance kegling classic, once again were responsible for a number of changes among the leaders in the various divisions as the American Bowling Congress championships went through their thirty-ninth day at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday.

" Today, when we are able to look back into the past and behold the spectacle of great nations and of great civilizations falling because they were unprepared for the future, we fully realize the truth proclaimed of old-where there is no vision the people shall perish,"

President Roosevelt, in his forthcoming message to Congress on estimates for relief expenditures and budget needs for the coming fiscal year, is planning to submit proposals for a slash of $250,000,000, it was reliably reported today.

The marriage of Miss Margaret MacLane Johansen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Johansen of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., to Robert Worthington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Briggs Worthington of Dedham, Mass., took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 12 West Ninth Street.

Japanese villagers wearing quaint costumes which they conceived to be American garb of the Eighteen Fifties paraded the streets of this little seacoast town today in commemoration of the arrival here eighty-four years ago of an American squadron under Commodore Matthew C. Perry.

Profound and ancient truths, which passing contentions cannot permanently bury, shine forth in the moving homily delivered by His Eminence Cardinal HAYES at the luncheon on Saturday inaugurating the annual drive for Catholic Charities in the archdiocese of New York.
The homing pigeon season opened yesterday with a flight of thousands of birds from Wilmington, Del., to New York. Pigeon fanciers from Manhattan, the Bronx, Westchester, Brooklyn,
George Puchta, former Mayor of Cincinnati, Ohio, died here today at St. Luke's Hospital. His age was 77. Death was attributed to an abdominal ailment complicated by pneumonia.

Gaining $11,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, total net sets of the Massachusetts Investors Trust on March 31, before provision for Federal taxes, were valued at $139,125,567, equivalent to $30.04 on each of the 4,630,632 shares outstanding, according to the organization's report.

Negotiations between officials of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and the United Rubber Workers were broken off today, after a session that started at 9 A. M. yesterday and adjourned at midnight.
Seven persons were killed and two houses were set afire by incendiary bombs in the center of Bilbao in an Insurgent air raid today.

The annual Spring luncheon under the auspices of the Alumnae Association of the College of Mount St. Vincent will take place May 1 in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium at the College. The occasion will mark the forty-first annual gathering of the organization.

Striking bus operators, employed by the Akron Transportation Company, voted at a meeting today to give up their American Federation of Labor membership and to seek affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Three months have passed since Congress convened, and the early unity of the Democratic party, the rosy hopes of a short session and the bright prospect of a swift adjournment have all vanished in thin air. One of our Washington dispatches spoke last week of party "seething with discord."

Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Glaser of Grymes Hill, S. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elsa Glaser, to Arthur Lincoln Webber, son of Mrs. George Henry Webber of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Webber. The announcement was made at a reception given yesterday at the Glaser home.
Although British exports currently are expanding in satisfactory measure, imports also continue to increase--and at a still faster pace.

Fifteen experts of the Philadelphia Chess Association played the annual inter-city match with the Manhattan Chess Club at the Hotel Alamac yesterday and, as in Philadelphia a year ago, Manhattan won 9 to 5, with one game adjourned.

Three persons, including Paul G. Jeans, editor of The Miami Tribune, were killed and a fourth injured in an automobile accident near St. Augustine today. Officers identified the other dead as M. Victor Miller, 32, of Miami, vice president of The Tribune and its attorney, and Edward Morr of Cincinnati.

Enrique Santamarina died this afternoon after a long illness. He was 64 years old. He was Vice President of the provisional government headed by General Uriburu after the revolution of 1930, which overthrew President Hipolito Irigoyen.

A total of 2,021,100 children and adults made use of the facilities offered last Winter at play centers of the Department of Parks, it was announced yesterday. The centers were closed yesterday for the Winter season, so that they can be repaired for the opening of the coming swimming season.

The Senators closed their training season today by defeating the Baltimore Orioles, 15 to 9, and squaring a two-game series. Joe Kuhel made three of four home runs hit by the winners, one with a man on base.

A new contest is under way between the Spanish belligerents for aerial superiority, which in the past few months has been the government's. Much now depends on which side first establishes the larger and superior air force.

With the beginning of this week the Boerse's month-long inertia ceased, and industrial securities advanced all along the line, without, however, impairing the firmness of the bond market. Secondary influences in this favorable turn were the satisfactory March employment figures and the general abundance of money.

Count Felix von Luckner, who, as commander of the famous commerce raider Seeadler, was one of Germany's World War heroes, sailed today on another good-will tour in command of the 200-ton schooner Seeteufel (Sea Devil).

It is universally accepted as true here that speculation played a large part in the recent general rise and that similarly the current recession is attributable principally to the liquidation of commitments rashly entered into at top prices.

Meeting of the National Association of Directors of Physical Education for College Women and the Eastern District Society of Directors of Physical Education for College Women, Hotel Pennsylvania, 9:30 A. M. Luncheon noon. Afternoon session 2 P. M. Dinner 7 P. M. Continues tomorrow.

The all-events mark of Billy Simon, San Antonio pinwoman, was the only score to survive the heavy individual shelling in the Women's International Bowling Congress tonight, although the St. Louis Camel Sodas retained their team lead against the drive of the eighteen Toledo outfits.
Six races were held in the weekly dinghy regatta today over the threequarter-mile course of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Apparition, owned by George Lauder 3d, was the winner on points.

The executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America issued yesterday a call to church members generally "to support all sound and effective measures for slum clearance and the rehousing of low-income wage-earners."

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 94.3, which compares with 94.5 the week before, 94.7 two weeks before, 94.4 three weeks before, and 93.7 four weeks before.
Plans for organizing Ford Motor Company employes, informed sources said tonight, will come before the high command of the United Automobile Workers at Washington tomorrow.

Mayor Frank Hague's campaign for re-election will be launched officially tomorrow by the Democratic Speakers Bureau, with the Mayor making his opposition to sitdown strikes and Communists his principal talking point.

Bringing optimistic forecasts for business, the advance guard of more than 500 publishers, editors and managers of newspapers throughout the United States and Canada began arriving yesterday for the annual meetings of The Associated Press and the American Newspaper Publishers Association this week.

Metals have been hit more severely in the recent commodities slump than any of the other leading staples. Before the United States gold valuation scare a substantial reaction from the peak levels of the present movement had occurred.

Two girl inmates charged before a legislative investigating committee today that they fled the Windham County Home for Children April 9 to escape the "unfatherly" attentions of Philip J. Provandie, the superintendent.

Imports or gold in March aggregated [pound]37,576,000 and exports [pound]21,913,000. Of the imports [pound]25,253,262 came from France, [pound]4,336,970 from South Africa, [pound]4,582,056 from Russia, [pound]1,165,335 from India, [pound]530,230 from Australia, [pound]469,567 from Southern Rhodesia, [pound]323,252 from West Africa, [pound]322,148 from Belgium, [pound]220,439 from Holland, [pound]103,287 from Germany and the remainder from other countries.

President Agustin P. Justo on a tour of Tucuman Province was impressed yesterday by the rosy cheeks of the school children in a district where malaria and other diseases have given the region a reputation for poor health.

It is one of the favorite contentions of the new school of economists that the productive capacity of this country has never had a real test. The reason it has never been tested, they contend, is that sufficient purchasing power has never been distributed to the population.

Representatives of the nation's banking fraternity are here for a three-day session of the executive council of the American Bankers Association. The association's president, Tom K. Smith of St. Louis, said today that all meetings would be secret.
Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Health Service, expects to complete his book, "Shadow on the Land: Syphilis," early in May, Reynal Hitchcock, who will publish it, report.

In spite of its being a cold, bleak Sunday morning, scores of thousands of Londoners lined the streets early today to witness a rehearsal of the procession in which King George VI and Queen Elizabeth will proceed to their coronation May 12.

Robert G. Barnes, '37, of Philadelphia, has been selected as the recipient of a fellowship granted by the Princeton-Yenching Foundation to enable a senior graduating from the Princeton School of Public and International Affairs to spend a year studying and teaching at Yenching University, Peiping, China.

Sylvia Manning and Gene Martel gave their first New York recital last night at the Guild Theatre, assisted by their concert group of ten dancers. It was a highly creditable debut, especially since it was of far more ambitious proportions than it needed to be.

Governors Frank Murphy, Democrat, of Michigan, and Francis P. Murphy, Republican, of New' Hampshire, who met here tonight for the first time; divided the responsibility for the maintenance of industrial peace between employers and employes.

The Roosevelt Savings Bank sold 4 to Walter A. Baron, operator, the four-story walk-up apartment house for eighteen families at 25 McDonough Street, Brooklyn. The house is on a plot 50 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $43,000 for five years at 4 1/2 per cent.

More than thirty new exhibitions are on the calendar for the current week in art galleries, museums, clubs and other institutions. As the number of attractions holds up so does the diversity of offerings, which has been so marked this season, also continue.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek has told in three preceding articles how she struggled to save Generalissimo Chiang, held captive at Sian, and to prevent civil war in China. Against the military leaders' strong opposition, she determined to fly to Sian.

The city will continue to give relief on the basis of need, without regard for the political views, race or religion of the recipient, Mayor La Guardia told 1,500 employes of the Emergency Relief Bureau yesterday at the second annual communion breakfast of the Ozanam Guild at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The following were the best sellers for the week ended Saturday: NEW YORK Reported by the American News Company, Brentano's, Doubleday Doran Book Shops, Gimbel's Macy's Scribner's Wanamaker's and Womrath's:
Although steel production continues at a high level, new buying is in lighter volume, according to the issue of the magazine Steel which will appear today.

The contention that 1935 marked the turn in the tide of the city's fight to restore its financial credit was made yesterday in a statement issued by the Department of Finance, coupled with a four-year statement of the city's income, penditures and debt status.

President Roosevelt told a group of Congressional leaders at a White House conference tonight that he would send a budget message to the Capitol proposing a new expenditure of about $1,500,000,000 for work relief for the fiscal year 1938 and containing reassurances of no increased taxes at this session of Congress.

Current employment and unemployment estimates confront still another challenge. This time the attack comes from Senator VANDENBERG, who voices the suspicion that the Department of Labor underestimates employment in the United States by at least 5,000,000.

The Twomey bill designed to permit the District Attorney of Brooklyn, instead of the Board of Estimate, to fix the salary of a law assistant in the District Attorney's office was vetoed tonight by Governor Lehman.

The many commissions and committees affiliated with the executive council of the American Bankers Association today began their individual sessions, preparing and considering reports that will be submitted tomorrow for adoption or rejection by the executive council.

A veritable zoo of mammals, birds and reptiles, which gave the freighter City of Rayville the appearance of a modern Noah's Ark, arrived here early yesterday. About 750 monkeys, numerous birds of various species, three female baby elephants and more than 200 snakes were included in the unusual cargo.

The trial of Salvatore Ossido, 26year-old barber, accused of criminally assaulting and murdering 9year-old Einer Sporrer, Germanborn parochial schoolgirl, in the back room of his barber shop on March 19, started yesterday before County Judge George W. Martin and a blue-ribbon jury in Brooklyn.

A bill by which six auxiliary naval vessels would be laid down during the next year at a cost of $48,000,000 was introduced in the Senate today by Chairman Walsh of the Naval Affairs Committee. Listed were one seaplane tender, a destroyer tender, a mine-sweeper, a submarine tender, a fleet tug and one oiler. or 36,050 tons in all.

Sales tax collections for the first quarter of 1937 were $10,760,579 up to last Saturday, against collections of $10,345,073 for the same period yast year, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, former world's pocket billiard champion, last night advanced to the threshold of another crown when he conquered young Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., 125 to 72, in an eight-inning encounter in the roundrobin play-off for the title.

Funeral services were held yesterI day at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, for Dr. Albert Potter Wills, Professor of Mathematical Physics at the university, who died suddenly on Saturday at St. Augustine, Fla. Chaplain Raymond C. Knox conducted the services.
Dragged from a hospital bed by police executioners, Liu Yung-ho, notorious Chinese robber, was shot and killed today at the "Bridge of Heaven."

Police investigation has disclosed that the slain Joseph Riedle, far from being the head of the Nazi organization in Argentina, as reported from Berlin, was merely the leader of a group of twenty men in the small suburb of San Martin, where he lived.

Archibald Norbury Milne of 235 East Seventy-third Street, a lumber broker with offices in the News Building, died yesterday morning of pneumonia in the Wickersham Hospital, Fifty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.
Several leases involving the occupancy of full floors were among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.

The Rev. James F. McDonald, pastor of St. Agnes Catholic Church, died at the church rectory Saturday night following several months' illness. Father McDonald, who was in his fifty-ninth year, was born in Jersey City and was ordained to the priesthood at Seton Hall College, South Orange, on Dec. 18, 1909.

Mr. and Mrs. Willard R. Downing of Country Club Road, New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of Mrs. Downing's daughter, Miss Sally Peabody Goodell, to Jacques S. Arouet of Stamford, Conn. The marriage will take place on May 8 at the Downing home.

Right-handed Frank Tosa of Townsend Harris hurled a no-hit, no-run game to defeat the Columbia Grammar nine, 6-0, at Central Park yesterday. He struck out thirteen men but walked six. Jack Matusow hit a home run in the sixth.

Jacob Silbert, 67 years old, a wellknown Yiddish actor, living at the Union Square Hotel, Fifteenth Street and Fourth Avenue, died suddenly last night while dining in a restaurant at 29 St. Mark's Place.

Clifford Stanley Fox, in charge of gas distribution in the Queens territory of the Consolidated Edison Company, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital after a ten-day illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 143-37 Beech Avenue, Flushing.

Edgar Appleby and Jerome Strauss were victorious as play in the final round-robin of the Poggenburg Memorial 18.2 balkline billiard tournament opened at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night. Appleby,

The report of the United States Foreign Securities Corporation for the first quarter shows a net asset of about $58,220,950 at March 31, equivalent to about $277 per share of first preferred stock. After first and second preferred stocks, a balance of $30.59 a share is indicated for the common stock, against $29.08 at Dec. 31.

The Spanish Government tonight defied the coast control of the European Non-Intervention Committee. The Ministry of Marine and Air ordered the government fleet and air force to protect all ships flying the Spanish flag and those of other countries asking protection in Spanish waters.

Testimony that a child patient died in the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital while a consultant physician was forced to walk up four flights because of the sit-down strike there last March 15 was given yesterday at the trial of seventeen former employes of the hospital and the president of their union local in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn.
A broadside of fourteen hits gave the Naval Training Station a 13-10 victory over the Harvard freshmen today.

The Sian rebellion broke out all of a sudden. The Central Government was much shocked and our very national existence was threatened. It may be recalled that before my second visit to Shensi I perceived that perverse ideas had already entered the mind of the Northeastern troops and that their conduct was rather wayward.
Russia's Red Army of 1,350,000 men is not generally credited in Europe with the great efficiency attributed to it in America, a survey of representative opinions in various capitals has determined.

Argument will be started before Judge Philip Forman in the United States District Court here tomorrow on the suit of five railroad companies and their subsidiaries for a permanent injunction restraining the State of New Jersey from attempting to enforce payment of taxes in excess of the amounts which the carriers contend would be fair on a valuation they consider proper.
The proposal to establish at Valley Forge a collegiate unit of the University of Pennsylvania was attacked today by The Daily Pennsylvanian. student newspaper.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Arrighi of 12 Fifth Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Thurber Arrighi, to Charles Horton Watson, son of Mrs. Charles H. Watson, also of this city, and the late Mr. Watson.
Jackson D. Smith of 99-21 204th Street, Hollis, Queens, a telegrapher for THE NEW YORK TIMES since 1930, died yesterday of pneumonia at Queens General Hospital after a long illness at the age of 29.

Although generally consigned to last place in the National League, the Phillies cleaned up both games of a holiday opening bill today by defeating the Bees by 2-1 in the forenoon contest and coming back to administer a 1-0 ??tout in the afternoon.

Members of the Alumnae of the Sacred Heart Convent will hold their annual luncheon today at the Convent at 1 East Ninety-first Street. During the luncheon Miss Marie Louise Falbo will present a program of songs. Mrs. Lea A.

Miss Shirley Newkirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Newkirk of Old Greenwich, has completed plans for her marriage to John Hamilton Tyson of Milbrook, Green wich, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Hamilton Tyson.

Hank Marino, the Italian kegler from Milwaukee who holds the national match-game championship, gave the matinee gallery in the 212th Coast Artillery Armory a real thrill yesterday as he took seventh place in the American Bowling Congress championships' singles division.
Three armed bandits held up the manager of the Oxford Burlesque Theatre, 552 State Street, Brooklyn, yesterday and escaped with $1,100 in week-end receipts.

Jack Siben, 43 years old, of 1,863 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, former supervisor of a large clothing business, is totally disabled by heart disease and therefore is legally entitled to quit work and receive the full benefit payments specified in his insurance policies, according to a ruling yesterday by Justice William S. Katzenstein in First District Municipal Court.

Attorneys for Associated Gas and Electric interests, challenging the Federal Power Commission's authority to investigate six Pennsylvania utilities, pressed the commission today for an immediate ruling to expedite an appeal, if necessary, to the Federal courts.

The National Association for Travelers Aid and Transient Service will celebrate its twentieth anniversary with a meeting on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Vanderbilt Hotel. Problems of adjusting the organization's social work program to transportation changes and the financing of the group's work will be discussed.

Complaints of discrimination have been made by former Ford Motor Company workers to the United Automobile Workers of America and sent to the Regional Labor Board in Detroit, Homer Martin, president of the union, announced here today.

Walter Damrosch described yesterday the additions he had made for operatic purposes to Edward Everett Hale's story, "The Man Without a Country." The first addition is a heroine. "You can't write a good opera without a woman," the composer and conductor explained.
Merritt resolution authorizing appropriation of $5,000,000 for the New York World's Fair in 1939 will have right of way in the House tomorrow as a result of action by the Rules Committee today.

More than 500 State Civil Service employes paraded around the Capitol tonight with a band to demonstrate their desire for passage of the FeldHamilton Civil Service "Career" Bill, which has passed the Assembly and is pending in the Senate.

A call for a meeting of the Tammany executive committee to be held soon after May 1 to consider election of a new leader in the place of James J. Dooling was expected yesterday after the return of James J. Hines and Charles W. Culkin, two veteran district leaders, from Miami, where Mr. Dooling is resting in an attempt to recover his health.

Sholem Asch reports to his publishers, G. P. Putnam's Sons, that the "Life of Christ" on which he has been at work for several years will be delayed beyond the Fall and will not be ready for publication until 1938. A new translation of one of Mr. Asch's early novels, "The Mother" will replace it on the Putnam Fall list.
Awards were made yesterday in the twelfth annual exhibition of the Art Center of the Oranges in the gallery at 14 South Harrison Street, East Orange.

Automobile production increased sharply last week as plants of four Chrysler divisions and Hudson and Reo resumed operations, and the adjusted index spurted to 105.3 from 85.5 (revised). It was 113.1 for the week ended April 18, 1936.

Spirited bidding that fetched prices far exceeding expectations marked the auction today of the art collection gathered mainly by Baron Lionel Nathan de Rothschild in the family's palace on historic Piccadilly.

A jury in Quarter Sessions Court here tonight, Judge Frank A. Henderson presiding, returned a verdict of not guilty in the case of Theodore Tobish of Trenton and the Tar Distribution Corporation of New York, indicted on a charge of false pretenses. The case was given to the jury about 4:30 o'clock this afternoon and shortly after 10 o'clock tonight the verdict was returned.

The State Racing Commission today granted to Bert S. Michell, prominent trainer, a hearing on charges of artificially stimulating one of Mrs. Emil Denemark's horses, for which he recently was ruled off the turf.

Exports of automotive products from the United States in February were valued at $26,981,528, an increase of 18.1 per cent over February, 1936, foreign sales of $22,845,760, the Department of Commerce announced today.

President Roosevelt today joined 32,000 other fans and took the afternoon off to go to the ball game. He threw out the first ball in a game in which the Philadelphia Athletics beat the Washington Senators, 4-3, in an extra inning, thus officially opening the local American League season.
Information from Tokyo indicates that the Chilean commission of business experts and trade promoters has already established contacts with foremost Japanese industrial and commercial leaders.

Gifts will be taxed by the State, as they are by the Federal overnment, if a proposal now being considered by the Republican leaders of the Legislature takes concrete form, receives legislative sanction and is approved by Governor Lehman.

The departing times of the Twentieth Century Limited between here and Chicago will be changed to conform with the change to daylightsaving time next Sunday, the New York Central Railroad announced yesterday.

Miss Sylvia Seymour, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Seymour of San Francisco, was married here this afternoon to John P. Cluett, son of Representative and Mrs. Harold Cluett of Troy, N. Y., and Washington, at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Brown of 1,111 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Adriane Brown, to Albert Milfred Gants, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milfred Gants of New Rochelle, N. Y.

Brooklyn College will hold its inaugural Alumni Homecoming athletic program at Manhattan Beach on Saturday, at which time the Kingsmen's baseball, handball and tennis squads will face strong alumni combinations.

The American Radio Telegraphists' Association is prepared to call a strike on the ships of those lines which refuse to accept it as the bargaining agency of their men under the provisions of the Wagner act, according to Mervyn Rathborne, president.

After dogging Johnny Kelley of Arlington, the favorite, for 23 miles, Walter Young, 24-year-old Canadian marathoner, made his supreme effort during the former's "haunted mile" and gained a decisive triumph today in the fortieth running of the famous Boston A. A. distance classic.

Mrs. Warner M. Van Norden was re-elected President of the Bible and Fruit Mission to the Public Hospitals of New York at the sixtysecond annual meeting, held yesterday afternoon at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Victor W. Logan, 1 Beekman Place.

A ghostly aroma of innumerable good dinners hovers about the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, where a special exhibition devoted to "Dining in Old New York," will be opened privately today and to the public tomorrow.

Commodity futures were generally firm in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, hide and cottonseed oil futures advanced, coffee and tin futures were easier and cocoa, sugar, silk, copper, and wool top futures were steady.

Governor James V. Allred said today he was "prepared for an all Summer fight if necessary" to repeal the Horse Race Betting Law. His remarks added weight to previous indications he would call a special legislative session if the Senate should fail to vote on repeal at the current session.

Gladys Karin, 5 years old, who posed frequently for photographic illustrations, died yesterday in Bellevue Hospital of injuries received Saturday when she was struck by an automobile at Sixtysixth Street and Columbus Avenue. The car was driven by William Hanford of 580 Jackson Street, West New York, N. J.

An effort to settle the strike begun last week on three public schools now under construction will be made today. Representatives of the Building and Construction Trades Council, who called the strike, will meet with officials of the Board of Education.

Despite serious increases in accidents, deaths and injuries due to traffic accidents over the past week-end, the totals for the past week declined as compared with figures covering the corresponding week of 1936, tables announced yesterday by the Police Department revealed.
Timpson Pl., 516, 3-story tenement and stores and 1-story rear building; Rosina C. Shriefer against Linda Panza; due $13,082; taxes, , $212; to plaintiff for $5.000.

The names of political personages figuring prominently in the news before the Third Reich came into being were mentioned today when the trial for high treason of Catholics was resumed in the People's Court.

Marion Av., 2,997 (12-3281); Sigrid Sattler to Max Nlsnewitz, 1,375 Ocean Av., Brooklyn; mtg., $7,000: $10,000. 230th St., 945 East (17-4866); Henry L. Hecht, referee, to Henrietta Bashwitz, 270 West End Av.; $1,000.
Victorious over the Washington Senators, the Athletics returned to Philadelphia tonight looking forward to tomorrow's home opener against the Boston Red Sox.

Again Germany is celebrating Adolf Hitler's birthday. He will be 48 years old tomorrow. It is his fifth birthday since he became Chancellor and his third since he became Fuehrer of the Reich, commander-in-chief of its defense forces, the embodiment of all power over a nation of 67,000,000 souls.
Two penguins, the third and fourth ever hatched in captivity, are now in the collection at the Bermuda Government Aquarium at Flatts Village.
The Forty-Niner, an all-Pullman train of streamlined design, will be put in service between San Francisco and Chicago about June 15, according to an announcement yesterday by the Southern Pacific,

The National Grange broke with the administration today in three fields, demanding rejection of President Roosevelt's judiciary reorganization plan, curbs on imports of foreign meat products and continuance of the present 3 1/2 per cent interest rate on mortgages held by Federal Land Banks.

Miss Grace Arnold of 150 East Seventy-third. Street, a member of an old New York family, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness. She was a daughter of the late Benjamin Greene Arnold and Frances Snow Arnold. Her father was a prominent New York merchant and importer. Two sisters, Mrs. Evan J.

Governor Johnstone signed an act today making fifty-five miles an hour top legal speed for automobiles on South Carolina highways, instead of forty-five, and increasing the maximum speed for trucks to forty miles an hour from thirty.

The will of former Governor Albert O. Brown, which was probated today, leaves $250000 and the residue of his estate, which may be as much as $100,000 more, to Dartmouth College, from which he was graduated in 1878.

A public offering will be made today, by means of a prospectus, of 9,500 shares common stock, at $78.50 each, of the Nashua Gummed and Coated Paper Company by a syndicate headed by Estabrook Co. and including Burr, Gannett Co., Paine, Webber Co., and Putnam Co. of Hartford, Conn.
Gems worth [Pound]20,000 were scattered about the pavement in the Regent Street shopping district at noon today when an attempted robbery was frustrated.
Foreign airplanes, warships and submarines reported about the Scandinavian countries brought a war scare to Oslo tonight.
Detroit Tiger followers were treated to two bits of good news today, on the eve of the season-opener with the Indians at Navin Field.

" Curtain Call" will not have its scheduled premiere this evening at the John Golden. After last night's preview it was decided early this morning that more time was needed to polish the first two scenes and, accordingly, the opening has been set back till Thursday.

Miss Esther Leypoldt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Leypoldt of this town, will be married to Fred J. Braun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul V. Braun of Newark, on the afternoon of June 19 in the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows,
The Fordham Rams followed their onesided victory over the Columbia Lions by beating the Boston College Eagles, 9 to 4, today.

Increased freight rates on a large group of commodities are going into effect on Class I railroads at midnight tonight. The railroads filed higher rate schedules for eighty commodity groups with the Interstate Commerce Commission thirty days ago.
The Yale freshmen defeated Collegiate School of New Haven, 12 to 8, today, in an eight-inning game marked by heavy hitting.

Two men who were prisoners in a police patrol wagon when it collided with another vehicle filed suit yesterday against the city and against Jacob A. Zerrenner, driver of the patrol, and the J. Kane Grocery Company, Inc., alleged owner of the other vehicle. Each plaintiff is asking $50,000 for personal injuries received in the accident.

Lew Feldman outboxed Irving Eldridge in the eight-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Palace last night before a crowd of 1,500. The Brownsville fighter was too clever for his East Side rival, building up a clear lead on points.
Each of the following Reserve officers, now on active duty with the Civilian Conservation Corps, is, with his consent, continued on active duty until the date indicated:

For the past several years Japan, with only partially successful attempts at secrecy, has been pouring tens of millions of yen into fortifications at the southern tip of the island of Formosa. Today, with seemingly not the slightest attempt at secrecy, Great Britain has begun pouring millions of pounds into strengthening Hongkong's defenses.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 18, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Jacob Jones, April 17; Acushnet. At Pearl Harbor: Avocet, Gannet and Gilmer, April 17. At San Francisco: Arctic, April 7: Utah. Manila to Shanghai: Edsall, Pope. At Coco Solo: Lapwing, April 17; S-43, 47. Augusta, at Swatow, April 19.
Brown Sharpe of New York, Inc., announce the retirement, after forty years' service, of Elmer H. Neff, as he ad of the local office. Until further notice Arnold K. Brown will direct the office.

The Cincinnati Reds and the St. Louis Cardinals open their National League season here tomorrow-the Reds with three new faces in the line-up, the Cardinals with the one and only Dizzy Dean. Ray (Peaches) Davis, who came to Cincinnati from Nashville for the last half of last season, will oppose Dean on the mound.
Employment in the woolen and worsted goods industry increased slightly in February to a point well above the 1929 level, the National Association of Wool Manufacturers reported here yesterday.

The manual training students at Buxton Country Day School, which believes in the practical application of classroom lessons, are building-all by themselves-a stage on which to give the school's dramatic productions, it was learned here today.

Edward Warren Meeker of Orange, singer and announcer in the early days of the cylinder wax phonograph records manufactured by Thomas A. Edison, died yesterday in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old.
Burr Av., 2,105 (15-4252); Tillie Feldman to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., 1 Madison Av.; extends mtg. to Aug. 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $196,900.

The Roosevelt Administration now stands at a crossroads in its fiscal policy, about to decide whether to follow the line of least resistance into more Government borrowing or to strike out courageously in the direction of a balanced budget.

Fireman First Grade Leo F. Costello of Engine 212 died April 17. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 55 South 4th St., Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Tuesday, April 20. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Queens. The Deputy Chief of the 11th Division shall detail a Lieutenant and twelve Firemen who, together with six members from the off platoon of Engine 212 (who shall act as pallbearers),

The 111th anniversary of the founding of the Old Guard of the City of New York. New York State Militia, will be observed on Saturday.
