The program will include the administering of the oath to the new officers at 2 P. M. at City Hall, a memorial service in the Chapel of St. Cornelius the Centurion at Governors Island and a banquet at the Hotel Commodore.

The plan for the union of the Methodist Episcopal Church, the Methodist Episcopal Church South and the Methodist Protestant Church was approved yesterday by 120 votes to 26 at the closing session of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.

In advance of President Roosevelt's expected relief message to Congress this week, State Governors presented an almost solid front today against reduction of the Federal program, if it meant putting a greater burden on the States.

The Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, one of the organizations planning celebrations to be held in this city on May 12 in honor of the coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, will give a luncheon on that date in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

Frank Lovejoy, manager of the service station sales of SoconyVacuum Oil Company, yesterday expressed the opinion that sales managers are "going too far in filling salesmen with intricate information which does them no good," in addressing the symposium on "How to Pick Good Men," held by the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

More than 500 members of The Associated Press, at their annual meeting yesterday at the WaldorfAstoria, ratified an amendment to their by-laws creating associate memberships. This and other amendments previously approved by the board of directors were ratified without opposition.

Chase S. Osborn, former Governor of Michigan, tonight described John Lewis as Huey Long's successor as the "champion of the social discontents" and said the only way to defeat him is "to give the masses a greater degree of sane social justice than he offers."

The coronation social season opened tonight with ??gala performance of Verdi's masterpiece, "Otello," before an audience whose gowns and jewelry made the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden the most resplendent spectacle since the pre-war days.
President Roosevelt attended the opening baseball game of the local American League season and conferred with Congressional leaders on his forthcoming message on the budget and relief.

There is one thing to be said when Throngs Flee City On Warm Spring Day, as we duly took note yesterday of the day before. It is quite all right for the throngs to seek the open country and the beaches on a warm Spring day, but there is a slur implied in the statement that the throngs flee the city.

Three apparently unrelated events reported in yesterday's news have an important bearing on developments which seem to foreshadow a change for the better in the European outlook. At midnight last night the long-debated plan to throw an international patrol around the land and sea frontiers of Spain finally went into effect.

The Secretary of Commerce in his address at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press expressed a liking for the practical philosophy of MARCUS AURELIUS, which insists that " men exist for the sake of one another" and they must be taught to " bear with one another."

The Canadian Amateur Hockey Association agreed upon complete affiliation with the International Ice Hockey Association today and completely broke the ties which formerly bound it to the Amateur Athletic Union of Canada.

More than 500 persons, including leaders in social and business circles. attended funeral services this morning at Brook Corners for Arthur Williams, retired vice president of the New York Edison Company, who died last Wednesday in Miami.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad's net income in the first three months of the year was about equal to the total for the same period last year, according to Ralph Budd, president. The gain in passenger revenues over last year was about 20 per cent, he added.

Sales promotion managers of retail establishments were criticized here today by Thomas Robb, manager of the sales promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, as failing to "follow through" or "back up" their advertising in order to achieve "maximum sales results."
Annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers Association begins this morning at 10 A. M. at the Waldorf-Astoria and continues through Friday.

A program calling for coordinated effort between consu??r, manufacturer, retailer, governmental and other groups concerned with the development of standards in the consumer goods field is being considered by the standards committee of the platform commission of the National Retail Dry Goods Association for recommendation to the commission, it was stated yesterday by Harold W. Brightman, vice president of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, and chairman of the committee.

An upward trend in employment in New Jersey is evidenced by figures of the State Department of Labor, showing a decrease in the number of applicants for jobs and an increase in employment and wages in manufacturing industries during the last year.

The Duchess of York slid into her berth here today, the first passenger vessel to open the navigation season since 1914. Captain Charles Richardson will receive the gold-headed cane of the International Harbors Board.

Miss Marietta Chapin Ewald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ewald of this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Winthrop Olmstead Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clifford Cook of Quincy, Mass.
Virgilio Ranzato, composer of operettas, died here today, at the age of 53. Several of his works, including "Luna Park," have been performed in the United States.

The Brooklyn members of the Board of Aldermen and members of that body's committee on public thoroughfares held an informal hearing yesterday at Brooklyn Borough Hall on the question of changing the names of borough streets to eliminate confusing duplications.

Steel ingot production in the United States is scheduled at 91.3 per cent of capacity this week, against 90.3 per cent last week, a gain of 1 point, or 1.1 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The Wembley Lions, English National Hockey League champions, took a long lead in the international roundrobin series in progress here when they defeated the Winnipeg Monarchs, Canadian junior champions, 4-2, tonight.

The text of Secretary Roper's address at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press follows: When I say to you that I am gratified to be with you today I am not indulging in a mere polite remark. I make the statement with all sincerity and with keen appreciation of your great kindness in extending me an invitation to address you.

Although the volume of business on the stock markets today was small, securities, generally, were firm and gave a good tone to the opening of the new account. Gilt-edge issues moved to higher levels, but foreign loans were featureless. Transatlantics were good except that United States Steel closed fractionally lower.
Movements In the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:
Alarm mounted tonight that the Spanish Insurgents' attem?? to blockade the Bay of Biscay might cripple Great Britain's vast rearmament program.

Lou Ambers, world's lightweight champion, gave Phil Baker of Norwalk a neat boxing lesson tonight in a feature ten-round nontitle boxing match. Ambers weighed 137 pounds, one-half pound less than the loser.

The scheduled operations of the steel industry at 91.3 per cent of capacity this week is the highest rate recorded since August, 1929, but due to a substantial incrrease in the industry's capacity, it represents theproduction f around 1,196,000 tons, the highest figure since may, 1929, when the average weekly output for the month was 1,193,284 tons.

Mrs. Martha Palmer Seymour, 80 years old, died Saturday night at her home, 15 Beech Tree Lane. She was the widow of James Sherwood Seymour, former publisher of The New York Evening Post. The Commercial Advertiser of New York and the old Record-Herald of Chicago. He died in 1924.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 17: COLONEL Cruse, F. T., (F. A.), relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps, Panama Canal Dep't, and ordered to Madison, Wls., as instructor of Field Artillery, Wisconsin National Guard.

THE NEW YORK TIMES (rag paper edition) of April 16 should be included in the memorabilia to be placed in the crypt of Oglethorpe University in Atlanta, Ga., if the hopes and plans of the president of the university, Dr. THORNWELL JACOBS, are realized.

Racing folk who backed C. V. Whitney's Flying Cross for Kentucky Derby honors in the Winter books were dealt a hard blow today when the son of Pennant finished a disappointing last in a field of eight in the Dixiana Purse, which featured the card at Keeneland.
Champion of Ireland, the Mayo Gaelic football team is scheduled to arrive in New York May 14 on the United States liner Manhattan for a six-game tour of this country.
Charles S. Blackett, a Federal judge in Alaska during the gold rush nearly forty years ago, died yesterday at the age of 75.

The joint preparatory committee of experts on Philippine affairs that is to study and report to the interdepartmental committee on the Philippines regarding economic relations between the two countries incident to the achievement of independence by the islands held its organization meeting today.

Mischa Ross, musician whom the family of Julia Nussenbaum had regarded until a few weeks ago as her fiance, was in a cell at police headquarters last night charged with homicide in connection with the hammer bludgeoning which caused her death in a midtown rehearsal studio Sunday morning.

Buster Vandal, 24-year-old Indian, gave his life to save three sons of his Indian employer, Teddy Deer Fly, whose home was destroyed by fire yesterday at the mine on the Blackfoot Reserve. Another son, Toughy Deer Fly. 2. died in the flames.

Senator McNary, the minority leader, asserted today that the President's program for a sweeping reorganization of executive agencies is "absolutely dead." It has "no chance for revival at this session of Congress," he asserted.

Thirty-two cleaning and dyeing plants in Essex, Union, Passaic and Middlesex Counties were closed today by a strike of about 1,000 men and women employes, it was announced here by Morris Klein, business agent of the Cleaners and Dyers Union of New Jersey, an affilate of the American Federation of Labor.

The new export drive with which Germany is cashing in on the world's hunger for goods created by the armament race is producing such gratifying results that her rulers are beginning to feel they are over the peak of their difficulties caused by their own rearmament and are growing confident they can now hold out until the Four-Year Plan establishes economic independence.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx challenged Mayor La Guardia yesterday to deny that Communists dominated relief, after citing the statement to that effect made last Saturday by Victor F. Ridder, chairman of the State Board of Social Welfare and former WPA Administrator.

Major league baseball, having been duly launched yesterday with the more or less exclusive inaugurals in Washington and Boston, will swing into action on all the remaining fronts today, and perhaps nowhere will the swinging be any lustier than that set to take place within the confines of the metropolitan area.
Miss Jane Will was a luncheon hostess yesterday at Theodore's for Miss Janet Smith, whose engagement to Gerald Phipps of Denver was announced recently.
The Yale Rugby team today outpointed the Boston Rugby Club, 21 to 8, in the most brilliant team performance of the season here.

The drought that seared United States grazing lands last year is boosting the market for Canadian cattle, particularly the lighter weights. Faced with a shortage of feed to finish their cattle, United States cattlemen have been using most of it for the heavy varieties and a pronounced shortage has developed for calves.
The Senate tonight denied as unconstitutional the plea against the impeachment of former President Miguel Mariano Gomez last December.

Continued acceleration of world economic recovery, now hampered only by the threat of war, was seen by Harold B. Butler, director of the International Labor Office at Geneva, in his annual report to be presented to the International Labor Conference at Geneva in June.

LO here, on April 20, 1937-a fine Spring day in the fourth decade of the twentieth century-is Ludwig Lewisohn, asserting that the panacea for all ills is faith, race and God. Not quite the panacea, to be sure, for, as he envisions it, the world "is headed for chaos and the devil anyhow. Yet it is a panacea that in some obscure way will mitigate the tragedy of downfall.

ALPER-Charna, beloved wife of Zalman, devoted mother of Nana Orenstein, Rose Less and Sallie Kronish. Funeral services Tuesday, April 20, 2:30 P. M., at the Prospect Funeral Home, 1,018 Prospect Av., Bronx. Interment Mount Hebron Cemetery.

Invitations to send representatives to the 200th anniversary ceremonies of Goettingen University in Germany June 25 to 30 should be rejected by American universities and colleges, according to Dr. Eugene H. Lehman, president of the Highland Manor School, here today.
Paul Revere's companion, William G. Dawes, roused the countryside and sounded the alarm twice this morning in a re-enactment of the ride of 162 years ago.

Turpentine firm, 35 3/4c; sales, 167 barrels; receipts, 276 barrels: shipments, 125 barrels; stock, 23,466 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 644 barrels; receipts, 1,446 barrels: shipments, 2.393 barrels; stock, 45.398 barrels.
Indiana's great track team, which dominated the Kansas relays Saturday, loomed today as the outstanding threat at the Penn relays Friday and Saturday.

Retail sales in March showed an 18 per cent increase over the volume in March a year ago, representing a dollar gain of about $560,000,000, the American Retail Federation announced today. The March sales volume totaled $3,600,300,000.

Two hundred and seventy-five disciples of the modern dance-all ages and sizes-donned light-colored dance tunics yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University, and danced with abandon to the beat of tympany.

The Senate passed tonight the Kleinfeld bill which would require a political group to get 3 per cent of the total vote cast for Governor, or about 175,000 votes, to get on or stay on the ballot as an official party. The vote was 38 to 11.
The Chicago Cubs, handicapped by the loss of two regular hurlers for perhaps two weeks to a month, open the National League baseball season tomorrow against the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Wheat markets advanced in almost as violent a manner today as they declined last week.

Destruction of Spain's largest arms factory, the Toledo plant where the famous Toledo sabers were made, was reported semi-officially tonight. The report said the factory was destroyed by an explosion and fire caused by a government artillery bombardment today.
Several sales of residential property in Westchester County were reported yesterday by Dudley D. Doernberg, broker in the deals.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today assigned for hearing on April 28 a registration statement by the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., of Glendale, Calif., in which the commission alleges "the appearance of untrue statements of material facts and omissions of material facts in eight items, two exhibits and the prospectus."
Germany scored another victory in the "battle of the stork" last year. According to an official announcement the total number of births was 1,312,345, compared with 1,294,000 in 1935.

Export copper markets were unusually quiet yesterday. Sales were made at 14.70 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, compared with 15.125 cents on Saturday. The domestic market was unchanged at 15.5 cents. Scrap copper prices here were lowered the equivalent of 1/4 cent a pound.

Chester Leo O'Brien, who received $56,329 from Marilyn Miller, stage and screen star, in the year and a half they were married, bitterly resented imputations that he was supported by his wife, a sister of the late actress testified in Supreme Court yesterday.

A taxpayers' suit against the city to compel reduction in the existing water rates was decided upon last night at a meeting of representatives of 157 organizations of Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan at the Long Island City Court House.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Emily Dickson Torrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Cates Torrey of Grovedge, Scarsdale, to John Price Cuddeback Jr., son of Mrs. John Price Cuddeback of San Gabriel, Calif., and the late Mr. Cuddeback, which will take place on May 15 in the Church of St. James the Less, Scarsdale.

Grover A. Whalen was the first witness for the New York World's Fair yesterday at the trial in Supreme Court of a suit to restrain further publication of The World's Fair News. Officials of the fair object to the magazine's name on the ground that it tends to mislead the public into believing that it is an official publication of the fair.

Irwin H. Kaiser of 3,845 Maple Avenue, Brooklyn, has been elected editor-in-chief of The Columbia Daily Spectator, and Robert July of 625 West 156th Street, business manager, it was announced yesterday.
Julian Erwin Howell, youngest son of the late Clark Howell Sr., editor of The Atlanta Constitution, died in a hospital here today at the age of 29. Death followed a nasal operation.

Headed by J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, winner at Pinehurst last week, a field of nineteen players started out today in the Mason-Dixon tennis championship on the new courts of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

Miss Gabriella K. H. Leavitt, daughter of Rufus E. Leavitt of 15 Euclid Avenue, formerly of Short Hills, and the late Mrs. Leavitt, has oompleted plans for her marriage to Walter Stokes Libby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Libby, also of Summit.

The reorganized Three-Eye Baseball League will open its schedule May 2 and will play 120 games. Representatives of the six clubs decided yesterday on the opening date, which will send Clinton, Iowa, against Bloomington, Ill., at Bloomington; Moline, Ill.,
TRUMPET OF JUBILEE, by Ludwig Lewisohn. (Harper, $2.50.) A new novel by the author of "The Island Within." ANARCHY OR HIERARCHY, by S. de Madariaga. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A plan for the social order.

American youth's most pressing needs, according to the replies of thousands of representative young persons to a questionnaire, are employment, a happy home life, guidance, a satisfactory philosophy of life and a knowledge of how best to discharge their duties as citizens, Homer P. Rainey, director of the American Youth Commission, said yesterday.

Governor Lehman vetoed a bill which would have taken away from the Board of Estimate the right to fix the salary of a law assistant in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office. He signed several other measures.

WillysOverland Motors, Inc., signed its first formal contract today with the United Automobile Workers. William Siefke, business representative of the local, said the contract was one of the most satisfactory in the automotive industry.

Nevada-California Electric Corporation and Subsidiaries-For 1936: Net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, amortization and other expenses and charges, $831,896, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to $1.14 a share on the common stock
Losing to the Baltimore Orioles of the International League by 9 to 6 today, the Naval Academy nine still made an excellent fight against the professionals and kept them working hard to the end.

Miss Alyce Elizabeth Buntin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Buntin of Rock Ridge, this place, was married this afternoon to Daniel Edward Hanlon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Edward Hanion of Mountain Lakes.
Governor Lehman announced tonight the commutation of the sentences of eight prisoners to permit their deportation. "This will save the State the cost of their maintenance," the Governor said.
The State Supreme Court ruled today that Allegheny County cannot tax a trust fund established by Henry C. Frick of Pittsburgh and New York for Princeton University.
Walter Klimczak's batting and fielding were outstanding features of Yale's 9-4 victory over Williams today. Klimczak's two three-base hits sent home three runs and he scored two himself.
Word was received here yesterday of the death on Sunday at her home in Colorado Springs, Col., of Mrs. Walter Graham, widow of Captain Graham, after an illness of several months.

The final results of the Window Display study will be discussed for the first time by Dr. Miller McClintock, in charge of the National Window Display Research, at the distribution and sales promotion session of the Association of National Advertisers at Hotel Springs on April 25 to 28.

The American Federation of Labor today attacked the Committee for Industrial Organization on two fronts while the latter's automobile and textile affiliates met here to plan further aggressive steps in their organization campaigns.

When Emmett Keefe hauled in his shad nets on the Hudson River here today he discovered he had caught, in addition to a few shad, a young buck deer, weighing about seventy pounds. Swimming in the river, the deer had become entagled in the nets, but was unharmed.

The green and white silks of Colonel E. R. Bradley were seen in the winners' circle for the first time this year when Bootless, the favorite, won the McHenry Purse, feature of today's program at the Havre de Grace track.

Mayor La Guardia called upon members of the Fire Department yesterday to declare whether they would take special leaves of absence with pay for the three days from May 20 to May 22, to attend a centennial celebration at Mechanicville, N. Y. They must, however, pay their own expenses.

Old-age asdistance was more than doubled in New Jersey for the year ended last June 30, compared with the 193233 fiscal year, both as to the number of beneficiaries and the average amount paid, William J. Ellie, State Institutions Commissioner, reported today.

Many college girls are endangering their health by using up too much energy in both mental and physical activities, Dr. Josephine L. Rathbone of Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday at the opening session of the National Association of Directors of Physical Education for College Women, at its annual conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Governor Lehman's fight against restrictions on the enrollment of Negro youths in Civilian Conservation Corps camps in this State was won yesterday when the War Department ordered that two new camps for Negroes be established, providing accommodations for all of the 380 young men who have indicated a desire to enlist for the Spring period.

J. M. Finne-Gronn, Norwegian Vice Consul, in 41 Central Park West; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., brokers. Leon Belasco, in the Wyndham, 42 W. 58th St.; Ellsworth L. G. Salmon, through Edgar Ellinger, in 137 E. 38th St.; Mrs. C. C. Chapman, in 580 Park Av.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.
The international stock market indices for April 17, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

A total of $288,554,000 was bid and $100,325,000 accepted, for two series of Treasury bills for the aggregate amount of approximately $100,000,000, the Treasury announced today. The offering was made on April 16. For one of the series, the 148-day bills maturing on Sept. 16, 1937, and amounting to about $50,000,000,

Georg Lansbury, being of the bulldog breed today besieged Berlin lone-handed in his struggle to remove the present causes of war. He reported Herr Hitler's cordial interest in concerted economic discussions, and, according to the dispatches, informed the Germans leader of the President's intense and abiding interest in the same.
British Cabinet Ministers met this evening to receive the first news of the budget proposals that Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain will present to the House of Commons tomorrow.

Representatives of nine patriotic organizations requested yesterday an appointment with President sevelt to voice their objections to any change in the existing structure of the Supreme Court. A telegram to the President said:
The intercession of County Chairman Kenneth F. Simpson to stop a Republican factional fight in the Ninth Manhattan Assembly District was urged yesterday by Fred M. Lewis in a letter to Mr. Simpson.

Prices moved slowly higher in trading in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The volume of dealings continued light, especially through the earlier hours of trading, but the total of transactions was a little larger than on last Friday, the aggregate of all bonds dealt in being $10,030,700, against $9,523,400.
An airplane flew over the Washington-Philadelphia baseball game at Griffith Stadium today carrying a huge red sign which read: "Play the game. Don't pack the court."

Alvan Macauley, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, said at the annual meeting of the company in Detroit yesterday that earnings for the first quarter of this year were about double those of the same period last year, when a profit of $1,248,029, or 8 cents a share, was made.

General Francisco Franco tonight set up a one-party State in Insurgent Spain under his sole rule. He issued a decree dissolving the Falangista Espanola, the Spanish Fascist organization founded by Jose Primo de Rivera, and the Requetes, or Carlists.
Announcement was made here yesterday of the sudden death on Friday of a heart attack at his home in Woodstock, Conn., of Francis Upton Johnstone, a retired New York banker.

The Lenox Hill Hospital and St. Ann's Academy, operated by the Marist Brothers, carried their fight against the proposed construction of a theatre at 1,109 Lexington Avenue into Supreme Court yesterday, asking permission to take part in the judicial review of proceedings before the Board of Standards and Appeals which resulted in the issuance of a permit for construction there of a movie house.

On his own application: LIEUTENANT-William J. Raftis, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $2,000 per annum. Appointed Oct. 18, 1906. Transfers and Assignments SECOND GRADE DETECTIVE-Alfred Laurino, from 18th Division, 8th Detective District, to 32d Precinct: designation as second grade detective revoked. THIRD GRADE DETECTIVE--Joseph W. Dugan, from 18th Division, 8th Detective District, to 24th Precinct; designation as third grade detective revoked.

The vacant plot of 90 by 190 feet on the northwest corner of Queens Boulevard and Forty-third Street, Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold for development with a theatre and store building to the Queens-Laurel Corporation.

Stanton St., 196 and 198; 24.9 1/2 and 25.1x 75; Ray Schwartz to Metropolitan Savings Bank,, two mtgs. $15,000 each held by bank. Avenue B, 202; 18.4x60; Benollel Realty Corp. to Lef-Co Equities, Inc., 1,440 Broadway (50 cents).

Plans for a five-story business building to be erected at 445 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of Thirtyninth Srteet, were filed yesterday by Starrett Van Vleck, architects, who estimated the cost at $600,000.

Robert H. Graham, president for the last six years of Wallach's, Inc., men's clothing chain, with stores throughout the country, yesterday announced his resignation from the post, to take effect shortly. Several months ago, Mr.

CAPUTO, PASQUALE (March 16). Estate, $8,950. To Vincenzo Caputo, son, 182 Hester St., $700; Anna M. C. Cicero, daughter, 258 Corson Av- New Brighton, S. I., $800; eleven varying bequests; Donato Caputo, son. Executor, 219 Mulberry St., $1,800.

While no official announcement has yet been made regarding a joint Franco-British declaration on Belgium's neutrality, it became known here today that the provisional text of this declaration had been received in Brussels Saturday night and that Cabinet members had examined its contents today.

To discuss possible courses of action on the limiting of volume discounts on boys' wear to 7 per cent, a meeting of boys' clothing buyers and divisional merchandise managers of department stores in this area will be held tomorrow afternoon in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Edgewater, N. J., plant of the Aluminum Company of America will be made the second largest aluminum rolling mill in the United States, as a result of proposed expansions, according to Edward H. Grotefend, manager.

Amendments to rules, regulations and forms controlling exemptions from registration and defining rights of stockholders under reorganization plans were issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

More than three-quarters of the common stock of the United States Steel Corporation is in the hands of investors, the company reported yesterday, but the proportion has declined from that on Dec. 31 of last year.

LONDON-Warships of four powers representing twenty-seven nations began a patrol of the coasts of Spain to bar aid to the contestants in the civil war. There was some confusion in establishment of supervision of the French and Portuguese frontiers. Page 1.
Mayor F. H. La Guardia was one of six former service men inducted into the Forty and Eight, the honor society of the American Legion, at Augrick's Restaurant 257 William Street,

General Motors strikers tonight rejected proposals for settlement of their twelve-day strike, Hugh Thompson, organizer for the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced. He said the vote was "practically unanimous."

BOSHES, MINNIE (March 5, 1937). Gross estate, $7,588; net, $6,996. To Rosa Attinson, daughter, Hotel Victoria, residue; several minor bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $7,588. DERAISMES, JOHN L. (Sept. 11, 1936). Gross assets, $20,000; net, $15,253. To Bertha C. Deraismes, widow, and Aline D. Lovett, daughter, one-half residue each. Chief assets, real estate, $20,000. J. Hunter Lack, attorney, 66 Court St., White Plains.
The Yankees in their annual visit to the army camp won from the Cadet nine today in a one-sided contest, 19 to 4.

Mrs. Eva Schilling, 38 years old, who had been mentally unbalanced since an Erie Railroad train killed her two youngest children almost two years ago, pulled on a pair of gloves and got a butcher knife from the kitchen during the night while her husband, William, and her remaining child, Helen, were sound asleep.

Positive measures to check the flow of gold coming to this country from abroad are being considered by President Roosevelt and his economic advisers, according to information received in Wall Street banking quarters yesterday.
Labor friends of President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Federal judiciary staged a nation-wide demonstration tonight in support of the measure.

Charles E. Gillespie has been appointed assistant secretary of the Harlem Savings Bank and will be in charge of the 157th Street and Broadway branch. Carl Pharis, president of the Pharis Tire and Rubber Company announced the election to the board of directors of H. N. Mallon, president of the S. R. Dresser Manufacturing Company.

A bitter factional dispute within the ranks of Flint Local No. 156, United Automobile Workers of America, the largest single unit of the international union, finds the membership divided over its leadership in a battle which is expected to reach its climax at the convention in August.

At its annual meeting last night the board of trustees of the Beth Israel Hospital Association unanimously re-elected David L. Podell as president, with the same associate officials as during his first term, just expired. These include Judge N. D. Perlman, Louis Satenstein and Harry Finkelstein, vice presidents;
Forcing the attack all the way, the Harvard varsity lacrosse team opened its home season with an 11-4 victory over the Boston Lacrosse Club on the new athletic field today.
The War Minister, General Wilhelm Roeder, will leave tomorrow for Berlin, where he will be the guest of Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister.

Exceptions to findings of the trial examiner in the Securities and Exchange Commission case against White, Weld Co. in the matter of A. O. Smith Co. stock will be argued in Washington Friday before the full commission, it was announced yesterday.

Orders placed by retail members of the Affiliated Clothiers, Inc., for men's Fall clothing are running about 15 per cent ahead of a year ago, Joseph Ellner, of the resident office, reported here yesterday at the opening of the buying convention for Eastern stores at the Hotel New Yorker.

Introduction of a resolution at a board meeting of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel last week in which the institute took a stand opposing all legislation interfering with free and open markets resulted in the resignation of the president and two of the governors of the institute, it became known here yesterday.

Remington Rand, Inc., announced yesterday in its preliminary report for the year ended on March 31, the largest volume of sales in six years. Domestic and foreign sales totaled $46,679,000, or 16.6 per cent more than the $39,358,000 reported for the preceding twelve months.

In order to facilitate matters for the golfers planning to enter the United States open championship which will be played at the Oakland Hills Country Club at Birmingham, Mich., June 10-12, the United States Golf Association yesterday announced that five additional districts have been provided for sectional qualifying rounds, making a total of thirty-three altogether.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street, has arranged an exhibition composed of drawings and small pieces of sculpture by Gaston Lachaise, who died in 1935. It opens to the public today and the work will remain on view through May 7.

Edward Livingston Burrill of 660 Park Avenue, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of E. A. Pierce Co., 40 Wall Street, died yesterday in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. A former member of the Stock Exchange, he had been in Wall Street for many years.

RKO acquired two new romantic comedies today, one for Barbara Stanwyck and the other for Harriet Hilliard, whom the studio is grooming for star roles. Miss Stanwyck's vehicle is ."She Married for Money," with screen play by Dudley Nichols.

Approving a suggestion for a change in the name of their organization, 225 members of the Silk Travelers' Association, meeting in the group's club rooms, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street, last night voted to alter the name of the organization to The Textile Salesmen's Association.
Inquiries from Brazil in connection with orders for locomotives, rails and other railroad material have been turned down by Osaka industrialists,
With a record number of exhibitors showing the latest developments in knitting in attendance, the thirty-third annual knitting arts exhibition got under way at the Commercial Museum here today.

The price of advertised brands of milk in New York City was reduced 1 cent a quart yesterday. No reduction in the price of unadvertised brands was reported. Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, president of the Greater New York-New Jersey Milk Institute, said he did not believe the reduction indicated a renewal of the price war that drove down the price of milk after April 1, when the Milk Control Law went out of effect.

Paris presented the curious appearance today of a city suffering from divided authority. Trade union patrols marched up and down the streets to make sure that all shops were keeping the law by remaining closed. At street corners the police and Mobile Guards stood patiently attentive to see that the trades unionists in turn kept the law.

Public offering will be made today of a new issue of $2,800,000 of Thousand Islands Bridge Authority, Watertown, (Jefferson County) N. Y., bridge revenue 4 1/4 per cent bonds by a banking syndicate headed by B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and including Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc.; E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Eldredge Co., Inc.; A. C.
The critical situation facing Jews in Central and Eastern Europe was described last night to a group of leaders in the liquor industry at a dinner in the Hotel Astor.

The Health Department issued a general warning yesterday against the use of nasal oil to relieve respiratory congestion on the ground that such preparations frequently lead to lipoid pneumonia, particularly among infants.

Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge was reelected president of the Young Women's Christian Association of New New York yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the board of directors in the Studio Club of the Y. W. C. A., 210 East Seventyseventh Street.

The nation's busiest air terminals will not measure up to safety standards now being written into the air commerce regulations to govern the operation of the new super airliners being built for use within the next year.

Philip Murray, chairman of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, said tonight negotiations had been completed for a union contract with the American Bridge Company, subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

Buck Hill Farms, a 600-acre estate with a large lake and trout streams in Pomfret and Brooklyn, Conn., embracing the former "show place" belonging to the late Adriana Bush, as well as the Reynolds and Sanford Chapman farms, has been purchased by Chase H. Davis of Stockbridge, Mass., and Cincinnati, Ohio.
A tentative agreement was reached today by the House Military Affairs Committee on additional drastic provisions for the Hill-Sheppard bill to take the profits out of war.
H. Grob of Switzerland, Reuben Fine of New York and Paul Keres of Estonia finished the international chess masters' tournament tonight in a tie for premier honors.

FROM now on the hits will count. That's the way the ball players figure it. There may be trades and there will be accidents, and the way the clubs look now may have little to do with the way they will finish in early October. But that can be taken up later under the head of New Business.

Professor Dana Munro of Princeton University, representing the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, arrived here this morning to represent claims of the American bondholders to the commission of the Cuban Government now seeking a

The Katonah (N. Y.) bank robbers muttered pleas of innocence to murder charges in today's court as Attorney General Cummings moved to hasten trial of the two for killing a Federal agent, Wimberly W. Baker, in a Topeka gunfight.

A supplemental report covering transactions in February in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders of corporations and some transactions for earlier months which had been held up for correction was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

At the close of testimony yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Mounted Patrolman John V. Buckley on a first-degree manslaughter indictment in the shooting of Harold Sullivan, a Greenwich Village night club owner, early last Sept. 21, Judge Collins directed the jurors to acquit Buckley.

The progress of the new policy of the Federal Reserve System in adding to Reserve Banks' holdings of government securities was discussed today at the weekly meeting of the Reserve's open market executive committee headed by Marriner S.

An industrial tract of two and a half acres in Bloomfield, N. J., at the intersection of Arlington Avenue, the Erie Railroad and the Lackawanna Railroad has been sold by Anheuser-Busch, Inc., to the Westinghouse Manufacturing Company.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, held his first formal meeting with the other newly appointed commissioners today, announced the appointment of special aids and counsel and stated that one of his first studies would be of the balance sheet of the commission,

Tickets went on sale yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House for the American Ballet's Stravinsky performances on April 27 and 28. All the parterre boxes have been sold for the first night and more than half for the second night. Grand tier boxes are still available for next Tuesday.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was recognized officially as a regu'lar feller" at noon yesterday in the rarefied atmosphere of the Empire State Building Tower.
Certificates were awarded last night to forty-four graduates of the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled, at exercises held in the institute building at 400 First Avenue.

The entire Jewish B'nai B'rith organization in Germany was smashed today when the Gestapo (secret State police) staged a nation-wide raid on its lodges, arrested their presidents and other officials, searched their homes, seized all lodge properties and announced that the organization had ceased to exist.
A burst of machine-gun fire from a deputy sheriff's weapon killed Clifford Sweet, 33, in a liquor raid, and caused officers,today to drop a twoyear search for the man.

Home relief cases on the rolls of the Emergency Relief Bureau in this city declined 18.8 per cent in the seven months ended April 1, while cases on the rolls of up-State home relief agencies increased 30.6 per cent, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration disclosed yesterday.

William Bonanzi, 45 years old, of 343 Sixty-second Street, Brooklyn, convicted member of an opium smuggling ring, was sentenced yesterday to serve ten years in Alcatraz prison by Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn.

David Wark Griffith, represented by his counsel, Woodson R. Oglesby, was the successful bidder yesterday at a receivership sale conducted in Federal Judge Leibell's court of all the rights he owned in twenty-one silent pictures.

Between 40,000 and 50,000 pupils in the New York City high schools are not equipped to do high school work, Dr. John L. Tildsley, Associats Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday to 500 teachers attending the in-service course of the Board of Education at P. S. 59, 228 East Fifty-seventh Street.

William (Bill) Cox of Washington, Pa., was named head football coach of the University of Rochester today, succeeding Richard Larkins, who resigned a month ago. Cox has coached Washington High School since 1932 and was formerly freshman coach at Ohio State.

Captain Walter B. Grigsby, for the last ten years an officer of the Fourteenth Regiment, N. Y. N. G., in Brooklyn, died of pneumonia on Sunday at his home, 33 Woodruff Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 44 years old.
Former General Felix Diaz, who has lived in New Orleans for the last seventeen years, and his wife arrived here today on the steamship Morazan.

In Canton, long a hotbed of revolutions, all is not well. Nanking's authority is not being seriously questioned, but the Central Government finds itself with a difficult political and military problem to solve regarding Kwangtung Province and its 36,000,000 people.

Mrs. Frances Louise Abney of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, widow of John W. Abney and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Louis Kirkbride, was married to Randolph Hiyde of Woodeliff, N. J., last night in the Church of the Transfiguration.

" Strange Rhythm," a play by Mrs. M. W. Bolton and Stephen Vagliano, tried out in St. James Theatre last night, presented an original situation in a newspaper office setting with a newspaper magnate finally reconciled to his long-divorced wife and their son.

Birthday cake customs of the days when President Roosevelt and his friends were children were revived yesterday when Mrs. James Roosevelt, his mother, took a large cake to the coming-of-age birthday party of the People's Chorus of New York at the headquarters of the organization, 41 East Forty-second Street, of which she is a patroness.

Pfeiffer Brewing Company's rights have been admitted to dealings by the New York Stock Exchange and "when issued" rights have been suspended from dealings. Gulf States Steel Company's common stock, no par, will be suspended from dealings today.
Victor Hospedale of the Catholic Youth Organization knocked out two opponents to take the 160pound honors at the amateur boxing show at the New York Athletic Club last night.

After a stretch duel that lasted more than a furlong, Mrs. E. Graham Lewis's Little Miracle, an 11-5 shot, captured the St. Albans Handicap at six furlongs, feature of the racing at Jamaica yesterday, by a scant nose from John Simonetti's Sgt. Byrne in the closest finish of the metropolitan season.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 16: CAPTAINS Williams, L. C., Dental Corps, Naval Academy, to Naval Training Station San Diego. Calif. Neill, W. C., staff of the commander of battle force to navy yard, Boston, Mass.

Apparently not sympathetic with their captain's enterprise in running the Insurgent blockade of Northern Spain, the owners of the British steamer Thorpehall ordered him today to leave Gijon, Spain, immediately.
University of Washington officials indicated today they might reconsider their decision to send only two of the three Husky crews, all national champions in their divisions, to Poughkeepsie in June.

A funeral service for Alfred H. Swayne. vice president and director of the General Motors Corporation and chairman of the board of General Motors Acceptance Corporation, was held yesterday morning at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Applause that verged on an ovation signaled the approval of the Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution at its opening tonight for the oratorical uppercuts at President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization plan, delivered with gusto by Messmore Kendall, President General of the Sons of the American Revolution.

A business building in the midtown section of Manhattan near Fifth Avenue figured in an investment purchase yesterday. Several Bronx properties, including an apartment house on University Avenue, also were listed as changing hands.

Monroe Loan Society new common A stock, $1 par value, has been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange. This has been issued share for share in exchange for the old no-par value A stock, which has been suspended from dealings.

With more than 1,400 retailers, manufacturers and stylists present, the Summer season in millinery was projected last night at a style show held under the auspices of the Millinery Stabilization Commission in the Hotel Astor. Eleven manufacturers displayed seventy-two creations.

An explosion in a manhole at Union Street and Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, last night interrupted electric current in the vicinity and darkened the homes of more than 200 families. For more than threequarters of an hour the surface cars on Fifth Avenue and Union Street were halted.
Summer is i-cumen in Not only the temperature heralds it, but "Penny Wise," which was frothily acted at the Morosco last night.

Modie J. Spiegel Jr., vice president and general manager of Spiegel, Inc., last year, was paid $75,000 by that company, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

The 286 savings and loan associations in New York State at the end of last year had total resources of S363,406,033, an increase of $6,836,046 during the year, according to a compilation made by the Banking Department and the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.

Hearings in the so-called "Kenyon case" before the Securities and Exchange Commission were delayed for a second time yesterday when Eugene L. Garey, representing the principal respondents, asked a week in which to move for withdrawal of their registration statements as over-the-counter dealers. His written argument in support of the motion to withdraw is to be filed tomorrow.
The meeting of the Disarmament Conference Bureau [steering committee] fixed for May 6 is likely to be postponed until the end of May, according to reports in League circles today.

H. R. Kurrie and Holman D. Pettibone, trustees in bankruptcy for the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railway, received $24,000 and $1,000 salaries, respectively, in 1936, according to the company's report to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Members of the Winfield committee of the Nearly New Shop have arranged a luncheon in behalf of the Winfield Day Nursery today in the Neptune Room of the Pierre. Each guest has been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for resale at the shop.
Bert Fish, United States delegate to the Egyptian Capitulations Conference here, moved today to amend the Egyptian draft convention to meet American World Court policy.

The Hudson Dispatch said ?? three local men had purchased stock control of the North Bergen Trust Company of North Bergen, from a New York group in an effort to retain for the bank an insured status under the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Remington-Rand, Inc., announced yesterday that its plant managers had been instructed to begin rehiring 700 former employes still out of work as a result of last year's strike in five factories of the company.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes of Montclair and Fishers Island, N. Y., to Alfred Faris King Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Faris King of Dongan Hills, S. I., will take place on June 11 in the First Congregational Church here.

Vince Dundee, 159 1/2, former middleweight boxing champion, extended his comeback streak to four victories in a row tonight by knocking out Leo (Red) Finnegan, 167, New York, in 1:08 of the third round.

Business failures in the United States totaled 189 for the week ended March 15, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure compares with 190 the week before and 174 for the corresponding week last year.

Plans submitted during March to the New York State Department of Labor for construction work on factories, mercantile establishments and places of assembly outside of New York City totaled 206 and represented contemplated expenditures of $2,512,275.

Unfair competition and unlawful trade practices were charged to the Schenley- Products Company, principal selling agent for Schenley whisky and gin in the United States, in a citation issued today by the Federal Alcohol Administration.

Due to an increasing volume of business the Howard Smith Paper Mills, Ltd., is expanding its plants producing soda pulp, sulphite, kraft pulp and other raw materials. Harold Crabtree, president, told shareholders at the company's annual meeting today.

Governor Lehman named former Representative James P. B. Duffy tonight as a Supreme Court justice for the Seventh Judicial District, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Robert F. Thompson.
A hitherto unrecognized form of heart disease in the United States caused by malnutrition and a specific treatment for it were described today before the American College of Physicians.

Miss Helen Woods, 55 years old, of 64 North Oratorio Parkway, East Orange, N. J., was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of operating an unlicensed employment agency in the Fisk Building at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.
The Princeton Theatre Intime will open its initial Spring production, August Strindberg's "The Father," tomorrow evening in the Murray Theatre for a five-night run.

New Yorkers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian S liner Roma include Mr. and Mrs. William Iselin, Mrs. Robert Lamont Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Deems, Mr. and Mrs. R. A. Hyde, Mrs. Carroll Dunham, Otto J. Baumgarten, Mrs. W. S. Bryant,

The present pension system of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company by which the employes contribute 3 per cent of their wages, fortified by an annual contribution of $500,000 by the company, is actuarially unsound, Carl M. Owen, attorfor the receiver for the company, admitted yesterday.
John Cudahy of Wisconsin, Ambassador to Poland, will be transferred to the Irish Free State as Minister, according to authoritative information today.

A special legislative investigating committee dug deeper tonight into charges of mismanagement at the Windham County Home for Children and allegations that several girl inmates received "unfatherly" attentions from 65-year-old Philip Provandie, its superintendent.

Regulations to promote uniformity and to aid collectors in the problem of granting extensions of time for filing income and excess profits tax returns for the year beginning Jan. 1 were issued today by Guy T. Helvering, Collector of Internal Revenue.

The Western regime in Harvard rowing seems to be bearing promise of success. Under the quiet megaphone of Tom Bolles of Washington, Harvard's varsity eights are working on the Charles River and tonight there was strong evidence that at least one good crew would
While it is strongly hinted in semi-official circles here that the French Air Ministry intends to cancel the New York-Paris air race, an official statement is still lacking.

The Mission Corporation yesterday reported for 1936 a net income of $677,833 after all charges and Federal taxes, equal to -48 cents a share on the 1,399,345 shares of capital stock. In the preceding year the company reported no income, no dividends having been paid on its stock holdings of either Tide Water Associated Oil Company or the Skelly Oil Company.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler promised George Lansbury, a British Labor party leader, today that if a conference is called to discuss armaments and trade Germany will participate. After talking to Hitler for two hours, Mr. Lansbury issued this statement with the Fuehrer's agreement:

Stocks closed firmer at irregularly higher levels in slowest trading since September; turnover, 818,120 shares. United States Government issues fractionally higher, corporate and foreign bonds steady and dull; transactions, $10,030,700.

The Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners will hold a meeting tonight at the Bronx County Court House, Walton Av. and 161st St. Clarence Crocheron. contract manager of the American Appraisal Co, will discuss property appraisals.

General Max von Gallwitz, one of the German World War command-, ers, died in Naples, according to a dispatch received at his home here. Chancellor Hitler has sent a warm message of condolence to his family.

Vivienne Mader, who dances under the Hawaiian name of Huapala, gave her first New York recital last night at the Town Hall, with the able assistance of Mikel Hanapi and his Ilima Islanders, a company of five who sing and play the ukelele, guitar and various drums and rattles.

The Rev. William Aloysius McCartney, S. J., since 1925 treasurer of the High School of the College of St. Francis Xavier at 30 West Sixteenth Street, died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 56 years old.

The membership of the Brick Presbyterian Church at a special congregational meeting held last evening in that edifice, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, voted to sell the present site and to build a new structure at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.

A deal was closed today for sale of the New Orleans Southern Association baseball team to Governor Richard W. Leche, Mayor S. Maessri and a group of business men for $155,000. The franchise and grounds went with the deal.

The quarterly statement of contributions to the League of Nations issued today shows that Italy not only is continuing to pay her dues to Geneva but is among the promptest members, more prompt than the United Kingdom and Canada.

William Harridge, president of the American League, is expected to watch the Chicago White Sox and the St. Louis Browns open the 1937 baseball season here tomorrow. Advance seat sales indicated a crowd of 15,000.

The mothers and babies division of the State Charities Aid Association, which for forty-three years has provided a service of advice and assistance for homeless mothers, is to be discontinued, it was announced yesterday. No new cases will be accepted after May 1, and the work of the division will be terminated on June 1.

A reunion of fifteen newspaper publishers and others who made maiden trips to South America two years ago and to China last October as guests of Pan American Airways aboard that company's clipper ships will be held at the Hotel RitzCarlton Friday evening.

Louis Torre, 23, former Bronx newsboy, who is now a C. I. O. organizer, told Mayor Joseph McLevy today that if the "Bridgeport Manufacturers Association wants a Detroit situation here we will give it to them."

Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association Spring sailing dates were announced today. They include the first annual intercollegiate dinghy championships at M. I. T. on Saturday and Sunday, the Brown University Yacht Club's invitation regatta off Providence on May 1, the M. I. T.

Another new thriller, "The Second Shot,", was staged at the "Q" Theatre tonight. The play develops an alibi which is made by having a clock fixed to discharge a revolver, but the author, Gordon Merrick, does not maintain the consistency, since his murderer escapes justice only owing ton a twist in the plot.

Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Newark yesterday that he visualizes a general moderate improvement in the earnings of the company, and added that unless "we are up against a wave of radicalism which would swamp all of us, there is no danger of public ownership or competition from Federal sources."
The Committee of Pan-American Experts on the Codification of International Law, which opened its sessions here on April 5, ended its labors today with the signing of a Final Act.

A recession in prices, bred of overproduction and the consequent damming up of merchandise on wholesalers' and manufacturers' shelves is probable in the coming Summer months, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., warned in a speech before a luncheon meeting of the New Haven Advertising Club in the Hotel Garde, here today.

W. Murray's colt Fairford was made sole favorite for the Epsom Derby at 9 to 1 in the call over at the Victoria Club last night. The Aga Khan's Le Grand Due, hitherto joint favorite with Fairford, fell back to second place in the betting at 100 to 11.

The press should become an even stronger bulwark against internal enemies and a more potent force i for civilization and world peace, Secretary of Commerce Daniel C. Roper told the nation's publishers yesterday.

Cotton advanced $1 a bale at the opening yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here, but renewed liquidation of May contracts, particularly from New Orleans sources, not only canceled the entire improvement but left prices 5 to 14 points lower than on Saturday.

Dr. Russell Forbes, the city's Commissioner of Purchase, has been named by New York University students as this year's recipient of the Griffith Hughes Honorary Medal "as an outstanding public servant who is also an effective public speaker."
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John T. Trigge of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Muriel Florence Trigge, to John J. Grandefeld of New York.

Jersey commuters wearing smiling faces must indicate only one thing-the fishing season is off to a good start. Yesterday, in a midtown office, the writer saw two slightly sunburned Jerseyites wrapping iced brook trout in packages to be distributed to friends.

Plunging from the window of his office on the twenty-first floor of the Equitable Building at 120 Broadway, Roland B. Frasse, an investment broker of 270 Taylor Road, Short Hills, N. J.. was killed about 2 P. M. yesterday before the eyes of thousands of office workers.

After a spirited debate the Assembly passed tonight the Fite bill, under which the State and municipalities would contribute $75 toward the expenses of bearing each child born in the State. The vote on the measure was 81 to 62 and cut across party lines.
Criticism was voiced today in circles supporting the government of the clash yesterday at Raclawice, in Kielce Province. A crowd of villagers resisted police and two were killed and two injured.

An oil portrait of the late William Travers Jerome. painted by Ellen Emmett Rand, has been presented to the Association of the Bar of the City of New York by "the members of his professional staff," and is now installed in the Blue Room of the association building at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
Senator Guffey said today in a speech at a rally sponsored. by Labor's Non-Partisan League that "even the Supreme Court is beginning to see the light" on labor legislation.

Kent Straat of this city, promotion manager for Pictorial Review, died last night of a streptococcic infection at Norwalk Hospital following an appendicitis operation a week ago. Mr. Straat, also a cartoonist, was 34 years old.

The spiritual, civic and educational ideals for which the University of Notre Dame stands were emphasized last night by 10,000 Notre Dame alumni meeting in eighty-five cities in the United States and in a dozen foreign cities to commemorate the fourteenth annual Universal Notre Dame Night.

A mortgage given to William Vincent Astor by Samuel Stein on Jan. 19, 1921, on. the four-story building at 189 Bowery, has been reduced to $16,725 at 4 per cent, according to the present holder of this mortgage, Joseph Weinberger.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 14 shows a decrease for the week of $63,000,000 in total loans and investments and increases of $89,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $88,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $44,000,000 in deposits credited to foreign banks, $94,000,000 in balances with domestic banks and $205,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Letters proposing a "conference" to discuss the "campaign" of the Morris Plan Bank on its arrangement for offering credit facilities to customers of R. H. Macy Co., for the purchase of durable goods have been sent to fifteen "representative" New York stores by the Credit Retailers Association of America, it was announced yesterday by H. Blumberg, director of the bureau of service of the organization.

William Morton Wheeler, professor emeritus, of Harvard and an international figure in natural science, collapsed on the Harvard Square subway station platform this evening and was dead before help reached him. He was 72 years old.
An administration bill to re-enact the marketing-agreements provisions of the old Agricultural Adjustment Administration Act was passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.

The Deutsche Bund, a society of Germans resident in Southwest Africa, must be wholly reorganized or must disband as a result of a government order published at Windsoek today, naming it a political organization under the terms of the proclamation issued April 2.

Lord Conway of Allington, mountain climber, authority on are and discoverer of paintings by old masters, died today at the age of 81. Into both pursuits-they were more than hobbies-he carried a spirit that had no sympathy either with solemn exploring or the equally solemn talk about the minutiae of painting.

J. D. Wooster Lambert, manufacturer of aeronautical supplies and chemical compounds, was in Federal Court yesterday and heard the testimony of Miss Dorothy Sabine, former chorus girl, 343 West Seventy-first Street, in her suit against him for breach of contract.
The sale of the fifteen-story Munson-Beaver Building and a four-story extension, at 80-92 Beaver Street, featured the auctions of properties in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday.
A new wave of "share pushing" in Great Britain has caused the government to circulate warnings calculated to put every investor on guard.
The sale of the fifteen-story Munson-Beaver Building and a four-story extension, at 80-92 Beaver Street, featured the auctions of properties in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday.
A new wave of "share pushing" in Great Britain has caused the government to circulate warnings calculated to put every investor on guard.

Notice Candidates who have not filed application for the examination for promotion to the rank of Battalion Chief, due to being on vacation or sick leaves, may do so upon their return to duty up to and including Monday, April 26.
All but three of sixty members of the Jewish B'nai B'rith Lodge arrested by the secret police yesterday were released today, but the Grand President of the order, Rabbi Beck, remained in custody.
George W. Gillet, State Department Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic in 1934-35, died at his home here tonight after a short illness. His age was 87.

Gus Hill, the veteran theatrical producer and actor, who is credited with discovering or aiding to success many of the older stars of the American stage, died suddenly last night of a heart attack in the hallway of 332 West Forty-sixth Street, where he had gone to call on a friend.

Judge John B. Hannum, a member of the Delaware County Orphans Court bench since 1921, died at his home here today in his eighty-sixth year. He became ill of bronchial pneumonia on Feb. 11 and had been ill ever since.

President Roosevelt's message on the budgetary problem served today to throw a spotlight upon several billions of dollars of "recoverable assets'"scattered through several Federal agencies and to breed discussion among fiscal authorities as to the rapidity with which such assets might be liquidated on a practical basis.
THE MIND OF MAN, by Walter Bromberg. (Harper, $3.50.) The story of man's fight against mental illness. THE MIRACLE OF ENGLAND, by Andre Maurois. (Harper, $3.75.)

Henry R. Barrett, dominant figure among the "Old Guard" Republicans in Westchester County and for many years chief assistant to the late William L. Ward, county Republican leader, resigned as chairman of the White Plains Republican Committee today.

President COFFIN not many months ago spoke of the Brick Church as having a flavor "all its own," as a "corporate personality" and an "indescribably unique " institution that has ministered to a vast company through the years in the very heart of New York. Here has developed a "specific genus of Christian." More explicitly:
Following an early decline that carried the list to within a few points of last week's low figures, prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered sharply yesterday to end with gains of 9 to 12 points.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week amounted to 3,463,550 barrels, compared with 3,427,500 in the preceding week, an increase of 36,050, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Ralph Greenleaf of New York conquered Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 125 to 71, in 15 innings last night at Ponzi's Academy, creating a triple tie for the world's pocket billiard championship and necessitating another round-robin play-off.

The impression is growing on Capitol Hill that the substitute revenue program over which Republican legislative leaders have labored for many days, may not prove acceptable to Governor Lehman when it comes before the Assembly in the form of legislative bills, and that some new method for balancing the Governor's executive budget will have to be devised.
Weeks ago when they drew up Keeneland's book they styled today's feature the Calumet Purse. So what could be more appropriate than for Calumet Stable to win it with Four Eleven.
It is beginning to look as if the final step in the controversy between Mr. CARLETON BEALS and his late associates on the Trotsky

Reflecting the automobile industry's recovery from three months of strike difficulties, production is nearing a peak for eight years. Automotive Daily News estimated this week's output at 133,370 cars and trucks.

The international aspect of Spain's civil war is most obvious in the air and perhaps nothing so important has hapopened in this field in recent years as the government's recent domination of the skies.

A banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,000,000 of 2 3/4 per cent bonds of Hartford County (Conn.) Metropolitan District on a bid of 101.133.
THE NEW YORK TIMES advertising class heard Stuart Campbell, vice president and art director of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., lecture last night on "Layout, Art and Mechanical Preparation."
The Wagner Labor Relations Law should be of aid in employeremployee relations, William C. Dickerman, president of the American Locomotive Company, said at the annual meeting yesterday.

The strongest demand for governmental savings to come from the Administration since the economy drive of 1933 was laid before Congress today by President Roosevelt along with a request for a lump-sum appropriation of $1,500,000,000 for relief and work relief for the fiscal year 1938.
Premier Ismet Inonu and Foreign Minister Tewfik Rushdu Aras of Turkey spent six hours here today while traveling from Belgrade to Angora.
Mrs. Charles H. Schweppe, philanthropist, art patron and wife of the banker, died suddenly of heart disease today in her apartment in the Ambassador East Hotel. She was 50 years old.
The Protestant Church elections ordered by Chancellor Hitler will be postponed until Autumn, it was authoritatively learned today.

Abandoning the company's longstanding policy of recognizing no "outside" unions, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of trustees of the Consolidated-Edison, announced yesterday that the company had given recognition to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. organization, and that negotiations for a contract were under way.

Reflecting a further break in prices abroad, the custom smelters and producers yesterday lowered the domestic price of copper 1 cent to 14 1/2 cents a pound. This is the third reduction in the price of copper in the domestic market in April and the new price compares with a high of 17 cents.

Attet giving him excellent fielding support through nine innings, the Car dinals came up with some stout batting in the tenth inning today to give their star, Dizzy Dean, a 2-0 victory over the Reds in the local opening game of the National League season.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., and the Texas Corporation completed yesterday negotiations for the purchase of the holdings of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., in the Colombian Petroleum Company for $2,050,000.

Convicted four times in the "Scottsboro case," Heywood Patterson, one of eight Negro defendants, will appeal to the Alabama Legislature Thursday against a seventy-five-year sentence. Patterson was convicted the fourth time last year in Morgan County and sentenced.

Emplayers who attended the first of a series of conferences on collective bargaining called by Secretary Perkins agreed today that they would join labor in living up to provisions of the National Labor Relations Act as the law of the land.

The report of the International Paper Company for 1936 shows a consolidated net profit of $5,159,696, equivalent to $5.37 a share on 960,846 shares of 7 per cent, $100-par, preferred stock, in contrast with a net loss of $2,840,898 in 1935.

Jerry McCarthy, customers' man of W. E. Hutton Co., asserted at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today the brokerage firm had no financial responsibility in the Atlas Tack stock deal which led to the commission's manipulation charges against

John Henry Hammond received salary at the rate of $24,000 annually from Jan. 1 to April 21, 1936, as president of the Bangor Aroostook Railroad, according to the report of the company to the Interstate Commerce Commission, made Public yesterday.

The stock market here was quiet but generally firm today. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, and among the foreign loans German bonds were strong. Some international issues were unsettled; International Nickel, for one, fell off.

Stocks closed generally higher in slightly more active trading; turnover, 1,127,760 shares. United States Government issues lower, corporate bonds irregularly higher, second-grade rails strong, foreign loans firm;
Paced by the perfect batting performance of Gerald Walker, the Tigers opened the American League baseball season here today with a 4-to-3 victory over Cleveland.

The Stevens Tech junior varsity baseball team swamped Webb Institute, 17-5, at Castle Point Field today. Stevens reached the Naval Architects for twelve hits, while Bill Lange and Bob Gilbert combined to limit Webb to five. A. Lange starred at bat, getting two homers and a double.

Smoky, a black-spotted Dalmatian dog, mascot of Hook and Ladder 7, Twenty-eighth Street and Second Avenue, traveled alone yesterday morning to the headquarters of the American Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, 50 Madison Avenue, near Twentysixth Street, and made himself at home in the lobby.

The Ohio House of Representatives voted, 51 to 50, late today outlaw sit-down strikes in amending a bill to set up a State Labor Relations Board similar to the Federal Board. Final vote was delayed until tomorrow.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:
Czech armament shares slumped suddenly today, some as much as 40 per cent, with reports of peaceful developments in the international situation.

Fred Weidlich, that indefatigable ink-slinger and squid-tosser of the West End Surf Fishing Club, watched some of the boys practicing in the surf along the Long Island shore last Sunday, and that got him thinking about the impending surf fishing season and the novelty of linen-thread fishing.

Governor Lehman will hold a public hearing at 2 P. M. Friday on the four Berg Election Law Bills pertaining to independent nominations. It has been asserted that the bills aim particularly at a possible movement by the American Labor party to nomnate Mayor La Guardia for re-election.

The 2,579-ton British merchantman Seven Seas Spray successfully ran the Insurgent blockade from SaintJean-de-Luz, France, last night and docked here this morning while tens of thousands of hungry Loyalist residents and refugees along the quays cheered themselves hoarse.

Preferred shareholders of the Cor E. L. Bruce Company have been notified that, unless they assent to a plan for wiping out arrearages of dividends by issuance of new 3 1/2 per cent preferred stock,. they will not be eligible for the half-yearly dividend of $1.75 on the new issue, payable on June 1 to holders of rec ord of May 15.
Several women from the New York area obtained divorces today. Mrs. Louise Odell received a decree from David Dallas Odell. They were married in New York City on Oct. 25, 1927.

Life insurance companies and mutual savings banks whose treasuries in the last generation have provided about half of the funded debt of America's railroads will make no more substantial investment in the general field of rails until basic railroad difficulties can be solved, Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank,

Denials that there had been any shortage of linen or disruption of the regular routine at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital during the eighthour sit-down strike there on March 15 were made yesterday by defense witnesses in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn.

An attempt by Minority Leader Thomas J. Curran of the Board of Aldermen to have relief agencies investigated by a joint committee of the Legislature and the Board of Aldermen was blocked yesterday when the Aldermen voted to send his resolution to the Committee on State Legislation.

Rudy Dusek, 218, Omaha, threw Bill Sledge, 214, Texas, after a rough and tumble bout in 19:31 of the feature wrestling match at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Dusek downed his rival with a back body slam.

A temporary injunction against a strike called March 24 by the United Shoe Workers of America was granted today by Justice Harry Manser in the Maine Supreme Court of the plea of Lewiston and Auburn Shoe Manufactures.

Thomas Ginty of the Pastime A. C. upset Robert Ford, New York Athletic Club ace, by 21-18, 21-6, in a second-round match of the Metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall handball singles tournament at the Pastime A. C. last night. Ford was seeded third.
Six three-story apartment houses at 35-29 to 35-41 Crescent Street, Astoria, Queens, have been purchased by Norman-Lila Estates, Inc., from the New York Life Insurance Company.
The program which Frederick Bristol played last night at his annual Town Hall piano recital was devised for musical palates surfeited with the day-to-day fare of concert halls.

Mrs. Julia Clark Howe, widow of William H. Howe, landscape painter, died here yesterday at her home. She was 85 years old. Mr. Howe died eight years ago. Mrs. Howe was a charter member of the Bronxville Woman's Club, a Bronxville literary group. She was a member of Christ Episcopal Church of Bronxville.

Hans Goepel, 26-year-old antiNazi refugee, who had been held for deportation at Ellis Island, was released yesterday in $500 bail provided by the Workers Defense League and the Political and Labor Bail Fund.

A fortified floating city of 40,000, the United States Fleet moved westward tonight toward a sham attack on Hawaii. The battle, one phase of the 1937 fleet manoeuvres, will climax a surprise attack on the islands, probably late this week.

Liquidating value of the National Aviation Corporation, an investment trust, on March 31 has been reported by the company as $17.59 a share, based on market values of listed securities and estimated values of unlisted securities.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Emily Weller Schweizer of this city and Noroton, Conn., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Jennings Weller of Brooklyn and Goshen, N. Y., to David Dows of Charlton Hall, Brookville, L. I. The marriage will take place the latter part of next month in the presence of the two families.

The first completed unit in the projected engineering elimination of pollution in the East River was inspected yesterday by engineers of the Public Works Administration, which supplies 45 per cent of the cost, and by engineers of the Sanitation Department of this city, which supplies the balance.

Broadway circles heard last night that the New Amsterdam Theatre, most renowned of New York musical comedy houses and last stronghold of the legitimate stage on -Forty-second Street, will be sold to Simon H. Fabian, president of the Fabian Brooklyn Theatres, Inc.

Count and Countess Francesco Maria Guardabassi of Torre di Pila, Perugia, Italy, have arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria after a stay in Prides Crossing, Mass. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Elliot Warren, who passed the Winter and early Spring at 502 Park Avenue, have gone to Still Pond, their country home in Hewlett, L. I.

J. Foster Warner, noted Rochester architect, died at the age of 77 today in his home here after a week's illness. He was the father of Major John A. Warner, Superintendent of the New York State Police.
The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation announced today that present prices on principal steel products would continue in the third quarter of the year on orders for shipment-before Sept. 30.

They had a perfect opening in Brooklyn yesterday. They had ideal weather and a crowd numbering 34,000 that was the largest in the history of Brooklyn baseball inaugurals. They had their Dodgers, adorned in a most amazing tone of green, a new manager in Burleigh Grimes,
