The arbitration committee of three clergymen in the strike of sixty-four editorial employes of The Long Island Daily Press yesterday made known its findings, which recommended that the strikers, members of the Newspaper Guild, receive all their demands with the exception of wage scales, which were granted in part.

In order to make available addittonal information on the changes In the volume of the various kinds of loans of member banks, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has revised the weekly condition report of member banks, it was announced yesterday.

The King of the Belgians has conferred the Cross of Officer of the Crown upon Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, a member of the Board of Education, attorney and chairman of the board of the Lafayette National Bank, it was announced yesterday at the Belgian Consulate here.

Four Goucher College girls were injured last night when a car in which they were riding was in a head-on collision with another machine. Those hurt were Natalie Kohn and Jeanne B Katz of New York, Grace 'Guinzburg of Flushing, L. I., and Cecilia Miller of South Norwalk, Conn.

Paul Moritz Warburg, who was one of the originators of the Federal Reserve System idea and who, early in 1929, predicted the stock market-crash and depression which followed, left a gross estate of $3,317,849, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

The St. John's University tennis team won its third straight match by defeating St. Francis College on the Queens Community Courts, 6--3, yesterday. St. John's took all six singles clashes but lost in three doubles engagements.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANT-Walter O'Hare, from 3d Division to 18th Division, assignment to desk duty discontinued. PATROLMAN-Max Bernstein, 47th Precinct to 48th Precinct. From precincts indicated to 18th Division, designated as third grade detectives:

The Attorney General's office, in advising the Legislature today that it had the right to declare sit-down strikes illegal, held that "a reasonable measure of prevention to avoid disturbance is not an infringement of anybody's constitutional rights."

Arriving here from Atlanta, where he scored a crushing victory over Bryan M. Grant Jr., Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., started in quest of the Mason-Dixon tennis championship today on the sun-drenched courts of the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook began an inquiry yesterday into charges by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, that two well-known criminal lawyers had deliberately offered perjured evidence in support of their efforts to get a new trial for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and Ralph Ligouri, one of his henchmen.
Plans for a thirteen-story apartment house and a Catholic School, both to rise on sites in the Bronx, were included in the list of new construction projects filed in the city yesterday.

Ted Creech, young mine superintendent and son of the owner of a mine at Twila, Harlan County, Ky., was arrested late today on a charge of perjury a few minutes after he had left the stand before the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage.

H. Hobart Porter, president of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that the public utility industry is sound and occupies a position in our economic structure second to none in importance.

International League baseball will return to Jersey City after more than three years' exile, with a general half-holiday declared throughout Hudson County when the Jersey Giants open the International League season against the Rochester Red Wings Thursday.

Burleigh Grimes and his gaudily caparisoned Dodgers gave their first at-home party to 32,387 paying guests from the Gowanus and other near-by centers at Ebbets Field yesterday and everything would have been all right but for a group of drably uniformed social climbers from the Polo Grounds.

Plans are now being completed for the annual May Day party and frolic of the Cherry Street Settlement and Day Nursery, operated by the Salvation Army, which will be held at the settlement's headquarters, 94 Cherry Street.

Following a hearing late yesterday afternoon on the form of an order confirming the reorganization plans of the Bush Terminal Company and its subsidiary, the Bush Terminal Buildings Company, Judge Robert A. Inch, in the Federal court in Brooklyn, said he will sign the order this afternoon after some slight changes have been made in it.

A Finno-Ugric Institute, the function of which will be to stimulate the "historic common background" of Finns and Hungarians, was opened last night at Columbia University's Casa Italiana, 117th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

The Princeton Theatre Intime opened its Spring season tonight in the Murray Theatre with a performance of August Strindberg's three-act psychological drama "The Father." The play, which was favorably received, will continue nightly through Saturday.
Buenos Aires is to have cheaper bread, but customers must bring their own wrapping paper for loaves weighing one pound or less.

Dr. Alvin L. Barach, member of the Columbia University faculty, told the House Military Affairs Committee today that he had to let "several patients die" because he could not obtain helium to treat them.

The Duke of Windsor sent a birthday gift today to little Princess Elizabeth, heir presumptive to the throne that he abdicated. The Princess will be 11 years old tomorrow. The large sealed parcel bore the label of a Vienna sports shop and was accompanied by a big, lace-edged card signed "Uncle David."

Conviction of the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation as having maintained a nuisance in Queens at the public highway on Palmetto Street and Myrtle Avenue, Ridgewood, was dismissed by the Court of Appeals today with an opinion by Judge Irving G. Hubbs in which the six other judges concurred.

Two deaths from diphtheria occurred in the city in the week ended last Saturday, bringing the total for the fifteen-week period since the first of the year up to nineteen, more than three times as many as in the same period last year, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday.
Police hunted a smiling young man tonight who kidnapped William Grinnell Blodgett 2d, 5-year-old son of a department store buyer, but released him five hours later, apparently conscience stricken.

Grover A. Whalen, frequently mentioned as a possible Democratic Mayoralty candidate this year, indicated last night that he does not expect to make the race. Speaking at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Astor, arranged by the Up-Town Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Whalen said:

Churchill Downs railbirds were convinced today Trainer Bob McGarvey means business with his Derby candidates. McGarvey and his troupe of twenty-nine Milky Way thoroughbreds got in from Texas at dusk last night, but at sun-up

The quarterly report of the Commercial Credit Company, to be made public today, shows earnings of $1.72 a share on 1,841,567 shares of common stock for the first three months of 1937. This compares with $1.64 a share on 1,166,932 shares in the same period last year.
The six-story apartment building at 15-9 Glover Avenue, Yonkers, on a site 100 by 100 feet, has been purchased by Ely Maran Son, together with Murray Maran, under the new firm name of Maran Maran.
Alderman John J. McManus of Brooklyn introduced a bill in the Aldermanic branch of the Municipal Assembly yesterday providing a five-day week for certain classes of city employes.
In a hard-hitting game the Lawrenceville School baseball team defeated the Princeton freshmen, 8 to 6, today. Three home runs climaxed the hitting for the victors, accounting for five tallies.
With singular accord but varying degrees of bewilderment, London critics found themselves wondering tonight what was happening on the stage of the Queen's Theatre, where "Post Road" was presented.

Throughout the depression Great Britain has kept close to a balanced budget even in the years when she did not quite achieve one. She rejected any policy of "spending for recovery," and succeeded by 1934 in reducing governmental expenditures below the 1929 level.

James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, is among the passengers sailing today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary for London to attend the coronation. Others are the Ranee of Sarawak, Lady Essendon, Sir Robert and Lady Craigie, J. Sterling Rockefeller, Miss Gloria Swanson, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stout,

The world's production of tin in the first quarter of this year amounted to 43,800 tons, compared with 39,065 in the corresponding period in 1936, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

Miss Louise Starr de Vore, daughter of Nicholas de Vore of 15 West Twenty-ninth Street, was married to Carl Payne Tobey of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Tobey of Nutley, N. J., last evening at a ceremony in the apartment at the Barbizon Plaza of Supreme Court Justice William . Harman Black. Justice Black officiated in the presence of relatives.

Sudbury Tigers, senior hockey champions of Canada, got off to a slow start tonight against Hershey, champion of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League of the United States, but found their bearings in the second and third periods to romp to a 5-2 victory.
Many luncheons were given yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin, where a novel fashion revue entitled "Down to the Sea in Suits" was held for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club.

Mrs. Delia W. Cunningham, wife of Matthew H. Cunningham and sister of the Rev. Daniel A. Stewart, assistant pastor of St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, died yesterday in St. Peter's Hospital. She was 48 years old and resided at 56 Dictum Court, Brooklyn.

Secretary of War Woodring will present wrist watches on behalf of the National Rifle Association of America tomorrow to William P. Schweitzer of Hillside, N. J.; Dave Carlson, New Haven, Conn., and William B. Woodring, East Alton, Ill., as the three outstanding rifle shots of the United States.

The first annual New England Relay Carnival will be held in the stadium here on Saturday with fourteen college varsity squads, eleven college freshman squads and twenty school squads entered in the 38-event, program.

Miss Mary Jeannette Rawlings, daughter of Mrs. Junius Ambrose Rawlings of this city and the late Dr. Rawlings, was married to Karl E. Robinson of New York tonight in St. Clement's Episcopal Church here.

Dr. Russell Forbes, the city's Commissioner of Purchase, received the honorary Griffith Hughes Memorial Medal yesterday "as an outstanding public servant who is also an effective public speaker" after the thirteenth annual student competition for the Griffith Hughes Memorial Medal in Public Speaking at the Washington Square College of New York University.

The council of the Actors Equity Association, at its weekly session yesterday, received a proposal to reduce the salaries of the president and executive secretary-treasurer to $7,500 and $5,200, respectively. The incumbents are Frank Gillmore and Paul Dullzell.

Father Divine, the dusky preacher whom his followers regard as God, fled from his Harlem Heaven yesterday and went into hiding from the police after a riot in the headquarters of his Peace Mission at 20 West 115th Street in which his angels routed the forces of outer darkness.
State Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews reported that building construction permits issued in March revealed a small-home building "boom."

Bringing the list of radio personalities to sixteen, the largest roster of any studio, Paramount today announced the acquisition of James and Marian Jordan, the Fibber McGee and Molly of the networks, for "This Way, Please," which will go before the cameras in two weeks.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture. follow:

Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, was re-elected yesterday by the board of directors. This marks the thirty-fifth consecutive time that Mr. McCarter has been elected head

A press "free from governmental restraint" is essential to the maintenance of liberty in this country, the American Newspaper Publishers Association was warned yesterday by its president, Jerome D. Barnum, publisher of The Syracuse (N. Y.) Post-Standard.
THE monopolistic magnates who keep the baseball slaves in such ghastly subjection received an even break in a couple of recent legal decisions. They won one and lost one.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation, which has contracted to purchase the Brick Presbyterian Church property at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, plans to utilize the site eventually for the erection of a business building, but plans for the new structure have not yet been completed, officials of the company explained yesterday.

Postmaster General Farley, participating in the dedication of three Pennsylvania postoffices today, declared that the "output" of the governmental machine was "no longer delivered into the hands of a favored few."

Mrs. Mathilde Welt of 30 West Seventieth Street, former president of the Sisterhood of Congregation Emanu-E1 of Staten Island, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. She was 60 years old.

Miss Dorothy Everett Spalding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Seaton Spalding of this place, will be married on May 8 in the First Congregational Church here to Dr. Cecil Collins Swann of Asheville, N. C., son of Mrs. Edward Swann of Marion, Ala., and the late Dr. Swann.

Everything was all right at the Yankee Stadium yesterday but the result of the ball game. In a tense but long struggle against the Senators the world champions launched their campaign for the 1937 pennant in the American League. They got off the mark all right, but in the wrong direction, for Washington turned them back, 3 to 2.
Edmund Lowe, movie actor, is being sued for $121,750 by two sisters of his late wife, Lilyan Tashman, it was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday.

In a brief and informal ceremony today the Ambassador of Great Britain and the Ministers of the Irish Free State and Canada handed to Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, permits for his company to use terminals and fly over the territory of their respective countries.

Northeastern University donated a baseball game to Long Island University, 5-4, at Manhattan Beach yesterday.' Outhitting the Blackbirds, 9-6, the visitors made seven errors to help L. I. U. win its tenth contest in twelve starts.

Drastic revisions of the tax structure, including a constitutional amendment to insure the legality of taxation of capital gains on an accrual basis, were recommended yesterday by the committee on taxation of the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc.

Boston's gilt-edged Red Sox struck pay dirt today, hammering three Athletic pitchers for eighteen hits and an 11-5 victory. The Sox chased Harry Kelley, Philadelphia's ace, with a five-run attack in the fourth inning to give Wes Ferrell an 8-0 lead. They continued the bombardment against -Ross and Herman Fink.
Miss Helen Gladys Hughes and Representative Dewey Short of Galena, Mo., were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
Cornell's baseball team opened its home season with a ten-inning 10-9 victory over Colgate today, winning on a wild pitch, with one out and the bases full.

Announcement has been made by Girard C. Thomson of Rockville Centre, L. I., of the engagement and approaching marriage of his sister, Miss Arlene Newton Thomson of this city, to Wesley Alsgood Kornder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Kornder of Brooklyn.

A colorful garden fete, with "County Fair divertissements," will take place Saturday afternoon in the Garth of St. Mark's, 111 East Tenth Street, to raise funds for beautifying that community center. Mrs. Albert R. Bogert will be the guest of honor.

The international chess congress in session here since April 11, ed at the Casino tonight when the winners in the amateur tournament became known. First prize went to W. A. T and Schelfhout of Amsterdam with 6 1/2 points.

The prospect of a plan of reorganization for the Standard Gas and Electric Company within sixty days was disclosed yesterday in announcements sent to security holders by the protective committees for the notes and debentures and the $6 and $7 prior preferred stocks of the company.

Captain Edward Miller, in charge of the Grand Avenue police station, Brooklyn, applied yesterday to Commissioner Valentine for retirement to take effect April 30. His application was accepted and he will receive an annual pension of $2,500.

By a vote of Ma 29 to 95, the Assembly today defeated the bill of Assemblyman did Doyle, Democrat, of Kings, which ma would have exempted old-law tene- nal ments in New York City from complying with the safety and sanitary A provisions of the Multiple Dwell- ma ing Law.

Sugar mills in Cuba have ground 2,515,883 tons of sugar of the present crop thus far, the National Sugar Institute announced today. This leaves only 423,150 tons of sugar to be ground in accordance with the restricted crop decreed by the government in line with the policy which has been followed by Cuba since 1930.

Miss Victoria LeMay Mial, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonidas LeMay Mial of this city, has completed plans for her marriage to Harold Kramer Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Minor C. Smith of Short Hills, N. J., which will take place on Saturday afternoon in the Church of the Redeemer here.

The fourth in a series of exhibitions designed to acquaint visitors with the various projects of the Federal Government was placed on public view yesterday at the New York Museum of Science and Industry in the RCA Building, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, for an indefinite period.

The North Bergen Trust Company here, which was the first banking institution in the nation to have its deposit insurance terminated by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, will apply tomorrow for restoration of the privilege.
The Chamber Music Society of America presented the second concert of its New York Spring Festival last night at the Fifth Avenue Galleries of the Central Art Galleries.

As the meeting between Premier Benito Mussolini and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria in Venice Thursday approaches, there is an increasing tendency in Italy to, play down the whole thing and warn the public against expecting anything very important to issue from it.

Bernard Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that business for the first two months of the fiscal year, February and March, was about 22.5 per cent above the 1936 period, but that the figures were not comparable because the Pittsburgh store was closed from March 17 to April 1, 1936, due to the flood.

The Merritt resolution authorizing a $5,000,000 appropriation for Federal participation in the New York World's Fair of 1939 was passed by the House and sent to the Senate today after a short debate in which only scattering opposition was voiced.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation upheld the bureau's manhunting tactics today against Topeka criticism of an attempt to make an arrest there which cost a young Federal agent his life.

John St., 146 (18 Burling Slip), 25.3 1/2 x 24.9 John C. Spallone to Manhattan Financial Corp., 44 E. 53d St., consid. $5,000 (foreclosure). Same prop.. Manhattan Financial Corp. to Manha Realty Corp., 44 E. 53d St. ($5).

B. E. Hutchinson, vice president and finance chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said tonight at a stockholders' meeting that the corporation was spending $10,000,000 weekly for materials and distributing $2,000.000 in wages to 75,000 persons in the United States and Canada.
Salary trouble has begun to break out again in France as the rise in the cost of living has overtaken last year's salary increases and been exaggerated on the excuse of devaluation of the franc.

By a vote of 691 to 3 striking state employes of the Remington Rand Noiseless Typewriter plant here today approved acceptance of the meet company proposals sent to plants in several cities to end the industrial dispute now more than eleven months old.
A nationwide strike of 600,000 coal miners appeared likely tonight as the Mineworkers Federation announced a ballot taken in England and Wales showed overwhelming sympathy for the projected walkout.
Earnings of the Phelps Dodge Corporation this year were estimated yesterday at the annual meeting by Louis S. Cates, president, to be from 30 to 40 per cent larger than a year ago.
Designed to solve mutual problems of apparel chain distributors and to foster better relations with manufacturers, the newly organized Women's Apparel Retailers Association, Inc.,

Up and Doing, a Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes eligible from which nothing much had been expected, soundly defeated his more stylish stable-mate, Mosawtre, in the featured Clinton Purse at Jamaica yesterday. Fortunately for the form players, the two- ran coupled as an entry and it mattered not who finished first in the field of five.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 17: COMMANDERS Fenn, H. K., Naval Academy, to the Trenton as executive officer, in May.
The disappointment in the President's budget message today is in the relief item. Whatever his plans for economies in the regular Federal establishment, it is relief that keeps the budget unbalanced.

Two steel companies filed registration statements for proposed new securities today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Carrel Steel Company of Chicago asked registration of $1,312,500 of $5 par-value capital stock to be sold for plant expansion and working capital. Allen Co.

Leases of additional space for expanding business featured commercial rentals reported by brokers yesterday. As the result of a large increase in its business during the past year, Ganger, Inc., builders of bars, kitchen equipment .and furnishings for clubs, restaurants and other enterprises, leased about 20,000 square feet of additional space in 71-79 West Forty-fifth Street, through the Cross Brown Company.

Announcement late yesterday by the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation that it had reaffirmed prices of principal steel products for the third quarter of 1937 means that the price situation of the steel industry has been stabilized virtually for the rest of the year.
The House heard today that "inefficiency" of relief labor added about 331-3 per cent to the cost of constructing the Resettlement Administration's projects.
An important painting by Auguste Renoir, "Le Bal," has just come to this country and been acquired by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts from Jacques Seligmann Co. of New York and Paris.

In announcing yesterday a general meeting of shareholders to be held in Wilmington on April 29, the Mengel Company stated that 94 per cent of the 7 per cent preferred stock has been deposited in acceptance of the recapitalization plan now before the company, calling for conversion of the 7 per cent preferred into 5 per cent preferred.

United States Government bonds were under considerable pressure in the early trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and prices yielded as much as 3/8 point before sufficient support was mustered to check the movement.

Holding that the general mortgage bonds and common stock of the American Writing Paper Company lack seasoning and that the predecessor company had a poor record of earnings, the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has declined to list the securities.
Measures designed to legalize dog racing in New York State were reported favorably tonight by the all-powerful.Rules Committee of the Assembly in a surprise move.

A jury that heard evidence in the $3,000 slander suit of Mrs. Mary Grenier, principal of the Jerusalem School in North Wantagh, against Fred at Hohenstern, president of the Board of Education' of School District 5, reported to Acting County Judge Willard M. Kent here today that it found "no cause for action against the defendant."

JOHN ADAMS called New York politics "the devil's incomprehensibles" The phrase is an apt description of no small part of the proceedings of the present New Jersey Legislature; in particular of the Senate, and almost usually of that modest young genius, Governor HOFFMAN.

In this article Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek continues the diary he kept during his captivity in Sian last December. Yesterday he told of the events leading up to his capture by the rebels and of the capture itself.

Thomas Clyde Colt, head of Colt's Express Company, which was founded here by his father more than seventy years ago, died yesterday of a heart attack at the home of his niece. Mrs. Frederick N. Ritchie.

Twentyeight forest fires were burning in New Jersey tonight, according to Colonel Leonidas Coyle, State fire warden. Only two of them, however, were regarded as dangerous. Sixty acres had been swept near McKee City in Atlantic County and fifty-five acres southeast of Whitings in Ocean County.

A suit to compel Hallgarten Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co., as fiscal agents for a $9,000,000 Colombian bond issue, to account for funds received by them, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by a bondholders' committee consisting of Robert L. Owen, Richard C. Patterson and Lawrence E. DeS. Hoover.

Trading was fair to slow. Steer hind and rib prices were stronger and veal hindsaddles higher. Fresh pork prices were mostly steady to slightly lower. The lamb market was steady to strong, but demand was slow.

Addition of four men from New York to the board of the Reo Motor Car Company was authorized by stockholders at their annual meeting held here this afternoon. The enlarged directorate, meeting immediately after the stockholders' session, continued the present management in charge of the company with the re-election of all officers.

The impending prosecution of two high-ranking Iraqi diplomats who have already been dismissed from the foreign service for allegedly using the government's name to send arms to Spain, was announced in Parliament today by Prime Minister Hikmat Sulaiman.

Gene Gagliardi, 34-year-old barber from Mount Vernon, N. Y., brought to a blazing finale what had been a dull and uneventful day of maple crashing as he sent 749 pins toppling into the pits to take the lead in the singles race of the American Bowling Congress yesterday at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

Not so long ago there was a man whose name was synonymous with baseball. In every day life he was George Herman Ruth, but to the millions of fans who thrilled to his diamond exploits he was just plain Babe.
J. J. Ricks, president of the Union Carbide and Carbon

The seventh annual exhibition of work by members of An American Group, Inc., has just opened at the Montross Galleries, 785 Fifth Avenue, where it may be seen until May 1. The membership list has been greatly increased and contains now the following names:

The property at the southeast corner of Eleventh Avenue and Fiftysecond Street, consisting of four four-story tenements with stores, has been purchased as an investment by a syndicate organized by Louis J. Witkin, lawyer. The new owners expect to modernize the houses.

The National Theatre has now been definitely elected to receive the incoming "Without Warning" on the evening of April 28. This is the mystery melodrama by Ralph Spencer Zink, which A. L. Jones will present, despite emphatic denials made until recently.

The Appropriation Bill for the Department of Agriculture for 1938, carrying $927,398,548, an increase of $143,402,149 over the present year, but $5,078,407 below budget estimates, was reported to the House today by the Committee on Appropriations.

John R. Inglis was re-elected president of the Metropolitan Section, Professional Golfers Association, at the annual meeting on Monday at the Park Central Hotel, it was announced yesterday. J. B. Mackie was named first vice president and Frank Turnesa second vice president.

MANHATTAN BERGSTRESSER, SAMUEL W. (Dec. 3, 1931). Gross assets, $71.78; net, a deficit. Otterbourg, Steindler Houston, attorneys, 200 5th Ave. BLOOM, LOUIS (Oct. 9, 1935). Gross assets. $16,447; net, $598.

Complete organization of the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine in the 371 parishes in the Archdiocese of New York will be speeded by the active, immediate participation of more than 3,000 Catholic public and private school teachers in its activities, it was announced yesterday.

Experiments suggesting a wide field of research in high blood pressure were reported to the American College of Physicians at its annual meeting today by Dr. Harry Goldblatt, Professor of Experimental Pathology at Western Reserve University School of Medicine.

The board of directors of The AsAssociated Dress, at their annual meeting yesterday at the headquarLers of the organization, 383 Madison Avenue, re-elected as president Frank B. Noyes, publisher of The Washington Star.

The Census Bureau reported today that the cotton spinning industry operated at 148.3 per cent capacity during March, as compared with 144.8 per cent during February this year and 108.1 per cent during March last year.

Four days after the First Circuit Court of Appeals at Boston held invalid the old age pension and unemployment sections of the Social Security Act, the government today asked the Supreme Court to review the decision on the first point at the present term.

Characterizing President Roosevelt as an "oily-tongued experimenter" whose policies were leading the United States toward financial disaster, former Municipal Court Justice John R. Davies, inducted last night as president of the National Republican Club, announced his intention of making the club a rallying place for "His Majesty's Opposition."
The annual reunion dinner of the Twenty-five-Year Club was held at the R H. Macy Co. store at Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway last night.

More than the required amount of stock of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Elmira, N. Y., has been deposited to make effective the affiliation of the institution with the Marine Midland Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

An editorial exposs" of the senior preference poll at New York University's Washington Square College, published in yesterday's issue of Varieties, monthly downtown humor magazine, caused the Student Council of the college to suspend the magazine.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today heard evidence on an application by the Cleveland Stock Exchange for delisting of the Class A stock of the North American Securities Company of Cleveland on the general ground that there had been manipulative activities in the stock.
Before a gathering of the world's outstanding explorers Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd received last night the Explorers Club medal. He was the thirteenth explorer to receive the award.

Additional highway facilities for Manhattan motorists bound to and from Nassau County will be provided by the extension of Union Turnpike in Kew Gardens, Queens, from its present westerly terminus at Metropolitan Avenue to Woodhaven Boulevard, the Long Island State Park Commission announced yesterday.
Herbert Leitstein, secretary to William Fox, former movie producer, was held in criminal contempt of court by Federal Judge John Boyd Avis here today. Sentence will be imposed later.

A gallant Irish 5-yearold ran away with the Great Metropolitan Handicap today as London racing crowds flocked out to the Downs to see the first race of the "Epsom Spring Double," on which thousands of pounds are wagered.

Service in times of emergency by a peace-time escadrille of twenty or more airplanes piloted by private owners was offered to Governor Lehman for the State by Henry G. Olmsted of New York City, the owner of three planes, who called on the Governor today. Mr. Olmsted lives at 1 East End Avenue.

Miss Nancy T. Conway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. P. J. Conway of this city, has chosen the afternoon of May 27 as the date for her marriage to John M. Flynn 2d, son of Mrs. W. Wagner Flynn, also of Philadelphia, and the late John M. Flynn.

Reports that the Chilean mission now in Europe inspecting airplanes and radio equipment, with the purpose of spending 100,000,000 pesos for such equipment, will visit the United States before returning home, reached exporters here yesterday.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were reminded yesterday that so-called old accounts must be liquidated on or before July 1. After that date Federal Reserve Board rules requiring margins of 55 per cent will go into effect without qualification.

George Henry Wightman, retired steel leader and one of the country's foremost pioneers of amateur tennis, died at the age of 81 today in his home, 43 Hawes Street, Brookline. Private funeral services will be held Thursday at Swanpoint Cemetery, Providence.
Georges Enesco, Rumanian composer-conductor, will direct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next season during the four weeks of John Barbirolli's rest interval, it was announced yesterday.

The announcement yesterday that girls would be excluded from next year's Columbia College varsity show cast and the spread of a Bachelor Club movement on the Morningside campus have lent a new twist to the poet's prediction about the effect of Spring on a young man's fancy.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith turned reporter yesterday and interviewed "the tallest man in the world," Robert Wadlow, youthful giant of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, atop the world's tallest building, the Empire State Building.

Miss Angelica Van Rensselaer Fales gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for her sister, Miss Ellen Dexter Fales, and David Lomasney, who will be married next Tuesday in St. James's Church.

Commodity futures were generally lower in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Hide and sugar futures showed the only advances. On the cash market all the grains, cotton and silk gained, but cocoa, butter, copper, zinc, tin, wool tops, hides and rubber declined.

Dr. JOSEPH GOEBBELS said one true thing in his broadcast celebrating HITLER'S forty-eighth birthday. He pointed out that authoritarian regimes do not have an easier time of it than parliamentary governments. But who imagines they do? Certainly no one who has seen the two systems in operation.

Referring to the recent warning by the Finance Ministry that the budget could not be balanced unless new sources of revenue were discovered the newspaperImparcial said today that it would be futile to impose more taxes on an already impoverished population.

Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, staggered the business community today by announcing a growth-of-profits tax as high as 331-3 per cent to help pay the colossal cost of Britain's rearmament program.

Guy A. Thompson, trustee in bankruptcy for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, charged in a suit filed here today that the late O. P. Van Sweringen illegally used $2,817.805 of the road's funds to buy its own stock. He requested an accounting and equitable relief.

A general improvement in the ?? maritime industry, as reflected in the increased activities of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, was described by H. W. Warley, president, in his annual report yesterday to the members at the association's building, 80 Broad Street.

Continuing his struggle for German cultural freedom outside the boundaries of the Reich and repeating his often-voiced demand that the spirit must be free throughout the civilized world, Thomas Mann, Nobel Prize winner in literature, and German exile, spoke again last night on the task of saving German culture "so dear and so important to other peoples and so important to humanity itself."
Mrs. Donald L. Bigelow was reelected yesterday as chairman of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club. Other officers elected were Mrs. Benjamin J. Shore, secretary;
Two brothers who had not seen each other for thirty-seven years were reunited today by a "happy accident" last night on the highway seventy-five miles north of Toronto.

A record game of 101 moves resuited from the second meeting between Mrs. Adele Rivero and Mrs. Mary Bain in their adjourned game from the eighth round of the women's open championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday.

Mrs. Elizabeth Bell of 301 Palisade Avenue, widow of J. Harvey Bell, former Mayor and real estate dealer, died last night at her home. She was 78 years old. She was the mother-in-law of Edward A. Fitch, vice president of the Otis Elevator Company.

MANHATTAN CURTIS, MARY A. (April 7). Estate, more than $10,000. To Marie R. Lyons and Susan T. Lyons, nieces, executrices, 16 E. 96th St., residue equally. DA GAMA, ELIZABETH (April 13). Estate. more than $20,000. To Morris R.

A caption in last Sunday's rotogravure section of THE NEW YORK TIMES credited to Taylor Levi, architects, the making of a model of the United States Pavilion for the Paris Exposition of 1937, exhibited by the Architectural League of New York.

Miss Frances Blaisdell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ferren F. Blaisdell of Red Bank, N. J., was married to Alexander Williams of this city yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Beethoven Association, 30 West Fifty-sixth Street.
The Durant Drake Fellowship in philosophy has been awarded to Miss Elizabeth Eleanor Clawson by Vassar College. Miss Clawson is now a fellow in philosophy at Bryn Mawr.
Harold Laski, economist and writer, lunched with President Roosevelt in the Executive office today.

While Laborites, joined by David Lloyd George, again taunted the government for its "safety first" policy toward the blockade of Bilbao, the international control of arms and volunteers for both sides in Spain was in effect today.

Irish Eddie Brink, Scranton, Pa., lightweight, won a close decision from Al Roth of the Bronx in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 16,000, the largest since the innovation of popular prices at the Bronx--arena two years ago, watched the Pennsylvanian come back strong in the last three sessions.

For an hour and a half today Adolf Hitler, Fuehrer and Chancellor of the Reich, stood in a great reviewing stand erected at the edge of the Tiergarten for his forty-eighth birthday anniversary celebration and watched the German Army march past in his honor.

With war veterans and Village Trustees finally in accord on a design for a Spanish-American War statue, Village Clerk Richard X. O'Connell wrote to the Works Progress Administration today and asked for the assignment of workmen to carve the statue from an eighteen-ton block of granite which has been lying unused in Summerfield Park since a wrangle over designs for the statue began last July.

Miss Ruth Eleanor Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ellsworth Crane of this city, has chosen June 2 as the date for her marriage to John Ballantine Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Young, also of Newark.

Governors Island Leave of absence is granted to each of the following named Reserve officers, effective on or about the date specified: 1st Lt. Angelo A. Franco, Med.-Res., fifteen days, May 17. 1st Lt. Robert A. Gaw, Inf.-Res., fifteen days, Aprll 20.
Miss Jane Todd, Republican Assembly member from Westchester, introduced today a minimum wage bill which includes men as well as women and minors under its provisions.

Jacob Goldstein, 52 years old, of 940 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, former president of the Burnwell Coal Company, Inc., who was convicted last Friday of concealing assets in a bankruptcy proceeding, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Marcus B. Campbell, in the Federal court, Brooklyn, to serve eighteen months in a Federal penitentiary.

The first quarter of the twentieth century was "the bloodiest period in all history," according to a study of the social and cultural movements of the last 2,500 years, just completed at Harvard University.

The grand national team-of-four contract bridge championships opened yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Montclair for the prize of a free trip to Europe to represent the United States in the International Bridge League championships, Budapest, starting June 12.

In my budget message of Jan. 5, 1937, I said that I would transmit at a later date an estimate of the appropriation for work relief for the fiscal year 1938. In connection with this estimate it is desirable to review our present fiscal situation.

President Roosevelt today expressed complete ignorance of any plan to limit the importation of gold either by a quota system or by placing a tax on such imports. Reports that the government was planning a move in this direction were said to be reaching Wall Street.

The table that follows shows the amounts of individual income tax payable on typical all-earned incomes under the new tax schedules announced today. In each case personal and married allowances, children's allowances and earned income allowances have been deducted.

A new figure entered the Gedeon murder mystery yesterday when Thomas Sweeney, 28 years old, an elevator operator of 232 East Eighty-seventh Street, was questioned for more than two hours by Miles M. O'Brien, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the Homicide Bureau.

ADICKES--On Monday, April 19, 1937, Mathilda E. Adickes, beloved sister of Frederick J. Adickes and Emma Rleper. Funeral service will be held at her late residence 213 West 16th St., Wednesday, at 8 P. M.
Continued improvement in the steel industry is reflected in earnings of the following companies which announced yesterday results for the first quarter of this year.
Cy Blanton's sinker-ball limited the Cubs to five hits today and the Pirates scored a 5-to-0 triumph in the National League opener before 18,940 chilled fans.

Walter N. Rothschild, general manager of Abraham Straus, Inc., which operates a department store in Brooklyn, was elected yesterday president of the corporation by the directors. He has been a vice president in addition to general manager for ten years. He succeeded Edward C. Blum, who will continue as chairman of the board.

Edwin Markham, famous for his "The Man With the Hoe" and other poems, was honored with the rank of Rotary Fellow of the World, messages from Rotary clubs throughout the United States and greetings from foreign diplomats yesterday afternoon at a dinner to him given by the Staten Island Rotary Club.

W. Forbes Morgan of New York, president of the Distilled Spirits Institute, Inc., and former treasurer of the Democratic National Campaign Committee, died here tonight in a committee hearing room of the State Capitol. His age was 57.

Siam, the stocky chestnut colt the Bomar Stable hopes will race to victory in the Chesapeake, Kentucky Derby and Preakness, scored his first triumph of the year in the Greenwich Purse, the outstanding event of today's program.

Tito Guizar, young Mexican tenor, gave a recital at Carnegie Hall last night that emphasized the sentimental mood. He sang arias and the ballads that dealt with the "sweet mystery of life," "furtive tears," dreams and other tender matters.
The Rev. H. Fairfield Butt 3d, pastor of Christ Church at Kensington, Md., was appointed chaplain today of the Military Academy by Secretary Woodring.

Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Howard of Farmington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Howard, to H. Parker Jones of Beaufort, S. C., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Dudley Jones of Clinton, S. C.

Only policy holders will benefit from the sale of securities of the New Jersey Fidelity and Plate Glass Insurance Company of Newark, which was taken over by the State Department of Banking and Insurance in 1932, under an opinion handed down today by Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan.

James Norris Gillet, former Governor of California and outstanding legal figure for many years, died today at his home in Berkeley. He was born in Viroqua, Wis. At the age of 18 he took up the study of law and was admitted to the Wisconsin bar in 1881.
Ludwig Lewisohn, the author, in what he said was his first interview in ten years, declared yesterday at the Hotel Tudor that the Semitic issue was a disease of the Gentile world.
Ben Johnson, Columbia's Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. indoor sprint champion, and Temple's Eulace Peacock will be seeded in the 100yard dash at the Penn relays, to be held Friday and Saturday.

The thirty-fifth anniversary of the United German Societies of New York was celebrated last night at the Hippodrome with speeches and pageants depicting the part played by German-Americans in the United States of the past and present.

The Title Guaranty and Trust Company of New York is entitled to share pro rata in the distribution of interest money with other holders of mortgage certificates, the Court of Appeals ruled today in reversing a decision of the Appellate Division, First Department, which had ruled in favor of the State Mortgage Commission.
The Boston Bees defeated Holy Cross, 6 to 5, in an exhibition game today. Vie Frasier held the Crusaders to six hits and fanned eleven.

The Court of Appeals today admitted its unfamiliarity with the language used by motion-picture people and reserved judgment on findings by the Appellate Division, First Department, in favor of Jack W. Springer and Sam D. Cocalis.

Making capital of its rival's errors, the Samuel J. Tilden High nine crushed Thomas Jefferson, 14--4, in a Section A contest of the Brooklyn P. S. A. L. baseball championship at Boys High field yesterday. Tilden, runner-up for the city crown last year, made only five hits, to register its second triumph in as many starts in the circuit.

Emma Redell, dramatic soprano, will sing tonight in Mecca Temple at a memorial meeting for German sufferers under the Third Reich. Rudolf Jankel will discuss Beethoven's First and Ninth symphonies tonight at the Downtown Peoples Centre.

Picking their way through what seems to be hundreds of sailing dinghies which dot the Charles River basin now that this sport has been added to college events here, the crews of Massachusetts Institute of Technology work twice a day in preparation for the opening of their season on Saturday against Princeton and Harvard on the flat, waters of Carnegie Lake.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Sutphin of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Una Sutphin, to Gilbert Martin Krinic, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Krinic of Dunellen.

Among the thousands of presents that poured in from every part of Germany for Hitler today the most remarkable was a pair of giraffes sent by National Socialist admirers in Africa. The animals-consigned to the Reich Chancellery in Wilhelmstrasse-were sent to the zoo.

Neville Chamberlain. Chancellor of the Exchequer, found a formula as new and unexpected as the United States tax on undistributed corporate ?? Then he notified unsuspecting industry today that the government hereafter would exact a "national defense contribution," which in effect is a supertax piled on the corporate income taxes, which carry the same basic rate as personal taxes.
John Steinbeck, author of "Tortilla Flat" and 'Of Mice and Men," arrived here yesterday from California by freighter accompanied by his wife, Carol. The journey had taken nearly a month.
Before 45,850 persons, including Mayor La Guardia, at the Stadium, the world champion Yankees lost to the Senators 3-2, yesterday in the opening of the major league baseball season in New York.
J. P. Morgan, who has been living at his country home here, will sail tomorrow on the Queen Mary to attend the coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth in London, it became known today.
Nathan Mann of New Haven and Maurice Strickland, New Zealand, heavyweights, will be the principals in the ten-round feature bout at the New York Hippodrome tonight.

Georgianna McGlynn Gleason and John McGlynn and his wife gave a mortgage to James J. Fitzgerald for $9,500, due in 3 years at 5 per cent, or 497 9th Ave. A mortgage for $33,000 on 38 W 73d St was assigned by Eda K. Loeb to John F. Kuhn.

Andrew Mellick Fine, vice president of the Hudson Coal Company, died here today after an illness of several months, in his sixty-second year. He was one of the most prominent mining men in the anthracite region.

American Steel Foundries rights have been admitted to dealings on the New York Stock Exchange and "when issued" rights have been suspended. United Electric Coal Companies rights have been admitted to dealings and "when issued" rights have been suspended.

After a brief ownership Etta Cherkos and Abraham Weinstein, through their Abetta Realty Corporation, sold the five-story apartment building at 2,103 Vyse Avenue, corner of 180th Street, in the Bronx, to an investing client of Albert Midonick.

A demand for a compromise in the fight over President Roosevelt's court reorganization proposal, "to avoid a head-on collision of powerful groups of our party," was made in the House today by Representative McCormack, Democrat, of Massachusetts, a fairly consistent supporter of the administration.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today granted permission to the trustees of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad to issue $2,175,000 in equipment trust certificates.
Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Eddy of 420 West End Avenue gave a dinner last night in the Jansen Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of their marriage.

The University of Miami tennis team swept six singles matches and took two out of three doubles matches today on the Church courts to trounce Princeton, 8-1, for its fourth consecutive triumph of the Spring.

Business failures in the retail division in the week ended April 15 were only slightly under those of the previous week, but they were ahead of the total in the same period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Red Baiting" is rather naive, to say the least. May I remind you that "the constitutional guarantees of freedom of speech" do not apply under the Federal law to two or more persons who, working together, advocate publicly the destruction of our government through- violence?
George H. Pabst Jr. was elected yesterday a director of the Fire Association of Philadelphia and the Reliance Insurance Company. He is treasurer of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

Irrational acts of Salvatore Ossido, 26-year-old barber, accused of criminally assaulting and murdering 9-year-old Einer Sporrer in the back room of his barber shop on March 19, were cited by defense witnesses yesterday in an effort to substantiate the defendant's plea of insanity.
The Spanish Government intends to be represented at the coronation naval review at Portsmouth on May 20 by the destroyer flotilla leader Ciscar.

There are passages in President ROOSEVELT'S budget message which recall in striking fashion his own early warning that liberal governments have often been wrecked on the rocks of a loose fiscal policy.

The Shady Side News, published by the students of Shady Side Academy in Pittsburgh, won first prize in the seventh annual scholastic newspaper contest conducted by The Daily Princetonian, Princeton University campus newspaper, it was announced here today by Frederick L. Redpath, '39, manager of the contest.

Frequent exchanges between opposing counsel enlivened today's proceedings in trial of the suit of five railroad companies in the Federal District Court here for a permanent injunction restraining the State of New Jersey from enforcing payment of allegedly exorbitant taxes for the years 1934, 1935 and 1936.
The Senate resolution condemning sitdown strikers and employers who fail to observe fair labor practices was favorably reported today by the House Labor Committee.

Dean Emery, a New York attorney and former president of the New York Lawyers' Club, was killed this afternoon when struck by an automobile as he was walking along Valley Road. He lived at Short Hills, N. J.

A coming event cast the long shadow of dissension over the Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution here today, preliminary to introduction of a resolution favoring a popular referendum on the Roosevelt plan for reorganization of the Supreme Court.
Clark Gable categorically denied paternity of 13-year-old Gwendoline Norton today in a court room besieged by hundreds of women.

United States ASSOCIATE PHYSICIST (ELECTROENCEPHALOGRAPHY), $3,200 a year. U. S. Public Health Service, Treasury Department. Applications must be on file not later than May 17, if received from States other than those named below. May 20, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana. Nevada, New Mexico.
A luncheon, fashion show and card party took place yesterday at the Carlyle for the benefit of the Cape Cod Institute of Music.
The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce approved and reported today to the Senate three bills of major importance to railway and water common carriers.

The May deliveries of grain developed independent strength today on the Board of Trade here while the deferred futures were inclined to lag. Most of the trading represented spreading operations with some buying of the May against sales of the July attributed to changing over hedges by cash interests.
Steel ingot production was unchanged last week in face of a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index receded to 121.6 from 124.1. It was 93.6 for the week ended April 18, 1936.

Samuel B. Howard, William M. Stevens and Samuel C. Wood of the Corporation Trust Company of New Jersey were elected directors of the United States Rubber Company at the annual meeting held in Jersey City yesterday, increasing the number of directors from twelve to fifteen.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area for the first half of April, covering thirteen shopping days, decreased 1.7 per cent from the same period a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Mischa Ross, unshaven and tieless, went through the terse routine of a man charged with homicide yesterday while District Attorney William C. Dodge began presentation before the grand jury of testimony he expects will result in the musician's indictment for firstdegree murder in the slaying of Julia Nussenbaum.
Bids for 1,016 tons of paper for printing currency and for an unestimated amount of paper for public debt securities will be received at the Treasury Department May 6.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 19: BRIGADIER GENERAL Merrill, D. T., relieved from assignment and duty at Ft. Sheridan, Ill's., on or about June 1; previous orders amended.

THE FRONTS--Rebels renewed their campaign for the capture of Bilbao and made gains. A British food ship ran the blockade and arrived at that port. In East Central Spain the government reported the capture of the key town of Celadas, in the Teruel salient.

Small demonstrations by Austrian Nazis in Vienna and the provinces marked Hitler's birthday anniversary today. At night thousands of paper swastikas and leaflets were scattered over Vienna streets, swastika flags were hoisted secretly on some buildings and wooden swastikas were fired outside two police stations.

Hearings on the financial condition of the Warner-Quinlan Company, which is in reorganization proceedings, were started yesterday before Federal Judge Murray Hulbert with a view to obtaining approval for the debtor's plan for rehabilitation.
A division in the ranks of the 3,700 strikers at the Oshawa plant of General Motors of Canada, Ltd., was indicated today and pointed to a possible break in the strike.

Columbia University's baseball team did an about-face on University Field today and came from behind to beat a highly favored Princeton nine, 8-7, for its first Eastern Intercollegiate League victory in three starts.
The United States policy of accumulating great quantities of gold was defended here today before the Rotary Club by Sir Charles MorganWebb, authority on Britain's managed currency.

The annual Spring card party for the benefit of the charitable work of the Ladies Aid Society of the Lenox Hill Hospital took place yesterday afternoon in the. Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Carl Eggers is president of the society and Mrs. Jacob Doll headed the benefit committee.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora denounced yesterday a contention advanced on behalf of three indicted union officials that they could not properly be charged with the larceny of the union's funds because they had title to them jointly with other members of the local.

A second accounting of the estate of Thomas A. Edison showed today it war worth $1,500,432 and the income was $170,161. The report was filed in Orphans Court by counsel for the late inventor's son, Assistant Secretary of the Navy Edison.

Of course, if their allegations are correct, the family which is suing the New York Zoological Park because they were thrown out of the Monkey House by a couple of apes have the law on their side. Undoubtedly they were innocent bystanders at a psychological crisis.

With the increase of golfers in America has come a corresponding growth in the number of officials necessary to run the game. This is evidenced more thin ever before by the list of subcommittees appointed by John G. Jackson,

three-year hosiery quota agreement has just been arranged between the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, acting for the entire hosiery industry in the United States, and the Japan Knitted Goods Exporters Association, it was announced tonight by Earl Constantine, managing director of the-national association.
King George spent half an hour tonight at Garrard Co., goldsmiths to the Crown, on Albemarle Street, trying on the Imperial State Crown, which has been remodeled for him.

Mapes Ave (18-5385), w s, 50 ft n Zulette Ave, 50x100; Emma Wagner to Carrie Sommerer, 1,557 Mayflower Ave. Melrose Ave (9-2408), s w cor 162d St, 96x50; Snerha Corp to Bunbuck Realty Corp, 25 Broad St.

Joseph M. Goldsmith, through Marcus Brown Sons, in 1,120 Park Av.; M. Morgenthau-Seixas Co., Inc., broker. Mrs. Edmund Breese, Mrs. H. K. Furman, Harold Schwartz and Herbert Schmidt, in the Beverly, 125 E. 50th St.

A record attendance at the thirtythird annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America to be held here June 20 to 23 was predicted yesterday by Sam K. Smith, president of the Advertising Club of Pittsburgh and chairman of the national attendance group. Plans for the various group sessions were also revealed.

Disorders marked a mass demonstration outside the Artcraft Silk Hosiery Mill here today as negotiations in Mayor Wilson's office between the management and the American Federation of Hosiery Workers reached a deadlock.

N. Baxter Jackson, vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, was elected a director of the Pennsylvania-Dixie Cement Corporation at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday, succeeding Percy Johnston.

A total of 269 Negroes was accepted yesterday at 39 Whitehall Street for enrolment in the two Negro Civilian Conservation Corps companies established by the War Department at the instance of Governor Lehman.

President Roosevelt disclaimed today any intention of calling at this time a world conference to discuss questions of disarmament and trade, as suggested by George Lansbury, the British Labor party leader, after a conference with Adolf Hitler.

A dog which caught a burglar was led triumphantly into General Sessions yesterday by its owner after the burglar, seeing the evidence going against him in this two-day trial before Judge Owen W. Bohan and a jury, suddenly entered a guilty plea to unlawful entry.

Mike Belloise of the Bronx, recognized in New York State as world featherweight titleholder, outpointed Maxie Fisher of Newark in ten rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. Belloise weighed 1301/2, four pounds less than his rival.
The Howard bill to place all fee-charging private employment agencies under State regulation was the subject of sharp dispute today at a public hearing before the Senate Finance Committee.

The first reaction at the Capitol to President Roosevelt's revised budget estimates and accompanying demands for governmental economy was the starting of a drive, led by some who are ordinarily warm administration supporters, to cut the proposed relief appropriation far below the $1,500,000,000 which the President suggested.

Federal relief officials in this city are seeking to set aside a ruling by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration that the earnings of young men and women employed as part-time workers on National Youth Administration projects must be deducted from family home relief budgets, after "reasonable" allowance has been made for the young persons' actual working expenses.

Lehman Brothers and Wertheim Co. will offer today 125,000 common shares of Bond Stores, Inc., at $25.25 a share. Bond Stores, Inc., was organized on March 19 through the consolidation of the Bond Clothing Company and its subsidiary, Bond Stores, Inc., the latter of Maryland.

The first public offering of securities of the Triborough Bridge Authority will take place today. A group headed by Dillon, Read Co. and including the First Boston Corporation, Blyth Co., Inc.; Lazard Freres Co., Inc.; the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation, White, Weld Co.;

Stores here were notified yesterday that Corday Parfums, Inc., had priced forty of its toilet goods items under the Feld-Crawford law. No announcement was made regarding the meeting of the committee of book publishers that is working on a standard resale price contract.

Fire about midnight completely destroyed the government fisheries biological station at Bay of Bulls, ten miles away, and also the plants of two fishing concerns, Williams Co. and Torscove Trading Company. There is no fire-fighting apparatus there and a heavy snowfall impeded St. John's fire engines. The loss is said to be at least $200,000.

IT is hard to see why Andre Gide's "Return From the U.S.S.R." (Knopf, $1) should have set France by the ears and sold 100,000 copies within a few weeks of its publication there. M. Gide says very little that hasn't been already stated in more compelling fashion.

Herbert Brazer of Brookline, senior partner of J. R. Worcester Co. of Boston, consulting engineers, died today at the Corey Hill Hospital, Brookline, at the age of 64. He was born in Roxbury and had been connected with his firm for nearly forty years.

Sixteen former employes of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and the president of their local union, all accused of participating in the eight-hour sit-down strike at the hospital on March 15, were found guilty yesterday on four counts of endangering property and the lives of patients in a conspiracy to prevent internes and nurses from working.
The Board of Tax Appeals entered judgment for the General Motors Corporation today in proceedings brought by the company to contest a $15.432.369 deficiency assessment on its 1926 income taxes.

At a hearing before the Military Affairs Committee of the House on the bill sponsored by Representative Lister Hill of Alabama, providing for the production of helium at cost in government plants, a witness today revealed plans for the creation of an American airship service for the North Atlantic.

Latin-American markets showed continued gains in exchange, credit and collection conditions in the first quarter of this year, according to information sent American exporters yesterday by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men.
Stockholders of the National Supply Company will vote on May 21 on a proposal to reduce the par value of common stock to $10 a share from $25.

Of the $16,255,040 principal in personal property received by the executors of the estate of Colonel Henry H. Rogers of Manhattan and Southampton between Oct. 25, 1935, and Jan. 31, 1937, a balance of $3,589,392 remains, most of the difference having gone for Federal and New York State inheritance taxes.

President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University announced yesterday the award of 164 fellowships and scholarships for 1937-38. The value of the awards was said to be more than $150,000. Of the total number 113 are men and fifty-one women.

As the General Motors strike at Oshawa closed its second full week, Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario obtained a preliminary agreement from company and union officials tonight calling for peace conferences in his office tomorrow afternoon on wages, hours and conditions, but with no recognition for the Committee on Industrial Organization.

The Crucible Steel Company of America is running virtually at full capacity and is booking orders at a rate insuring such operations for some time, F. B. Hufnagel, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday.

The city of Boston, Mass., awarded yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of short-term notes to a banking group headed by Edward B. Smith Co., on a 1.22 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $133. Other members of the group were Lazard Freres Co., Inc.;

A study of President Roosevelt's budget message sent to the Congress on Tuesday has convinced many persons in the financial community that considerably higher taxes must be levied by the next Congress in order to bring Treasury receipts for the next fiscal year up to the President's estimate of $6,906,000,000.
The annual business meeting of the Textile Color Card Association will be held this morning at the offices of the organization, 200 Madison Avenue.
Xavier J. Barile has moved to a new studio at 213 West Fourteenth Street, where a small life class will be in session on Sunday mornings and Monday evenings during the Spring and Summer.
The Army tennis team defeated Lafayette by 9-0 today. Because of rain the match was played on the concrete courts of the hockey rink.

The New York Curb Exchange committee on securities has ruled that transactions after May 3 in Niagara Hudson Power Corporation second preferred stock, Series A and B, shall be designated as in the second preferred 5 per cent series and either A or B shares of that series shall be good for delivery.

Giving a superb performance from the ten-foot board, the 19year-old Women's Swimming Association star, Miss Janice Lifson, captured the women's metropolitan senior high board diving championship for the seventh successive year last night in the A. A. U. meet held at the Downtown Athletic Club.
Mrs. Charlotte M. Deyo of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Madeline B. Patterson, to Frederick R. Avis, son of Mr. and- Mrs. Samuel W. Avis of Providence, R. I.
James A. Beha will announce today his return to the practice of law. He will open offices at 70 Pine Street, about May 1.

Stockholders of the Skenandoa Rayon Corporation will consider at their annual meeting on May 26 a plan of recapitalization providing for the exchange of 1.4 shares of new 5 per cent convertible prior preferred stock, plus $5.50 in cash, for each share of present $7 convertible preferred stock, on which arrears on July 1 will total $45.50 a share.

Grand Concourse, 1,183-1,185 (9-2463); Arvo, Inc., to Stanley Properties, Inc., 551 5th Ave, mtge. $205,800. Bracken Ave (17-4981), e s, 100 ft. n of Randall Ave, 50x100; Rose Fried to Esther Kinberg, 2,139 Daly Ave. 151 St, 417 E (9-2374); Elsie Chattin, executrix, to Adolph Pfeiffenschneider, 2,455 Amsterdam Ave.

Fitzgerald Hall, president of the Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railroad, had his salary increased from $22,500 to $25,000 in 1936, the report of the company to the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday. Charles Barham, vice president and traffic manager;

The four-story apartment house at 1,702 West First Street, on the corner of Quentin Road, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Hambro Realty Corporation from Land Estates, Inc. The building is on a plot 100 by 100 feet and is said to have an annual rent roll of $18,750. It was sold for cash above a first mortgage of $105,000. J. Tobias Goldberg was attorney for the buyer and David Bronstein was the broker.

Gunter Ulack, 27, of Roslyn, L. I., was killed when he fell or leaped from the thirteenth floor of a Baltimore hotel early today, his unclad body striking the automobile of J. Goldenberg of Philadelphia.
A number of units of space in Madison Avenue and Fifth Avenue were involved in the commercial leases reported yesterday by brokers.

Dr. Julius Rappaport, rabbi of Beth-El Temple in Chicago from 1886 to 1921 and rabbi of Beth Hillel Temple in Kenosha since 1925, died today of a heart attack at Miami, Fla., where he had gone two weeks ago for his health. He was 74 years old.
Earl Beatty, eldest son of the British naval hero, and Mrs. Dorothy Power Sands, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. F. Power of Virginia, were married today at the London Register Office.

The Wharton Institute, sponsored by the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania, will hold a two-day session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, beginning Friday, April 30, it was announced yesterday.

Movements Of likestock on the Chicago markets today, ?? reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS RECEIPTS-13,000, including 5,000 direct. Market fully 10 higher than Tuesday's average: spots up 15 on weights averaging 210 pounds down: packing sows 10 higher; bulk good and choice 200-320-pound,

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for April 15 shows an increase in the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation from 132.75 per cent on March 31 to 135.27 per cent on April 15. The ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities increased from 91.71 per cent on March 31 to 92.27 on April 15.
College students in the city were busy yesterday with final details of their plans for the annual anti-war "strike" scheduled for 11 o'clock this morning.

Mr. and Mrs. Gilliat de Ghequiere Schroeder Jr. of Devon, Pa., have joined Mr. Schroeder's parents at the Berkshire. Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien have returned to the Waldorf-Astoria after passing the season at their villa in Palm Beach. Mr. and Mrs. Faris R. Russell have left the Ambassador and are in Mill Neck, L. I.

Dr. Eugene S. Dalton, attending physician to the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, died Monday night at his home, 353 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 54. Since his graduation from the Medical School of Syracuse University, and his interne service in City Hospital, he had practiced in Brooklyn.
Acme Steel Company executives told stockholders at the annual meeting today that prospects indicated sales in 1937 would reach $20,000,000, the largest total in the company's history.
Steele Mitchell, president of the Adams Express Company, has been elected a director of the Otis Elevator Company to succeed the late Charles Hayden.
The Blackwell Cup regatta among Columbia, Yale and Pennsylvania on the Harlem River May 1 will start at,11:30 A. M., it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Reynolds Benson of Columbia.
Governor Carl E. Bailey tonight visited the executive council of the American Bankers Association to make Hot Springs its permanent meeting place.

Miss Florence Meachem Hyde, daughter of Mrs. Dana Cheney Hyde of 122 East Seventy-sixth Street and the late Mr. Hyde, has completed plans for her marriage to Henry John Wynkoop 3d, which will take place on the afternoon of May 15 in Christ Church, Greenwich, Conn.
As if regretting the bright and merry mood that made Greater New York's two major league baseball openings the best in years, the weather yesterday turned to prodigious frowning and weeping.
Embattled portrait painters and illustrators will try to convince Deputy Controller Milton Solomon this afternoon that the city should not levy a 2 per cent sales tax on their work.

There is no longer an International Brigade, strictly speaking, on the Spanish Government fronts. Foreign volunteers have been incorporated in mixed brigades, in which the proportion of Spaniards ranges from 75 to 90 per cent.

Insurgent shells, pounding mercilessly for hours today, caused havoc such as the world's capitals dread in modern war. The heart of this metropolis of 1,000,000 inhabitants, it seemed at times, was being leveled by the rain of explosives. The bombardment lasted throughout the daylight hours. Fully 250 shells found targets.

There is one "chain" service about whose value to communities and to the nation at large there can be no question. It is that of the Travelers Aid Societies. Beginning today, representatives of the National Association, now twenty years old, are assembling here in New York to consider how to maintain and strengthen the cooperative

Colonel E. R. Bradley's hopes for a fifth Kentucky Derby victory were dealt a crushing blow today as Billionaire and Brooklyn suffered a decisive defeat at the hands of the lightly regarded Grey Gold, also a Derby eligible, from the E. W. Duffy stable.

An eclipse seven quadrillion miles distant, seventy-five million times as far away as the sun, was studied today by astronomers who hoped to gain secrets of the structure of the gaseous atmospheres of the stars.

Miss Elizabeth Ray Goodrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Goodrich of 170 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, and Monmouth Hills, N. J., was married here last night to John Hardie Karrh Jr. of this city, formerly of Carbon Hill, Ala., in St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan.

Welbourne Jake, bay gelding who has won at the Middleburg and Deep Run hunts meetings this year, was one of six entries named today to start the four-mile Virginia Gold Cup Steeplechase on the Broadview course Saturday, May 1.
Maurice Strickland, clever heavyweight boxer from New Zealand, and Nathan Mann of New Haven fought to a draw in the main bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome last night.

The new technique of State resale price laws and the passage of Federal enabling acts designed to maintain those laws is a "dangerous" procedure, Irving C. Fox, counsel for the National Retail Dry Goods Association, told members of the Metropolitan Controllers Association last night.

Eleven former Brooklyn College captains are to see action in the varsity-alumni baseball, handball and tennis encounters which are on the Homecoming Day program to be held at Manhattan Beach on Saturday.

Clark Gable appeared briefly on the stand today to close the government's mail fraud case against Mrs. Violet Norton, who asserts that he is the father of her illegitimate child. The actor was recalled only to identify checks paid him in Oregon in 1923. It was in that year Mrs. Norton said she had known him in England as "Frank Billings."
Sunday bowling before paying spectators will become legal in New York State unless Governor Lehman wields a veto pen.

A first mortgage loan of $213,500 for ten years at 41/3 per cent interest on the six-story store and office building at 767769 Lexington Ave, which houses Lambert Bros., jewelers, has been arranged by Samuel Kronsky, Inc., for the Deane estate.

The resignation of Miss Genevieve H. Cheney of Mount Vernon as president of the Westchester County Drama Association was announced today. The association adopted a resolution expressing gratitude for her leadership during the last eight years.

Assailed by foes as one of the chief "ripper" bills of this session, the Feld bill to "reorganize" the New York City Board of Education was passed in the Senate today by a party vote of 29 to 19. Denunciation of Mayor La Guardia by Democrats was a feature of the debate which preceded the passage.

Members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in convention at the Waldorf-Astoria were urged by their paper committee, in a report made public yesterday, to use caution in making contracts for newsprint.

Governor Lehman spent a busy day considering legislative bills. The Senate passed by a party vote a bill to oust the Fusion Board of Education in New York City and substitute a board composed of fifteen members, with the Mayor appointing only five, the others to be appointed by the borough presidents.
Reports that Soviet Russia's crack fliers plan to fly to the North Pole and make an air base there were bolstered today by Valery Chekaloff, long-distance aviator.

The men's club of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, 2 West Seventieth Street, celebrated last night the 500th anniversary of the birth of Don Isaac Abravanel, a Spanish Jew who was a statesman and the confidant of four kings.
Motorists using the upper roadway of the Manhattan Bridge will be more adequately protected against accident by a new high steel curbing put into service yesterday at a cost of $28,187.

The heads of the National Youth Administration in Washington backed regional NYA officials yesterday in their dispute with the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration over the extent to which the earnings of part-time NYA workers should be deducted from family home-relief budgets.

The Treasury is continuing its study of the problem of stopping the heavy flow of gold to this country, but without giving any information whether it is close to a decision as to the most feasible problem for meeting the situation.
The Majestic Radio and Television Corporation, Chicago, has appointed Morris Davidson, Inc., Chicago advertising agency.

President Roosevelt conferred with Senator Barkley on flood control and with members of the Civil Service Commission on improvement of the merit system for government employes. He announced that he would leave April 28 for a fishing cruise off the Texas coast, during which he will visit New Orleans, Biloxi, Galveston and Fort Worth.

Rush V. Greenslade of Tulsa, Okla., tumbler, has been elected captain of the Princeton University gymnastic team for next season, it was announced tonight by Coach Richard Swinnerton after the team's annual dinner

Robert McBride, member of the music faculty of Bennington College, recipient of the 1937 Guggenheim Award, was the composer whose music was exposed to examination in last night's session of the Composers Forum-Laboratory at the WPA Theatre of Music. A large and attentive audience was present.

Commercial air service to China began today with the departure of the China Clipper on a regular transpacific flight. She carried three passengers, a large consignment of first flight covers for stamp collectors and light merchandise.

Vincent Astor's Nourmahal arrived at St. George's Harbor this afternoon, having sailed from Cape Haiti in 2 days and 21 hours. On the yacht were more than 300 Galapagos fish of thirty-five species, two spider monkeys of Central America and the largest Panama rodent, capybara, which will go to the Staten Island Zoo.

The International Boxing Union today suspended Lou Brouillard, New England middleweight, for one year and disqualified his manager, Johnny Buckley, for life, for fouling Marcel Thil, French claimant to the 160-pound title, in their championship bout, Feb. 15.

Instructions in the operation of Mack Pumping engines will be given from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M. daily, except Sunday, from Thursday, April 22, to Thursday, April 29. inclusive, at 41st Ave. and East River, Queens.
