Two young men held up the manager and a cashier in the basement office of the Childs Restaurant at 530 Fulton Street, near Flatbush Avenue, in the Brooklyn shopping district, yesterday at 11 A. M., while fifty persons were eating on the floor above. The bandits took $300, all that remained of a $1,500 payroll, and escaped in the crowd outside.

A team of five men from Occidental College, Los Angeles, the Far West's representatives in the Penn relays Friday and Saturday, arrived today and worked under the stands at Franklin Field. Rain prevented practice on the regular track. The five, Captain Jerry Isett, Claude Kilday, Stan Langsdorf, Walter Middleton and Paul Sampsell, drilled under the eyes of Coach Joe Pipal.

Mr. GEORGE LANSBURY, indomitable pacifist that he is, declared on leaving Berlin after his interview with HITLER: "A world conference is possible if statesmen mean what they say." Even as he spoke, German Government officials were qualifying and toning down his version of his conversation with
Confronted with President Roosevelt's demand for strict adherence by Federal departments to revised budget estimates, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration has
Following is the text of the address of Senator Bennett Champ Clark of Missouri yesterday before the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the WaldorfAstoria:

Charles (Red) Ruffing, the big right-hander who won twenty games for the Yankees last season, said tonight he was ready to call off his holdout campaign if Owner Jacob Ruppert would give him $15,500 for 1937. Most persistent of the important holdouts, Ruffing had insisted on $16,000.

Thomas R. Dester, general traffic manager in the United States for the Associated British and Irish Railways, representing all the railroads in the British Isles, was found dead of a heart attack yesterday morning in a Pullman berth in the Pennsylvania Station. The train had arrived from Chicago shortly before.

Stockholders of the Phoenix Securities Corporation yesterday elected John A. Stevenson, secretary, a director of the company, and approved management contracts with Wallace Groves, chairman, and Walter S. Mack Jr., president,

Leaders of the United Radio and Electrical Workers of America proposed to their membership today a possible sit-down strike to "convince" the General Electric Company that its workers "desire higher pay." Leo Jandreau, business agent, and William Turnbull, national vice president of the union, an affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization,

Senator Felipe Buencamino of the Philippines returned last night on the French liner Ile de France after attending the International Sugar Conference in London as a fellowdelegate with Norman H. Davis, representative of the United States.

Proponents of slum clearance have turned in recent years from the emotional appeal in furtherance of their cause to an emphasis upon the economic loss represented by the blighted areas, Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, said yesterday at the inaugural meeting of a housing seminar under the auspices of the women's committee of the

Jerry McCarthy denied before the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he told Mrs. Katherine Smith of Detroit that Atlas Tack stock "will go to 50 or you can kick my head around for a football."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said over the radio tonight that if she remained in the White House all the time she would "lose touch with the rest of the world." The First Lady, whose varied activities have attracted so much attention, added:

Under a heavy downpour, Venice is preparing for the meeting between Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria tomorrow, at which questions of the greatest interest for Austria and the whole of Central Europe will be discussed.

The State Board of Review rescinded today its order of last week deleting from the news film March of Time remarks of Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Montana Democrat, in a dialogue concerning President Roosevelt's Supreme Court reorganization plan.

Six months ago, according to members of his family, Giusseppe Fiore, 56-year-old gardener of 630 West Christopher Street, had a portentous dream and the next day he predicted that he would die on April 17.

Preparing for the regatta with Rutgers on the Raritan River at New Brunswick, N. J., Saturday, Manhattan's crews were boated with several changes by Coach Allen Walz yesterday. The three Jasper eights, which will race against the Scarlet-varsity, 150pound and freshman--were put through a stiff two-mile trial on the Harlem River.

Strength in the pound sterling and weakness in the French franc characterized the foreign exchange market yesterday. The pound rose to $4.93??, which was the highest price since Oct. 5 last, and closed at $4.93 1/2, up 1 1/4 cents on the day.
Clifton Ave, n e c of 181st St, 6-story brick tenement, 150x92; Ters Construction Corp,. Jacob Wacht, treasurer, 550 7th Ave, owner; Samson V. Becker, architect; cost, $225,000.

ADERER--Eugenie, at Mount Vernon, N. Y., on. April 21, 1937. ADICKES-On Monday, April 19, 1937, Mathilda E. Adickes, beloved sister of Frederick J. Adickes and Emma Rieper. Funeral service will be held at her late residence. 213 West 16th St., Wednesday, at 8 P. M.
The annual Spring meeting of the archdeacons of the Episcopal Church of Queens and Nassau Counties, including the women's branch, was held at Trinity Church today with more than 300 attending.

Eighth Eastern States Regional Conference of the Civil Service Assembly of the United States and Canada begins at the Hotel Commodore today at 9 A. M. and continues Friday and Saturday. Speakers, opening session, Mayor F. H. La Guardian and James E. Finegan.

The Assembly passed four labor bills today,including the Fischel measure for minimum wages to women and children. The others were the Dunnigan bill providing for a sixday, forty-eight-hour week for males between 16 and 18 and women in hotels and restaurants;
GEORGE LANSBURY'S visit to HITLER has a picturesque interest, quite apart from its practical significance, if any.

A committee of directors of the Distilled Spirits Institute, Inc., will conduct affairs of that organization until a successor to the late W. Forbes Morgan, who headed the institute, is selected, it was made known here yesterday.

Peoria Eastern The Peoria Eastern Railway reported yesterday a net income of $182,588 for 1936, in contrast with a net loss of $37,553 in 1935. New York, Chicago St. Louis The New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad reported as follows for March and the first three months of the year:

Another list of companies which have accepted the edict of the Securities and Exchange Commission denying confidential treatment of certain data, in most instances concerning sales and cost of sales and salaries of executives, was made public today by the commission. The information is required from the companies as a condition of registration of their securities on national securities Exchanges.

The 145 West Thirtieth Street Corporation yesterday sold the twelve-story store and loft building at that address to an investor. The property is 75 by 98 feet, 150 feet east of Seventh Avenue. It was sold through Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc., who will manage the building for the new owner.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area showed a rise of 24 per cent for the week ended April 17, in comparison with a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service.

The board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday that in its opinion the government "owes the same duty to workers who do not desire to join a union as to those who do."

Mr. Kawakami, who interviewed Premier Mussolini, spent more than thirty years in the United States as a correspondent for Japaonese newspapers and as a writer and lecturer on political science. He is the author of "AmericanJapanese Relations," "The Real Japanese Question" and other books.

The Rev. Dr. Geza Takaro, president of the East Hungarian Classis of the Reformed Church in the United States, voiced yesterday an objection to statements published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 18 that Robert Suhay, 23 years old,

Sir Fisher Dilke, well-known British yachtsman, has been selected by the Royal Yacht Squadron to be its representative on the cup defender of the New York Yacht Club in the America's Cup match off Newport at the end of July. He will occupy a like position on the American yacht that Van S. MerleSmith, representative of the New York Club, will on T. O. M. Sopwith's challenger, Endeavour II.

The Copperweld Steel Company, which has just applied for listing on the New York Curb Exchange, estimated net sales for 1937 at $5,200,000 against $4,864,095 in 1936 and $2,826,757 in 1935, according to the listing application.

The inauguration of a great number of public works throughout Italy today marked the celebration of the 2,699th birthday of Rome and Labor Day, which was advanced from May 1 to April 21 by the government.

Heavy shipments of finished steel are creating an easier situation for the steel user, causing a relaxing of some of the intense pressure on the mills for deliveries that was prevalent a month or so ago, The Iron Age says this week.

Extolling the value of a close relationship between bankers and industry as a prerequisite to investment bankers fulfilling their responsibilities to both borrower and investor, Edward B. Hall of Harris, Hall Co., Inc., of Chicago,

An action to recover an oil painting known as "Madonna and Child" ascribed to Del Sarto, sixteenth century Italian painter, was begun in Supreme Court yesterday by Mrs. Julia Muller of 3,100 Broadway, who says her family, who live in Chile, have owned it for generations. Tobias A. Keppler, an attorney, of 25 West Forty-third Street, is the defendant in the action.

Edith Mason Polacco, opera singer, received a divorce here today from Giorgio Polacco, opera conductor, whom the singer divorced once before. They were married the second time in May 15, 1931, at Zurich, Switzerland. In the interval between these marriages Miss Mason became the wife of Maurice A. Bernstein of Chicago and divorced him.

President Roosevelt's action in proposing provisionally to add to the number of Supreme Court justices at a time when the government is a litigant in many cases pending before that tribunal would be regarded as contempt of court in any commonlaw court or court of equity, Edward T. Lee, dean of the John Marshall Law School of Chicago, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today.

Charles Wilson Hawley, head of the Hawley Hardware Company and vice president of the Bridgeport Peoples Savings Bank, died at his home here today of heart disease after an illness of several weeks. His age was 80. His son, Edmund S. Hawley of New York, and his daughter, Mrs. Chauncey L. Fenton of West Point, N. Y., were with him. The funeral service will be held Friday afternoon.

The Borden Company's business in the first quarter of 1937 showed gratifying improvement over the same period of 1936 both as to volume of sales and net income, Arthur W. Milburn, president, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders in Jersey City.

Films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday unless otherwise specified have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Three homes, a country club and a creamery plant were bombed early this morning. A sixth bomb exploded tonight. The first two blasts were in North Shore suburbs, and the police suspected that labor troubles caused them.

The Class I railroads had 46,439 freight cars on order on April 1, including some under construction in their own shops, and this was the largest number for the same date since 1926, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday.
Fishermen are linked in a fraternity that girds the world. And so it is not unusual that the day's mail brings grist to the mill from opposite ends of the globe.
William A. Davidson, vice president of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company, died today. He was 66 years old.
Walter A. Graff, president of Baker, Fentress Co., bankers for the timber and lumber industry, died today in the Presbyterian Hospital. He was 62 years old.

Passengers arriving today from Mediterranean ports on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia will include Mr. and Mrs. Amos T. French, Major and Mrs. Hamilton Gibbs, Marchese A. Pallavicini, Baroness Renata Durini, Judge Robert Grand, Mr. and Mrs. Max Thornburg, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Curtis, the Marchese Giuseppe Cattaneo, and Mgr. Joseph Corrigan.
A pair of tennis racquets and a gold wrist-watch from her "Uncle David"--the Duke of Windsorwere among the presents received today by Princess Elizabeth on her eleventh birthday.

The problem of keeping solvent in the face of rising operating costs and the possibility of increasing the price of newspapers as well as advertising rates were among the subjects discussed by members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at a closed session yesterday afternoon at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Duane E. Minard, Special Assistant Attorney General for New Jersey, was sustained today by Federal Judge Philip Forman in objecting to some of the evidence offered by the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company in support of its suit for a

Sitdown strikes as practiced in the United States are labeled as "a sort of revolutionary exercise" that has been "brought into fashion by communism," in a pastoral letter sent today by Mgr. Georges Gauthier, Archbishop - Coadjutor of Montreal, to the Catholic clergy of the city.

The Harvard lacrosse team defeated Tufts by 14-4 today, the Crimson overpowering the Jumbos from the start. Harvard found three Tufts goalies easy, scoring during the first half of the game almost at will. Al Hunsaker, Harvard first attack, was high scorer with five goals.

Miss Hazel Mary Gadsby, 39 years old, of 60 Guyette Road, North Cambridge, Mass., applied at the Municipal Building yesterday for a license to marry Thomas J. McCarthy, 62 years old, convicted of forgery April 14 and now in the Tombs pending further proceedings to determine whether he is subject to life imprisonment. Subsequently,
Police Commissioner Valentine expressed resentment yesterday against "unfair" newspaper editorials which he said had incorrectly accused the Police Department of brutality.

BLACK, MARY M. (March 25). Estate, less than $10,000. To Jessie B. Black, sister, executrix, 2,816 Ellis Av., Chicago, Ill. BLACQUE, KATE READ (April 3). Estate, more than $10,000. To American Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity, Avenue George V, Paris, France, $13,000, as memorial to decedent's husband, Valentine Alexander Blacque; New York Public Library, collection of old prints: Metropolitan Museum of Art,
Personnel of Thornley Jones, Inc., the advertising agency which has just been organized by George H. Thornley and John Price Jones, was announced here yesterday.

Keglers competing yesterday failed to make a single change in the standing among the leaders in any group at the thirty-seventh American Bowling Congress tournament at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.
Yale's board of athletic control made basketball a major sport tonight. The decision followed a recommendation by the Undergraduate Athletic Association.

Troubles disturbed the peace of Father Divine's main and subsidiary "heavens" yesterday as the man whose followers call him God assumed his most invisible form. He who has been regarded by the Negro and white converts to his cult as "sample and example" of the doctrine, "Peace, it's wonderful," was being sought by police in connection with the almost fatal stabbing of a white man in the "kingdom" at 20 West 115th Street.

Mrs. John Brush Warren of this city and Philadelphia has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jane Louise Warren, to George Starr Scofield 4th, son of Mrs. George S. Scofield of Geneseo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Scofield of Staten Island.

Edward Endelman, attorney for a group of creditors of the Prudence Company, Inc., filed yesterday with the clerk of the Federal court in Brooklyn an answer to a motion of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, now pending,

The Senate went on strike today against the House. Irked because the Representatives had disregarded or killed some of their measures, the Senators blocked action on all House bills by sending them to the Executive Committee.

An apartment of fourteen rooms and four baths leased by Eugene B. Kline in 910 Park- Avenue featured the contracts for residential space reported yesterday. Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., negotiated the lease.

More than 1,400 members and guests of the Sunshine League for Orphan Children of New York City, Inc., were congratulated for their work in support of orphan asylums and nurseries by public officials and philanthropists at their annual Spring luncheon and card party yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

Crowding the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, more than 135 boys' clothing buyers, merchandise managers, buying representatives and store executives met yesterday afternoon to oppose the movement to fix maximum terms of 7 per cent, ten days,

Awards for distinguished accomplishment in architecture, painting and sculpture were made yesterday in connection with the fifty-first annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York, which will be opened to the public today at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street and continue through May 15. A private view was held last night.

There has always been a deepsea atmosphere about Columbia rowing in the years that have followed since the Glendons came there to take over the coaching about a decade ago. In part it may have been because of the fact that Old Dick Glendon learned his watermanship aboard a mackerel schooner out of New England ports.

Some slight a changes in the wording of the 4 Anglo-French declaration regarding Belgian neutrality having been suggested by the Belgian Cabinet and accepted by Paris and London, it is expected that the text will be published tomorrow.

The program of Spring steeplechase races was outlined at an informal dinner given by the Rockaway Steeplechase Association for turf writers at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. John G. Livingston, president of the association, and Fred Alexandre, secretary, presided.

An evening of well-bred amusement was furnished last night by opera students of the Juilliard School of Music who gave in the admirable theatre of the building on Claremont Avenue the American premiere of Vaughan Williams's "romantic extravaganza" in three acts, entitled, "The Poisoned Kiss."

Alleging that the opening of the Paris Exposition on May 17 will prevent the attendance of Socialist Ministers, the administrative committee of the Socialist party today adjourned the party congress from that date until July 10.

Dr. William Waldemar Share, since 1913 chairman of the board of the Meurer Steel Barrel Company of Newark, N. J., died Tuesday night at his home, 99 Macdonough Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 78. He was a bachelor and is survived by no members of his immediate family.

Making its deliberations public for the first time in its nineteen years of existence, the New York division of the Association Western Union Employes announced yesterday that it had voted to seek a 10 per cent wage increase, a five-day forty-hour week, minimum wage scale and closed shop.
Abandonment of the International Harvester Company's company union was announced today by Sydney G. McAllister, president of the company, in letters to 35,000 employes.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Eileen Halleran, daughter of Mrs. Thomas A. Halleran of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Halleran, to John E. B. Murphy, son of Mrs. J. Edward Murphy of this city and the late Mr. Murphy, which will take place on May 1 in St. Michael's Church, Flushing. The ceremony will be performed by Bishop James E. Kearney of Salt Lake City.

Edward J. Clarry, retired lumber dealer, pioneer real estate developer and long active in Catholic fraternal and welfare affairs in Queens, died early yesterday at his home, 92-12 Fifty-second Avenue, Elmhurst. He was born seventythree years ago in Brooklyn. His father was Hugh Clarry, who, for years, was prominent in the affairs of Brooklyn.

The Amherst baseball team bowed to Clark University, 5-3, in the first game of the season here today. Clark scored in the first, sixth and eighth frames to keep the lead all the way, while Granger went the route for the visitors, allowing only six hits.

The new films scheduled for today are: "A Star Is Born," first none-costume story to be filmed in technicolor and featuring Fredric March, Janet Gaynor and Adolphe Menjou, at the Radio City Music Hall; "Good Old Soak," from Don Marquis's "The Old Soak," with Wallace Beery, Una Merkel, Ted Healy and George Sidney, at the Capitol, and Edward G. Robinson's English-made "Thunder in the City," at the Criterion.
Without debate, the Assembly passed today the bill of Assemblyman Hall, Nassau Republican, to legalize dog racing and pave the way for open betting at dog tracks.

In preparation for the first national convention of the legitimate theatre, which will be held at the Hotel Astor from May 24 to 27 under the auspices of the new American Theatre Council, Paul N. Turner and Warren P. Munsell,
The annual luncheon of the New York Chapter of the Alumnae of St. Mary's Hall for Girls, Burlington, N. J., was held yesterday at the Carlyle.
The moderating elements in the Valencia government, pursuing a rigid campaign of suppression by force, are slowly getting the upper hand over troublemaking anarchists.

A jury in Federal court deliberated an hour and a half yesterday and then brought in a verdict in favor of J. D. Wooster Lambert, St. Louis manufacturer, in the suit brought against him by Dorothy Sabine, former chorus girl, for alleged breach of contract.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved yesterday, the list recovering $1 a bale in sympathy with outside markets and closing with net gains of 9 to 14 points. After the market had moved within a narrow range in the morning, foreign buying, attributed to inflationary aspects of unbalanced budgets in both Great Britain and this country, started a sharp upturn.

Mrs. Myrtle Shea's Merry Maker qualified for his engagements in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness by galloping to victory over a muddy track in the Glen Oaks, a mile-and-seventy-yard contest that featured today's midweek program. In the wake of the gelded son of Cynic were Sunphantom, Court Scandal and Matey. Merry Maker not only disposed of this highly touted opposition but was under a strong retaining grip in the final sixteenth of a mile.

Former Prince Nicholas was ready this morning to leave his native land for Italy. His private plane was prepared and his pilot, Captain Christescu, waited at the Bucharest Airdrome while the Prince procured the necessary permits to fly over Hungary and Austria. At the last moment the departure was postponed because of bad weather.

The United States will depend upon Don Budge, Frankie Parker, Gene Mako and Joseph Hunt in first round Davis Cup tennis competition against Japan at San Francisco on April 30, May 1 and 2, The Associated Press announced yesterday. This quartet was named in accordance with the rule that each team must nominate a squad of not more than four men ten days in advance of Cup matches.

The April grand jury handed up to Judge William Allen of the Court of General Sessions at 12:50 P. M. yesterday a first-degree murder indictment against Mischa Ross, mandolin player and theatrical agent. He was indicted as Mischa Rosenbaum, his real name.

Miss Josephine Meany, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Meany of Greenwich, and sister of Miss Helen Meany, former Olympic diving champion, was married to Harris Grant Nelson of Shanghai, China, on Sunday, in Yokohama, Japan, according to word received by the bride's parents.

Mrs. William Woodward Phelps, wife of Rear Admiral Phelps, U.S.N. (retired), will give a piano recital this afternoon in the ballroom of the residence of Mrs. George F. Baker, 75 East Ninetythird Street, for the benefit of the Church Army Training Center. The ballroom has a seating capacity of 300 and it has been reported that all the tickets have been sold. Several women of prominence are patronesses.

As a site for Immediate improvement with a six-story elevator apartment house the plot, 132 by 134 feet, on the east side of Park View Terrace, 400 feet north of East 196th Street, the Bronx, was sold by Nat Hirt to the Bellerose Central Corporation. The Roemer, Kenny Company and Armstrong Brothers were the brokers. Siegel Markel, attorneys, represented the seller.
Rhode Island State won its fifth straight game today when it scored thrice in the fourth to defeat Boston University, 4 to 2. The game was called by rain in the fifth. The box score:

Chester Odiorne Swain of 1,220 Park Avenue and Bedford Hills, N. Y., vice president, a director and a member of the executive committee of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, who was formerly its general counsel for twenty years, died last night in the Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. His age was 60. Last December he suffered an influenza attack, which was followed soon afterward by bronchial pneumonia.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are April 20 unless specified: At Port Angeles: Cincinnati, Concord, Dewey, Hull, MacDonough, New Mexico, Worden. At Foochow: outer anchorage, April 21: Augusta, Isabel.

Judge Robert A. Inch in the Federal Court in Brooklyn confirmed yesterday a report of James G. Moore, Special Master, who on March 11 had said a plan of reorganization for the PrudenceBonds Corporation was not fair and equitable and that the corporation was insolvent.

ORDNANCEMAN, 78c, 84c. 90c per hour, Naval Ordnance Plant, Baldwin, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the branch office of the Labor Board, Naval Ordnance Plant, Baldwin, N. Y., not later than April 30.
The Rev. Bardley W. Kindley, who had been pastor of several Methodist Episcopal churches in Pennsylvania and Maryland, died today at his home in Bel Air, Md., at the age of 75.

Mr. and Mrs. Kingdon Gould and their daughter, Miss Silvia Gould, gave a dinner last night at their home. 160 East Seventy-second Street, for Miss Barbara Hope Gatins and her fiance, James Freeman Curtis Jr., and for Miss Minnie Fox Hopkins and Dr. Charles Louis Gilbert, whose engagement has also been announced.
Sales of copper were made in the export market yesterday at 14 cents a pound, c. i. f. European base ports, a new low for the current movement.

Long Island University conquered Harvard at Rugby today by 13 to 12. The Crimson players came back strongly after trailing in the first half but failed to overcome the visitors' 8-3 lead. The line-up:

Two former employes of J. Edward Jones, dealer in oil royalties, who is on trial for alleged mail fraud, testified yesterday in Federal Court that they had resigned in 1932 after telling him they questioned his practices.

John R. Williams, president of the Electric Storage Battery Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Philadelphia that, while operations were tied up for six weeks owing to a strike, and operations of the Willard Storage Battery Company, a subsidiary,

Postmaster General Farley, speaking to nearly 4,000 persons today at ceremonies dedicating the new Norwalk Postoffice Building, defended President Roosevelt against a "barrage of criticism and vituperation" which, he said, had followed proposal of his court reorganization plan, and said his motive was "to get around an obstacle which threatens to block his whole program."

The existence of a new vitamin, the lack of which in the diet of black rats, young or old, caused their hair to turn gray, was reported here today before the fourth annual meeting of the American Institute of Nutrition.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders, today dated April 19: COMMANDERS Edgar, C. D., San Diego, Calif., to the Louisville as executive officer. Forster, O. M., Quantico. Va., to the Pensacola, as executive officer. Linsley, L. N., Newport, R. I., to the Northampton as executive officer.

Physicians of the United States are faced with a new opportunity in preventing disease by teaching human beings to live with each other and to adjust themselves to their environment, Dr. John Dewey of Columbia University said today in an address at the convocation of the American College of Physicians.
Diplomatic missions in Moscow tonight discussed the apparent disappearance of their useful Russian "friend," Boris Steiger.

Mr. and Mrs. Earle Williams Shutter of this town have announced the wedding of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Janice Shutter, to Robert Charles Grant Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Grant of Newton, Mass. The ceremony took place in Newton last Saturday.

Defeating Edward Martinson in thirty-six moves yesterday, Frank J. Marshall, former United States chess champion, strengthened his hold on first place in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Club.

Defeating Hyde Park High, 7 to 3, today, Phillips Exeter Academy gained its first baseball victory of the season. Walter Howell, starting on the mound for the first time; pitched well until the fifth. Then Pete Howie relieved him and blanked the visitors the rest of the way.

Nonresident foreign corporations, subject to provisions of Section 351 of the Revenue Act of 1936, which relate to personal holding companies, must include in gross income for tax purposes gains from the sale of capital assets within the United

An expanded advertising program for New Shinola White Shoe Cleaner in newspapers and magazines will start soon, it was announced yesterday by J. F. Forsyth, general manager of the shoe-polish division of the Hecker Products Corporation.. The campaign will include color pages and large black-andwhite space in Sunday newspapers,

Attacks upon President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan and the governmental attitude toward sitdown strikes were received with applause last night at the annual meeting of the Empire State Society, Sons of the American Revolution, held in the Hotel Plaza. The speakers were Clarence J. Shearn, president of the Association of the Bar of New York City, and Messmore Kendall, president-general of the Sons of the National Society,

The Hershey Bears of the United States, Eastern Amateur League champions, suffered their third straight defeat in the international hockey tournament tonight, losing by 8-7 to the Winnipeg Monarchs, Canadian junior champions.

A defense of the Jefferson Memorial Commission's plans was made in the House today by its chairman, Representative Boylan of New York. Concurrently the economy demand, apparently gaining speed, was regarded as a possible threat to an early start on the $3,000,000 project.

Isaac Cohen, a Jewish leader here for many years, died this morning at the Alexian Brothers Hospital. He was 75 years old. A resident of this city forty-five years he was president of the Anshe Sfard Synagogue, a member of the board of the United Hebrew Charities Organization and a member of the board of the Gomel Chesed Cemetery Association.

Filing of claims of $70,000,000 against various estates of the late O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen brought a prediction today that creditors of the railroad-empire builders "may collect scarcely one cent on a dollar."

Soviet industry will continue using bourgeois specialists even though they are hostile to the regime but will closely watch them to prevent mistakes, sabotage and espionage, Premier Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff indicates in a lengthy article on wreckers and spies that has been widely published.

Miss Fanny V. Greenhut, daughter of the late Captain Joseph B. Greenhut, one of the founders of Greenhut Co., died yesterday at the age of 69 in her apartment in the Hotel Delmonico, Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, where she had resided since returning six months ago after five years at her old home in Peoria, Ill.

Eight teams survived a knockout round yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Montclair in the Grand National team-of-four championships of the United States Bridge Association. The winners will have the privilege of representing this country in the international championships at Budapest and will get a free trip at the expense of Mr. and Mrs. Ely Culbertson.

The membership of the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street, voted at a special congregational meeting last evening to merge with the Brick Presbyterian Church. Sixty persons were present. There was only one dissenting vote.
Two French army officers are surveying France's border along the battle zone of Northern Spain "in case fortifications become necessary," it was learned authoritatively today.

The stock market here today was overshadowed by a reaction to the budget presented yesterday and although gilt-edge issues continued firm, domestic industrial shares were weak in general. Among foreign bonds, German loans did well.

The promotions of various agricultural commodities by chain stores here have been so successful that cooperative groups in Canada are seriously considering engaging in similar campaigns, it was learned here yesterday.
Morton won promotion to the first division of the Scottish Football League today by defeating Dumbarton, 5-0.

In an effort to provide a domestic supply of gasoline as a measure of national security, the Commonwealth Government agreed today to cooperate in a fresh effort to develop the Newnes shale deposits, 120 miles west of Sydney. These deposits total 20,000,000 tons and average 100 gallons of crude oil to the ton.

Great Britain has an Air Raid Precautions Department which is instructing householders what to do when air raiders drop gas bombs upon cities. The first line of defense is the gasproof room to which the whole family flees in the hour of need; the second a supply of 30,000,000 gas masks,

Rumors that the Swiss Government intends to refuse to permit Haile Selassie's delegates to enter Swiss territory to attend the League of Nations Assembly on May 26, admitting Egypt to the League, have brought no denials from Berne.
The tendency in sports to exploit a few participants rather than provide recreation for all was condemned yesterday by Mark A. McCloskey, New York City director of the National Youth Administration.
Coach Charles Walsh today announced changes in the Navy varsity and jayvee boating for the regatta with Columbia here on Saturday. The plebe crew remains intact.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that it had invited spokesmen of several shipping and commercial organizations in the port district to a meeting tomorrow at which the action of the Interstate Commerce Commission in designating a metropolitan district under the provisions of the Federal Motor Carriers Act will be discussed.
After a tenmonth truce while they waited for the Leftist government and parties to make good their promise to give women the vote, Mrs. Louise Weiss, leader of the feminist movement in France,

Evidence that the public expects Foreign Minister Naotake Sato will inaugurate a policy that will terminate Japan's isolation appears in the newspaper Nichi Nichi this morning in the form of a trial balloon regarding the revival of Anglo-Japanese friendship.

Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury in the Hoover Cabinet, declared here last night that "two major political forces are fighting for supremacy in the world today; one is the all-powerful collectivism, the other is individualism."
Taxation experts have been figuring today how Neville Chamberlain's proposed tax on excess profits or "national defense contribution" will be applied to various classes of industrial concerns.

As the Senate committee prepares to wind up its hearings on the President's Supreme Court plan, more talk is being heard, at least on the floors of Congress, of the possibility of a compromise. It comes chiefly from middle-ofthe-road Democrats who do not want to see their party wreck its unity in a

Senator Guillermo Alonso Pujol, Democrat, from Matanzas Province, and Senator Jose Manuel Casanova, Liberal, from Oriente Province, who is president of the National Sugar Institute, were appointed by the Senate this afternoon to serve on the governnment commission which is now studying a possible plan for resumption of payment of the public works bonds, which have been in default since 1933.
Industrialists throughout the country were still licking their wounds today twentyfour hours after the announcement of a new excess-profits tax in the guise of "national defense contributions."

More than,65,000 fans are expected to visit the ball parks at Jersey City, Newark, Baltimore and Syracuse today-if the weather is goodto see the curtain ascend on the International League's fifty-fourth season.

The Duke of Connaught, King George's greatuncle, who is confined to his bed in his hotel at Bournemouth with a muscular weakness of the leg, was reported officially tonight to be making good progress.
Colby Jones, sophomore, pitched Union College to a 13-to-3 victory over Middlebury today in the season's opener.

While the United States has taken more than half of its imports of hides from the Argentine, there is a possible danger of war-minded countries competing for this heavyweight leather used for shoes, Jesse Adler,
Jews will not be eligible for membership in the Camp of National Unity, according to an announcement today, "unless by their deeds they prove to be good nationalist Poles."

J. Harvey Turnure was elected chairman of the White Plains Republican committee tonight to succeed Henry R. Barrett, who resigned yesterday after nineteen years in the office. Twenty-seven committeemen voted for Mr. Turnure, while twenty-three cast ballots for Earle P. Hite,

The body of Mrs. Carmella Carreri, a 54-year-old widow, was found yesterday in her apartment at 173 Mulberry Street. She lived in a building the rear of which is across Center Market Place from police headquarters. She had been bound and gagged and also apparently strangled.
As the first reactions to the administration's economy drive were developing in Congress and the departments today, the Works Progress Administration made known its

Failure to file returns and pay taxes under the old-age pension and unemployment provisions of the Social Security Act will result in penalty assessments by the Treasury unless the Supreme Court should hold the law invalid, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Guy T. Helvering, warned today.

Interest in bond trading lagged yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as prices drifted irregularly lower on a slower trading pace. United States Government obligations were in moderate supply, which, with the absence of near-by bids, resulted in further declines throughout that list.

" The Second Hurricane," a playopera by Aaron Copland with text by Edwin Denby, received its world premiere at the Playhouse in Grand Street last night under the auspices of the music school of the Henry Street Settlement.

The police were notified yesterday that Julius S. Rosenbaum, a Chicago insurance agent, was being held in that city for the New York authorities on a charge of grand larceny. An investigation showed that Rosenbaum had been indicted for selling to Jack Dempsey,

The American Newspaper Publishers Association, holding its golden anniversary convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, will devote its session, beginning this morning at 10 o'clock, to the discussion of newsprint.
The explosion of a film last night during a showing at a school in Killingi, Estonia, where 100 children had assembled, caused five deaths.

Expansion of the Republic Steel Corporation's operating facilities in Alabama was forecast today when T. M. Girdler, chairman, and R. J. Wysor, the corporation's new president, inspected properties here of the Gulf States Steel Company, recently merged with Republic.

The Arts Department of St. Bartholomew's Community House will give its annual Spring play tonight and tomorrow night at the organization's headquarters, 109 East Fiftieth Street, when "Dulcy," a three-act comedy by George Kaufman and Marc Connelly, will be presented.

A net profit of $841,257 was reported by the Stewart-Warner Corporation and subsidiaries for the first quarter of 1937, equal to 67 cents a share on 1,241,847 capital shares, nearly double the $432,327, or 34 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1936. Gross operating profit was $2,111,349, against $1,466,992.
Mrs. Nina B. Taylor, horsewoman and wife of Winthrop Taylor of the Manhattan law firm of Taylor Roberts, died at their home here last night after three months of illness.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on April 10 were 297,468,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

A grant of $10,500 by the Rockefeller Foundation for a six-week experimentation course of study fordirectors, playwrights and designers of the Federal Theatre units of the WPA at Vassar College this Summer was announced yesterday by Mrs. Hallie Flanagan,

The Milbank Memorial Fund, founded by the late Mrs. Elizabeth Milbank Anderson, has given $100,000 to endow a health education program for Barnard College, it was announced yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve. Mrs. Anderson was a trustee of the college from 1894 until her death in 1921 and was vice chairman of the board for many years.

Terms of the settlement of the Remington Rand, Inc., strike, withheld for a month at the request of James Rand Jr., were made public today simultaneously with information to the International Association of Machinists that strikers in five of the six plants favored the proposal by about 2,000 to 200.
The Book-of-the-Month Club selection for June will be "The Constitution, an American Biography," by Burton J. Hendrick. Little, Brown are the publishers.

The Durieux Chamber Music Ensemble will be heard in concert tonight at the Greenwich House Music School. Blanche Winogron, pianist, will assist. The first of a series of student recitals will be given tonight at the Music School of the Hebrew Educational Society, Brooklyn.

The $25,000,000 of 4 per cent revenue bonds of the Triborough Bridge Authority offered yesterday had a quick sale when all but $2,000,000 was sold in the day. The bonds were offered by a large banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co.

A letter to President Roosevelt urging passage of the WagnerSteagall Low-Rent Housing Bill was approved yesterday at the monthly meeting of delegates of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at Sixty-fifth Street.

Miss Elizabeth M. Marshall, descendant of Chief Justice John Marshall and daughter of the late William St. John Elliot Marshall and Elizabeth Stuyvesant Fish Morris Marshall of Pelham, N. Y., and Natchez, Miss., died here today at the age of 74 after a long illness.

Inching along the marble halls, past historic portraits, velvet roped doorways and the gold braid of military aides' uniforms at the White House reception in their honor this afternoon, more than 3,000 delegates to the forty-sixth Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution congratulated each other on the uninterrupted serenity of their sessions.

Earnings of the General Foods Corporation in the first quarter of this year were the most favorable of any three months' period since the March quarter of 1932, when 84 cents a share was shown, according to the report announced yesterday by C. M. Chester, chairman, and Clarence Francis, president.

Secret warrants were drawn today to make a criminal court issue of the marriage of 12year-old Geneva Hamby and Homer Peels, 32-year-old mountaineer. "Prosecution and annulment action will follow immediately," said District Attorney General Beecher Witt.

Carl Adler, who has been appointed president and general manager of Wallach's, Inc., men's clothing chain with ten stores in the metropolitan area, will assume his new duties tomorrow, he announced here yesterday.

A strike against ships of the Cunard White Star and Furness Withy Lines in all ports from Portland, Me., to Hampton Roads, Va., was declared yesterday by the International Longshoremen's Association in an effort to force those lines to recognize the union in the Port of Montreal.
Argentina's imports of machinery and vehicles show a notable increase in tonnage and value for the first two months of 1937, according to a report from the Trade Commissioner at Buenos Aires.

A plan for the strengthening of inter-house undergraduate athletics at Harvard, based upon recommendations recently made by the Student Council, has been approved by the masters of the seven houses and the university authorities, and will go into effect next Fall, it was announced tonight.

Harry Harris, a practicing attorney in New York for thirty-seven years, died suddenly on Tuesday in the home at Great Neck, L. I., where he lived with his nephew and niece, Emanuel and Martha Jacobs. His age was 65.

The report of the Northern States Power Company of Delaware and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $5,190,816, against $4,933,765 in the preceding year. Gross operating revenues of the system were $34,857,967, an increase of $2,070,700 or 6.3 per cent, over 1935.

As every paterfamilias knows, there are times when, after breaking the news to the family that the old car must do for another year because of a sudden cramp in the income, it is possible to assuage disappointments all round by compromising on a new one several price-grades below the job selected by the distaff side.

Three men were jailed tonight and a dozen others sought as detectives rounded up what they described as a fake insurance ring that had inoculated willing factory workers with lead poisoning so they could collect compensation.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 20: COLONELS. Churchill, L. S. (Lt. Col.). Air Corps, one month and 28 days leave, July 20. Bristol, M. C., Finance Dept., three months leave, May 1. LIEUTENANT COLONELS. Candee, R. C. (MaJ.), Air Corps, two months leave, June 7, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Thomas Sweeney, 28 years old, an elevator operator of 232 East Thirty-seventh Street, pleaded guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to a charge of having impaired the morals of two 6-year-old children. He was remanded to the Tombs to await sentence on Saturday.

A charge of homicide made several weeks ago against Seymour Magoon, 26-year-old lieutenant of Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein, was dismissed yesterday In Queens Felony Court by Magistrate Savarese. Magoon was taken into custody on a warrant as he left the city penitentiary several weeks ago,

With no assurance that their substitute revenue program will prove acceptable to Governor Lehman or even to the Republican members of the Senate and with a distinct threat that it might fail of passage in the Assembly through lack of Republican votes, leaders in the lower house today caused three bills to be

The administration's economy drive got off to an uncertain start in Congress today when the House passed a bill, not contemplated in President Roosevelt's new budget estimates, which would embark the government on a ten-year program of aid to States, municipalities and industries for control of water pollution.

On his own application: PATROLMAN-David J. Foley, 18th Division, 9th Detective District, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 28, 1907. Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANT-John F. McNamara, from Grand Central Parkway Precinct to Traffic P. assignment to Desk Duty continued. THIRD GRADE DETECTIVES - From 18th Division, Detective Districts indicated to Precincts specified, designation as Third Grade Detectives revoked:

Profit in 1936 of the Banco de la Nacion of Argentina, which yesterday published its annual report, was 14,224,965 pesos, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. The announcement said the bank's activities reflected the general prosperity of Argentine industry and agriculture last year.
Judge Robert A. Inch in Brooklyn Federal Court signed a decree yesterday confirming the plan of reorganization of the Bush Terminal Company and its subsidiary, the Bush Terminal Buildings Company.

Edouard Daladier, French Minister of Defense, arrived here today for a series of talks with British officials. It is believed that the forthcoming meeting of the steering committee of the Disarmament Conference,
President Roosevelt will, a week from today, start his fishing vacation in the Gulf of Mexico, which will include incidental trips to New Orleans, Biloxi, Galveston and Fort Worth.

Fifty thousand miles of telephone wire were required for the telephone circuit-said to have been the greatest in history-that carried the voice of Guy W. Cox yesterday to every representative of the John Hancook Mutual Life Insurance Company, gathered in 368 offices in continental United States and one agency in Honolulu.

Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair, supported by about fifty citizens of New York, most of them from the Borough of Queens, appeared before the Senate Committee on Commerce today to urge passage of the Senate Joint Resolution which appropriates $2,500,000

Arthur Sainsbury's 5 year-old William of Valence proved himself master of crushing weight and a heavy course by winning the City and Suburban Handicap today. He finished the mile and a quarter in 2:14.

Controller Frank J. Taylor made public yesterday a letter on the proposed relief investigation sent to him by the Aldermanic investigating committee and indicated that the resolution authorizing the inquiry was broad enough to cover the phases the Finance Department wants investigated.

William H. Hoffman, publisher of the Long Island Daily Press, accepted yesterday the wage and hours provisions of the arbitration award in the strike of editorial employes on the paper but asked that the award be amended in other respects before he could accept it. The award was made on Tuesday by a committee of three clergymen, the Rev. Andrew Magill, the Rev. William Kelly, and the Rev. Joseph Titus all of Jamaica.

The new WPA financed sports stadium at Droyer's Point here, which cost $1,500,000, will be opened formally tomorrow with an International League baseball game between the Jersey City and the Rochester teams.

After hearing from their president, William E. Levis, a statement of record-breaking business in 1936, stockholders of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company today approved the plan to split the common stock in a ratio of two for one and decrease the par value of the shares to $12.50.

American whisky is being imported by Great Britain for the first time since repeal, according to T. C. Wiehe, president of the Schenley International Corporation, who returned from France yesterday on the French liner Ile de France.

A warning that the "philosophy of centralized monopolistic control" would be adopted in the United States unless advocates of a free competitive economic system conduct an earnest campaign in behalf of their theory was voiced tonight by William B Hard,

The third day's sale of Baron Lionel Nathan de Rothschild's collection of art treasures was devoted mainly to pieces of French furniture. Almost every English and French dealer of note was present in the ballroom of the historic mansion and keen international competition forced the day's receipts to [Pound]31,000.

Most commodity futures were higher in more active trading on the local markets yesterday. Silk, zinc and domestic sugar futures declined. On the cash markets oats, cocoa, lard, tins, cotton and rubber advanced, but wheat, corn, rye, eggs and printcloths declined.
Secretary Woodring presented wrist watches in behalf of the National Rifle Association of America today to three men selected as the country's outstanding rifle shots.

The Florida Legislature has passed a new budget bill for Tampa, which would place that city's fiscal affairs on a strictly cash basis, it was announced here in behalf of R. E. L. Chancey, Mayor of Tampa. The bill is awaiting the signature of Governor Cone.

The engagement of Miss Betty Buechner, daughter of Mrs. C. Fred Buechner of 940 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Buechner, to Morgan Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. George David Baker, also of this city, has been announced by her mother.
In all lines of industry and business Canada is today about 15 per cent ahead of her position at this time last year and trade between the United States and Canada is steadily increasing,

Colonial Utilities, Inc., and the Colonial Utilities Corporation have registered as holding companies under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission announces. The Commission states that a plan of reorganization for both companies is being prepared under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act and may result in a new company to succeed to their business.

Trading was only fair to slow on most classes. Some steer cuts were higher and veal carcasses higher. The lamb market was weak to slightly lower and fresh pork cuts mostly steady to slightly lower. Early trading in kosher meats was very slow on most classes, with beef weak, veal and lamb mostly unchanged, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A syndicate composed of Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Dick MerleSmith and Stroud Co. obtained yesterday the award of an issue of $6,800,000 of Cincinnati, New Orleans Texas Pacific one-to-fifteenyear 2 1/2 per cent equipment-trust certificates on a bid of 96.678.

The revue, "And on We Go," the first joint venture of Paul Murray and Robert Nesbitt, was produced at the Savoy Theatre tonight. It is- modeled on the newsreel. The show opened with a prologue showing camera men taking shots of various events which are then reproduced on the stage.

Two persons were killed and four others injured severely today in a collision between a stolen automobile and another car on Jericho Turnpike west of Lake Ronkonkoma Road. The dead are August Desantis, 18 years old, of 518 East Eighty-fourth Street, Manhattan,

Displacement of a lightweight streamlined train with a streamlined train of standard steel construction on next Sunday on the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's line between this city and Washington will demonstrate that steam is meeting the competition of newer forms of motive power, Daniel Willard, president, said yesterday.
The low bidders on the first two contracts on the Northern-Wantagh State Parkway extension in Nassau County were announced yesterday by the State Department of Public Works.

The importation of 17,523 tons of Soviet anthracite at Boston in one week recently was reported here yesterday by the Heating and Air Conditioning Bureau, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The coal will be used in New England.

Division of cosmic radiation into two parts, "hard" and "soft" rays, which has been suggested by some physicists in recent years, is supported to a remarkable degree by data obtained during a series of recent airplane flights here. Dr. W. F. G. Swann, director of the Bartol Research Foundation, stated this in his annual report before the Franklin Institute.

King Carol of Rumania and President Ignaz Moscicki of Poland will exchange visits this Summer. Colonel Josef Beck, Foreign Minister, went to Bucharest tonight for a three-day visit to make the final arrangements there. The series of visits was begun in November when Victor Antonescu, Minister of Finance, came here,

William Spissak of 260 Seaman Avenue, Bronx, a 15-year-old firstyear student at Manhattan College High School, suffered a heart attack while swimming in the college pool yesterday afternoon and died at once.

Jerome Strauss and Leonard Coleman triumphed in the Poggenburg Memorial 18.2 balkline billiard tournament at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night. Strauss defeated Lester Fisher, 175 to 66, in twenty innings, while Coleman, a Class C player, upset Anthony La Via, 125 to 143, in twenty-four frames.

For nearly four years there have been oceans of talk about the revival, rejuvenation, regeneration of the Republican party. At last something is to be done about it. Colonel THEODORE ROOSEVELT, turning over to his successor the office of president of the National Republican Club,

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: Except for need of rain for germination in Texas, the week was decidedly favorable in the Cotton Belt, with generally warm and sunny weather. In the Mississippi Valley section planting was active, with some put in locally nearly to the northern limits of the belt.

THE man in the subway car did not have the build of a practical joker, nor did he look as though he had been drinking all night. He sat looking at the hygiene and food advertisements in an alert, eager sort of way and talking to himself. When the train stopped at Times Square we could hear what he was saying.

Notifications covering what is believed to be the largest number of items priced by manufacturers under the provisions of the FeldCrawford Fair Trade Act for a single day were received yesterday by local stores.
William H. Gosch of Reading, Pa., was re-elected president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers at the annual meeting today at the Convention Hall.
Steelhelmeted men of Maine's National Guard took over tonight the Lewiston-Auburn shoe strike area, torn by violence for the second successive day.
AMOR, a play in Spanish in three acts, by Oduvaldo Vianna; staged and produced by Paulina Singerman and her assistants. At the Ambassador Theatre.

Overriding substantial objections by Deputy Controller John Dwight Sullivan, the Sinking Fund Commission voted yesterday to commit the city to improvement of North Beach Airport in Queens so that it could be used as a transatlantic seaplane base.
Dr Bruce R. Payne, president of George Peabody College for Teachers, died tonight of a heart attack at his home. He was 63 years old.
James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, sailed yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to attend the coronation in London as a special envoy of President Roosevelt.

Norman H. Davis, special United States Envoy, tonight told a group of members of the House of Commons that economic appeasement was the first step toward settlement of political differences in the world.
Children whose fathers are on WPA work show a higher morale than those whose parents are home relief cases, said Justice Justine Wise Tulin of the New York Domestic Relations Court,
Mayor La Guardia received a collection of Irish whisky yesterday from Lord Mayor Alfred Byrne of Dublin, marking the beginning of a new steamship service between Dublin and New York.

Miss Mary Chandler Stearns, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Edwin I. Stearns of this place, will be married on April 30 to the Rev. David Armon Hughes, son of Mrs. Helen M. Hughes of Baltimore. The ceremony will take place in the evening in the First Presbyterian Church. here, and will be performed by the prospective bride's father.
Electric power output declined last week when an increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index receded to 106.8 from 107:3. It was 97.7 for the week ended April 18, 1936.

Thousands of youths, who have congregated within the city in groups known generally as "cellar clubs," need "guidance" rather than "repression," according to educators, city officials and welfare leaders who joined in a discussion of this subject yesterday at an informal luncheon in the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

Miss Mary Chandler Stearns, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Edwin I. Stearns of this place, will be married on April 30 to the Rev. David Armon Hughes, son of Mrs. Helen M. Hughes of Baltimore. The ceremony will take place in the evening in the First Presbyterian Church. here, and will be performed by the prospective bride's father.
Electric power output declined last week when an increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index receded to 106.8 from 107:3. It was 97.7 for the week ended April 18, 1936.

Thousands of youths, who have congregated within the city in groups known generally as "cellar clubs," need "guidance" rather than "repression," according to educators, city officials and welfare leaders who joined in a discussion of this subject yesterday at an informal luncheon in the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

Graduation exercises at the United States Military Academy here will be held on June 12 this year. The tentative program for the June week includes daily full-dress parades, an athletic review, alumni exercises and the distribution of diplomas at the base of Battle Monument.

A. Herbert Mathes of New York University won the first prize of $100 in the ninth annual bridgedesign competition of the American Institute of Steel Construction, in which eighty engineering and architectural students of sixteen colleges participated. The results were announced yesterday.
Whether the master plumbers like it or not, they are going to get a fancy title-sanitary engineer-if Samuel Fassler, Commissioner -of Buildings in Manhattan, has his way.

Six members of the family of Mark Degnan, 532 Wales Avenue, New York City, were severely injured today when the automobile in which they were rushing to their father's funeral was wrecked. They were removed to the St. Raphael and New Haven Hospitals where it was said tonight that none was on the danger list.

The two twenty-family apartment houses at 521-523 West 156th Street were leased for ten years by Mrs. Sarah Beam to the 521 West 156h Street Corporation, Lewis Suslow, president. They were acquired by the owner in 1926 and were remodeled recently from six-room apartments to two and three room units. The broker was Jacob Rosenkrantz.

The body of W. Forbes Morgan, former treasurer of the Democratic national campaign committee, left here tonight for Washington, where funeral services will be held Friday at 10 A. M. in St. Thomas's Episcopal Church. Burial will be in Arlington National Cemetery.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek continues in this installment of the story of his captivity at Sian last December the diary he kept there. Yesterday he told of his indignation on meeting Chang Hsuehliang, his captor, and previously he told of his capture by the mutineers.

For the first time in recent railroad history no question was asked, no criticism voiced and no controversy injected into the annual meeting of the stockholders of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad here today.

Several hundred letters from retail stores throughout the country have been received by women's apparel manufacturers protesting against possible action by manufacturers in imposing a delivery charge on packages to the delivery companies next month, it was learned here yesterday.
Charles White, who preserved the exploits of the Babe Ruths and Ty Cobbs for baseball posterity, died today after a heart attack. He was 76.

Production of rails in the United States last year amounted to 1,219,846 gross tons, the largest output since 1930, and it compared with 711,537 gross tons produced in 1935, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Mike Jacobs yesterday denied reports that he has signed articles for Joe Louis to fight in London on July 30.
An indication that the new railroad retirement plan would be accepted by the railroads came today from Robert V. Fletcher, counsel for the Association of American Railroads.

Mrs. Congreve Jackson gave a tea yesterday at her home, 1,049 Park Avenue, for members of the committee in charge of arrangements for the benefit card party of the Marymount Day School on Friday afternoon at the headquarters of the school, 1.027 Fifth Avenue. The benefit has been planned by members of the alumnae.

The final step in the program of refunding the Argentine Government's outstanding dollar debt, begun last year, will take place today with the offering by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of a new issue of $35,000,000 of Argentine Republic sinking-fund conversion loan 4 per cent bonds due on April 15, 1972.

Two new American speed-boat records made last month at Miami by S. Mortimer Auerbach of Atlantic City in the 135-cubic inch class were protested in surprising fashion last night at a special meeting of drivers and boat owners of this racing class at the Hotel Lexington.

Engineering contracts totaling $669,202 were awarded today by the War Department as follows: General Engineering and Drydock Company, Oakland, Calif. - For repairing dredge "Dan C. Kingman," Seattle district, $122,726. Driver Company, Memphis, Tenn. -- For earthwork construction, Bird's Point-New Madrid front line levee, upper St. Francis levee district $39.402.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company; in addressing about 250 shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday, indicated that telephone rates must ultimately follow the rising spiral of prices unless the increase in prices, including wages and taxes, be so gradual and within such limits that inventions and improvements in operating technique can be made fast enough to create offsetting economies.

Postponed from Tuesday evening, "Curtain Call," that play about the last days of Eleonora Duse by Le Roy Bailey, will have its premiere tonight at the John Golden Theatre. Ara Gerald will have the role of the memorable Italian actress.
Market closed higher, with steel, motor and copper shares up 1 to 4 points; turnover, 1,247,980 shares.

Miss Frances T. Mackey, formerly connected with the public school system here as a teacher and department principal in Public School 1 for forty-three years, died this morning at her home, following an illness of several weeks. She retired in 1913.

The Artcraft Silk Hosiery Mills, Inc., asked Judge Harry S. McDevitt today to have the Sheriff evict twentyeight sit-down strikers who, with the aid of several thousand union members and sympathizers, forcibly took possession of the plant here last night.

Thomas Mann, German author and exile, spoke last night before 4,000 persons at a mass meeting at Mecca Temple under the auspices of the League of American Writers and the Joint Committee of German-American Organizations of Greater New York.

BARTLETT, FRANK TERANCE (Jan. 6, 1937). Gross assets, $17,912; net, $16.159. To Ellen Borst Mann, aunt, life estate in residue: four friends share remainders in residue and several other persons receive bequests of personal property. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $12,495. Levisohn, Niner Levisohn, attorneys, 366 Madison Av.

Encouraging progress in the collection of funds by the special gifts committee of the Cardinal's committee of the laity to assist in the Catholic Charities appeal was reported yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, director of Catholic Charities.
The science of pedagogy has disappeared from the German universities, where professors of pedagogy during the last few weeks have one after another received their dismissals.

More than eighteen billion gallons of gasoline were used on the nation's highways in 1936, according to figures made public today by the Bureau of Public Roads. This was a 10.8 per cent increase over 1935.
MIDDLETONW IN TRANSITION, by Robert s, Lynd and Helen Merrell Lynd. (Harcourt, Brace, $5.) A Study in cultural conflicts.
There were thirty-nine hits in the slugfest the Browns won from the White Sox, 15 to 10, to open the American League baseball season here today, but Rogers Hornsby's home run led all the rest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I second your editorial urging the necessity of a census of the unemployed? Such a census is indeed long overdue. For years I have pointed out that although we are the most statistically minded nation knowing accurately the number of pigs,

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of Mrs. J. Borden Harriman of Washington to be Minister to Norway. She will succeed Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. of Philadelphia, whose nomination to be Ambassador to Poland was also approved today by the committee.

A new pocket billiard champion of the world was crowned last night as Ralph Greenleaf, New York veteran, rallied brilliantly to overcome Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia, 125107, in a tense 12-inning struggle at Ponzi's academy.

Wheat prices advanced rather sharply in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, with the May delivery at the extreme 2 cents a bushel above yesterday's finish as the result of strength in foreign markets and on buying attributed to cash and milling concerns.

Leonid M. Lyadoff, director of the famous Mali Theatre here, has been summarily dismissed and, it is understood, is under arrest on charges "of wrecking the theatre's production program and endeavoring to corrupt

An elderly man registered at a hotel as Cecil A. Elliott of 230 East Fiftieth Street, New York, was found dead in his room tonight with a bullethole in his right temple and a revolver beside him. He was last seen alive in the afternoon and had registered at the hotel Friday.
Thousands of green-shirted Fascist Integralistas marched today in front of the Catholic Cathedral to pay homage to Brazil's dead independence heroes.

Distilled spirits in the volume of 422,882,665 tax gallons remained in bonded warehouses at the end of March. During the month 22,384,951 gallons were produced, 745,123 gallons withdrawn on the payment of tax, and 152,784 gallons removed for denaturation.

The passage by the House of an appropriation of $5,000,000 for Federal participation is another gratifying step in the steady metamorphosis of the New York World's Fair from dream to reality. Such Federal participation is not merely appropriate but indispensable if the aims and the occasion of the Fair are to be truly expressed.

Rudy Vallee was convicted here today of assault and battery despite his emphatic denials that he had struck a newspaper photographer. Harry Paul, a publicity man who was with Mr. Vallee when the scuffle took place, was fined $50, but Judge Daniel J. Gillen let Mr. Vallee off by putting the charge "on file." Mr. Paul appealed and posted $100 bail.

A stay granted by Harlan F. Stone, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, and filed in the Federal District Court here yesterday by August Heckscher, as president of the Anahma Realty Corporation, halted reorganization proceedings of the ParkLexington Corporation until the case is presented to the Supreme Court.
Representative Taber, senior minority member of the House Appropriations Committee, estimated today that measures calling for expenditures of $150,000,000,000 were pending in Congress.

Negotiations for a new agreement affecting 45,000 garment workers in this city were opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker between the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers and the Joint Board of the Cloakmakers Unions, affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers.

Two garment manufacturers, one of whom is said to do a business of $2,000,000 a year, were arrested yesterday by detectives attached to the staff of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets. Both are charged with having filed false and fraudulent State income tax returns for 1934.

Lawrence A. Howard, a young Kentucky miner, palpably nervous as a witness, told the Senate subcommittee investigating violations of civil liberties today that he was warned by telephone yesterday to leave for his home in Harlan County tonight "or be buried in Arlington."

Members of the Italy America Society and the American Society of Royal Italian Orders gave a large supper dance and entertainment last night In the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the Italian Ambassador, Fulvio Suvich, and Mrs. Suvich. The occasion marked a celebration here of the birth of H. R. H., Prince of Naples, and the proceeds will be used to found a scholarship in the name of the Prince.

Attacking New Deal policies and aims, Walter Lippmann said tonight, "We are faced now with the choice between the restoration of constitutional government and a rapid descent into personal government."

Arthur J. Wylie, banker and industrialist, died last night at his home here in his eighty-first year. He was a director of the Farmers National Bank and Trust Company, vice president of Oneida County Savings Bank and a founder of the Rome Textile Company.
A brush fire that swept 600 acres of the South Side Sportsmen's Club preserve north of this village yesterday claimed the life of Fire Warden Frank Cizek Sr. of Bohemia, L. I. The body of Mr.

The Citizens Union has forwarded to Governor Lehman a memorandum asking him to veto the four Berg bills, affecting independent nominations for public office, passed by the Legislature last week. The Governor will hold a hearing on the bills tomorrow.
Burleigh Grimes, new manager of the Dodgers; and his chief aide, Andy High, were guests of honor at a luncheon of the 12:45 o'Clock Club at Oetjen's Restaurant in Brooklyn yesterday.
Major John Herschel Hardcastle, one of the leading authorities on small-arms ballistics and author of many technical treatises on gunnery, died today at Sidcup, Kent. His age was 66.

John Viers, 26-year-old wine salesman of 104-45 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, was acquitted by a jury in the Queens County Court yesterday of a charge of second degree manslaughter. He was charged with killing his stepfather, Herman J. Donavin, former Ogdenburg, N. Y., attorney.

The marriage of Miss Cynthia Ann Wills, daughter of Mrs. Norbert Morin of 156 East Fifty-second Street and of Van Leer Wills of Grand Rapids, Mich., to John Corson Blair, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Blair of this city, took place yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich.

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, was sued for separate maintenance by his wife today. Mrs. Laura Hall Hamilton charged her husband with gross neglect of duty, abandonment for more than a year and extreme cruelty.

Senator Bennett Champ Clark warned the American Newspaper Publishers Association yesterday that the President's judiciary program would abolish the Supreme Court as it has existed since the Republic was founded.

The Citizens Union has forwarded to Governor Lehman a memorandum asking him to veto the four Berg bills, affecting independent nominations for public office, passed by the Legislature last week. The Governor will hold a hearing on the bills tomorrow.

About half of the 2,121,850 pounds of dry skim milk for which the Agricultural Adjustment Administration has just awarded contracts will be supplied by the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association of New York, the administration announced today.
The Legislature passed and sent to the Governor today the Neustein Bill, which will permit New York City to establish a Summer camp for under-privileged children on Fire Island.

George Muirson Woolsey, president since 1932 of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and partner in the Stock Exchange firm of H. N. Whitney Sons, 49 Wall Street, died early yesterday in the Doctors Hospital after an illness of three weeks. He was 65 years old.

Bassford Ave (11-3053), n e cor 183d St. 80x35: Ferdie Contracting Co., Inc., to Ferdinand Vetter, 2,261 Washington Ave. 227th St (17-4828), s s. 105 ft w of Prospect Ave. 33x100: Augusto Bertero to Syd Steinberg, 47 Featherbed Lane; mtg $11,000.

Cornell lost its first tennis match of the season today as the experienced University of Miami team took an 8-1 decision. Rain fell heavily during the day and the match was held in the drill hall instead of on clay courts.
The Senate passed and sent to the Governor today the Brownell bill to clear up the titles of hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of waterfront property in New York City.

Steer hind and rib business was fair to good, and prices continued strong; rail supplies in slaughter houses were the lightest in several weeks. Demand for veal hindsaddles continued fair to good. Lamb business was better at lower prices, and cooler weather was favorable for fresh pork consumption. Thursday being an offkosher day, the slaughter of cattle and vealers was extremely light, but lamb about normal, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
The Toronto Maple Leafs trounced the Orioles, 10-7, to open the International League race today, the home team being beaten although blasting four home runs.
A bill to prevent price-slashing on branded and trade-marked merchandise was passed by the Senate today and goes to the Governor. The measure had the sponsorship of several mercantile groups.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders to day, dated April 20: CAPTAINS Bellinger, P. N. L., the Ranger, to Chief of Staff, Commander of Aircraft, Battle Force.

Thousands of college students left their classes at 11 A. M. yesterday for the fourth annual "peace strike" in a planned nation-wide demonstration against war. On the whole, the demonstration was peaceful, except for a few minor clashes attributable to youthful spirit.

Fillies held the spotlight at Jamaica yesterday, three of them wining on the six-race card, including North Riding, a daughter of Hightime, who was\first in the featured Coquette Purse, a prep for the Acorn and Oaks races. Dabney Harrison, the young Virginian who succeeded Captain P. M. Walker as Howe Stable trainer, saddled North Riding and she ran the kind of race the betting indicated.

GRAIN PRODUCTS CORP., 11 W. 42d St.--Answer filed to involuntary petition filed on March 26 asks leave to effect a reorganization under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law. Complete figures on the present financial condition of the corporation are said to be unavailable due to the liquidation of Grain Products Corp., S. A., Antwerp, against which the debtor has a claim for $160,630 and the pending arbitration of another claim.
Jessie Mae Wilkes, 30 years old, indicted April 5 on a misdemeanor charge of uttering defamatory statements against Mrs. Coy A. Stephenson, was shot to death on a street here today.

An early trial of a taxpayer's suit seeking to invalidate the Yonkers City Manager referendum of last November was asked by the plaintiff today. Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme reserved decision.

A joint committee representing the glove manufacturers here and the International Glove Workers Union will go to Gloversville, N. Y., to line up active support for the plan to have Congress place quota restrictions on the imports of women's leather dress gloves in order to aid the domestic industry, it was stated yesterday by Joseph Burkholz of the Max Mayer Company.

C. D. Caldwell, president of the Interlake Iron Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that in his opinion common dividends would be resumed some time this year, but that it was up to the directors to determine when the action should be taken.
