In this installment of the diary he kept while a captive in Sian last December, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek tells of the events between Dec. 15 and Dec. 21. In yesterday's installment he told how he had defied his captors and of their demands and pleas.

The Flushing High School and St. Agnes Academy nines battled to a 2-2 deadlock in eight innings at Memorial Field, Flushing, yesterday. The game was called off because of rain. Jim Fitzpatrick went the route for St. Agnes and hit the double that drove in two teammates in the second.

Further evidences of the heavy movement of gold to this country from abroad were provided yesterday when the pound sterling rose in foreign exchange to the highest point in six months, a shipment of $21,729,100 gold came in from England and the engagement of $7,992,000 of additional gold abroad for shipment here was reported to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A sharp drop in Dominion Government deposits due to government spending was shown in the weekly statement of. the Bank of Canada issued today. Dominion deposits yesterday were $24,748,616, against $35,045,723 on April 14.

The promotion of "packaged" homes by so many companies in the appliance and building material field this year will raise national linage on homes to the highest point ever reached, according to comment here yesterday.

Public hearings' on President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan will be ended by the Senate Judiciary Committee tomorrow and the committee will start executive consideration of the measure Tuesday, it was announced today by Senator Ashurst of Arizona, chairman.

While the western democracies are establishing what the Germans have called a "commuting service" for their statesmen between London. Paris and Brussels to perfect their, solidarity, the authoritarian powers of Central Europe apparently are determined to trump this effort by an even more spectacular exchange of visits to demonstrate the solidarity of the Rome-Berlin axis and its auxiliaries.

Stockholders of the Tennessee Corporation approved yesterday an issue of $5,000,000 of convertible bonds, debentures or notes which are to be issued at the discretion of the directors. The proceeds are to be used to retire the $4,046,300 of 6 per cent debentures now outstanding which are callable on Sept. 1, next, at 103 1/2 and interest.

One more year at its present pace and the fight game will be washed up, Jack Dempsey bluntly predicted today. "Something must be done, and if it isn't done within the next year we just won't have any boxing," flared the 42-year-old former heavyweight master. "In the past five years boxing has deteriorated so much that all other sports have gone far ahead.

A gold medal was awarded yesterday to Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, for being "America's Beloved Mother" and because "her wisdom and inspired teachings have been the guiding influence to her son."

The sit-down strike at the Harrison plant of the Crucible Steel Company of America, called suddenly at 10:30 this morning by C. I. 0. officials, came to an end at 6:45 o'clock this evening when the company set May 3 as the date for negotiations on the demands of employes.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Bishop of Boston have announced the engagement of Mrs. Bishop's daughter, Miss Margot A. Nietsche of the Barbizon Club, this city, to Alfred Frederick Melzig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred H. J. Melzig of Roselle, N. J.

The celebration of Goettingen University's 200th anniversary at the end of June, like the celebration last year of Heidelberg's 550th anniversary, threatens to become a Brown Shirt pageant. The fate of the ceremonies now depends upon how stiff an opposition the still rather liberal faculty shows to the desires of the National Socialist Ministry of Education and National Socialist student functionaries.

A radio car patrolman shot and slightly wounded a Negro and hurt a fellow-patrolman with the same bullet about 10:45 o'clock last night in a scuffle with two Negroes on the second-floor landing of a tenement at 685 Herkimer Street Brooklyn.

The National Institute of Immigrant Welfare presented its annual awards to three foreign-born citizens who have made "significant contributions to American life," after a dinner at the Hotel Biltmore last night.

Negotiations for a new agreement were begun last night at the Hotel Governor Clinton between the Merchants' Ladies' Garment Association, representing 170 jobbers, and the Joint Board of the Cloakmakers' Unions, affiliate of the International Ladies' Garment Workers. On Wednesday evening negotiations were begun by the union with the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, representing 410 "inside" shops.
A death threat sent to Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri caused a Capitol policeman to be stationed at the door of each public gallery when the Senate convened today.

Plans for the food products section of the 1939 World's Fait, depicting the manifold steps in production of food for the present day and for the "world of tomorrow," were set in motion yesterday with the award of architectural commissions for three exhibit halls.

Hiding behind a furnace in the nether regions of a house in Milford, Conn., Father Divine was arrested yesterday as a fugitive from New York. He fled Monday night from his Harlem "heaven" at 20 West 115th Street when police sought him for questioning about an assault by his "angels" upon three white men visiting his "kingdom."

Beginning on May the 1,395 employes of the Finance Department will go on a five-day week, Controller Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday. He notified all his bureau heads of the change, but told them that a sufficient staff must be maintained in each borough office to handle necessary business with the public.

Mayor La Guardia demands the utmost caution and law observance from his chauffeur, never exercises his prerogative of going through traffic lights, and rarely has his automobile's siren sounded. But Wednesday morning he became involved in the first auto accident since his election.

Lehman Brothers head an underwriting syndicate which will offer today 50,000 shares of Mead Corporation $5.50 cumulative preferred stock, Series B, of no par value, with warrants attached for the purchase of common stock. The stock will be' priced at $99 a share, plus accrued dividends from March 1 to date of delivery.

The driving rainstorm that pelted the New York area yesterday morning and 'continued with difinished violence spasmodically throughout the afternoon flooded the streets with 1.74 inches of water, chopped up the sea along the North Atlantic Coast and caused property damage.

A further slight decline in wholesale prices occurred in the week ended on April 17, atributable principally to the effect of falling agricultural prices, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The bureau's index, based on the 1926 average as 100, dropped to 87.6 from 87.9 the preceding week and compared with 79.7 the corresponding week in 1936.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported today that employment in retail stores in New York State advanced 3.9 per cent between the middle of February and the middle of March. Payrolls rose 2.6 per cent.

An unusual Keats association item--the poet's own set of the works of Shakespeare, with notes in Keats's autograph-was bought by Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach for $31,000 last night at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the library of the late George Allison Armour of Princeton, N. J.

Divorce proceedings were started today by Mrs. Alexandra Plaut against Edward Plaut, wealthy owner of Broad Brook Farm in Springdale. An attachment for $350,000 was filed in the town clerk's office this morning.

The conference of Swedish, Danish, Norwegian and Finnish Foreign Ministers ended this afternoon after two days of strenuous deliberations. The first ever held in Finland, the conference marked a new milestone in the political cooperation among North European officials, a fact that was emphasized by all participants. Richard Johannes Sandler, Swedish Foreign Minister, said:
Directors of the American Safety Razor Company have amended the corporation's by-laws to shift its annual meeting to the third Thursday in April from the third Thursday in March.

A small but well chosen group of oarsmen is gathered in the handsome boat house of the Naval Academy ready to meet the first. invaders of the year, the sweepswingers of Columbia, who are due in town tomorrow in time for an afternoon workout before the two institutions share in the official opening of the Eastern rowing season Saturdav.

Miss Lorraine Barlow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Main Barlow of Greens Farms Road, Greens Farms, has selected June 11 as the date for her marriage to George E. Kirsten of Greenfield Hill. The wedding will take place at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport.

The Right Rev. Frank W. Sterrett, a trustee of Lehigh University, speaking on "The Preservation of American Ideals in Our Colleges" at the annual Conference of Trustees of Colleges and Universities today, made a plea for freedom of speech and expression. He assailed loyalty oaths and the "suggested muzzling or censoring of honest teaching by real or implied threats of discipline."

Robert E. Sherwood and Mrs. Sherwood will depart tomorrow in the Conte di Savoia for a vacation trip to Italy, Greece and France before settling down for the Summer at their English country home in Surrey.

Assets of the 13,974 insured commercial banks in the United States on Dec. 31 amounted to $56,300,000,000, compared with $50,900,000,000 a year earlier, or a gain of 10.7 per cent, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. announced today.

A plea that this country take the lead in striving to prevent war between "any nations anywhere on the face of the earth" was voiced by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd at a mass meeting tonight in the Municipal Convention Hall.
A report on twin celestial bodies, self-eclipsing stars 300 trillion miles away, was announced today at. the University of Arizona.

A total of thirty-two awards have been made to members of four Manhattan College Winter sports teams, it was announced yesterday by Brother Anselm, director of athletics. Nineteen varsity letters, including eleven for basketball and eight for swimming, were among the insignia presented.
Plans to raise $4,000,000 for the Carnegie Institute of Technology at Pittsburgh were announced yesterday by Dr. Robert E. Doherty, its president.
Proxies to be voted at the forthcoming annual meeting of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, under reorganization proceedings before Federal Judge Holly in

Mayor La Guardia and William F. Carey, Sanitation Commissioner, inspected a new mechanical loader yesterday which is designed to lift heavy cans of garbage and ashes from the pavement 'o Sanitation Department trucks.

Governors Island Paragraph 6, Special Orders 86, April 14, 1937, relating to 1st Lt. William G. Renshaw. Inf-Res., is revoked. Verbal orders relieving 1st Lt. William G. Renshaw, Inf-Res., from further assignment and duty with CCC Co. 2208, Camp CE-18 (NY), Wawayanda, N. Y., and directing him to proceed to CCC Co. 212, Camp SP-11 (NY), Laurens, N. Y., for assignment, are confirmed and made of record.
The will of Mrs. Jennie C. H. Denton of Greenwich, who died on Feb. 28, 1936, left an estate in excess of $300,000 to her daughter, Miss Dorothy Denton of Old Greenwich.

A net income of $9,947,712 for the first quarter of 1937 was reported today by the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation after deductions for interest on funded debt, depreciation, provision for estimated income-and other taxes and other charges.

Madison Square Garden continued its legal battle for an injunction against the Jimmy Braddock-Joe Louis bout yesterday by charging that Braddock "is putting forward his greed as equitable defense" for repudiating his contract to meet Max Schmeling for the Garden here June 3.

A $750,000 planetarium and institute of popular science is to be built on the site of the old Alleghany City Hall, now used to house the North Side Police Station and fire alarm system, according to Mayor Scully.

One hundred and fifty-five students and faculty advisers from twenty-three colleges and universities today opened the eleventh annual sessions of the Middle Atlantic division of the Model Assembly of the League of Nations.
A riot this morning among inmates of the Presidio Maria Zelia, a penitentiary at Sao Paulo, is believed to have caused more than a score of casualties.
Dick Shikat, former heavyweight wrestling champion of the world, defeated Bobby Bruns, his German compatriot, in the feature grappling exhibition at the New York Hippodrome last night.

From a highly competent source fully cognizant of Germany's economic and political situation this correspondent has obtained an authoritative exposition of the Reich's attitude toward a world economic conference and the soundings now progressing toward determining the advisability of calling one.

Jacob Gruber, counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he expected to complete his presentation of testimony against W. E. Hutton Co. this week. The hearing, on a charge that the firm manipulated stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation, began on Feb. 8.
Mrs. Violet Wells Norton testified today that she is convinced that Clark Gable, screen idol, is the "Frank Billings" she named as the unwed father of her daughter.

The newspaper publishers of the United States were asked last night by J. Edgar Hoover to enlist in the fight against crime. The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice made his request at the sixteenth annual dinner of the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Two books have been chosen by the Literary Guild for June. They are "Before I Forget," the autobiography.of Burton Rascoe, which Doubleday, Doran will publish, and "King Edward VIII," by Hector Bolitho, which will be published by Lippincott.

The Canberra Conference of Protectors of Aborigines passed a resolution today recommending the absorption of half castes by whites with education and employment at white standards as the only solution of the half-caste problem.

For an hour last night radio listeners heard how a newspaper was made, from police report to the delivery truck pulling away for the city's newstands, in a National Broadcasting Company broadcast titled "THE NEW YORK TIMES GOES to Press."

The problem of finding and developing men for skilled jobs, and technical discussions of various phases of production marked the closing session today of the American Management Association. More than 500 production executives from manufacturing companies in all parts of the United States attended the conference, which opened yesterday.

Declaring that increased costs, especially taxes, were responsible for reduced earnings, the directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company yesterday cut the regular quarterly dividend on the company's capital stock from 75 cents a share to 40 cents, tantamount to placing the stock on an annual basis of $1.60 a share, against $3 formerly.
Lumber production increased less than seasonally last week and the adjusted index declined to 84.1 from 85.0. It was 77.3 for the week ended April 18, 1936.

Turpentine firm, 351/2c. Sales, 110 barrels; receipts, 199 barrels; shipments, 522 barrels; stock. 22,986 barrels. Resin firm. Sales, 506; receipts, 682; shipments, 2,441; stock, 45,198. Quote: B, $7; D. $7.10; E, $7.50; F. G. H, $8.021/2; I, K, M, N, $8.05; WG, $8.10; WW, X, $8.75.

Three goals by Tony Lemay, flashy center, gave England's Wembley Lions a 3-3 overtime draw with the Sudbury Tigers, newly crowned Allan Cup champions, in the first game of their best-of-three series for the
The text of the statement issued by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor tonight was as follows:
The committee on commencement at Dartmouth today made public a list of twelve seniors invited to compete for the three speaking assignments before their classmates in June. The twelve are Wayne K.

A ten-point program of "must action" to prevent crime was outlined yesterday by L. B. Nichols, Administrative Assistant of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, at the annual convention of the American Physical Education Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The eight-and-a-half-acre estate of Daisy C. Rowland on the Boston Post Road at Rye, N. Y., has been purchased by Edward H. Davis of New York, publisher of business papers.

Wise Prince, coal black son of Wise Counsellor, showed a liking for the heavy, holding track here today and won the featured Landsdowne Purse, a six-furlong sprint. Making his first start of the year, the 5-year-old had to be put to pressure by Harry Richards to hold a half-length advantage over the Bomar Stable's Billy'Bee. Clingendaal, the lightweight of the field of six, was third, a length farther back.

Edwin Goodman, president of Bergdorf-Goodman, gave a dinner last night in-the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to open the drive of the department stores, apparel trades and resident buyers division, of which he is chairman, to fill its quota of $150,000 in the campaign of the Joint Distribution Committee and United Palestine Appeal.

Manhattan ARNOLD, GRACE (April 19). Estate more than $10,000. To Frances Arnold niece, Windsor, Vt., $5,000; Edna Rapallo, sister, 129 E. 29th St., one-half residue; Constance A. Rapallo, sister executrix, 129 E. 29th St., $20,000 and one-half residue.

Anti-Semitism is now part and parcel of the program of the new government party, the "Camp of National Unity" created at the order of Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz and sponsored by President Ignaz Moscicki. This was made clear, according to leaders of Polish Jewry, in a special communique published by the Camp's "chief of staff," Colonel Jan Kowalewski, explaining his press statement of yesterday that Jews were not eligible for membership in the new party.
Governor Lehman today reappointed John J. Merrill of Alfred, and John P. Hennessey of Syracuse, as members of the Tax Commission. The nominations were confirmed immediately by the Senate.

Fifteen fellowships were awarded today by the Harvard Law School for the next academic year, in the amount of $20,200. A teaching fellowship was given to William B. Lockart, an attorney of Des Moines, Iowa.

Due to tne increasd business, plans have been made by the National Broadcasting Company for a program of expansion and building in six cities, according to an announcement yesterday by Lenox Lohr, president.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed no change in any of the important items. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank reached a new low figure for the year.

The People's Chorus of New York, Lorenzo Camilieri, conductor, observed its twenty-first anniversary last night in Carnegie Hall with a Spring Festival, in which it was assisted by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and a full house of friends.

The $17,500,000 estimated cost of the new suspension bridge to be built from Whitestone, Queens, to Old Ferry Point, the Bronx, should be divided between the Triborough Bridge Authority, which will construct the new span, and the city in the same manner as the cost of the Triborough Bridge was divided, Robert Moses held yesterday.

In a three-hour conversation between Premier Benito Mussolini and Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano on the Italian side and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt on the Austrian this afternoon, Mussolini delivered a death blow to Dr. Schuschnigg's hopes of obtaining Italian support for restoration of the monarchy in Austria.

Four weeks have now passed since the Chrysler workers marched out of the plants which they had seized in defiance of the laws of Michigan, and during this period the country has had fewer sit-down strikes than at any time since the ??.
The claims of the 'have not' nations are being formulated in three principles which, according to Asahi, Japan will submit to the League of Nations Raw Materials Commission in June.

Charles Chaplin, the screen actor and producer, was charged with stealing ideas and sequences from the French movie "A Nous La Liberte" for his 1932 production "Modern Times" in a suit filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Films Sonores Tobis, Societe Anonyme.

The Soviet Union was held up as "one of the pillars of world peace" and as a democratic government employing to a certain degree dictatorial methods in an emergency for defense by Alexander A. Troyanovsky, the Russian Ambassador, in an address at a luncheon today of the National Press Club.

Member organizations of the United States Chamber of Commerce are asked to state, in a referendum started today, whether they favor a proposal of the chamber's transportation committee that "the longand-short-haul clause" of the Interstate Commerce Act be repealed.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 21: COLONELS Burnette. C., Cav., Ft. Oglethorpe, Ga.. detailed in the Bureau of Insular Affairs, Washington. D. C.

E. J. Kulas, president of the Ohio Steel Company and the Midland Steel Products Company, which supplies steel for automotive purposes, said yesterday that he expected production of automobiles to continue at high levels through the shares Summer.

The women swimmers of New York University won their twelfth annual meet with the Savage School for Physical Education team last night. Winning all save one of the six events in the American Woman's Association pool, N. Y. U. scored 29 to 25.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for various alterations in Manhattan and for three tenement houses and a motion picture theatre in the Bronx. The plans follow:

In just a few weeks a natural phenomenon will take place in a great body of water out on Long Island. It is the annual run of weakfish in Peconic Bay, the greatest concen tration of that species in one body of water anywhere along the Atlantic Coast.
THOMAS MANN sails for his exile's home in Switzerland after a very brief visit, but he has been with us long enough to leave behind him the permanent impress of a noble spirit.

Edwin Markham, the poet, was guest of honor at a testimonial dinner last night in the Meurot Club, St. George, S. I. The dinner, given by a citizens committee headed by Borough President Joseph A. Palma, was in honor of the poet's eighty-fifth birthday.

Icy water ran down the grooves of National Guardsmen's bayonets here tonight and sleet and snow crusted on their shoes as they obeyed the order of Governor Lewis O. Barrows to control rioting growing out of the four-week-old shoe strike called in nineteen plants of the Lewiston-Auburn area by the Committee for Industrial Organization.

CURTAIN CALL, a play in two acts and seven scenes, by LeRoy Bailey. Staged by Dickson Morgan; settings by Cleon Throckmorton; produced by Jack Quigley and Irving Schachtel. At the John Golden Theatre.

Passengers sailing today for Ireland and England on the Cunard White Star liner Scythia include Lieut. Commander Alastair MacKenzie, Colonel Mackenzie Waters, Lieut. Col. Teizo Tokeda, Miss Griselda Ellis, Miss Geraldine Jackson, E. B. Proctor, Mr. and Mrs. M. B. Flynn, Charles Drury, Miss Mary H. Hinton and Miss Dorothy Park.
Mrs. Hetty Sylvia Howland Green Wilks, daughter of the late Hetty Green, was called to the witness stand here yesterday but counsel got very little from her, even her age.

With the arrest of fourteen contractors and two notorious gangsters yesterday, John J. Bennet Jr., State Attorney General, disclosed an alleged labor racket involving painting and decorating contracts in Brooklyn and Queens public schools amounting to $2,000,000.
Mr. and Mrs. Harold Dennis of Newark gave a dinner at the Greenbrier tonight for Mr. and Mrs. L. H. Conklin of New York and Mrs. Henry Iselin.

Following another twenty-four-hour interruption forced by heavy rain, the Nationalist (Insurgent] offensive on the Bilbao front was resumed this morning in bright sunshine under an almost cloudless sky. Before 6 o'clock this evening Mount Carrascain and Mount Saretti were captured as well as other heights dominating El Gueta to the west and El Orrio to the north.

Plans for an increase in the number of buyers' groups functioning under the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association from four to twelve were made by the board of the division at a meeting here yesterday.
The appointment of Mrs. BORDEN HARRIMAN as Minister to Norway strengthens the precedent made by the President when he named Mrs. RUTH BRYAN OWEN Minister to Denmark.

Miss Mary E. De Maria, daughter of Alphonse De Maria of Red Bank, and Dr. Frank P. Pignataro, son of Mr. and Mrs. P. Pignataro of Middletown, were married this morning at a nuptial mass at St. James's Roman Catholic Church here. Rev. Dr. J. B. McCloskey officiated.

Oshawa negotiators approved terms for settlement of the General Motors Canada strike, which were accepted last night by the 300 shop stewards. The workers were called to a mass meeting today for ratification of the agreement. Page 1.

Donald Douglas, president of the Douglas Aircraft Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Santa Monica, Calif., yesterday, that the outlook for a dividend was very hopeful, provided additional orders received did not require too much additional working capital.

Two men were burned to death and a third injured yesterday in a fire that followed an explosion in the basement of a building at 322 Warren Street, Brooklyn. The building is used as a garage and warehouse by J. Michaels, Inc., a furniture concern.
Reversing a former ruling the Internal Revenue Bureau has ruled that the 50 per cent tax on silver transactions is deductible from gross income in the preparation of Federal income tax returns.

The stock markets were quiet today, but a steadier tendency prevailed in most sections. Gilt-edge issues made fresh headway and industrials also were slightly better. Among the foreign loans, German bonds continued in demand.
Golfers in the Greater New York area will have opportunities to test two solutions of the troublesome stymie problem in this Summer's tournaments.

Horace C. Stoneham will forget for a day that he is the president of the New York Giants and, ignoring the Giant opening at the Polo Grounds, will take part in the inaugural program of the Jersey City ball club today at the new Roosevelt Stadium.
A yearning for ner 10-year-old daughter, whom she had not seen since Christmas Eve, led yesterday to the arrest of Mrs. Helen K.

W. L. Ross, who resigned as president of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad in 1933, received total compensation last year of $22,500 from that company and another which it jointly controls, according to reports filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission and made public yesterday.
Under his administration, Mayor La Guardia asserted yesterday afternoon, civil service in the city has been administered in strict accord with the laws of the State for the first time in history.

Charles Pinnell of Fred Butterfield Co. was re-elected president of the Textile Color Card Association at the annual meeting of the organization held yesterday at its headquarters, 200 Madison Avenue.

In the search for more revenues to meet higher expenditures, both the British and the American Governments have placed heavier burdens on their corporations, and have subjected them not merely, to one but to several different taxes.

The Four Aces and the team headed by Fred D. Kaplan entered the semi-final round of the team-of-four championship of the grand national contract bridge tournament of the United States Bridge Association as play in the quarter-finals ended yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Montclair.
A three-year plan for the further development of industry and communication within the Kwantung Province of China,

The Pressed Steel Car Company is looking for a purchaser for this Beaver County town. Two months ago Koppel found itself an industrial community of 600 persons without any industries, when the company moved the equipment of its subsidiary, the Koppel Industrial Car and Equipment Company, to McKees Rocks.

The Air Conditioning Manufacturing Association reported today that the installed cost of equipment sold by members broke all records in March and in the first quarter of this year. March's sales totaled $17,137,870, compared to $5,531,656 in March, 1936, an increase of 209.8 per cent.

Mrs. Robert H. Meck of this city died Tuesday in Washington, where she was serving as an alternate from the Orange Mountain Chapter at the Daughters of the American Revolution congress, according to word received here today. She was 61 years old.

Robert Campbell MacCombie Auld, a leader in Scottish societies here and an authority on Scottish history and on Robert Burns, the poet, from whom he was descended, died on Wednesday of a paralytic stroke at the Home for Incurables, the Bronx, after a fiveweek illness.

Mischa Rosenbaum, a musician and theatrical agent also known as Mischa Ross, was arraigned yesterday before Judge William Allen in the Court of General Sessions to plead to an indictment charging him with murder in the first degree for the slaying last Sunday of Julia Nussenbaum, a violinist.

A new scientific approach to the study of virus diseases, such as infantile paralysis and the common cold, has been opened up, Dr. W. M. Stanley of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research said today, in the isolation of a virus which is both living and non-living.

A one-man show of canvases by the distinguished German artist, Lovis Corinth, opened to the public yesterday at the Westermann Galleries, 24 West Forty-eighth Street, to remain current until May 21. So far as our records reveal, this is the painter's first solo apipearance in New York. Corinth, who was born in East Prussia in 1858, died twelve years ago.
Changing the name of the TransLux Daylight Picture -Screen Corporation to the Trans-Lux Corporation will be considered by shareholders at their general meeting here on May 12.

Mrs. Percy M. Kessler of Washington has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Mershon Kessler, to Lieutenant Laurance Hilliard Brownlee, Coast Artillery Corps, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Bedell Brownlee of Woodmere, L. I. The wedding will take place late in May.
Steps will be taken at once to begin improvement of North Beach Airport, Queens, into a first-class terminal for sea and land planes, Dock Commissioner John McKenzie said yesterday.
Elections to the honor societies of the Yale academic department and the Sheffield Scientific School were announced today as follows: AURELIAN Ogden Miller (honorary membership).
In a dull, damp and discouraging setting at Ruppert Stadium the curtain was raised on the 1937 International League campaign today as the Bears turned in an 8-to-5 victory over the Montreal Royals.

A group calling itself the Stockholders Association of the Pittsburgh Terminal Coal Corporation issued yesterday a call for proxies for use at the annual meeting of the corporation on May 4. The letter was signed by Alexander Guttmann of 39 Broadway, executive director of the association.
William Douglas, builder of one of the first successful motor cycles, whose machines were extensively used by the British Army during the World War, died in Bristol today at the age of 78.
President Roosevelt received Dr. Hans Luther, the retiring German Ambassador, and devoted the day to routine matters.

A plot 200 by 100 feet, on the west side of 195th Street, 282 feet south of Forty-fifth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, has been purchased by the Rev. John B. Delea for St. Kevin's Church from the Schumacher estate.

Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, winner at Pinehurst, barely exed out a victory over Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York today to gain the final round of the women's Mason-Dixon tennis championship with Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of Boston at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

A committee for New York, Westchester Boston Railway firstmortgage 5 1/2 per cent bondholders, headed by Irving D. Steinhardt, issued yesterday an appeal for support in a plea which it is proposed to make in the Federal court in New Haven Monday that the company be continued in operation for nine months to one year longer.

Channing A. Leidy, newspaper man and former assistant to the late Maurice E. Connolly, Borough President of Queens, died yesterday at his home, 415 West 118th Street, of heart disease. He was 68 years old.
Mrs. Ernest Frederick Eidlitz gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 920 Fifth Avenue, and later took her guests to the exhibition of Japanese Flower Arrangements at The Nippon Club.

The Works Progress Adminstrattion reported today that it had 2,714 790 workers on its rolls March 27, Officials said the rolls will have to be cut eventually if President Roosevelt's $1,500,000 relief apporpriation recommentdation goes thorugh Unofficial esimeates fixed 1,786.000

On trial under a cluster of thorn trees, the divorced queen of the powerful regent chief of the Bamamgwato tribe pleaded guilty today to charges of trying to harm the queen mother by mystic potions and incantations.

Hazard faced a water famine today following a Health Department order condemning the source of supply as contaminated. Dr. D. D. Turner, health officer, said the water was poisoned by a slate fire at mines five miles from Hazard, where a small stream empties into the Kentucky River.

The discussion of war debts in the British House of Commons today was regarded by government officials as confirming the view held here since the general series of defaults began that the question is not a closed one.

A forecast of showers failed to dampen enthusiasm around Drake Relay headquarters tonight as hundreds of the country's best athletes poured into Des Moines for the twenty-eighth annual track and field carnival.
Mr. Matthews, writer of the following dispatch, has been Madrid correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES for four months. He is now visiting London.

The seven major railroads in the metropolitan area requested a special Federal statutory court yesterday to annul an order of the Interstate Commerce Commission which would prohibit them from giving alleged unlawful warehouse storage concessions to shippers at less than cost.

First evidence that rodents existed on the earth before the early Eocene Age of 60,000,000 years ago, and that they originated in North America instead of Asia, was presented to the American Philosophical Society today by Dr. Glenn L. Jepsen of Princeton University.

Argentina has signed a new reciprocal trade treaty with the Netherlands by which she reduces the tarrifs on nine groups of articles imported from the latter in exchange for an increase in the Netherland quotas on the importation of Argentine meats, edible fats and fruits.

The six-story apartment at 606-616 W 142d St was sold by the 610 W 14 St Corp. Joseph Schwartz, president, to the Eden Management Corp. Morton Wasserman, president, for an indicated consideration of $33.000 over the mortgage of $250.000, the buyer giving back a purchase money mortgage for $17,500, due in five years at 6 per cent.
Condition of Federal Reserve Banks: During the week ended April 21 member bank reserve balances decreased $24,000,000.

Drawing a parallel between the attacks on President Roosevelt and the abuse heaped by the Tories upon Thomas Jefferson, Postmaster General Farley, in an address here tonight, declared that the courts must keep in step with social and economic changes or American democracy will be doomed.

A fighting Princeton University Rugby team battled the Hofstra College fifteen to a 0-0 deadlock today on rain-swept Bedford Field. In a preliminary engagement the Hofstra seconds turned back the Tiger jayvees, 5 to 3.
The list of 164 fellowships and scholarships awarded by Columbia University, as announced in yesterday's TIMES, is an imposing array.

An effort to make Congress economyconscious by pointing to the threat of a sales tax or of increased income levies in the lower brackets has been started at the Capitol by some leaders who are endeavoring to reduce Federal expenditures to balance the budget and avoid tax rises, both now and in 1938.

A "go slow" strike started at 8 o'clock this morning, partly paralyzing Tokyo municipal street cars, which are running at only half speed. Thousands of the poorer workers who travel long distances for a two-cent. fare were severely inconvenienced.

Joseph J. Collins, secretary to Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City since 1917, died today at his home here of heart disease after an illness of several months. He was 47 years old. Mr. Collins had been employed as a stenographer in the Jersey City City Hall during the administration of the late Mayor H. Otto

Gifts to Yale University totaling more than $175,000 were today announced by the Yale Corporation, following its April meeting. The largest were $50,000 from the estate of John A. Garver, '75, increasing to $151,000 the endowment of the Garver Professorship of Law, and $61,666 from the Rockefeller Foundation for Research and Publication.

Four younger set members, the Misses Emily French and Elise Connett of South Orange and Amanda Pope and Mary Humphries of Orange, will act as models tomorrow afternoon for "Fashions in Flower," wearing costumes to illustrate the use of flowers, at the annual Spring bridge for the benefit of the Episcopal House of the Holy Comforter in the parish house of Grace Church, Orange.

Jacob and Emil Leitner, Inc. has placed for the Wardmar Realty Corp a permanent loan of $90,000 with the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank for ten years, with interest for five years at 41/2 per cent and for the remaining five years at 5 per cent. on the apartment on the west side of Sherman Ave. 114 feet north of 167th St, the Bronx.

A Gift Horse Party was given yesterday afternoon on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis under the auspices of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work as one of several events scheduled to take place during the extensive membership drive being conducted by the organization to enlist public support in its philanthropic projects.

MANHATTAN BEHR. PETER B. (April 23, 1936). Gross assets. $14,758; net, $11,952. To Elizabeth L. Behr, widow, residue of $8,952; Gladys B. Barstow, sister, Benjamin L. Behr, and Edward L. Behr, brothers, $1,000 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $13,836. Lydecker, Van Riper, attorneys, 258 Broadway.

An investigation to determine minimum costs of "adequate maintenance and protection of health," as the first step in the enforcement of the State's new Minimum Wage Law for women and minors, was unanimously approved yesterday at a meeting of the Minimum Wage Conference and State Labor Department officials.

An attempt will be made by Senator Lonergan to substitute a Stream Pollution Bill without specific authorization for funds for the one passed yesterday by the House authorizing $1,000,000 a year for ten years for studies and experiments in stream purification.

Rising opposition on the Republican side of Senate and Assembly against the Republican revenue program sponsored by Chairman Moffat of the Assembly Ways and, Means Committee brought again to the front today Governor Lehman's plan to increase by $20,000,000 the tax on gasoline.

Mrs. Henry R. Caraway has been re-elected president of the Women's National Republican Club, the club announced yesterday after its annual meeting at 3 West Fiftyfirst Street. Five new members elected to the board of directors are Virginia Blood, Mrs. Ira Campbell, Jane H. Todd, Mrs. Clarence Blair Mitchell and Mrs. Kenneth M. Reed. Those re-elected are Mrs.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended April 22 were announced today: BRIGADIER GENERALS Williams R. H., headquarters. Washington, D. C., to duty as commanding general, first Marine Brigade. Fleet Marine Force, Quantico, Va., June 1.
The doors of the Hobo College swung shut today and from Slim Brundage, the founder, came an appeal to the poets to save its good name.

The annual report for 1936 of the J. I. Case Company, to be made public today by Leon R. Clausen, president, shows a net income of $3,083,281 after provision for depreciation, interest and provision for Federal and State income taxes, including approximately $100,000 for Federal undistributed profits tax.

On a brisk December day fifty years ago a 19-year-old railroad telegrapher whose monthly salary was $60 and a Kansas farm girl of 17 were married. Together, they had $4-hardly enough to pay the minister.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I, as an employe of an agency distributing offshore refined sugar in the American market, reply to the letter of W. P. C.? My job is just as important to me as his is to him, and my job is now more seriously threatened than his will ever be.

The silver anniversary dinner of Brooklyn Insurance Brokers Association will be held on May 11 in the Towers Hotel, Charles Reppa, chairman of the dinner committee, announced yesterday. Mortimer Weinberg, a past president of the association, will be toastmaster.

A former dishwasher whose advances a 25-year-old waitress had repulsed was sought yesterday by the police following the discovery of her body yesterday morning in the vestibule of her home at 628 West 114th Street.
Mrs. Marcus M. Marks, widow of the Borough President of Manhattan, died of a heart ailment yesterday in her home at 300 Park Avenue. She was 67 years old.

Guild Hall at East Hampton, L. I., the gift of Mrs. Lorenzo E. Woodhouse eight years ago and maintained by public subscription for the benefit of music art and drama in the community, was the beneficiary of a dinner dance last night in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's.
No fresh approach to the solution of the problem of the war debts is indicated in the statement made in the House of Commons yesterday by the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Directors of the Diamond Match Company declared yesterday a dividend of four-fiftieths of a share of Pan-American Match Corporation stock of $25 par value on each share of Diamond common stock, in addition to two cash dividends of 25 cents a share each. They leclared also a dividend of onefiftieth of a share of Pan-American Match stock on each preferred share.

Sherman Ave, 1,225 (9-2453); Wardmar Realty Corp to Emigrant Industrial savings Bank; demand, 4'_ to 5 per cent: S12,5008 169th St. 87 W (9-2519); Irma Management Corp to Merit Factors Corp, 41 iE 57th St; demand, 6 per cent; $13,000. 148th St. 240-242 E (9-2336); Glow Realty Corp to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtgs to April 20, 1942, at 3% to 4% per

The Interborough Rapid Transit system, including subway and elevated lines, carried 92,050,270 passengers in March, according to a report submitted yesterday to Federal Judge Julian W. Mack by Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver.

Operators and investors participated yesterday in housing transactions in the Yorkville section. In the vicinity of Carl Schurz Park an investor bought the fivestory triple tenement house at 1,617 York Avenue, northwest corner of Eighty-fifth Street, from Rose Hartman, who acquired it recently from George W. Diggons and Nathan H. Stern.

The following Coast Guard orders for the week ended April 21 were announced today: Hamingway, Cmdr. H. G., the Samuel D; Ingham, to office of Eastern Inspector. Ryan, Cmdr. M. J., to command the Samuel D. Ingham, until that vessel is relieved from Bering Sea patrol, then to resume duty in the Seattle Division.

Professor Millar Burrows of the Yale Divinity School, president of the American Schools of Oriental Research, announced today the excavation in Transjordan of a pagan temple of the time of Christ and said that the finds, which include reliefs of pagan deities and several well-preserved examples of portrait sculpture, afford new and valuable material for the study of the culture of the little-known Nabataeans.

Thomas McGrath, veteran actor, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital from a complication of diseases. He was 79 years old. Born in Boston, he made his stage debut with the Boston Theatre company in English melodramas,
The Admiralty today announced plans for the battleship Royal Oak to relieve the battle cruiser Hood in Bay of Biscay waters of Northern Spain.

Mrs. Enzabeth Baron Cleaver, widow of the Rev. Joseph Bradford Cleaver, pastor of the Central Christian Church, 142 West Eighty-first Street, died yesterday at her home, 541 West 113th Street, after a short illness. She was 77 years old. Mrs.

The Cotton-Textile Institute's National Cotton Week idea book, titled "Here's How," is being distributed to thousands of merchants throughout the country who will participate in this year's event, starting May 31.

Reorganization of the army, removal of conscription limitations, the fortification of "weak spots" along the frontiers and an increase in her air force are part of Czechoslovakia's answer to Germany's growing legions and Chancellor Adolf Hitler's drangg nach osten" dream.

Death Announced Fireman 1st grade John A. Kearney of Engine 214 died April 20. Funeral wil take place from his late residence, 380 E 35th St., Brooklyn, at 11 A. M., Friday April 23. Interment at Calvary Cemetery Queens.
The Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice is undergoing a reorganization, Attorney General Cummings stated today.

Gustavus Sylvester Kimball, teacher and editor, died last evening at his home, 465 West Twenty-third Street, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was born in Yale, Mich., in 1860 and began teaching at the age of 15 in the rural schools of his State.

Renewed liquidation in the speculative commodities carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices slightly lower in the last week, the index declining to 144.2 on Tuesday from 144.3 (revised) the Tuesday previous.

After two weeks of buying, ag, gregating $56,356,000, the Federal Reserve System brought its openmarket purchases of government securities to a halt this week, it was disclosed in the system's report, issued yesterday. The condition report of the twelve Reserve Banks combined showed total holdings of $2,486,583,000 of "governs ments," unchanged from week before.

Dr. Hans Luther, the retiring German Ambassador, said good-bye to President Roosevelt at the White House today. He explained that, although he was not leaving immediately, he would be gone before the President returns from his fishing trip off Texas, for which Mr. Roosevelt will start from Washington April 28.

The Tome baseball team won, 9 to 6, from Marblehead High School of Massachusetts today in a see-saw game. Murphy's homer and McDevitt's relief pitching helped to give Tome a winning margin, while the playing of Hayes, Driscoll and Patram stood out for the visitors.

State retail organizations in fifteen States have affiliated with the American Retail Federation, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting of a group of New York merchants at which the research and organization programs of the federation were discussed.

The shipbuilding industry showed a healthy growth last year despite the fact that orders for sea-going merchant tonnage were confined to tanker construction, according to the annual report of H. Garrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders.

Wells F. Wise. at 10 Midchester Ave., White Plains, Westchester, Chauncey B. Griffen, broker. Richard Thornton, at 93 Greenacres Ave, Scarsdale; John Schneberger, at 11 Boulevard; Robert Schneider, at 8 Rutgers Place;

Last week Business activity in the Pittsburgh District recovered part of the loss suffered in the preceding two weeks. Changes in coal production and coal shipments have been largely responsible for fluctuations in the district's business in the last three weeks.
The House Rules Committee approved a resolution today under which the Doughton bill for repeal of the income-tax salary-list publication will be brought up in the House for action.

Irving G. Rudow of 420 Central Park West, president of the B. and R. Clothing Company, was arraigned yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora, charged with having filed a false State income tax return, and was released in $1,000 bail after he had pleaded not guilty.
E. John Dugan, terrace apartment: Dr. George H. Koegler; William Albert; Lewis Hiler; Charles N. Thorp; Helen D. Lambeth, in 5 Riverside Drive; by Orpington Estates, Inc.

Trading on the West Side was featured by the sale of the thirteenstory and penthouse apartment building at 124 West Seventy-second Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, and the adjoining five-story house at 128 West Seventy-second Street.

The Federa Trade Commission today announced approval of rules of fair trade practice for the tubular pipings and trimmings manufacturing industry which, in general, are similar to those adopted for other industries.
A lease of an additional floor of 10,000 square feet taken by the Norcross Publishing Company in 244 Madison Avenue featured the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday.

Zeke Bonura and Monte Stratton were thorns in the flesh of the Browns today as the White Sox evened the two-game series with a 6-to-1 victory. Five hits, only one for extra bases, were all the heavy-hitting Browns of yesterday could garner off the delivery of Stratton.

Frank Diodine of 5-13 124th Street, College Point, Queens, a pressman in the rotogravure department of THE NEW YORK TIMES for twenty-three years, died on Wednesday in New York Hospital after an illness of six months. He was 60 years old.
The Coffee Growers Federation has suspended purchases of the commodity from Colombian growers in a move designed to stabilize prices as further funds are unavailable, according to the Espectador.

The consolidated report of the Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended March 31, shows a net income of $8,751,753, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to $4.71 a share on the common stock outstanding,

The Treasury today invited bids for two series of discount bills of $50,000,000 each. One series will be of 141-day maturity and mature on Sept. 16, 1937; the other, of 273-day maturity, will mature on Jan. 26, 1938.

Dr. Samuel Pierson, a leading physician and surgeon in Stamford for half a century, died tonight in Stamford Hospital. He was 79 years old. Surviving are three sons, Samuel N. Pierson and Norris E. Pierson of Stamford and Dr. Richard N. Pierson of New York.

The State Racing Commission today absolved trainer Bert S. Michell of any knowledge that Mrs. Emil Denemark's filly All Round was illegally stimulated at Tropical Park, but ruled him off the turf for sixty days under a regulation that holds the trainer responsible for his horses.

The general debate on the budget ended in the House of Commons tonight with the members silently accepting the principle of the proposal by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, for an excess profits tax.
Rio, by Hugh Gibson. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.50.) The Ambassador to Brazil writes of Rio de Janeiro.

Sholem Asch, novelist and playwright, arrived yesterday from Nice on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to make a two months' tour of the large cities of the United States on behalf of the $4,650,000 campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, for aid to distressed Jews overseas.

With retail sales during the last four to five weeks falling below both expectations and budgeted figures, the advance in prices is developing a "public buying resistance that is very real and sharp," Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, said yesterday at a luncheon held by the National Notion Association in the Hotel ??.

Commodity futures were generally steady in lessened activity on the local markets yesterday. On the cash market butter, tin, silk, wool tops, corn and lard gained, but cocoa, zinc, printcloths, rubber, wheat, rye and oats fell.
Continued weakness in United States Government bonds yesterday carried almost all other classes of domestic loans to lower levels in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The strike called by the International Longshoremen's Association against ships of the Cunard White Star and Furness-Withy lines over its jurisdictional dispute with the National Independent Longshoremen's Union, a Canadian organization, for control of the longshoremen in the port of Montreal, continued yesterday as officials of both organizations were striving to adjust the controversy.

The following appointments to the United States Building and Loan League were announced yesterday. F. J. Ludeman, assistant deputy superintendent of the Banking Department of New York, is to be a member of the supervisors' division of the league:
Mrs. Paul Fitz Simons of Newport is expected to arrive today at the Savoy-Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. Reginald L. M. McVitty of Tivoli, N. Y., are at 14 East Sixtieth Street.

Election of Christie E. Cuddeback as vice president of the Sheffield Farms Company was announced here yesterday by Leroy A. Van Bomel, president of the company. Mr. Cuddeback, who will direct the company's entire sales program, succeeds his father, Alva Cuddeback, who retired as vice president a week ago after more than fifty years in the milk business.

With the directors of the United States Steel Corporation due to meet for dividend action on Tuesday, there is no clue as to what action may be taken beyond the hope expressed by Myron C. Taylor, the corporation's chairman, at the recent annual meeting that the holders of common stock might not have to wait overlong to receive "a reward for their patience."
A fight over the issue of the Committee for Industrial Organization today split the Georgia Federation of Labor's annual convention into two factions, each holding a separate meeting.

The corner stone of the new hospital building of the Bronx Eye and Ear Infirmary at East Tremont Avenue and Echo Place, the Bronx, will be laid tomorrow at 3 P. M. it was announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman, chairman of the committee in charge.

The Tranquillity Farm's Teddy Green, dismissed from consideration after his poor showing last Monday, jumped back into the Kentucky Derby picture today as he galloped off with the Crystal Springs Purse, featured mile and a sixteenth allowance event.

The Japanese Army hopes the efforts to improve relations between North China and Japan will be further advanced when a delegation of sixteen North China officials, headed by General Chang Tse-chung, Tientsin's Mayor and trusted subordinate of General Sung Chehyuan, head of the Hopei-Chahar Political Council, departs tomorrow for a tour of Japan.

The State's Attorney today asked the People's Tribunal to sentence the Rev. Joseph Rossaint, chief defendant in the Catholic treason trial, to fifteen years in the penitentiary. One to seven year sentences were asked for the other six involved.

The varsity, junior varsity and freshman crews of Columbia held their final workout on the Harlem River yesterday for the meeting with Navy rivals tomorrow. The Blue oarsmen will leave this morning for Annapolis.
The Hall bill legalizing dog racing in New York State under supervision of the State Racing Commission was passed by the Senate today and now goes to the Governor.
Mayor La Guardia praised the work of the New York Urban League yesterday when he received members of the 1937 campaign committee at City Hall.

Movement of vessels follow, all dates are April 21,unless specified: Port Angeles to Dutch Harbor: Cincinnati, Concord, Dewey, Hull, MacDonough, New Mexico, Worden. At Shanghai, April 22: Edsall, Pope. Case, Hamilton, Bermuda, to Casablanca, Mor.

Movements in the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow: HOGS Receipts 13,000 including 5,000 direct. Early market strong to 10 cents higher than Wednesday's average; top 10.45; bulk good and choice. 200-320 pounds.

Labor difficulties flared up again in May's department store, 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, causing a noontime disturbance which threw the store into confusion and blocked traffic outside for forty-five minutes.
Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard of this city will inherit the entire estate of her late husband, Major Elisha D. Hubbard, which an inventory listing in Probate Court today showed to be worth $192,820.

Operations of the Miami Copper Company are about at capacity, E. H. Westlake, vice president, told stockholders on Wednesday. He said that the average cost of production last year was 9 cents a pound. Because of the likelihood of competition from South African producers, he added, he was in favor of continuing the 4-cent tariff on copper.

The Wagner act decision of the Supreme Court is far more important in elation to its effect on cases arising under possible new laws than in respect to future proceedings under the collective bargaining statute, the American Newspaper Publishers Association was advised yesterday by its general counsel, Elisha Hanson.

A price war among wholesale liquor distributors disrupted discount schedules on practically all brands here yesterday. The discounts, normally ranging at 2 to 5 per cent, depending on the quantities purchased, were raised to 8 per cent yesterday morning and by nightfall had climbed as high as 121/2 per cent plus 1 per cent, with distillers, jobbers and retailers all reported making vain efforts to halt the break.

Charging American and British oil companies with acting in bad faith' because of the recent increase of 2 cents a gallon in the price of gasoline, the Cabinet authorized President Federico Laredo Bru this .afternoon to reduce the price by a proper decree.
Robert S. Ament of 70 Grove Street, formerly Sunday art director of The World, died on Wednesday at the New York Postgraduate Hospital after a short illness. His age was 57.

Mrs. Suzanne Carroll Hill, a lineal descendant of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, obtained an absolute divorce today from Brig. Gen. John Philip Hill, attorney and former Maryland Representative who is practicing law in New York.
Charles P. Taft, son of the late President, told Daughters of the American Revolution tonight that they cannot get anywhere "by painting red networks of communism across every evening sky."
E. D. Spicer, manager of the General Electric Company's plant here, announced tonight immediate wage adjustments by union agreement for all employes there.

Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin told the House of Commons today that the government would participate willingly in a world economic conference "provided a thorough and comprehensive investigation showed that such a conference would be likely to succeed and provided there had been adequate preparation."
Wayland E. Stearns, for more than thirty-one years principal of Barringer High School, died suddenly yesterday at his Winter home at St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 75 years old. He had retired in 1931.

Five men were indicted yesterday on charges of first-degree murder by the New York County grand jury in the fatal shooting of Detective Michael J. Foley in a hold-up April 10 in the Boulevard Restaurant at 144 Second Avenue.

Bank clearings for the principal cities throughout the nation totaled $5,855,725,000 for the week ended on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was a decline of 5.7 per cent from the $6,207,962,000 reported a year ago, but a gain of 15.1 per cent compared with last week.
The Cardinals made it two straight over the Reds today by taking a wild scoring contest, 14 to 11.. Manager Charley Dressen used eighteen players and St. Louis thirteen.

Virginia Blake bought for occupancy the three-story brownstone dwelling on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 382 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn. The dwelling is assessed at $7,500 and was sold by Meller Shalita, Inc., for Hazel C. Moody.

Representatives of nearly a score of liberal organizations, minority parties and labor unions will attend the hearing before Governor Lehman on the Berg election bills in Albany today, it was announced last night by the American Civil Liberties Union.

The Wagner act decision of the Supreme Court is far more important in elation to its effect on cases arising under possible new laws than in respect to future proceedings under the collective bargaining statute, the American Newspaper Publishers Association was advised yesterday by its general counsel, Elisha Hanson.

A price war among wholesale liquor distributors disrupted discount schedules on practically all brands here yesterday. The discounts, normally ranging at 2 to 5 per cent, depending on the quantities purchased, were raised to 8 per cent yesterday morning and by nightfall had climbed as high as 121/2 per cent plus 1 per cent, with distillers, jobbers and retailers all reported making vain efforts to halt the break.

Charging American and British oil companies with acting in bad faith' because of the recent increase of 2 cents a gallon in the price of gasoline, the Cabinet authorized President Federico Laredo Bru this .afternoon to reduce the price by a proper decree.
Robert S. Ament of 70 Grove Street, formerly Sunday art director of The World, died on Wednesday at the New York Postgraduate Hospital after a short illness. His age was 57.

Mrs. Suzanne Carroll Hill, a lineal descendant of Charles Carroll of Carrollton, obtained an absolute divorce today from Brig. Gen. John Philip Hill, attorney and former Maryland Representative who is practicing law in New York.
Beginning May 1, the curfew for Glens Falls persons under 16 years of age will ring nightly at 9 o'clock at the behest of the Board of Public Safety.

The Underwear Institute at its annual meeting here today adopted a resolution of opposition to the Ellenbogen bill which seeks to regulate the textile industry and which union labor is actively backing in Washington.

New Yorkers who visited the 212th Coast Artillery Armory last night saw Everett Scott, one of their former baseball heroes, come back to Gotham in the role of kegling contestant. His presence stirred interest during an otherwise uneventful-day in the American Bowling Congress championships.

The President and Mrs. Roosevelt will attend the funeral of W. Forbes Morgan, former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, and an uncle by marriage of Mrs. .Roosevelt, which will be held tomorrow at 9:30 A.M at St. Thomas Episcopal Church. Burial will be at Tivoli, N. Y.
118th St. 54 E, 20x101; Gabriel Matalon and wife to Jerome Cohn. 500 West End Ave. 117th St. 313 W, 25x101; Roosevelt Savings Bank to Jack Lavenstein. 67-18 Woodside Ave. Woodside ($17.50).

Major league baseball, which slipped back into the camphor bag after its gala inaugurals last Monday and Tuesday, will endeavor to burst out afresh with a new set of openings today when the teams which did the "visiting" earlier in the week now take their turn at starting the championship cam?? at home.

A decline of $1 a bale in the price of cotton here yesterday canceled all of the recovery of the previous day and left the list on the Cotton Exchange with losses of 17 to 20 points. As was the case on Wednesday, virtually all the markets moved in the same direction, and when speculative buyers in cotton resold in the absence of any broadening demand from consumers, quotations moved off rapidly.

Ambassador Georges Bonnet of France, in an address here last night, urged the immediate preparation of a firm understanding on arms, economics and finance among Great Britain, France, the United States and other democracies.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Lois Swan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rockwell Swan of 435 East Fiftysecond Street, to Joseph de Forest Junkin 3d, son of Mrs. Erastus T. Tefft, and of Joseph de Forest Junkin Jr., which will take place on May 22 in St. John's Church, Salisbury, Conn. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Henry J. Chiera.

With prospects of a heavy track. several thousand college and schoolboy athletes from all parts of the country await the starter's gun in the forty-third annual Pennsylvania relay carnival, which gets under way tomorrow.

The Holley bill, designed-to eliminate thirddegree methods by the police, was killed in the Senate today after one of the most heated debates of the current session. The measure, already passed in the Assembly, was backed by the American Civil Liberties Union. Senator John J. McNaboe used this sponsorship as one of his main arguments against the bill.

Asserting that the "time is propitious," Sir Robert Horne, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, has urged the government to make a more "definite currency stabilization agreement at the same time it concludes a trade treaty with the United States.

Sheriff Theodore R. Middleton of Harlan County, Ky., received a "kickback" of $90 monthly for several months and $75 monthly during the remainder of the last three years and up to and including January of this year from the salary of Henry M. Lewis, his chief deputy, the latter today told the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage and violations of civil liberties.
The Hongkong Clipper of Pan American Air Lines arrived today from Honolulu and is scheduled to take off for Hongkong tomorrow.

Pensioned On his own application: CAPTAIN-Edward Miller, 80th Precinct, at $2,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 22, 1908. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-Louis Sisapel, from 46th Precinct to office of the Second Deputy Police Commissioner, for duty in Legal Bureau. Edward A. Muller, 75th to 80th Precinct.

President Roosevelt found a mistake in the wording of General John J. Pershing's commission as one of the United States representatives at the coronation of George VI of England, it was learned today when General Pershing called to say good-bye to the President before sailing.

Inactive gold in the Treasury's general fund aggregated $505,500,631 on April 20, according to the Treasury daily statement for that date, made public today. This was an increase of $13,937,395 from the previous day.

Awards for engineering construetion in the week ended yesterday reached a total of $44,308,000, representing an increase of 52 per cent over the same week last year, when the figure was $29,081,000, according to The Engineering NewsRecord.

Miss Mary Melissa Hoadley Dodge, daughter of the late William Earle Dodge, left a net estate of $2,787,616 when she died Dec. 24, 1934, according to a report filed yesterday by Transfer Tax Appraiser Jacob Manicoff. The bulk of the estate was invested in securities.

In a statement attacking the Committee for Industrial Organization as "steeped in the cesspool of illegality and irresponsibility," the executive council of the American Federation of Labor today announced it was calling a special conference in Cincinnati, May 18, to rally all loyal unions to its support in the struggle with the C. I. o. and to raise funds for an organization campaign.
THERE is no blinking the fact that "Middletown in Transition: A Study in Cultural Conflicts" (Harcourt, Brace, $5), by Robert S. and Helen M. Lynd, is a work of phenomenal interest.

The Junior League of New York will inaugurate tonight one of the most ambitious entertainment projects it has undertaken in many years-a full-size theatrical production entitled the New York Junior League "Follies," which will be presented at the New Amsterdam Theatre, with subsequent performances tomorrow afternoon and tomorrow night. All the entertainment units of the organization, including the Junior League Players.
The short positions in all New York Curb Exchange stocks as of March 31 was 65,358, according to a report yesterday. This compared with 83,259 shares Feb. 26.
Stocks receded and closed lower; turnover, 1,180,020 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower, foreign issues steady and mixed; transactions, $11,570,700.

The city of Jacksonville, Fla., has Invited bids for a new issue of $1,250,000 of electric revenue certificates, award of which will be made on May 12. The bonds will be dated May 1, and will mature serially from May 1 next year to 1949. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.

Harvey T. Hill, for. ten years assistant to the president and executive vice president of the Chicago Stock Exchange, will leave the Exchange on June 1 to become a partner in Clement, Curtis Co., he and Allan M. Clement, senior partner in the brokerage house, announced today.

Argentina completed the first quarter of this year with a favorable balance of trade amounting to 532,600,000 pesos ($177,600,000 at the official rate of exchange), which compares with 120,900,000 pesos ($40,000,000) in the first quarter of 1936,

The appointment of Rev. Dr. John C. Schroeder, pastor of the State Street Congregational Church of Portland, Me., as Professor of Homiletics and Pastoral Theology in the Yale Divinity School is announced by President Angell of the university.

The ladies' auxiliary of Manhattan College will hold its annual Spring bridge and reception at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria tonight. Mrs. James E. Dougherty, chairman of the committee, has received more than 500 reservations.
It was during the budget conference at the White House Monday afternoon that the intermittent suggestion of a per*centage slash in all appropriation bills came to life again.

Principal shareholders of the American International Corporation on March 4, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, were the Adams Express Company and the SolvayAmerican Investment Corporation. The former owned 69,300 shares in its own name and 38,100 shares in

On a Churchill Downs track that was deep in mud, I. J. Collins's Derby colt, Bernard F., worked three-quarters of a mile today in 1:18 4-5. It was the day's best time and to backstretch observers the most impressive workout of the day.
Jimmy Leto. Hartford, Conn., welterweight, was disqualified on a foul in the fifth round of his fifteen-round match with Alf Blatch, Australian lightweight champion, tonight.

The nominating committee of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday renominated John C. Botts for president. Thomas F. Cahill and John H. McFadden Jr. were nominated for the board of managers to succeed Homer W. Orvis and Frank Brown. Other officers were renominated.

Simon W. Rosendale, former Attorney General, died this afternoon. He was 94 years old. Gave Last Years to Charity Simon W. Rosendale, lawyer, Jewish leader and philanthropist, believed that when a man retired

The recognition of those times "when silence is golden" was listed as one of the requisite virtues of the "ideal girl" according to the composite picture of "Miss Manhattan, 1937," as drawn by 210 members of the graduating class of Manhattan College in the annual senior poll.

While trading was quiet in all sections of the wool goods market this week, prices remained firm, as manufacturers "are resting on a comfortable backlog of orders and see no necessity for forcing business at this time," according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.

Six hundred young Germans from South Africa will meet in convention from May 15 to May 17 in Hohstein Castle, Saxony. The purpose is to "express loyalty to Germanism in Southwest Africa and the Fuehrer."
At the organization meeting of the Art Metal Construction Company Henry K. Smith, who has been president, was elected chairman of the board and chairman of the executive committee.

A Federal investigation of the forces behind the student "peace strike," which it denounced as an attempt by radicals to "cause dissension, strife and even bloodshed in America," was urged here yesterday by the National Catholic Alumni Federation, representing 300,000 Catholic college graduates.
Ed (Dutch) Brandt, veteran southpaw, pitched the Pirates to a second straight triumph over the Cubs at Wrigley Field today, 4 to 2.

As a result of the big rise in Canadian newsprint prices for 1938, the American Newspaper Publishers Association took steps yesterday to promote the development of a newsprint industry in the South, where large supplies of pine are available.

United States MINOR OBSERVER IN METEOROLOGY. $1,020 a Year, Weather Bureau, New York, N. Y.-Applications must be on file with the manager, Second U. S. Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher Street, New York, N. Y., not later than April 27.
It is gratifying to note that the associated Master Plumbers/of our own Empire State adjourned their forty-ninth annual
Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, accompanied by his wife and several officials of the Foreign Office arrived this evening for a three-day visit.

C. E. Hil dum, executive vice president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, testified in the United States District Court here today that whereas the carrier's gross revenue in 1926, its peak traffic year, was in excess of $80,000,000, it had dropped to less than $40,000,000 in both 1933 and 1934 and was not much better in 1935.

A House Agriculture subcommittee tentatively agreed today on a quota system for apportionment of the domestic sugar market among domestic and off-shore producers. Using the basic consumption as 6,514,000 tons annually, the quota system would distribute it as follows:

Outlines of a picture of life in which the activities of mind and matter constitute a super-radio, with the quintillions of living cells sending out their individual waves to be tuned in by quadrillions of receiving sets in the brain, emerged here today in reports presented before the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.
Myra Hess, English pianist, will be guest of honor at a private recital to be given tonight at the Neighborhood Music School.
A warrant for the arrest of Ann Harding, issued last May on complaint of her first husband, Harry Bannister, was annulled today by Judge Laetare Roy. Mr. Bannister.

To offset increases in the cost of living in the past three years, the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad made numerous increases in salaries in 1936, H. A. Scandrett, president, said in his report to stockholders yesterday. The railway entered bankruptcy in 1935.

53d St, n s. 167 ft e of 5th Ave, 21x100.5: Cabin Holding Corp to Column Holding Corp, 565 5th Ave, care of Joshua Bernstein. 2d Ave, 406, 23.4x73.10; Domna Condiles to Gust Condiles, 33-44 Academy St. Queens; mtgs $13,850 (50 cents).

Republican efforts to carry President Roosevelt's economy drive further than the objectives which he stated were credited with another apparent set-back to the anti-spending program in the House today.

Mrs. Marion Snowden Reed, heiress to an oil fortune, said today she would file suit Monday for divorce from Louis Reed Jr., son of a retired New York attorney, and would be married soon after the decree is granted to Bradley S. Dresser.

While organized wholesale liquor dealers strove yesterday to put an end. to the price rivalry by which discounts offered retailers have more than doubled, conditions in the market here remained much the same as on Thursday, when the price competition broke out.

A two-member debating team from the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking defeated a two-member team from the Essex County (N. J.) Chapter tonight in arguments on "Resolved, That tax-exempt securities shall no longer be issued."

The Gallic Annabella, comparatively unknown here before she appeared on the Music Hall's screen last month in "Wings of the Morning," has been signed for starring roles in two unnamed pictures on next season's program of Twentieth Century-Fox.

Dr. and Mrs. James C. Greenway of Kincraig, Mead's Point, Greenwich, Conn., gave a dinner and dance last night in the Jansen suite of the Waldorf-Astoria at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna L. Greenway, to John Sloane Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. S. Griswold of 883 Fifth Avenue and Black Hall, Old Lyme, -Conn.
Daylight saving, as surveyed and estimated by the Merchants Association of New York, will be observed by
Stocks weakened and closed lower; turnover, 1,202,769 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower; foreign issues irregular; transactions, $10,140,500.

QUARTER-MILE CHAMPIONSHIP Trial Heats (Four Fastest Qualify for Final) First Heat-Won by North Texas Teachers (E. Brown, A. Chrisman, J. Stovall, D. Brown), 0:41.8; second, Occidental. Los Angeles, 0:42.4; third, Columbia, 0:42.4; fourth, Wayne (Detroit), 0:42.8. Second Heat-Won by Duke (Woodward, Shehan, Johnston, Reavis), 0:43.1; second, Yale, 0:43.2: third, Army, 0:43.6; fourth. Morgan, 0:43.7.

The engagement of Miss Lucetta Plum, daughter of Mrs. William TerHune Plum of this place, and the late Mr. Plum, to Lester Butler Churchill, son of Mrs. Lester Butler Churchill of Rumson, N. J., and the late Mr. Churchill, has been announced by her mother.
The Rev. Alexander von Schlichten, pastor for thirty-eight years of St. John's Lutheran Church, 46 Hudson Street, Yonkers, N. Y., will officiate for the first time on Monday,

Mayor Bernard Dickmann today refused use of Municipal Auditorium tonight for the showing of an antiHitler motion picture, "Der Kampf" (The Struggle) after Reinold Freytag, German Consul here, had protested.
Struggles among labor unions, which time and again caused bloodshed in Mexico, will soon come to an end, President Lazaro Cardenas announces.
Miss Justine Anne Clay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Ward Clay of this place, was married this afternoon to Charles Lamb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lamb, also of this place.

A typical ninth-inning Gas House Gang rally brought the Cardinals a 5-to-4 victory over the Cubs today, their third triumph in as many starts this season. Johnny Mize singled after two were out and with the bases filled to drive in Stuart Martin and Frenchy Bordagaray.
Delegates to the International Sugar Conference today brought pressure against Russia's export quota demands after Czechoslovakia appeared today to accept compromise figures.

The largest and one of the best fields which has gone to the post in recent years will contend in the forty-fourth running of the famous Maryland Hunt Cup tomorrow over the course on the estate of J. W. Y. Martin near Glyndon, Md. Ten starters are assured, two more than last year, from the eleven nominations.

About 250 employes of the Torresdale Hosiery Mills here operated by Marshall Field Co., Inc., staged a sit-down strike today in an attempt to prevent the company from closing the plant and suspending manufacturing.

A nation-wide program of athletics was proposed yesterday to inculcate tolerance and to preserve democracy, just as compulsory youth activities are used to strengthen dictatorships and communism in other countries, at the annual convention of the American Physical Education Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The bringing of Delaware River water to the city moved forward yesterday when the Board of Estimate authorized the issuance of $118,000,000 in fifty-year corporate stock to complete the financing of the project.
