Miss Genevieve G. Brady, daughter of the late James Cox Brady, financier and philanthropist, was married to Anderson Fowler of New York this. afternoon in the chapel of Hamilton Farms, the country home here of the bride's stepmother, Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting, and Mr. Cutting.
Today's stock markets were quiet and the general tone was better, although early gains were not uniformly held. Gilt-edge issues lost ground, although Germans hardened among the foreign loans.
A sit-down demonstration by sixty-three men threw 2,700 employes of two General Motors plants into idleness today, but the strike was settled four hours after it began.
Henry Doscher, son of the late Claus Doscher, sugar refiner, of Brooklyn, died Thursday night at his home, 52 Gramercy-Park North, in his eighty-first year. Mr. Doscher was a native of New York.
Obedience to orders, a quality which prompted the selection of Colonel Andrew S. Rowan to carry the famous "Message to Garcia," distinguished his observance today of his eightieth birthday.

Miss Mary Goodenow Willcox, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter F. Willcox of Ithaca, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Alexander Wiley of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Wiley, in the Church of the Ascension by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Donnelly of Oswego, N. Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Donnelly's daughter, Miss Gretchen E. Van Buren, to Kenneth Granger White of New York.
The number of victims in the film explosion at Kilingi, Estonia, has grown to twelve school children. Nine more are in a critical condition. Thirty others are suffering from serious injuries.
An exhibition of amateur photography will open this afternoon in the art galleries of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue, and continue through next Saturday.

The gray-and-white-clad officers and men of the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh Regiment), N. Y. N. G., paraded last night at their armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, in honor of Major Gen. Albert H. Blanding, chief of the National Guard Bureau of the War Department.

Shelling Frank Pearce from the mound with a five-hit assault in the sixth which produced five runs, the Buffalo Bisons opened their International League season with a 6-to-1 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs today.

Bill Feiler, 120-pound Drake University sophomore distance runner, earned a draw with a pair of Uncle Sam's 1936 Olympic stars, Sam Francis of Nebraska and Mack Robinson of Pasadena Junior College, today in the opening program of the twenty-eighth annual Drake relays.

The bureau steering committee of the adjourned World Disarmament Conference, sparring for time in the hope of improved chances of success, announced indefinite postponement today of a meeting scheduled for May 6.

Funeral services for J. Foster Warner, the architect, were held in Christ Church here today while his son, Major John Adams Warner, superintendent of the New York State Police, played the organ and State troopers acted as bearers.

This is the final installment of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's own story of his captivity at Sian last December, presented in the form of the diary he kept there. In previous installments he told of his defiance of the rebels and of their wavering in the face of his determination.

The first test case attacking the constitutionality of the New Jersey law permitting State banks to reorganize by issuing preferred stock for deposits is before Circuit Judge Wilfred H. Jayne, sitting in the New Jersey Supreme Court.
Elaine Barrie obtained a divorce today from John Barrymore, and Judge Walter S. Gates, who granted the decree, wished the girl "better luck next time."

Ater a secret ballot, it was announced today that the 560 employes of the Thermoid Company, who are members of a local union of the United Rubber Workers of America, a unit of the Committee for Industrial Organization, had rejected by a two-to-one margin a proposal that they return to work under terms of their present agreement.
The Senate Judiciary Committee ended the public hearings on President Roosevelt's Court Reorganization Bill today, the forty-fourth day since they started.

Mrs. Sue Wise March, daughter of Mrs. Homer Clift Wise of Baltimore and the late Mr. Wise, was married to Joseph Walker, New York attorney, yesterday afternoon at the residence at 15 East Seventy-fifth Street of Ernest W. Pittman, a half-brother of the bride.
Most commodity futures held steady on the local markets yesterday. Turnovers, however, were smaller. Rubber, silk and cottonseed oil futures showed the only declines.

Building plans filed yesterday included one for a factory project at 77-89 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, for the American Safety Razor Corporation, to cost $550,000. In Queens, plans were filed for a total of 140 one-family dwellings to be erected in various parts of the borough. The list follows:

Band Orders The members of the Department Band and Bugle and Drum Corps shall be directed to report, in full uniform, to Captain Julius A. Unrath, at the Metropolitan Opera House, Broadway and 39th St., Manhattan, at 12:15 P. M., Sunday, April 25, and at 8:15 P. M.. Sunday, April 25. Members shall wear their pouches.

Carter County authorities sought further details of the fatal shooting of Jimmy Scott, 16, who died in a darkened room while playing "postoffice." Coroner C. W. Henderson said that Stella Stevens, 14, daughter of Drew Stevens, admitted shooting the youth with her father's revolver during a "souffle," but claimed it was an accident.

Extreme tension gripped the shoe factory district this evening when strikers, leaving a rally at City Hall, crossed to Auburn by way of an unpoliced railroad bridge and filtered into the area patrolled by National Guardsmen and State troopers.

The publishers of this country have not sought and will not seek any special privilege and will resist all efforts to deprive a free people of their rights or a free press, James G. Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville (Tenn.) Banner, declared yesterday in assuming the presidency of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
Fifty persons were injured, some seriously, in a riot of cannery workers at Stockton, Calif. Police used shotguns and gas shells before a truce was arranged. Page 1.
Great crowds saw a preview of coronation splendor today as King George VI, in the first public speech of his reign, dedicated a monument to "my dear father."
President Roosevelt today agreed to visit, on Thursday, the Bonnet Carre spillway which protects New Orleans from floods.

By THOMAS F. BURCHILL 104th St, 186 E. 5-story tenement and stores, 20x100.11; Bowery Savings Bank against Joseph E. Beller: due, $9,162; taxes, , $700; to plaintiff for $8,000. Lexington Ave, 1,706. 4-story tenement and stores, 16.8x75: Aloysius Klein against Vincent Morizio; due, $18,600: taxes, , $1,750; to plaintiff for $10,000.
With the first Parliamentary skirmish over the new budget ended, there is no longer any doubt that a stiff tax on the growth of profits will be placed on Great Britain's statute book before Summer.

The apartment and store property at 907 East 221st Street, northeast corner of Bronxwood Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold through the Kempner Realty Corporation to a client of Isidore Tankus. The seller was the estate of Minna G. Goddard, represented by Mitchell VanWinkle as trustees and attorneys.

Holding that retail installment sales are continuing to mount steadily, the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association yesterday announced it is undertaking to reappraise the scope and trend of deferred payment selling and interpret its implications to retail distribution in general.

Calvert Brewer, in 3 E. 84th St.; Richard Halliday. W. W. Hawkins Jr., in 300 Park Ave.; Mrs. M. B. Chappell, in 3 E. 77th St.; Mrs. Sidney Sonnenbaum, in 70 E. 77th St.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers. John Fiske, in 1,225 Park Ave. through Byrne Bowman; Walter J. Fried, Louis Berizzi, in 45 E. 85th St.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc., broker.

President Roosevelt today signed a bill authorizing the Federal Housing Administration to insure banks and other financial institutions against losses from loans made for rehabilitation and improvement of real estate, machinery and equipment damaged by floods or other disasters.

American diplomatic officials here have taken formal action to obtain a reprieve for Helmuth Hirsch, 20-year-old son of a naturalized American citizen, sentenced to death following his conviction of high treason by the People's Tribunal on March 20. Pending clarification of his citizenship status, American officials were unable to undertake steps in his behalf, but the State Department is reported now to have instructed them to proceed.
William L. Finley, noted wildlife photographer and official of the American Nature Association, loves to talk about beavers. He likes beavers, thinks they are the foremost wildlife citizens.

A statement that the Boy Scouts, with their citizenship training, represent an American youth movement which is serving as one of the bulwarks of democracy was made by Arthur A. Schuck of New York City, national director of the division of operations, Boy Scouts of America, in an address to 500 Scout leaders from New York and New Jersey at the sixteenth annual meeting here today.

Suppression of a book that charged, in one passage, that Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin was disturbed by "muddling, fuddling and meddling" in his contacts with King Edward VIII was demanded today by the former King's legal representative.
A spotty track kept most Kentucky Derby candidates inactive today. But the Milky Way Farm candidates-Reaping Reward, Military and Case Ace-were out for speed tests. .

The annual Spring field trials of the Irish Setter Club of America got under way today with a record entry list. When the judges called it a day the Derby Stake had been decided and six brace in the all-age event had been sent down.

Election of a board of five directors for the Gibson Oil Corporation was approved today by Chaancellor Josiah O. Wolcott. The directors were elected yesterday at a meeting conducted by Henry M. Canby, special master in receivership.
Two residents go through their last Broadway paces today--"Sun Kissed," at the Little, and "The Masque of Kings," which started at the Shubert and is winding up at the Majestic.
An official war communique issued at General Francisco Franco's headquarters takes vigorous issue with Valencia's claim that the supremacy in the air has been taken from the Insurgents.

In a decision unprecedented in the Northern New York Judicial District, Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant today ordered receivers of the Schenectady Railway Company to recognize the Transport Workers Industrial Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, as sole bargaining agency for its employes.

Newspaper reporters should weave more "background" into their articles and place less dependence on the assumption that cold facts will present themselves to the reader, according to- a general conclusion reached by twenty student journalists attending a round-table discussion on journalism at Princeton University today.
A heavy police guard was on duty as thousands of Moslems, in headdresses and flowing robes of the desert tribes, marched into Jerusalem today for the annual feast of Nebi Musa.

Control of the Old Colony Manufacturing Company, Taunton, Mass., manufacturers of-cotton yarn and mechanical fabrics, has been acquired by a group of Boston men, headed by Ernest M. Hood, former treasurer of the Naumkeag Steam Cotton Company, Salem, and Philip A. Moreland, associated with Mr. Hood for many years as a cotton buyer.

Prosecutor Anthony M. Hauck of Hunterdon County, N. J., received yesterday a warrant sworn out by John J. McNally, a private detective, of 171 Manhattan Avenue, Jersey City, charging "on information and belief" that one "John Jacob Nosovitsky, alias J. J. Faulkner," conspired to kidnap Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. on March 1, 1932.

Arthur C. Stratford, president of the George Stratford Oakum Company of Jersey City and president of the Jute Packing and Oakum Institute, a national trade society, died suddenly at his home here today. His age was 56.

Celebrating its five-year circulation growth from 250,000 to more than 1,000,000, the American Home Magazine has doubled its advertising budget and expanded its schedule, Henry L. Jones, vice president and advertising director of the Country-Life-American Home Corporation, announced yesterday.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 21: COMMANDER Gillette. N. C., Washington, D. C., to the Omaha, as executive officer. LIEUTENANTS Barrett. J. P. B., Washington, D. C., to the Idaho.
New editorial officers of The Concordiensis, Union College student newspaper, include Hyman A. Enzer of Elizabeth, N. J., as editorin-chief.
William High Parker, president of the Emerson Hotel Company and for years a prominent builder of Baltimore, died today at his home here at the age of 76.

Governor Lehman heard the five Berg Election Law Bills sharply assailed today as a threat to independent political action and a blow to democracy, yet hailed with equal positiveness as essential if "racketeering and fraud in independent nominations" were to be driven out.
The Four Aces entered the final round yesterday afternoon in the team-of-four championship play of the Grand National contract bridge tournament, conducted by the United States Bridge Association.

James Geddes Stahlman, publisher of The Nashville Banner, at the age of 44 is the youngest man to become president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. He has passed most of his life with The Banner and is of the third generation of his family to .be connected with that newspaper.

New records were set for attendance at the thirty-third annual Knitting Arts Exhibition which closed at the Commercial Museum tonight, according to Albert C. Rau, managing director. Orders booked by machinery and accessories exhibitors during the week were the best since 1930, he said.

There is an aspect of the German position regarding a European settlement that apparently is not yet taken into account by those now making soundings into the chances for a conference to restore world trade and thereby reduce the temptation to go to war. This is the domestic aspect. It is no less important than are the German terms for entering such a conference.
In the title of one of his searching novels, "Death in Venice," perhaps the departing Thomas Mann provides the proper caption for the meeting this week of Mussolini and Schuschnigg.
The annual "Tip Top-Ball," given under the auspices of Auxiliary No. 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium, took place last night in the Colonnades Room of Essex House.

With retail distribution failing to reach its seasonal degree of acceleration this week, as the result of unsettled weather conditions, buying was restricted in some of the principal wholesale markets, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A test of the right of relief authorities to withhold assistance from World War veterans until bonus funds received last year have been consumed is being started by the Kings County American Legion, it was disclosed last night. Angelo J. Cincotta, the legion's attorney, said that about 5,000 ex-soldiers were affected.

Influenced by unsettled outside markets and accelerated liquidation of the May position prior to notices on Tuesday, near-month contracts on the Cotton Exchange broke into new low ground yesterday, but rallied in the late trading to end with losses of 4 to 8 points.
The verse play that Archibald MacLeish wrote for radio production, "The Fall of the City," has been put into book form by Farrar Rinehart and will be published on Monday.
Women are ill one and one-half as often as men, Dr. John W. Williams of Cambridge, Mass., told the American College of Physicians today, yet the "weaker" sex lives slightly longer.

Trains on the Queens Boulevard line of the city's Independent Subway, which have been operating between Church Avenue, Brooklyn, and Kew Gardens, Queens, since Jan. 1, will run to the end of the line at 169th Street and Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, beginning at 1 P. M. today.

The Puerto Rican Legislature wants the military district of Puerto Rico elevated to a brigade command, according to a resolution approved today and to be sent to the President and the Secretary of War.
Supreme Court Justice Raymond Aldrich was informed of a $22,500 settlement out of court in a damage action against Ogden Reid of Purchase and Mr. Reid's chauffeur, Robert Loughran.

Movements in Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 14,000, including 7,000 direct. Market slow: weight averages 200 pounds, up 10c-20c lower than Thursday's average;

Retail trade here improved during the week but the showing continued to run under expectations for this period. Main-floor departments did not experience the pickup anticipated, and store executives were inclined to cite this situation as the major reason for the showing. However,...

Class 38, Open Jumping-First, Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Stephen Gilbert's ch. g. The Thruster, second, Rodwyn Stables' ch. g. Teddy Boy: third, Patrick McDermott's Dun M. Pretty Good; fourth, Patrick McDermott's blk. g. Shanghai. Class 18, Novice Horsemanship-First, Miss Irene Demuth Steckler; second, Miss Diane Shewan; third, Miss Edith Rubin;

A widow and her two children were found asphyxiated by gas in the bedroom of their home, 6 Catherine Street, North Long Branch, today. Police said that two gas jets on a kitchen gas range were turned on.
What to do with 175 bathtubs, slightly used, was a vexing problem today for Oscar E. Hewitt, City Commissioner of Public Works.

" Cheap" radio serials for adults and children and all "canned" music broadcasts, because they deprive musicians of employment, were attacked today by speakers at the Spring conference of the Westchester County Federation of Women at the Contemporary Club here.

The George Washington High School nine, P. S. A. L. champion last year, lost its first game in fourteen starts yesterday, bowing to Morris High School, 7-5, at Sterling Oval in an upper Manhattan-Bronx P. S. A. L. test. It was the fifth in a row for Morris and its second league victory. Murray Rothman paced the winners with three hits in three times at bat, one a home run.

If we worked only four hours a day-enough in a properly organized world according to some efficiency engineers--how would we spend our leisure? The problem has bothered social scientists, statesmen, ministers, newspaper editors and reformers, even though we are not yet even in sight of Utopia.

The Columbia Medal for Distinguished Service to Radio will be presented on May 2 by William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, to Barry Bingham, co-publisher of The Louisville Courier-Journal, which operates Station WHAS, Louisville, Ky.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order permanently suspending an offering sheet of non-producing landowners' royalty interests in the AndersonPrichard Oil Corporation Swisher lease in Oklahoma County, Okla., filed on Nov. 21 by George E. Fisher of Oklahoma City.
Mortimer B. Hoffman, counsel for the B. M. T., died last night in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica. He lived at 40 Jewel Street, Forest Hills.

Miss Suzanne Jeanne Searle, daughter of Clarence Eugene Searle of this place and the late Mrs. Searle, was married this afternoon to Horace Brinton Passmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Hearshey Passmore of Pelham, at the home of her father here.

An oil painting by Henri Matisse, "Baigneuses," was bought by M. Clewes for $3,000 last night at the Rains Galleries at the auction of modern art formerly in the collection of Mme. W. Zborowski, with supplementary items.
The decline in cotton mill activity last week matched the usual seasonal drop and the adjusted index continued unchanged at 138.9. For the week ended April 18, 1936, the figure was 106.9.

Shareholders of Aktiebolaget Volvo. Gothenburg, Sweden, have authorized an increase of the share capital from 13,000,000 kronor to 18,200,000 kronor through the issuance of 104,000 new 50-kronor par value shares. Shareholders residing outside the United States may subscribe until May 11 at par for two new shares for each five now held.

Twenty-five thousand members of the Brotherhood of Railway and Steamship Clerks were asked yesterday by union officials if they wanted a strike called following a breakdown of negotiations for pay increases in the metropolitan area.

The Glendhu Farms' chestnut gelding The Thruster became the front-running contender for champion jumper honors when the 6 year-old entry of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Stephen Gilbert of North Salem, N. Y., carried off the blue in the open jumping class as the Riding and Polo Club's two-day Spring horse show began in the club's spacious arena in Manhattan last night.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Here are a few more remarks on the photo finish as demonstrated in the Brown Top race at Pimlico last Fall regarding which there was a letter in THE TIMES last week.

The racing committee that will supervise the annual meeting of the Fairfield and Westchester hounds, scheduled for the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club at Rye on May 31, was announced last night by George L. Ohrstrom.

The efforts of George A. Ball, glass manufacturer, of Muncie, Ind., to sell control of the Van Sweringen network of railroads to the highest bidder took an unexpected turn yesterday when it was learned that Frederick H. Prince of Boston, banker and promoter, was seeking to complete negotiations for its acquisition.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 23.-Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Hasler entertained a company of forty at the Greenbrier tonight in honor of Prince George Scherbatow.

Miss Jane Shaw Churchill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Whitfield Churchill of 41 Boulevard, Pelham, was married here this evening to Lockwood Chappell Barr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lockwood Barr of 20 Beech Tree Lane.
Four records in domestic sales of motor vehicles were established in March, Alfred Reeves, vice president of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, announced yesterday.

Another witness testified yesterday that Mrs. Edward H. R. Green knew what she was doing in 1917 when she signed away her rights to the $70,000,000 estate left to her husband by his mother, Hetty Green.

The automotive industry is operating close to the level of 1929, Ward's Reports, Inc., indicated today in estimating aggregate production this week at 139,090 cars and trucks. Last week's output was estimated at 127,755 units; that for the comparable week of 1936 at 115,340.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 17 totaled 751,328 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today. This was 35,284 cars, or 4.9 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 109,050 cars, or 17 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 140,187 cars, or 22.9 per cent, more than in the corresponding week two years ago.

A hitherto undisclosed story of arrests and trials, the "liquidation" of large numbers of alleged foreign spies in the Soviet Far East, was told today in a detailed article in Pravda describing the machinations of the country's enemies.

Pennsylvania staged a comeback yesterday in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League by defeating Columbia, 5-0, at Baker Field. John Conway, starting his first game for the Red and Blue, held the Lions to five scattered hits.

Dr. and Mrs. Henry Schermerhorn Stearns will leave their home at 655 Park Avenue on May 1 to go to their country place at Bass Rocks, Gloucester, Mass. Mr. and Mrs. Edgar J. Williams of the Waldorf-Astoria will sail Wednesday on the Europa for London. Later they will go to Paris and return for a motor trip through England and Ireland.

A first mortgage of $97,500 at 41/2per cent has been obtained by the Hargold Realty Corp, Harry Goldsmith, president, on the new six-story apartment house at 1,592 Jessup Ave, the Bronx. Byrne Bowman, Inc, arranged the loan. The Capitol Theatre Building on Main St, Haverstraw. N Y, will be offered at auction at 2 PM today on the premises by John J. Reynolds, auctioneer.

Commission sessions on peaceful change, trade relations and sanctions occupied delegates to the Model League of Nations, Middle Atlantic division, at Cornell University, today, after the first plenary session this morning.

Reversing the result of their meeting in the final at Pinehurst last week, as well as a year ago, Mrs. Virginia Rice Johnson of Boston defeated Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio today to win the women's Mason-Dixon tennis championship at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.
Employes of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation today rejected the United Chocolate Workers of America as their agency for collective bargaining.
Driven to cover by a drizzling rain and a penetrating chill, the world champion Yankees spent the first day of their visit here cooped in hotel quarters or whiling away the time at the movies.

A plot of about one and one-half acres on Twin Ridge Farm, Chappaqua, N. Y., has been purchased by Arlene Crangle Rosner of New York for improvement with a dwelling. The plot is on the Frances B. Still property and was sold through Raymond V. Guernsey, broker.

Mrs. Helen K. Harper, 33 years old, of 9 Ascot Ridge, Great Neck, asked Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday to defer until she could retain a lawyer her plea on an indictment in the theft of about $50,000 from her former employers, the Hold-Meredith Lumber Corporation of 205 East Forty-second Street.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a summary of additional registration statements filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933 covering securities with gross proceeds of about $185,000,000.

The Phillies almost won their home opener today, but their ninthinning efforts were about on a par with the first ball pitch made by City Solicitor Joseph Scharfsin and the Dodgers edged in ahead by a score of 4-3.

Detectives from the office of John J. Bennett Jr., State Attorney General, were looking yesterday for four more Brooklyn painters and contractors accused of conspiring with labor racketeers in maintaining a monopoly of Board of Education contracts in Brooklyn and Queens public schools.

Dr. Isaac Surnamer died today at his home here of a heart attack. He was 64 years old. Born in Riga, Latvia, he came to America in 1892 and in 1896 was graduated from Bellevue Medical School, New York. He also studied at Fordham and Johns Hopkins Universities.

A new eight-acre park is to be created by the Park Department on the site of the old Prospect Heights reservoir, between the Brooklyn Museum and Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, under an authorization made yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

The Pan American Pioneers, veterans of the first clipper ship flights to China and to South America, held a reunion dinner last night at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in honor of Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, chairman of the board of Pan American Airways, and Juan J. Trippe, presdent.
Darkness caught up with the Princeton and Holy Cross baseball teams on University Field today and forced an end to hostilities at the end of the ninth inning with the score tied at 5-5.
Senator Nathan Lynn Bachman of Tennessee died of a heart attack at 7:30 o'clock tonight at his residence at the Hotel Continental. His age was 58.
The ball given this evening at the Bellevue-Stratford for the benefit of the Cancer Research Institute of the Lankenau Hospital was designated as "A Night in the Orient."

Net income of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and wholly owned subsidiaries in the first quarter of 1937, amounted to $16,013,346 after allowance for depreciation and obsolescence, and provisions for interest and Federal income taxes, including surtax on undistributed profits in 1937. This result compares ??th $14,713,782 earned in the March quarter a year ago.

Hiram C. Todd started suit yesterday in Supreme Court against the city for $41,023.11 which he holds is due him for his services as Special Assistant Attorney Genral in prosecuting the Drukman investigation.
Some 60,000 children under 12 years of age will get lost during the 1939 World's Fair, Grover Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, estimated last night.
Arthur Gilmore, former national titleholder, captured the metropolitan senior A. A. U. flying rings crown at the West Side Y. M. C. A. last night with a total of 53.8 points.

By a three-to-two vote the Appellate Division affirmed yesterday an order requiring former Governor James M. Curley of Massachusetts to enumerate alleged offensive passages in an article on which he is basing a $500,000 libel suit against Harpers Magazine before the defendants be required to answer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES published recently the statement of Ambassador Joseph E. Davies to the effect that the Soviet was operating industry on a profit system, and that he believed it must adopt capitalistic principles to develop its industry.

Miss Helen Stephens, great woman athlete of Fulton, Mo., set a new indoor shot-put record tonight in the women's national A. A. U. meet with a toss of 44 feet 1 1/2 inchs. This bettered her mark of 41 feet 11 inches. established a year ago.
Gar Wood, white and lemon pointer owned by Dr. H. E. Longsdorf of Mount Holly, captured the junior all-age stake in the eleventh annual Spring meeting of the Lambertville Field Trial Club today.
A $2,000 judgment was awarded today to Miss Roberta Semple in her $150,000 slander suit against an attorney for her mother, Aimee Semple McPherson, who left the court in tears before the verdict.

The President and Mrs. Roosevelt attended the funeral of W. Forbes Morgan, former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee and president of the Distilled Spirits Institute, which was held in St. Thomas Church today. Mr.

In the largest anti-trust action of its kind since 1911 when the Standard Oil Company was declared a monopoly, the United States Government filed suit here yesterday asking for the dissolution of the $174,000,000 Aluminum Company of America, alleging that it is a trust controlled by Andrew W. Mellon, his relatives and associates.

By capturing Mount usaia, more than 3,500 feet high, dominating the eastern approach to Durango from Vergara, on the Basque front, the Insurgents today were able to move on the villages of Arrazola and Apatamonasterio.
The Italo-Austrian conversations here ended this morning, after a conference lasting an hour and a half, with a communique that is as revealing for what it does not as for what it does say.

Ole G. Olsen of Northport, L. I., president of the Olsen Water and Towing Company of 17 State Street, Manhattan, died of a heart ailment yesterday at 1 P. M. in front of the Long Island Railroad station at Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 67 years old.

Jerry McCarthy, Detroit customer's man in the Detroit office of W. E. Hutton Co., testified today he "could not remember telegraphing for confidential information" on stop-loss orders in Atlas Tack stock.

The C. I. O. strike activities in the United States are described as a militant labor movement which the American Communist party is energetically supporting, in a long article by Moissaye J. Olgin, the New York correspondent of Pravda, just published in that newspaper.

Hilaire Belloc, prominent Roman Catholic layman and world literary figure, now delivering a series of lectures in the Graduate School of Fordham University on the crisis of civilization, identified "the evil" yesterday.

The block front on the south side of Palace Boulevard, between 209th Street and Corporal Kennedy Avenue, Bayside, L. I., has been purchased by the Bayside Company, Inc., for improvement with a threestory garden apartment. The deal was arranged through the M. Gladstone Company in conjunction with the L. O. Trilsch Agency, Inc.
Crude oil produced in Venezuela in March was 14,707,931 barrels, a daily average of 474,449 and an alltime high, according to O'Shaughnessy's Oil Bulletin.

A hospital inspector, in his report of two Bronx private hospitals operated without a license, revealed conditions so "filthy" and "unbelievable" that one of the three judges who convicted a doctor yesterday in Bronx Special Sessions for operating them illegally declared that "these patients were living like animals."
Dan Chappell, attorney for Trainer Bert S. Michell, said today he would oppose in the State Supreme Court the Florida Racing Commission's rule holding a trainer entirely responsible for his horses.
The sixteenday-old General Motors strike of 3,700 workers ended officially this afternoon when the strikers voted, 2,205 to 36, to accept the terms signed by a committee and the company heads.

Tomorrow history will be made in Europe. The British and French Ambassadors will present officially in Brussels the joint declearation of their government releasing Belguim from her obligation to give assistance to Britain and France if attacked by a third power while the Anglo-French guarantee of Belgian sovereignty and territorial integrity will be maintained.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook deferred his decision yesterday on the application for a new trial made by attorneys for Charles (Lucky Luciano) Lucania and Ralph Liguori, convicted in Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of vice and prostitution.
The almost continuous decline in security prices in the last few weeks the absence of any important bearish news is becoming a subject of much discussion in the financial community.

Sixteen 3-year-olds, including half a dozen of the most formidable in this section of the country, are named for today's revival of the $3,500 added Stuyvesant Handicap at Jamaica. It is the Stuyvesant's first running since 1924.

A downtown deal in which Frederick Brown, operator, figured as the buyer featured real estate activity in Manhattan yesterday. Mr. Brown purchased from the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., the buildings at 194 William Street and 17 Leonard Street. The former,

A total of thirty-seven jute mills in Calcutta is now affected by the political strikes there and 55 per cent of the looms are shut down, cutting production more than half, according to cable advices received here yesterday.

Miss Justine Anne Clay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Ward Clay of Englewood, was married at the home of her parents, this afternoon to Charles Lamb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lamb of Englewood.

Rowing under overcast skies, oarsmen of Harvard, M. I. T, and Princeton took their final workouts this afternoon on a placid Lake Carnegie for tomorrow's fourrace regatta, the first of the season for all three colleges.

Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Francis J. West, 24th Precinct, assigned to tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and 4 P. M. to 12 midnight for 30 days. From 46th Precinct to 19th Division, for duty in Raided Premises Squad, for 22 days: George M. Del Gaudio, Maurice J. Dorney.

The Indians pounced on five St. Louis pitchers today to beat the Browns, 9 to 2, for their first victory of the American League season. Nearly 21,000 spectators were on hand to watch the Indians in their initial home performance of 1937.
During the week ending last Wednesday the Reserve Banks bought no United States bonds from the member banks, but the largest member banks continued to reduce their holdings.

Gregory W. O'Keefe, Assistant Collector of Customs, said yesterday there was no evidence of war materials aboard the freighter Felix Taussig, which sailed on Thursday from Jersey City for a destination believed to be Bordeaux, France, about 100 miles from the Spanish border.

The Italian Government's round-up of all foreign stocks and bonds held by its citizens disclosed, according to information received here from a trustworthy source; that 56 per cent of the bonds of the loan Italy floated in New York in 1926 was bought by Italians in Italy.

Although daylight-saving time does not begin officially until 2 A. M. tomorrow, thousands of forehanded New Yorkers are expected to advance their timepieces one hour before retiring tonight. Those who forget-and there will be many-will make the change in the morning.
Great political interest in France centers on the by-election that will take place Sunday at Sete-Montpellier, for the two candidates represent two tendencies among the Left parties.
Ellis A. Gimbel Jr., executive head of Gimbel Brothers, anbounced yesterday the promotion of Herbert Lack from assistant buyer of men's clothing to buyer of boys' clothing and furnishings.

Ten of the thirteen women arrested Thursday following a labor disturbance in May's department store, 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, appeared yesterday before Magistrate George H. Folwell in the Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, and pleaded not guilty to charges of disorderly conduct, rioting and conspiracy to injure the store's business.

Edgar J. Kaufmann, director and president of the Kaufmann Department Stores, Inc., received $74,100 from the company in the last fiscal year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Waite Hoyt's relief pitching gave the Pirates a 4-3 triumph over the Reds today in Forbes Field's liveliest opener in years. A throng of 22,000 fans saw the Pirates win their third straight game of the new season.

Toronto today made it two straight by defeating the Orioles, 8 to 6, after the Flock had rallied to tally five runs and tie in the eighth. The Orioles made their first hit off Jim Pattison in the seventh and added five blows in the eighth.

As candidate for President in 1932 Mr. ROOSEVELT forecast an inevitable reckoning for any Government which continued to live beyond its income after an emergency had ended. It might borrow safely "for a year or two," if its revenues failed in some crisis to provide necessary funds.

A two-day strike of longshoremen on the piers of the Cunard White Star Line and Furness, Withy Co. was ended yesterday morning when contesting unions agreed to merge their membership in the port of Montreal.

Only a moderate volume of bond offerings yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange forced prices in virtually all classifications to substantially lower levels. Interest again centered on the market for United States Government longterm obligations, which continued downward.

MANHATTAN GREPPO. THEODORE (Nov. 20. 1936). Gross assets, $37,057; net, $16,162. To Charles R, Danforth, residue; four varying bequests. Chief assets, real estate. $23,000. Man Man, attorneys, 120 Wall St.

The fact that Mayor La Guardia would be nominated by the American Labor party was reason enough for the Republican party not to endorse him, Charles G. Bond, former Representative, who recently announced his candidacy for Mayor, told an audience last night in the Twenty-second Assembly District Republican Club, 236 Barbey Street, Brooklyn.

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America has created a "Commission for the Study of Christian Unity." This was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the council.

J. D. Mortimer, president of the Illinois Power and Light Corporation, said yesterday in a letter to stockholders that proxies representing 223,000 shares of the company's $6 dividend cumulative preferred stock and 23,500 shares of the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock had been received in support of the plan of reorganization.
General Francisco Franco .decided today upon a twenty-man junta, modeled after the Italian Fascist Grand Council, to help him rule Insurgent Spain.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had received and granted applications by five firms and one individual in New York City for the withdrawal of registration as over-thecounter brokers and dealers under Section 15 (b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

From all parts of the United States several thousand music lovers came to Indianapolis today for the twentieth biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs, a seven-day session with notable concerts and recitals.

UNIVERSITY DISTANCE MEDLEY Won by Drake (Kohl, Horstmeier, Mahannah, Feller); second, Nebarska; third, Wisconsin; fourth, Ohio State; fifth, Michigan State. Time--10:21. UNIVERSITY SPRINT MEDLEY Won by Ohio State (Beetham, Howell, Lewis, Squire); second, Rice: third, Iowa: fourth, Kansas State; fifth, Michigan State. Time-3:29.7.
Buick motor plants returned to normal operation tonight after the first major sit-down strike in the company history forced almost complete curtailment of production Thursday night and today.
Mrs. Caroline Harris Barthelmess, mother of Richard Barthelmess, the actor, died yesterday morning in her home, at 1 West Sixty-seventh Street, after a short illness. She was 70 years old.
Dr. Harry L. Hall, physician, pioneer in X-ray work and later a research chemist, died yesterday in Orange Memorial Hospital at the age of 64. He had suffered from a heart ailment for a year.
Edwin Markham, the poet, celebrated his eighty-fifth birthday yesterday and in response to the thousands of felicitations he said, "This is the happiest day of my life."

MANHATTAN BISHOP, JESSIE MORSE (April 18). Estate, more than $20,000. To Beatrice C. Ohnell, 19 Stratton St., Scarsdale, N. Y., and Eileen C. Renshaw, 2,126 Shunk St., Philadelphia, Pa., daughters, personal effects. Allen R. Bishop, husband, executor. 108 Waverly Pl.. residue.

Repeating the victories she scored in 1934 and 1935, Miss Helene Mayer of Germany last night won the United States women's fencing championship for the third time. Invincible as she took every bout on the strips of the Fencing Club, the statuesque blonde who won the Olympic gold medal in 1928 and the silver medal in Berlin last year, gave a lesson in fencing style to the other nineteen entrants.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Wait Lord of 238 East Sixty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Wait Lord, to Robert Gordon Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Gordon Pierce of 64 East End Avenue.

Reports that both civil and military prisoners in Loyalist Spain are well treated, that refugees from Madrid and other parts are being well cared for and that the morale and organization of the Spanish republican army is steadily improving were brought to Paris today by the Duchess of Atholl, Dame Rachel Crowdy and Miss Ellen Wilkinson, M. P.

James A. Roe, Democratic State Committeeman in the Fourth Assembly District in Queens, announced yesterday he and his followers would name a complete ticket of candidates to run in the Democratic primaries next September against the designees of the county organization for all posts to be filled in the county at the November elections.
North American wheat markets declined sharply in the early trading today, largely reflecting a break of 5 to 6 1/8 cents a bushel in futures in Liverpool.

Sales by candy manufacturers of higher priced candies in 1936 were 11 per cent higher in poundage and 13 per cent higher in value than in 1935, the Department of Commerce announced today. The figures, according to F. H. Rawls, chief of the foodstuffs division, were based on reports of 308 manufacturers, representing 70 per cent of the industry.

President Roosevelt attended the funeral of W. Forbes Morgan, informed President Manuel Quezon that he would be unable to make his contemplated trip to the Philippines next Fall and discussed plans for his visit to New Orleans next week with Governor Leche of Louisiana.

A first edition of John Milton's "Comus" was valued at $6,000 in a transfer tax report, filed yesterday, on the estate of John Whipple Frothingham, formerly of Tarrytown. The book was part of a collection of rare volumes, valued at $55,680.

In its annual report filed today with Governor Lehman and the Legislature the Power Authority of the State of New York declares that in another decade the State will be faced with a serious shortage of cheap power unless steps are taken without delay to make available all the power potentialities of the St. Lawrence and Niagara Rivers.

Turpentins firm, 35 3/4c; sales, 138 barrels; receipts 283 barrels; shipments, 4 barrels; stock, 23, 265 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 452: receipts, 1,19; shipments, 991; stock, 45,316. Quote: B, $7.05; D, $7.10-15: E, $7.55: F. G, $8.05; H, $8.05-07 1/2; I, K, M, N, $8.07 1/2; WG, $8.10; WW, X, $8.75.

After deliberating for slightly more than three hours, a Kings County blue-ribbon jury at 9:25 last night returned a verdict of murder in the first degree against Salvatore Ossido, 26-year-old barber, for criminally assaulting and killing 9-yearold Einer Sporrer in the backroom of his barber shop at 293 Irving Avenue, Brooklyn, on March 19.

There was great rejoicing in "Heaven", yesterday. The "angels" danced and sang in the streets, for Father Divine, the messiah of Lenox Avenue, had returned to earth, or, more specifically, had "rematerialized" himself in and out of a cell at Plice Headquarters.

With exports increasing by 21 per cent. and imports gaining' 25 per cent, Japan's unfavorable trade balance was increased by 40 per cent during the first three months of this year, according to a report from Commercial Attache Frank S. Williams at Tokyo, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

In you-know-whose words, it's a blessed event at the Roxy, a bundle from Darryl Zanuck's West Coast heaven, a first dividend from that clearly eugenic (and thoroughly compatible) blending of Walter Winchell and the talkies. Mr.

The March index of factory employment and the index of payrolls reached their highest levels since November, 1929, according to Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, who announced today that more than 305,000 workers were returned to employment in March and that weekly payrolls were $15,100,000 greater in the manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries surveyed each month by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

NOWADAYS almost every one is ready to explain that in American literature William Dean Howells doesn't count for much. That is, indeed, one of the favorite critical cliches of our time. Edgar Allan Poe and the bells, bells, bells? He was a great man, a very great artist. Fenimore Cooper? He too was great,

THE following is a communication received from a man who knew nothing about golf until he went to Florida and there discovered a few things, to wit and viz: "Sir: I'm going through Texas now, heading for Mexico, but here's something I found out recently when I passed through Sarasota, Fla.

Dartmouth opened its New England Intercollegiate Lacrosse League campaign by defeating Brown, 14 to 1 today. Dartmouth dominated the play in all except the third period when Brown accounted for its single point. Malloy was high scorer with five goals.

With the British Navy protecting them from any interference outside the three-mile limit of Spanish territorial waters, the British food ships Hamsterley, MacGregor and Stanbrook ran through General Francisco Franco's blockade and arrived at Bilbao, Spain, today after an eventful voyage.

More than 2,000,000 Canadians ill eighteen cities, seventeen in Eastern Canada and one in the West, will have daylight saving time this Summer, and prospects today were that Winnipeg would fall into line.

Sewell L. Avery, chairman and president of Montgomery Ward Co., at the annual meeting today reported rising earnings for 1937, but disclosed that the company is in need of additional capital because of its record-breaking volume of sales.

A four-point program for the elimination of misleading advertising copy by joint action of advertisers and media, in order to "stave off unwelcome and bureaucratic government censorship," was advocated by Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store, Brooklyn, in addressing the Advertising Club of the Columbus Chamber of Commerce yesterday.
Most immigrants to America in these later years come, as WORDSWORTH says in his "Ode on Intimations of Immortality," "trailing clouds of glory" directly "from GOD who is our home."

Governors Island Captain Julius H. Haecker, CA-Res.. is relieved from further assignment and duty with CCC Co. 210, Camp SP-9 (N. Y.), Katonah, N. Y., and will proceed to Headquarters Redding District, CCC, Redding, Calif., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities.

Judge Benjamin P. Epstein of the Criminal Court today held an entire jury in contempt of court, sentenced eleven of the twelve jurors to terms in the county jail and fined the twelfth juror $50. A six-month jail sentence was imposed on the bailiff in charge of the jury.

The value of sales on all national securities Exchanges in March was $3,416,595,823, the largest since the Securities and Exchange Commission began compilation of such figures in October, 1934, according to a tabunation issued today by the commission.

A revival of activity in the new Issue market lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $96,682,000, the largest volume since the week ended March 12, when offerings aggregated $135,594,250. This compared with only $7,650,000 in new bonds placed on the market last week, and with $159,718,910 marketed during this period a year ago.

Miss Elizabeth Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dashiell Myers of Merion, was married this afternoon to Frederick Godfrey Corbus Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Godfrey Corbus of this city. The ceremony was performed by Canon Ernest Earp in the Church of the Redeemer, Brvn Mawr.

Within twenty-four hours of announcement that a special conference would be called by the American Federation of Labor to make further plans to combat the Committee for Industrial Organization, the John L. Lewis group acted to issue charters to local industrial unions and to city and State industrial councils.

Creation of a legislative committee to investigate transportation facilities in the metropolitan area in the hope of bringing about a reduction in rates, so as to permit families to move to sparsely settled sections, is proposed in a resolution introduced today by Senator Dunnigan, Democratic leader.
Charles M. Wetzler, editor and president of the Eagle-Gazette Publishing Company here, died early today. He was 84 years old.

The engagement of $6,221,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $6,096,000 in England and $125,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Four local banks purchased the gold.

The Hydro-Electric Securities Corporation reported yesterday for 1936 a net income of $743,580 after all deductions, exclusive of $8,553,504 net loss on sales of securities and $17,084 loss on exchange, compared with net income of $519,935 in 1935, exclusive of $13,968 profit on sale of securities and profit of $5,611 on exchange. The accounts are maintained in Canadian currency.

A sharp increase in the production and use of industrial alcohol was indicated by Treasury figures today. Thirtythree plants produced in March 19,883,412 proof gallons of industrial alcohol, compared with 17,571,531 gallons in February and 13,899,209 gallons in March, 1936.

Many churches will observe tomorrow church music week backed by the Municipal Art Commission. This will be with special services of song and organ and by sermons on sacred music. In several of the leading edifices there will be given the closing oratorio of the season.

The Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center yesterday placed on public view an exhibition of about 100 models of historical and modern locomotives, passenger and freight trains, complete to the last detail.

Miss Elizabeth Price Yallalee daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Yallalee of this city, has chosen June 29 for her marriage to Bayard Dominick 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gayer G. Dominick of New Canaan, Conn., and New York.

167th St, 190th to 198th E (9-2456); Drake Operating Corp to N. Y. Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, 105 E 22d St, extends mtg to April 15, 1947, at 41/2 per cent; $55,000. Grand Concourse, 840 (9-2459): Post Orchard Corp to Aetna Life Insurance Co, Hartford, Conn, installments, 4 per cent; $465,000.

The New York Athletic Club, defending titleholder, and the Duquesne Dolphins of Pittsburgh progressed to the final round of the national A. A. U. hard-ball water polo championship at the New York A. C. pool last night. The teams will meet tonight in the final.

Performing under climatic conditions that put almost every one in an expectant mood for a Notre Dame touchdown over Army at any moment, the Giants pried open the National League season at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
A bridge foursome, Mr. and Mrs. S. W. Smith, Mrs. Frank A. Crehan and A. C. Capron, all received perfect hands in one deal last night.

Associated Telephone and Telegraph Company-For 1936: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, $117,339, against $143,205 in preceding year. Fig es do not include accounts of associated companies.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to the list Spiegel, Inc., cumulative preferred stock, $4.50 convertible series, no par value; Borg-Warner Corporation capital stock, $5 par value; Hupp Motor Car Corporation common stock, $1 par value; Neisner Brothers, Inc., common stock,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 22: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Lindt, J. H., C.A.C., General Staff Corps, one month and 5 days leave, April 24, with permission to visit foreign countries. Uhl, F. E., Infantry, 21 days leave, April 23.

Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hunnewell of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Ticknor Hunnewell, to Richard Sanders Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh D. Scott of Wellesley, Mass.
Not long ago the Albany Legislature passed several bills tending to impair the efficient and disinterested administration of New York City's school system.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Leaders of child welfare agencies and other enterprises serving South gathered in Central Park yesterday afternoon to attend dedication ceremonies of a memorial tree in tribute to the late Charles Hayden, financier and philanthropist, who was actively interested in scores of organizations helping boys and girls.

Internal-revenue collections for the first nine months of the 1937 fiscal year amounted to $3,244,265,243, the Treasury announced today. This was materially below the expected yield, but was an increase of $587,175,160 over the first three quarters of the preceding year.
The Athletics, who ruined Washington's inaugural game Mondays spoiled a Senators' Ladies' Day affair today by scoring a 7-to-1 victory before some 15,000 fans.

Mr. and Mrs. Zalmon G. Simmons Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., who are at the Park Lane, entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Elizabeth Shelby Sinclair and Louis W. Hoyle of Pasadena, Calif., whose engagement has been announced.

With Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan unexpectedly lining up with Mayor La Guardia, the Board of Estimate failed to adopt a resolution yesterday authorizing the use of $50,000 from accruals for an Aldermanic relief investigation. The resolution was introduced by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens.

A letter from King George VI will be read at a pre-coronation service which will be held under the auspices of the American Order Sons of St. George tomorrow at 4 P. M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The coronation will take place in London on May 12.

Rentals reported yesterday indicated a demand for business quarters in scattered sections of Manhattan. Most of the renting, however, was done in the midtown area and involved leases with a variety of tenants. Some deals were closed with concerns in the fur trade.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Aside from a spotty demand for some fine pulled wools and very occasional interest in fine Australian wool, the market has been very dull locally.

The House Ways and Means Committee was told today by H. H. Kent, assistant general counsel of the Treasury Department, that the new Railroad Retirement Tax Bill would yield the required amount of revenue but that the department had withheld its recommendation of the measure because it did not agree with two methods suggested.

Six-hit pitching by Roxie Lawson and a twelve-hit attack on three opposinga hurlers gave the Tigers a 10-2 triumph over the White Sox today in the opening game of the American League in Chicago. A crowd of 15,000 saw the contest.

Mrs. Ann E. Mackey Flynn, widow of William J. Flynn, Chief of the United States Secret Service and of the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice, died on Thursday night after a long illness in her home at 3,681 Broadway. She was 60 years old.

Overcrowded and insanitary school buildings are endangering the health of thousands of children, the West of Central Park Association declared yesterday in making public a "startling" survey on public school conditions in the Eighth School District, Manhattan.

Mr. and Mrs. James Burke Irwin of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Rankin Irwin, to James Crane Kellogg 3d, son of Mrs. James Crane Kellogg Jr., also of Elizabeth, and the late Mr. Kellogg.

The hostility to Mayor La Guardia in the Fifteenth Assembly District Club flared up at its annual meeting last night, despite efforts to prevent it. The result was the passage of a motion, made by Edward Bruen, an anti-La Guardia member, for a meeting soon to discuss the club's position on whether it should support the Mayor for renomination on the Republican ticket.

A sharp increase in activity in the State and municipal new issue market is indicated for next week with a total of $23,958,203 new issues scheduled for sale,. represented by one State and fifty-four municipalities.
In a dull, dismal setting at Franklin Field today two Olympians touched off the sparks of great performances as the forty-third annual Penn relay carnival began on sodden rain-soaked cinders.

Jack Schwartz, 37 years old, jobless printer of 1,048 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, was held in $2,500 bail yesterday in felony court for examination Monday on a charge of obtaining $970 from two brothers on the promise of obtaining Federal and city jobs for them.

James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President, flashed a blue-tinged "union" card and then assisted a professional steam shovel engineer in breaking ground yesterday for the new Christopher Columbus High School, Astor and Radcliff Avenues, the Bronx, as city school officials applauded and 4,000 youngsters cheered.
Stockholders of the Aviation Corporation approved yesterday a proposal for the sale of certain securities held by the company and the payment of the proceeds to the stockholders.

Jack Schwartz, 37 years old, jobless printer of 1,048 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, was held in $2,500 bail yesterday in felony court for examination Monday on a charge of obtaining $970 from two brothers on the promise of obtaining Federal and city jobs for them.

James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President, flashed a blue-tinged "union" card and then assisted a professional steam shovel engineer in breaking ground yesterday for the new Christopher Columbus High School, Astor and Radcliff Avenues, the Bronx, as city school officials applauded and 4,000 youngsters cheered.
Two long homers by Warren (Buddy) Rosar, rookie catcher, featured a 7 to 6 victory the Newark Bears scored over the Montreal Royals at Ruppert Stadium today.

The 373d anniversary of the birth of William Shakespeare was celebrated yesterday afternoon by a small group of persons before the Shakespeare statue in the Mall in Central Park. One of the leaders was Daniel Frohman, dean of American producers.

Raymond H. Fiero sold to the Kanan Building Corporation a plot of 9,500 square feet at the northeast corner of Albany Avenue and Avenue D, Brooklyn, which is being improved with a taxpayer containing six stores.

A plot 182 by 117 feet at 129 Bentley Avenue, between the Boulevard and West Side Avenue, Jersey City, was sold by the estate of Rosalind B. Towor to David Lerner, builder, for improvement with one-family homes. It was sold for $12,000 through Ben Schlossberg, Inc., broker.

Sailing for Havre via Southampton today on the French liner Ile de France are Mr. and Mrs. Demetri Draghicesco, Edouard Jonas, Dr. Thomas Mann, Andre Chevrillon, Mr. and Mrs. George Toland Cameron, Baron Valentin Mandelstan, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Young, Warren Irvin and Bernard Ragner.

An attempt to rescue a young deckhand from drowning at the government wharf here today ended in a double drowning. Geoffrey R. Milne, naval architect and supervising engineer of the Manseau Shipyards Company, and Charles Moreau, 23, were drowned.

Professor Joseph Halban, gynecologist and honorary member of the American College of Surgeons, died today. His age was 76. He was the husband of the late Selma Kurz, opera singer, and father of Desiree Kurz Halban, a soprano of the Vienna State Opera.
Movements of commodities by truck during March increased 25.93 per cent over March, 1936, according to the monthly survey of the American Trucking Associations, Inc., made public today.

Everett Scott of Fort Wayne, Ind., former Yankee baseball star, rolled 207, 234 and 212 for 653 to set the pace in yesterday's singles session in the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.
Mrs. Violet Wells Norton was convicted by a Federal jury tonight of misuse of the mails in pressing her contention that Clark Gable, film star, was the father of her illegitimate daughter.

In the April Bulletin of the New York Public Library, so rich in material about baseball, Mr. ROBERT W. HENDERSON denies the conclusion reached by the late A. G. SPALDING'S commission to investigate the history of the game that it is "of modern and purely American origin."
Six hundred sit-down strikers evacuated the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant early today to the accompaniment of tooting automobile horns and shouting.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Painting in Germany, England and France," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M. "After Impressionism," Edith R. Abbot, 2 P. M.; "The Exhibition of American Silver," Alfred Busselle Jr., 2 P. M.; "The Daily Life of the Egyptians - Ancient and Modern; Last of the Wood Engravers," motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

Indignation has been aroused here by reports of violent methods employed by officials of the Spanish Government yesterday when they examined the luggage and other personal effects of the Chilean Ambassador, Aurelio Nunez Morgado, a few minutes before he intended to take a plane in Valencia.

Daily average retail sales in March for small towns and rural areas showed larger increases in the South than in other parts of the country over the sales for March, 1936, according to estimates of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce made public today.

After ten hours' deliberation, a Federal court jury reported to Judge William Bondy at 10 o'clock last night that it was unable to agree on the guilt or innocence of Harry H. Levey, advertising agent, who has been on trial for two weeks on charges of mail fraud, brought by the government.

The first medical weapon for combating fatal peritonitis, which promises to become a milestone in medical progress, was reported here today before the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

A possibility that body growth and functional development may depend upon three or more chemicals easily obtainable in commercial quantities was suggested to members of the American Philosophical Society today by Dr. Leonard G. Rowntree, director of the Philadelphia Institute for Medical Research. He reported remarkable results from the injection into rats of a synthetic hormone composed of agents found previously in thymus extract.

The New York Junior League "Follies" -opened last night at the New Amsterdam Theatre before a large audience. The program of musical gayety and comedy skits running into twenty-two scenes had a cast of 150 New York girls and young men and was presented with the smoothness of a professional theatrical production.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth Abel, daughter of Mrs. Henry Abel of this place and the late Mr. Abel, to Edward J. O'Byrne of Paterson.

A strike of workers of the Etched Products Company, 39-01 Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, was ended yesterday when Albert Nierenberg, president of the corporation, and James Lustig, representing the International Association of Machinists, reached an agreement.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of New York, defendant in a suit brought by the Federal Trade Commission, produced witnesses here today to disprove allegations that it was violating the Robinson-Patman act of 1936.
Hilo, second city of Hawaii, was theoretically destroyed today by a "bombardment" from eight ships of the United States Fleet.

Demand for lamb continued selow and carcasses sold about 50 cents below Thursday's early quotations. Other classes were in fair to good demand and prices stronger. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be steady to slightly higher, veal sharply higher, lamb about steady with Thursday's late decline, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. Mary E. Coppell Coster, the wife of Oliver De Lancey Coster, vice president of the real estate firm of Pease Elliman, Inc., died on Thursday of a heart ailment at her home, 525 Park Avenue, after a month's illness.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick of the Riverside Church called upon youth to do more than merely to "keep the law," in an address opening a three-day session of the United Christian Youth Conference yesterday.
The Northwestern University A Cappella Choir, under the direction of Max T. Krone, gave a concert in Carnegie Hall last night, with Alec Templeton, blind English pianist, as assisting artist.

Employes of the Packard Motor Car Company will vote Wednesday in the automobile industry's first election under the National Labor Relations Act to decide whether they wish the United Automobile Workers of America to represent them in collective bargaining.

Formation of Stewart, James Co., Inc., export and import house with offices at 1 Broadway, was announced here yesterday by George F. Dixon, president and general manager. Mr. Dixon formerly was president of Sears International, Inc.

The Senate Civil Service Committee, at the suggestion of Postmaster General Farley, referred to a subcommittee today the bill passed by the House putting first, second and third-class postmasters under the Civil Service.
Lee Pattison, director of the Metropolitan Opera's Spring season, will speak this afternoon at the Spring luncheon of the Barnard College Club, at the Hotel Plaza.

With those automobile companies which had been affected by strikes returning to newspaper advertising within another week or so, May is expected to be the first month of the year in which auto linage will register a substantial rise over 1936, -according to comment here yesterday.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

Proposals to reduce the capitalization of the International Paper and Power Company by $37,500,000 will come before a general meeting on May 12. The directors have proposed that the par value of the 1,000,000 common shares be cut from $52.50 to $15 a share.

Burton A. Zorn, managing director of the City Industrial Relations Board, recently created by Mayor La Guardia, announced yesterday the settlement of a threatened strike in the boot and shoe repair trade with a 10 per cent increase for the workers and a shorter week.

A plan to change the hours at three public markets in New York City, proposed by William Fellowes Morgan, Commissioner of Markets, was defeated tonight at a meeting of 231 farmers of Nassau and Suffolk in the police auditorium here.

The glamour of Hollywood held only a passing interest for four Middle Western University co-eds who rejected parts in a picture, one of them said today. "I guess we belong on the Middle Western plains," said Miss Mary Fislar of University of Nebraska, whose beauty won her a free trip to California and a screen test.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange will consider on April 29 formation of the new firm of Simmons Peckham. Members will be Edward C. Simmons, Henry A. Peckham, James S. Martin, Lillian H. Martin and Alfred F. Smith. The last two will be special partners.
A dinner for B. J. Van Ingen, president of B. J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., marked last night the twentieth anniversary of the formation of that municipal bond firm.

Bradford M. Couch, investment broker of Philadelphia, died yesterday in the Florida Medical Center at Venice, Fla., of heart disease, it was learned here yesterday. Mr. Couch, who was 53 years old, had been ill for a year.

Fox St (10-2720). s e cor of Longwood Ave, 100x100; Bessie Handler to Benjamin N. Nelson, 851 W. 177th St; mtg $150,000. Hoe Ave (11-2987), e s 125 ft s of Jennings St, 1OOx100; Bessie Brotman to Enarc Realty Corp, 154 Nassau St, mtg $121,000. 176th St (11-2918), n w cor of Bathgate Ave, 129x33; Tribridge Operating Corp to Anna Christensen, 21 W. 65th St, mtg $26,000.

Ferrisdale Village Vamp, a white and black pointer, today was announced as the winner of the Junior All-Age Stake, most important of three opening events at the tenth annual Spring meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club.
Eugene V. Daly, lawyer, died yesterday at his home, 143-38 Thirtyeighth Avenue, Flushing, Queens, of heart disease. He was 70 years old.

Maurice Nast, 67-year-old retired salesman, of 35 Waldorf Court, Brooklyn, who was rescued by a fireman from a ledge atop the Hotel Pennsylvania last Dec. 15 while tense crowds looked up from the street, fell or jumped to his death at 10:45 o'clock last night, according to the police, from the clubrooms of the Southern Travelers Association on the seventeenth floor of the same hotel.
Now the bottle washers are on strike. Asking for an increase from 10 to 30 cents an hour from three dealers in old bottles, they say they will wash no more bottles until the rise is forthcoming.

TORONTO, known already for its symphony orchestra, its Hart House String Quartet and its Promenade Symphonies, recently advanced with one bound into another musical area with the prduction of "Tannhaeuser" by the Opera Guild of Toronto.

Miss Elizabeth Browning Canfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Browning Canfield of Haverford, was married this afternoon to Marcel R. MacAlpine. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Roulston McKean in Old Christ Church.

Miss Ebba Christine Hartten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey F. Hartten of Cranford, became the bride of Rufus King Weeks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Weeks of Elizabeth, in St. Luke's Episcopal Church this afternoon.

Junior members of the Brooklyn Woman's Club will hold their annual Spring luncheon Friday at the clubhouse, 114 Pierrepont Street. Special guests will be Mrs. Thomas Henry McClintock, president of the Brooklyn Woman's Club; Mrs. William R. Bayes, chairman of the advisory committee for the junior membership; Mrs. William J. Baldwin Jr. and Mrs. Richard W. Reid.

General Ballington Booth, leader of the Volunteers of America, announced yesterday the appointment of Colonel A. C. Wright as commander for the Eastern Area of the United States. Colonel Wright formerly commanded the Northern California District with headquarters in San Francisco.

Ninety-seven building ways are available or could be made available for the construction of sea-going tonnage in the United States, according to a survey just completed by the National Council of American Shipbuilders. The council limited this classification of shipping to vessels 300 or more feet long.

Oswald Jacoby, a member of the Four Aces team, and Lester Bachner, his partner, won the grand national open pair championship and the Ely Culbertson cup early this morning ni the bridge tournament conducted at the Hotel Montclair by the United States Bridge Association. They had 450.5 match points.

About 500 women shoppers in May's department store, 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, were thrown into disorder at noon yesterday when twelve girls entered the store, took up positions on various floors and shouted "Fire!" There was no fire, no one was injured and police restored order after making one arrest.

Advance reports from the committee in charge of arrangements for the Central Atlantic regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards to be held in this city at the Hotel Biltmore, May 14 and 15, indicate that the attendance will be the largest of any of the regional conferences in various parts of the country held during the last two years under the auspices of the national body.

Miss Shirley Woodward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cedric Rainey Woodward of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married to Herbert Fletcher Eggert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Eggert of 117 East Seventy-second Street and Quogue, L. I., yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth, planning to adapt American and European ideas on farm tenancy and cooperatives to the Philippine Islands, said today that he had engaged Frederic C. Howe as an adviser.

Service on the Queens branch of the city's Independent Subway was extended to 169th Street and Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, yesterday, with Mayor La Guardia and a group of city and borough officials joining with civic groups to celebrate the event.

" Smoky Joe" Martin's son, Joseph B. Martin Jr., whose life ambition to become as great a fireman as his father was partially realized when he became a battalion chief, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital, Flushing.

An increase of more than 2 per cent in the city's death rate is attributed by the New York City Department of Health to influenza and pneumonia which broke out throughout this country and abroad at the start of the year.
Wooldon Manor, the oceanfront estate of Mrs. James P. Donahue at Southampton, L. I., will be sold at auction on Saturday, May 22, on the premises. Joseph P. Day will be the auctioneer.

MR. GARRATT, in his foreword, describes the book that should be written about Gladstone. It is a book that would reveal the man himself, the secret of his worldwide and continuing fame, the atmospheric spell of his personality over the imagination of the common people.
Sir Walter Sidney Shaw, chairman of the Palestine Commission of Inquiry, died today at his Dorset home. He was 74 years old.

Puerto Rico's -three Supreme Court justices consider President Roosevelt's letter to the new Commissioner of Education, Jose M. Gallardo, in which the President referred to future Puerto Rican generations as American citizens who should know English, as one of the most important official declarations during the island's American regime.

MADRID-Civilian rule was restored in the city, General Miaja being relieved from all except military duties. A former baker, a Socialist, was elected chief of the Municipal Council. Shelling of the city by the Rebels was halted. Page 1.

The annual country fair of the Home for Seamen's Children will be held May 8 on the grounds of the home, 657 Castleton Avenue, Staten Island. Proceeds will be devoted to the maintenance of the institution, which cares for more than eighty destitute children of seamen.

Music Hall of the Air-Viola Philo, soprano, Jan 'Peerce, tenor, and Robert Weede, baritone, will be soloists with the symphony orchestra conducted by Mischa Violin in an hour broadcast: WJZ, 12:30 P. M.
HOLDS 'OPEN HOUSE' TODAY

The gift of a completely equipped gymnasium, from the estate of the late Mr. and Mrs. William S. Hofstra, through the generosity of the trustees, Howard S. Brower and James H. Barnard, was announced today at Hofstra College of New York University here.

Members of the junior committee for the supper dance to be given by the New York Wellesley Club in the Astor Gallery of the WaldorfAstoria on Friday will be guests at a dinner in the Therese Worthington Grant restaurant before the dance.

Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, Mayor and Mrs. Fiorello La Guardia and others of prominence in civic, artistic and social circles are patrons and patronesses for the eighth annual series of garden days to be held under the auspices of the School Nature League, beginning May 13.
The Kittredge Players will present as their annual Spring production on Thursday and Friday nights at the Heckscher Theatre Rose Franken's three-act comedy, "Another Language."

Two plays by students in Professor Hallie Flanagan's playwriting class were presented tonight in the Vassar College experimental theatre. "Fallen Mangoes," by Barbara Dole, '37, is a tragic story of racial conflict in Hawaii. Ethel Frank, '37, contributed a comedy satire, "Relax," concerned with Summer theatre actors.
Outranking in scope all other measures now before the Legislature is the Florida "Recovery Act," which would eliminate chain stores, and there is little indication as to its ultimate destiny.

" I haven't played a social game in fifteen years," Mrs. J. Borden Harriman was overheard to remark recently to a friend. "I've been too absorbed in politics." Politics is the sole hobby of this woman whose service to the Democratic party has won for her the appointment of Minister to Norway, confirmed last week by the Senate.

Formed by factory workers in the automobile plants to combat activities of the C. I. O. and to provide a medium for the thousands of workers not affiliated with any union to obtain representation in collective bargaining with General Motors, the Independent Automobile Employes Association has been formed, it was announced here tonight.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Palmer, a retired school teacher, 72 years old, died at her home here this morning of accidental asphyxiation when a tea kettle boiled over and put out the flame on her gas stove. Her body and that of her cat, also killed by the gas' fumes, was found by a nephew, Robert Palmer.

Attired in their traditional goldbraided uniforms and towering bearskin shakos, the military garb of more than a century ago, the Old Guard, New York City's oldest military organization, paid its annual visit to City Hall yesterday for the installation of officers for the coming year.

RECENT news dispatches from San Francisco report that the colony of large-eared seals on the Farallon Islands is being decimated by a school of king killer whales. The Farallons lie about twenty miles to seaward of the Cliff House and the nearly completed Golden Gate Bridge, and on clear days they are plainly visible from the shore.
