As a kind of valedictory to her work at Mount Holyoke College, from which she retires this year, President Mary E. Woolley has suggested to the heads of the neighboring institutions of Amherst and Smith the possibility of a "University of the Connecticut Valley."

Fritz Crisler's Princeton football squad climaxed its annual Spring training drive today by scrimmaging for nearly two hours and a half with St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia on Fitzpatrick Field. Carl Perina, Tiger freshman fullback, scored the only touchdown of the informal contest on a short line plunge.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in smaller volume than in the preceding period. Consisting largely of retirements for sinking funds and small parts of outstanding issues, the calls covered a diversified list of bonds, many of foreign companies.

With the addition of the Japanese and other beetles to the long list of plant enemies, it is a comfort to a busy gardener to find that there are some plants that seem to remain unmolested or are at least relatively free from attack by the worms or the sucking or chewing insects.

In the last fifteen months the WPA project on vocational guidance in secondary schools has advanced such training by at least ten years, according to Charles M. Smith, Board of Education director of the project.

Members of the board of directors of the Brooklyn Music School Settlement have arranged a motion picture presentation of Schubert's Unfinished Symphony and a dance interpretation of Schubert's "Quartet in A Minor" for the night of May 11 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Dr. George E. Vincent, former president of the Rockefeller Foundation, will be the featured speaker at the Spring convention of the Eastern Federation of Delphian Chapters, meeting Friday at the Hotel Roosevelt. He will talk on "The Pain of Thinking" to the 400 delegates from sixty chapters in the New England States, as well as New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

The skippers of the M. I. T. Nautical Association gained a 3-point lead over Harvard and Dartmouth today in the first three of a series of eight races on the Charles River Basin in the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association's first title dinghy regatta. The races will conclude tomorrow.
VANCOUVER, B. C. BRITISH Columbia's long Win ter is over and the highway to the north that, when ex tended, will provide access from the United States to Alaska, is again attractive to motorists.
B. Henry Pelzer of this city has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Grace Washburn Pelzer, to Carr Robinson Purser, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Purser of Charlotte, N. C.

A testimonial dinner to the Very Rev. Mgr. James F. Kelley, who became president of Seton Hall College here last August, will be held at the Essex House in Newark on Wednesday evening. More than 800 persons from all sections of the country will attend.

March saw an increase of 36 per cent in the value of buildings to be constructed in the country's principal cities, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to figures made public today by the Department of Labor. Permits for new dwellings indicated an increase of 87 per cent in value from March last year. Only in the case of non-residential structures was a falling off indicated.
The National Railways of Mexico have ordered 18 locomotives from the American Locomotive Company, 400 freight cars from the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company and 175 freight cars

George E. Gifford of 110 Haven Avenue, in charge of the credit department of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, died in that hospital yesterday of a stroke of apoplexy which he suffered on March 27 while playing bridge at the New York Athletic Club.

In the days when Adelina Patti and Lilli Lehmann were making rich musical history for New York, the love of song gave courage to a troop of young women to form one of the earliest chorals for women in this city.

Joseph Kelban, 45 years old, of 722 Alabama Avenue, Brooklyn, business agent and delegate of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Operators Union, convicted on April 13 of endangering the safety of persons in a public place, was fined $200 yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn.

Miss Katharine Caroline Gilchrist of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gilchrist of Havensmead, Jaffrey, N. H., became the bride of Roswell Delmege Trimble Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell Delmege Trimble of Tyrone, Lorraine, Va., at St. Paul's Episcopal Church here today.

THE guest artist this week in our regular "Gone With the Wind" item is George Cu kor, its director-to-be, who by this time must be dreamily studying the aristocratic cornices and fine ante-bellum balconies of old houses along the James River.

Sir George Paish, British economist and former editor of The London Statist, will discuss "Essentials for Permanent Prosperity" at a dinner of the Wharton Institute of the University of Pennsylvania on Friday at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. The institute meeting will continue on Saturday.

BY the time this note is published all, or most, of the national exhibitions arranged by the American Artists Congress throughout the country will no doubt be current. The regional plan adopted for the first annual embraces these cities: Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland,

Archie San Romani, mighty little flier from Emporia, Kan., State Teachers College, gave the famous Rideout twins of Texas a lesson in distance running today, and five Rice Institute sprinters sped to a pair of championships in the raindrenched twenty-eighth annual Drake Relay Carnival.

Fordham fashioned its fifth victory of the diamond campaign yesterday with an impressive 11-0 romp over Lehigh behind the air-tight twirling of Johnny Barris, the timely hitting of his mates and the perfect defensive work of an infield which is at least the equal of any collegiate nine in the metropolitan area.
EXHIBITION developments of the week have been very diverse. The largest of the group affairs is the Architectural League annual in the American Fine Arts Building, which will be on until May 18.
Newsprint made of pine pulpwood sufficient to mail a sample fourpage newspaper to 2,170 publishers in the United States began rolling from a machine in the Savannah Pulp and Paper Laboratory today.

The camp life which thousands of children are anticipating this Summer will be discussed from various angles tomorrow at a conference of executives of seventy organizations called by the Jewish Vacation Association.

Ossie Linden's triple in the tenth to score Pitcher Bob Lane, who had been walked, gave Dartmouth a 9-8 victory over Brown on Aldrich Field today. Lane pitched the extra frame after Ted Bruce had worked the regulation nine innings.
Mrs. James F. Curtis entertained last evening at a large dinner for Mrs. John T. Pratt, former representative, who came from New York to pass the week-end here.

The threatened strike of 15,000 to 25,000 railway freight handlers and clerks in the metropolitan area was postponed until tomorrow at noon under a forty-eight-hour truce made yesterday when negotiations for a settlement were resumed.

The marriage of Miss Alice Parker Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse W. Murphy of Battle Creek, Mich., to Arthur Joseph Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Barrett of Portsmouth, N. H., took place here yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Joseph A.
In Washington the Biological Survey is preparing to add to the strange list of government pamphlets a dictionary of American nicknames for birds.

The age-worn contention that 3year-olds, unless standouts, do not beat older horses in the Spring of the year again was borne out as Calumet Farm's Count Morse, shouldering top weight of 117 pounds, scored a romping victory in the first running of the Ben Ali Handicap, feature at Keeneland Park today.

A bridge party and tea will be held next Saturday afternoon in the Florentine Room of Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the work of the Rev. Robert P. Kennelly of the Mary Knoll Mission of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society, Ossining, N. Y. Father Kennelly is here for a sabbatical year after ten

Tonnage from the Eastern Seaboard through the Canal to California, Oregon, Washington and British Columbia for March set an alltime high. Intercoastal westbound freight totaled 530,746 tons, as compared to the best previous mark of 336,019, set in July, 1929.

Tallying three runs in the tenth, the Panzer College baseball team defeated the Stevens Tech nine at the Castle Point field today, 10-7. Stevens rallied to score twice in the eighth and three times in the ninth to tie the score.

A letter from President Roosevelt praising the Jewish Welfare Board was made public last night at the board's annual meeting at the Hotel Astor. The President called the organization and its work a "significant social enterprise."

" Heaven" is a five-story brownstone house at 20 West 115th Street and "God" is a short, middle-aged Negro, in the simple theology of the followers of Father Divine, Harlem's most successful evangelist and entrepreneur.

Approval of a declaration by the North American Gas and Electric Company, a registered holding company, for the issue of 82,400 shares ot its 80-cent par value common stock and $764,000 of 6 per cent: cumulative income debentures, due, on Jan. 1, 1949, has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

APPLICATION of the Diesel engine to motor trucks in this country has heretofore chiefly been thought of in connection with the long haul of heavy loads. There are indications, however, from experience already recorded in practical use, that oilburning motors may find an increasing place even in city traffic in the East.
The Italian Official Gazette said today that Alessandro Lessona, now the Minister of Colonies, had been named Minister for the newly created division of Italian Africa.

Ten scholarships for study this Summer at the Academy of International Law, The Hague, have been awarded by the division of international law of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. Four women are among the recipients.

Steel work is scheduled to start this week on the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building which Sam Minskoff Sons will erect at 152 East Ninety-fourth Street. Several leases have been made from floor plans.

The regulation minimum height for recruits for the United States Marine Corps has been lowered from 5 feet 6 inches to 5 feet 4 inches, according to an announcement by Major Allen E. .Simon, in charge of the recruiting station at 641 Washington Street.
How long Premier Leon Blum's government will be able to continue cannot be safely predicted, but there is no doubt that the process of disintegration is well begun.
A ninth inning attack which netted two runs brought the Syracuse Chiefs their first triumph of the International League season today. They topped Buffalo, 5 to 4, in the second game of the series.
Sixtyone and a half acres ol land in this city and Clark Township, recently purchased by Harold A. Miller of Brooklyn from the Linden Trust Company, will be utilized for a large housing development.

From the town of Hughes, Ark., comes word of the organization of a Junior American Wildlife Institute by Harry Williamson, superintendent of the local special school district. "We should have our young people thinking about the conservation of our wildlife," says Mr. Williamson.
In 598 out of 760 replies of students to a questionnaire at Vassar College religion was voted "an essential element in the life of a wellbalanced and thoroughly integrated person."

The tenth anniversary of the New York to Paris flight of Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh will be celebrated with a luncheon on May 20 at the Lotos Club, 110 West Fiftyseventh Street, it was announced yesterday by Harry W. Chase, president of the club.

County Prosecutor Anthony M. Hauck said today he did not expect anything to develop from the "new" phase in the Lindbergh kidnapping case arising from a complaint filed by J. J. McNally, a private detective of Jersey City, accusing one Jacob Nosovitsky, alias J. J. Faulkner, of conspiracy in the crime.

Five mirrors, the property of Grenville T. Emmet, United States Minister to the Netherlands, were sold yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries for $1,075. The mirrors, which included a Chinese Chippendale overmantel mirror and two pairs of Chippendale sconce mirrors, were all bought by J. P. Fritz.
The Rutgers varsity crew opened its season by defeating the Manhattan College first eight over a mile-and-a-quarter course on the moonlit Raritan River tonight.

Westover Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Ellen Douglas Bruce Crane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crane of Westover, and Frederick Schilling Fisher Jr. of New York. Mr. Fisher is the son of Frederick S. Fisher and the late Mrs. Fisher of New York. The Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving, assisted by the Rev.

The ample surplus which is anticipated from the current budget has led the government to allocate the sum of 500,000 soles for the purchase of the properties facing the north side of the Presidential Palace. During colonia' times the grounds of the present palace were open as far as the banks of the River Rimac.

ROME.--Powerfully backed by the government, the Italian film industry is making a strong bid to recapture the place it held before the World War. Millions have been invested in the construction of a movie center, called "Citta del Cinema," or "Cinema City," a few miles from Rome.

A bridge party, fashion snow and tea will be held on May 5 at the Plaza in behalf of Colony House, Inc. Mrs. John Nix is general chairman of the benefit. Her aides include Mrs. Alfred H. Everson, Mrs. Harry M. Rice, Mrs. James M. Roche, Mrs. John D. Graham, Mrs. Charles W. Fyfe, Mrs. Gordon Edwards, Mrs. John R. Garnaus, Mrs. Leverett S. Lyons, Mrs.
Although there were indications of weak spots, the trend of busily ness last week showed some improvement over the previous week in various sections of the country.

The general committee in charge of the coronation dinner, which will be held on May 12 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the EnglishSpeaking Union of the United States, will be assisted by a junior committee headed by Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr.

The United States Fleeto opened. a concerted air and sea drive to "capture" the Island of Oahu at 4:15 P. M. today (9:45 P. M. New York time). Scores of planes from the aircraft carriers and battleships engaged in the war games flew over Honolulu and theoretically bombed Pearl Harbor and other ports.

David Bell, treasurer of Billy Minsky's Republic Burlesk Theatre at 213 West Forty-second Street at Times Square, was robbed of $2,200 at 8:45 o'clock last night by three armed hold-up men who passed twice through Saturday night audiences jamming the house without alarming any of the 1,100 customers.
Miss Helen Radey Woolford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Whitefield Woolford of Haverford, has completed plans for her marriage to Alfred Duff Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. G. Lewis of Pittsburgh.

THE superlatives used in circus ads would seem pretty well to cover the qualities of cir cus folk, and yet the superlative that fits them best has been ignored in the ads. Circus folk are the world's most inveterate hobbyists.

Trustees of the Children's Aid Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, will give a reception on Wednesday afternoon, May 5, to William Church Osborn. president of the society, in recognition of his thirty-five years of service in that office. It will be held in the Grand Central Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

Reductions in the home relief case load will make possible the elimination by July 1 of seven of the forty-five district offices mainstained by the Emergency Relief Bureau, the ERB governing board announced yesterday.

A new kind of youth movement, which aspires to a national status, has been started among the junior and senior classes at the Morgan Park High School, in Chicago. Its aim is not to obtain new rights for youth, but to make young people appreciative of their many privileges as American citizens and aggressive in their defense.

Following a conference yesterday at Pittsburgh, Irwin D. Wolf, chairman of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, announced a settlement of the discount controversy raised by the boys' clothing manufacturers when their association recently announced a reduction in terms for the Fall season.

Scoring four runs in the fifth inning in its only offensive of the game, Rhode Island defeated Boston College, 4-2, today to chalk up its sixth successive triumph. George Hines pitched steady ball to hold Boston College well in hand until the ninth, when he filled the bases, The Eagles got only one run, howl ever.
Long needed by the department of dramatic arts and by the playing group, the Masquers, Amherst College, is to have a little theatre to be known as the Kirby Memorial Theatre.

Scientists have found, buried inside a pyramid, a flaming red jade-encrusted throne upon which the ancient rulers of the Mayans used to sit. Carnegie Institution scientists call the find one of the most spectacular that has been made in the New World.

Chief of Police Timothy J. Crimmins has established a constant watch over all the town cemeteries against prowlers, who have been so anxious to get old lead, copper and iron for the present profitable junk market that they are even invading the graveyards.
THE treatment of recent events," observed Mr. Oberholtzer in the preface to his last volume on American history, "is an unhistorical exercise.
More than 4,000 persons filled Carnegie Hall last night at a meeting and concert in celebration of the fortieth anniversary of The Jewish Daily Forward, largest Jewish daily in the world.

If a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 becomes effective by the close of business Thursday, April 29, holders of record of the common stock of the Fedders Manufacturing Company will receive rights to subscribe, at $15 a share, for one additional share for each five shares held, according to a notice received by the New York Curb Exchange.

THIS was smoked out across the luncheon table at the track. When Racing Secretary John B. Campbell lights his post-luncheon cigar and his agile assistant, Francis P. Dunne, fills up his pipe, they certainly spin some odd tales of the turf. It was Mr. Dunne who came up with the one about a horse in a Futurity of the past.

John T. Flynn, member of the city's Board of Higher Education, has donated a plaque and an annual cup to be awarded to the "best player on the City College varsity tennis team," according to an announcement made yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics at C. C. N. Y.

Seeking greater continuity in the academic schedule, the faculty of Vassar College abolished the regular mid-year examination period and adopted recommendations including the termination of probation for the three upper classes.

THE largest collection in the world of the smallest books in the world is owned by James D. Henderson. A drummer for the miniature voltime, he organized the LXIVmos (or 64mos), which published a globe - trotting News - Letter printed each month in a different city.

Former Queen Bagakgametsi was sentenced today to pay a $250 fine or serve one year in jail for witchcraft. She pleaded guilty to charges of trying to harm the Queen Mother by mystic potions and incantations.
Vivian McGrath, Australia's ranking tennis player, appeared definitely out of the Davis Cup series with Mexico following an examination of his injured hand by a physician today.

The engagement of Miss Muriel Hottenroth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Hottenroth of 1,215 East Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn, to Frederick E. Magenheimer, son of Mrs. Frederick Magenheimer, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Magnheimer, has been announced by her parents.
Women's colleges are realizing more and more the value of the arts in the training of the undergraduate to appreciate beauty, according to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College.
On the site of what once comprised a part of his "beautiful and darling forests of Kentucky" is rising a shrine to a man who captured the beauty of birds and put it on paper-John James Audubon.
Each Thursday at 2:30 P. M. the Aldermanic Committee on Public Thoroughfares is scheduled to meet in City Hall to consider what's in a name. The committee is the street-naming body for the city.

THROUGH many centuries men have watched in wistful wonder the trackless flight of migratory birds. Now, in Machine Age trailers, men, too, obey a primitive instinct, and, like the feathered flocks, answer the inaudible warning that sends them out of bitter Winter's range; respond to the same return call that summons the birds to the greening meadows in the North.

Several leases of suburban residences were reported yesterday by Previews, Inc. Dr. Winifred Bronson rented the G. A. Shedden property at Chappaqua, N. Y., and H. G. Smith took the C. S. Powers house In Greenwich, Conn. The same brokers rented the Redfield estate in Westhampton Beach, L. I., the G. W. Merck property at Quogue, L. I., and the J. H. Ardrey place in Rye.

More than 13,000 homes in and around New York City are in the process of construction under the FHA insured mortgage system, according to Thomas G. Grace, director of the New York State FHA. A total of 11,000 homes are being built by operators.

WITHIN Radio City's massive shell of concrete and steel is a windowless, fire proof room lined with racks loaded with music ranging from "Summer Is a Cummin'," composed in the year 1250, to the latest song hit, "This Year's Kisses."

The marriage of Miss Anne Benton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Benton, to William Belden Hagyard, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Hagyard, took place this afternoon in the First Congregational Church here.
Higher wages and shorter hours and their probable effect on operating costs are the subject of a report just released by Fenner Beane, Wall Street brokerage house.

The "Americanization of England," which brings an outburst of protesting letters to the newspapers every few months, is spreading to advertising. Signs of the change are to be seen in almost any newspaper.
The United States lost an aviation record today when the French ace Captain Rossi covered 5,000 kilometers in 16 hours 3 minutes 382-5 seconds, averaging 312.5 kilometers an hour.

The provincial government here has experienced open rebellion against its method of dealing with recalcitrant church people. Last week more than 1,000 Protestants demonstrated four hours against police efforts to suppress a Confessional Synod gathering.

Scoring six runs in a hitless fifth inning Wagner College scored its first victory of the season yesterday at Clove Lake Field, S. I., defeating the Savage School of Physical Education, 8 to 3. Wagner trailed, 3 to 2, going into the fifth. Four errors, two walks,

Once again after a Lapse of fifteen years the nations are building battleships. The recent refusal of Japan to adhere to the 14-inch gun limitation suggested at the London Naval Conference last year, and the suggestion (officially denied) that she might build two 40,000 or 50,000 ton

Harvard's nine presented a tight defense against Cornell all the way today and capped a 9-3 Eastern Collegiate League victory with a fiverun uprising in the ninth before 1,500 spectators on Hoy Field.

Much interest was occasioned in Moscow by the sudden attack in Pravda on Alexander Serebrovsky, former head of the gold trust, who was recently appointed Vice-Commissar of Heavy Industry-the commissariat in which appalling instances of sabotage were alleged in the January Trotskyist trial and from which Gregory L. Piatakoff went to his death as a traitor.

The -Social Security Board will begin on Tuesday to issue social security account numbers to employes who have passed the age of 65, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the board, announced yesterday.

HALF Jeremiad, half Apocalypse, Ludwig Lewisohn's powerful and poetic new novel combines and carries to the uttermost limits all that he had to say in "The Island Within," that message to Israel. and "An Altar in the Fields." that extraordinary and extraordinarily weak epistle to the Gentiles.
Responding to inquiries from members, the National Association of Manufacturers made public last night some interpretations of rights and obligations under the National Labor Relations Act.

Miss Dorothy Harding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Austin Harding of Chestnut Hill, was married today to Samuel Rodger Callaway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Trowbridge Callaway of 34 East Sixty-eighth Street, New York.
A PARK AVENUE automobile salon for the display of Plymouth, De Soto and Chrysler motor cars is being opened this week on the ground floor of the Ritz Tower, Fifty-seventh Street and Park Avenue.

APRIL'S showers appear to have! Lampened the cinema considerably, causing a noticeable shrinkage in the ready-to-wears put on by the West Coast: Muse. It has been a capricious month, too. with several of the so-called "A" pictures getting "B"

Miss Elizabeth Martine Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Wood Smith of this place, has chosen May 29 for her wedding to Donald W. Roe, son of Mrs. Harriet E. Roe of East Orange. The ceremony will take place in the Church df St. Andrew, South Orange. A small reception will follow at the Woman's Club of Orange.

Two sales of industrial properties, one in Newark and the other in Irvington, have just been closed through the realty office of David Cronheim of Newark. The Newark deal involved the two structures at 126 First Street, on a plot 50 by 127 feet, sold for Katherine McKeon to Max Bernstein of Newark

ELIEL SAARINEN of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has been chosen by the trustees of the Berkshire Symphonic Festival as architect of the building to be erected at Tanglewood, between Stockbridge and Lenox, Mass.,

Telephone operators in the Time Bureau of the New York Telephone Company were preparing last night to handle more than 190,000 calls over the week-end-more than double the average--as the city's millions went on daylight-saving time today.

Rookie Infielder Lee Handley, who got $20,000 for signing with the Pirates, delivered a ninth-inning hit with two out to give Pittsburgh a 3-to-2 victory over the Reds today. Thirteen thousand fans saw Handley connect in the ninth with the bases loaded and drive in the tying and winning runs.
James S. Andrews, official astronomer of the observation roof at Rockefeller Center, reported yesterday that he had observed through the telescope two unusually large groups of sunspots.

The marriage of Miss Donita Helen Stahl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donn Marion Stahl of Meriden, Conn., to George Kirkpatrick Whitney of Farmington, Conn., son of Mrs. Charles Hayden Whitney of Concord, Mass., and the late Mr. Whitney, took place yesterday morning in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, this city.

Mrs. Lynn Wentworth Thompson of this place announced today the marriage of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Gail Thompson, to Lee Parsons Davis Jr. of New Rochelle, N. Y., son of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Lee Parsons Davis of Sutton Manor, New Rochelle, at New Castle, N. Y., last Monday night.

AN old adage spoken long before the age of radio explained that "a swarm of bees in May is worth a load of hay; a swarm of bees in June is worth a silver spoon; a swarm of bees in July isn't worth a fly." Nothing was said about a swarm in April. But from Massachusetts there comes a report of an April "swarm."
The engagement has been announced of Miss Evelyn Willoughby Sharp, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Henry Talbot Sharp, to Dr. Samuel McLanahan Jr. She is a member of the Junior League.

Scotland today acclaimed Celtic, Scottish football cup winners for the fifteenth time, as worthy victors in the grueling competition, but the acknowledgment was tinged with regret. When the Celts overcame Aberdeen, 2--1, before a record cup crowd of 144,000 at Hampden Park, it was the eighth consecutive triumph for Glasgow clubs.
What exactly is Britain's policy in Europe, and what are its methods? The British prosper by peace. Hence they have always been against the troublemakers in Europe.
THIS little book records one of the many adventures in friendship of the broad hearted George Russell, whom the world of letters knows best by his pseudonym AE.

Miss Caroline A. Seelye, who for forty-one years before her retirement in 1919 was a teacher and principal at the Barnum School, died at her home last night. Among her pupils were many of the present industrial and professional leaders of the city.
Three years distant from the campaign bands and the political hyperbole of 1940, the Democratic donkey already is starting a prance through the green pastures of the Southland.

EACH of the States rescued from slavery by the War Between the States has a special pride of its own. North Carolina is proud of having become since the final Confederate surrender (of General Johnston to General Sherman at Durham two weeks after Appomattox) the most "progressive" of all these rescued States.

Northwest Iowa was cut off today from all telegraph and telephone communication by the worst storm in history for this season. Beginning late yesterday afternoon with misty rain, the storm turned into snow in the northern parts of the region during the night.

One-third of the people of Southeastern Kentucky, a typical Appalachian area, are on relief, according to Dr. John Gross, President of Union College here, spokesman of the Institute of Public Affairs, which held a meeting recently in Barbourville to discuss factors in the social problems of the Kentucky mountains.

GREAT BRITAIN is facing destiny. She is celebrating a coronation that, as a pageant, breaks all records. Also she is aware of ominous possibilities. With significant rapidity, the British are rearming.
Two big scoring innings gave the Brooklyn Knights of Columbus nine a victory over Seton Hall today, 9-4. Setonia made the most hits, but also the most errors.

With Bud Abbitt allowing only one hit to the twenty-eight middies that faced him, the University of Virginia won from the Navy baseball team today, 7 to 0. The Cavaliers scored five runs in the first and two in the ninth.
Mrs. William Wallace Atterbury, widow of General Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, died today at her home, Boudinot Farms, Radnor, after a long illness. She was 58 years old.
The police gave out today the confession of a robber who killed Joseph Riedle, Nazi leader, April 10. German authorities in Berlin had charged Riedle was assassinated by Communists.
Reactions in New England to the Supreme Court legalization of the Wagner Labor Relations Act are varied.

The study of careers is being introduced this Spring at Lynchburg College for the first time. In order to assist the students in choosing a vocation, and then to prepare to enter upon it, lecturers representing many professions have been invited to hold career conferences with the students each Monday evening during the Spring quarter.

Banks were among the sellers of Brooklyn properties reported in deals yesterday. The Brooklyn Savings Bank sold the six-story building for fortyeighth families at the southwest corner of Ocean Avenue and Avenue I in a deal arranged by Harry Drucker, broker.

Although the Supreme Court of the United States has now passed judgment on many of the major enactments of President Roosevelt's first administration, judicial appraisal of the New Deal is not yet completed.

Vermont probably has more kinds of farms than any other State in the Union. There are dairy farms, chicken farms, turkey farms, pig farms, valley farms, hill farms - some farms which are largely pasture land, others which consist mostly of wood-lots, and a surviving few which specialize in the raising of sheep.
While prospective guests at a cocktail party, numbering, according to some estimates at more than a hundred, gathered in the lobby at 480 Park Avenue, at Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon,...

For the first time in fifty-three years an Allardice is not working on the Hudson River Night Line. When John W. Allardice of Albany resigned as chief engineer of the steamer Trojan, it marked the end of twenty-four years with the line for him and concluded a period of family service with the line that began with his father in 1884.
Van Lingle Mungo, luckless ace of the Dodger pitching corps, ran into another of those defeats not of his own making when the Phils hammered Brooklyn into a 7-3 defeat today.

James F. Brown, a sculptor and building contractor, died here today. His age was 78. Mr. Brown, a native of this city, carved some of the statuary on the City Hall here, spent two years as a carver on the Washington monument and engaged in the construction of many buildings.

A driverless automobile, rolling from its parking place on a steep hill on to a downtown Michigan Central Railroad crossing tonight, caused the derailment of one freight car on each of two trains speeding in opposite directions.

THE record of the Metroplitan Opera tour, ended last week, is so successful that is should cause even the most conservative of opera, officials to wonder whether the company cannot plan a comprehensive trip through the country.

NOT a little of that restless energy which has made of us a nation of nomads and implemented the development which made these continual wanderings possible has been captured by Mr. Glasscock in this book on the history of the automobile in America.

The first official World's Fair group to go abroad will sail for France Wednesday on the French liner Normandie to obtain approval of the fair's rules by the International Bureau of Expositions, which has twenty-two member nations. The group will also complete arrangements for the New York Fair kiosk at the Paris International Exposition.

Bowing before a glittering gold lotus altar and a huge gilt Buddha, Count Kocho Otani, hereditary chief abbot of one of Japan's sects of Buddhism, married himself shortly after dawn today to a 19year-old princess.

British rearmament has sent up the price of scrap iron, and this in turn ?eems to be solving a peculiarly perplexing little problem which at some Lime or other during the last few years ?as bothered practically every town in Britain.

Deputy Executive Director National Youth Administration The popular belief that more and still more education is the answer to the problem of unemployment among youth is not borne out by facts revealed through a study of the first year's operation of the Division of Guidance- and Placement of the National Youth Administration.

Women active in the work of the Brooklyn Children's Aid Society will act as hostesses tomorrow and Tuesday at T. A. L. F. Newman's Department Store in Brooklyn, when a percentage of the sales will be given to the society.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday he would establish an accident fraud bureau as a permanent part of his office. He made the announcement after Assistant District Attorney Bernard Botein, in charge of the accident fraud investigation, said the present inquiry would end June 1 and after that date the present quarters at 54 Lafayette Street would be discontinued.

Hokanum Hill, the estate of Mrs. Edgar C. Leonard in Westport, Conn., has been purchased by Fenton R. Brydle of Forest Hills, L. I., chairman of the board of the Tilo Roofing Company. The new owner will occupy the place, which is convenient to his factory at Stratford.

Caviar fit for a king--in fact, a variety that is usually reserved for the royalty of Europe--has just arrived from Russia. It is yellow in color, as compared with the usual black-gray variety, and sells for $100 a pound.

DODGE CITY, Kan. THE streamlined age has not dulled the lure of buried treas ure in the Southwest. There is hardly a week that Dodge City hardware merchants are not asked about "doodle bugs," magnetic needles which are supposed to be capable of locating buried metal.

Anna Rzienkowski filed suit against Mayor Couzens of Detroit, Police Commissioner Pickert and the Police Department today, asking $50,000 damages for injuries she claimed were suffered during eviction of sit-down strikers from a ciger factory here March 20.

The combined Glee Clubs of Vassar College and New York University, numbering 138 voices, will present their first New York performance of Rameau's opera, "Castor et Pollux," on Saturday in the auditorium of the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

Authors League of America, Inc., floor in 6 E. 39th St. through the Cross Brown Co. Otto Becker, Inc., retailers and designers of women's wear, in 3 E. 4Sth St.; Anson B. Moraa. and Henry Clews Co. (renewal) in 139 E. 57th St.; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens Inc., brokers. Alfred Lasek and Peter B. Schneider's Sons Co., in 509 Madison Ave.; Riker Co., Inc., broker.

Percy Smith, a crippled boy who lives in this village, has learned how to make adversity pay dividends. Not satisfied with the ordinary crutches which he could buy, he began to experiment in remodeling them. He kept at it until
Resolution Adverse to Roosevelt Proposal Will Be Taken Up at Tulsa Meeting as Expression of Women's Clubs Throughout the Country

Closing what is described as "the political bargain of the century," Paul Spaak, the Belgian Foreign Minister, exchanged notes this morning with the British Ambassador, Sir Robert Clive, and the French Ambassador, Jules Laroche, whereby Belgium was freed from her Locarno Treaty obligations while continuing to have her neutrality guaranteed by France and Britain.

Miss Betty Brooks, daughter of Mrs. H. Davis Brooks of 365 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, was married here yesterday at One Fifth Avenue to Gideon Stewart of Eau Claire, Wis., formerly of Pittsburgh, son of Thomas Fulton Stewart of Long Beach, Calif., and the late Mrs. Stewart.

The West Side Y. M. C. A. captured the metropolitan Y. M. C. A. indoor track and field championship by scoring 32 1/2 points at the Twenty-third Street branch last night. Brooklyn Central was second with 22 1/2, while the home team tallied 17 points.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann, accompanied by their sonin-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Wyllys R. Betts, will sail May 4 on the Bremen for London. Meredith Underhill is giving a luncheon today at the Union League Club.
Henry Brady will sell in the Vesey Street rooms on Tuesday the twostory garage on the southeast corner of Broadway and 219th Street, fronting 77.7 feet on Broadway and 188.5 feet on 219th Street.

St. John's hit hard yesterday to down City College, 8--3, in the first game of the annual baseball series between the rivals, at Lewisohn Stadium. Joe Salerno, second baseman, paced the Redmen with a homer, two doubles and a single in four trips to the plate.

If the unusual vigor of Congressional remarks at the White House budget conference last Monday afternoon means the most important of the several things it could mean, then the American people have sent word to Washington that they expect economy and a balanced budget. If such is the fact, the budget for the 'next fiscal year will reveal the marks of determined slashing in relief and other items.

On the eve of Better Health Week in the Bronx, the cornerstone of the new hospital and clinic building of the Bronx Eye and Ear Infirmary at East Tremont Avenue and Echo Place was laid yesterday. Civic, political and religious leaders of the Bronx participated.

ROCKY MOUNTAIN ranches from New Mexico to Montana are getting ready now for a bumper dude crop. An increasing number of Eastern travelers have heard the call of the West and are planning to spend their vacations riding, fishing, going on pack trips and watching rodeos.
THE speech which Thomas Mann made in German on the subject of Richard Wagner last Monday at the New School of Social Research is available in English translation.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Uslar of Maplewood of the marriage on Oct. 31 in Elkton, Md., of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Carol Uslar, to John Hollis Burroughs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sidney Burroughs of South Orange.

In 1936 $319,560 was spent by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee for vocational training of Jewish children and adults in economically depressed communities of Eastern and Central Europe, it was reported yesterday by Joseph C. Hyman, executive director of the committee.

Complete control of interscholastic athletics by the State Board of Regents, particularly to promote safety in football and other sports, was urged yesterday by F. R. Wegner, secretary of the New York State Public High School Athletic Association.

At the end of business on April 20, the day President Roosevelt sent his relief request and new budget figures to Congress, the United States Government had a debt of $34,832,075,135 By that day it already had spent during the current fiscal year, which began on July 1, 1936, $6,054,340,619. To offset this it had collected only $3,994,091,855.

Mrs. William Gray Larimer of 405 Park Avenue, formerly of Pittsburgh, has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Peggy Larimer, to Thomas F. C. Frost, son of Mrs. Thomas F. C. Frost of London and the late Mr. Frost.

Followers of schoolboy fencing were-provided with many exciting moments yesterday morning at the Washington Irving High School gymnasium as the concluding set of matches in the Public Schools Athletic League round-robin team championship took place.
THE most characteristic value to be seen in the long line of vigorous novels which Johan Bojer has written is a persistent emphasis upon man's fundamental nobility of spirit in the face of adversity.
A SECOND annual festival of American music will be held by the Westminster Choir School, May 4, 5 and 6 at Princeton, N. J.

THAT Wagner's first Isolde, Malvine Schnorr von Carolsfeld, was an aunt of Charlotte Masaryk, wife of Thomas G. Masaryk, the first President of the Czechoslovak Republic, is the Interesting fact which the eminent critic, Dr. Paul Stefan, has just made public in an article in the Vienna Stunde.

Seckler Shepperd, developers of the Highland Lakes community at Vernon, near Stockholm, N. J., reports that during the past year several miles of new roads and trails have been cut through the mountainous environs of the property, and the new clubhouse will soon be opened for the season.

The civic work of the Woman's Town Improvement Association of Westport, Conn., will be aided by a fashion showing to be known as "The Coronation of Spring Fashions," tomorrow and Tuesday in the auditorium of the Young Men's Christian Association in Westport, Conn. Mrs. Irving Sametz is head
The children and adults who live near Gramercy Park joined yesterday afternoon. to honor James A. Hannan, who has been the park's superintendent for thirty-five years.
The Muhlenburg College nine defeated Swarthmore College, 9-7, today on the Garnet Field. Swarthmore opened the scoring in the first, making two runs.

The marriage of Miss Isabel Livingston Fountain, daughter of Mrs. Livingston Fountain of 1,000 Park Avenue and Quogue, L. I., and the late Mr. Fountain, to George Frederick Brackett Jr. took place yesterday afternoon in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. George A.

Miss Gertrude Levis is one of a group of young women headed by Miss Carol Barnes, who will act as manikins in the preview exhibition of royal robes and court gowns worn at the coronation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra,

Yacht clubs, fully as much as the pleasure boats, have a fitting-out season of their own each Spring and this is it. In each of the 150 clubs in the metropolitan area flag officers and house committeemen are now following programs formulated last Winter in undertaking new work, constructing new wings and ells and a general renovating of the quarters and grounds.

Because civilization today flows to the sites of raw material, Soviet Russia, which is building a vast industrial empire in Siberia, will be a tremendous power in the new industrialism which will develop in Asia, Professor Bruce C. Hopper of Harvard University told the luncheon meeting of the Boston branch of the Foreign Policy Association today.

Dr. Thomas Mann, German author, who lives in Zurich, Switzerland, sailed yesterday for Havre on the French liner Ile de France. He spent eleven days here lecturing under the auspices of the New School for Social Research and the American Guild for German Cultural Freedom.

The Kamikawa Maru, first of four new freight ships built by the Japanese ship line Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha to operate between Yokohama and New York, is due in port tomorrow with a cargo that includes 7,000 bales of raw silk, whose value is estimated at $2,000,000.

Miss Phyllis Rankin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Vernon Rankin of this place, formerly of Hyde Park, was married here tonight to Richard Lawrence Whipple, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Ladue Whipple of Crestwood, N. Y., in All Souls Church.

Miss Katherine Keller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. HenryWorkman Keller of St. James Park, Los Angeles, became the bride of Kenneth Augustin O'Brien, son of Dennis O'Brien of Yonkers, N. Y.. at the little parish church of St. James. The Rev.

Mrs. V. Olga von Goeben-Jost of Montclair has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Olga Elizabeth Jost, to Robert H. Menzel, son of Mrs. Paul A. Menzel of Washington and the late Rev. P. A. Menzel. The announcement was made today at a reception at the Jost home.

To be informed fully as to what passed between Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria in Venice we must await the return of the Austrian Chancellor to Vienna. However, the following indications can be regarded as accurate:

MORE than a decade ago Dr. and Mrs. Lynd made a sociological study of a Midwestern city to which they gave the name of Middletown. The work was recognized instantly as a classic, and is bound to remain perhaps the most valuable record

THE British possession of Southwest Africa has released a new 1 1/2-penny stamp picturing the transportation facilities of the colony. Red-violet in color, the adhesive shows a railroad train, ship and airplane. The train bears the initials S. A. R., for South African Railways, on the tender.

LONDON through its several stations, directing their waves to all parts of the world, presents the Crystal Palace Band today at 6:20 P. M., Eastern standard time, over the following channels: GSF, 15.14 megacycles; GSD, 11.75, and GSB, 9.51.

Brooklyn Tech's No. 1 team captured the honors in the second semiannual City College interscholastic rifle shoot at the C. C. N. Y. range underneath the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, pacing the eight teams entered by scoring 1,042 points.

FLORA SEYMOUR'S "Meriwether Lewis, Trail-Blazer," which was reviewed in this department a few weeks ago, was the first adequate presentation for young people of the Lewis and Clark expedition which we have had in over three decades. Now, hard on its heels, come two other narratives, each worthy of notice.

History and Biography FRIEND ANTHONY BENEZET. By George s. Brookes. Svo. Philadelphia, Pa. 1 University of Pennsylvania Press. $5. A life of an eighteenth-century humanitarian. THE SILVER FLEECE. By Robert Collis. Svo. New York: Doubleday, Doran Co. $2.75.

Miss Angela Heckscher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maurice Heckscher of By-the-Way, Strafford, was married at noon today to Arthur Richard Niessen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Niessen of Rydal.

A personality and ability chart to guide the young business school graduate, now perplexed with questions of office decorum, will be ready for distribution this Spring, Miss Louise Cheney, educational chairman of the Transcription Supervisors Association, announced yesterday.

Discussing accident prevention in large office buildings, James D. Shevlin, custodian of the Chrysler Building, writing in a recent issue of The Real Estate Record, states that in a recent survey of twentyfive office buildings in New York City it was found that 46 per cent of all accidents were falls.

A sample of nearly everything which it takes most college undergraduates four years to experience has been crowded into the past three days for 280 high school girls from 100 schools in six States, who still have one day of college life ahead.

Mayor La Guardia ordered Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday to impress his men with the necessity for stricter enforcement at this season of the year of the city's anti-noise ordinance which went into effect a year ago.
Lieutenant Robert Fisher, 26, of Randolph Field, San Antonio, plunged 4,000 feet to death from an airplane he was piloting near here today.
L. A. King, a farmer living three miles east of Kirklin, has just been graduated from high school at the age of 60. Mr. King long has been interested in school work.

Plans for this year's May Day parade were discussed last night at a rally in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street. Reports were presented to the meeting by Paul White of the International Seamen's Union and Brendon Sexton, chairman of the Workers Alliance of New York City.
WITH music, realism, nos talgia and just plain ambition for their several inspirations, four new cinema groups set out hopefully last week to try their hands at bringing the movies to maturity.

Columbia broke Pennsylvania's winning streak in tennis today, recording victory by 6-3. Coach Wallace Johnson's pupils had taken five matches in a row. George Dunn, Eastern intercollegiate indoor champion, lost to Ray Antignat in three sets, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, and Captain Harry Albert bowed to Gus Ganzenmuller in straight sets.
A radical revision of college textbooks that treat of the cultural background of European peoples is predicted by Professor Werner Neuse, dean of the Middlebury College School of German.

Borden, Jr., referee, to Peter Schunk, 129 Wiman Ave, Great Kills, S I. Harper Ave (17-4945), w s, 100 ft n of Light St, 33x100; Maxwell Lustig, referee, to Home Owners Loan Corp. 350 5th Ave.

Enactment of a 4-point highway safety program was urged today by Charles A. Harnett, motor vehicle commissioner, as of "far greater effectiveness" in reducing accidents than a proposal for compulsory inspection of motor vehicles, advocated by Governor Lehman.

About 500 R. O. T. C. students from colleges of New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Puerto Rico will receive field training at United States Army Summer camps for periods of six weeks, according to an announcement yesterday from the Second Corps Area headquarters at Governors Island.

MR. BRADY'S autobiography is both entertaining and inspirational. His advice to young men and women has nothing to do with diet or regular morning intervals of silent thought or how to make a good impression on red caps.

There has been a large subscription for the program to be presented by Miss Beatrice Herford and Miss Jane Wyeth on Wednesday afternoon in the ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the New York Women's Auxiliary Bible Society.

EMBARKING upon a career as a radio actress, Miss Helen Menken confesses that her entry into the new metier is the cause of far more trepidation than the breathless palpitations that precede the raising of the curtain on any important premiere in the theatre.

The proficiency of some students at pinball machines is a matter of concern to the University of Illinois Student Senate. The student self-governing body adopted a resolution urging faculty members to remove the "menace of pinball games."

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, told 1,000 General Motors of Canada workers today that a man who "claimed to represent General Motors Corporation" attempted to bribe him in Detroit while Oshawa strike negotiations were under way.

Herbert S. Rosen, realty broker, reports an excellent demand for suites in old apartment houses which have been well altered. Four buildings of that type of which he was appointed manager during the past year he states are now fully rented.
A BOOK could undoubtedly be written-and who knows but what some day it will-telling the entire story, from beginning to ultimate end, about the production of "The Eternal Road."

Purchases by the Soviet government in this market in the first quarter of 1937 aggregated $7,325,000, approximately the same amount as was expended here in the first quarter of last year. Buying by Russra ordinarily is slower in the opening quarter than in the balance of the year and exporters look forward to a substantial rise in commitments in the current quarter.

Reports from sixty Federal savings and loan associations in New York State show that in the year ended on April 1 the number of investors increased by 8,421 from 87,616 to 96,037 and the accounts of investors by $7,274,681 from $99,778,936 to $107,053,617,

Horatio Parker's "Hora Novissima," based on the famous twelfth-century poem of Bernard of Cluny, will be offered for a second time this season by Antonia Brico, conductor of the New York Women's Symphony Orchestra, this time on May 4 in New Rochelle.

Morgan R. Seiffert of Trenton asked the National Rivers and Harbors Congress projects committee today to approve construction of the Delaware and Raritan Canal between Trenton and Perth Amboy to connect with the Hudson River and the New York Barge Canal.

The formal opening of the outdoor garden of the Park Lane on May 4 will be the occasion for a luncheon, fashion show and bridge party for the benefit of the work conducted by the New York Diet Kitchen Association at five health stations for infants in crowded districts of Manhattan.
Henry Morgenthau Sr., financier and former United States Ambassador to Turkey, will celebrate his eighty-first birthday anniversary tomorrow with a party in his home at 1,133 Fifth Avenue.

To mark the closing of its tenth annual campaign, the New York City Cancer Committee has arranged an entertainment for tonight in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The program will present William La Varre, explorer, in an illustrated lecture on "Gold, Diamonds and Orchids"; Armand Tokatyan, tenor and Margot Ros, 11year-old pianist.

The end of life came yesterday for John Henry Harris, 65, of 332 Stratford Avenue. But so carefully did he plan his "design for dying" that detectives at first were convinced that he could not have committed suicide.

A sudden windstorm reached J. F. Boring's garage, twelve miles west of here, at the same moment Boring did--and the garage went with the wind. As Boring reached for the door handle the garage trembled violently, then soared into the air

Seventy-two changes in the Columbia University faculty, affecting thirty-eight branches of the institution and involving promotion for fifty-one persons and new appointments for twenty-one others, were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. The changes will become effective next September.

In March, 1934, Premier Mussolini of Italy, the late Premier Goemboes of Hungary and the late Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria signed protocols at Rome pledging international collaboration, respect for the independence of "all countries" and economic cooperation.

Mrs. Regina K. Kniffen of this place, widow of Otis A. Kniffen, was married to Edward K. Hanlon, also of Rockville Centre, this morning in St. Agnes Church here by the Right Rev. Mgr. Peter Quealy. Mr. and Mrs. James V. Cullen of Rockville Centre were the only attendants.
Jackson Whitlow, 45-yearold trapper, lay near death in his mountain cabin today, the fortysixth day of what he said was a self-imposed fast made "at the call of the Lord."

As in the beginning of their series and in most of their meetings, New York University conquered Rutgers, 5 to 3, at Ohio Field yesterday in the fiftieth edition of their baseball rivalry. The Violet, victor in their opener in 1898, now holds thirty-six diamond decisions over the Scarlet.
The "Bryan Dynasty" will bow its way out of American politics three weeks from tomorrow for the first time in half a century. On that day Mayor Charles W. Bryan will leave office.

Justice of the Peace G. W. Kimbrough said today that he would hold a hearing next Friday for Homer Peels, 32-year-old mountaineer, charged with willfully understating the age of his child-bride, Geneva Hamby Peels, on a marriage license.
The Bureau ot Navigation released the following orders today dated April 22: REAR ADMIRAL Taussig. 3. K., orders bf March 8 modified. to additional duty as commander, Cruiser Div'n. 5.

Miss Elizabeth Eagles of Montclair will be wed on May 29 to James Edwin Knowlton of Brooklyn, at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. R. P. M. Eagles in East Orange. Mrs. Walter M. Delavan of Newark will be the bride's only attendant. Mr.
Daylight-saving time is effective today. With the official deadline at 2 A. M. Eastern standard time, most New Yorkers advanced their clocks and watches one hour last night before retiring.

WRITING to THE TIMES from Toronto, Robert B. Johnston says that with thirty-seven countries reporting their records for 1935 in Whitaker's Almanac (1937) Canada stands fourth in mileage flown with 7,522,000, beaten by Germany for third place in passengers carried by only 580, and with 11,800 tons of freight, Canada flew 42 per cent of the world total for an easy first.

Thomas Willis Joyce, president and treasurer of Thomas W. Joyce, Inc., printers and publishers, died at his home today at the age of 65. Funeral services will be held at the Joyce home on Monday at 2 P. M., with Hamilton Commandery Knights Templar, of which Mr. Joyce was a member, taking part.

Strong consumer resistance to higher retail prices, if it develops, may not measurably affect retail trade until late Summer or early Fall, because "consumers have not yet seen high prices, comparable to the advances in the wholesale markets," according to views expressed yesterday by retail executives.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Newhouse of Rocky Hill, near here, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Margaret Newhouse, to Richard A. Lester, son of Mrs. G. K. Lester of Hamburg, N. Y., and the late Dr. Lester.

Oliver Brothers, Inc., of 421 Canal Street, New York, a brokerage agency dealing principally in hardware, today answered the Federal Trade Commission's charge of violating the "brokerage clause" of the Robinson-Patman act by admitting the practices alleged in the commission's complaint and challenging the constitutionality of the law involved.

A clearer understanding of the (Wagner) National Labor Relations Act and its implications was brought about this week at the first of a series of conferences of labor and employer groups which Secretary Perkins has arranged to follow up the Supreme Court's recent validation of the act.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lashbrook don't know what to do with the family cat. It doesn't like to see them spank their 3-year-old son. Mrs. Lashbrook attempted to paddle the youngster for being disobedient.

THE broadcasters had a double quick hour early this morning so that now they are op erating on daylight-saving time. The shift causes not the slightest flurry in the nation-wide show, so closely allied to the fleeting seconds.

Opening of the long-awaited subway extension of the Eighth Avenue municipal system from Kew Gardens to Jamaica, the terminus now being at Hillside Avenue and 169th Street, will stimulate homebuilding activity in all of the residential centers in and around Jamaica, according to leading Queens brokers and builders.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, New York Supreme Court Justice, president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States and leader of the forces which opposed American participation in the 1936 Olympic Games in Germany, has accepted the chairmanship of the current $1,000,000 campaign of the American Committee Appeal for the Jews in Poland.
THE sallow, long-faced child who stood in the window of a dismantled London house on a day in the year 1810 was the daughter of Mary Anne Clarke, the Duke of York's all too-notorious mistress.

Miss Patricia G. Hinch, daughter of Mrs. Richard C. Hinch of 3,507 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Hinch, was married to Francis P. Rogers, son of Mrs. Cornelius P. Rogers of Worcester, Mass., and the late Mr. Rogers, yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady Help of Christians, Brooklyn.
WITH the first Summer tickets going on gale on May 15, railroad men are busy preparing for the Western travel season. More than 100 years ago the poet William Cullen Bryant wrote of his Western trip:

Although George Sisler Jr. held Penn State to three hits, the Nittany Lion baseball team scored a 3-to-2 victory over Colgate today. Penn State made all of its runs in the second inning on an error, two hits, a base on balls and a hit batsman.
AS that so-called young giant of transportation and touring, the highway bus industry, greets another Spring it is no longer really very young, and it has a more definite idea of where it is going.

The baseball forces of Holy Cross, perennial power of diamond warfare, routed Columbia, 12-3, yesterday at Baker Field before 1,000 persons. After a wabbly start, in which the Lions picked up two runs in the opening frame, the Crusaders hopped into a lead in the second and were never headed. The game was called by agreement at the end of the eighth.

Residential construction is leading the upturn in building work which is noted in first-quarter reports from all parts of the country. Figures for the first three months of 1937 show that in many of the leading cities building permits and contracts are running double the figures for the same months last year.
WHOEVER has tried to come to some understanding of Japan has had the same experience. It is like working through a cloud. With the Japanese in the mass one has only agreeable and easy relations.

QUITE the most gala theatrical opening in these parts since the frenzied first night of "Once in a Lifetime," some six years ago, took place Monday evening, when the Biltmore curtain rang up on the long-awaited and highly ballyhooed "Tovarich,"

Former Supreme Court Justice James V. Coffey was stricken while driving with his wife in their automobile on the Taconic Trail just outside Williamstown, Mass., at 6 o'clock tonight and died instantly.

King Zog of Albania still wants a wife, but royal romance comes high. Diplomats, denying rumors of his engagement to a member of Italian aristocracy, said there remained two obstacles to the King's marriage.

Evidence piles up that the entire Chinese nation is rapidly unifying in order to meet Japanese encroachments with armed resistance. The recent and highly significant dispatch in THE NEw, YORi TrmEs to the effect that the anti-Japanese leader, Pai Chung-hsi,

The feeling appears to be growing in Nicaragua, as reflected in newspaper editorials and comments of prominent citizens, that the United States will pay Nicaragua $15,000,000 as compensation for the decision not to build the Nicaraguan Canal.
The government rang up $230,000 on its cash registers in 1936 because the public was careless in addressing mail.

The Rev. E. J. Flanagan, who has given shelter and comfort to 4,446 boys in the nineteen years he has operated the nationally known boys' home bearing his name, today called the American system of dealing with juvenile law violators as "a huge manufacturing plant of hardened criminals." It is "void of any semblance of intelligence," he said.

William Denman, one of the circuit judges of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, comprising Northern California and several other States, called on the President today. Mr. Denman last year presented to the President recommendations for the lower Federal courts now embodied in the court reorganization plan.
Louis Perrizzo, 60 years old, a laborer, of 311 East 109th Street, was killed by a hit-and-run automobile driver in Second Avenue near 107th Street about 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

Students of the College of St. Eliabeth here will hold their annual May Day exercises on Sunday, May 16, it was announced today. The play "Robin Hood," by Alfred Noyes, will be presented in the outdoor theater near O'Connor Residence Hall.

Emphasis upon the importance of child health is being increased in the New York City schools, according to Charles Degan, supervisor of health activities in vocational schools. He revealed yesterday that an effective plan of cooperation has been worked out between parents and teachers.

In observance of his twenty-fifth anniversary as a member of the Teachers College faculty, 300 students and associates of Dr. Jesse Feiring Williams, head of the Physical Education Department there, honored the educator yesterday at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

FOR the gallery-goer who prefers group shows to one-man exhibitions, there are at present available the annual exhibition of advertising art, a large and diversified display, at the illustration studios of Underwood Underwood, 319 East Forty-fourth Street;

Four outstanding student honor organizations at the University of Vermont, Boulder, Mortar Board, Key and Serpent, and Gold Key, recognize in their membership service to the university and attainment of high scholastic honors.
A pinch single by Jack Rothrock off Buck Newsom gave the Athletics a 6-to-4 victory over the Senators today.

IT is a tendency of ideas to find a way to social power No political movement is so aimless and disorganized as to be altogether without guiding principles and purposes. Clearly not all ideas can be equally sound and the final strength
The Manhattan College baseball team scored a 7-to-0 victory over the University of Newark at St. Benedict's Field today.
Dr. C. C. Little, New Yorker, here for the tarpon fishing, swears to the veracity of this: He was trolling in Gulf of Mexico waters today. He hooked an eighty-pound tarpon-not so large, as tarpon go.

The marriage of Miss Grace French Taylor, daughter of Mrs. Edward Thomson Taylor of South Orange, N. J., and the late Dr. Taylor, to Carson Boyd Harman of Detroit, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Milton U. Harman of Bryan, Ohio, took place here yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Harold F. Lemoine performed the ceremony.

Helmuth Hirsch, 21-year-old American art student whom the United States Government is trying to save from the execution block, to which he was sentenced by the People's Tribunal on charges of "high treason and the possession of explosives,"
Miss Ginbar, E. N. Thompson's 4year-old daughter of Zev, won the Dallas Handicap in a photograph finish before 18,000 fans at Arlington Downs today.
Although the Republicans drew up the blue prints for many of the fine new Federal buildings in the national capital, the New Dealers are enjoying the benefits of the new quarters.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Raymond Mitchell, daughter of Mrs. Brundred Mitchell of Greenwich and James L. Mitchell of New York, to James Stokes Frazier of Nashville. Tenn., will take place in Christ Episcopal Church here, May 8. The Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson. the rector, will perform the ceremony.

Steam railroads of the country had 845 accidents in January, in which 398 persons were killed and 3,218 were injured, according to figures made public today by the Bureau of Statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Gounod's "Faust" and Rossini's "Barber of Seville" were given yesterday by the Hippodrome Opera Company in the evening and afternoon, respectively, before audiences of approximately 7,500.
Firemen tonight rescued two Eastern Nazarene College students from a narrow coping, on Munro Hall, girl's dormitory at the college. The students,

ALARMED by the sharp increase in traffic deaths this year compared with last, Detroit is inaugurating a program which it hopes will soon cut down the number of accidents and provide more intelligent control over its traffic problem.

A ntaion-wide search for a competent educator to head Queens College is under way, John T. Flynn, chairman of the administrative committee appointed by the Board of Higher Education to organize the new institution, has disclosed. Scores of applications have been received for this post and each will be considered carefully before the final decision is reached, he indicated.
Walter Young of Verdun, Canada, who led the pack home in the Boston A. A. Patriot's Day marathon, not only won the laurel wreath and a lot of fame but also a place on the Montreal police force.

Mrs. Eleanor Lansburgh of the Savoy Plaza has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lou Mathews Lansburgh, to Dick Hyland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Hyland of San Francisco, Calif. Miss Lansburgh was graduated last June from Leland Stanford University.
Londoners stampeded bookstores today and bought up all the available copies of a book that accused the Duke of Windsor of "muddling, fuddling and meddling" when he was King of England.

The Kentucky colonels-there are enough of them to officer an army of 3,000,000 men-were invited today to come to town May 7, the eve of the Derby, for their annual meeting, banquet and."julep reception."

Of the 44,671 young men selected for the Civilian Conservation Corps in January, 30,687 were 17, 18 or 19 years of age, according to a survey made public by Robert Fechner, director of Emergency Conservation Work.

Delegates from thirteen American Federation of Labor white-collar unions cheered yesterday a message from John Brophy, director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, that they could "contribute to the work of building a more powerful labor movement."

Harry Clemons, librarian of the University of Virginia, has asked the students, through a letter printed in College Topics, what kind of books they want in the browsing room of the new library when completed.

Flames that consumed the Ulster County "Promised Land" residence of Father Divine's "angels" added new woes yesterday morning to those already besetting the cult leader whose Harlem followers tell him and the world that he is God.

" Austria is following an Austrian policy only, and my government is applying the late Chancellor Dollfuss's program to maintain our country's independence and sovereignty," said Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg today in a statement to the official news agency.

Starting on May 4, when the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association holds its initial tourney of the season-a one-day event at the Essex County Country Club, West Orange, N. J.-the women golfers of the district will be on the go almost constantly from then until Oct. 29, when the members of the Women's New Jersey Association hold a wind-up one-day tourney at the Knickerbocker Club at Tenafly.

An interesting description of recent improvements in glass materials for use in business and residential structures was presented to a group of architects and builders at a meeting of the Producers Council Club in Chicago last week by Harold M. Alexander, architectural engineer of the LibbeyOwens-Ford Glass Company.

Brooklyn College held its inaugural Alumni Homecoming Day athletic program at Manhattan Beach yesterday. Despite the splendid weather, the graduates failed to enjoy the day, as the varsity nine turned back the the alumni, 10-6, in seven innings, and the varsity handball team conquered the graduates, 4-1.
Miss Mary Page Waddill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wood Waddill, was married here tonight to Spencer James Jr., son of the late Spencer James and Mrs. Elizabeth George James.

Peace tentatively enveloped Stockton's labor battlefield today pending efforts to mediate the cannery strike, but county authorities said that the opposing forces were increasing their potential fighting power.

The third in a series of special dinner dances, which have been arranged at the Ambassador in recent months by Mrs. Constantin R. Goodlet (Bonnie May Murray) in behalf of various philanthropic enterprises, will be a "Night in Rio" party to be given on Friday night in the Garden of the hotel.

The Cubs pounded five Cardinal pitchers for fifteen hits and a 13-to-12 victory today. It was the first defeat in four starts for St. Louis. A ninth-inning Cardinal rally off Clay Bryant and Bill Lee yielded four runs, one short of a tie.

HE recent inspection trip by Harold L. Ickes and Harry L. Hopkins has renewed public interest in the proposed Everglades National Park in Florida, designed to preserve as wilderness some 1,200,000 acres of that vast sub-tropical area, neither land nor water, which defied exploration until recent decades.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Corwin Williamson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Englis Williamson of this town, to Theodore Stephen Haass, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Haass, also of Freeport, took place here this afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev.

If the proposed reorganization plan for the Lawyers Mortgage Guarantee Corporation is approved by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler when it is presented before him on May 19, the continued and complete ownership as well as control of the underlying real estate and other collateral will remain with the present holders of the guaranteed mortgages and certificates, it was announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of April 18, entitled "To Settle Labor Disputes," you say: "As long as the constitutionality and range of application of the Wagner act remained in doubt it was not thoroughly analyzed on its own merits."

HOW does one become a successful writer? In the second volume of his memoirs, now coming out in convenient pocket size. the veteran Danish Nobel Prize winner Henrik Pontoppidan tells how he took the decisive step of burning all his bridges behind him like another Napoleon.

Several gardens in the historic Washington Square section of the city-some of them as notable as they are picturesque-will be on exhibition on the afternoons of May 13 and 14 as a benefit for the Judson Health Center, which has its headquarters in that district.

The British Empire Building in Rockefeller Center was reported yesterday as fully rented. This seven-story structure at 620 Fifth Avenue is the first of the eleven completed units in the midtown development to attain 100 per cent occupancy.

Princess Juliana, whom Prince Bernhard zu Lippe-Biesterfield rescued from the IVictorian age, is taking the lead of the Dutch smart set, and most of her future subjects, after understandable preliminary hesitation, like the idea.

Twenty-five sales in Long Island and various other parts of the metropolitan area made by affiliated brokers were reported last week by the Easy-to-Own Homes organization, Russell Page, sales director. The deals included the following:

Parents' Day will be celebrated on the Mall in Central Park on Sunday, May 9, it was announced last night by Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer. "The proceedings, lasting from 2:30 to 4:30 P. M., will be broadcast over city radio Station WNYC, through the kindness of Mayor La Guardia," Uncle Robert said.

THIS new estimate of Talleyrand, whose statecraft was identified with four Kings and an Emperor of France, with the States General, Constituent Assembly, Convention, the Directory and the Consulate, is both timely and apposite.

Students at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute are being made to feel that they, as well as faculty members, are a part of the teaching force and that what they contribute as a group is a vital influence in the benefits derived by the individual student in his college years.
THE American Ballet will present its program of three ballets by Stravinsky on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings at the Metropolitan Opera House, for the benefit of its scholarship fund.
AT the risk of being widely read, William Allen White has been editing The Emporia Gazette in the heart of Kansas with considerable bounce and pungency for about forty years.

The powerful New York Athletic Club team successfully defended its National A. A. U. hard-ball water polo title last night at the Winged Foot pool. Facing the aggressive Duquesne Dolphins of Pittsburgh in the final for the second successive year, the champions won by 8-3, leading throughout.

Yale's debating team gained a 2-to-1 decision tonight over a Princeton trio who upheld the affirmative on the question, "Resolved: That This House Favors the President's Pian for the Reorganization of the Judiciary."
Meetings of fifteen companies with shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange have been postponed or adjourned in the last month because a quorum of outstanding stock was not represented.

Hofstra College, New York University's educational affiliate here, announced today the gift of a completely equipped gymnasium from the estate of the late Mr. and Mrs. William S. Hofstra through the generosity of Howard S. Brower and James H. Bernard, trustees.

Public officials and members of the financial, civic and professional bodies with which he had been associated attended the funeral at noon today in the First Presbyterian Church of Dr. Samuel Pierson, who died in Stamford Hospital on Thursday night.

On the lips of the several thousand Negroes and several hundred whites who worship as God the short, black, bald-headed man who calls himself Father Divine, there trembles constantly the watchword, "Peace." Last week the cult's Harlem "heaven" was characterized by the conspicuous absence of peace.
Mr. and Mrs. Julius A. Horwitz of 850 Seventh Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vivian R. Horwitz, to Frank Chayes of New York, formerly of Chicago.

Cornell's campus dogs, the pedigrees and mutts owned communally by fraternities, are no longer to have unrestricted run of the classrooms and grounds. Campus police have issued an edict that, unless "claimed by the owner," such canines will be impounded in the veterinary college.

WEEK-END opera at the Hippodrome will continue with performances which feature debuts of several singers. "La Serva padrona" and "The Romance of Robot," the two chamber operas, given under theI auspices of the WPA Federal Music Project, remain at the Theatre of Music, with performances on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday evenings.

Eighteen New York University undergraduates have been elected to class offices by the School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, Washington Square East. The term of office starts in September. Those elected include;

ABRAMS--Mr. and Mrs. Max announce the arrival of a daughter. Nancy Ellen, April 20. at Medical Center. AUERBACH--Dr. and Mrs. Romeo W Auerbach announce the birth of son, April 23, 1937, at Jewish Hospital.

Richard T. Fox, for nearly thirty years president of the Citizens Service Bureau of Chicago and a brother of the late John Fox Jr., author, died of a heart attack today. His age was 65. He came here two months ago from Chicago to visit a sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Fox Moore.

Ten German heavy bombers flew over Bulgaria on Thursday en route to Turkey. Four were forced to land on account of bad weather, one of them crashing near Burgas. The pilot escaped death, but the plane was wrecked.
