Dr. Daniel F. Daley, pathologist, died at Nesbitt Memorial Hospital today after a long illness at the age of 49. He was a native of England. He was graduated from the Jefferson Medical College in Philadelphia in 1915. Later he studied in Vienna and Berlin.
A 13-yearold girl who commutes regularly twice a week from Springfield, Mass., to Rye today won the championship class of the Kenilworth Riding Club's Spring competition for juniors.
Closing a two-day conference, the Second District National Campfire Girls Organization today elected Mrs. Henry A. Simon of Reading as chairman;

Spring fashions will take a day off at London's coronation ceremony on May 12. By dictate of the Earl Marshal, hereditary arbiter of forms at such rites and attendant parades, the nobility of Britain will have to distinguish itself from the commonalty,

ONLY a few weeks to coronation day, May 12-the first coronation that London has had since 1911. The actual ceremony, as always, will take place indoors, in Westminster Abbey, but the great procession to and from the Abbey will be everybody's show.
THE GAUDY EMPIRE," sequel to "Another Caesar," is not fictionized history but rather history in the form of fiction.

THE distinguished services rendered by amateur collectors in preserving our heritage of documents and books cannot be mentioned too often, for the most important and significant rarities in our public and university libraries are there by the gift of individual bibliophiles.

National Supply Company of Delaware has notified the Exchange of a proposal to change authorized common stock from 500,000 shares, $25-par value, to 1,500,000 shares, $10-par value, each present share being exchanged for three new shares.
A Navy varsity crew, following the example set by Academy oarsmen in two preliminary races, rowed to a stunning triumph against Columbia on the waters of the Severn today.

Opposition to a plan that would place the Interstate Commerce Commission under the jurisdiction of the Department of Commerce was expressed yesterday by the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce in communications to the Joint Congressional Committee on Reorganization of the Executive Department.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Mary McEvoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McEvoy of 1,728 Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, to Leo Joseph Sullivan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Sullivan, also of Brooklyn, took place there yesterday morning in the Church of the Holy Ghost.

Soran an old war song, Roark Bradford tells us; presumably by way of explaining his title. "The Three-Headed Angel." A man can work like a horse. prey upon his fellow like an alligator, and, with luck and the help of the Almighty, now and again play the man.

Prizes have been awarded in the Barnard poetry contest in the Sea View Hospital, Staten Island, where the patients have been writing verse to help fill their hours. Julie Landauer, Ward 54, won first prize for her poem "Written by Full Moonlight."

Waterways, railways, highways, airways and pipe lines must be considered as one national problem to avoid duplication and waste, Dr. C. S. Duncan, economist of the Association of American Railroads, said in a recent address before the Great Lakes Shippers' Regional Advisory Board.

President Roosevelt has approved the promotion to the rank of rear admiral of Captain Archibald L. Parsons of the navy's Civil Engineering Corps, now serving as public works officer at the New York Navy Yard.

Lorin W. Willis of Trumbull was appointed State's Attorney for Fairfield County to succeed William H. Comley of Bridgeport by the Assembly of Supreme Court Justices and Superior Court Judges, meeting in New Haven today.

Nathaniel King, a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1905. who had been a partner in the brokerage firm of Eisele, King Studdiford of 9 Clinton Street, Newark, since 1892, died here today at his home, 179 Harrison Street, of an internal ailment. He was 70 years old.

Miss Melissa Yuille, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Burks Yuille of this city and the late Mr. Yuille, was married at noon yesterday to Harry Payne Bingham, also of New York, at the home of her mother, 1,040 Fifth Avenue.

From both sides of the center aisle, the Senate heard last week a demand for greater local responsibility in the matter of relief. Senator BORAH crititized the practice of "great States and "cities trekking their way to Washing"ton about every fortnight" in search of Federal aid.

The annual Daffodil Show, to be held tomorrow and Tuesday in the rooms of the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue, is the first of a series of seasonal "special flower" exhibitions which will be staged by the society.
IF Tommy Farr ever brings his gloves to America to battle for the heavyweight crown he will find radio "serenading" him differently than at the London ringside when he recently encountered Max Baer.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alvah Berkeley Davis of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cary Mulford Davis, to Swain Joseph Swainson of Cranford, N. J.

Miss Elise Julia Sieker, daughter of Mrs. Adolphus T. Sieker and the late Mr. Sieker, was married here this afternoon at the home of her mother to Warren Willard Walker of Montclair, son of Mrs, Stephen Walker of Stoughton, Mass., and the late Mr. Walker. The ceremony was performed by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Otto Sieker of Saranac Lake, N. Y.

Announcement is made that the greater part of the 400-acre estate of the well-known sculptor, Gutzon Borglum, located on Wire Mill Road and Old North Stamford Road, Stamford, Conn., is being offered for sale in residential acreage plots or for residential development by Arthur I. Crandall, Stamford broker.

Owing to the rapid progress made in evening-up May accounts, there was less selling pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, which facilitated a recovery of 1 to 6 points. Fluctuations held within unusually narrow limits, and May not only steadied, but ended the session a point over July.

Miss Sallie Hawes Bacon, daughter of Mrs. John F. Bacon of Tarrytown, N. Y., and the late Mr. Bacon, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Prince Landis, son of Dr. and Mrs. W. S. Landis of Old Greenwich, Conn., which will take place on Saturday.

Responsibilities of trade associations, the Walsh-Healey act and social security and economic trends will be among the discussions of the American Trade Association Executives at its Spring meeting, opening tomorrow in the Mayflower Hotel, Washington, D. C., it was announced here yesterday.

Professor Leo Frobenius, director of the Ethnological Museum at Frankfort-on-the-Main, Germany, who is regarded as one of the world's authorities on prehistoric art, arrived here yesterday on the Hamburg American liner Deutschland.
On the discretion of three men and the legal judgment of a fourth rests a major portion of responsibility for the future of labor relations in America.

Harvard's varsity eight moved across the finish line on Lake Carnegie early this evening with the effortless rhythm of a ghost and Crimson rowing had come back to a place among the leaders of the East.
Intercollegiate debating activity at Rutgers University during the past year was participated in by seventy-two students, Professor Richard C. Reager, coach of debate, announced today.

The engagement of $13,991,000 gold abroad for shipment to this country, $11,185,000 in England, $2,546,000 in Canada and $260,000 in India, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Stanford's track and field team, not so powerful as its national championship outfits of the past but still strong enough for the business at hand, humbled its oldest collegiate rival-University of California-today, 771-3 to 53 2-3.

Columbia concluded its Spring football training yesterday by engaging Manhattan College in a three-hour scrimmage at Baker Field. Practically every man on each squad was given an opportunity to display his ability.

The annual report of the Banca Commercials Italiana, which has just been received here, shows operating profits for 1936 of 18,271,144 lire, which, with the approval of the shareholders, have been credited to reserves.

Net proceeds from dinner and supper dancing in the Garden of the Ambassador on the night of May 6 will be donated to the Big Brother Movement, which for thirty-three years has conducted a noteworthy service for underprivileged boys of this city. The benefit will mark the formal opening of the Garden for the Summer.

The Swedish Methodist Episcopal Church, which recently soldits old property at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fiftysecond Street, has assembled a plot at 148-50 East Sixty-second Street through Douglas L. Elliman Co. as the site for its new edifice.

John Gumbosh of Akron, Ohio, broke the three-day spell of low scoring in the American Bowling Congress championship at the 212th Coast Artilley Armory by rolling 705 in singles yesterday. This gave him ninth place in the division.

SLOWLY but perceptibly New York's famous East Side is not only changing but lengthening. Once the East Side meant only Manhattan's south on the island's heel into which America's immigrants had been gravitating for generations.

Lucy Beaumont, identified for more than forty years with the English and American stages and who was known to many as the "mother of the screen," died last night at the Hotel Royalton, 44 West Fortyfourth Street.
For nearly twenty years, San Francisco has boasted of being the only city except New York to retain the 5cent fare, at an estimated saving to its car-riders of $8,500,000 a year.

After eloping by starlight in the best romantic tradition from the bride's home on King's Point, Great Neck, L. I., William Hotine, radio engineer and inventor, and Barbara Green, 21-year-old daughter of Horace Green, war correspondent, former publisher and author, were married yesterday afternoon in Flushing, Queens.

AN experimental game refuge, comprising 2,200 acres, is to be established in the historic Patuxent River Valley of Maryland by the Bureau of Biologcal Survey of the United States Department of Agriculture.

The tenth annual get-together of the Central Council of Associations, whose members are directors of local groups organized to assist the Seamen's Church Institute of New York by raising funds, knitting and furnishing linens for 25 South Street, the home of merchant seamen in the Port of New York, will be held at the institute on Wednesday afternoon. The Right Rev.

The Trinity nine defeated Massachusetts State on Alumni Field by a score of 8-1 today. Faulty support behind the pitching of Frank Riel and Frank Fanning aided in the downfall of the home team. State was guilty of eight errors.

Current bills in the State Legislature affecting education were condemned yesterday by speakers at the fifteenth anniversary luncheon of the Teachers Guild Associates in the Hotel Astor as detrimental to the school system and designed to deliver it into the hands of politicians.

A card party and tea to aid the Dr. White Memorial Catholic Settlement Association will be held Tuesday at the Plaza. Miss Irene A. Farrell heads the benefit committee, and Mrs. W. Harry Sefton is president of the association.
There is a man in Washington who wants the Federal Government to supply him money to kill wolves from airplanes, and he is no boondoggler, either.

Two thousand high school students throughout the country, eager for scholarships to Eastern universities, waded yesterday through a new series of College Entrance Board achievement and aptitude tests in the hope of winning at least a partly free college education.

ONCE more Diego Rivera is involved in a drama. It was he who asked President Cirdenas to permit Leon Trotsky to come to Mexico; it was Mrs. Rivera who met the Trotskys upon their arrival in port (Rivera himself was ill), and it is in the Rivera house that Trotsky trial has been going on. Rivera is hardly the center of the Trotsky drama. but he is at the core of many.

The marriage of Miss Dorothes Bernard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest E. Bernard of Brooklyn,to John Francis Dooling Jr., son of Mrs. John Francis Dooling, also of Brooklyn, and the late Dr. Dooling took place yesterday morning in St. Saviour's Church, Brooklyn Mgr. William T. Conklin performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass that followed.

The dissatisfaction of Congressmen and coffee growers with the results of the Coffee Federation's policies and methods of attempting to sustain coffee prices reached a climax today when the National Coffee Growers Committee accepted the resignation of the federation's manager, Alejandro Lopez, through 'the device of a temporary leave of absence.
Southern California's track and field team crushed the University of California at Los Angeles today, 91-40.

Distribution of prizes to members outstanding during the past Winter in ski jumping comprised the most important part of the first annual dinner of the Telemark Ski Club of Rosendale, N. Y., last night at Glass and Lieberman's Hall in Brooklyn. About seventy-five members and guests attended.
EDWIN EVANS, an English writer, has concerned himself industriously for a considerable time with the complete works of Johannes Brahms, in a bibliographical and analytical way.

The business of renting office buildings was explained before the West Side Y. M. C. A. real estate class recently by William J. Demorest, first vice president of William A. White Sons and formerly president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

The marriage of Miss Helen B. Dexter, daughter of Mrs. James H. Grady of Maplewood. to Robert C. Halsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund R. Halsey, also of Maplewood, took place today in Prospect Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Nelson Butz. A wedding breakfast for the bridal party followed at Chanticler, Millburn.

The window of the hotel is open and, as you lie in bed, you hear the firing in the front line seventeen blocks away. There is a rifle fire all night long. The rifles go "tacrong, carong, craang, tacrong," and then a machine gun opens up. It has a bigger caliber and is much louder--"rong, cararong, rong, rong."
The winning streak of J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange was brought to a halt today in the final round of the Mason-Dixon tenis championship at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club.

For the May 1 demonstrations in Sweden, labor groups will rally primarily around the Social Democratic manifesto with its plea for peace and justice and against the further spread of Fascist control in the world.

Several thousand nationally branded items have now been placed under the price provisions of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, with the addition last week of almost two hundred more items bringing both the total of manufacturers and products
JOBLESS COUNT: "Our vital need (is) for an accurate, authentic, current census of the unemployed so that we may know our problem instead of guessing at it."-Senator Vandenberg. . . .

SO far as movies are concerned 1936 and the first three months of 1937 have been notable for a bumper crop of musicals. Not since the first days of talkingpictures-days in which everybody made musicals because that seemed the only type of picture they could think of-have so roany singing and dancing pictures graced the screen.

The marriage of Miss Helen D. Kuper, daughter of Mrs. George H. Kuper of 610 Park Avenue and Redding, Conn., and the late Mr. Kuper, to John Edward Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Barrett of New York and New Canaan, Conn., took place at noon yesterday in the chantry of Grace Church.

The Rodwyn stables of Greenwich, Conn., captured two of the three championship awards as the Riding and Polo Club's two-day Spring horse show came to a successful conclusion last night. A large gallery witnessed both the afternoon and evening sessions of the twenty-six-event second-day card.
BROADBENT, MALCOLM G. (Feb. 22, 1930). Estate, $5,600. To Marie Broadbent, widow, executrix, 333 W. 28th St. SCHURR, SARAH (March 9). Estate, $1.500. To Henry Schurr, son, executor, 153 Norfolk St.

The great Irish navigator, Saint Brendan, who set out in the year A. D. 574 to discover the so-called "Land of the Blest," is traditionally supposed to have started from the harbor of Foynes and to have been seven years on his journey.

It is a pleasure to learn from Commissioner COLLIER'S annual report that our Indians, believed only a few years ago to be remnants of a vanishing race, are now increasing more rapidly than any other segment of our population, The Office of Indian Affairs says that births among the aborigines at present exceed deaths by 3,500 a year.

Women of five countries will open a discussion of the Women's Charter when delegates to the North American Conference of the Young Women's Christian Association meet in Toronto on Wednesday for a three-day session devoted to world trends.

" Unless Japan is constantly mindful of the nature of China's new national unification there is no hope of a readjustment of Chino-Japanese relations," was the frank admission made in Shanghai by the Japanese Ambassador to China, Shigeru Kawagoe, who sails Wednesday for Japan for a series of conferences with. he Ministers of Foreign Affairs, War, Navy and Finance.
THE winner of Little, Brown Co's Novelette Contest, which closed on Jan. 1, is Wallace Stegner of Salt Lake City, Utah. His novelette. "Remembering Laughter."

City College's junior varsity baseball team played to a 6--6 tie with the St. John's freshmen at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The game was limited to six innings by mutual agreement. A rally in the last inning produced the run for St. John's which enabled it to tie the score.

THE annual horticultural trek is now under way to the blooming orchards of North west Arkansas. The dogwood and iris are flowering here in the Ozarks, which remind the Easterner of the Berkshires and the Southerner of Western Carolina.

FIRST real adventure of our tour--a ride in a Mexican cab. Squeeze your eyes tight every time ?? mad hombres charge at a space hardly large enough for a motor cycle. Make it every time, too, though you wonder how. Finally learn it's done with horns.

At the request of counsel for the manufacturers, Judge Harry Manser of the Supreme Court ruled today that maintenance of a commissary and field kitchen by C. I. O. shoe unionists, violated the injunction outlawing the thirty-day-old strike.

Production of heavy steel materials increased more rapidly in 1936 than did the output of light steel items used principally by the consumers' goods industries. This situation, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, reflects recovery as being the more pronounced in the railroad, construction and other "heavy" or capital goods industries.

Collections of city real estate taxes for the first half of the current year are $17,953,111 ahead of the same period in 1936, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday. First-half taxes must be paid by the end of this month.

Stephen Leacock, humorist and until recently head of the McGill University -Economics Department, will receive the Lorne Pierce Medal for literature. L. J. Burpee, president of the Royal Society of Canada, said other awards would be the Flavelle Medal for science to Dean Frank D. Adams of McGill,

Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business Machines Corporation, said today that "a fair revision of trade barriers between countries and improvement of conditions in each individual nation will do much" to promote world peace.

A warning of the dangers attendant upon increasing prices, resulting either from inflationary developments or action by monopolies, was sounded today at a luncheon of the People's Lobby by Corrington Gill, assistant WPA administrator; Dr. Leon Henderson, WPA consulting economist,
Even before the Wagner law decisions it should have been no trouble at all to prove that a baby was interstate commerce

Damage estimated at $100 was caused by a fire of undetermined origin in a rack of pamphlets and papers in the vestibule of the Holy Name Roman Catholic Church, 748 Amsterdam Avenue, shortly before 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

Measures to fit the graduates of American secondary schools for public life were discussed last night by the headmasters of Phillips Exeter Academy and Lawrenceville School in addresses at the annual Lawrenceville School dinner at the Hotel Plaza.

The New York Americans, national soccer champions, were defeated by Brookhattan, 3 to 0, in an American League contest before 1,500 at Starlight Park yesterday. Brookhattan went into an early lead when Bob McIntyre beat Stanley Chesney to the ball from Joe Boyle's cross on the left after five minutes of play.

Construction of ten or twelve high-type residences in the Old Farms Riding Country section of the extensive acreage which has been acquired in recent years by Ernest L. Conant in and around Pound Ridge, Westchester County, is being planned by Mr. Conant as the first step in his plan for the improvement of his property embracing nearly three square miles.

A Federal grand jury today completed the first chapter of the government's investigation of the election here on Nov. 3 by charging eighteen more persons with a vote fraud conspiracy, bringing the total thus indicted to 126.

Nearly thirty conferences have been held in different parts of the country by officials of the Federal Housing Administration to discuss subdivision and land planning methods with developers and other realty interests.
London's railway porters are getting a stiff workout in these bustling precoronation days from the influx of Eastern potentates who travel any way but light.

An immigration board today barred Jyotirmoyee Sarma, a 14-year-old East Indian girl, from admission to the United States because the visa on her passport gave her age as 15. The board paroled the girl in the custody of her aunt and uncle, Dr. and Mrs. T. J. Sarma, pending an appeal to Washington authorities.

DODGE CITY, Kan. THE Medicine Lodge Treaty Association has begun preparatory work for the pageant Oct. 5 to 7, which will commemorate the signing of the peace treaty between the Federal Government and the plains Indians in 1867.

War Admiral, the Glen Riddle Farm's swift-striding Kentucky Derby nominee, stretched himself over a mile-and-sixteenth route for the first time in the Chesapeake Stakes and performed so much like a champion that he was six lengths in front of the field at the finish.

The Rev. Michael O'Flanagan, former Vice President of the socalled Irish Republic, arrived in New York yesterday from Ireland for a two-month visit, during which he will make appeals in several cities for medical aid to the Basque Catholics and Spanish Loyalists.

The Westchester Gardening School, conducted under the auspices of the Westchester Hortioulture and Agriculture Association, will be held Tuesday and Wednesday of this week at the Westchester County Center, White Plains.

A last-period rally which netted three goals in eight minutes gave Princeton a victory over Rutgers in lacrosse today, 8-7. After trailing 'at half-time, 7-5, the Tigers added a point midway in the fourth quarter and then tied the count on Sandy Ormond's overhand shot- when Art Perry, Scarlet center, was on the bench because of a penalty.

Daniel D. Bidwell, newspaper man and author, died today in Hartford Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old on Aug. 7. Born in East Hartford, Mr. Bidwell was graduated from Yale University in 1886.

Aid from public school funds is now being received by 340 schools conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, it was revealed yesterday in a nation-wide report compiled by the Institute of Catholic Educational Research of Fordham University.

MORE or less of an expatriate, Lyonel Feininger in the seventh decade of his life is about to return to this country. An exhibition of his oils, water-colors and graphics has been put on by Karl Nierendorf at his recently opened gallery, across the street from the Museum of Modern Art, and may be visited there until May 15.
Secretary Morgenthau will be prepared to present to Congress next November the results of an exhaustive study of possible tax revision if this information is desired, it is stated at the Treasury.

Frederick B. Lindsey, retired teacher, was found dead last night near his automobile in the yard of his home here. A heart attack was the cause of death. His age was 68. Mr. Lindsey was graduated from Allegheny College in 1889. He was an honor student and a member of Phi Beta Kappa.

An early decision by the Court of Appeals was promised tonight by Judge Arthur W. Doyle in the case of Walter Morrow, editor of The Times Press, fined $50 today by Judge Walter B. Wanamaker for publishing names of witnesses and cases under consideration by the county grand jury.

REGRTTABLY brief today must be comment on several one-man shows just opened. Peggy Bacon has some new pastel satires at Rehn's. They are larger and perhaps freer, too, than has been this delightful artist's wont, artistically among the best of them being "The Great Question" and "The Spirit of Rain."

United States Government longterm bonds were about the only strong group on the listed market in the two-hour trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Having been under persistent, but relatively light, pressure during the preceding four days, the Treasury list rebounded rather sharply on a sizable volume for a Saturday.

Upheavals in the legal and the labor status of women employes in three critically affected areas, subsequent to the Supreme Court's reversal of its opinion on the Minimum Wage Law, have released a swelling volume of inquiry into the mail baskets and the correspondence files of the Women's Bureau at Washington.

A DANCE of the fireflies to the music of a chorale by Martin Luther is more or less what you get in "Susan and God," Rachel Crothers's new play, now in the second week of a fortnight's engagement at the Forrest Theatre, with Gertrude Lawrence starred. (As announced, the play has closed until next season--Ed.)

Wheat futures in North American markets fluctuated in an erratto manner today within a range of 1Y% to 17% cents a bushel, with early firmness in sympathy with Liverpool, followed by a recession on local selling, while the close was on P good rally.

The first adventure of the Coolidge Expedition for the study of the greater primates in Asia and Malaya was to flee a vast jungle fire set by natives in Siam, according to a letter received at Johns Hopkins University.

Yale turned an impending 2-1 defeat into a spectacular 3-2 victory over Pennsylvania today before 3,500 spectators to take the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League with two victories in two starts.

In 1875 CLERK MAXWELL electrified his colleagues by demonstrating mathematically that light waves are electromagnetic and that there must be other waves, also electromagnetic, to which our limited eyes are blind. Physics is an eminently practical science.

Cardinal Hayes gave credit to the Ladies of Catholic Charity for its part in helping to organize Catholic charities here, at the thirty-fifth annual conference of the group yesterday in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

Decent housing accommodations for all income groups should be the fundamental objective of a com- 25-3 plete and national housing policy, declares Paul E. Stark, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

APPROVED: The United States added a woman last week to its list of diplomatic representatives when the Senate approved the appointment of Mrs. J. Borden Harriman as Minister to Norway. Long active in the Democratic party and prominent in welfare work, Mrs. Harriman continues the tradition that a woman should speak for the United States in a Scandinavian country, a tradition established when Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen was sent to Denmark.

A rescue squad of 200 worked feverishly tonight to release two miners trapped in their independently mine working near New Philadelphia. The miners, Anthony Gristitus and Stanley Pushka, were entombed in a tunnel seventy feet from the surface today by a cave-in.
Numerous managers of State floral shops have been ordered arrested on charges that they had made too much profit on a funeral. G. Goronoff, manager of the Greenery Trust, and others

F. H. Memitz, vice president of the Order of Railway Conductors, described as a "lie" today any implications there was "something crooked" in his organization's agreements with the Southern Pacific Company.

Mr. and Mrs. William Baumrucker of River Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Alice Baumrucker, of 34 East Sixty-first Street, this city, to Edward Washburn Maynard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Washburn Maynard of Wilmington, Del.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Knowlton Walker, daughter of Commander Hugh MacLean Walker, U.S.N. (retired), of Augusta, Ga., to Joseph Maull Carey 3d, son of the late Senator Robert D. Carey of Wyoming and Mrs. Carey,

Making her first New York appearance in public since her $80,000 "flying laboratory" crashed in Honolulu on March 20, Amelia Earhart told 500 members of the Gimbels Stamp Club yesterday afternoon that she purposed to attempt the "round the world at the Equator" flight again "some time around the middle of May."

The marriage of Miss Alice Dean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Dean of St. Paul, to Robert B. F. Wylie, son of Mr. and Mrs. James K. M. Wylie of Helensburgh, Scotland, took place here at noon today in the chancel of the House of Hope Presbyterian Church.

With the utterly bewildered and fogbound Bees of Boston still striving desperately to recall by what manner of means a ball club goes about the business of scoring a run, it remained for Clydell Castleman to spin another shutout for the Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the forces of Colonel Bill Terry flattened Bill McKechnie's grief-stricken array 3 to 0.

Today W. A.-Dorothy Crawford, diseuse, 8:30 P. M., clubhouse. ??appa Delta Alumnae-Tea, 4 P. M., Beekman Tower. national Poetry Center-Meeting. Poetry reading by Edward Leon Meyerson, 7:45 P. M., Rockefeller Plaza.

With three of its components higher, three lower and one unchanged, THE NEW YORX TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended April 17 has advanced to the year's high, 107.4, which compares with 106t3 for the previous week and 95.4 for the week ended April 18, 1936.
John W. Eyles Sr., former Mayor and Councilman of Sea Bright and for many years active in the civic and fraternal life of this section, died last night of pneumonia at his home here at the age of 83.
Completing her schedule of nine games in the women's open championship tournament at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, Mrs. Adele Rivero of Manhattan

L. C. Gunter, vice president of the Southern Appalachian Coal Operators Association, announced tonight a new wage agreement tentatively reached here Friday with mine union officials had been canceled because of new demands by the miners.

American newspapers follow or mirror public opinion rather than play a significant role in molding it. This was one of the general conclusions reached today by twenty undergraduate delegates participating in a round-table session on journalism at the first annual Intercollegiate Literary Conference, which closed its second day's sessions this afternoon on the Princeton University campus.

The second exhibition of amateur photography for the benefit of the American Colonies Charities Association was opened yesterday afternoon in the art galleries of the Squibb Building, 745 Fifth Avenue.

NEITHER Europe nor Asia nor South America has a prospect in which sea and wood and snow mountains are so united in a landscape," Viscount Bryce once wrote in depicting the Far West of the United States.

RACING against time-that alltoo-short time that intervenes between the opening of the roads-after the heavy Winter snows and the arrival of the vanguard of Summer travelersthose responsible for the welfare and entertainment of visitors are pushing their preparations for the biggest season in the history of the national park and monument system.

Younger members of the parish of St. James Church are now arranging the annual Spring fete for the benefit of the missions and social service work of the parish. The festival will take place on the afternoon of May 6 at the Plaza and will provide a variety of games and divertissements for children and their elders.

A "Gambol on the Green" will mark the opening for the season of Chatham Walk, at the Hotel Chatham, during the luncheon hour on May 8. The entertainment has been arranged under the auspices of the New York Chapter of Kenwood School Alumnae to further the work for the blind at the Sacred Heart Convent in Albany.

INDUCED by the rise in the price of gold, the revival of mining in Australia at deep levels on an unprecedented scale owes its present success to a 350-mile pipeline from the coast to the arid interior, through which water must travel for three weeks before it reaches its destination.

EVER since a sizable segment of humanity emerged from its exclusive preoccupation with getting enough to eat, it has been deeply concerned with deciding what to eat Issues of politics come and go, but the debate about diet is perennial. And for a very good reason.

THE problem of art in relation to society is so on the tip of all our minds that even those opinions disregarding society make it through absence conspicuous. Then why not read some books on the subject, or at least, to start with, three?

THE second parade of the 1937 season will be held at West Point today at 5:30 P. M. During May battalion parades will be held on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday at 4:33 P. M., and on Sunday regimental parades will t be held at 5:30 P. M.

Bills calling for drastic reorganization of the State Government and improved housing were on their way to Governor Lehman today, following the final session of the annual student conference at Syracuse University this afternoon.

THE world has suffered a serious loss since it ceased to believe in devils. Recently the Federal Theatre has been doing its bit to compensate for this grave lack by supplying the current season with two excursions into daemonology:

Gypsy Rose Lee, burlesque actress, was voted the "most prominent woman today" by senior students of the Peddie School here, according to results made public today of a poll conducted by the school yearbook. Amelia Earhart and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt ranked second and third, respectively.
Some clerk on Capitol Hill nodded and so the new Guffey-Vinson Coal Control Bill is likely to go on the statute books with a typographical error in it.

JASPER PARK LODGE, center of Summer social activity in this large national playground, will open June 15. The coming season promises to be most successful. The number of parties already booked exceeds 1929, the park's banner tourist year.
Several hundred persons attended a garden party yesterday afternoon to commemorate the 300th anniversary of the loss of Peter Stuyvesant's leg and to raise a fund to buy window boxes.

Ruxtons Rhu Brenda, owned by Ernest D. Levering of Ruxton, Md., came through to a brilliant triumph today in the all-age stake at the annual Spring field trials staged by the Irish Setter Club of America on the grounds of the State Fish and Game Commission.

Germany's colonial ambitions found new expression today in a declaration by General Franz von Epp, head of the Reich Colonial Federation, that her pre-war colonies now under mandate to other nations are really German property.

A high foul back of third base that slipped past the desperate clutch of Pinkey Higgins paved the way for the first victory of the season for the Yankees today as the world champions did their bit in celebrating the Red Sox home opening at Fenway Park before 25,000 frozen fans.

Two hundred Columbia College freshmen and their guests celebrated the Formal Fiesta of the class of 1940 in John Jay Hall last night. The chairman of the dance was Charles H. Schneer, who was assisted by eight of his classmates in the preparations.

A benefit luncheon and bridge party will be given by the Nursing Sisters of the Sick Poor of Jamaica tomorrow at the Lido Country Club, Long Beach. Committees include Mrs. William J. Plant, chairman of tickets, assisted by Mrs. Philip Fagan, Mrs. Lawrence Cook and Mrs. Philip Hensel; Mrs. James Fitzgerald,

England is planning to readopt the excess-profits tax. Whatever may be said against this form of taxation it will be conceded that without exception the excess-profits tax proved itself to be the greatest producer of governmental revenue ever devised.

Benjamin H. Brown of Memphis, Tenn., has won the annual Alumni Prize as "the most faithful and deserving" senior by a vote of Columbia College undergraduates, it was learned yesterday. Thirty-one offices and five prizes were distributed in a three-day voting period, during which 1,042 Columbia students cast ballots.
S. Stewart Clark, works manager of the local General Electric Company plant, today announced an extensive power house modernization program at a cost well above $1.000.000.

The legislative committee of the Citizens Union approved yesterday the Moffat bill to establish a definite system of planning the State's capital expenditures over a six-year period. The hill also would change the beginning of the fiscal year so that tax collections would take place at its beginning, eliminating necessity for temporary borrowing and consequent interest charges.

The question of industry's relations with labor unions assumed a growing importance tonight on the agenda of the United States Chamber of Commerce, which begins its annual meeting here Monday. Delegates arriving for the convention found that a half-dozen proposals already are on the program for their attention.

As the C. I. O.'s Steel Workers' Organizing Committee continues to report additional contracts with concerns of the industry, now listing seventysix, and giving the number of lodges of Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers established as 559, there still is talk among some of the former employes' representatives of forming rival organizations.

The B'nai B'rith lodges recently dissolved throughout Germany by the government have for years been spending 1,000,000 marks annually for charitable purposes, it was revealed today by Alfred M. Cohen, international president of the order.

Humble Oil and Refining Co. announced today that it had discontinued its "joint conference," or company union plan at its Baytown Refinery where 3,300 men work. In a formal statement, the company announced it would bargain collectively with any group representing a majority of the employes and also consider grievances presented by individual employes or groups.

Long envious of the monorail subway cars that carry Senators between the Capitol and the Senate Office Building, House members may decide to install a subway system between the House wing of the Capitol and the two House office buildings.
Open house will be observed at Sarah Lawrence College here tomorrow afternoon from 4 to 7. Some 700 residents of this place and elsewhere in Westchester are expected for the occasion.
A 12 per cent increase for the 600 employes of the Skenandoa Rayon Corporation is provided in an agreement signed by the company and the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O.

THE present function of the Supreme Court of the United States is not written specifically into the Con stitution. It is an evolutionary function, the function of arbiter. Many questions, interests, conflicting claims arise in the course of our national life, which must be settled not with absolute justice but with a workable compromise. We have more of those questions in the United States than confront any other nation.

ACCORDING to the literary critics of practically all lands--except his own--Thomas Mann is the greatest living German author and one of the greatest writers in the world today. According to his secretary, stenographer, best adviser and frankest critic, who happens to be Mrs. Mann, Thomas Mann is extremely "bescheiden." The word "bescheiden," says the dictionary, means "modest" or "unassuming."

Miles Colean, director of the FHA technical division reports that the work of the architectural inspectors in making periodic checks on new construction projects financed under the insured mortgage system, is exerting a definite influence in encouraging better workmanship and the use of proper materials.
OLD ACQUAINTANCE: The President of the United States had as a luncheon guest last week Harold J. Laski, Professor of Political Science

Toronto made it three straight over the Orioles by taking today's final game of the series, 11 to 9. The Leafs belted Leon Chagnon and Harry Matuzak for seventeen hits, Petoskey and Porter hitting homers.

The thirteen - story apartment house at 246 West End Avenue, on the northeast corner of Seventyfirst Street, which was recently renovated so that each floor contains two four-room and six threeroom apartments, is now fully rented, according to Victor M.

Many amateur gardeners seem to have acquired the belief that gladiolus corms are not to be planted out-of-doors until the coming of thoroughly warm, settled weather. As a matter of fact, the colorful "glad" is one of the hardiest of our tender bulbs and may be planted as early as the ground is ready to work.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Adele Barry, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Frederick Barry of Hackensack, N. J., and the late Mr. Barry, to Frederick Gordon Ketcham, son of Frederick A. Ketcham of River Edge and the late Mrs. Ketcham.

Domestic friction between household employes and employers will be analyzed for cause and studied for cure at a "household clinic" convening Tuesday under the direction of the National Committee on Household Employment.

Miss Victoria Le May Mial, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonidas Le May Mial of this place, was married to Harold Kramer Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Minor C. Smith of Short Hills, this afternoon in the Church of the Redeemer by the rector, the Rev. Thomas W. Attridge.

ARLSBAD CAVERNS, nature's underground wonderland in New Mexico has al ready been explored to a depth of 900 feet, and the present concerted effort of the National Park Service and the National Geographic Society aims at the 1,320foot level as a definite objective.

" Unless broadcasting companies begin to pay attention to public criticism they face a rough road ahead," declared George Henry Payne, Fe'deral Communications Commissioner, in a talk here today before the annual conference of District 2 of the American College Publicity Associationn at Adelphi College.
James Wilkie Lestrade, retired food products exporter, died Thursday midnight of uremic poisoning at his home, 161 West Sixteenth Street.

IT'S week-ending time. Bicycles are being put into commission. The good old swing must be tried out for the golf course. Birds and blossoms are luring hikers into the open. City cliff dwellers no longer dare to plan parties for a Saturday night, lest the invitees reply to their invitation: "Sorry, I'm going to the country."

Cyrus Dallin, gray-bearded and stooped at the age of 74, witnessed on the Charles River Esplanade today the unveiling of a clay model of his equestrian statue of Paul Revere which won him first money in a contest conducted by the Boston Art Commission fifty-three years ago.

The spread of Harvard's new prize scholarship program to the graduate schools of the university received impetus today with the announcement that the Medical School has adopted the plan and has awarded honor fellowships to three men entering next Fall.

Analyzing the present status of realty conditions on Manhattan Island, J. K. Cronin, vice president in charge of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York, sounds a warning against excessive optimism,

The report for 1936 of Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., issued yesterday, showed a net profit of [Pound]100,360 after charges, depreciation, depletion, taxes, contingencies and a reserve of [Pound]7,966, or 5 per cent, from profits from operations. For 1935, net profit was [Pound]29,272, excluding a 5 per cent reserve amounting to [Pound]24,802 which was charged against surplus account.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hodgman Saylor of Manhattan and Huntington Bay Village have sent out invitations to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Miller Saylor, and Robert Charles Muhlhausen, which will take place in the Old First Presbyterian Church here May 14.

" MASSIMILLA DONI," an opera in six scenes by the Zurich composer Othmar Schoeck, recently received its premiere in the Dresden Opera House. The work, with book by Arnim Rueger, is founded on Balzac's novel of the same name.
Sociology students of the University of Rochester are using the city's social agencies as their laboratories and are receiving classroom credit for a variety of services.

The Undistributed Profits Tax. By Alfred G. Buehler, Assistant Professor of Economics, University of Vermont. Deals with main provisions of new tax law, historical background, economic and fiscal implications. Considers effects on corporate dividend policies, financing, stock and bond holders, large and small companies.

Crowding home in a driving finish, the Chicle colt Chicolorado captured the $5,650 Stuyvesant Handicap before 20,000 persons at Jamaica yesterday and further enhanced his chances for the Kentucky Derby and other 3-year-old specials.

Since the international control of the coast and frontiers of Spain, which is to prevent fresh fuels being added to the civil conflagration, began on Monday, dozens of vessels have been boarded by observers. But the oath of secrecy has been so well kept that nobody is yet aware how this novel experiment in international cooperation is proceeding.

More than 600 persons last night attended the annual junior promenade at Skidmore College. Guests from many different States were at the dance at the Canfield Casino. C. E. H. Pledger and J. H. Kemnitz, guests of honor, came from Otaga University in New Zealand.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose Spencer Arnold of Fort Lee, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Bovee Arnold, to Gerald K. Ebbesen, son of William Ebbesen of this city and the late Mrs. Ebbesen.

Theatrical history was made this week with the Moscow Art Theatre's presentation of Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina," unanimously hailed as the best accomplishment of that distinguished theatre-which in the view of most foreign critics means the finest in the theatrical world.

Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, stressed the C. I. O. and what he termed its progress, in an address made today before a meeting of the Empire Typographical Conference.
An intercollegiate poetry reading in which six Connecticut universities and colleges will participate will be held at Connecticut College Tuesday evening.
More than 300 New York University alumni and their guests attended the annual supper dance of the Washington Square College Alumni Association last night at the Park Central Hotel.

An overhauling of methods used in training scholars in the individual branches of intellectual history as a means of overcoming "manifest and urgent" difficulties faced by present-day specialists in those fields was recommended by Dr. Arthur O. Lovejoy,

Payments on open credit accounts receivable by department stores fell from 44.4 per cent in February, 1936, to 44 per cent in February of this year, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestio Commerce announced today.

In its first race of the year, the Choate four-oared shell defeated the Princeton freshmen today in 3:30. Choate stepped up the stroke in the last few seconds to stave off the invaders' rally. In the second crews' race, the Princeton yearlings won by a quarter length in 3:31. The beatings:

The man who stole the automobile of Dr. John N. Drury called the physician later and told him where the car could be found. Police found it, but the ignition was damaged and several kits of surgical instruments were not visible.

WHEN a book upon a subject of great timely im portance, and written by a man abundantly equipped by training and experience to discuss it, is animated by a spirit at once of earnestness and moderation, the temptation is strong to give it unqualified praise. Mr.

One of the most ambitious undertakings in undergraduate dramatics at Princeton University will be staged in the McCarter Theater Friday and Saturday'evenings when the Princeton- Theatre Intime and the Theatre Arts Department of the Finch School of New York City will present their annual house party week-end production, Shakespeare's "The Tempest."

Chicora Sensation, white, black and ticked English setter dog, today won the chief trophy in the amateur all-age stake at the tenth annual meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club in old Bedford Village. He is owned by Mr. and Mrs. George W. Cole

Kansas public opinion won another battle for free speech this week; but, although the promptness of the State Censor Board in reviewing the sound film from which last week it had deleted remarks of Senator Wheeler as "partisan and biased," and restoring the remarks, silenced the editorial uproar over the incident, the affair will not be forgotten when political leaders assemble.

The aid of many younger members of society has been enlisted in planning novel divertissements for the opening of the Essex House Promenade and Casinp-on-the-Park next Saturday for the benefit of the child adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

Immigration quotas for 1937, released by the Minister of Labor, permit a total entry into Brazil of 85,214 persons from the whole world under the 2 per cent constitutional immigration restriction clause computed on the records of the last fifty years.

Of late years there has been a growing practice of throwing open to the public, on special occasions, old gardens and fine estates. Usually such "visiting days" are sponsored by garden clubs or horticultural societies.

The Tennessee Electric Power Company, in a letter to the Tennessee Railroad and Public Utilities Commission which was made public here yesterday at the offices of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation, parent company for operating units in the Tennessee Valley, said "it is vitally important that permission be granted the power company to construct a $2,000,000 steam power-generating plant at Nashville."

The Board of Censors of the New York State Medical Society ordered reinstatement yesterday by the Medical Society of Queens County of two Queens Village doctors who were suspended last October when articles lauding their newly-built offices appeared in a Queens Village paper.
Behind the steady pitching of Mike Petroskey, Georgetown scored its fifth victory of the season today, defeating a traditional rival, Maryland University. The score was 9-1.

BERG-STEIN-Mr. Henry (Harold)) Stein announces the engagement of his daughter Paula-Leona, to Mr. Arthur W. D. Berg of Melrose, Pa. Yonkers papers please copy. BODERMAN--PRAGER-Mr. and Mrs. L. W. Prager, 98 Riverside Drive, announce the engagement of their daughter, Isabel, to Mac Boderman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Boderman of Brooklyn.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Mary Elizabeth Conway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Conway of this city, to Thomas Francis Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Clark, also of New Haven.

Announcement has been made by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. George W. C. Hill of Sunset Farm, this city, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Walbridge Hill, to Richard Lyon Hughes, son of Mrs. Clarence Hall Wilson, also of West Hartford, formerly of Honolulu.

Further scientific discoveries, such as have brought world-wide fame and three Nobel Prizes to California Institute of Technology, may be made possible by the extensive building program which has just been started on its campus at Pasadena.

Striking bus and trolley operators voted unanimously today to reject a proposal that they return to work at once, attempt to conciliate their differences with the Akron Transportation Company while working and guarantee the city sixty days' notice of any future strike.
Seven college students from the Metropolitan area were among the twelve recommended for enrollment as aviation cadets in the navy from the Third Naval district, Lieutenant William C. Allison,
Dr. Frederick C. Ferry, president of Hamilton College, tendered his resignation yesterday to the board of trustees at its annual Spring meeting here.

Alexander Shaw, counsel for the United Electrical and Radio Workers, said today. that he would recommend to the National Labor Board a government -supervised election to determine the collective bargaining agency for workers in the East Pittsburgh plants of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.
Bennington College's second commencement, in charge of members of the senior class, will take place on Friday and Saturday, June 11 and 12. The simple half-hour

Convinced that dictators and dictatorships call for study as a technique in government, the School of Social Sciences at Colgate University is to offer a course in "Dictatorships" as a contrast to another course, "Democracy in the Modern World."
City College defeated the Brooklyn College tennis team on the Concourse courts yesterday, splitting six singles and winning three doubles to score by 6-3.

Former associates of the late Charles B. Stover, Park Commissioner under Mayor Gaynor, met yesterday to commemorate the eighth anniversary of his death at the memorial bench dedicated in his honor last November on the site overlooking the Shakespeare Garden in Central Park.

Is it worth while. for the wildflower gardener to attempt to grow the native lady's-slippers? This is a question of considerable importance- in this day of diminishing plant species and conservation policies.

Ending a nation-wide controversy, a pardon was granted today to the golden eagle, formerly Public Enemy No. 1 in wild life. William P. McIntyre, State Game Warden, telephoned a cease-firing order, effective April 30, to Deputy Mike Wilkins at Salmon City, gateway to the Central Idaho wilderness, where eagles are said to have killed deer, wild goats and sheep.

Developments of the week in Europe made the Old World diplomatic map look more like it did before 1914. On the one hand, Belgium got back into her old role of neutral State, while Britain and France publicly proclaimed they stood together officially as being ready to fight side by side in the event of an attack on either. This is even more formal than the old Entente Cordiale of pre-war days.

While organizations have gone a long way in training salesmen in recent years, most of them still fail. to educate their representatives in the proper use of their advertising campaigns, according to Edmund D. Gibbs, one of the pioneers in sales training methods.

In an effort to bolster the failing cause of a public works program, several thousand men, women and children gathered this afternoon in the Spring sunshine in the great park at Vincennes to hear Leon Jouhaux, general secretary of the Confederation of Labor, explain his plan for financing the program.

Sharp contrasts are apparent here to observers who were in Michigan during the Chrysler strike. One outstanding aspect of the new scene is the almost incredible presence of heavily armed forces in a small, good - natured community which seems unable to realize the possibilities of the situation.

An analysis of rents for residential and office space shows that they have not advanced from their low level in proportion to the increase in costs of other basic commodities, according to W. J. McLaughlin, editor of Skyscraper Management, the official publication of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

The pleasantries exchanged by Herr Hitler, allpowerful Fuehrer of Germany, and George Lansbury, intrepid and everoptimistic Parsifal of British pacifism, together with the somewhat vague communique issued by the latter at the close of their interview on Tuesday, seem to have produced elsewhere a journalistic sensation and some confused thinking which the facts as seen here at close range certainly do not warrant.

Purification and concentration of a powerful substance from the liver which has been found in tests on animals and human beings to prevent the formation of blood clots, one of the bugbears of surgery, was announced here today before the closing sessions of the annual meeting of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology.

Smith College will hold its junior promenade on May 8 in the Scott Gymnasium. Dinner dances for juniors and seniors and their "runners" will be held May 7, and the annual garden party will be held in the Great Quadrangle on the afternoon of May 8.

The number of noted educators and scholars who have been called upon to fill Princeton University's thirty five endowed professorships since the first special chair was occupied in 1863 was recalled today in connection with the faculty appointments made by the board of trustees earlier this month.

Having heard the rather astounding report that Miss Ruth Aarons, the New York-born table tennis champion, had played a match before 11,000 spectators in the spacious new stadium at Wembley, England, the writer called on the young lady in question for an interview-and found that the facts of the case were even more remarkable than the report.

APRIL--Walter, on April 19, beloved husband of Bertha (nee Lager), brother of Abram, and Gertrude Baum. Services at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Sunday, April 25, at 1 P. M.

WHILE the earlier Easter this year upset trade comParisons, it became clearer last week that retail sales have suffered a setback in recent weeks in many sections of the country. Larger stores have not suffered as much as smaller dealers, but even the volume of the big distributors has been curtailed.

The first exhibit of an adult art school of a new type opens tomorrow. It represents about six months' work of the Contemporary Art Center of the WPA Federal Art Project, conducted since late last Fall at the Yorkville Y. M. H. A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

A tiny remnant of the once proud race of Samaritans gathered on Mount Gerizim at sundown today to celebrate the Samaritan Passover, one of the oldest of religious ceremonies. Robed priests performed the sacrificial rites in strict accordance with Old Testament injunctions before the entire community of Samaritans, numbering just 160.
The White Horse Ball to be held on Tuesday night at the Astor will be under the patronage of several prominent men and women representative of society and the artistic world.

Horace M. Albright, president of the American Planning and Civic Association, made public today a letter to Representative Boylan of New York, chairman of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Commission, protesting against the choice of the Tidal Basin as a site for the proposed memorial.

Promising to rank as one or tne most significant developments of the year in the field of distribution, the broad movement to give more and accurate facts on merchandise to consumers and to set up standards for a wide variety of goods is destined to achieve substantial progress during the next few weeks, it was learned here yesterdav.

One of the largest office-building modernization projects of recent years in the Broadway district, involving the reconstruction of the old Postal Telegraph Building at Broadway and Murray Street, is nearing completion.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that the hearing on the registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Kinner Airplane and !Mvotor Corporation, Ltd., had been postponed from Anril 28 to May 3.

THE song recital by Claudia Muzio album, promised at the time her set of operatic arias was released, contains ten songs on three twelve and two ten inch disks (Columbia Masterworks 289). One would judge that these were selected by Mme. Muzio

One of the most important and extensive postal emissions since the British Silver Jubilee issue of two years ago is being prepared by Great Britain and its dependencies for the coronation of King George VI on May 12.

RECENTLY the little town of Columbia, Tenn., paid honor to the humble mule with banners, floats and a parade. Columbia knows mules. It calls itself the largest outdoor mule market in the world and appraises the animal with a keen eye.

Mrs. Samuel B. Webb has organized a committee of young matrons to assist with arrangements for the dinner and supper dance to be given on the night of May 6 in the Starlight Roof Garden of the WaldorfAstoria in behalf of the Masters School Day Nursery of this city. The benefit will mark the formal opening of the roof garden for the Summer.

IN the course of the discussion, reported in this column last week. concerning the inordinate output of new books, the opinion was expressed that booksellers suffered through the large number of competing volumes treating of the same subject.

The freshman class choir at Smith College won the annual choir competition held Wednesday eveninig. Leland Hall, Professor of Music at Smith College, presented to Sara Hyde, leader of the freshman choir, the trophy cup given by Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, Smith College alumna and former trustee of the college.

Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, said yesterday on sailing for Europe on the Ile de France that there have been no signs of cancellation of steel orders nor of slackening of demand for steel products since third-quarter prices were reaffirmed at second-quarter levels.

As more gardens come into being and opportunities for comparison become widened, the interest of a garden-maker in achieving personal expression becomes keener. He gradually becomes a student of the underlying principles of garden design.

For the last six or seven weeks London has been the center of rumors and hopes built on rumors that another international conference will be held this year to reduce tariffs, stabilize currencies and bring economic appeasement to the world.

HOT SPRINGS, Va.--The seventh annual Spring tennis tournament takes place on the Casino courts this week, with the first round to be played tomorrow. There will be men's and women's singles, men's and women's doubles and mixed doubles.

About 1,000,000 ' Integralistas ,(Fascists) throughout Brazil. according to figures made public by the Intergralista General Headquarters, celebrated yesterday the fourth anniversary of the first Integralista march in Sao Paulo in 1933.

IT may be significant that the new president of the University of Wisconsin, Clarence A. Dykstra, appointed re did not have a single honorary degree until professor in three colleges in a specialized field.

Substantial gains were made in production of gold and silver in Ontario in March, the Department of Mines reported this week. The output of gold was $7,308,394, against $6,895,604 in February, and $6,714,506 in March, 1936. Gold production was 208,328 ounces, while silver output was 61,742 ounces.

Miss Ceora Jennings Hufnagel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick B. Hufnagel of this place, has chosen the afternoon of May 14 for her marraige to Walter Ware Slocum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Slocum of Ardmore, Pa.

Twenty-five sales of homesites and cabins in the Lake Hiawatha development near Boonton, N. J., were reported last week by Morton Kline, president of the owning corporation. Twenty-seven various types of cabins in the development have recently been opened.

National champions who have represented the New York Athletic Club in amateur athletics during the past year will be the guests of honor at the sixth annual "All Sports" dinner and show to be held in the gymnasium of the city clubhouse on Wednesday evening, May 12.

About 6,100 young men have registered for the Citizens' Military Training Camps of the Second Corps Area for this Summer, it was announced yesterday by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, who pointed out that 1,000 additional registrations are needed to complete the quota for this area.

POOR FRED" was Frederick Louis, son of George II and father of George III, a Prince of Wales who did not live to reign in England, but who led an opposition party against his father the King and Sir Robert Walpole the Prime Minister.

Annual communion breakfast of Congress Own Council No. 502, Knights of Columbus, Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, 9:15 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. Alfred Vey, Francis J. McCaffrey Jr., Francis J. Mahoney and James V. Hayes.
Several deals involving property in the Mohegan Lake district near the boundary line of Westchester and Putnam Counties were reported yesterday by A. L. Shongut, broker.

THIS book was published in England under the title of "Letters From Prison," which is both more direct and more explicit. These letters and poems written in prison during the years 1919-24 comprise the thoughts and feelings of a passionately honest man who has looked out upon the world, then deep into himself, and rendered judgment upon the world out of the depths of himself.

Gene Buffalo, Philadelphia welterweight, outpointed Dewey Anderson of Silver Springs, Fla., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Rockland Palace last night. A crowd of 2,500 saw the Quaker City boxer hold the edge all the way. Buffalo weighed 146 pounds and Anderson 144.

PROFESSOR MERRIAM, whose book was prepared in the first instance as a series of lectures, in November, 1935, on the Stokes Foundation at New York University, is concerned with the "lack of balance" in the modern world "between what is called the political and what is called the economic."

Miss Amy Endlich Schaeffer of Mount Penn, Reading, was married to Frank Leavenworth Connard of Easton, Pa., in Trinity Lutheran Church here today by Dr. Charles M. Jacobs, president of the Mount Airy Lutheran Seminary.
THIS documental and statistical study of the press was conducted by the Carola Woerishoffer graduate department of social economy and social research of Bryn Mawr College.
THE scene of the murders with which this story deals is a place called the Big Top. It is not a circus, but an amusement park which has been converted into a night club with a circus atmosphere.

Accused by the manager of the La Rue Restaurant at 45 East Fifty-eighth Street of "horsewhipping" William R. Seymour, a diner in the restaurant, smashing valuable crockery and causing such a disturbance that about seventy other customers departed abruptly without paying their checks, three married women were arrested last night on disorderly conduct charges.

The combination of one-hit pitching by Andy Lipscomb and loose play in the field sent Princeton down to a 1-0 defeat at the hands of a hustling Army nine today on University Field before 1,200 spectators.

Following the same course which in a few years brought her from comparative obscurity to a position of importance in world cotton markets, Brazil has entered into the export of cotton piece goods and, in the opinion of American exporters, appears certain to challenge Japan's hold in Latin-American, European and some Far Eastern markets.

Tony Canzoneri knocked out Joey Zodda of the Bronx in 1:59 of the seventh in the listed feature tenround bout at the Ridgewood Grove before 4,000 fans last night. The former lightweight champion weighed 138, while Zodda tipped the scales at 137 1/4.

The Boston University nine collected one hit with a walk and two errors in the sixth inning for a pair of runs that gave them a 3-to-2 victory over Wesleyan at Nickerson Field today. The victors got only three safeties off Horne.

Real estate interest in Nassau County, L. I., especially in those suburban areas near the Queens line, indicates that the buying and building activities this year will show a very marked advance over 1936. Brokers report that within the last six weeks a number of builders and operators, some of whom have been affiliated with large Queens projects, have been inspecting tracts available for improvement and conveniently situated to traffic and shopping centers.
Emanuel Romm, a Philadelphia lawyer, was convicted by a jury in Federal court on a charge of extorting $5,000 from a truck operator under the threat of causing labor trouble that would halt his vans.

A feature of the second session of the Wharton Institute of the University of Pennsylvania which will be held next Saturday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria will be discussion on recent developments in real estate and building with particular regard to government activities, Dr. Joseph H. Willits, dean of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce, announced yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif. LONG before the summit snows start to melt, the first contingent of approximately 50, 000 "knapsackers" will be out on the longest continuous pathway in America, the Pacific Crest Trails System.

Few poets can be more out of fashion than SWINBURNE. Singing has gone out. The homely and naked word, the harsh construction, are preferred. If there is an ecstasy, it is metaphysical rather than lyric. The new school has its geniuses and is cruel to the old. So the centenary on April 5 was a bit chilly. One pleasant note, however,

A luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop will take place Thursday at the Versailles. Guests have been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for resale later at the shop, maintained at 705 Second Avenue for the benefit of the Manhattanville Day Nursery,

William Martin Jeffers would "rather be president of the Union Pacific Railroad than President of the United States"--and so he will be, bringing to a climax his meteoric rise in the service to which he has devoted his energies since he was 14 years old.

Back in 1920, when the courts were investigating organized baseball's notorious "Black Sox" scandal, the owners of four major league clubs issued a joint statement to the effect that "we shall have to clean up the game and give it back to the public."

A RECENT proclamation by President Roosevelt has added 305,920 acres of land to Death Valley National Monument, California, a region romantically reminiscent of the feverish days of '49 when men raced westward in quest of gold.
Marjorie Coogan has been elected editor-in-chief of The Fonthill Dial, literary quarterly of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Riverdale, to succeed Antoinette Maher. '38.

Students and faculty of the College of New Rochelle and their friends will witness the final rehearsal of five one-act plays, the term's work of the play production course, on Thursday evening in Chidwick Auditorium.

MIAMI, Fla.-The annual State A. A. U. Boxing Tournament will be held on Tuesday and Wednesday in Miami Beach Arena. Entries in the tournament, which, with nearly a hundred competing, is called the largest of its kind in history, include, in addition to those from throughout the greater Miami area, numbers also from Jacksonville, St. Petersburg, Tampa, Deland, Fort Myers, Sebring, Orlando, Gainesville and other principal centers.

In the greatest race he has ever run in his brief career as a jumper, Paul Mellon's Welbourne Jake today won the coveted Maryland Hunt Cup over the four-mile course on the estate of J. W. Y. Martin at Glyndon, Md.

More than 2,500 persons attended the annual dinner dance of the Joseph P. Ryan Association at the Hotel Commodore last night. Mr. Ryan, for whom the organization is named, is president of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Indiana's system of turning out distance runners on a mass-production scale paid a heavy dividend at sunflooded Franklin Field today as a gathering of 40,000 watched four Hoosier youngsters break the world record for the four-mile relay, the crowning achievement of the fortythird annual Penn relay carnival.

MAY: Slighted by Poets It seems to me that May has been neglected somewhat by the poets, who seem to find plenty of inspiration in the other months of the year. Offhand, I can't recall a single piece celebrating the merits of this most delightful month.

UNCLE SAM, in spite of the President's instructions to the various departments the other day to go over their budgets and find ways to pare down, plans to be pretty generous in the matter of aid to Federal highway projects during the coming fiscal year.
Mr. and Mrs. James K. Scott of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Nettie Scott, to Albert J. Lyman, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. R. Lyman of Hackensack.
THE festivities connected with the crowning of King George and Queen Elizabeth will not go unsung by the nation's minstrels. Coronation concerts are the order of the day;

Kent School's two crews won their races over the mile course today against two crews from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The Kent oarsmen are being coached this season by Dixon Walker, who assisted Father Sill at Henley last Summer. The latter has taken over the crews of the two lower classes.
Home buying is one of the most practical methods of saving during a period of rising prices, pointed out Harold Mott, president of Mott Brothers, Garden City developers.

Thirty old Italian violins, owned by American musicians and collectors and valued at $1,000,000, are on their way to Italy on the Conte di Savoia, which left here yesterday. The instruments will be shown at the exhibition in Cremona being held in observance of the 200th anniversary of the death of the famous violin maker, Antonius Stradivarius.

Commanders John Bayliss, Stephen S. Yeandle and other Coast Guard officers will be guests at "Coast Guard Night" of the Marine Trades Association on Thursday, at the Hotel Lexington, in a program arranged by President George W. Sutton Jr.

Miss Muriel Emma Jensen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Jensen of this town, was married to Everett Borden Post, son of Mrs. David A. Post of South Orange and the late Mr. Post, this afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George G. Vogel, former pastor of the church.
Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure nineteen nineteen six, result happiness. Annual income twenty pounds, annual expenditure twenty pounds ought and six, result misery.
A single by Smead Jolley in the ninth inning with the bases loaded gave Jersey City a 2-to-1 victory and an even break in its series with the Rochester Red Wings today.

Thirteen Degas bronzes, modern paintings, drawings, etchings, drypoints and lithographs from the estate of Cornelius J. Sullivan and property belonging to Mrs, Sullivan will be sold at auction at the American -Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday and Friday evening and on Saturday afternoon.

Fire of undetermined origin, which started in the painting department of the Atla Steel Barrel Company, Avenue A and Second Street, caused heavy damage to stock, finished products and valuable machinery today. The loss was estimated at about $150,000.

Fred L. Emerson, an Auburn manufacturer, hopped off today on a projected thirty-day round-the-world air tour. He plans to use passenger airplanes throughout, except for a hop from Frankfort, Germany, to Lakehurst, N. J., in the Hindenburg.

THE airport history of the United States has been marked by a combination of enthusiasm, careful planning, municipal stupidity, cupidity and Ignorance. Coupled with this has been a record of intelligent action to meet emergencies.
Fred Thon, sophomore right-hander, hurling his first varsity game, fanned eighteen as Lafayette defeated Haverford today, 12 to 2. Thon allowed only two hits, one a home run by Magill.

Dr. Robert Heywood Fernald, a widely known engineer who, since 1930, had been dean of the Towne Scientific School at the University of Pennsylvania, died of a heart ailment tonight in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital following a long illness.

Ann Harding, the actress, arrived here from England today just twenty-four hours after a Quebec judge had annulled a warrant for her arrest on a kidnapping charge. Accompanied by her husband, Werner Janssen, and her daughter, Jane, 13, Miss Harding boarded a train and it was understood she was bound for New York.
A parallel between President Roosevelt's court proposal and similar problems in English history has been brought out by Roger B. Merriman and James P. Baxter 3d, Harvard history professors.

SIMEN ARTEMOWSKY'S operetta, "Zaporogetz Za Dunayem" (Cossacks Beyond the Danube), will receive its American premiere May 8 and 9 at the Venice Theatre, by the Ukrainian Theatrical Company of New York, under the baton of Jacob Kazze.

Dr. Margaret Maltby, formerly of Barnard College, will introduce two holders of current fellowships of the American Association of University Women, at the annual meeting and election of the New York branch on Saturday at Brooks Hall of Barnard College.

Henry L. Crane, a descendant of the founders in 1669 of Cranetown, which became Montclair, died in a nursing home here today at the age of 86. Among his ancestors were Joseph Crane, a settler of Newark in 1666, and Robert Treat, former Governor of Connecticut.

Miss Adele Payton Masset, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Masset, was married here this morning at the home of her parents to Peter H. Treffers Jr., son of Peter H. Treffers of New York and the late Mrs. Treffers. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harry Coleman

Mrs. Alfred H. Hausrath, president of the Bronx Women's Club, was named outstanding woman civic leader of the Bronx for 1936 at the annual dinner of the Soroptimist Club of Bronx County, an organization of professional women and woman executives, held last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, 161st Street and Concourse Plaza.

The recent violent ups and downs of wheat prices reflected both the wave of speculation that has swept leading commodity markets in the past few months and the close balance of the supply and demand of wheat throughout the world.

Edwin Henry Colpitts, retired president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories in New York,. was decorated today by Emperor Hirohito with the Fourth Order of Merit of the Sacred Treasure in recognition of his promotion of electrical engineering in Japan and his furthering of good relations between Japan and the United States.
Representatives of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the Artcraft Silk Hosiery Mills, Inc., conferred today in an effort to settle a sit-down strike which began at the plant Tuesday.
The opening luncheon of the Women's Golf Association of the Wykagyl Country Club here will be held on Friday. More than 100 members are expected to attend the event. Mrs. W. E. Barnes is secretary.
With Jim Gleeson, pinch hitter, striking the telling blow, the Newark Bears made a three-run drive in the ninth inning today to defeat Montreal, 6 to 4, for their third straight victory.

Coach Ossie Solem thinks his 1937 Syracuse football team is going to be all right. Here as honor guest at a dinner given last night at the Hotel McAlpin by New York alumni of Syracuse, Solem, former coach at the University of Iowa, said:
