PATROLMEN - Mariano Ruffino, from 23d Precinct to 18th Division, for seven days, from 8 A. M., April 24. Philip A. Lang, from 83d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, Kings, for two days, from 4 P. M., April 22.
The corridors of Bellevue Hospital were deserted yesterday. Medicinal odors were evident, but there were no patients hobbling along on crutches or being pushed in wheel chairs.

Miss Constance Wilmot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wilmot of this place, was married today to Horace Henry Manchester Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace H. Manchester of White Plains, at the Wilmot home. The Rev. Dr. Cary S. Osborne, pastor of the North Baptist Church of Port Chester, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a breakfast.

Plans for the marriage on May 28 of Miss Molly Owings Shriver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Nicholas Shriver of Baltimore to Rutherford Stuyvesant Pierrepont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford S. Pierrepont of Far Hills, N. J., have been announced.

JANOVER--STEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stein announce the marriage of their daughter, Justine Marie, to Mr. Robert Gumpert Janover on April 20 at SavoyPlaza Hotel. RICHTER-FRIEDMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Saul Friedman announce the marriage of their daughter, Inez, to Mr. Irving E. Richter, son of Mrs. E. Richter, on Wednesday, April 21.

Breaking 197 out of a possible 200 targets, Tracy H. Lewis, one of the veteran gunners of the organization, won the trapshooting championship of the New York Athletio Club yesterday. L. F. Sanman, who took the title in 1936 with 196, finished in a tie at 189 with Z. G. Simmons for seventh place in Class A.
Smith College is distinct among women's colleges in possessing a Summer residence for graduate students, women members of the faculty and alumnae engaged in graduate work.

Edwin Henry Colpitts, retired president of the Bell Telephone Laboratories in New York,. was decorated today by Emperor Hirohito with the Fourth Order of Merit of the Sacred Treasure in recognition of his promotion of electrical engineering in Japan and his furthering of good relations between Japan and the United States.
Representatives of the Committee for Industrial Organization and the Artcraft Silk Hosiery Mills, Inc., conferred today in an effort to settle a sit-down strike which began at the plant Tuesday.
The opening luncheon of the Women's Golf Association of the Wykagyl Country Club here will be held on Friday. More than 100 members are expected to attend the event. Mrs. W. E. Barnes is secretary.
With Jim Gleeson, pinch hitter, striking the telling blow, the Newark Bears made a three-run drive in the ninth inning today to defeat Montreal, 6 to 4, for their third straight victory.

Coach Ossie Solem thinks his 1937 Syracuse football team is going to be all right. Here as honor guest at a dinner given last night at the Hotel McAlpin by New York alumni of Syracuse, Solem, former coach at the University of Iowa, said:

PATROLMEN - Mariano Ruffino, from 23d Precinct to 18th Division, for seven days, from 8 A. M., April 24. Philip A. Lang, from 83d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, Kings, for two days, from 4 P. M., April 22.
The corridors of Bellevue Hospital were deserted yesterday. Medicinal odors were evident, but there were no patients hobbling along on crutches or being pushed in wheel chairs.

Miss Constance Wilmot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wilmot of this place, was married today to Horace Henry Manchester Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace H. Manchester of White Plains, at the Wilmot home. The Rev. Dr. Cary S. Osborne, pastor of the North Baptist Church of Port Chester, performed the ceremony, which was followed by a breakfast.

Plans for the marriage on May 28 of Miss Molly Owings Shriver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Nicholas Shriver of Baltimore to Rutherford Stuyvesant Pierrepont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherford S. Pierrepont of Far Hills, N. J., have been announced.

JANOVER--STEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stein announce the marriage of their daughter, Justine Marie, to Mr. Robert Gumpert Janover on April 20 at SavoyPlaza Hotel. RICHTER-FRIEDMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Saul Friedman announce the marriage of their daughter, Inez, to Mr. Irving E. Richter, son of Mrs. E. Richter, on Wednesday, April 21.

Breaking 197 out of a possible 200 targets, Tracy H. Lewis, one of the veteran gunners of the organization, won the trapshooting championship of the New York Athletio Club yesterday. L. F. Sanman, who took the title in 1936 with 196, finished in a tie at 189 with Z. G. Simmons for seventh place in Class A.
Smith College is distinct among women's colleges in possessing a Summer residence for graduate students, women members of the faculty and alumnae engaged in graduate work.

A refreshing contrast to the picture of American college life as a succession of classes, athletics and social events is furnished at Cornell University in the variety of extracurricular activities of a more serious import which have a definite relationship to one's chosen career.

The prediction made early in the year by Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey FHA director, that 8,000 new homes would be built in that State this year, was evidently not too high, states Mr. Colleton, who points to the fact that figures prepared for his office by the Dodge Statistical Research Service show that construction was started in 1,213 new homes in New Jersey during the first three months of the present year.

THE scope of the professional decorator is widening to include details of room arrangement formerly left to other specialists Illumination, for example, has of late developed such possibilities that the decorator now works out a scheme with the lighting expert.

Fewer out-of-town buyers were in the New York wholesale market last week, and purchasing in general fell off, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.
An extension service, designed to increase the opportunity for reading among rural ministers of South Carolina, is a new addition to Furman University's Carnegie library.

Holy Cross and Rhode Island State shared the major honors today when 600 college, prep and high school track aces from thirty-three institutions braved a chill wind to compete in the first New England relay carnival at the Harvard Stadium.
FOUR days before his death, Leopold II, King of the Belgians, married the Barones de Vaughan, who had been his mistress for nine years That was in 1909. Many people can still remember. If they try,
" Best wishes from 500,000 semipro players" came to Tris Speaker today through Honus Wagner, high commissioner of the National Semi-Pro Baseball Congress.

Bob Feller lost his first official start of the season today as the Browns beat the Indians, 4--3, but the pitching prodigy maintained his record strike-out pace by fanning eleven men in the six innings he worked before a pulled muscle in his "million dollar" arm forced him from the game.

THE making of comedies is a serious business. From that day twenty years ago when one of the Stern brothers told a scoffing competitor, "Our comedies ain't to be laughed at," down through the ages the pursuit of the screen's humor has been a pretty somber affair.
SEVERAL communications concerned with the proposed Jefferson Memorial at Washington and bearing reference to the article that appeared on this page last Sunday have been received by the art editor.

THE Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology met last week in Memphis, Tenn., thumped man on the chest, explored his brain, probed his glands and in general picked him apart and put him together again--all in the name of science and a longer life.

Debits sai to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended April 21 aggregated $9,406,000,000, or 6 per cent above total reported for the preceding week and 8 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

The American Women's Club coronation ball will be held on May 25. Mrs. Ormond Lawson-Johnston and Mrs. Wallace F. Kirk will give a debutante dinner dance on May 19 in honor of Miss Vesta Culbertson of New York.

Mrs. Ercole Locatelli is honorary chairman and Mrs. Carlo Savini active chairman of the executive committee working toward the success of the gala Primavera entertainment in behalf of Columbus Hospital, which will take place next Saturday night at the Plaza.

Week-end developments touching the two most important buffer States of Europe, Belgium and Austria, immediately suggest a realignment of the Powers very similar to that of 1914. Formally released from the obligation assumed under the Locarno treaty to assist France and Britain, Belgium returns to her pre-war status of neutrality.

Miss Florence Alice Morgan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome John Morgan of this place, was married to William Lawrence F. Hardham, son of Mrs. John Stuart Hardham of Newark and the late Mr. Hardham, here tonight in the Morrow Memorial Church by the Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, the pastor.

Recent surveys have shown that only one to two-fifths of the students at Dartmouth College speak in such a way as to be regularly intelligible, according to Dr. Charles H. Voelker of the speech clinic.
William S. Murray, chairman of the Republican State Committee, says that the "young Republicans," are to have representation and recognition in the councils of the party.

The invasion of Newport by the America's Cup sloops in preparation for the international match in midsummer will start this week. Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee, which has been hauled out at the Lawley yard in Neponset, below Boston, after her few trial spins under her new rig, is to be put overboard again today.

The possibility that President Roosevelt's bill for reorganization of the Federal courts might reach the Senate floor with a recommendation from its Judiciary Committee that it be defeated was admitted today by Chairman Ashurst, the bill's strongest partisan on the committee.

REMODELING of the brownstone residence at 59 East Sev enty-fifth Street into modern apartments has just been completed by the Union Dime Savings Bank, owner of the property. Commenting on this and other alterations projects recently carried out by this institution, William L.

Facing need of additional space for patients and advanced medical equipment, many of the sixteen general hospitals in Westchester; County are planning to build additions. The population of the county.

IT would not take an Isaiah to prophesy that long after the present bumper crop of dream children have passed into oblivion aged people will still be talking nostalgically about the goldenhaired heroine of "The Perils of Pauline."

THERE are five or six spots on the earth's surface where nature has shown what she could do if she really got inhospitable. Such places are Death Valley, the upper Himalayas, the Amazonian jungles, the wastes of the Antarctic and the Bonneville Salt Flats.

The body of Senator Nathan L. Bachman of Tennessee, who died here last night, left the Capital tonight for Chattanooga where the funeral will be held Monday, in the care of a joint committee of eight Senators and four members of the House of Representatives.

The College of william and Mary will be host tomorrow to Vice President John N. Garner and a party of 200 members of Congress. The party is spending the weekend visiting points of interest in Newport News, Hampton and Langley Field, Va., and will visit Yorktown, Va. and Jamestown, Va. tomorrow before coming to Williamsburg.

The Boerse was resistant when it closed today after a small turnover and after having been weak and listless at the opening. Heavy industrial shares continued to show considerable losses, which included those of both Rheinstahl and Hoesch.

THE public knows A. L. Berman as a theatrical attorney, and the trade as an occasional and quiet investor in Broadway entertainments. Now Mr. Berman would like to know himself as a producer in his own right, wherefore he has acquired the American rights to a fantasy with incidental music, "The Melody That Got Lost."

A proposal for the Canadian Government to enlarge the channel of the Richelieu River near St. Johns, which would result in lowering the waters of Lake Champlain so that they would be permanently at or slightly above the present minimum elevation of 92.5 feet, is causing dissatisfaction in Burlington and other cities and towns along the lake.

Calling attention to the plight of scores of American commercial representatives stranded in hotels in South America for weeks at a time because accommodations are lacking on ships and airplanes, the Overseas Automotive Club yesterday appealed to steamship and air lines to find some means of assurin space to exponnrt travelers.

AT this time of year shop counters bloom bravely At thisth varicolored cheeses. Golden Swiss and redcoated Edam, yellow Brie and gray Roquefort, with all their creamy brethren, come to lighten meals made heavy by long Winter months.

Treasury Department agents arrested four men today after confiscating a 1,000-gallon still and 6,000 gallons of mash on an estate owned by the du Pont de Nemours Company at 574 Mountain Avenue. The estate had been leased to John Mishuraca, for whom a warrant was issued.

Governor Lewis O. Barrows today signed a bill creating a State "liquor monopoly" by which importation of liquor by individuals through express companies and other carrier services would be prohibited.

The Committee for Industrial Organization announced during the past week that its first move against the Ford Motor Company in its campaign to unionize the last of the big three in the automobile industry would be to file charges of unfair practices against Ford under the Wagner Labor Act.
Savings banks have solved their real estate problems caused by the depression and will continue to meet rising exigencies, according to Charles G. Edwards, president of the Central Savings Bank.

The week in the markets was one of nervousness. Stocks and bonds declined; commodities fluctuated widely but showed relatively unimportant net changes on the week. THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks lost 2.28 points on the basis of the closing level of 430.45.

The Rev. Henry S. Hitchcock, pastor of the Chicopee Falls Congregational Church, is known to hundreds of Chicopee residents as "the straight-shooting pastor." This not not only because of his forthright sermons from the pulpit but because he is exceptionally proficient with the bow and arrow.
The Official Gazette announced today that the title of "doctor" had been taken from Julius Katzenstein, who received it at Greifswald University in 1917. The title was not honorary but earned.

Within eighteen days of the coronation with London teeming with visitors from all over the world, 45,000 omnibus operators decided today to strike Friday unless their demand for a seven-and-a-half hour work ing day is immediately conceded.

Miss Elizabeth Swift of Verona, daughter of William H. Swift Jr. and the late Mrs. Swift, will be married on June 12 to Thomas William Goas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Goas of Orange. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Morgan Phelps Noyes, pastor of Central Presbyterian Church, Montclair.
Two Montenegrin peasants were killed and six injured by a volley fired by Serbian gendarmes into a party of mourners at a rural cemetery near Podgoritza yesterday.
The Rev. William J. Engelen, S. J.. cofounder of the Catholic University of Tokyo, died of paralysis at a hospital here yesterday. He was 64 years old.
There is no better evidence of the difference in basic philosophies of the United States and Great Britain than the two national budgets published this week. On the one hand,
Jenks, Gwynne Co. have prom pared a list of companion in RSe elected industries. Tailer Robinson have moved tS 120 Wall Street.
The Crescent A. C. lacrosse. team defeated the Montclair A. C. today, 9-7. The home ten led at half time, 5-3, but a last-quarter rally, with goals by Paice and Cook, brought victory to the visitors.
Close cooperation with the people and institutions of Northern New York and Southern Ontario is one of the most important scopes of activity at St. Lawrence University.
Temple scored its fifth victory of the season today by turning back Gettysburg, 3-2, on the Owls' stadium diamond.

Buying policies of industrial purchasing agents have undergone drastic changes in recent months and many purchasing executives are making no important commitments at the present time, according to the regular monthly report of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, released yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Johnson, 55 years old, owner of a rooming house at 113 West 103d Street, died at 10:30 yesterday morning while walking to a neighborhood shop to buy some brandy for an ailing tenant, Mrs. Nora Bridgett, 80. At 4:45 in the afternoon, Mrs. Bridgett, who suffered a blood clot on the brain, also died. Dr. William M. Richards,

To introduce greater efficiency and effectiveness into the four Spring meetings of the League of Women Voters in the State, the first of the series, on Tuesday at Vassar College, will stress a program of direct action.
Twelve students in the graduating class and one member of the faculty at City College have won major and minor insignia from the Student Council for prominence in student life at the college
The man with the most anxious and responsible job in London is the Commissioner of Police for the metropolis, whose headquarters are at new Scotland Yard.

Miss Mary Hirsch, only woman training a Kentucky Derby eligible, sent her candidate, No Sir, over the full mile and a quarter today in 2:111-5. No Sir worked on a slow track, and the time was regarded as good.
William Erwin Cate, principal of the senior high school here since 1926, died suddenly at his home here today at the age of 68. He was working in his garden shortly after 9 A. M. when he collapsed.
The model League of Nations defeated a commission report on sanctions and collective security at its closing plenary session here today.
A card party under the auspices of Auxiliary Six of Stony Wold Sanatorium will be held the afternoon of May 11 at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League for the benefit of the sanatorium.

THE very name of the tariff has become suggestive of boredom. And yet here is a book that will seize and retain the interest of almost every kind of reader, the seasoned economist and the plain, everyday man and woman alike.

The Cadets of Virginia Military Institute will march to victory Friday in Petersburg National Military Park, Va., when they represent the Confederate troops in a reenactment of the historic Battle of the Crater. The battlefield will be dedicated as a part of Petersburg Park.

The annual musical and luncheon of The Godmothers' League will be held next Wednesday at 11 A. M. at the Hotel Astor for the benefit of the league's non-sectarian nursery at 115 East 101st Street. Mrs. Zion De Frece Bernstein is president of the league.
An official of the Ford Motor Company and a union leader were speeding here tonight to iron out a situation involving sit-downers, 600 of whom evacuated the company's West Coast assembly plant today.

Speaking recently on the influence of financial institutions upon the quality of building construction, Frederick V. Goess, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, indicated that such influence is being exerted to a much larger degree than was the case a few years ago.

The twelfth annual military ball of the New York University Chapter of Scabbard and Blade, national honorary military fraternity, will take place on Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Following an early-morning clash between strike pickets and police outside the plant of The Long Island Daily.Press in Jamaica yesterday, a conference was called to try to settle the differences which resulted in the strike of editorial employes of the paper, members of the American Newspaper Guild, two weeks ago.

Argentina has signed an agreement with the Netherlands permitting the immigration of Netherland colonists to be settled on State lands. Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas announced he would offer similar agreements to Sweden, Denmark and Hungary.
Brooklyn Tech outscored Tilden, 6--1, to go to first place in the Brooklyn, Section A, P. S. A. L. baseball race at Commercial Field yesterday. Tilden was the victor in the Section B drive last year.

Four elderly women clerks of the United States Treasury Department were without their jobs today for accomplishing the seemingly impossible feat of robbing the Federal Treasury right under the noses of guards.

A luncheon and children's fashion show will be held on May 8 at the Merry-Go-Round Bar in the Maisonette Russe of Paris for the benefit of the Holy Child School in Suffern. Mrs. William J. Pedrick heads the entertainment committee.

THE trip to Budapest promised by the United States Bridge Association to the winner of its current Grand National team-of-four tournament is still at stake. With other events of the week's tournament finished, the final matches of the team-of-four contest will be played "at the convenience of the players."

The annual chore of putting away the family's Winter clothes can be lightened if the housekeeper takes advantage of practical devices offered by the shops. At this time of year many of them set apart special departments of aids to cleaning,

Mayor John Boyd Thacher's car got a new coat of gray-green paint today, but it was all an accident. The car, occupied by Mrs. Thacher and a chauffeur, was parked on North Pearl Street when a gallon can of paint came hurtling down from a scaffold swung against an upper story of a near-by building. Mrs.

The transportation strikers and the municipality both have apologized to the public for the go-slow strike, but that is all the satisfaction the public has obtained. The third day of the strike for higher pay opened with street cars running at 50 per cent of their normal service.
Frank R. Ellis, who was with the American Book Company here for fiftythree years and who sang in the May Festival Chorus for fifty years, died at his home here today. He was 89 years old.

The Student Council of Manhattan College, through its president, Gilbert McInerny of Hollis, announced yesterday an approved list of nominations for offices in the senior class, Student Council and Athletic Association for the 1937-38 school year. Elections will be held this week.

IN the theatre impartiality is almost a vice. "Write with blood and you will find that you have written with genius," is a saying that dramatists are entitled to apply to themselves. If politics is the pulse by which their blood is driven, they must write politically, and we w' o do not share or are actively opposed to their views have no right to complain.

Testimony that there were no powder marks on Mrs. Verna Garr Taylor's clothing and that there were spots, alleged to be blood, on the heavy overcoat of Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt was placed before the jury trying Denhardt on a murder charge here today.

BY producing Dr. Friedrich Wolf's "Professor Mamlock" the Jewish Unit of the Fed eral Theatre reminds us.that the terroristic persecution of the Jews in Nazi Germany cannot be effectively represented on the stage.

Oral examinations now in use for candidates seeking teaching positions in the New York City school system test the prospective teacher's "petty" faults rather than the ability to speak correct English, Charles G. Spiegler, former speech examiner at the College of the City of New York, declared yesterday.

Princeton's rugby team scored a surprising, decisive 15-7 triumph over the New York Rugby Club at Randalls Island yesterday. The Tigers outplayed their rivals from the opening whistle although the losers offered stubbon opposition, especially in the beginning of the first half and the latter part of the second.

The hopes and fears of labor, industry and a strike-weary public were focused last week upon the three-man National Labor Relations Board and its regional officers, whose authority to enforce collective bargaining was firmly established thirteen days ago in a historic decision of the United States Supreme Court.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channel of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.

THE wilderness of the United States is dwindling rapidly. While you are reading this, the jack hammers the bulldozers and thousands of men are pushing. it back on several dozen frontiers. Literally, however, it is not the frontier that is being pushed back.
GREATER comfort and increased mileage per traveldollar are the announced objectives of air, rail and bus lines as they swing into preparations for the annual Western vacation season.

The Nationalists [Insurgents] today took full advantage of the first fair weather to favor their offensive on the Bilbao front since its inception. They advanced from Vangara to Beizbal, only three miles from Durango, sixteen miles southeast of the Basque capital.

STATISTICS say that the average American at present is spending $1 out of every $12 of his income on travel. The result is that the travel business for 1987 bids fair to stend next to steel and automobiles in the ranks of American industry.

Miss Anna Lodge Minot, daughter of Mrs. Presley Morgan Taylor, will be married on May 12 to Henry Canby Biddle of Green Gardens, Wayne, in Holy Triinty Church by the Rev. John Hart, the Rev. Richard Lyford and the Rev. Henry Weir.

Youth organizations were warned to guard against "communistic zealots" who were attempting to poison the minds of young and old alike, in an address yesterday by George F. Denniston, executive director of the Catholic Youth Organization, Archdiocese of New York.
A new two-story home designed to show recent developments in residential building materials and equipment will be opened to the public today at Strathmore-at-Manhasset, L. I., by Levitt Sons.
The Spanish Government announced today a company of Insurgent infantry, numbering 175 men, had revolted on the Cordoba front, shot their officers and deserted to the government lines.

Objects of art, personal possessions and household furnishings of the late James Anderson Hawes, New York attorney and for 20 years secretary of Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity, brought $5,700 at a twoday auction which closed today in the Hawes home on Purchase Lane. Mr. Hawes died at Mount Kisco Feb. 28, 1936.

A cross bill demanding that the American Federation of Labor account for a defense fund, which followers of John L. Lewis charged has been depleted by $200,000, has been filed in Federal court by counsel for the Aluminum Workers Union of-New Kensington. Pa.

The Long Island University tennis team defeated the St. Peter's College squad, 5-4, on the Utica courts in Brooklyn yesterday. The teams broke even in the singles, but the Blackbirds took two of the three doubles to triumph. The summaries:

Everything that makes for a successful parade, including a band, a reviewing stand with a city official and distinguished guests, a police contingent and fine weather, combined yesterday for the seventh annual baby parade of the Madison Square Boys Club at 312 East Thirtieth Street.
For the fifth year in a row, President Roosevelt this week faced a difficult budget problem because of money needed for relief of the unemployed.

The Schuschnigg- Mussolini conversations in Venice this week and the overtures toward Czechoslovakia in the Viennese press have aroused speculation as to whether the Austrian Chancellor has become disillusioned as to Italian friendship.

The National Capital Park and Planning Commission suggested today the erection of a memorial to Pan-American ideals and principles on the site selected for an office building annex for the Pan American Union.

GOODWIN, ELMER C. (Aug. 18, 1934). Gross assets. $23,185; net, $13,831. To wife, Regina M. Goodwin; daughter, Madeleine F. Goodwin; sons. Frank J. and Peter J. Goodwin, one-fourth of residuary estate each in trust. Chief assets.

Plans for a 25 per cent increase in the undergraduate enrollment of Bryn Mawr College were disclosed today in connection with an announcement by Dr. Marion Edwards Park, the president, of a three-point building project.
Bucky Jacobs, University of Richmond baseball captain, hurled his second no-hit game in two weeks when Richmond shut out Hampden-Sydney, 4 to 0, today.

Youthful voices-more than 1,000 of them in all-took part today in the twentieth biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs. From the cotton mills of South Carolina to the Bacone Indian School of Muskogee, Okla., came groups of young musicians to provide the festival's Junior Day program.

Miss Margaret Woodworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur V. Woodworth of this city, was married here this afternoon to Stuart Scott Jr., son of Mrs. Stuart Scott of New York and the late Mr. Scott, in the Emmanuel Church.

The Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, Samuel Untermyer, president, will sponsor a concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday, which will consist solely of compositions that have been banned from Germany by official decree.

While total registrations for the first three months of 1937 fell more than a thousand behind the record figures for the same period of 1936, according to an announcement made yesterday by the American Kennel Club, there is little doubt that the deficit will more than be made up before the close of the year.

Spokesmen for the American Federation of Hosiery Workers will meet here Wednesday with representatives of two groups of employers, the Full Fashioned Hosiery Association, Inc., and the Full Fashioned Hosiery Manufacturers of America, to iron out all hosiery union difficulties north of the Mason-Dixon line.

Escorted by a mother ship carrying supplies, fuel, extra parts, mechanics and a physician in case of accident or sickness, a score of small cruisers will leave Miami on Saturday for a unique sixteen-day voyage around the southern half of Florida, recently made an island by the cross-State canal from Stuart to Fort Myers.

JUST off the edge of the Milky Way of broadcasting, in which more than 700 stations are crowded, quite alone, shines Station WQXR on the 1,550 kilocycle channel projecting skyward from Long Island City, although the studios are in New York at 730 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of Fifty-seventh Street.

Eduard Herrman, violinist and composer, died of a heart attack today in his Winter home at the age of 86. Mr. Herrman, who retired in 1929, was organizer of the Herrman Quartet and concertmaster under Theodore Thomas in the old Chicago Symphony Orchestra.

Miss Margaret Ackerman Van Valen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Garret A. Van Valen, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to John Augustus Fischer, son of Mrs. William A. Fischer of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Fischer, by the Rev. Francis A. Seibert.
The office of Counselor of the State Department is to be re-established under legislation recommended to Congress by Secretary Hull.

The agreement reached between the city's Health Department and five leading medical schools, whereby services and facilities will be interchanged in the world's largest program for the training of medical students in preventive medicine, will be put in force soon, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

No recovery movement in the history of this country has lasted so long as the present one, but neither has one ever been so slow and halting, according to a study of "eadjustments Required for Recovery" published by the Public Affairs Committee of Washington,
The American Aid Society of Paris, although in existence here for some fifteen years, is giving its first public benefit on May 7 this year.

Miss Alison McDaniel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Boyer McDaniel of Chevy Chase, Md., and Anthony Francis Bisgood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Philip Bisgood, were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel at the home of Charles Mason Remey. The Rev.
Representative and Mrs. Sol Bloom entertained at luncheon today in honor of Speaker and Mrs. Bankhead.
THREE COMRADES, by Erich Maria Remarque. (Little, Brown, $2.75.) A new novel by the author of "All Quiet on the Western Front."

Wesley Cochrane, 19 years old, an unemployed carpenter's helper, of 90-25 207th Street, Hollis, Queens, was arrested just before last midnight when he was captured running from the Queens Village Baptist Church, Ninety-fourth Avenue and 217th Street, where an attempt had- been made to break upon a safe.
Herman's tally in the first period gave Hispano a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Germans in an American Soccer League contest played at Hawthorne Field yesterday.

The state of the Federal budget has become the central feature of the recovery problem, with an importance transcending that of any other economic question facing the country, says the Guaranty Trust Company in the current issue of its publication, the Guaranty Survey.

The Rodwyn Stables, belonging to Mrs. Stephen Porter and Rodney Waterman of Greenwich, Conn., captured their third horse show championship in two days at the second annual one-day Hutchinson event today. The exhibition was held on the grounds of the Hutchinson Riding Academy and marked the first outdoor show of the local season.

The New York World's Fair of 1939 can become either a "barbarian display" of commercial exploitation or a "vast display of culture and beauty," John Haynes Holmes, pastor- of the Community Church, declared yesterday in an address at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.
Wholesale prices on April 14 were 105.9 against an index number of 106.2 on April 7. Germany's retail turnover in February was 7 per cent better than correspondingly a year ago.

Last Summer, if anything had happened to the University of Washington's brilliant eight-oared crew the varsity of Pennsylvania would have been the logical representative of the United States at the Olympic Games in Germany, for Penn was the nearest thing to Washington in the Olympic trials and one of the great sprint crews of the year, probably the best of the East.
To Japan's national pantheon, which orthodox religious books say includes "eighty myriads of gods," 1,148 new deities were added in solemn ceremonies today.
Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System gained $320,000,000 from March 24 to April 21,
A survey of the last 2,500 years conducted at Harvard by Professor SOROKIN leads to the conclusion that the first quarter of the
Loans and discounts through the Farm Credit Administration amounted to $69,800,000 in March, a 12 per cent increase over a year ago, exceeding any month since the beginning of 1936.

Representatives of the State and city gathered this afternoon to pay tribute to Simon W. Rosendale at a funeral service in the Temple Beth Emeth. Rabbi Bernard J. Bamberger read the Psalms and this was followed by the eulogy by Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu-El of New York, formerly of Albany.
President Lazaro Cardenas intensified today Mexico's fight against the narcotic habit by establishing a special committee under the National Department of Health to deal with the problem.

Among the passengers arriving today from Havre via Southampton on the French liner Normandie are Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Dewey Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Felix Warburg, Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Warner, Mr. and Mrs. Sam E. Morris, H. J. Symington, Bernhard Gardner, Professor Christian Richard, Dr. Andreas Bogdan, Charles A. Faissolle, Baron de Chollet, Dr. Salomon Lowenstien, Oliver Edel Craig Biddle, Lucien Brule and Camille Allard.

New York City commuters and others using the railroad terminals here took the swing to daylight saving time in stride. There was little confusion apparent although the telephone calls to information desks were numerous.
Paul V. McNutt arrived today to take over his duties as High United States Commissioner to the Philippines with a noticeable lack of ostentation.
Al Mangan of Lowell, Mass., member of America's 1936 Olympic walking team, led a score of heel-and-toe artists today to capture the national A. A. U. 50,000-meter walk in a cold, stiff headwind.

The Esquire Theatre at Fortyfourth Street and Eighth Avenue, which used to be a neighborhood theatre until Consolidated Amusement Enterprises took it over and transformed it in line with the intimate cinema motif, will open tonight with the first showing in Lull Deste "Im Sonnenschein." being released here as "Thank You, Madame."

Boilers were heated tonight and other preliminary arrangements made for the return to work tomorrow morning of more than 3,000 employes of General Motors of Canada, Limited, who went on strike April 8.

The centennial gift of the Mount Holyoke College alumnae fund, named the Mary E. Woolley Fund in honor of the college's retiring president, will be allocated to salary endowment for members of the faculty, Miss Gertrude V. Bruyn, field secretary, announced today.

Governor Lehman issued a proclamation today designating Saturday, May 1, as Child Health Day. He pointed out that the Federal Government had provided to the State "means for developing a social security program for the purpose of promoting maternal and child welfare services.

Reports of an impending Reich loan 'flotation dominated the week's Boerse, and trading in stocks was somewhat less active. Monday opened firm, with some sharp rises, including Steel Trust, Kloeckner, Rheinstahl and Mannesmann.

While a hundred thousand spectators at Vincennes annual air circus watched, first In admiration and then in horror, Clem Sohn, 26-yearold American parachute jumper, swooped and glided far above their heads on his "bat wings," then plunged to his death before their eyes.

L. R. Gignilliat Jr., deputy administrator of the Federal Housing Administration in charge of Title One, the modernization credit provisions of which expired on April 1,- has resigned to become associated with the Commericial Investment Trust in New York, Stewart McDonald, administrator, announced today.

The full casts of four of the five opening week operas of the Metropolitan Opera Spring season were announced yesterday. The season will begin next Monday evening with "Faust." Hilda Burke will be the Marguerite, Sydney Rayner the Faust and Leon Rothier the Mephistophelea.
A study of the financing and management of Rochester's Philharmonic and Civic Orchestras will be made this Summer as the first step in a nation-wide survey of symphony orchestras.

The Right Rev. Stephen Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, confirmed 400 children in two parishes here this afternoon. He first administered the sacrament to a class of 150 at the Holy Rosary Church and then confirmed a class of 250 at the Corpus Christi Church.

The annual report of the United Light and Power Company and subsidiaries for 1936, which will be mailed today to stockholders, shows a consolidated net income of $4.508.262 after expenses, taxes, interest and other charges, compared with $2,411,651 in 1935.

Dark Knight of Dorick, a year-old black dog, was chosen best in the match show conducted by the Cocker Spaniel Club of Long Island today at the Ivor estate in Dix Hills. He is owned by Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Kettles Jr. of Old Brookville, and was handled by William Black.
Employment in the manufacturing industries has reached 1929 levels, with 11,000,000 persons on the payrolls on April 1, the National Association of Manufacturers reported yesterday.

Driving Elden Auker from the mound with a six-run spree in the first two innings, the Chicago White Sox hung on for an 11-7 victory over the Detroit Tigers today to gain an even split in the abbreviated two-game series.

Ingrid Wiengreen, the 20-year-old daughter of the Paraguayan Minister to Austria, Gustav Wiengreen, was found unconscious in her automobile with two bullet wounds in her left temple and one in her shoulder last night.

Wholesale prices declined slightly this week principally as the result of a relapse in the levels of raw materials abroad. In addition, traders have accumulated stocks while consumers seem to have decreased their purchases with the rise in retail prices.

The Federal restrictive immigration laws should be replaced with "an open door policy," Representative John J. O'Connor of New York City, chairman of the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives, declared yesterday afternoon at the annual conference of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society in the Hotel Astor.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James R. Rowell of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Rowell, to George Franklin Whitley Jr. of the George Washington Hotel, New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Franklin Whitley, also of Smithfield.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:
Stocks lower on the week in less active trading; turnover, 6,384,289 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds continued to decline; foreign issues irregular; transactions, $64,479,100.

Mrs. Roxana Drew WolfsKeil, wife of Judge William D. WolfsKeil of the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals, died last night at her home here after a four-day illness. Mrs. WolfsKeil was born in New York City, the daughter of Thomas Drew and Mary Harris Christopher Drew. She had been a resident of Elizabeth for the last thirty-seven years. Two sisters, Mrs. John E.

The street car strike was settled this morning by a compromise by which wages were increased by 10 per cent. The agreement was reached at a conference inaugurated by Sukenari Yokoyama, Chief of Police,

With an aerial advance, theoretical landing operations and long-range firing, the United States fleet ended today its "attack" on Oahu Island and more than sixty of its 111 ships berthed in Pearl Harbor.

Three peaks of the Enchortas, which Air Minister Indalecio Prieto of the Valencia Government, a native Bilbaoan, said General Francisco Franco would never take because Napoleon's army could not capture them have fallen to the Nationalists [Insurgents].

Mrs. Helen Kim Mont, 25-year-old actress, who committed suicide by gas in her apartment at 840 Park Avenue on Saturday, was unaware of the chain letter "mystery invitations" that drew a large crowd into the lobby of the apartment house almost at the moment she ended her life, it was learned yesterday.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated at 92 per cent of capacity, 1 point above the uniform rate of the preceding three, weeks. Increased production is ascribed to better use of facilities, not to heavier demand.

Although activities in intercollegiate baseball during the week were curtailed on account of the weather, Long Island University turned in three triumphs, while Fordham and Manhattan each won twice to keep their places among the leaders in the metropolitan district.
On the eve of the resumption of the parliamentary session, Jules Moch, Socialist friend and colleague of Premier Leon Blum, led the poll in a bitterly contested by-election at Sete today.

The marriage of Miss Grace Agnes Williams of 671 Fifty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Williams, to Michael Joseph Brand, son of Mrs. Wenz Brand of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Brand, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Agatha's Church, Brooklyn, Rev. Luke V. Duff officiated.

To focus legislative attention upon the "plight of the substitute," more than 1,000 New York City teachers will go to Albany this afternoon to urge passage of the Steingut-Fischel bill providing qualifying examinations for substitute teachers.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth A. Dosch, daughter of Mayor and Mrs. Joseph P. Dosch of this place, to Edward Demarest Keller, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Keller of Essex Fells.

The Academy singers of Erie, Pa., appeared in a program of choral music at the Town Hall last night, under the direction of O. L. Grender. The group consists of about sixty mixed voices. The boys and girls of the ensemble seemed to be in their 'teens. Their singing impressed the good-sized audience with the seriousness of its purpose and the competence of its musicianship.

Formation of a united Protestant youth movement to start a "crusade" against many of the injustices prevalent in the world was advocated yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Robert Wyckoff Searle, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.
A strike of seventy youthful target markers on the rifle and pistol range at Camp Smith, the New York National Guard encampment outside Peekskill was promptly dealt with today by army officers.
A hard and fast policy of neutrality that can be changed only by vote of Congress is one of the country's best safeguards against becoming entangled in another world war, Senator Gerald P. Nye,
Insurgent General Gonzalo Queipo de Liano claimed in a broadcast tonight the Insurgent cruiser Canarias had forced the government ship Jaime I aground off Southern Spain.
In another of the series of successful experiments on the transmutation of elements in Yale laboratories, chlorine has been converted into potassium and argon into calcium.
Hazel Hedge Hikers Gadder, white and orange setter, won the shooting-dog stake at the eleventh annual Spring meeting of the Lambertville Field Trial Club today.

At 4 o'clock this morning, Sergeant Frank Hamilton, on desk duty at Kearny police headquarters, received a telephone call from a gasoline filling station at the intersection of Harrison and Belleville Turnpike. A man's voice said:

Magistrate Louis Brodsky recommended "a good old-fashioned spanking," yesterday as punishment for a husky 20-year-old college boy and amateur boxer who was brought into Yorkville Court with another college boy on charges of hitting a woman.
A note for the future: Long Island sport fishing organizations, anglers and boatmen's clubs have been advised of the Fisheries Building which will be erected for the 1939 New York World's Fair.

After three hours of competition on the New York Athletic Club strips yesterday, the six men who will compete for, the national Individual foils championship on Wednesday night earned their places in the final round, setting the pace in the field of nineteen of the country's leading fencers.

Joe Gould, manager of Heavyweight Champion James J. Braddock, said today that Braddock's attorneys would file an answer Wednesday in Madison Square Garden's legal action asking that the titleholder show cause why he should not meet Max Schmeling before going through with a bout with Joe Louis here on June 22. The litigation is being heard in Federal court at Newark, N. J.

Resolutions calling upon the American Federation of Labor to help organize office and white collar workers into one big union and expressing sympathy with the C. I. O. were adopted yesterday at a regional meeting of thirteen locals representing these classes of employes.

United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt was made a free citizen of the town of Beaune, in the Burgundy wine country, and a "Chevalier du Tastevin" (Knight of the Wine Bowl) during a week-end visit to Dijon, Beaune and the vineyards of the famous Cote d'Or.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. "The Mayas--America's First High Civilization," Herbert J. Spinden, 11 A.M.: "State Legislation," Natalie F. Couch, 7 P. M. Conference of the Jewish Vacation Association, A. W. A. clubhouse, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street, 3:30 P. M. Dinner at 6:30 P. M.

With a secrecy possible only in a country where all publicity is coordinated and controlled, Germany has for some time been organizing her own international exposition for this Summer. Its site is Duesseldorf, on the Rhine, and it will be opened by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, commissar for the Four-Year Plan, on May 8.

Following a week of heavy liquidation and the severest declines for some time, during which July wheat dropped to 8s. 9 3/4d. a 100 pounds, the market experienced considerable recovery to 9s. 3 1/2d., which compares with 9s. 7 3/8d. ruling the week previously.
Although moderate selling of stocks on the Boerse predominated late In the week, the markets, in general, were firm. The British blockade running with food to help Bilbao caused some nervousness.

Lithuanians, Poles, Armenians, Finns and men and women of five other nationalities participated the first of the season's folk dance festivals held in the Randalls Island Stadium and sponsored by the Folk Festival Council in cooperation with the Department of Parks.

BALSAM-Maurice, nusband or Sa?? father of Leonore, Daniel, Muriel, Lucille and Philip, and brother of Adolph, Leo; George, Gus and Sadie, suddenly, in his fifty-sixth year. Notice of funeral hereafter.

Freight ships operating in many of the major trade routes are carrying their capacity of freight while industrial traffic managers bid for space at rates far beyond those quoted in the tariffs, according to steamship operators.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In defending capitalism I am not necessarily defending capitalists, though these are simply our fellow-citizens. As Dean Hodges said, in explaining the shortcomings of the clergy, "We have nothing to make clergymen out of but laymen."

Elsie Ullman, 35-year-old saleswoman living at 390 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn, was held in bail of $500 for hearing next Friday by Magistrate John Mason in the Bay Ridge Court yesterday. The complainant, Harry Schwartz of Mays Department Store,
Germany's national income in 1936 from wages and salaries, including the military and naval establishments, was 35,010,000,000 marks, against 32,157,000,000 marks in 1935.

Airplanes droned steadily over crowded Fenway Park today, but the hum of their motors only dulled the sound of base hits that whistled about the ears of Wes Ferrell and the loud detonation that accompanied the crack-up of Irving (Bump) Hadley.
Thousands cheered real cheers for a makebelieve coronation procession today, just to get the horses accustomed to the noise.

IT has been suggested that President Ford Frick of the National League and President Will Harridge of the American League set up some investigating staff to be known as the Baseball Bureau of Missing Persons. Or should that come under the jurisdiction of Judge Landis? Either way, such a bureau could be a big help.

With 56,900,000 tons goods loaded and discharged in German ports last year, a new high record was established. The figure in 1929 was 50,059,000 tons and in 1932 only 36,284,000. The whole increase in 1936, however, fell to Baltic ports.

The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday that it had served notice upon the Board of Transportation that it was demanding recognition as the sole collective bargaining agency for the 4,000 operating employes of the city's Independent Subway.
The Chilean Ambassador, Aurelio Nunez Morgado, declared persona non grata by the Spanish Government, boarded the Argentine gunboat Tucuman tonight.

President Roosevelt has had on his desk for at least several weeks a report of the Business Advisory Council urging that the Bureau of the Census be authorized to make an immediate survey of unemployment, it was learned today.
Insignia granted by the Committee on the Regulation of Athletics for work in various sports during the Winter season were announced today at the Harvard Athletic Association.
King Victor Emmanuel today inaugurated a comprehensive exhibition of paintings by Tintoretto, great master of the Italian Renaissance, the second large Venetian art show of recent years.

After a century of publication under the cover which gave it the name of "The Little Lady in Brown," The Yale Literary Magazine, the oldest monthly publication in the United States, will appear tomorrow in a new format.

Dr. Sam Genest, for many years chairman of the Ottawa Separate School Board and a leader of French-Canadian thought in many controversies over bilingual education, died at his home here tonight, in his seventy-second year.
Captain Leopold, leader of the illegal Austrian Nazis, and his adjutant, Dr. Tavs, who were dismissed from their high posts in the Austrian civil service, are expected to return from Berlin soon.
Heavy hitting by George Mcquinn and Bob Seeds enabled Newark to chalk up its fourth straight victory of the season at Ruppert Stadium today, 9 to 3, Rochester being the victim.

Miss Mary Hughes, St. George Dragon Club ace, of Brooklyn, made a whirlwind finish to capture the women's metropolitan junior 100-yard free style championship, feature event of the A. A. U. swimming meet at the Hotel Shelton yesterday. Two feet behind the victor, who was clocked at 1:08.9, came Miss Emma Heckel of the Park Central A. A. Miss Ruth Krayer of the Women's Swimming Association, pace-setter for threequarters of the race, placed third.

IT is probable that Erich Maria Remarque never has read Ernest Hemingway's "A Farewell to Arms." The German author of "All Quiet on the Western Front" likes people and dogs more than he likes books, prefers a cafe to a library. Yet it happens that Mr. Hemingway's best novel and Mr. Remarque's new "Three Comrades" (Little, Brown, $2.75) are almost as like as twins.

Senator Bennett Champ Clark. chairman of the Bolivian Bondholders Protective Committee that was organized in February, 1936, to protect holders of defaulted 8 per cent bonds of 1922, issued today a call to holders of $37,000,000 in three other issues of defaulted Bolivian dollar bonds to deposit them with the committee.
A favorable factor in the American economic scene is discerned in President Roosevelt's effort to reduce expenditures and re-establish a balanced budget.
The First Presbyterian Church of Jamaica, Queens, believed to have been the first Presbyterian Church in the Western Hemisphere, celebrated yesterday its 275th anniversary.
With representatives from 1,600 member organizations scheduled to attend, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States will open its twentyfifth annual meeting tomorrow.

Wheat flour imports will hereafter be taxed 600 reis a bag under a bill passed by Congress last night to promote domestic wheat growing. The proceeds of the new duty will be used to pay the expense of experimental stations and to provide seed for planters.

There is only one genuine basis for a stable and enduring national State and that is faith in a living God, said the Rev. Dr. Julius A. Bewer of Union Theological Seminary at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, in a sermon yesterday morning.

Mrs. Henrietta Hartford of New York and Newport, R. I., became Princess Pignatelli last night when she was married to Prince Guido Pignatelli by the Rev. John M. Lavelle, C. M., in St. Vincent's Church.

Attaches of the New York Conservation Department will release tomorrow 500 rainbow trout in Wampus and Byram brooks and Byram Lake, in the town of North Castle, as the first step in the plan to stock all Northern Westchester streams with 25,000 trout.

The latest official payroll showed today that clerks and secretaries in the offices of twenty-five House members bear the same surnames as their Congressional employers. Five members have sons, with "juniors" attached to their names, on the salary list.

About 5,000 persons attenaed exercises yesterday at the Admiral Dewey Flagpole at Shore Road and Eightieth Street in Brooklyn, marking the thirty-ninth anniversary of Dewey's victory at Manila Bay. The program was under the auspices of the Thomas H. Barry Camp, 73, United Spanish War Veterans.

Detector Bimpkins, white and liver pointer dog owned and handled by Ray Carter of Newark, N. J., today won the open all-age stake, chief event of the three-day Spring meeting of the Southern New York Field Trial Club, contested in the covers in Old Bedford Village.

Mrs. Malka Rose, wife of Rabbi Judah Leib Rose of Congregation Anshel Brzezany, 180 Stanton Street, died on Friday at her home, 151 Suffolk Street, at the age of 62. Mrs. Rose, who was active in charitable work in the neighborhood, was for many years president of the Ladies Auxiliary of the congregation and was a member of the Kadishah Sisterhood.

C. Frederick Clark of 41-35 Hampton Street, Elmhurst, Queens, who had been cost accountant for several large textile houses, died Saturday in the Polyclinic Hospital of diabetes after an illness of two years. His age was 62.

The Potomac River and Wills Creek, fed by a twenty-four-hour rain, threatened to flood this city tonight. Wills Creek was rising a foot an hour and the Potomac eight inches an hour. A blast of a local brewery's whistle warned residents of their peril. The National Guard was prepared to mobilize.

Humbled on Saturday by the Brookhattan eleven, the New York Americans, newly-crowned national soccer champions, sustained another defeat yesterday, losing to the Passon Phillies in the second game of an American League double-header before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park. The score was 4 to 2.

John Owens, 22-year-old bartender, shot and killed his wife and two members of her family today and then ended his own life with poison, Sheriff Earl Brandel said. "Papa shot mama and grandma," Janet May, 3-year-old daughter of Owens. told police.

Nearly thirty exhibitions are on the calendar for the present week, with little sign of waning activity in the art galleries as April draws to a close. The material ranges from reproductions of work by prehistoric man to Italian primitives and paintings by contemporary New Yorkers.
Settlement of the threatened rail workers' strike here was looked for as the Federal Mediation Board moved for peace, with action by the President held a possibility. Page 1.
Although Japan's general election is only five days away, the public is so apathetic that candidates have resorted to stunts such as using women speakers to draw hearers to their meetings.

Of 2,692 national advertising accounts surveyed, 96 per cent uses an average space of 10,000 lines or less in individual newspapers, according to a study on local-national rate differentials, issued by the newspaper committee of the Association of National Advertisers.
William Waxman, one of the favorites, was upset by Thomas Ginty, team-mate from the home club, 21-12, 21-18, in the quarter-final round of the Metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall soft-ball handball

The C. I. O. response to Judge Harry Manser's warning of yesterday that further mass meetings would influence his decision on the question of closing the shoe strikers' commissary and relief kitchen took the form of an enthusiastic rally of 3,000 persons at the City Hall here this afternoon.

Establishment of a loan fund for students of the Fordham University School of Social Service in memory of Miss Elizabeth Cady, social worker, was announced yesterday by the Rev. Edward S. Pouthier, dean of the school.
Battle flags of legions vanquished seven decades ago were unfolded today in the Deep South's annual tribute to heroes of the Confederacy.
David Remer of Philadelphia has been admitted to general partnership in J. E. Baker Co., who will move to 14 Wall Street, it was announced yesterday by the investment banking firm.

An expedition into the wild Split Rock Pond region, near here, in search of Dutchman's breeches, an early Spring wild flower, ended abruptly this afternoon when a three-foot copperhead snake bit Miss Lillian Haskins, one of the members of the flower-picking group, on one leg.

Perhaps the most complete investigation yet made of the Maya Indians, considered by many to be the ancient human link between America and Europe, is now ready to start from Veracruz under the auspices of the Mexican Government.

The greatest use any individual can make of his life is to dedicate himself to human service and to the betterment of mankind, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, the pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street,

The Rev. Dr. James J. Henry, pastor of the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, 106 East Eighty-sixth Street, asked members yesterday to confer Friday evening on steps to prevent the threatened loss to the church of its place of worship.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange last week; also the new highs and lows and total number of issues for the past three weeks:

John D. Rowland, New Brunswick gunner, dominated the annual Northern Zone trapshooting championship of New Jersey today by capturing three titles. The competition, held on the North Jersey Gun Club traps, attracted one of the largest fields of the year, eightyfour participating.

In a May Day message to New York City mothers in the current issue of Neighborhood Health, publication of the Department of Health, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt emphasizes the necessity of training mothers in child-health care, particularly in large cities.

Every German youth between the ages of 15 and 17 should be taught "an autogene training," described as European fakirism, according to a proposal made in the press today by Professor J. H. Schultz, the Berlin inventor of the new method.

Dr. Samuel Buchler, founder of the Jewish Court of Arbitration, said last night at a meeting celebrating the court's sixteenth anniversary that since the court's inception it had settled some 8,000 cases. The meeting, which was attended by 400 persons, was at the Hotel McAlpin.
A campaign against graft and bribery was added today to the current hunt through the Soviet and Communist party organizations for Trotskyists, spies, wasters, saboteurs,

Patsy D'Agostino, 23 years old, and his bride of yesterday afternoon, the former Jennie Graziosi, 19, were found unconscious-in their apartment at 694 Summit Avenue this afternoon, apparently the victims of a poison.

A special convention of the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization, adopted a resolution tonight demanding that the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company recognize it as sole bargaining agent for the company's 47,000 workers.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wink of 70 East Ninety-sixth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Elizabeth Wink, to Jehu Bishop Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Davis of Drexel Park, Philadelphia.

Umpire Tiny Parker and Buddy Hassett each made a tremendous drive out of the park today, the official's performance annoying Burleigh Grimes no end, but the Dodger first sacker's wallop served as balm to a sorely wounded managerial soul.

The new Russian Constitution "perpetuates the dictatorship of the proletariat" and provides communism with "a valuable weapon" in its struggle against fascism, the Foreign Policy Association asserted in a report published today.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the World's Fair Corporation, announced yesterday that the cornerstone of the administration building, the first structure to be erected on the fair site at Flushing Meadow, would be laid at exercises at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

Colonel General Hermann Goering, the German Air Minister, will be received tomorrow morning on his return from Naples by Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, and by Premier Benito Mussolini in the afternoon.
The Maine Legislature early today enacted a 1 per cent retail sales tax to finance old age assistance and equalization of education. The session adjourned a few hours later.
The board of control of the Yale Athletic Association today announced that it had authorized a total of 287 awards in Winter sports, an unusually large number for the season's competition.

Shorts in May corn were active buyers at s times last week on the Board of Trade here, and closing of spreads between the May and July, as well as spreads between wheat and corn, furnished an unusual situation. Scarcity of old corn in all positions is such as to check short selling of the deferred futures and scare in the shorts in the May de- t livery.

Scientific method achieves a verbal truth which, for a full life, must be enriched by more directly felt approaches to reality, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in his sermon at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street.
Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee came off the ways at Lawley's Yard, Neponset, with the morning tide and is expected to start within thirty-six hours for Newport, R. I., to resume her tuning-up spins.

Rumors current a fortnight ago, that our Government would reduce the price it pays for gold, were officially denied. Since then reports have been current that the Treasury might, by imposition of a "license fee" or "import tax" on imported gold,

Jersey City won its second straight victory today behind the strong pitching of Glen Gabler, tall right-hander, who shut out the Montreal Royals, 1 to 0, before a paid attendance of 13,228. Gabler allowed only six hits, fanned three and walked three.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Quinn of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Marie Quinn, to J. Peter Jaffe, son of Mrs. George E. Ratsey of Greacen Point, Mamaroneck, N. Y. The announcement was made this afternoon at a reception given by Mr. and Mrs. Quinn to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their marriage.

Mrs. Marguerite Cassidy Barrett, wife of the Rev. Francis A. Barrett, pastor of Advent Protestant Episcopal Church, at 7 West 128th Street, died suddenly yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 28 years old.

Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation have announced that $875,000 of dollar bonds and [pound]320,200 of Sterling bonds of the State of San Paulo 7 per cent Coffee Realization Loan of 1930, have been purchased and canceled, completing redemption requirements for the last half of the year ended March 31, 1937.

The American Perfumers' Laboratories, Inc., will move their executive offices on about May 15 to 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The National Association of Accredited Publicity Directors, Inc., will hold a dinner and meeting tomorrow at 6:30 P. M. in the Transportation Club at the Hotel Biltmore.
The annual regimental service of the Knickerbocker Greys, junior cadet corps, was held yesterday afternoon at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.
Delegates of forty Roman Catholic churches in Nassau County met at the Parish Hall of Corpus Christi Church, Garfield Place, today to discuss plans for the county Holy Name Society rally May 16.

The annual Americanization Day celebration in Jersey City brought out more than 12,000 marchers for the parade from the Bergen Square area to Pershing Field this afternoon and 15,000 other persons assembled at the field for speeches by Mayor Frank Hague and others.

Plans have been completed by Miss Barbara Root, daughter of Albert Keyes Root, for her marriage to Walter Squires Hollister, son of Mrs. Richard D. Freeman and the late William Hollister, which will take place the morning of May 10 at the home of the bride's father, 277 Park Avenue. The Rev. Augustus Steimle will perform the ceremony.
President Roosevelt's message to Congress in with his revised budgetary statement got no comment in the newspapers here.

James Leroy Murrill, believed to have been the last surviving soldier of the Confederate Army living in Baltimore, died today at Union Memorial Hospital, where he recently underwent an operation. His age was 91.

The elusive Greta Garbo may soon make a court appearance here. James P. McCarty, lawyer, said a process server, who had attempted to reach her for three weeks, finally caught her automobile at a stop signal and tossed a subpoena into her lap.

New York State's "traffic college" has graduated its first class. More than 100 men, members of the State police and city police departments, received diplomas last night from Maxwell Halsey, assistant director of Harvard University's bureau for street traffic research.

The salaries of all foreign missionaries of the United Lutheran Church of America will be restored to their pre-depression levels on July 1, it was made known here yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, member of the Board of Foreign Missions of the church. The action was taken by the board at a meeting in Baltimore on Thursday. About 187 American missionaries and about one thousand native workers are involved.

Intervention by the National Labor Relations Board in the situation confronting the ConsolidatedEdison Company, its subsidiaries and 40,000 employee appeared likely yesterday when it was learned that Mrs. Eleanor M. Herrick, regional director of the board,

George W. Stewart has resigned as director of Whittlesey House, the trade division of the McGrawHill Book Company. Hugh Kelly, assistant vice president of McGrawHill, will succeed to the position on May 1.

Prominent furniture manufacturers saw tonight a revival of the Victorian influence in furniture design as they previewed the semiannual Jamestown furniture market, which opens tomorrow and continues through May 5.
Germany's coal output in the first three months of this year was 44,240,000 tons, against 39,180,000 correspondingly in 1936.

A tea will be given by Mrs. John A. Topping this afternoon at her home, 1 East Eighty-eighth Street, for members of the New York Council of the Students International Union and others interested in international affairs.

The contract bridge team of Mrs. Emory Clement, Mrs. Nelva Demarest, Harold Lockridge, all of New York, and Henry Chanin of Atlanta, Ga., last night won the Mrs. G. U. Harris trophy for mixed team of fours in the Grand National tournament held at the Hotel Montclair by the United States Bridge Association.
The "naturalization" into the American language of the "strangling, gargling word which is spelled h-o-r-s-d-o-e-u-v-r-e" was urged last night by George Rector, author and former restaurateur.

John J. McElligott, Fire Commissioner of New York City, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus from a cruise to Havana and Nassau. Each fireboat station, starting on the Brooklyn shore, sent one of its craft to salute the commissioner by shooting off streams of water eighty feet high.

Activity slackened somewhat in the wholesale market here last week, although ready-to-wear departments were generally busy. Formal dresses sold well in bridesmaid and graduation types, and interest was shown in wedding gowns for May and June promotions. In street wear, sheers and prints were called for. There was an early response to offerings of sports dresses in active and spectator types.

In the Appendix of the Congressional Record of April 22 is printed by request of the Hon. ROBERT RICE REYNOLDS, junior Senator from North Carolina, "a very interesting, instructive and inspirational address" delivered by the Hon. ARTHUR HARRY MOORE before the Daughters of the American Revolution.

A seven-day festival of American music, presenting performances of chamber opera, symphony orchestras, instrumental and choral ensembles and soloists, will be given by the WPA Federal Music Project at the Theatre of Music the evenings of May 2 to May 8, inclusive, it was announced yesterday by Chalmers Clifton, New York City director of the Federal Music Project. The programs will be given in connection with the celebration of National Music Week.

Any plan to amend the State Constitution to provide assistance for low-rent housing should be discussed by the forthcoming constitutional convention before being submitted to the people, the New York City Housing Authority said yesterday in announcing that it had addressed a letter on the subject to Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly.

Cold-weather dinghy racing wound up today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club with Bob Fraser scoring in the Class B OneDesign competition. He won two out of six races in his boat, Hot Spot, to register 16 points against 15 each for O. H. Chalkley in Popover and Thomas Haire in Delirium.

George H. Bond, president of the New York State Bar Association, has announced the appointment of a special committee which will conduct a campaign to acquaint the public with the seriousness of the automobile accident situation.

Annin S. Prall, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, endorsed yesterday, as a spokesman for radio, the Will Rogers Memorial Week, which starts in the theatres Friday. In a talk over a WABC-Columbia network he urged public support of the Will Rogers Memorial Commission.
ABRAMS -Mr. and Mrs. Max announce the arrival of a daughter, Nancy Ellen, April 20, at Medical Center. KIRSCHSTEIN-A son to Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Kirschstein on April 18, 1937, at Park East Hospital.
Case Ace, one of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's three Kentucky Derby hopefuls, worked a handy half mile in 0:50 at Churchill Downs today in preparation for a longer trial tomorrow. He ran the quarter in 0:24.

Today Mr. Anthony Eden goes to Brussels to confer with his friend Premier Paul Van Zeeland. This visit means many things beyond the fact that these two statesmen, of the same age, the same temperament and much the same outlook on the world, see more nearly eye to eye than any other two representatives of different governments in Europe.

Two men and a boy clinging to a capsized motor boat several hundred yards off the foot of West Tenth Street, Coney Island, were brought ashore at 4 P. M. yesterday by several members of the Iceberg Athletic Club, an organization of Winter bathers.
Yesterday we published on this page a letter from Senator WAGNER in reply to the criticisms that THE TIMES has frequently made of the National Labor Relations Act which bears his name.

The need for people to keep changing in a changing world was stressed yesterday morning by the Rev. Wendell Phillips, rector of Trinity Church, New Rochelle, in his sermon in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

Capric culturists of Passaic, Essex and Morris Counties are getting ready to enshrine the goat above the cow as a producer of milk. They hope to make New Jersey goat conscious through an educational campaign, stressing not only the nutritious advantage of goats' milk, but the value of the animal to families in financial distress.
Elimination of street surface railroad tracks on the West Side will be completed on June 28, the New York Central Railroad announced yesterday.
The Rev. Arthur Kleps, preaching yesterday at the Immanuel Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street, deplored the tendency of Christians to balk at giving liberally to the church.

Governor Lehman announced- tonight that he would appoint Charles Poletti, his personal counsel, to the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial District, to fill the vacancy caused by the recent death of Justice John V. McAvoy "as soon as his duties
Baron De Saumarez, veteran British diplomat, who served in the Paris Embassy during the Commune rioting of 1871, died at his home, Saumarez Park, on the island of Guernsey, today. His age was 93.

Richard Southam, president and managing director of the Southam Publishing Company, died in the Toronto General Hospital today. He was 65 years old. He had been ill since two weeks before Christmas, and entered the hospital four days ago upon his return from Atlantic City.
Stepin Fetchit, Negro comic who made a career of laziness in the movies, was critically injured yesterday in the speed of real life. While driving his automobile on Eighth Avenue a tire on a front

The American Olympic track and field team, which won about everything in sight at Berlin, has not lost any of its momentum. That was proved over the past week-end when Olympians dominated both Penn and Drake relay carnivals. Their trophy collection mounted to the extent of eleven gold medals.

With industrial activity continuing to show an advance in March, the volume of output, on a seasonally adjusted basis, in the first quarter of this year was somewhat above that for the final three months of 1936, according to the regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.

In their study of visibility and fog for the Port of New York, Works Progress Administration workers have completed tabulations of hourly values of relative humidity covering a period of sixteen years, on which hourly normals may be established, Deputy Administrator Aubrey Williams announced today.

It was learned here yesterday that Ch. Pfeffer von Bern, owned by John Gans of Grymes Hill, S. I., president of the German Shepherd Dog Club, had won the annual Sieger championship of the German Shepherd Dog Club at Munich, Germany. Odin Busecker Schloss was the reserve. Traute von Bern and Thora von Bern were the winner and reserve, respectively, in the Siegerin class. which is for bitches.

Vigorous opposition to religious instruction along denominational lines in the public schools was expressed yesterday by Dr. Horace L. Friess, Associate Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, and Dr. John L. Elliott, senior leader of the Ethical Culture Society, at a regular meeting of the society at its meeting house, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

Members of the West Side Auxiliary of the Silver Cross Day Nursery will give a tea this afternoon at the headquarters of the nursery, 249 East 117th Street. There will be an entertainment presented by the children of kindergarten age cared for daily at the nursery by the auxiliary's charitable fund. Mimi Morton, daughter of Mrs. Albert H. Morton, a member of the auxiliary, will give a group of dances.

Paced by the brilliant sailing of Freshman Runyon Colie from Barnegat Bay, the crews of the M. I. T. Nautical Association won the first intercollegiate dinghy championship sponsored by the Intercollegiate Y. R. A. as a two-day regatta in the Charles River Basin was concluded today.

Who has forgotten the many lugubrious predictions, during all the years from 1931 to 1936, that the country would never again witness the level of employment reached at any time in 1929? Factory employment is at that
The political situation here continues to cause much anxiety, not only in financial circles but also among manufacturers and trades people.

The report of the Bank of France dated April 15 shows a decrease of 536,000,000 francs in bills discounted, besides which the market repaid to the bank 72,000,000 fans on loans against securities and 450,000,000 francs on loans against government bonds.

Fulfillment of the second Five-Year Plan by "industry as a whole" nearly a year in advance of schedule was announced tonight by the National Economic Statistical Administration of the State Planning Commission.

Johnson Wood have moved to 67 Broad Street; Bayles, Softye Co., to 60 Wall Street; H. C. Wainwright Co., to 14 Wall Street, and Tailer Robinson, to 120 Wall Street. David E. Wilson, Robert F. Chamberlain and Rudolph Cihelka are in the trading department of the L. G. Smith Company, Inc.

Sixty-seven delegates to the national convention of the Federation of Dyers, Printers, Bleachers and Finishers of America voted unanimously today to affiliate their union with the Textile Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O.
