The six programs to be given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, during the Berkshire Symphonic Festival to be held at Tanglewood, between Lenox and Stockbridge, Mass., Aug. 5-15, will include three devoted respectively to works by Beethoven, Wagner and Brahms.
The Second Indian Infantry Brigade of the British Expeditionary Force marching toward the Khaisora Valley, stronghold of the anti-British Fakir of Ipi, met slight opposition during the week-end.

A 13-year-old girl and a man were wounded, the man critically, while they were sitting in the hall of Local 56 of the Workers Alliance, an organization of WPA employes and relief clients, at 222 East 119th Street, near Third Avenue, late last night when a man visiting the organization attempted to shoot a member.

Conditions in the grain and other commodity markets are the most unsatisfactory that have been experienced in years, according to some of the oldest and most successful traders. This, they maintain, tends to restrict speculative operations and, at times, to reduce open commitments and precipitate sharp price fluctuations.
Current problems of the American political and social orders will be considered by the general council of the National League of Women Voters, meeting here May 3 to 5.

More than 1,000 employes of thirty-two cleaning and dyeing plants in Essex, Union, Middlesex, Passaic and Bergen Counties, who have been on strike for a week, will return to work tomorrow under a settlement negotiated by Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein of Newark with the employers and representatives of the Cleaners and Dyers Union, affiliated with the A. F. of L.

The Philadelphia Orchestra will give ten Tuesday-night concerts in Carnegie Hall next season, its twentieth in this city, it was announced yesterday. They will take place on Oct. 19, Nov. 9 and 23, Dec. 14, Jan. 25, Feb. 15, March 8 and 22, April 12 and May 3. Leopold Stokowski will direct the three concerts in November and December; Eugene Ormandy will direct the others.

The Orchestrette Classique, Miss Frederique Petrides conducting, will play music by Mozart and Bach and three Americans, Julia Smith, Henry Holden Huss and the late Arthur Foote, at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall tonight. Alice Whitney, soprano, and Richard Malaby, pianist, will give a joint recital at the Barbizon this evening.

The State of New Jersey is at last coming to the aid of the Jackson Whites of the Ramapos, fast dwindling from disease and poverty. The Rev. A. F. Chillson of Hohokus, pastor of a Protestant Episcopal church here, said today that William J. Ellis, Commissioner of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies, had assigned an assistant to investigate conditions in the hill-billy colony, fortyfive miles from Broadway.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,852,466,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:
There was urgent liquidation here this week of speculative positions in the commodity markets as a result of the continuation of the pronounced unsettlement in the metal markets.
Amos Pinchot, New York lawyer, in an open letter to President Roosevelt, made public here yesterday, accused the President of seeking the powers of a dictator.

Barlow Seelig Manufacturing Company--For 1936: Net income, $406,633, after providing for $35,000 for surtax on undistributed earnings, compared with $354,581 in 1935. On Dec. 31 current assets were $1,078,579, and current liabilities; $298,946.

James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, will leave Miami next Saturday and arrive home Sunday, it was learned yesterday. A meeting of the Tammany executive committee to consider the leadership situation is expected within a week or ten days after his return.

John Lamb, white secretary to Father Divine, cult leader of Harlem, expressed the opinion yesterday that the fire that razed the cult's "extension heaven" in Ulster County Saturday morning was incendiary. He added that Father Divine would undoubtedly build a larger and more elaborate structure to replace the three-story twentytwo-room building.

Dr. and Mrs. Nelson J. MacArthur of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Carol MacArthur, to Walter J. Masterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Masterson of Noroton, Conn.

Two players traded to Cleveland by the Browns took part in two rallies today, one of them tying the score in the ninth inning, and the other producing the winning run in the eleventh, enabling the Indians to defeat St. Louis, 5-4.

The report of the receivers of the Wabash Railway Company for 1936, issued for publication today, shows gross operating revenues of $46,428,262, compared with $41,492,889 in 1935, an increase of 11.89 per cent. Freight revenues were $40,626,685, an increase of 11.32 per cent. while passenger revenues were $2,511,367, a gain of 13.02 per cent.

Dr. David A. Robertson, president of Goucher College, advised delegates to the Pre-College Guidance Conference at New Jersey College for Women today to be prepared for some disappointments and disillusionments in college life, but added, "Keep an open mind and look for happy adventures."

The Reich's debt return at the end of February, which, as usual, omits to set forth liabilities for work creation and rearmament, shows 15,299,000,000 marks, against 14,457,000,000 at the end of February, 1936.

The Chinese Laundry Alliance of New York celebrated a victory last night over "hatchetmen" who tried to take over the organization with a dinner at the Joy Far Low restaurant, 24 Pell Street. A hatchetman was described as Chinatown idiom for racketeer.

Major honors in the fifth inter-city match show held by the Philadelphia Cocker Spaniel Club today on the grounds of Mr. and Mrs. W. Morgan Churchman, near Whitemarsh. went to Mrs. Churchman's Orthodox Frivolity, which was judged best in show.

Heralding the Wagner act as the "savior of democracy in Harlan County," the United Mine Workers of America opened here today a campaign seeking to unionize Harlan County coal miners within sixty days. The goal is 16,000 members.

Contractors estimating on construction work in the metropolitan area are advised by Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service to figure their estimates at least 15 to 20 per cent higher to meet an increase of 15 per cent in the minimum average wage scale for the building trades, which, he declares, is inevitable in the near future.

The 13-story apartment at 124-26 W 72d St and the 5-story building at 128 W 72d St were sold by Calvert Estates. Inc. Theodore Locker, vice president, to the Lindsey Management Corp, Lester Meyer, president, for a consideration shown as $26,000 over a first mortgage for $410,000. the buyer giving a demand 6 per cent mortgage for $20,340 to the Merit Factors Corn.

Stocks of crude oil and its products held by the principal marketing companies in California on March 31 amounted to 126,197,126 barrels, compared with 127,842,283 at the end of February, a decrease of 1,645,157, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

An announcement by the Valencia Government that a British oil tanker had twice been stopped outside Barcelona today by an Italian destroyer topped a series of incidents that transferred the interest in the naval aspect of the Spanish civil war from Bilbao to the Mediterranean.

Charity is "the only enduring foundation stone" upon which the future of this country can be built, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. "The charity of which I speak is not alms-giving," he said.

Indications that the Republican party is planning an early emergence from its post-election hibernation into an active political role along definitely charted lines were seen by some observers today in the announcement of
Major Gen. Sir Thomas Yarr, an authority on the care of soldiers' eyes, and well known in United States medical circles for his writings, died yesterday at the age of 74.

Although the British budget introduces only two additional burdens, of which only one--namely, the increase of 3d to the pound to the income tax--directly affects the ordinary taxpayer, it came as a considerable shock to the financial markets in Great Britain.
" Curtain Call" vanished from the John Golden after Saturday evening's performance, having opened there the preceding Thursday.

Chinese newspapers here reported today that a peasant woman at Luanhsien had given birth to quintuplets, all normal boys and all living. Because the parents are extremely poor, the village elder has promised to help bring the babies up.

Union and company officials today announced an agreement to reopen tomorrow the Ford Motor assembly plant, tied up by a short sitdown strike Friday. Ed Hall, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, who flew here from Detroit, said that the company agreed not to discriminate against any man for union

The scores that hold the top places in doubles and singles in the thirty-seventh annual American Bowling Congress championships loomed larger than ever yesterday as some 500 keglers from here to Colorado fired at them with little or no effect.

Miss Catherine Fischer Carlton of New York, daughter of Mrs. James E. Carlton of Atlanta and the late Mr. Carlton, has completed plans for her marriage to Albert Perrine Craig Jr., also of this city, son of Mrs. Albert P. Craig and the late Mr. Craig, which will take place the afternoon of May 15 at Flowerland, the home of the brideelect's uncle and aunt, Dr. and Mrs. L. C. Fischer, in Chamblee, Ga.

Northwest Iowa, Northeast Nebraska, Southeast South Dakota and Southwest Minnesota were emerging tonight from a thirty-sixhour blizzard rivaling the midwinter type, except that temperatures were only slightly below freezing.

Large-scale unemployment is likely to continue, and enterprise in the building trades, real estate operations and home building cannot gather any real headway in this country until the capital-gains sections of the Federal Income Tax Law is repealed or drastically modified, in the opinion of Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller.

Miss Josephine Carter Barney, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Nicholson Barney of this city and Fredericksburg, Va., and the late Dr. Barney, has chosen June 5 as the date for her marriage to Dr. John Elmer Lewis of Ottawa, Ont., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Henry Lewis.

Robert M. Gow, for more than fifty years an officer in the American Jersey Cattle Club, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 81. He was first a secretary of the club, then secretarytreasurer and later treasurer, an office he held at his death.

Mayor Andrew J. (Bossy) Gillis climbed a thirty-five-foot fire ladder today to open the new $500,000 Newburyport High School for a public inspection contrary to a vote of the School Committee. The Mayor had said that the inspection would be held anyway to show the citizens the alleged defects of the building.

The absence from their homes of officials of the United States Polo Association yesterday made it impossible to confirm the report cabled from Argentina that another of the brilliant polo teams of that country was to invade Long Island fields this Summer.

Dr. William C. Vivian, professor of optometry at the Pennsylvania State College of Optometry, Philadelphia, said today that by retraining the eye nerves and muscles 70 per cent of the cases of cross-eyes can be corrected.

This still being an age wherein wonders never cease, it remained for the Bees to spring the outstanding surprise and upset of the young baseball season at the Polo Grounds yesterday by actually scoring enough runs to win a ball game. They did it, too, in the face of what might easily have proved insurmountable odds. For they entered the fray with the unenviable
The Constitutionalist party in Sao Paulo today virtually launched the candidacy of Armanda Salles de Oliviera, former Governor of Sao Paulo. for the Presidency of Brazil.

A general police alarm was sent out yesterday for Mrs. Cecilia Baker, 26 years old, of 306 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, who disappeared April 14 after telling her roommate that she had given certain information to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

Miss Josephine Woods, daughter of Mrs. George Adams Woods of this city, was married to Huntington English, son of Mrs. John C. English of this city yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Arthur F. McKenny.
Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, and Mrs. Quezon were honored today with a variety of formalities during an elevenhour visit here.
A fixed rate of 32 cents has been placed by the Canadian Government on the German mark, in accordance with the requirements of the recently adopted Canadian-German trade agreement.

Preceded by a solemn high mass yesterday morning, the fifth annual grand convocation of Dominican Religious and lay members of the Third Order of St. Dominic of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut was held yesterday morning in honor of the Catholic patron saint of peace, St. Catherine of Siena,

An academic storm is brewing at Oxford over the invitation to send a delegate to the bicentenary celebrations of Goettingen University, Germany, on June 30, the anniversary of the Nazi party purge of 1934.

The Committee for Industrial Organization, not content with fighting the American Federation of Labor in the United States, is apparently determined to extend the battle to Canada, where hitherto C. I. O. and A. F. of L. affiliates have lived side by side in peace.

American newspaper reporters were described today by the Rev. Dr. William H. Fineshriber, rabbi of Keneseth Israel Synagogue, as guardians of democracy and civilization. He spoke at a memorial service for newspaper men and women who have died in the last two years or so.

The Works Progress Administration announced yesterday that it had begun excavations for two new houses for the City Fire Department and that it would begin work on two others as soon as plans were ready. President Roosevelt has approved a Federal grant for labor and materials of $394,700, to which the city will add $70,300 for equipment.

Reports that a bloc of Republican Assemblymen have served notice on Speaker Heck that they intend to vote with the Democrats for Governor Lehman's bill increasing the gasoline tax to four cents, strengthened belief at the Capitol tonight that the Legislature will adjourn this week.

The New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, a civic businessgetting agency to coordinate and direct the solicitation of new business, reported yesterday that in the first quarter of this year it had announced the decisions of sixtynine national and State associations to hold conventions and exhibitions here, compared with twenty-seven such decisions in the first quarter of 1936.

A general police alarm was sent out yesterday for Mrs. Cecilia Baker, 26 years old, of 306 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, who disappeared April 14 after telling her roommate that she had given certain information to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey.

Miss Josephine Woods, daughter of Mrs. George Adams Woods of this city, was married to Huntington English, son of Mrs. John C. English of this city yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Arthur F. McKenny.
Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Commonwealth, and Mrs. Quezon were honored today with a variety of formalities during an elevenhour visit here.
A fixed rate of 32 cents has been placed by the Canadian Government on the German mark, in accordance with the requirements of the recently adopted Canadian-German trade agreement.

Preceded by a solemn high mass yesterday morning, the fifth annual grand convocation of Dominican Religious and lay members of the Third Order of St. Dominic of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut was held yesterday morning in honor of the Catholic patron saint of peace, St. Catherine of Siena,

An academic storm is brewing at Oxford over the invitation to send a delegate to the bicentenary celebrations of Goettingen University, Germany, on June 30, the anniversary of the Nazi party purge of 1934.

The Committee for Industrial Organization, not content with fighting the American Federation of Labor in the United States, is apparently determined to extend the battle to Canada, where hitherto C. I. O. and A. F. of L. affiliates have lived side by side in peace.
More than 1,000 scientists from university, industrial and government laboratories will gather hens this week for meetings of six scientific societies.

The Association of Long Island Commuters announced its approval yesterday of a proposal to create a legislative commission to survey transit conditions in the suburban area surrounding New York City, with special reference to the possibility of establishing "postalized" uniform rates of fare.

Z. G. Simmons won the final regular shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, taking the scratch trophy at 100 targets by breaking 97. In the handicap events the Class A Cup went to L. F. Sanman, who had 100 full targets, while in Class B, E. B. Horwath, H. S. Sergison and F. J. Wagner all finished with scores of 100 and Horwath won in the extra series.

The Rev. Dr. George Linn Kieffer, statistician of the National Lutheran Council, fell dead of heart failure yesterday afternoon in the pulpit of Christ Lutheran Church, Rosedale, Queens, two minutes after he had opened an address. He died, at the age of 53, in the only church he ever served as pastor.
A total of $18,400 has been pledged toward the $50,000 needed to buy back the assets of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday at the morning service.

A big fifth inning, in which they banged out six straight hits off Leo Mangum, clinched the series opener for Toronto's Maple Leafs over the Chiefs today by a score of 6 to 2. More than 5,000 watched the game. Mike Meola, who hurled for Syracuse last year,

Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, left here at 9 o'clock tonight He told newspaper men he was pleased to find that Rumania appreciated as much as Poland the value of the Polono-Rumanian alliance and said his visit had increased its value and strengthened the possibility of its bringing about constructive work for peace between the two countries.
A threeday strike of 700 city garbage and refuse haulers was settled tonight with an agreement Described by Mayor George J. Zimmermann as "unanimous and satisfactory."

Government supply awards under the terms of the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on April 22 totaled $3,540,538, compared with $4,679,241 the preceding week, the Department of Labor has announced.

Senator Harry F. Byrd today answered the President's message of last week calling for economies with a proposal to combine two kindred recovery agencies, the Home Owners Loan Corporation and the Federal Housing Administration.

With communism, nazism and fascism all striving for the extinction of liberty, America, the British Commonwealth of nations, France and other freedom-loving countries must stand together if free government is to be preserved, Bishop William T. Manning declared

A call to Jews to embrace again the basic law of Judaism to combat modern paganism was made in a talk yesterday morning by Ludwig Lewisohn, novelist and critic, before the congregation of the Free Synagogue in Carnegie Hall. "We often speak of freedom as an escape from restraint," he asserted.

It was all Dizzy Dean today and the Cardinals took a 4-to-0 decision from the Cubs in the last game of the series. The victory gave the Red Birds the edge in the series, two games to one. Dizzy achieved his second straight shut-out of the season and at the same time had ten strike-outs.

Sorrow over another's death is too often self-pity over the temporary loss, the Rev. Gordon B. Wadhams, pastor of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, said in his sermon there yesterday. His subject was "The Christian Attitude Toward Death."
The American motto "E pluribus unum," political in origin, was used yesterday to describe the unique national culture which is being developed in this country from diverse racial sources.

Seven of the sixteen members of the Ogdensburg police force, the entire welfare force with the exception of the commissioner, and the highway maintenance crew of the city were out of work today as the result of a tax election Friday. Eight of ten resolutions were voted down by the taxpayers, all but those for the school and Fire Department appropriations.

Net assets of the Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland and its subsidiaries at March 31 were reported yesterday to amount to $3,985 for each $1,000 of debentures, $1,130 for each share of Class A preferred stock and $21.20 a share of Class B common stock. This compares with corresponding values at Dec. 31, 1936, of $4,194 a debenture, $1,209 a Class A preferred share and $22.59 a Class B common share.
Ezra P. Griswold, who as a boy saw plenty of Indians in his native State of Ohio and who cast his first Presidential vote for Abraham Lincoln,

Unless German booksellers succeed in winning over the masses to buying more books their justification for commercial existence will be placed in jeopardy, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels warned today.

The career of Benedict Arnold will receive dramatic interpretation by the Morningside Players of Columbia University in their play "The Brink of Glory," which opens at Earl Hall tonight for a week's presentation.
Officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that they were entering the final phase of their investigation of investment trusts and probably would end it "in the Summer."

Lillian Shapero and her dance group presented a program consisting almost entirely of new compositions at the Guild Theatre last night, assisted by Maurice Rauch, pianist and musical director, and a small company of vocal and instrumental musicians.
Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's deep belief in Christianity is shown in a document received from Nanking by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions.

A red cordon reputedly worn by Napoleon Bonaparte at St. Helena and a lock of the "Little Corporal's" hair are included among several items recently added to the Princeton University Library's collection of Napoleonic material, it was announced today by James Thayer Gerould, universitv librarian.

Contributions of government and private industry to the control of business booms and the effect of international economic policies on business stability will be the major A topics of discussion at the second session of the two-day Wharton Institute Conference which will begin on Friday in the Waldorf-Astoria it was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph H. Willits, dean of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce.

The State Federation of Labor took charge today of the workers' side in Stockton's still ominous cannery strike situation and announced organization of a new union to take over the factory employes who are members of the Agricultural Workers Union and replace the more conservative group organized under the banner of the Modesto Cannery Workers Union.

The most important feature in the monetary situation is the continued weakness of the United States dollar in relation to the pound sterling. This broadly is ascribed to three main factors--heavy gold shipments from London to the United States;
The body of United States Senator Nathan Lynn Bachman was brought back to his native Chattanooga today. The Senator died suddenly of a heart ailment in Washington Friday night.

In the current Atlantic Monthly Mr. GILBERT SELDES points an unerring and accusing finger at the banalities that still encumber the radio program sponsored by the advertiser and at Hollywood's misuse of sound on the screen.

There were 35,028,682 telephones in the world as of Jan. 1, 1936, according to a report made public yesterday by the chief statistician of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The United States had nearly one-half, or 17,423,871, of this total on the same date.
George Gilham, a former major league baseball player, died of Hodgkin's disease at his home in Lansdowne today, in his thirty-ninth year.

A nine-foot statue of Father Francis P. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the 165th Infantry Regiment, formerly known as the "Fighting Sixty-ninth," will be unveiled next Sunday afternoon at the north end of Times Square.

Organizations affiliated with the Council of Fraternal and Benevolent Organizations of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City have increased 200, it was announced at the council's third annual convention yesterday at the Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 137th Street and Amsterdam

The spread of communism in New York City and its antagonism to the Roman Catholic Church was decried by speakers yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of Court Ave Maria, 34. Catholic Daughters of America, at the Hotel Astor.

Having opened officially the baseball season last week, Mayor La Guardia last night turned his talents to the theatre, adding a new chapter to his own history and that of the Metropolitan Opera House.

George Fields, radio comedian of the National Broadcasting Company networks, died suddenly yesterday in the Pennsylvania Station. He had just arrived from his Bayside (L. I.) home to take a medical examination when he was stricken with a heart attack. Dr. C. B. Mathews of the Pennsylvania Railroad medical department pronounced him dead shortly after he had been removed from the upperlevel waiting room.

Mayor La Guardia struck yesterday at "the professional agitators" who try with "half-truths" to mislead persons on relief into taking desperate and unwise actions. Asserting that there was "little comfort" in being on relief, he warned that it was society's duty to help relief recipients and not to leave them "at the mercy" of agitators.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 93.8, which compares with 94.3 the week before, 94.5 two weeks before, 94.7 three weeks before and 94.4 four weeks before. The average of three weeks ago was the highest of the year to date; the lowest was 90.1,

The indications are for rain today and for generally fair weather tomorrow. Continued cool weather is expected, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock, E. S. T., last night.
The Baltimore home of Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, fiancee of the Duke of Windsor, was opened to the public here today.
Six major exhibitions for the season 1937-38 are announced by the Whitney Museum of American Art in a program extending from Oct. 13, when the first one opens, to May 15, when the last closes.

Announcement of third-quarter steel prices at second-quarter levels for most steel products has done much to stabilize the market, the magazine Steel says this week. The publication reports that the determination of prices so far before the usual date was in response to pressure by steel consumers who found it difficult to quote on their products without knowledge of their costs. Continuing, it says:

Bob Feller's pitching arm was "all right" today, Manager Steve O'Neill of the Indians said. The injury to the "million dollar" arm-object of tender ministrations from trainers and physicians after the 18-year-old strikeout artist had ,pulled a muscle yesterday-will not delay Feller's return to the game, O'Neill said.

Miss Doris Long of 140 East Sixty-third Street, a former member of the Council of Social Agencies here, who had lately been connected with the Board of Education, died Saturday night in the Galen House Hospital, Rye, N. Y., after a long illness, following a cerebral hemorrhage. She was born in Babylon, L. I., forty-seven years ago, a daughter of the late Rev. Dr. John D. Long.

Although cotton prices fluctuated over a wide range last week, at the finish they showed only small changes from the close of the preceding week. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of future deliveries were 4 to 14 points lower on the week.

In a driving rain, twentyfive Senators and seventy-two Representatives and the wives and other members of the families of many of them visited historical points of interest at Yorktown, Williamsburg and Jamestown today. They were guests of the Virginia Peninsula Association of Commerce.

A hearing on a disorderly conduct charge against Mrs. William R. Seymour, 37 years old, of 75 East Fifty-fifth Street and her two sisters, all of whom are said to have attecked Mr. Seymour in a midtown restaurant Saturday night,

The Sheppard-Hill War Profits Bill was characterized yesterday by the Council for Social Action of the Congregational and Christian Churches as "misleading, unnecessary and dangerous to American liberties."

An 8-year-old "G-man" was the hero of the capture of a real escaped Federal prisoner today. Robert Schaffer, 8, has been playing "Federal agent" for a long time. He and his playmates have toy guns and disguises. His father gave them a shack for an "office" and "jail."

Silas F. Seadler. in 1,100 Park Ave; Philip E. Dobbin, in 14 Sutton Pl: Albert Kartens, in 929 Park Ave; Joseph J. Morsman Jr., in 425 E 51st St; Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc. broker. John C. Messer, in 308 E 79th St. through Duff Conger. Inc; Butt, Gilliam McVay, Inc, broker.

On the average, stocks and bonds ended lower last week; but the change was not great, and there were days when prices rose. The stock market average, although still about 18 points above the low figure of 1936 and 53 above that of 1935, is now some 12 1/2 points below the present year's highest.

Wil liam H. Richardson, city historian of Jersey City since 1931, died today at his home, 92 Summit Avenue, of heart disease after an illness of two months. His age was 73. He was born in Norritonville, Pa.; attended schools in Bridgeport, Pa., and before coming here in 1902 edited The Miller's Review, a trade paper, in Norristown, Pa.

Miss Phoebe Root, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Root, of Lake Avenue, Greenwich, will be married to Dr. Whitman Mead Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. R. Reynolds of Greenwich, on May 22, in Christ Episcopal Church, Greenwich. A reception will be held at the Root home.
Sites in Queens were acquired in deals reported over the week-end for new housing. The blockfront on the east side of Sixty-third Drive, between Saunders and Booth Streets, in the Elmhurst section,

A preview, reception and tea this afternoon preceded the opening of the nineteenth Spring Exhibition of the Greenwich Society of Artists at the art gallery of the Greenwich Library scheduled for tomorrow and to be continued through May 8.

ANDREWS, HELEN M. (April 4). Estate, more than $10,000. To Richard E. Woods, nephew, Oakville, Pa., $13.000. share in residue and remainder of $5,000 from estate of deceased husband, James K. Andrews; Mary Stuart Whitney, niece, L519 2d, St.. Harrisburg, Pa., $14,000,

Dozier A. De Vane, counsel for the Federal Power Commission, agreed today to a postponement of the commission's investigation of six Pennsylvania affiliates of the Associted Gas and Electric Company until the United States Circuit Court of Appeals decides on the commission's jurisdiction.

The crack University of Miami tennis team, now on a Northern tour, blanked Harvard, 9 to 0, on the Divinity courts today. Former room-mates, Gardner Malloy of Miami and Dick Dorson of Harvard, the teams' No. 1 men, provided the feature match.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson today reserved ruling on the motion of stockholders of the Central Republic Trust Company to reconsider his decision of last October subjecting them to 100 per cent assessment on holdings, in a suit entered against them by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Metropolitan Museun, of Art. The Egyptian collection, general tour, 11. A. M.; "Color: Far Eastern Robes," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; "Digging Into the Past": "Drypoint-a Demonstration," motion pictures. 2:30 P. M.; "Design in Dress," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Renaissance Metalwork Design," Alfred Busselle Jr., 4 P. M.

Automobile production spurted last week to its highest point since the week ended May 25, 1929, and the adjusted index advanced to 111.5 from 105.7 (revised). It was 115.2 for the week ended April 25, 1936.
Packers' stocks of canned foods were generally lower on April 1, 1937, than on the same date a year ago, F. H. Rawls, chief of the Commerce Department's foodstuffs division announced today.

Publishers of the magazine The New York Woman filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court for permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law. They announced at the same time that the magazine would appear hereafter as a monthly, the first issue to come out on May 20.

Once again, as on so many historic occasions in the past, the Supreme Court has acted to uphold the constitutional guarantees of American liberty. In this latest instance it had before it the case of a young Negro convicted of inciting insurrection against the State of Georgia, under a statute passed in Reconstruction days.
The Sudbury Tigers, Canada's Allan Cup hockey champions, won a post-season international amateur series tonight by playing a 2-2 tie with the Wembley Lions, champions of England's national league,

Floyd Gibbons, radio commentator, is being sued because of one of his flood broadcasts last January, it was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday. Charles Locke, script writer and newspaper man, contends that his reputation as an accurate reporter was damaged by the changes Gibbons made in his script and asks $250,000.

Oxford University finally took its stand today with every other important British university in refusing to send a delegate to the bicentenary celebrations of the German University of Goettingen in June.

The Right Rev. Alfred Alonzo Gilman, Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Missionary District of Hankow, China, has been nominated by the Synod there to succeed the Right Rev. Logan H. Roots, who is resigning as Bishop of Hankow.

The Dowager Duchess of Roxburghe, the former Miss May Goelet of New York and Newport, R. I., one of England's greatest hostesses and close friend of King George V and Queen Mary, died here today at the age of 58.

Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature tonight expressing "sincere hope" that the Assembly would pass his bill, adding a fourth cent per gallon to the State tax on motor vehicle fuel.
James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., pleaded innocent in Federal court today to a charge of violating a Federal law during a strike at the firm's Middletown plant.
Prombank, the branch of the Soviet State Bank that finances Soviet industries, is being investigated under charges it has been used by "Japanese and German Trotskyist agents" to sabotage industry.
Fernando Costa, a wealthy Sao Paulo coffee planter, it is learned from a reliable source, will be appointed president of the National Coffee Department, probably tomorrow.

The National Football League came to terms with two leading minor circuits, the Dixie League and the American Association, regarding player transfers at a meeting here last night, but failed to settle the question of territorial rights, The Associated Press reports.

The demand for a census of unemployment grows in volume and insistence. Congressmen complain that they are being asked to vote an appropriation of $1,500,000,000 for relief without knowledge of the real size and nature of the problem. Now it is learned that

In the long exchange of compliments between Great Britain and Belgium, marking Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's official visit, Mr. Eden emphasized that working out the problem of Belgian neutrality envisages also the ultimate prospects of a wider European settlement.

" The Last Night," a Soviet film chronicle of events in Moscow on the eve of the 1917 October revolution, will have its American premiere tonight at the Cameo after the last screening of "Beethoven Concerto."

The threatened railroad tie-up in New York City was blocked by law for at least sixty days, as a board of arbitration was named by the President. Page 1. Police and Federal agents ejected 300 strikers from the Parke Davis plant in Detroit, where $2,000,000 in medicines and narcotics were stored. Page 16.
Expanding its advertising budget considerably over that for 1936, the Knox Hat Company will launch its straw hat advertising campaign in three morning papers here on May 15. Copy ranging from 1,000

Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr. gave a tea yesterday at her home, 226 East Sixty-first Street, for members of the junior committee of the Spring drive to assist the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. The drive will continue through May and June. Mrs. Reid is serving as
Police at 9 o'clock (Eastern standard time) tonight estimated that 6,000 persons had been evacuated from their homes in different parts of London, as the worst flood in forty years overran the city.

A further stepping up of production of airplanes, of which Russia already is producing probably more than any other country of Continental Europe, was forecast today in an order by L. M. Kaganovich, Vice Commissar for Defense Industries.
The Reichsbank's statement as of April 23 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, conferred for three-quarters of an hour this morning with Count Galeazzo Ciano. Italian Foreign Minister, and for more than an hour this evening with Premier Benito Mussolini. He will leave for Berlin tomorrow.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, largest United States Steel subsidiary, notified its workers and the Labor Relations Board today that it would no longer recognize the employee representative plan. Union leaders have referred to the plan as a "company union."

Harry Barton Chamberlain, former vice president of the Erie Railroad and receiver for the Tennessee Central Railway from 1910 to 1912, died today at Sweetbriar Farm, home of his daughter, Mrs. Joe C. Yowell, after a long illness. His age was 78.

Mgr. Francis J. Dubosh of Lakewood, Ohio, spiritual director of the First Catholic Slovak Union of America, was welcomed by a large delegation of priests and lay members of the organization when he arrived on the French liner Normandie yesterday afternoon.

New York Yankees vs. Philadelphia Athletics, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, Bronx ........3:15 P. M. Brooklyn Dodgers vs. Boston Bees, at Ebbets Field, Bedford Avenue and Sullivan Place, Brooklyn ...............3:15 P. M. Fordham vs. St. John's, at Fordham Field, Third Avenue and Fordham Road, Bronx, 3:30 P. M.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday overruled the objections raised by the attorney for John H. Manning and other stockholders to the auction sale of the assets of D. W. Griffith, Inc., which took place before him last Monday.

The resignations of Gustav Steiner, 55 years old, of 782 Cauldwell Avenue, the Bronx, and Maurice J. Hoffman, 38, of 120 East Fortythird Street, as members of the bar were filed in the Appellate Division yesterday by Bernard C. Botein, Assistant District Attorney in charge of the new Accident Fraud Bureau.

In a land where Spring has yet to make its appearance, a new regime is starting in Cornell rowing. The visitor here finds it hard to realize that, farther south, races have already been rowed and a rowing season is actually under way. The men of Cornell look as the oarsmen of warmer climes do during the bitter days of March.

A period of comparative quiet- settled yesterday over the wholesale liquor market as wholesalers began returning to normal discount schedules after four days of sharp competition for volume. Distributors of only one or two large distilling corporations were quoting discounts higher than the industry standard of 2 to 5 per cent, depending on quantities, late yesterday.

Colonel H M. Boykin, assistant general freight agent in the Richmond offices of the Seaboard Air Line Railway until last September, died yesterday at his home here. He was 76 years old. In 1914, Governor

The Greenwich Garden Club and the Hortulus Club of Greenwich joined in holding the first annual Narcissus show in the coach house at Wilshire Farm, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wilshire on Round Hill Road, this afternoon. Members of Greenwich society attended in large numbers.
A labor dispute marked by a brief fight today between two groups of workers closed the plant of the Baker-Perkins Company, large manufacturer of-baking and confectinnery machinery.

Whopper is assigned top impost of 126 pounds for the Jamaica Handicap, with $5,000 added, for 3-year-olds and upward at six furlongs, which will be run Saturday. Only One is rated next at 122 in the weights announced yesterday by John B. Campbell, official handicapper, for the thirty-three eligibles. The weights:

General Francisco Franco, virtual dictator of Insurgent-held Spain, received a message today from Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany congratulating him upon the creation of a one-party system similar to Germany's National Socialist party.

Included in the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday was a lease for a floor of 15,000 square feet taken by the Universal Cork and Seal Company in the former Knox Hat Company plant at 601 Grand Avenue, corner of St. Mark's Place, Brooklyn. A number of business rentals on Broadway were reported. Details of the leases follow:

On the basis of the newly established United States citizenship of Helmuth Hirsch, 21-year-old art student sentenced to death for "high treason and possession of explosives," the United States Embassy, on behalf of the American Government, addressed to the German Government today a plea for clemency, which only Chancellor Adolf Hitler can grant.

Yale emerged a 4-1 winner in a windswept diamond bout with Providence College today, largely through the steadier pitching performance of its second-string twirler, Monroe Jubitz, sophomore, who allowed only seven safe hits and fanned seven batsmen.

Meyer Berson, 48, of 4,600 Ninth Avenue, Brooklyn, one of the Brooklyn painters and contractors accused of conspiring with labor racketeers to maintain a monopoly of Board of Education contracts in Brooklyn and Queens public schools, surrendered yesterday.

The band went through its motions yesterday morning at a special performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, but it was unable to make much music heard. There was too much whistling.

Twenty-five undergraduates at New York University's Washington Square College, Washington Square East, were tapped yesterday for membership in Eclectic and Sigma, honor societies, at ceremonies in the university's East Building, 239 Greene Street.
A pistol used by General Aguinaldo when he led the Philippine insurrection after the Spanish-American War was used today to hold up the Chicago Historic: 1 Society.

Most commodity futures were sharply lower in active trading on the local markets yesterday. Sugar and zinc futures were steady. On the cash markets all the grains, cocoa, sugar, butter, tins, cotton, printcloths, silk, rubber, flour and lard declined, but hides and wool tops advanced.

President Kyosti Kallio stressed today that the foreign policy of Finland was constitutionally fixed upon republican principles. His remark was amplified by Foreign Minister Rudolf Holsti, who said the weight of Finland's diplomacy would be thrown on the side of the League of Nations.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation, announced yesterday that consolidated net earnings applicable to the common stock for the first quarter of 1937 were equal to 99 cents a share earned on 43,500,000 common shares, compared with $1.17 a share in the corresponding period of 1936.

NEARLY every one knows the fable of the poor donkey unable to make up its mind from which of two piles of hay to take nourishment. Something of the same perplexity must assail any one who has read in succession two new books dealing with America and the next war-"The Tragic Fallacy" (Knopf, $4), by

The annual report of the Cities Service Company and subsidiaries for 1936, issued today, shows a consolidated net income, after prior charges, applicable to the stocks of Cities Service, of $6,965,496, as compared with $5,856,265 in 1935, an increase of $1,109,231.
Neisner Bros., Inc., is offering to the holders of 21,822 outstanding shares of 7 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock the right to exchange each share for 11-l0th

The United Licensed Officers Association announced yesterday that it had been selected by a majority of the officers of ships of the Merchants and Miners Transportation Company as their spokesman in wage negotiations. The poll was the first to be completed by officers' unions since the Supreme Court upheld the Wagner act.

Felix M. Warburg, banker, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie from a trip to Europe where he attended executive committee meetings of various Jewish charities. Mrs. Warburg accompanied him.

The Standard Oil Company of California and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the March quarter a net profit of $7,889,489 after depreciation, depletion, taxes and other deductions. The profit is equivalent to 61 cents a share on 13,014,754 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Counsel for Hearst, Inc., and other William Randolph Hearst corporations, asked the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals today to dismiss its injunction suit against the National Labor Relations Board in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer case.

The government Navy Ministry announced today that its fleet had routed Insurgent warships in the Mediterranean and, simultaneously, charged that the German cruiser Leipzig was a scout for the Insurgents.

In a report filed in Supreme Court, Henry A. Thellusson, as special referee, has recommended that Eugene J. Cohan be required to return $34,670 to Funeral Chauffeurs Local 643 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers, of which he is secretary-treasurer, it was revealed yesterday.
William F. Gleason, a member of the editorial staff of The Evening Bulletin, died of pneumonia yesterday at his home here in his fifty-sixth year.

American-made army overcoats protected General Francisco Franco's Spanish Insurgent troops today from the chill winds that blew along trenches they had just won atop Mount Enchorta, in the Bilbao area.
Paramount Pictures, Inc., issued yesterday an estimate of its consolidated earnings for the three months ended on April 3 at $2,011,000. This includes about $391,000
Dr. T. G. Macauley Hine, whose discovery of "carriers of meningitis" was credited with saving thousands of lives, died Sunday at Slapton, Devonshire, at the age of 66.
Three men who had spent sixteen hours in an open boat in the path of a northeast gale were rescued by a Coast Guard cutter shortly after noon today in Delaware Bay, five miles from here.

Father Divine, Harlem cult leader whose followers believe he is God, plans to take over the whole of Ulster County and make it into a model cooperative community reminiscent of Upton Sinclair's proposed "production for use" communities in California, it was learned yesterday.

Candy, with an increase of 92.2 per cent over last year, led in the departmental sales increases of large stores in the Second Federal Reserve District during March, according to the monthly analysis issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

President Roosevelt today withdrew the nomination of Murray W. Latimer as a member of the Social Security Board. Confirmation of Mr. Latimer's appointment was held up in the Senate on the ground that he would make a third Democrat on a board which under the law cannot have more than two members of the same political party.

The Rev. Dr. Allan A. Macrae, one of the founders of the Westminster Theological Seminary, offered his resignation from its faculty today with the charge that "control of the faculty and direction of its policies has passed into the hands of a small alien group without American Presbyterian background."

If the Federal Theatre Project wants to produce any or all of George Bernard Shaw's thirtythree full-length plays and fifteen short ones Mr. Shaw is "quite ready to entertain a proposal" to that effect.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The activities and utterances of a variety of people with respect to foreign war seem to be attributable in large part to two factors: immaturity of intellect and itch for publicity. The "student oath" and the student parades typify the one; and the other

The New York University tennis team blanked the Brooklyn College players, 9 to 0, at the Fleet Hollow Tennis Club yesterday. In one of the sternest matches of the day, Herb Abrams defeated Bob Keese, 6-4, 5-7, 6-2.
Waters of the Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers spilled into the fringes of Pittsburgh's "Golden Triangle" tonight while residents of the city prepared for a possible major flood.
State laws establishing criminal penalties for bookmaking at places other than licensed race tracks were held valid today by County Judge Gerald Nolan of Westchester County.

After three witnesses had testified in General Sessions yesterday against William Watson, 24 years old, a plumber, who defrauded six men under the pretense that he would obtain jobs for some of them in mechanical departments of THE NEW YORK TIMES, Watson suddenly pleaded guilty to attempted grand larceny. Judge Donnellan remanded him to the Tombs for sentence May 4. He is liable to a Sing Sing term of two and one-half years.

The scientists at the Glasgow University reported a few weeks ago that Scotland was moving westward. The distance covered is not great, but it is enough to suggest a leaning toward America. This is of special interest

Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks tonight put an end to efforts to reorganize the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company, the electric commuter line serving New York's populous Westchester County.

The traditional Spring moving season, now at its height, appears to be passing almost unnoticed by the average New Yorker although the records indicate greater activity than a year ago in many sections of the city.

A cross-island mail truck service, planned to speed up the delivery of letters for Nassau County mailed in the county, was started today from the Freeport postoffice when a truck loaded with mail left for Mineola shortly before noon.
Miss Sally Peabody Goodell, daughter of Mrs. Willard R. Downing of New Canaan, Conn., has completed plans for her marriage to Jacques S. Aronet of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony will take

Marshall Field's Foray was made the 3-1 favorite for Wednesday's Two Thousand Guineas, first of the season's classics for 3-yearolds, in a callover at the Victoria Club tonight. The second choice was Fairford,

The battle over the courts reorganization plan continued today, with Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, attacking it over the radio as a move toward dictatorship, and Attorney General Cummings, also on the air, defending it as required to carry out the will of the People.

Mrs. Corinne Bramlette Walworth, daughter of Thomas Elliott Bramlette, Civil War Governor of Kentucky, died here this morning at the age of 82 in the famous Walworth mansion, where she had lived for twenty-five years.

The first step in planning industrial exhibits for the 1939 World's hair was taken yesterday with the signing by the nation's largest corporation, the $5,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, of the first contract for space for a private exhibit.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are April 25 unless specified: At Pearl Harbor: Melville. Monaghan. Nautilus, Partridge, Perry, Preble, Pruitt, Porpoise, Rail, Richmond, Robin, Shark, Sands, Sicard, Simpson, Sturtevant, Southard, Tern, Tracy, Trever. Truxtun, Vireo, Williamson, Wasmuth, Aylwln, Argonne, Bainbridge, Barry, Borie, Bushnell, Brooks, Broome, Brant, Chandler.
The international stock market indices for April 24, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

When the higher reserve requirements of the Federal Reserve System go into effect on May 1 excess reserves of the member banks will be reduced, it is officially estimated, to $700,000,000 and any additional that may be brought about in the meantime by the purchase of government securities by the regional banks of the system in its program for an orderly market for government securities.

Hamilton Township police battled striking employes of the Thermoid Rubber Company with tear-gas bombs outside the plant gates here tonight after the pickets had prevented the departure of a company truck.

Representatives of both sides in the month-old shoe strike conferred for the first time tonight, after Judge Harry Manser of the Supreme Court had ruled this morning that the C. I. O. relief stations could stay open.

Elimination of third shift operations by cotton textile mills is unlikely to be achieved without some form of Federal legislation, selling agents here said yesterday, although they pointed out that some reductions to two shifts have already been arranged voluntarily.

More than 2,000 acres of forest and brushland were swept by a series of fires in Suffolk County today. The major blaze centered south of this village, where employes of the Academy of St. Joseph, a girls' school maintained by the Sisters of St. Joseph, were forced to backfire a large area to prevent the flames from sweeping across the convent cemetery near Old Commack Road.

Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Eastman of 96 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, and Walpole, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Hooper Eastman, to Jay Alan Abercrombie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Abercrombie of Denver. Col.

The New York Board of Trade urged yesterday that the city undertake a "complete and impartial investigation" of home relief, with special reference to charges that Communists dominate the work of the Emergency Relief Bureau.
Reflecting further weakness on the London Metal Exchange, sales of copper in the export markets were made yesterday at 14 cents a pound, c. i. f. the European base ports. Some sales were made early

The Fieldston School girls' tennis team defeated the New York University squad, 3-2, at the victors' courts yesterday. In a hard-fought singles encounter, Miss Ann Eiseman of Fieldston took a threeset victory from Miss Margaret Schlichting, 1-6, 7-5, 6-1.

Ellis H. Parker Sr., the veteran Burlington County (N. J.) detective, who is accused of having plotted the kidnapping of his onetime friend, Paul H. Wendel, in a scheme to "solve" the Lindbergh crime, will be placed on trial this morning in the Federal court in Newark.

Steel production this week is scheduled at 92.3 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 91.3 per cent last week, a gain of 1 point, or 1.1 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Harry Maslow of Brooklyn, N. Y., Morris Rosenberg and William Britton Stitt and Herbert W. Haldenstein of New York were admitted to practice today and the following proceedincs were had:

The Orchestrette Classique, composed of women and directed by Miss Frederique Petrides, presented classic and modern works at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night. Three Americans were represented: Julia Smith, 26-year-old Texas composer, by an "Episodic Suite" for small orchestra;

Mrs. Catherine Barrett Farnsworth filed suit today for divorce from John S. Farnsworth, former navy officer, now serving a four-to-twelveyear prison term at Atlanta, Ga., on a charge of having sold naval secrets to the Japanese.

Angelo Herndon, young Negro Communist, was freed today by a five-to-four division of the Supreme Court from the eighteen to twenty-year prison sentence imposed for violating a Georgia law of the Reconstruction era forbidding advocacy of forceful resistance to the State's authority.

It is the belief of Valentine A. Ely, chairman of the Eastern Junior and Interscholastic Committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, that future Davis Cup hopefuls will emanate from the country's schools. This opinion was voiced by
J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., and Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., captured the MasonDixon tennis doubles championship by outscoring Martin Buxby of

Wheeling mobilized tonight to fight the flood waters of the Ohio River. Citizens determined to prepare against the possibility of a flood like the one on St. Patrick's Day, 1936. which took several lives.
The vast programs of conservation that are constantly being planned by Federal, State and private organizations alike often raise a question of finding experienced men to carry on such work.

Stocks closed weak, with widest declines of year; turnover, 2,023,710 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, convertible issues weakened, foreign loans steady; transactions, $12,130,000.
Coronation-year debutantes, 260 altogether, including two Americans, were the stars in a colorful ceremony tonight at the Queen Charlotte birthday ball in the West End.

Liquidation was under way in the grain markets today from start to finish, with wheat and rye on the Board of Trade here and Winnipeg breaking 5 cents a bushel at the extreme, the maximum permitted for one day's trading under Exchange regulations. Soy beans dropped 4 cents, the permissible limit, and are off 8 cents a bushel in two days.

Another British steamer was stopped on the high seas tonight almost at the same time the British Government protested to Insurgent Chief Francisco Franco against the Insurgent attempt on April 23 to prevent the British steamer MacGregor from entering Bilbao.

Experiments on salamanders and tadpoles, in which the elemental clay of life was molded into eyes, nose, ears, mouth and other organs of the head, foreshadowing a time when man might regenerate lost organs, were described today before the annual Spring meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

John McD. Murray has been nominated for re-election as president of the New York Produce Exchange. Other officers chosen by the nominating committee to succeed themselves are Robert F. Straud, vice president; Clifford B. Merritt, treasurer, and B. H. Under, trustee of the gratuity fund. The election will be held on June 7.

Max Schmeling, former heavyweight champion, and his trainer, Max Machon, sailed for New York on the Bremen tonight, confident that Schmeling's title fight with Jimmy Braddock will be held in New York June 3 despite the legal warfare going on over it in the United States.

Mrs. Marion Snowden Reed became the bride here today of Bradley Sherman Dresser of New York a short time after she had received a divorce from her second husband, Louis F. Reed Jr. The ceremony took place in the chambers of Judge Beniamin F. Curler.

Documentary evidence that Sheriff Theodore R. Middleton of Harlan County, Ky., acquired, with his wife, property valued at $102,728 and frequently "shifted" funds from three separate official bank accounts to his private account when he needed to make payments on notes, was put into the record today by the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage.

The current type of industrial management should spend more time in "selling" itself to the public and in outlining the manifold problems which confront it, Oswald W. Knauth, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

With public opinion in a disturbed state and political feeling running high, the French Government again will go before Parliament tomorrow and may be called on before the end of the week to defend its general policy, especially with regard to the demands of labor.
Henry Morgenthau Sr., former Ambassador to Turkey, received many messages of felicitation yesterday on his eighty-first birthday at his home, 1,133 Fifth Avenue.

The last of the defending bowling champions took their fling yesterday and failed. Anthony Slanina and Mike Straka of Chicago, 1936 doubles titleholders, were unable to repeat as the American Bowling Congress championships went through the forty-eighth session at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

More than 1,000 substitute teachers from New York City marched on Capitol Hill tonight bearing banners urging passage of the Steingut-Fischel bill providing qualifying examinations for substitute teachers. They came in a special train.

Movements in the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000, including 3,500 direct. Market generally steady to 10 higher than Friday's average; bulk good and choice 200-280 lb., $10.10@$10.25; top $10.30; most 150-190 lb., $9.60@$10.10; good packing sows, largely $9.60@$9.85, scarce and 5 to 10 higher.

George D. Simon, vice president of Franklin Simon Co., yesterday announced his retirement from the management of the store, founded in 1902 by his father, Franklin Simon. The retirement becomes effective Aug. 1.

Making the most of seven hits, Toronto's Leafs scored a 6-3 victory over the Chiefs today. Syracuse collected thirteen hits and benefited by five Toronto errors, but failed to bunch the blows effectively, leaving thirteen men strapded

Mrs. Deering Howe's Only One, who two years ago ranked with Discovery and Top Row among others as one of the leaders of the handicap division, came back to the races at Jamaica yesterday and showed all of his old-time speed.

Harry Bannister, former husband of Ann Harding, motion picture actress, will shortly renew his court fight to secure partial custody of the couple's 8-year-old daughter, Jane Bannister. his attorney, Stanley J. Harte of 11 West Forty-second Street, announced yesterday.

The seventh annual Eastman School festival of American music was opened tonight in the Eastman Theatre with a performance by the University of Rochester symphony band, Frederick Fennell, conductor. The band was included

Increased demands for space for freight moving from the United States to Western Europe, particularly ports of France, have prompted the United States Lines to add the 7,500-ton ship American Traveler to its May sailing list, it was announced yesterday.

The Supreme Court Building, across the east grounds from the Capitol, was proposed today as a memorial to Thomas Jefferson, with the court abandoning its new quarters for a place again in the Capitol.

Former Prince Nicholas of Rumania began his exile from Rumania today in the seclusion of his hotel suite. He will remain in Austria several days, a spokesman said, and then go to Italy. He flew here from Bucharest today. His wife had preceded him.

J. Murray Forbes, pioneer merchant in China, sportsman and former Midwestern railroad executive, died today at the age of 91. A native of Boston, Mr. Forbes began trading in China in the early Sixties. Several years later,
Colby M. Chester, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, appealed today to labor, industry and the government to cooperate in a joint program for industrial peace and prosperity.

Dr. Bernard Sachs, director of the Child Neurology Research, de cried the "vogue of false doctrines' that is making normal children abnormal in an address last eve ning before a conference called by the Jewish Vacation Association at the American Women's Associa tion.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and affiliates for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $39,085,353 after interest, depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, but before provision for minority interests.

A spirited debate over the Supreme Court reorganization issue marked the opening of the meeting of the council of the General Federation of Women's Clubs here today. The council is composed of representatives of club women throughout the United States.

The highest water since March 17, 1936, surged into Johnstown today from the watersheds of Somerset County, but tonight the danger was believed to be past. The waters of Stony Creek and Conemaugh River were receding.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, which acquired the two five-story apartment houses at 1,710-12 Amsterdam Avenue at foreclosure, has sold them to the Ronard Holding Corporation, represented by Barron, Rice Rockmore, attorneys.

The New York Central Railroad's control of the Universal Carloading and Distributing Company has been reduced to somewhat less than 50 per cent, according to testimony introduced before Claude R. Porter of the Interstate Commerce Commission at a hearing in the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday.

The De Capriles brothers, backbone of fencing at New York University when the sport was in its infancy there and more recently members of the American Olympic team, both were upset and eliminated from the epee division of the national fencing championships last night at the New York Athletic Club as the decks were cleared for tomorrow night's finals.

The newspaper Diaro da Noite reported today that President Franklin D. Roosevelt had been informed that President Getulio Vargas of Brazil would visit him in June, returning the American Executive's visit of last November.
Detroit's first sit-down of the week was staged this morning when about 300 employes at Parke Davis Co. refused to work after entering the plant. Soon afterward twenty-five
Chairman Dickstein of the House Immigration Committee renewed his accusations today that there were 50,000 Fascists with a $2,000,000 fund "working to foment trouble in this country."

In a furiously fought eight-round bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night, Bobby Pacho, veteran California Mexican welterweight, and Young Baby Salvy Saban of Greenwich Village battled to a draw before a near-capacity crowd of 4,300 persons.
High water, which crept slowly into the business section here for twelve hours, halted late today, with the edge of the flood lapping at the doors of stores on the main business street.

The indefinite postponement of the adjourned meeting of the world disarmament conference, scheduled for May 6 at Geneva, is a recognition of the unhappy realities among which we live. Talk of disarmament now,

Two union members who failed to obey subpoenas to appear before the extraordinary grand jury in Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of the trucking racket were sentenced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora to five days each in the Tombs.
Riding easterly winds that at times approached gale force, a coastal storm drenched the Potomac Valley last night and today, driving waters for miles up and down the river to flood levels.

Resort by governments to "emotional appeal" and to the promotion of mass thinking to influence the action of their nationals is the source of some of the most important factors making for war, John Foster Dulles of New York said tonight in an address at the banquet of the American section of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Passengers due to arrive today from Southampton via Cherbourg on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania include the Countess of Berkeley, Mrs. Hugh B. Auchincloss, Mrs. C. K. Morgan, Simon Ackerman, Kenneth F. Mackenzie, Miss Helmi Armstrong, Mrs. D. M. Gregg, F. G. Hine, Mrs. Frederick Laist, Miss Virginia Laist, Mrs. C. G. Roberts, H. T. Ripper, Mr. and Mrs. C. L. Marshall, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cardell and Alfred Phiilips.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved the application of the Atlantic Coast Line to issue $3,900,000 of 23/4 per cent equipment securities. The proceeds will be

The Four Aces, spurning a free trip to Europe at the expense of Mr. and Mrs. Ely Culbertson, leading exponents of a rival bridge system, won the Grand National teamof-four championship and the Crockford Cup by 8,460 points yesterday at Crockford's Club, 14 East Sixty-second Street. The Aces,

Mr. JOHN HAMILTON, who seems to believe that a national chairman's cardinal duty is to make speeches, is about to end a season of comparative silence heroically endured. He has been listening for six months, he says.

James F. Fogarty. president of the North American Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that earnings of the system for the twelve months ended on March 31 equaled about $1.89 a common share, against $1.45 a share for the preceding twelve months, an increase of more than 30 per cent. Mr. Fogarty expressed confidence in the future of the utility industry.
Orders for May Day duty were issued yesterday by Commissioner Valentine to New York City's 18,000 uniformed and plainclothes policemen to whom the day means extra duty instead of a celebration.

All constitutional questions concerning the Social Security Act which have been brought before the Supreme Court were assured a review at the present term when the justices agreed today to examine a Massachusetts case in which the old age parts f the law were held unconstitutional by a lower court ten days ago.
Premier T. D. Patullo announced today that an agreement had been reached with the Federal Government for the acquisition of the Yukon Territory by British Columbia.

The Manhattan Players, first of the 1937 Summer stock companies in Westchester County, presented "Fly Away Home" tonight at the auditorium of the Westchester Woman's Club here. It was the company's third presentation of the season. About 200 persons attended.
The first two conferences scheduled by the Maritime Commission with ship lines on the matter of adjusting ocean mail contracts have been canceled, it was learned yesterday.
The monarch of the nation that owes not merely its wealth and power, but its very existence, to the prowess of British sailors, will open tomorrow the world's finest collection of marine paintings.

Incorporated Investors reported yesterday net assets of $81,969,154 on March 31, equal to $27.33 each on 3,000,000 shares of capital stock, compared with net assets of $77,305,950, or $25.77 a shore, on Dec. 31 and with $61,577,558, or $22.07 each on 2,790,821 shares, on March 31, 1936.
Miss Jean Saunders of Calgary advanced but Miss Jean Burritt of Toronto was defeated today in the first round of the British hard court tennis championships. Miss. Saunders defeated Miss M.

Harold Baker, estranged husband of Mrs. Cecelia Baker, 26-year-old waitress, who vanished from her home at 306 Cumberland Street on April 14 after telling her roommate that she had given certain information to Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, was questioned at police headquarters yesterday but could give no information on his wife's disappearance.

The Erie Railroad and town officials were getting all sorts of spirited complaints here tonight about the railroad's new schedule which went into effect with the advent of daylight-saving time and had its first and unsatisfactory test this morning.

L. J. Winston, broker, has moved his office to 170 Waverly Place, corner of Grove St. The Heights Taxpayers Protective Association will hold a meeting tonight at the Paramount Mansion, 601 W. 183d St. Elmer C. Gates, president of the Bronx Real Estate Board, will be the speaker. Legislative developments at Albany, Washington and City Hall will be discussed.

After watching Australia's Davis Cup players in practice for a couple of weeks, Mexico's tennis experts are about ready to agree with the folks from down under that it's about the best tennis team ever to come over from Australia in the annual quest for the trophy.

A coroner's jury inquiring into the death of Miss Rosamund Sopwith, 66 years old, sister of the America's Cup yachtsman, T. O. M. Sopwith, today found Miss Sopwith committed suicide while of unsound mind.

Mrs. Silas H. Paine, widow of a vice president of the Standard Oi1 Company, died yesterday morning at her home in Silver Bay, according to word received here by the Silver Bay Association, 347 Madison Avenue.

Among the bills signed by Governor Lehman today was one reducing the penalty for tax arrears in New York City. The penalty on tax arrears was 7 per cent before 1934, when it was raised to 10 per cent to bring increased tax collections.

A suit to recover securities and cash amounting to more than $2,000,000 from affiliates of the bankrupt Yellow Taxi Corporation was begun in Federal District Court yesterday by Samuel C. Coleman, trustee in bankruptcy for the taxi company.

GOODNESS gracious, the situation was astonfishing, and Connie Mack from Mexico admitted as much. It was high noon yesterday, with a brisk breeze blowing and the baseball season a week under way, and the Athletics were leading the American League. Of course, it was generally understood that the altitude of the Athletics was just an accident or pro tem.

The Red Sox chased Jimmy DeShong early and pounded Ed Linke, his successor, without mercy today while overwhelming the Senators, 12 to 5. A three-run burst in the second inning served as DeShong's exit cue and Linke was the victim of a sixrun uprising in the fourth.
Characterizing the dealer reaction as very favorable, key manufacturers of the Jamestown Furniture Market which opened today to continue through Wednesday, May 5,

Withdrawal of the United States Table Tennis Association from the International Table Tennis Federation was announced today by Carl Zeisberg, president, who said the action was voted by the executive committee. "Our step is designed to simplify efficient reorganization

Although the market for the higher grade bonds held fairly steady through most of yesterday's session in the face of broad declines among the secondary and convertible issues, prices softened in late trading. This led to a close at generally lower levels in almost all sections of listed bonds on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Spring Coffee Dance, the final in the series of Coffee Dances for this season, was held last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. Many E dinners preceded the event, the hosts and hostesses taking their guests later to the clubhouse for coffee and dancing.

The Federal Government collected $4,027,713,039 in the July 1-April 23 period of the current fiscal year from sources of revenue other than borrowing. If this sum had been allocated evenly each man, woman and child in the country would have contributed $155 during the period.

General Francisco Franco's troops entered Durango, the key to Bilbao, at 7 o'clock this evening. Eibar, a town of 25,000 inhabitants and the site of one of Spain's largest arms factories, was taken this morning. [The Basques set fire to Eibar before fleeing, other sources state.]

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today the following additional applications from New York City for registration as brokers and dealers in the over-thecounter market (Symbols: S, Sole proprietor; P, Partnership; C, Corporation):

Eleven members of the Princeton University faculty and twenty-six undergraduates have been elected to the 1937-38 board of directors of the Student-Faculty Association, campus social service organization, it was announced today by Laurence Fenninger, '09, the association's director.

A Wagner festival will be presented at the Lewisohn Stadium this Summer under the direction of Fritz Reiner, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of the Stadium Concerts.

The University of Virginia's undefeated tennis team scored its ninth consecutive victory of the season today by turning back the Princeton racquetmen, 5 to 3. Rain squalls and high wind hindered the contestants throughout the afternoon.

Wage-earners above 65 years of age who are engaged in employment covered by the State UnemPloyment Insurance Law were urged yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews to apply at postoffices for Federal social security account numbers.

Undeterred by another fall on the Stock Exchange that lopped more than [Pound]200,000,000 off the listed value of speculative shares today, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced the flotation Thursday of a short to medium term defense loan of [Pound]100,000,000.

Mischa Rosenbaum, 31-year-old theatrical agent, also known as Mischa Ross, pleaded not guilty yesterday before Judge William Allen in General Sessions on a charge of murder in the first degree for the killing of Julia Nussenbaum, night-club violinist, on April 18.

General recessions ruled throughout the stock market list today, with some forced liquidation in evidence. Gilt-edge securities held steady, while among the foreign, the only activity was a little profit-taking in German bonds.

A proposal to make registration of all trade-marks mandatory was discussed at the convention here today of the Association of National Advertisers, and some members expressed a feeling that the Federal Registration Act might be amended to eliminate many of the trademarks registered in Washington which have not been used for many years.

Manufacturers of iron and steel in the Newcastle-on-Tyne district of England are having difficulty in satisfying the domestic demand and at the same time meet export commitments, a report received by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce discloses.
President Roosevelt signed a new Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill today, setting up a "little NRA" for the bituminous coal industry.

Albert Montlake, accused by Federal authorities of having helped the old Dillinger gang to dispose of its robbery loot, was shot to death in a gangland assassination tonight in the South Shore district. He had a fortune in diamonds in his pockets and his car.

Late of the Group Theatre and now a producer in her own right, Cheryl Crawford has visions of starting her schedule next October. The first item might be a play about Thomas Jefferson by Melvin Levy-he has been working on it for a couple of months on a monthly retainer basis, and is expected to finish it by July. Miss Crawford herself does not plan to direct this or other plays she will present.

Madison St, 216, 5-story building. 26.1x100; Herman Goldner against Arthur Mc C. Conger; due. $1.376; taxes, ,. $1,873; to plaintiff for $500. By ROBERT FISHEL 30th St. 20 W, 5-story loft and store building, 27x98.9; New York Life Insurance Co against 20 West Thirtieth Street Corp; due. $10.583: to plaintiff for $30.000.

There is an old custom (still kept in some parts of the British Isles) called "beating the bounds." It consists of a processional encircling of a borough by its inhabitants-men, women and children walking or riding around it to keep themselves mindful of their possessions and especially to teach the children their inherited borders.

The number of homeless men receiving relief in this city declined by 21 per cent in the last six months as compared with the same period in 1935-36, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday.

Social snobbishness and any sense of official superiority will not be tolerated from the vast corps of civil servants in the Third Reich.
