Dr. Wilhelm Frick, Reich and Prussian Interior Minister, who addressed the "half-week convention" of civil servants here today, asserted that it was the National Socialist government's wish to democratize this type of government employee.

Mrs. L. Harrison Dulles of Philadelphia, who is at the Plaza, will sail tomorrow on the Normandie. Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer will sail tomorrow on the Aquitania for the coronation. They will return in June to their place in Southampton.

The Princeton golfers, playing over the rain-soaked Springdale course, defeated the University of Virginia, 5 1/2 to 31/2, today. It was the second Nassau victory in three starts. Ed Clark, Tiger sophomore, scored easily over Dick Payne, 3 and 2.

Mrs. Ida A. Meyerson Belinky, long active in Jewish philanthropic organizations in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn and wife of Heyman Belinky, a retired business man, died on Saturday at her home, 982 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was 62 years old.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today that bids of $289,790,000 had been received by the Treasury for two series of Treasury bill offerings of $50,000,000 each and that an aggregate of $100,076,000 had been accepted. The average rate
Susanne Fisher, Metropolitan Opera soprano, will be the solist at the Spring concert of the Apollo Club in the Brooklyn Academy of Music tonight. Alfred Boyce will conduct.

Claiming a majority of the 4,200 employes of the Postal Telegraph Company, the Commercial Telegraphers Union announced yesterday through Willard Bliss, organizer, that it planned to submit charges today to the National Labor Relations Board accusing the company of discrimination.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 21 shows a decrease of $25,000,000 in total loans and investments, increases of $84,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $13,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of $79,000,000 in government deposits, $116,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $56,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.
All general organization stores now in operation in the city high schools are being liquidated, David H. Moskowitz, director of high school organization, disclosed yesterday.
Production lines were rolling today in the General Motors of Canada plant for the first time in eighteen days, as 3,700 workers went peacefully back to their machines.

Jamaica, defending Queens P. S. A. L. champion, remained undefeated in seven games as it scored its fifth straight league victory, outscoring Cleveland, 5-4, at Farmers Stadium yesterday. The loss was the first in three circuit starts for Cleveland. Co-captain Bob McBride of Jamaica drove a home run with one on in the fifth.
A world sugar agreement calculated to net producers an additional $35,000,000 to $40,000,000 annually through stabilized prices was being drafted tonight by delegates to the International Conference.

Dr. Jean Piccard announced today that he was planning a twomile ascent into the stratosphere with eighty small balloons. He said the proposed flight would probably be made near Rochester, Minn., some time in June, and would be a forerunner to one he was planning for next year with several thousand balloons.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 23: CAPTAIN McCain, J. S., to command the Ranger instead of the Lexington; orders of March 26 modified.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation will hold one of the most important meetings in the history of the company this afternoon, as the principal decision to be made is whether to eliminate current dividend arrears of $39,630,921 on the company's 3,602,811 preferred shares and thus write finis to the depression era for the 217,055 registered stockholders.

The marriage of Miss Frances Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hall Myers of this city, to Lawrence Cremin Gaynor, son of Arthur C. Gaynor of Stratford and the late Mrs. Gaynor, took place here this morning in St. Augustine's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas B. Gloster.

Thirty-eight scholarship awards for study next year in the Columbia University School of Business were announced yesterday by Dean Roswell C. McCrea. Eight of the grants went to students who will major in accounting with the goal of becoming certified public accountants.

The British Government will pay United Kingdom coal mine owners ??66,450,000 in return for extinction of their claims to all future royalties, which will become the property of the government, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin announced in the House of Commons today.

A man who keeps his hat on in the presence of women in a bar and grill is a potential disturber of the peace and therefore is guilty of disorderly conduct, Magistrate Michael A. Ford ruled yesterday in suspending sentence on James Phillips, 25 years old, of 418 East Seventy-second Street.
THE DREYFUS CASE, by Alfred Dreyfus and his son, Pierre Dreyfus. (Yale University Press, $3.75.) The complete and intimate story of the case based on Alfred Dreyfus's journals.

Miss Elizabeth Taylor Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight G. Stone of this place, has chosen her sister, Miss Janet Van Vranen Stone, as maid of honor for her wedding to Franklin F. Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin E. Pierce, also of West Hartford.
Marquis James, Pulitzer Prize winner for his biography of Sam Houston, was unable to complete the second volume of his biography of Andrew Jackson in time for Spring publication.

Reports here yesterday indicated that negotiations are under way for the purchase of a store in Washington, D. C., which would become the first unit in the cooperative league of department stores planned by E. A. Filene, Boston merchant.
Drastic restriction of the powers held by the Board of Examiners to reject teachers taking licensing examinations was recommended yesterday by Edward Mandel, Associate Superintendent of Schools.

James F. Jackson, chairman of the Boston Elevated Railway public trustees from 1919 to 1925, and past chairman of the Massachusetts Railroad Commission, died yesterday at his home in Winchester. He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage a week ago. His age was 85.
Dr. A. L. Norfleet of 10 East Ninety-third Street, retired physician and banker, died Saturday in the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center of cirrhosis of the liver at the age of 79. He was born in
The Association of American Rhodes Scholars in the last month has collected $73,000 in the worldwide appeal for an endowment fund recently issued by Oxford University.

Statements by speakers that the morale of the anthracite interests has been restored through the cooperative promotional activities of the Anthracite Industries, Inc., featured an all-day session of 600 executives of companies supporting the industry-wide project at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

President Roosevelt signed the Guffey-Vinson Coal Bill and appointed a commission to administer it, appointed a mediation board to act in the threatened strike on Eastern railroads, withdrew the nomination of Murray Latimer as a member of the Social Security Board and received numerous callers, among them Chairman Connery of the House Labor Committee, with whom he discussed at lunch labor and industrial legislation.
The Providence College freshman nine blanked its Yale class rival today, 16 to 0, by superior batting and fielding. Pitcher Kewasnewski allowed the Yale yearlings only two hits.
Austria - and Hungary, dismembered segments of the old Hapsburg Empire, are build-

Howard Bergman outscored Lester Fisher, 175-89, in the Poggen. burg Memorial Cup 18.2 balkline billiard play at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night in fifteen innings. Bruno Klerings defeated Leonard Coleman, 125-67, in twenty-nine frames.
Claus Spreckles Jr. and Jane E. Turner, both of San Diego, made application for a marriage license here today. They plan to marry Saturday morning in a Catholio church in Coronado.

Acting Special Sessions Justice Henry H. Curran imposed a $500 fine with the alternative of a tenday jail sentence yesterday on Jack Criton, truck driver for the H. Feuerstein Coal Company, South and Roosevelt Streets, who was convicted of delivering short-weight coal to a West Forty-third Street hotel.

Many box seats have been purchased for the all-Stravinsky program to be presented tonight and tomorrow night by the American Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House in aid of the ballet's scholarship fund.
Commercial failures in the United States totaled 191 for the week ended April 22, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

Several thousand blooms were exhibited at the annual narcissus show of the Westbury (L. I.) Horticultural Society, which opened yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Horticultural Society at the headquarters of the latter society, 598 Madison Avenue. The show will continue today, free to the public, from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M.

By common consent among most of the Republicans in Congress, all possible benefits have been derived from the groundhog policy they have deliberately pursued since the President sent his Supreme Court Bill to the Capitol.
The Duke of Windsor won from his Austrian place of self-exile today a fight to have a British book about him taken out of circulation.

Members of the bridal party in the wedding of Miss Shirley Newkirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Warren Newkirk, to John Hamilton Tyson 2d, which will take place tomorrow, were entertained at luncheon today by Miss Dorothy Newkirk, sister of the prospective bride, at the home of her parents.

It was inadvertently stated in a news story on this page last week that Joseph Burkholz, chairman of the committee to curb glove imports, is connected with the Max Mayer Company. Mr. Burkholz is president of the Max Mayer Glove Manufacturing Company of Brooklyn.

Services will be held tomorrow at 8 P. M. at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, West Sixty-fifth Street and Central Park West, Manhattan, for the Rev. Dr. George Linn Kieffer, statistician of the National Lutheran Council, who died suddenly on Sunday while addressing a gathering at Christ Lutheran Church, Rosedale, Queens. Burial will be in Millersburg, Pa., Friday morning.

Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Legislature urging acceptance of his proposal to add a fourth cent to the per-gallon tax on gasoline which would bring in about $20,000,000 and restore his budget to balance.

Parimutuel betting at race tracks was endorsed tonight by the State Racing Commission for the third straight year, to be conducted "side by side" with the present book wagering. In its annual report to the Legislature the commission said that
Mr. LA GUARDIA'S linguistic talents continue to astound. Every day brings new proofs of his extraordinary range.

Senator John J. Dunnigan and Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr. introduced a bill tonight to permit the City of New York to build a spur into the World's Fair grounds from its independent subway line in Queens.

The Pennroad Corporation, a holding company controlled by the Pennsylvania Railroad management, continued in a dominant position in the control of the Boston Maine Railroad, according to the last named company's report to the Interstate Commerce Commission issued yesterday.

Business activity in the wholesale dress market picked up slightly last week, but the gains made were not sufficient to bring the industry out of the dull period which has gripped it during the last few weeks, according to the report issued yesterday by the research and statistics department of the joint board of the Dress and Waistmakers' Union.

Intimations that a dual program for the regulation of industry and labor would be proposed by the administration if the President's Supreme Court reorganization plan went through Congress were heard today after the Miller-Tydings price agreement bill was ordered pigeonholed by - the White House.

A powerful -east wind shifting from a southerly to a northerly direction swept in a gale along the Atlantic Coast last night, turning Spring into Autumn in the sixth successive day of unusually cool weather. More of it, with rain, is expected today.

The Fordham University golf team defeated Manhattan College, 7-2, at the Oak Ridge Country Club today. Sam Nield of Manhattan defeated Captain Vic Del Guercio, 1 up, and then paired with Edward Kringle to turn back Del Guercio and Pat O'Hara, 2 up.

In a conciliatory reply to Mohandas K. Gandhi, Richard Austen Butler, Parliamentary Undersecretary of the India Office, told the House of Commons today that the Indian Provincial Governors would not use their special powers--the crux of the present impasse resulting from the Congress party's refusal to accept office in the six provinces it controls--"for detailed interference in administration."

Some of the most important works of art of Madrid's famous Prado Museum will soon be exhibited in Paris, cording to an announcement by Max Aub, art attache of the Spanish Embassy here. The works to be exhibited include paintings by Velasquez, El Greco and Goya.
The Lehman Corporation, it was learned yesterday, has sold its holding of New York Steam Company common stock to the Consolidated Edison Company of New York.

Mayor La Guardia renewed his drive yesterday against pin-ball games that pay the player in cash in a letter to Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine directing enforcement of the law against such devices.

Ignoring both low temperatures and high winds, the Dodgers played a ball game with the Boston Bees at Ebbets Field yesterday and enjoyed it even less than the 2,278 fans who were hardy enough to pay for the doubtful privilege of watching it.

The six-story apartment house at 405 Seventy-eighth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold to the Fradin Realty Corporation, who utilized a purchase money mortgage and paid cash over a first mortgage of $100,000. The Adnorma Holding Corporation was the seller. Gettinger Gettinger, attorneys, negotiated the deal.

Total expenditures of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., exceeded by $7,000,000 last year the total receipts from the company's sales in Canada, Wallace R. Campbell, president of the Canadian company, reported at the annual meeting of shareholders today.

After a three-hour conference at City Hall yesterday between representatives of The Long Island Daily Press and the New York Newspaper Guild, Mayor La Guardia announced that both sides had reached an agreement that would end the strike started by the Guild against the newspaper on April 5.

A period of comparative quiet- settled yesterday over the wholesale liquor market as wholesalers began returning to normal discount schedules after four days of sharp competition for volume. Distributors of only one or two large distilling corporations were quoting discounts higher than the industry standard of 2 to 5 per cent, depending on quantities, late yesterday.

Pauline Weissman gave a mortgage for $6.000, due in four years at 4 per cent with $125 paid off semi-annually. on 92 Lewis St, which she bought from the 92 Lewis St Corp on April 23. For a consideration of $4.000 Florence M. Lalor assigned to Teresa Sargent and Mildred 0. Canessa. Lynn, Mass.. a mortgage for $12,000 on 301 E 106th St, given on Oct l0, 1904.

The current slump in sales of both gray and finished goods, fear of overproduction and pressure from labor groups will force a return to the forty-hour week and elimination of the third shift in the great majority of cotton mills which have adopted it, according to comment in the Worth Street district yesterday.

Plans for the early occupany and opening ceremonies for several government-owned branch postoffices in New York were announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman. The new stations will replace quarters formerly rented from private property owners.

General Francisco Franco's recent decree uniting the Carlists, Phalanxists [Fascists] and Renovationists in one organization under his leadership for the civil war's duration has been accepted with enthusiasm by the various elements supporting him.

Plans for a six-story fifty-one family apartment house to be built on the 78 by 195-foot plot at 39-43 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, were filed yesterday. The new structure is expected to cost $280,000. The Nuns of the Order of St. Dominic, Holy Cross Convent, also ta filed plans for a three-story brick high school, to cost $250,000,

The Phillips-Jones Corporation, manufacturers of shirts, collars and pajamas, will establish a branch plant at Arthurdale, the resettlement community in Preston County, W. Va., according to announcement yesterday by the Committee for Economic and Social Progress.
John C. R. Taylor, attorney and former State Senator, died today at his home, 75 Highland Avenue, after a long illness. He was an uncle of Assemblyman Rainey S. Taylor of Middletown. His age was 71.

Bucking a nor'easter and menaced by a fast-closing rival, Jimmie Cabaniss, a gelded son of Ormont, stuck by his running guns long enough to win the Laurel Claiming Handicap, the mile-and-seventyyard feature, at this track today. Jimmie Cabaniss refused to yield
The Rev. William Fraser McDowell, retired Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died at his home here today of a heart attack. He was 79 years old.

Bruised and dizzy after a night in which 35-foot waves battered their boat and winds reached a velocity of 65 miles an hour a Congressional party returned to the capital this morning, most of them determined never again to brave Chesapeake Bay.

Arthur Douglas Stone, a retired New York woolen goods commission merchant, died here yesterday at his home. He was 73 years old. Mr. Stone retired from business in 1930 and became a collector of rare books and prints. He was a former president of the Mount Vernon Garden Club.

John Milton of Jersey City was allowed today a counsel fee of $40,000, one of the largest ever authorized in Union County, by Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan in connection with his work as solicitor for the trustee in liquidation of the New Jersey Fidelity and Plate Glass Insurance Company of Newark. Carl F. Witchers,

Eleven railroad are affected by the order of President Roosevelt today creating an emergency board to investigate the dispute between the railroads and the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, Freight Handlers, Express and Station Employes, referred to generally as the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks.
Enrico Venturi of Italy was forced to the limit to win an eight-round decision from Mickey Duca of Paulsboro at Laurel Garden tonight. Venturi weighed 141 1/4 pounds and Duca 135 1/2.

The Y. W. C. A. of the City of New York had a total membership of 17,868 women and girls at the end of 1936, it was announced yesterday in the annual report of Miss Margaret Webster, general secretary. A total of 18,649 persons were

F. Burton Fisher, business promotion manager of the Hotel Plaza, was elected president of the Greater New York Hotel Sales Managers Association at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt last night. He fills the vacancy left by Hugh J. Connor, business promotion manager of the Roosevelt, who last month was elected to the presidency of the national organization. Joseph P.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today called a hearing for May 17 on a declaration by the National Gas and Electric Corporation, New York City, covering the issue and sale of $400,000 of firstlien collateral trust bonds, sixteenyear, 5 per cent, Series B, due on April 1. 1953; 35.000 shares

Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie from his annual trip through Europe to visit Warner Studios and study conditions in the film industry. He said that during the next year his company would produce sixty films, several of them in color. One of the early productions

Miss Mildred Iliffe Feely, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Alan Feely of Edely, this place, was married to Vincent Gavin Hart, son of Mrs. William J. Hart of New York and the late Mr. Hart of Buffalo, at noon today in St.Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Narberth by the Rev. Vincent F. Hamilton.

No stocks or groups of stocks escaped the heavy selling on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Because of a further break in the price of non-ferrous metals abroad, the copper group probably suffered the heaviest decline.
The Newark Bears went on an extra-base hitting rampage and registered their fifth straight International League victory today, defeating Rochester's Red Wings, 9 to 7.

George A. Ball, glass manufacturer of Muncie, Ind., who bought control of a $3,000,000,000 railway and real estate empire at a creditors' sale on Vesey Street in 1935 for a little more than $3,000,000, announced yesterday that this control had been sold to two members of a New York Stock Exchange firm and a director of a Wilkes-Barre bank for an undisclosed price.

New York's "tube railway" is "the most intensified form of hell during its rush hours there ever has been," Captain Austin U. M. Hudson, Parliamentary Secretary of the Transport Ministry, assured the House of Commons today. The members listened in horror as he continued:

The $7,917,660 Highway Fund Diversion Bill for Unemployment Relief passed the State Senate last night over the veto of Governor Harold G. Hoffman by a vote of 11 to 7. The Democratic House of Assembly adjourned shortly before midnight and met again an hour later and adopted the measure by a vote of 32 to 5, which was one vote more than the necessary majority of 31.

H. P. Headley's Old Nassau, one of the more lightly regarded Kentucky Derby candidates, scored an impressive victory at Keeneland Park today in the feature offering at one mile and a sixteenth to atone for two previous disappointments.

Miss Jessie Simpson, who two years ago was voted "Miss Hackensack" and who has represented the city in beauty pageants, fell under the wheels of an Erie Railroad train this morning and suffered the loss of both her legs.

The settlement of the boys' clothing discount controversy, reached last Saturday in Pittsburgh between Irwin D. Wolf, chairman of the vendors' relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, and Abraham Landau,

Influenced by a combination of weak outside markets and liquidation of the May position preparatory to notices today, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke $1 a bale yesterday, declining into new low ground for the movement and ending with losses of 18 to 27 points.

Accidents, deaths and the number of persons injured in traffic within the city limits declined again last week and week-end, figures made public yesterday by the Police Department showed. The data were based on comparisons with corresponding periods of 1936.
Henry H. Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Motor Company, said today that settlement of the strike in the Richmond (Calif.) Ford plant included no provision for dealing with the union.

President Roosevelt put his administration on record today as being opposed to speculation by government employes in stocks, bonds or commodities. In a letter to Harry B. Mitchell, president of the Civil Service Commission, he stated that engagement in such activities should be a factor in passing on retentions or promotions in the service.
Two more large companies have declined, in reporting to the Securities and Exchange Commission, to state the remuneration of officers and directors on the customary form. The Sloss-Sheffield
Jose Ferrer Morejon, leader of the Democratic bloc in the House of Representatives, tonight challenged Eduardo Suarez Rivas, the Republican leader, to a duel. It is expected to be fought this week.

An issue of 350,000 shares of $1 par common stock of Monogram Pictures Corporation is being offered today at $3.75 a share by J. A. Sisto Co., to provide the company with additional capital for expansion. Authorized capital

James Bridie's comedy "What It Is to Be Young," revived at the Q Theatre tonight, must set the playwright's admirers wondering how it ever came to be written, according to The Times of London, since "it strains the fancy to suppose that even the author himself is amused."

Funeral services for Mrs. Helen Kim Mont, actress bride of a month who ended her life Saturday in her apartment at 480 Park Avenue, were held yesterday at the Constantinides Funeral Parlors, 186 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.

H. N. Elterich, in charge of export advertising for N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., New York office, for the last four years, will form his own advertising agency to specialize in export advertising. Under the name H. N. Elterich, Inc., he will open offices on Monday at 205 East Forty-second Street.

IT was a gloomy day, filled with low clouds and driving rain, and along came a gent who made it worse. It was Fred Corcoran from Boston, the tournament manager of the Professional Golfers Association.

Jim Gilson, sophomore outfielder playing in his first college game, hit a home run with the bases full in the eighth inning to give Colgate a 10-7 victory over Clarkson Tech today. The game was poorly played, cold weather causing loose ball handling.

Retired Captain John F. Scanlan, formerly a member of H. and L. 122, residing at Ballycannon, County Limerick. Ireland. died April 11. Retired Captain Michael J. Heslan, formerly a member of Engine 205. reading at Washington Ave., Hillsdale, N. J., died April 24.
The American Ballet covered itself with honor last night in the first presentation of three ballets by Stravinsky at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Research scientists at the University of Toronto have produced a new insulin preparation more effective in treatment of diabetes than earlier compounds, Dr. H. J. Cody, president of the university, told an alumni dinner here.

Headed by Marshall Field's Americanowned Foray, eighteen three-yearold colts are expected to face the barrier tomorrow in the Two Thousand Guineas, first of the season's classics to be run over one mile At Newmarket.

Forty officials of the leading educational institutions of the East, including fifteen or sixteen college presidents, a dozen deans and heads of preparatory schools, paid honor to President William Allan Neilson last night in this city in celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the day he became head of Smith College.

Regulation of freight-forwarding companies by the Interstate Commerce Commission was urged yesterday by W. J. H.McEntee, vice president of Acme Fast Freight, Inc., at a hearing before Claude R. Porter of the Interstate Commerce Commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

The statement of the SoconyVacuum Oil Company, Inc., for 1936, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $42,909,362 after expenses, taxes, reserves for depreciation and depletion and other charges, equal to $1.38 a share on the 31,151,071 capital shares outstanding.

The United States Military Academy today announced the award of 121 athletic insignia to members of seven Winter sports squads. The major "A" was awarded to six of the basketball team and Clarence R. Bess, who won the 115 pound championship in the Eastern intercollegiate boxing tournament.

The Brown University freshman baseball team defeated the Harvard freshmen, 3 to 2, on Soldiers Field today in a five-inning game called because of rain. Nelson, shortstop for the visitors, got two hits in three trips to the plate, one of them a home run.
Weakness in the stock market here today was alleviated by a slight recovery for some issues in late trading. Gilt-edged issues joined in the declines and most foreign loans receded.

The Pennsylvania Society's medal for outstanding achievement, given to Pennsylvanians for public service, has been awarded to Dr. Victor G. Heiser, epidemiologist, formerly of the Rockefeller Foundation, it was announced yesterday at the thirty-ninth annual luncheon meeting of the organization in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
New stories of terrorism and brutality in Harlan County, Ky., were told this afternoon before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee.
Two and a half weeks in Chicago will be enough for "Red, Hot and Blue!" which will end its run at the Grand Opera House out there on Saturday night.

Mrs. Ivah Wills Coburn, actress, wife of Charles D. Coburn, with whom she had appeared in a great number of theatrical productions In the last thirty-five years, died early yesterday morning in Lenox Hill Hospital after a week's illness of intestinal influenza.
Paul V. McNutt, new High Commissioner to the Philippines, spent his second day here receiving calls from and paying calls to United States Army and Navy officers and Philippine officials.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,496,400 barrels, a new high record, compared with 3,463,550 in the preceding week, an increase of 32,850, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The sale and improvement of property along the Manhattan waterfront have been adversely affected for many years because title to such land has been under the cloud of old water-grant covenants, Governor Lehman was told in a letter from the. First Avenue Association, Inc., L. Gordon Hamersley, president, in which the Governor was urged to sign the Brownell bill which recently passed the Legislature.
The City of New York is without power, the Court of Appeals decided today, to impose a tax in addition to the one agreed to in the franchise agreement during the term of the agreement.

Herman B. Silberstein, vice president of the Dreyfuss Art Company, Inc., with which he had been associated for twelve years, died on Monday night in his home at 255 West Ninety-eighth Street after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

An 18-year-old Cuban girl attempted suicide yesterday in the government barge office at South Ferry while being taken to Ellis Island as an illegal immigrant. The girl, Sara J. Rodriguez, was in Ellis Island Hospital last night, but her condition was not serious.

Fred J. Fisher of Detroit, formerly an executive of the General Motors Corporation, today told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he "couldn't afford" to promise General Motors business to a company in which he bought stock as a personal investment or speculation.

Herbert L. Bowman of New York was one of the players to advance today in the men's singles of the invitation tennis tournament of the Hot Springs Golf and Tennis Club before rain interrupted the program.

Professor Philip Schuyler Allen, who had taught at the University of Chicago since 1894 and in late years had been one of the legendary figures on the campus, died at his home here of a heart attack this morning. He was 65 years old.

Officials of B'nai B'rith, Jewish fraternal organization, said today they had been given to understand that Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in a letter to be sent soon to Alfred M. Cohen of Cincinnati, president of the organization, would set forth his views concerning the recent dissolution of B'nai B'rith in Germany.

Plans for two new six-story tenement houses in Manhattan were filed today. One of the buildings will be erected at 842-50 Ninth Avenue and 357-75 West Fifty-fifth Street, on a plot 200 by 100.5 feet, and will cost $300,000. The second will be built at 120-30 Bennett Avenue and will cost $250,000.

A restatement of the anti-trust laws to restore their force, weakened by the passage of time and crippled by court decisions, was recommended to President Roosevelt today by Attorney General Cummings in a report on identical bids for government contracts by the large steel companies.

Stepin Fetchit, the Negro film comedian, whose skull was fractureed Sunday when his automobile crashed into an elevated pillar, was reported in a "somewhat improved" condition and "doing nicely" last night at Gotham Hospital, 30 East Seventy-sixth Street.

The four Scandinavian governments of Norway, Sweden, Denmark and Finland have through their legations at Lisbon presented notes in similar terms to the local representative of General Francisco Franco protesting the seizure of neutral shipping in Spanish waters.
President Roosevelt nominated Harry H. Woodring today to be Secretary of War. The former Governor of Kansas has been in that office since the death in August of Secretary George H. Dern.

SENIOR SUPERINTENDING MARINE ENGINEER, $4,600 a year: Quartermaster Corps, War Department, Applicantions must be on file not later than May 24 if received from States other than those named below; May 27 if received from the following States; arizona, California, Colorado, idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.

OF GREAT RICHES, by Rose Franken. (Longmans, Green, $2.50.) A novel by the author of "Another Language." IN DEFENSE OF CAPITALISM, by James H. R. Cromwell and Hugo E. Czerwonky. (Scribner, $3.50.) On capitalism and the money system.

Beginning today, temporary Florida Power Corporation first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series C, due Dec. 1, 1966, may be exchanged for definitive bonds with coupons at the corporate trust department of the main office of the Guaranty Trust Company.

The Alumni Association of Public School 6, Eighty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue, held its second reunion dinner at the Hotel Del monico last night. About 300 men who were graduated from the school from 1895 to 1914 attended the dinner.

Miss Elizabeth Gilmor Locke, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Locke of Williamstown, who will be married to Dr. John Hillyer Boyd of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. F. Hillyer Boyd of Toronto, Ont., on May 8, has chosen her sister, Miss Jane Swann Locke, as maid of honor.

Putnam Co. won yesterday the award of a new issue of $230,000 of refunding bonds of the town of Killingly, Conn., on a bid of 101.43 for 3s. The bonds are dated April 1, 1937, and will mature on April 1, 1938 to 1957.

General Emilio Mola's Insurgent army plowed through the smoldering ruins of Eibar today toward the last tottering defenses of Bilbao. Basque militiamen fled in disorder along the sixteen-mile Durango-Bill bao highway.
Andrew L. McMaster, Montreal lawyer and former Provincial , Treasurer of Quebec, died here suddenly today at the age of 60 in the home of his son-in-law, Jonathan Robinson.

A simple but most sincere tribute was paid to the memory of Viscount Grey of Fallodon by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today at the ceremony of unveiling a memorial tablet affixed to the wall of the Foreign Office, where, as Sir Edward Grey, he presided during the war.

The Postoffice Department began yesterday to issue applications for social security account numbers to persons beyond the age of 65. More than 100 applications were received in Room 4518 of the General Postoffice Annex, Thirty-third Street and Ninth Avenue.
Janice Jarratt and Melvin Purvis went their separate ways tonight, both noncommittal on the sudden postponement of their marriage only two days before their wedding date.

More than half of the banking resources of the United States on Dec. 31 were concentrated in four StatesNew York, Pennsylvania, Illinois and California-the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today in issuing details of the condition of these financial institutions as of that date. Totals for all banks already have been made public.

Captain Frank Huckabone of Brooklyn said today he would raise the tug Cherokee, which overturned last night near Lock 16 in the State Barge Canal, plunging him and six members of his crew into six feet of water.

There is a wider gap today between what could be done and what is done to control disease and prolong life than in any previous period in history, Dr. Howard W. Haggard of Yale University said here today.

Sergeant Major Daniel Daly, U. S. M. C., retired, who during his twenty years of service won eleven medals, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, 78-45 Sixty-fourth- Place, Glendale, Queens. He was 63 years old.
The four-story private dwelling at 21 East Eightieth Street has been sold by the Bank for Savings, represented by Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft, to the Oshlag interests, represented by Marks Marks.

Conferees trying to find a basis for negotiation in the thirty-four-day-old shoe strike struck a snag on a basic issue tonight, after an all-day session during which "remarkable" progress was reported.

Rudie may be only a sprinter, as most racegoers have concluded since William H. Gallagher sent the colt to the races at Hialeal Park last Winter, but he found the sloppy track at Jamaica yesterday so much to his liking that he went a mile and seventy yards in the featured Victorian Purse, with his competition floundering behind him.

The trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford were authorized today by Judge Carroll C. Hincks to apply to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to abandon three segments of railroad-Slatersville to Harrissville,

Charles Polescheck, 31 years old, a WPA worker, of 121 East 123d Street, one of two persons who were shot Sunday night while attending a meeting of the WorkerS Alliance at 222 East 119th Street, died early yesterday morning. Aurora Sanchez, 13 years old, was shot in the leg.

The first fifty-one railroads to report for March, which companies earn about 90 per cent of the gross revenues of all the railroads, showed an increase of 92.3 per cent in net operating income for the month.

Arturo Godoy, Chilean ace, is the betting favorite over Tony Galento of Newark in the ten-round feature bout at the New York Hippodrome tonight. Galento will have a thirtypound advantage over the South American, who tips the beam at 200 pounds.

Japan led the world in the number of new products introduced in 1936, Commerce Department reports made public today indicate. Among the new products developed in Japanese research laboratories and now being marketed are two new dyes for the printing ink industry, a non-coloring enamel, a fumigant, a chemical known as "sofna" used for softening food, a smallpox vaccine and a sleeping sickness serum.

In preparation for "Stewart Week," beginning May 3, when women executives will operate Arnold Constable Co., Fifth Avenue department store, Miss Laurette Yonkers, underwear buyer, yesterday took over the duties of Isaac Liberman as president, while Miss Pearl Friend, head of the misses' dress department, succeeded Meyer Liberman as vice president.

Inevitably, General FRANCO has prescribed a salute for the civilian followers he has lately ordered to merge their differences in a united front. They are to extend the right arm upward and outward at an angle of forty-five degrees.

In a flag-bedecked and canopied setting which contrasted sharply with the bleak grayness of the weather, Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair Corporation, assisted by city officials and civic leaders, laid the cornerstone yesterday for the administration building, the first structure to be started on the Flushing Meadows site of the fair.

Representatives of retail liquor stores in this vicinity accused the Seagram Distillers Corporation of Massachusetts at a Federal Trade Commission yesterday at 45 Broadway of refusing to permit the resale of their products except at prices fixed by the company.
Minimum Wage protection for women and children in industry was agina put on the statute books today when Governor Lehman signed the Fischel bill.

New York business men were urged yesterday by Samuel P. Gilman, general counsel of the New York Board of Trade, to take an active part in the city primaries next September to bring about economy in the municipal administration, reduce indebtedness and preserve the city's credit.

The Eastern Polo League will be restricted to fifteen teams this season, the organization announced last night after a meeting at the New York Athletic Club. Team entries will close on May 22 and outdoor play will start June 13.

While tennis experts predicted today the United States would defeat Japan in the Davis Cup zone play Friday, Saturday and Sunday, Don Budge and his American teammates were warned by Edward (Bud) Chandler, non-playing captain, "they cannot let down a minute if they expect to win."

A special type plane for the Army Air Corps, which has been built at the Lockheed plant at Burbank, Cailf., for experimental operation in the substratosphere will soon be submitted to acceptance tests as an experiments in high altitude operation of military and commercial aircraft.

Residents and business people of East Harlem breathed more easily yesterday when word was spread around that General Sessions Judge Allen had just sentenced Salvatore Scianti, 38 years old, of 360 East 121st Street, to a State's prison term of thirty years to life.

Action on a resolution against President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal and organization politics promise lively sessions at the council meeting of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, as a result of developments today.
Sale of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange for $106,000 was announced yesterday. The last previous transaction was on April 16, at $110,000.

Stocks rallied and closed higher in less active trading; turnover, 1,411,800 shares. United States Government, corporate and foreign bonds irregular in second slowest trading of the month; transactions, $8,957,700.

Some of the rugged juveniles of the gas-house district on the East Side put aside their boxing gloves yesterday afternoon and donned white aprons with flowing strings, so that they could enter a cooking contest at the Madison Square Boys Club, where the seventh annual Boys Week is being observed.
By a vote of 52 to 2, the Board of Aldermen adopted a liberalized compulsory city residence bill yesterday which would give city employes until next Jan. 1 to move into the city.

When John J. Pershing, General of the Armies, sails tomorrow to represent President Roosevelt at the coronation of King George VI he will carry one of the most gorgeous uniforms ever worn by an American officer.

An increase of 34.5 per cent in passenger revenue in 1936 from the total for 1935 was shown in the report of the Union Pacific Railroad for last year, issued yesterday. Compared with 1934, the increase was 62.6 per cent.
Eight hundred guests attended a testimonial dinner in honor of Frank W. Smith, retiring president of the Consolidated Edison Company, last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

W. Creighton Peet of Oyster Bay, L. I., has been appointed secretary of the Maritime Commission. Mr. Peet succeeds John Carson, whom President Roosevelt yesterday named consumers' counsel of the new National Bituminous Coal Commission, just a week after he was appointed to the Maritime Commission.

Turpentine firm, 35c; sales, 294 barrels; receipts, 453 barrels; shipments, 236 barrels; stock, 23,- 859 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 654; receipts, 1,425; shipments, 4,020; stock, 43,749. Quote; B. $7; D. $7.10; E. $7.10; E. $7.50; F, G, H, I, $8.071/2; K .M. $8.10; WG, $8.20; WW, X $8.90.

Organized business, as represented by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, began a drive today for amendment of the Wagner National Labor Relations Act and repeal or modification of the undistributed profits tax.
The new Japanese freighter Kamikawa Maru started to unload her freight yesterday morning at her pier at Thirty-third Street, Brooklyn, after completing her first voyage from Kobe and Yokohama.

Wealth is less important to successful parenthood than "firm but fair discipline," coupled with understanding, recognition and companionship, according to the consensus of 2,000 children ranging in age from 10 to 20 years.
The Swedish motorship Sandhamn of Stockholm cleared today at 3:30 P. M. with 4,500 tons of scrap metal for Wilmington, N. C., where the cargo will be completed to 7,500 tons consigned to Japan.

Thirty students from Lafayette College, at Easton, Pa., visited the Federal Court -in Brooklyn yesterday and witnessed the proceedings by which 230 persons were admitted to citizenship. Of the applicants for citizenship 130 were women. Judge Grover M. Moscowitz presided.

Brown, Harriman Co. and associates will offer today a new issue of $7,740.000 Pennsylvania Railroad Series H 2 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates, maturing $516,000 on May 1 from 1937 to 1952, inclusive. They are priced to yield 1.10 to 3.15 per cent, according to maturity.

Lincoln Ellsworth, who flew across the Antarctic Continent from the Wedell Sea to the Bay of Whales in the Ross Sea in December, 1935, has set himself a new goal-a flight as long and perilous across the opposite side of Antarctica, where the last great unexplored area of the earth lies.

The sirens of vessels from all parts of the world, anchored in the Pool of London, and the cheers of thousands of spectators lining the banks and wharves acclaimed King George VI, Queen Elizabeth and Princess Elizabeth today as they cruised down the Thames to open the National Maritime Museum at Greenwich.

The House of Representatives today appointed Marcelino Garriga, Liberal, and Antonio Bravo Acosta, National Democrat, to serve on the government commission studying the possibility of a resumption of payments on the defaulted public works bonds.

On the shores of the outlet just across from the banks of Onondaga Lake, the latest chapter in the fascinating book of intercollegiate rowing is being written as James A. Ten Eyck starts his thirty-fourth year as head coach of Syracuse University crews.

Copies of the proposed agreement under which the prices of books will be maintained under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act were sent to book publishers yesterday, following the completion of the work of the committee appointed by the National Association of Book Publishers to draft such an agreement.

Coast Guardsmen reported today that the Cape Henlopen Naval Compass Station received a wireless message that the Nova Scotia fishing steamer Lake Ormac had rescued "all hands" from a lifeboat of the fishing schooner Charles and Verna.

The Rivoli's new tenant this morning is "Cafe Metropole," a Twentieth Century-Fox item delineated by Tyrone Power, Loretta Young, Charles Winninger, Helen Westley and Gregory Ratoff, who also contributed the story. Jacques Deval,

Twelve colleges besides Brooklyn College, defending champion and host institution, will compete in the metropolitan Class B track and field championships at Randalls Island on Saturday, May 8, it was announced yesterday by Louis R. Oshins, Brooklyn business manager of athletics.
In twenty-two seasons in organized baseball Rogers Hornsby never has had a charley horse. His legs, from the calves up, are "as good as any youngster's,"
Five seniors at Barnard College have won foreign fellowships and scholarships, the administration announced yesterday.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today sold to the Triborough Bridge Authority $7,000,000 of the $35,000,000 bonds of the authority that it purchased from the Public Works Administration and exchanged the remaining $28,000,000

The Hungarian Supreme Court today overruled a threemonth sentence against Ferenc Szalassy, Hungarian Nazi leader, who had been imprisoned on. charges of inciting people against the State and the Jews.

The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Feb. 28, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $12,078,352, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to $2.21 a share on the common stock outstanding at the end of the period.

Danno O'Mahoney, Irish giant, threw Ed Meske of Akron, Ohio, in the feature wrestling bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Aggressive from the outset, O'Mahoney tossed Meske through the ropes and, after the Ohioan returned to the ring, dropped him with a body slam in 20 minutes and 3 seconds.

Union Ave (10-2673). w s 106 n of 168th St, 40x94; Jembe Realty Corp, to Loberg Realty Corp. 60 E 42d St. Hatting P1 (18-5524), n s 255 e of Pennyfield Ave. 30x100: James F. McKenna to Betty Landau. 1.920 Anthony Ave.
H. W. Warley, vice president of the Calmar Steamship Company, was re-elected president of the Maritime Association at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon.

Registration statements for proposed new securities filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission included: Albert Pick Company, Chicago-$771,846 of $1 par common stock, partly for working capital; underwriters, A. W. Porter, Inc., and Maurice Rothschild.

Robert L. Brookings, 34 years old, a West Point graduate, who for the last six years had been an aerial survey pilot for the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, plunged to his death yesterday afternoon from his room on the fourteenth floor of the Hotel BarbizonPlaza.

President Roosevelt today expressed an opinion that it would be for the general good if his policy of barring government employes from speculation could be more universally applied, illustrating his point with a story of an up-State New York community where 104 out of 125 families lost money in the market.

The three winners of the Hunter College contest for the best oneact play written by an undergraduate were announced yesterday by Mildred Sold, chairman of the dramatics committee at the college, which held the contest.

The deadlock over Governor Lehman's revenue program which began with the defeat in the Assembly of the Governor's bill to add a fourth cent to the per gallon tax on gasoline persisted tonight, but a belief prevailed that some definite action would be taken tomorrow to clear the muddle which has kept the Legislature in session overtime.

A big field of open jumpers will come into the ring of the Essex Troop Armory in Newark, N. J., at 7:30 o'clock tonight to inaugurate the seventeenth annual Newark horse show. The exhibition will continue through Saturday, with a matinee at 1:30 o'clock the last day.

President Roosevelt recreated his emergency flood committee today and left it with authority to mobilize the government's forces for aiding the Red Cross whenever the need arose. He did this at a conference at which he received encouraging reports of the flood situation from Admiral Cary T. Grayson, head of the Red Cross, and meteorologists.

Tony Rock of Scranton, Pa., making his initial New York appearance, stopped Eddie Carroll Of Ottawa in the feature eight-round boxing bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night. A crowd of 8,000 watched the contest, which ended in 2;06 of the third session.

The recently improved Lorenz ultra-short wave blind landing system, now in use on ten of the leading airlines of Europe, will be tested at Indianapolis by American Airlines this week, it was revealed yesterday in the offices of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, 67 Broad Street.
Although she rolled into fifth place in the all-events Mrs. Ella Burmeister of Madison, Wis., dropped her 1936 singles and allevents titles in the women's international bowling congress today.

Ending a five-day trial, a court here today sentenced to life imprisonment eight members of the Iron Guard convicted of killing a former comrade, Michael Stelescu, in a hospital in July, 1936. Two others who watched the doors during the killing were sentenced to ten years in the penitentiary.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Nelson Street of 22 East Thirty-sixth Street at a luncheon yesterday at the Pierre announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Street, to Ivy Lee Jr., son of Mrs. Ivy Lee of this city and the late Mr. Lee.

A jury-tampering story told in a booming voice by a florid WPA supervisor supplied a dramatic touch to the opening here today of the Federal Government's kidnapping case against Ellis H. Parker Sr., the 64-year-old detective, and his four co-defendants.
William Stewart, custodian of the chemical laboratory at Johns Hopkins University and known to thousands of graduates as "Old Bill," died today. He was 82 years old.

Patrolman Thomas O. Nolan of the Astoria precinct was cleared yesterday of criminal negligence in a fatal automobile accident in Jackson Heights last Dec. 9 when Judge Charles S. Colden instructed a jury in Queens County Court, Long Island City, to bring in a verdict of acquittal.

A one-year contract regulating working conditions in the editorial department of The Newark Star Eagle, a Paul Block newspaper, was signed today by the Newark Star Publishing Company and the Newark Newspaper Guild.

A suit to establish their right to place members with contractors building the Sixth Avenue subway was started in Supreme Court yesterday by Locals 102 and 45 of the Compressed Air, Tunnel, Subway and Sewer Construction Workers Union.
Edgar Bromberger, Deputy Sanitation Commissioner, will become a city magistrate in connection with a number of administration changes announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall.

A criticism of the nation's unpreparedness for war was offered today by the House Appropriations Committee in reporting favorably the 1938 Appropriation Bill for the War Department, carrying $416,413,382 in funds, an increase of $25,395,677 above last year but $358,079 below budget estimates.
President Leoni Cortes Castro virtually sentenced his brother Ricardo to thirty days in jail today for firing an unlicensed revolver.
Joseph B. Martin Jr., son of former Assistant Fire Chief "Smoky Joe" Martin and a battalion chief himself, was buried yesterday with departmental honors. He died Saturday in Flushing Hospital.

President Getulio Vargas signed a decree today granting a ninetyyear concession for the construction between Rio de Janeiro and Petropolis, twenty-two miles to the northeast, of an overhead electric transport line.
Plans were announced yesterday for a cruise of twenty-one and a half days by the French liner Normandie to the West Indies and South America, starting Feb. 11, 1938.
A commercial agreement has been signed between Argentina and the Netherlands, subject to ratification by the government of the Netherlands, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Warning against the "present hazard of undue advances in prices, with a resulting rise in the cost of living," President Roosevelt asked Congress today to postpone action on the Miller-Tydings bill to control prices of trade-marked articles in interstate commerce.

Five deaths from diphtheria reported during the week ending last Saturday brought the total for the sixteen weeks since the first of the year to twenty-four deaths, exactly four times as many as were reported in the corresponding period of 1936.

As second event in the Eastman School festival tonight' in the Eastman Theatre, the Eastman School Symphony Orchestra, Eastman School chorus and soloists presented a "founder's day" program, in memory of George Eastman.

Speaking before the Watertown Kiwanis Club yesterday, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne struck out at efforts that oppose postponing the opening of the bass season in Lake Ontario and the St. Lawrence River until July.

Edward Everett Horton and Lucien Littlefield, film actors, and Esther Dale, character player, were badly cut and bruised today when their automobile skidded off the rim of a 300-foot precipice near here.

High winds and heavy seas buffeted the Long Island and New Jersey coasts yesterday, stopping traffic on many waterfront highways. In the city, an inch of rain fell during the twelve hours from midnight to noon.

A proposal that Great Britain abandon its preferential trading system with empire countries and ?? foreign commercial policy more closely with that of America" was voiced today by James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council and former president of the United States Steel Corporation, in a discussion of foreign trade trends at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Dr. Thomas C. Poulter, scientist and second in command of the Byrd Antarctic expedition of 1933-35, was presented today a special gold medal of the National Geographic Society in a ceremony in Explorers' Hall of the society's building here.
Never since the general strike of 1926 have there been such ominous rumblings in the British trades union movement as are being heard today.
Bobby Doerr, 19-year-old Red Sox second baseman, suffered a slight brain concussion when accidentally beaned by Ed Linke of the Washington Senators yesterday, the X-ray films revealed today.

The recent mix-up over the purchase of raincoats by members of the Fire Department was somewhat straightened out yesterday when Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott ruled that non-regulation coats could be used until they were condemned or replaced.

Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of New York University, announced yesterday the award of twenty-four fellowships and scholarships in the Graduate School of Liberal Arts to graduate students of six States, upon the recommendation of Dean John Musser.

The first commercial shipment to the United States of Government House Rum, manufactured by the Virgin Islands Company, a PWA project, was unloaded from the Bull Line steamer Emilia in Brooklyn yesterday.

The law of 1935 which banned "heart balm" court actions was upheld today in respect to alienation of affections suits in a ruling by the Court of Appeals, which reversed an order of. the Appellate Division, second department, and the special term.

An order for a 100-Kilowatt output short-wave broadcasting unit, to be erected in Rome, has been placed by the Italian Broadcasting Company with the Electrical Apparatus Company of Milan, Italy, it was announced yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Company of New York.
A plan to buy a paper factory and issue preferred stock to raise the money for it will be submitted to shareholders of the Detroit Paper Products Corporation, meeting in Detroit on next Tuesday.

On his own application: PATROLMAN-Patrick Cullinan, 2d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed April 11, 1905. Transfer PATROLMAN-James J. McArdle, from 8th Division to 52d Precinct, assignment to clerical duty discontinued.
Lefty Bob Welland held the Pirates to six hits today as the Cardinals won, 3 to 1, and by doing so may have assured himself a regular berth with the Gas House Gang.
Ford Frick, president of the National League, yesterday fined Manager Burleigh Grimes of the Dodgers $25 for numerous remarks made to Umpire George (Tiny) Parker in Philadelphia last Sunday.
The Dessoff Choirs presented another characteristically rewarding program at the Town Hall last night. Secular music, old and new, was the order of the evening's performances. Ludwig Senfl,

The officers of next year's sophomore, junior and senior classes at Princeton University were announced today by the elections committee of the undergraduate council at the conclusion of the annual class-election period.
Miss Jean Saunders, formerly of Calgary, Alberta, today defeated Miss Mary Stewart, English star, 3-6, 6-1, 6-2, in the second round of the British hard-court tennis championships.

The residence at 167 Greenrldge Avenue, White Plains, has been purchased by Alexander Dietch, who will occupy it. The seller was the Home Title Guaranty Company, in rehabilitation, and the broker was Chauncey B. Griffen.

Under the combined influence of foreign withdrawals of investments made here and continued purchases of gold abroad for shipment here, the dollar weakened yesterday in terms of most important foreign exchanges.
Pope Pius suffered a slight heart attack today, but remained determined to conduct his customary Wednesday reception for newly married couples tomorrow.

Plans for a bundle party, musical revue and fashion show to be conducted next Tuesday night by Thrift House, 7 East Fifty-seventh Street, which is celebrating its fourth anniversary, were completed. last night at a meeting of committee chairmen.
Evidence for the existence of a "timeclock" in the brain which goes on ticking in a cyclic rhythm all its own when we are asleep or awake, was presented today before the National Academy of Sciences.

Hearings looking toward approval of a plan for reorganization of the Roxy Theatres Corporation, which had been expected to extend several weeks, ended abruptly yesterday before Addison S. Pratt, Federal special master, when groups of creditors agreed on certain amendments to the plan.

President ROOSEVELT has taken an entirely reasonable position in warning Government employes not to speculate in commodities, stocks or bonds. There are special reasons why such speculation might be unethical.

Jack Doyle, the Irish tenor, struck another blow to uphold British boxing prestige tonight when he gave Kingfish Levinsky of Chicago a brutal twelve-round beating at Wembley Stadium before a crowd of 11,400, which included King Farouk of Egypt.
Western Pennsylvania's highest April flood waters in eighty years dropped slowly back tonight as the Ohio River carried the muddy burden down upon lower valley towns.

The new trade agreement between the United States and Cuba, with its reciprocal benefits, has strengthened sympathetic understanding as well as trade relations between the two countries, Pablo Suarez, Cuban Consul General, said yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Brooklyn Kiwanis Club at the Towers, 25 Clark Street, Brooklyn.
The directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday elected Ralph W. Gallagher a vice president to succeed Chester O. Swain, who died on April 19.

Several East Side tenements which figured in realty sales yesterday will be remodeled by the new owners. A store property on Broadway, long held by the Wendel interests, also figured in the day's deals.

The Commodore Dutch Association, which has carried on since 1901 the tradition of the old-time Chuck Connors ball, will hold its thirty-seventh annual ball Friday night at Teutonia Hall, Sixteenth Street and Third Avenue.
Three days ahead of the prearranged schedule for their offensive on the Bilbao front, the Insurgents consolidated positions today in the El Gueta-Eibar-Marquina sector.
On the way for what may be his fourth straight national saber championship, Norman C. Armitage swept through four opponents in the semi-finals at the New York Athletic Club last night.

The marriage of Miss Myrtle Joan Koch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor M. E. Koch of Jackson Heights, Queens, to Elias Beall Van Zandt of Fort Worth, Texas, son of Mrs. F. William Pferdmenges of Forest Hills and of the late E. B. Van Zandt, took place last night in St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, Jackson Heights. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Raymond L. Scofield.

The marriage of Miss Ellen Dexter Fales, daughter of Mrs. Dexter Fales and of Haliburton Fales of this city, to David Arms Lomasney, also of New York, took place yesterday afternoon in St. James's Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, which had been decorated with Spring flowers and cybotium ferns. The Rev. Dr.

Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, attacked in Commons tonight on the proposed excess profits tax, threw sections of it back into the melting pot, giving industrialists some hope that it would be recast in a more attractive form. But no one doubted that the tax on the growth of profits would be enforced by Summer.
Arthur E. Morgan has resigned as principal of McGill University because he considers it "in the best interests of the university.". He assumed the post Sept. 1, 1935.
Provisions of the Undistributed Profits Tax Law were sharply attacked today in round-table discussions at the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
Vice President GARNER was one of a large Congressional tourist party caught in a bad storm on Chesapeake Bay.

H. Bernard Hawley, 47-year-old Lake George business man, was fatally injured this afternoon when an automobile in which he and his wife were riding was in a head-on collision with a bus carrying eleven passengers on the Glens Falls-Lake George road.

Almost game half of the $4,000,000 Tom Yawkey is believed to have invested in the Red Sox over a four-year period On has melted away, according to the club's financial statement for the plate year ending last Nov. 30.

Trading was fair on most beef and fresh pork cuts. Lamb moved slowly and demand for veal hindsaddles fell off sharply. Steer beef sold steady to strong and some cuts were higher. Veal hindsaddles showed weakness and some lamb sales were fully 50c lower. Fresh pork cuts were steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be about steady, veal weak and lamb uneven, as reported by the U. S. Department of Agriculture.

Commodity futures were mixed, in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, copper, lead, cocoa, coffee and cottonseed oil futures advanced, while hide, zinc and wool top futures declined. Sugar and silk futures were steady. On the cash markets all the grains, rubber, cotton, tins, lard, coffee, cocoa and butter rose, but flour, eggs, printcloths, silk, wool tops and hides lost ground.

The price that Robert R. Young, Frank F. Kolbe and Allan P. Kirby have agreed to pay for securities of the Alleghany Corporation carrying working control of the former Van Sweringen railroad empire was $6,375,000, it was announced last night by Mr. Young.
Preston Selleck, an employe of the metropolitan Life Insurance Company for thirty-five years, died this morning of a heart attack at his home here. He was 67.

Yesterday's brokers' reports of commercial leasing were featured by a contract for the store, basement and second floor, aggregating about 20,000 square feet, taken by Don Ruseau, Inc., interior decorator, at 307-9-11 East Fifty-third Street, through Butler Baldwin, Inc.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 26: BRIGADIER GENERAL Darrah, T. W., two months and fourteen days leave, about May 18.

Proposals to limit committee debate on President Roosevelt's Court Reorganization Bill to two weeks, to substitute for it the McCarran plan for an outright increase in the Supreme Court membership by two justices and to appoint a subcommittee to draw up a compromise bill were among the suggestions that occupied today's meeting of the Senate Judiciary Committee, the first session since public hearings ended Friday.

First evidence that primary market prices are meeting definite resistance from retailers who are either unable or unwilling to lift standard merchandise out of fixed price brackets, was seen in three separate divisions of the dry goods markets yesterday and, in at least one instance, pressure for lower prices has been carried effectively through all stages back to the graycloth mills.

By an odd coincidence Great Britain and the United States each took a crucial step on Monday in governmental control of the coal industry. In each country that industry is "sick," but the contrast in the two methods chosen for dealing with this sickness is instructive.

Word has come from the English publishers of "King Edward VIII" by Hector Bolitho that the biography is already in its sixth edition there and that the first edition copies are now selling at double the original price.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the name of Harold P. Burke of Rochester to be District Judge for the Western District of New York.

David Batt, 48 years old, who lives at the Lincoln Hotel and has a law office at 299 Broadway, pleaded not guilty yesterday before General Sessions Judge Allen on two subornation of perjury indictments, growing out of an accident suit.

The annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks will open today in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and will continue through Thursday and Friday. Carl M. Spencer, president of the association and president of the Home Savings Bank, Boston, will preside. Andrew Mills Jr.,
Brig. Gen. Herbert Henry Austin, soldier and author, died here today. He was 68 years old. General Austin served with the British forces in India and Africa, and won many honors.
Lucy Monroe, American lyric soprano, has been engaged for the Metropolitan Opera Spring Season, Lee Pattison, director, announced yesterday.

Fourteen dogs, twelve cats and seventy white mice, scheduled to die in the interests of scientific research, were suffocated yesterday in a smoky fire that raged for nearly three-quarters of an hour on the top floor of New York University's Loomis Research Building, a five-story structure at 410 East Twenty-sixth Street, opposite Bellevue Hospital.

The golden "last" rivet in the Golden Gate Bridge. became the lost rivet today when it shattered beneath a pneumatic hammer, somewhat disrupting dedication of the $35,000,000 structure, longest suspension span in the world.

Eleven properties in various parts of Manhattan figured yesterday in forced sales in the Vesey Street auction rooms. Seven four and five story tenement and stores buildings were among those changing hands. Details of the transactions follow:
An inquiry into the methods used in the sale of stock in the magazine The New York Woman was started yesterday by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

Announcement was made here today that the marriage of Miss Nancy Parshall Cooper, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dexter P. Cooper, to Brian Alfred Hamilton would take place at St. Anne's Church, Campobello Island, N. B., on May 2.

The 60 Park Place office building at Park PI. and East Park St. in Newark. N. J., had an excess of receipts over disbursements of $74,304 for the year ended Jan. 31. 1937, according to Amott, Baker Co., Inc. This is at the rate of 4.80 per cent on its outstanding $1,547.000 first mortgage bonds,. before interest and depreciation.

Registrations of visiting buyers during the week ended yesterday were slightly under the preceding week and considerably below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
Following are the titles of the Berg Election Bills on which the Governor acted today and the text of his veto messages:...

Holders of Class A preferred stock of the Square D Company have indicated an almost unanimous acceptance of the share-for-share exchange of their stock into Class B common stock, Henry S. Morgan, secretary and treasurer, announced yesterday.

Agreement on neutrality legislation to replace the law that expires by limitation at midnight Saturday was reached late today by the conference committee appointed by the Senate and the House to iron out the differences in the two resolutions the respective chambers had passed.

Spilling the pins with a mastery hitherto unequalled in the thirtyseven years of national competition, 29-year-old Max Stein of Belleville, Ill., scaled the bowling heights yesterday as he soared to a new record of 2,070 in the all-events division of the American bowling congress.

Miss Shirley Newkirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Warren Newkirk of this place, was married here tonight in the First Congregational Church to John Hamilton Tyson 2d of Millbrook, Greenwich, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John H. Tyson. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Alden S. Mosshammer.

The search for Aaron Dab, 7 years old, who was last seen Monday night when he broke away from his older sister and dashed into Bronx Park, continued yesterday with more than fifty detectives and patrolmen grappling in the Bronx River and playing flashlights in near-by caves and gulleys.

A bill authorizing the payment of $3 a month to each of the more than 4,500 unsalaried cooperative observers of the United States Weather Bureau was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Smith of South Carolina.

The New York City Housing Authority is tearing down the row of eleven old homes on the west side of Seventh Avenue, between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets thus removing another landmark of Greenwich Village.

Plans for harnessing the nation's latent power sources in a country-wide TVA were discussed this afternoon at a White House conference in which Senator Norris, legislative father of the TVA; Benjamin V. Cohen, member of the National Power Policy Committee, and J. D. Ross of the Securities and Exchange Commission joined.

Estate, more than $20,000. To Mary Bovee McAdoo, 435 E. 57th St., Gertrude Bovee Johnson, Stockbridge, Mass., nieces, and Lorna Livingston and Mary Bovee Taylor, greatnieces, both of 410 E. 57th St., $10,000 each; Bessie Bovee Vernam, cousin, 480 Park Ave., $2,500; St. Thomas Church, 5th Ave. and 53d St., and Robert Jackson, former employee, 28 Hall St.

The Doughton bill repealing the section of the 1936 Income Tax Law providing for publication of the salaries of corporation officials in excess of $15,000 annually was passed, 229 to 112, by the House today.
A tumultuous session of Congress resulted today when the Speaker cleared the galleries and caused the arrest of Barboza Lima, Integralista provincial chief, at Congress Hall.

The Rev. Dr. Charles L. Goodell, Methodist Episcopal minister, who was pastor of Calvary Church, 1904-13, and of St. Paul's Church, 1913-18, died last night in Doctors Hospital, after a brief illness, of a heart disease. He was 82 years old.

Bernie Friedkin, hard - hitting Brownsville featherweight, outpointed Henry Hook of Indianapolis last night in a fast eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. Friedkin captured every round, although the first three and the sixth and eighth were close.

I. Nicholas Gordon, 43 years old, disbarred lawyer, who was released last Sunday from the Federal House of Detention after serving a threemonth term for posing as an army officer in a hotel, was arraigned before General Sessions Judge Allen yesterday on two theft charges made by former clients.

Certificates of graduation were presented to 242 young men and women students of the evening classes of Pratt Institute at exercises last night in the institute's memorial hall at 215 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn.

The creation of a group of citizens to raise $250,000 among wealthy residents of Manhattan for welfare work in the boroughs of Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company and chair man of the group.

Jerome Strauss outscored Bruno Klerings, 175-83, in 32 innings in the Poggenburg Memorial Cup 18.2 balkline, billiard play at Lawler Brothers Manhattan Academy last night. Edward S. Knapp Jr. defeated Leonard Coleman, 125-109, also in 32 frames.

The Southern New York and, Connecticut Antiques Exposition, the fourth to be held here within three years, opened today at the Westchester County center. Nearly 1,200 persons attended. The show will continue through Friday eve-' ning.

On the twenty round trips between Germany and Lakehurst, N. J., beginning next week, the airship Hindenburg will provide a ten-ton weight allowance for freight, it was announced yesterday by N. P. Ballou, air express director of the Railway Express Agency.
The male spelling team of twenty-five which will do orthographical battle May 7 with an equal number of women for a hospital fund took on renewed confidence today. Captain Howard C.

Governor LEHMAN'S veto of the four election bills that bear the name of Senator BERG of the Bronx is no less welcome because it was expected. At the public hearing last week no even faintly plausible defense of them was made.
Governor Lehman vetoed four bills which opponents said would have blocked independent political movements and given the major parties an advantage.

Contracts for residential building in the metropolitan area awarded during the first three months of this year totaled $48,198,000, more than double the total for the same period in 1936 when the figure was $23,870,100, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey advanced yesterday the price of heating oil, light industrial fuel oils and marine Diesel oil in tank cars 3/8 cent a gallon along the Atlantic seaboard.

Fire was completing today the destruction of Guernica, ancient town of the Basques and center of their cultural tradition, which was begun last evening by a terrible onslaught of General Francisco Franco's Insurgent air raiders.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ordered the Carib Syndicate, Ltd., yesterday to appraise the value of its stock and to repurchase shares of a minority group that attempted unsuccessfully recently to prevent the sale of stock held by the syndicate. The order was sought by H. Paul Shanik on behalf of himself and other dissenters.
Homer Martin, president of the United Auto Workers, was nominated today for election as a director of the General Motors Corporation at the annual stockholders' meeting. He received five votes.

A bill to impound 15 per cent of appropriations approved for the fiscal year beginning next July 1 was introduced in the House late today by Representative Clarence Cannon of Missouri after he had returned to the Capitol from a conference with President Roosevelt.

Reports from Socompa, near Port Arica, say the population is alarmed on account of an inexplicable sinking of the surface of the earth over large areas. Wide fissures extending for miles are said to have appeared also across agricultural lands close to dwellings.

Gross assets, $101,524; net, $85,615. To Marjory E. Faber. Dorothy E. Hess and Herbert G. Einstein Jr., grandchildren, $1,000 each; Mabel E. Schulte, daughter, and Herbert G. and Walter S. Einstein, sons. one-third residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $83,346.

Miss Maria Willets, a descendant of Thomas Willett, first Mayor of New York under the English, serving in 1665, died yesterday at her home, 32 East Seventy-fifth Street, where she had been confined as an invalid for more than forty years.

Business failures declined in the retail and manufacturing groups in the week ended April 22, in comparison with the same period last year, but increased in three other divisions, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Score another for the girls. A team of youthful "Annie Oakleys" from Munhall, Pa., has won the national junior rifle championship. Competing against 150 teams from all over the country, most of them boy sharpshooters, the Pennsylvania girls became the nation's best prep rifle team.
Though Congress is to remain on land while the President goes afloat after Gulf tarpon, Congress, in a figurative sense, will be more at sea than Mr. Roosevelt during his fishing excursion.

Dissension within the group of Presbyterian Fundamentalists who founded Westminster Theological Seminary here eight years ago, led today to the resignation of two executive officers, with still other defections in prospect.

Following the publication today of a leading editorial in The Yale Daily News urging the university not to accept the invitation to be represented at Goettingen University's 200th anniversary celebration, Secretary Carl Lohmann said that Yale would send a brief message, but no delegate.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., had for the first quarter of this year a net profit of $979,691, equal, after dividend requirements on the preference stock, to 45 cents a common share, according to a report which will be made public today.

The return of the I. C. A. A. A. A. outdoor track and field championships to New York for the first time since 1903 is expected to attract a record entry. Blanks were sent yesterday to the forty-six members of the association for the sixty-first annual meet to be held at Randalls Island Stadium on May 28 and 29.
