A measure to outlaw the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers in Nebraska rode roughshod over a small opposition bloc in the one-house Legislature today and advanced to select file.

The United Automobile Workers of America was involved in six strikes in Michigan tonight, on the eve of a government-conducted election to determine whether the union shall be the sole bargaining agency for Packard Motor Car Company employes.

Conde Nast gave a large supper dance last night at his apartment, 1,040 Park Avenue, for Clare Boothe, author, who in private life is Mrs. Henry Luce; Ilka Chase, comedienne (Mrs. William B. Murray), and Margalo Gillmore, actress.
General Wilhelm Roeder, Hungarian Minister of War, arrived here today on his official visit. He came from Berlin and Berchtesgaden, where he had been received by Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany.

Davidson Brothers Davidson Brothers, Inc., which operates eleven general department and apparel stores in Detroit and vicinity, reported yesterday a sales volume of $1,178,817 for the twelve weeks ended on March 27.
Heavy losses have occurred in the last eight days on the Stock Exchanges in Central Europe.

Governor Lehman today designated Supreme Court Justice Albert Cohn of the First Judicial Department, as an associate justice of the Appellate Division, First Department, to succeed the late Justice John V. McAvoy.

Governor Lehman vetoed today a series of Election Law amendments declared to have been designed to block minority movements and give a virtual monopoly in politics to parties already established on the ballot.
Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville will give a dinner Saturday at Hi-Esmaro, their place in Pleasantville, N. Y., for the Right Rev. James C. Freeman, Bishop of Washington.

Movements in the Chicago livestock markets today, reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 14,000, including 3,500 direct. Early market steady to higher; later mostly steady to strong with Monday's average; bulk good and choice 200-300 pounds. $10.10-$10.30; top, $10.35; comparable 140-190 pound, $9.50-10.15; most packing sows $9.60-$9.85.

The grain markets on the Board of Trade here reversed their recent action today and prices were on the upgrade from the start with the better action of the security and commodity markets in general the main influence.

Delivery of virtually the entire certificated stock of 41,000 bales on the May position carried May contracts 15 points under July on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, when the whole market advanced sharply $1.50 a bale to end with gains of 14 to 25 points.

In the first quarter of this year the Texas Corporation earned the equivalent of $1 a share on the present outstanding capital stock, compared with about 60 cents a share in the corresponding quarter last year, when a smaller amount of stock was outstanding, T. Rieber, chairman, told stockholders at their meeting yesterday.
Movements of Vessles follow; all dates are April 26 unless specified : At La Hama Roads: Chester, Housing Louisville, April 25; Northampton ??, Salt Lake City.

Vincent Bryan, author of many song hits of the last three decades, including. "In My Merry Oldsmobile," "Tammany" and "Is It a Sin?" was found dead here today in his hotel room. He was 54 years old. He had been ill for several years.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opens to the public today an exhibition that conducts visitors back into the past some 200 centuries. Effectively installed on three floors are facsimiles of prehistoric rock paintings and engravings by "dawn artists," chosen from the vast collection assembled by Professor Leo Frobenius.

ABELSON--Abraham Judah, brother of Rabbi Alter Abelson, April 27, 1937. Interred Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, L. I. ADLER--Anna E. beloved wife of Simon, devoted mother of Beatrice Proops and Silvia, sister of Harriet Ach, Ottilie Ehrlich and Rae Harris. Funeral strictly private.

Stockholders of the Mullins Manufacturing Company yesterday. approved an increase in the authorized Class B common stock from 172,500 to 560,000 shares, and the transfer of 200,000 new Class B shares to the Sharon Steel Corporation in return for the plant, property and assets of Youngstown Pressed Steel Company, its wholly owned subsidiary.

Anthony M. Hauck Jr., Hunterdon County prosecutor whose term expired last night, was sworn in today by County Clerk C. Lloyd Fell as a Special Assistant Attorney General to handle the county prosecutor's office until a new prosecutor is appointed by Governor Hoffman.

Poet Laureate John Masefield's "Prayer for the King's Reign" appeared today in the official souvenir program for the May 12 coronation of George VI. The poem, which comes from the pen of the author of a recent coronation sonnet, follows:

The flood-burdened Ohio River moved tonight toward a predicted height of forty-five feet at this industrial city of 70,000 residents. Tributaries already had taken two lives. The predicted crest, nine feet over the 36-foot flood stage, was expected during the night.

W. Alton Jones of New York, vice president of the Cities Service Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting today that until the United States Supreme Court had passed on the constitutionality of the Public Utilities Act "the company will follow a policy of rigid cash conservation."

Trudi Schoop and her company of dancing comedians opened an engagement of eight performances at the Longacre Theatre last night in a new pantomimic comedy called "Blonde Marie," with music by Paul Schoop.

New tariffs on freight transported, eastward by intercoastal ships, which provide for higher rates on majority of commodities, have been filed with the Federal wariLium Commission by the United States Intercoastal Freight Association, it was announced yesterday.

As reported this week by the Federal Reserve Board, the " industrial production index number," compiled from actual monthly output of some dozen or more separate industries, reached in March the figure of 118 on the basis of 100 for the three years 1923 to 1925 inclusive.

Among those sailing today for Europe on the French liner Normandie for Havre, via Southampton, on their way to the coronation in London and the Paris Exposition, are Grover A. Whalen, Mr. and Mrs. Percy S. Straus. Stephen F. Voorhees, W. Francklyn Paris and Rear Admiral William H. Standley.

Non-striking employes of the Thermoid Company, who returned to work yesterday afternoon with the intention of remaining inside the plant, got some sleep today when, shortly before dawn, State troopers, acting on Governor Hoffman's orders,

Walter Post Duvall, 62, its former assistant secretary and assistant treasurer and one of its oldest employes, was charged today by the grand jury with the larceny of $47,500 from the Mercantile Trust Company.

Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee for the C. I. O., will defend the labor policies of John L. Lewis in an address at the 121st dinner of the Economic Club of New York at Hotel Astor tomorrow night, it was announced yesterday by Paul D. Cravath, president of the club.

Two young men held up a clerk in the office of the Atlantic Auto Plan Company, 1,273 Bedford Avenue, near Brevoort Place, Brooklyn, yesterday at 1 P. M. and then inadvertently threw away more than half of their loot.

The six-story apartment house at 1,954 Unionport Road, opposite Bronx Park, in the Bronx, was purchased by Maran Maran, operators, through Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc. The house, on a plot 147 by 100 feet, contains 235 rooms divided into eighty apartments, and is reported to have an annual rental of about $40,000. Gold Maran acted as attorneys for the buyers, and Goldwater Flynn for the sellers.

The property at 37-09-19 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City, consisting of a plot 150 by 100 feet improved with a garage of one and two stories, and other buildings, has been acquired by MahoneyClarke, Inc., dealers in heavy hardware and contractors' supplies, who will utilize it for storage purposes.
With Carl Ferris, All-America attack man, scoring nine goals, Hobart's lacrosse team defeated Syracuse today, 12 to 7 for its first victory over the Orangemen in nine years.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Paul P. Rao and Nathan Witt of New York City were admitted to practice today, and the following proceedings were had: 625-Ernest K. James, individually, , appellant, v. the Dravo Contracting Co. Argument concluded for appellant.

New summonses to a war against racketeering and organized crime were sounded yesterday by Supreme Court Justices Philip J. McCook and Ferdinand Pecora as they impaneled two extraordinary grand juries to carry on the investigations directed by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor.
Lester Jerome Gillen, secretary of the Henry Gillen Sons Lighterage Corporation of New York and present of the Gillen Realty Company of Hempstead, died here today. He was 39 years old.

Max Feder, in 333 Central Park West; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker. Samuel M. Fisher, In 1,225 Park Ave., David H. Taylor, in 112 E. 74th St.: Samuel Howard. Milton Tomlinson, in 205 W. 54th St.; Ruth Relner, In 125 E. 93d St.; Ray Earles, Aristides de Leon, in 55 W. 11th St.; Byrne Bowman, Inc., broker.
A seventy-foot Carolina poplar tree, which has become very unpopular with the neighbors, was the subject of litigation yesterday in Flatbush Magistrates Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Seldom does a brief headline in a newspaper so stir those of us New Yorkers who know and love the old town as did the six words in THE TIMES headline, "Removal Is Voted for Brick Church."

IT is not impossible that students of American life and letters will come to regard April 11, 1937, as a day of more than ordinary significance. for on the evening of April 11 Archibald MacLeish's verse drama called "The Fall of the City," written especially for the radio, was broadcast over the Columbia network with a distinguished cast including Orson Welles and Burgess Meredith.

Navigation released the following orders today dated April 24: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Bahm, G. H., the Schenck, to the Arkansas as Gunnery Officer. Dean, G. S., to the Rigel instead of the Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa.

When a holder of a college degree takes a job in a kitchen, says one who did, there's no reason to be self-conscious about a stigma of social inferiority attached to housework as a means of livelihood.

Taking a militant attitude on price competition, liquor wholesalers, emerging from a price war which started last week, warned distillers yesterday that they will meet future outbreaks with court action under the Feld-Crawford Law.

A mysterious assailant slipped up behind Municipal Court Justice John F. O'Neil at Sixth Avenue and Twelfth Street at 9:10 o'clock yesterday morning and drove a long, sharp knife twice into his back. Although the attack took place before the eyes of half a dozen shopkeepers and others, the would-be assassin escaped unmolested.
The United States, the State of Minnesota and Ontario provincial governments will join forces this Summer to control forest fires along a 30-mile stretch of the international border. R. U. Harmon,
The silver, red and gold silks of the Detroit-owned Bomar Stable were borne to victory by Benjam today in the twenty-fifth running of the Aberdeen Stakes, closing-day feature of this meeting.
Accompanied by official statements from both sides, the ballots for Equity's latest referendum vote on a constitutional amendment will be reaching today all actors who are members of the association.

The empire that single-mindedly is trying to bury the memory of Edward under the pomp and circumstance of the coronation of his successor a fort-night hence was strikingly reminded of the exile's existence when his solicitors filed suit for libel today against William Heinemann, Ltd., publishers, and Geoffrey Dennis, author of "Coronation commentary."
Otto Karl Ludwig, the German arrested on charges of violating the Official Secrets Act, was discharged from custody today, but immediately requested to leave Britain.

The worst flood in London's history washed through the city tonight, leaving five dead, at least 6,000 homeless, industry crippled, 15,000 workers idle, $3,000,000 damage and the city faced with food, water and electric power shortages and a threat of disease.
Steel ingot output increased less than seasonably last week. and the adjusted index receded to 120.3, which compares with 121.6 for the previous week and 92.3 for the week ended April 25, 1936.

The Musicians Emergency Fund's luncheon will take place this afternoon at the St. Regis Hotel. Mrs. Vincent Astor will preside. Lee Pattison, Georges Barrbre and Samuel Barlow will be among the: speakers.

Giles Whiting of Scarborough-onHudson, president of the Persian Rug Manufacturing Company and a former treasurer of the Architectural League of New York, died yesterday in the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center of heart disease after an illness of three weeks.

All the new younger men added to the board of directors of the United States Steel Corporation in recent months were present at yesterday's board meeting, while five of the older men out of the eighteen directors were absent.

Bond prices moved irregularly and the volume of business was much smaller in yesterday's trading in the bond section of the New York Stock Exchange. Secondgrade and speculative issues, particularly convertible bonds, showed scattered strength, in keeping with the recovery in the stock market.

As the citizens' appeal for the Salvation Army entered its fourth week and neared the half-way mark yesterday, Chalmers Wood, general chairman of the drive, announced at a report luncheon of 100 workers at the Bankers Club that $233,489 had been raised. The goal is $600,000.
For the first time, the Independent City Subway has carried more than 1,000,000 passengers in a twenty-four-hour period, the Board of Transportation revealed yesterday.
That it is not a crime for any one to go to an adjoining State, buy liquor for his personal use and bring it into this State was the decision of the Court of Appeals today.

A four-point program for financial houses to win public confidence was outlined yesterday by Edward L. Bernays, public relations counsel, at a luncheon meeting of the New York Financial Advertisers Association at the Lawyers Club.

Eugene Underhill, a member of one of America's most distinguished old families and a former trustee of the Bowery Savings Bank in New York, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of several months.

The point has been reached in the recovery cycle where American industry must finance a vast expansion in its productive capacity if price inflation is to be headed off, Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said tonight in a talk at the annual dinner of the Illinois Manufacturers Costs Association.

Tributes to Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue, were paid last night by President Roosevelt, Dr. Albert Einstein and Mayor La Guardia, among others, in connection with the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Free Synagogue.

Senator McNaboe of New York, in a two-hour speech today, declared that Mayor La Guardia had failed to stamp out alleged subversive teachings in New York City schools, and then withdrew a motion he had made to bring out of the Finance Committee a bill continuing the legislative committee created last year to investigate alleged communism in schools and colleges.
It was announced today that beginning May 1-the Day of National Labor-the membership of the National Socialist German Labor party would be raised from 3,500,000 to approximately 6,000,000.

Addison Patillo Youngblood, Confederate veteran, died at 7 A. M. yesterday at his home, 551 West 178th Street. He was 93 years old and, according to the New York Camp of the Sons of Confederate Veterans, he was the last surviving Confederate veteran in the metropolitan area.

Madison Ave, 1,080, Ann Clare Brokaw to George Tuttle Brokaw, (former husband), 1,010 5th Ave, release of dower (instrument dated July 1, 1929). First Ave, w side, 51.2 s of 73d St, 25.6x100: trustee will of Ferdinand S. Blun and Anita R. Bellow to Charline Realty Co, Inc. 214 East 85th St ($18,000).

When for a consideration of $18,000, the Charline Realty Co. Inc. Richard Eberhart. president, bought the house at 1.355 First Ave from the trustee of the will of Ferdinand S. M. Blun and Anita Bellew, the latter took back a purchase-money mortgage for $13,000, due April 5, 1940, at 5 per cent.
Alleging habitual intemperance, intolerable cruelty and statutory offenses, Mrs. Edna C. Dunham Plant of Greenwich has filed suit for a divorce from Philip Manwaring Plant of Oswegatchie, Waterford.
Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Owen J. Roberts attended the funeral in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here this afternoon of Mrs. Roberts's mother, Mrs. Jennie Somerville Rogers.
Reaping Reward, Milky Way Farm Derby candidate, worked a mile and an eighth in 1:58 today at Churchill Downs in company with Military, another of Mrs. E. V. Mar's hopefuls for the May 8 classic.

The attention of the people of Manhattan and the Bronx is especially called to the statement by Mr. JAMES G. BLAINE in this morning's TIMES concerning the plight of the welfare agencies in the Boroughs of Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond.
John H. Dockman, president of John H. Dockman Son, Inc., a candy concern, which he founded more than sixty years ago, died last night at his home here. He was born ninety years ago in Germany.
Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, today urged the House Interstate Commerce Commission to make permanent the Connolly "hot oil" act which will expire this year.

The emergency board of three members appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate the dispute which threatened to culminate in a strike of 25,000 employes affiliated with the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks in this area is tentatively scheduled to open its hearings on Monday, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank M. Swacker, member of the board.
Cockfighting, which has long been one of the most popular sports in Latin-American countries, is not favored by several governments because of the gambling it involves.

President Roosevelt headed south early today for eleven days at sea off the Texas coast, where the big silver-sided, blunt-headed tarpon are reported to be running and other varieties of deep-sea fish are waiting for his lure.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $5.75 a share on the preferred stock, of which $4 was on account of accumulations, leaving unpaid accumulations of $5.25 a share as of March 31, amounting to $18,914,758.
Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, today urged the House Interstate Commerce Commission to make permanent the Connolly "hot oil" act which will expire this year.

The emergency board of three members appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate the dispute which threatened to culminate in a strike of 25,000 employes affiliated with the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks in this area is tentatively scheduled to open its hearings on Monday, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank M. Swacker, member of the board.
Cockfighting, which has long been one of the most popular sports in Latin-American countries, is not favored by several governments because of the gambling it involves.

To the reproach leveled against him during the last month's parliamentary vacation that he was not governing the country, Premier Leon Blum replied today by showing that he had lost none of his skill in manipulating both men and affairs.

President Roosevelt made public a recommendation by Attorney General Cummings for revision of the anti-trust laws, and indicated opposition to an unemployment census, before leaving for a fishing trip off the Texas Coast.

The severest sentence thus far imposed in the garnishee racket in which 4,000 city employes have been victimized in recent years was imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Streit on Abraham Horowitz, 45 years old, an itinerant "garnishee salesman."

Describing himself as "blamed for everything except introducing Mrs. Simpson to King Edward," Mayor La Guardia lashed out in a speech in Queens yesterday at the State Legislature for adding to the city's financial burdens without providing State funds to ease the burden.

At the annual meeting of shareholders of the New England Power Association in Boston yesterday Frank D. Comerford, chairman of the board, said earnings for the first three months of 1937 showed a continuance of the trend toward better business conditions generally throughout the system's territory.

The delivery yesterday of an official communication from the Spanish Government to Chile through the Spanish Ambassador here has closed the incident resulting from the opening of the luggage of Chile's Ambassador to Madrid, Nunez Morgado, to learn whether he was being employed to export valuables.

Two women and a man were seriously burned and another woman was injured in a fire and an explosion caused by the ignition of a five-gallon bottle of a chemical in the laboratory of the Sunfoot Remedies, Inc., 828-830 Third Avenue, near Fifty-first Street, at 3:20 P. M. yesterday.

Motorists finding it necessary to travel through flood areas were advised yesterday that, if the rises continued, they should carry boiled water, emergency rations, a flashlight and a safety hospital kit.

Commander and Mrs. Robert W. Cary, U. S. N., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Frances Cary, to First Lieutenant Lewis Pembroke Brown, Seventh Field Artillery, O. R. C. Miss Cary was graduated last year from Flintridge Sacred Heart Academy at Pasadena, Calif.

John Caples of the copy staff of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborne, addressed the final session of THE NEW YORK TIMES advertising class in the club room of The Times Annex last evening. His subject was "Testing Advertising Results."

An easier situation prevails in the steel market, the principal incentive for forward buying having been removed by the announcements of a continuation of present steel prices through the third quarter of 1937, Iron Age says this week:

Wholesale arson and mass murder, committed by Rebel airplanes of German type Monday afternoon and early evening, left the ancient Basque capital, Guernica-except for the historic Casa de Juntas, where the Viscayan Parliament used to meet-a smoldering ruin. With utter ferocity and scientific thoroughness, the incendiary and explosive bombs and machine guns of the Junker and Heinkel planes destroyed this center of Basque culture and political tradition.

An application by Farrar Rinehart, Inc., publishers, for a temporary injunction restraining the Literary Guild of America, Inc., from selling at retail three books it issued recently, was granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag.

Specific recommendations comprising a program by which business can put its house in order were laid down here today by H. A. Batten, president of N. W. Ayer Son, Inc., speaking before the Association of National Advertisers.

Six former directors of the National Assets Corporation, most of them well known in the business community, were criticized severely yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman for failing to exercise greater supervision over the corporation's activities.

A lower Fifth Avenue improvement will result from the sale yesterday by St. Luke's Hospital of the four-story business and apartment building at 68 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the southwest corner of Thirteenth Street.

Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, women's national tennis champion, worked out at the Court House on East Sixty-fifth Street yesterday before sailing for England with her coach, Miss Eleanor Tennant.

Almost a week to the day it first broke out the price war which disrupted wholesale liquor price schedules was definitely ended last night. The National Distillers Products Corporation, last of the large producers sanctioning abnormal discounts by its jobbers, announced that regular discounts will be in effect this morning.
Representative Fish of New York proposed today that Congress direct the Treasury not to buy any more gold from foreign sources at more than $25 an ounce.

ALTERMAN--Esther, beloved wife of Abraham B., dear mother of Harold J., Dorothy H., Joseph and Lottie, sister of Louis Kurlansky, Sam and Joe Kurlan, Lena Rosing, Ray Margolies, Ethel Sherr. Services at late residence, 350 Fort Washington Ave., today, 12 noon. Interment Mount Hebron Cemetery.

James Hart, a retired police lieutenant, died yesterday after a long illness at his residence, 955 Grant Avenue, Bronx, at the age of 74. Surviving are his widow, Maria Grogan Hart; three daughters, Abina M., Hester M. and Marie M. Hart, and three sons, the Rev. James V. Hart, assistant pastor of St. John's Church, White Plains;

The annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund will begin today at the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street. Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University and a director of the fund, will preside.

Premier Mussolini this afternoon under a heavy rain started work on the 1941 world exhibition to be held in Rome by planting three pines on its site, and then inaugurated a new film city designed to become the Italian Hollywood, which is now ready to begin production.
The Moffat bill barring sale in New York State of child labor-made goods was passed in the Senate today and sent to Governor Lehman.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 14 per cent for the week ended April 24 in comparison with the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. This figure contrasts with a rise of 24 per cent for the preceding week.

Theatrical circles were surprised and somewhat bewildered yesterday when it became known that Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians had refused to accept an invitation to take part in the national convention of the recently formed American Theatre Council which will be held here next month.
At a meeting of the board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric International Company yesterday, John W. White was elected vice president and general manager of the company.

About 900 striking employee of the National Can Company in Maspeth, Queens, voted yesterday to accept the terms of a strike settlement offered by the company and to return to work as soon as a written agreement is signed. The vote to end the strike was taken at a mass meeting of strikers in Clinton Hall. Maspeth.
Behind Woodrow Wilson Davis's seven-hit pitching, Toronto won its sixth straight victory of the season today, downing the Jersey City Giants, 8 to 1.

Mel Harder held the White Sox to five hits today to show that his arm no longer ails him, and Earl Averill hit a home run with the bases full to quiet muttering about his weak hitting this season as the Indians defeated Chicago, 7 to 2.

Miss Frances Haney, daughter of Mrs. W. Fred Haney of Fairmont, W. Va., and the late Mr. Haney, was married here yesterday afternoon to John Spencer Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix B. Atwood of Springfield, Mass., in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Claud Reader.

Representatives of the Blind Workers Union and officials of two shops where blind employes have been on sit-down strikes for more than three weeks, met yesterday at the office of the National Labor Relations Board, 45 Broadway, in an effort to end the conflict.
Weakness developed in foreign markets following an early rally yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange here broke sharply $1.50 a bale, all months selling at new low prices for the movement.

Examinations The mental examination for promotion to the rank of battalion chief, in this department. will be held at Room 436, 641 Washington St., corner of Christopher St., Manhattan, on Thursday, April 29, and Friday, April 30. The following captain candidates shall be directed to report at 9:30 A. M. each day:

University Ave, (12-3249), e s 78 n of 195th St, 26x107: Joyce Bushel, referee, to Doflar Savings Bank, 2,792 3d Ave. Mosholu Parkway, n, (12-335). s e cor of 206th St, 50x100; Lena Cohen to C. C. Estates, Inc, 1.440 Broadway. 147th St, (10-2582). n w cor of Union Ave, 100x64; Walter A. Donnelly, referee, to P. Walker Morrison, trustee, 1,214 Pacific St, Brooklyn.

President Roosevelt was reliably reported today to be willing to accept a reduction in the relief appropriation for the fiscal year 1938 from the figure of $1,500,000,000 as recommended last week, to $1,200,000,000, or $100,000,000 a month, if this step should be deemed necessary by Congressional leaders to bring the budget quickly into balance.

A resolution calling for a legislative investigation of reports of lobbying activities of "representatives of the milk monopoly" was introduced today by Mrs. Rhoda Fox Graves, Republican Senator from St. Lawrence.

Mrs. Edward Norton, a former teacher at Union Academy, died today. She was 101 years old. Mrs. Norton, who was born in Rutland and would have been 102 May 21, was graduated from Fort Edward (N. Y.) Institute.

The danger of inflation and runaway commodity prices in this country is a thing of the past and while both remain in the realm of "possibles" they are now "distinctly improbable," according to a diagnosis of the business and financial outlook given today by Lionel D. Edie of New York before the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

The five-game winning streak of the Bears was ended today as Big Bob Kline pitched Buffalo to a 7-3 victory in the series opener. Kline limited the hard-hitting Newark team to seven blows. Charlie Keller's home run in the first inning with two on the bases produced the only runs for the Bears.
A month before their third birthday, the Dionne quintuplets stepped on the scales today and laughed up at Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe as he marked up their weights and measured their heights.
The Prudential Life Insurance Company of America ended a threeday convention with a dinner last night at the Hotel Commodore which was attended by some 870 representatives.

Declaring that 75 per cent of all antiques imported into this country since 1906 were "fakes," the Treasury Department moved today to take them off the free-entry list. The total importations in the last twenty-eight years were estimated at $640,633,302.

Mrs. Esther Leslie Hennessy obtained a divorce here today from Richard Francis Hennessy of New York on a charge of cruelty. Mrs. Hennessy received authority to resume her maiden name. A property settlement was made out of court.

A majority of the freshmen and sophomores at Princeton University feel that "taking the profits out of war" would not completely remove the hazard of war from international affairs, according to a questionnaire vote taken by the Princeton Anti-War Society.

The Senate Committee on Commerce voted today to report favorably to the Senate the bill, already passed by the House, authorizing an appropriation of $5,000,000 to finance Federal participation in the New York World's Fair of 1939. Passage of the bill is expected early next week.

License Commissioner Paul Moss began yesterday a two-day hearing in his offices at 105 Walker Street which may result in the closing of all the fourteen burlesque houses in the city and a refusal of licenses for three more contemplated theatres.

Following Attorney General Cummings's recommendation to President Roosevelt yesterday for revision of the anti-trust laws, Senator Borah expressed the hope today that the administration was ready to deal in "thorough fashion with monopoly all along the line."

As an aftermath of the gun battle last Dec. 15 between Federal agents under J. Edgar Hoover and Harry Brunette, a fugitive from justice, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott announced yesterday that four of the thirty-one members of his department to receive heroism medals this year would be honored for standing in the line of fire while they extinguished a blase in the fugitive's apartment.

Mayor La Guardia and his friend and supporter, Samuel Seabury, held a conference in the latter's cabin on the French liner Normandie yesterday, and Mr. Seabury later declared that the people of the city would remember the Mayor's good deeds in office if he decided to run again.

39th St, 51-57 W, 85.8x98.9; Charles J. Cohen and Abraham Simonson to Nodis Realty Co, Inc, 521 5th AV, care of D. Geiger (S38). 45th St, s s, 400 ft w of 9th Av, 25x100.4; Terry Forrest to Jeanette Kaplan, 165 Broadway, care of H. Fluegelman (50 cents).

Stocks of wheat held by 701 reporting concerns amounted on March 31 to 82,134,445 bushels, of which 88.4 per cent was in private terminal elevators, in transit and in mills and mill elevators attached to mills;
The New England Council's index of business activity for the territory advanced from 108.9 in February to 115.5 in March, the highest level it has reached since 1929, it was announced here today.

Grain markets on the Board of Trade here fluctuated in a more erratic manner today, breaking early in sympathy with stocks and commodities in general, only to rally violently later under the leadership of May corn, which soared 3 7/8 cents a bushes from Tuesday's finish.

President Roosevelt's opposition to passage of the Miller-Tydings bill which would validate State Fair-Trade Laws in interstate commerce provoked varied comment among trade association representatives here yesterday, who seek to eliminate or substantially reduce the use of loss leaders.

INVERTEBRATE SPAIN, by Jose Ortega y Gasset. (Norton, $2.75.) What lies behind the Spanish civil war. THE AMBERLEY PAPERS: The Letters and Diaries of Bernard Russell's Parents, by Bertrand and Patricia Russell. (Norton.

It is depressing to notice that grave trouble continues in the benevolent and beneficent society of Union Square. For some years the New York Republicans found their chief duty and pleasure in electing a State chairman who, in almost a routine or ritual proceeding, was badgered and thrown out in favor of a successor destined to the same treatment.

Five store units in the building at the southwest corner of Northern and Parsons Boulevards, Flushing, Queens, have been leased by the Marcel Parsons Club, Inc., Marcel Cornibert, president, and are being remodeled for occupancy as a night club and restaurant.
The Rev. Thomas A. McGovern, permanent pastor of Holy Name Catholic Parish, which he founded in 1909, and one of the best-known priests in Springfield Diocese, died here today. He was 67 years old.

Sidney Claman, owner and operator of the Hotel Times Square in West Forty-third Street, has purchased the twelve-story Hotel Breslin, a 400-room building at the southeast corner of Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, it was announced yesterday.

George H. Rhinehart, recently elected president of the Trust Company of North America, was entertained last night at a dinner by more than 200 of his friends at the Lawyers Club. Jacob Schapiro, chairman of the institution, was toastmaster.
A stream of cancellations of steamship passage booked for the coronation in London has altered the entire picture of American participation in the colorful ceremonies, it was revealed yesterday.

The Governor is to be congratulated on his appointment of Mr. CHARLES POLETTI to succeed the late Judge McAVOY in the Supreme Court of this State. Mr. POLETTI has a brilliant student and professional career, but he has also found time to give to the State a service of exceptional merit as a private citizen.
Dr. Preston P. Satterwhite of 960 Fifth Avenue will leave today for Louisville, Ky. On his return in a fortnight, he will go to Preston Hall, his country place in Great Neck.

William Hastie, district judge of the Virgin. Islands, will attend his first reception to be given in Government House tomorrow by Lawrence Cramer, Governor of the islands, to permit the judge to meet officials and prominent persons of the community.
Tiger batsmen raked four pitchers for fifteen hits, including Gerald Walker's second home run of the season, taking the Browns into camp today, 11 to 5, before 10,000 spectators.

Herbert Morrison, British labor leader and chief of the London County Council, sailed on the lin-r Normandie yesterday after a four weeks' tour of the United States. During his visit in Washington he had a conversation with President Roosevelt, whom he termed "a most remarkable man."

Censored dispatches from Rio de Janeiro say Governor J. A. Flores da Cunha of Rio Grande do Sul has accepted the situation created by President Getulio Vargas's decree depriving him of authority to enforce martial law in his State, which virtually deprives him of governing power.

A State "luxury" tax to provide for hospitalization of the indigent, thus relieving the burden of high costs for those who can afford to pay, has been recommended to the Medical Society of New Jersey by its advisory committee on hospital relationships.

The start of the season for the new international one-design class yachts, originally slated for next Saturday and Sunday, has been deferred, according to an announcement yesterday. The opening races for the new boats for the James D. Sparkman Trophy have been postponed until May 15 and 16, in order to allow boats that have not as yet been commissioned to participate in the series.

The American yacht Midge II, sailed by Issac Patch Jr., took the first of the series of Star Class races, for the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy, today. The race was sailed in a light, fluky northerly wind over a windward and leeward course, the boats going twice round.

Jesse L. Livermore testified in Supreme Court yesterday that most of his living expenses now were paid by his present wife, despite reports that he was making a "come-back" in Wall Street after going through his fourth bankruptcy.

District Attorney Cleon B. Murray revealed tonight his intention to open a grand jury investigation into activities in Father Divine's Ulster County "heavens." The prosecutor's first move was to serve a grand jury summons on Faithful Mary, former lieutenant of the Negro cult leader whom followers refer to as "God."
The Shirt Institute, Inc., composed of about ninety manufacturers of men's dress shirts in the metropolitan area, will hold its annual dinner in the Hotel Biltmore on Saturday night, May 8.

Trudi Schoop, the Swiss mime who made her American debut last season, has ensconced herself and her little company in the Longacre Theatre for a brief engagement in a new full-length dance comedy called "Blonde Marie."

A Rip Van Winkle who returned to Washington after an absence of four years might rub his eyes at some of the changes which are apparently in progress. The same Government which used NRA in 1933 to grant exemption from the Anti-Trust Laws is now urged by its own Attorney General to make the Anti-Trust Laws more effective.

Anti-Semitic riots between students closed the Academies of Commerce and Agriculture today. The police dispersed students who demonstrated before the Ministry of Education after clashes between Jewish and non-Jewish students had brought the closing order.

A direct statement that railroads the country over soon will face demands for higher wages came today from a meeting of a mediation board trying to solve labor problems of the Southern Pacific Railroad.

The results of the visit to Bucharest of Colonel Josef Beck, Polish Foreign Minister, are summarized in today's official Gazeta Polska as a reinforcement of the alliance based on mutual respect of "sound egoism" and the national interests of Poland and Rumania.
A new favorite for the Epsom Derby, the French colt Le Ksar, emerged tonight from the 129th running of the historic Two Thousand Guineas, first of the season's classic stake events for 3-year-olds.

Sales of copper were made abroad in the early trading yesterday at 13.90 to 13.95 cents a pound c.i.f., European base ports. This compared with a range of 13.85 to 14.20 cents on Tuesday. However, export sales dried up on a further decline in prices on the London Metal Exchange.
The W. Arthur Cunningham Junior High School at Avenue S and East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday with many tributes to the late Controller, whose name it bears.

Mrs. Ethel Cheney Thorne, wife of Samuel Thorne, New York lawyer, died here today at her home of heart disease, from which she had suffered intermittently for ten years. Mrs. Thorne was born in Boston fifty-nine years ago, a daughter of the late Arthur and Emeline Lewis Cheney.

The text of the correspondence between Senator Ashurst, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and Stanley Reed, Solicitor General, concerning the effects of the Roosevelt judicial reorganization plan on the Supreme Court's work, was as follows:

A progressive rise in the prices of all agricultural products, particularly wheat, barley, beans and lentils, to unprecedented levels is causing a widespread discussion that now is going beyond the limits of the economic problem and into the dangerous sphere of politics.
Those Peace Bridge robins are back again-back to their penthouse at the immigration headquarters of the international span between this city and Buffalo.

A swank $3,000,000 vacation spot at Grand Beach, Mich., sixty-five miles from Chicago and on Lake Michigan, will be James J. Braddock's training camp for his scheduled world heavyweight championship bout with Joe Louis here June 22.

An impression of Rembrandt's famous etching and drypoint, "Christ Healing the Sick," better known as the "Hundred Guilder Print," was sold for $1,750 last night to the firm of Charles Sessler at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at an auction of engravings and etchings from three private collections.
The German press is beginning to take to task those moviegoers who laugh at pathetic and tragic scenes in new German films, now produced under virtual government supervision.

STEAMING this way on the Bremen-and the word "steaming" is used advisedly-Herr Max Schmeling said just before he walked up the gangplank in Germany the other day that he expected the New York State Athletic Commission to do something for him in case Jim Braddock fails to keep the engagement with him in the Long Island Bowl.

Dr. Harold W. Dcdds, president of Princeton University, announced today that Princeton would not send an official delegation to the twohundredth anniversary celebration of Goettingen University, although a formal greeting in Latin has been sent to the Rector.

Mr. and Mrs. Wright Barclay of 1,165 Park Avenue were hosts at a buffet supper with dancing last night in the Candle Light Room, 12 East Sixtieth Street. Mr. and Mrs. C. Douglass Green gave a dinner in the Persian Room of the Plaza, later taking their guests to the supper.

The French Parliament's Cinema Commission today heard representatives of the United States film industry explain that American movies were extremely moral since they did not glorify wrongdoers and always showed the forces of law and order triumphant.

Wider interest in national and international affairs became a part of the future program of the council of the General Federation of Women's Clubs here today, but the issue of whether to approve or condemn the Roosevelt court plan threatened to disrupt the federation's business.
G. A. Litchfield, owner, editor and publisher of The Boston Daily Traveler from 1898 to 1908, died at his home today at the age of 98. He had lived here since his retirement in 1911.

The United Rubber Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, signed their first contract with a major rubber company late today ending a twomonths strike of 10,000 employes at the Firestone Tire Rubber Company.

Embezzlement and misuse of millions of rubles by Soviet trade unions is charged by Trud, the organ of the Central Council of Trade Unions in an editorial rebuking the council itself for lax financial methods.

The Stock Exchange has authorized listing of 450,000 shares of Hinde Dauch Paper Company common stock, $10 par value; $130,000,000 Philadelphia Electric Company first and refunding mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series due in 1967;

A groom walked a half-mile through the ankle-deep mud at Jamaica yesterday, leading to the post the Jamestown gelding, Rebeliion. This handsome chestnut, a blaze of light away from the barrier, but a quitter in the stretch. is one of the most nervous horses in the barn of George D. Widener.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Wagner's discussion of the Labor Relations Act in your issue of April 25 and your reply thereto urges me to supplement your answer.

Mutual savings bankers of the na tion, in annual conference yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria, heard a savings banker describe an improved outlook for railroads, a railroad labor leader plead for fair play in labor-capital relations and an economist paint an optimistic picture of a future "more promising and secure" than ever before for the average American.

Successful advertising this year has to give more thought to the factors which influence people and to the means of reaching them, Ben Duffy, vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., said here yesterday.

David Saperstein, director of the trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said last night in an address at a monthly meeting of the Cashiers Association of Wall Street that "most securities are altogether insecure" and that the insecurity of securities was one of the most obvious lessons to be derived from a study of corporate finance.

Plans for apartment houses were announced yesterday in connection with sales of properties in the Bronx A six-story elevator building will be erected at the southwest corner of Bedford Park Boulevard and Briggs Avenue, where a plot 119 by 100 feet has been purchased by the Commonwealth Syndicate, Inc.

Movements on the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 15,000, including 5,000 direct. Market strong to 5 higher than Tuesday's best time: early bulk good and choice 200300 pound, $10.15-$10.35;

The British steamer Backworth, toward whose cargo David Lloyd George contributed [Pound]250, arrived here at 5 P. M., having been accompanied by a British destroyer to the limit of Spanish territorial waters. She carried coal, wood, in addition to 200 tons of food presented by British subscription.

Mrs. Juila Brown Fincke Humphreys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Clarke Fincke of this city and Fair Haven, N. J., was married yesterday to Edwin Lewis Singleton in the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street. The Rev. T.

Miss Edith Dent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Magruder Dent of Greenwich, gained the riding championship at the annual Spring senior horse show of Rosemary Hall School at the Round Hill Stables today. Miss Helen Donner of Boston was second.
With the largest entry in its seventeen years, the Essex Troop of the 102d Cavalry tonight opened its annual Newark Horse Show in the great arena of its armory in Roseville Avenue.

Albert Bein, playwright, who won a Guggenheim scholarship last year, testified yesterday as his own witness in his plagiarism suit against Warner Brothers Pictures, alleging that Edward Chodorov's "The Mayor of Hell" was based on his play, "Little 01' Boy" and a book, "Youth in Hell."
Aurora borealis, the enemy of telegraph services, struck in record fashion throughout the Dominion today. Not for ten years has the magnetic pole's interference been so widespread.
Mrs. William Feick of Scarsdale, N. Y., gave a luncheon today at the Casino for Mrs. George S. Eccles, Mrs. John C. Wright, Mrs. Victor F. Rotering, Mrs. J. T. Rohr and Mrs. C. C. Burnes.

Francis Bennett Gerrard, former vice presiSent of the Commercial Cable Company in New York, died last night at Halifax at the age of 82. He was well known in New York, where for many years he was connected with the cable business.

A program to give the coat and suit industry a voice in Federal, State and municipal legislation through "constant vigilance" on all legislation by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board was approved at a meeting of that body at 132 West Thirty-first Street yesterday.
A sharp drop in commodity prices on world markets forced the liquidation today of Cudebec Co., an American private bank. The bank was unable to meet its New York commitments.

The airmail plane Venezolana, missing since Friday, was reported tonight to have been found near the Cuyuni River. The report, which came through usually reliable channels, said one passenger and the pilot had been injured and were left with the plane by the other passenger, the co-pilot and the wireless operator, who made their way to Eldorado.

Mrs. Agnes McKinnon Read, widow of Walter C. Read, president of the New Jersey Brush Manufacturning Company in Newton, died here today at her home after a long illness. She lived with her son, Kenneth Read. Her age was 72.
The National Safety Council reported today that about 8,500 persons died in traffic accidents during the first quarter of 1937, a 26 per cent increase over the same period of last year.

Proceeding on the theory that an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure, President Ford C. Frick of the National League yesterday summoned Burleigh Grimes, manager of the Dodgers, to a conference at league headquarters this morning before the Giants and Dodgers renew hostilities at the Polo Grounds.

The Japanese freighter Kamikawa Maru established a new record for the run from Yokohama to New York on her maiden voyage which ended late Monday night, it was announced yesterday by officials of the Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, her owner.
Judge Mortimer W. Byers in United States District Court, Brooklyn, confirmed yesterday a report of Special Master Stephen Callaghan that the Symes Foundation, Inc.;

Unfounded rumors cabled abroad that the murder of the daughter of the Paraguayan Minister to Austria-the attractive and talented 29-year-old Ingrid Wiengreen-at Neunkirchen in Lower Austria last Sunday was carried out by Nazis for political reasons were finally disposed of today.

Deliveries of rayon staple fabrics during March were the highest for any month on record, according to the index compiled by the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., and the Rayon Weavers Association, Inc.

General John J. Pershing, former commander-in-chief of the A. E. F., sailed yesterday on the President Harding of the United States Lines for London as an official delegate of the United States to the coronation.

Peddie's baseball team halted Lawrenceville by 3-2 in a hard-fought game today. Joe Wolcott drove a single with two on base to tie the score in the fifth after Lawrenceville had gained a 2-0 advantage.
The Reds won their first game of the National League season today, scoring a 10-to-8 decision over Chicago that also cost the Cubs the services of their ace left-hander, Larry French, for two months.

The "collectivist" philosophy underlying the New Deal administration is basically the same as the philosophy underlying fascism and communism, Ogden L. Mills declared last night in a lecture at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

Despite Republican attempts to eliminate the item, the House voted $700 today to provide a suitable medal for George M. Cohan, actor and theatrical producer, as a tribute to his work during the World War and for composing the song, "Over There."

The J. G. Brill Company, a subsidiary of the American Car and Foundry Company, which manufactures electric and steam railway cars, trucks and like equipment, reported yesterday for 1936 its first net profit in many years.

After a sinking spell which made it impossible for District Attorney William C. Dodge to question him, Justice John F. O'Neil of the Municipal Court, who was stabbed at Sixth Avenue and Twelfth Street Tuesday by an assailant who escaped, rallied in the afternoon and last night was reported to be "slightly improved."

In the same afternoon--yesterday--that Senator Pittman announced a conference agreement on the new war-policy bill, the House Committee on Military Affairs voted a favorable report on a proposed statute to "take the profit out of war." Were the Capitol a stage, there should have arisen a cry of "Author."

ANDRE MALRAUX, former commander of the International Brigade's Loyalist Air Force in Spain, sat in a Central Park West hotel room talking in rapid spurts of the line-up of the armies in Spain. He spoke of the mechanized forces under General Franco, the trucks, the fast Italian airplanes, the well-armed infantry. "What about your infantry?" he was asked.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Glasgow, daughter of Mrs. Edward Lincoln Glasgow of this place, and the late Colonel Glasgow, U. S. A., to Alfred A. Fraser 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Fraser of 828 Park Avenue, New York, and Lane's End, Water Mill, L. I.

Choral work that could be wholeheartedly endorsed for its vigor, alertness and spontaneity was put forth by the Down Town Glee Club at the Spring concert of its eleventh season, given in Carnegie Hall last night under the able direction of Channing Lefebvre.

Following meetings of local councils throughout the State last night, several hundred representatives of the Associated Service Industries were scheduled to move upon the State Capitol in Albany today to urge the passage of the McElroy bill designed to set up fair trade practices for some 600,000 small merchants and employes in service lines throughout the State, it was announced yesterday by John Lyons, chairman of the organization.

The relief rolls of the Board of Child Welfare in this city will be opened to illegitimate children and the children of divorcees on Saturday when the provisions of the new State Social Security Law covering aid to dependent children become effective.

The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, controlled by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in its report for the three months to March 31 shows a net income of $4,376,783 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.

Albert W. Staub, director of the Near East College Association, and Miss Henderika Rynbergen, a Simmons College graduate and founder of the Department of Dietetics in the American University Hospital which is connected with the medical school of the university in Beirut, Syria, will be guest speakers tonight at a dinner to be given by the Alumnae Association of Simmons at Midston House, Madison Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

March sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district averaged 21.4 per cent higher than in the corresponding period in 1936, the largest increase since last July, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent here.

Speeding South for a vacation of tarpon fishing off the Texas coast, President Roosevelt conferred tonight over the dinner table with Senator Harrison. who as chairman of the Finance Committee is responsible for all revenue raising bills in the Senate.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relatidns Board, last night summoned attorneys for the International Mercantile Marine Company, the International Seamen's Union and the rank-and-file group of union members to a conference today on the question of union leadership.
A bank teller and a messenger were held up in the street here this afternoon and robbed of $4,800 in old onedollar notes.

More than $3,000,000 has been expended on German-Jewish relief since Chancellor Adolf Hitler came into power by the American Joint Distribution Committee which is conducting relief activities in Europe.
The Standard Oil Company of Indiana announced tonight that because of the Supreme Court's ruling on the Wagner Labor Relations Law, it was abandoning its eighteen-yearold industrial relations plan.

More than 1,200 persons attended yesterday the third annual musicale-luncheon and bridge party of the Godmothers League at the Hotel Astor. The league sponsors the Day and Night Shelter for Babies, at 115 East 101st Street.
The Northwestern Ohio Natural Gas Company notified city officials today that it would cease natural gas service within the city limits on Aug. 2. It serves 60,000 homes here.
Four New Yorkers asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine deficiencies totaling $487,433 in income tax, fraud penalties and interest assessed for various periods from 1925 through 1933.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine warned members of the force yesterday against laziness, disrespect for the public and violation of departmental regulations. He spoke at the sixth annual luncheon of the Lieutenants Benevolent Association at the Hotel Commodore. About 1,000 persons attended.

Inquiries on behalf of individuals and organizations collecting funds for both factions in the Spanish civil war were received in the capital today as a result of the compromise neutrality resolution agreed upon yesterday by Senate and House conferees, which is expected to be enacted by both houses tomorrow.

Conferees on the shoe strike adjourned abruptly at 8:30 tonight. They insisted, however, that there was still a chance of reaching a basis of negotiation in discussions which grew vehemently argumentative this morning and looked virtually hopeless throughout the day.

One hundred and twenty-eight needy musicians are on the rolls as receiving aid from the Musicians Emergency Fund, it was revealed yesterday by Mrs. Vincent Astor, who presided at a luncheon meeting of the organization held at the St. Regis Hotel.

The principles of the Railway Labor Act were hailed as making for industrial peace by Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, and P. W. Litchfield, president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, today, in commending, at the second day's meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, study of the act with a view to ascertaining how it might be used in general industry as well as transportation.

Formation of the Committee for American Private Enterprise, with members representing business and industry from all parts of the State, was announced yesterday by Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council.

Keglers from New Jersey dominated the scene during the fiftieth day of the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday, virtually monopolizing the alleys as well as accounting for all the principal performances.
Plans for the construction of a new film theatre on the southwest corner of Broadway and Fortyninth Street were announced yesterday by B. S. Moss, operator of the Criterion and other houses.

Dr. and Mrs. Charles Beatty Worden of Princeton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ora Otis Worden, to James Miles Hubball, son of Samuel Williams Hubball and the late Mrs. Hubball of Pasadena, Calif., and Vancouver, B. C.
Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson will be free on next Tuesday to become the Duchess of Windsor, if her divorce keeps its schedule in the courts.

Professor William Z. Ripley of Harvard said today that "the bandyingabout" of the Van Sweringen rail empire and other recent events "emphasize the importance" of the O'Mahoney Federal Incorporation Bill.

The plant of the General Optical Company, manufacturers of lenses and optical instruments,was shut down today when 300 employes went on strike for a $15 weekly minimum wage, a 15 per cent salary increase, one week vacation with pay and a closed shop.

" The worst famine of the last 100 years" is the report telegraphed from Chengtu to Nanking by General Chu Chinglan, chairman of the National Relief Commission, who has just flown over Szechwan on an investigation tour.
Stymies will not be played in Westchester events this year, it was announced yesterday by Thomas W. Bresnahan, president of the Westchester County Golf Association.
Electric power production increased less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index declined to 106.0 from 106.8. It was 98.8 for the week ended April 25, 1936.
John Garland Pollard, chairman of the Board of Veterans Appeals and former Governor of Virginia, died today at his home of bronchial pneumonia. He was 65 years old.
Representative Clarence Lea or California, chairman of the House Commerce Committee, urged today early Congressional action on a bill to provide Federal control of natural gas in interstate commerce.

The AllIndia Congress party's working committee, which convened at Allahabad on Monday, endorsed today Mohandas K. Gandhi's conciliatory interpretation of the conditions under which the party would agree to take office in the six provinces where it has legislative majorities.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. George Linn Kieffer, statistician of the National Luthern Council, was held last evening at 8 o'clock in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

The Dartmouth lacrosse team opened its home season today by crushing M. I. T. by 18 to 1 in a New England League contest. Led by Harris and Pickering, who scored four goals apiece, the Green took an early lead to be in front, 12-0, at the half.

Customs agents in the guise of seamen seized three men early yesterday on a charge of smuggling forty pounds of crude gum opium on the liner President Harding at Pier 59, Hudson River. They will be arraigned today before United States Commissioner Garrett W Cotter.

Mrs. William Church Osborn is retiring from the presidency of the board of managers of the Bellevue School of Nursing, a post she has held for thirty-two years. She is succeeded by Mrs. Linzee Blagden, former executive vice president of the board.

L. F. Loree received $45,000 salary from the Kansas City Southern Railway last year, according to the company's annual report to the Interstate Commerce Commission. He resigned as chairman of the executive committee last May and as chairman of the board on Dec. 31. His salary in 1935 also was $45.000.
Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, six-time women's national golf champion, said today she hoped to regain the title at Memphis this year. The crown was won last year by Miss Pamela Barton of England.

J. Bryon Creamer, 23 years old, of 1 Spier Avenue, Allenhurst, ended his life about 10:30 o'clock this morning by jumping from the George Washington Bridge at a point about forty feet from the New Jersey shore.

The first election to determine whether the United Automobile Workers of America should represent employes of a major automobile producer in collective bargaining sent 14,800 Packard Motor Car Company workers to voting booths today and tonight.

Austin Prokop of Stuyvesant won the William F. Strobel Medal, emblematic of the P. S. A. L. individual form fencing championship, by outscoring seven rivals in a roundrobin competition at the City College School of Business yesterday. The victorious foilsman compiled an average of 8.34.
The "offspring" of the noted elm at Daniel Webster's birthplace in Salisbury, planted by the statesman's father more than 175 years ago, has assumed the burden of spreading its fame.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Eleanore Davison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Davison of Hightstown, N. J., to Robert Arthur Lang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur C. Lang of New York and Old Lyme, Conn.
The Securities and Exchange Commission learned today about women's intuition from Mrs. Evelyn Mendelssohn of Detroit, a wealthy widow.

Three former champions were restored to national fencing titles last night on the strips of the New York Athletic Club. Before a large gallery in the flag-draped gymnasium Joseph L. Levis of the Salle d'Armes Peroy, Lieutenant Thomas J. Sands of the Fencers Club and Dr. John R. Huffman of the home club regained the foils, epee and saber honors respectively.

President Roosevelt resorted to a ruse last night to prevent his sleep from being disturbed. His special train for the South did not leave Union Station until 6 o'clock this morning, although the White House had issued an official itinerary giving the departure time as 1 o'clock.
The Manchukuo government, in a vigorous protest to the Soviet Union today, charged Soviet secret police with the "abduction" of two Manchukuo citizens, one a woman, at Blagovestchensk, Siberia.
The House balked today at providing funds for starting construction of a $112,000,000 dam proposed as the first link in a "super-dam" to control floods on the Ohio, Tennessee and Cumberland Rivers.
Spring conference of the Controllers Institute of America begins at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this morning at 10 o'clock and continues all day. Afternoon session 2:30 o'clock. Dinner at 7 P. M.

Outstanding among the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday was one for three floors consisting of approximately 50,000 square feet at 601 West Fiftieth Street, taken by Richard G. Krueger, Inc., toy manufacturers. Adams Co. negotiated the lease for Vincent Astor. Expansions and renewals featured the general activity. Other reported contracts follow:

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that the Interstate Commerce Commission has extended for thirty days the effectiveness of its order defining the commercial zone of New York City under the terms of the Federal Motor Carriers Act.
Edward Albright, United States Minister to Finland, and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Scribner are among the passengers arriving tonight from Europe on the Washington of the United States Lines.

Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant Jr. of Atlanta a rived at the Homestead today to play in the annual Spring tournament. His coming had been eagerly anticipated by the gallery, which had almost given him up. He was accompanied by his doubles partner, Marion Reese.
It now appears that local member banks will meet with entire comfort the final increase in reserve requirements which is to take effect on Saturday.

Except for United States Government issues, which went forward on renewed assurances from Washington that the Federal Reserve System had been an active buyer, bonds dealt in on the New York Stock Exchange followed a declining trend yesterday.
The Bank of America announced today that its stockholders had approved a two-for-one stock split to facilitate distribution of the stock to shareholders of the Transamerica Corporation.

The estate of George Ehret, brewer, increased $3,647,553 in value since April 30, 1931, and was worth $8,713,334 on Feb. 18 last, according to an accounting filed yesterday. It was made necessary by the death of his daughter, Baroness Anna M. von Zedlitz, mole surviving executor of his estate, who died on Feb. 18 last.

Establishment of a permanent planning roup charged with the task of coordinating the activities of all hospitals, dispensaries and like institutions in the metropolitan area, to the end that the public may be better served, has been recommended by the Hospital Survey for New York, sponsored by the United Hospital Fund.
MANHATTAN BAKER, CHARLOTTE M. (May 29. 1935). Gross assets. $215,536; net, $204,894. To Stephen D. Baker, husband. Chief assets. stocks and bonds, $185,265. Atwater Clarke. attorneys. 2 Park Av.

A naval investigation has found no basis for charges that dope peddling, organized and open gambling and perversion exist at the Naval Prison at Portsmouth, N. H. The investigation was suggested by Senator Bridges of New Hampshire.

A garden party under the auspices of the Netherland-America Foundation will be held on Saturday afternoon at Paradou, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Theodore Scheepers in Brookville, L. I., in celebration of the birthday of Princess Juliana of the Netherlands. W. P. Montiin.

Most commodity futures were sharply lower in active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, tin, cocoa and copper futures were the heaviest losers. Domestic sugar futures, the exception to the downward movement, ruled steady.

George Fabry, as a riding master, lost his sight in a fall from a horse twenty-five years ago and, after casting about for a time, became a news stand operator. Since then he has put in long hours in all kinds of weather, working overtime to keep his stand and the sidewalk near it meticulously clean. Yesterday he was rewarded.

A plan designed to convert the loss suffered by the owners of 65,000 New York tenement houses into a $67,500,000 profit in three years was recommended yesterday to the Joint Committee on Low Priced Housing by its chairman, James J. Lyons. Borough President of the Bronx. Mr. Lyons's proposal was contained in a letter addressed to Alderman Edward J. Sullivan, vice chairman of the committee.

Rainbow, the America's Cup defender of three years ago, which is to be a contender again for the international match honor the coming Summer, will not be under sail before May 20. That is the estimate of Chandler Hovey, who purchased her last Winter from Harold S. Vanderbilt.

On Saturday morning this expedition will set out from here bound for American waters to continue the long quest of the America's Cup. The little fleet consists of four vessels-the two Endeavours and their consorts.

Films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools. The list follows:
Captain the Hon. Frederick Edward Guest, former Secretary of State for Air, died of pleurisy today at Sunburyon-Thames. He was 61 years old.

" Orchids Preferred," a new musical comedy in two acts and twelve scenes, book and lyrics by Fred Herendeen, music by Dave Stamper, staged by Alexander Leftwich, produced by Charles H. Abramson, was presented tonight for the first time at the Forrest Theatre.

Compositions of Paolo Gallico and Goddard Liederson were performed last night at the WPA Theatre of Music in the Composers' ForumLaboratory. Mr. Gallico's works were "West-Montereyan Rhapsody" and "East-Worldly Rhapsody."

Circuit Judge Arthur Webster today convicted seventy-nine women and forty-one men, arrested during the eviction of sit-down strikers from the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company plant here. They were charged with contempt of court.

The Assembly paused in its work today to congratulate Governor and Mrs. Lehman on their twenty-seventh wedding anniversary. Mrs. Lehman was sitting in the rear of the chamber when Assemblyman Steingut, the Democratic leader, interrupted a heated debate.

Pressing irresistibly onward, the Yankees, with Lefty Gomez cutting a handsome figure on the firing line, annexed their fourth straight victory of the championship season today by bringing down the Senators, 6 to 1.

Preliminary returns indicate that earnings of the railroads in March reached the highest levels since the boom year 1929. The result was obtained despite the loss of the emergency freight surcharges that expired on Dec. 31.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Seymour S. Bernfeld of New York was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 621-First National Bank and Trust Co. of Bridgeport, Conn.. trustee, petr., v. Francis E. Beach. argued for both.

Lefty Vografos and Moe Wallberg engaged in a keen pitchers' duel as the New York University freshman nine and the George Washington High team struggled to a 1-all tie yesterday at Washington Stadium. The game was called at the end of the ninth by agreement.
The board of directors of the Audit Bureau of Circulations, at a recent meeting in New York, adopted the new two-page publishers' statement forms for magazines, farm papers and business papers.

TOBIAS AND THE ANGEL, a play in three acts and six scenes, by James Bridie. Staged by Ellen Van Volkenberg; scenery by Samuel Leve; costumes designed by Mary Merrill; music composed by Lora Deja and arranged by Nelle Fisher: presented by the Studio Theatre unit of the Federal Theatre Project.

The Fifth Avenue Association appealed yesterday to members of the Assembly to vote favorably upon a bill which would give the New York City Tunnel Authority the power to construct the proposed midtown underpass between Second and Tenth Avenues.
Mrs. Flora MacDonald Woodcock Potter, widow of Frank H. Potter and sister-in-law to the late Bishop Henry Codman Potter, died yesterday at her town residence, 150 East Seventy-second Street.

Prediction that retail sales of furs this year will reach record proportions, equaling or exceeding the $500,000,000 done in the peak year of 1929, was made yesterday by Louis F. White of Vogel, White Co. and chairman of the Fur Fashion Show and Exposition to be held here in June.

Shifting auditoriums from the Eastman Theatre to Kilbourn Hall, the Eastman School of Music festival was devoted today to chamber music. In the afternoon, Irene Gedney, in earlier years piano recitalist of this festival, played what was called a symposium of unpublished music for piano by American composers.
Miss Sara Lippincott Richards gave a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room of Sherry's for Mrs. Pierson Mapes.
Seldom has a Macedonian cry been answered so promptly as Dr. BERNARD SACHS'S plea for a little more discipline in the training of children and
The Phillies won their fourth game in six starts today, piling up an early lead to defeat the Bees for the third straight time, 7 to 4. The victors moved into third place.
The mints are producing the greatest number of coins in their history, and Nellie Tayloe Ross, mint director, says an upturn in business is responsible.
The German Government formally inaugurated today a new private clearing system for German-American trade by which it hopes to obtain increased quantities of American raw materials.
Special tax school district bonds of Dade County, Fla., in the amount of $7,574,000 were purchased yesterday by R. E. Crummer Co. of Chicago on a bid of 101 for the securities as 43/4s.

After many months of careful study, the Citizens Committee on V the Control of Crime in New York, Inc., announced yesterday that it had completed detailed plans for combating organized crime and for assisting in the more efficient administration of justice in this city.

Disorderly charges against Mrs. Tuppie Seymour, 37 years old, of 75 East Fifty-fifth Street, and her two sisters, Mrs. Edith McNab and Mrs. Robert Adams, were withdrawn yesterday in Jefferson Market Court.

Between forty and fifty families, numbering about 250 persons, were removed from their homes tonight as flood waters of the Thames River overran an area two miles square. Hundreds from the surrounding territory fled their homes.

The worst magnetic storm in a hundred years has been raging during the past four days in the great ocean of magnetism surrounding the earth, it was reported today at the meeting of the American Geophysical Union by Dr. A. G. McNish of the Department of Terrestrial Magnetism, Carnegie Institution of Washington.

Net income of the International Business Machines Corporation, ineluding earnings of foreign subsidiaries, amounted to $2,572,311. for the first quarter of 1937, after deducting regular reserves, depreciation and other charges, but before providing for Federal taxes.

Manhattan Alterations 78th St. 166 E. to 5-story tenement; Mutual Life Ins Co of N Y, 32 Nassau St, owner; David E. McElroy. architect; cost. $25,000. Oak St, 51; to 4-story tenement and stores; Ambrosia Guariglia, 230 South St. owner; J. A. Rofrano, architect; cost, $3,500.

Speaker Heck of the Assembly urged Governor Lehman today to break the deadlock over the Governor's proposal to add a fourth cent a gallon to the tax on gasoline. The responsibility, Mr. Heck asserted, rested with the Governor. It was his tax proposal.

In an address at the dedication of a new $71,000 postoffice here this afternoon Postmaster General James A. Farley asserted that the Supreme Court as constituted was an unsurmountable barrier to enactment of progressive legislation contemplated by President Roosevelt and Congress.
Robert Montgomery will emerge this morning at the Capitol as the psychopathic murderer in Metro's screen edition of Emlyn Williams's "Night Must Fall," which Broadway saw earlier this season.

With the Governor's signature of the Fischel bill, New York again has a Minimum Wage Law. The recent decision of the Supreme Court on the Washington State law having wiped out the legislative "no man's land" in this respect, once more women and children will be protected from exploitation by unscrupulous employers.

The Senate Committee on Commerce refused today to accept the suggestion of President Roosevelt, made at a press conference yesterday, that a census of the unemployed was not needed and voted to hold hearings on the Maloney bill, which provides for taking such a census.
The French Government proposed today to take over control of the nation's debtburdened railroads and put them back on a sound basis by boosting freight rates from 10 to 15 per cent.

Yale scored a 19-5 lacrosse victory over Brown today. taking a 6-2 lead in the first period and maintaining it with increasing power in each succeeding chapter. Bob Smith's seven goals exceeded the Brown total. Paul Roche with four and Haviland with three also featured the Yale attack.

Following early rallies from the recent heavy losses, the stock market here reacted in late trading today and most of the gains were lost. Giltedge securities were quiet and German bonds advanced in an otherwise quiet foreign-loan field.

The House of Representatives has voted by more than two to one to repeal the noxious provision of the Income Tax Law compelling publication of the salaries of corporation officials in excess of $15,000 a year. The vote is gratifying.

A judgment for $16,202 was entered today by Judge Robert V. Kinkead in Orphans Court here against Henry C. Steneck of New York, former president of the closed Steneck Trust Company of Hoboken, who is at liberty on bail pending an appeal from a sentence of three to seven years in State's prison for violation of the State banking laws.

The second annual contest for orchestral compositions by nativeborn composers was announced yesterday by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, its sponsors. As in last season's contest, a first prize of $1,000 will be awarded for a work that requires more than twenty-five minutes to play, in any form desired by the composer.

Borough President Ingersoll opened bids yesterday for the largest sewer project in the three years of his administration. The highest bidder submitted a figure of $3,680,000, the lowest, $1,627,947. The award will be made within two weeks.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 27: MAJOR GENERAL Brigham, C. E., Chief of Chemical Warfare Service, 4 months' and 6 days' leave, May 24, and on Sept. 30, retired, upon his own application.

Katharine Cornell now is considering a world tour with a group of American and English players, giving repertory in Australia, New Zealand, Japan, China, India, South Africa, Egypt, Palestine, Europe, Great Britain and, perhaps, South America and Mexico.
