Fifty-eight conventions and trade exhibitions will be held in New York during May and will bring to New York at least 25,000 visitors, according to announcement made yesterday by the convention bureau of the Merchants Association of New York, in issuing its monthly convention list.
Counsel for the Federal Trade Commission elicited further testimony on "price rixing and resale price maintenance" in the retail liquor field,
The problem of evacuating civilians from Bilbao as the Insurgent forces approach is engaging the attention of Wilfred Roberts, a Liberal; the Duchess of Atholl, a Conservative;
Arturo Godoy, heavyweight from Chile, beat Tony Galento, Newark's hard-hitting bartender, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome last night.

Dr. Samuel Wolfe, founder of Temple University Medical School in Philadelphia, died in a hospital here today. His age was 85. He had been associated actively until 1909 with the institution which he founded and had had staff consections with Samaritan, Garretson and Blockley Hospitals.

The Long Island Railroad Company announced yesterday that it would pay at maturity on May 1 the 5,202,100 of 5 per cent twentyyear debentures and the $114,000 of Series "E" 5 per cent equipmenttrust certificates.
Lieutenant James Monroe Richardson, World War flying ace decorated with the Distinguished Service Cross, died on Monday In Hahnemann Hospital, after a brief illness, at the age of 43.
Britishowned airships may be operating between England and Canada, India and South Africa within the next two or three years if plans now under consideration should be realized.

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that he would approve the workmen's compensation retrospective rating plan for use in the State "on an experimental basis" if several amendments to the plan, which he proposed, were accepted.
Federal food experts predicted today that the average family would need a little more money in the next few weeks to pay the grocer, the butcher and the baker.

The Board of Tax Appeals ruled that the National City Bank of New York was $218,973 and $111,910 deficient in 1922 and 1923 income taxes, respectively, as executor of the estate of James E. O'Neil of Garden City, N. Y., former president of the Prairie Oil and Gas Company of Kansas.

A transaction in the Carl Schurz Park section of Yorkville involved the five-story apartment house at 1,660 York Avenue, near the northeast corner of Eighty-seventh Street, which was sold by the Chase National Bank, as trustees, to the Boris Routel Corporation.
With London Stock Exchange values already shrunken by [Pound]500,000,000 compared with the prices of a month ago, the process of deterioration went on almost unchecked in financial markets today.

Hugh Taylor, a deputy sheriff of Harlan County, Ky., testified today before the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage that he had been shot by fellow-deputies and left for "dead" because he failed to take part in the shooting, some weeks before, into the home of M. A. Musick, preacher and union organizer, when a young son of Music was killed.

Willam E. Wheeler, president and general manager of The New York Woman, charged yesterday in a letter to Governor Lehman that interests of the magazine's stockholders were seriously jeopardized by allegedly baseless statements in an affidavit filed in Supreme Court in a proceeding to enjoin further stock sales.

The engagement of $21,603,000 gold in England and for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was the largest single day's taking of gold in England for United States account this year.

Thomas H. Brant, employed for fifty-five years by Park Tilford, grocery and liquor merchants, died early yesterday at the Swedish Hospital in Brooklyn following the amputation of an infected leg. He had worked until a few days ago. His age was 76.

Chiang Chin-ko, prodigal elder son of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, has returned to China after twelve years' residence in Soviet Russia, it was disclosed today, and has made his peace with his father.

With eight women and three men already chosen as jurors to try Ellis H. Parker Sr. and his four co-defendants on Federal charges in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case, the Federal grand jury investigating yesterday's jury-tampering charges called as a witness today William S. Conklin, former press representative of Governor Hoffman of New Jersey.
The four-story dwelling at 314 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, has been sold by Dr. Raymond Sullivan to a client of L. L. Yearsley for investment.
The directors of the New York Telephone Company yesterday called the 61/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the company for redemption on July 15 at $110 a share and accumulated dividends.

The Board of Education at a meeting last night adopted a building contract clause designed to end labor troubles after Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, the only member dissenting, condemned it as illegal and as an attempt to force contractors to employ only union labor.

In 1790 New York inaugurated its first community service for the sick. The city then had only 33,000 inhabitants--no more than Newburgh, N. Y., today. In 1937 the metropolitan area within eleven miles of City Hall has a population of 11,000,000, and the enormous sum of $715,000,000 has been invested in 856 institutions, of which 329 are hospitals.

The Giants and Dodgers collided in another interborough battle at the Polo Grounds yesterday. There were all the trimmings. A pop bottle landed a harmless distance from its traditional target, an ??pire.

Montreal today scored its first victory of the season by defeating the Orioles, 7 ,to 3, in the opening game of their series. The defeat gave the flock undisputed possession of last place. Lauri Myllykangas held the Orioles to five hits. Hal King hit a tworun homer in the eighth.
Princeton returned to the victory column today by defeating Rutgers in a well-played game, 5 to 1. Dawson Farber, sophomore southpaw, outpitched Roy Lins, Scarlet veteran.
The directors of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the common capital stock, payable June 21 to stock of record May 21.
The Senate was in recess, but the Judiciary Committee continued secret deliberations on the Courts Reorganization Bill, and three members announced their opposition to the bill in its present form.
Plans to resume at once the disposal of the war fleet of rusty merchant vessels were announced by the Martime Commission after a long meeting this afternoon.
The Utilities Power and Light Corporation adjourned its annual meeting today until June 15 pending distribution of the annual report in accordance with requirements of the New York Stock Exchange.

Miss Betty Benjamin, granddaughter of the late Professor Charles Avery Doremus, member of an old Dutch family, and of the late Park Benjamin, well-known lawyer, was married to Peter Bradley Clark yesterday afternoon in the Byzantine Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, which had been decorated with yellow Spring blossoms and ferns.

P. L. Smith, financial vice president of the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that his company's $150.000.000 plan to acquire the securities of three other utilities in Illinois was intended to simplify and integrate the utility system of the Chicago area.

The main purpose of the National Labor Relations Board is to arrive at an amicable adjustment of complaints. Our experience has taught us it would often be a mistake to rush the teeth of the law into action. The maladjustments more often are the result of ignorance or a misunderstanding of the law than a stubborn desire to violate it.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 26: CAPTAIN McKee, E. W., the Henderson, to Naval Academy, July 15. COMMANDERS Hall, C. M., to staff. Naval War College, Newport. R. I.
A post position in the Kentucky Derby their goal, six Derby eligibles were listed tonight as starters in the $5,000 added Blue Grass Stakes tomorrow, feature event of Keeneland's closing card.

Yale scored an 8-7 victory over Brown University today when Captain Larry Kelley romped across the plate on Bill Loveday's fly to left field in the ninth inning to end one of the most erratic games here this season.

Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, landed from a special plane this morning and was received by Premier Constantin Kotta, Foreign Minister Ekrem Libohova, General Araniti, commander of the army;
George Washington University alumni, faculty, students, trustees and others will be guests Friday at a dinner marking President Cloyd H. Marvin's tenth year as its head.

Dr. John A. Hartwell of New York City has been named chairman of a volunteer committee to carry on organization plans of Ducks Unlimited in New York State. E. Herrick Low has been chosen treasurer and Rolfe Floyd Ir secretary.

Susan Lawrence Davis, through her attorney, Maxwell E. Sparrow, filed suit in Federal court here yesterday against the Macmillan Company, charging that "Gone With the Wind," by Margaret Mitchell, was a violation of the copyright of a book,
Mrs. A. J. Schultze's 2-year old Miss Georgette ran four and a half furlong in ??3 4-5 seconds to equal the track record and win the feature race today at Arlington Downs.

The idea that Canada, the United States and Britain might make new trade agreements, bilateral in form but trilateral in inspiration, which would give the world an example of freer trade and would be capable of extension to other countries, is being much discussed in Canadian newspapers.

Cooperation to achieve substantial progress in the labeling of merchandise for the information and guidance of consumers in making their purchases was urged by speakers at the "laboratory" luncheon held yesterday by Abraham Straus, Brooklyn.

The Nomad Realty Corp, Rose Levine, president, gave a demand 5 1/2 per cent mtg for $18,000 to the Anelsirom Realty Corp on 280 Madison St. When Rose Hartman bought from the Greater New York Taxpayers Mutual Insurance Assoc the parcel at 1,288 1st Ave for $23,000 she gave back a purchase money mtg for $20,000, due May 31, 1944, at 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

The National Academy of Design at its annual meeting yesterday afternoon unanimously re-elected last year's officers and elevated eight painters, two sculptors, one architect and one etcher from associate membership to full membership. The meeting was held at 175 West 109th Street.

A longtime government policy looking toward the coordination of all means of transport was advocated today by leaders in air, land and water transportation, meeting in round-table discussion held in connection with the sessions of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

MANHATTAN BRADLEY, ELSIE TOTTEN (April 20). Estate, more than $20,000. To Edith Bradley Dinsmore, 1,088 Park Ave., personal effects, chattels and life estate in one-half residue with power of appointment; Allan B. A. Bradley, husband, executor, 969 Park Ave., one-half residue.

Public offering of an issue of 15,000 shares of convertible cumulative $1.40 dividend series $20-par preferred stock of the Credit Acceptance Corporation, Rochester, N. Y., will be made today by Amott, Baker Co., Inc., at $23.50 a share, subject to prior subscription rights to all classes of present stockholders.

Mortgages accepted for examination and valuation by the New Jersey office of the FHA in the last week totaled 218, and carried loans for insurance valued at $1,133,455, according to George B. Underwood, Associated State Director. New construction accounted for eightyfour with loans totaling $515,500.

Still undefeated in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, Theodore A. Dunst yesterday moved closer to Frank J. Marshall, former national champion and leader in the competition, with a score of 7 1/2--1 1/2.
The International Sugar Conference, in formal plenary session, approved tonight a 'network of agreements that is expected to regularize world sugar production and distribution for five years.

Earl Jellicoe and Earl Beatty, Britain's two great World War admirals, who died within a few months of each other, are to be honored like Nelson, Hood and Rodney by having battleships named after them.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for 1936 a consolidated net income of $26,356,003 after all charges and taxes and reserves for depreciation, depletion, amortization and abandonments, equal to $2.90 a share on the 9,076,202 shares of common capital stock outstanding at close of last year after payment of a 100 per cent stock dividend.
Governor Lehman signed three Dunnigan bills insuring a forty-eight-hour week for women employee in hotels and restaurants throughout the State.
After all charges and taxes, the New York Curb Exchange and its subsidiaries in 1936 made a net addition of $327,851 to surplus, it reported yesterday.

An error by the pilot and "improper dispatching" were blamed by the Accident Board of the Bureau of Air Commerce in a report made public today for the wrecking of an Eastern Air Lines plane near Milford, Pa., in December.
A total of [pound]125,262 was realized when the seven-day sale of the art collection of the House of Lionel Rothschild was ended tonight at Sotheby's Galleries.

The Board of Examiners recommends that license as teacher in training in day high schools, in the subjects indicated, be issued to the following applicants, who have met the eligibility and examination requirements therefor:

Howard B. Smith, a mild-mannered 66-year-old man with white hair and mustache, described as one of Father Divine's "angels" and a resident of his "heaven" at Kingston, N. Y., was surrendered by his counsel, N. N. Kranzler of this city, at the United States marshal's office here today to face a conspiracy indictment in Los Angeles.

The National Carloading Corporation, control of which was acquired this week from George A. Ball by Robert R. Young, Frank K. Kolbe and Allan P. Kirby, figured in a hearing held yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission in the Pennsylvania Hotel as part of its investigation into practices followed by freight consolidating and forwarding companies.

Three previously uncommitted members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, all Democrats, publicly expressed themselves today as opposed to President Roosevelt's Court Reorganization Bill, making it apparently certain that the measure would be unfavorably reported to the floor by a vote of at least 10 to 8.
The stock market fell sharply yesterday to new low ground for the year in the heaviest trading in seven weeks. Leading issues dropped 1 to 7 points and a few more than that.

Movements of naval vessels follow, all dates are April 27 unless specified: At Dutch Harbor: Cincinnati, Concord, Dewey, Hull, MacDonough, Worden. Algiers, La. to New Orleans, April 28: Decatur, Moffett. At Sa., Pedro: Kanawha, Utah.

The First Boston Corporation, F. S. Moseley Co., Kean Taylor Co. and R. W. Pressprich Co. Will offer today $7,050,000 of Illinois Central Railroad Series R 3 per cent equipment trust certificates at prices to yield from 0.75 to 3.45 per cent.

Governors Island First Lieut. David S. Boxer. Med-Res., 1.549 E. 33d St., Brooklyn, N. Y., 350th Medical Regiment (RAI), is ordered to active duty for a period of six months. effective May 1. He will proceed to Headquarters Binghamton District, CCC., Binghamton, N. Y., for assignment in connection with CCC activities. Lieut. Boxer will rank from May 27, 1936.
Indignation flared in the House of Commons today over the Spanish Rebel destruction of the open town of Guernica on Monday.

A cable has just been received from Jose Ortega y Gasset, author of a volume of collected essays translated by Mildred Adams and published by Norton today, that he will be unable to make his expected visit here because of illness.

A rejuvenated Brooklyn College nine found its batting eye for the first time this season and pounded Dexter Boerckel for thirteen hits for an 11-to-4 triumph over the Nassau Collegiate Center team of Garden City at Manhattan Beach yesterday.
As Eiji Amau said farewell to the foreign correspondents today his declaration as Japanese Foreign Office spokesman in April, 1934, seemed to have become a dead letter.

Jules S. Bache, banker, has presented his private collection of art, one of the finest of its size in the United States and valued at many millions of dollars, to the State of New York, it was announced yesterday.

The hum of saws and crash of falling trees in the Columbia River Basin has ceased as 6,000 loggers took a "vacation," which some feared might last two or three months, because of a dispute with operators over working conditions.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has sold the two-story taxpayer on the southeast corner of Roosevelt Avenue and 149th Place, in the Murray Hill section of Flushing, Queens, to Lipton-Jentes, Inc. The building contains two stores and two apartments. Franklin E. Tyrrell was the broker.

The People's Tribunal sentenced the Rev. Joseph Rossaint, chief defendant in the Catholic treason trial, to eleven years in the penitentiary today. He was found guilty of "preparation for high treason."

The annual luncheon and meeting of the Colonial Dames of America will be held tomorrow in the roof garden of the Pierre. Walter W. Price will speak on "Tradition and Its Influence on Character, National and Individual." Mrs. Henry G. Bartol heads the committee arranging the event.

The Central Italian Corporative Committee, representing twenty-two corporations embracing every phase of Italian economic life, tomorrow will increase wages of several million workers from 5 to 14 per cent.

Governor Lehman resubmitted the nominations of all except one of the members of the Saratoga Springs Commission to the Senate today, and, with the substitution of Denis J. Parrington of Saratoga Springs for Dr. Carl R. Comstock, early confirmation is expected.

Dividend Shares, Inc.-Report for March 31: Net assets, $44,161,033, with unrealized appreciation $14,324,554, giving a value of $2.087 a share on 21,159,199 shares, against $1.975 a share on Dec. 31 and $1.637 a share on March 31. 1936.
Health Commissioner John L. Rice yesterday urged the healthy children of the city to invest in the Healthy Hearts bond issue of Irvington House tomorrow, Child Health Day.

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the performance of "Miss Quis" last night at the Henry Miller Theatre which had been taken over to raise funds for the Society for the Relief of Half Orphan and Destitute Children. Mr. and Mrs. Duer McLanahan gave one at their home, 175 East Eightieth Street, taking their guests later to the benefit.

Almost 200 controllers responsible for the operating figures of such corporations as Standard Oil of New Jersey, Colgate-PalmolivePeet, New York Central Lines, American Chicle and National Dairy Products were told yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that collective bargaining had become absolutely essential, that Henry Ford was wrong and that the C. I. O. was here to stay.

Although creditable performances were recorded by a number of contestants during the fifty-first day of the American Bowling Congress championships at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday, they created little disturbance among the ranks of the tourney leaders.

A mortgage originally given for $16,000 on 29 Greene St was assigned to the 115 Wooster St Corp by Cortland Betts for a consideration of $8,000. George T. Raab and Blanche N. McCay, as trustees for themselves, have agreed with the Property Realty Corp, Lazare Jacob, president, owner of 102 Canal St and 29 Forsyth St, to extend the mortgage for 339,000 thereon to March 9, 1947, at 6 per cent.

Due largely to the increase in farm income, which has expanded at the rate of $1,000,000,000 annually for the past four years, farm real estate values on March 1 stood at 85 per cent of the 1912-14 level, as against 82 per cent on March 1, 1936, according to a statement today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture.

Mrs. Carl Puhl of Tucson, formerly Mrs. Mary Hight of Chicago, died last night of a heart attack at the age of 52. Formerly Republican national committeewoman, she also was director of the Northwestern University Players and was with the National Broadcasting Company in Chicago three years ago before her marriage to a Tucson merchant.

Stores here were officially notified yesterday that a retail price of $1.96 has been set for a 25-ounce bottle of Government House Rum, produced under the auspices of the Public Works Administration at the Virgin Islands. The notification was made by William A. Taylor Co., wholesale distributors for the rum.
The Rev. Kilian J. Hennrich of New York today presented to the Vatican a "spiritual bouquet" of 25,000,000 prayers gathered by the Catholic Boys Brigade all over the United States.
Homer J. Forsythe of Montclair, N. J., official of the General Motors Corporation, died here today after an appendix operation. He was 52 years old.

Columbus Ave, w s, 100 ft s of 94th St, 20.7x100; Fairbanks Baking Co, Inc, to Ernest B. Keirstead, 101 Belvedere Dr. Yonkers; mtg, $40,000 (50 cents). St Nicholas Ave, 197, 29.7x79.6; Crofton Estates, Inc, to D. and D. Realty Corp, 11 W. 42d St, care of N. A. Lashin: mtg, $19,125 ($1.50).
Dick Shikat, former world's heavyweight wrestling champion, wasted little time in disposing of Frank Sexton, California strong boy, in the feature bout at the Hippodrome last night.
Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta and Wayne Sabin of Hollywood, Calif., disposed of quarterfinal opponents with ease today in the annual Hot Springs tennis tournament.

The United Automobile Workers of America gained recognition as bargaining agency for more than 14,000 Packard Motor Car Company employes tonight with a four-to-one margin in the first governmentconducted election in the automobile industry under the Wagner act.
Colonel Samuel T. Mackall of the military intelligence division of the War Department general staff died in Walter Reed General Hospital yesterday at the age of 56.

A strike was called yesterday in thirty-three body-building plants here by the United Automobile Workers Union, Local 259, in what the union characterized as a move of the Committee for Industrial Organization to organize the automobile industry in the East.
The Blue Ridge Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $53,103,602 at March 31, after provision for normal Federal income tax on unrealized appreciation of investmends.

A clash of opinion on the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act and an appeal to business management to restore the "enterprise principle" and save the American system were the features yesterday of the second day's sessions of the annual conference of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Al Glossop's home-run in the sixth with Frank Pearce on first gave the Chiefs a 4 to 3 victory over the Rochester Red Wings in the series-opener today.

Taking direct issue with an economy proposal understood to have originated with President Roosevelt, Senator Robinson today declared himself in favor of the Bvrnes plan to cut 10 per cent from all appropriations for the fiscal year 1938, excepting those for fixed charges and contractual obligations of the government.

One hundred thousand underprivileged children in camps this Summer is the goal of the Committee on Vacation Homes and Camps of the Children's Welfare Federation of New York City working in cooperation with the second annual Camp Pow-Wow of The Camping World Magazine.

Dr. Gershom Franklin White, senior pathologist of the Federal Bureau of Entomology, died Tuesday of heart disease at the Department of Agriculture laboratories in Moorestown, N. J., where he had been stationed recently.

Norman Hapgood, whose trenchant editorial pen attracted wide attention in the first quarter of this century, died yesterday morning at New York Hospital, 525 East Sixtyeighth Street. He had been ill for several weeks and death followed an operation. He was 69 years old. His home was at 139 East Sixtysixth Street.

Mrs. Jeanette Fishman. in 360 Central Park West; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker. Finley Bailey Krause, through Byrne Bowman, in 1,133 Park Ave.; Reliance Property Management, Inc., broker. John D. Allen, in 47 E. 64th St.; Thomas T. Driver, Frederick G. Carr, Robert T. Meyers, in 440 W. 34th St.; Mrs. Oliver Sawyer, in 2 Beekman Pl.; Albert B. Ashforth. Inc., broker.
Dr. Frank K. Hallock, medical director of Cromwell Hall, a sanatorium for nervous invalids, died there today at the age of 76.

Manhattan 28th St, 346-8 W, 61x42.10; for 3-story nursery; the Ecole Maternele Francaise, premises, owners; A. Freeman, architect; cost, $30,000. Alterations Delancy St, 170; to 6-story tenement and stores; A. Z. Holding Corp, 26 Court St,

Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson directed J. P. Morgan Co. of New York today to return to the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, undisbursed interest of $46,922 due on Jan. 2 last on the iron company's 5 per cent refunding bonds and its twentyyear convertible 6s.

A special performance of excerpts from the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta, "The Grand Duke," will be given tonight at the Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park South, by members of the Blue Hill Troupe of amateur players who appeared in leading roles when the operetta was produced on April 7, 8 and 9 at the Heckscher Theatre for the benefit of Everybody's Thrift Shop.
Clifford Walker, a retired actor who had appeared often on Broadway, died on Wednesday at Liberty, N. Y., of tuberculosis. He was 67 years old.

" The last thing I fear is a boom in business," said Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, after announcing first-quarter results yesterday. He went on to say that he could not understand the atmosphere prevailing in some quarters that there was something wrong with a situation where there was good, sound business and increased employment.

The Roosevelt Savings Bank, Gates Avenue at Broadway, Brooklyn, reported yesterday the following twenty-five sales in various parts of the metropolitan area: In Brooklyn, one-family houses at 760A Quincy Street, to Anna Rieber; 103 Doscher Street,

The price of copper was reduced 1/2 cent a pound in the domestic market yesterday to 14 cents. The price now is 3 cents a pound below the record for the year, established just before President Roosevelt's statement early in April that the price of the metal was too high.
London residents heard with incredulity tonight that the government had failed to avert the threatened "Coronation" strike of 45,000 omnibusmen scheduled to start at midnight tomorrow.
William Gillette, the Sherlock Holmes of the stage, died in Hartford Hospital today of pulmonary hemorrhage. The veteran actor and playwright would have been 82 years old on July 24.
After a brief ownership Loomis J. Grossman has sold the two fourstory apartments at 89-06 146th Street and 145-16 Eighty-ninth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, to an investing client of Low Gross, Inc.

Warning that government ownership and operation of the private banking system would surely follow its failure in another major economic crisis, Raymond N. Ball, president of the New York State Bankers Association, proposed today the establishment of three regional banking research institutes to keep bankers currently informed of developments in all parts of the country.
The second annual Opportunity Contest for Amateur Musicians to be conducted by the Department of Parks was announced yesterday. The contest will be open to junior and senior musicians.
Tomorrow should be for the blind a May Day of special rejoicing. The longawaited social security program for them goes into effect. They will be able to walk with greater security into the future.

A. C. Compten's Weston, often a Maryland failure following his five victories at Santa Anita last Winter, today showed sharp improvement under the handling of Jockey Harry Richards and won the Chincoteague Purse, opening-day feature at Pimlico.

Angelo Trulio, defending champion, and Vladimir Kotal of the West Side Y. M, C. A. gained the final round of the Metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall handball singles championship tournament at the Pastime A. C. last night.

Dissatisfied with the results of a field investigation of the slump in income-tax payments during March, Secretary Morgenthau has instructed Under-Secretary Roswell Magill to make a personal survey of the situation in New York, and possibly other States,

A portrait by Thomas Eakins, "Young Woman in Pink Dress" (Maud Cook), has been bought from the E. C. Babcock Galleries, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street, by Stephen C. Clark, New York collector and trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Two homers from the bats of Ben Sankey and Dan Hafey gave the Montreal Royals their second straight triumph over the Orioles, 2 to 1, today.

Centralized responsibility, in place of the dual authority which led to friction within the Bureau of Air Commerce and criticism from the outside, is provided in the plans for reorganization of the bureau announced today by J. Monroe John- be son, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie May Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tillman 0. Lane of this village, to Clifford S. Willis, son of Dr. and Mrs. William E. Winkelman, took place this evening at the home of the bride. The Rev. Egbert C. Macklin, pastor of the Victoria Congregational Church of Jamaica, officiated.

Governor Lehman submitted to the Senate for confirmation today the renominations of all the members of the Saratoga Springs Commission except that of Dr. Carl R. Comstock, for whom Denis J. Harrington of Saratoga Springs was substituted.
The Federal Reserve System bought $39,657,000 of United States Government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the official summary covering the period, and issued yesterday.

Business in the Pittsburgh district showed almost no change last week, according to figures released by the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Major changes for the week were a decline in the seasonally adjusted index of iron and steel production and a rise in the index of coal production.
Conferees in the Lewiston-Auburn shoe strike ended their fourth day of discussions late today "continuing to strive for agreement."

As 223 Fire Department captains started a two-day test yesterday for promotion to battalion chief, Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott appointed 297 new firemen at the Fire College in Long Island City.

Cammeyer Shoe Shops, Inc., which occupies the store and basement at 427 Fifth Avenue, will move to a new location on the same thoroughfare as the result of a lease yesterday of the six-story and basement building at 448 Fifth Avenue, adjoining the northwest corner of Thirty-ninth Street, the former Wendel residence site on which S. H. Kress erected a store.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended April 29 were announced today: COLONELS Upshur, W. P., Naval Operations, Washington, D. C., to duty as Officer in Command, Marine Corps Reserves, and to duty in Reserve Section, Headquarters, Marine Corps, Washington, D. C., May 15.

Where and when the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson will marry after the latter's final divorce decree is handed down in London Monday is not yet certain. The probabilities are, however, that it will be in this old Touraine town at the British consulate on the Place de Michelet.

The New Rochelle High School baseball team handed the Manhattan freshman nine its third defeat in as many starts by a 3-1 score at Manhattan Field yesterday. The Jasper cubs made only one hit off Burpee and Barillari.

The savings of 6,548 members of twelve building and loan associations in New Jersey, with assets of $9,575,472, will be insured up to $5,000 each by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, it was announced today.

A blond 18-year-old dairyman's daughter with a working knowledge of cows was chosen "Miss Milk Maid of the World," here today. Tied with four others in a beauty contest, Miss Aloha Warner of Fairview, Kan., joined them in a tournament more practical for milk maids, milked 11.25 pounds in two minutes and won with ounces to spare. Her cow,

Closing its 171st annual meeting in Chalfonte-Haddon Hall here tonight, the Medical Society of New Jersey went on record in favor of a State "luxury" tax to provide funds for hospitalization for the indigent.

Net profit of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation and subsidiary and affiliated companies amounted to $1,648,624 after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes, subsidiary preferred dividends, minority interest and other charges, according to the report for the March quarter, announced yesterday.

The Cardinals made only five hits off Ray Davis and Lloyd Moore today, but three were triples and they combined them with three walks and two errors to defeat the Reds, 6 to 1. Only one Cardinal base runner was left stranded.
Catcher Al Todd scored the run that gave the Pirates a 6-5 victory today as Bill Lee, relief pitcher for the Cubs, walked Arky Vaughan in the thirteenth inning with the bases filled.

Miss R. Cordelia Gurnee, daughter of Mrs. Burgess Gurnee of 322 East Fifty-seventh Street, and Frederick L. Stagg, also of New York and La Isla, Quito, Ecuador, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building. No formal announcement of their engagement had been made.

The end of the last season of the Philharmonic - Symphony Society found the organization "not only in a far better position financially than it had dared to hope but with a surplus to carry over to next year," Arthur Judson, the manager, told a meeting of the committee on subscription activities of the society at Steinway Hall yesterday.

Seven Americans have applied for permission to purchase Bermuda properties. Edward Mauran Beals Jr. of Boston seeks two acres on Saint David's Island; George Marion Brown of Pembroke, Bermuda, three-quarters of an acre in Pembroke Parish; George Buell Hollister of Corning, N. Y., two acres in Hamilton Parish; Franklin Kronenburg of Cambridge, Mass.,

Miss Emilia A. Thoorsell, executive secretary of the Girl Scout national camp advisory staff, died Wednesday at the New York PostGraduate Hospital after an illness of six weeks. Miss Thoorsell, who was 40 years old, lived at 7 Mitchell Place.

A six-hour rescue job, the longest which Robert Coles, in twelve years of emergency work for the S. P. C. A., can remember, was successfully completed yesterday in behalf of an unnamed small kitten which had fallen down a ventilating shaft of a six-story apartment house at 245 East Fifty-first Street.
Another fault has been discovered by Montreal philatelists in the new issue of King George VI 3-cent Canadian stamps.

Liquidation in wheat, cotton and rubber carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices lower for the third consecu tive week. The index declined 143. on Tuesday from 144.2 the Tuesday previous and a seven-year high of 145.7 established on March 30 and April 6.

Miss Ruth Nichols, well-known aviatrix and alumna of Wellesley College, will be the guest of honor at the supper dance in behalf of the Wellesley College Swimming Pool Fund to be held tonight in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the New York Wellesley College Club.

The Berkshire School of Crippled and Deformed Children, the Berkshire County Home for Aged Women and the Pittsfield House of Mercy Hospital are named residuary legatees in the will of Mrs. Catherine Pingree Dawes of Pittsfield, who died April 11 at Florence, Italy.

Lamb business continued slow. Trading in steer hinds and ribs was active in some sections and slow in others. Demand for veal and fresh pork was mostly fair. Some sales of plain and medium-grade lightweight lamb were fully $3 or more higher to the Greek trade.
Toronto's Leafs continued on the unbeaten path today when they won their second straight from the Jersey Giants and their seventh International League victory, 7 to 4.

Announcement was made yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, that in conjunction with the Bureau of Internal Revenue the board intended to proceed at once with investigation of complaints concerning violations by employers of the Social Security Act and to penalize those who have willfully violated the act.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

A reported hitch has occurred in negotiations for the establishment of a herring meal and oil reduction plant in Newfoundland by American capital through Stanley Heller, president of the Santa Cruz Oil Company.

The thirteen-room and four-bath residence on a plot of one and onehalf acres, at 50 Heywood Road, Pelham Manor, Westchester, has been sold by Mrs. Henry Fox to James B. Thorpe for occupancy. Chauncey B. Griffen was the broker.

During the week ended April 28 member bank reserve balances increased $57,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves rose from increases of $48,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, and $45,000,000 in gold stock,...

Offenbach's comic opera, "The Grand Duchess," was successfully revived at Daly's Theatre tonight. To tuneful music has been added modernized dialogue, which, except for one or two crudities, is happily inspired and harmonizes with the gay costumes and scenery.

Observance of 148th anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as President, 33 West 116th Street, 9:45 A. M. Speakers: Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein, Isaac Siegel, Emilie M. Bullowa and Professor Irving Mariash.
In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 716-Great Lakes Transit Corp., petr., v. Interstate Steamship Co., et al.-Argument concluded for respondents.

Edward F. Hudson, at 5 Bon Mar Road, Pelham, from Bowery Savings Bank; A. J. L. Haskell, the residence of Mrs. W. L. Harris, in Pelham; Chauncey B. Griffen, broker. Courtlandt D. Barnes Jr., home of Ellery S. Husted, in South Salem, N. Y.; William A. Eldridge, the Edward K. McCagg property onSarles t. Mount Kisco; Beatric L. Renwick, broker.
General Owen O'Duffy's Irish Brigade will abandon its "crusade against communism" in Spain and return to Ireland.

Gustav Schuetzendorf, former baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Company in New York, died Tuesday of heart disease. He was the husband of Grete Stueckgold, operatic and concert soprano, and a brother of the late Leo Schuetzendorf, German baritone.
Charles M. Breder, secretary of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and its subsidiaries, died yesterday at the New York Hospital. He was 67 years old.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

The additional April New York County grand jury in a presentment to General Sessions Judge Allen yesterday, criticized an Aldermanic committee, headed by Alderman James J. Molen of Bay Ridge, for refusing to report out to the Board of Aldermen a bill, known as 118, pending since March 9, to prohibit the sale of bootleg coal in this city.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. O. D. Duncan of this place of the marriage last Friday in Elkton, Md., of their daughter, Miss Jean Duncan, to Howard Wallace Soule Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Soule of Passaic.

Miss Elizabeth Merrill Ames, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfrederick S. Ames of this place, has chosen June 19 for her wedding to Douglas L. P. Hamilton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Hamilton of Milwaukee. The ceremony, which will be performed at the Ames home, will be followed by a small reception.

Fencing, trained by Earl Sande, defeated five other Kentucky Derby eligibles by a length in the $5,000 added Blue Grass Stakes today, including Colonel E. R. Bradley's favored pair, Brooklyn and Billionaire.

The food situation in this city remained acute today despite the arrival of more British food ships. Three got in this morning. The average daily menu even at the best hotels in Bilbao consists of a few potatoes, soggy cabbage and a little black bread.

Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt told a jury trying him on a murder charge today he did not kill his fiancee, declared one of her employes had threatened to prevent their marriage and that she had talked of suicide.

The bulk of large American holdings of land near Mexicali, Lower California, in which more than $10,000,000 in United States capital has been invested, is dividable immediately among Mexican peasants under the agrarian reform program, President Lazaro Cardenas ruled personally today.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday urged college-trained men to enlist in the ranks of the city's Sanitation Department with the aim of advancing to supervisory posts. He made his plea at the annual luncheon of the National Civil Service Reform League in the Hotel Commodore before an audience that included students representing thirtytwo college and universities.

Mrs. Ryc Trier Guggenheim of 305 West End Avenue, widow of Edgar Guggenheim of this city and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Peter Trier, was married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Alexander Lyons in his study to Jack A. Silberman of this city, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Silberman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In our estimate, and still more in our condemnation, of contemporary Germany, let us not forget that there are two distinct opposing Germanys. During the past thirty-five years I have visited the land of Luther on seventeen occasions.

Forty lawyers and examiners have been borrowed by the Maritime Commission from the Department of the Interior, Public Works Administration, Postoffice Department and Reconstruction Finance Corporation to assist in adjusting the fortytwo ocean mail contracts which automatically expire on June 30.
Columbia's rowing squad went through its final heavy drill yesterday on the Harlem River in preparation for its meeting here tomorrow with Yale and Pennsylvania in the Blackwell Cup Regatta.

Ithaca College's music library of more than 2,000 orchestrations was destroyed last night when fire swept the interior of the administration building. Dr. L. F. Rebmann, director of music, estimated the loss at $20,000.

Efforts were under way here yesterday to organize a join protest by a number of trade organizations in the wholesale and retail distributing trades against delaying passage of the Miller-Tydings bill to validate State fair-trade acts in interstate commerce.

Mystery shrouds the motive for the attempted assassination of General Liu To-chuan, made Wednesday at Nanyang, in Honan Province, when an unidentified assailant opened fire with a revolver at short range, wounding the general and his wife.

An increase in Dominion Government deposits of about $1,000,000 coupled with comparatively small reductions in gold, sterling and United States dollars held by the Bank of Canada reduced the bank's net ratio of reserve to 59.29 per cent yesterday from 59.52 the week before, according to today's weekly statement.

Mosawtre did it again yesterday at Jamaica, winning in the same moody fashion that leaves Trainer Max Hirsch wondering whether he has a horse of stake caliber, capable of winning the Kentucky Derby, or merely a keen colt that will win ordinary races.
Warm, drying winds and bright sun today saved Chatham from flood disasters like those the Thames River visited upon London and other municipalities to the east.

Details of the reorganization plan of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company were announced here yesterday by E. Stanley Clines, chairman of the committee for the first terminal and unifying mortgage bonds. It provides for annual fixed charges of $1,868,912 and leaven undisturbed $22,363,000 of the road's obligations,

Approximately 1,000 persons attended the funeral service yesterday afternoon for the Rev. Dr. Charles L. Goodell, Methodist Episcopal clergyman and an early religious speaker on the radio, at the Marble Collegiate Church, Twentyninth Street and Fifth Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, conducted the service, with the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble church, pronouncing the closing prayer and benediction.

Maurice Frere, Belgian financial expert who is visiting European capitals as a special agent of Premier Paul Van Zeeland in search of a plan for world economic and financial stabilization, arrived in Berlin today and had an immediate prolonged conference with Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank.

Commodity futures generally were irregular in active trading on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa futures registered heavy losses in the second largest trading day on the Exchange. On the cash market corn and rye advanced, but copper, tins, cotton, wool tops, wheat, oats, lard and cocoa declined, the latter to a new low for the year.
Baseball's current struggle on the banks of the Potomac continued unchanged today with the Yanks and Senators still moving in opposite directions.

The government has restricted the May Day celebration here. According to the ruling the festival must be held outside the capital. All banners and placards must be approved by the police and must be concealed when carried within the city limits.

Machine-gun and rifle bullets ended an attempted prison break today, killing three convicts and critically wounding another. Guards on the fortress-like walls of the West Virginia penitentiary and within the six-acre enclosure turned their weapons on a truck seized by the four men in their attempt to rush the prison gates.

Governor Lehman will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at Niagara University's commencement exercises June 7. Niagara will also confer honorary degrees on the Most Rev. John A. Duffy, Bishop of Buffalo and chancellor of the university, and Dr. Robert T. Bapst, superintendent of Buffalo schools.

The Davis Cup zone elimination matches between the United States and Japan will start here tomorrow with long-legged Don Budge paired against the island empire's No. 2 shotmaker, Fumiteru Nakano, in the opening skirmish.

An informal supper party, to serve as a reunion of the cast of the New York Junior League "Follies," the show presented by the league last Friday and Saturday at the New Amsterdam Theatre, will be held on May 7 in the Garden of the Ambassador.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from W. Wallace Lyon to Edward R. Whitehead Jr. and from William Stix Friedman to William H. Frank of Smith, Frank Co. Members will ballot on May 13 on proposals to transfer memberships from Don M. Kelley to William P.

The April Suffolk County grand jury, discharged today, did not return criminal assault or murder indictments against Howard Magnussen, 27 years old, of Huntington Station, L. I., who was arrested in connection with the death March 1 of 4-year-old Joan Morvan.
A pre-Derby dinner dance, with typical Southern beverages and menu, was given by the Kentucky Society of New York last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The Soviet press celebrated the approach of May Day today with congratulatory comment on a reduction of prices to the consumer of certain goods announced for June 1 and July 1.

Wheat was erratic on the Board of Trade here today, within an extreme range of 3 cents a bushel. Prices declined around 1 cent early on scattered liquidation and the failure of Liverpool to fully reflect the strength in North America late yesterday, but there was no material pressure and later prices advanced rapidly with corn. The break in stocks,

The break in soccer relations between France and Italy was patched today by French assurance of a cordial weleome to the Italian team. Fascist fears of an unfriendly reception here caused the break April 8.
Drastic changes in the National Labor Relations Act were demanded by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in resolutions adopted today.

A "Night in Rio" will be celebrated tonight in the Garden of the Ambassador at a special dinner dance for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Connecticut College for Women. Under the direction of Mrs. Constantin R. Goodlet (Bonnie May Murray), the party will be featured by a historical pageant and a South American dinner, with Brazilian, Mexican and Spanish beverages and courses.
Amid much evidence of public indifference, Japan's tentieth general election opened at 7 o'clock this morning. The polls will close at 6 P. M.

Instructions were issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange holding specialists responsible for the maintenance of fair and orderly markets for the issues in which they specialize and requiring them to take positions in stocks in order to achieve that end.

Exports to the United States during the nine months ended March 31 were more than double those in the corresponding period of 1935-36, assuring Australia's ability to take care of the f28,500,000 service on her overseas debt without drawing on the London pool.

Both houses of Congress put other business aside today to rush to enactment a permanent neutrality law to replace the temporary legislation, which has been in effect in one form or another since the Summer of 1935, expiring at midnight Saturday.

The fight to the finish between the National Socialist regime and the Roman Catholic Church in Germany which has been recognized as inevitable since the reading of a papal encyclical in the churches on Palm Sunday has apparently begun.
Government observers predicted today that more strikes were likely this Summer, despite the Supreme Court's decisions upholding the Wagner Labor Disputes Act.

William C. Johnson, who said he had acquired the nickname of "Thug" as a railway and industrial detective and by being acquitted on two murder charges in Wise County, Va., told the Senate subcommittee investigating civil liberties today that he had frequently terrorized Harlan County union miners, with the intention of preventing unionization of mines in that county.
The Guaranty Trust Company as been appointed depositary for he 6 per cent and 7 per cent cumliative prior lien stock of the Midand Utilities Company.

William F. Ellison, 41 years old, of 132 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, former head of a company using his name at 545 Fifth Avenue, which Sold "guaranteed first mortgages," pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to defrauding one of the ,investors of $4,925.
With the traditional May 1 moving day in the business world at hand, many firms yesterday were making last-minute transfers of equipment and furniture to their new quarters.

A banking group headed by Burr Co., Inc., Sidney S. Walcott Co., Inc., and Stephenson, Leydecker Co. will offer today not more than 80,000 shares of common stock of the Fedders Manufacturing Company, Inc., at $15 a share.

The engagement of $7.634.000 of gold abroad for shipment here, $1,274.000 in England, $130,000 in India and $6,230,000 in Japan, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The Reserve Bank announced the arrival here yesterday of $2,012,100 gold from Colombia.

General Douglas MacArthur, military adviser to the Philippine Commonwealth and former United States Army Chief of Staff, said last night that he and Miss Jean Faircloth of Murfreesboro, Tenn., will be married here today, according to The Associated Press.

The annual convention of the American Booksellers Association will be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania on May 9, 10 and 11. Rockwell Kent, Sholem Asch, Dale Carnegie and Dean Alfrange will be speakers at the annual dinner to be held on Tuesday evening, May 11.
Bob Feller's pitching arm still was sore today and the Indians' club physician said it probably would not be well "for a week or so."

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, making his first trip to Europe in May and June, will pay for it, at least in part, by cabling back five 1,000-word articles for which he will receive "approximately $1 a word."

Judged by the trend of sales so far this year, earnings of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana in 1937 will be as large or larger than those of 1936, Edward G. Seubert, president, said today prior to the annual meeting in Whiting, Ind.

New Jersey troopers were called on by Governor Hoffman today to carry out "to the letter" a Chancery Court injunction restraining Local 83, United Rubber Workers of America, from acts of violence and interference with the business of the Thermoid Company, Inc., rubber manufacturers.
A brief discussion of war debts in the House of Commons was marked today by a reference to "rude comments" concerning the British attitude made by American newspapers.

As the Legislature ended its work for the week leaders of both parties in the Assembly expressed confidence that another week would see an agreement on Governor Lehman's proposal to add a fourth-cent a gallon to the gasoline tax.

Schiaparelli features a new svelte evening silhouette that is long and narrow, giving an impression of height at the opening of her midseason collection. She calls it "Paris, 1937," because of the impending French Exposition.

Representative James A. O'Leary of Staten Island urged a Federal subsidy to American shipping as an aid to the opening of markets which are not now available to American commerce at a luncheon meeting of the Propeller Club yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club building.

The nominating committee of the New York Wool Top Exchange yesterday nominated Arthur R. Marsh for president and Joseph R. Walker for first vice president. H. Clyde Moore was selected for second vice president and Clayton B. Jones for treasurer.

At the close of a stormy session today in the Federal court here, the government's conspiracy case against Ellis H. Parker Sr. and the other defendants in the Paul H. Wendel Kidnapping case struck a snag.

The House began general debate on the $416,413,382 War Department 1938 Supply Bill today, with leaders admonishing the membership that nothing should be done to restrict the army's growth to a point where national defense would be adequate.
The Republicans of the Assembly held up action today on two Milk Control Bills after the Democratic leader, Mr. Steingut, had issued a warning against "playing politics with milk."

Auburn motorists were talking today about an unidentified railroad engineer who blocked their path in North Street here for several minutes while he backed his switch engine off a trestle so that a dog could cross first.
Controller Frank J. Taylor said yesterday that midnight tonight would be the deadline for payment of the real estate taxes for the first half of 1937.

In the interest of economy and more efficient public health administration, reorganization of Federal agencies should be so made as to include health activities in a department separate from welfare activities, Dr. Floyd S. Winslow, president of the Medical Society of the State of New York, declared last night at the annual dinner meeting of the Cornell University Medical College Alumni Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

The full adoption of the report of the President's Committee on Administrative Management would concentrate such tremendous control in the executive department over the people's economic and social activities that "it would be only a short step to a dictatorship," according to the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The Senate passed the compromise Neutrality Bill, passed the Second Deficiency Bill, heard Senator Vandenberg assail the administration's gold and silver buying policy, received the Lee bill to appropriate $2,200,000 for the education of adults in public affairs, received the King resolution requesting information from the WPA on relief workers and adjourned at 5:29 P. M. until noon Monday.
One angle of the present retail situation is of marked interest in connection with reports of increased consumer resistance to higher prices, merchandising executives pointed out yesterday.

THE May selections of the Book-of-the-Month Club are novels by two young Americans: Millen Brand's "The Outward Room" (Simon Sehuster, $1.25, low-priced because of the unusual size of the edition) and William Maxwell's "They Came Like Swallows" (Harper, $2). Mr. Brand's is a first novel, Mr. Maxwell's a second, having been preceded in 1934 by "Bright Center of Heaven."

An electrolytic method of recovering manganese from its ore, holding out the hope of utilizing large deposits of low-grade manganese ore in this country for steel manufacture, was described before the American Electrochemical Society at its general meeting today by Professor Colin G. Fink of Columbia University.

The Presbyterian Church of America, formed by Fundamentalists who seceded from the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, charged in Common Pleas Court today, through counsel, that this action was forced upon the members because the parent denomination had abandoned its traditional doctrines.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 27: CAPTAINS Davis, M. S., Long Beach, Calif., to duty as Inspector of Naval Material, San Francisco District, Calif. Mayfield, I. H., the Tuscaloosa, to Bureau of Navigation, Washington, D. C., Aug. 5.

THE esteemed president of the National League, Ford Christopher Frick, was in a bit of a mild dither yesterday. It seems that he spoke in Buffalo recently and let a "wise-crack" about Bob Feller of the Cleveland Indians (American League) slip lightly off his agile tongue. Mr. Frick thought he was making a hit.

Another great private collection has become the heritage of the people. A few months ago ANDREW W. MELLON offered his wealth of Old Masters to the Federal Government, that it might form the nucleus of a National Gallery. Now it is JULES S. BACHE who performs a similar act of munificence, this time with the State of New York as recipient.

President Roosevelt's Courts Reorganization Bill will come to a vote in the Senate about the middle of July, Chairman Ashurst of the Judiciary Committee predicted today. He added that if this Congress does not pass it, "outraged public opinion" will demand that the next session do so.
Two hundred members of the United Electrical and Radio Workers' Union evacuated a plant of the Emerson Electric Manufacturing Company today, ending a fifty-three-day stay-in strike.
The last living member of the drill gang, Omar L. McQueen, recalled today how a band of wildmatters brought in New York State's first oil well fifty-six years ago.

Probate Judge Nelson J. Brewer took under consideration today a report by two court-appointed attorneys which, if accepted, would lift some of the legal uncertainty surrounding the status of the Midamerica Corporation, the holding Company through which the Van Sweringen railroad temple changed hands this week.
President Roosevelt's proposal to reorganize the Supreme Court was assailed and defended today before the council of the General Federation of Women's Clubs by spokesmen from the national capital.

The will of Alfred H. Swayne, vice president and director of General Motors Corporation, who diedApril 16, was filed for probate today in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court. It contains a bequest of $25,000 to St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H., where Mr. Swayne prepared for Yale.

The report of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries for the first quarter of this year shows a consolidated net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $8,094,758, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to 30 cents a share on the common stock of U. G. I. outstanding.

When Auriol Lee arrives here on May 24 by steamer from the Coast she will be bringing the script of a new play by John van Druten. "Gertie and Maude" is the name, presumably for production first in England under Miss Lee's direction.

The body of a man shot three times through the head and found floating last Monday in the East River was identified yesterday as that of Philip Sheridan, ex-convict and labor racketeer, missing since December.

A brisk upturn in United States Government obligations was the outstanding development in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Influenced to some degree by the moderate recovery in stocks during the greater part of the day,

Management of the UnderwoodElliott-Fisher Company, in submitting the annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which was made public by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, declined to reveal salaries paid its officers and directors.

The Court of Appeals today unanimously upheld a decision handed down in October, 1935. granting a judgment of $37,495.55 against the Hearst Hotels Corporation to Mrs. Mary Maloney, widow of Edward R. Maloney, a fireman who was killed while fighting a fire in the Ritz Towers Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, New York City, owned by the corporation, on Aug. 1, 1932.

The marriage of Miss Alice May Conried, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Conried of this city, to Henry Glendon Walter Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Glendon Walter of Elmhurst, L. I., took place yesterday in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. The Rev. Charles D. Gallagher performed the ceremony.

With the occupation today of Guernica, ten miles northwest of here, by Carlist troops and one of General Emilio Mola's Regular Army columns, controversy continued to rage over whether the virtual destruction of the ancient Basque capital was done by German bombers flying for General Francisco Franco or by Anarchists.

The adoption of a resolution urging the Chinese Government not to be deceived by the new "smiling face policy" adopted by the Japanese army was among the accomplishments of the congress of young Chinese Communists which has just concluded its sessions at Yenan, the Communist capital of Northern Shensi Province.
THE OUTWARD ROOM, by Millen Brand. (Simon Schuster, $1.25.) A first novel that has roused great prepublication enthusiasm; 140,000 copies already have been printed.

A threat to tie up the ships of the International Mercantile Marine Company was made last night as a conference of spokesmen for the officials of the International Seamen's Union and a group of union members ended in the office of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

The marriage of Miss Evelina Hollins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Hollins Jr. of East Islip, L. I., to Henry L. Hoguet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Hoguet of 47 East Ninety-second Street, took place yesterday morning in the rectory of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-third Street.
Atley Donald, giant rookie from Binghamton, outpitched the veteran Bill Harris today and the Bears scored a 2-1 victory over Buffalo. It was Newark's sixth victory in seven games.

Executives of Class I Railroads today approved provisions of the Doughton railroad retirement plan at a business meeting of the Association of American Railroads in the Stevens Hotel. Approval of the association's public relations program for this year also was voted.

The May program at the Hayden Planetarium, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West, will include reproductions of the colorful aurora borealis and of the way the Summer sun looks from the North Pole, it was announced yesterday.

Curtis High's nine, 1936 winner, broke a first-place tie with Seward Park High and took undisputed possession of the lower ManhattanRichmond P. S. A. L. lead by taking a 7-3 decision from Seward at Curtis Field, S. I., yesterday. The victory was the fourth straight in the league for Curtis.
Offer?ings in today's wool auction totaled 8,965 bales, including 971 Falkland Islands, of which 7,085 bales were sold. Frequent withdrawals of slipes were made after the opening.

Wholesale prices in the average registered a fractional decline in the week ended on April 24, the third consecutive weekly recession, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The latest index (April 24) is 87.5, compared with 88.3 on April 3, the high point before the change in trend.

A Federal court order temporarily halted today the government's anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America. Federal Judge R. M. Gibson granted a restraining order holding up the suit filed last week in the Southern District of New York.
Clay Ave, 1,350, 3-story brick tenement, 24.11x90; North Side Savings Bank against Laydon Realty Corp; due, $11,724; taxes, , $1,294; to plaintiff for $500.

NIGHT MUST FALL, an adaptation of the play by Emlyn Williams; screen play by John Van Druten; musical score by Edward Ward; directed by Richard Thorpe; produced by Hunt Stromberg for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. At the Capitol.

Two purchases of adjoining property in Brooklyn were reported by the Safeway Petroleum Corporation yesterday. Through its subsidiary, Safeway Service Stations, Inc., the petroleum firm plans to demolish the building now occupying the plots and erect a gasoline filling station on the combined plottage of 75 by 55 irregular.
Because of numerous complaints he has received, Frederick Sasse, borough secretary of Queens, is investigating the advisability of granting permits to surf fishermen along the Rockaway beaches.

Aroused by the campaign of Archbishop Pittini of Santo Domingo during his visit on a flying trip around South America, Santiago newspapers recommend contributions to a fund for a large statue of Christopher Columbus near Santo Domingo.

Scoring twelve runs in the fifth frame, the St. John's University freshman baseball team downed La Salle Academy of Manhattan, 16-3, at Carey Field in Brooklyn yesterday. Bob Gill, first sacker for the Redman yearlings, hit two home runs.

Total net sales of 564 manufacturers throughout the country increased 31.4 per cent in March as compared with March, 1936, while total net sales of 1,212 reporting wholesalers increased 24 per cent, a survey made jointly by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce and the National Association of Credit Men showed today.
A Republican effort to outlaw sit-down strikes in New York State was thwarted in the Senate today by an abrupt adjournment forced by the Democratic majority.
Despite a slight decline from the previous week, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday increased 8.5 per cent over the corresponding week last year.

Votes may shift in the Judiciary Committee before the Administration's Supreme Court plan is finally reported in the Senate, but from the present lineup one significant fact emerges. As matters stand, the President's proposal to add six justices to the court is actually opposed by a majority of committee members of his own party.

Secretary Morgenthau announced today that $100,000,000 in Treasury bills, half for refunding purposes and half for new money, would be offered under date of May 5. On that date $50,000,000 in bills will be retired.
Mrs. Monaei Groves arrived here today and engaged counsel for a suit for divorce from Wallace Groves of New York. She was accompanied by her 3-month-old son and is staying at a ranch.
Tony Cuccinello's fifth successive hit, a home run into the left-field bleachers with Rabbit Warstler on first and one out, gave the Bees a 6-4 triumph over the Phillies in eleven innings today.

The $757,000 additional bid of Starrett Brothers Eken, Inc., of New York, present contractor on the $13,569,000 Williamsburg houses in Brooklyn, the largest public housing project ever undertaken in the United States, has been accepted by the Public Works Administration, Secretary Harold L. Ickes announced today.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculure, follow: HOGS Receipts, 14,000, including 4,000 direct. Market around 10 lower than Wednesday's average; few sales on butchers' 300 pounds up off more;
Two boys, 16 and 18 years old, chased a coyote half a mile through Prospect Park in Brooklyn yesterday in a hot pursuit as thrilling as many an old-time hunt on a prairie.

Employes of the Hershey Chocolate Corporation, who refused to accept a unit of the C. I. O. as their agency for collective bargaining, formed their own union. They elected Charles Hallman as president and adopted the name of the Independent Chocolate Workers of Hershey.
Texts of the more important resolutions adopted today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States are as follows:

The first group of scientists bound for Peru to observe the solar eclipse on June 8 will depart today on the Grace liner Santa Maria. Professor William H. Barton Jr., associate curator of the Hayden Planetarium; Mrs. Barton, Mr. and Mrs. Hans Christian Adamson and Mrs. Sara Van S. Pyle, secretary of the expedition, are among those sailing.

The reaction in the stock market, particularly the decline of Wednesday, attracted attention because it interrupted rather emphatically an advance which had continued, almost without interruption, since the Spring of 1935. With few exceptions, every month in that period had carried Stock Exchange prices higher, and inasmuch as production, company earnings, dividends and general business activity had risen simultaneously, more interest than usual was taken, both in the rise and in the recent decline.

Mrs. Anita Eisner, daughter of Mrs. Simon Berger of New York, was married this morning at the Pickwick Arms HQtel to Julius Kroll, jeweler of 580 Fifth Avenue, NewYork. Twelve members of the immediate families accompanied the bride and bridegroom to Greenwich.

The procedure for conciliation and arbitration of apparel returns, and the settlement of the recent issue on terms in the boys' clothing industry were endorsed yesterday by the executive committee of the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at a meeting here.
Despite the objection of the Citizens Union, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he would sign a local law giving to the Controller power to settle any claim of $250 or less against the city.

This community selected its "pensioner" tonight and was all set to see how fast and furiously the Townsend Recovery Plan would operate once he gets the word to start spending the $200 in Townsend scrip that is waiting for him in the First National Bank.

Thirty thousand government Basques, three-quarters of the republic's hard-pressed army, fell back to Bilbao's last line of concrete and steel trenches encircling the city tonight and dug in for a long Insurgent siege.
Fedders Manufacturing Company Inc., rights have been admitted to "when-issued" dealings on the New York Curb Exchange.

Housing and nutrition were taken up yesterday at the annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund as potential new fields for public health research. A two-day session opened at the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.

Officials of the Cardinals announced today Paul Dean, pitcher who has an ailing right arm, would remain on the active list but would not make the club's trip starting Saturday. Sam Breadon, president;

Jay Randolph Monroe, president and founder of the Monroe Calculating Machine Company, manufacturers of business machines in Orange, died today at his home here, 6 Halsey Place, of a heart ailment. He was 54 years old.

The Coast Guard issued the following orders today for the week ended April 28: Lieut. W. B. Chiswell, U. S. Naval Academy, to Navy Yard, Philadelphia, Pa. for further instruction, upon completion of which assigned San Franciscan Division for course of instruction at the University of California, to report not later than Aug. 2.

The intimidation which the very name of Henry G. Yagoda imposed when he was head of the political police [Ogpu] was attested to by Alexander Afinogenoff, Soviet playwright who has an American wife, in acknowledging before the playwrights' section of the Union of Soviet Writers his association with the group of writers accused of showing Trotskyist tendencies.
In a statement made this morning at a private meeting of the Socialist party Premier Leon Blum reiterated that the "breathing spell" in his program of social reform would be continued.

Harriet Hubbard Ayer, Inc., has sent out price lists to retail stores for minimum resale prices on its entire line of cosmetics. Miss Lucile Babcock, formerly fashion editor of The Delineator Magazine, has joined Felix Lilienthal Co., Inc., as editor of Breadth of the Avenue, fashion service for retailers.

This virtually isolated southwest China province today celebrated the arrival of a good-will motor caravan from the Nanking Government. Spreading the doctrine of national unity, the government representatives drove the 2,000 miles from Nanking in twenty-four days, considered the start of a new era in overland travel in China.

201st St (12-3281), n w cor Marion Ave. 78x120; Benjamin Silver to Pauline Construction Corp, 1,070 Anderson Ave; mtg, $17,000. Vireo Ave (12-3391), w s, 72 ft s of 238th St, 37x115; Augusta A. Ruppert to William T. Aglieber, 411 E 237th St.

Imports into the United States in the first quarter of this year are considerably higher than American exports for the same period, but the upward trend must be carried even further before foreign nations are able to buy the quantities of goods we must market abroad, Henry A. Wallace,

Further weakness in the foreign markets brought heavy selling from abroad yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange here broke $1 a bale into new low ground and ended with losses of 20 to 22 points.

Freddy Fitzsimmons and his knuckle-ball still hold their longtime mastery over the Dodgers. Yesterday, while 11,241 fans looked on in mixed admiration and chagrin, the roly-poly veteran spun a five-hit shutout, while the Giants were battering five Brooklyn pitchers for thirteen hits and a 9-0 triumph at the Polo Grounds. The victory sent the Terrymen to third place in the National League.

Net income of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for the first quarter of 1937 was $8,293,833 after all deductions, it was announced yesterday after the quarterly dividend meeting of the board of directors.

The House Agriculture Committee agreed today on a bill extending the present emergency interest rate on Land Bank farm loans to the 1938 fiscal year. The emergency rate of 31/2 per cent would be stepped to 4 per cent in 1939, under the bill's provisions.
Women no longer accept their husbands' political doctrines without question, according to Miss Mary Dewson of New York, vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

The Chilean military mission now in Europe seeking to purchase war material to replace obsolete material to be discarded in accordance with plans for the modernization of the army, navy and aviation corps of Chile has not met with success, it is reported from Paris.

Dr. Abbott William Allen of 117 East Seventy-second Street yesterday agreed in Supreme Court to accept $400 in settlement of his $450 bill for attending Jesse Livermore Jr. after he had been shot in Santa Barbara, Calif., on Thanksgiving Day, 1935.
Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 84.4 from 84.1. It was 77.2 for the week ended April 25, 1936.

Twenty-eight high school boys and girls who had been selectedby their classes took over the various public offices yesterday in Brooklyn for a few moments as part of the observance of Boys and Girls' Week program.

Cities and States, which spent $810,000,000 in 1936 for outdoor relief, as compared with $332,000,000 in 1933, will spend "more and more" in 1938 and 1939, Harry M. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, asserted at his press conference today.

Mayor John F. Dore said today that a "gigantic" civic reception will be held here next Wednesday for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. Invitations were sent out to 1,000 citizens by the Mayor to attend a mass meeting at which Mrs. Roosevelt will speak.

In its course of recreating local history, the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets. has traced the chronology of a number of families that have made theatrical history here.

MANHATTAN BREWSTER, NELSON W. (March 20). Estate, not more than $900. To Sarah M. Brewster, 22 E. 29th St., widow executrix, residue. DUBOIS, REGINA (April 25). Estate, less than $10,000. To Elvira Du Bois, daughter, 104 W. 70th St., residue. Daniel Levy, brother, executor, 148 7th Av.

Hunter College students, holding a contest to find the faculty member who could contribute the most attractive baby picture of himself or herself, had a hard time choosing the most winsome from the group of about sixty submitted photographs.
Midge II, representing Cape Ann and sailed by Isaac Patch Jr., today repeated her success of yesterday by easily winning the first race of the yachting series for the Bermuda Challenge Trophy.
Alwintour, sporting the silks of J. E. Lane, scored a two-length victory in the feature race today at Arlington Downs.
The St. John's University golf team scored its fourth triumph in as many times out by downing the Fordham linksmen, 5 1/2 to 3 1/2, at the Hillcrest Golf Club in Jamaica yesterday.

Undergraduate members of Princeton University's seventeen upper class clubs will be host to 592 young women at the annual "Prospect Street" house parties, the highlight of the Spring social season at Princeton, to be held here tomorrow and Saturday.
Larry French, the Cubs' star left-hander who suffered a smashed right hand yesterday, said today he thought he would be back in action in ten days, with the aid of a metal cast.
Dr. Wallace H. Carothers of Wilmington, research chemist for the E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., was found dead in a hotel room here this evening.

It is reported from a diplomatic source that the high command of the German aerial forces made arrangements some time ago for its most experienced pilots to serve by turn in Spain under General Francisco Franco, leader of the Insurgent forces. Thus Germany is using the Spanish civil war as a training school for military airmen.

The future of burlesque in the city was left undecided yesterday afternoon as License Commissioner Paul Moss reserved decision as to whether he would renew the licenses of the present fourteen burlesque theatres, which expire at midnight tonight, and grant permit to three more contemplated houses.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Bernard J. J. Kelly, from 114th Precinct to 28th Precinct, assignment changed from desk duty to telephone switchboard duty. Assignment to desk duty continued: Thomas J. Henry, from 10th Division to 16th Division; Wllliam C. Beneke Jr., from 16th Division to 114th Precinct.

The Nunan-Moffat bill, which would prohibit the sale of child labor products in New York State, has been passed by the Legislature by overwhelming majorities in both houses132 to 15 in the Assembly, and 48 to 3 in the House.

James J. Walker waxed philosophical last night about the coming mayoralty election, and the inference drawn from his remarks was that he was not a candidate for the Democratic nomination, and that no sensible person would be.
