Despite the known desire in Tokyo to improve Anglo-Japanese relations, both British and Japanese quarters here said today there was no truth in reports that negotiations had been begun in London aimed at a Far Eastern agreement.

Henry W. Taft, brother of the late President, in a prepared statement presented to the Senate Judiciary Committee yesterday, attacked President Roosevelt's proposal for a change in the court as "vicious in principle, being contrary to a condition implicit in our form of government."

Turpentine firm, 343/4; sales 85 barrels; receipts 439 barrels: shipments 408 barrels; stock 23.451 barrels. Resin firm: sales 1.056; receipts 1,568; shipments 1,528: stock 41,859. Quote: B, $7-7.05; D. $7-7.15; E, $7.40-55 F, G. $8-8.05; H, 8.05; I, K, $8.05-071/2: M, $8.05-10; N, $8.05-20;WG.8.25; WW, X, $9.

Manager Burleigh Grimes of the Dodgers made his scheduled visit to President Ford Frick of the National League in the latter's office yesterday and came away with no freshly blotted stub in his check book to represent a fine for wrangling with umpires.
The PWA administrator, Harold L. Ickes, and WPA administrator, Harry L. Hopkins, are at it again.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday he would retire as president of the American Iron and Steel Institute at the annual meeting on May 27 under a by-law which he sponsored two years ago limiting a president to two terms of office.

Advertising agencies here yesterday expressed no concern over the possible effect of the stock-market weakness upon advertising schedules and, while in some offices it was said no immediate increase in advertising is looked for,
Joe Louis, the Brown Bomber, will plunge into active training within a week to prepare for his quest of the world heavyweight championship.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 28: MAJOR GENERAL Allison J. B., Chief Signal Officer, two days' leave, April 30. COLONELS Bryden, W. (F. A.), General Staff Corps, five days' leave April 30.

The funeral of Mrs. Ivah Wills Coburn, actress and wife of Charles D. Coburn, with whom she had been prominent in the American theatre for more than thirty years, was held yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), at 1 East Twenty-ninth Street. Mrs. Coburn died on Tuesday following an illness of one week with intestinal influenza.

Erin's Son, veteran jumper in the string of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kennedy of Brookline, Mass., tonight came into his own when he defeated a score of rivals in the Touch-and-Out Sweepstake, one of the second-night features of the Newark Horse Show.

Harold Levin, secretary and treasurer of Joseph H. Reinfeld, Inc., wholesale liquor dealer, of Newark, N. J., yesterday testified before John J. Keenan, examiner for the Federal Trade Commission, that the Seagram Distillers Corporation maintained a "missionary man" at the Reinfeld offices.

The Brotherhood of Interborough Rapid Transit Employes, for more than twenty years regarded by organized labor as an outstanding example of company unionism, passed out of the transit picture yesterday.

At noon today the Jamestown furniture market registration passed 500, exceeding comparable day totals for both markets of 1936. The market for dealers only opened Monday and continues through Wednesday, May 5.

Any doubt that Belgium would stand by her obligations to the League of Nations was dispelled today by Paul Spaak, Foreign Minister, who in addressing the crowded Chamber on the recent Franco-British declaration said:
A jury in the District Court acquitted Mrs. Mary Krieger, former Oklahoma teacher, and Samuel L. Frooks, a New York lawyer, today of blackmail charges.

Watson R. Ayers, Sussex County insurance executive and president and founder of the Sussex County Octogenarian Club, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of several months. He was 91 years old.

The six-family apartment at 260 New York Ave., Jersey City. N. J., has been sold for cash by Edward Koehler to Minnie and Esrael Rosen for investment. The building occupies a plot 31 by 100 and all the apartments are of five rooms. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and Isidore Halprin was attorney for the buyers.

The metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships, a preview of the chances of Columbia and Manhattan in the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. title games at the same site four weeks later, will be staged at the Randalls Island Stadium this afternoon.

Stocks closed irregular after early rally; United States Steel shares declined below par; turnover, 2,026,120 shares. United States Government issues strong, corporate bonds irregularly higher, Brazilian loans weakened; transactions, $12,815,700.

Messages from interstellar space carried by the cosmic ray and decoded at Harvard by Drs. J. C. Street and E. C. Stevenson reveal the existence of a new fundamental particle of matter different from any of the primordial building blocks of the universe that have been discovered so far.
The 1937 edition of New York University's annual Spring varsity show, "In Praise of N. Y. U.," opened last night before 1,500 persons at the Manhattan Opera House.

" Orchids Preferred," Charles H. Abramson's new musical show which opened at the Forrest Theatre last night, was banned tonight by Mayor S. Davis Wilson. The Board of Theatre Control, in a unanimous report, had termed the production "vulgar, profane, indecent and not a credit to the theatrical profession."
Yankee, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup defense candidate, arrived at 9 o'clock tonight from Boston and anchored out in the harbor. The yacht encountered hard going offshore in nasty weather.

The Federal Music Project Chamber Orchestra, Samuel Gardner conducting, will present the second of a new series of chamber concerts tonight at the Theatre of Music. Four debuts are listed at tonight's performance of "Aida" by the Hippodrome Opera Company.

The Boys Club of New York receives the residue of the estate of Ricard A. Strong of Greenwich, a member of the New York firm of Strong, Hewat Co., Inc., who died April 6. The personal estate exceeds $10,000, according to the petition filed with the will admitted by Probate Judge Harold L. Knapp here today.

Although Sherlock Holmes went into retirement as the master-mind among detectives as soon as Sir ARTHUR CONAN DOYLE ceased writing about him, he was still one of us on this planet until yesterday, when WILLIAM GILLETTE died at the age of 81.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday plans for the erection of six new station houses in the city, five of which will replace antiquated buildings, two of them at least seventy-five years old. The sixth structure will be established in the Inwood section of Manhattan, near 207th Street, at a site yet to be selected.

The body o Stanton Whitney, socially prominent New York stock broker, was found today by his wife in a tool shed on their estate on Navesink River Road, Middletown Township, near here. He had been shot through the right temple. A pistol lay near by.
Miss Patty Morris, '37, of Bethesda, Md., who has been elected May Queen at Swarthmore College, will receive her crown in the May Day exercise Saturday on the green at the east end of Parrish Hall.
Denials from German and Insurgent sources on the bombing of Guernica, historic Basque city, have merely furtheir inflamed opinion here.

The Washington Gas Light Company, Washington, D. C., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due on March 1, 1962;

Details were made public today concerning the order called the German Eagle, which Chancellor Hitler will create Saturday. It is to be bestowed only upon foreigners who have been of service to the Reich.

Detectives investigating the mysterious stabbing of Municipal Court Justice John Francis O'Neil on Tuesday morning took a suspect to the Mercer Street police station for questioning early last evening, but after four witnesses to the attack had failed to identify him they released the man.
Officials today clarified reports that the British Navy would cooperate in evacuating refugees from Bilbao by outlining the exact conditions under which such work would be carried out.

Mrs. George U. Ladd, a member of the original company of "Way Down East," died here today. Her age was 69. Under her stage name of Ella Hugh Wood she played the role of Marthy Perkins, the village gossip, in the original presentation of "Way Down East" in Chicago early in the century.
The Indians bombarded four Detroit pitchers for thirteen hits today to win the opener of a two-game series with the Tigers, 12 to 3.
The second Hall Dog Racing Bill was passed by the Senate today and sent to Governor Lehman.

Joseph Walker, 55 years old, an investigator for the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, was found slumped over the wheel of an automobile last night in front of his home at 1,414 Cortelyou Road, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
No political significance is attached here to the recall of Leo M. Karakhan, Russian Ambassador to Turkey. According to his friends, Mr. Karakhan is returning to Moscow for personal reasons.

Preparations are nearly complete for the May festival of students of Sweet Briar College, which will take place Saturday, when Miss Molly Gruber, daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Edmund L. Gruber of Washington, will be crowned queen at an Elizabethan celebration.

On the eve of the opening here of the conference called by the Coffee Growers Federatior reports in the press tell of a secret session at which the house voted to increase the export tax on coffee from 10 to 25 centavos a sack.
The Williams nine defeated Colby today on Weston Field, 3-1. The game was a pitchers' battle

The total of engineering construction awards reported in the week ended yesterday, $40,264,000, represented a gain of 6 per cent over the figure for the corresponding week of last year, and a rise of 104 per cent in awards for private construction over the 1936 figure for that classification, according to the Engineering News-Record.
The White Sox combined a robust nineteen-hit attack with shut-out pitching by Monte Stratton to defeat the Browns today. 12-0.

Mayor La Guardia paid a warm tribute to the late William F. Deegan, formerly Tenement House Commissioner, when he signed an ordinance at City Hall yesterday naming the westerly approach of the Triborough Bridge in the Bronx for Major Deegan.

The text of the Neutrality Bill, as finally passed today by both houses of Congress, follows: That the joint resolution entitled "Joint resolution providing for the prohibition of the export of arms, ammunition and implements of war to belligerent countries;

The United States Embassy formally requested today the extradition of Alexander Pompez, fugitive New York racketeer, on a charge of extortion. This offense is extraditable under a treaty between the United States and Mexico.

With the slump in the financial markets checked and the financial skies cleared for the time being, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, expressed tonight the belief that the European situation also was improving and that the nations would find some commonsense method of ending the race in rearmament.

MANHATTAN BEEKMAN, WILLIAM F. (Feb. 4, 1936). Gross assets, $114, 868; net, $103,337. To Henry R. Beekman, brother; Josephine L. and Mary E. Beekman, sisters, One-third residue each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $69,925.

The election of twenty-nine New York University seniors, including twelve girls, to the Washington Square College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, was announced yesterday by Dean Milton E. Loomis, president of the Beta chapter at the university. Students honored were:

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had issued an order suspending the effectiveness of the registration statement filed on July 27. 1933, under the Securities Act of 1933 by the National Boston Montana Mines Corporation of Helena. Mont.

Henry Eckhardt, president of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., was today elected chairman of the board of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, holding its twentieth annual meeting at the Greenbrier here. He succeeds Paul Cornell, of Geyer, Cornell Newell.

The directors of the Chrysler Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, payable on June 11 to stock of record of May 14, compared with $1.50 a share paid on March 13 and with total dividends of $12 a share paid in 1936.

Brazil was cut off from communication with the outside world all day today by the strictest censorship since the 1930 revolt that overthrew President Washington Luiz du Albuquerque and put Dr. Getulio Vargas into power.

The number thirteen was not unlucky for the Blackbirds of Long Island University yesterday. They celebrated their thirteenth victory by blanking Middlebury College, 13-0, at the Manhattan Beach diamond.

" Dr. Knock," the French screen version of Jules Romains's satirical novel and play on the medical profession, which was at first rejected and later approved by the State Board of Censors, will have its American premiere today at the Cinema de Paris. Louis Jouvet,

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole were at the lowest.

Royal robes and court gowns worn at the coronation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra of England will be displayed this afternoon at a preview exhibition at the American Anderson Gallerias, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Roger Vernon, French ex-convict, was sentenced tonight to ten years' imprisonment at hard labor in a court sequel to England's "first gang murder."

The April Suffolk County grand jury completed its work today without finding an indictment against Dr. William B. Gibson, 85 years old, Huntington physician and a county coroner, who was arrested last Winter on a charge of performing an illegal operation.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterlay; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

While trading in the wool goods markets here was generally slow this week, sentiment showed improvement on news of strong wool and yarn values and a rise in prices at the Colonial wool auctions in London, at which world-wide values are established, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service.
George Comer, last of the old New England whaling masters, died last night at the Veterans Hospital in Northampton, Mass., where he went two weeks ago. His age was 79.
Secretary Morgenthau will leave tomorrow for his farm in Dutchess County, N. Y., to spend a week's holiday.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had directed Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., of New York City, to discontinue certain alleged unfair methods of competition in the sale of dress goods and garments.

President Roosevelt was headed down the Mississippi tonight for eleven days of his favorite sport-deep-sea fishing. He boarded the destroyer Moffett here late this afternoon to transfer to his yacht the Potomac, which is waiting in the Gulf of Mexico.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Moore Bleecker are returning today on the Monarch of Bermuda from their Winter home in Bermuda and will be at the Weylin before going to Laurel Hill, their country place in Cold Spring Harbor.

Southern New York Area So much of paragraph 4, Special Orders 22, April 12, 1937, as pertains to Captain Roy O. Franzen, Sig.Res., is revoked. Each of the following reserve officers, is relieved from his present assignment to the 40th Engineers (Cam.), and is assigned to the organization indicated:

If there is a wealth of problems before the nation and the world today, there is no absence of suggested cures-a hopeful symptom. Though the administration again appears-as in 1934-to stand hesitant at a crossroads of policy, with a foot on both paths, it is worth recording that some of its most constructive critics are in optimistic mood and believe a sound course will be laid out and followed in ample time.

The strike of editorial employes of The Long Island Daily Press, settled last Monday upon intervention by Mayor La Guardia, was resumed yesterday by the Newspaper Guild after S. I. Newhouse, owner of the paper, had announced that twenty-five members of the striking staff of sixty two would be dismissed.

Retailer-consumer relations and employeremploye relations, currently important owing to public interest in the Wagner Labor Relations Act and the government's newly announced anti-price-fixing campaign,
Almost day now, as soon as Herr GOEBBELS can get around to it, laughter may be coordinated--gleichgeschalter--in the
The heavy losses of the last few days in the stock markets here were halted this afternoon and at the close of trading firmer conditions prevailed.
The finals of the second annual Opportunity Contest for Amateur Musicians will be held in Central Park on June 19, the Department of Parks announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Geraldine Spritzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Spritzer of 1,442 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, to Leonard Hartman, son of Mrs. Norbert Rosenband of 40 West Sixty-seventh Street, this city, took place here last night at the Gotham.

More than 400 members of the Police Department gathered last night in the gymnasium of polic headquarters, 240 Center Street, to form an organization designed "to promote the religious and social welfare of the department." It was tentatively named the St. George Association.
Private industry rather than relief labor was advocated yesterday by Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, as the best medium to be employed on the city's future park and arterial projects.

It was stated officially here that 1,800 German "volunteers" had landed at San bastian on April 26. A false air raid alarm was sounded to keep the population underground to prevent the Germans being seen as they passed through the town.

Thomas A. Morgan, president of the Sperry Corporation, announced yesterday that the company had arranged with Fred J. Fisher and Harry F. Vicker to acquire Vicker, Inc., a Michigan corporation, which manufactures hydraulic pump valves and variable speed transmissions for automobile manufacturers. ers.
Dr. W. Reid Blair, director of New York Zoological Park in the Bronx, said yesterday that he had appealed to the police to issue wholesale summonses to persons annoying animals in the park.

Pope Plus XI will leave Vatican City tomorrow for Castel Gandolfo, where he will remain all Summer. All audiences and ceremonies which he has been scheduled to attend will be performed at the papal Summer residence instead of at the Vatican.

Red-haired Don Budge, America's first-ranking tennis star, and poker-faced Frankie Parker blasted Japan's Davis Cup hopes today by scoring singles victories to give the United States a 2-to-O lead in zone eliminations of the international competition.

The Alabama Educational Foundation has sold the vacant 100-by100-foot plot on the southeast corner of Northern Boulevard and 171st Street, Flushing, Queens, to Irving Bienenstock, who plans to improve the property with onestory taxpayers. Halleran Agency and Hyman Maschet were cobrokers in the deal.

The dwelling and six garages on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 529-31 Forty-eighth Street, Union City, N. J., have been sold by Carrie Bodine to Harold M. Cameron, who will occupy the house. J. I. Kislak, Inc., acted as broker.

Producers of limburger cheese and dealer representatives announced the limburger cheese making holiday would continue to May 15. Production of the cheese was suspended March 15 when dealers reported the market was glutted and a severe price drop threatened.
A special meeting of the stockholders of the Phelps Dodge Corporation has been called for May 24 to approve an issue of $20,285,000 convertible debentures, which will be offered to stockholders.

The management of the White Motor Company has sent to brokers and stockholders another appeal for proxies required to reduce the par value of capital stock by $30,625,000 in order to write off the year-end deficit of $5,709,138 and permit resumption of dividends when justified.

Harry Smythe was nicked for 12 hits today by the Orioles but tightened in the pinches and Montreal, scored a 5 to 2 victory. It was the third straight for the Royals, and the sixth consecutive loss for the Flock.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 985,000 bales, against 979,000 a week ago, 994,000 two weeks ago, 1,007,000 three weeks ago and 718,000 a year ago, of which American 412,000 bales, against 979,000 a week ago, 438,000 two weeks ago, 439,000 three Weeks ago and 338,000 a year ago.

Miss Martha Louise Morris, daughter of Mrs. Harry H. Morris of New York and of Harry H. Morris, who lives in Augusta, Ga., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Walton Storm, son of Mrs. H. Battin Storm, also of this city, and the late Walton Storm, in the chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
Idell McKnight, 28, Negro, shuffled up to the desk in the Marriage License Bureau. "Your name?" asked the clerk of the applicant. McKnight answered that one without a hitch.
It is not quite clear whether the young college woman in Philadelphia who now makes a living as a kitchenmaid looks upon this as her permanent career.
Sir Neville Henderson, the new British Ambassador to Berlin, replacing Sir Eric Phipps, who has been transferred to Paris, arrived here today to take up his duties.
It was announced today that the two best known Jewish concerns in Germany had passed into "purely Aryan" hands.

Accausing the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company and the Philco Radio and Television Corporation of violating seniority rights of certain employes, three locals of the United Electrical and Radio Workers Union voted today to call a strike against the two concerns.

James von Bleichroeder, internationally known banker, died today. He was 77 years old. The banking house of von Bleichroeder was adviser to Otto von Bismarck, the "Iron Chancellor," in determining the amount of French indemnity after the Franco-Prussian War of 1871.
Nervousness dominated the stock markets today, but generally firmer conditions obtained. Gilt-edge issues were strong after early dullness, but foreign loans changed little.
Approximately 1,000 persons attended the twelfth annual military ball of the New York University chapter of Scabbard and Blade at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night.

Floyd B. Davis Jr., chairman of the board and president of the United States. Rubber Company, last year received $227,260 for his services to that concern, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

Current consumer demand for more informative labeling was stressed by practically all speakers participating in an all-day conference on consumer education sponsored by the Textile Education Bureau at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday.

Leonard C. Wason, builder of the Harvard Stadium and other prominent structures, died here today. President of the Aberthaw Construction Company, he built the $4,000,000 Christian Science Publishing House, home of The Christian Science Monitor here.

Some of the pastors of the city will comment in their sermons tomorrow on the crusade of Catholics, Protestants and Jewish leaders against burlesque houses. Tomorrow is annual Rural Life Sunday and sermons will be preached in the interest of the churches in the country which need money.

THE leaflet handed out, free of charge, by a young man with a deadly serious look on his face turned out to be a neat bit of communistic literature, an invitation to join any or all May Day demonstrations against the wicked Capitalists all over the world.

Appropriations for philanthropic purposes by the seventy-eight community trusts in the United States and Canada totaled $1,109,793 last year, according to an announcement made yesterday. The New York Community Trust led with a distribution of $200,794.

May Day, proclaimed by law to be the "national holiday of the. German people," was initiated by Chancellor Adolf Hitler with two events today staged with the now-familiar ceremonies and designed to demonstrate what his regime has done for the nation in general and the workers in particular.

The marriage of Miss Mary Chandler Stearns, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Edwin I. Stearns of this community, to the Rev. David Armon Hughes, son of Mrs. Helen M. Hughes of Baltimore, took place here tonight in the First Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father.

Scoring all their runs in the first three innings, the Princeton freshmen turned back the Hill School, 3-2, today. Captain Kobak, Hill ace, struck out ten Orange and Black batters, while Rowe, visitors' hurler, fanned eight.

Miss Margaret Edwards Van Nostrand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Abbott Van Nostrand of Forest Hills, Queens, was married to Frank Hargreave, son of Mrs. Raymond Mandeville, also of Forest Hills, and the late Frank Hargreave, list night in the Dutch Reformed Church, Elmhurst, where the bride's great-great-grandparents and her grandparents were also married.
The Milky Way Farm's Reaping Reward,- working out of the Churchill Downs chute, turned in an impressive mile spin in 1:40 3-5 today, pulling up at a mile and an eighth in 1:55 1-5.

Cotton-mill activity declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 140.4 from 138.9. It was 109.9 for the week ended April 25, 1936. Prices for most printcloth constructions declined last week, but improvement in raw cotton at the close of the week brought some

The marriage of Miss Jeannette Bloch, daughter of Mrs. Paul Bloch of this town, to Charles Horace Hundley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hundley, also of South Orange, took place this evening in the Church -of St. Mary Magdalene, Newark.

In protest against what he termed the "unpatriotic" sentiments recently expressed by students of Brooklyn College in anti-war demonstrations, George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, cast his vote in the Board of Estimate yesterday against a $20,000
The ballroom of the Greenwich Country Club was the scene tonight of a concert given by the-Yale Glee Club under the direction of its conductor, Marshall Bartholomew of this place.

Net railway operating income of firstclass railroads in the United States during the first three months of this year was $146,174,646, which was at the annual rate of return of 2.93 per cent on their property investment, the Interstate Commerce Commission and Association of American Railroads announced today.

The member lines of the Transatlantic Steamship Freight Conference have reduced their rate on whisky shipments from Glasgow to New York from $16 to $12.75 a measurement ton during May, it was announced yesterday.

Purchase of the old Franklin Institute building on Seventh Street below Market Street by A. Atwater Kent and its presentation to the city for use as a historical museum was announced today by Mayor Wilson.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Chrystal of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Chrystal, to John Rhodes Drury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Hamilton Drury, also of Montclair.

Member-trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange continued to be about onefifth of the total volume in the week ended on April 3, the percentage being 20.45 per cent, compared with 20.04 per cent in the preceding week, according to the weekly summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Clarenco Chamberlin, who flew the Atlantic Ocean in 1930, announced here last night he would attempt within two months to pilot an airplane from New York to Paris in ten hours. He spoke at a dinner meeting of the University of Michigan chapter of the Institute of Aeronautical Science.

A gain of 11 per cent in volume was reported to the Census of Business by 1,099,663 identical retail concerns for 1935 over 1934, according to announcement today by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census.

Miss Elizabeth Coster Hepburn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Hepburn of Babylon and New York, was married this afternoon to Henry Noyes Gammack, son of the late Rev. and Mrs. John W. Gammack of Glen Cove, in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, of which the bridegroom's father was rector for thirty-five -years. Rev. Lauriston Castleman. rector, officiated.

Creation in the laboratory within the hearts of atoms of temperatures of 10,000,000,000 degrees, 250 times greater than Sir Arthur Eddington's estimate for the temperature in the interior of the sun, and equal to the temperature of the interior of the hottest stars, was described here today before the meeting of the American Physical Society at the National Bureau of Standards.
William J. Wells, president of L. Bamberger Co., has been elected a director of the National State Bank of Newark, N. J., which is celebrating its 125th birthday this year.

Advertising agencies were called upon today to assume new responsibilities, to embody a wider social vision in their activities, to act as counselors to business and to work for higher ethical standards in American journalism by speakers at the open sessions of the twentieth annual convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the Greenbrier here.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN-George P. Obach Jr., 104th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed May 29. 1911. On police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMAN-Martin J. Parkes, Traffic Precinct E. at $792 per annum. Appointed Nov. 1, 1926.

Patrolman Richard Maher was cleared yesterday in General Sessions on indictments which grew out of the general shooting in an alleged drunken brawl at Seventh Avenue and Christopher Street on Sept. 21, 1936.
The Canadian Government is following closely operations of Japanese who are making surveys off the Alaskan and Canadian coasts with a view to discovering new fishing grounds, officials said today.

Miss Carolyn Bartow Sherwood, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Charles Sherwood and the late Mr. Sherwood, was married here this afternoon at the home of her mother to David Ives Mackie Jr.. son of Mrs. David Ives Mackie of New York and the late Mr. Mackie. The Rev.

Du Val R. Goldthwaite, president of the International Printing Ink Corporation since 1932, has been elected chairman of the board of the company under its new name, the Interchemical Corporation. E. W. Pittman, formerly vice president, has been elected president, and H. B. Woodman has been elected vice president and treasurer.

A mortgage for $515,00 on 1,776 Broadway held by the Bank for Savings from Setay Realties, Inc, Frederick R. Ryan, president, and Benjamin Eichberg, individually, was extended to April 1, 1942, the 4 1/2 per cent rate being reduced to 4 per cent for the first three years.

Miss Virginia Marvin, -daughter of Mrs. Charles Arthur Marvin of 122 McDonough Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Marvin, was married here last night at Sherry's to W. Alvord Finn, son of Harry Dennison Finn of Nutley, N. J., and the late Mrs. Finn.

Sixteen former employes of the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, and the president of their union local, all convicted April 22 of charges arising from their participation in the eight-hour sit-down strike at the hospital March 15, received suspended sentences yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn.

Philip Phillips, regional counsel for the National Labor Relations Board, expressed belief today that a company union held a legal status under the Wagner act, provided employes selected that type of organization.
Purchase of the screen rights to "Yes, My Darling Daughter" was announced officially yesterday by the Warner Brothers.

While President Roosevelt headed toward the Texas fishing grounds today, the temporary White House offices established here in. the Roosevelt Hotel completed arrangements for him- to sign the new Neutrality Bill tomorrow, the day on which the present law expires.

In his address before the American Physical Society last evening Mr. DAVID SARNOFF acknowledged the debt of industry to the mathematical physicist. Like others, he found it easier to dwell on the more obvious benefits that have flowed from the work of MAXWELL, HERTZ and MARCONI than to specify the kind of society which is best able to utilize the gifts of science and invention.

The "mob" and a Supreme Court "aloof from politics" were termed the strongest safeguards of civil liberties by Professor John A. Scott of Northwestern University last night at the thirtieth annual meeting of the Classical Association of the Atlantic States at the Hotel Brevoort.
Henry Baglay of Belle Haven has filed plans in the office of Building Inspector Charles D. Crosby to erect a miniature farm on his estate overlooking Long Island Sound. The project will cost $50,000.
The Pirates went down to defeat before the Cubs, 7-2, today on the fiftieth anniversary of Pittsburgh's entry into the National League.

A lifeboat crew of the American Scantic liner Scanmail went out in a storm several hundred miles off Cape Race, Nfld., about midnight Thursday and transferred a passenger from the Swedish-American Line ship Svanholm who was reported seriously ill.

Lawrence W. Roth, 40 years old, for more than ten years a carrier attached to the Woodside postal station, who pleaded guilty to an indictment charging him with theft from the mails, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz, In the Federal court in Brooklyn, to serve a year and a day in a Federal penitentiary.

The twelve-story unit of the Ageloff Apartments, at 43 Avenue A, one of the few remaining large apartment houses on the East Side, was sold yesterday at foreclosure proceedings in the Vesey Street auction rooms.
Harry M. Nimmo, a founder and editor of The Detroit Saturday Night, died suddenly here today in Jennings Hospital.
The production of "Aida" given last night by the Hippodrome Opera Company introduced no less than four singers new to the organization. All took principal parts.

The Senate Committee on Agriculture served notice on the administration today that it intends to play an independent role in the formulation of farm policies and the drafting of agricultural legislation.

" Active Forces Engaged in Securing Accuracy and Good Taste in Advertising" is the title of a symposium to be conducted by the advisory committee on advertising at a special session during the convention of the Proprietary Association at the Hotel Biltmore on May 25 to 27.

Mrs. William Adams Brown and Mrs. Ernest R. Adee gave a dinner last evening at the Colonial Dames House, 215 East Seventy-first Street, for the Rev. Dr. Noble C. Powell, who will be installed as Dean of the National Cathedral at Washington next Thursday.

Leaders of the insurgents of the International Seamen's Union decided yesterday not to interfere with the operation of merchant tonnage pending settlement of their quarrel with leaders of the union over the question of union control.

General Francisco Franco, the Insurgent commander, informed the British Government tonight that he would not promise to respect foreign ships in Spanish waters taking part in the evacuation of refugees from Bilbao.

Miss Kathryn Elizabeth Behrens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Behrens of this city, was married here tonight to Alfred Emile Runge, son of. Mrs. Emile Runge of Flushing, Queens, in Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church by the pastor, the Rev. Lloyd Ellis Foster.

Miss Helen Lois Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles William Brown of Pittsburgh, was married to John Wright Ballard Jr., son of Mrs. John W. Ballard of Norfolk, Va., and the late Mr. Ballard, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray, the rector.
The Yukon Council "firmly and emphatically" protested today the proposed annexation of this territory to the Province of British Columbia.
Carnarvon, running in the interests of George A. Garrett, overcame poor racing luck to win the Pikesville Purse, featured event of today's Maryland Jockey Club program at Pimlico.

Reflecting the easing in tension abroad, the grain markets on the Board of Trade were on the upgrade today with wheat displacing corn as the leader. Wheat prices closed with net gains of 3 1/3 to 3% cents a bushel while corn was 1 to 13/4, cents higher.

Loans disbursed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in March totaled $10,359,886, and repayments of previous loans aggregated $69,775,117, according to the monthly report submitted today by the governmental agency to Congress.
The annual Spring plays at Barnard College, written by alumnae, were presented last night by Wigs and Cues, the dramatic organization, in Brinckerhoff Theatre.

Members of three Hollywood film studio unions were called out on strike tonight at 6 P. M. (10 P. M. New York time) as a prelude to a possible strike of all eighteen unions composing Federated Motion Picture Crafts, which claim 10,000 members.
The Jersey Giants brought Toronto's seven-game winning streak to an end today when they handed the Leafs their first International League setback of the season, 4 to 1.

The Princeton University Council of Athletics has awarded the B. F. Bunn Basketball Trophy to John C. Appel of Indianapolis and the William B. Blackwell Hockey Cup to Peter G. Cook of Kingston, N. J., it was announced tonight by Asa S. Bushnell, secretary of the council.
Sales of copper in the export markets were negotiated yesterday on quotations ranging from 13.775 cents in the early trading to 14.25 cents at the close c. i. f. the European base ports.

Interest in bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was turned principally to the secondary and convertible corporate lists. Many issues in this section responded to a broad demand, eradicating much of the decline of Tuesday.

King Zog held a long audience today with Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, after which they lunched together privately and discussed Albanian questions in the light of the recent Italo-Yugoslav accord.

Starting at 11:30 this morning, New York City will hold its big day of intercollegiate rowing as the eights of Yale, Pennsylvania and Columbia battle over the Harlem River course, with the Blackwell Cup for the varsities as the feature.

The creation of a committee to represent eleven life insurance companies in the Wabash Railway foreclosure proceedings was announced yesterday. Dwight S. Beebe. vice president aid financial manager of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, is chairman.

Gorham Godwin sailed the International Star Class yacht Dice to the lead today in two trophy events of the Bermuda Spring racing series. In the morning Dice finished first in the second contest for the Bermuda Yacht Club trophy and repeated the performance in the Bermuda Challenge Trophy engagement this afternoon.

The wedding of Miss Gladys Victoria Trowbridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Trowbridge of this town, to Arthur William Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Moore of Newark, took place this evening in Prospect Presbyterian Church.
The Columbia Jester, comic magizine of Columbia University, was announced last night to be the winner of a contest in which more than thirty such magazines were entered.

The Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman has just been reassigned for another year by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area to the pastorate of St. Paul's Methodist Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

William McNeir, chief of the Bureau of Accounts of the State Department, retired today after more than fifty-six years in the department and sixty years in the government service. He is 72 years of age, having been born in this city and appointed a page in the House of Representatives in 1877.
John M. Young, vice president of Madeira, Hill Co., coal dealers, died at his home in Cynwyd today after a heart attack. He was stricken at his central city office.

Movements on the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 8,000, including 3,500 direct. Market fully steady with Thursday's best time on weights averaging 300 pounds, down; heavier butchers and big weight packing sows solw, weak; top $10.-30: bulk good and choice 200-300 pound. $10.00-25; comparable 150-190 lb., $9.65-10.15; good 350-500 pound, packing sows $9.50-75; bigweights down to $9 .and medium kinds, to $8.50.
Early election returns from four large voting centers today indicated sweeping victories for the Minseito and Seiyukai, parties opposed to the government.

Miss Dorothy Elizabeth MacVicker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. MacVicker of this place, was married this evening to John Christie Gillies of Newark, son of Charles Gillies of Edinburgh, Scotland.
The final match in the Scottish Football League resulted in a riot of scoring tonight, Motherwell trouncing Celtic, 8-0, to finish in fourth place in the first division table.
With Manager Joe Cronin setting the pace, the Red Sox battered four of the Athletics' pitchers for a total of nineteen hits today while piling up a 15-5 victory for Wes Ferrell.

With Governor Wilbur L. Croon of Connecticut presiding, the New England Council yesterday dedicated a series of indoor billboards of mountain and sea resorts, which occupies the entire east balcony of the Grand Central Terminal.
Lucian E. Baldwin, deputy sheriff of Middlesex County, died today at the Middlesex Hospital following an operation. He was 67 years old.

With an enrolled membership of 243,000, the largest in its history, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union plans to make "a determined fight" for the thirtyhour week, it was disclosed yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the union.

The Transport Workers Union was authorized last night, at an emergency meeting attended by 2,000 or more employes of the Third Avenue Railway Company, to call a strike on all of the company's street car and motor bus lines unless the union's demand for a referendum on collective bargaining is granted by noon on Monday.

The Essex County Tax Board today set Newark's tax rate for 1937 at $3.69 for each $100 of valuation, a decrease of 12 cents from last year's figure. The amount to be raised by taxation is $35,465,109, compared with $34.982,217 in 1986,

Rosenstock Bachrach, Yorkville operators, have purchased from Maria Bazata, executrix of Anna. Opperman, the five-story tenement house on a lot 25 by 102.2 feet at 302 East Seventy-fifth Street. There are twenty three-room apartments in the building, which adjoins the southeast corner of Sea ond Avenue.

New bond offerings in April were the smallest in volume for a month since February, 1935, and the smallest for an April in four years. New stock offerings, however, were slightly larger than in the previous month, and also showed a gain over April, 1936.

The principal foreign exchanges weakened in terms of the dollar yesterday, this reflecting a diminution of withdrawals of foreign funds from this market and a reduced volume of purchases of gold in London for shipment hare.

Copies of an interim report urg ing enactment of pending legislation to revise and consolidate the seventeen-year-old Arbitration Law were sent yesterday to members of the Legislature by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The twentieth biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs has closed with the election of Mrs. Vincent Hilles Ober of Norfolk, Va., as president to succeed Mrs. John A. Jardine of Fargo. N. D.

Knight Publications report a fast sale for their recently published "Life and Death: The Autobiography of a Surgeon," by Andrea Majocchi. The book is being printed direct from type and is already, the publishers say, in a fifth edition.

Commodity futures generally were higher yesterday in fairly active trading on the local markets. Rubber, copper, tin, lead, zinc, hide, cocoa and 'cottonseed oil futures gained, while silk, coffee, wool top and sugar futures were irregular. On the- cash market sugar, silk and wool tops declined, but all the grains, lard, tins, cotton and rubber advanced.

The storm in the financial markets appeared to have blown itself out today, leaving a trail of shaken confidence and minor wreckage. The 52-year-old jobbing firm of Higham Brothers, one of the foremost dealers in South African gold mining shares, announced today that it had decided to close its business. It is understood, however, that every commitment is being met and that one or more of the principal directors will form a new partnership.

The move to make William Griffin, editor and publisher of The New York Enquirer, a candidate for Mayor has met expressions of friendliness, according to John. J. Sullivan, chairman of the Griffin for Mayor Labor Committee.
Police, fire and park commissions would be abolished here under a proposed new charter filed with city authorities today by a Charter Revision Commission.

London's "coronation bus strike" started at midnight and simultaneously it was announced that a national coal strike three weeks hence had been voted by a special delegate conference of the Mine Workers Federation held in London.

Two women who lost their lives attempting to save others were among twelve persons honored today by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission in awarding twelve bronze medals in recognition of acts of heroism.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated April 29: MAJOR GENERAL Brown, A. W., the Judge Advocate General, four months' leave, Aug. 1. with permission to visit foreign countries.
A son was born here yesterday morning at the Harbor Sanitarium to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Outerbridge of Oyster Bay, L. I. Mrs. Outerbridge is the former Miss Sarah McC. Richmond,

Morris H. Wadley, in 435 E. 57th St.; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., brokers. F. Jackson Hauser; Hans Mandl; Fred Kirsch: William McFeeley; The Doctor's Telephone Service; Marshall J. Rouse, through Duff Conger, in 155 E. 96th St.; Clark T. Chambers. Inc., broker.
As a result of an increase in deaths from diphtheria, Health Commissioner John L. Rice warned parents yesterday to have their children immunized against the disease.

After three days examination of retail and: wholesale liquor dealers in New Jersey and New York, John J.Keenan, examiner for the Federal Trade Commission, 45 Broadway, yesterday. adjourned hearings into charges that Seagram's Distilleries, Inc., had fixed prices along the Atlantic seaboard until May 5, when they will be resumed in Providence, R. I.

By a vote of 4 to 3 the Court of Appeals today ruled that in a foreclosure action there was no right to a jury trial. The appeal was that of the Jamaica Savings Bank, plaintiff, vs. M. S. Investing Company, Inc., and others, defendants; William E. Kennedy and Colley E. Williams, defendants-respondents.
J. Gilbert Hall, North and South champion, turned back Bryan (Bitsy) Grant Jr., the Atlanta Giant Killer, 7-5, 5-7, 6-3, in a surprising upset today in the annual Hot Springs tennis tournament.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Schuyler Cammann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann of Lindemere, Merrick, L. I., to Howard Schiller Lipson, son of Mrs. William F. Wall of Scarsdale and the late Howard S. Lipson, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, which -was decorated with ferns and dogwood standards. White flowers adorned the pews in the middle aisle.

Franklin Munch, 38, latest Ohio penitentiary arrival, gave Warden James C. Woodard a problem in weight today. The Cincinnatian, shoes, coat, hat and all, tips the scales at 387 pounds-the largest man ever admitted.

With the unexpected withdrawal of General Owen O'Duffy's Irish Brigade from Spain, reports reached London tonight of an encounter between Spanish Rebel troops and their Irish allies, whom the Rebels mistook for Loyalists.

Slyvia Marks, leading lady in New York University's annual Spring varsity show, "In Praise of N. Y. U.," played her role last night in the second performance of the show despite the fact that her face had been slightly bruised when one of the supporting players delivered too realistic a "stage punch" at the show's opening, Thursday.

Pompoon's acid test for the Kentucky Derby will be applied this afternoon in the $20,000 added Wood Memorial at Jamaica when he will be asked to run more than a mile for the first time since he met defeat last Fall in New England.

Two persons pleaded guilty and ten pleaded innocent today in Circuit court on contempt charges in consection with a cleaners and dyers dispute. They were arrested yesterday for picketing the Flint Cleaners and Dyers plant in

Thomas F. Shields, 67-year-old conductor on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's Berkshire trains, made his final run out of the Grand Central Terminal at 3:40 P. M. yesterday, after completing fifty years of service.

In a report filed with the- Appellate Division, Referee John P. Cohalan has decided that the Association of the Bar had failed to prove its charges looking to the disbarment of J. Richard Davis, attorney for the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, it was said yesterday.

Intimacy, restraint and refinement were the salient characteristics of the playing put forth by Louis Bailly, erstwhile member of the late Flonzaley Quartet, and Genia Robinor, pianist, at their second joint recital of the season given last night in Town Hall.
The University of California student executive committee last night voted to send the varsity and freshman crews to the annual Poughkeepsie Regatta June 22.
Endorsing the Doyle bill to operate a State Labor Relations Board, Governor Lehman augmented his program for eliminating industrial strife today by proposing a State Board of Mediation.

Daniel Johnston Kerr died last night of a heart attack at his home in Llewellyn Park. He was 87 years old. For more than fifty years he was identified with S. M. Swenson Sons of 52 Wall Street, New York,

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. J. Edward Rayne of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Coralie Russell Rayne, to Irving R. Groves, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Groves of Summit.

After a lapse of over half a century a Dartmouth crew raced over the waters of the Connecticut River today, and the modern edition brought joy to more than 8,000 spectators by defeating the Williams varsity by one and three-quarter lengths. The winning time for the mile was 4:56.
Controller Frank J. Taylor made public his financial report for 1936 yesterday, showing the city had total collections, with its cash balance, of $1,596,322,495 and had paid out $1,455,833,686.

A gift of $50 from an anonymous donor living in Sussex, England, to the current $600,000 campaign in behalf of the Salvation Army was announced last night by Chalmers Wood, chairman of the Citizens Appeal for the army.

The inauguration of the first President was commemorated yesterday by exercises on the steps of the Subtreasury Building in Wall Street, where the statue of George Washington keeps watch over the bustling financial district.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: In John Kieran's column of Feb. 14 (which has just reached me) he predicts the season in the big leagues. May I call attention to one thing? Mr. Kieran says that if Pie Traynor can find six new pitchers in camp he may make trouble. .That is the usual size-up of the Pittsburgh team.
A five-hit pitching performance by Truett (Show-Boat) Sewell enabled Buffalo to chalk up a 4-to-3 victory over Newark today.

The conviction of Charles Stolof, Joseph Rivlin, Isidore Goodman (true name Isidore Gutman) and Jacob Wellner, appellants, and Michael Belsky in Kings County for attempting to obtain $300 from Louis Rogoff, a painting contractor,

The marriage of Miss Jean Collins, daughter of Mrs. Daniel Merritt Collins of 35 Midwood Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Collins, to Robert Russell Hall, son of Mrs. Frank Wells Hall of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mr. Hall, took place yesterday in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold Olafson.

Part of the Chadeayne farm, on the Inningwood Road in the Town of New Castle, about three miles from Ossining and Briarcliff, Westchester County, has been sold to a New York client of William J. Yates.

Thomas J. Wolre, Director of Public Safety in the City Commission here for the last three years, died at his home on Magnolia Avenue just before midnight tonight. Mr. Wolfe, who was 61 years old, had, been on a leave of absence for about a year because of illness.

An abrupt cessation of foreign selling, which had been a feature of the persistent decline recently, started a recovery movement on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. In sympathy. with the rebound in outside markets, prices improved over $1 a bale to end with net gains of 22 to 25 points.
The firm of Douglas Vought Co. has changed its name to Vought. Campbell. Ward Co. There have been no changes in the personnel and the business will continue at 25 W. 43d St.
One boy was killed, another slightly injured and a third escaped unharmed today when a one-pound war shell exploded in a washroom at St. Hedwig's School here.

Wayne C. Taylor, Assistan t Secretary of the Treasury, wrote yesterday to Harold J. Gallagher of 15 Broad Streets' New York, attorney or the Seaboard Bay Line, a subsidiary of the Seaboard Air Line, stating that the Company must pay interest of about $261,000 on government loans of $1,256,000. He ias made the same demand previously.
Gladys Cooper, English actress, and Philip Merivale, both starring in a stage show here, "Close Quarters," were married today by Superior Judge Joseph Sabath in the County Building.

The body of 7-year-old Aaron Dab, for whom water had such a strange fascination that his parents had moved from Sheepshead Bay to the Bronx, according to the police, was found at 11 o'clock last night at the bottom of the Bronx Park Lake after it had been drained.
Miss Helen Bippart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Achill Bippart of this place, was married this evening to Charles Holbrook, son of Mrs. Frederick S. Holbrook of Orange.

Harry C. Fichter, 30-year-old contractor, who was chosen last night as this community's Townsend Plan "pensioner," indicated today that if the object of the experiment is to make money "fly" he was lust the man to select.
The Bees had their batting eyes open today and behind the six-hit pitching of Jim Turner, rookie, clubbed Jorgens, Mulcahy and Sivess for fourteen hits and a 10-to-2 triumph over the Phillies.

A red-headed boy in a Western Union uniform walked along the promenade in front of the Public Library on Fifth Avenue at Fortysecond Street yesterday afternoon carrying a good-sized paper bag about which a flock of pigeons fluttered. He was doing a mission for Nikola Tesla, the famous inventor.

Engineering difficulties which are expected to limit the progress of booing the Queens Midtown Tunnel to one foot a day will prevent the completion of the tunnel before Dec. 31, 1940, in the opinion of Colonel Arthur W. Copp, general manager of the New York City Tunnel Authority, who reviewed recent developments concerning the tunnel at a luncheon of the First Avenue Association, Inc., yesterday at the Beekman Towers.

The Treasury Department's Silver Life Saving Medal was presented to Sergeant Jacob J. Gussak, Company L, Seventy-first Infantry N. Y. N. G., last night by Brig. Gen. Walter G. Robinson, adjutant general of the State, at a formal review at the Seventy-first Infantry Armory, Park Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street.
The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that holders of common and preferred shares of the Cosden Oil Corporation of Maine of record of May 6 may subscribe for common stock in the new company.

Max Tepper, one of the founders and partner of Tepper Brothers department store here for thirty years, died last night in a Buffalo hospital after an operation. He was born in Hungary and was 67 years old.

The Commercial Bulletin will asy tomorrow: "The President's price pronouncement, added to some financial distress in London, which resulted in a general selling wave in securities and commodities, has unsettled the wool market; so that despite the strong statistical position of raw wool, the market has come to a definite pause and prices have turned in favor of the buyer.
The Hippodrome Opera Company will present "Rigoletto" tomorrow afternoon, and "La Forza del Destino" in the evening.
Granby Consolidated Mining, Smelting and Power Company rights have been suspended from dealings on the New York Stock Exchange.

Before 2,000 guests the fifty-sixth annual review of the Knickerbocker Greys, crack junior cadet corps, was held yesterday at the 107th Infantry (Old Seventh Regiment) Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.

The State Banking Department announced today its approval of a license to the Railroad Employes Personal Loan Company of New York to transact business as a licensed lender, with a capital of $25,000. The office is to be at 160 Dyckman Street, Manhattan.

A smooth-stroking freshman heavyweight crew scored a one-length victory over the sophomore boat today on Lake Carnegie to annex the Princeton University interclass rowing championship. The victors covered the mile in 5:19.3.

Not long after the exhibit of the New England Council had been officially opened at Grand Central Palace by Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut yesterday, an announcement describing the fishing prospects in one New England State--Maine--was received from George J. Stobie, commissioner of the Pine Tree State's Department of Inland Fisheries and Game. Said Mr. Stobie:
A memorial service for Dr. William C. Carl will be held on Wednesday at 8 P.M. in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue , between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.
The Federal Chamber Orchestra, Samuel Gardner conducting, presented an unhackneyed and interesting program last night at the Theatre of Music.

As the crowning achievement of his term of office President Eamon de Valera gave to the Free State tonight the text of his longawaited new Constitution. For the last twelve months the President has been working hard upon this charter or fundamental law, that the people will be called upon to enact by a plebiscite in June.

Sir Herbert Marler, the Canadian Minister, and Lady Marler, who are at the Ritz-Carlton, will give a dinner tonight in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. Mrs. Ernest G. Vietor of Mayfair House and Mrs. Willis D. Wood of 635 Park Avenue are sailing today on the Kungsholm and will go to London. Mr. Vietor will sail Tuesday on the Paris to join Mrs. Vietor in France.

Coal dealers, labor union officials and prosecutors from three counties joined yesterday with Roderick Stephens, coordinator of the retail solid fuel industry, in demanding immediate action on a pending ordinance to check the sale of bootleg coal in the city.

William Armstrong Perry of Westport, Conn., a geologist, was rendered unconscious and, it is feared, suffered a fractured skull, and Frederic D. Grab of Chicago, United States Commercial Attache at Caracas, received contusions and probably broken ribs in the crash of a Venezuelan government plane during a storm last Friday in a dense,

With Jacinto Benavente presumably living as calmly as is possible these days in Valencia, where he was reported to be some time ago, his rather sultry philosophical drama "When Eve's Sons Are Not Adam's" was presented by Paulina Singerman and her players from Argentina to the satisfaction of the majority of a large audience at the Ambassador Theatre last night.

Clay Ave, 1,350 (11-2887); John J. Gillen. referee. to North Side Savings Bank. Matthews Ave (16-4438), e s, 100 ft n of Waring Ave. 50x100; Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Assn to Anna Glannetta. 1.274 Adee Ave. Classon Point Rd (14-3662). e s. 122 ft n of Story Ave. 40x100; Louise Cannovo to Fannie Feldman, 1,001 E 167th St.

Governors Island Kenneth P. Lord Jr., Fort Hamilton N. Y., a prospective graduate of the Unit versity of Vermont and State Agriculture College, Burlington, Vt., is assigned to the 1st Division as 2d Lt., Inf.-Res. Each of the following prospective grad?? ates of New York University, University Heights, New York, N. Y., is assigned to the 1st Division as 2d Lt.

General Douglas MacArthur, military adviser to the Philippine Commonwealth and former chief of staff of the United States Army, married Miss Jean Marie Faircloth of Murfreesboro, Tenn., daughter of Edward C. Faircloth, yesterday morning in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building directly after the couple had obtained their license.

Registration statements for securities under the Securities Act of 1933, with estimated gross proceeds of $469,907,000, became effective in March, increasing the total for the first quarter of 1937 to $1,391,297,000, according to a summary published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The National Association of American Composers and Conductors held its annual reception last night at the Town Hall Club Sigmund Spaeth acted as master of ceremonies and Gene Buck, Deems Taylor, Albert Stoessel and John Tasker Howard were speakers.

Communists and Socialists will celebrate today in many foreign countries and in some of our own larger cities, but there will be little response from the American countryside. The Marxian movement in this country remains what it has always been:

The volcano Petorca, situated in the Andes opposite the Chilean city of Curico, is throwing up thick columns of smoke, ashes and rocks, it is reported, causing a panic among those who live in the vicinity.

The new reserve requirements of member banks, which will take effect today, represent in effect a return to the requirements that existed prior to the establishment of the Federal Reserve System in 1914, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York concludes in a discussion of the changes in reserves contained in its current monthly review, published yesterday.
Eugene R. Miller, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been admitted to partnership in Tefft Co.

The House refused today to accept a 25 per cent reduction made by the Senate in a $1,660,000 deficiency bill on motion of Representative Woodrum of Virginia, who characterized the Senate action as "economy hysteria."

The Democratic revolt against President Roosevelt's court reorganization bill has spread to include Senators Lonergan and Maloney of Connecticut, according to friends of the two Senators. Both intend to make their position known publicly within a short time, these friends have been led to believe, and meanwhile are actively helping a State-wide fight against the bill which seems to have the support of a considerable part of the Democratic State organization.
Striking out twelve batters, Marty Cogan hurled a no-hit game as Samuel J. Tilden High beat Alexander Hamilton, 14-1, in a Section A, Brooklyn, P. S. A. L. struggle at Commercial Field yesterday.
By a vote of 285 to 66, President Roosevelt's court reorganization plan was condemned today by the council of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, representing 2,500,000 membets in all States.

Income tax deficiencies amounting to $5,199,218 have been filed against the Henry Pfeiffer family of Riverside Drive, New York, by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, it was revealed in an action filed before the Board of Tax Appeals today.

A new two-way air-service between New York and Kansas City, providing also for quicker travel between certain Middle-Western cities and the Pacific Coast will be started today by Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc.

Dividends declared in April amounted to $232,449,421, declared by 806 corporations, comparing with $282,103,222 dividends declared by 1,318 companies in March and with $172,636,197 dividends of 737 corporations in April, 1936.

Manager Charley Grimm of the Cubs has joined Burleigh Grimes, pilot of the Dodgers, as an example in President Ford Frick's annual campaign to keep rowdyism out of the National League, it was reported yesterday by The Associated Press.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Douglas Sloane, daughter of Mrs. William Sloane of 686 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Sloane, to Dr. Robert Lee Patterson Jr. of Athens, Ga., wi11 take place today in the chapel of the Union Theological Seminary.

A banking group headed by the Bank of the Manhattan Company was awarded yesterday a new issue of $1,553,000 of water, refunding, school, public works -and local improvement bonds of the city of Albany, N. Y., on a bid of 100.275 for 2 1/2s.

The 'Rev. Dr. Carl Christian Hein, president of the American Lutheran Church for the last six years, died yesterday morning at his home in Columbus, Ohio, in-his sixty-ninth year, according to word received here.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it had issued an order prohibiting a group of radio manufacturers and dealers from using popular trade names of other manufacturers without the consent of the lawful owners.

Shareholders of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company, meeting on May 25 in Jersey City, will be asked to approve a recapitalization plan designed to wipe out arrears of dividends on the preferred stock, as well as most of the funded and bank debt.
A strict surveillance of retail prices was ordered today by the Central Corporative Committee simultaneously with a general wage increase of 10 to 12 per cent.

MANHATTAN BATES, LINDELL T. (April 13). Estate, more than $5,000. To City of Pittsfield, Mass.. tract of land of about 450 acres near Pittsfield for use as a public park in memory of decedent's father and brothers; Susan Page, godchild, 404 Lexington Ave., real property at Kitchawan, Westchester, N. Y.; Yale Law School, New Haven, Conn., books,

The Erie Railroad Company, stating it could-'not' get funds for payment "on reasonable terms" from banks or the public, today petitioned the Interstate- Commerce Commission for permission to extend the due dates of loans- totaling- $20,760,310 obtained from the Reconstruction Finance- Corporation, the first of which will mature on June 1..
William Gillette celebrated American actor, will be buried tomorrow as he wished-with simple, private services attended only by a few close relatives.

An advance in rates for Stock Exchange time money was the only important change in the short-term money market in April. Call money continued unaltered throughout the month at 1 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange and 1 1/2 per cent on the Curb, compared with three-fourths of 1 per cent and 1 1/4 per cent, respectively, a year ago.

Atlantic passenger rates will remain at their present levels throughout this year, it was decided today at the semiannual meeting of the Atlantic Conference in which representatives of all steamship lines participate.
SANTANDER--The Rebel battleship Espafia was sunk by bombs from five airplanes off Santander as she pursued a British blockade runner.

Harry W. Colmery, national commander of the American Legion, presented today to his alma mater, Oberlin College, the Fidac Medal in recognition of work for the promotion of international peace and goodwill.

Dr. E. Bright Wilson Jr., Assistant Professor of Chemistry at Harvard University, is the winner of the 1937 American Chemical Society prize of $1,000 for his experimental work in physical chemistry, the society announced yesterday. Dr. Wilson is 28 years old.
Registration statements for proposed new securities filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission included:
Oliver Deridder, Rochester shoe manufacturer, died last night in his home here at the age of 69. President of E. P. Reed Co., Inc., shoe concern, he had been associated with the firm since boyhood.
Miss Alice Gregg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hayes Gregg of this place, was married tonight to Sidney Bartram Schou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Schou of Glen Ridge.

Now that New York is fast becoming--in the phrase of the demon publicists--the most popular Summer resort in America, it is fitting that more and more attention should be paid to providing facilities for entertaining the migrating hot-weather crowds.

The Rev. John Robert Davidson, 57-year-old Methodist minister, died here yesterday while on a leave of absence from the Saranac Lake Methodist Church. A native of Ireland, he was granted leave a month ago because of ill health.

Arthur M. Curtis, Republican National Committeeman from Missouri, said today that there was a "spontaneous movement" among Missouri Republicans to help return Bennett Champ Clark of St. Louis to the Senate in 1938 "because of his record as an anti-New Dealer."

The Phelps Dodge Corporation of New York City has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission the provision for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 on the ground that its utility operations are only incidental to its general business.

With six horses named and only five likely to start, the veteran jumper Fugitive, owned by Mrs. George H. Bostwick, will probably be the favorite for the sixteenth running of the Virginia Gold Cup at four miles tomorrow over the Broadview timber course on the estate of Alexander B. Hagner.
James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany Hall, who has been convalescing here for the past eight weeks from a lingering illness, has no intention of relinquishing his post, he said today.

The first contingent of the Hayden Planetarium - Grace - Peruvian Eclipse Expedition to the Andes Mountains sailed yesterday afternoon for Lima, Peru, from the pier at the foot of West Fifteenth Street and the Hudson River on the Grace liner Santa Maria.
Representatives of the United States and Canada took part today in ground-breaking ceremonies at the site of the new International Thousand Island Good- most Will Bridge here.

F. G. (Teddy) Oke, financier, soldier and sportsman, died at his home here today. He was 51 years old. Known, as the "Good Angel of Sport," Mr. Oke at one time probably had more sport connections than any man in Canada. Many athletes owed their success to his backing.
Charles I. Sparks, who represented the Sixth Kansas District in Congress from 1929 to 1933, died here today. He was 64 years old.
The merry month of May opens in the theatre tonight with a mystery melodrama. "Without Warning," they call it, and Ralph Spencer Zink is the author.

In a sharp Attack here today on the Roosevelt administration's conservation polcy Gifford Pinchot, former Goverlor of Penndylvania, declared that Secretary Ickes was conducting a 'raid" on the natural resources of he country.
Building plans filed yesterday included preliminary sketches of the new $1,000,000 home for the Museum of Modern Art in West Fiftythird Street.

Imports of gold received here in April totaled $155,881,800, the largest amount for any month since last October, according to the daily gold reports of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This amount compared with $93,002,800 imported in March and $22,516,400 received in April, 1936.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $11,295,002, represented by one State and forty municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $25,958,203 for this week. The weekly average of new sales for the year to date now stands at $34,256,996.

The marriage of Miss Jessie Allan Merrill, daughter of-Mr. and Mrs. William Converse Merrill of New Rochelle, to William Oscar Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Roth, also of New Rochelle, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Of NORMAN HAPGOOD, Mr. Dooley said his motto was " Yes--and No." Whether he yessed or noed, he was usually emphatic about it. He was a natural dissenter. He was an independent; a "liberal" and "progressive" before those words had lost their edge. He was a friend of liberty.

The French people continue to express their devotion to the memory of MYRON T. HERRICK. His love for France, as evidenced dramatically by his remaining in Paris when all the foreign embassies and legations fled, made him the more loved by his own country.

The drive against burlesque throughout the city received impetus yesterday afternoon when District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Kings County announced that he would appear before the grand jury on Monday to present evidence gathered in raids on three Brooklyn burlesque theatres Thursday night.

Student and faculty committees on arrangements and a group of 150 patrons and patronesses were named yesterday for the celebration on Friday of Charter Day. at City College, sponsored by the House Plan, the social activities center at the college..

L. F. Loree, head of the Delaware Hudson Company, retained his position in 1936 as the highest paid railroad official, according to statements filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission and made public yesterday.

American, British and Netherland dealers bid keenly for a collection of pictures, chiefly of Dutch seventeenth-century masters, formed by Lewis Lloyd about the middle of the last century, which was sold here today. The sale realized a total of [Pound]53,487.

In an effort to effect peace among warring longshore factions in Montreal, Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, instructed his Montreal representative yesterday to sign an agreement with the Shipping Federation whereby all steamship freight in that port would be handled by members of the newly created Local 375.
The last trace of capitulations, or the treaties under which foreigners have special rights in Egypt, will end in 1949, it was agreed here today by the powers enjoying these privileges.

Fifty-twoyear-old Steve Donoghue today won the One Thousand Guineas for the first time, riding Sir Victor Sassoon's Exhibitionist to an exciting half-length victory in the first of the season's classics for three-yearold fillies.
The Florida Legislature has killed a proposal to keep the sources of newspaper reporters' information confidential.

Moscow became a seaport today as the waters of the Volga River, pouring gently through the newly dug MoscowVolga canal, rose to navigable height beneath the Kremlin wall, transforming the shallow Moscow river into a great waterway linking seas and oceans to the Bolshevist capital.

The National Association of Mutual Savings Banks closed its annual conference at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday with adoption of a resolution hailing the current moves for Federal economy and with speeches condemning as "unwarranted", the continuation of Federal encroachments in the mortgage lending field.

The New York Curb Exchange has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for unlisted trading privileges in the $5 par value common stock of the UtahIdaho Sugar Company, now registered and listed on the Salt Lake Stock Exchange.

The marriage of Miss Nancy MaeGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. A. MacGregor of Baltimore, to Frank Lawton Getman, son of Mrs. Frank Lawton Getman of New York and Havana and the late Mr. Getman, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Thomas Church here.

Twenty-four States have voted to take part in the New York World's Fair of 1939 and twelve more Legislatures have bills for participation pending, it was announced yesterday at headquarters of the Fair Corporation.

Four hundred students of the Horace Mann School, Broadway and 120th: Street, ranging in age from 6 to 14, resurrected the costumes of late nineteenth-century school children as they celebrated yesterday the fiftieth anniversary of their school's existence.

A story of a two-day battle with a giant stingray they said attacked their steel-laden freighter off the southern coast of Mexico was-told here today by Captain F. Fink and First Engineer J. E. Ahearn of the Lewis,Luckenbach.

Metropolitan Museum of Art, "Painting in Germany, England and France," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "Gothic and Renaissance Furniture," Alfred Busselle Jr., 2 P. M.; "Roman Imperial Portraits," Stuart M. Shaw, 2 P. M.; "The Pottery Maker; The Pilgrims," Yale Photoplay, motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.

The proposal to legalize dog racing in New York State, which had gone to Governor Lehman for approval or veto, was recalled for a conference by the Legislature under a resolution adopted by the Senate today.
Yale's Spring football practice closed today with a regulation game in which the Flashes, captained by Bill Dickens, defeated the Hopefuls, led by Al Hessberg, 14--6.
Two patrolmen were sentenced here today to nine months each in the house of correction after a trial based on alleged corruption,in the Police Department of Brookline, a suburb of Boston.

Misrepresentation of Japanese goods as "Made in the U. S. A." was charged against Adolph Wein, trading as American Toy Works, 41 East Eleventh Street, New York, in a complaint filed today by the Federal Trade Commission.

An ever-increasing responsibility rests upon the private welfare agencies in seeing that social security and relief do not become "routine" functions of the Federal Government, William Hodson, Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare, said yesterday.

Mrs. Mabel Walker Willebrandt, former Assistant United States Attorney General, was named defendant in four damage suits docketed here today for the May term of the Circuit Court. The plaintiffs asked a total of $62,000.

Cram's Reports, Inc., today estimated automobile production for the current week at 139,475 cars and trucks, compared with 133,164 units last week and 118,764 assemblies during the week ended on May 2, 1936.
Harry Servas and Robert Davis of North Bergen, N. J. shot 1,318 yesterday to land in fourth place in the doubles division of the American Bowling Congress championships.
The New York State Athletic Commission, at its regular meeting yesterday, announced the list of boxing and wrestling dates for the coming Summer.

The Long Island Daily Press of Jamaica, Queens, announced its indefinite suspension last night, interrupting publication for the first time since it was founded in 1819. William F. Hofmann, publisher, declared: "I am discontinuing publocation involuntarily."
John B. Waterman, president and founder of the Waterman Steamship Company, the largest concern in the Gulf trade, died here today. He was 71 years old.
First of the championship competitions of the seventeenth annual Newark Horse Show was won tonight by Miss Frances M. Dodge of Rochester Mich.

Mysterious errands and obscure bargainings are going on in Central Europe. Little noted in greater excitements, but perhaps more important in the long-range view, are the two diplomatic visits made this week by the Foreign Ministers of Poland and Italy.

The Federal Government is seeking to introduce against Ellis H. Parker Sr. and the other defendants in the Paul H. Wendel abduction case evidence concerning behind-the-scenes phases of both the Lindbergh investigation and the delay in executing Bruno Richard Hauptmann, it was indicated here today.
