Although a general business "revival" has set in, a boom and crash period similar to that of 1928-29 is unlikely in the next thee or four years, financial and business leaders were told yesterday at the opening of the eighth annual conference of the Wharton Institute of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

Dolph Camilli, the Phillies' slugging first baseman, today ended his holdout, accepting terms offered by President Gerry Nugent. Terms were not disclosed, but Nugent is believed to have offered Camilli a contract for $11,000, an increase of $2,000 over last year. The first baseman was reported demanding $15,000.

Far from being one master organ, totalitarian in scope and unified in function, the ruling mind of Germany seems to work in compartments, as separate and incoherent as if the coordinating brain of the dictatorship were more scattered and argumentative than any parliament.

Dizzy Dean ran his string of victories for the season to three and his strikeouts to 22, but the colorful pitcher failed today to keep the Reds from scoring a run that broke his shutout streak at twenty innings.

The Court of Errors and Appeals affirmed today the murder conviction against William J. Stephan, Camden furniture salesman. He must go to the electric chair unless the Court of Pardons intervene. Stephan was charged with killing Curtis W. Dobbins, 28 years old,

The Board of Estimate approved an appropriation of $62,490 yesterday for equipment and personnel to increase the production of pneumonia serum, and referred to the budget director a request for $30,932 for research in pneumonia control submitted by Health Commissioner John L. Rice.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on April 24 totaled 761,182 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Tugging easily at her mooring before a brisk northerly breeze, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup yacht Yankee lay in Brenton Cove out in the harbor here today, the initial arrival for the coming racing connected with the sixteenth match for the filigreed old silver trophy that would never adorn a mantle or table, as much as it is prized.

A banking consortium has been organized under the auspices of the Central Bank to float local loans with which the government will buy up its outstanding foreign bonds. The first loan will be 200,000,000 pesos (roughly $60,000,000).

Stocks closed higher in less active trading; Wednesday's losses recovered; turnover, 1,449,500 shares. United States Government issues irregularly higher, corporate bonds higher, second-grade and convertible issues strongest; foreign loans steady; transactions, $11,153,800.
William T. McGraw, former Michigan State Senator and resident of this suburban Windsor town for almost twenty-five years, died at his home last night at the age of 76.

The expiration date of licenses of motor vehicle operators and chauffeurs has been extended from May 31, Charles A. Hartnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, announced yesterday. The extension, Mr. Hartnett said,

The first step in the further simplification of the corporate structure of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, was taken yesterday with the filing of an application by Consolidated Edison with the Public Service Commission seeking the approval of a proposed plan of exchange of preferred stocks of the two companies.

Tomorrow will be Easter in Greek Orthodox and Russian Orthodox Churches throughout the world. The Eastern Orthodox Church, with which they are affiliated, follows the Julian Calendar rather than the Gregorian Calendar.
The National securities Traders Association will hold its fourth annual convention in the Hotel Traymore, Atlantic City, from Sept. 8 to 11, it was announced yesterday.

Leonard St, 45, 38x100.11; 51, 25x100; and 53, 25x100, James J. Minot to James J. Jr., George R. and Henry W. Minot, 104 Beacon St. Boston, Mass. Spring St, 244, 25x100, also n s of Dominick St, 125 west of Clark St, 76.7x 75, and facing on Varick St, 45.11 1/2, Spring Street Social Settlement to the Salvation Army ($5.50).

The Hamilton Grange Reformed Church, at Convent Avenue and West 149th Street, will merge with the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, at West 181st Street and Fort Washington Avenue. The final service in the Grange edifice will be held tomorrow morning.

Nearly all trade divisions showed improvement in activity this week, all of the leading cities reporting an increase in retail sales over the previous week's volume, with the average running from 2 to 5 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

All is not well in Brazil. The strictest censorship since the revolt of 1930, which brought GETULIO VARGAS to power, was imposed by him Thursday on all outgoing communications. No news of the real situation was allowed to filter even into Uruguay, just across the southern border.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Representative Hoffman on the subject of the National Labor Relations Act, appearing in your issue of April 29, seems to me misleading in a number of ways.

The Taylor-Colquitt Company has announced that all the new issue of 14,200 shares of common stock recently offered to the corporation's stockholders was subscribed for except fourteen shares, whose owners could not be reached.

An American Federation of Labor union here today called out its members in sympathy with a strike sponscored by the Committee for Industrial Organization. Despite disaffection between the two rival national organizations,
Secretary Hull appeared before the House Agriculture Committee today to criticize the pending O'MahoneyJones Sugar Bill as unfair and a breach of good faith with Cuba.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the smallest in any month since last September. Sales for April, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 34,613,169 shares, compared with 50,344,350 shares in March and 39,616,438 shares in the corresponding month in 1936.
Gerald Faulkner Shepard, former New York lawyer and descendant of a long line of educators and lawyers, died yesterday at his home in Hamden.

Edsel Ford, son of Henry Ford, has added to his art collection a painting by the French impressionist Auguste Renoir, entitled "The Cup of Chocolate," bought from the Durand-Ruel Galleries, 12 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Endeavour I and Endeavour II, T. O. M. Sopwith's racing sloops, leave here tomorrow at noon for America, with their owner hoping one will return with the America's Cup.

Tear gas, smoke bombs and a set of portable barbed-wire barricades to hold mobs in check will be part of the equipment of the "flying riot squads" that the government plans to add to the Paris police force to avoid bloodshed in suppressing disorders.
The United States in the first three months of this year purchased $113,959,000 more merchandise in foreign countries than it sold abroad in the period, the Department of Commerce announced today.

A couple of streaks cracked right in the middle today when, to the untold delight of a ladies' day crowd of 14,000, the Yankees, with five straight victories behind them, tripped over Buck Newsom and the Senators to blow the final fame of the series here 4 to 1.
Johnny Reder's single in the eleventh inning with the bases loaded ended a tight battle between the Chiefs and Rochester Red Wings today, Syracuse winning, 3 to 2.

Trupentine firm, 343/4C.; sales, 112 barrels; receipts 854 barrles; shipments, 982 barrels, stock, 23,323 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 497; receipts, 992 stock, 42,851. Quote: B, $7.05; D, $7.15; E; $7.55; F to K, $8.10; M, N, WG, $8.12 1/2; WW. X, $9.

May 1 is moving day this year principally for families in Brooklyn and the Bronx, while most Manhattan and Queens residents are content to remain in their old quarters, according to figures made public yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.

A trade practice conference for the popular price dress industry, having an output valued at $200,000,000 annually, has been authorized by the Federal Trade Commission and will be held at the Hotel Astor on May 20, according to announcement made yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive director of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group.

Brushing aside as irrelevant the Court of Chancery decision that the alleged atheistic and communistic beliefs of Mrs. Mabel Eaton of New York made her unfit to rear her two minor children, the Court of Errors and Appeals nevertheless affirmed today the. decree of divorce granted to Warren P. Eaton of Bloomfield, N. J., and the award to him of the children's custody.

Ashley C. McKinly, 45 years old, official photographer of the Byrd Expedition to little America in 1929, and Zeki Dervend, 42, commercial pilot, narrowly escaped death from suffocation this afternoon when an airplane in which they were riding crashed while making a forced landing in the marsh that fringes the Great South Bay a quarter mile west of the Babylon Yacht Club.
The first of 150.indigent families which the Oakland County Relief Administration plans to house under canvas was moved to its new tent home today.

The thirty-day sit-down strike of thirty blind workers in two charitable workshops for the blind is expected to end this morning under an agreement arranged yesterday through the offices of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director of the National Labor Relations Board.

Smothering fire in her No. 2 hold with steam, the crippled Alaska Steamship Company's Cordova arrived here today with 104 passengers, after a battle with fire and heavy seas off the British Columbia coast.
Governor Lehman heard sharp differences of opinion expressed today at a public hearing on the Piper bill to make illegal practice of law criminal contempt of the Supreme- Court.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Irvin Waldman of New York City was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 703-Old Colony Trust Co., trustee, petr., v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Argument continued for respondent and concluded, for Petitioner.
The action of the securities markets recently in the face of heavy selling for both domestic and foreign accounts drew favorable comment in the financial community yesterday.

A big part of the population of the United States is improperly fed, due to two factors-insufficient income in a large cross-section composed of workers and ignorance of food values on the part of another group which had adequate income for a correct diet if properly spent, according to a report yesterday by Dr. E. V. McCollum of Baltimore.

General Yang Hu-chen, co-leader of the Sian coup in which Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was kidnapped, today resigned as pacification commissioner of Shensi Province and said he planned a tour of Europe and America.

BERTRAND RUSSELL'S father, Lord Amberley, was the eldest son of Lord John Russell, the Prime Minister. In 1864 he married a daughter of Lord Stanley of Alderley. Within a dozen years both husband and wife had died, leaving behind two sons and a mass of letters and journals.

The world's greatest scientific. instrument moved a step nearer completion today when the last bolt was put in the seventy-five-ton steel framework tube which will support the mirror of the 200-inch telescope to be set up in California.

With the Senate in recess, its Agriculture Committee decided to call a conference of State Agriculture Commissioners to obtain their views on farm legislation; the La Follette subcommittee continued its investigation of labor espionage,
OLD WINE, by Phyllis Bottome. (Stokes, $2.50.) A novel set in post-war Vienna. CONTACT, by Charles Codman. (Little, Brown, $2.) A story of air service during the World War.
Frank J. Sheridan Jr., retired commercial and advertising artist, of Barker's Point, L. I., died yesterday in a hospital here after an operation. Mr. Sheridan,

Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Robert Morris Associates at the Federal Reserve Bank that "if we are only to balance our national budget during very prosperous years and continue to pile up debts in ordinary or lean years, we are merely committing ourselves to long-term inflation."

Whatever their status may be with the Metropolitan Golf Association, which left their names off the honor roll when it was made public earlier in the year, Charles H. Mayo Jr., holder of the Long Island amateur crown, and William Tobin are in good standing with the Long Island Golf Association.

The Inland Waterways Corporation, for its operations during the calendar year 1936, had a consolidated net income of $485,402, and a consolidated net profit of $539,552, according to the annual report today of Major Gen. T. Q. Ashburn, president of the corporation.

Premier Duplessis of Quebec ordered the Montreal police tonight to arrest Bernard Shane, organizer of the strike of 5,000 members of the Montreal branch of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and Raoul Trepannier, chairman of the strike committee. The union is a C. I. O. affiliate.

Over the protests of their four lawyers, the hearing yesterday on the assault charge against Father Divine, Negro cult leader, and three of his "angels" again was postponed in Felony Court until next Friday. Magistrate McKiniry freed each in the $500 bail furnished at their first arraignment, last week.
Miss Anita Lizana of Chile gained a 6-4, 6-2 victory today over Miss Dorothy Round, the English star, in the semi-finals of the British hard-court tennis championships.
Directors of the Burlington Mills Corporation yesterday declared aa initial quarterly distribution of 25 cents a -share to common stock holders, payable May 15, to holders of record May 5.

Edgar M. Johnson, an attorney, died suddenly here today of a heart attack at the age of 76. Mr. Johnson, who served as State Senator from 1908 to 1912, was a member of the executive committee of the Cincinnati Bar Association.

The report of the Boston Edison Company for the twelve months ended March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $5,360,338, equal to $8.69 a share on the company's 617,161 shares of capital stock outstanding.at the end of the period.

For a few fleeting moments yesterday at the Polo Grounds Carl Hubbell's marvelous record of successive victories was in Jeopardy. He served a home-run ball to Heinie Manush of the Dodgers with one on and two out in the first inning of the interborough series finale and the screw-ball maestro was embarrassed no end.
Retail trade here, beset by adverse weather conditions and a falling stock market, was only fair during the week.

Regarded as one of the city's outstanding college nines, the St. John's University team displayed further evidence of its prowess at Manhattan Field yesterday, blasting the offerings of three Manhattan College pitchers for twelve hits while pounding out a 10-to-5 victory.

The four-story apartment and stores at 2,657 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by a bank to a syndicate represented by Charles M. Riesiger, attorney. Sale of the structure, which contains twenty-one apartments and four stores, was for cash above a fiveyear purchase money mortgage of $61,000. It is assessed at $70,000.

Sheriff Theodore R. Middleton of Harlan County, Ky., told the Senate subcommittee investigating violations of civil liberties today that "I guess a large part of the crime and violence has been committed by my deputies."
The University of Pennsylvania will not be represented at the 200th anniversary celebration of the University of Goettingen. Dr. Thomas S.

The seriousness of Columbia's designs on the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. track and field championship a month hence was made clear at the Randalls Island Stadium yesterday as the Lions made a runaway of the metropolitan intercollegiate title games. It was not even close.
Buyers of denims seeking yesterday to duplicate recent purchases of the standard 28-inch 2.20s at less than the quoted market of 16 cents found that mills uniformly were holding firm at that level.
The Tigers reached Lloya Brown for two doubles and a single in the tenth inning today to defeat the Indians, 4 to 2.
J. Edward Jones of Scarsdale, oil royalties dealer, who termed his indictment a year ago for

Mrs. Ferne Elwyn of this city, widow of Robert Elwyn, was married to Roselle F. Woodhull of Rockville Centre, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Edgar Woodhull, yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Karl F. Moore, pastor of St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church of Rockville Centre.
The major May Day demonstration in this city today will be the parade and mass meeting in Union square to be held by thousands of workers under the direction of the United May Day Committee.

New bond financing this week amounted to only $21,069,000, represented by two classifications, compared with $96,682,000 last week. During this week a year ago a total of $237,315,000 in new bonds was placed on the market, consisting largely of corporate loans.
At the annual meeting of the Decorators Club, the new York organization of professional women decorators, Bertha Schaefer was elected president.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

Steps toward putting the returned goods arbitration agreement between the National Retail Dry Goods Association and the Apparel Industries Inter-Trade Bureau into effect as soon as possible will be discussed at a conference of representatives of both groups early next
The Cleveland Buffalo Transit Company filed an application in the United States court today for reorganization under Section 7Tb of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
The Bureau or Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 28: COMMANDERS Harrill, W. K., the Saratoga, to duty as Assistant Naval Attache, American Embassy. London. England.

Oriental Garden, restaurant, floor in 205 W 50th St Direct Photo Electro Corp of N. Y., loft in 209 W 48th St, through Joseph P. Day Management Corp: Kersey Co, broker. Leo H. Hirsch Co, buttons, in 374-80 Second Ave; European Linen Importing Corp, floor in 244 Fifth Ave: Seymour Kramer, surgical supplies, in 24-6 E 21st St: M. L. Hess. Inc.. broker.

Frederick I. Daniels, executive director of TERA, defended the policy of withholding relief from veterans who have not satisfactorily explained the disposition of their bonus, at a hearnig before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler yesterday.

Unable to meet its current obligatoins, Elsie de Wolfe, Inc., of 677 Fifth Avenue, the interior decorating concern founded by Lady Mendl, the former Elsie de Wolfe, petitioned Federal court yesterday for permission to reorganize under the Bankruptcy Act.

The Sinclair Refining Company, as successor to the Sinclair Prairie Pipeline Company of Texas, filed today a protest against the tentative value of its pipe-line property as determined on Dec. 31, 1934,

James J. Braddock's lawyers told the Federal court today that granting the Madison Square Garden Corporation's application for an injunction against the Braddock-Joe Louis fight might force their client "to remain for the rest of his life under an injunction not to fight again."

MANHATTAN ASPINWALL J. LAWRENCE (May 16, 1936). Gross assets, $175,609; net, $165,- 539. To endowment fund of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, $1,000: Estelle C. Exham, $5,000: Rosanne Roundebush, $10,000: Maude Clements, $5,000: Gouverneur M. Carnochan, $5,500: five varying bequests.

The Julius Rosenwald Fund has awarded fellowships to thirty Negroes, it was announced yesterday by Edwin R. Embree, president of the fund. The awards average $1,500 and provide for a year's advanced study and experience to persons of unusual achievement and promise any field of work. About 540 Negroes applied for the fellowships.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are April 29 unless specified; At Washington Yard: Acushnet, Leary. Pearl Harbor to sea, April 30:

Information gleaned in Catholic circles makes it fairly clear that much of the material on which the present wholesale prosecutions of Catholic monks, priests and lay brothers are being undertaken was furnished all unwittingly by Catholics themselves.
Standard shades for kitchen and bathroom accessories were ap proved yesterday at a conference held by the National Bureau of Standards of the Department of Commerce at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
There were a total of 17,016 automobile accidents in New York State during the first three months of this year, according to a report issued yesterday by the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
Mrs. Queenie Smith Garland, musical comedy actress, obtained a divorce here today on grounds of cruelty from Robert Garland, drama critic. They were married on May 17, 1931. No alimony was asked.

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation yesterday reported for the three months ended on March 31 a consolidated net income of $1,233,025 after expenses, taxes, depreciation, depletion and other charges, but before any provision for surtax on undistributed profits.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP).-Representatives of the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company and the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America agreed today to confer in an effort to settle a strike of 8,500 workers.
Among many women's clubs in New York whose nomenclature tells a story of nostalgic longing, dominance of State pride is the strongest tie that binds.

Fair and unfair methods of rush ing new members are among the organization problems coming up for consideration before 200 dele gates of college fraternities, both active and alumnae, meeting for a district Panhellenic Conference Fri day at the Beekman Tower Hotel.

BERLIN, April 23 (AP), (by Mail). --Chancellor Adolf Hitler's cheap people's car which he promised Germans for three years and with which the Fuehrer dreams of con quering the European market will remain a myth for at least two years.

A so-so week in films has slipped by, featured chiefly by James Cagney's spurning of Warner overtures, by the addition of the Esquire Theatre to the roster of midtown Manhattan cinema houses, and by Paramount's decision not to make that film...
WORCESTER, Mass., May 1.-Holy Cross turned back Harvard by 3 to 2 today in a well played game before a crowd of 4,000. Roy Bruninghaus, Crusader ace, struck out eight and walked only one.

PICTURESQUE Key West, once described as "four square miles of lovely ruin and decay snooz- ing in lush tropical growth," looks forward to the future with new hope as work progresses on the $3,600,000 motor causeway across the Keys which is to renew its link...

EXETER, N.H., May 1.--The Yale freshmen scored a 20-7 victory over Phillips Exeter's nine to day. The visitors started scoring early, getting thirteen runs in the first two innings on nine singles, four walks and two misplays.

Controversy on compulsory mili tary training has flared recently in three places throughout the country, in the East, West and Middle West.

Gold Star parents in each borough of the city have been selected as guests of honor at the tenth annual Parents' Day celebration on the Mall in Central Park next Sunday from 2:30 to 4:30 P. M. Each of the parents had a son in the Amer ican service who died during the World War.

WHEN you see a photograph of a savage who is wearing a civilized man's coat and vest above his loin cloth, you need not be horrified by the indications. Perhaps the original owner did not go into the stew pot.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On reading the editorial on "Purchasing Power" in THE TIMES of April 19, I found myself wondering whether the writer was serious or merely indulging in some economic satire. I decided that he meant it, so the laugh is on me if he did not.

HIGH in the Adirondacks, 300 miles north of New York City, a tiny stream known as the Hudson River trickles southward through fragrant pine and spruce. Children sometimes build dams across it for swimming holes, trout pools and toy boat habors...

Market prices for real estate will continue to show a gradual rise unless some unusual economic change, such as inflation, occurs is the near future, according to Arthur J. Horton, vice president of the Bulkley Horton Company, Brooklyn and Queens brokers. Values, he adds...

A 13-year-old Armenian boy, Harry Ohnigian of 240 East Twentyfifth Street, received a silver trophy yesterday afternoon for being the healthiest boy on the East Side between Twenty-third and Fortysecond Streets.

IN the lengthening procession of books written to justify a "liberalizing" of the Supreme Court, "The Power to Gov- ern" is the most thoroughly documented and constructively rea soned, and thus the most persuasive and indeed convincing.

HARTFORD, May 1.--About 1,500 of the 2,000 machinists and helpers of the Pratt Whitney tool division of the Niles-Bement-Pond Company quit work this forenoon, met in a near-by assembly hall and adopted demands for higher wages and recognition of the C.I.O....

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 1.-Miss Mary Baldwin Bruyn, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles De Witt Bruyn of this place, was mar ried today to Dr. Charles Dewees Roberts of Milton, Mass., son of the Rev. and Mrs. W. Dewees Roberts of Bushkill Road, Milton.

SOMERVILLE, Mass., May, 1.-"Thar she blows:" is the slogan of James Henry Blake of West Som erville. Mr. Blake has studied whales all his life, in the peace and security of his own fireside, and is recognized throughout the country as an authority on the subject.

A REASONABLY modern tinge may be noted at the temporary galleries of the Municipal Art Committee, where the galleries on all four floors are occupied by oil paintings in tha twenty-second exhibition of the series by resident New York artists.

LYNDONVILLE, Vt., May 1.-Kentucky may have its coloneis, but Vermont has sent a very unusual ambasasdor to Kentucky. His name is Bobby Fechner, but he is not in any way related to the director of the Civilian Conservation Corps, al though that is where he got the name.

Manhattan College's campus is gaily bedecked for inspection by several thousand relatives and friends of students who will attend the fifth annual campus day cere monies today. A program has been arranged for the fete by Brendan J. O'Callaghan, head of the general committee.

The Anvil Chorus, a Brooklyn organization of politicians and news, paper men, held its annual stunt dinner last night at the WaldorfAstoria, Manhattan, with more than 1,000 persons prominent in public life in attendance. The guests included Postmaster General James...

Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons will act as manikins is a fashion show, "Calling All Models," to be presented in con junction with a luncheon Tuesday at the Weylin for the benefit of the Girls Service League.

Seats for 75,000 spectators have been provided at Louisville, Ky., today for the season's first speed boat regatta on Northern waters, but instead of being races against time and for world records they may resolve themselves into races against floods.

GOSPORT, England, May 1.--The radio signal, "all well, weather smooth, making good progress," brought news to T.O.M. Sopwith tonight that Endeavour and Endeavour II were well started on their quest of the America's Cup.

DESPITE widespread reports that various States have been penalized by the Federal Gov- ernment for diversion of their gasoline and other automotive tax revenue to non-highway purposes, no final action has been taken in any case. Even Maryland, branded the...

John Francis O'Neil, municipal court justice, who was stabbed in the back Tuesday by a mysterious assassin, died of his wounds at St. Vincent's Hospital at 6 A. M. yes terday. The police say they do not know who killed him or why.
TICONDEROGA, N.Y., May 1.-A friend of the Fort Ticonderoga Museum, at preseat anonymous, is restoring the southeast bastion of the fort. Work will be completed in July, it is expected.

Legislative action has just been adopted do Maine and West Vir ginia requiring State licensing of real estate brokers and salesmen. With these recent additions to the number requiring real estate licensing, there are now twenty-nine States in addition to the territory...

PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--For the second time in a week Ted Horton, spectacled Yale pitcher, humbled Pennsylvania by turning in a sevenhit performance for a 9-2 victory on Franklin Field today. This was the third straight triumph in the Eastern Intercollegiate League for the Elis.

The stock market was narrow and dull yesterday and closed irregular. The trading total on the Stock Exchange was 551,000 shares, the smallest in two weeks. The market was up slightly at the opening, but there was little disposition to continue the brisk rally of the day before.

The two weeks' campaign to raise $310,000 to build and maintain a cathedral house on the grounds of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation started tonight, with a total of $138,130 in pledges reported at the outset.

Dr. A. R. Mann, provost of Cornell University, has been elected vice president of the General Education Board, it was announced yesterday by Raymond B. Fosdleck, president. The board was founded in 1902 by John D. Rockefeller to administer funds for educational purposes.

Governor Richard C. McMullen has called a conference of all members of the State Legislature for Tuesday at Dover in an inquiry to determine whether they passed the $7,000,000 School Appropriations Bill at the regular session which ended April 21.

More than 4,000 persons thronged the Manhattan College campus yesterday for the fifth annual campus day ceremonies. Favored by perfect weather, the visitors were entertained by a program of contests, exhibitions, concerts and a picture of curricular and extracurricular activities at the college.

The winners of the Olin awards, which carry grants of $2,000 for the first year in college of students, picked from a group of twenty who visited the campus a week ago, have been announced by Wesleyan University. Two prospective students have also been selected for the Thorndike Scholarships, which provide $450 a year for the four years.

The Insurgent warship Espana sank Friday after having struck a mine placed at the entrance to the harbor of Santander by one of General Francisco Franco's own mine layers, according to an official bulletin published at Salamanca today by the Insurgent Admiralty staff.
Worshipers at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday were urged by the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg to initiate "a crusade to restore to womanhood the respect this age has lost for it."

About 1,500 persons, many of them members of American Federation of Labor building trades unions, attended a meeting of the "Building Trades Council of the C. I. O." yesterday at the Brownsville Labor Lyceum, 219 Sackman Street, Brooklyn.

Mrs. Gordon Wright's top-flight jumper Sonny captured the championship at the seventh annual Harrison horse show, conducted in the ring of the Kentucky Riding Academy today. The exhibition attracted a record entry of 362.

Creation of a people's front in this country as a weapon to "wipe fascism off the face of the earth" was urged last night by Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, at a mass meeting in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the Young Communist League, opening its eighth national convention here.

In view of the declaration of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, that the Reich is eager to cooperate for the restoration of international commerce, the following statement of the director of the Reich Bureau of Statistics is enlightening:

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, announced today that reports from Federal relief agencies throughout the nation showed that State and local governments spent nearly four times as much from their own funds for relief and work programs in 1936 as they did in 1933.

Prices of cotton moved irregularly lower last week and, at the close, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange reflected net losses of 31 to 37 points. "Prices started to decline early in April after an upward movement subject to brief interruptions, which had been under way since November, last year," the Cotton Exchange Service says.

Newark divided a double-header with Toronto today, winning the first game by 23 to 1 and bowing in the nightcap, 3-2, before 20,569 paid admissions, the largest gathering in Newark's baseball history.

Wall Street's weakness through the week, according to market opinion here, was very largely a reflection of London's violent downward readjustment. Resistance in the United States would, however, probably have been greater if the Washington administration's attitude toward the stock and commodity markets had been more moderate.
Villagers in native costume serenaded the Duke of Windsor topight in a colorful music fete. A huge swastika burned on the mountain aide, illuminating the pageant, which lasted more than an hour.
Political sources debated today whether a plebiscite by which Philippine women voted themselves suffrage rights also granted them the right to seek elective offices in the Commonwealth Government.

Miss Anna Frances Fogarty, 60 years old, a registered nurse and owner of several valuable pieces of property in New York and California, was found dead yesterday in a six-room apartment, almost devoid of furniture, at 536 West 133d Street. The apartment was in a building she purchased last year.

The seventeenth annual meeting of the Brooklyn Citizens Patriotic May Day Celebration Committee attracted nearly 13,000 persons to Prospect Park yesterday afternoon. James M. Golding, chairman, said last year's program had failed to draw one-tenth that number and the sponsors were frankly disturbed.

The Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 181st Street, declared that the day of preaching was not over.

Ferris Greenslet, editorial director of Houghton Mifflin, has just returned from England with contracts for two new books by Ramon Sender, Spanish author of "Pro Patria," a book about the revolt of Abd el-Krim that was published here in 1935.

Cardinal Hayes presided yesterday noon at high mass at the Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception at Stapleton, S. I. The service marked the fiftieth anniversary of the church. In the afternoon the Cardinal dedicated a new building of the Staten Island division of Manhattan College at New Brighton.

Danes of American descent will observe the silver jubilee of the reign of King Christian X of Denmark by raising a "Jubilee Fund" for the benefit of the Danish-American Archives and American Library at Sohngaardsholm, near Aalborg, Denmark, which has been in service since 1931.
The Supreme Court may rule tomorrow on the constitutionality of the unemployment insurance provisions of the Federal Social Security Act and on supplementary State legislation.

According to information made public here today, the names of nine candidates for County Clerk will be presented to the executive committee of the Westchester County Republican organization when it meets with Chairman Charles H. Griffiths Friday afternoon. Because of the large number seeking the office there may be a bitter primary fight.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,902,495,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

Detectives investigating the murder of Municipal Court Justice John Francs, O'Neil, who was fatally stabbed last Tuesday morning at Sixth Avenue and Twelfth Street, said yesterday that they had run up against a stone wall in their search for his assailant and had no clue whatsoever as to his identity.

Mrs. Frederic Clark Sayles of AIdwill, Irvington-on-Hudson has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Caroline Alden Sayles, to Ward Rathbun Clark of New York, son of Mrs. S. Allen Clark and of the late Mr. Clark of Oneida. N. Y.

The army-supported Cabinet of General Senjuro Hayashi, overwhelmingly defeated in Friday's general election, faced a choice today between resignation and an attempt to continue in power in disregard of the electorate's rebuke.
Mrs. Frances Velie Dominy, a resident of this village for the last thirty-eight years, died at her home on Montauk Highway last night, at the age of 73.

Gerald Walker, continuing his heavy hitting, smashed a home run in the seventh inning today to give the Tigers a 6-5 victory over the White Sox. Walker had a perfect day at bat, with two singles and the home run, his third this season, in three times at bat.

Miss Constance Klee, daughter of Mrs. C. Fred Klee of 115 Henry Street, Brooklyn, will be married to Clarence Richard Foulkes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Foulkes of Bangor, Pa., May 14 in the First Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn Heights.
A survey by American military authorities disclosed today that at least 55,000,000 trained men can "spring to arms overnight" in forty-eight nations.

Various developments have Improved steel-market conditions since announcement of third-quarter price policy, according to the magazine Steel. Buyers, it says, have accepted this as assurance that they can proceed with certainty and need not press the mills for position on rolling schedules.

The Third Avenue Railway Company yielded yesterday to the demend of the Transport Workers t Union for a referendum election at which the company's 4,500 employes could designate the labor organization they desired to act for them in collective bargaining with t the management.

Nevin (Bunny) McCormick, right halfback, took a lateral pass from Mario Tonelli, fullback, and ran twenty-eight yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter to give the 1937 Notre Dame varsity football team a 7-to-0 victory over a team of former Rambler stars before 15,000 spectators today.
Offering will be made today of 150,000 shares of common stock of the Di-Noc Manufacturing Company of Cleveland, Ohio, by an underwriting group composed of Falvey, Waddell Co., Inc.;

The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had settled two disputes involving union jurisdiction, one in the plant of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation at San Diego and the other among the licensed officers employed by the Merchants and Miners Transportation Company of Baltimore.
Publisher Benito Mussolini's newspaper Popolo d'Italia here profits by a system that would make American newspaper publishers green with envy.

Busle ness activity in the Netherlands further increased month by month in 1937 and over twelve months back. Dutch imports in March were 125,000,000 guilders, against 105,000,000 in February, and exports were 94.000,000 guilders and 79,000,000, respectively.

Trailing by two runs as they came into the ninth, the Senators staged a five-run drive to win, 10 to 7, and split a two-game series with the Athletics today. Twenty-two bases on balls were Issued by the six pitchers, three for each team, who participated in the game.

ADAMS--George Freaerick, in New York City, April 30, 1937. after a brief illness. BARBRETT-On Sunday, May 2, 1937. George N. Barrett of New York City, age 45 years, husband of Augusta H. (nee Peters), brother of Edward E. Barrett and son of the late Captain Richard J. and Grace A. Barrett (nee Bradford). Notice of funeral later.

Fifty-four gunners from three States fired away on the three-trap layout of the Valhalla Skeet Club today in the second half of the metropolitan open skeet shooting championships. When the final scores were posted the results simply added to the imposing record of the Roseland Community Gun Club, which made a grand slam of the three titles at stake.

The indications. are for fair weather today and for increasing cloudiness tomorrow. Little change in temperature is expected, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock Eastern standard time last night.

Eleven members of the crew of the freighter Alecto were drowned early-yesterday morning in a collision with the freighter Plavnik in the North Sea during a fog, according to a wireless message received by the Radio Marine Corporation from the steamship President Roosevelt of the United States Lines.

A warning that "Western ways" were gaining ground in Hejaz brought an angry outburst from King Ibn Saud at a dinner marking the recent departure of Crown Prince Emir Saud to represent his father at the coronation of King George VI in London, it became known today.

In spite of the apparent certainty that President Roosevelt's court reorganization bill would be reported unfavorably by the Senate Judiciary Committee as a result of the declaration of three previously uncommitted members in opposition to the bill, Postmaster General James A. Farley reaffirmed his belief yesterday that Congress would pass it in the form the President proposed.

At the annual Founders Day celebration at Highland Manor School this afternoon, a resolution was adopted by the audience of parents and friends of the students, urging all American universities to decline an invitation to participate in the 200th anniversary celebration at Goettingen University in Germany.

With the addition of seven more clubs to the entry list, a total of eighteen will be represented in the second annual golf tournament of the interclub council of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City at the Century Country Club, Purchase, N. Y., on June 13.

The Pulitzer committee is finally ready to lift the veil of secrecy with which it has guarded the identity of the 1936 prize winners in journalism and letters whom it selected last Friday. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will announce the winners tonight at the Hotel Biltmore, where the Columbia School of Journalism will hold its annual alumni dinner.

Arriving buyers may register in this column by teleshoning LAckawanna 4-1000. RETAIL BALTIMORE--Hochschild, Kohn Co.; N. Schenthal, shoes; M. Merz, cheaper apparel; E.B. Moreland, furs; 11 W. 42d (F. Atkins).

Melodist, surprise winner of the Wood Memorial, will be shipped tonight in a special car for the Kentucky Derby to be run Saturday at Churchill Downs, according to an announcement from his veteran trainer, Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons.

Lifted out of their doldrums by the three-hit pitching of Van Lingle Mungo and the four-hit slugging of Gibby Brack, Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers yesterday beat the Phillies, 5-1, and in the process wrote some new paragraphs in their 1937 history.

Harold Dicterow, 17-year-old vio. linist, of Elmhurst, L. I., displayed a decided gift for his chosen instrument at his recital in Town Hall last night. There were fire, poetry and imagination in his performances and a sensitive feeling for color and nuance.
The Insurgent chief, General Francisco Franco, today signed a decree exempting jobless persons and militiamen from paying rent when it is less than $8.25 a month.

Plymouth Rock, traditional stepping stone of the Pilgrims when they' came I'ashore in 1620, was blotched with several coats of brilliant red paint today. The vandalism was discovered by Augustus Wurtzburger, caretaker of the shrine, at 6:30 A. M. Police and Selectmen believed the painting was either May Day work of Communist demonstrators or a prank of boys.

Secretary Perkins- announced today that estimates had been prepared by the Labor Department showing an increase of 8,241,000 in employment outside of agriculture since the low WIN point of the depression in March, 1933. According to these estimates, 34,138,000 persons were employed in non-agricultural industries in The March as compared to 35,377,000 in March, 1929, and 25,897,000 in March, 1933.

Uncertainty as to the outcome of the grain crops, particularly in the United States and Canada and in certain of the European countries, combined with the sharp decline in gold and security prices, placed the world grain trade at principal centers in a most uneasy position where sudden changes in quotations are to be looked for at any time.
William J. Pedrick Co, Inc, insurance and real estate, and general agent in the metropolitan area of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, in International Building, Rockfeller Center.

Public offering of a new issue of $1.553,000 of city of Albany, N.Y., 2 1/2 per cent bonds will be made today by A. C. Allyn Co., Inc.; Granbery, Safford Co., Charles D. Barney Co., Rutter Co. and Sherwood Co.

From various channels: Princeton is a beautiful place, especially in the Spring...Lake Carnegie is picturesque, more so when college crews row over its surface....But the patient angler is ever present even in a college town.

The Pirates took first place in the National League today, defeating the luckless Reds, 7 to 2, as the Cubs tripped the Cardinals. It was the Corsairs' second straight triumph over the cellardwellers, who suffered their eighth defeat, against a lone victory, for the season.

The Culture Society Workers Chorus, directed by Vladimir Heifetz, presented its seventh annual concert at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The assisting artists were Arnold Eidus, boy violinist, and Roselle Starkman, contralto. Sonia Eidus was at the piano.
Forty years ago Mr. and Mrs. Emil Steding of Glendale, Queens, invited their neighbors to join them in the formation of a new church. Yesterday they were guests of
Jersey City and Buffalo divided a double-header today before a crowd of 25,000. The Little Giants came back to take the second game, 6 to 3, after Buffalo had earned an 8 to 7 decision in the first.

How a Cossack rising against the Polish Government was organized with the aid of Germans in the Province of Wolhynia on the Polish-Russian border was told in the course of the trial here of forty-four members of the Unakor, the Ukrainian National Cossack movement.

John M. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, announced yesterday that Kenneth D. Dawson, prominent West Coast shipping man, had been designated as vice president of the company with complete charge of the concern's activities on the Pacific Coast.

MONTHS ago Ellsworth Vines and Fred Perry set out from here and voyaged all around the country, playing tennis en route. They faced each other across the net in the hinterland, on the Coast, in the North, in the South. They played fifty-five matches. That should have been a sufficient test to determine who's who in professional tennis.

A change in the nation's overnight telegraph service, involving reductions in the rates for both long and short messages, is provided in a tariff approved by the Federal. Communications Commission, it was announced yesterday by the four major telegraph Companies.

Miss Lynette Fowler, daughter of Mrs. John McCall of 42 West Twelfth Street, has completed plans for her marriage to Quentin Raymond Burke, son of Mrs. Walter A. Burke of 1,111 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Burke, which will take place on May 21 at the Carlyle. The ceremony will be performed by Mgr. Charles E. Wood of Middletown, N. Y., a friend of Mr. Burke's family for many years.

The whole of creation is an aspiration toward God but man must give it a voice, the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. McComas, vicar of St. Paul's Episcopal Chapel, Trinity Parish, Broadway and Fulton Street, said in his sermon yesterday.
Legislative leaders returned to the Capitol tonight with the hope that, this time, their predictions of final adjournment before the end of the week would not be another will-o'-thewisp.
Hearn's became yesterday the first major department store organization to sign a contract with the Department Store Employes Union,

The Foreign Policy Association reported today that discontent was growing among the German working classes. "That the Nazi regime has to some extent lost its hold on the masses," said John C. Dewilde of the association's research staff, "is indicated by the frequency of government appeals and exhortations.

Billionaire alone will carry the hopes and the green and white colors of E. R. Bradley in the Kentucky Derby, to be run next Saturday. That Brooklyn, who two weeks ago was better liked than Billionaire,
Federal intervention was sought tonight on behalf of two leaders in the dressmakers' strike here who are threatened with arrest by the Quebec government for alleged conspiracy against public order.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board has handled nearly as many cases in the three weeks since the Wagner act was upheld as it did in the eighteen months between the passage of the act and the Supreme Court decision, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, the board's regional direetor, reported yesterday.

More than 300 World War veterans joined today in the observance of the silver jubilee fete in celebration of the ordination of the Rev. James J. G. Halligan, wartime infantry chaplain, at Holy Name Roman Catholic Church, on Petersville goad.

The theft of fourteen paintings from the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and their recovery at Harrisburg were made known today while a dismissed watchman was awaiting a hearing on a charge of malicious mischief for mutilating other paintings and statuary.

This channel city of California has turned to New York City for expert aid in wiping out its slum areas. Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, director of Greenwich House, model settlement in New York, is here for a conference with Mayor Patrick Maher and Dr. Roome, City Health Commissioner.
Murray Presslaff, formerly with Presslaff Bernstein, has organized Murray Presslaff, Inc., manufacturers of beach and sportswear, with offices at 1,350 Broadway.

Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, sets forth a twelve-point program of activity in conservation work in the State in his annual report, to be submitted to Governor Lehman and the Legislature tomorrow.

Edward Wilmann, who was construction engineer of the government explosives plant at Nitro, W. Va., in the World WaY, died Frlday in Mount Vernon, N. Y., after a four months' illness, at the age of 73.

A scattered trade in lard futures was done last week here, with fair buying support on the breaks, while bulges, due to short covering, met moderately increased offerings. May lard closed at $11.55 a hundredweight, a net decline of 7 1/2 cents for the week,
Seventy airplanes and the Goodyear blimp Resolute, bearing a cargo of 46,523 membership cards, participated in the fifth annual national aerial membership round-up of the American Legion here today.

Miss Laura Knox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Whitney Knox of this city, was married to Rial Strickland Peck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert P. Peck, yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents. The Rev. Warren S. Archibald, pastor of the South Congregational Church, performed the ceremony. Mr. Peck and his bride were unattended.

The Chase National Bank has received funds for the payment of the coupons due on Saturday at 32.5 per cent of their face value, or $9.75 for each $30 coupon, on City of Sao Paulo (Brazil) 6 per cent external secured sinking fund bonds due in 1943.

Defeating the New York Americans yesterday at Celtic Park before a record crowd, St. Mary's Celtics took first place in the national division of the American Soccer League, and won the right to meet the Brooklyn Hispanos, leaders of the American division,
The number of employed persons in all industries in Germany increased 3 per cent in March, the chief increase being in the capital-goods branches.

General Emilio Mola's Insurgent troops were reported in diplomatic dispatches from Bilbao tonight to have smashed through the last line of Basque defenses on the Bay of Biscay coast and to have reached the gates of Las Arenas, between Bilbao and the sea.
Governor Lehman today proclaimed May 14 as a day for celebration of the 150th anniversary of the opening of the Constitutional Convention. In his proclamation he wrote:
The German index of wholesale prices on April 21 was 105.6 against 105.9 on April 14.
Albert Sequin, a farmer living on the Marcy Road, waters his cows and gets gas for cooking from the same well.

Letters from college presidents who had been asked about the recent student peace demonstration were read by Gerald L. K. Smith yesterday at a meeting of more than 700 supporters of his "Committee of 1,000,000" at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Alexander Jamieson, three of whose landscape paintings in a style reminiscent of Constable are included in the coronation exhibition at the Royal Academy, died today at the age of 63. Sir John Lavery praised him tonight as "perhaps the greatest landscape painter of our time."

March sales volume in the British retail trade increased 15.2 per cent over the corresponding month of 1936. This is the largest increase, and month, since statistics first were compiled in 1933. It compares with an increase of 7.1 per cent in February, 2.4 in January, and 7.9 in March 1936.

Beginning a two weeks' celebration of the hundredth anniversary of Grace Episcopal Church, Bishop Benjamin M. Washburn of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark dedicated two memorial windows at the 11 o'clock service today. Bishop Washburn preached at the service preceding the dedication.

Mrs. Agnes Nutting Ladd entertained many of her friends from this place, Westchester County, N. Y., and New York City at her home in Belle Haven, Greenwich, this afternoon, having invited them to view the flower garden on the estate, now at the height of bloom.
Saturday, May 29, will see Richard II" ending or at least breaking its run at the St. James Theatre, the management reports.
Despite the month-end demand for cash, which today raised the rate on day-to-day loans from 2 3/4 to 3 per cent, the money market here remains extraordinarily fluid.
A try in the last minute of the game by Bill Halton gave the New York Rugby Club an 8-6 victory over Harvard in one of the most interesting games of the current season at Randalls Island yesterday.

The Rev. Gustave Laass, retired biographical secretary of the New York Eastern Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, died Saturday night in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, of a h heart ailment at the age of 83.

The Millinery Quality Guild, Inc., 711 Fifth Avenue, New York, and twentyfour member and affiliate companies were ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to "cease and desist" from practices alleged to create a monopoly in the designing of hat styles.

Officials of the 1939 World's Fair announced yesterday that Finland was the first nation to send a fair representative to New York. He is Jaakko Kahma, managing director of the Finnish Export Association and a member of Finland's State Exhibition Committee.

With only one of the crews of the country yet to go into action; college rowing for 1937 began to take definite shape with the close of the events of the past Saturday. Cornell has yet to swing a sweep in intercollegiate competition, but all of the other varsities have been in at least one race;
The "Portrait. of Heer Pieter Tjarck" by Frans Hals has been bought by Harry Oakes of Nassau, the Bahamas, from M. Knoedler Co., Inc., 14 East Fifty-seventh Street.

A jury of eight New Jersey housewives and mothers, and four men, is expected to begin tomorrow the hearing of evidence in the government's conspiracy case against Ellis H. Parker Sr. and the other defendants in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case.

As a result of modifications made by the Board of Estimate's chief engineer, Vernon S. Moon, in the plans of Park Commissioner Moses for a "Riverside Park" development of part of Shore Drive in Brooklyn, the cost of the project will be reduced from an original estimate of $3,000,000 to about $2,500,000, it was learned yesterday.

Communist activities in the school were denounced yesterday by State Senator John J. McNaboe, who spoke at the annual communion breakfast of McGivney Council, Knights of Columbus, at the Hotel Astor. The need for militant "Catholic action to combat the menace of communism" also was stressed by other speakers.

The soy-bean trade was erratic last week with periods of dullness and price recessions, although there were several rallies. The close on May beans was $1.73 1/3, a net decline of 1 7/8 cents compared with the previous week.

A special committee on old age security completed a fifteen-month study for the Twentieth Century Fund yesterday, and recommended the financing of benefits under the Social Security Act largely out of the general revenues of the United States on the pay as you go principle, without setting up a large reserve.

The Hudson Motor Car Company and the United Automobile Workers of America signed a supplemental agreement last night to their strike settlement of April 8, which ended a month's tie-up. The agreement provides for minimum hourly rates of 75 cents for men and 65 cents for women;

Warning that this nation ranks first "in the grosser crimes which man commits" because of a prevalent disrespect for law, Dr. Roelif H. Brooks, chaplain of the old Seventh Regiment, told members of the regiment yesterday afternoon their duty is to "fear God and keep His commandments" and lead a temperate life.
Mayor Ernest E. Estes of Auburn told striking Lewiston-Auburn shoe workers today that city officials had requested National Guard intervention "over my name, but without my knowledge."

With the circus departed from New York, Johnny Broaca decided to entertain baseball's largest crowd of the season yesterday with a juggling act of his own. But a gathering of 52,150 at the Yankee Stadium found no entertainment value in it.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Which Way America," .Dr. William Starr Myers. Meeting of te Government Club, Hotel Astor,: 2:30 P. M. "A WellPlanned City," Conrad Connor.
The substantial decline in the Bank Of England's circulation, which followed the end of the Easter holiday, has ceased and the trend again is upward.

More than 800 spectators witnessed the eleventh annual May Day festival this afternoon at Marymount College. An elaborate program was given on the campus which is a natural amphitheatre surrounded by flower gardens and budding trees.

A number of human activities are upset by rains of particles and light of various kinds from the .-sun, scientists said today. These rains, or radiations as the scientists prefer to call them, may cause weather changes, violent upsets in telephone, telegraph and radio communication, great inaccuracies in the compasses of ships and airplanes, inaccuraces in delicate electrical measurements, and shortages of food on which the human population of the earth depends.
Martha Graham and her group were greeted by an audience of good size and high enthusiasm in their final recital of the season at the Guild Theatre last night.

John P. Northcott of Leonia, N. J., has been appointed general chairman of a seventy-two-man committee which will make arrangements for the Columbia College senior promenade on May 31 in John Jay Hall.

A group of young parachute jumpers won a day-long argument with law-enforcement agencies late today. Sheriff's forces were withdrawn from the Mount Healthy Airport and students were permitted to make jumps one at a time.
Royal Kid Regards, a fifteenmonths-old dog, making the third appearance of his show career, went to the top in one of America's leading specialty dog shows today.

Sweeping condemnation of the "rule or ruin" policy of the American Federation of Labor's executive council in handling the problem of the Committee for Industrial Organization was disclosed today in the report of the general executive board of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union.
This is the desperate tale of the murder of Riley by crucifixion, hanging, beating, torture and the calling of bad names.

The United States is threatening to take from Great Britain the lead in exports to Argentina, the Pan-American Union announced today. This change is being brought about by booming trade conditions in the South American republic, stimulated by heavy exports of raw materials which in turn are being followed by a sharp jump in imports.

Officers for 1937-38 were elected yesterday at the May meeting of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at the Hotel Astor, the last meeting until Fall. Roderick C. Grant of Yonkers was re-elected president;

The New York Stock Exchange firm of F. S. Smithers Co. will celebrate today its eightieth anniversary. Started in the panic in 1857 as Henry Broeklman Co., the house originally dealt in foreign exchange, but also handled such securities as existed at the time.

James Purcell of Boonton, a printer expert with the National Aniline and Chemical Company, New York, and a former textile mill superintendent, died today of a heart attack in the Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 42 years old.

The United States Davis Cup team swept its first-round international zone competition with Japan by winning today's two concluding singles matches for a 5-to-0 victory in the three-day series. Donald Budge, first ranking American, smashed out a 6-2, 6-2, 6-4 victory over Japan's champion,

The report of the Bank of France for April 23 showed an increase of 757,000,000 francs in bills discounted. It showed also a rise of 65,000,000 francs in thirty-day loans against government bonds, but loans against securities fell 46,000,000 francs.

The new Danish freighter Marchen Maersk will arrive here today under temporary charter to the Hamburg-American Line. Built in the Bremer-Vulcan yards at Vegesack, Germany, for the Isbrandtsen-Moller Company, the Maersk follows her sister ship, the Grete Maersk, to this port by about five weeks.

William Bertrand Goldsbro, advertising manager of The Evening Telegram for three years, died last night at his home at the age of 52. In his younger days he was a marathon runner and com peted in the Olympics in London in 1908. Before joining The Telegram twenty-five years ago, he was advertising manager of the former R. S. Williams Company.

Mayor La Guardia received the medal of The American Hebrew for promotion of understanding between Jew and Christian last night in a ceremony at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel- in which he was praised for his political and econemric beliefs as well. as his tolerance.

Chalmers Wood, executive chairman of the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, announced yesterday that thirty-two cleaning women of the 195 Broadway Corporation have contributed 25 cents each toward the drive.
The association of citizens outside the structure of government for solving their mutual problems was praised last night by former President Herbert C. Hoover in an address at the Hotel Astor.

Sunshine lured thousands of persons yesterday to the beaches and parks, and roads leading to the recreation centers were crowded. Coney Island, as usual, drew the largest crowd-400,000 persons, according to Captain John Martin of the Coney Island police.

The motion picture industry strike received a temporary setback tonight when the strong Screen Actors Guild voted to defer action on a walkout until its board could confer with the film producers on Wednesday night.

The "great American disease is nervousness," declared the Rev. Dr. J. Stanley Durkee yesterday morning at Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, in a sermon commemorating the ninetieth anniversary of the founding of the church made famous by Henry Ward Beecher.

James F. Butterworth, superintendent of schools here for twentytwo years, died today. His age was 69. Illness compelled him to resign last year. Mr. Butterworth, a graduate of Harvard, was headmaster at Milton Academy from 1890 to 1892 and principal of the Saugus, Mass., high school from 1910 to 1914.

Charles Francis Boynton, a mem-ber of the executive staff of the New York office of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, 155 East Forty-fourth Street, died Saturday night in his apartment in the Hotel Lucerne, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, after a short illness.

One of the weaknesses of civilization is the failure to use increased leisure to think things through, to decide on a goal, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, Rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at Ninetieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.
Rochester cracked its losing streak by taking both ends of today's doubleheader from the Orioles. The Red Wings won the first,. 12 to 10, in twelve innings and the second, 8 to 2.

Joseph K. Savage, New York lawyer, was elected president of the United States Figure Skating Association yesterday at the Hotel Madison to succeed Charles M. Rotoh of Boston, who has held the post for two years.
Lorain Street Railroad Company employes announced today that they had voted to strike early Tuesday unless their demands for a wage scale of 70 cents per hour are met.
Immigration Bureau officials said today that their problem now was alien policing rather than immigration control.
Two operas by Verdi, "La Forza lel Destino" and "Rigoletto," were performed by the New York HippoIrome Opera Company at the Hippodrome yesterday, the former At night and the latter in the afternoon.

The Rev. Abraham J. Muste, a founder and former director of Brookwod Labor College, Katonah, N. Y., has been chosen director of the Presbyterian Labor Temple, Second Avenue and Fouteeenth Street, according to an announcement made last night. He succeeds the Rev. Dr. Edmund B. CHaffee, who died last fall.

To comprehend what the Irish Channel divides, it is necessary only to read the full text of the draft Constitution of Eamon de Valera while reflect the recent constitutional crisis in England. In London, at a time when the monarchy is of paramount importance, the most popular and well-trumpeted of kings fell with hardly a struggle before a constitutional idea, never written or defined, which firmly supports the most solid governmental structure in the world.

PROGRAM FOR TONIGHT 8:20-George M. Lott vs. Y. Satoh 9-Fred Perry vs. Ellsworth Vinea 10:30-Perry and Vines vs. Lots and Bruce Barnes. Professional tennis comes back to Madison Square Garden tonight with the return meeting there between Fred Perry of Great Britain and Ellsworth Vines of California.

Before the eyes of 30,000 persons massed in Times Square yesterday, while surpliced altar boys held aloft a crucifix and candles, there was unveiled the statue of a Roman Catholic priest in the uniform of a soldier of the A. E. F.

The Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway continued in 1936 the wholesale junking of equipment which it has been compelled to carry on since 1922, the year in which it last was reorganized, according to the report of the company for 1936.

Mayor La Guardia pledged his administration yesterday afternoon to a "bitter fight to the finish" against the fourteen burlesque theatres throughout the city whose applications for license renewals were denied Saturday by License Commissioner Paul Moss.

Richard B. Goetze' bought from the Eastern Baptist Theological Seminary of Philadelphia the house containing nine rooms and occupying a plot 100 by 130 feet at 7 Interlaken Drive, Eastchester, N. Y. Prince Ripley, Inc., negotiated the sale.
Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany arrives in Rome at 11:30 o'clock tomorrow morning for a three-day stay that is attracting a great deal of attention both in Italy and abroad.
The French weekly wholesale price average as of April 24 was 537, compared with 529 on April 17 and 400 on Sept. 12, 1936, just before the franc was devalued.
From recent declarations of the Finance Minister, Vincent Auriol, it appears that the French Treasury has borrowing powers sufficient to cover all its requirements for the current year.

William St, 194, 17.4 1/2x76.7: Charles F. Noyes to Cabin Holding Corp., 565 5th Ave ($15). Leonard St. 17, 25x91; same to same ($10). Lot in rear of 51 Franklin St, about 23.5x 20, with a three-foot alley approach to the s s of Franklin St, 297 ft e of Broadway. 1/2 interest:
Insurgent artillery sent shells screaming among promenaders in Madrid today on Spain's national holiday. A score were killed or wounded as they strolled in the warm sunshine.

Eleven Federal agencies awarded 105 contracts amounting to about $5,398,674 in the week ended on April 29 under the restrictive provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced.

A plea for world peace was made this afternoon at the annual May pilgrimage to Rosary Shrine, by the Rev. Edward L. Hughes, editor of The Torch and national director of the Third Order of St. Dominic. He spoke to 6,000 or more Catholics on the grounds of Rosary Shrine.

A MONG sociology's test tubes are 140 selected American villages. Sociologists have been studying these chosen Main Streets off and on for fourteen years. They watch the record of bank deposits, chain store sales, church attendance, the birth rates and the death rates, the incidence of wedding breakfasts and the styles in sport.
Larry Cece of the Irish-American A. C. captured first place in the annual four-and-a-half-mile handicap road run conducted in Washington Heights yesterday by the Manhattan Athletic League.

False spirituality, in which a distinction is set up between the material and the spiritual, is responsible for that sort of religion which is greatly concerned about life in the after world, but which steadily refuses to face the problems in this world, the Very Rev. A. T. B. Haines,

In concluding his recent report on the work of the Bartol Research Foundation--as clear a summary of the present state of atomic physics as one could wish--Dr. W. F. G. SWANN remarks that "nature seems to have "decided to open a new chapter in "her story of the universe; and that "chapter is the most exciting one "that the man of science has so far "read."

The recent reaction in prices of commodities and securities has been wholesome, in the opinion of the National City Bank. If it has dissipated the boom psychology, the situation is sounder all around, the bank says in the current issue of its monthly letter, published yesterday.
Possibly the break in stocks, during the first half of last week, threw Wall Street for the time more completely off its balance than any reaction since the midyear break of 1933.
Under the influence of weakness in the London and Wall Street Stock Exchanges, the German markets were uncertain but in no wise depressed this week.

Chicago's jinx-ridden Cubs won and lost again today, conquering the Cardinals, 4 to 1, behind Bill Lee's sparkling three-hit hurling, but losing the services for probably a week of their star second baseman, Billy Herman.

Preaching a sermon on "Running Away From Home," the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, warned boys and girls yesterday that "you can't run away from yourself."
Normal life in several world-famous hotels was in a halt today as nearly 6,000 guests watched employes circling the buildings in strike picket lines.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wheeler Francis will return today on the Queen Mary, and will be at 101 East Seventy-first Street. Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne have come back from Claremont, Columbia, S. C., and are at the Ambassador. They will depart in June for Europe.

The Jamaica Ministers Association expressed yesterday a belief that responsibility for continuation of the strike of the editorial workers on The Long Island Daily Press lay "primarily upon the shoulders and conscience of the management of The Press," and not upon the New York Newspaper Guild, which called the strike.

Passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include Lieut. Col. Sir Walrond Sinclair, Baroness Jeanne Empain, Colonel H. H. Aykroyd, Commander J. Harding, Archibald Lindesay, F. C. Topham, Miss Mary Pickford, Miss Gwynne Pickford. Miss Vera Engels, Mrs.

Favored with ideal weather and the attention of 10,000 persons standing in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, dancers wearing the picturesque costumes of seven nations took part in a program of peasant dances sponsored by the Folk Festival Council.

The Rialto sets its face toward the open spaces this morning with "'Way Out West," a Laurel and Hardy matter which its sponsors are calling a "horse-laugh opera." In the cast are Stan Laurel, Oliver Hardy, Sharon Lynne, Rosina Lawrence, Vivian Oakland, James Finlayson and Stanley Fields....The Filmarte Theatre is continuing "The Wave" for a third week.

In the deadening monotony of modern industrialism, American culture must provide escape, Rabbi Louis I. Newman said yesterday in his sermon at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street. "We are all harnessed to certain unpleasant tasks," he said, "but we must look beyond them to the social good they help perform.

Demand for dresses increased somewhat in the wholesale market here last week, with formals in sheer fabrics leading in activity. Dark sheer daytime dresses and printed cotton formals and sports types sold well in the better-price groups.

Howland D. Perrine, who was with the legal department of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, New York, for many years until his retirement in 1923, died here yesterday in a nursing home at 111 Gates Avenue, after a long illness.

Miss Amalie Baruch, daughter of Hartwig N. Baruch of New York, was married to Polan Banks, New York novelist and playwright, this morning in the National Hotel here. Juan Luis Gelabert, a notary, performed the brief civil ceremony, at which the witnesses were Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff; Colonel Julio Velasco and Captain Belisario Hernandez, staff officers, and Dr. Raul Garcia Cantero, Assistant Secretary of Justice, who represented President Federico Laredo Bru.

The Bowery Savings Bank sold to Dorothy Gruenhut the parcel on the west side of Columbus Ave., 51.2 feet north of 74th St., 25 1/2x100, taking back a mortgage for $25.000, due in five years at 3 per cent.

After the joyous send-off yesterday of the two Endeavours, with one of which T. O. M. Sopwith hopes to win the America's Cup, the first Endeavour was held here today while the motor yacht Viva II, which was to tow us across the Atlantic, returned to Southampton for repairs to her steering machinery.

Although most of the college baseball games in the metropolitan district were rained out during the past week, those which were played threw the race for titular honors among the local teams into a wideopen one.

" The supreme event in any me is to know Christ. for to know Christ is joy," the Rev. Carlos G. Fuller, pastor of the Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, University Avenue and 174th Street, the Bronx, said yesterday in his sermon.

Ten sailing dinghies, five each in Class B One-Design and Class D, took part in the so-called "ocean" race today, which was an aftermath of the long Winter season. The winners were Ted Clark, with his B boat Eskimo, and Bob Fraser, Jr., with his D craft Shiver II.

Vatican prelates saw the likelihood of a Vatican-German agreement over religious differences diminished by Chancellor Adolf Hitler's May Day remarks on religion. The Pope, they declared, would take the declarations as an unfriendly gesture.

An original crayon portrait of Goethe, regarded by scholars as one of the best likenesses of the great German poet in his later years, has been presented to Princeton University by the estate of the late George A. Armour, '77, of Princeton. it was announced today by President Harold W. Dodds.
The United States section of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom urged President Roosevelt today to call for mediation of the Spanish Civil War.

Merton E. Lewis, former Mayor of Rochester and former State Attorney General, died at his home here today. He was 75 years old. Mr. Lewis, who spent an active life until three years ago as a lawyer, legislator and Republican officeholder, resigned from active practice three years ago because of failing health.

Housing officials representing twenty of the largest cities in the country expressed today, in a statement issued by the American Federation of Housing Authorities, their resentment at "misleading statements" attributed to Treasury Department officials and others concerning the cost of the WagnerSteagall Housing Bill.

Not one, but two, economy plans have been submitted to Congress, and both are apparently receiving more serious consideration than has been given to any proposal in this field since the spectacular but ill-fated "economy drive" of early 1933 was undertaken. One plan, coming from the Senate side, has been proposed by Mr. BYRNES of South Carolina.

Mrs. Josephine Burnett Kidder of 120 Beacon Street and Southboro, wife of Charles A. Kidder, retired member of the firm of Kidder, Peabody Co., died today at the Copley-Plaza Hotel. Her age was 80. She had returned to Boston a few days ago after spending the Winter in Arizona.

Songs, dances and customs marking the advent of Spring in many lands will be features of the annual Spring Festival under the auspices of the International Institute of the Young Women's Christian Association to be held Thursday and Friday nights at the headquarters of the institute, 341 East Seventeenth Street.
Chester A. Patterson, who retired from the police force in January of this year after twenty-seven years service, died at his home, 104-15 200th Street, Hollis, Sunday morning.

The security markets of London have experienced their worst slump of years in the last fortnight, and next week's settlement of the account is faced with great uneasiness. The markets, indeed, will regard themselves as lucky if no failures occur.
Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., defeated J. Gilbert Hall, NorthSouth champion, today, 6-4, 2-6, 8-6, 6-3, to win the men's singles title in the Hot Springs tennis tournament.
More than a score of exhibitions are on the calendar for the week as May begins, with water-colors bulking large on the list and both wellknown artists and newcomers in evidence.

The possibility that the military-supported regime of President Federico Laredo Bru might lose control of Congress was foreseen today as former President Mario G. Menocal abandoned the Democratic party, which he founded in 1935, to organize a new party to oppose military interference in civil affairs.

Four clergymen, two of whom are from the New Jersey Synod, are being put forward by their friends for the office of Moderator of the 149th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church which will be held in Columbus, Ohio, the week beginning May 27.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Henry J. Walton of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Alford Walton, to Richard Manning of Glenburnie-onLake George, N. Y., and East Orange, N. J.

Arthur Brisbane in his lifetime established living trusts to which he transferred the bulk of his estate for the benefit of his family, it was disclosed by his will, filed for probate with Surrogate John L. Donahay, who received it in the mail here on Saturday. The will,
