George Bramwell Baker, retired financier and a former partner in the firm of Baker, Young Co., Boston and Philadelphia investment securities dealers, died today at his home, 76 Crafts Road, Chestnut Hill, after a short illness. His age was 70.

The Spring season of the Metropolitan Opera Association opens to night with a performance of Gounod's "Faust." Hilda Burke will be the Marguerite, Sydney Rayner will appear in the title role and Leon Rothier will sing Mephistopheles.

The coming coronation of Great Britain's rulers has crept into fashions for furniture in this country for next year. "Windsor" and "Kent" are the names of new dining-room suites exhibited at the May Furniture Market, which will be opened this week.

In anticipation of the American amateur championship event which will begin on Friday and last over the week-end, the gunners of the New York Athletic Club held a practice contest at the Travers Island traps yesterday.

At a tea given at the Cherry Valley Club here this afternoon, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Munson announced the engagement of Mr. Munson's daughter, Miss Anne Munson, to Charles Richards Leake 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Leake 2d.

James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, returned yesterday afternoon after an eight-week stay in Miami and will confer with members of the Tammany executive committee on the leadership situation during the week. He again indicated that he had no intention of resigning.

Major Gen. John Dallas Edge, who as a British army doctor performed gallant service in many Victorian wars, died yesterday at Dublin at the age of 89. Entering the army in 1871, General .Dallas was promoted to staff surgeon the next year for gallant conduct against the Indians at Orange Walk, British Honduras.

Endorsing the Doyle bill to operate a State Labor Relations Board, on the model of the National Board created by the Wagner act, Governor LEHMAN has proposed that there be created in addition a State Board of Mediation.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 93 per cent of capacity, up 1 point from the rate of the preceding week and 2 points from that of three weeks before.

New Jersey defeated New York, 8 to 3, in an interstate Gaelic football game at Innisfail Park yesterday before 2,000. It was a lively contest all the way as the players were the picked stars from whom the New York team will be chosen to face Mayo, Ireland's champions, at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday, May 16, in the first game of the Mayo team's tour.

Republican "schools for women" will be held next week throughout the State, it was announced yesterday. The schools will be sponsored by the New York State Republican Women, Inc., of which Mrs. Harold Remington of Watertown is chairman of programs and study service.

Perfect weather held to the end of the Sport and Conservation League's seventh annual Spring field trials today and a gallery exceeding 1,000 persons saw Junedale Jack, pointer owned by Dr. R. R. Bloom of Ossining, N. Y.,

The airship Hindenburg is scheduled to leave Frankfort on the Main late tomorrow night for the first of its eighteen scheduled round trips to Lakehurst, N. J., this Summer with passengers, mail and express. She is due at Lakehurst early Friday morning.

The Germans are certainly a most ingenious people. They are now secretly engaged in putting over a secret World's Fair--something which nobody on earth has ever succeeded in doing before. This exposition, which secret information printed on the first page of THE TIMES informs us will be at Duesseldorf, is expected to rival the Paris Exposition, which the French have signally failed to keep secret, due to labor troubles and politics and things like that.

The cornerstone for the Roosevelt Jewish Center was unveiled today with ceremonies attended by more than 300 members and guests. The building was started two years ago and completed at a cost of $6,000.

Stocks recovered after declining to the lowest levels since last July; turnover, 9,988,360 shares. United States Government bonds higher on the week; corporate and foreign obligations improved; transactions, $61,311,900.

With Earl Cook pitching three-hit ball in the second game, the Chiefs swept both ends of a double-header with Montreal today, 6 to 4 and 4 to 1. More than 10,000 fans watched the home club snap a four-game winning streak of the Royals and run their own string of consecutive victories to five.

ALFRED HOUSMAN died a year ago last Saturday. One of his characteristic poems is called "The First of May." Many of us must have remembered and revisited his Shropshire, Mr. ROCKWELL did in his poem in yesterday's TIMES. It is curious that the poems of a man whose temperament was essentially aristocratic and haughty should have become popular.

RURAL TRENDS IN DEPRESSION YEARS: A SURVEY F VILLAGE CENTERED AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES, 1930-1936, by Edmund de S. Brunner and Irving Lorge (Columbia University Press $3.25.) An authoritative study of rural America.

Organization of an executive committee which will form the nucleus of a University of Pennsylvania Bicentennial Committee of New York was announced today by C. Alison Scully, vice president of the Bank of Manhattan Company, who will serve as chairman of both committees.

Winthrop Parker, a retired lawyer who practiced here from 1881 to 1922, died yesterday at his home, 309 West Eighty-ninth Street, after an illness of six weeks. June 10 would have been his eightieth birthday.

Plans are under way for an extensive promotional campaign by outdoor advertising interests to cover a period of several years, according to reports. A yearly promotional fund, said to total several hundred thousand dollars, will be expended over the next few years.

The church has lost its sense of divine authority and its most difficult task is to recover its position, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday in his sermon at Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. "The man on the street," he said, "accepts the statements of an Einstein, an Eddington or a Millikan in science,

Fifty years ago Professor William Adams Brown of Union Theological Seminary preached his first sermon as guest of the seminary. Yesterday morning in the same institution he reviewed that sermon, and through the social, political and personal changes of the interevening. time found the message. still true that Christ is the one unchanging foundation in a changing world.
Major Gen. Sir Patrick Hehir, who had a distinguished career in the Indian medical service before and during the World War, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 77.

A dummy attack arranged to test motorized ground defense and aerial units gave National Guardsmen a stiff workout today as defending "blues" captured an imaginary "enemy" column holding the municipal airport.

Dean Milo H. Gates of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine warned yesterday afternoon against the acceptance of the type of pacifist propaganda that would prevent the taking up of arms in the defense of the country against enemy attacks.

(Figures in Parentheses indicate Par) Bayside (71)--Kickers' handicap (drawn number, 76): Won by Dr. Ralph Pepino, 90-14--76; Charles Gardner, 89-12-77, second. Brookville (72)-36-hole medal play handicap, Class A: Earl W. Doebler, 143 net; George R. Duryea, 144; Dr. K. Barney, 144. Class B: Dr. Garret Duryea, 138 net; H. H. Coop, 140.

The New York State. Liquor Au. thority started its radio programs on liquor control and temperance yesterday with the broadcast of an electrical transcription of a fiveminute speech by Governor Lehman in which he urged continued publi- support of State liquor laws.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 85.7 on April 28, which compared with 86.8 a fortnight before, 87.2 a month previous and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

President Roosevelt spent today quietly at sea, his only reported activity being a call from Governor Allred, who was a visitor on board the Potomac, the President's yacht. It was the third full day at sea of his fishing cruise.

William- Waldron Hanold, an employe of the Johns-Manville Corporation for the last sixty-four years, died early yesterday in the Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn, after a short illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 1,140 Pacific Street, Brooklyn.
Governor Lehman signed today the Piper bill making the illegal practice of law criminal contempt of the Supreme Court.
Excluding the government's defense bond issue of [pound]100,000,000, new capital issues in April total [pound]11,947,382, against [pound]11,257,135 in March and [pound]10,456,037 in April, 1936.

Cliff Melton had his revenge against the Bees on a gale-swept field today before an admiring gathering of 23,767. The Giants' towering southpaw, mowing down the clan of Bill McKechnle with machine-gun speed, squared the setback he suffered at the Polo Grounds a week ago by holding the Bees to four hits and beating them, 3 to 1.

Shorts and processors were fair buyers of oats last week, both the cash grain and futures. Seeding of the new crop is late, especially in Central Illinois, one of the best oat sections of the country, and indications are that the acreage this year will be less than in recent years.

Trustees of Williams College announced today an appropriation of $854,389 for the 1937-38 budget, appointment of twelve new faculty members and preliminary arrangements for construction of a squash court building.

In compliance with the Reserve Board's order of last January, the final increase in reserves required to be held by member banks went into effect doubtful Saturday. In August, 1935, the board was empowered by Congress to alter such reserve requirements, but not to increase them to more than twice the requirement of that date.

The French equalization fund has been obliged this week to intervene, on a large scale, in the foreign exchange market to meet the demand for foreign currency with the result that it must certainly have lost a fairly large amount of gold.

An exhibition of water-colors to illustrate the development of the English school from 1770 until 1850 will open tomorrow in the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts and continue through June 6. It will contain examples of the work of Gainsborough. Blake, John Sell Cotman, Peter De Wint, Turner and Thomas Girtin.
J. W. Davis Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have admitted Marshall J. Dodge Jr. as a general partner.

The statement for the three months ended on March 31 of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company, controlled by the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $907,254 after expenses, depreciation and obsolescence and taxes, equal to $2.15 a share on the 421,981 capital shares outstanding.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution will open today its uptown office in new quarters at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The office was formerly at Madison Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

To the Editor of The New Times: I am not making a defense of the voluntary hospitals of Greater New York against any criticism made in the survey undertaken by Dr. Emerson, a preliminary study of which was outlined in THE NEW YORK TIMES. To my mind, however, an explanation is needed of the one charge that THE TIMES notes in its heading, "Wide Waste Shown in Hospital Survey."

The proposed establishment at the Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn of one of the most extensive and well-equipped departments for cancer therapy in the country was made known yesterday in an announcement by Edward Cornell, president of the hospital's board
Melodies from 150 grand pianos, played simultaneously by 275 musicians, thrilled 28,000 persons who filled the Butler University fieldhouse at two performances here today.

William F. Bleakly, Republican candidate for Governor last Fall, criticized President Roosevelt's plan for change of the Federal judiciary in an address today before 700 persons at the Peekskill Military Academy.

As individuals and as a nation we have retrogressed because we have lost faith in a personal God, the Rev. Leon M. Flanders, pastor of the Tremont Presbyterian Church, 178th Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx, said in his sermon there yesterday.

Sir Herbert Samuel, British Liberal leader, writes in the May issue of International Conciliation, published today by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, that an international war on the same order as the civil war in Spain may be impending in Eastern Europe. He characterizes it as a "war of ideas."

Authoritative sources here believe that the joint committee of experts studying future American-Philippine relations will go into the question of probable revision of the Philippine currency and banking system.

Announcement has been made by Judge and Mrs. George H. Boyce of Forest Hills Gardens, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Estelle Boyce, to Jose Enrique Berumen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Enrique A. Berumen of Kew Gardens. The announcement was made at a tea given yesterday at the Boyce home.
The executive committee of the City Fusion party endorsed the administration of Mayor La Guardia in a declaration of principles for the coming campaign, made public yesterday.

Resigned to the threat of a strike of live-poultry handlers today, dealers perfected plans yesterday for getting 60 per cent or more of their normal supply of poultry by truck, instead of by railroad.

A picked team representing clubs affiliated with the New York State Football Association defeated the Brookhattans of the American Soccer League yesterday, 3 to 1, before 1.500 fans at Starlight Park.

Organizers for the United Mine Workers of America, led by their district president, William Turnblazer of Jellico, Tenn., continued their drive to unionize the Harlan County coal field at four mass meetings today. A score of Kentucky State patrolmen, sent by Governor Chandler, acted as observers at the meetings all of which were quiet.

The observance of the fourteenth annual National Music Week began yesterday on many fronts throughout the country. David Sarnoff, chairman of the Music Week committee, opened the ceremonies in the afternoon with a nation-wide broadcast.

Sir Arthur Somervell, composer, who set to music "Maud" and "Shropshire Lad," died today at the age of 73. Sir Arthur, who was Professor of Harmony and Counterpoint at the Royal College of Music from 1893 to 1901,

Dr. Daniel Phelan, for twenty 3ears- surgeon at Portsmouth Penitentiary and a former president of the American Prison Surgeons Assqciation, died in hospital early today. His age was 83. Born in North Gower, he was educated at Ottawa University and was graduated in medicine from Queen's in 1877. He retired in 1918.

The New York Telephone Company announced yesterday that a Theodore N. Vail Medal in bronze had been awarded to Pierre Paul Vervlied of Haworth, N. J., for his rescue last Sept. 3 of Joseph Diaz, 9 years old, of 170 East 100th Street, from drowning. Vervlied is employed as a test box maintenance man.

Police Inspector Louis F. Dittman, in command of the Emergency Division of the Police.Department for the last five years, died suddenly yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his home, 221 Linden. Boulevard, Brooklyn.

The Staten Island Zoo will soon receive a group of interesting specimens from the southern part of the New World, Carol Stryker, director of the zoo, revealed yesterday. Just when the specimens will arrive was not known last night, for Vincent Astor had turned back to Bermuda
Carl Albert Schwab, for. thirty years director and corresponding secretary of the Isabella Home, 190th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, died yesterday at his home in Riverdale, Bronx, at the age of 68.

People who blame the maladjustment of our social institutions upon "the system," should look to themselves first, the Rev. Dr. Minot Simons said yesterday in a sermon at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and eightieth Street. "The people of the country are so profoundly resenting the evils from which they are suffering," he said,

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise celebrated his thirtieth anniversary service as head of the Free Synagogue yesterday by. paying tribute to colleagues, leaders of the Christian church and to world figures whose achievements were sources of inspiration to him.

The sharp break in prices in Wall Street and in London caused a similar serious decline on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange, where large sums had been invested in American securities during the prolonged bull market.

Princess Elizabeth--"just past 11"--will wear a coronet and be attended by a lady-in-waiting for the first time in her life on Coronation Day. She is looking forward to it as the greatest day she has ever known.

With the Imperial Conference, which is scheduled to hold its first formal session here May 14, drawing near, there is a growing impression that it will recognize the need for strengthening the ties between the United States and the British Empire.

Competition in the American Bowling Congress championships advanced to within forty-eight hours of completion at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory yesterday as Stephen Keenan of Elizabeth, N. J., rolled 701 and tied for twelfth place in the singles division.

The Convocation Medal of Fordham University, awarded to members of the faculty for twenty years of service to the institution, was presented yesterday to three members at the seventh annual faculty convocation in Keating Hall.

Miss Margaret Pierce, 19, a Boston debutante, was killed here early today when the automobile in which she was riding struck a telephone pole. Roger F. Hooper Jr. of Boston, who police said was driver of the car, suffered severe cuts on the head and was confined in the Salem Hospital.

In the presence of 500 persons, including members of the American Explorers Club and the American Polar Society, the General A. W. Greely, a three-masted schooner, in which a party of meteorologists and other weather experts will sail for the Arctic June 25, was christened today at the city docks at Port Newark.

Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, left for Rome poll today on what is believed to be a formal visit of consultation with Premier Benito Mussolini. One of the objects of the visit, it was indicated, is to make arrangements is for Mussolini's visit to Chancellor Adolf Hitler, now tentatively set for next month.
Three brush and grass fires were reported in Suffolk County today and the danger of such blazes increased with the continuance of the dry weather of the last several days.
Divine services were held on quarterdecks under tropical skies in mid-Pacific today, but not for a minute did any of the 139 ships of the United States fleet relax wartime vigilance.

The series of dances held at the Ritz-Carlton this year in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association, Inc., will be continued next year on an enlarged basis under the chairmanship of Mrs. Grosvenor Farwell.

President Leon Cortes, in a message opening the regular session of Congress, emphasized the necessity of Costa Rica's meeting her foreign debt obligations in order to preserve her good name. He urged that Congress approve the revised debts settlements now being arranged with British and American bondholders.

A strike of 3,500 milk wagon drivers was threatened yesterday in protest against wage cuts, longer hours and reduced commissions, all of which, the drivers say, have come as a result of the milk price war.

Religion is being forced into a secondary position by secular interests, the Rev. John Walter Houck, pastor of the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse at 175th Street, the Bronx, said yesterday in his sermon there. The increase of political inventiveness has caused people to question the place of religion in the social life of America, he said.
The anomaly presented by the continued heavy flow of gold from London to the United States at a time when British holders of American securities are freely liquidating them is not easy to explain.

Ten persons, five passengers and the crew of five, escaped late today when fire destroyed the Inland Waterways Corporation's $50,000 inspection yacht President on the Mississippi River near Clarksville, about eighty-five miles north of here.

A total of 3,558 patients were admitted in 1936 to the Neurological Institute of New York, Fort. Washington Avenue and West 168th Street, according to a report made public yesterday. There were 10,583 visits in its clinics, in addition to 19,200 visits at the neurological division of the Vanderbilt Clinic at the Presbyterian Medical Center.
New propellers will be installed on the liner Queen Mary this Summer in an effort to enable her to regain the Atlantic speed championship from the Normandie, according to The Daily Telegraph.
Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation-Quarter ended March 31: Earnings, $504,498, equal to 67 cents a share, compared with $337,949, or 45 cents a share, last year. Shipments increased 27.6 per cent.

The American Institute of Chemists announced yesterday that its annual medal for notable service to the science of chemistry had been awarded this year to Dr. James F. Norris of the Massachusetts In- in stitute of Technology. Dr. Norris, a Professor of Organic Chemistry, is in charge of graduate students in chemistry and is director of the research laboratory in organic chemistry.

Hundreds of thousands of London's "black coat" office workers realized fully this morning what the bus strike meant to them, for they had to get up hours earlier to try to crowd into the Underground and street cars, which are overtaxed during rush hours at any time.

Rain and cold marred Pope Pius's first day in his Summer home here today. The household was forced to take special precautions to prevent a relapse in the Pontiff's condition. All fireplaces were lighted, although the central heating plant was going full blast.

Conditions on the bourse have been very bad this week. Anxiety caused by the internal situation, weakness in Wall Street and on the London Stock Exchange and in raw-material markets; all contributed toward the recession in quotations.
Hundreds of thousands streamed into the center of town on this golden Spring Sunday to see how completely London has been transformed for the coronation ten days hence.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 93.5, which compares with 93.8 the week before, 94.3 two weeks before, 94.5 three weeks before and 94.7 four weeks before.

The lights that move along the curbs of this city from midnight until dawn, subject of many telephone inquiries to the police, are carried by WPA workers operating "aquaphones," an electrical device that tells what is going on in the water pipes under the street, it was explained today by William H. J. Ely, State WPA Administrator.

A detective and six attendants at the Steel Pier tonight hauled ten Philadelphia business men to safety after their disabled 37-foot cabin cruiser Perry had been smashed against the east side of the pier on the crest of a rising comber.

Miss Mary Pennock Horn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Horn Jr. of Orange, will be married on June 12 to Eugene A. Williamson, son of Mrs. Charles A. Williamson of West Orange. The ceremony will be performed in Christ Episcopal Church, East Orange.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John K. Nevius of Plainfield, N. J., of the engagement of their niece, Miss Florence Nevius Lane, to Carl Johann Ahlers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Ahlers of Summit, N. J.
Three persons were killed near here today by Walter Davis, 30 years old, who then committed suicide. Sheriff's deputies said Davis had attempted to annihilate his whole family.

The Parxon Corporation, which recently bought through Butler Baldwin, brokers, the five-story apartment house at 64 East Fiftysixth Street, has extended its holding by purchasing through the same brokers the adjoining five-story house at 66.

Fifty thousand of Moscow's remaining open devotees of religion overflowed the few surviving churches in the city last night and early today for the Russian Easter services, carried on against the sternest anti-religious drive in seven years.

A hearing will be held on June 2 in Federal court on a plan of reorganization of the Downtown Athletic Club proposed by the General Realty and Utilities Corporation, creditor of the club in the amount of $2,750,000, with interest to March 19, 1937, amounting to $1,324,681.

Dr. George Henry Fox, physician, medical school professor and Civil War veteran, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 145 East Fifty-fourth Street. He was 90 years old. Born in Ballston Spa, N. Y., Dr. Fox, whose hobby was genealogy, traced his family to its first American ancestor. Thomas Fox,
The General Motors Corporation earned 99 cents a share on its common stock in the first quarter, and the directors yesterday voted a dividend of $1 a share.

John Garrett Underhill of 2 Grace Court, Brooklyn, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Susan Prudence Underhill, to Richard Crane of Scarsdale, N. Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mitchell Crane of Scarsdale.

Anticipating an early withdrawal of Federal aid for recreational activities, the Westchester County Recreation Commission urged the Board of Supervisors today to maintain by adequate appropriations the high standards established during the depression.

An unidentified member of the crew of the steamship Acajutla caused consternation among passengers and the crew on the deck of the ship before sailing this morning by tearing up and swallowing two bits of paper, worth $2,000. The seaman in a fit of frenzy and believed to have been under the influence of narcotics did not explain his action and members of the crew did not attempt to .restrain him.

The pamphlet report of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Delaware and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended Feb. 28, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, amortization and other expenses and charges, of $1,584,074, comparing with a net of $1,486,778 for the twelve months ended Feb. 29, 1936.

The Board of Education filed plans yesterday for a new fourstory brick high school, to be erected on the south side of Thirtyfirst Avenue, from Forty-eighth to Forty-ninth Streets, in Astoria, Queens, at an estimated cost of $2,000,000. Plans for a number of alterations were filed in Manhattan. The list follows:

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana was eliminated yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin as a defendant in a suit brought by Louis Blaustein against various officers, directors and stockholders of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, of which he is president.

Francis J. Dillon, an American Federation of Labor organizer, said today that the A. F. L. would seek to become sole bargaining agent for workers in all distilleries connected with t . Distilled Spirits Institute.

The sugar section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today issued its monthly statistical statement covering the first quarter of 1937, consolidating reports obtained from cane refiners, beet-sugar processors, importers and others in the industry.

The coolness between Germany and Britain that set in at a marked pace after the signing of the .German-Japanese "anti - Communist" accord has reached the stage of an open press feud between the two countries, for which the Spanish war is providing topical material.

The new Danish freighter Marchen Maersk arrived here yesterday morning on her maiden transatlantic voyage. She went to Pier 84, Hudson River, to unload freight brought from Hamburg under charte to the Hamburg American Line, and will be transferred Thursday to Pier 18, where she will be open for inspection on Saturday.

Declaring "Massachusetts should take immediate steps" to assist in the development of aviation, Governor Hurley asked the Legislature today to create a special five-man commission to study the problem and develop a State policy on aviation.
Closing of play scores in first class English cricket matches, started Saturday, follow:

The Newark Bears scored a 5-to-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs today, with Tom Henrich featuring a seven-hit attack. Henrich, sent to the Bears by the Yankees when Charlie Keller was hurt, clouted a three-bagger in the fifth with George McQuinn and Bob Seeds aboard.
The Court of Claims awarded to the Seminole Indians of Florida today $10,099 for the government's alleged violation of a treaty drawn in 1856.
Of the sixty-nine leading railroads analyzed and charted in the Sloane Year Book of Railroad Revenue Charts, only twenty-one earned their fixed charges in each of the past seven years.

C. E. McDonald, who entered the service of the Western Pacific Railroad in 1921 in the division office at Elko, Nev., was appointed yesterday general manager in charge of wages and working conditions,
Five Coronation liners are leaving today for English and Continental ports with 5,300 passengers on board, the largest number for an eastbound sailing since 1929.

Relentless warfare on marihuana, which was termed the latest narcotic menace to youth, was urgently recommended to the National Congress of Parents and Teachers here today by Mrs. Hamilton Wright, special representative of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics. The congress opened its convention this morning with 2,000 members present.

Frederick Wheeler White, chairman of the board of directors and former president of the Mutual Chemical Company of America, 270 Madison Avenue, died here tonight of a sudden heart attack at his home, 170 Bayview Avenue. He was born in New York 73 years ago.

W. R. Buckley and John B. Connell have been appointed associate managers of the 522 Fifth Avenue office of H. N. Whitney Sons, members of the New York Stock Exchange. Edward R. Harris has joined the investment securities firm of E. S. Reinthaler Co.

Prices on women's high grade Fall footwear showed an average rise of 10 per cent at the Fall show of the Shoe Fashion Guild of America, which opened yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. Thirty-two leading manufacturers exhibited their lines on the fifth and sixth floors of the Hotel.

Miss Theodate W. Proctor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Proctor of Saco, Me., was married here to Richard S. Stetson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Stetson of Copenhagen, Denmark, and Brunswick, Me., yesterday in Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, West 104th Street.

Throbbing blood vessels in the head can be connected directly with the throbbing pain of a migraine headache, Dr. J. R. Graham of the New York Hospital told the twentyninth annual meeting of the American Society for Clinical Investigation here today.
The Legislature received from Governor Lehman tonight a special message urging enactment of legislation to create a board of mediation to intervene in labor disputes.
The airship denburg started on its first flight in 1937 to North America at 8:15 P. M. today in a light southeast breeze, with ideal weather conditions. Captain Preuss is in commeand of the ship.

Premier Senjuro Hayashi issued today a statement on the House of Representatives election which corresponds to the situation by being obscure to a degree uncommon even in Japanese political utterances.

The German-American Mixed Claims Commission is scheduled to meet Friday to act on three major questions affecting a final settlement of American claims against Germany for $50,000,000 growing out of wartime explosions at Black Tom and Kingsland, N. J., which American representatives blamed upon German spies:

To illustrate the activities of the proposed Museum of Costume Art which is planned as a unit of the projected Municipal Art Center of the City of New York, an exhibition of costumes was opened last night with a preview at La Maison Frangaise, Rockefeller Center. Today the exhibition will be open to the public; it will continue through May 16.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 1: COLONEL Sturdevant, C. L., Eng'rs., relieved from duty at Washington D.C., and ordered to Kansas City, Mo., as Assistant to the Division Engineer.

The New York Rowing Association will hold its fiftieth annual regatta on the Harlem River on May 30, it was announced yesterday by Allen Walz, president of the group. About twenty boating organizations, including the Columbia University A. A. and the Manhattan College A. A., will be represented.

Three restaurant and hotel associations, two of them nation-wide in scope, threw a surprise yesterday into the hearing in which Swift Co. is defending itself against charges of unfair trade practices by intervening on the side of the respondent "in the interest of preserving a free, healthy and unfettered market."
Hind Harrison Plush Company of Clarks Mills, employing 360 persons, closed its plant today until it could be determined which of two unions was entitled to carry on collective bargaining. C.

The Millinery Quality Guild will fight the cease-and-desist order is sued yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission, it was stated yesterday by G. Howard Hodge, chairman of the Guild. He said a meeting of the Guild will be held within the next few days at which plans for carrying an appeal of the commission's order to the Circuit Court of Appeals will be presented by Lowell M. Birrell, counsel for the organization.

Jerry R. Morris of Jacquelin DeCoppet, president of the Wall Street Golf Association, has announced that the twenty-first semiannual golf tournament of that organization will be held at the Upper Montclair Country Club, Montclair, N. J., on June 9.

The Giants ran Into their first taste of real Summer weather today but the heat came simultaneously with Lefty Bill Weir, and had disastrous results. For, under the combination of Weir's southpaw flinging and the unexpected rise in temperature, the Terrymen dropped to a low in hitting, and took defeat from Bill McKechnie's Bees, 3 to 1, also losing the series, two games to one.

Sal Di Buono, pro at the Bonnie Briar Club, paced a field of thirty-six Connecticut, Westchester and Long Island professionals in today's metropolitan section qualifying test for places in the National P. G. A. championship which is to be held at the Pittsburgh Field Club, May 24-30.

The Yankees, plunging into the West for their first extended road trip of the year, which opens in Detroit tomorrow, overshot their mark by some 160 miles today, but upon halting in this throbbing metropolis found the detour an exceedingly profitable one.

In a statement issued here tonight, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced that an alumnus would represent the institute at the 200th anniversary of the University of Goettingen in Germany.

The efforts of 109 Princeton undergraduates in intramural Winter athletics have been rewarded with Intracollegiate Athletic Association medals, it was announced today by Thaddeus T. Hutcheson, '37, of Houston, Texas, the association's president.

There was a vast quantity of entertainment for 5,105 Flatbush fans at Ebbets Field yesterday. Its quality was distinctly low grade, as may be partially deduced from the score, 14 to 8 in favor of the Phillies, and the time consumed, three hours and one minute.

With trading the lightest in several weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday fluctuated rather uncertainly, to end with gains of 1 to 12 points. A further recovery abroad started July above the 13cents-a-pound-level, but the opening quotations proved the highest of the day.
SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ-The wife and two children of President Aguirre, of the Basque Republic, fled from Bilbao to France. Their action was taken to indicate the seriousness of the city's plight. Page 1.

A large group of Brooklyn residents met yesterday at Sartori's Roman Gardens, Nevins Street, to celebrate the action of the Board of Estimate in approving a $20,000 appropriation to prepare final plans for Brooklyn Central, Library, a project that was first proposed in 1899. One wing was completed at Eastern Parkway and Grand Army Plaza in 1919.

Traffic in Forty-third Street between Broadway and Sixth Avenue was delayed for about twenty minutes shortly after 6 P. M. yesterday when a fire occurred in the covering of an emergency exit of the B. M. T. subway.

Thirteen officials of the General Motors Corporation reported an aggregate net increase of 71,161 shares in their indirect holdings of the common stock of that company through the General Motors Management Corporation,

Two boys were rescued by police yesterday afternoon after they had drifted helplessly for two hours in a rowboat on the choppy waters of the lower bay. The boys were Edward Hartman, 15 years old, of 491 Ninety-first Street, and Anthony Asbrack, 13, of 662 Ninetieth Street, both of Brooklyn.

Standard Brands, Inc., is planning to issue 200,000 shares of new preferred stock, of a series to be established and on terms still to be determined, and has called a special meeting of stockholders for June 11 to vote on the proposal.

Formalities lasting less than a half minute ended today the most celebrated divorce suit of modern times, clearing the way for the marriage of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield Simpson, the woman for whom he renounced the British throne.

A physician telephoned to police headquarters about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon to report that he had seen an elderly man carrying a- baby in a black handbag on the Thirty-fourth Street station platform of the Eighth Avenue subway.

21st St, 405 W, n s, 22x90; Bertha Gerson to Bankers Trust Co and ano, trustee, Anna A. Albright and Manufacturers Trust Co, executor, Theo. H. Albright , p m, 5 yrs, 4-41/2 per cent; $11,000. 65th St, 52-56 W, s s, 75x100.5; 56-65th Corp (Monte Ageloff, pres) to the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; p m, demand, int per bond; $150.000.

Operations in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today were considerably restricted. Trade was largely of a local character with bearish sentiment predominating in the wheat pit on reports of scattered showers in Kansas.

Congress met today for its last term and will give an indication tomorrow of the trend in the Presidential campaign when Pedro Alexio, majority leader, and- Antonio Carlos, the Speaker, contest for the leadership.
The first intimation by an administration supporter that a compromise on the bill to reorganize the Supreme Court might be acceptable came today from Senator Logan.

Mrs. Emil Denemark's Finance, son of Bull Dog, shook off a determined challenge by R. H. Heighe's Purple Knight to win by a neck in the Brooklandwood Handicap, today's Maryland Jockey Club feature at Pimlico.

Communists were urged to take an active part in the C. I. O. and the American Youth Congress yesterday by William Z. Foster, chairman of the Communist party, at the Young Communist League's national convention in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

Trial of a suit brought by the Trubenizing Process Corporation against the Jacobson Shirt Company for an accounting, an injunction and damages of an unstated amount began yesterday before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, sitting without a jury.

The New York Central Railroad paid $109.53 a share for 157,825 shares of Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad capital stock, now selling around $19 a share, the report of the trunk line to the Interstate Commerce Commission disClosed yesterday. The holdings give closed yesterday.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000 including 3,000 directs. Weight averages from 210 pounds up, fully 10 higher than Friday's average; lighter weights 10-15 higher: spots up 20:

Fourteen of this city's largest bakeries court's discretion. were closed today by a strike of union bakery workers demanding higher wages and union recognition. Frank Rushton, president of the Kansas City Wholesale Bakers Club, said 90 per cent of the metropolitan bread supply was cut off.
Henry A. Roemer has been elected chairman of the Mullins Manufacduring Corporation. He represents Pittsburgh Steel and Sharon Steel interests, which recently obtained control of the company.

The Senate passed the resolution for participation in New York's World's Fair, adopted the conference report on the Treasury-Postoffice Bill, received the Schwellenbach resolution to enable the Public Works Administration to aid in eliminating hazards

Constantine Mittendorf of New y, York City is the winner of the MacLeish Memorial Swimming Trophy, it was announced today at Yale. The prize was presented last year in memory of Kenneth A. MacLeish, '18, who was killed in' the World War, and goes to the member of the team who best exemplifies MacLeish's spirit.

Exports of iron and steel products from the United States in March, amounting to 208,327 tons valued at $13,784,606, reached the highest level since July, 1929, according to a report made public today by the Department of Commerce.

How the total eclipse of the sun on June 8 would appear from shipboard in mid-ocean at the point where totality is longest, is being demonstrated this month to visitors at the Fels Planetarium of the Franklin Institute.

Margaret Shafer, 23, former employee of the Smith Brothers Cough Drop Company, was arraigned before City Judge Charles J. Corbally today on a charge of attempting to blackmail an executive of the firm.
The name of Sherwood a. Stedman, 26, of Rochester, N. Y, was back today on the list of living alumni of the Stockbridge School of Agriculture of Massachusetts State College.

The elaborately embroidered robe to be worn by Queen Elizabeth during the coronation ceremonies has been hastened to completion by the royal robemakers in time to permit her to practice for the skillful manoeuvring of its heavy train.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public a summary of twenty-six additional registration statements filed recently under the Securities Act of 1933, including one by the Inland Steel Company, Chicago, covering 74,950 shares of nopar-value capital stock to be offered to stockholders of record of May 14 in the ratio of one share for each twenty shares held.

Handkerchief buyers will hold a meeting tomorrow at the SyndicateAlliance, 33 West Thirty-fourth Street. Equity Buyers, Inc., buying representatives, was opened for business yesterday in temporary quarters at 225 West Thirty-fourth Street by Myer Shapiro, Max Fately and A. G. Lorenz, all formerly associated with the office of Jack Anstendig.

Armour Co., meat packing concern here, have a refinancing plan involving $75,000,000, R. H. Cabell, president, announced tonight in a letter to stockholders. He called a special meeting for June 7 to act upon the proposals.

Declaring that his name and reputation are being used without his consent, George W. Rector, gourmet and restaurateur, asked Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter yesterday to restrain Rector's Tavern, Inc.,

Charles C. Field, former nead or the Field Feature Company, a motion picture producing company, which operated in Florida twenty years ago, died at his home here Saturday night. He was 63 years old. Surviving are his widow, a daughter,

Frank Coyle and Ed Linz of the New York Athletic Club, defending champions, defeated Richard Bruck and Adolph Schumacher of the Lone Star Boat Club, 21-10, 21-10, in the second round of the metropolitan A. A. U. four-wall doubles handball tournament last night at the Pastime Athletic Club.

Payment last year of $343,237 as salary, fees and bonus to Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corportion, of $246,174 to George W. Hill, president of the American Tobacco Company,

Mary Pickford, motion picture producer, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary and announced that her marriage to Charles (Buddy) Rogers would take place in California at the end of June, when Mr. Rogers will have finished his present contracts.

The monthly unemployment report issued by the Ministry of Labor today shows a decrease in the number of unemployed of 146,758 from March 15 to April 19, which reduced the total to a seven-year record low of 1,454,443.

Seven hundred striking employer of three of the nineteen shoe factories involved in the Lewiston-Auburn general shoe strike will act tomorrow on a "consent election" proposal for determination of their bargaining representative.

The British Government waited patiently but somewhat skeptically today for some sign that Premier Senjuro Hayashi and the military rulers of Japan would support the diplomatic soundings recently taken here by Ambassador Shigeru Yoshida.

Victor Ghezzi, giant professional of the Deal Golf Club, today hurdled the first obstacle in his path to a Ryder Cup team berth when he led the New Jersey sectional qualifying round for the National P. G. A. championship.

The emergency board appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate the labor dispute which recently threatened a strike of 25,000 members of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks in this area began hearings yesterday at the Bar Association Building, 42 West Fortyfourth Street.
Rochester scored a 10 to 7 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in a listless two-and-a-half hour game today. It was three straight for the Red Wings and the- tenth- consecutive defeat for the Birds.

The funeral of Mrs. Caroline Harris Barthelmess, the mother of Richard Barthelmess, the actor, was held yesterday. afternoon at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street. Mrs. Barthelmess died on April 23 at the age of 70.

To please a Millburn, N. J., detective who confused him with the famed Long Island phantom burglar, District Attorney Martin W. Littleton of Nassau County today sent his fingerprints, a photograph and his "record" to the New Jersey authorities.
Governor Lehman' sent a special message to the Legislature tonight: endorsing the Doyle Labor Relations Board Bill and urging creation of a State mediation board in addition.

Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Duncan Smithers have come from Del Ray, Fla., to the Waldorf-Astoria before going to Dunrobin, their place in Locust Valley, L. I. Mr. and Mrs. George Mellon have arrived at the Ritz-Carlton from Pittsburgh.

Two new directors were elected to the Board of the National Better Business Bureau at its eleventh annual meeting held today. The new board members are John A. Spooner, vice president, The Viscose Company, and Edward Krehbiel, vice president, Black, Starr FrostGorham Company.

The President is fishing today for tarpon in the Gulf of Mexico, leaving Washington and its atmosphere behind him. Last Sunday, as he reported by wireless to the shore at Galveston, he had "a grand rest."

Caroline Miller, who in 1934 won the Pulitzer Prize for her novel, "Lamb in His Bosom," received a final decree of divorce from her husband, Will D. Miller, a former superintendent of the Baxley (Ga.) school system, here today.

The monthly average of commodity prices as of May 1, compiled by Dun Bradstreet, calculates a decline of slightly more than onequarter of 1 per cent from the April 1 average, and about three-quarters of 1 per cent from Jan. 1.

Recent statements made at Buenos Aires, Argentina, by General Carlos Ibafez, former President of Chile, expressing an inclination toward Socialist principles in analyzing Chile's present political difficulties, have caused a sensation here. His movements have been followed with anxiety during his many years in exile.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Wesley Breck of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Breck, to Robert Wilson Blake, sc of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Blake of Rowaytown, Conn. The marriage will take place in the Autumn.
Real estate owners broke all records for paying their taxes in advance when they contributed $45,199,460 in advance payments up to last Saturday night, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday.
Automobile assemblies continued to increase last week when a small decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index spurted to 118.9 from 111.8 (revised). It was 113.2 for the week ended May 2, 1936.

IT certainly does seem cruel.. For all his soft voice- and mild manerr, Mr. Clark Calvin Griffith, owner of the Washington Senators, must be a hard-hearted gent. Just recently-he shipped J. Francis Hogan back to the minors. It was a ghastly thing to do after all the suffering J. Francis had gone through to fit himself into a Washington uniform.

Representatives of colleges and universities founded as early as the twelfth century or as recently as the twentieth will march in the academic procession preceding the formal academic centenary ceremonies at Mount Holyoke College Saturday morning.

An inspection of the new 1,000,000-volt X-ray unit recently installed for cancer treatment at the Collis P. Huntington Memorial Hospital of Harvard University will be made during the Spring meeting of the Harvard board of overseers, May 10 and 11.

Dodd, Mead has just received the manuscript and illustrations of "Away to Quebec," by Gordon and Putriam Brinley. The author and artist of "Away to the Gaspe" now tell of travel adventures from the city of Quebec along the north shore of the St.. Lawrence to the Sazuenay and Lake St. John.

A prediction that an Ohio River stage of 47 to 48 feet would be reached late this week at Cairo, Ill., brought an order today for an emergency evacuation of the southern part of the 101,000-acre flood prevention spillway in Missouri.

Sweep ing the three doubles matches and capturing five of the six singles encounters, Manhattan's golf team defeated the Rider College linksmen of Trenton, N. J., 8 to 1, over the Sprain Lake course today. It was the second triumph in three matches this season for the Jaspers, who were undefeated in 1936.

Lewis M. White has sold his house and grounds on the Moriches Road at St. James, Smithown, L. I., through Malcolm E. Smith, Inc., broker. The dwelling was erected by William J. Collier, the actor, who occupied it when he was in the East.
Amelia Earhart arrived here today from New York to complete preparations for resumption of her flight around the world.

TO celebrate the fact that The Baltimore Sun has shone upon the face of Maryland for exactly 100 years, four members of the present Sun staff have banded together and written a book. They call it "The Sunpapers of Baltimore" (Knopf, $3.75). They are Gerald W. Johnson, Frank R. Kent, H. L. Mencken and Hamilton Owens.
Three senior officials of. the United States Embassy and their wives, in addition to Ambassador and Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, have received Westminster Abbey seats to witness the coronation ceremony.

A continued shortage in the votes necessary to pass Governor Lehman's bill to add a fourth cent per gallon to the tax on gasoline made it necessary tonight for the legislative leaders. to postpone consideration of the measure until tomorrow.

After observations of the Andes made in the last few days, the head of the seismologic services of the University of Chile, Dr. Enrique Donoso, declared today that volcanic activity noted at Mount Petorca, near Curico, had now been followed by emission of smoke and rock from near-by Mount Planchon to such an extent that it was difficult to investigate which of the two was the more active.
The stock market today showed signs of increasing confidence and conditions improved all around. Gilt-edge issues advanced and German bonds were outstanding on the up side among foreign loans.

Furniture shows opened today at the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart with manufacturers optimistic over the business outlook. Attendance was virtually double that of last November's furniture market.

A National Youth Administration trade school is in readiness at Quoddy Village for the accommodation of 500 young men. Confronted, upon their arrival at Quoddy late in February, with the task of repairing a large number of leaking buildings erected for the tidal power project, the WPA staff, of which L. Philip Theriault is chief engineer, has made the village ready for occupancy two weeks ahead of schedule.

For discovering a new star on June 18, 1936, a barber of Nagano, Japan, was tonight honored by the American Society of Variable Star Observers,' according to announcement by Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory.

Frank J. Denniston, former $10,000-a-year director of the United States Shipping Board, must serve a sentence of a year and a day in prison, which he received on Oct. 24, 1936, when he pleaded none contender to an indictment charging failure to report a total of $30,830 in his tax returns for 1931, 1932 and 1933, the United States Circuit Court ruled yesterday.
Lieut. Gen. Sir John Lindesay Keir, commander of the Sixth Division of the British Expeditionary Force, the "Old Contemptibles," in the World War, died tonight at Leamington at the age of 80.

Mayor Edmund C. Gause and the village Board of Trustees considered an offer from the Westchester Electric Railway Company tonight to substitute a bus for the famed "Toonerville trolley," which has wended its way through this village for forty years.
High officials of the German Propaganda Ministry changed pens for picks and spades today. A decree ordered those who have spent their time signing State documents to lend a hand

The gold and arms situations appear as the darkest shadows in the picture of the world-wide upswing that the Bank for International Settlements draws in its annual report surveying the monetary and economic world.
Establishment of direct airplane service between Cali, Colombia and the Canal Zone, as announced by Pan American-Grace Airways, will provide four services between the Isthmus and Colombia.

Charles Augustus Brown, one or Hawaii's leading figures for forty years, died tonight at his temporary home here. His age was 81. Mr. Brown, a resident of Honolulu since 1877, except for annual visits to this city, was president of the John I.-I. estate.

A jury will decide some day next week whether License Commissioner Paul Moss abused discretion when he refused to re-license the city's burlesque theatres, Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman indicated yesterday.

The requiem mass for Inspector Louis F. Dittman, in command of the Emergency Division of the Police Department, who died on Sunday at his home, 221 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, will be celebrated tomorrow at 10 A. M. in Holy Cross Church, Veronica Place and Church Avenue.

Charles N. Teetor, inventor of a railway cycle, which was the forerunner of the modern "speeder" car used by repair men, died last night at his home here. He was 66 years old. In recent years he had been president of the Perfect Circle Company, makers of piston rings.

Psychiatrists at Bellevue Hospi tal having declared him sane after a month's observation, Alexander Kinderman, 49 years old, was held for the action of the grand jury yesterday in the Felony Court after he had pleaded not guilty before Magistrate McKiniry on his alleged confession to starting the first and second of three fires in the West End Synagogue at 160 West Eightysecond Street.

Despite all King George has done to restore the atmosphere of his father's reign, his civil list, published today, shows the royal family's expenses are budgeted at the lower level set by his brother, Edward VIII.

The National Labor Relations Board, opposing requested dismissal of an injunction suit brought against it by William Randolph Hearst Corportions, today renewed its request in the United States Court of Appeals here for an enforcement order in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer case.

Paul Dean, ailing Cardinal pitcher, agreed today to undergo an operation for a shoulder injury which has prevented him from attaining his former effectiveness. "I'll do whatever the club wants me to do," Paul told Sam Breadon, Cardinal president, during a conference at which Breadon recommended the operation.

Accidents, fatalities and the number of persons injured in traffic mishaps showed marked improvement last week and week-end as compared with totals for the corresponding periods of 1936, figures made public by the traffic division of the Police Department showed yesterday.
Charlew Ailing Gifford, retired New York architect, died at his home, 7 South Brighton Avenue, today after a long illness, at the age of 76.

The search for a player to fill the leading male role in "Hurricane," that of the native boy Terangi, ended over the week-end when Samuel Goldwyn signed Jon Hall, who was chosen from among hundreds of candidates by John Ford, the director.
Gregory Mason, archaeologist, author and explorer, and Mrs. Ruth Fitch Boyd, poet and literary agent, came from New York today and were married by Justice of the Peace Herbert Wheeler.

Two records were established in the first quarter of 1937 among the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's 17,500,000 industrial policyholders. The company announced yesterday that the death rate from' automobile accidents in the group was the highest ever recorded in the first quarter of a year and that

Senator Wheeler announced tonight an Interstate Commerce subcommittee would meet on Thursday to inquire into the recent sale of Midamerica Corporation, holding company of the Van Sweringen rail empire.

Two residents of New York, Mrs. George Temple Bowdoin and Miss Anne Schenck, are among twelve American women who will be presented to King George and Queen Elizabeth at the first court to be held in Buckingham Palace by their Majesties, which will take place on Wednesday. Mrs. Homer Cummings,

Most of the American secular press has unwittingly deceived its readers by failing to print unbiased and reliable news from both sides in the Spanish Civil War, Micha.el Williams, editor of The Commonweal, Catholic review, charges - in an article appearing in the May 7 issue of his magazine,. published today.

Tear gas tonight broke up a riot of Harvard students, who, 2,000 strong, were marching on Radcliff College after drenching one another and passers-by with bags of water and with streams from hose. The demonstration started when a student began spraying passers-by with a garden hose from his rooms.

There will be one really happy participant in the coronation. For the King and Queen the stately ceremony in the Abbey will be an ordeal. All the pomp and splendor of the historic ritual, a spectacle without counterpart inthe niodern world,

The Kane Carpet Company of Newark, wholesalers of rugs, linoleum and other floor coverings, bought the building at 111-117 Patperson Street, Harrison, N. J., from the estate of John D. Crane through the David Houston Corportion, as broker.

A group of 140 employes of the Shell Petroleum Corporation's refinery here began a sit-down strike today in the compounding house. They demanded restoration of their regular hourly schedule, recently changed.

Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany arrived in Rome at the head of a large German delegation at 11:35 o'clock this morning and got a reception in which every possible emphasis was laid on Italo-German friendship.
A bill making the Civilian Conservation Corps a permanent agency at an authorized annual cost of $350,000,000 received right of way in the House today by action of its Rules Committee.
The Maday Realty Corporation, represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, purchased from Leo Eisenberg the seven-story apartment house at 1,307 Boscobel Avenue, near 169th Street, the Bronx.

Progress" was reported today in negotiations between strikers and employers at the plants of the Publicker Commercial Alcohol Company, the Continental Distilling Company and the Philadelphia Storage Battery Company.

The Chase National Bank, as successor trustee, is inviting tenders of the Syracuse Lighting Company, Inc., first and refunding 5% per cent mortgage bonds, due 1954; at 105 in an amount sufficient to exhaust $31,380.

The Federal Government opened its case in the Parker conspiracy trial here today by charging that Governor Hoffman of New Jersey knew about the alleged scheme whereby Paul H. Wendel was produced as the "real" kidnapper of the Lindbergh baby, a few days before Bruno Richard Hauptmann was to be put to death for the crime.

After fifty-six consecutive adjournments since it first offered the collateral for sale in May, 1932, the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company will offer on Friday through Adrian H. Muller Sons, in Jersey City, securities held to cover $1,500,000 borrowed by the bankrupt Insull Utility Investments, Inc.
High Man, racing in the colors of Mrs. R. O. Burns of Texas, led from start to finish today to score a surprise victory in the mile-and-70yards feature at Aurora.

Finishing gamely after he appeared to be beaten at the head of the stretch, Count Arthur, veteran handicap campaigner owned by Mrs. John D. Hertz, captured the Rialto Handicap at Jamaica yesterday and avenged his defeat the last time out by reversing the decision on Cleaveland Putnam's Moon Side,

Fleisher Mills, occupying the entire block hounded by Twenty-fifth, Reed, Twenty-sixth and Dickinson Streets, Philadelphia, has been sold by the Fleisher Bondholders Protective Committee, Henry G. Drueding, chairman, to the Quackenbush Warehouse Company of Scranton.

The Krakow Furniture Company team from Detroit became the first 1937 champion of the American Bowling Congress late last night as the five-man division race came to an end at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory.

Greenwich Village is mentioned "only in passing" in the revised edition of the WPA Federal Writers Project's leaflet "Your New York," Donald Thompson, assistant State director of the project, said yesterday.

Bond prices advanced moderately in extremely dull trading in the bond section of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The total of transactions amounted to $6,620,000, compared with $11,158,800 on last Friday.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States dropped in the final week of April to the lowest level since March 1, Dun Bradstreet announced yesterday. The total reported to that organization for the week ended April 29 was 183, compared with 191 in the previous week and 196 in the corresponding 1936 week.

The Treasury Department went to trial here yesterday at the Old Postoffice Building to collect $1,824,112 income tax for 1929 from Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob. This is in addition to the $5,747,323 they paid that year.

Mrs. Anna Tappe, mother of Herman Patrick Tappe, New York women's clothing stylist, died yesterday in the home built for her by her son. She was 92 years old. Born in Ireland, she came to United States at the age of 3.
The arrival today of the main Eastern contingent, following the withdrawal of E. R. Bradley's Brooklyn, left horsemen as much at sea as the racegoers over the outcome of Saturday's Kentucky Derby.

In the Prologue of CHAUCER'S Canterbury Tales mention is made of one of the company that wended their way to Canterbury who was a priest "that Christ's gospel truly would preach." And what was said of him might almost In.the same words (with modernized spelling) be written of Father DUFFY:

ADLER, ANNA E. (April 26). Estate, more than $10,000. To Simon Adler, husband, 505 West End Ave., household, personal effects and residue; Beatrice Proops, daughter, 8,632 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, jewelry and $2,000; Sylvia Adler, daughter, executrix, 505 West End Ave., $5,000, jewelry and personal effects; Ottilie Ehrlich, sister, 13 Vernon Terrace, East Orange, N. J., $2,000;

The fifth anniversary of the rebuilding of Irvington House, the sanitarium for cardiac children at Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., will be celebrated on Thursday afternoon at the sanitarium's annual meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103d Street.
Parents who wanted milk for their children were forced to present notes from physicians before striking dairymen allowed them to enter dairies to get the milk today.

Hammering the offerings of three visiting pitchers for a total of thirteen safeties, Manhattan's baseball team overwhelmed the Seton Hall College nine of East Orange, N. J., 10 to 2, at Manhattan Field yesterday.

President Roosevelt's Federal court reorganization plan is an issue in tomorrow's special election in California's Tenth Congressional District to choose a successor to the late Representative Henry Stubbs of Santa Maria.
Charles Edwin Fox, former District Attorney of Philadelphia County and widely known as a civic and welfare leader, died of a heart attack early today at his home here. He was 54 years old.

Dr. Reginald D. Margeson, Boston surgeon, will leave Newark Airport this morning at 9 o'clock on a United Air Lines plane on the first leg of a trip around the world on regularly advertised and scheduled air routes.

These National Guard commissions were issued today: Lane, 1st Lt. Charles L., 106th Infantry, for further assignment to Headquarters Company, Second Battalion. De Bold, 2d Lt., Leroy, 106th Infantry, for assignment to Company B. Hedgecock, 2d Lt. John H., 212th Coast Artillery, for further assignment to Service Battery.

Monroe at, 37, 5-story tenement and stores, 25x10??; Marine Midland Trust Co. against Ulan Corp.; due, $10,488; costs, $523; taxes, etc., $1,118; to plaintiff for $8,000. By EDWIN J. McDONALD 7th St, 220 E, 5-story tenement and stores, 25x90.10; Fulton Trust Co. of New due, $11,308; taxes, etc., $1,675; to plaintiff for $9,500.

Edward C. Maguire, counsel for the Milk Wagon Drivers. Union, Local 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, an affiliate of the A. F. of L., warned a group of milk dealers last night that the union would hold a general meeting Thursday night in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, to vote on whether to strike.
Rear Admiral Robert Stocker, United States Navy, retired, died today at a hospital here. He was 71 years old.
As a guide to vacationists who always insist upon including fishing tackle in their luggage, the State has issued a handy fishing directory.
If junior doesn't eat his oatmeal, do his homework or come in at night when dad whistles, Dr. Dennis H. Kelly, child specialist, has the answer:

Steel Workers Union notified the Republic Steel Corporation today that it would "disavow responsibility" for keeping union members at work in the company's mills unless a conference was arranged to negotiate a written labor contract.

With the resumption today in the United States District Court of argument in the suit of five railroad companies for a permanent injunction to restrain New Jersey from collecting allegedly exorbitant taxes, Judge Phillip Forman admitted in evidence an exhibit showing the value of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company's treasury assets.
The State of California will receive tenders today for the purchase of $8,300,000 of its registered general fund warrants. Bids are to be submitted in fractions no smaller than 1/2 per cent.

George F. Truesdell, retired actor, died yesterday at his home, 535 West 110th Street, after a long illness. He was 64 years old. Mr. Truesdell, who was the son of Colonel George Truesdell, a Civil War veteran, and Frances Pringle Truesdell, was graduated from Yale in 1895.

Orders booked by furniture manufacturers in the first three months of this year showed a gain of 50 per cent in dollar volume compared with the corresponding quarter of 1936, Seidman Seidman, accountants specializing in the furniture industry, reported yesterday.

An offering to the public is being made today by Hill, Thompson Co., Inc., by prospectus, of $350,000 first mortgage 51/2 per cent sinking fund bonds due on April 1, 1947 of the O'Sullivan Rubber Company, Inc.

Federal Judge Murray Hulbert will appoint a special master tomorrow to hear witnesses and make recommendations involving acceptance or rejection of a plan proposed to cover reorganization of the Warner-Quinlan Company.
Representative White of Ohio said today that his proposal that a street in the capital mall be named for Ohio had won a new recruit, the executive committee of tie Ohio American Legion.

A $10,500 recovery suit against Greta Garbo was postponed today and the audience grunted indignantly. On June 21, however, the actress's counsel assured the court, she will be on hand to defend herself against David Shratter's charge that he "grub-staked" her-to a film career and she never repaid him.

William E. Wheeler, president and general manager of The New York Woman, Inc., was questioned at a public hearing yesterday morning in the office of State Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., 80 Center -Street; regarding the methods used in the sale of stock,.

Alfred Decker Cohen, clothing manufacturers of Chicago, has appointed the Salem N. Baskin Advertising Agency, Chicago, according to an announcement by G. M. Forbes, advertising manager of the company.

Pointing out that the expanded Park Department facilities were being used to capacity, Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, issued a statement yesterday in which he characterized police protection in city parks as "a joke."

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 91 per cent of ingot capacity this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports, compared with 92.3 per cent last week, a decrease of 1.3 points, or 1.4 per cent.

Dr. John D. MacPherson of 14-22 122d Street, College Point, Queens, died Sunday night at his home after a brief illness, of pneumonia. He was 76 years old. For more than twenty-five years Dr MacPherson served on the staff of Flushing Hospital, resigning in 1928.

Century 7, Gedney Farm 4 1/2, Innis Arden 3 1/2 Mrs. R. P. Limburg, Century, halved with Mrs. R. Holman, Innis Arden, and Mrs. H. Dietrich, Gedney Farm; Mrs. Dietrich defeated Mrs. Holman. Mrs. D. H. Sulzberger, Century, defeated Mrs. J. J. Lawler, Gedney Farm, and halved with Mrs. A. McLave, Innis Arden; Mrs. McLave defeated Mrs. Lawler.
Sixty-ninth annual meeting of the Dental Society of the State of New York begins this morning at 10 o'clock at the Waldorf-Astorla and continues until Friday. Morning, afternoon and evening sessions.

The second program at the WPA Theatre of Music in the local Federal Music Project's observance of National Music Week, given last night, was devoted to chamber works. American compositions for various instruments, as well as for voice in one instance, were presented.
A severe attack of laryngitis kept Vivian McGrath from leaving for New York last night with the other members of the Australian Davis Cun team.

The net earnings of the Amerada Corporation were slightly higher in the first quarter than in the corresponding, period last year, when they were 60 cents a share on the common capital stock, A. Jacobsen,

American Catholics contributed $641,000 in 1936 to missions organized under the auspices of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, Mgr. Thomas J. McDonnell of New York reported to the general assembly of the society today.

Dr. James Rowland Angell, outgoing president of Yale; Dr. Livingston Parrand, retiring president of Cornell, and Lewis W. Douiglas, former Director of the United States Budget, were elected members of the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History at the Spring meeting of the trustees held at the museum last night.

Postmaster General James A. Farley and former Governor Alfred E. Smith joined last night in paying tribute to Daniel P. Higgins, president of the Catholic Youth Organization, at a testimonial dinner for Mr. Higgins in the Empire Room at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
In a surprise announcement at a meeting of the Twenty-Year Club of the B. F. Goodrich Company tonight, James D. Tew said he would retire as president of the company.

With horns blaring impatiently in an incessant din, hundreds of Jersey-bound trucks and automobiles stood still four abreast for more than an hour yesterday in a line from Fourteenth to Twenty-eighth Street along the West Side waterfront as fifty-seven employes of a ferry company went on strike.
President Roosevelt sent a message of "warmest personal greetings" to the twenty-third convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today.

A pair of amateurs, John Mikrut and James Oleska, manufactured a 68 to top a field of fifty-three teams in the Long Island Golf Association's inaugural tournament of the year at the St. Albans Golf Club in Queens yesterday.

King George summoned Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin and Minister of Labor Ernest Brown to Buckingham Palace tonight and urged the government to make every effort to settle the bus strike in London before the coronation a week from Wednesday.
The Yale freshman nine today defeated the Milford (Conn.) School, 18 to 4, largely through the efforts of Harley Jackson, former Andover star, who allowed only three scattered hits in seven innings.

The forty-year-old school ship President Sarmiento sailed for Philadelphia this afternoon on her thirty-eighth and last voyage. She will be replaced next year-by the light cruiser La Argentina, now building in England.

Roland Taylor, chairman of the Tubize Chatillon Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that net profit for the first quarter was $369,741 and that the rate of operations in March and April was well above the first quarter average, with net profit running at about $140,000 per month.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey yesterday declared an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the capital stock in addition to the regular semianhual disbursement of 50 cents, both payable on June 15, to stock of record of May 17. On June 15.

The Montreal garment workers' strike provoked a heated debate today in the legislative Assembly in which Premier Duplessis praised the firmness of Premier Hepburn of Ontario toward international organizers- and criticized the Ottawa government for what he regarded as apathy.

With five entrants in Class A and fourteen in Class B, competition' got under way today in the Long Island women's interclub team tournament at Cherry Valley and at the completion of the opening matches, North Hempstead, with 6 points, had assumed the lead in Class A, while Queens Valley, with 8 points, had forged to the front in Class B.

Total advertising linage in Manhattan newspapers during April comprised 10,444,891 lines, compared with 9,802,544 lines in the same month last year, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures. This represented a gain of 642,347 lines, a rise of 6.6 per cent over 1936. Increases were reported chiefly for general, including national advertising, classified, and ,retail linage.
Three Nashville textile plants closed today as the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. 0. affilate, started a campaign to sign up workers in middle Tennessee.

Deputy Chief Inspector Edward Bracken appeared at 6:30 yesterday morning at the plant of The Long Island Daily Press in Jamaica with 150 policemen, in answer to the charge of William Hofmann, publisher, that he had been forced to close down his newspaper because of insufficient police protection.
Intent on carrying out his part of the bargain to the letter, Max Schmeling arrived in this city from his native Germany aboard the Bremen of the North German Lloyd line yesterday.

Paulie Walker, veteran welterweight from Trenton, scored a knockout triumph over Werther Arcelli of Boston in the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. The Jersey battler stopped his foe in one minute and ten seconds of the seventh round with a series of rights to the jaw.
Columbia plans to enter its 150pound varsity crew in the regatta with Harvard and M. I. T. on the Charles River, Cambridge, next Saturday.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on April 28 shows decreases for the week of $66,000,000 in total loans and investments and $94,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks,

Any attempt to understand Japanese politics in terms of Western ideas of parties and parliamentary government tends to confuse rather than clarify an extremely complicated situation. The overwhelming defeat of the Cabinet in the general election last week,

Former directors and officers of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company have tentatively offered to pay $900,000 in settlement of a $6,800,000 suit brought against them by Frederick V. Goess, the bank's receiver, Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy was told yesterday.

An investor bought for altering the four-story building at 214 East Forty-fifth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, in a deal announced yesterday by the Joseph Milner company, Inc., broker. The property was sold by Dighton W. Forrest and Abel E. Blackmar Jr., trustees of the henry D. Winans estate.
Fifteen-year-old George Rizzalo was back in his Hillside, N. J., home last night after a three-day flight from his high school classes which brought him more distress than freedom.

The Illinois Per and Light Corporation, an indirect subsidiary of the North American Company, a registered holding company, has been'authorized by the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue 4838,00 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $50 par;

The New York Light Opera Guild will present Victor Herbert's "Mlle. Modiste" at the Venice Theatre tonight and tomorrow. A concert of chamber music composed by Emil Koehler, Charles Jones, Rudolph Gruen, Alexei Haeff, Berenice Robinson and Norman Cazden, Juilliard Graduate School students, will be presented tonight at the school.

Funeral The funeral of Inspector Louis F. Dittmann, Commanding the Emergency Service Division, Police Department, will be held from his late residence, 221 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Wednesday, May 5. This department will -be represented at the funeral by a battalion of two companies (twenty-four men to a company), commanded by Assistant Chief of Department George L. McKenna.

The present Federal administration has set an example for believers in democracy everywhere, Rabbi Joseph Konvitz of Newark, president of the Union of Orthodox Rabbis in the United States and Canada, said here tonight, opening the annual convention of the group.
Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, Called upon organized labor today to oppose enactment of Governor Frank Murphy's Labor Relations Bill.

Five hundred and four of the 1,320 applicants who took the State bar examinations March 15 and 16 were successful, the State Board of Law Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark, New York City; Philip J. Wickser, Buffalo, and Rollin B. Sanford, Albany, announced today.

Dr. Isidore B. Kaplan of 140 Rivington Street went on trial in Speoial Sessions yesterday on conspiracy and petit larceny charges growing out of an alleged fake indemnity claim on an insurance company.

The Postoffice Department has put a new obstacle in the way of lottery 'promoters. Hereafter, Postmaster General Elliott said today, letters suspected of containing lottery tickets or remittances will

Ten friars of Rhineland Catholic monasteries and one layman were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from six months to three and one-half years. Three of the defendants were convicted of aiding suspected members of the Franciscan Order to flee from Germany.
