Father Gregor, secretary of the Rhineland Franciscan Province, was sentenced to one year in the penitentiary.

The small republic of Estonia has resolved to purge her geographic nomenclature of all foreign-sounding names, just as thousands of Estonians in recent years have changed family names, recalling German, Russian or other origins, into genuine Estonian forms.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 1 unless specified: Off Aransas Pass: Decatur, Moffett. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk. Asheville, Shanghai to Pagoda Anchorage, May 2. Babbitt, Coco Solo. to Almirante, May 3. Brazos, at Pearl Harbor.

Turpentine firm, 35 1/4c; sales, 172 barrels; receipts, 433 barrels; shipments, 1,389 barrels; stock, 22,670 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 887; receipts, 1,242; shipments, 4,062; stock, 41,187. Quote: B, $7.05; D, $7.15: E, $7.65; F, G, H. $8.07 1/2; I, K, $8.07 1/2-$8.10; M, $8.10; N. $8.20: WG. $8.25; WW, X $8.95.

The Rev. John X. Pyne, S. J., regent and Professor of Jurisprudence of the Fordham University Law School, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after undergoing a major operation recently. Father Pyne was 66 years old.

James M. Speers, president of James McCutcheon Co., has been elected president of the American Committee for Christian German refugees, It was announced yesterday by Dr. E. Graham Wilson, chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Speers succeeds the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman.

Dr. Edward T. Devine, one of the country's pioneers in social work, was praised by speakers yesterday for being responsible during his service with the Charity Organization Society for -starting many importent welfare' and civic- efforts which are now permanent parts of American community life.

Collateral behind the Alleghany Corporation's $24,387,000- 5 per cent bonds of 1950 remains below the 150 per cent of their face value required by their indenture, the Guaranty Trust Company, trustee, reported yesterday.
The Senate passed tonight, the Dunnigan bill authorizing New York City to build a spur from the Independent Subway in Queens to the site of the 1939 World's Fair. The cost is estimated at $1,200,000.
Archbishop Pietro di Maria, former Apostolic Delegate to Canada and later Papal Nuncio at Berne, Switzerland, died here today. His age was 71.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated April 30. COMMANDERS Clay, A. T., 12th Naval District, to command the Argonne. Northcroft, P. W., when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., to home, relieved from all active duty.

The Pulitzer Prizes in letters and journalism for the current year were announced last night by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, at the annual dinner of the alumni of the School of Journalism.

The average price of real estate bond issues advanced 0.2 per cent in the four months ended April 30, according to the May 1 AmottBaker realty bond averages, based upon 200 selected issues of properties in New York, Buffalo, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and other Eastern cities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although I know it has been advocated before, I feel that repetition on this particular subject can do no harm. The country talks of balancing the budget. One way to help that result without harm to any one is to legalize all forms of lottery.

James J. Dooling, ailing leader of Tammany, who returned from Miami on Sunday, began yesterday a series of talks with district leaders that undoubtedly will have a bearing on whether he will reconsider his decision not to resign.

The art collection of Richard M. Hurd, its three dozen or so items acquired over a period of about thirteen years, has been placed on view at the Newhouse Galleries, 5 East Fifty-seventh Street, where the work may be seen until May 29.
The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee urged Congress today to authorize a Federal Trade Commission investigation of active power company opposition to public power developments.

Properties in Brooklyn sold recently by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn included the following: 725 Avenue M to Vincent Ostrowski; 246 Cumberland Street to Barbare Wagenblast, through J. J. Garahan; 1,125 Eighty-second Street to Marco Scoglio, through the Dyker Realty Company;

A. C. Norris's Guy Fawkes, a 3-year-old Happy Time colt, proved a keen sprinter when he won today's Narragansett Park feature race at six furlongs. Guy Fawkes scored by six lengths over W. C. Stroube's Patrolite in 1:11 1-5.

The National Orchestral Association presented the sixth and final concert of its evening series at Carnegie Hall last night, Leon Barzin conducted a program of familiar works: Beethoven's vernal Sixth symphony, known as the "Pastorale"; Mozart's Concertante quartet for oboe, clarinet, horn and bassoon, and Richard Strauss's tone poem, "Don Juan."

Four anonymous gifts totaling $32,000 from philanthropic foundations to the men's division in the current Catholic Charities appeal for the Archdiocese of New York were announced yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, honorary chairman of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, which is directing the appeal.

Two flags to be flown over Westminster Abbey on Coronation Day refused to rehearse nicely today. Three times workmen tried the blue and white flag royal standard and each time it failed to break perfectly.

Filing of the inventory of the estate of Judge Leonard J. Nickerson showed as the greatest single item cash deposits of $36,612.50 in fifty-one banks of the State. There are only seventy-three savings banks in Connecticut.

Curtis B. Dall of 37 East Sixtyseventh Street, former son-in-law of President Roosevelt, testified in Supreme Court yesterday that he was greatly embarrassed by a magazine article purporting to describe his suicide in the White House in the presence of Mrs. Roosevelt and his former wife. He is suing Time, Inc., publishers of the mazagine Time, for $250,000 on the basis of the article.

Late reports tonight from the Bermeo and - Durango sectors indicate the Basque forces held the Rebels all day, except for a small valley position below Sollube, just outside the fishing village of Bermeo, on the Bay of Biscay northeast of Bilbao. The Basques there were driven out by an air bombardment.

Striking employes of the Thermoid Rubber Company will vote Wednesday their acceptance or rejection of a settlement reached here late tonight at a conference of company officials and union officers, it was announced by William C. Liller, Department of Labor mediator.

Miss Patty MacRobert, daughter of Mrs. Mona G. MacRobert of this city and Dr. Russell G. MacRobert f New York, was married here tolay to M. Clay Adams of Beverly Hills, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Clay Adams of Larchmont, in the chapel of St. Augustine's Church.

The fingerprint files of the United States Bureau of Investigation caught up with a quiet little Perth Amboy fish peddler yesterday and he faces return to the Westchester County penitentiary, from which he escaped fifteen years ago.

The Transport Workers Lodge, which is seeking recognition for purposes of collective bargaining with the management of the Third Avenue Railway system, called off its threatened strike yesterday and asked the newly created City Industrial Relations Board to intervene immediately.

The prices of the more expensive Coronation seats tumbled today. The drop resulted primarily from reports from New York that many Americans had canceled steamship bookings, although a marked decline in exorbitant prices had been generally expected to come a short time before the Coronation.

Sampson Smith of the United States today won the Bermuda Challenge Trophy with his International Star Class Yacht Pioneer. With H. S. Grew Jr. crewing with him, Smith, a member of the Otsego Lake fleet, finished second to the Bermuda boat Bugs, skippered by B. G. H. Snowdon, in the final race of the series, but won the trophy on points.

The United Electrical and Radio Workers Union asserted tonight officials of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company had agreed to cooperate in employee elections under the Wagner act to determine who should represent its 47,000 workers in collective bargaining.

Great Britain has sent an "urgent inquiry" to General Francisco Franco, leader of the Spanish Insurgents, asking him whether he intends sending his airplanes to raze Bilbao. So far no reply has been received, nor has the British Government yet had a complete response to its inquiries regarding the destruction of Guernica, apparently by German planes in the service of General Emilio Mola and the Rebel army in the north.

Joseph Michael Cassidy, a discharged watchman of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, was held in $5,000 bail today for a further hearing on Thursday on charges of larceny and malicious mischief after he had confessed stealing fourteen paintings from the academy and slashing twenty-three others.
There was another slight increase in the average rate of interest paid by the Treasury today in the sale of $50,014,000 of 273-day Treasury bills.

The election of Mrs. Jacob Schechter of 262 Central Park West as president of the United Parents Association was announced last night at a meeting of the delegate assembly of that organization at the Hotel Astor. Mrs. Schechter, who served as vice president of the association during the last year, formerly was a teacher in various city high schools.

After a threehour debate the Assembly tonight passed one milk bill and defeated another. The bill passed would permit producers and distributors in milk sheds. to fix prices. The vote was 80 to 62. The bill was sponsored by Assemblyman Allen, Dutchess Republican.

FAUST, opera in French In four acts: music by Charles Gounod; book by Jules Barber and Michel Carre; conductor, Wilfred Pelletier; stage director, Desire Defree; chorus master, Fausto Cieva. Presented at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Hurling thunderbolts with his service as in his amateur days, Ellsworth Vines of Pasadena, Calif., came back to Madison Square Garden last night to make amends for his disappointing showing of last January against Frederick Perry of England.

Theodore Dreiser testified in Supreme Court yesterday that he did not regard himself as a "recognized American author," despite the fact that the I 'veright Publishing Corporation in 1929 contracted to pay him $1,250 a month as advance royalties on a new book to be called "The Stoic." Alleging that he has failed to produce the book to date, the company is suing him for $17, 000 representing advances made between 1929 and 1932.

Mrs. Elizabeth Murphy Cudahy, wife of Edward A. Cudahy Sr., chairman of the board of the Cudahy Packing Company, died in her home here today after an illness of a year. She was 78 years old. Born in Milwaukee, Mrs. Cudahy was married to the co-founder of the packing company in 1884.

A plan understood to be under administration consideration for creation of a board empowered to fix maximum hours and minimum wages in industry has developed an undercover fight between certain labor and industrial groups.

The outlook dimmed tonight for immediate settlement of the strike against sixteen of San Francisco's "luxury class" hotels. Although hotel operators appointed a "policy committee," they made no apparent move to meet with strike leaders.

In the Court of Claims of the United States the following proceedings were had today: C-531 (3)--The Sioux tribe of Indians. Petition dismissed. Opinion by Judge Green. 418 (3)-B. Ogden Chisolm. Findings of fact. Plaintiff entitled to recover; the entry of judgments suspended to await the filing of computations by the parties. Opinion by Judge Whaley. Concurring opinion by Judge Green.
The Commonwealth of Kentucky asked the death sentence today for Henry H. Denhardt, who has served as its Lieutenant Governor and as head of its National Guard.

Islam Auster, author of plays and short stories, testified yesterday as a defense witness in the damage suit brought by Albert Bein against Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., for the alleged plagiarism of Bein's play, "Little 01' Boy," in Edward Chodorov's "Mayor of Hell," a motion picture.

Mrs. Henry H. Sharples of Quebec, who is visiting here, announced today the engagement of her niece, Miss Muriel Gallagher, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Gallagher of New Haven,- Conn., to Charles Goodspeed Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Murdoch Lord of Sunnyfields, Worthington Valley, Baltimore.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, 228, Ireland, made short work of 'George Overly, 218, California, in the finish wrestling exhibition at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night. While 3,000 watched in amazement Casey lifted his rival aloft with a crotch and body hold and Referee George Bothner declared it over in 9 minutes 54 seconds.

The government has distributed land free to 1,700,000 Mexican families who are now living under a.communal agricultural system, the official newspaper, Nacional, states today. Counting four persons to a family, this means that 45 per cent of Mexico's population is living communally on its own lands.

The Department of Purchase was ordered to open its contracts for printing to bids from lithographers employing union labor in a decision handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman. Since 1934 the city has insisted on the presence of the Allied Printing Trades Council label on all its printing, thereby barring lithographers from competing, since their union employes are not members of the council.

There are 1,178 unsafe school buildings in the United States and its dependencies, according to a report of the Federal Administration of Publie Works submitted to the Senate today by Secretary Ickes.

Some sales of copper were reported yesterday as high as 14.325 cents a pound c. i. f., the European base ports. Early in the day the range was between 14.125 and 14.20 cents. On Saturday the export prices ranged between 13.90 and 14.25 cents.
The French franc rallied well yesterday on the strength of the improved political and financial outlook in France and the indications that the rise in sterling was being halted.
Whether jigsaw puzzles are really games and should be taxed under the sporting goods section of the 1932 Revenue Laws will be ruled upon by the Supreme Court, under an order issued today.

Jamaica was upset by Newtown yesterday, 4-2, at the Jamaica Stadium, but kept first place in the Queens P. S. A. L. race. It was the first league defeat in seven starts for Jamaica. Tony Hessler held the victors to three hits, but a four-run attack in the first was too much to overcome.

Ten carefully guarded prisoners accused of taking part in the kidnapping in 1933 of John J. O'Connell Jr. of Albany were arraigned today on Lindbergh law indictments charging kidnapping, conspiracy and extortion. They pleaded innocent.

AHLBORN--On Sunday, May 2, 1937, Clara Backus widow of Henry Ahlborn, in her eightieth year. Funeral service Tuesday, at 2:30 o'clock, at her residence, 70 Fairview Ave., Verona, N. J. Interment at the convenience of family. Kindly omit flowers. ANDERSON--At his home, 59 Fairview Ave., Verona, N. J., on Monday, May 3, 1937, Charles F., husband of Amelia Bloodgood Anderson, in his sixty-second year.
Major Victor W. B. Wales, U.S.A., has taken charge of the military academy in Guatemala, relieving Major John Davis, whose contract has expired.

Dr. John R. Mott, president of the World Alliance of the Y. M. C. A., and president of the International Missionary Council, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after seven months abroad. He said he was convinced there would not be another world war.
At their recent convention in Sarasota, Fla., the covered wagon nomads, otherwise known as trailer owners, gave thanks for a carefree life. Taxes? Some had to be paid for gasoline and registration.

Alexander Lamport, in 315 Central Park West; Albert M. Greenfield Co, Inc, Mrs. F. Staatstuttle, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, in 375 Park Ave; Norman J. Dicken, in 15 E 48th St; Roland K. Young, through Samuel L. Fuller, in 322 E 57th St; Henry B. Hall, in 111 E 75th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, broker.

Women executives operated the Arnold, Constable Co., Fifth Avenue department store, yesterday, which marked the beginning of "Stewart Week." Orders throughout the week will emanate from these women, headed by Miss ILaurette Yonkers, underwear buyer, who 'has taken over the duties of Isaac Liberman as president of the store, and Miss Pearl Friend, head of the misses' dress department, temporary successor of Meyer Liberman as vice president.
William S. Gubelmann, owner of the square rigger Seven Seas, which has been on a West Indies cruise, is ill. The cruise has been canceled and the yacht will sail for New York totomorrow.

Twenty-nine pieces of fire apparatus, "the finest equipment money can buy for the best fire-fighting force in the world," were commissioned yesterday by Mayor La Guardia after a spectacular demonstationn at the Battery sea wall had thrilled- more than 10,000 noon-hour watchers.

There is one thing which the local communists by general consent do better than anybody else, and that is filling Madison Square Garden. When the Communists call a mass meeting the headline writers automatically take a pencil and piece of paper and say Reds Fill Garden.

The Inland Steel Company announced yesterday that May 14 has been fixed definitely as the record date for stockholders entitled to receive rights to subscribe to one share of stock at $90 a share for each twenty shares held.

Miss Frances Taucher, 36 years old, who described herself as ,an importer, was taken to the Women's House of Detention from the West Side Court yesterday after Magistrate Dreyer had turned her over to Detective Coleman of .the West Forty-seventh Street Station

The Board of Tax Appeals determined today that there was no deficiency in the 1930 income taxes of William D. Thornton of the Anaconda Copper Company of New York. The Bureau of Internal Revenue had assessed $125,585 against him. Mr. Thornton contended that the bureau erred in disallowing $556,822 deducted for losses in 1930 in a stock syndicate corporation with the late John D. Ryan of New York.

" Money Mad," the revised "Bet Your Life," will be along just a week later than first planned-i. e., on Tuesday, May 18, instead of May 11, at the Forty-ninth Street. (If it holds to this schedule it will conflict with the premiere of "Sea Legs.") The delay is explained by cast changes, one of which may find Gladys. Feldman joining the company.

More than 200 entrants from fourteen universities and colleges are to compete in the Metropolitan Class B intercollegiate track and field championships at Randalls Island on Saturday afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Louis R. Oshins, business manager of the Kingsmen, who are conducting the meet.

Dawes Brothers, Inc., and members of the Dawes family individually today paid a total of $1,027,600 to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, pursuant to a Federal court order, as stockholders of the defunct Central Republic Bank and Trust Company.

A home run by Hank Greenberg with the bases full set off an attack that enabled the Tigers to defeat the White Sox, 12--9, today, sweep the series and Strengthen their hold on first place in the American League.

Edward Steinhardt, 24 years old, of Brooklyn, N. Y., was killed Saturday while skiing on Mount Puy de Sancy, 6,000-foot peak near Mont Dore Les Bains in Puy de Dome Department. Mr. Steinhardt was employed by a Paris banking house and left here Friday for a two-day holiday.

Speaking for the shipping interests of the port of New York, the Maritime Association yesterday urged the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries to enact legislation which would qualify graduates of State merchant marine schools for certificates as able bodied seamen upon conclusion of their training courses.

A probability that Mme. Helene Barth of Paris would inherit the entire estate of Colonel Anthony J. Drexel was indicated in Orphans' Court today when counsel for the executors told Judge Allen M. Stearne that the estate was not large enough to pay all legacies.

Declaring a common dividend of $1 a share for the first quarter, the directors of the General Motors Corporation, at a meeting that lasted two hours and a quarter yesterday afternoon, reorganized the high executive personnel of the company. The directors met in the General Motors Building here.

Mayor LA GUARDIA has begun an experiment in labor relations that will be closely and hopefully watched not only in New York City itself but in many other communities. He has selected a panel of 150 men and women who have agreed to act as arbitrators in labor disputes.

The marriage of Miss Jacqueline Tompers, daughter of Mrs. George U. Tompers of this place and the late Mr. Tompers, to Dr. H. Easton McMahon, son of Mrs. Henry E. McMahon, also of Garden City, and the late Mr. McMahon, will take place on the afternoon of June 19 in the Cathedral of the Incarnation here.

Dr. Way Sung New, aluminum of Harvard Medical School and one of China's outstanding surgeons, died today of a kidney malady at the age of 45. Dr. New, an orthopedic specialist, founded in 1928 the Orthopedic Hospital of Shanghai, the only institution of its kind in the Orient, of which he was superintendent and chief surgeon.

Government economies and budget-balancing were the chief topics of discussion in the halls of Congress today, and the movement for reducing the relief outlay for 1938 to $1,000,000,000, instead of the $1,500.000,000 asked by President Roosevelt, appeared to be gaining ground.

Surprised and indignant when he was informed that a man waiting trial before him for burglary had escaped from a prison van by cutting his way through its roof with handcuffs, County Judge Charles S. Colden of Queens criticized the Department of Correction.

An international race between the trotting champion of the United States and Europe's champion for a big side bet is expected on the Grand Circuit this Summer if a challenge recently issued by E. J. Baker of St. Charles, Ill., is accepted.

Another step in the concentration of business-machine concerns in lower Fourth Avenue was taken yesterday when the Burroughs Adding Machine Company leased five floors in the twenty-story Clarendon Building at 215 Fourth Avenue, southeast corner of Eighteenth Street.
President Roosevelt landed a tarpon at Port Aransas at 6:20 P. M. today, his first in coastal waters here. He hooked the silver Ring at 6 o'clock,' played him 20 minutes, and brought him to gaff.

Three dual meets have been scheduled for City College's varsity track and field team for the outdoor season. Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics, announced yesterday. The first will be with R. P. I. in Troy on Saturday, after which Fordham and St. John's will be engaged at home.

Benjamin F. Mathias of 188 East Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, who won the Distinguished Service Cross while with the Sixth Ammunition Train at the Meuse-Argonne in the World War, died Sunday in the Naval Hospital, Brooklyn, after a fortnight's illness, at the age of 48.
Tomorrow at Chateau de Cande, seven miles from here, the Duke of Windsor will meet again the woman he loves and for whom he abandoned his empire, his crowns and his people.

A proclamation bringing the Canadian National Railways Capital-Revision Act into operation as from May 1 was issued tonight. The law, passed at the recent session of Parliament, provides for revision of the capital structure and the accounting set-up of the government-owned railway.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petition Filed-Against PIKE-KAHN CO., INC., fur manufacturers, 350 Seventh Ave. -- By Rudolph Edelson for $250; Brickner Bernfeld, Inc., $250; Pelto Trading Co., $250. Petitions Filed-By WILLIAM J. ADAMS, Clerk, 88 W. 169th St.--Liabilities $1,159; no assets except insurance. WILLIAM FELTERMAN JR., engineer, Prescott Rd., White Plains--Liabilities $19.574; assets $150 plus insurance.
A request that the House Naval Affairs Committee speed consideration of the Senate-approved Walsh bill for protection of naval fuel oil reserves was made by the Navy Department today.

The existence and validity of the Roosevelt-Litvinoff agreement, reached three and a half years ago by the President and the Commissaor of Foreign Affairs of the Soviet Republic, today were formally recognized by the Supreme Court when the justices decided that the United States was legally qualified to sue

Reinstatement John N. Klein is reinstated at a patrolman, fifth grade, effective May 1, subject to the approval of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, the interval between July 23, 1936, the date upon which he resigned without fault or delinquency on his part, and the date of reinstatement, is not to be counted as service in the Police Department. He is assigned to the 42d Precinct.

William Przylylowice of the Catholic Youth Organization of New York knocked out William Wall of the East Side A. C. of Philadelphia in the second round of the heavyweight special contest of the amateur boxing program at the New York Athletic Club last night.

By a strictly partisan vote of 10 to 9, Senate Republicans defeated tonight a resolution to seat Jesse D. Ludlum, a Democrat, as the member from Cape May County and then, by the same vote, adopted a resolution calling a special election to fill the vacancy caused
Boarding houses provide a fruitful source of material for novelists and play-wrights, and Sheila Donisthorpe makes abundant use of it in "Guests at Lancaster Gate," produced at the Q Theatre tonight.

Arthur Flynn, tenor, appeared in recital at the Town Hall last night. He sang an opening Italian group by Torelli, Caldara and Durante. Then came songs in English by Rubinstein and Grieg, followed by arias from "L'Elisir d'Amore," "Tosca" and "Rigoletto."
Rights to subscribe to new common stock of the Hupp Motor Car Corporation were mailed to holders on Saturday, according to an announcement by Thomas Bradley, president.

Stores that have been outspoken in opposition to the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Practice Act, will reverse their views when they realize the benefits which such legislation brings to retailers, Louis E. Golan, vice president in charge of sales and advertising for the Schenley Products Company, predicted yesterday before 350 members of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., at their weekly luncheon meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.
Despite the Supreme Court validation of the National Labor Relations Act, coal miners who join locals of the United Mine Workers of America in Harlan County, Ky.,

The merger voted last March by two Brooklyn Congregational churches was formally approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lewis L. Fawcett in Brooklyn. The churches are the Central Congrenational, of which the late Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman was pastor, on Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, and St. Paul's, on Sterling Place near New York Avenue.

Women athletes of New York University were honored last night at the thirteenth annual dinner given by the Women's Athletic Association of the university at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Six special awards for distinguished service and thirtyeight varsity letters were given to members of the field hockey, basketball, swimming, fencing and tennis combinations.

With every member of the team having a hand in the scoring, the Century Country Club stepped out in the lead in the Westchester County women's interclub golf matches over the rolling green fairways of the Century Club today. Runner-up a year ago to Innis Arden in the Class A tournament, the home forces proceeded to start the new season in rousing fashion by taking a two-point margin on their nearest pursuers.
The Duke of Windsor, all smiles and happier than at any time since he gave up the throne of the British Empire, sped tonight aboard an express train to the arms of "the woman I love."

Governor Hurley directed the Commissioner of Public Safety, Paul G. Kirk, today to offer the assistance of his department to the Plymouth police in tracking down the vandals who painted Plymouth Rock red on May Day.

Mrs. Genevieve Johnson's alimony sit-down strike accelerated business today in this Northern Colorado sugar-producing community. Merchants reported gains from out-of-towners who came to see Mrs. Johnson sit in her rocking chair with the announced intention of remaining in front of his home until her estranged husband Ralph, pays her $6.70 a week.

Governor Lehman vetoed today a bill which would have allowed employes of the State to retire at the age of 55. In disapproving the measure, Governor Lehman cited a recommendation of the State Pension Commission and added:

A recapitulation by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, of the number of WPA employes affected by Harry L. Hopkins's order to reduce non-relief personnel and limit wages in excess of the security scale, showed yesterday that 2,508 non - relief workers had been dropped from the rolls and 16,086 other workers had had their wages cut.

The Ver Rev. Noble Cilley Powell will be installed as dean of the National Episcopal Cathedral, Washington, D. C., Thursday, which is Ascension Day. He will also become warden of the College of Preachers, which is on the cathedral grounds.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Allegra Knapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Knapp of Bayside, Queens, to James Bain Brickell, son of Mrs. Charles C. B. Brickell of Miami, Fla., and the late Mr. Brickell. The ceremony will be performed on May 24 in All Saints Episcopal Church, Bayside, by the rector, the Rev. Richard Trapnell, and will be followed by a reception at the Bayside Yacht Club.

Mrs. James Roosevelt, mother of the President, and Mrs. S. William Blood, president of the J. Evans Brown Memorial Foundation, "planted" two "coronation trees" in the Shakespeare Garden in Central Park, just east of the West Drive at Eightieth Street, shortly after noon yesterday.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had: CUSTOMS 4008-S. S. Kresge Co. v. United States. Opinion by Judge Graham. The United States Customs Court judgment is reversed. 4021-Maple Leaf Petroleum, Ltd., v. United States. Opinion by Judge Bland. The United States Customs Court judgment is affirmed.

Columbia's undefeated tennis team won its fifth match of the season yesterday by defeating St. John's, 8 to 1, on the South Field. courts. The Lions swept all of the six singles matches and won two of the three doubles.

Informed sources said today that poor health probably would force Marshal Rodolfo Graziani to give up his post as Viceroy of Ethiopia. These. sources said the report had not been confirmed nor denied but it was admitted the wounds received by Marshal Graziani when a bomb was thrown at him and other officials in Addis Ababa last February had undermined his health.

Christian Belle, French Consul-General in New York, will make a luncheon address at 12:30 today to the combined Lions Clubs in the Hotel Astor, marking Paris Exposition Week, which was proclaimed by Mayor La Guardia.

Four jurors were chosen yesterday at the re-trial of Louis Luckman on a charge of perjuring himself before the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case. On April 11 another blue-ribbon jury disagreed as to Luckman's guilt after deliberating more than ten hours.

The use of fictitious price markings and of other false representations was alleged by the Federal Trade Commission today in a complaint against the Gotham Sales Company, Inc., and its officers, Harry J. Alfred, Max Martin and Alexander Gottsegen, of 37 Union Square, New York.

The Supreme Court many hand down findings on the old age and unemployment insurance provisions of the Social Security Act by Monday, May 17, it was indicated today. The justices will hear arguments on the old age features in the next few days. Those on unemployment insurance already have been heard.
With actors passing through picket lines unmolested, Hollywood studios continued operation despite a strike of 6,000 film technicians, whose leaders charged the use of strike-breakers. Page 1.

With the public debt rapidly approaching the $35,000,000,000 mark, the Federal Government ended the tenth month of its 1937 fiscal year with a deficit of $2,154,685,287 on April 30, the Treasury announced today.

The air record from Australia to England was lowered by more than a full day today when H. F. Broadbent, Australian distance flier, landed at Lympne Airport, just 6 days, 10 hours and 55 minutes after he had left Australia.

New York City will get a refund of $88,435 on taxes it paid for water supply property in Westchester, under a settlement with the city of Yonkers which was announced yesterday by George S. Parsons, head of the water supply division of the Law Department.
Women sit-down strikers at the Puerto Rican-American Tobacco Company's plant here missed lunch today and in about two hours hunger ended the strike which had begun only this morning.
William C. Appleton, who has been sales manager, was elected president of the Viscose Company at the annual meeting at Marcus Hook, Pa., yesterday, it was annnounced here last night.

Jean Cohen, 23 years old, of 319 Hewes Street, Brooklyn, went on trial yesterday before Kings County Judge George W. Martin and a jury on a first-degree manslaughter indictment charging her with fatally stabbing Frank Di Blasi, 24 years old, of 16 Garden Street, Brooklyn, on May 2, 1936, at Morrell and Debevoise Streets, Brooklyn. The trial will continue today.

An application of a South American subsidiary of the Royal Dutch Air Lines for permission to extend a line across the Caribbean from Curacao to Miami by way of Portau-Prince, Haiti, has been rejected by the Department of Commerce.
Net earnings of the Coca-Cola Company for the first three months of this year amounted to $3,803,289 after Federal income taxes and dividend requirements on the Class A stock.
Pittsburgh at Brooklyn-Blanton vs. Henshaw. St. Louis at Boston-Warneke vs. Lanning or Fette. Cincinnati at New York--Hollingsworth vs. Hubbell. Chicago at Philadelphia-Shoun vs. Mulcahy.

When Father Divine failed to appear in answer to a summons, Miss Jessie V. Birdsall, a former follower of the Negro evangelist, obtained by default a judgment against him for $2,739.20 in City Court yesterday.

The hazards of gathering meteorological data on Elsmere Land were told by Captain O. J. MacGregor last night at the Spring meeting of the American Polar Society in Roosevelt Memorial Hall in the American Museum of Natural History.
Rowland B. Mahany, who represented a Buffalo district in Congress as a Republican from 1895 to 1899, died yesterday at the age of 73. He was Minister to Ecuador in 1892.

In the Supreme Court of the United States, Frank C. Myers, Seward A. Miller, Robert J. Fitzsimmons, James P. Farrell and Samuel J. Silverman, of New York, were admitted to practice today and the following proceeding were had: 659--Cincinnati Soap Co., petr., v. United States. On writ of cert. to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals,

Robert Conklin, former Sheriff or Bergen County, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 75. For years Mr. Conklin was a figure in the Democratic party of the county, where he was Sheriff from 1910 to 1913.

Dr. C. T. Wang sailed this morning on the liner President Hoover for San Francisco en route to Washington, where he will succeed Dr. Alfred Sze as China's Ambassador. A large group of Atnericans, headed by Consul General Clarence Gauss, and many prominent Chinese boarded three special launches and accompanied Dr. Wang aboard the ship to say farewells.

A, plan of reorganization has been promulgated by a bondholders' protective committee for holders of the Philip Schuyler Corporation 6 per cent certificates. Copies of the prospectus with respect to certificates of deposit issuable in exchange for these certificates can be obtained from W. H. Eisenhut,

Miss Ada Mosby, daughter of the famous Confederate cavalry commander of the Mosby Rangers and who for twentythree years was superintendent of the James L. Kernan Hospital for Crippled Children here, died today at the age of 65.
Whopper, with 127 pounds, tops the list of probable starters in the $7,500 added a sixteenth, which will be the feature of the closing day at Jamaica Saturday.

Buyers in all the principal carpet-producing centers in Iran made heavy purchases during the period from Jan. 1 to Feb. 18, particularly during the Iranian month which extends from Jan. 21 to Feb. 19, according to American Vice Consul Earl T. Crain, Teheran, in a report made public by the Department of Commerce.

The text of The Baltimore Sun' editorial "The Opposition," which appeared on Nov. 6, 1936, and which was instrumental in winning the. Pulitzer Prize for John W Owene follows: The careful reader may have observed in the recent campaign one important fact which was not mentioned in public discussions. It is the fact that no spokesman of the Republican party made the front page in the regular run of things save Mr. Landon himself.

Buying activity for Summer in the wholesale markets increased here yesterday, but the volume ran somewhat under expectations due mainly to the unsettled weather conditions last week. However, reports indicated that the fairly heavy retail inventories of apparel and accessories are being steadily reduced and that with the completion of clearances this week the way will be paved for more active concentration on Summer lines.

Miss Lola Jane Maloney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elwood L. Maloney of Maplewood, has selected June 17 as the date of her wedding to Theodore Bradley Pugh, son. of Mr. and Mrs. Nevitt J. Pugh of Beckley, W. Va. The ceremony will be performed in the evening in Prospect Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Nelson Butz. A reception will follow at Maplewood Country Club.

Mrs. J. F. P. Des Garennes of Northport was elected regent of Ketewamoke Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, at the annual meeting held in the Chapter House on Nassau Avenue, Huntington, this afternoon.

The New York state Economic Council, through Merwin K. Hart, its president, urged yesterday the defeat of the Doyle-Neustein labor bill, now before the Legislature. In letters to Senator John J. Dunnigan and Speaker Oswald D. Heck, Mr. Hart declared that some of the provisions of the bill were more severe than the Federal Wagner Act.

The heart of the problem of balancing the national budget lies in the question of relief, and in the matter of relief there are many who believe that the Federal Government is being asked to carry too large a share of the burden.
Pope Pius is completing a "white book" to show that the German Government and not the Vatican has violated the Catholic Church's concordant with the Reich, prelates said tonight.

Mrs. Edward L. Hunt gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Mrs. Thomas T. Gaunt and Mrs. J. Allen Townsend, who are sailing today on the Queen Mary. Other guests were Mrs. Robert S. Granniss, Mrs. George H. Ingalls, Miss Jane Randolph, Mrs. Orin B. Mitcham, Miss Lucy Howe and Mrs. Clark Potter Read.
CHILD WORKERS IN AMERICA, by Katherine DuPre Lumpkin and Dorothy Douglas. (McBride, $3.50) On child labor. THE IRISH COUNTRYMAN, by Conrad M. Arensberg, (Macmillan, $3.) An anthropological study.

Representatives of New York shipping interests left for Washin on last night to attend the opening today of the hearing before the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries on a bill to change the system of fixing Panama Canal tolls. The bill, which was drafted at the request of President Roosevelt, is based on a report made by a special committee that went to the Canal last year and studied conditions.

Miss Helen Elizabeth Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Jones of South Orange, has chosen June 25 as the date of her wedding to Daniel Geary Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Lewis of South Orange. The ceremony will take place in Hillside Presbyterian Church, Orange.

For the first time since Hungary regained her independence Austrian , colors flew today over the former Hapsburg palace here. For the first time, also, the strains of the Austrian Imperial anthem, "Gott Erhalte,"

Appearing before the House Agriculture Committee the other day, Secretary HuLL urged the committee to reconsider its recent action in altering the basis of the sugar import quotas. His statement was another example of the balance, clarity and thoroughness that distinguish his state papers.

Stockholders of the Crane Company, at a special meeting in Chicago yesterday, approved the plan to refund the preferred stock by calling the 7 per cent issue for retirement at $110 and $5.25 a share of cumulative dividends.

The Massachusetts birth rate in 1936 was the lowest in nearly 100 years of vital statistics recording, Frederic W. Cook, Secretary of State, today announced. The birth rate last year, he said, was 14.1 per 1,000 population. lowest since 1841.

Bill Harris, veteran right-hander, kept fifteen Jersey City hits fairly well scattered today to give the Buffalo Bisons a 9-to-4 victory and a 2-to-1 edge in the series. Buffalo was held in check from the fifth inning on by Stiles after Jersey City rallied for three runs to tie the' score.

The American Committee for Spanish Relief, which maintains headquarters in New York, was declared by the Spanish Embassy Yesterday to be "identified with the cause represented by the Robels in Spain."

William Post Duvall, former assistant treasurer and assistant secretary of the Mercantile Trust Company, pleaded guilty today to charges of larceny and false banking entries, a shortage in his accounts of $47,500 during twenty-five years. He was sentenced by Judge Rowland Adams to three years in jail.

The schedule for the Eastern Intercollegiate Golf Association, providing for thirty dual matches and setting dates for championship play-offs, was released today by Asa S. Bushnell, executive secretary of the association and graduate manager of athletics at Princeton University.

A plan for a satellite 500-family development of one and two-family houses similar to the Resettlement Administration's development at Greenbelt, Md., now nearing completion, to be erected on an inexpensive site in Queens or outlying Brooklyn, was divulged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at a slum conference in Brooklyn.

Hugh J. Duncan Pritchard of Norwalk, Conn., who had been president of the Utility Equities Corporation since 1928, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital, Eighty-seventh Street and East End Avenue. He was born in Galveston, Texas, sixty-two years ago.

The thirty-seventh annual championship tournament of the American Bowling Congress passed into history last night. Since the wintry evening of March 10--just fifty-six days ago--when Mayor La Guardia opened the classic at the 212th Coast Artillery Armory, until the final squad left the lanes last night at 6:30, some 22,000 keglers fired away at the tenpins to gain glory and gold.

The dishwasher whom the police have been seeking in connection with the. killing of Irene Wadas, 25-year-old waitress found slashed to death in the vestibule of her home at 628 West 114th Street early on April 22, was in their custody yesterday.

Dissatisfied with subcommittee changes in the administration's Sugar Control Bill, President Roosevelt has indicated to associates in the executive branch and to some Congressional leaders that he will veto the measure and scrap the entire sugar quota system rather than permit it to become law in its present form.

Their homes threatened by a destructive brush fire raging along a belt seven miles long and one mile wide, 300 residents of this community of 1,500 bungalows were ordered evacuated tonight after efforts of 500 volunteer firemen and 200 private citizens had failed to halt the advance of the flames.

THE master of ceremonies at the convivial smoker cleared his throat and said in a threatening voice: "We will now hear from one of the speakers of the evening, Mr. Steve Owen, coach and manager of the New York Football Giants." So the audience heard from stout Steve. But they didn't hear the half of it.

They put the pressure on the Yankees in earnest today and the result was an explosion that almost blew the Tigers right out of their ball park. A devastating six-run blast in the third inning, a rather ornamental run by Frankie Crosetti in the ninth and sundry other eruptions by Signors Joseph DiMaggio and Anthony Lazzeri ended with Mickey Cochrane's Detroiters and a crowd of 13,500 virtually prostrated.

The Boston Red Sox slugged out an 11-6 victory over the'Browns today in the first of a three-game series, with home runs for both sides helping the heavy scoring. The Browns used three pitchers. The Red Sox scored eight runs off Julio Bonetti and three more off Earl Caldwell on Fabian Gaffke's home run with two on.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Heinrich Bruening, Chancellor of Germany from 1930 to 1932, has received an appointment to the Harvard faculty, effective in September, and will lecture on government. He will also be a tutor in the Division of History, Economics and Government.

Reaping Reward, considered the West's main hope to turn back the principal Eastern challenger, War Admiral, in the Kentucky Derby. was defeated at Churchill Downs today by Dellor. Reaping Reward thus joins Pompoon, Fairy Hill and others in partial eclipse for the prize of $50,000 added to be run for at a mile and a quarter on Saturday.

The American Bridge Company has taken an order for 2,750 tons of shapes and plates for steel dam gates in Arizona and California, 1,400 tons for a bridge in Pennsylvania, 1,425 tons for bridges at Cleveland and at Alexandria, Va., and 1,000 tons for a mill building at Canton, Ohio.

The New York Light Opera Guild presented Victor Herbert's operetta, "Mlle. Modiste," last night at the Venice Theatre. Lillian Kraff was the Fifi and Normon Durask the Etienne. Other important roles were taken by Marjorie Monks (Fanchette), Florence Schilling (Nanette), Herbert Caldwell (Rene), Gerry Raph (Mme. Cecile), Inez Clark (Marie Louise),
Behind Fred Fussell's three-hit pitching, the Chiefs closed their first home stand today with an 8-0 victory over the Montreal Royals, giving them a 3-1 edge in the series.

Mrs. Cecelia J. Ochs, wife of Ernest Ochs, insurance broker of New York and Brightwaters, died yesterday at her home here of a heart attack. She was 56 years old. Her father, the late Oscar L. Schwencke, was a well-known Long Island real estate developer.
The new mainsail of Gerard B. Lambert's Class J sloop Yankee, one of the contenders for the honor of defending the America's Cup this Summer, doesn't fit exactly, it was learned today.

Scoring in every chukker, a powerful Lawrencevile School polo team galloped to an easy 13-3 victory over the Princeton Freshmen today on Devereux Field for its second consecutive triumph of the outdoor season. The contest opened the Nassau Yearings' season.

How and when the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Simpson will be married is not settled yet, but tonight these two romantic lovers are at least once more together and free to get married when and where they may decide.
A list of scholarships, of which twelve are available to freshmen entering Fordham College next Sepmember, was announced yesterday by Fordham University.

W. Forbes Morgan, president of C the Distilled Spirits Institute, Inc., and former treasurer of the Democratic National Campaign Committee, who died in Columbus, Ohio, on April 20, left an estate of less than $10,000. This was learned yester- ai day when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

Scatched out of yesterday's fifth race, when she was scheduled to carry the comparatively light burden of 102 pounds, F. L. Flanders's Phlox went postward at Narragansett today with 108 pounds up and captured the Block Island Purse at six furlongs for 3-year-olds.

A strike of operating workers of Electric Ferries, Inc., was ended yesterday afternoon after having tied up the company's three ferryboats operating between Weehawken and Twenty-third Street, Manhattan, for twenty-four hours. The men returned to work at 5 P. M. yesterday.

After a warm debate today in which a lobbyist was ejected from the floor, the Assembly passed by a vote of 110 to 35 a bill sponsored by Minority Leader Steingut to facilitate the promotion of substitute teachers to regular positions in the New York City schools.

The marriage of Miss R. Cordelia Gurnee, daughter of Mrs. Burgess Gurnee of this city and the late Walter S. Gurnee, to Frederick L. Stagg of New York and La Isla, Quito, Ecuador, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, 322 East Fifty-seventh Street. The Rev. Lester L. Riley, rector of the Zion Protestant Episcopal Church in Douglaston, Queens, performed the ceremony in the presence of near relatives.

Action to standardize discount terms at 8-10 E. O. M., to eliminate volume discounts and to ban advertising allowances to retailers has been taken by the infants' and children's knitwear division of the National Knitted Outerwear Association in fair trade practice rules covering eight major provisions, which became effective yesterday.

Mrs. Helen K. Harper of Great thefts. Neck pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a forgery charge to cover two indictments in the theft of $53,000 from the HoldMIeredith Lumber Company, at 25 East Forty-second Street, of which she was the treasurer and bookkeeper. Judge Donnellan remanded mention for sentence May 14.

Mrs. Harriet Berry Potter, mother of William C. Potter, chairman of the board of directors of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Monday at her Winter Park (Fla.) home, after an illness of several months. Mrs. Potter, a descendant of American settlers, was 88 years old.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $4,504,988,092 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. The average price of all listed stocks on May 1 was $41.80 a share, compared with $45.26 at the beginning of April.

About 1,800 persons attended the bundle party given by Thrift House last night at the Hotel Commodore. Admission to the affair, marking the fourth anniversary of the organization, was a bundle of old clothes or other salable merchandise.
James J. Braddock, world's heavyweight champion, put on his gloves today for the first time since coming to his training camp here and sparred four rounds.

Miss Anne Elizabeth Mulligan of Westfield, N. J., daughter of John A. Mulligan of Brooklyn, was married here yesterday afternoon to Walter Pierre Wells, son of former Assemblyman and Mrs. John Walter Wells of Coudersport, Pa., in the chapel of All Saints, Trinity Church. by the Rev. Lewis Nichols.

The Pullman Company, parlor and sleeping car operating subsidiary of Pullman, Inc., has written off virtually all its wooden or part-wooden cars, at a cost of $7,050,675 to initial surplus, Pullman, Inc., reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

John Corigliano will be concertmaster of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra during the Stadium concerts this Summer, it was announced yesterday. Mishel Piastro, regular concertmaster of the orchestra, will then be on tour in the Orient.

Five of the largest and fastest Atlantic liners sailed yesterday and this morning, carrying 5,290 passengers, the largest number to leave for Europe in a twenty-four-hour period since 1929. They were the last steamships that would arrive in England in time for the passengers to see the coronation. Had it not been for heavy cancellation the total would have reached 6,000, according to officials of the lines.
High tide on the Kennebec River at approximately 1:30 P. M. next Tuesday is expected to see Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger take her maiden dip, Bath Iron Works officials said today.

John Dioguardi and James Plumeri, who were described as the heads of the trucking racket in the garment industry when they were arrested March 19 by representatives of the staff of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, were named yesterday in a superseding indictment charging them with conspiracy, extortion, assault and malicious mischief.

The Senate was in recess. Its Naval Affairs Committee heard testimony in support of the bill for construction of auxiliary vessels, the Banking and Currency Committee heard Chairman Eccles of the Federal Reserve Board on monetary problems, the Judiciary Committee continued consideration of the Courts Reorganization Bill, and the La Follette subcommittee heard testimony of alleged lawlessness in Harlan County, Ky.

The national council of the International Seamen's Uniion will confer today in Chicago on the demands of insurgents in its Atlantic Coast membership for an election to determine the union bargaining agency on ships of the International Mercantile Marine Company.

The opposing sides in the hotel strike here maintained an inactive siege today. From the office of J. J. Schlaepfer, spokesman for the operators of sixteen strikebound hotels, came the statement: "There is nothing doing here." Union leaders said:

An elderly organ grinder, arraigned yesterday in Flatbush court for soliciting alms, proved to be a veritable walking bank. The police found sewed in his pockets four tobacco cans containing $1 bills and more than 500 pennies, the entire hoard amounting to $189.29.

Carl Hubbell yesterday became the first pitcher in twenty-five years to score nineteen straight victories in major league championship ball games, but the matchless master of the screwball found out about it indirectly. He wasn't on the scene when the victory was cinched. He had been shelled out of a game for the first time since last July 26.

Just before General Sessions Judge Donnellan imposed a sentence of fifteen years to life in prison yesterday on David MacLevy, 62 years old, a blind habitual criminal with one of the most remarkable careers ever brought to light in that court, MacLevy expressed an intention at the bar to deliver an oration against society.

A third party has entered the lists of the coming election of officers for the Actors Equity Association. It is headed by E. J. Blunkall, an actor who at one time was the liaison officer between Equity and the Federal Theatre Project and who now is rehearsing the role of the Priest in Anne Nichols's revival of her "Abie's Irish Rose."

So much of paragraph 3, Special Orders 27. 1937, pertaining to 1st Lt. Everard A. Elledge, Engr.-Res., is amended to read "368th Engineers (GS)." So much of paragraph 9, Special Orders 27, April 27, 1937, as reads "Lt.-Col. John D. Groves, FA-Res.," is amended to read "Colonel John D. Groves, FA-Res."

A lecture on the importance of the word "if" was delivered yesterday to the Supreme Court jury trying a $250,000 libel suit brought by Curtis B. Dall, former son-in-law of President Roosevelt, against the magazine Time.

Active purchasing increased yesterday at the Fall show of the Shoe Fashion Guild of America at the Hotel Biltmore, with buyer registrations again notably heavy. Many of the "lookers" turned into buyers, but there were no reports of extremely heavy orders being placed. Similar reports were made at the showing of cheaper lines of shoes at the McAlpin and New Yorker Hotels.

The only woman polar explorer, Miss Louise Boyd, whose Arctic explorations in the last ten years have rivaled those conducted by men, will sail for Norway today aboard the Norwegian American liner Bergensfjord to start another expedition to Greenland waters. An attempt will be made to locate the undersea shelf believed to connect northeast Greenland and Spitsbergen.

Many luncheon parties were given yesterday in connection with the fashion show entitled "Calling All Models" held in the Caprice Room of the Weylin to assist the Girls Service League. Young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons were manikins in the revue and participated in a contest for which awards were made for beauty, charm, poise, grace and perfection of costumes.

Six men who were convicted of second-degree manslaughter as a result of -the collapse of an apartment house at 112 East Mosholu Parkway South last June 19, in which eighteen workmen died, were sentenced yesterday by Judge Lester W. Patterson in Bronx County Court. Two of them received susended sentences.

The Board of Aldermen moved yesterday to name the upper part of Times Square for Father Francis J. Duffy, wartime chaplain of the 165th Infantry and pastor of Holy Cross Church in West Forty-second Street near Ninth Avenue. Alderman John J. Mahoney and Minority Leader Thomas J. Curran, who represent the district, introduced an ordinance jointly for the change.

Masons of New York State, observing the two hundredth anniversary of Freemasonry in the State, heard Grand Master Jacob Charles Klinck open their annual meeting yesterday with a defense of Masons "persecuted even unto death" In many parts of the world, and a recommendation to Masonic lodges to study social questions and set up committees on unemployment.

Loomis J. Grossman sold to an investor the six-story elevator apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 94-26 Thirty-fourth Road; Jackson Heights. There are fifty-eight apartments in the building, which was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $174,000 for five years at 4.A per cent. Low Gross, Inc., negotiated the sale and J. Cohen, attorney, represented the buyer.

The general level of retail food prices rose fractionally in the month ended on April 13, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1923-25 average as 100, rose to 85.6 from 85.4 on March 16. On April 21, 1936, it was 79.7.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Aileen Timothy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William George Newton Timothy of 955 Park Avenue, formerly of Bryn Mawr, Pa., to Phillips Roome Turnbull of this city and Montclair.

Investors and operators were active yesterday in trading involving housing properties in the Bronx. The five-and-a-half-story walk-up for forty-seven families at 1,465 Nelson Avenue, southwest corner of 172d Street, was purchased by Isadore B. Geller, operator, who paid cash over a first mortgage of $131,000 at 4 1/2 per cent held by the New York Life Insurance Company.
Germany, through the mouth of her Ambassador to London, today opposed any ban on the bombing of undefended towns in Spain.

Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, urged bankers today to save profits for the next depression, instead of paying larger dividends on bank stocks. In a speech prepared for delivery at the annual convention of the South Carolina Bankers Association he said that "values must fluctuate in a competitive business system."

The late Sir Lindsay Parkinson's Merry Mathew today ran away with the Chester Vase, finishing Four lengths ahead of Sir Victor Sassoon' Renardo. Sir Frederick Eley's Winnebar, a length behind Renardo, was third in the field of fifteen.

Irving School, defending champion of the Eastern Private School Baseball League, captured its initial league game today on the home field by defeating Trinity School, 4 to 0. Marciniak shut out the losers with one hit, while Irving nicked Scully for eight.

Milbank Co., which is headed by Jeremiah Milbank, president of the Provident Loan Society, retained its position as the largest stockholder in the Southern Railway, the report of the line to the Interstate Commerce Commission for 1936 disclosed yesterday.

The board of trustees of Cornell University has established the "Todd Chair of Chemistry," honoring George W. Todd and Grace L. Todd of Rochester. Announcing the new professorship President Farrand stated:

The maintenance of general missionary work in outlying and neglected parts of the world was termed yesterday one of the church's gravest problems by members of the Women's Auxiliary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, Diocese of New York, at their annual meeting at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Chicago nicked four Philadelphia pitchers for nineteen hits and a 14to-7 victory today before 3,000 fans. Trailing by 4-3 at the start of the seventh the Cubs knocked Mulcahy out of the box and scored six runs to clinch the victory. In the next inning they amassed five more runs on home runs by Collins, Marty and Bottarini, combined with three singles and a two-bagger.
President Roosevelt shifted the scene of his quest for tarpon today and this afternoon fished with

Adults and younger members of the parish of St. James Church are combining their efforts toward the success of the annual Spring fete in aid of the missions and social service work of the parish, which will be held tomorrow afternoon at the Plaza.

Prices of most commodity futures improved moderately in quiet trading yesterday. Silk and hide futures declined slightly. On the cash markets, corn, cotton, cocoa and rubber rose, while wheat, rye, butter, silk, tin and eggs declined.

Pope Pius XI told Adolf Hitler today that the Catholic Church must be left free to fulfill its mission in Nazi Germany. The Pontiff's reply to the recent German note, which itself was a reply to the Pope's pre-Easter encyclical accusing the German Government of violating the 1933 Church-State concordat, was delivered by Cardinal Pacelli, Papal Secretary of State, to the German Ambassador to the Holy See, Diego von Bergen.

After deliberating only forty minutes a Kings County jury returned a verdict of not guilty yesterday in the case of Jean Cohen, 23 years old, of 319 Hewes Street, Brooklyn, tried on first degree manslaughter in the fatal stabbing of Frank Di Blasi, 24 years old,

The longest route for an excursion of its kind will be covered by a special train that will leave the Pennsylvania Station on May 16, carrying a party that will inspect the Pennsylvania Railroad's shops at Altoona, Pa.

The Children's Aid Society, which today receives the portrait of WILLIAM CHURCH OSBORN, marking the completion of thirty-five years as its president, has initiated so many special reforms and pioneer services in behalf of underprivileged children that it deserves to be called The Society of Firsts.

Madison's baseball team defeated New Utrecht, 5 to 1, yesterday at the Bay Ridge Oval to maintain its grip on first place in the Brooklyn B group of the P. S. A. L. race. Ed Mele, hurling for the winners, kept five blows scattered and struck out eleven.

Two more apartment houses are to be erected in the Bronx, one on the Grand Concourse at the southwest corner of 182d Street and the other on Mosholu Parkway North on the southeast corner of 206th Street, according to building plans filed yesterday.
Miss Dorothy Irene Peterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Peterson of this place, has chosen June 19 as the date of her marriage to Jean Paul Deusinger, also of Nutley.

American shipyards are building 218 ships of 310,051 tons, according to the monthly report of the American Bureau of Shipping issued yesterday. This represents an increase North of eighty ships and 147,758 tons over the totals reported a year ago.

With Premier Benito Mussolini watching them, cheering Deputies of the Italian Parliament tonight passed his 5,500,000,000 lire national defense budget for 1937-38, an increase of 727,000,000 lire over the 1936-37 defense expenditures.
The "popular prize" in the Corcoran Gallery of Art fifteenth biennial exhibition of contemporary American paintings was awarded today to Feodor Zakharov of New York for his painting "Ballerina."

Wearing ceremonial robes over their ordinary clothing, King George and Queen Elizabeth, with the officers of state who will be in personal attendance on them, rehearsed today for an hour and a half their parts in the coronation ceremonies of May 12.

Increased car registration, construction of more than 30,000 miles of new roads last year and a mounting volume of tourist service inquiries are among the reasons why all the leading gas and oil companies have sharply increased their advertising budgets this year.

Mrs. Carl Raymond Gray of Omaha, Neb., the 67-year-old wife of the president of the Union Pacific Railroad and who was chosen as "The American Mother of 1937" by the Golden Rule Foundation, arrived here yesterday.

The Allegheny Singers, a cappella chorus of fifty mixed voices from Allegheny College, Meadville, Pa., were heard in a concert of its annual Spring tour last night at the Town Hall. Morten J. Luvaas conducted.

Eric Seelig, German middleweight. who was to have opposed Harry Balsamo of Harlem in the tenround feature bout at the Hippodrome tonight, was suddenly taken ill yesterday and Promotor Mike Jacobs called off the entire card.

Secretary Perkins appealed to labor and management today to cooperate in eliminating strikes and lockouts and then expressed her opposition to amendment of the Wagner Labor Relations Act to guarantee rights of employers, until more experience with its operation was had or until evidence appeared that it worked injustices upon employers.

Giuseppe Cosulich of the Italian Lines has sold to Henry Nires, attorney and certified public accountant, the French Provincial chateau at 4,720 Grosvenor Avenue in the Fieldston section of the West Bronx. Erected by the seller at a cost of $100,000, the residence occupies a plot 119 by 126 feet at a high point in the development.

Hank Barber, 220, Boston, and Wally Dusek, 220, Omaha, wrestled to a draw in the feature finish wrestling match before 1,000 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Referee Arthur Berger counted both out after they had fallen from the ring.

The exhibition of paintings suitable for Summer use in decoration now current at the Decorators Club Gallery, 745 Fifth Avenue, has been extended until May 15. A. D. Gruskin, director of the Midtown Galleries, announces that the attendance for the recent exhibition of Paul Cadmus paintings reached the 7,000 mark, with visitors still asking to see the paintings. Twenty-six paintings,

Funeral services for Major Lindell T. Bates, O. R. C., international lawyer and writer and member of an old Colonial family, who died at London on April 13, were held yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.
Mrs. Diego Suares of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Barbara Field, to Anthony A. Bliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius N. Bliss of New York and Westbury, L. I.

An action to have all but a small strip of its property at 29 East Thirty-sixth Street declared tax-exempt was started in Supreme Court yesterday by the Pierpont Morgan Library. It bases its claim for exemption on the fact that it is a library.

Mr. and Mrs. Grover Whalen, with Mr. and Mrs. Percy S. Straus, Admiral Standley Voorhees and others connected with the New York World's Fair of 1939 were the guests this evening at a dinner given by Raymond Laurent,

Governor Richard C. McMullen said today that a special session of the Legislature would be convened May 18 to correct a deficiency in the school budget. The Governor conferred today with fifty-two members of the Legislature, who agreed that no other legislation would be considered.

A little more horse-sense in some human beings would help the world along, Magistrate Henry H. Curran philosophized in Yorkville court yesterday, as he fined a laundrywagon driver $5 for beating his horse.

Arrangements have been made for sale of a New York Stock Exchange seat for $100,000. The price is unchanged from the last previous transaction on April 30. Simmons Company rights have been admitted to dealings and when issued rights have been suspended.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helene Manheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Manheimer of this place, to Dr. J. Stanley Cohen, also of Lancaster.

In making the announcement, Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the association, said that the joint efforts of producers and distributors "to foster cordial and beneficial relations has greatly increased in scope during the last year, and has been productive of so much good on both sides, that the services of a full-time executive to carry on the work has been considered essential."

The Federal Power Commission demanded today that Congress give it full jurisdiction over Bonneville project rates or relieve it of responsibili1ty in the matter, and in the demand some observers saw an indication that the long-awaited formulation of President Roosevelt's power policy would be necessary to straighten out legislative difficulties over the $75,000,000 project.

Walter E. Hudson, a retired theatrical manager, died Monday in a hospital here after a brief illness. He lived at 501 West Thirty-eighth Street and was 73 years old. As a youth he was employed by Shook Collier in the box office of the Union Square Theatre.

Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Healy Jr. of New York have announced the double engagement of their daughters, Miss Rosemary Frances Healy, to William J. Walsh Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Walsh of Brooklyn; and Miss Marjorie Cecelia Healy, to Lester D. Borden, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lester D. Borden of Everett, Mass.
Fedders Manufacturing Company, Inc., rights have been stricken from when-issued dealings and admitted to issued dealings on the New York Curb Exchange.

An appropriation for the Treasury and Postoffice Departments about $230,000,000 larger than last year's cleared Congress today. Officials said most of the increase was funds included for the social security retirement reserve.

A surgical operation devised for the relief of baldness was outlined yesterday before the sixty-ninth annual meeting of the Dental Society of the State of New York, at the Waldorf-Astoria, by Dr. Gustave Aufricht, Associate Professor of Clinical Surgery at Post-Graduate Hospital and Columbia University School of Medicine.

While business failures increased in the retail and manufacturing divisions in the week ended April 29, as compared with the previous week, there was a decline in the building group, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

Eighteen stakes, including steeplechase features, and topped by the Belmont, will be run at the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park beginning Monday and running through June 5. On the list, which was announced yesterday, the Toboggan Handicap, with a value of $5,000, at six furlongs, will be the feature for the opening day.

The national debt of the United States is about to cross the thirty-fivebillion-dollar mark for the first time in history. There is bound to be a certain remoteness about this news for most people who see it in the headlines. The figure of thirty-five billions is too large to be readily comprehensible.
Fortunately the Pulitzer Committee did not try to give the fiction prize to THEODORE DREISER. An awkward situation might have

Joseph E. Haven, United States consul here, died today at the age of 52. He had undergone an operation after suffering from a stomach malady for several weeks. Besides holding his consular position, Mr. Haven was United States diplomatic representative to the smallest republic in the world, San Marino.

A student boycott of the Charter Day celebration tomorrow has been voted by the City College Student Council in protest against a military color guard. The celebration in the Great Hall will mark the ninetieth anniversary of the grant creating City College.

John Simonetti's Sgt. Byrne, always a sprinter of quality but who has been racing in poor luck this season, finally came into his own at Jamaica yesterday. Favored by a small field, he was an easy winner of the Morvich Handicap at six furlongs, and ran the distance. in the sparkling good time of 1:11, the same time Pompoon recorded in winning the Paumonok Handicap on opening day.

Dr. Esther Boise Van Deman, American archaeologist, died last night. She was born seventy-four years ago in South Salem, Mo., a daughter of the late Joseph Van Deman. Funeral services will take place in the Protestant Cathedral tomorrow. She had lived in Rome for many years.

With the bases filled in the eleventh inning, the Senators staged a sensational triple steal today to break a 5-all tie and go on to a 12-to-5 victory over the Indians. Ben Chapman, wily outfielder, stole home, and his team-mates, John Lewis and Al Simmons, darted safely to third and second.

In a spectacular photo finish Burley Park's Fair Mole conquered H. D. King's Baldy by a nose today in Aurora's mile-and-seventy-yards feature event. Baldy, ridden by L. Guymon, raced into the lead at the start and set the pace almost to the wire, but was unable to withstand Fair Mole's great drive in the last sixteenth.

William Church Osborn's thirtyfive years as president of the Children's Aid Society will be celebrated today. His fellow trustees, two former trustees, Thomas W. Lamont and Arthur Curtiss James, and senior members of the society's staff will present a portrait of Mr. Osborn to the society at a reception at 4:30 P. M. at the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.
Six persons were United States citizens today because they gave what the court termed the "right answer" to Circuit Judge W. R. Hunter's question:. "Do you apDrove of sit-down strikes?"

Some of the vexation of spirit which palpably afflicts Congress at this time ,can be traced to the fact that most of its members accepted in a Pickwickian sense the President's speech of Oct. 31, 1936, at Madison Square Garden.

Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany saw Premier Benito Mussolini for only a few minutes this morning and this afternoon had an hour and a half conversation with Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano of Italy, who later reported to Mussolini.

An irate resident of this borough, whose identity police have not learned, took a pot shot with a 22caliber rifle this afternoon at a low-flying airplane, and narrowly missed wounding the pilot when the fuel oil tank was punctured.
Ben Cantwell hurled the Jersey City Giants to an even break in their four-game series with Buffalo today, when he halted the Bisons, 4 to 3, to register his third victory in as many starts.

The Salvation Army has received almost 40 per cent of its gifts during the first month of its 1937 Citizens Appeal from New York business and industry, Chalmers Wood, general chairman of the drive, announced yesterday.

The fastest airplane in Canada has become the this property of the Dominion Government. The Department of Transport accepted the swift, silvery Lockheed 12-A from Fairchild Aircraft, Ltd., the Canadian Lockheed distributors, for use in experimental flights over the new TransCanada air route.
A honey bear, known also as a kinkajou, placidly awaited its owner yesterday under the protection of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals after a Broadway adventure.

At 23:00 Greenwich mean time (7 P. M. New York daylight saving time) last night Captain Max Pruss reported the position of the airship Hindenburg about 400 miles north of the Azores on its way toward Lakehurst, N. J., on the first of its eighteen trips of the current season.

The list of the President Monroe of the Dollar Line, which arrives today from the regular 'round-theworld voyage via the West Coast, includes Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Burns, Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Findlay, Edward J. Gillroy, Mr. and Mrs. William C. Owens, Miss Dorothy Pattison and Miss Belle Smith.

Enrico Venturi of Italy received the verdict over Charley Gomer of Baltimore in the ten-round finale bout before 3,500 at the Broadway Arena last night. The victor at 141 was six pounds heavier than his rival.
Trophies for the second annual charity horse - show of the Wall Street Riding Club on May 15, at 7 West Sixty-sixth Street, have been donated by leaders in the banking and investment field.

Treasury Department proposal to set up a revolving fund out of which to pay for losses of funds and documents shipped by departments to banks and agencies, was embodied in a bill introduced in the House today.

Mrs. Abraham Hatfield entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. Among her guests were Mrs. James H. Schmelzel, Mrs. Harry Robie, Mrs. Jared C. Baldwin, Mrs. Noah Rogers, Mrs. J. Addison Woolley, Mrs. Lockwood Bishop, Mrs. J. Willard Travell,

A bill proposing the creation of a new Federal agency, capitalized at $500,000,000, to aid farm tenants, sharecroppers and agricultural laborers was introduced in the House today by Representative Boileau of Wisconsin, leader of the Progressive bloc.

On his first day as president of the General Motors Corporation, William S. Knudsen talked frankly on labor policies, the outlook for automotive business and world conditions. He predicted that the rest of the year would see a continuance of the demand for automobiles shown in the first quarter and then, with a broad smile, "knocked wood."

The German press, which is being swept by what The Times of London calls "a wave of violent Anglophobia," returned to the attack against Britain on a broader front today with simultaneous assurances of friendship for Britain.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 8,497,450 barrels, a new high record, compared with 3,496,400 in the previous week, an increase of 1,050, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson sailed last night on the Bremen for London. They will go to Paris later. Mr. and Mrs. George Ledyard Stebbins have returned from Santa Barbara and are at the Westbury before going to Cedar Cliff, their Summer home at Seal Harbor, Me.

Another step in the refunding program of the American Bell Telephone System, began late in 1935, will be taken today. It involves the issuance of $45,000,000 of Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Com!pany twenty-five-year 3% per cent debentures, due on April 1, 1962.

The great need of the poor in Tennessee was outlined yesterday in a statement by Miss Margaret S. Lehman through the Save the Children Fund of America, Inc. Miss Lehman, a nurse, is director of the fund's relief and welfare work in Fentress and Overton Counties, Tenn., and makes her headquarters at Wilder, Tenn.

A group of 400 Massachusetts Institute of Technology students mixed in combat late tonight with Came F police from Cambridge and the Metropolitan District in Memorial almost; Drive, adjacent to the Charles River, which is District park area. Police finally routed the students with tear gas bombs.

Trading was slow. All classes showed some weakness and a few cuts were sharply lower. Early trading In kosher meats indicated all classes to be about steady with Monday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Brooklyn College, which scrambled the metropolitan collegiate baseball race by upsetting St. John's University last Saturday, lost yesterday to Long Island University, 16--2, as Bernard Pearlman struck out eighteen men.

The Treasury refused yesterday to allow Pierre S. du Pont to admit without further detailed proof by the government, that he and John J.
