Raskob established losses of $7,496,170 for income tax purposes after the crash of 1929, by privately selling their stock holdings to each other at current market prices, and that each bought back his original holdings from the other after a month.

The holdout siege of Charlie (Red) Ruffing, the longest in the history of the Yankees, is believed to be drawing to a finish. The burly hurler, who stoutly refused a $15,000 salary, an increase of $3,000 over his 1936 contract, is expected to report here from his home in Chicago tomorrow to confer with Manager Joe McCarthy.
Stocks advanced and closed higher in quiet trading; turnover, 871,930 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other groups firm and dull; transactions, $9,670,600.

With hope as bright as the Spring sunshine on the boat deck of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, where she posed for batteries of news cameras, Miss Alice Marble, national tennis champion, sailed yesterday for England and her first try at the Wimbledon world title.

Threats of "rough stuff," near fisticuffs and explosions of tempers marked yesterday's proceedings in the investigation being conducted here by the emergency board appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate the controversy that led to the recent strike threat of 25,000 members of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks on nine railroads in the New York area.

A blue-ribbon jury with an alternate member was chosen yesterday for the retrial of Louis Luckman on a charge of perjuring himself before the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case.

The stock market here continued to show signs of returning confidence today and .a more optimistic tone prevailed. Giltedge issues moved to higher levels and among the foreign loans Japanese bonds were outstanding. International issues improved on the whole after a dull opening.
Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne of the stage, and Dr. Frederick Stock of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra received today awards for distinguished achievements in drama and music.

The eight-year high record for exports of iron and steel products from the United States in March, announced by the government, was somewhat surprising to observers, but upon analysis it was evident that the exports covered less active lines, such as unfinished plates, black steel sheets and heavy rails, whereas the main domestic activity is in other products. Statistically,

With premiere ceremonies to which many notables have been invited, the Warner Brothers tonight will present at the Strand their new version of Mark Twain's "The Prince and the Pauper," complete with a coronation tie-up,

Dr. Helmuth C. Engerent, a Christian writer, has won first prize in the national essay contest on how to combat anti-Semitism, conducted by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, John Haynes Holmes and Ludwig Lewisohn, editors of the magazine Opinion, it was announced yesterday.

Henry Dazian, who made a fortune providing costumes and other stage materials for two generations of American actors and actresses, died zast night at his Winter home in Miami Beach, Fla., according to an announcement here by the Actors Fund of America, of which he had been a trustee for thirty years. He was 83 years old on Monday.

The open-market committee of the Federal Reserve System met today to review the economic situation and consider its future policy on the money market. Members were reported to be particularly ratified that the additional reserve requirements of member banks made effestive on May 1 had resulted in no disturbance in the bond market, and as satisfied that an orderly market in government securities would continue.

Although the meat packing concerns exchange credit information, in no case have they discriminated for or against any person by fixing credit terms in this exchange, James W. Walsh, credit manager In the New York area for Swift Co., testified yesterday at the Federal hearing in which the company is answering a complaint of unfair trade practices.

" The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse," the Barre Lyndon play which has formed Sir Cedric Hardwicke's second vehicle in this country, will close its run after Saturday evening at the Hudson Theatre. It will have played eighty performances since it opened on March 2.
Steel ingot production was unchanged last week when a slight decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 121.3 from 120.3. It was 93.2 for the week ended May 2, 1936.

Acid fumes released by an explosion of bottles in the science laboratory of Long Island University, 300 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, seared Israel Kasarsky, 21 years old, as student, of 1,417 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn, at 11:15 A. M. yesterday.

Percy L. Guiterman, president of Guiterman Company, Inc., exporters, and a director of the affiliated London organization of S. Guiterman Company, Ltd., died on Monday at his home in New Rochelle. His age was 55.

James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, continued his talks with members of the organization's executive 'committee yesterday in accordance with his statement on his return from Miami on Sunday, that he would seek their advice on the political situation.
A book containing ninety-two letters praising his anti-noise campaign will be sent to Mayor La Guardia this afternoon by E. H. Peabody, president of the League for Less Noise, 580 Fifth Avenue.

Mayor La Guardia received yesterday a scroll, the gift of the Park Association of New York City, in recognition of the work his administration has done in improving and increasing the city's park space.
Philip Johnson and Howard Agg, authors of "New School for Scandal," produced at the Embassy Theatre tonight, not only put Sheridan's famous story into modern clothes but into modern slang.

The Chase National Bank, trustee, has notified holders of General American Tank Car Corporation equipment trust certificates, Series 25, dated June 1, 1934, that $556,000 of these certificates will be redeemed on June 1 at 1001/2 and accrued dividends.

A preliminary organisation meeting of the workers who will conduct the campaign for $250,000 for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service next Autumn was held yesterday at the Henry Street Settlement main office, 99 Park Avenue.
Governor Lehman worked in his office today and was called upon to send to the Legislature a number of "emergency" messages to permit immediate passage of amended bills.

Coronation skies over England are clouded by a transport workers' strike which King GEORGE has himself taken in hand. It will probably be out of the way by a week from today, the solemn day. But in any event this labor cloud has a substantial silver lining in the latest British unemployment figures. By going down considerably below 1,500,000 they touch a seven-year low.

London's 25,000 striking busmen offered tonight to break their own strike as an aid to blind pedestrians. Strikers, whose walkout has thrown traffic in coronationjammed London into a turmoil, offered to provide transportation for the blind who customarily ride the cty's big red omnibuses.

Remarks made by one non-union man started a strike at the Hudson Motor Car Company plant today and halted production for two hours. Three days ago an agreement was signed between the company and the United Automobile Workers of America.

A Negro staged a daring hold-up on a busy downtown corner at 1 P. M. and escaped on foot after robbing Sherman Fowlxes, 42, Negro porter of the National Life and Accident Insurance Company, as he started for the bank with two days' accumulated receipts.

A $8,000,000 loan guaranteed by 500,000 bags of coffee by the Hardrand Company to the National Coffee Department was reported here today, but it was impossible to obtain official confirmation of the port.

Movements in the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department ot Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 18,000, including 5,000 directs. Market steady to $10 lower than Monday's average; top $10.35 paid frequently; good and choice 200-300 pounds, mostly $10.15$10.30; 150-190 pounds, $9.75-$10.25; bulk goods 350-550 pounds, packing sows $9.50$9.80; shippers 1,500; estimated holdover 2.000.
Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers played host to the Pirates for the first time this year at Ebbets Field yesterday, and, according to Manager Pie Traynor's reaction, did it charmingly.

Death Announced Retired Engineer of Steamer Dennis M. Maguire, formerly a member of Eng. 10. residing in Jersey City, N. J., died April 6. Appointments The following ununiformed firemen, having completed their probationary period of three months satisfactorily, are appointed as firemen, fourth grade, in this department, Bureau of Fire, with compensation each at the rate nf $2,000 per annum:

The seventh annual baby health contest and conference of. the Colony House, 297 Dean Street, Brooklyn, was held there yesterday morning. The babies, who were examined by Dr. Russell H. Iler and Dr. Anthony Surdakowski, were judged not only for their health but for general good conduct and personality.

Three men who fed monkeys in the Bronx Zoo were fined $2 each yesterday afternoon by Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud in Bronx Magistrate's Court. The trio was arrested Sunday for feeding a baboon gumdrops, a monkey popcorn and another monkey crackers.

The annual report of the Central Maine Power Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $1,650,315, comparing with a net of $1,305,750 in 1935.

John A. Kennedy, acting in the name of the Stoker Realty Corporation. has acquired the properties at 327-29 and 331-33 Cherry Street, together with the four parcels at 574-80 Water Street, which adjoin the Cherry Street property on the rear.

The Prix Femina Americain winner is "The Yankee Bodleys," by Naomi Lane Babson, a story of a New England family from Civil War days to the present. This is the second first novel published by Reynal Hitchcock to be selected for this award in three years.
The position of the Insurgents at Bermeo on the Bay of Biscay was made more difficult today by Basque occupation of Anetu Hill, overlooking the village of Pedernales.

The French franc, following its rally on Monday, was allowed to move on its own momentum yesterday and dropped back slightly. The closing price was off 1 5/8 points at 4.49 1-16 cents from its high of the day of 4.50 7-16 cents. Offerings were small.

Mrs. Byron Hilliard, daughter-in-law of Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, and Mrs. George W. Norton Jr., her niece, both of Louisville, will be presented at the first royal court of the season at Buckingham Palace tomorrow night.

The Senate today passed the Doyle bill to create a State Labor Relations Board and the O'Brien bill to establish a State Board of Mediation, both major items on Governor Lehman's program of labor legislation.

By unanimous vote the Assembly today passed and sent to Governor Lehman the Burchill bill, empowering the- New York City Tunnel Authority to build a cross-town tunnel under Manhattan at Thirty-eighth Street to connect the Queens Midtown Tunnel under the East River with the Lincoln Tunnel under the Hudson.
Three Brooklyn postoffice clerks were named yesterday in an indictment handed up by the Federal grand jury to Judge Marcus B. Campbell in the United States District Court in that borough.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, which will acquire the Roxy Theatre if the Federal Court approves a plan of reorganization, has made a qualified offer to buy Class A stock of the Roxy Theatres Corporation at $1 a share.

The first stay-in strike in Tokyo began last evening when nearly 1,000 railroad workers barricaded themselves in a railway club, prepared to endure a siege until their demands for a rise in wages were granted.

In sympathy with a further improvement in outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday to end with gains of 5 to 11 points. A better' demand from trade sources carried both old crop deliveries above 13 cents a pound and narrowed the May discount to 5 points under July.

The scene in the motion picture "Kiondike Annie" showing Mae West with a copy of the "Police Gazette" was interpreted yesterday by the National Police Gazette Corporation as a piracy of its copyright of that publication.

The United States Coast and Geodetic Survey ship Oceanographer, formerly a yacht of J. P. Morgan, sailed last night from the Navy Yard in Brooklyn to continue a project begun last Summer to make the first detailed survey of the ocean floor between New York and Chesapeake Bay.

James Emmi, 23, made his gasoline-powered model airplane just a little too good and today he asked help in locating it. The plane was within twenty minutes of establishing a world's record when he saw it last at an altitude of about 8,000 feet.

The Rutland Railroad Company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission the deposit, as of March 31, of $1,840,000 Ogdensburg Lake Champlain Railway first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, due in 1948, under an agreement for a reduction in the interest rate.

Proceedings calling for disbarment or lesser disciplinary action have been instituted in the Supreme Court here against fifteen lawyers. Records in such matters are impounded pending final disposition because of the possibility that hearings will produce no cause for action, but it became known that among those cited was former State

Earnings of the American Snuff Company in the first quarter of 1937 were slightly below the same period a year ago, it was announced at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday, due to a lower sales volume following the start of a new selling policy in January.

A thouand sand tons of "mud" was Germany-bound through the New York State Barge Canal today, reportedly destined for a secret German chemical process which will reclaim silver. platinum and tin residue.

Passage by the Assembly yesterday of the gasoline tax recommended by Governor LEHMAN breaks a month-old deadlock at Albany and foreshadows an early adjournment of the Legislature. No tax is pleasant, and the economic soundness of the gasoline tax in particular is open to question,

Two American students at Oxford won commendation today for their heroism in rescuing Gwydol Evans from a capsized canoe on Sunday on the River Cherwell. The Americans are Harvey Picker of New Rochelle, N. Y., a former Colgate and Harvard student, and Kemper Campbell of Victorville, Calif.

Public opinion here--which is favorable to the Nationalist [Insurgent] forces--is still disturbed by allegations abroad that the beautiful Basque town of Guernica had been destroyed by incendiary bombs dropped by Nationalist aircraft.

Although the number of visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was slightly less than in the previous week, the total was well above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

Music written by seven Westchester County composers was played this evening by the Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra at a concert in the County Center. Jaffrey Harris of Bronxville was conductor of the orchestra, a unit of the Federal Music Project.

T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour, the yacht with which Sopwith unsuccessfully tried to win the America's Cup in 1934, sailed for America today after a three-day delay due to repairs on the motor yacht Viva II, which is to tow the Endeavour across the Atlantic.

The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania voted today to give the name "church" to each of its forty-eight "missions" and put them on an equal footing with the 141 "parishes" in the election of a Bishop or of deputies to the denomination's General Convention.
Traffic through the Panama Canal d? lined in April, according to the monthly report issued today by the War Department.
The Reichsbank's statement as of May 3 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

The five-story hotel at 44 Myrtle Avenue, corner of Pearl Street, Brooklyn, was sold by Mrs. Anna Langerman to a client of the Richard-Murray Corporation. It has been operated as a hotel for men by the same tenant for thirty-nine years and was sold for cash over the first mortgage.

With a House of 285 deputies, only 15 members being absent, and with the galleries jammed with spectators, the Brazilian Congress elected today Pedro Alexio as Speaker to serve during the lest term of this Congress, Mr. Alexio received 152 votes against 131 cast for Antonio Carlos, the retiring Speaker.

J. D. Ross, who was connected with public power operation in Seattle for years before his appointment to the Securities Exchange Commission, said today that "a willingness to lend funds to public plants is replacing the old war-to-the-death attitude in Wall Street."

Appointment of an advisory committee to recommend specific measures looking toward elimination of commercial frauds was voted at a conference on the subject at the New Yorker last night. The committee will be chosen by Major Benjamin H. Namm president of the Namm store, Brooklyn, who presided.
Irate town fathers, indignant at defacement of historic Plymouth Rock with red paint, called in a chemist today to do what turpentine and paint remover could not.
The Bears took possession of the International League lead today by beating Toronto, 8 to 1, while Jersey City defeated Buffalo. The game was the last of the home stand for Newark.

A bill to include all types of firearms in the National Firearms Act was sent by Attorney General Cummings to the Speaker of the House today. The law now covers machine guns, sawed-off shotguns, sawed-off rifles and silencers, but the smaller weapons are not affected.

Dr. Jerome Kingsbury gave a reception yesterday afternoon at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street for Rear Admiral and Mrs. Reginald R. Belknap. The occasion was the final meeting this season of the New York Commandery of the Naval Order of the United States. Admiral Belknap is commander- e general of the order and Dr. Kingsbury is commander of the New York unit.

The legislative deadlock of almost a month's duration over Governor Lehman's revenue program was broken today when the Assembly, by 76 to 71 and votes, with six in the affirmative the g furnished by Republicans, passed the Governor's bill adding a fourth cent to the present three-cent-a-galion tax on gasoline.
A program for the production of between forty-four and fifty-two feature length pictures and 194 short subjects during the 1937-38 season was announced yesterday by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Naval Operations, appeared before the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs today in support of legislation to authorize construction of fleet auxiliary vessels to cost about $48,000,000.

Earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation in the, first quarter were substantially better than the 50-cent dividend declared for the period, Stephen Birch, chairman, said at the annual meeting yesterday.

A clause guaranteeing American exports against discrimination in Ecuador was urged by the National, Foreign Trade Association in a brief filed with the State Department yesterday in preparation for the reciprocal trade treaty to be negotiated with that country.

Monday's report on world economic conditions, submitted to the Bank for International Settlements at Basle, is in the main hopeful; but it lays the greater emphasis on those uncertainties which still exist.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot of 1,175 Park Avenue and Cedar Hill, Oyster Bay, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucile Thornton Thieriot, to Elisha Walker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Walker of 33 East Sixty-ninth Street and Les Pommiers, Syosset, L. I.

The line of cleavage between the right and left wings of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union on the issues involving the American Federation of LaborCommittee for Industrial Organization controversy was forecast here today at the garment union's twenty-third convention.

Organization of a fraudulent claims bureau, similar to those set up in the grocery and drug industries, was announced yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association. It will act as a clearing house of information on claims for damages resulting from imperfections in electrical household appliances.

The Bengal Government yesterday intervened in the strike of 150,000 jute workers, who have tied up operations in some forty jute mills during the past few weeks, shutting down about 70 per cent of the industry's burlap looms, according to cables received here yesterday by C. E. Rockstroh Co., burlap brokers.

King Yeta III of Barotseland, in Britain's South African colony of Northern Rhodesia, carried his ivory handled fly switch when he disembarked today to attend the coronation of King George VI. The switch, used to keep flies away from the royal personage, is a symbol of the King's authority.
The Municipal Civil Service Commission was asked yesterday by the Board of Aldermen to waive the age limit on candidates for civil service positions who are veterans of the World War.
A substitute resolution proposing a Congressional inquiry into alleged monopolistic practices in professional baseball was introduced in the House today by Representative Cannon of Wisconsin.

Five Hunter College alumnae who specialized in the field of botany while at college have received fellowships for advanced work in the subject, it wax announced yesterday by Professor Margaret A. Graham, head of the Department of Biological Sciences at the college.

An amazing story of a secret radio station, death in an orange grove, vanishing witnesses and secret societies led police today to conclude they had unearthed an international syndicate for smuggling arms. The central figure in the fantastic story is Reuben Schenzvit, who once sold arms in South America for the late Sir Basill Zaharoff, Europe's greatest munitions merchant.

Darting out of the starting gate with a rush, W. H. Lipscomb's Tedema won the John S. Skinner Purse, today's feature race at Pimlico, in runaway fashion. With Bobby Merritt doing little more than the guiding, the daughter of Teddy was in front from flag to finish and was not even challenged.

Queena Mario, soprano; Hortense Monath, pianist; Mario Chamlee, tenor, and Benno Rabinof, violinist, will appear tonight at Carnegie Hall in a concert sponsored by the Dress Industry Division of the American Committee for Settlement of Jews in Birobidjan.

Alexander Afinogenoff and Vladimir Kirshon, leading Soviet playwrights, who have been under attack for the past fortnight as alleged participants in a writers' group harboring Trotskyist views, were expelled today from the directorate of the playwrights' section of the Union of Soviet Writers.

To support his charge that Communists dominate the work of the Emergency Relief Bureau, Victor F. Ridder, former Works Progress Administrator, made public yesterday a list of the days on which district officers of the ERB meet with the Workers Alliance, which Mr. Ridder described as "the representative of the Communist party in New York City."

Every one said it wax a handsome. news stand and then they all shook hands with Thomas Hines, the blind 41-year-old proprietor, and congratulated him. After they had gone Hines sat behind the shining glass and metal counter and submitted to an interview.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Dick Merle-Smith and Stroud Co., Inc., will offer today at prices to yield from 1.10 to 2.90 per cent, $6,490,000 of Northern Pacific Railway 23/4 per cent equipment trust certificates, due from 1938 to 1947.
Twelve men, ordered to decide whether Kentucky's Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt killed his fiancee or whether she shot herself, began consideration of the case tonight.

A United States International Star Class team of three boats triumphed over a trio of Bermuda rivals today by the narrow margin of threequarters of a point. The course, laid out in the Sound, consisted of two beats, a reach and a run, with the start off the Bermuda Yacht Club anchorage. B. G.

The election of Robert H. Colley as president of the Atlantic Refining Company to succeed W. M. Irish was announced today by J. W. Van Dyke, chairman of the board. Mr. Irish's retirement, which came four years after he had reached the retirement age of 65, was effective yesterday. A director of the company since 1905, he became president in 1927.

An intoxicated man who apparently without provocation slashed a detective on the hand with an army bayonet, inflicting a painful wound, was questioned for several hours yesterday afternoon as a possible suspect in the murder of Municipal Court Justice John Francis O'Neil, but was eventually eliminated from consideration in this connection.

Mrs. Belle Wallace Swift, former resident of East Orange and widow of Professor John Trumbull Swift of the Imperial University at Tokyo, Japan, died Friday in Yokohama, according to word received here today by relatives. She was 67 years old.

After defeating the McElroy bill last night, the Senate made a right-about face today and passed the measure which would have the effect of setting up a "Little NRA" for the service trades of the State by a vote of 26 to 16. Both Democrats and Republicans voted against it.

Two old-time friends, now much estranged, confronted each other in the Federal court here today when Paul H. Wendel was called to the stand to relate before the narrowed eyes of Ellis H. Parker Sr. his story of betrayed friendship.
A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $950,000 of relief bonds of the city of Buffalo, N. Y., on a bid of 100.15 for 2.70s. The bonds, dated May 15,

The Securities and Exchange Commission heard testimony today that heavy losses resulted from $1,600,000 of loans which the Ungerleider Financial Corporation made to men prominent in New York just before the crash in 1929.

An outbreak of violence in the motion picture strike sent six men to hospitals tonight while committees representing producers and the Screen Actors Guild, hoping to avert further conflict, conferred on disputed points.

W. R. Kane, on Berkshire Road, Great Neck, L. I.; William Clark, on Bancroft Lane; August V. Grosskopf, on Windsor Road; R. L. Robertson, on Middle Neck Road; William W. Smith, in Kensington Gardens; Louis Gabell, on Valley View Road; J. F. Graecen, on Vista Road; William H. Brown Jr., on North Drive, Kensington: Edward J. Clancy, Inc., broker.

Samuel Rothberg, who, as Stitch McCarthy, built up a strange and unique reputation as bondsman, friend of notables and notorious figures, smoker of 15-cent cigars, and, above all, Chief Mayor of the League of Locality Mayors, died at 4:20 P. M. yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital.
Private Thomas Arbuckle, 30 years old, a deserter from the Royal Irish Fusiliers, war shot by police seeking to arrest him at dawn today and died two hours later in a hospital.

A plea to wholesale grocers to "quit doing business with concerns you know are violating the Robinson-Patman Pair Trade Aet'was made by Representative Wright Patman of Texas, co-author of the measure, in an address here this afternoon before the convention of the United States Wholesale Grocers Association, Inc.

Operations of the American Zine, Lead and Smelting Company and subsidiaries in the first quarter of this year resulted in a net profit of $92,530 after depreciation, depletion, normal Federal income taxes and other charges but before surtax on undistributed income.
One more trifle was added by A. A. Milne's "Sarah Simple," his first play in many years, staged at the Garrick tonight, to the present theatrical vogue for trifles.

Lou Fette, rookie right-hander from St. Paul, boosted the Boston Bees into the first division today by holding the St. Louis Cardinals to three hits while his mates battered four of the Gas House hurlers for 16 safeties and an 8-1 victory.
Congressional action was completed today on the Merritt resolution authorizing a $5,000,000 appropriation for the New York 1939 World's Fair, the House concurring in several Senate amendments.
A sitdown of union barbers in chairs of non-union shops brought rapid results today.

Plans to hold an international health congress during the New York World's Fair in 1939 are being completed by the National Health Council in collaboration with the World's Fair Advisory Committee on Medicine and Public Health, it was made known yesterday.

The Wisconsin Central Railroad applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue $2,500,000 in equipment securities to be paid off semi-annually over a period of ten years and to bear interest at 31/2 per cent.

Educational programs to protect the youth of the nation against the ravages of disease and to -train children for parenthood and citizenship were urged today by speakers at the forty-first annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.
The Rev. Dr. Willis Wilkinson Memminger, one of the South's most prominent ministers, died here today at the age of 60.

The number of births in the city in recent weeks has averaged about 200 more a week than in the corresponding period for 1936, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday in his weekly health survey.

Members of fish and game clubs who have become somewhat anxious concerning shipments of trout promised by the New York Conservation Department have been asked to be patient "and not fret at any seeming delay."

Dr. Carleton Sprague Smith, head of the music division of the New York Public Library, championed "swing" music tonight, terming it an "appropriate" musical expression which must receive serious consideration.

The largest automobile salesroom opened on Broadway since the boom days of 1929 was presented in preview yesterday by A. E. Barit, president, officials of the Hudson Motor Car Company of Detroit and a group of nearly 300 automotive news reporters and publishers.

A study of the financial structure, the bal- The ance sheets and performance records of all steamship companies which expect to benefit through differential subsidies under the Merchant Marine Act is being made by the Maritime Commission.

Miss Kathleen V. Mulcahy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Mulcahy of South Highland Street, West Hartford, was married to Arnold Rogers Storrs, son of Mrs. Florence Rogers Storrs of Scarborough Street, this afternoon in St. Joseph's Cathedral. The Rev.

Probably after the verdict this year there will be far less than the usual disturbance in the court room. The acknowledged connoisseurs, the dramatic critics, picked out their favorite in advance of the Morningside judgment.

Checking a spirited last-inning rally that left the bases filled after two runs had crossed the plate, New York University's nine eked out a 3-2 triumph over St. John's University at Dexter Park yesterday.

Further amendments to registration statements and annual reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission were made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. Among them was a schedule showing that Powel Crosley Jr. and Gwendolyn A. Crosley between them controlled the Crosley Radio Corporation, the former owning 152,699 shares, or 28 per cent, on Jan. 31, 1936, and the latter, 130,910 shares, or 24 per cent.
Continuing a series of victories on its northern invasion, the University of North Carolina today defeated Yale, 8 to 1, taking five of the six singles matches and all the doubles.
Wagner College overwhelmed the Webb Naval Institute nine yesterday in a seven-inning contest, 17-2. Gwynne Swartz held the Webb batsmen to four scattered hits whilEthe Wagnerites collected fourteen.

Military experts estimate that the greater part of the Hungarian Army must have been brought to Budapest today to give an impressive military exhibition before President Wilhelm Miklas and other official visitors from Austria.
With several deals now pending, Hearn's has "very definitsly" adopted the policy of becoming a chain of department stores, it was stated yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, vice president of the store.
John Strootman, retired shoe manufacturer, died here this morning after a short illness. He was 89. Mr. Strootman was founder and president of the John Strootman Shoe Company.

The first step toward redemption of the last of the tax-free bonds issued during the war will be taken tomorrow when books will be opened on a conversion loan designed to take care of a part of the $236,299,800 of 5% per cent Victory Loan bonds maturing on Dec. 1, 1937.

A solemn requiem mass was celebrated yesterday for Municipal Court Justice John Francis O'Neil at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, Sixth Avenue and Washington Place, where he served as an altar boy many years ago.

The wish that his home and three-mile railroad at Hadlyme would not fall into the hands of "some blithering saphead with no conception of where he is or with what surrounded," was expressed in the will of William Gillette, famous actor, filed here today.

Support of the Williamson bill, which provides a method for tapering off the mortgage moratorium, is urged in a joint letter sent yesterday to Governor Lehman by E. A. MacDougall, representing the mortgage committee of the real estate boards in the metropolitan area, and Robert Louis Hoguet, president of the Mortgage Conference of New York, according to the Real Estate Board of New York.

Unless the city's rackets are exposed and smashed, sooner or later every business man will face the alternative of "pay up-or else!" Harry F. Guggenheim, president of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, said yesterday at the 169th annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in its Great Hall at 65 Liberty Street.

In the face of increasing efforts to Search out an acceptable modification of the President's court reorganization proposal, Senator Ashurst, a strong administration supporter, declared today that he wanted the Roosevelt plan "or nothing."

From a propped pillow in Hackensack Hospital, Miss Jessie Simpson, 18 years old, who lost both her legs about a week ago when she fell under a train, expressed her determination today to work when she recovers.

Miss Charlotte Glutting, Curtis Cup team star, won the opening tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association season today at the Essex County Country Club with a gross score of 85. Two other players were tied for the honors with the Rock Spring Club luminary, but they lost on the match of cards.

Houses in Yorkville proved attractive to investors in deals announced yesterday. Raymond C. Smith purchased for investment the four-story brownstone dwelling on a lot 17 by 100 feet at 129 East Eighty-first Street, near the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue. It was bought for cash over a mortgage of $20,000 from Alma Carlson.

Anarchists tonight were in control of a part of Barcelona, capital of the' autonomous Spanish State of Catalonia, after a rising in which at least 100 persons have been killed, according to news received across the frontier.

Virtually all classes of bonds moved forward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in trading which, although somewhat more active than on Monday, was still well below the average volume of recent weeks. High-grade loans,

Sweeping all six of the singles matches, the New York University tennis team routed the City College net squad, 7 to 2, at the Fleet Hollow courts in the Bronx yesterday. The victory was the third in a row for the Violet.
The government will give Italian parents 18 to 38 cents a week for each new baby as part of Premier Benito Mussolini's plan to check the decline in the birth rate.

The first public financing by the Federal Home Loan Bank System will be done today when $25,000,000 of one-year 11/2 per cent consolidated non-callable debentures of the Federal Home Loan Banks will be offered at 100 and interest.

Striking employes of three of nineteen Lewiston-Auburn shoe factories involved in a forty-one day strike voted tonight to return to work tomorrow and to participate fifteen days hence in a "consent" election under the Wagner Act.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western RailIroad Company, which, with four other railroads and their subsidiaries, is seeking a permanent injunction to restrain New Jersey from collecting taxes in excess of an amount which the petitioners consider equitable, began today to present its argument before Judge Phillip Forman in the United States District Court here.

Sweeping all six of the singles matches, the New York University tennis team routed the City College net squad, 7 to 2, at the Fleet Hollow courts in the Bronx yesterday. The victory was the third in a row for the Violet.
The government will give Italian parents 18 to 38 cents a week for each new baby as part of Premier Benito Mussolini's plan to check the decline in the birth rate.

The first public financing by the Federal Home Loan Bank System will be done today when $25,000,000 of one-year 11/2 per cent consolidated non-callable debentures of the Federal Home Loan Banks will be offered at 100 and interest.

Striking employes of three of nineteen Lewiston-Auburn shoe factories involved in a forty-one day strike voted tonight to return to work tomorrow and to participate fifteen days hence in a "consent" election under the Wagner Act.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western RailIroad Company, which, with four other railroads and their subsidiaries, is seeking a permanent injunction to restrain New Jersey from collecting taxes in excess of an amount which the petitioners consider equitable, began today to present its argument before Judge Phillip Forman in the United States District Court here.

A new issue of $1,700,000 of fifteen-year collateral trust 4 1/4 per cent bonds, Series A, of the United Stockyards Corporation will be offered today by Bond Goodwin, Inc., at a price of 96% and accrued interest. In addition,

A proposal to limit the number of golf clubs permitted each player in tournaments was defeated today when it failed to secure the requisite two-thirds majority at a business meeting of the Royal and Ancient Club, governing body of the sport in Great Britain.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Lambert Fairchild stated: "Any one who has listened to the Communists who regularly promulgate these ideas at the forums held by the Adult Education Project in connection with the Board of Education of the City of New York, knows that Communists are not entitled to that measure of 'free speech' which you would grant them."

Mr. and Mrs. William Crane Ivison gave a dinner last night at their home, 417 Park Avenue, for Mr. and Mrs. George Dallas Yeomans, Mr. and Mrs. Edward deC. Chisholm, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Randolph Manice, Mr. and Mrs. George F. Hurd, Mrs. Edwin A. Strong and Welsh Walker.

A two-run rally in the last half of the ninth inning gave the Princeton freshman baseball team a 5-4 triumph over the Rutgers yearlings today on the Brokaw diamond. It was the fifth victory in seven starts for the Princeton team.

LPrompt balancing of the Federal budget was declared today by Tom K. Smith of St. Louis, president of the American Bankers Association, to be "a necessary condition to avert an inflationary movement" in this country.

The late Colonel Edward H. R. Green, son of Mrs. Hetty Green and heir to an estate estimated at $80,000,000, rented a room in Terrell, Texas, "to establish a legal residence there," according to testimony given yesterday at a hearing before Surrogate Harry E. Owen of Essex County, N. Y., in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

HARRY F. GUGGENHEIM, president of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in'New York, reminds the business men of the city that even those who have not personally been " shaken down" by racketeers are daily paying to the racketeers of this city some part of the dollars they spend.

While sixty-seven policemen listened to a lecture on how to be better policemen, a woman came in and handed Captain L. E. Bowery, the speaker, a telegram. Later he asked the officers to write a description of the woman.

S. B. Robertson, formerly executive vice president, was elected president of the B. F. Goodrich Company at a meeting of the board of directors following the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday. He succeeds J. D. Tew, who declined to stand for re-election but who will continue to be a member of the executive committee and the board of directors. Other officers and directors were re-elected.

Mrs. Jerome B. Crowley heads a group of women who have planned a card party and tea for the benefit of the National Guard and Naval Militia Relief Society to be held Saturday afternoon in the EAst Ballroom of the Commodore.
A concerted protest to Governor Lehman against the McNaboe-Dollinger bill, which is before the Governor for signature, has been made by architects and architectural organizations.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has consented to the withdrawal of the following registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933: Chateau DuBols International Vintages Corporatlon-12,000 shares of $10 par value 7 per cent non-cumulative preferred stock and 6,000 shares of $5 par, value common stock.

Fourteen of the fifteen kitchen employes of the Divan Parisien walked out of that restaurant at 17 East Forty-fifth Street, near Fifth Avenue, at 5:30 P. M. yesterday on strike for higher wages, shorter hours and union recognition. John Paffrath, the proprietor, said'he would discuss workingconditions but wanted nothing to do with unions, since his previous experiences with them had been "unhappy."

Publishers of The Long Island Daily Press agreed yesterday at a conference with representatives of the Newspaper Guild and the typographical unions in Mayor La Guardia's office to submit their dismissal of twenty-seven employes to an impartial arbitration board.

Coming at a time when most motion picture companies are ready to announce 1937-38 production plans and advertising budgets, the current strike in the Coast film industry, like the automotive tie-ups, may make a sizeable dent in advertising linage, according to comment here yesterday.

Reviewing a drive against obscenity during the last year, the New York Society for Suppression of Vice revealed yesterday in its annual report that in addition to opening the fight against burlesque it had caused the confiscation of more than five tons of obscene printed matter.

An increase in the proportion of goods distributed by manufacturers through their own wholesale branches, and a moderate decline in the amount of goods distributed through other wholesalers and jobbers has occurred since 1929, according to a report issued today by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census.

" Blind Joe," proprietor of a radio repair shop at 153 Avenue A, near Tenth Street, was found murdered yesterday afternoon in his oneroom living quarters behind his store. The 39-year-old blind man, whose name was Joseph Alonzo, had been beaten on the head with a heavy weapon.

H. H. Buttner, vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, said today that the country's aviation experts would come here May 11 and 12 for blind-landing demonstrations. He said the Municipal Airport is the only field in the country equipped with the Lorenz, Bureau of Air Commerce and Army "bentbeam" methods of blind landing.
Two moves in campaigns to raise funds for relief of victims of the Spanish civil war, in both Loyalist and Rebel territory, were made known here yesterday.
King Boris of Bulgaria is sending Gus Phillips of this city a "souvenir" which thge Nebraska railroad engineer will receive through the Bulgarian legation at Washington.

The Italian liner Rex will arrive today from Mediterranean ports. On board are Charles Munroe, Countess Contini Bonacossi, Cesare Verona, Henry Rainville, Captain Candido Camalich, Commander Gonippo Raggi, Mrs. Rufus King, Professor Luigi Cavaliere, Colonel Giovanni Ferrando, Siegfried Sonnenberger and Mrs. Clara Hood Rugel.

Frank Anthony Blair, vice president of the Centaur Company and for twenty-three years president of the Proprietary Association, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. He was 67 years old,

Mayor La Guardia's plans for a Summer camp for poor children on Hoffmans Island in the lower bay moved ahead yesterday when the Sinking Fund Commission authorized Controller Frank J. Taylor to negotiate a lease of the property.
Winning five out of six' singles matches and sweeping the doubles, Princeton University's varsity tennis team scored its third successive victory today by turning back Lehigh, 8 to -.

Training in all the Industries rather than in specific professions and arts will help alleviate "the suffering and the vulnerability" of Jews in Eastern Europe, according to Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, who spoke at a luncheon yesterday before more than 400 members of the Women's American Ort at the Hotel Astor.

The annual luncheon of the Maternity Center Association will be held today in the Empire Room of, the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Shspard Krech, president of the association, will preside and the guests of honor will be Dr. Thomas Parran Jr.,

Sena.tor Norris of Nebraska said today that if Congress could not adjourn by the time Washington's Summer weather arrived it should recess during the hot months and return in the Fall to complete its work.
Leases for store units and entire floors predominated in yesterday's report of commercial contracts closed. Food retailers took most J of the stores in a day of little activity. The list follows:

Munleipal FIREMEN. FIRE DEPARTMENT-Salary: Entrance salary $2,000 with statutory increases to $3,000 per annum the fourth year; vacation; sick leave; no present pension payment; promotion opportunities; retirement possible on half pay after twenty years. Vacancies: 3,800 vacancies anticipated. The present list,

Irwin L. Moore, president of the International Hydro-Electric Systern, told shareholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Boston that preliminary figures for the first quarter of this year indicated a consolidated net income of $627,152, compared with a net of $141,290 for the Marnh quarter of 1936.

Passenger carrying in New Jersey costs the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company more than it receives for that service, Philip D. Jonas, assistant controller, testified here today before Federal Judge Philip Forman in the suit of that and four other railroads for a permanent injunction restraining

Students of the Horace Mann School, Broadway and 120th Street, dipped far back into the past last night and with the aid of imposing sets and colorful costumes traced the course of "man's eternal quest for truth" from the time of Pythagoras, through the medieval schoolmen down to Horace Mann and the progressive educational system of which they are products.

A substantial reduction in the work relief appropriation for the next fiscal year from the $1,500,000,000 set by President Roosevelt was regarded as likely today following the appearance of new cleavages in the House.

Max Schmeling, who has hopes of meeting James J. Braddoek for the latter's heavyweight championship of the world on June 3 in the Garden Bowl, paid a courtesy visit to the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday.

Practically unanimous endorsement of a proposal to close the New York Stock Exchange on Saturdays s in July and August is expected today from a special committee appointed last year to study the question. The report, however,

Alva Johnston's series of articles on Samuel Goldwyn, now appearing in The Saturday Evening Post, will be published in book form by Random House under the title, "The Great Goldwyn." The book will be published on July 1.

Alfred J. Elliott, who campaigned as a "Roosevelt supporter" and said that he had thA confidence of the Townsend pension plan organization, held a comfortable margin over two other candidates today for the post of Representative from the Tenth California District to succeed the late Henry Stubbs, Democrat.

Ave St John, 1,014-16, 1-story brick stores, 75x100; Burcrim Holding Corp against Jacob Cohen, due, $3,474, to Plaintiff for $1,000. Park Ave, 3,766, 3-story frame tenement, 20x150; Mary P. Murray against Concetta ' Sannino, due, $4,661; to Plaintiff for $4,000.

The Madrigal Singers, Lehman Engel, conductor, will present a program of American music tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music. The orchestra of City College, William Neidlinger conductor, will present a free concert this evening in the Great Hall.

Although mill executives have attempted to shut off both reports of cancellations in wool piece goods .and the efforts of some buyers, particularly in the men's wear field, to renege on orders for Fall merchandise, there has been sufficient evidence of revisions to produce a considerable degree of uneasiness in that market, it was admitted yesterday by millmen and jobbers.

Puccini's "La Boheme" was presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night in a production that justified the existence of a Spring season. It was, in fact, a performance that compared favorably with "Bohemes" of the regular season.

Emergency powers for Danzig's National Socialist Senate for four more years were voted tonight by a majority of forty-seven against twenty, well over the two-thirds needed for changing the Constitution.

Catholic circles here were delighted today over the decision of the Mexican Supreme Court that the religious law of the State of Chihuahua permitting only one priest in the entire State is unconstitutional.

General Telephone Corporation and Subsidiaries--Twelve months ended March 31: Net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, $1,302,500, comparing with $1,063,125 in the twelve months ended March 31, 1936.
The George M. Kober Medal, one of the most prized recognition in the medical profession, was awarded today to Dr. William H. Park, director of laboratories of the New York City Department of Health.

Jack Strain hurled the Manhattan College freshman team to a 22-0 no-hit triumph over the Yonkers College nine at Ludlow Field today. The Jasper Cubs sent nine runs across the plate in the first inning to insure an easy victory.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 3: REAR ADMIRAL Blakely, C. A., detached as Commandars Naval Air Station, Pensacola, Fla., July, to duty as Commander Carrier Division 2.

A protest was filed today here against probate of the will of John Sage, who died in Ridgewood last October at the age of 70 and left a will disposing of an estate of $425,000, including a bequest of $300,000 'for British soldiers and sailors blinded in the World War.

Herman Minkowitz, 41 years old, a junk dealer, of 111-65 Corona Avenue, Corona, Queens, was found guilty in Queens County Court yesterday of criminally receiving 110 pounds of bronze name plates and American Legion emblems which had been stolen from graves in Mount Hebron Cemetery in Flushing.

Some members of the House of Commons sought information today regarding the circumstances under which the Spanish battleship Espana of the Insurgent forces had been sunk last Friday. Sir Samuel Hoare, First Lord of the Admiralty, said all information in possession of the Admiralty pointed to the conclusion that the Espana had been sunk by a mine and not by bombs.

35th St, 314-16 E; to 3-story factory and offices ; West Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam and 86th St, owner; W. H. J. F. Dusenbury, architects; cost 58,000. 23D St, 408-410 E, to two 5-story tenements and stores; Emil G. Hantsche Jr; 735 1st Ave, owner; Joseph Lau, architect; cost, $4,000.

The International Bureau of Expositions announced yesterday its official acceptance of President Roosevelt's invitation to the New York World's Fair in 1939, in a broadcast from Paris transmitted here over the network of the National Broadcasting Company.

Lybrand, Ross Brothers Montgomery, auditors for the Bell telephone system, were paid $504,450 by] the American Telephone and Telegraph Company last year. This figure stood out from data contained in approximately 200 annual reports for 1936, made to the Securities and Exchange Commission and released yesterday by the New York Stock i Exchange.

Immunization against appendicitis is a possibility offered by research work at McGill University, according to the Canadian Medical Association journal. Dr. Hans Selye, a Viennese research worker in the Department of Biochemistry, reports that accumulation of evidence that

In our correspondence columns on this page today we publish a letter from COURTENAY DINWIDDIE, general secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, expressing the opposition of that committee to the Nunan-Moffat and Wheeler-Johnson bills. The objections that Mr. DINWIDDIE cites are understandable, but they do not seem to us convincing.

Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts proposed in the House today that the Securities and Exchange Commission be directed to Investigate the "abnormal" fluctuations in the stock of the Aluminum Company of America before and after the announcement on

The advance model of the new Hupmobile, which is expected to get into production by Aug. 15, has been shown privately here by Thomas Bradley, president of the Hupmobile Motor Car Company. Its general features, up to this time, had not been made public.

Death Anpoulneed Retired Captain Paul N. Bossert, formerly a member of Engine 152, residing at 41 Harrison Ave., Jersey City, N. J., died May 5. Cbrrectlon The names of the following ununiformed firemen, appointed in compliance with Paragraph X, Special Order 76, April 30, 1937, are hereby corrected. as follows:

The five-story apartment house at 89 Hopkins Street, Brooklyn, has been sold to Louis Katzman by the 89 Hopkins Street Corporation. The structure contains twenty apartments and one store. Alex P. Watts was the broker. Max Chertock acted as attorney.

Properties in Manhattan reported sold yesterday included houses that will be modernized for investment. A syndicate headed by James A. Deretchin bought from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank the two four-story tenement houses at 215 East Fifty-ninth Street.

The complex financial structure erected by the late 0. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen to insure themselves control of a $3,000,000,000 railroad and real estate empire through an initial investment of $800,000 is to be "unscrambled," it was announced last night.

Receipts of the Federal Government for the 1937 fiscal year through May 3 amounted to $4,128,368,000 and were greater than for the entire fiscal year of 1936, when the income was $4,115,956,000, the Treasury announced today.

A meeting of the executive committee of the Millinery Quality Guild will be held this evening to discuss plans for the appeal of the cease and desist order issued by the Federal Trade Commission against the guild on the ground that its trade practices hampered trade and tended to create a monopol.

The Athletics, aided by two infield errors, rushed over six runs in the eighth inning today to open their first invasion of the West with a 7-to-6 victory over the White Sox. Monty Stratton, towering righthander who was after his third straight victory, fell victim of the Philadelphians' big rally.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for May 20 on applications by the Union Electric Light and Power Company of St. Louis and its subsidiaries, the East St. Louis Light and Power Company and the Union Electric Light

A polo team very nearly as strong as the one which defeated the United States for the Cup of the Americas last year is coming back to .this country from Argentina this season, according to word received from there.
Rabbi Asher Chassin, Talmudist, writer and educator, died on Tuesday night in his home at 95 St. Marki's Place of a heart ailment. He was 58 years old.

The Warners' film of Dodie Smith's Theatre Guild play, "Call It a Day," goes into the Capitol this morning, succeeding "Night Must Fall," which had been scheduled for a second week. Its players include Olivia De Havilland, Ian Hunter, Anita Louise and Alice Brady.

An improvement in prices of cotton in foreign markets brought a further recovery of 9 to 12 points on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday. Owing to extensive liquidation of speculative accounts on last month's decline of nearly $10 a bale, a limited floating supply of contracts left the market without selling pressure.

The engagement of Miss Elenore Montague, daughter of Mr. and Mrs; Harry Everett' Montague- of this place, to Robert Vincent Harry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Guy Harry of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

Gains in the number of telephones in use were reported yesterday by companies operating in widely separated sections of the country. The Southern California Telephone Company reported 637,123 telephones in service as of April 30, an increase of 3,323 in the month to a high record.

Delegates at the final session last night of the eighth annual national convention of the Young Communist League went on record in favor of a four-week vacation with pay for employes, the thirty-hour week, collective bargaining, abolition of company unions and freedom of the press and of speech. The session, attended by 529. delegates from thirty-six States, was held at Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street.

Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Cocoa, rubber, copper and coffee futures advanced, while silk and hide futures declined. Other staples were steady. On the cash markets cocoa, buitte'r, eggs, cotton, rubber, all the grains and quicksilver advanced, but' silk, lard, flour and Straits tin fell.

Records subpoenaed from the files of Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob revealed yesterday that they actually lost nothing to each other in $29,766,754 of mutual stock transactions, although they deducted losses of $7,496,170 thereafter from their 1929 taxable incomes.

Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. of New York, founder and sponsor of the Bayway Community Center here, was entertained yesterday at a tea in the center. The Woman's Auxiliary of the Bayway Employes Federation and the Progressive Club assisted the Mothers Club, the official host.

Premier Mitchell Hepburn of Ontario announced today a surplus of $9,313,938 when he issued details of the Province's financial statement for the fiscal year ended on March 31. He said also that a "substantial" reduction in license fees for passenger automobiles will be announced before Oct. 15.
An intense un dercover drive to get the Legislature to 'override Governor Lehman's veto of the four Berg bills, aimed at the American Labor party, failed late this afternoon.
Dr. Robert F. Hyland operated today on Paul Dean's right arm in an effort to enable the Cardinal pitcher to hurl effectively again.
William Alciphron Boring of 420 Vrest 116th Street, dean emeritus of he Columbia University School of Architecture, died yesterday in St. ,uke's Hospital after a long illness. le was T77-years old.

Refusal of officers of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation of Glendale, Calif., to testify resulted today in suspension of a hearing being held by an examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission on a registration statement.

Better business and expanding employment have widened the opportunity'to cut the cost of relief in Canada, and the Federal Government has decided to reduce grants-in-aid to the provinces in the current fiscal year by about 25 per cent.
William E. Felin, president of John J. Felin Co., Inc., meat packers, of 45. Mr. Felin was the son of the founder and succeeded to the presidency upon his father's death in 1929.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local private and public elementary and high schools.

Thirteen horses have been named to compete in the famous, Cedarhurst Grand National handicap steeplechase, feature of the annual Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association, scheduled for Saturday at Cedarhurst,

MIss M. Dorothea Culver, daughter of Mrs. Rudolph C. Culver of this place and the late Mr. Culver, has chosen the afternoon of June 19 for her marriage to Roderick O. Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger H. Williams of 35 West Ninth Street, New York, and Saugatuck, Conn.

A proposal to build an express automobile highway on the east shore of the Hudson River from Yonkers to Peekskill was revived tonight when 125 officials and civic leaders of Hudson River communities voted unanimously in its favor at a meeting called by Yonkers branch of the Architectural and Engineering Alliance of Westchester County. The estimated cost is $60,000,000.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, last night became the first Briton to be admitted as an honorary member of the Society of the Cincinnati, founded by officers of the Cincinnati Line in 1783 and drawing its membership ever since according to the English law of primo. geniture.

Miss Virginia Goodrich, daughter of Mrs. Alfred Goodrich and the late Mr. Goodrich, has chosen June 12 for her marriage to Anthony J. Rytina of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. G. Rytina of Baltimore.

The body of a man identified by the police as Stantes Manetzakes, 47 years old, of 118 West Eightythird Street, a rooming house, was found early yesterday morning in back of the statue of William Cullen Bryant in Bryant Park.

Two of the Minsky brothers, Herbert K. and Morton, who have been among the leaders in the field of burlesque for twenty-five years, announced at their offices in the Oriental Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-second Street, yesterday, that they would no longer be connected with or produce burlesque performances.

A parcel of one and one-quarter acres fronting on Manhasset Bay in Great Neck, L. I., has been sold by the Mesenger estate to Thomas L. Leeming, who plans to erect a Colonial dwelling for occupancy about Oct. 1. Edward J. Clancy, Inc., was the broker.

Desperate but fruitless attempts by the Insurgents to free 2,000 Italian troops trapped in the Bermeo sector northeast of Bilbao occupied the spotlight today in the battle for this capital of the Basque State.

PIE in the sky, has long been the hobo's dream. Now it's a Pittsburgh reality. Pie is up there with his Pirates. It's astonishing and possibly cataclysmic, though Manager Harold J. (Pie) Traynor denied this last with emphasis yesterday. "I know it's strange for us to be in the lead at this time of year," said Pie as he sipped a glass of orange juice.

Dr. Elias Potter Lyon, former dean of the University of Minnesota Medical School, died suddenly of a heart attack in his automobile yesterday. He became ill while he and his wife were motoring to Minneapolis from a vacation in Florida. Dr. Lyon, who resigned as dean last year, was a trustee of Hillsdale College in Miphigan.
Establishment of a clearing house to coordinate activities to "protect the consumer" to be known as the Consumers' National Federation was announced here yesterday. Helen Hall,

The New York Chapter of the National Republican Builders, at a meeting last night in the Bank of the Manhattan Building, Madison Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, adopted resolutions rejecting Mayor La Guardia as the Republican candidate for Mayor next Fall.
A resolution requesting President Federico Laredo Bru to call a conference of all American countries for reducing working hours was approved tonight by the House of Representatives.

Striking employes of the Philadelphia Storage Battery Comlpany and its allied Philco Radio and Television Company held a mass demonstration before the companies' plants today and voted to begin "twenty fourr-hour-a-day picketing."

The Committee for Industrial Organization revoked yesterday the charters of ten building trades locals established in the name of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, a C. I. O. affiliate, by Patrick J. Commerford, who was an influential Tammany labor leader and vice president of the State Federation of Labor until his conviction in December, 1932, on Federal income tax it evasion charges.

Eva Gauthier was heard in a "Coronation Program" of English songs last night at the Hotel Gotham Ballroom by a sizeable audience. The concert was given under the patronage of the British Ambassador and the Canadian Minister to Washington.

Ico on ailerons and wing tips caused the crash of the Transcontinental Western airplane near Clifton, Pa., on March 25, which killed ten passengers and a crew of three, according to a report of the Accident Board of the Bureau of Air Commerce.
Hal Price Headley's Whopper has been assigned top weight of 130 pounds for the Toboggan Handicap, at six furlongs, with $3,000 added, which will be the feature for the opening of Belmont Park Monday.

Some days ago in this column, there was related the story of how Bernard M. Baruch devised and named the "cash-andcarry" (or, as he prefers to call it, the "scuttle-and-run") provision of the new War Policy Law, which has now gone into effect for two years.

Beach Ave (15-3899), e s, 200 ft s of Archer St, 75x92: Lillian Cotkin to Glei-Sol Realty Corp, 349 E 149th St; mtge $68,000. 175th St (11-2878), s e cor of Montgomery Ave; 148x110; Lillian Cotkin to New Deal Associates, Inc, 349 E 149th St; mtge $72,000.

With rain falling, and mud prevailing at Churchill Downs, the question among the thousands invading this city is whether any horse can beat Man o' War's son, War Admiral, for Saturday's $50,000 added Kentucky Derby. He 'rules a heavy choice,.but there was a return of support to Pompoon following a fine workout this morning.

Charles P. Barry, secretary of the Board of Higher Education and also secretary of Washington Square College of New York University, was elected president of the community councils of the City of New York at a meeting of 200 representatives of eighty-two civic organizations of the five boroughs held in the Aldermanic chambers at City Hall last night.

President Roosevelt's bill for reorganization of the Federal courts was condemned as "an utterly futile gesture" and "an extremely dangerous innovation" in a radio speech tonight by Senator O'Mahoney, Democrat, of Wyoming, a warm supporter of the New Deal and a friend of Postmaster General Farley.

Distributors here notified local stores yesterday of the establishment of minimum resale prices on a number of cosmetic products. The Vendome Sales Company issued a price list on Rimmel mascara and lipstick.

Acclaimed as a success by players and umpires, the new legbefore-wicket rule, adopted experimentally for the past two years in 'England, has been incorporated in the laws of cricket. Announcement was made today by the Marylebone Cricket Club, governing body of the sport, that the new rule had been officially and unanimously endorsed.

Merle Middleton, a second cousin of Sheriff Theodore Middleton of Harlan County, Ky., and a former deputy sheriff, who has been named as one of the "head men" jn the reign of terrorism and intimidation of union miners, denied the charges today when called to thie stand before the Senate subcommittee investigating labor espionage and violations of civil liberties in that mining region.

Steel production during April was probably the heaviest for any month in the history of the industry, according to estimates now in process of preparation. Official figures to be issued within a few days should show the output for the mnnth well above the 90 per cent

The Yarine Engineers Beneficial Association and thirty-five engineers formerly employed by the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation were declared the winners in a contest with the company in a decision rendered yesterday by Robert M. Gates, examiner of the National Labor Relations Board.

Trading continued slow on most classes and prices were weak to lower, with slow demand principal factor. All kosher meats declined during late trading Tueday and opening prices yesterday were no more than steady, as reported by the United States Department of AGriculture.
Usinger knowledge of her home course D best advantage, Miss Peggy ,eBoutillier today acquitted herself obly in the opening one-day tourament of the season on the meadow Brook links.

The sugar section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration today issued its fourth monthly report on the status of the 1937 sugar quotas. The report shows that the quantity of sugar charged against the quotas for all off-shore areas, including the full-duty countries, during the four-month period January-April, amounted to 2,038,705 short tons, raw value.
Great Lakes fishermen, demanding higher Federal tariffs to protect American markets from Canadian fish shipments, have arranged a mass meeting at Cleveland Friday for a further protest.

James F. Cronin of the Fanny Farmer Candy Shops of New York has been elected president of the Association of Manufacturers of Confectionery and Chocolate of the State of, New York, it was announced here yesterday.

With London still in the grip of the busmen's strike and with a nation-wide walkout in the coal mines threatened for a week after the coronation, Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin today made a supreme appeal in the House of Commons for peace in industry.

Three-day conference of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers begins at the Hotel Commodore this morning at 11 o'clock. Metropolitan Museum of. Art, "The Art of Italy," Edith R. Abbot, 11 A. M.; "Oriental Art: the Near East," general tour, 2 P. M.;

The .cadets of the' New York Military. Academy will give a full-dress review in honor of three veteran cavalry horses which are being retired on Saturday after long service to the academy's equestrian division.

KING EDWARD VIII: An Intimate Biography, by Hector Bolitho. .(Lippincott, $3.) The author was "official narrator" for the King. CAN ALL THIS GRANDEUR PERISH? and Other' Stories, by James T. Farrell. (Vanguard, $2.50.) New stories by' the author of "A World IT Never Made."

The fate of the old-age pension features of the Social Security Act was left with the Supreme Court today in the final arguments to be heard by the justices at the present term. A decision may be given on May 17, to which date the court recessed after the legal debate ended.

Twenty directors of Ufa., the largest German film concern, have resigned, and the government news service announces a general reorganization of the German film industry according to Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels's ideas.

An incident in Red Square on May Day became known generally only today because it was invisible to all but a few in the immediate vicinity. When the delegation of Spanish Loyalists marched toward Lenin's tomb, their fists raised in the revolutionary salute,
Harvard has a distinguished new teacher in the person of Dr. HEINRICH BRUENING. He was the last Chancellor of democratic

John W. Austin, 36 years old, of Bronxville, N. Y., a disbarred lawyer who, according to Assistant District Attorney John J. Sullivan,defrauded twenty-eight men and women of more than $500,000 in the last four years, pleaded guilty to grand larceny in General Sessions yesterday. The plea, which was accepted by Judge Donnellan,

Several dinners were given last night in the roof garden of the Pierre, which was opened for the season. Mrs. Longstreet Hinton and Miss Lucy Tew entertained for their mother, Mrs. William H. Tew, who celebrated her birthday. Other guests were Mr. Tew, Mr. Hinton, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Truesdale and Louis R. Ripley.

Today is Ascension Day, which a commemorates the ascension of d Jesus Christ into Heaven. In the b Rornan Catholic Church it is one Z of the six Holy Days of Obligation 1 in the United States. At St. Pat- 1 rick's Cathedral the masses will be at 6, 7, 8, 8:30, 9, 10 and 11 A. M., and at 12:15 and 12:50 P. M.

The City Industrial Relations Board will try at a conference in City Hall this afternoon to untangle the labor union jurisdictional dispute which is now threatening to revive possibility of a strike of the street car and bus employes of,the Third Avenue Railway Company.
The FeldHamilton "Civil Seryice Career" Bill was passed in the Senate today and, after the Assembly had concurred in minor amendments, was sent to the Governor.

Quick action by postal employes saved Postmaster General Farley today from uttering one historical inaccuracy, only to voice another. Just before he began speaking at the dedication of a new postoffice in Arlington, Va., a department official pushed his way

The New York bank loans of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, recently reported at $21,528,000, which fell due on May 1, have been renewed at the same rate of interest, 4 per cent, and have been reduced to $20,882,160 by the payment of $645,840, officials of the company announced yesterday.

Next to the largest racing yacht built in this country this year was launched on the high tide at 7 o'clock last night from the Nevins shipyard in City Island. She is the international twelve-meter racer Gleam, for Clinton H. Crane, which he designed. Only Harold S. Vanderbilt's new America's Cup racer Ranger is larger.

First notices of the Bond Club of New York's annual field day were sent yesterday to members in the form of an invitation to join a syndicate for "the best issue of the year." Some 600 members received the following message:

Guarded optimism over the prospects for an Anglo-American trade treaty was expressed by Ambassador Norman H. Davis today in an informal conversation with London correspondents, his first since his arrival last month as chairman of the United States delegation to the International Sugar Conference.

BARCELONA-Peace was restored in the city after the rebellion of anarchists, although occasional shots were heard, said dispatches to France. Anarchists still held two towns. A new provisional government containing only one anarchist was ruling Catalonia. Page 1.

Masterful pitching by Cy Blanton and Arky Vaughan's hard hitting gave the National League's leading Pirates their fourth straight triumph yesterday at Ebbets Field and extended the Dodgers' losing streak to three games.

Commissioner David C. Adle of I the State Department of Social Welfare estimated yesterday that ( 165,000 persons would receive $3,- 4 560,000 this month under the new State social security program for dependent children, the needy aged 1 and the dependent blind.

Investment companyy of AmericaReport for April 80: Net asset value $60.02 a share after adjustment of securities to market prices, Federal income taxes and compensation on unrealized appreciation, compared with $65.55 a share on March 31, 1937, and $49.09 on April 30, 1986.

A program of early American choral music, including seldom-heard cornpositions from the early seven-teenth century, was sung tonight by the Westminster Chapel Choir of 100 voices, one of the features of the second annual festival of American music, which opened here yesterday at the Westminster Choir School.

Turkey was the heaviest purchaser of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States during April, expending $1,904,551 for mnilitary aircraft and $625 for commercial aircraft parts, a total of $1,905,176,

Bernard H. Ridder Jr., '38 of New York City, has been elected captain of the Princeton Tniversity squash racquets team fao next season, it was announced today by the university council on athletics. Doddridge G. Nevitt Jr., '38 of Atlanta was named manager.

A plan to end the Hollywood movie studio strike was accepted by producers but rejected by the Federated Motion Picture Crafts, strike sponsor, late today. "I am in no-way interested," said Charles Lessing, head of FMPC. "The strike goes right on."
The Harvard varsity lacrosse team defeated the M. I. T. stick wielders, 15 to 1, on the Harvard field today. The victory was the fourth straight in the New England Intercollegiate League for Harvard.
City College trounced Upsala, 10-1, at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday to register its sixth victory of the season and avenge the 6-5 triumph the East Orange nine scored over the Beavers last year.

Royal robes and state gowns of Alexandra, consort of Edward VII, were paraded by models and sold to the highest bidders yesterday afternoon at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

Sir Edward Beatty, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, told shareholders at the annual meeting here today that "strong action on the part of all governmental authorities will be required to curb the relief expenditures which are tending to increase, despite returning prosperity."

Mrs. Ratharine Bleecker Meigs was re-elected president of the New York League of Business and Profesional Wodmen at a meeting last night at the Hotel Eiitmore. Outlining plans for the coming y-ear, Mrs. Meigs said the club would con.tmue its program of assisting young women in their careers by offering apprenticeships in several fields m cooperation with emploreras.

According to credible reports reaching here, the Greek dictatorship has added to the number of political personages interned on Aegean Islands for alleged subversive activities connected with Communist propaganda.

The thirteenth annual New Haven Horse Show opened tonight in the Arena to continue through Saturday. Entries failed to come up to expectations and the matinee scheduled for tomorrow has been canceled.

Irving Bacheller, novelist and essayist, received yesterday the annual award given by the Grand Lodge of Masons of New York State for distinguished achievement in the field of art. The award, known as the Grand Master's Medal, was presented at yesterday's session of the annual meeting of the Grand Lodge, at the Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.
