CLONG 109th at, 104 W, 5-story tenement, 25x 100.11; Pamela M. McCaughey against Potick Construction Co, Inc; due, $19,572; taxes, , $3,096; to Plaintiff for $18,000.

Interest in the bond market yesterday was devoted more to the distribution of two large new loans than to trading in seasoned issues on the Stock Exchange. The market for high-grade bonds, however, presented a good background for the marketing of the new issues, prices being firm to slightly better on a moderate turnover.
The new Andrew Jackson High School, erected with Federal funds at a cost of $2,528,000 in Springfield, Queens, will be opened on Monday. Formal dedication will take place in September.

Jannie Ingham Frith, said to be the oldest active schoolmistress in the world, died today of pneumonia at the age of 95. She had been a teacher for seventy-nine years. Her home was Rose Cottage, Paget, where she had been teaching since she was 16. She had taught four generations of many prominent local families, and when she was taken ill three months ago she had twenty-two pupils.

Emil Textor, since 1916 president of the Oldtime Pressmen's Association, died yesterday of meningitis after a day's illness at his home, 105-04 135th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, at the age of 75. For the last twenty years he had been a salesman for J. T. Buntin, Inc.,

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 4: COLONELS Pickering, R. R. Adjutant General's Dept., 1 day's leave, May 5. McCook, P. H., Inf., Ft. Sam Houston, Texas, to El Paso, Texas, in connection with recruiting.

Dr. Finley Ransom Cook, an early practitioner in the use of X-ray therapy in this country, died today at his home, Sleepy Hollow Farm. Twenty years ago, due to frequent exposure to X-ray, he developed cancer, to which he finally succumbed, it was said at his home. He was 66 years old.
Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany informed Great Britain today that Germany would cooperate in a move to prevent airplane attacks on civilians in "open towns" in Spain.

Plans for a spiritual crusade among the Methodists of the United States in celebration of the 200th year of Methodism were outlined to the Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church today by Bishop Ralph S. Cushman of Denver,

Twins never impressed this cor?? as being much of an advantage, ?? something of a gratuitous ?? in fact, until last night when the identical Mauch youngters. Bobby and Billy, came to the Strand in the Warner edition of Mark Twain's "The Prince and the pauper."

The State Supreme Court decided today that the order requiring former State Senator Alexander Simpson of Jersey City to show cause why he should not be disbarred would be dismissed when he filed a release signed by the guardian of a woman client who had complained to the ethics committee of the Hudson County Bar Association that Mr. Simpson had accepted a $500 fee and failed ti perform promised services.
In the teeth of a biting gale that swept off the lake and froze a gallant gathering of 17,000 to the very marrow, George (Twinkletoes) Selkirk twinkled today like a star on a frosty night.
President Roosevelt went after tarpon at Port Aransas late today, and led his party in catching kingfish with four six-pounders. HIis son Elliott landed one.
Federal Judge John W. Clancy yesterday directed J. Rhodes O'Reilly, special master, to take proof relating to the stock holdings of Cities Service Company directors in their own company.
Following civil service examinations taken by 5,342 policemen for promotion to the rank of sergeant, the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday that i,345 officers had qualified.

The condition of the Winter wheat crop was well maintained in April and the indicated yield, as estimated by statisticians here, is 652,000,000 bushels, or only 3,000,000 bushels less than was forecast a month ago. The total wheat harvest in 1936 was 519,000,000 buhsels.

The Republic Steel Corporation, third largest steel producer, stated today that it would meet for collective bargaining purposes with the Committee for Industrial Organization, "but sees no necessity for a signed contract."

The annual Country Fair in behalf of the Home for Seamen's Children will be held Saturday afternoon at the headquarters of the home, 657 Castleton Avenue, Staten Island. Carnival attractions generally associated with old-fashioned country fairs--side-shows, a pet show, the "Country Store," a "White Elephant" table, booths for fortunetelling, a plant and flower table, and rural games will be features.

The old 212th Coast Artillery Armory was returned to the soldiers yesterday. During the last fifty-six days the drill-shed had reverberatedwith the thunderous crashing of mineralite against maple as 22,000 keglers from coast to coast sent countless thousands of balls down twentyeight alleys, toppling tenpins in the thirty-seventh annual championship tournament of the American Bowling Congress.

The Dixiana entry of High Maria and Pete's Niece finished one-two in the Jeanne d'Arc Stakes, a fourand-a-half-furlong sprint for 2-yearold fillies, the feature of today's midweek card at Narragansett Park.

Representative John Luecke, Democrat, of Michigan, told the House today that he believed a six-hour workingday would create jobs for the country's unemployed and suggested that Henry Ford be the first to etablish it.

Up to now the Rockefeller interests have not gone on record as to whether the Stallings-Schwartz operetta, "Virginia," would find a haven at the Center Theatre next season. Nevertheless, negotiations are proceeding with scenic designers. For instance,

The Cardinals downed the Bees, 13-1, today as Dizzy Dean hung up his fourth straight triumph of the season. Dizzy fanned eleven batters and did not issue a base on balls. The Cardinals wasted no time granting Dean a four-run margin.
Retail package deliveries for the !week ended May 1 showed an increase of 10 per cent over the corresponding week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United States Parcel Service.

The Society of Automotive Engineers opened itsI five-day annual meeting here this morning with an attendance which included delegates from all over the country and England. South Africa and Japan and a program of topics ranging from airplane radio to road trailers "de luxe."

The Norwood Country Club at Long Branch, N. J., has been purchased by William I. Rosenfeld of 604 Fifth Avenue, whose bid has been approved by the court. The property includes an eighteen-hple golf course, a clubhouse valued at $250,000, outbuildings and tennis courts.

The Cubs pounded four pitchers for seventeen hits, which included home runs by Joe Marty, Frank Demaree and Ripper Collins, to score a 17-4 victory over the Phillies today in the second game of their series.

Uniformity of social security and labor laws in the forty-eight. State. is necessary before the preacnt re" "I lief set-up can be -brought to'n t: end, Mayor La Guardia said last night at the twelfth annual dinner meeting of the Welfare Council of ' New York City at the Hotel Delmonico.

Now that the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Simpson are reunited in the Ch de Cande there is only one point of interest-the date of their marriage. It is precisely the only points on which no definite information is forthcoming.

Advising emphasis on quality and style, George Miller, president of the Shoe Fashion Guild of America and head of I. Miller Sons, counseled retailers "to let price levels next Fall take,-care of themselves" in an address at the luncheon closing the Fall show of the guild at the Hotel Biltmore.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Niagara Hudson Power Corportion, said today at a hearing before the Public Service Commission: "Assuming no major setback, such as a war in Europe or radical inflation, Niagara Hudson will need to spend at least $100,000,000 in the next five years to build additional generating plants and distribution facilities to serve its customers."

The Sixty-first Cavalry Division has accepted an invitation to participate in the jumping tests of the Jubilee Horse Show scheduled for Soldier Field, Chicago, June 9-13, it was announced yesterday by Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy,
The probable pitchers in the major leagues today follow: American League Boston at St. Louis-Walberg vs. Walkup. New York at Detroit-Hadley vs.Bridges. Washington at Cleveland-Weaver vs. Brown.

Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced in the House of Commons yesterday that the fees and stamp duties, ranging from [Pound]350 for a duke to [Pound]100 for a baronet and [Pound]30 for a knighthood and similar honors would be abolished.

A minimum wage law for women and workers under 21 won the approval today of Pennsylvania's Legislature. The House had changed the bill to exempt newsboys, domestic help and those engaged in agriculture, and returned it to the Senate for approval.

The Chase National Bank issued yesterday a statement that in March it had sold 2,500 shares of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation common stock and 1,200 shares of preferred from holdings which amounted at the beginning of that month to 340,189 shares of the former and 680,378 shares of the latter, not counting a small block of stock in escrow.

President Wilhelm Miklas, Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg and other Austrian officials who have been visiting in Hungary for three days left here this afternoon. Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent, conferred on President Miklas the Grand Cross of the Hungarian Order of Merit-the only foreign decoration apart from papal honors the Austrian President lhas ever accepted.

Joseph Gedeon, who was arrested on a charge of illegal possession of a pistol during the investigation into the murder of his wife, Mary; their daughter, Veronica, and a roomer, Frank Byrnes, was held yesterday by Magistrate McKiniry for trial in Special Sessions. His former bail of $1,000'was continued.

Mary Nolan, who was known under that name and as Imogene Wilson on the stage and screen, was released from the psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon. Worn and pale, she answered questions put to her by reporters with the remark:

Governors Island Leave of absence is granted to each of the following Reserve officers, effective on or about the date specified: Capt. Julius H. Haecker, C.A.-Res., five days, May 3. Capt. Nathan P. Rudjtsky, M.I.-Res., one month, May 12.

Aided by two home runs, Penn defeated Swarthmore on Franklin Field today, 11-7. Jim Hauze connected for the circuit in the first with Diven on base, and Ed Mohler drove into the center-field stands in the thrid to start a theree-run spurt. Hauze and Sonny Brown each made three hits.

The securities and Exchange Commission issued a report today concerning a reorganization plan for the International Paper and Power Company which is to be presented to the stockholders at their annual meeting in June. In issuing this,

By virtually a straight party vote, the Assembly today passed a bill introduced by Assemblyman Moffat, New York City Republican, in his capacity as chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, to repeal the capital gain and loss provision in the Personal Income Tax Law.

The battle in Congress to enact sea-safety legislation began in earnest today when the Senate Committee on Commerce held a hearing on the "safe ship bill," drafted to make effective the rules and regulations for ship construction and operation recommended by a committee of marine engineers, architects, builders and operators.

George C. Johnston has arranged a tenyear first mortgage building and perma- I nent loan of $170,000 with the New York Life Insurance Co. on the six-story apartment under construction on the e s of I 77th St 100 ft n of 37th Ave, Jackson Heights, Queens, for the Paul Dor Realty Corp.

A building containing a 600-seat moving picture theatre and six stores will be erected on the north side of East Tremont Avenue, between the Concourse and Anthony Avenue, the Bronx, where the Viewland Holding Corporation bought a vacant plot 100 by 87 feet

On the ground the city was not financially able to afford it, the State Supreme Court, for the second time within four years, voided today a Camden referendum authorizing the construction of a municipal power plant costing $10,000,000.

Nominations for the four chief WOODBUR offices of the Hunter College Stu- Mr. and Mrs. dent Self-Government Association of Woodbury were made along 'platform" lines engagement yesterday rather than on the more Miss Jessie usual basis of personality and school Stanley J. service Mass.

The engagement of $3,254,000 gold in Great Britain for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This engagement brought to $490,300,000 the total of gold obtained in England for United States account since Sept. 26, 1936.

James L. Carhart, Civil War veteran and retired actor, died here last night at the home of Mrs. Mary Pearsall of pneumonia. He was 93 years old. After the war he became an actor and supported many of the leading players of the time, including E. L. Davenport, Edwin Booth, John Drew, Maurice Barrymore and Laura Keene.

The United Carr Fastener Corporation has called its remaining $1 preferred stock for redemption on June 15 at $23 a share plus a dividend of 25 cents. Of the original total of 50,000 shares issued in September, 1935, 6,300 are outstanding. Up to June 9 the stock is convertible, share for share, into common stock.
Reports reached here tonight that the armistice declared at Barcelona between the warring trade union factions had already been -broken and that street fighting had been resumed.

The whole Irish detachment of 750 men is leaving the Madrid front for Caceres, Lisbon and Ireland. Insurgent General Francisco Franco is paying all expenses of the voyage. Franco sent a warm letter of thanks to General Owen O'Duffy.
Electric power production increased last week when a decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index advanced to 107.04 from 106.0. It was 99.3 for the week ended May 2, 1936.

Albert Bigelow Paine, biographer of Mark Twain, left his library on Joan of Are to the National Institute of Arts and Letters in New York City, it was disclosed today. His will, admitted to probate yesterday by Judge Jonathan Sanford, specified that the institute should receive the volumes by Mr. Paine

Four bronze plaques were given by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to division managers of the Borden Company in recognition of their safe-driving records in the last year. H. A. Cronk, president of the Borden Farm Products division of the company, introduced three of the managers to the Mayor.

Henceforth observers of international politics must reckon with the existence of a new factor which has been emerging for some time and now begins to assume a definite shape. Russians describe it as Leon Trotsky's organization; the people of Western Europe loosely speak of a "Fourth International";

More than $100,000 was spent in newspaper and radio advertising to promote the magazine The New York Woman, with the result that the circulation rose so high that printing and paper costs far exceeded estimates and operating deficits amounted to $436,070 within a year, William E. Wheeler, president of The New York Woman, Inc., testified yesterday before Assistant Attorney General Ambrose V. McCall.
Mayor LA GUARDIA does not have to beware the fate which overtakes individuals when all men speak well of them. Yet he must find satisfaction in the praise that seeks him out and finds

Be- to hind the six-hit pitching of Patton, hurl the Trinity College baseball team vanquished Wesleyan today, 7-1. stee Horne, who had the hurling assign- SprJ ment for the losers, allowed only Stem eight blows.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, evoked repeated demonstrations of applause at the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today when he made impassioned pleas for unity in the inter-union controversy that has split the ranks of organized labor.

The Senate approved today two bills which sponsors asserted would avert a crisis in the milk industry. One was the Rogers-Allen bill. This has been attacked from various quarters, but on the insistence of Governor Lehman it was amended from the form in which it was passed by the Assembly so as to bar any fixing of prices to consumers.

The Alpha Delta Phi Club, one of the oldest fraternity clubs in New York, celebrated its forty-seventh anniversary last evening at its club headquarters, 136 West Forty-fourth Street. erected thirty years ago.
A large audience attended the benefit concert given last night at Carnegie Hall under the sponsorship of the Dress Industry Division of the American Committee for Settlement of Jews in Birobidjan.

Stockholders of Educational Pictures, Inc., will be notified today by E. W. Hammons, president, that the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on May 1 a minor amendment to the registration statement covering 150,000 shares of sixty-cent dividend cumulative convertible preferred stock of $5 par value and 499,729 shares of $1 par common stock. The registration statement is expected to become effective about May 21, according to the letter to stockholders.

The National Board of the Young Women's Christian Associations at its annual meeting yesterday at its headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue, re-elected Mrs. Frederic M. Paist of Wayne, Pa., president. She will head the board for her sixth consecutive year.

In the presence of Chancellor Adolf Hitler and amid the cheers of 50,000 delegates from all parts of the country, there was launched here today from the shipyards of Blohm and Voss the first ocean liner ever built as a workers' vacation ship.

Holding the first court of their reign, King George and Queen Elizabeth tonight received the diplomatic corps, the British aristocracy and many others at a brilliant reception that began the royal entertainments in celebration of the coronation.
Stocks eased and closed lower; turnover, 767,160 shares. United States Government bonds steady and higher, other issues fi'nm and mixed; transactions, $9,.177.700.
A four-week strike of several hundred hub and die cutters, tool and chain makers in the Providence jewelry industry was settled today.
Miss Helen M. Dobbins, niece of Mrs. John B. Parsons, was married this evening at the home of her aunt to Kendall E. Read, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kendall Read of Rose Valley.
Canada will permit the sale of "Coronation Commentary,"- a book about King Edward VIII and his abdication, despite its withdrawal in Britain by .the publishers.

A portrait of William Church Osborn was presented to the Children's Aid Society by the board of trustees, two former trustees, Thomas W. Lamont and Arthur Curtiss James, and staff members at a. reception and tea yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue. The presentation was in recognition of his thirty-five years' service as president of the society.

A concurrent resolution calling for adjournment of the Legislature Friday noon was adopted by the Assembly today and sent to the Senate, where it went to the Committee on Finance. The action was taken after a conference between Senator Dunnigan and Speaker Heck of the Assembly.
Rafael Lugo Julbe, 17 years old, today pleaded guilty to placing the May Day bomb which exploded outside the plant of the newspaper Imparcial.

The Phillips Andover Academy team defeated the New HIampshire Freshmen by 5-1 today. Joe Phelan, in his first game, pitched no-hit ball for five innings, the cubs scoring on two errors in the fourth. Hazen,

The trials of Catholic friars in the intensive German campaign against alleged immoralities in monasteries were resumed today. A Coblenz court convicted a number of defendants on charges of immoral conduct with minors, and in one case a Capuchin monk was found guilty of having befriended hoboes in an immoral manner.

A plea that women take more interest in government affairs and in health conditions was made by' Miss Ruth de Young, woman's editor of The Chicago Tribune, in an address before the Congress of Parents and Teachers today.

Dr. Cesar Charlone, Finance Minister of Uruguay, arrived yesterday on the Munson liner Southern Cross to start with officials of the State Department conversations that may lead to negotiation of a trade treaty with the United States.

With the hazard of timber fires increasing with a continuance of the dry weather of the last several days, more than twenty brush fires were reported in New Jersey and several on Long Island yesterday.

With a bullet wound through the head, the body of a man identified from his fingerprints as Joseph Bonura, alias "Baby Steve" Lojacano, 28 years old, of 327 East 108th Street, was found at 9:20 o'clock last night not far from his home on East 108th Street near the East River Drive, where it evidently had been flung from an automobile. Police found no clues to the killers.
Earnings of the American Rollng Mill Company for the first quarter of this year, announced yesterday, were the largest for any threemonth period in the history of the company. Moreover,

Offering will be made today of $950,000 of city of Baltimore (Md.) Burnt District Improvement 3% per cent registered. stock by a group composed of Lazard Freres Co., Inc.; Blyth Co., Inc., and R. W. Pressprich Co. The stock will be priced to yield 2.60 per cent.

The second year class of the Columbia Law School, under the supervision of Professor James P. Gifford, will publish next Spring what is considered to be the first law school annual ever publishedI in the East.

Employment in March was higher than in 1929 in the twenty-five major manufacturing industries, according to a report issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. The number of wageearners employed in the reporting manufacturing industries in March was .5 per cent higher than in 1929.

Washington Irving High's gymnasium re-echoed with the ringing of steel blades last night as twentyfour outstanding schoolboy fencing stars participated in the preliminary round of the P. S. A. L. individual championship. After several hours the list of contestants was pared to twelve 'ioilsmen, who qualified for'the semi-final round, slated for next Tuesday.
The residence at 49 East Sixty-eighth Street was leased by Warren L. Marks, spaniel Brener, Inc., for Margaretta Clark. It adjoins the residence of Percy Pyne and will be occupied by the lessee.

In a day that was characterized by rough riding, two jockeys sustained broken legs at Jamaica yesterday. Eddie Litzenberger suffered a double fracture in his left leg in a jam that occurred in front of the clubhouse in the nightcap, in which he had the mount on Marfree, and Mike Corona received a fracture riding Buddies in the opener.

The Ostrucon Distilled Products Company, Inc., of New York today was cited by the Federal Alcohol Administration on charges of violation of the Federal Alcohol Administration Act and of labeling regulations.
Last night's session of the Composers Forum Laboratory held at the WPA Theatre of Music presented works of Hunter Johnson of the University of Michigan, a winner of the Prix de Rome.

Large investments outside the field of railroading were disclosed in the report of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway to the Interstate Commerce Commission made public yesterday. Slight increases in the salaries of its leading officers also ALLE were reported.

The House Naval Affairs Committee ordered an investigation today to determine whether further legal action should be taken in an effort to recover about 23,000 acres of oil lands held largely by the Standard Oil Company of California.

Indications that there will be a Czech shoe factory at Lima, Peru, were reported to the Department of Commerce by Julian Greenup, American Commercial Attach6, it was announceid today. The report said plans for the building have been made and a survey of Peruvian taxation and labor regulations started. The first plant will confine itself to manufacture of canvas-top shoes, it was added.
Fire destroyed the Castle Baths on the Boardwalk here this afternoon and damaged several adjacent waterfront stores before it was brought under control. The total damage was estimated at $50,000.

The explosion of a bomb on the Bordeaux-Marseilles express, racing at a mile a minute, killed a French passenger today and injured twenty others. The bomb, apparently smuggled aboard the train, was tied to the coupling between two passenger coaches. Investigators said it was a combination explosive and incendiary infernal machine.

A conference at an early date with a committee representing the Infants' and Children's Knitwear Division, affiliated with the National Knitted Outerwear Association, on the new trade practices adopted by the division was sought yesterday by W. L. Walker,
Mr. and Mrs. Asahel Willis Mitchell of Woodbury have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Miss Jessie Stanton Mitchell, to Stanley J. Slater of, Wollaston, Mass.

A total-of $69,800 was given to the Special Gifts Committee of the cur- rent Catholic Charities appeal last week, John A. Coleman, chairman of the committee, reported yesterday at a meeting of the Empire *State Club.

Circuit Judge John Simpson imposed a thirty-day jail term and a $250 fine today on William Kics of Cleveland, United Automobile Workers organizer, charged with contempt of an anti-picketing injunction following a clash with police at the Trenton Garment Company plant Tuesday.
It is not surprising that the communique following the meeting in Rome between Premier MUSSOLINI and Baron VON NEURATH records the usual "community" of interests and identity of "views."

Francisco Castillo Najera, the Mexican Ambassador to Washington, is expected to return tomorrow or Friday by plane to his post after hav-. ing conferred with President Lazaro i Cardenas. He flew here hurriedly:
The second annual plant sale for the benefit of the Women's Exchange of Oyster Bay will be held here on Friday afternoon and all day Saturday at the Women's Exchange Building.

The Federal Government definitely accused Governor Hoffman of New Jersey today of participating in the Parker conspiracy case, as Federal Judge William Clark admitted, over the heated protest of defense counsel, testimony depicting the Executive as an important background figure in the affair.

Through the intercession of Federal Judge John C. Knox and the work of Major William J. Mack, appointed by Judge Knox to be special master and arbitrator, peace has been restored between the Schulte cigar-store chain and more than 1,000 of its employee in stores in six Eastern States.

A solemn requirem mass was celebrated yesterday for Police Inspector Louis F. Dittman at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church on Church Avenue, Brooklyn. Rev. Richard A. Walsh was the celebrant; the REv. Joseph Egan, deacon, and the Rev. Frederick Hentz, subdeacon. Burial was in Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.
There was a Greek at the Polo " Grounds yesterday who had a word for it-and he" said it with home . runs. Alex Kampouris is his name and he plays an infield post for the Reds. ..

Manufacturers of better coats and suits are looking forward with interest to the reception accorded West Coast showings of Fall and Winter lines, scheduled to start next week at price advances which, on the basis of increases in cost of materials alone, will average 10 to 15 per cent, regardless of what settlement is arrived at with the union.
Freak weather within the last few days produced heavy frost, flood and drought in this equatorial zone.

An American business executive who has just arrived from Rio Grande do Sul reports that State is absolutely calm. The tension caused by the Federal government's action in transferring to the commander of the military zone powers hitherto held by Governor J. A. Flores da Cunha has apparently abated.

The Soviet authorities, who appear to be deeply concerned over the dangers of foreign espionage, have begun the systematic education of the people on how to detect foreign spies and how to avoid being drawn by trickery into their service.

Dr. W. A. E. Cummings died at his home here this morning. He was born at Putnam seventy-seven years ago. He was graduated from the Albany Medical College in 1884, but because of ill health he did not practice his profession.
Finland and Germany are indignant over the Estonian Government's: restrictions on the German Lufthansa airplane service between Berlin, Riga, Latvia; Reval, Estonia and Helsingfors.

The annual Spring benefit bridge, tea and fashion show of Colony House, Inc., Brooklyn settlement, the proceeds of which will be used to send underprivileged children to camp this Summer, was held yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Plaza.
Secretary Roper advised American business today against "unguarded expansions," predicated on "abnormal demand conditions" resulting from foreign armament activities.
Hopkins School pounded a 13-to-4 victory over Loomis after Pitoher Vanderbeau, faltered in the fifth inning today,. Bobby Wood allowed Loomis only seven hits.

Edward E. Loomis, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company for twenty years, resigned today at a meeting of the board of directors here. He explained later that he was "going to try to take thingsgs a little easier."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial "Barring Child Labor," in which you support the Nunan-Moffat and Wheeler-Johnson bills as a method of accomplishing the abolition of child labor, you state that Section 4, "boldly adopting the principle of the invalidated Child Labor Act of 1916, prohibits the shipment of the products of child labor in interstate commerce."
Lawrence Mullen, one of five gunmen who held up Barney's clothing establishment at 111 Seventh Avenue Jan. 2, was declared sane in a report yesterday to General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi by a

For the second straight year,' Soldiers Fate, from the stables of Campbell Weir, near Wilmington, Del., won the Gardner Cassatt Challenge Cisp event, a two-and-a-half-mile race over brush,"at-the opening of the Radnor Hunt Club Spring meet on the Chesterbrook Farms course today.

The registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 49,000 shares of $1-per value common stock of Air Associates, Inc., of Garden City, L. I., has become effective, F. Leroy Hill, president, announced yesterday.

The stock market here continued to be cheerful today and, although price advances were small in general, some strong individual features developed. Giltedge issues failed to hold early gains but among the foreign bonds Japanese loans again advanced.

The ugly lines of electric wiring which for forty years have disfigured the exterior of the sixteenth century Spanish fortress, El Morro, will be removed by order of Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, commander of the Second Corps Area in New York, according to Colonel J. W. Wright, commanding the Sixtyfifth Infantry, which is quartered here. The new wiring will be buried in the walls.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted, with conditions, an application by the Boise Gas Light and Coke Company for an order declaring it not to be a subsidiary company of Hugh M. Morris and John N. Shannahan, trustees of the estate of the Midland United Company, a registered holding company.

Beginning this week, General Motors advertising will appear in approximately 400 college newspapers and in Collegiate Digest, a rotogravure supplement circulating with 316 college papers throughout the country.

A special stamp bearing the portraits of -the king and queen-which looks for all the world like the tops of the souvenir boxes of candy now being sold to tourists-will be issued the day after the coronation. In addition, a new, permanent series replacing Edward's "streamlined" issue will be placed on sale Monday.

A city-wide strike of journeymen barbers, affecting 20,000 men in 7,500 shops, was voted last night at a meeting of the joint board of the Journeymen Barbers International Union of America, held at 1 Union Square.
Governor Lehman sent two special messages to the Legislature today. One expressed approval of the Ives bill to create a commission to study the fiscal picture of the State.

With a desire to correct any existing evils, the Association of Sportsmen's Clubs of Greater New York and Long Island has called upon sportsmen to cooperate so that fishing privileges along the Rockaway beaches will not be discontinued.
In the midseason Paquin collection only Summer models are being shown. Lace is Important for black and navy-blue afternoon frocks, as well as for black and 6cru evening gowns.

There is no "immediate danger" of the socialization of either dentistry or medicine, Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, president of the American Medical Association, and Dr. Leroy M. S. Miner, president of the American Dental Association, told the sixty-ninth annual convention yesterday of the Dental Society of the State of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria. Hotel.

I Lady Blackett will arrive Monday from London to visit her sister, Mrs. Charles W. Bowring of 66 East Ninety-first Street. Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Adams Jr. have arrived at the St. Regis from Wellesley, Mass.

Suggestions for reorganization of the Republican party have cropped up again, but have found leaders reluctant to discuss them pending the outcome of the intra-Democratic-row over the Supreme Court enlargement bill.

Powers Hapgood, New England secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization, testified before a Supreme Court jury today that the union spent about $60,000 in its efforts to organize LewistonAuburn shoe workers.

More erratic afield, but considerably more fortunate than Yale on the base paths, Columbia defeated the Elis, 4 to 3, in ten innings at Baker Field yesterday, thus ousting the visitors from a tie for the lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League and atoning for an early season 17 to 2 setback.

The Union of Orthodol Rabbis of the United States and Canada, at its thirty-second annual convention in the Hotel Ostend, here, voted today "not to recede one iota" in its contention that the agunah, or deserted Jewish wife, cannot obtain a religious divorce so long as the husband refuses to return and give his consent.

A recital of sales and merchandising helps extended by Standard Brands, Inc., to small and medium size bakers, opened the company's defense yesterday in the Federal Trade Commission's complaint that Standard Brands violated the Robinson-Patman act through discriminating in price between different purchasers of baker's yeast.
Pounding out thirteen hits off two pitchers for a total of twentytwo bases, Fordham's baseball team gained an easy victory over Temple yesterday at Fordham Field. The score was 14-8,

Jamaica High's powerful nine advanced another step closer to its second successive Queens P. S. A. L. championship by conquering Richmond Hill by 7-4 yesterday at Farmers Stadium as Phil Feldman and Tom Kelly combined in letting the losers down with a pair of safeties. The triumph was the.

Dr. Arthur Hunter of New York, vice president for the United States of the permanent committee of the International Congresses of Actuaries, was appointed chairman today of the delegation to the Eleventh International Congress of Actuaries to be held in Paris from June 17 to 24.

Mrs. Thomas J. Beresford of West Suffield has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bernice Elizabeth Beresford, to Charles Stockwell Comstock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Comstock of Simsbury.

A. C. Compton's Weston won his fifth race of the year in the Grade A handicap, high spot of today's program. The 5-year-old sprint star bounded to the finish line a length I and a half in advance of A. G. Vanderbilt's Airflame, who in turn led Mrs. Emil Denemark's Higher Cloud by a length.

Yesterday the Supreme Court heard arguments on the last important enactment of the Roosevelt Administration to come before it at this term. The question at issue was the constitutionality of the old-age pension plan established by the Social Security Act.

Owen Cathcart-Jones, British aviator, who with Ken-Waller set a flight record of 5 days 15 hours 23 minutes between Australia and England in 1934, pointed out here yesterday to the Canadian Press that reports of last Monday, crediting H. F. Broadbent of Australia with a new mark for the flight, had been in error.
The Works Progress Administration, which has seen just about everything in the way of demonstrations, witnessed yesterday its first parade by pickets encased in barrels.
With his brother, former Mayor Cornelius H. Burns, so dangerously ill at his home that he could not be informed, James H. Burns, former postmaster, died suddenly of a heart attack today.

HECTOR BOLITHO is a colonial who has found in England's royal institutions the prolonged joy of a convert. He was writing historical dramas about empresses when he was 16, a schoolboy in New Zealand. Hebecameashipnews reporter for an Auckland newspaper, had a turn as literary editor for a daily in Australia, and then went to England.
Miss Lillie May Clarkson, daughter of Mrs. Rutgers Clarkson of this city and the late Mr. Clarkson, will be married to Walter Edward Stager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Stager of Nutley, on June 5.

Steel production for the country is estimated at 92 per cent of capacity for the current week with new business showing only a slight decline, according to the weekly summary of Iron Age. Bookings for April were heavier than expected in view of the recordbreaking March tonnage and the fact that prices will not be advanced for the third quarter, the survey shows.

MANHATTAN LEVY, MINNIE D. (April 27). Estate, more than $10,000. To Tena D. Harris, sister, Hotel Beacon, 75th St. and Broadway, household, personal effects and one-third residue; Carrie Moos, sister, 329 Moss Ave., Peoria, Ill., and Charles S. Davidson, brother, 315 West End Ave., one-third residue each; Janet Moos, greatniece, 211 W. 106th St., $1,000; Ettie Samuels, sister, 230 Central Park West, specific jewelry.

Charles (Red) Ruffing, burly right-handed pitcher and major league baseball's last holdout of the season, terminated his one-man strike against the Yankees tonight. After a day of conferences with Manager Joe McCarthy and much telephoning with Colonel Jacob Ruppert in New York, it was announced that Big Red had capitulated.

Rudolph Arnstein, an importer of linens and former New York and Newark department store executive died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 55. Mr. Arnstein was born in Hungary. When he was 25 years old he came to this country and studied merchandising in Graduate Schools at Columbia and New York Universities.

John A. Palm, 25-year-old paroled convict of Mount Vernon, was found guilty today of murder in the first degree in the shooting of Deputy Sheriff Peter Kaminski of this city at Gulf Beach, Milford, last Fall.

Dr. and Mrs. Leslie P. Abbe of West Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lois Seville Abbe, to Frank Thomas Carney, son of Mrs. Helen A. Carney, also of this place, and the late James M. Carney.
An informal poll of Nebraska's onehouse Legislature disclosed today an overwhelming sentiment for retention of the unicameral system and against reversion to the twohouse Assembly.

The organization of a new national union of seamen, with a potential membership estimated at 100,000 men, was announced here yesterday by leaders of the insurgent groups of sailors and stewards who directed shipping strikes last year on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts.

Seven men who were convicted March 25 of conspiracy, extortion and attempted 'extortion in. New York's restaurant racket' filed an application for a. writ of. habeas corpus-here today. The defendants, now in Sing Sing prison at Ossining,. alleged that Supreme Court Justice-Philip J. McCook erroneously and illegally continued their New York trial after an eighth defendant, on trial with them, -had won a mistrial.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company of California voted yesterday to declare an extra dividend of 20 cents, in addition to the regular quarterly distribution of 25 cents. Extra dividends of 5 cents a share were paid in the four preceding quarters.
Awards by the Commission for Relief in Belgium EducationalI Foundation of fourteen Summer stipends for Study of Flemish art and modern Belgian art in Brussels this Summer were announced yesterday.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, threw his support yesterday to the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks against the International Longshoremen's Association in the jurisdictional dispute between these two A. F. of L. unions which last month threatened to cause a strike of 25,000 members of the brotherhood on nine railways in the New York area.

Savings deposits in Argentine banks in 1936 reached the record total of 1,800,000,000 pesos ($605,000,000 at the official rate of exchange), compared with 1,650,000,300 pesos ($555,000,000) in 1935, according to the Argentine Information Bureau. Last year's deposits even surpassed the peak year of 1929, when savings deposits amounted to 1,732,000,000 pesos ($580,000,000).

A virtual threat to seek the break-up of the New York, New Haven Hartford system and a proposal for competitive operation in the heart of what has been considered New Haven territory for a half century was revealed today' in a letter of protest to the trustees sent by the members of the stockholders' protective committee of the Old Colony

The Municipal Civil Service Commission distributed about 10,500 applications for the forthcoming examination for fireman yesterday on the first day of the distribution period, which continues until May 19.

Fordham's tennis team registered a 5-3 triumph over Rutgers today. Del Guercio, Walsh and Maciezewiski scored singles victories and Del Guercio and Walsh and Hogan and Maciezewiski won doubles matches for Fordham.

In the space of seven months the hostile attitude of South Africans toward American goods has been completely reversed and the Union now hopes to increase its purchases in the United States by better than 30 per cent,

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, threw his support yesterday to the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks against the International Longshoremen's Association in the jurisdictional dispute between these two A. F. of L. unions which last month threatened to cause a strike of 25,000 members of the brotherhood on nine railways in the New York area.

Share prices drifted irregularly lower yesterday in dull trading. Losses ranged from small fractions to about 2 points, with final quotations approximating the day's low levels. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange was' 770,000 shares, compared with 871,000 on Tuesday and with 638,000 on Monday.

Dr. Joseph Epps brown Jr., former Princeton University faculty member, died here today after an illness of two years. Dr. Brown was connected with the Doubleday, Page Publishing Company for five years before taking his doctor's degree at Princeton.
Members of the United Automobile Workers of America at General Motors' Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants began a sit-down strike today in protest against the discharge of thirty-seven employes.

Rear Admiral Charles A. Blakely, commander of the Naval Aircraft Station at Pensacola, was designated today to command Carrier Division' 2, which will be composed of the new 20,000-ton aircraft carriers Yorktown and Enterprise, with their aviation squadrons, and will be based with the United States fleet.
Duke University's widely heralded nine lived up to advance notices today on University Field in routing Princeton, 8-1, for its sixteenth victory in eighteen starts this Spring.

Borough PresidentIngersoll opened bids yesterday at Brooklyn Borough Hall for the new Appellate Division court house, Monroe Place and Pierrepont Street. There were thirteen bids. The lowest offer was $772,000 by the firm of Psaty Fuhrmann, Inc., and the highest, $887,500, by Rosoff Brothers, Inc.

Directors of Carib Syndicate, Ltd., have declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common capital stock, or at the option of the holder, one-quarter of a share of stock for each share held, the company announced yesterday. The dividend is payable on June 7 to stock of record of May 14.

Tlhe text of Prime Minister tanley Baldwin's "last-appeal" in the House of Commons today, a plea for industrial peace, follows: I felt I should like to make a contribution to this debate on two grounds. First of all,

The Zeppelin Hindenburg, making its first voyage this year from Germany to the United States, bucked headwinds last night along the North Atlantic seaboard. With the dirigible slowed to 42 knots, according to reports received by American Airlines, plans to land at Lakehurst, N. J., at 6 A. M. today were abandoned.

KINGS DAWSON, EMMA L. (Jan. 10, 1936). Gross assets, $4,952; net, $2,925. To sister, Helen B. Dawson, one-half of residuary estate and $11,213; brother, James T. Dawson, one-half of residuary estate and realty. Chief assets, real estate, $4,400; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $552. George A. Logan, attorney, 70 Pine St.. Manhattan.
Broadcasting companies, including the short-wave educational station W1XAL from Boston, will carry various events during the Mount Holyoke Centenary celebration this week-end.

Manhattan's baseball team turned back the University of Newark, 5 to 1, at Manhattan Field yesterday but the triumph, the seventh in nine starts for the Jaspers, was only incidental to the loss for the season of Frank 'Jost, brilliant sophomore shortshop, and the discovery of an excellent pitching prospect in Don Phillips, a righthander.

The army contract under Invitation 270 for 1,725 wool-filled comforters, 84 by 96 inches, containing 7 1/2 pounds of wool or noils in grades not lower than 56's today was awarded to the Comfy Manufacturing Company at $11.93 each, less 2 per cent twenty days.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag ruled yesterday that Curtis B. Dall, former son-in-law of President Roosevelt, had been libeled by an article in Time magazine purporting to describe his suicide in the White House.

Mrs. Ruth Haller Ottaway of 128 Central Park South, widow of Elmer James Ottaway, and Nikolai Sokoloff of Washington, orchestra conductor and director of the WPA Federal Music Project, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building.

One of the major steps in the construction of the $30,000,000 Wards Island sewage disposal project will be completed at 3 P. M. today, when the sewage tunnel between the island and 100th Street, Manhattan, is holed through.

Nearly 800,000 persons now living in this country will be murdered and about 200,000 Americans will cornmit murder before they die, it the present homicide rate continues, D. M. Ladd, head of the Chicago staff of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, predicted here in an address tonight.

The most talented students of the Music School Settlement appeared on the program of that institution's annual Spring concert at Town Hall last night under the direction of Melzar Chaffee.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau' follows: The weather of the week was rather unfavorable in the Cotton Belt. East of the Mississippi River rains were frequent, there was much cloudy weather and in considerable areas temperatures were relatively low, making unfavorable conditions for seeding and germination.
The four-cent gasoline tax forced through the Statfe Legislature on Tuesday was denounced yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, executive vice president of the Automobile Club of New York.

Registration for the Catholic Schools Music Contests, sponsored by the Music Education League in cooperation with the Archdiocese of New York and the Diocese of Brooklyn, is more than double that of last season, it was announced yesterday.

The twentyeight-day strike of Thermoid Rubber Company employes was settled tonight when, in the presence of Governor Hoffman and William C. Liller, United States Department of Labor conciliator, an agreement was signed at the Stacy-Trent Hotel by Fred E. Schluter, company president, and Joseph P. Dietrich, president of Local 83. United Rubber Workers of America, a unit of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Movements ot vessels follow, all dates are May 4 unless specified: Hawaii to sea: Argonaut. Beaver. Bushnell, Idaho, Lark, Mississippi, Montgomery, Quail, Ramsay, S-21, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27, 29, 30, 32, 33, 34, 35. Seagull, Tanager, Texas, Whippoorwill, Widgeon, Wright.

The world's wheat markets developed a stronger undertone today. Light deliveries on May contracts, rumors that Germany was attempting to negotiate a loan with which to buy foodstuffs and a better demand for cash wheat served to strengthen futures in Liverpool which closed 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel higher.

Candidates who campaigned against the Roslyn type of progressive education were defeated tonight in the election of trustees for the Roslyn School District, but there were indications that the controversy over the method of instruction in the local grammar school would not be settled by the balloting.

The most talented students of the Music School Settlement appeared on the program of that institution's annual Spring concert at Town Hall last night under the direction of Melzar Chaffee.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau' follows: The weather of the week was rather unfavorable in the Cotton Belt. East of the Mississippi River rains were frequent, there was much cloudy weather and in considerable areas temperatures were relatively low, making unfavorable conditions for seeding and germination.
The four-cent gasoline tax forced through the Statfe Legislature on Tuesday was denounced yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, executive vice president of the Automobile Club of New York.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation voted yesterday to continue the present management in power for the ensuing year. This group, composed of a majority of the present directors, includes R. W. Higgins, president, and C. K. Blandin and Thomas Bardon, vice presidents.

Thomas W. Osborne, who had been a stenographer in the Court of General Sessions for the last forty-two years, died yesterday morning in the Polyclinic Hospital at the age of 73. He lived with his wife, Lillian E. Osborne, at the Robert Fulton Hotel, 228 West Seventy-first Street.

Miriam Lundy of The New York Daily News was elected president of the New York Newspaper Women's Club at a meeting last night at the clubrooms, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street. She succeeds Marjorie Mears of The Sun.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on April 24 amounted to 300,737,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today. Compared with a week before, this total represents an increase of 1,805,F000 barrels,

The twentyeight-day strike of Thermoid Rubber Company employes was settled tonight when, in the presence of Governor Hoffman and William C. Liller, United States Department of Labor conciliator, an agreement was signed at the Stacy-Trent Hotel by Fred E. Schluter, company president, and Joseph P. Dietrich, president of Local 83. United Rubber Workers of America, a unit of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Movements ot vessels follow, all dates are May 4 unless specified: Hawaii to sea: Argonaut. Beaver. Bushnell, Idaho, Lark, Mississippi, Montgomery, Quail, Ramsay, S-21, 22, 24, 25, 26, 27, 29, 30, 32, 33, 34, 35. Seagull, Tanager, Texas, Whippoorwill, Widgeon, Wright.

The world's wheat markets developed a stronger undertone today. Light deliveries on May contracts, rumors that Germany was attempting to negotiate a loan with which to buy foodstuffs and a better demand for cash wheat served to strengthen futures in Liverpool which closed 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel higher.

Candidates who campaigned against the Roslyn type of progressive education were defeated tonight in the election of trustees for the Roslyn School District, but there were indications that the controversy over the method of instruction in the local grammar school would not be settled by the balloting.

Mrs. Maria Teresa de Olaya Herrera, widow of the President of the Republic of Colombia, has booked passage for today on the Grace Liner Santa Lucia, which will carry the body of the diplomat, who died in Rome.

The Senate confirmed the nomination of Harry H. Woddring as Secretary of War and other nominations, heard Senator Borah assail fascism and communism, received the Barkley bill to give the Securities and Exchange

The WPA Federal Dance Theatre made its second Broadway production at the Bayes Theatre last night when it presented Tamiris's "How Long, Brethren" and Charles Weidman's "Candide," with both composers in the cast.
Mrs. Sally Pancoast Coles, widow of Thomas Coles, one of the earliest settlers of Glen Cove, died today at the North Country Community Hospital at the age of 80.

A strange assortment of animals, acquired during a 12,000-mile cruise to Central and South America and the South Pacific was brought into port yesterday by Vincent Astor in his yacht Nourmahal. Last night they were in their new home at the Staten Island Zoo, in West New Brighton.

Manufacturers in the popularprice dress industry are receiving the cooperation of more than 900 retailers throughout the country in checking unjustified dress returns, according to a detailed report made last night by Louis Rubin, chairman of the Dress Returns Control Bureau, to the board of governors of the Popular-Priced Dress Manufacturers Group. The board met at the headquarters at 1,440 Broadway.
Business of the Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation this year will be substantially better than in 1936, A. Cross, president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders in Montreal yesterday.
Pounding out fourteen hits, Newtown High crushed Bayside, 11--0, in a Queens P. S. A. L. game on the victor's diamond yesterday.

A realignment of officers and directors of the Hudson-Harlem Valley Title and Mortgage Company and of the Trust Company of Northern Westchester eliminated today the in terlocking managements that caused Supreme Court Justice Sydney A.

Stockholders of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company at their annual meeting yesterday elected three new directors: John J. Hopkins of the Pacific Western Oil Corporation; Carl H. Beal, a large individual stockholder, and John Hertz, a partner in Lehman Brothers. J. A. McCarthy did not stand

A preliminary announcement that the United States contemplates the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement with. Czechoslovakia was made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today, so that interested persons might arrange to present their views to the trade agreements organization.

Davidson Ave. 1,903, 4-story brick dwelling, 31x63.11x43.1x60; Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases against Agnes Boecher; due, $14,807; to plaintiff for $13,000. By JAMES R. MURPHY Grand Concourse, 1,291, 1.8x85.5x25x84.3. vacant, parcel 1; and 169th St. E. n s, 1.8 ft w of Grand Concourse, 125.1x84.3, vacant, parcel 2;

The rush ofnew amendments to the President's Supreme Court Bill presages one event and stresses another fact. The foreshadowed event is a new effort, which will be made immediately upon the President's return by his stanchest Senate supporters, to induce him to accept important modifications in his proposed statute.
Mrs. John E. Berwind entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Plaza for the group of women who are assisting her in the campaign to raise money for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.
Pasquale Ferrara, tenor, who has been heard in productions of the Hippodrome Opera Company, gave a recital last night at the Town Hall, with the assistance of Louise Pecorelli, soprano.

Prediction of a 12 per cent increase in total advertising volume this year, "provided that the labor situation and the financial situation do not operate to upset the procession," was made yesterday by Henry Eckhardt, president of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc.,
SOUTH AFTER GETTYSBURG, by Cornelia Hancock. (University of Pennsylvania Press, $2.) Letters of a young woman who saw action in the Civil War.

Miss Elsa Marguerite Waeber of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hans R. Waeber of Montclair, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Alan McEwen Thompson, son of Mrs. Thomas Owen Thompson of New London, Conn., and the late Mr. Thompson,

Washington airship experts and congressional leader received the news on the Hidenburg disaster with amazement and expressions of sorrow. But in every instance those who commented pointed out that the three disasters of the United States Navy were structural, while that of the German craft was due to the use of a combination of hydrogen and blue gas, the most dangerous of all gases for inflation of airships.

Washington and Lee's crew, which will meet Manhattan's varsity eight in a match race on the Harlem River tomorrow afternoon, arrived in New York last night. The Generals, who took up rowing as an intercollegiate sport only. this year, will work out over the course today in a shell borrowed from Manhattan.

Designation of the fifth wedding anniversary as a date to be observed with gifts of electrical merchandise is under consideration by the American National Retail Jewelers Association, but decision on the proposal will be deferred until August at least, pliance manufacturers were informed yesterday.

Mrs. Harry Horton Benkard was elected president general of the Colonial Dames of America at the annual meeting of the organization, which was held recently at the Pierre. The other officers are Mrs. William W. Hoppin, vice president;

At a hearing yesterday in the Warner-Quinlan Company's .reorganization proceeding, Federal Judge Murray Hulbert deferred until today the appointment of a special master to conduct hearings in the case, but he appointed three appraisers to determine the value of the company's gasoline stations.

Not at all disturbed by the fact that several months will pass before their favorite sport returns to formal action, about a hundred members of the Touchdown Club gathered at dinner in the Hotel Martinique last night and made Spring practice do for the present.

Verinda Brown, a former "angel" in the flock of Father Divine, brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday to strip the Harlem messiah of his temporal possessions, asking, in addition, that he be compelied to account for all the funds he has handled since 1930 for the Father Divine Peace Missions.

In a setting of flowering dogwood trees, cedars and cybotium ferns in the Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday afternoon, Miss Elizabeth B. Glover, daughter of Mrs. Bryce Metcalf of Ardsley, N. Y., and the late Dawson Coleman Glover,

The Browns outhit the Red Sox today, but Johnnie Marcum was tight in the pinches and Boston won, 2 to 1, to go into a tie with the Yanks and Tigers for the league lead. It was Marcum's third consecutive victory. He hasn't lost a game. Four Browns fanned and not a one walked.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Standard Dredging Company has been called for June 15 to consider. the expansion of plant and equipment by merger and consolidation with the National Dredging Company and the exchange of present stock holdings, including all rights to dividends, for stock in the merged company and other securities. The plan has been approved by the directors of Standard Dredging Company.

W. W. Watson Jr.. in 350 E. 57th St.; William M. Wherry, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens. Inc.; James de R. Geaves. in 1,088 Park Ave; Mrs. June M. Lillybridge, in 983 Park Ave; Talman Bigelow. Inc. broker. Teddy Bergman, in 200 W 86th St; Apartment Locating Bureau, broker.
At the annual convention of Monogram Pictures in Chicago, W. Ray Johnston, president of the company, yesterday announced a 1937-38 production program of forty-two releases.
One American-born woman and the great granddaughter of Queen Victoria were presented to King George and Queen Elizabeth tonight in the gleaming white and gold ballroom of Buckingham Palace.
The Manhattan - Wards Island sewer tunnel, a part of the $30,000,000 Wards Island sewage disposal plant which will be put into operation late this Fall, was "holed through" yesterday.

Net income of the Virginia Transportation Corporation, owned by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, was $340,853 in 1936, according to a report filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the Chesapeake Ohio. Income from dividends was $417,933. Expenses were $77.085.

Birger Brink, one of the editors of the Stockholm Tidningen, whose body is believed to be among those buried in the twisted framework of the Hindenburg, was making a brief visit to this country to interview Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and Dr. John H. Finley.

Wood Selick, Inc., of New York City, who deals in and manufactures grocers', confectioners' and bakers' supplies, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a complaint against allegedly excessive freight rates charged by eighteen railroads for transportation of desiccated coconut from San Francisco and Seattle.

The death of Mrs. ADOLPH S. OCHS brings sorrow to a great circle of friends, to whom she endeared herself by the beauty of her character. She deserved the name that was given to the sister of the sons of Lamech, who has been remembered through the centuries for the sweetness of her nature.

Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Larom of Valley Ranch, Wyo., gave a large reception yesterday afternoon in the Carpenter Suite of the WaldorfAstoria. Mrs. Larom is leaving today to return to Wyoming. Mr. Larom will join her there later.
Jesse James, 188, of Hollywood, Calif., and Billy Raburn, 182, of Oklahoma, wrestled to a draw in what was scheduled as a finish exhibition at the Hippodrome last night.

Recorder's Judge John J. Maher sentenced four Black Legion members to prison today for conspiring to incite a riot. A fifth man was admitted to probation. All were convicted April 21 of plotting to break up a political meeting.
A ball and entertainment will be held tonight at the Plaza for the benefit of the $600,000 stabilization fund now being raised by the Near East College Association. Floyd H.

The Federal Reserve System bought practically no government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, according to its weekly statement, issued yesterday. Government security holdings of the twelve regional Reserve banks rose $50,000 over the total for the previous week, a gain of negligible proportions when measured against the system's total holdings of $2,526,290,000 and the purchases of $39,657,000 made in the preceding week.

Ernest Russell Willard, formerly editor-inchief of The Democrat- and Chronicle here for twenty years and chairman of the Rochester Chapter of the Red Cross, died today. He was 83 years old. Mr. Willard, after his retirement in 1911, was active in organizations devoted to the relief of human suffering.
Shocked by the Hindenburg disaster at Lakehurst-today, President Roosevelt tonight sent from his yacht The Potomac a message of sympathy to Adolf Hitler, the German Chancellor.

Transfers PATROLMEN--From precincts indicated to sixtieth Precinct: Angelo J. Flore, 7; Rubin Stein 18; Hugh P. Ludden, 42; August E. H. Rose, 67; Thomas F. Heaney, 70; Edward T. Tobin, 71; joseph M. Gorton, 74; Edward F. Reilly, 75;

The enthusiast from Nova Scotia was speaking: "Tuna like herring and herring nets dot all the bays in Nova Scotia. The tuna come in and lurk around the nets to get any escaped herring on the bounce when the nets are pulled in. So all the angler has to do is get up early in the morning and take his boat alongside a herring net.

Charter Day, commemorating the ninetieth anniversary of City College as an institution of free higher education, was observed yesterday in the Great Hall. Although classes were dismissed at 10:30 A. M. for the exercises at 11 A. M., only 200 students met with 400 members of the faculty.

Sir Henry Francis Wilson, distinguished. British colonial administrator who, as private secretary to .Joseph Chamberlain, then Colonial Secretary, helped to organize the first Imperial Conference in 1897, died in Winchester today at the age of 77.

Retired Captain William Dugan, formerly a member of Engine 273 residing at 89-10 35th Ave., Jackson Heights, died May 4. Funeral will take place from McGrath's Funeral Parlor, 91-20 37th Ave.. Jackson Heights, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, May 7. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.
Resignation of W. A. Duckham of W. A. Duckham Co., a brokerage house, was received and accepted today at a special meeting of the Pittsburgh Stock Exchange's board of directors, officials announced.

Robert D. Teller has sold his famous yawl Playmate, which he raced for years in many of the distance contests through Long Island Sound, particularly the BaysideBlock Island event. Sparkman Stephens yesterday announced that Ephraim E. Sander had purchased her.

The North Carolina University tennis team scored a 9-to-0 victory over New York University at the Fleet Hollow courts yesterday afternoon to register. its second shutout victory in as many days. On Wednesday the Tar Heels defeated the Army, 9-0.

Sam Park, United States vice consul at Biarritz, France, died at his villa, Castellamare, yesterday in his eightieth year, it was reported here. Mr. Park, a retired lumber merchant, had been vice consul at the French resort since 1920.

Wilbert Diggers, 29 years old, a mechanic, narrowly escaped death yesterday afternoon when the elevator he was repairing on the seventh floor of 304 West Ninety-ninth Street suddenly fell to the basement. Diggers, who lives at 162 North Fifth Street, Paterson, N. J.,

Cornelius K. G. Billings. capitalist, sportsman and a member of one of Chicago's distinguished families, died shortly before noon today at his estate, Billings Park, near Santa Barbara, Calif., according to dispatches received here. He was 75 years old.

While the Legislature was working at top speed today in an effort to clear the Senate and Assembly calendars for final adjournment of the legislative session tomorrow, Republicans in the lower house sharply attacked Governor Lehman's bill to impose a 2 per cent tax on the gross income of public utility corporations, other than railroads under the control of the Interstate Commerce Commission, for unemployment relief.

Estates, Inc, Louis Grodsky, president, to Hilda Silberberg, 1,663 Eastburn Ave; mtg, $147,000. ($12). Columbus Ave, 942, 25.1x100; Pemberton H. Powel to Samuel and Isidore A. Woltheim, 343 E 80th St. ($8).

With the first batch of child refugees on the way to- France after their. evacuation from war-torn Bilbao, sympathetic Britons .were paring today to take care -of another group of about 4,000 in this country.

A strike.of service men in gasoline stations in all parts of the city was ordered yesterday for tomorrow morning by the Gasoline Station Attendants Union, Local 20,408, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Representatives of the Newspaper Guild and the management of The Long Island Daily Press agreed to settle the strike on that newspaper at a conference yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office in City Hall.

Members of the Hayden Planetarium-Grace Peruvian Eclipse Expedition will sail tonight for Lima, Peru, to observe, on June 8, the longest solar eclipse in several centuries. The scientists will be guests of the Explorers Club at a farewell party at 5 o'clock this afternoon in the club headquarters, at 10 West Seventy-second Street.

Officers and representatives of ten building trades locals affiliated with the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers, a C. I. 0. organization, met yesterday in Long Island City and formulated a protest against the revocation of their charters by the international.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that it had addressed to the Rules Committee of the State Assembly a communication urging the committee to report favorably before adjournment the Joseph-Pack Mortgage Bank Bill.

A deal involving 228 lots, said to be the last remaining large vacant parcel in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, featured the trading in that borough reported yesterday. Wood, Harmon Co. and a Boston subsidiary syndicate sold the parcel, which consists of land on Sixty-fourth and Sixty-fifth Streets, Sixteenth and Seventeenth Avenues, Ovington Court, Wallaston Court and Cambridge Court.

Effects of the income tax appeared in today's weekly statement of the Bank of Canada. "All other assets" jumped to $8,867,592 yesterday from $3,705,602 on April 28. This item, which represents checks in the mail on the way to being cleared, reflected some of the last-minute rush of taxpayers.

James M. Mathes of Plandome, L. I., was chosen president of the Dartmouth Green Kay today. Herbert Mattlaga of Douglaston, L. I., was elected vice president; William H. McCarthy of Manchester, Mass., was selected as recording secretary;

After a brief ownership, Maran Maran, operators, have resold the six-story apartment house, on a plot 100 by 100, at 15-19 Glover Avenue, McLean Heights, Yonkers, Westchester, to an investing client of Weiss Brothers.

Mr. and Mrs. Milton Strong Harrison of Cedarhurst, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Terry Harrison, to John G. Livingston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Livingston of Lawrence, L. I.

Captain Ernst August Lehmann, former master of the Hindenburg, was injured seriously when disaster overtook the great ship yesterday. His recovery was reported "doubtful." Captain Lehmann is a veteran in the construction and flying of lighter-than-air craft. He is married.

Stocks improved and closed generally higher in quiet trading; turnover, 756,500 shares. United States Government bonds firm and mixed, second-grade rail and convertible issues higher; transactions, $9,117,700.

Frederick W. Shelley, secretarytreasurer of the Morris County Savings Bank, Morristown, N. J., was elected yesterday president of the New Jersey Savings Banks Association at the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the association, held at the Montclair Golf Club.

After an early improvement that carried the price of cotton for delivery in October within a few points of 13 cents a pound and $2 a bale above recent low figures, prices on the Cotton Exchange reacted yesterday and ended the day with losses of 3 to 9 points.
Dodd, Mead Co. announce a new $2,000 prize competition open to American newspaper and periodical writers for the best manuscript for book publication received before March 1, 1938.

The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it granted a license on Tuesday to the AngloAmerican Good - Will Coronation Flight, Inc., to operate a 50-watt radio transmitter in connection with a coronation flight to England.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, was re-elected president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace yesterday at the annual meeting in the offices of the Carnegie Corporation, 522 Fifth Avenue.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 4: CAPTAINS Calver, G. W., Med. Corp, Naval Dispensary, to duty at the Navy Medical Center, Washington, D. C. Ransdell, H. B., to Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, Navy Dept., Washington D.C.

Meadow Brook Club members' matches tomorrow and Sunday at the J. S. Phipps estate in Old Westbury, L. I., along with exhibition games on Sunday at both Governors Island and Fort Hamilton are officially scheduled to usher in the outdoor polo season in the metropolitan district.

The following Marine Corps changes for the week.ended May 6 were announced today: MAJOR GENERAL Little, L. M., Headquarters, Washington, D. C., to command Fleet Marine Force, Marine Corps Base, San Diego, Calif., and to additional duty as Commanding General of Marine Corps Base, Naval Operating Base, San Diego, Calif.

An opinion that an accountant cannot be deemed to be independent if he is an officer or director of a company registering securities under the Securities Act of 1933, or holds an interest in the registrant significant to. its total capital or his own personal fortune, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission as the second of a series of interpretations on accounting principles. The opinion follows:

The Senate gave approval today to the Burchill resolution for a constitutional amendment which would relieve railroads of a major part of the expense they are now required to bear Buffa for grade-crossing elimination projects.
Russell Long, son of Senator Huey P. Long, is credited with engineering a Louisiana State University campus election sweep yesterday.

Chief Justice Hughes made what his hearers construed as a reference to the Supreme Court when he told the American Law Institute today that if society is to choose the processes of reason at opposed to the tyranny of force, "it must maintain the institutions which embody those processes."

On May 10 the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey will reduce the price of its ethyl grade of gasoline in New Jersey, Maryland and the District of Columbia 1/2-cent a gallon to tank-wagon dealers and 3/4cent a gallon to tank-car buyers and jobbers.
Foreign Minister Naotake Sato's "new start" in China was redefined in a simple answer to a Chinese correspondent at a reception given to fifty foreign correspondents this afternoon.

The 1,407 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,058,334,548 par value as of May 1, had a total market value of $43,920,389,575, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

Initial steps toward organization of an Independent Wholesale Druggists Association were taken at a meeting of about fifty jobbers from the New York metropolitan area and from other points in the East at the Pennsylvania last night.
The new National Investors Corporation, Maryland, reported yesterday total assets of $30,884,138 at the commencement of business on April 1, including $27,401,708 in common stocks at market value.

Samuel Kilpatrick bought from the Bowery Savings Bank through James Felt Co. the five-story flats at 944 Columbus Avenue, near 106th Street; 2,121 Eighth Avenue, near 114th Street, and 2,197 Eighth Avenue, near 118th Street.

A strong defense of the sanitary treaty between the United States and Argentina was made by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in a letter, made public today by the State Department, to C. C. Hastings of Williamsville, Ill., secretary-treasurer of the Illinois State Veterinary Medical Association, which recently adopted a resolution opposing the pact.

A personal estate of $3,363,339 was left by Horatio Gates Lloyd, Philadelphia banker, according to an inventory filed here today. His partnership in the firm of Drexel Co., Philadelphia, and J. P. Morgan Co., New York, is valued at $2,629,014.

Efforts of the city Industrial Labor Relations Board to iron out differences between employer and employee on the Interborough Rapid Transit system and the bus and trolley lines of the Third Avenue Railway Company were temporarily checked yesterday because of a jurisdictional dispute between two unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole were at the lowest. The reserve ratio for the New York bank also reached a new low figure for the year.

The catastrophe that overtook the airship Hindenburg has so overwhelmed Dr. Hugo Eckener, builder of that ill-starred craft, that even this intrepid exponent of the airship, whose courage has survived so many difficulties in the past, is in doubt as to whether lighter-than-air aviation can ever recover from this blow.

TWO ONE-ACT PLAYS, by Paul Green, consisting of UNTO SUCH GLORY and HYMN TO THE RISING SUN. The former staged by M. Manisoff and the latter by Arun Foxman, with settings by Robert Chertov and Theodore Fuchs.

Monte Weaver held the Indians to three hits until the eighth inning today, when young Roy Weatherly, with Lyn Lary on base, rifled a home run over the right-field wall, helping the Indians to a 4-to-2 victory over the Senators.

When Chief Justice HUGHES addressed the annual meeting of the American Law Institute a year ago he was able to tell its members that the Supreme Court was fully abreast of its work. Yesterday he spoke to the same audience and to the same point.
The immediate pitching future of Bob Feller, on the shelf for nearly two weeks with a muscular injury to his right arm, was in doubt today.

Fighting their way. through 100 policemen while 12,000 sympathizers. of the Committee for Industrial Organization cheered them on, 300 strikers stormed and took possession of the Apex Hosiery Company plant at Fifth and Luzerne Streets this afternoon and remained in occupation for a sit-down strike.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the three months ended March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, After interest, depreciation. ing expenses, Federal income and other charges, of $1,444,372, equivalent to $1.38 a share on 1,045,278 shares of capital stock outstanding at the end of the period.

Plans formulated by the Municipal Assembly committee on lowpriced housing which provide for housing 2,000,000 persons over a three-year period at a cost of about $90,000,000 will be considered at the committee's meeting in City Hall at 2:30 P. M. on Thursday, it was said yesterday by James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President.

The mobilization of public opinion and medical and public health facilities to combat the hazards of maternity, which now cause the "needless" death of about 10,000 mothers and 100,000 infants annually, was urged yesterday at a Mother's Day luncheon conference held by the Maternity Center Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Production of steel ingots in the United States last month was at an average rate of 1,182,255 gross tons weekly, a new high level for the movement and the best since the record month of May, 1929, when the average was 1,193,284 tons.
The American Savings Bank sold to the Lemust Holding Corporation the apartment house on a plot 123 by 100 feet at 1,793 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx. The terms were cash over a mortgage of $53,000.

Formation of a Consumers Foundation, comparable in its field to the Twentieth Century Fund or the National Bureau of Economic Research, is being studied and the foundation may reach the preliminary organization stage before the end of the month, it was learned here yesterday.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday reached the highest level in a month with a total of $6,608,837,000 for twenty-two cities, but they were 0.9 per cent less than a year ago when the total was $,671,348,000, according to figures piled by Dun Bradstreet, The turnover was $1,019,016,larger than in the proceeding week.

I was in my cabin, in the forward section of the Hindenburg, packing my belongings in preparation for the landing that seemed only minutes away, when I felt a slight tremor shaking the ship.
