That was an explosion that rent the tail of the airship, the first of the three that tore the dirigible apart, but its. effect where I stood was like that oftan "air pocket."

The horrors of Spain and Ethiopia moved Senator William E. Borah of Idaho to warn the Senate today that its members did not realize "the insidious, subtle effort being constantly put forth in this country by the advocates of that theory of government called fascism."

A group of Morehead City citizens, led by Mayor H. S. Gibbs, today drove three C. I. O. organizers out of town. One of them, W. I. Smith, of Norfolk, Va., said that he was beaten up when he tried to distribute handbills in front of the Regal Shirt Company's plant.

Various new proposals for restricting Federai relief expenditures in the fiscal year 1938, including one to wipe out the Works Progress Administration and turn the funds over to the States for distribution, were proposed or discussed at the Capitol today as the movement for reducing President Roosevelt's requested $1,500,000,000 work relief appropriation appeared to gain headway.

Wilson Co., Inc., meat packers, informed stockholders today of plans soon to offer $6,500,000 of ten-year convertible - debentures to increase working capital and finance an enlarge inventory because of rising prices.

Zaruba Brothers, furniture, floor in 1.905-7 3d Ave; Porter Co Real Estate, Inc. broker. Daum. Rogers, Spritzer Co, floor in 315 5th Ave: Ames. Cunehan Newman, Inc. and John W. Hahner. co-brokers. Nat's Tavern. Inc, store in 567 7th Ave; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, brokers.

The Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association at Cedarhurst, L. I., tomorrow will attract a large gathering of society and racing notables. For several weeks all Of the boxes have been subscribed for and it was necessary to build others to meet the demand.

Andrew Ponzi increased his advantage over Irving Crane to 50 points in winning the seventh block and tying in the eighth of ,their 1,500-point pocket billiard match at Ponzi's Academy yesterday. Ponzi, who leads by 1,000 to 950, won the afternoon session, 125 to 18, in eleven innings, while the night meeting ended in a tie at 125-all in nine frames. High runs were:

Jacob C. Klinck, president of the Kings County Savings Bank, was re-elected Grand Master of the Grand Lodge of Masons of New York State at the concluding sessions yesterday of the three-day annual meeting in the Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

As trustee for Chesapeake Corporation ten-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds due in 1944 and twenty-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds due in 1947, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York has notified the Stock Exchange of conversion

Joseph Love, head of the infants' and children's apparel firm of Joseph Love, Inc., was named chairman yesterday of the advisory committee for apparel and accessories for the New York World's Fair of 1939 in an announcement by Grover Whalen, president of the fair corportion.

The National Industrial Conference Board reports that employment in March in the twenty-five major manufacturing industries was higher than in 1929. This finding does not conflict with that of the Department of Labor, which recently reported the index of March factory employment to be the highest since 1929 and higher than in all but four months of that year.

After moving irresolutely in the first four hours in dull trading, the stock market firmed up in the final hour yesterday, increased activity and closed the day generally higher. Railway and steel stocks were prominent in the late advance, as were some of the motor and specialty issues.

A strike of seamen of the United, Fruit Company was ended in its second day. yesterday when officials of the company agreed to permit agents of the newly organized National Maritime Union to board its ships 'to organize the crews.

At a creditors' meeting yesterday in the Federal Building, Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, authorized the Irving Trust Company, as trustee of the International Match Company, to begin negotiations with the Federal Government for the purpose of settling tax litigation and to seek a return of about $1,200,000 in income taxes for 1929 and 1930 deemed to have been overpaid.

The Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria was formally opened for the season last night, with net proceeds from dinner and supper dancing providing a fund for the Masters School Day Nursery of this city. Many persons of prominence in society gave dinner and supper parties.

It was a few minutes after 1 o'clock this morning when the first news of the disaster to the Hindenburg reached Berlin by telephone from The New York Times Bureau in London. The bureau forwarded the brief bulletin to the effect that the airship had been destroyed while making its landing. No details were given.
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 86.0 from 84.4. It was 77.0 for the week ended May 2, 1936.

St. Benedict's Prep School of Newark overwhelmed Newman School today, winning in seven innings by a score of 26 to 7. The Newark nine scored seven runs in the first inning and followed with eleven in the second.

Governor Cross and other high officials of the State and town will attend the unveiling of a bronze tablet marking the landscaping of the Merritt Parkway at Round Hill Bridge, Greenwich, at 2 P. M., tomorrow.

Mrs. Florence Majestic, 41 years old, of 1,477 Lexington Avenue, who says she is a minister of the Spiritualist Church of America, was acquitted in General Sessions yesterday when Assistant District Attorney Finnegan had finished submitting the State's evidence on a first-degree grand larceny indictment.

There will be no "unreasonable" hotel rates in Paris during its international exposition, which opens May 25, and visitors also will enjoy "important reductions" in railroad fares, Georges Bonnet, the French Ambassador, told the New York Rotary Club yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore.
Steve Dragon, 12-year-old Gary schoolboy, sacrificed his life today in a vain effort to save his pet dog from being crushed to death between the wheels of an automobile.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was quiet yesterday as prices fluctuated irregularly within restricted limits. While the main body of high-grade issues maintained a firm undertone generally, the market as a whole lacked the uniform strength that has characterized trading of late.

Samuel Franko, noted musician, died at 9:15 o'clock last night in Roosevelt Hospital of a fractured skull suffered when he fell on the steps in the lobby of the Hotel Des Artistes at 1 West Sixty-seventh Street, near Central Park West. Mr. Franko, who lived at the Hotel Ansonia, was calling on a friend at the Hotel Des Artistes and apparently fainted as he was descending the stairs.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Geraldine Schwabe, daughter of Mrs. Henry Salz of 1,225 Park Avenue and the late Joseph M. Schwabe, to Leo H. Hirsch Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo H. Hirsch, also of New York.

Taxpayers of the strife-torn East Kingston School District voted to accept the offer of the village parent-teacher association to rehire two teachers whose dismissal led' to a strike of nearly 200 pupils last month.
Miss Maribel Yerxa Vinson, nine-time holder of the women's United States figure-skating crown, has decided to join the ranks of professional skaters.

Awarding of the Pulitzer literature prizes usually results in increased advertising activity on those books receiving an award but yesterday some publishers had not completed details on future campaigns.

Dr. Mildred S. Wertheimer, research associate of the Foreign Policy Association, in charge of studies on Germany and Central Europe, died yesterday in the El Cortez Hotel, San Diego, Calif., after a long illness, according to word received here by the association. She was 41 years old.

A large number of-executives in rayon mills and virtually the entire silk-weaving industry favor Federal regulation of wages and hours with government enforcement, Sylvan Gotshal of Well, Gotshal Manges, counsel to the General Committee for National Textile Legislation, declared yesterday.-Mr.

Since the experiments of Count Zeppelin, started in 1859, began, at the turn of the century, to hold out promise of serious pretentions for this type of aircraft, the career of lighter-than-air ships has been a checkered one. At one moment spectacular accomplishments have won the world's admiration; at the next equally spectacular destruction has cost many lives and shaken the faith of all but the most stanch adherents.

Creston Ave, 2,084-86 (11-3161); East End Associates, Inc, to Tranquil Realty Co, 225 Broadway; 6 per cent; $10,750. Morris Ave (9-2449) w s, 345 ft n of McClellan St, 108x100; 1,024 Walton Corp to Manufacturers Trust Co: 1 year, 6 per cent, building loan; $130,000. Clinton Ave (11-2951), e s, 115. t n of Fairmount P1, 85x140; Rosewin Construction Co to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtgs to May 5, 1942, at 41/2 per cent; $105,000.

The War Department released the following orders to. day, dated May 5: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Wainer, M. R., Q. M. C., three months leave, May 15. Reinecke, P. S., Corps of Engineers, one month leave, June 15, with permission to visit foreign countries.

Politicians, lawyers, bondsmen, doctors, locality Mayors and many others attended the funeral yesterday of Stitch McCarthy, whose real name was Samuel Rothberg but who became a leading figure on the lower East Side under his Irish pseudonym.

Powers Hapgood, New England secretary of the Committee for Industrial Organization, and five other leaders of the forty-three-day LewistonAuburn shoe strike were sentenced to six months in jail here today, after a jury found them guilty of violating a temporary injunction against strike activity.

CRUSIUB, HENRY NZCHOLAS (Dec. 3). Estate, not more than $1,600. To Virginia Crusius, 936 Woodycrest Ave., Bronx, $1,500; one other bequest. Thomas J. Garcia, 174 Cranford Pl., Teaneck, N. J., executor. DONALDSON, JULIUS A. (Feb. 10). Estate, $3,500. To Eugenle McIntyre Donaldson, widow, executrix, 45 W. 35th St., residue.

Bids for $100,000,000 in Treasury bills, half for cash and half for refunding purposes, were asked today by Acting Secretary Roswell Magill. Tenders will be received up to 2 P. M., Eastern standard time, Monday, May 10, at the Federal Reserve Banks and branches.

The engagement of $7,461,000 of gold abroad for shipment here, $5,583,000 in England and $1,878,000 in India was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gold taken in England, it was announced, was secured on Wednesday, in addition to the $3,254,000 previously reported engaged there that day.
Sixty-five passengers were listed to make the return trip on the Hindenburg. At the last moment one of them, Sidney Davidson, canceled his booking. Ten were making the trip to attend the coronation.

Tony Canzoneri, one of the greatest of all lightweight champions in his prime, will attempt to make ring history at Madison Square Garden tonight when he trades punches with Lou Ambers, the present titleholder, in a fifteen-round bout for the 135-pound crown.

The second annual George Vanderbilt Cup auto race will be held Saturday, July 3, at the Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., it was announced yesterday. The $60,000 added race, an international test at 300 miles, originally was scheduled for Monday, July 5.

A bill giving to the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to pass upon indentures under which bonds and debentures are issued on and after Jan. 3, 1938, and setting up a standard of requirements for the eligibility of the corporate trustee intended to minimize conflict of interests with those of the security holders, was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Barkley of Kentucky.

During the week ended May 5 member bank reserve balances decreased $52,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $45,000,000 in money in circulation, $57,000,000 in Treasury cash, $15,000,000 in non-member deposits
The Cubs completed a sweep of the three-game series with the Phillies, winning today, 1 to 0, in a game called at the end of the fifth inning because of rain..

In making public new contributions to the Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army, Chalmers Wood, chairman of the campaign, last night urged the 3,105 volunteer workers not to slacken their efforts "because of anticipation of favorable -week-end weather and lure of outdoor attractions."

By a vote of 120 to 25, the Assembly tonight repassed the Rogers-Allen Milk Bill after drastically amending it so that it affects only producers. Earlier in the day the Assembly passed the McElroy-Young bill, which provides for a State-wide organization of producers to bargain for better prices.

The industrial advance that marked Canadian business in March continued throughout April, except in districts affected by the automobile strike, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

Fleeting Moon, 6-to-1 shot, owned by Ral Parr of Baltimore, upset the dope in the Windsor Hills Purse, feature offering at the Pimlico track today. The 3-year-old daughter of Flying Ebony-Bright Luna broke in Front of the field of five and prevailed at the end by a half length, with A. G. Vanderbilt's Grand Play second.
Frank Gillmore, president of the Actors Equity Association, disclosed yesterday that he had protested to Assembly leaders against the Dunnigan measure approved by the State Senate on Wednesday.

Senator McAdoo of California added today to a long list of substitutes for President Roosevelt's bill to reorganize the judiciary a proposal that the Supreme Court be increased at once to fifteen members, instead of an indefinite number which, under the administration bill, would depend on how many of the justices over 70 years of age might elect to retire.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, one of the larger public utility holding companies, is giving serious consideration to registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, officials of the company indicated yesterday.

In the words of Colonel Newcome's favorite Latin quotation Englished, "knowledge (or science) softens manners." The undergraduates at Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Columbia have just been illustrating this saw for the benefit of the citizens of Cambridge and New York.

Divergent interpretations of the Wagner Labor Act increased the tension tonight between John L. Lewis's Steel Workers Organizing Committee and three of the country's largest independent steel producers.
The report of the public tribunal issued tonight three hours after final evidence had been taken seems to make a truce between the bus strikers and the London Passenger Transport Board inevitable.
Police raided tonight the Peruvian Consulate and confiscated a radio transmitting apparatus allegedly used by Spanish refugees to supply military information to the Insurgents.

A luncheon and children's fashion show to mark the Silver Jubilee of the School of the Holy Child Jesus in Suffern, N. Y., has been arranged by members of the Alumnae of the school tomorrow at Maisonnette Russe.

Information now in the possession of the British Government shows that the recent destruction of Guernica, former holy town of Spain, was "a particularly deplorable example of bombing and machine-gunning from the air," Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.

Donald Grant Geddes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Geddes of the Hotel Pierre and Glen Cove, L. I., died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Geddes, who resided in Great Neck, was with the brokerage firm of Clark, Dodge Co., 61 Wall Street.

Emilius Griffiths, holding the post of official political delegate of the Spanish Insurgent government at La Linea, was placed under arrest this morning at La Linea and was taken immediately to Seville following instructions from Salamanca.
The power of the Federal court at Pittsburgh to enjoin the government's suit against the Aluminum Company of America in New York

A total of $216,955,000 for engineering construction awards in April represented a gain of 11 per cent over the same month last year, and March of this year, according to The Engineering News-Record. It is made up of $112,073,000 for private work and $104,882,000 for public work. The total of $195,458,000 in April, 1936, included $63,703,000 private, and $131,755,000 public awards.

The British Government flatly refused today to prevent private companies from selling second-hand arms to foreign countries, although this trade furnished a mass of disagreeable evidence in the hearings before the committee in Washington.

Pat O'Brien, Joan Blondell, Humphrey Bogart and the hill-billy variety team of the Weaver Brothers and Elvira will serve in the Warners film edition of the Kenyon Nicholson-Charles Robinson comedy, "Swing Your Lady."

La Salle Academy scored 37 points to win senior team honors in the annual Manhattan-Bronx-Westchester Catholic High Schools A. A. track and field championships at Fordham Field yesterday. Fordham Prep was a distant second, with 16 tallies, while All Hallows, the 1936 champion, and Mount St. Michael tied for third with 15 each.

The president and fellows of Harvard College were named residuary legatees in the will of Harriet C. Messervy, widow of George P. Messervy, which was filed yesterday. The estate was formally valued at "more than $100,000."

Democrats and Republicans in Congress joined forces today to hurl defiance at the athletic power of the press. Representative Tom McMillan, South Carolina Democrat, issued a call for his baseball stars to condition themselves for the annual game between the legislators and the scribes at Quantico, Va., May 22.

State and municipal financing for the month of April aggregated $94,986,198, as compared with $111,953,757 in April, 1936. The total for the first four months of this year was $455,192,204, against $420,114,521 for the same period last year.
The Mexican Attorney General today presented the Alexander Pompez extradition papers to the Criminal Division of the First Federal District Court.

The notes of a trumpeter, sounding from the tower of Clapp Laboratory at 7:30 o'clock tomorrow morning, will proclaim to the world the opening of the two crowded days of festivities which will mark the centenary of Mount Holyoke College, one of the pioneer institutions of higher education for women.

Another success for Germany's barter system was reported here today. The general manager of the Rumanian State Railways went to Berlin to order hydraulic brakes at the Knorr factory. The British Westinghouse offer was rejected because cash was demanded. Rumania will pay partly with oil and partly with assets frozen in Germany.

The address of Chief Justice Hughes to the American Law institute as follows: For the eighth time it is my privilege to greet you at this annual rendezvous of the members of the bar and bench. Last year we paid our tribute to George Wickersham, whose outstanding service as the president of the American Law Institute was the crown of his professional career.
L. C. Erickson resigned yesterday as a director of Vulcan Detinning Company, reducing the number of directors to eight. The other members of the board were re-elected.

James E. Gorman, president of the Rock Island Lines, told stockholders today at their annual meeting here "no man living can tell" when the road's reorganization plan, now before the Interstate Commerce Commission, can be completed.
F. B. Hufnagel was elected yesterday chairman of the Crucible Steel Company of America, succeeding H. S. Wilkinson, deceased. Mr. Hufnagel retains his office of president.

After spending two weeks running trivial errands in the Mayor's office, a police lieutenant who made "uncomplimentary" remarks about the Mayor in the muster room of the Astoria precinct several weeks ago has been transferred to monitor duty in Harlem, far from his home, it was disclosed yesterday.

Describing actions of fur strikers and nion officials here as "nothing more or less than mob law," 'Justice J. E. Adamson in Manitoba Court of King's Bench awarded $2,869 damages and court costs today against. officials of the International Fur Workers Union in favor of A. H. Hurtig, local fur manufacturers.

Increases in salaries of officials and a realignment of some of its investments in affiliated and nonaffiliated companies are revealed ir the annual report of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for 1936 to the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday.
The third series of wool auctions ended today. Offerings at today's session totaled 7,643 bales, including 3,604 from South America, of which 5,606 were sold.

In an open letter to the presidents of Harvard, Tufts and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, District Attorney Warren L. Bishop of Middlesex County today called on them to warn their students that "drastic action" would be taken in the event of any more rioting.
The recess appointment of Harry H. Woodring, former Governor of Kansas, as Secretary of War was confirmed by the Senate today. the Senate today.

Police of the East Fifth Street station continued yesterday their search for the murderer or murderers of Joseph (Blind Joe) Alonzo, 39-year-old radio repair-shop proprietor, who was found dead on Wednesday in his store, 153 Avenue A, near Tenth Street.

The program of public relations and other activities mapped out by the late W. Forbes Morgan, president of the Distilled Spirits Institute, before his death last month, will be carried out as planned, the executive committee announced yesterday.

About 100 employee of the Max Fleischer Studios, 1,600 Broadway, producers of the animated motionpicture cartoons, "Popeye" and "Betty Boop," voted last night to strike. The action was taken after union officials reported that Mr. Fleischer, president of the studios, had refused to grant union recognition, improved working conditions, higher wages and vacations with pay.

Still another of last year's plays--surely there can't be many left--has been amiably digested by Hollywood's voracious cameras and as amiably regurgitated upon the screen. Here it is Dodie Smith's Theatre Guild pleasantry, "Call It a Day," which the Warners are showing at the Capitol.
Captain Max Pruss, commander of the airship Hindenburg, who escaped in yesterday's crash, rose from the ranks, having joined the Zeppelin Company in a clerical capacity in 1911.

The new $10,000,000 Mellon Institute of Industrial Research, a Parthenon of granite and limestone in which modern science takes the place of Zeus, was officially dedicated to the service of mankind today by Andrew W. Mellon, its founder.

Georges Bonnet, the French Ambassador, and Mrs. Bonnet have arrived at the Plaza from Washington. Mrs. Ralph Seward Allen returned yesterday on the Rex after a Mediterranean tour and has joined Mr. Allen at the Pierre. They will sail next month for Europe.
Lewis Cochrane, assistant mechanical superintendent of THE NEW YORK TIMEs since 1916, died last evening at his home in Babylon, L. I., of heart disease. Mr.

Dr. William Herbert Prescott, retired psychiatrist, who was at one time assistant superintendent of the Boston City Hospital and an alienist for the city of Boston, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Augustus F. Jones, in Franklin. His age was 76.
Movements on the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: griculture, follow:

Italian correspondents in Spain forecast another important battle in the Bilbao sector. They disclose that a large concentration of Insurgent troops, including Italian volunteers, is proceeding to Bermeo on the Bay of Biscay to repulse an attack by Basque forces that is believed imminent.

Harry Linsley Cort, theatrical producer and musical comedy writer, died early yesterday morning at his home, 47 East Seventy-fourth Street. Death occurred while he was asleep and was attributed to heart disease. He was in his forty-eighth year.

Soon after he closed his defense on the witness stand yesterday, Dr. Isidore E. Kaplan of 140 Rivington Street was convicted in Special Sessions of conspiracy and petit larceny in a $75 fraud on an insurance company in a fake accident indemnity claim.

Intending to officiate rather than compete, Harold Van Buskirk of the Fencers Club made a last-minute entry in the annual veterans' three-weapon competition of the Amateur Fencers League of America at the Salle Santelli last night and captured the honors by 'outscoring four rivals in a round-robin.

Prior to establishing the first regular passenger service for lighter-than-air craft across the Atlantic, the Hindenburg, originally known as the LZ-129, first took to the air on March 4, 1936, for a trial flight over Lake Constance from her base at Friedrichshafen, Germany.
Joseph E. Brakeley of Montclair, formerly a canning factory owner here, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Brakeley, in Montclair. after a long illness. His age was 85.
A bill to bar from interstate commerce any goods which are manufactured by child labor was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Barkley of Kentucky.

Industrial peace for another six months in France has been secured, it is hoped, by an accord obtained by Premier Leon Blum, between workers' and employers' organizations that the Matignon agreements of last June should be continued in operation.

A possible increase in Soviet purchases of American machinery for preparing food and the use of American technical assistance are indicated in a demand today by the Food Commissariat for improved methods along American lines.

The Railway Mail Department of the New York Postoffice, responsible for transoceanic mails, was uninformed early today regarding the amount of mail destroyed in the explosion and fire aboard the Hindenburg.

Governor Gordon Browning tonight appointed Major George L. Berry, Federal Industrial Co-ordinator, to the United States Senate to succeed the late Nathan L. Bachman of Chattanooga. Mr. Bachman, the State's junior Senator, died suddenly of a heart attack in Washington April 23.

President Roosevelt interrupted his vacation at sea today to spend the morning at his desk on the yacht Potomac. The President signed thirty-two minor bills, mainly private ones; signed the commissions of Henry F. Grady and William J. Sears, the two new Tariff Commissioners, and a large amount of official and personal mail.

By utilizing the consumers' present curiosity about quality of products they buy, ice cream manufacturers can increase sales substantially in this country, Miss Aubyn Chinn, lecturer on the staff of the National Dairy Council, told a regional meeting of the Ice Cream Merchandising Institutee of the International Association of Ice Cream Manufacturers at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
The work of several modern composers received world premieres at the concluding sessions of the second annual Festival of American Music here today at the Westminister Choir School.
Captain Danger, from the stable of Mrs. George Tilden of Chicago, galloped to an easy victory in the top event at Aurora today, romping home four lengths ahead of M. Estopinal's Habanero.
Traffic accidents in Pennsylvania, piling up to nearly double the 1936 daily rate, have taken more than 1,000 lives since the first of the year.

Canada has spent nearly $800,000,000 on relief. Bank of Canada statisticians today put the amount spent by Dominion, Provincial and municipal governments to the end of March 1936 at $635,000,000. In his budget speech at the last session of Parliament Finance Minister Dunning estimated $800,000,000 as the Dominion's contribution to relief in the fiscal year ended March 31 last.

Count C. G. von Zeppelin, 30 years old, a nephew of the German inventor of the dirigible airship, who is in the United States on a business trip, expressed the opinion tonight that the explosion of the Hindenburg might be a case of sabotage.

Soon after the Hindenburg burst into flames yesterday phone calls poured into the telephone room of the NEW YORK TIMES. From 7:30 P. M. until 9:30 P.M. six telephone operators handled more than 5,000 calls.
Joseph A. Des Jardins Jr., 12 years old, shot and critically wounded himself this morning in front of his mother because she had insisted he would have to take a music lesson later in the day.
The zeppelin Hindenburg was destroyed by fire and explosions here at 7:23 o'clock tonight with a loss of thirtythree known dead and unaccounted for out of its ninety-seven passengers and crew.

Cherry St, 327-33, 93.3x114.4; for 1-story garage: Stoker Realty Corp, 120 Marlborough Rd. Brooklyn, owner; Philip Bardes, architect; cost, $30,000. Alterations 61st St, 120-22 W; to 4-story tenement; J. S. Modernization Corp, 66 Court St, Brooklyn, owner; P. Birnbaum, architect; cost, 36.000

Returning to tournament competition after an absence of more than two years, Mrs. Charles Eastman, the former Catherine Singer, today won the initial eighteen-hole handicap event of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association on the south course of the Westchester Country Club.

The entire student body of this Hudson River community-eleven youngsters ranging in age from 7 years to 12-went on strike today against the impending dismissal of their attractive 24-year-old teacher, and picketed the home and place of business of the one-man Board of Education.

The Big Brother Movement, which assists underprivileged and maladjusted boys of this city, was the beneficiary of net proceeds from dinner and supper dancing last night in the garden of the Ambassador. The occasion was the opening of the garden for the Summer.

THIS admirer of James T. Farrell's earlier work must report that his new book, "Can All This Grandeur Perish?" (Vanguard, $2.50), is a disappointment. It consists of seventeen short stories, most of which have not been previously published and some of which might better never have been published at all.

There is a definite shortage of skiled and semi-skilled labor in many major industries, according to a survey just completed by a subcommittee, it was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, chairman of the Consumers Goods Industries Committee.

More than 3,300 persons, arriving in about 1,000 automobiles, visited today Inisfada, thE home of Mrs. William J. B. Macauley, the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, in the North Hills colony. here, to -get a preview of the contents of the eighty-seven room mansion that are to be sold at auction, May 10 to May 15.

Fifteen Columbia College sophomores and juniors have been elected to the Van Am Society by the outgoing members. They are Justin N. Feldman, Richard A. Kussat, James Corcoran, Robert D. Prince, Frank W. Snepp, Hugh A. Croly, Daniel J. Edelman, H. Ellis Bowden, Ellis B.

Bunching for of their seven Nits for all their runs in the eighth inning, the Philadelphia Athletics defeated the White Sox, 3 to 1, today to sweep the two-game series. It was the fifth straight loss for the Chicagoans.
A judge on one of the most important benches of the Moscow District Court who has the bad habit of signing unread any document placed before him has just sentenced himself to jail.

World sugar futures rallied somewhat yesterday on news that the International Sugar pact had been signed, although to some extent such action had been discounted by the trade. Statements by Ramsay MacDonald and Norman Davis were made at the formal signing. Mr.

Adam E. Fischer, Brooklyn architect who had practiced for half a century, died on Wednesday night at his home, 862 Bushwick Avenue, at the age of 74. Mr. Fischer, whose office was at 373 Fulton Street, was a charter member
A bill requiring that 80 per cent of the payrolls of concerns doing business in Cuba be paid to Cuban citizens had the approval today of the House of Representatives.
The Spring festival of the International Institute of the Young Women's Christian Association opened last night with a large group of members appearing in native costumes in folk songs and dances.

In one of the great Zeppelin dicks at Friedrichshafen a sister ship to the Hindenburg, the LZ 130, is nearing completion. The new airship in many respects was built to be like the Hindenburg but is to have more powerful engines, greater speed and slightly greater lift.

Additional entries for the fourth annual Princeton invitation track meet June 19, announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics, will enhance the international aspect of the Palmer Stadium games.

The great need of the city government today is economy, Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday. Increases in city turn capital appropriations, addition of new employes and similar factors have contributed to this condition, he said.

Offering to the public, by means of a prospectus, of a new issue of $1,500,000 of ten-year 41/2 per cent sinking-fund debenture notes dated April 1, 1937, and maturing in 1947, and 78,870 shares of new common stock of the Fruehauf Trailer Company, Detroit, will be made today by a group composed of Watling, Lerchen Hayes, Lawrence Stern Co., Inc.;
An income tax return for 1930, placed in evidence here yesterday, revealed that John J. Raskob paid no income tax that year. It indicates his net holdings were then about $10,000,000.
The ninth biennial exhibition of water-colors opens today at the Brooklyn Museum with a reception and preview for members and guests and to the public tomorrow. It will continue through June 13.
Superlative hurling by Jack Bissell and Sophomore Bob Riddle gave Princeton University's baseball team a 4-1 triumph over an all-graduate nine today on University Field.

Agents for Standard Brands, Inc., help small bakers and independent wholesalers, who pay more for yeast than large chains, to solve such problems as holes in bread, burned loaves, lack of crust, , through large scale research that the company maintains, according to testimony yesterday by Peter Pirrie, chemical engineer and editor of Bakers' Weekly before Trial Examiner John T. Norwood,

Yorkshire overwhelmed Oxford University in' a first-class cricket match concluded today ahead of schedule, winning by an inning and 160 runs. Hutton and Leyland I made 95 and 94 runs, respectively, in the White Rose County's big innings of 444 for six, declared, but the students were dismissed for 149 and 137.
Mrs. Lily Doane Wicks, wellknown Syracuse church and civic worker, died Tuesday morning at Syracuse Memorial Hospital of bronchitis after an illness of three days, it was learned here yesterday.

The annual Ascension Day evensong service for the American Guild of Organists was held at St. Bartholomew's Church last night. The service was conducted by the Rev. Paull T. Sargent, rector of St. Bartholomew's.
Governor Lehman conferred with group of milk producers on pending milk-control legislation, and also named Charles Poletti his counsel, as a member of the State Supreme Court.

The following Coast Guard orders for the week ended May 5 were announced today: Hottell, Capt. J. F., New York Division, to Fort Trumbull Training Station, as Director of Coast Guard Institute in addition to command of training station. Molloy, Capt. T. M., detached as Eastern Inspector, and ordered to command New York Division.

L. A. Young, president of the L. A. Young Spring and Wire Corporation, received last year remuneration of $174,928. This was the highest figure among the 1936 annual reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission which the New York Stock Exchange made public yesterday.

Support of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union for Mayor La Guardia of New York if he runs for re-election in the Fall on the American Labor party ticket was pledged today at the union's convention by David Dubinsky, president of the union, after the Mayor, in a brief address, declared he was proud of his pro-labor record.

Trading was only fair to mostly slow. Steer hinds and ribs continued weak. Lamb carcasses sold weak to fully $1 below Wednesday's early quotations. Other classes were barely steady to weak. Thursday, being an off-kosher day, the slaughter of those classes generally dressed kosher was exceptionally light.

Brown Harriman Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $2,450,000 of city of Pittsburgh, Pa., registered notes on a bid of 100.111 for 1 3/4s. The notes, due on April 1, 1940, were reoffered on a 1.60 per cent interest basis.

The gloom that enveloped the city late yesterday afternoon settled heaviest over the Polo Grounds, where the Giants swallowed their first shutout of the year, 4--0, dropped their second straight to the Reds and lost their second straight series.
The Dixiana' horses, trained by Clyde Van Dusen, today continued to dominate the 2-year-old races at Narragansett Park when Wicked Time, a gelded son of High TimeSin, won the featured Brewster purse.

The Illinois Central Railroad System, in its pamphlet report for 1936, made public yesterday, shows a net income of $764,743 after taxes and charges, which was equal to $4.10 a share on its 186,457 shares of 6 per cent preferred stock.

The marriage date of the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Simpson has not been set. The only thing that is known is that it will not be on the-day of the coronation of King George VI for obvious reasons or on the day following, May 13, because of superstition.

To the Editor of The New York Tims: A decision as to what should be done about the sugar quotas will be helped by considering the following: Our exports to Cuba have gained under the trade agreement, but imports from Cuba have gained four times as much.

Completing the first ten years of its corporate existence, Remington Rand, Inc., yesterday reported that earnings for the first quarter of this year were the largest for any three-month period in its history.

Aaron Rabinowitz, member of the State Insurance Board and of the State Board of Housing, was elected yesterday a director and chairman of the board of the Fred F. French Investing Company, parent corporation controlling one of the largest realty and building organizations in the city.

Motorists will pay a fourth cent of State gasoline tax in New York beginning next Monday. Governor Lehman signed the Buckley bill tonight restoring the additional penny-a-gallon levy, finally approved by the Legislature on Tuesday after a month's wrangling in the Republican-ruled Assembly.

William J. Dugan of 89-10 Thirtyfifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, retired captain of the New York Fire Department, 'who died on Monday, will be buried today. Captain Dugan served in the New York City Fire Department from 1901 to 1932, when he retired.

City College awarded 345 insignia to members of ten teams yesterday at the annual Charter Day exercises of the college, which commemorated the founding of the school. Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, presided over the exercises, which were held in the Lewisohn Stadium.
John H. Fahey, chairman of the Home Owners Loan Corporation and publisher of The Worcester Post, announced today that he had disposed of all his interests in the newspaper.
A generally firmer tone prevailed in the local commodity futures markeets yesterday. Rubber, hides, silk and coffee were strong, while cottonseed oil and copper eased slightly.
Stanley J. Sarnoff, '38, of Brooklyn, has been elected president of the Princeton University Fencing Association for 1937-38, it was announced today following the annual election meeting.

Despite an unfavorable report from the committee appointed last year to investigate the advisability of closing the New York Stock Exchange on Saturdays during the Summer, the Youth's Day governing committee of the Exchange acted favorably on the proposition yesterday. The final vote was so close that the president for the day, young Edward F. Bradley, was accused of "railroading" the measure when he dropped his gavel and pronounced it carried.

A further stage in the renewal of good relations between Peru and Colombia, seriously threatened four years ago by the Leticia incident, was reached yesterday when a mixed commission that will study better customs relations commenced its sessions.

Northern New York Area Each of the following Reserve officers. having reported a permanent change of address, outside the jurisdiction of the Northern New York Reserve Area, is relieved from assignment or attachment to the organization indicated:

Miss Anne Moberly, first principal of St. Hugh's Hall (now St. Hugh's College) of Oxford, died today at the age of 90. Until 1920 women were not members of the university, but from the first Miss Moberly worked for the ultimate granting of full membership to women and her earliest students were urged to take degree courses.

In a speech before business representatives at Wuerzburg published today, the Minister of Finance, Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk, admitted that the National Socialist government was still financing a good part of its undertakings on credit and that the public debt was still rising.
The unsolved shooting of William Desmond Taylor, film director, was paraded before a county grand jury today in a renewed attempt to clear up the fifteen-year-old mystery.

The third concert of the thirty-second biennial Cincinnati May Festival this afternoon in Music Hall presented for the first time in Cincinnati Eugene Goossens's one-act opera, "Judith," after the apocryphal tale. The libretto is the work of Arnold Bennett.

The fate awaiting the thirtyfive leaders of the Leftist revolt in November, 1935, will soon be known, for the National Security Tribunal will meet tomorrow to pass judgment, continuing in session until each defendant has been sentenced following the reading- of the evidence in his case.

A Democratic attempt to amend a bill to keep the polls open until 8 P. M. in New York City at the Fall election failed in the Assembly today. The amendments, offered by Assemblyman Steingut, minority leader, were rejected by a party vote of 76 to 74, the Republicans voting in opposition.

The stock markets were quiet but firm today. Giltedge issues acted well, while among the foreign bonds a demand for Japanese loans continued in a generally stronger list. Industrial shares were well supported.

The first half of Argentina's repatriation loan was oversubscribed so heavily during the first two days that the Central Bank authorities have decided to offer the entire 200,000,000 pesos, instead of handling it in two series of 100,000,000 each, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

Directors of the Saco-Lowell Shops have completed a reorganization plan, modified substantially in line with suggestions made by the special stockholders' committee, and have called a special meeting of stockholders on June 21 to consider the proposal.

I was running like hell to get some movies of the landing and the big Zeppelin was nosing down toward her mooring mast, ropes lowering. The front end of the Zep was exceptionally low, the tail high--a steeper landing than she took when I rode in here from Akron to Seville, Spain, in 1933.

A Variety of animals that would have put Noah to shame was exhibited yesterday afternoon by 150 members of the Boys Club, Avenue A and Tenth Street. The boys held, their annual pet show on the roof of .their clubhouse.

From a reliable source it was learned yesterday that the screen rights to "Excursion" have gone to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for $125,000, and that the terms specify some distant date (beyond next season) for the release of the film.
Newpaper here today give some prominence to a proposal to move the capital of Ethiopia from Addis Ababa to some other place more suitable for habitation by white men.

A landscape by Gainsborough entitled "The Market Cart," brought $1,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson, Inc., at an auction of paintings consigned by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company of New York, Mrs. Leo F. Wormser and others.

PERPIGNAN--Anarchists were reported to have regained positions in Barcelona and to have demanded the dissolution of the government's shock troops. Withdrawal of 12,000 men from the Aragon front, to deal with the situation, was also reported. leading to an advance by the Rebel armies. Page 1.

A seven-run attack in the fifth inning, touched off by Cookie Lavagetto's opening home run off the veteran Red Lucas, yesterday gave the Dodgers victory at Ebbets Field and Van Lingle Mungo his third triumph as the Pirates lost the series final, 9-5.

Dispossess notices affecting fortyeight families in two Bronx apartment houses were signed yesterday in Bronx Municipal Court by Justwice Michael B. McHugh. The notices, effective Monday, are directed against forty-five tenants of 2,802 Olinville Avenue and three at 2,758 Holland Avenue for failing to pay their rent.

As an observance of National Music Week, the program given last sight at the WPA Theatre of Musio by the Madrigal Singers under Lehman Engel was a happy inspiration. It was devoted to American vocal music, largely choral, from the pre-Revolutionary to the post-Prohibition periods.

County Judge Richard W. Hawkins, signed an order today committing Howard Magnussen, 27 years old, of Huntington Station to the Matteawan State Hospital. Magnussen had been a prisoner in the county jail here since he was held two months ago for the action of the Suffolk County grand jury on the charge of murder in connection with the death of Joan Morvan, 4,

Notables from many walks of life were among the passengers on the ill-fated Hindenburg. They included merchants, students and business and professional men and women. Many of the survivors owed their lives to the fact that they were apparently near windows in the dirigible when the accident happened and were able to leap through them to the ground in safety.

The Senate Civil Liberties Committee looked today to "the Governor and the public conscience of Kentucky" to "stamp out once and for all the reign of terror which has gripped the Harlan County coal fields for the last fifteen years."
The Yankees and Tigers went at it hammer and tongs today in the final engagement of their three-game series and forthwith produced something of a major sensation.
Fire of undetermined cause destroyed Fiedler's Hotel,- largest. at this resort, at 6 A. M. today. The loss was estimated at more than $50,000.
The Committee for Industrial Organization began to loom large tonight as a possible ally of striking film studio craftsmen and laborers seeking a closed shop.

The unsolved phases of the Lindbergh case appeared in the background today as attorneys in the Parker conspiracy trial began laying the groundwork of the defense case through the cross-examination of Paul H. Wendel.
One of the anti-church laws of the State of Chihuahua has been declared unconstitutional by the Mexican Supreme Court, and similar action is expected for other States. Some people here at home

The Goodnews Bay gold strike developed into an oldtime Alaskan stampede today with arrival of the first boat of the season. Two hundred to 300 prospectors flocked over the sands of Kuskikwim Bay, a remote area of Southwestern Alaska, where recent gold, platinum and palladium strikes were reported.

The Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association will hold its annual meeting and election of officers and governors for next year at the Lunch Club Wednesday at 12:80 o'clock, it has been announced by J. R. MacNeille, assistant secretary. Darwin P. Kingsley Jr.

Sunny Sunday, the bay gelding owned by the Moreland Stables, took first in the $250 working hunter class in the second session of the New Haven horse show tonight. With Miss Elmina Brewster up, the mount moved well along its way to annexing the blue in this division, which consists of a series of four performances, one on each night of the four-day show.

The German dirigible Hindenburg, largest lighter-than-air craft in the world, had been made fast to mooring cars and was being manoeuvred to the mooring mast of the Lakehurst Naval Air Station here when it caught fire in the stern and became enveloped in flames at 7:23 o'clock tonight.
Buddy Baer, brother of Max Baer, former heavyweight champion, stopped Jim Wilde of Great Britain in the fourth round of their match in Harringay Stadium tonight.

The emergency board appointed by President Rbosevelt to investigate the situation which threatened to provoke a strike of 25,000 members of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks on nine railroads in the New York area, moved yesterday to bring about an armistice between the brotherhood and the International Longshoresmen's Association pending efforts for an amicable adjustment of the Jurisdictional dispute between these two-A. F. of L. unions.

Delegates from more than a score of nations instituted tonight a new world-wide experiment in international cooperation by signing a five-year compact designed to regularize the production and marketing of sugar.
Driving Hy Vandenburg to cover under a barrage of hits in the tenth inning, the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 4, today in the opening game of the home season here.

Dr. Edwin I. Harrington of Watertown, N. Y., assumed office yesterday as president of the Dental Society of the State of New York. The society, which is holding its sixty-ninth annual convention at at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, elected Dr. Russell W. Tench of this city as president-elect.

The leasing by Herman A. Groen, wholesale jeweler, of the nine-story building at 192 Broadway, northeast corner of John Street, was an-. nounced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker in the deal.
The Mary Harriman Rumsey Playground on the site of the old Casino in Central Park, will be opened this morning without formal ceremony, the Park Department announced yesterday.

John Hay Whitney's Royal Ralment, regarded as one of the best 3-year-olds in the Whitney string, qualified at Jamaica yesterday for a chance in the Coaching Club American Oaks and other specials in which she is engaged.

Production of rayon yarn in this country in the first quarter of 1937 was the highest for any quarter in the history of the industry, with mills generally operating at capacity, according to The Rayon Organon, published by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

Hans Luther, the German Ambassador to the United States, arrived here by airplane from Washington just after midnight. He was accompanied by the German air attache, Herr von Boettischer. They went into conference with officials of the Zeppelin company.

A rainy morning and cool afternoon held the local opening-day crowd down to about 12,500 as the Bisons edged out a 3-to-2 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs to replace the visitors in third place in the International League today.

Corn was the feature of the trading in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today. Congestion was more apparent in the May delivery, which advanced 2 1/4 cents a bushel at the extreme to $1.35 1/8, a new high price since 1925, and went to 5% cents above the May delivery of wheat.

Although weakness in the commodities was less pronounced than in previous recent weeks. The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined for the fourth consecutive week and on Tuesday stood at 143.0 against 143.5

THE conversation was general except where the brass-bound voice of James J. Johnston. the pugilistic impresario of Madison Square Garden, broke in on a particular subject. He stuck stubbornly to his favorite text. One fellow said it was funny how little some citizens knew about golf.
The Hindenburg, giant silver liner of ?the air, suddenly became a torch above the naval air station here tonight. What began as a routine landing of the transatlantic airship ended in a holocaust.

It is suggestive that STANLEY BALDWIN'S "last appeal" in the House of Commons should be an appeal for industrial peace and a profession of faith in collective bargaining as "the right thing," the only alternative to anarchy or force, as long as the industrial system remains as it is.

The Senate gave a unanimous vote of immediate confirmation today to Governor Lehman's nomination of Charles Poletti as a Supreme Court justice. Mr. Poletti, counsel to the Governor, who will fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice John V. McAvoy, was hailed by the Senators as a "brilliant young man" who would "do honor to the bench."

Although none of the title. and mortgage companies now in process of rehabilitation and liquidation under the auspices of the State is financially capable of being revived and permitted to go back in business, reorganization plans for the companies are being constantly filed in the courts by creditor groups, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance,

Brig. Gen. Henry H. Denhardt was released in $25,000 bail today after a jury reported it was hopelessly deadlocked on whether he shot to death his fiancee, Mrs. Verna Garr Taylor. Richard Adcock, jury foreman, said the eleven farmers and a filling station operator stood seven to five for acquittal.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed trustee for an authorized issue of $41,097,000 of New York Central Railroad fifteen-year 31/4 per cent bonds due on May 1, 1952. The Colonial Trust Company has been appointed trustee for Buckingham Community, Inc., first mortgage sinking fund 41/2 per cent bonds.

One of the main impressions left here by the exchange of views by the governors of more than twenty European central banks, and after -the annual World Bank assembly, is that they remain unassured despite Washington's assertions that the United States will not lower the price of gold.

A significant indication of the new Italian attitude toward Austria that evolved out of the Venice meeting of Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg of Austria and the-Rome meeting of Premier Mussolini and Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath of Germany was given today by Virginio Gayda, recognized mouthpiece of the Foreign Ministry, who, in the Giornale d'Italia, terms Austria a "free and independent German nation."

Within an hour after the Hiindenburg disaster, doctors and nurses, ambulances and policemen throughout Central New Jersey and in New York were mobilized into a rescue army. Many of them arrived at the scene as the burned hulk of the huge airship was still smoldering. Tensely calm, the doctors stood ready with unguents and bandages as the victims were carried from the ruins an. laid on stretchers.

Captain Bud Abbitt, Virginia's big right-hander, duplicated his recent performance against the Navy by twirling a one-hit game today as Virginia defeated Virginia Military Institute, 9-1, making it two straight over the cadets.

Dr. Erna Levy Lublinsky, 36-yearold physician and German refugee, fell or jumped four stories to her death yesterday morning from her room in the Clara De Hirsch Home, 225 East Sixty-third Street, between Second and Third Avenues, where she had been a resident for two weeks.

Ogden H. Hammond, United States Ambassador to Spain from 1925 to 1929, paid a $1 fine in Yorkville Court yesterday after he had pleaded guilty to having taken his wire-haired terrier into Central Park, unleashed and unmuzzled. He was among sixty violators of Park Department ordinances who appeared before Magistrate Henry H. Curran.

An indeterminate penitentiary sentence up to three years was imposed by Judge Donnellan in General Sessions on William Watson, former plumber, who defrauded six men of $800 under the pretext that he could use "influence" with a mythical executive of THE NEW YORK TIMES to obtain jobs for them or for relatives.

Frank J. Marshall, veteran chess master, who a year ago- retired as United States champion after holding the title for over. twenty-six years, yesterday annexed the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, this year's premier club in the Metropolitan Chess League.
Three hundred persons attended a funeral service for Dr. George Henry Fox, dermatologist, in the Universal Chapel, Fifty-second Street and Lexington Avenue, yesterday afternoon.

An exhibition of children's arts and crafts will be held at the University Settlement, 184 Eldridge Street, from next Monday until May 17. Sponsored by the United Neighborhood Houses, Inc., the exhibit will display the work of children various settlement houses, about. two-thirds of it from classes of the WPA Federal Art Project.

Representative W. R. Poage, a firstterm Texas Democrat, likes gardening. He could not find a plot of ground in the crowded capital, so he won permission to help tend the flowers and shrubbery in the government's botanical gardens.
Thousands of persons craned their necks in Times Square yesterday afternoon as the Hindenburg, a familiar sight to this area, soared above the tall buildings in a brilliant sun.

Spirited bidding by the "same old faces" marked the public auction of seized and abandoned goods yesterday in the United States Customs seizure room, 201 Varick Street, when more thai 200 dealers and private buyers acquired more. than 1,000 lots, ranging from "wrinkle removers" to a $14,000 assortment of liquors.

This capital today witnessed the biggest military parade staged since 1918. In the morning the troops assembled in the main square, where King Boris distributed the new colors, after which there was a parade past the reviewing stand in which stood the King and Queen with members of the diplomatic corps and military officials.
The probable pitchers in the major leagues today follow: American League New York at Cleveland--Hadley vs. Whitehill. Boston at Chicago--Walberg, vs. Kennedy.

Breaking a scoreless deadlock in the seventh inning, the Duke University baseball team shut out the St. John's University nine, 3--0, at Dexter Park yesterday. It was the third straight setback for the Redmen in six days.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday reserved decision on a motion made by counsel for a bondholders' committee to remove Judge Frank Cooper in reorganization proceedings for the Fonda, Johnstown Gloversville Railroad Company.

Miss Frances M. Henretta of Kane, Pa., a 20-year-old Connecticut College junior, beat off an attack by a man in her Mary Harkness dormitory room early today. Police Sergeant John J. Courtney said that Carl Phillips, 22, a Negro, was arrested two blocks

H. Gordon Selfridge, who used American methods of merchandising to create the great Oxford Street department store that bears his name, has decided to become a British subject, because "I expect to live in London the rest of my days and die here and, if I am lucky, be buried here."

KINGS BURNSTEIN, SAMUEL (May 21, 1933). Gross assets, $101,156; net. $16.786. To wife, Annie Burnstein; daughter, Rose Levy; son, Jacob Burnsteln, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, $95,500; stocks and bonds, $2,400; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,256. Jacob Burnstein, attorney, 11 W. 42d St. Manhattan.

Mrs. Effie Wise Ochs, widow of Adolph S. Ochs, late publisher of THE NEw YORK TIMES, died shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning at her home, "Hillandale," on North Street, White Plains. Her death followed a heart attack.

More than 130 church leaders yesterday urged Christians to aid Jewish victims of oppression by supporting the United Palestine Appeal for $4,500,000 for the settlement in Palestine of a maximum number of Jews of Germany, Poland and other lands.

The Metro Glass Bottle Company has purchased an industrial property comprising about 80,000 square feet, adjoining its present plant at 137-51 Westside Avenue, Jersey City, N. J. The parcel, which was bought from the United Wall Paper Factories, Inc., includes 15,000 square feet of one and two-story warehouses, and a large brick boiler house.

A $250,000 subscription by the Commonwealth Fund of New York, covering almost one-half the cost of a $600,000 building project to enlarge the facilities of the Columbia School of Medicine, was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. Other gifts received by the institution in March amounted to $26,938.

A syndicate of investors headed by Sol Atlas bought the northwest corner of Hillside Avenue and Midland Parkway, Jamaica, for improvement with a business building. The syndicate also bought the southwest corner of Queens Boulevard and Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills.

Destruction of the dirigible Hindenburg wrote finis today to Dr. Reginald Margeson's projected speed flight around the world by scheduled airlines. "The whole thing depended on the Hindenburg," said the Boston physician, -who had planned to depart tomorrow for Hongkong on the Philippine Clipper. But he canceled his reservation in view of the Zeppelin's explosion at Lakehurst, N. J.

Spain's deepening tragedy, though the danger of foreign complications has lessened, continues to cause serious repercussions abroad. The bombing last week of Guernica--presumably by German planes in the service of General FRANCO--in addition to arousing worldwide indignation against the Rebel leadership, has tended to worsen Anglo-German relations.
The formal dedication of the Mellon Institute's huge new building, a temple of science in outward appearance and inward spirit, is an event of national magnitude.

Graphic Arts Technical Conference, Hotel Commodore. Morning session, 9:30 o'clock. Speakers: John Clyde Oswald, V. Winfield Challenger, W: M. Passano, J. H. Holloway. Luncheon, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Dr. John H. Finley, James H. Herron, A. E. Giegengack. Afternoon session, 2:30 o'clock. Continues tomorrow at 9:30 A. M.

The oil with which the Archbishop of Canterbury will anoint King George VI at his coronation will be produced according to, a formula of the seventeenth century, which has been employed at the last two coronations.

The Fordham University golfers triumphed over New York University's team, 8-1, on the Elmsford Country Club course today. The Rams annexed five of the six twosomes matches and all three of the foursomes.

Beginning this afternoon an investigation of the sale by the George and Frances E. Ball Foundation of Muncie, Ind., of the control of the $3,000,000,000 Van Sweringen system of railroads, coal mines and other properties, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce sought to prove that the Ball Foundation was organized for taxavoidance purposes, thereby taking out of the Federal tax reservoir income and inheritance taxes on profits of more than $10.000.000.
Mr. and Mrs. C. S. Dale of Crestdale, Lexington, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wesa Eloise Dale, to Maurice Garabrant of Garden City, L. I.

The marriage of Miss Julia Lake Crawford, daughter of Mrs. Harden Lake Crawford of this city and Rumson, N. J., to W. Irving Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Harris of East Orange, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Central Presbyterian Church.

The Chautauqua Institution, 64year-old center of Summer education at Chautauqua, N. Y., has completed a three-year campaign to cancel $800,000 of indebtedness and is expected to end its receivership before the opening of the 1937 season, it was announced last night.
A powerful University of North Carolina tennis team downed the Princeton varsity by 7-2 on the Church courts today for its fifteenth straight victory of the current campaign.

Two workmen were burned fatally and three others sustained minor injuries early yesterday in a fire that started in a crude oil still at the plant of the Socony Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., at 400 Kingsland Avenue, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

Following is a list of the dead and missing and the injured and other survivors in the Hindenburg disaster, compiled from lists issued by the Zeppelin Transport Corporation, Coroner Raymond A. Taylor of Ocean County and the various hospitals:

A deal in the insurance district was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, which sold for the United States Trust Company the six-story office building at 12 Gold Street, southeast corner of Platt Street. The building, which occupies a plot 91 by 84 feet, was bought by the Pacific Fire Insurance Company, the Bankers and Shippers Insurance Company of New York and the New Jersey Insurance Company.

Senate committee action that may swing the city's main industry out of the toy balloon stage cheered Dexter residents today with hope of a new market for its helium gas supply. The Dexter field has been producing non-inflammable gas thirty years, but lately, due to slackening in the United States manufacture of lighter-than-air craft, there has been little sale.

A voluntary increase in wages to hotel employes was urged by J. Howard Slacum of Princeton, re-elected president of the New Jersey Hotel Association, in an address today at the organization's convention here. The sessions closed tonight.
New York's real underworld grows by leaps and' bounds, but nobody is complaining. Day before yesterday they "holed through"

The preliminary statement of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company for the three months ended on March 31, issued today, shows a consolidated net income of $8,537,100 after expenses, depreciation and estimated income taxes, but before mine depletion, equal to 98 cents a share on the 8,674,338 shares of capital stock outstanding.

It remained again for the flotation of a major public utility bond issue to lift the investment market out of its recent period of inactivity. The marketing of $42,500,000 of Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company 3 1/4 per cent debentures swelled the total of new bond offerings this week to $83,964,000.

The executive committee of the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce contributed $5,000 for the relief of the victims of the Hindenburg disaster. The amount will be divided equally among Americans and Germans, passengers and crew, who are in need. F. W. von Meister, American representative of the German Zeppelin Company, will be in charge of the distribution.

With only two more matches to be played, the Century Country Club today increased its lead over the other Class A teams competing for honors in the Westchester and Fairfield division of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub tournament.

Behind the effective twirling of Joe Dooley, who gave only one hit, a single, and fanned ten, the pacesetting Jamaica High nine scored its eighth victory in nine Queens P. S. A. L. starts yesterday by crushing Bayside, 16-O, at Jamaica Stadium.

A tiny pearl-handled pistol that once belonged to the mother of Mary Miles Minter, star of the silent screen, was sought by detectives tonight as officials pushed a new investigation of the fifteen-year-old slaying of William Desmond Taylor, film director.

The Committee for Industrial Organization entered the local transportation field last night with the avowed intention of organizing under its banner all workers in the New York area employed on subway, elevated, street car and bus lines.

Jockey Joe Dyer galloped home with three winners today at Aurora, scoring with Burr Hickman in the first race, Baldy in the second and Mr. Joe in the featured fifth event. In the mile and seventy yards contest Dyer rushed Mr. Joe, owned by J. R. Bridwell, to the front at the start and kept him there all the way to conquer

The State Mortgage Commission sold to a client of Arthur H. Kahr the five-and-a-half-story walk-up apartment house at 1,060 Fox Street, the Bronx. This is a thirty-six-family house, on a plot 75 by 100 feet. It was sold subject to a first mortgage of $88,500 at 41/2 and 5 per cent interest. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc.. was the broker.
Twenty-eight warships of Britain's Home Fleet, including her two modern battleships the Nelson and Rodney, arrived today for their coronation visit to London.

With the very generous, if reluotant, assistance of the Cardinals, the Giants crushed the feared maulers from St. Louis at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 8 to 2, and climbed within half a game of second place.
Lawrence Allderdice, manager of the Carnegie Hero Fund, a position once held by his father, died tonight in a Pittsburgh hospital. His age was 41.

The Hindenburg is gone. In a Government building at Lakehurst lie the bodies of the dead; on the ground, some engines and some blackened frames of metal. Without the aid of our technical records an engineering archaeologist of the remote future would find it extremely difficult to form from the

Exchanges of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country in April totaled $28,818,389,551, a decrease of 10.6 per cent from the preceding month, but 6.5 per cent in excess of the turnover in April, 1936. Among the factors responsible for the shrinkage in checks drawn were the reduced volume of trading in securities in New York to the smallest total since last September, with an accompanying decline in the average price;

A banking group composed of Harris, Hall Co., Inc., R. W. Pressprich Co. and the Milwaukee Company yesterday obtained the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 of city of Chicago water certificates on a bid of 105.183 for a fixed rate of 3 1/2s.

After a spirited debate, the Assembly early today defeated the Joseph bill which would have authorized the creation of mortgage banks in New York City and a fifty-mile radius. The vote was 43 for and 92 against.
The Pack ard Motor Car Company and the United Automobile Workers of America signed an agreement late today after several weeks' of negotiations.

A surcharge of $5,200 was imposed on the City Bank Farmers Trust Company by the Appellate Division yesterday for an alleged oversight in connection with the investment of trust funds in a mortgage participation certificate.
The annual Hunter College Sing, interclass competition held yesterday afternoon at the Center. Theatre, Radio City, was won by a senior class, whose chief song portrayed the seven ages of man.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 1 totaled 782,423 cars; the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 21,241 cars, or 2.8 per cent, more than for the preceding week 111,535 cars, or 15.1 per cent,

In half-a-dozen hospitals, from the smaller ones in the New Jersey resort towns of Pinewald, Lakewood, Asbury Park and Point Pleasant, to the skyscraping edifices of New York, survivors of the crash of the airship Hindenburg fought tonight against the death which had taken thirty-two of their co-voyagers.

John Pannes, passenger traffic manager of the combined North German Lloyd and Hamburg American steamship lines, was believed yesterday to have lost his life when the Hindenburg crashed, in an effort to save his wife, who had accompanied him on the crossing.

Aaron Sapiro, nationally known lawyer who once sued Henry Ford for libel in behalf of the Jews of America and joined former Mayor James J. Walker in a plea for the pardon of Tom Mooney, was ordered disbarred from practice in the Federal court here by John C. Knox, senior judge of the district.
The Jewish Relief Committee arranged today to distribute money to Jewish exiles from Germany who agree it will be the last financial assistance given them here.

The second meeting of the Little Entente's interparliamentary conference here today developed into a solemn manifestation of unity. A number of Cabinet members of Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Yugoslavia were among the many delegates.

Amid bickering and political squabbles the 160th session of the Legislature was winding tortuously to a close early today after passing bills to round out a $440,000,000 fiscal program and authorizing permissive jury service by women.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 940,000 bales, against 985,000 a week ago, 979,000 two weeks ago, 994,000 three weeks ago and 732,000 a year ago; of which American 417,000 bales, against 412,000 a week ago, 979,000 two weeks ago, 438,000 three weeks ago and 335.000 a year ago.

Harry H. Woodring, Secretary of War, and Mrs. Woodring, with members of their family, have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington. Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French, who returned recently from Europe, left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday for their place in Chester, N. H. Mr. and Mrs. Harvey S. Firestone Jr. are at the Ritz-Carlton.

The strike of 4,000 employes of the Chevrolet and Fisher Body plants here ended late today in an agreement which union leaders predicted "will establish a national precedent" and do away with the strikes that have beset General Motors plants.
The successful conclusion of the world sugar conference at London is important both for its immediate achievements and for its symbolic value.
A number of Britons in Gibraltar have received confidential information warning them they would be arrested if they went to La Linea, a neighboring town in Insurgent territory.
The banking community has been prepared for legislation on corporate trustee business ever since the publication last June of the report of the Securities and Exchange Commission on this subject.

Station W of the New York Post-office will move on Monday to its new quarters; 127-135 West Eightythird Street, from 160-162 West Eighty-third Street. Postmaster Albert Goldman will preside at the dedication of the new station at i 11 A. M. on Monday.

Clergymen tomorrow will refer in their sermons to the airship Hindenburg disaster and will offer prayers for the victims. A "Mother's Day" will be marked as well as "Coronation Sunday" in anticipation of the crowning next Wednesday of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth.

Stocks fluctuated narrowly and closed steady and mixed; turnover, 817,045 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds steady and fractionally higher, foreign issues irregular; transactions, $10,459,300.

Responsibility toward the less fortunate is growing stronger in this country, as evidenced in the work of the women's division of the United Hospital Fund, Mrs. William Armour, general chairman, told the annual meeting of division committees yesterday at the American Red Cross Building, 315 Lexington Avenue.
The 154th annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of New York will be held at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, beginning on Tuesday at 11 A. M. with a service of holy communion.

Although the sixteen concerts to be given by the New Friends of Music in Town Hall next season will be devoted to chamber music and songs by Mozart, Schubert and Schumann, it is to the popularity of the works of the first-named that the organization attributes

To illustrate the part played by the automobile retailer in the country's economic system speakers told assembled Dodge dealers in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday of the billions of dollars spent by American motorists, in 1936, on the purchase, operation and maintenance of their passenger cars and trucks-$2.630,000.000 for new cars;

A call for the Sixth International Congress for Steel Development, which was canceled after having having been scheduled to be held in New York, has just been issued from the executive offices in The Hague, Holland, and is to be held in France and Germany instead.

What are believed to be the first Moorish troops to set foot in any Basque province other than Southern Navarre in the entire history of Moorish invasions of Spain over a period of centuries assisted the Insurgents today in their attack on Mount Solluve.

City College seniors accepted the "Supreme Court plan in principle" by a ratio of three and one-half to one, but repudiated the plan in method, two to one, notwithstanding the fact that they selected President Roosevelt as the greatest American.

Uncle Robert's tenth annual Parents' Day celebration-dedicated this year to Gold Star fathers and mothers-will take place on the Mall in Central Park tomorrow afternoon. The exercises, which will be broadcast by Radio Station WNYC, will be held from 2 to 4:30 o'clock. If the weather is unfavorable, the rally will be postponed until Sunday, May 16.

The defeat of the Pari-Mutuel bill at the present session of the State Legislature was accomplished with a $100,000 slush fund established by leading bookmakers of the State, George H. Sibley, regional director of the National Federation of Young Republicans, declared last night.
John L. Lewis urged here today the reopening of abandoned coal mines as a means of solving the bootleg coal problem.

Serene amid encircling hills, in the full dignity of her one hundredth year, Mount Holyoke College flung wide her gates today to alumnae from all corners of the world, come back to recall and reenact with undergraduates an event of paramount- importance in the annals of feminine education in America.

Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" was given last night by the Hippodrome Opera Company with a familiar cast that was headed by Annunciata Garrotto as Cio-Cio-San, and Lawrence Power as Lieutenant Pinkerton.

The Board of Estimate took the first step yesterday in providing a new Criminal Courts Building and a new city prison to replace the Tombs when it authorized Controller Frank J. Taylor to negotiate for the necessary land.

The Golden Hill Chorus, a women's group conducted by Channing Lefebvre, gave its annual Carnegie Hall concert last night. Its offerings included works of Purcell, Weelkes, Gretchaninoff, Wagner, Holst, Herbert Hughes, Rachmaninoff, Lefebvre and Strauss, and a group of folktunes of German, Irish, English, South African and Creole origins. Grace Roberts served as piano accompanist.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Scattering small sales of wool are reported but the market is generally very quiet and the trend of prices is easier. Just how much the market has declined is a matter for debate but the trend is downward both here and abroad.

An agreement was signed yesterday by the New England Steamship Company and the newly organized National Maritime Union providing for a 15 per cent increase in wages for cooks and stewards and 60 cents an hour overtime, it was announced last night.

Restaurants in computing the amount of sales tax charged to customers for meals must deduct the price of any beer or ale which has been served, the Appellate Division ruled in a unanimous decision yesterday, reversing the position previously taken by Controller Frank J. Taylor.

4th St, 275 18.3x50; Ida E. Cairns et al to Ida Nicola, 271 W 4th St; mtge $3,300 ($4.50) 45th St, 338 W, 17.6x100.5; Louise Gard and ano to 338 W 45th St Corp. 92d St, 63 E. 17x100.8; Henry H. Jackson to 1.361 1st Ave Corp. 136 E 57th St ($31).

Word has been received here of the birth of a son to Captain and Mrs. Louis Kenedy Jr. on May 3 at their home, Seaton, Rockley, Barbados. Mrs. Kenedy is the former Miss Patricia Greenidge, daughter of Mrs. Norman Mitchell of Barbados.
