A development of the three-centsa-day plan of the Associated Hospital Service, which would provide for medical care in addition to hospital care for persons in the lower income brackets, was discussed last night by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals and a director of the service.
The urge to unionize has spread to secretaries and employes of members of Congress.

Twenty thoroughbreds have been named for Kentucky's glamorous Derby, to be run here tomorrow for the sixty-third time before a crowd which it is estimated will reach 50,000. The official forecast is for clear weather and a fast track for the mile and a quarter test that carries $50,000 in added money.

Retail trade improved sharply here during the week, with department store sales volume estimated as averaging 12 to 13 per cent ahead of the corresponding period last year. The special "week" staged by some stores brought notably favorable consumer response, gains for the first four days ranging up to 25 per cent.
The Reds gave Wild Bill Hallahan plenty of hitting and airtight support today while lengthening their belated winning streak to three straight with a 5-3 victory over the Bees.

Oliver E. Sweet, director of the bureau of finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission, has served notice on the Chesapeake Ohio Railway that it must reveal the details of its connections with other Van Sweringen interests at the hearing on May 13 in regard

Flags flew at half-staff today on all public buildings in this little Lake Constance town, which was the cradle of airship transportation, but in the three great construction halls work proceeded as usual. The Hindenburg's sister ship, the LZ130, which is now to be its successor, is well on its way to completion, and the huge aluminum rings already are taking form near by for the LZ131.

More than 400 delegates, representing 248 clubs in the city, adopted a resolution yesterday opposing the Supreme Court plan of President Roosevelt at the 103d convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, Inc. The convention was held in the Hotel Astor.

The Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into operations of investment trusts produced today evidence that the General Investment Corporation had a loss of $67,000,000 on its total assets of $77,000,000 between 1932 and Aug. 8, 1936.

The Grately Realty Company, Inc., representing Joseph G. Haft, Jesse Segal and David B. Smith, builders, has purchased the block front on the east side of Fourth Avenue, with a depth of 134 feet on Eighty-second Street and 97 feet on Eighty-third Street, Brooklyn. It is proposed to erect two six-story apartment houses on the plot.

Queen Shenandoah XIV was crowned here today with solemn ceremonial in the presence of 10,000 to 12,000 persons gathered for this ritual of the valley's annual Apple Blossom Festival, a tribute to the fruit which means the livelihood of a third of the inhabitants between this city and Lexington.
By something deeper than coincidence both Mr. Stanley Baldwin and M. Leon Blum almost echo one another in simultaneous appeals to the patriotism of labor.

Millions of men and women became eyewitnesses to the Hindenburg disaster yesterday when newsreels of the destruction of the dirigible were rushed into major motion-picture theatres in the key cities of the nation. Audiences stiffened as the giant airship nosed toward its mooring mast and fell, a white-hot, crumpled skeleton.

Last-minute changes in plans of State officials resulted last night the postponement to an indefinite date of the sale of $40,000,000 of New York State bonds. Controller Morris S. Tremaine had intended to offer the bonds for sale at his office on May 19. Public notice of a sale must appear at least ten days prior to the opening of bids.
Officials of the Second Corps Area, Governors Island, announced yesterday that only 700 more C. M. T. C. applications can be considered from young men residing in New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

" Make Way for Tomorrow," which Leo McCarey directed and produced for Paramount from Josephine Lawrence's "The Years Are So Long," will arrive this morning at the Criterion. Victor Moore, Beulah Bondi, Fay Bainter, Thomas Mitchell,

Activity increased in the bond market yesterday resulting in a resumption of the upward movement in high-grade issues over a broad front. The improvement in the better grade and underlying loans held the attention of traders while the secondary and convertible industrial issues were allowed to drift.
Dr. Clyde Fisher, curator of the Hayden Planetarium, received yesterday the flag of the Explorers Club to carry on the Hayden Planetarium-Grace Peruvian Eclipse Expetition, of which he is leader.
Daniel Joseph Leonard, acting lieutenant of the 105th Detective Squad in Queens Village for the last two years, died yesterday afternoon of pneumonia at his home, 115-23 173d Street, St. Albans.

The 10,000-ton light cruiser Savannah will be launched at the yard of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation here at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow. The sponsor will be Miss Jane M. Bowden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Bowden of Savannah.
Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, representing 800 cotton mills which employ about 345,000 workers, today registered his opposition to the National Textile Bill.

Michael J. Hogan, 66 years old, a former Republican member of Congress from Brooklyn, who has had several brushes with the law in recent years, pleaded guilty to participation in a "job-fixing" conspiracy yesterday in General Sessions, and was released in $2,500 bail by Judge John J. Freschi for sentence on May 21.

The stock markets generally were cheerful today, with firmness in most of the sections. Gilt-edged issues were steady. German bonds were featured among the foreign loans. International stocks moved upward on better news from Wall Street,

Henry T. (Dick) Merrill, transatlantic flier, took off from Floyd Bennett Field yesterday afternoon for a flight to Richmond and Washington for a final check on the two Wasp engines of his Lockheed Electra plane before starting a roundtrip flight to London today.
A feat no other City College nine in history had been able to perform was recorded at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday when the Beavers defeated New York University for the second time this Spring, 6-5.

Miss Laura W. Rhodes. daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Goodrich B. Rhodes of 32 Washington Square, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents to Donald C. Taylor of this city, son of Mrs. George C.,Embody of Ithaca, N. Y., and the late James B. Taylor.

Joseph H. Nuelle, president of the New York, Ontario Western Railway Company, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to become president of the Lehigh New England Railroad Company and five other railroads to succeed S. D. Warriner, resigned.

IT is the custom in this corner to consult Mr. Lucien Franck each year as the Kentucky Derby draws near. Mr. Franck knows something about that race. He was at Churchill Downs when it started. Of course, Colonel Matt Winn was there too.

Testimonial dinner of the Association of Teachers of Social Studies in honor of Dr. John L. Tildsley, Hotel Pennsylvania, 12:30 P. M. Speakers, Mayor F. H. La Guardia, Professor Stephen Duggan, James Marshall.
Rep resentative Edward T. Taylor, Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, is in a suburban sanitarium for a rest prescribed by Dr. George W. Calver, Capitol physician.
Miss Elizabeth Straub Stimson, daughter of Mrs. Earl Stimson of Roland Park, was married today to Thomas Everett MacMannis, son of Mrs. Andrew MacMannis.

Twenty-two years ago yesterday, with two torpedoes in her. side, the Lusitania, "fastest and largest in Atlantic service," sank ten miles off the southeast tip of Ireland. carrying 1,198 persons, among them 124 Americans, to their death.

Footsore but still good-tempered, Londoners waited unavailingly tonight to hear that last night's temperate findings of the public court of inquiry into the bus strike had been made the basis of settlement. No truce, however, was in sight.
Rear Admiral R. R. Waesche, commandant of the Coast Guard, announced today that seventy-two cadets will embark from New London June 5 on the cutters George W. Campbell and Cayuga for Marseilles.
Mrs. Marjorie U. Stern obtained a divorce here today from Robert B. Stern of London on charges of cruelty. Later today she was married to Elliott M. Kahn of New York City.

Holding an 18-3 lead at half-time, the New York Athletic Club six downed the West Side Y. M. C. A., 27 to 12, in a preliminary round match in the senior national A. A. U. soft-ball water polo championship tournament in the New York A. C. pool last night.

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation battled and captured a man today who, according to Bliss Morton, acting chief of the local bureau, is wanted in connection with a $25,000 bank hold-up in Grand Rapids, Mich.

Walter M. Jeffords's Matey, moving up to his engagement in the Preakness, to be run here May 15, won the Kalitan Purse, feature race on the Pimlico card today before 8,500 fans. He triumphed by a head over A. G. Vanderbilt's Scotch Bun.
Two men were sentenced to death today for the hold-up murder of a policeman, and the "finger man," who was a State's witness, was sentenced to ten to fifteen years in State prison.

The news-gathering Ostroms, father and son, plan to celebrate jointly golden and silver wedding anniversaries at a dinner in Owego May 17. William Ostrom, retired owner and editor of the old Olean Herald, and his wife, Katherine, will have been married fifty years on that date.

Farm bankruptcies declined 15 per cent to 3,642 during the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1936, from 4,311 in the preceding fiscal year, the Department of Agriculture has reported on the basis of return to the Attorney General.

Chancellor Livingston Jenks, retired Chicago lawyer, former president general of the national society of the Sons of the American Revolution, died on Tuesday in Pasadena, Calif., it was learned today. He and his wife, the former Janet Lyons, had been visiting at the home of a niece, Mrs. Frederick B. Carter. His age was 74.

Synthesis and refinement of a new chemical, which furnishes medicine with a new and powerful weapon against all types of pneumonia, were described here today before a symposium on recent progress in science which featured the second day of the dedication exercises of the new ten-million-dollar Mellon Institute of Industrial Research.

A program of contemporary American compositions was offered by the Federal Music Project Chamber Orchestra, under the direction of Jacques Gordon, last night at the WPA Theatre of Music at a concert forming part of the May festival being held by the Federal Music Project in connection with National Music Week.

Some of the Hindenburg's mail cargo has been salvaged, the postmaster's office announced here yesterday. According to advices from Philadelphia, where the mail is being handled, 133 letters were saved.

GERBER, TEREZIA (April 4). Estate, not more than $2,000. To Elizabeth Umstetter, daughter, executrix, 219 Court St., Brooklyn, residue; one other bequest. GOLDMAN, BELLA (March 20). Estate. more than $10,000. To Muriel B. Goldman 97 Arden St., $275 and one-half residue; Nanon H. Weinschenk, 97 Arden St., $375 and three-eighths residue; Louis M. Goldman, 40-45 201st St., Bayside, L. I., $225 and one-eighth residue; two other bequests. Herbert S. Weinschenk, 97 Arden St.. executor.
Miss Josephine Turney Brown, daughter of Albert Turney Brown of this city, was married this afternoon to George Ellsworth Currey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Currey, also of East Orange.

The Yankees virtually were victims of a one-round knockout today when the Indians, showing a most extraordinary amount of vehemence, ripped into one Irving Bump Hadley for five runs in the first inning. Not until the eighth did the world champions recover from that surprising jolt. Then they swung into action.
Jack M. Brooks's Corum, a 4-yearold gelded son of Crack Brigade, won the mile and one-sixteenth feature race by two lengths from Mrs. Ed Haughton's Cascapedia at Narragansett Park today.

The members of the advanced, senior and junior classes of the Naval War College, who will be graduated and receive their diplomas from Assistant Secretary of the Navy Charles Edison next Friday, were guests of honor, together with their wives and members of their families, at a farewell reception given this afternoon by the president of the college, Rear Admiral Charles P. Snyder, and Mrs. Snyder.

Striking pickets parading in front of the Max Fleischer Studios at 1,600 Broadway, between Fortyeighth and Forty-ninth Streets, defied police orders last night and precipitated a disturbance that resulted in the arrest of fourteen persons. Fists and placards were swung with abandon, but no injuries were reported.

Captain Ernst A. Lehmann, wearer of the Iron Cross, who would not jump to safety from his post in the control car of the flaming Zeppelin Hindenburg until his clothes were burning from his body, died in the Paul Kimball Hospital here at 5:55 o'clock this afternoon.

With the seizure in a Harlem flat yesterday of 280,000 fraudulent sweepstake -tickets, postal inspectors believed they had prevented the spread to the metropolitan area of a gigantic racket that in the last four years has defrauded gullible New Englanders of more than $2,00,000.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $8,348,500, to be represented by one State and thirty-nine municipalities. This compares with the revised total for this week of $17,545,002.

Miss Elberta Kate Shipley, teacher and poet who was known throughout the country for the Daniel Boone costume she wore while lecturing for many and varied causes, died yesterday morning in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, of pneumonia. Miss Shipley, who was 50 years old, had lived at 198 Monroe Street, Brooklyn.

Puts, calls and straddles have been defined as speculative by the New York Stock Exchange committees on business conduct and customers' men. The former committee ruled yesterday that "any account in which there is carried a put, call, straddle or other privilege,

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, announced last night that he had received notice from the Works Progress Administration here that 5,000 relief workers were to be dropped immediately from Park Department projects. He said the notice came from Colonel Brehon Somervell, local WPA Administrator.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated over a range of about 10 points yesterday to end 2 points higher to 4 points lower. Improvement abroad was responsible for the best quotations of the day at the start, but selling developed later on better weather in the Cotton Belt and a decline in wheat.

Stockholders of the H. L. Green Company, Inc., have been called to vote on May 18 on authorization of 80,000 shares of new first preferred stock and reclassification of the present 4,777 shares of first preferred stock into a like number of shares of second preferred stock.

Commander Sir Charles Dennistoun Burney, Britain's leading airship expert, writing in The Daily Telegraph tonight, contends that airships as a factor in world transport are being outpaced by the steady progress of flying boats.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, chief protagonist of rigid airships and veteran skipper of both the Graf Zeppelin and the Hindenburg, was quoted yesterday in dispatches from Austria as saying that the disaster to the world's largest airship proved that helium instead of hydrogen must be used as a lift gas hereafter.

Factory sales by members of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, which includes all car builders except the Ford Motor Company, in April, amounted to 387,163 cars and trucks, the association reported yesterday.

The news that the first weakfish of the season has been taken in Peconic Bay is an important signal. Figuratively, it is a flash to salt water anglers that the Spring activities on Long Island will soon bloom into maturity.
Hunter College will hold its annual Spring Junior Promenade tonight at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. More than 350 couples are expected to attend. Among the invited guests are Dr. Eugene A. Colligan,
TIERRA BAJA, a play in Spanish in three acts by Angel Gulmera; presented by Paulina Singerman's Argentine Company. At the Ambassador Theatre.

Tribute to the reserve officers of the United States Army was given by Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn yesterday in welcoming 150 delegates to Brooklyn for the annual convention of the Department of New York, Reserve Officers Association of the United States.

Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt will leave tomorrow for London to represent Austria at the coronation. On his return journey he will stay a few days in Paris. Thus he will have an opportunity to confer with Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and Yvon Delbos, French Foreign Secretary, on outstanding Austrian problems.

The third match of the season at Preece Field took place today, with the White poloists defeating a Red quartet, made up of Godfrey Preece, G. H. (Pete) Bostwick, Jimmy Mills and Ivor Balding, 6 to 5.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 5: COMMANDERS Read, O. M., to the staff of the Naval War College, Newport, R. I. Trammell, W., to duty as commander of Destroyer Division 3; orders of Jan. 6 modified.

The truce between labor and employers in France, which was announced yesterday, for the duration of the Paris Exhibition got new confirmation today when Premier Lion Blum, addressing the Chamber of Deputies during the debate on his policy, made an appeal in much the same manner and terms as that made in London two days ago by Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin for concord and peace in the name of democracy.

Miss Leila Ammon Bernstorff, who will be married to Dr. Hans Joachim Grauert of New York and Hamburg, Germany, this Summer, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner given by the Misses Ethel and Margo Harsanyi at their home, 468 Riverside Drive.

IF your history teachers were of the conventional sort, they taught that when Henry VIII drove monasticism out of England he committed his greatest and grossest crime. They explained that since Henry had broken with Rome over the matter of divorce, he soon found it necessary to break also with English monks, nuns and friarswho "generally remained loyal to the Pope"--and that therefore he harried and even murdered

Open-market discount rates on bankers' acceptance were reduced yesterday by from one-sixteenth to one-eighth of 1 per cent in an effort by dealers to attract additional offerings of bills into the market to meet a rising demand.

BILLINGS-- C. K. G., husband of Blanche MacLeish, father of Mrs. W. H. Vander Poel. Funeral services at 2 o'clock in the afternoon of May 8 at All Saints Episcopal Church, Santa Barbara, Calif. Interment will be made later in the family plot in Graceland Cemetery in Chicago, III.

Three bills carrying total appropriations of $1,760,000 for parkways in and near New York City were passed today by the Assembly. Two of the measures previously had been approved by the Senate and now go to Governor Lehman.

Harvard's varsity lacrosse team defeated Brown, 12 to 0, today, for its fifth straight New England Intercollegiate League victory. The Brown freshmen defeated the Harvard freshmen, 1 to 0, in a preliminary game.

The Spring takes its toll of three more attractions tonight -- "The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse," ex the Hudson; "Candida," from the Empire; "Miss Quis," from the Henry Miller's. Their scores, respectively, 80 performances, 49 and 37.

That May Day whirlwind which was so disastrously reaped by the local burlesque houses caused a chilling back-draft through those livelier and lustier night spots where the customer's imagination was seldom overtaxed and sent them hurrying to put up stormshutters as precaution against a more particular blow.
Mrs. Susan G. Tierney, who was active for many years in Democraitc party and civic affairs in South Orange, died today at her home here at the age of 63. She was the wife of John A. Tierney.

Hugh de Tenebrokes Glazebrook, noted portrait painter, who, as honorary secretary of the Anglo-American Ambulance Corps, was closely associated with Henry James during the World War, died yesterday in Alassio, Italy. His age was 82.

The loss of the German dirigible Hindenburg is the costliest in the history of aviation. The airship's value for insurance purposes alone was [pound]500,000, of which about [pound]225,000 was covered in the London market.
A group of employes of Clayton Mark Co. of Chicago challenged constitutionality of the Wagner Labor Relations Act today.

The Seaboard Air Line Railway reported yesterday a profit and loss deficit of $57,913,461 on Dec. 31, against a deficit of $51,649,802 a year previously. Total assets were $296,213,895, against $291,955,085.

Mayor La Guardia deplored yesterday the effect that the destruction of the Zeppelin Hindenburg would have on the future of lighterthan-air craft in this country. The Mayor said he had received a police call from New York as he was returning last Thursday night from Atlantic City.

Vice President Garner and a dozen Senators departed today for Louisville and "the Darby." "Its just plain Derby to me," Garner said, "but the crowd I'm going with says its pronounced Darby so I guess that's what it'll be. It still sounds pretty high toned to me."

Funeral services for Mrs. Effie Wise Ochs, the widow of Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, were held this afternoon at Hillandale, her home here, attended by relatives and many firends. Mrs. Ochs died yesterday.

Mr. BORAH took occasion on Thursday to warn the Senate that an "insidious, subtle effort" is being made to preach the gospel of fascism in the United States. He did not identify the groups which he believes are working toward this end.

Representatives of Yale University and the city of New Haven met today. Mayor John W. Murphy, for the City Committee, advanced five requests as follow: That Yale contribute a substan-i tial sum to help meet the costs of the municipality.

Leaders in the fight for the Roosevelt court reorganization legislation rejoiced today in the appointment of Major George L. Berry as Senator from Tennessee. Major Berry is a supporter of the legislation.
Federal Judge R. M. Gibson ruled today that a temporary restraining order be continued for ten days, halting prosecution of the government's anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, veteran Zeppelin skipper, in a brief talk yesterday afternoon from Berlin by short waves to American listerners, announced that he would sail today on the Europa for this country with a technical committee appointed by Colonel General Hermann Goering, Air Minister, to investigate the tragedy of the Hindenburg.

Mrs. Simpson and the Duke of Windsor were photographed arm in arm this morning. It was the first time since the former King Edward VIII's abdication that they had posed together and both looked happy.
Robert A. Taft asked the Supreme Court again today to compel the United States to pay him $1.07 interest on a gold Liberty bond, called in by the Treasury in advance of maturity date.

Defendants in a stockholders action brought against various banks and former officers and directors of the National Surety Company have offered to pay $1,350,000 in settlement of all claims against them for alleged wrongful acts, it was announced yesterday by Wolfgang Schwabacher of Hayes, Wolf, Kaufman Schwabacher, attorneys for the plaintiffs.

Miss Catherine Creighton Cooke, daughter of Mrs. Mayme M. Cooke of Bronxville and the late James Negley Cooke of Pittsburgh, will be married to Alexander James Troy Jr., also of Bronxville, on May 20 in the Church of the Trasfiguration, this city.
Cotton-mill activity increased last week, when a slight decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index spurted to 143.3 from 136.9 (revised). It was 104.9 for the week ended May 2, 1936.
Amateur racing, which has been flourishing in the South for weeks, returns to the metropolitan area today with the annual Spring meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association at Cedarhurst, L. I.

Spurred by the bombing of Guernica and the indignation aroused in many countries, the British Government proposed today to send an appeal to both sides in the Spanish civil war "to renounce entirely the use of bombing from the air."

The employers' group of the International Labor Organization's governing body, recalling that Soviet Russia at the last maritime conference of the I. L. O. was represented by a full delegation including government, employer and worker delegates, raised the question today whether Russia was entitled under the I. L. O. constitution to have employer delegates since there is no longer private industry there.

The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company will call a special meeting of stockholders, probably early in June, to vote on issuance of about $16,100,000 of new convertible preferred stock of $100 par value to carry a maximum dividend rate of 4 1/2 per cent per annum.

Funeral rites for William A. Boring, dean emeritus of the Columbia University School of Architecture, who died last Wednesday after a long illness, were held yesterday in the university chapel. Chaplain Raymond C. Knox officiated at the services.
Charles Lessing, union chieftain, announced tonight that 1,000,000 persons would begin picketing motion picture theatres on a nationwide scale Monday.
The senior class of the University Heights Colleges of New York University held its annual senior ball at the Hotel Biltmore last night. Approximately 300 persons were present.

Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, told the convention of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union today that both labor and industry had duties and responsibilities toward insuring industrial peace as a result of the Supreme Court's validation of the National Labor Relations Act.

Mrs. Edith Judson Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Judson of South Orange, N. J., was married here yesterday to Robert O. Norton, son of Clifford Norton of Summit, N. J., and the late Mrs. Norton, in the chapel of the Marble Collegiate Church, by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale.

Engineering contracts totaling $1,259,907.79 were awarded by the War Department today, as follows: John Young Jr., Elmhurst, N.Y., for constructing towers, footings and guy anchors for the relocation of the Beach City-Cambridge cable line of the Ohio T. T. Company,

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to unlisted trading Bunker Hill and Sullivan Mining and Concentrating Company new common stock, $2.50 par value, in substitution for the old $10 par value common stock.

All of Italy read with consternation the news of the Lakehurst disaster, but the newspapers, although publishing ample details, did not give the story any particular prominence, perhaps out of a sense of delicacy with regard to Germany, with which Italy wishes to cultivate very amicable relations.

The last of fifteen employes of the Tilo Roofing Company plant in Stratford, who spent the night in jail there after they attempted a sit-down strike at 7:30 o'clock last night, were released late today on bond. They are to appear in Town Court Monday on charges of trespassing.
Mrs. Christine Hopkins Jones of Port Deposit, Md., widow of Robert Holcomb Jones, was married to Archibald Alexander Talmage of this city yesterday afternoon at the home of her cousin,
Colonel General Hermann Goering, German Secretary for Aviation, today cabled his country's thanks for the rescue work of the Naval Air Station force to Commander Charles E. Rosendahl.

Mayor La Guardia dedicated the new city ferryboat "Gold Star Mother," which will run between Manhattan and Richmond at Mariners Harbor, S. I., yesterday. "The name of this vessel is symbolic to those mothers whose sons gave their lives in the World War," the Mayor said.

The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, after fifty-six consecutive adjournments since it first offered the collateral for sale in May, 1932, "purchased" yesterday for $817,413 the collateral for a loan of $1,500,000 made to Insull Utilities Investments, Inc.

The Citizens Savings Bank sold to Isadore Lorber, Inc., operator, the six-story apartment house containing 119 rooms at 470 West 146th Street, between Convent and Amsterdam Avenues. The house occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and was sold through Schimmer, Kerner Feder, brokers.

The National Labor Relations Board today petitioned the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals for an enforcement decree to make the Delaware New Jersey Ferry Company carry out the board's order of December, 1935, to deal with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association 13 as the "exclusive bargaining agent" of the engineers.

Warnings of possible dictatorship and regimentation if schools and colleges do not meet their responsibilities were sounded today at the opening session of the annual meeting of the American Council on Education.

Stephen Leidy Coles, former managing editor of The Radio World and former radio editor of The New York Herald Tribune, died yesterday of heart disease at his home, 101 Quentin Street, Kew Gardens, Queens.

Burlesque throughout the city received two severe legal setbacks yesterday in its fight to reopen its closed theatres, all fourteen of which were shut down by police last Saturday when License Commissioner Paul Moss refused to renew their expired licenses.

After it had been bitterly assailed and warmly defended, the Assembly today adopted and sent to Governor Lehman the Dunnigan bill vesting broad powers in city licensing commissioners to bar "strip-tease" and other theatrical performances. The vote was 104 to 22.

In the opening day's play of the Eastern intercollegiate golf tournament, held today on the Yale course, the Elis defeated Dartmouth, 8 to 1; Holy Cross blanked Brown, 9-0, and Harvard downed Williams, 8-1.

Affidavits made by three prostitutes recanting testimony given by them at the trial of Charles J. (Lucky) Luciano were branded as "poisonously false" yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook in refusing to grant the former vice overlord a new trial.

The total cash income from principal farm marketing in the first quarter of this year amounted to $1,739,000,000, or 16 per cent more than the corresponding period of 1936, the Agriculture Department disclosed today.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 6 unless specified: At Tsingtao, May 7: Canopus, Pigeon, S-36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, May 7. Arctic, at Pearl Harbor.

Willis Co., real estate brokers, held a reception yesterday to mark the opening of their new Queens office at 95-36 Queens Boulevard, West Forest Hills. About 300 brokers, builders, investors and operators attended. Nathan Willis, president, said the firm was forced to change its location and expand its office space by reason of recent increased activity.

A contract with its 3,500 union coal miners was signed today by the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, ending a shutdown that began March 31. The United States Steel subsidiary accepted union demands for full Appalachian Scale of wage increases.

After a short period of comparative calm, Arab terrorists again are renewing their activities in Palestine. Last night C. Fibrook, a British constable, was shot in the hand while sitting in a cafe in Tulkarem, an Arab town in Northern Palestine.
John E. Joyce, referee in bankruptcy, was appointed yesterday special master by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert to conduct hearings in the reorganization proceedings of the Warner-Quinlan Company.
Secretary Perkins was quoted today as saying that legislation to establish "minimum working conditions" for labor was point No. 1 in the Roosevelt administration's labor program.

Jacob Hilder, former head of New York corporations identified in the chemical, dry goods and leather goods trade, died here yesterday at his home. He was 66 years old and had come to this country from Germany, where he was born, fifty-one years ago.

Four Jersey City pitchers were unable to hold Rochester in check today, the Red Wings inaugurating their home season with a 9-3 vietory before 6,640 fans. Overcast skies and a cool breeze held down the attendance.

An as sertion that four forms of discrimination against Hawaii ,and Puerto Rico exist in the Sugar Quota Bill as recommended By the subcommittee to the House Committee on Agriculture was made by Secretary Ickes today in a letter sent to Representative Marvin Jones of Texas, chairman of the committee.

The best approach is to clear the atmosphere by solving minor outstanding problems. If this apparently modest but really significant program toward China, announced by Foreign Minister NAOTAKE SATO on Thursday,...

The Committee for Industrial Organization's New England Council tonight called upon the United States Senate subcommittee on Education and Labor to give its "immediate and earnest attention" to the imprisonment of six labor leaders in Maine.

Unless the United States Government, acting on the advice of the National Aeronautic Association, forbids the international transatlantic air race scheduled for late in the Summer, it will be held. This decision was announced here today by the Aero Club of France.

John H. Gewecke, who rose from an office boy in the treasurer's department of the United States Steel Corporation at 71 Broadway, New York, to the office of assistant treasurer, died yesterday at his home here. He was 53 years old.

Zionism is losing most of its youth, power and educational influence in Europe because of that movement's constant straining for funds and contributions, Dr. Hugo Bergmann, rector of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, told members of the Zionist Organization of America, at a luncheon in his honor yesterday, at the Commodore Hotel.

Mayor La Guardia made an attack yesterday on the contract system under which school custodians are hired when the Board of Estimate refused to endorse a bill putting the custodians under civil service.

The Yale freshmen today extended their long winning streak by outscoring the Derby High School nine, 13-1. Triples by Poole and Grayson figured heavily in the victory. Harley Jackson struck out ten Derby batsmen and allowed only seven safeties.

Mrs. Pastoriza Flores Hendel, teacher of Spanish history and literature at the College of New Rochelle, died yesterday of a throat infection at her home, 1,088 Park Avenue. Mrs. Hendel, who was 37 years old, came to this country from her native Ecuador at the age of 10 and was educated here. She received a Ph. D. from Columbia in history and political science.

Amassing seventeen hits and capitalizing on as many errors by the invaders, the Drew baseball team routed Johns Hopkins of Baltimore, 16 to 2, today. Raymond Kohn, Drew shortstop, hit a homer with two of his mates aboard in the third, and in the fourth Everett Stannert smashed a three-bagger to clear the bases.

After more than eighty years of service on the operatic stage of this city, Verdi's "II Trovatore" was able to acquire a certain amount of new interest for those who heard the performance of it last night at the Metropolitan.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during March have been announced by the Department of Commerce; they are here compared with those of the preceding month and with March, 1936. Exports as given in the tables that follow cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

Dr. Hugo Eckener expressed unrestrained grief last night when he was informed of the death of Captain Ernst A. Lehmann. "He was my oldest and ablest collaborator," exclaimed Dr. Eckener. "It was in 1909 that we met for the first time in Baden Baden.

Since primitive times the maximum of births have been in March and conceptions in June, Professor Ellsworth Huntington of Yale University's Department of Social Sciences said here today in a presentation of data indicating the birth month was a major factor in determining a person's future.

Hinting that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh may have mistakenly identified the body of another infant for that of his own kidnapped baby, the defense in the Parker conspiracy trial here sought today to attach sinister significance to a cryptic code letter dealing with the Lindbergh case written by Paul H. Wendel to Ellis H. Parker Sr. early last year.
With John Cerny striking out ten and yielding only six hits, the Columbia freshmen baseball team downed Roxbury School of Cheshire, Conn., 10-1, at Baker Field yesterday.

Miss Carolyn Ward, daughter of Mrs. Howard Boyd Ward of this city, and the late Mr. Ward, was married to Charles Evans Diehl, son of Mrs. Aaron H. Diehl of Sewickley, Pa., this evening in the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Wykagyl.

The New York Public Library has received an extensive theatrical collection of stage photographs, programs, books and miscellaneous items relating to the New York stage as a bequest from John Henry James, collector and theatrical devotee.
Joe Bowman, right-hander traded by the Phillies to Pittsburgh at the start of the season, pitched the Pirates to an 8-to-3 victory over his former team-mates today.

The Tigers pulled ahead of the Yankees but dropped to second place in the American League today with a 4-to2 victory over the Senators behind the seven-hit pitching of Roxie Lawson. The Red Sox moved into first place alone by defeating the White Sox, while the Yanks fell before the Indians.
The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today Murray Feigenbaum of New York City and the S. D. G. Dress Delivery, Inc., of Brooklyn, N. Y., to operate as contract motor carriers.

What was described as a plot to waylay seven trucks transporting florist supplies from Suffolk County to New York City was upset about 1:30 this morning when Nassau County police arrested twenty-one striking greenhouse workers in Massapequa. When the trucks arrived there they were given a police escort to the New York City line.

George B. Van Valkenburgh died this afternoon at Kingston City Hospital following a long illness. He was born at Lexington, N. Y., Feb. 22, 1871, son of J. Monroe Van Valkenburgh and Mary O'Hara Van Valkenburgh in the family homestead where he lived until his death.

Winning both of the opening singles matches, Germany's Davis Cup tennis team took a 2-0 lead over Austria today in their secondround European zone series. After Heinrich Henkel had defeated Adam Baworowski, 6-1, 6-4, 6-1, Gottfried von Cramm disposed of George von Metaxa in straight sets, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3.

Paul Rusen, Ohio Valley subregional director for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, said today that charges would be filed with the National Labor Relations Board concerning forcible ejection of Committee for Industrial Organization members from the Weirton steel mill at Weirton, W. Va.

Joseph Hiestad, the - brilliant trapshooter of Hillsboro, Ohio, came to the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club and recaptured the. amateur championship of America at double clay targets yesterday.

The Ninth Biennial Exhibition of Water-colors opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum with a reception and preview for members and guests, including many of the American artists represented. More than 200 invited pictures, most of which have not previously been publicly shown in New York, have been assembled by John I. H. Baur,

Jumpers, thoroughbred hunters and saddle horses battled for ribbons in the third day of the thirteenth annual New Haven horse show today. Erin's Son, a sure-footed timber flyer from the stables of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kennedy, appeared well on its way to annexing the touch and out sweepstake trophy by coming through first in the third performance of the four-day competition tonight.

Capt. Sydney R. Smith, Cav-Res., now on active duty with CCC Co. 219, Camp S-78 (N. Y.), Cherry Plain, N. Y., is by reason of physical defect, relieved from further active duty, and will proceed to his home, Canaan, N. Y., to arrive threat not later than midnight, May 12.

After two shut-out victories in two days, Rutgers fell victim to a fast-stepping Duke team today, 16 to 3. The game was called at the end of the eighth because of darkness. The Blue Devils collected fourteen runs off three Scarlet pitchers in the first four frames before Len Shachnow halted the attack.
Bad news for ticket merchants appeared today as prices for seats along the coronation route tumbled like ringside berths at a blighted prize fight spectacle.

Dr. Hugo Eckener, veteran chief of the Zeppelin service, who was scheduled to lecture in Graz tonight, learned of the Hindenburg disaster early this morning in a telephone conversation with a correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Dramatic word pictures of the fire and explosions which wrecked the Hindenburg with a loss of thirtythree lives were given yesterday by persons who were at the Lakehurst naval air station and witnessed the disaster. Survivors of the accidentthose who were able to talk-could add little to the story of the end of the giant airliner.
William Bramhall Stearns, who was with the investment banking firm of Kidder, Peabody Co. of Boston since 1890, died last night at the Palmer Memorial Hospital in Brookline. He was 69 years old.

Carl Phillips, 22-year-old Negro, was remanded to jail today for trial in Superior Court, charged with breaking and entering the room of Frances M. Henretta of Kane, Pa., Connecticut College junior, "with intent to commit a crime."

Widespread reports that the destruction of the dirigible Hindenburg was due to sabotage were discounted officially today by the German Embassy. The embassy announced that its air attach, General Friedrich von Boetticher, reported there appeared to be no possibility that the dirigible could have been set off by an incendiary bullet fired into its hydrogen-filled gas bags.
The first edition of Jerome Weidman's first novel, "I Can Get It For You Wholesale," was sold out within twenty-four hours of publication, Simon Schuster report.

With conditions in the money market again more favorable to financing, the Union Electric Company of Illinois of Monsanto, Ill., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $22,000,000 of first mortgage 33/4 per cent bonds, series due in 1967.

Steamship ticket offices were busy yesterday booking new passage or making cancellations for the sixtyfive persons who were to have flown to Europe on the Hindenburg. Twenty-seven of the number are to sail today on the Italian liner Rex, including most of a group of ten who were going to the coronation.

Unbelievable things are happening at Ebbets Field. Yesterday, for the second successive day, Burleigh Grimes's Kelly green athletes went on a seven-run scoring spree in one inning and a Brooklyn hurler other than Van Mungo pitched nine full innings.

An amendment to the charter of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., which would require the consent of two-thirds of the entire membership to any change in trading regulations, was approved yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in a 4-to-1 decision reversing the ruling of a lower court.

Plans of Standard Brands, Inc., to retire temporary bank loans of $8,700,000, made in connection with the redemption of 72,061 shares of $7 preferred stock, through the sale of 200,000 shares of proposed new preferred stock, were disclosed by Joseph Wilshire, president, in a letter to stockholders yesterday.

Secretary Ickes again followed his policy of awarding material contracts on identical bids to the bidder farthest removed from the point of delivery today and expressed the opinion that the identical bid situation is improving.
The fourth concert of the present Cincinnati May Festival, attended by a very large and brilliant audience tonight, offered music that was uncommon and provocative.
Stockholders of the Robert Gair Company, Inc., approved yesterday a reduction in the company preferred stock from $560,000 to $200,000 and a change in value from no par to $10 a share.

The Pennsylvania Railroad paid $9,173 last year to the Railway Audit and Inspection Company, an organization which specializes in industrial espionage, according to the report of the railroad to the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday. The Pennsylvania also paid $45,823 to the Pinkerton's National Detective Agency last year.

Trade movements were more uniform in all of the leading centers of the country this week, with more favorable weather conditions and special clearance events stimulating retail distribution, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

With Borough President Raymond V. Ingersoll of Brooklyn voting in the negative, the amended City Residence Bill introduced by Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx was passed yesterday by the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly.

Heroism of a cripple with one leg who walked fourteen miles to warn a family of approaching fires was reported here today when Elmer Craig, his wife and two daughters reached this town, sixty miles southwest of Edmonton, in the heart of the area swept by bush fires early this week.

Flags at halfstaff over all of Germany today are the outward sign of a nation stunned momentarily by the Hindenburg disaster in Lakehurst. Yet, to judge from the newspapers, the German Government and the German people are more than ever determined to keep up the Zeppelin tradition in spite of the tragedy.

Edward Schafer, securities broker, died yesterday of heart disease at his country home in Elberon, N. J., where he had gone earlier in the day for a short rest. Mr. Schafer, who was 63 years old, had not been feeling well lately. His town address was 983 Park Avenue.

Sister Adelaide of Mount St. Vincent, New York, died of a paralytic stroke at Harbour Island last night. Sister Adelaide was born sixty-six years ago in New York and received her early education at St. Peter's Academy, Staten Island. She later attended St. Catherine Academy, Springfield, Ky., and then entered the novitiate of Mount St. Vincent in 1893.
A program of "vendors' procedure" for putting into effect the agreement on the conciliation and arbitration of returned goods controversies was approved yesterday by the Apparel Industries

An audience in which bewilderment seemed to have a slight edge on genuine entertainment saw the first American performance of "The Dog Beneath the Skin" given at the Copley Theatre this evening by the Harvard Dramatic Club.

Commissioner Claude R. Porter of the Interstate Commerce Commission has decided to press to "a speedy conclusion" hearings on the plan for reorganization of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway, which has been in progress since October, 1936.

The Waldorf-Astoria Importation Corportion of New York, whose capital stock is owned wholly by the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation, was denied today the right to use the name "Waldorf-Astoria" in connection with alcoholic beverages

Trading continued slow on most classes. Demand was improved on some cuts, however, and some large quantities of medium and heavy weight steer hind and rib accumulations were moved at weak to lower prices. Best quality kosher lamb opened stronger and other kosher meats steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Hohenzollern, the high butte in the Swabian Mountains of Germany, whence former Kaiser Wilhelm's house took its name and spread its rule throughout the Reich, is now serving as the take-off for the latest development in German aviation, night gliding, according to a reliable American traveler who recently arrived in Geneva from this region.

Mrs. Daisy M. Kingston, 56 years old, former superintendent of the Somerset Hospital, here, was sentenced to two to three years imprisonment by Judge Ralph J. Smalley in Quarter Sessions Court today when she pleaded guilty to charges of embezzling $6,000 of hospital funds.

Burke Ave (16-4605), n s, 242 ft e of Barnes Ave. 64x47; Mafalda Di Giolo to Louis Ruggiero Sr., 829 Burke Ave; mtg $12,950. 149th St (9-2275), s s, 149 ft w of St. Ann's Ave, 40x100; Frances E. W. Hood to Jean Fitterman, 1,121 Morrison Ave.

Standing in a position unique to Harvard crews in recent years-at least during the sprint season of May-the Crimson varsity racked its shell in the old boathouse on the Charles River tonight, a strong favorite to defeat Columbia and Massachusetts Institute of Technology tomorrow.

Amsterdam Ave. 681-9, n e c 93d St. 16story apartments and stores: Brooklyn Trust Co against 225 W 71st St Corp; due, $1,861,301; taxes, , $25,580; adjourned to May 10. By THOMAS F. BURCHILL 31st St. 140 E, 4-story brick tenement and stores, 21x98.9; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Margaret Courtney; due, $14,903; taxes, , $786; to plaintiff for $1.000.

Stranding seven runners in the last five innings, Lefty Grove turned in his first 1937 triumph today as the Red Sox defeated the White Sox, 5 to 3, and extended the Chicagoans' losing streak to six straight. The victory gave the Boston team undisputed possession of first place. Grove allowed eight hits, three more than his mates could get off Vernon Kennedy, but the latter was wild, walking nine. Kennedy fanned eight and Grove five.

COSGROVE, JOHN N. (Oct. 8, 1936). Gross assets, $13,815; net, $12,327. To Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum Society of Brooklyn, $300; Flora and Joseph A. Churchill, $200 each; grandson, John D. Cosgrove, $1,000; son, John D. Cosgrove, $1,000 and cancellation of debt; daughters, Mary E..

The Italian liner Rex will sail today for Mediterranean ports with 1,400 passengers. They include Colonel Frank Knox, Chicago news-paper publisher, who was Republican candidate for vice President last Fall, and Mrs. Knox. Others are Countess Elena Dandini De Sylva, Richard Aldrich, John G. Aldrich, R. C. Donahue, enrico Ducrot, Baron Wolfgang Ridesel Eisenbach,

BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition ALBEE COURT CORP., 120 BroadwayVoluntary proceeding under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law. The corporation operates the Albee Court apartments at Larchmont. Petitions Filed--By LILLIAN COHEN, housewife, 215 W. 90th St.--Liabilities, $2,808; no assets. JOSEPH DECKINGER, salesman, 507 W. 113th St.--Liablities, $4,336; no assets. WILLIAM FALTA, baker, 122 E. 109th St.--Liabilities, $72,240;

The New York Stock Exchange has been notified that the interest of the estate of the late Clifford Howard Davis in Slepack Co. ceased April 23. As trustee for Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company consolidated and refunding mortgage,

Professor John Dewey urged yesterday continuation of the investigation into the Moscow trials in which Leon Trotsky was convicted of high treason. He is chairman of the commission studying the question.

The eleven school children of this village who went on strike with the consent of their mothers because the one-man Board of Education had announced their attractive teacher would not be rehired next Fall were back at class today after a two-day absence.

In observance of its thirtieth anniversary, the Riverdale Country School presented its fifth annual May choral festival last night at the Town Hall. A varied program enlisted the youthful talents of the Lower School Chorus, the Riverdal. Glee Club, the Middle School Glee Club and, combining the smaller groups, the Riverdale School Chorus. David B. Scoular directed the vocal groups.

Use of present-day automobiles for towing trailers was condemned here today by engineers speaking at the convention of the Society of Automotive Engineers. James H. Booth of the Buick Motor Company declared that the extra weight of a trailer produced a strain on the engine, clutch, transmission, drive shaft and axles equal to that of a twenty-passenger bus.

Yale today won a stubbornly contested tennis match from the University of Pennsylvania, 6-3, taking four of the six singles and two of the three doubles. The 13-11 opening set of the doubles between Hinchliff and Stephens of the Elis and Reps and Lewis featured.

In the face of the Supreme Court's decision on the Wagner Labor Relations Act, the Pennsylvania Greyhound Lines, Inc., challenged anew in Federal Circuit Court today the right of the National Labor Relations Board to "disestablish" company unions.

Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant, today ordered the name of Herbert Gebhardt of Hoboken, N. J., stricken from the indictment which listed him as a member of the gang accused of using the mails to obtain ransom for the release of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr.,
Mrs. Ellsworth H. Augustus's Chatter Chat, hunter champion of the 1936 National exhibition, was beaten twice in hunter classes at the opening of the three-day Washington horse show today.

The industrial and social significance of the engineering profession is increasing so rapidly that the destiny of the nation during the next twenty-five years may rest in the hands of the engineer, Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology,

New Jersey commuters charged yesterday before Examiner John McChord of the Interstate Commerce Commission that the Pennsylvania Railroad's basic commutation rate and its supplemental charge for delivery and departure at the Pennsylvania Station were "excessive, unnecessary, unjust and discriminatory."
Order and quiet returned here today, with the public forces commanding the situation and the workers heeding their leaders' voices, laying down their arms and returning to work.

The following forecast for fishing and boating parties was issued yesterday by the local Weather Bureau: Near-By Coastal Waters-Increasing northeast winds; mostly cloudy. Eastport to Sandy Hook-Fresh easterly winds; overcast, possibly light showers.

Of the $6,877,000,000 of British and foreign capital invested in the Dominion of Canada at the end of 1936, United States capital was estimated at $3,956,000,000, and Great Britain's at $2,824,000,000, according to a preliminary report from Avery F. Peterson, assistant trade commissioner at Ottawa, to the Department of Commerce.

Two principal theories to explain the fire and explosions which wrecked the dirigible Hindenburg over its Lakehurst (N. J) landing field appeared yesterday as airship men and experts from all parts of the United States discussed the disaster.

Scattered liquidation developed in May wheat today, and, with reports of highly beneficial showers in parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas and Nebraska and a break in the price of May oats, wheat lost 1 1/8 to 2% cents a bushel, with the May leading.

With revised figures showing thirty-three dead and sixty-five survivors, with a member of the ground crew among the victims, the Department of Commerce took charge today of the official investigation of the disaster which overtook the German dirigible Hindenburg when she fell in flames here last night at the end of her first transatlantic voyage of the year.

Alexander R. Thompson, through Tishman Realty Construction Co., in 125 E. 72d St.; Potter, Hamilton Co., Inc. L. Stanley Kahn, In 270 Park Ave.; Mrs. Mary Hope Hammond, in 300 Park Ave.; E. H. Robbins, in 161 E. 81st St.; Douglas Elliman Co., Inc. broker.
The Athletics scored in six different innings, but Jim Walkup held them to a run each time as he pitched the Browns to a 9 to 6 victory today.

With a six-foot boa constrictor at large in the neighborhood, the inhabitants of the block bounded by Sumner, Greene, Throop and Lexington Avenues, in the Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, fled to the street last night, afraid to stay in their homes.

Nearly half the Tammany Assembly district leaders, who make up its executive committee, have told James J. Dooling that they will leave it to him to decide whether he feels that his physical condition is such that he can continue as leader, it was said yesterday.
Who to the graveyard goes with me? A lover, perhaps, to dream and grieve, A friend or two, to sigh and leave And-Awe and Peace and Majesty.

The Mackay Trophy and the Cheney Award for 1936 will be presented to officers and men of the Army Air Corps by General Malin Craig, chief of staff of the army and Acting Secretary of War, at Bolling Field tomorrow.
The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra will be heard in eleven outdoor concerts this Summer, under the direction of Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince.
A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Kip Finch of 404 East Fifty-fifth Street on Wednesday at Harkness Pavilion, Medical Center. Mrs. Finch is the former Miss M. Laird Van Winkle,
The trial of thirty-five alleged leaders of the revolt in November, 1935, began today before the National Security Tribunal. No defendants were present.

President Roosevelt, who yesterday interrupted his fishing vacation to send a message of sympathy to Chancellor Adolf Hitler over the Hindenburg disaster, today received a message ofthanks from the German ruler.

The opening one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association season at the Upper Montclair Country Club was won today by Miss Maureen Orcutt of the White Beeches Golf and Country Club. The victor, who in recent seasons has been competing under her marriage name of Crews, requested today that her name appear on the score board simply as Maureen Orcutt.

While the Columbia Lions are favored to win tomorrow's heptagonal games in the Harvard Stadium, not only Yale but also Cornell and Dartmouth are primed to make a real battle for first place. Princeton has some slight hope.
The Middlebury College baseball team lost its first home game today, bow-ing toWilliams on Porter field by 5--1.

Hollingsworth Whitney Co., paper manufacturers, in New York Central Building, 230 Park Ave; Butler Baldwin, Inc, broker. Benay Art Embroidery Co, R. D. A. Sales Corp, floors in 740 Broadway; Gancher Radio Co, Spengrays Metal Cap Corp, through M. L. Hess, in 148 W 23d St; Barsarobes, through Zobel Realty Co, floor in 102 Madison Ave; Electrical Fittings Corp,

Kent and Gloucestershire returned smart victories in county cricket championship matches concluded today. Kent trounced Worcestershire by seven wickets and Gloucestershire had a 297-run margin over Hampshire.

Two sales of large acreage in Nassau and Queens Counties were among the Long Island transactions reported yesterday. Fifty acres of the southerly portion of the former Deepdale estate of William K. Vanderbilt have been sold by L'Ecluse, Washburn Co.

Not one Prime Minister of a great nation but six, the representatives not of the 4,000,000 subjects of the British Crown a few centuries ago but of 400,000,000, gave King George a tumultuous welcome today at a history-making luncheon under the storied oak beams of Westminster Hall.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine said yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had prevented the dismissal of Police Lieutenant Bernard J. Kelly on departmental charges after he had used insulting language in referring to the Mayor last month.

The Spring meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club at Jamaica will come to a close today with the Excelsior Handicap and the Rosedale Stakes as the feature events on the getaway day program. Monday racing will be resumed at Belmont Park.

Former Assistant District Attorney William W. Kleinman, testifying yesterday at the Louis Luckman perjury trial in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, denied that he had ever known Luckman, that he had ever ridden in an automobile with him in the late Summer of 1935 or that Luckman had visited him in the Israel Zion Hospital in Brooklyn in April, 1935.

Harvard University today sent formal greetings to the University of Goettingen, Germany, and an expression of regret that Harvard will be unable to have a delegate present when the German university celebrates its 200th anniversary this Summer.

An increase from $650,000 to $800,000 in the appropriation for reconstructing the Willetts Point Boulevard station of the jointly operated I. R. T.-B. M. T. rapid-transit line to Flushing, Queens, was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

At Riom, an ancient Gallic town, the other day there was a curious manifestation of the old Gallic gayety and levity. It was the more striking because it was displayed in a court of justice. PHILIBERT BESSON, sometime Deputy, was charged with the theft of a legal document from the public prosecutor some three years ago.

Demanding a general wage increase and a shorter working week, 125 managers and clerks in twenty-nine stores of the United Cigar Stores Company here and in near-by communities went on strike this afternoon.

Norman H. Davis ended a highly satisfactory mission of unofficial inquiry today with final calls on leading cabinet members among whom he has acted for the last month as extraordinary liaison agent for President Roosevelt.

James Rera, the "tip-off" man who assisted Merle Vandenbush in planning the first Katonah Bank holdup, pleaded guilty today to firstdegree robbery before County Judge Gerald Nolan and was remanded to the county jail for sentence later.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The Japanese realize the truth of your remark in last Saturday's issue of THE TIMES that it is for the host to begin the instruction of the International Auxiliary Language. They already have begun preparing for the thousands of visitors who will visit their country in 1940 for the Olympic Games.

The report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for the three months ended March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation. operating expenses, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $3,378,630, which after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to 32 cents a common share outstanding during the period.
Governor Lehman signed today the bill imposing the 2 per cent tax on receipts of utility companies designed to raise $24,000,000 for unemployment relief.
Sir John Siddeley today gave [pound]100,000 as a coronation gift to the Fairbridge Farm Schools, which establishes English boys in empire life and maintains a large farm on Vancouver Island.

Mexico's Supreme Court pledged itself yesterday to support the Mexican Attorney General- and the. government's revolutionary social program. The-local papers feature this news on their front pages today.
Gregory B. Smith and his brother, Gerard C. Smith, entertained with a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Molly O. Shriver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Shriver

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Wilson Stetser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Stetser of Addisleigh, St. Albans, Queens, to Daniel Denham, son of Major James L. Denham, U. S. M. C.,
Miss Muriel Brittin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Brittin of 1,806 Caton Avenue, Brooklyn, was married to James B. MacLean, son of Mrs. James G. MacLean, also of Brooklyn,

More than 1,500 persons crowded into the Princeton University Chapel this afternoon and evening to hear the Westminster Chapel Choir of 130 voices sing the complete Bach mass in B minor, opening the annual Talbott Choral Festival of the Westminster Choir School.

Representatives of two unions and the railroads entering New York conferred yesterday with Frank M. Swacker, chairman of the mediation board seeking to compose the differences between unions and carriers. At the end of the day Mr.

Trading by members on the New York Stock Exchange in round lots for own account in the week ended on April 10 amounted to 4,233,085 shares bought and sold, or 22.41 per cent of total volume, compared with 3,215,240 shares, or 20.45 per cent, in the week ended on April 3, according to the weekly summary published today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Park Avenue, so far as the courts are concerned, has no connection with Fourth Avenue, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in a fourto-one decision interpreting the State Liquor Control Law.

Paul Manshio, sculptor, and Mrs. Manship gave a tea yesterday at their home, 319 East Seventy-second Street, for Mr. and Mrs. John M. Sitton Jr., who celebrated the first anniversary of their marriage.

Hank Leiber, Giants' outfielder, is suffering from a "mild concussion," officials at the Medical Center announced yesterday, The Associated Press reported. They said Leiber would need to remain at the hospital for rest and
Ambassador William Phillips cabled the State Department from Rome today that reports that three American women missionaries had been expelled from Ethiopia were unfounded.

The marriage of Miss Diana Bonner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Charles Dempster Bonner of Maplewood, to Salim L. Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Lewis of New York, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
Miss Leonice Merrels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic B. Merreis of this city, will be married on May 22 to Robert C. Knox Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Knox, also of Hartford.

Like the pitcher of proverb that went to the well once too often, Tony Canzoneri cracked up last night in Madison Square Garden while making his bid for a third lightweight championship before a partisan, sentimental gathering of more than 11,000 fight fans.

Negotiations are under way for the sale of Station WLWL, operated by the Paulist Fathers at 415 West Fifty-ninth Street, to Arde Bulova, watch manufacturer, it was announced by the management of fo the broadcasting station yesterday.

Garden amateurs are ever in search of new hints on landscaping and the layout of annuals and perennials and shrubs. When owners of private gardens of considerable beauty share them for a day with the general public, the opportunity for studying them is made the most of.

LAKEHURST, N. J., May 8.-The United States Navy appointed its own special board of investigation into the Hindenburg disaster today, as two more deaths brought the total to 35.

HENDAYE, France, May 8.--Insurgent guns thundered closer to Bilbao in Spain tonight. The heaviest fighting centered about a hill in the Solluve range about eleven miles east of Bilbao. The Basques' last-line positions were growing more perilous hourly.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., May 8. --Williams turned back the Wesleyan track team today, 75--60. The victors won six firsts in the eight running events, but fell off in the field events.

It seems a reasonable idea to suggest that cruising yachtsmen make a new resolution for another sea son that is almost here and decide to get acquainted with the Harlem River. Too many of them have had a curious fear about this connecting waterway.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP).-Representative Keller, chairman of a House labor subcommittee in charge of the National Textile Bill, predicted today that the "little NRA" measure would be a model for the mining, steel and automo bile industries.

"Streamlined" furniture, in keep ing with modern styles in homes, is growing in favor, according to A.W. Forester, advertising man ager of W. J. Sloane. Examples of this style will be a feature of the "house of tomorrow" at the North American Homes Exposition.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--The nation's relief bill stands today at about $11,000,000,000. This is the price the Federal, State and local governments have paid to take care of the needy throughout the nation since March, 1933, when the New Deal first came into office.

The jury in the second trial of Louis Luckman, who is charged with obstructing justice by commiting perjury is the Samuel Drukman murder case, retired at 6:43 P. M. yesterday after a charge by Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogera, in Brooklyn.

Many new works will be heard at the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial concerts of the Goldman Band this Summer, Edwin Franko Goldman, conductor, announced yesterday. These are either newly written or transcribed for band or are new to the repertoire of the Goldman Band.

ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP).--The Browns lost all their hitting power today and Oral Hildebrand could not hold the rampaging Athletics as Harry Kelley pitched Philadelphia to a 5-to-1 victory over Rogers Hornsby's men.

The stock market quieted down last week after the wide fluctuations in prices the week before. The bond market steadied perceptibly, as did most of the commodity markets. THE NEW YORK TIMES average of fifty stocks showed a net gain on the week of 2.08 points...

The roster of the 165th when it left for France twenty years ago was heavily Dublin Irish; but abroad there were Protestant, Jewish, even Orangemen...

A powerful New York Athletic Club team successfully defended its senior National A.A.U. soft-ball water polo championship last night in the Winged Foot pool by turning back the Queens Central Y.M. C.A., 14--6, in the final round of the annual tournament.

A benefit luncheon and Spring fete entitled a "Gambol on the Green" took place at Chatham Walk of the Hotel Chatham yes terday, when the outdoor garden was opened for its fifth season. The benefit was arranged under the auspices of the New York Chapter...

In a stirring finish that thrilled 16,000 spectators as three horses fought it out in the scratch scarcely more than heads apart, Buckley M. Byers's Thorson yesterday cap tured the thirtieth running of the Excelsior Handicap, closing-day feature at Jamaica.

THE strike that has put Holly wood on the front pages is the last week did not dampen the enthusiasm of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer executives, who gathered their sales and exploitation forces in convention in Los Angeles and unconcernedly...

A three-year experiment is speech improvement, conducted at the Yorkville Vocational High School, Eighty-eighth Street and First Avenue, has developed new techniques in teaching students how to talk better, Mrs. Anna H. Wilcox, supervisor of continuation schools...
WARSAW.--Poland is vaguely but perceptibly leaning--though ever so slightly--toward the German side of the Russian-German fence.

Completion of a quarter of a century of growth in size, service and influence will be celebrated by the Pan American Society Tuesday night at a dinner of its members in the Hotel Waldorf Astoria, marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the organization.

Jumping into the lead at the out set and increasing its margin with every stroke, Manhattan's varsity crew scored its first victory of the season by defeating the Washing ton and Lee eight of Lexington, Va., over the Henley course of one and five-sixteenths miles on the Harlem...

BRUSSELS. IN the mines and along the canals of Belgium there are hundreds of aged, hard-la- boring horses and mules, bearing the brands of the British, Cana dian or American armies. These unrepatriated veterans of the World War are now being sought...

ON BOARD THE BATTLESHIP PENNSYLVANIA IN MID-PACI FIC, May 8 (AP).--Two naval air men were killed when their air plane crashed and sank in the Pacific Ocean during the United States fleet's war games, naval of ficers reported today.

On Tuesday afternoon, at the Bath Iron Works up in Bath, Me., the new America's Cup defense yacht built for Harold S. Vanderbilt will be launched. Her design ers, W. Starling Burgess and Spark man and Stephens, plan to have her mast stepped at once and to...

The Student Self-Government Association of Hunter College will hold its annual convention on Friday from 4:30 to 9:30 P.M. at the student hall of the Bronx buildings, Bedford Park Boulevard and Navy Avenue, Shirley Goidel, chairman of the convention, has announced.
LONDON, May 8.--If sheer excitament--excitement to the bursting point--could destroy a great people, then England's enemies might safely disarm and wish her only a few more coronation weeks.

PRINCETON, N. J., May 8.-Princeton's baseball team unleashed one of its heaviest barrages of the season today on University Field and, with fifteen hits, including four extra-base blows, routed N. Y. U. by 12--5 for its eleventh tri umph in seventeen starts.
A 12-year-old girl was killed and two brothers, 11 and 9, were crit ically hurt in automobile accidents in Queens yesterday.

An interesting feature of the gar den exhibitions to be held in the Washington Square district on Thursday and Friday afternoons will be the showing of color motion pictures of the 1936 Interna tional Flower Show at Haarlem, Holland.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--A broadening of its control over the financial transactions of railroads, especially in regard to holding companies in which the roads have an interest, was recommended today in the report of the Interstate Commerce Commission on its investigation...
AVALON, Calif., May 8.--Twentyfive years ago an unknown youth named Glenn Martin made aviation history in the first round-trip overwater flight.

DUESSELDOAF, Germany, May 8.--Germany's great national expo sition, which presents a cross sec tion of German economy under Chancellor Adolf Hitler's new Fouryear Plan for "raw material inde pendence" was formally opened to day by Col. Gen. Hermann Goering...

Yale's fifteen accounted for its initial victory of the season yesterday by taking the measure of a more experienced New York Rugby Club team, 5-3, in a well-played con test at Randalls Island Stadium. Previously the Elis had lost two games and tied two.

The first Vermont flag of which there is any record was the Stars and Stripes, with the addition of the word "Vermont." This was adopted by act of Legislature in 1803, according to information obtained in the course of research work done on the origin and form...

THE world premiere of Walter Damrosch's "The Man Without a Country" will take place at the Metropolitan Opera House Wednesday evening. This opera, to be sung in English, is based on Edward Everett Hale's story of the same title.

Probably Dr. ELLSWORTH HUNTING- TON, Yale's distinguished authority on the relation of civilization to climate, never gave a thought to Mother's Day when he wrote his paper on "Season of Birth" for presentation before the American Association on Mental Deficiency which met in Atlantic City...

LONDON, May 8.--The corona tion strike fever among London's transport workers gained ground today, and at midnight there were grave fears that the striking busmen would be joined in a few hours by operatives in the subway, tram and electric trolley bus services...

Superior passing enabled the New York German Hungarians of the Metropolitan League to blank the Reading German Americans of the Pennsylvania soccer circuit by 3-0 today in an interstate exhibition match. A large crowd witnessed the contest.

Aubrey W. Williams, deputy administrator of the Works Progress Administration, came to the defense of the frequently ridiculed WPA worker today at the dedication exercises for the new physiotherapy pool addition to the Betty Bacharach Home for Crippled Children at Longport, near here.

In many of the churches throughout Westchester County today, special services were held in celebration of Mother's Day, which ineluded an extra service here in celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the founding of Trinity Lutheran Church, at which several Gold Star mothers were honored guests.

The following table, prepared by Transit Commissioner Godley, based on figures of the commission's engineers for the year ended June 30, 1936, shows that unified operation of company lines under the Seabury-Berle plan would result in an annual deficit of $3,361,630.

Services at the Wesley Methodist Episcopal Church, 177th Street and the Grand Concourse, yesterday marked the beginning of a week's celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the church from which the Wesley Methodist Church sprang.

A note of utility will mark the eighteenth annual Columbia University Alumni Fund campaign that has just started, according to an announcement yesterday by Francis Blossom, a graduate of Columbia in 1891, chairman of the Alumni Fund Committee.
The Derby Special arrived today, bringing several groups of New Yorkers on their way home from Louisville. Parties were given at the Greenbrier and Casino.

The soy bean trade last week on the Board of Trade was not large but the movement of prices was erratic. The May position closed at $1.77 a bushel, 3 7/8 cents lower than a week before, while the July delivery finished at $1.75 3/4, off 3 5/8 cents for the week. No 2 yellow in the cash market brought $1.80.

A thousand years' precedents immortalized in the coronation ceremonies were pushed aside today when at noon a company of Canadian soldiers, alien to British soil, took over sentry duty at Buckingham and St. James's Palaces for six hours as the King's bodyguards.

Eugene F. Moran, president of the Whitehall Club, announced yesterday the appointment of a committee headed by Harry Fowler, to direct two golf tournaments for club members during the Summer season. The committee includes J. Herbert Todd, James J. Murphy, Samuel P. Vatcher, Charles V.

Eight hundred barbers of Local 4, New York Joint Board of the International Journeymen Barbers Union, will go on strike today in the Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn, Barnett Jacobs, local organizer, and John Tartamella, international representative of the union, announced today.
Led by Governor Aiken of Vermont, more than 2,000 persons celebrated today the anniversaries of the birth of Ethan Allen and his capture of Fort Ticonderoga.

Jimmy De Shong held the Browns to four hits today while the Senators were shelling Chief Hogsett and Sheriff Blake to win the series opener, 7 to 1. The defeat skidded the Browns into last place as the White Sox tripped the Yankees.

Elimination of about $3,000,000,000 in exceds reserves of member banks through an increase in reserve- requirements placed the Federal Reserve System in a good position normaily to control the national credit situation through open-market operations-sale or purchase of government securities-at a time when it was feared inflation might run wild, the Federal Reserve Board said in its monthly bulletin, issued today. A detailed analysis of financial activities of the last few months was presented.

Frank J. Marshall, who on Thursday clinched the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, completed his schedule yesterday by playing a draw with Harold Sussman of Brooklyn College. Sussman played white in a Zukertort opening and held- his own for thirty-three moves, when the draw was agreed upon.

When the Master of Arts degrees are conferred by President Nicholas Murray Butler at the Columbia University graduation' exercises June 1, one of the recipients will be Mrs. Rose A. Cahan of 395 Riverside Drive, familiarly known to her fellow-classmates as the "college grandmother."
District Judge A. M. Abramson, who sentenced himself to prison, was dismissed today by the Moscow District. Judicial Committee as "unfitted to hold such a responsible position."

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Frances Clark by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Allen H. Clark of West Orange, to M. Rusling Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. M. R. Wood of East Orange.
Announcement was made here last night of the recent death in France of Mr.' Elizabeth Bell Bates da Gama, widow of Domicio da Gama, former Brazilian Ambassador to the United States.
