Demand for dresses improved last week. and formals, cottons and daytime sheers sold well at all price ranges. New satin evening gowns met with good reception. In the volume market, manufacturers concentrated on washable synthetic sports styles, which met with good consumer acceptance.

Tableaux depicting the activities of Miss Henrietta Szold, founder and honorary president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, were enacted in the honor grove in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon by about 500 Jewish children.

Mayor Jasper McLevy's Socialist city administration prepared tonight to break the strike of city ash and garbage collectors tomorrow morning with police protection of newly hired men. As Director of Public Works, Peter Brewster announced that collections of refuse would be resumed tomorrow, on order of the Mayor.
The outdoor polo season was in full swing today with both Monmouth County Country Club fields utilized for hard-fought encounters. Attendance at both fields set a record for early season play.

Mrs. Jenny Johnson, 73 years old, of 115-40 146th Street, Jamaica, was killed instantly and seven other persons were injured, five critically, at 12:30 o'clock this morning when two automobiles collided head-on in the rain at 121st Avenue and Sutphin Boulevard, Jamaica.

Federal Mining and Smelting Company-Quarter ended on March 31: Net earnings, $928,083, including profit of $232,684 on metal stocks sold, against $254,475, including profit of $221,549 from stocks sold in the final quarter last year and $169,072 in first quarter of 1936, when there was no profit from stocks sold.

In the presence of a congregation of 1,100 persons, including many city officials and Catholic laymen, and a score of Monsignori and priests of the Newark Diocese, Bishop Thomas J. Walsh today dedicated St. Rocco's New Church, at Fourteenth Avenue and Hunterdon Street.

FOX-Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence, announce the confirmation of their daughter, Annette Lucille, May 16, at Eighth Avenue Temple. Reception temple house, 8th Ave. Garfield Place, Brooklyn, after 8 P. M. LEVY--Harry and Margaret (nee Moskowitz), announce confirmation of daughter, Doris, May 16, 10 A. M., Brooklyn Jewish Center. Home, 11 Ludiam Place, 4-7.

Corn is attracting unusual attention on the Board of Trade here owing to the scarcity of domestic grain. Deliveries in the Middle West by farmers last week were moderate and were readily absorbed by feeders and shippers.

Holding its rival to one actual goal, the First Division quartet launched its polo season yesterday before 2,000 at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn by routing the Fort Hamilton team, 9 to 2. Major J. A. Nichols led the victors' offensive with four tallies, three of which came in a four-goal attack in the fifth chukker.
Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York, celebrated Pontifical solemn high mass yesterday at the Golden Jubilee services of the parish of St. Veronica's Roman Catholic Church, 149 Christopher Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Charles C. Marshall, after defining the police power of the States, adds: "It is therefore very clear that the police power can properly be exercised only when 'conditions currently prevailing' call for it.

Sherwood Co. and Shields Co. will offer today a new issue of $300,000 of city of Schenectady, N. Y., 2 per cent bonds, maturing on March 1, 1938 to 1947, at prices to yield from 0.90 to 2 per cent, according to maturity.

Willis Hudlin, veteran right hander of the Indians, who waited until the next to last day of the season to pitch his only 1936 victory, today hurled a four-hit triumph over the Red Sox by a score of 39 to 1.
Twenty-two-year-old Miss Pearl Perkins of Philadelphia won the women's all-around gymnastics championship in the national Amateur Athletic Union meet last night with 1,858 points.
Count von Preysing, Catholic Bishop of Berlin, protested today in a pastoral letter against anti-Catholic propaganda in the German press based on the socalled immorality trials.

Theatrical Protective Union Local 1, the stagehands' union, yesterday afternoon re-elected all its officers at the annual meeting held at its headquarters, 254 West Fifty-fourth Street. Two of the three trustees chosen were also incumbent.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, will confer today in Washington with officers of the Transport Workers Union, it was disclosed last night. The union, which says it has 16,000 members among the workers on subway, elevated, street car and bus lines, recently left the American Federation of Labor and voted to affiliate with C. I. O.
The greatest thrill of his life came to Carl Hubbell yesterday before the season's largest crowd at the Polo Grounds in the fastest game played this year in the shadow of Coogan's Bluff.

Cases in court and the number of divorces would be lessened if more homes were influenced by Christian education, the Rev. Erwin R. Jaxheimer said in his morning sermon yesterday at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, Eighty-fifth Avenue and Eighty-seventh Road, Queens.

Led by their non-playing manager, Clifford Sproule, the Australian Davis Cup players completed their long- journey from Mexico yesterday, and went into camp at Forest Hills, where they will meet the United States in the final round of the North American zone on May 29, 30 and 31.

In line with its purpose to effect adjustments of claims of citizens of this country for confiscation of and damage to their property in Russia at the time of the Soviet Revolution, the Association of American Creditors of Russia has mailed to its members and other interested parties a summary of the situation and the background relating to the claims.

In April 1,689 new stock corporations were formed in this State, the division of corportions of the Department of State reported today. This brought the total as of May 1 to 6,699, an increase of 291 over the same period last year and that of 1935 by 289. The April list exceeded last year's figure of 1,580 by 109 and the April tally of 1,562 by 127.

The New York Germans, of the German-American League defeated the New York Americans, holders of the National Challenge Cup, by 3-0 at Starlight Park yesterday. The game had been under way only a few minutes when Dannemann, inside right for the Germans, kicked the ball through the outstretched hands of Goalie Zipps for the first goal.

The idea of lowering the purchase price of gold as a means of putting a brake on the output of the metal is not taken seriously in financial circles here. In the first place, it is asked what is meant by such a proposal.

More than 1,100 endorsements have been received of the statement issued on April 19 by Episcopal clergymen in different parts of the country in which they advocated legislation by the triennial General Convention of the Episcopal Church against permitting church sanction to the marriage of a divorced person. The next convention will be held in October at Cincinnati.

The welfare of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church in America depends upon the proper training of Ukrainian-American children so they will respect and revere their ancient religion, the Most Rev. John Theodorovich, Archbishop of the church in the United States and Canada,

Stewart B. Iglehart climaxed his first Long Island appearance as a ten-goal poloist by scoring in the final five seconds to give a team of Reds an 8-to-7 victory over a side of Whites in a Meadow Brook Club members' match today.

Nearly 1,000 sportsmen among members of the New York Athletic Club have sent in their reservations for the gala All-Sports dinner, comprising several boxing and wrestling bouts, a fencing exhibition and a few vaudeville acts.

The results of the regattas Saturday failed to change the aspect things in college rowing circles. In races at Cambridge and Annapolis, Harvard and the United States Naval Academy strengthened their positions at the front of the earlyseason parade and built one more episode into what may be an undefeated career for the pair of them up to the time they come together on the Schuylkill May 29 for the Adams Cup.

The Rev. James de Wolf Perry Jr., the only United States citizen taking part in Wednesday's coronation, today hid his distinction under a mask of modesty. He will act as one of the two chaplains with the Archbishop of York.

Galway held Kerry to a 7-point tie in the feature Gaelic football game at Innisfail Park yesterday before a crowd of 3,000. The proceeds went to popular Tommy Armitage who was injured three weeks ago.

The official report on the condition of German cereals is very unfavorable. Winter sowing was belated and subsequently 46 per cent of the cereal area suffered from excessive rain. On an index basis, with the figure 2 meaning good and 3 mediocre, Winter wheat at the beginning of April was 3.2, compared with 2.4 at the same time in 1936.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,952,535,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

The increase of ??6,342,320 that was reported this week in the circulation of the Bank of England raised the total to a new high record of [Pound]475,158,646, the previous record having been [Pound]474,115,561, in December.
Unless all this may develop into a mere flash in the pan, a serious threat apparently looms to the speed records of such luminaries as Jesse Owens, Sir Malcolm Campbell and Gar Wood.

Fire that broke out mysteriously in a fortyfour-stall barn at the Pimlico race track left sixteen thoroughbreds dead today, among them J. W. Y. Martin's Preakness candidate, Triple Action, a promising gelded son of Canter-Black Momma.

Luncheon of the New York Municipal Bond Club, the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, 12:30 P. M. Address by John W. Davis. Civic luncheon marking cornerstone laying of Kips Bay-Yorkville Health and Teaching Center, New York Hospital Nurses Residence, 1,320 York Avenue, 12:45 P. M. Speakers: Mayor La Guardia, Dr. Livingston Farrand.

Charging that "powerful influences," including Soviet Ambassador Alexander Troyanovsky, were trying to "sabotage" and disrupt objective investigation of the guilt or innocence of Leon Trotsky in the accusations of which he was convicted in the recent Moscow trials of leading Bolsheviks, Professor John Dewey declared last night that the inquiry over which he is presiding would nevertheless be continued "until the end."

The Department Medal of Honor is awarded to the families of four policemen killed in the performance of police duty in 1936, in a general order issued by Commissioner Valentine, it was announced yesterday.

102d St, 225 E, 25x100.11: Sol Uliman, referce, to 225 E 102d St Corp, 100 Bway; foreclosure ($1.50). Haven Ave, 134, n w cor 172d St, 81.6x125, to Riverside Dr; Port of New York Authoeity to 134 Haven Ave Corp. 291 Bway; purchase money mtg. $190,000.

After an absence of seventeen years from the repertoire, Henri Rabaud's "Marouf" will be revived Friday night, May 21, at the Metropolitan Opera House. The opera will be given in an English version of Lucien Nepoty's libretto written by Madeleine Marshall and George Mead.

Arthur George Williams, Professor of Modern Languages at the Divisions here of the College of William and Mary and Virginia Polytechnic Institute, died at his home here this afternoon. He was 65 years old.

Kathleen Strange, who won a $1,000 Canadian award with her book, "With the West in Her Eyes," a story of a modern pioneer woman, is preparing a new book on a well-known Canadian character, "Buckskin Billy."

It was raining in London today-all day. This simple and not unusual statement might ordinarily not be worth making. But this time it covers a tragedy or close to it-real discomfort for hundreds of thousands of visitors who have come here at great cost for the biggest show the British Empire has ever staged, accompanied by dire apprehension lest the weather gods should not be kind next Wednesday.

The business forecast of the Federation of British Industries for the second quarter of this year says that unsettlement in certain directions in the next few months would not occasion surprise, but that there is no indication of any change in the basic trend.

Ground was broken this afternoon for the new $200,000 Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul's parish at Union and Second Avenues, Clifton. The Rev. Paul P. Guterl, rector of the church, turned over the first spade of earth before 1,000 parishioners.

Reorganization of the Underwriting Section of the Federal Housing Administration into a division of the administration owing to the growing importance of the appraisal and risk rating system of the FHA was announced today by Stewart McDonald, administrator.

A chart of world powers' army expenditures compiled by American military authorities indicated today that Americans pay substantially less per capital for national defense than citizens of any other major nation.

BILL NYE used to contend that WAGNER'S music is better than it sounds. On a similar principle one might remark that the record of the session of the State Legislature just closed seems considerably better in retrospect than it did while it was going on.

Strands from spider webs are among essential spare parts now being transported to the tiny Phoenix group of islands in the South Pacific to be used in getting pictures of the eclipse of the sun on June 8 by members of the National Geographic Society-United States Navy Expedition.

Thousands of strollers on the Coney Island boardwalk in the vicinity of Stillwell Avenue heard yesterday about 6 P. M. what they thought were the usual mildly hysterical screams of passengers on the Tornado, a roller coaster there.

A resolution condemning lotteries and any form of gambling as a means of raising funds to maintain synagogues and other Jewish institutions was adopted today at the eighth annual convention of the New Jersey Branch. United Synagogues of America, at Temple B'nai Israel. These devices were called unethical.

As in the days of the Caesars, Rome held a triumph today. There were no fettered captives to be dragged sullenly behind the chariot of the victorious commander, and the legions of Rome wore modern steel helmets and carried modern arms.
Dr. John Moore Reade, director of the University of Georgia Biological Laboratories and for years a professor of botany, died here today. His age was 61.

Far from being daunted by the Hindenburg disaster, the Soviet Dirigible Administration plans to build more airships than ever. It will study the lessons of the-Hindenburg's destruction, however, and as quickly as possible fill its ships with helium, for which a big reduction plant will be started this year.

Lian Brothers, importers of linens and lingerie, in 319 5th Av and 1 E 32d St; Puritan Mfg Co and the Linen Guild, Inc, additional space in 315 5th Ave; Carolina Mfg Co and Haddad Sons, in 313 5th Ave; Ames, Cunehan Newman, Inc, broker.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-By HENRY CLAY, doing business as Henry Clay's Service Station, 50 North Rd.. Poughkeepsie.-Liabilities, $31,877; no assets except real estate which is subject to mortgages. CHARLES RABIN, formerly Rabinowitz, contractor, North Tarrytown-Liabilities, $30.606: no assets except real estate which is subject to mortgages.

About 10,000 persons attended the opening day of the Children's Science Fair yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West. The exposition, which is under the auspices of the American Institute of the City of New York, will continue until Sunday.
General Hermann Goering, in his capacity as Minister of Aviation, has ordered the withdrawal of the Graf Zeppelin from passenger service until the results of the Lakehurst investigation are known.

A private watchman, George Schuck Jr., 42 years old, of 1,650 Jefferson Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, who told the court that he had shot a burglary suspect in selfdefense, was paroled on a technical charge of homicide in Queens Felony Court yesterday, for hearing Friday.

Miss Irene Harriet Dunkak, daughter of Mrs. Everett Higby of Mount Vernon, N. Y., and the late Henry Dunkak, has completed plans for her marriage to Joseph Anthony Campagna, son of Count and Countess Anthony Campagna of Riverdale-on-Hudson, which will take place the afternoon of June 5 in St. Thomas Church.
Henry W. Dreyer, a pioneer of trapshooting in the metropolitan district, died Saturday of pneumonia at his home, 2,123 Avenue M., Brooklyn, after an illness of three months, at the age of 79.
Union labor and its activities have not been the theme of many movies from the Screen City, though there have been a few which
Puccini's "La Tosca" received its first performance of the present season by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company last night at the Hippodrome. Dorothy Githens,

Twelve telegraph clerks instead of the usual two will be. on duty in the Buckingham Palace postoffice Wednesday to receive the flood of coronation congratulations from all parts of the world as well as messages to foreign royalty staying there.

A petition asking Great Britain not to do anything to infringe Jewish rights in Palestine was sent last night to Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, and to Secretary of State Cordell Hull, by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist organization of America.

The first anniversary of the Italian Empire was celebrated this morning with a gigantic military review, but it was marked by an event with greater significance from a political viewpoint, namely, the carrying out of the boycott decided on yesterday of all news relating to another empire with which Italy is competing in the Mediterranean.

The Museum of the City of New York will open a small exhibition of its recent accessions this morning. The show, which will be on view for a month, is made up of some of the items presented to the museum during the first four months of this year.

President Roosevelt's announcement that he would confer with Congressional leaders on the general legislative situation immediately after his return to the White House Friday aroused speculation in legislative circles today on what would be taken up first.

The first birthday of the Kasper quadruplets was celebrated at an elaborate dinner this evening for their parents, physician, nurses and other persons who have contributed funds, services or advice for their rearing.

Under the sponsorship of Great Britain, and with the cooperation of eleven other Powers, Egypt has won its freedom from the more than 300-year-old system of capitulations. Its independence is to have general recognition later this month when Egypt is admitted to membership in the League of Nations.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 93.3, which compares with 93.5 the week before, 93.8 two weeks before, 94.3 three weeks before and 94.5 four weeks before.

Regaman, chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. A. A. Frierson of West Point, N. Y., and ridden in all his classes by Captain Frierson, was awarded the hunter championship this afternoon at the seventh annual Lawridge Horse Show, held on the Lawridge estate.

With foreign notables arriving day by day to represent their governments at the coronation, the hard-headed diplomats of Whitehall will have a golden opportunity for private talks that may influence the immediate future of Europe.
Mrs. Altha Covey Beaufort of 983 Park Avenue, widow of John E. Beaufort, oil operator, of this city, died yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Hospital, after a long illness, at the age of 56.

Despite heavy losses suffered by buyers, the settlement of the account at the end of April was accomplished without difficulty or any failures. The sharp rise that has been recorded proves that stocks which weak speculators were forced to sell have been taken up by financially stronger persons, who took advantage of the slump to acquire them cheaply.

The most difficult and critical settlement the Stock Exchange here has experienced in many years was negotiated this week without failures. For this immunity from actual disaster the markets have to thank the cooperative effort put forward inside and outside the Stock Exchange to mitigate the worst effects of the recent collapse.
After clinging two hours to an overturned sailboat in midstream in the Hudson, a girl and two young men, local residents, were rescued this afternoon by a tugboat going upstream in the channel.
Winners of the State prizes in the eighth Gorgas Essay Contest were announced today by Admiral Cary T. Grayson, chairman of the board of directors of the Gorgas Memorial Institute.

The Department of Commerce will open public hearings here at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning in its investigation of the Hindenburg disaster of last Thursday night, which caused the death of thirty-five persons. South Trimble Jr., chairman of the board, and its other members--Major R. W. Schroeder, Assistant Director of the Bureau of Air Commerce, and Dennis Mulligan, chief of the Regulations and Enforcement Division of the bureau-arrived here today and set up offices.

As the supreme example of the journalist in power, Mussolini is the supreme example of what happens to journalism when it becomes the function of government. Of all the businesses governments take over nowadays, the one in which they are most inept is the publishing business.

Mayor La Guardia, from his desk in City Hall, will go on the air tonight at 5:30 o'clock to voice his views on the Transit Commission's rejection of the $436,000,000 unification plan negotiated and sponsored by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr.
Cincinnati slapped four pitchers for twenty-four hits, including four home runs, to score a. 21-to-0 victory over the Phillies before 7,000 fans today.

Following are some questions put to Secretary Wallace in a recent interview: "How can the government justify spending $500,000,000 this year to restrict major crops through soil conservation payments while you are urging farmers to fill up their bins?

A sharp decrease in the open interest in May contracts for lard last week on the Board of Trade followed another increase of more than 7,000,000 pounds in stocks in Western markets, speculative longs liquidating freely.

" The Show Is On," Broadway's sole new revue of the season,. is advertising the "last weeks" of its highly successful career at the Winter- Garden. As its stars, Beatrice Lillie and Bert Lahr, hold run-of-the-play-contracts,
Threat of a general strike by the Screen Actors Guild which would have paralyzed the motion picture industry was averted tonight.

Miss Lucy Pease Gay, daughter of Mrs. Wilbert H. Gay of East Granby, was married to Harrison Spencer Brown, son of Mrs. Walter S. Brown of Hartford, yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother.

A syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and including Lazard Freres Co., Inc., and King, Crandall Latham, Inc., will offer today approximately 10,200 shares of Neisner Brothers, Inc., 4 3/4 per cent convertible serial preferred stock at $104 a share.

A foul at the start of the final race cost M. I. T. its chance to regain the Boston Dinghy Club challenge cup in the intercollegiate regatta on the Charles River Basin today. Brown's sailors took possession of the trophy and Cornell's defending crew was third in the series standing.

Governor Lehman has departed on a motor trip that will take him to Virginia. Pending his return next week his aides will be putting in order for him the 750 bills on which he has thirty days from the session close to consider.
Firenze Red Tape, noted brown gelding belonging to Mrs. M. Robert Guggenheim, won top honors as the three-day Washington Horse Show came to a successful close at the Meadowbrook Club today.

It takes more than an alarm clock to awaken Richard F. Hess of Manheim, Pa., a 21-year-old senior in Columbia College, who, not unlike a great many others, faces the early-morning sunlight and the clock's familiar ring with defiance.

Plans for a large apartment house and store development in the Riverdale section of the Bronx were announced yesterday by Morton R. Cross, president of the Cross Brown Company, for the A. C. H. M. Hall Realty Company, large developers of Dyckman Street and adjacent properties.

Membership gains made by the Committee for Industrial Organization were hailed today by the National Executive Committee of the Socialist party as affirming "our traditional position that it is absolutely necessary to organize workers on the basis of industries if the American labor movement is to become the increasingly significant."
The French Government seems to be overestimating the benefit of the forthcoming exhibition of 1937 here in stimulating industrial and commercial activity and improving general conditions.

With many unflattering comments on countries which cling to their superfluous gold without having the courage to re-establish stable currencies, German economic associations and the German financial press emphasize the Reich's apparent abundance of capital and cash, relatively stable prices and orderly industrial development, all achieved with virtually no gold reserve.
This desert stronghold, representing theoretically the city of Los Angeles, becomes the object of a relentless assault from the air tomorrow.

Nehring Brothers, Inc, arranged for the Blitzer Realty Co an extension for five years at 4 per cent of a first mortgage of $163,600 on 575 W 172d St. The Staten Island Real Estate Board will hold its annual dinner on Wednesday at the Meurot Club, St. George.

THE man who knew John L. Sullivan wanted to know whither we were drifting and what were heavyweights now, men or mice? He ruffled his surviving gray hairs with an angry gesture and puffed furiously on a scarred briar pipe.

Soon to be carried into the Spanish war are the names of Louis Joseph Papineau, whose fiery words stirred excitable lower Canada habitantss" to rebellion in 1837, and William Lyon MacKenzie, leader of the struggle for self-government in upper Canada and grandfather of Canada's present Prime Minister.
Miss Frances Skinner, who has been buyer for the junior department of Franklin Simon Co., early in June will become buyer for women's coats and economy coats.

War Admiral, Man o' War's son, and Kentucky Derby winner, contentedly munched his oats and hay today and turned not a hair, following his history-making gallop yesterday at Churchill Downs, as he headed for the Preakness.

The complete surrender by the city of its control over the development and extension of its rapid transit facilities for the next seventy-five years, in the opinion of all three members of the Transit Commission, is the outstanding peril contained in the Seabury-Berle unification plan they have rejected by unanimous vote.

A motorist was burned to death today when his automobile caught fire after colliding with another car at a sharp curve on the Black Horse Pike at Penny Pot, six miles from Hammonton. Four other persons were injured.

A Venezuelan frontier inspector tonight reported to El Dorado the death of Frederic D. Grab of Chicago, one of two American passengers injured in the crash of an airliner April 23 in the jungle near the Brazilian border. Mr. Grab was commercial attach of the United States Legation here.

Last week in most markets represented a halt after the somewhat severe readjustment of April and March. On the Stock Exchange, the averages rose about 2 1/2 points, making gain of 7 3/8 from April's lowest, which itself was 17 1/2 points below this year's high level, reached in March. The recovery occurred on the basis of unusually light trading.

Elspeth Davies of Barnard College and J. Robert Harrison of Columbia College have received scholarships from the Students International Union to the Summer seminar on world affairs at Geneva, Switzerland, it was learned yesterday. The seminar, which opens late in July, will be under the direction of Sir Norman Angell, former member of the British Parliament and Nobel Prize winner.

The outdoor polo season at Governors Island was launched yesterday and a crowd of 3,000 spectators at Morris Memorial Field saw the home riders go down to defeat before the Blind Brook quartet in a wellplayed and hard-fought game. The score was 8 to 7.

The American League. Against War and Fascism has announced the establishment of a music division to encourage the performance of music significant in the movement against war and fascism, and also to present concerts and conduct research in American folk song.

More than 20,000 children and their parents gathered on the Mall in Central, Park yesterday afternoon to pay homage to Gold Star fathers and mothers of the nation at the tenth annual Parents Day celebration of Uncle Robert, children's radio entertainer.
Frank Lorello of Hoboken reported to the Jersey City police today that the life-size bronze bust of his father, weighing fifty pounds, had been stolen from his grave in Holy Name Cemetery.
Herbert Claiborne Pell, newly appointed Minister to Portugal, and Mrs. Pell will arrive at the Madison today from Newport, R. I., and will sail next week for Lisbon.

The Transit Commission announced yesterday its rejection of the $436,000,000 plan of rapid transit unification negotiated and sponsored by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr., trensit advisers to Mayor La Guardia.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the mechanical "selfloaders," which will be part of the equipment on new Department of Sanitation collection trucks and will be installed on trucks-now in use, would eliminate many of the injuries received by -department employes in their work and develop "the highest efficiency in an important public service."

Six high school boys from Greensboro, Fla., were killed in a collision of their school bus and a motor truck near here last midnight. All members of the Greensboro Club of Future Farmers of America, the boys were returning from a convention trip to Marianna when the bus and the flat-bottomed body of the truck came into collision.

For the city to accept the Seabury-Berle plan for rapid transit unification "would be the unforgivable blunder of the century," according to the report submitted to the Transit Commission by John J. Curtin, special counsel, made public yesterday.

Franco Autori, regular conductor of the WPA Buffalo Symphony Orchestra, directed the concert of the Federal Symphony Orchestra given last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. Phyllis Moss, 15-year-old pianist, was the soloist.

A three-story brick Colonial structure, built to house the educational and recreational activities of the Lutheran Church of the Good shepherd, was dedicated yesterday at Fourth Avenue and Seventy-fifth Street, Brooklyn.

After a decline of 100 to 158 points in April, cotton futures on the New York Stock Exchange showed more stability last week. At the close on Saturday active futures were up 15 to 24 points for the week. The market was quiet most of the week. Following fairly heavy selling in April, selling pressure was limited last week, and even small demand disclosed scarcity of contracts.

Mr. and Mrs. John Lang announced at a reception yesterday at their home, 683 Forty-first Street, Brooklyn, the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Muriel Lang, to Richard Charles Corcoran, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Corcoran of Brooklyn.

The Federal Trade Commission ordered today the Gynex Corporation, 211 East Nineteenth Street and 301 Madison Avenue, New York, to "cease and desist" from misrepresenting the therapeutic value and effectiveness of. certain feminine hygiene preparations and appliances, some of which are sold under the names of "Gynettes," "Gyn-oSol," "Gynex Tablets" and "Viornetts."

The full reduction of member bank surplus reserves, as a result of the doubling of reserve requirements in the three increases between August, 1936, and May 1 of this present year, has now been officially reported. The excess reserve remaining is $890,000,000;

The second week of May finds the season in the art galleries keeping up a good pace, with important group and one-man shows on the roster and a considerable variety of exhibitions. Museums and other institutions are again in the spotlight.
The Athletics overcame a six-run lead today, defeated the Tigers, 9 to 8, and jumped into a tie with the Indiane for the American League o: leadership.

New milestones in the treatment of epilepsy, which bring nearer the goal of eliminating epileptic seizures and at the same time shed much new light on the chemical activities the brain and the nervous system, will be reported here tomorrow at the opening of the ninety-third annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

Providence College turned back the St. John's University baseball team for the second time this season with a 7-to-2 triumph before 2,000 fans today. Crowley's three-run homer in the second inning climaxed an uprising that netted four runs.

The seamen of the world, who save life in time of peril, were praised yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Romig, pastor of the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-ninth Street west of Broadway, in his morning sermon.

Members of the Girls Service Club held their annual meeting and election of officers yesterday at their clubhouse, 138 East Nineteenth Street. Later in the afternoon the organization gave its annual Mothers' Day tea at the clubhouse. A musical program was presented.

Residents of the lower East Side, dressed in the costumes of a dozen countries, sang and danced yesterday afternoon in Seward Park in a pageant depicting Manhattan from the time Indians were the sole dwellers up until the present.
Midshipmen winners of three prizes to be presented during June week were announced at the Naval Academy today. Midshipman William D. Brinckloe Jr. of Easton, Md.,

The first attempt at a transatlantic airplane flight this year started at 4:36 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when Henry T. (Dick) Merrill and John S. Lambie. his 27-year-old co-pilot, took off from Floyd Bennett Field on a projected non-stop flight to Croydon Airfield, London.

A world-wide appeal to "all men of good will" to raise their voices in "overwhelming protest" against the recent bombing by Spanish Insurgent air raiders of the ancient Basque holy city of Guernica, in which 800 noncombatant men, women and children were reported killed, was issued yesterday by seventy-six religious, educational, political, civic, business and professional leaders.

PEDLAR'S PROGRESS: THE LIFE OF BRONSON ALCOTT, by Odell Shepard. (Little, Brown, $3.75.) A prize-winning biography. THE RING IS CLOSED, by Knut Hamsun. (Putnam, $2.50.) A novel by the author of "Growth of the Soil."

France celebrated today in honor of Joan of Are with all the pomp of former years. If the air was supercharged with the electricity arising from political side-issues, the day passed without much lightning and thunder, for two reasons:

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the three months ended on Jan. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $2,378,963 after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, in contrast with a net of $1,902,684 in the three months ended on Jan. 31, 1936.

Mothers throughout the nation received the tribute of their children yesterday. Bright skies and a warm sun lent a perfect background to the celebration here and many sons and daughters went walking with their mothers in the city's parks and along Riverside Drive.

Alice Pettee Adams, known throughout Japan as the "mother of social service," died today in suburban Newton at the age of 71. At her request, a Japanese flag, gift of friends in Japan, will be buried with her.

Sales of American aircraft and aircraft engines and parts reached a total of $20,496,517 in the first three months of this year, an increase of 67.9 per cent over the same period last year, according to a survey made public yesterday by Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

New York University athletes who been active in basketball, indoor track, swimming and other sports on University Heights will receive their annual awards tomorrow night at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, placed the name of his institution yesterday among the list of American universities that will not be represented when the German University of Goettingen celebrates its 200th anniversary from June 25 to 30.

The United States shared in the generally increased prosperity of. LatinAmerican countries in 1936, while the important gains made by Germany through the use of compensation marks tended. to fall off toward the end of the year, according to the annual Latin-American economic survey made public today by the Pan-American Union.

The first union service of the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, West 181st Street and Fort Washington Avenue, and the former congregation of the Hamilton Grange Reformed Church, Convent Avenue and 149th Street, was held yesterday at the 181st Street place of worship.

Sir George W. Badgerow one of the empire's most noted ear, nose and throat specialists, and a native of Toronto, died suddenly today. He was 65 years old. He was stricken while in a taxicab bound for Waterloo Station.

Motor vehicle registrations in the United States reached a new all-time high in 1936, surpassing the 1935 figure by nearly 2,000,000 and the previous record of 1930 by 1,700,000, the Bureau of Public Roads announced today.

This was the second Sunday since the Rev. David Wesley Soper, pastor of the Castle Heights Methodist Episcopal Church in the town of North Castle, just across the city line, started a free church taxi service, and it proved a boon to a number of elderly men and women who desired to attend the Mothers' Day services.

The Mercantile Express of the Pennsylvania Railroad, bound from St. Louis to New York, crashed into the rear of a halted freight train early today, injuring fifteen passengers and derailing five empty freight cars.

Edward Bimberg, proprietor of the Palm Garden, 306 West Fifty-second Street, died yesterday at his home, 205 West Fifty-fourth Street, after a brief illness. He was 49 years old. Mr. Bimberg, a native New Yorker, was well known to an older generation of theatrical persons, having spent many years on the vaudeville stage.

The annual Mother's Day fulldress parade of the Seventy-first Regiment, New York National Guard, from tis armory at Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue west to and up Fifth Avenue to St. Thomas Episcopal Church at Fifty-third Street was held yesterday

Bus service will be resumed in London, if at any time in the near future, only at the eleventh hour before the coronation. The busmen's committee of the Transport and General Workers Union will meet at 5 o'clock tomorrow afternoon to decide whether to call off the strike pending investigation of its claim that the sevenand-a-half-hour day is necessary to avoid ruining bus workers' health.

Because of the gloomy outlook for early increase in income from endowments, the colleges and universities of the United States must continue to put large dependence on new gifts and bequests, says a report of the American Council of Education made public over the week-end at the council's annual meeting. The institutions have total endowments of about $1,500,000,000.

Farm prices of chickens have gone up more than seasonally in recent weeks, but market prices of eggs have declined. Discussing the poultry and egg situation, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reports the following "important developments" of the past month:
Mr. and Mrs. George Gordon Douglas entertained with a dinner last night at Mapleshade in Red Cross Avenue.

Trapped by a chief of police who posed as a butler while a fellowofficer hid behind heavy curtains in the Cohasset home of Hugh Bancroft, two men were arrested last night, charged with attempting to extort $100 from Mr. Bancroft by blackmail, the police revealed today.
The "wild flower patrol" of scoutmasters on duty in Palisades Interstate Park reported yesterday that it had stopped 109 persons found picking wild flowers, many of a rare variety.
Mrs. Seaver B. Buck, wife of the headmaster of the Berkshire School, gave a tea yesterday afternoon to 100 visiting alumni who held their annual-May dinner in the evening at the Berkshire Inn.
The recently formed Society for the.Advancement of Jewish Music presented Sidor Belarsky, Russian bass, in a recital entitled "The Jewish Song" last night at Town Rail.
The Bisons blanked Jersey City, 4-0, today to win their third game in four home starts and remain in second place in the International League.

The active state of British trade has received further confirmation from employment figures and provincial bank clearings. The number of work people employed on April 19 was 152,000 above a month before and 609,000 above the total a year before, while provincial bank clearings in April were 22 per cent higher than in April, 1936.

Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, speaking yesterday on "Christian Anti-Judaism and Pagan Anti-Semitism" in the Free Synagogue at Carnegie Hall, charged the "hatred which Christianity has engendered" was responsible for the persecution of religious groups in Nazi Germany.

Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their company of dancers brought' their local season to a close last night with a performance at the Guild Theatre for the benefit of the Cooperative School for Student Teachers.
J. G. Geddes, vice president of the National City Bank of Cleveland, announced today that the twentyfourth National Foreign Trade Convention would be held here from Nov. 3 to 6.

George Norman Gardiner of Seawane Drive, Hewlett, L. I., former president of the Gardiner Paint Company of New York, died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Hospital, where he had undergone an operation. He was 62 years old.

The Hollywood Revue and Bridge party, originated by its chairman, Mrs. George Horace Lorimer, will be held tomorrow under the auspices of the Welfare Committee of the Hannah Penn House group in the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom.

In connection, with Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Four-Year Plan, and particularly with the view of alleviating Germany's great need for fats, a whaling company is being formed in Hamburg. It will have an initial capital of from 8,000,000 to 10,000,000 marks.

The Merchants Association of New York has wired Chairman Doughton of the House Ways and Means Committee asking for a hearing on a bill recently introduced by Mr. Doughton at the request of the Treasury Department, amending certain administrative provisions of the Tariff Act, including those relating to marking and exemptions.
Mrs. Elizabeth Fisher King, widow of Edward King, who was president of the Union Trust Company from 1883 until his death in 1908, died yesterday at her residence, 71 Park Avenue.

The Red Wings knocked the Newark Bears out of first place today, by handing the Bruins a 5-3 setback in the opening game of the series. The Wings shelled Al Piechota for nine hits-including two home runs by Crabtree and four doublesin six innings for a five-run lead that the Bears were unable to overcome despite a ninth-inning rally.

The truce declared in the strike of 1,200 Bronx gasoline station employes was extended yesterday until tomorrow after an all-night conference of representatives of the Intercity Gas Dealers Association, the Petroleum Dealers Association, and the Gasoline Station Attendants Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate. The conference was h Id at 500 Whitlock Avenue, the Bronx.

The statement of the Bank of France for April 30 shows a decrease of 524,000,000 francs in bills discounted. The only other outstanding variations from a week before were an increase of 1,894,000,000 francs in circulation and a decrease of 1,038,000,000 francs in the Treasury account.

F. J. Lawrence of Sussex, N. J., won the amateur championship of America at distance handicap targets over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. This was the final event of the three-day meet and brought 108 gunners to the firing line.

Two hundred members of the Town Hall Club listened for more than two hours last night to stories about the Metropolitan Opera House at their "opera dinner" in honor of members of the Metropolitan Opera Association.

The shore and the country were in a welcoming mood for visitors from the city yesterday as thousands of men, women and children went traveling on a bright sunny day that held just a touch of coolness, from fresh breezes, in its warmth.

The ninety-ninth birthday of Mrs. Sarah Ann Ross was celebrated at her home in Moriches today. She was hostess at a luncheon followed by a Mother's Day reception to about forty-five guests. There were five birthday cakes, one of which bore ninetynine pink candles.
Ten Federal agencies awarded eighty contracts valued at $2,385,457 under the terms of the Public Contracts Act in the week- ended on May 6, the Department of Labor has announced.

The United States liner President Roosevelt will arrive today from European ports with 179 passengers, including George C. Becker, entomologist of the United States Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 92 per cent of capacity, down 1 point from the rate of the preceding week and equal to that in the three weeks before. Output for April is reported at 90.27 per cent. Output slightly exceeded that of March and was the greatest in history, buf the percentage rate had been exceeded in some months of 1929 because then there was less capacity.
Eugene McGuckin, an advertising executive, died of a heart ailment today in Abington Memorial Hospital after an illness of ten days. He was 56 years old and was a graduate of St. Joseph's College.

With the cheaper seats for the coronation procession on Wednesday virtually gone, thousands of Londoners paced the route today, picking out the places where they will camp out for twenty-four hours for a free view.

The talk that is heard concerning a lowering of the price of gold is frowned upon here in circles which originally deprecated President Roosevelt's devaluation of the dollar. It is objected that a change in the price of gold would increase and perpetuate the tendency of governments to correct through currency manipulation all temporary and undesirable. phenomena in prices in industry and on the Stock Exchanges.

Since the resumption of banking after the holiday of March, 1933, 323 licensed banks have suspended, involving deposits of $205,273,000, according to figures given out today by the Federal Reserve Board. The data do not include non-licensed banks placed in liquidation or receivership after the bank holiday.
Miss Margaret S. Davison, daughter of C. Herbert Davison of this city, has chosen June 28 as the date for her marriage to John Paul Chubet 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. A. Chubet of Boston.

ALLGAIER-At Atlantic City, on May 9, 1937, Frederick William, husband of Margaret Burke Allgaier. Relatives and friends, also all organizations of which he was a member, are invited to the funeral on Wednesday morning at 8 o'clock from the J. Bunker Plum Building, 15 South Indiana Ave.

President Rooseveit will seek a final engagement tomorrow with the fighting tarpon in Gulf waters off the mouth of the Brazos River. Tomorrow's sport will conclude the President's annual Spring fishing vacation, and at nightfall the Presidential yacht Potomac will turn toward this port where, early Tuesday, the Chief Executive will entrain for a brief visit in Fort Worth, from where he will leave for Washington.

The Freeport Tuna Club has decided to issue prizes for those who are successful in catching tuna this season. An angler may gain further distinction-besides having landed the fish-from the club. There will be blue, red and gold seals for tuna in the 50, 80 and 125 pound class and a special certificate will go to any member. catching a tuna weighing more than 300 pounds.

Clifford D. Mallory today served notice on owners of this year's crop of six-meter yachts that Totem, which he owns with Billy Luders, is not to be counted out of the forthcoming international tests just because she is past the first blush of youth.

The Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, pastor of Holy Cross parish in midtown Manhattan, announced yesterday that the parish had purchased a plot 100 feet square almost directly opposite Holy Cross Parochial School in West Fortythird Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, at a cost of $70,000, and would build a playground for children of the "midwest side," and particularly for the children of the parish.

The complete program of the Westchester music festival, to be held May 20, 21 and 22 at the Westchester County Center, White Plains, under the leadership of Hugh Ross, was announced yesterday. Participants will include the Philadelphia Orchestra,

A high degree of prosperity for the next two years, a stock market collapse in the Summer or Fall of 1939, a minor recession in business of one or two years beginning at that time and a period of prosperity following this recession.

Two union mass meetings voted loudly tonight in favor of a strike in the two mills of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation next Wednesday at 11 P. M. unless the company signs a labor contract with the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

The index of wholesale prices in France on May 1 was 533, compared with 537 on April 24 and 529 on April 17. The index for raw materials on a world gold basis was 55.2 on May 1, against 55.6 on April 24 and 56.4 on April 17.
Mrs. Gerald Griffin of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jessie Lucille Griffin, to Dr. Hugh Francis Leahy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh F.

On Mother's Day here. yesterday at least one million shoulders bloomed with pink or white carnations, but despite this florists generally said that business in the traditional flowers was below previous years.

Some 2,000 adult and 300 boy and girl delegates to the annual convention of the American Red Cross streamed into Washington today to find the Capital bedecked in the flags that symbolize humanitarianism in every corner of the globe..

All inhabitants of this picturesque town in the south of France like bullfights, but some do not like hulls from Spanish Insurgent territory. One hundred Leftists today invaded the local "corrida," featuring the well-known matadors Ortega, Bienvenida and Lalanda, giving catcalls because the bulls had been brought from Rebel territory in Spain.

Members of the Young New Yorkers Club will hold a dance May 22 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Children's Aid Society which provides convalescent homes, farm training schools and Summer camps for underprivileged children.

Many clergymen and laymen speaking at churches and other religious gatherings throughout New York City yesterday chose the forthcoming coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth of England as the topic of their sermons and addresses.

Henry P. Talmadge, retired president of the New York banking firm of Henry Talmadge Co., founded by his father, with which he was associated for sixty-five years, died today at his home here at the age of 90.
Ed Brandt, Pirate southpaw ace, kept eight Boston hits scattered except in one inning today as his mates pounced on three Bee hurlers for seven hits and a 6-to-3 victory.

The National Biscuit Company has subscribed for $100,000 of the New York World's Fair 4 per cent debentures, and General Mills Company for $50,000, according to an announcement made by Richard Whitney, chairman of the bond sales committee.

Champion Vigow of Romanoff, Louis J. Murr's famous Borzoi, added further laurels to his imposing record today when the handsome cream-white Russian wolfhound went best in show at the fifth annual exhibition of the Trenton Kennel Club.

Definite indications of returning prosperity to the advertising agency field are shown in the number of new agencies formed since the start of the year, a halt of consolidations, addition of personnel, numerous removals to larger offices and expansion of present facilities, according to a survey here.

The stock market here this week was irregular and without character, with only a slight decline in the average. Steel shares were undecided. Mannesmann was active and firm while Vereingtestahl weakened. Machinery issues were in temporary demand, making Orenstein Koppel advance substantially, while electrical shares were irregular.

The Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn handled 1,443 social service cases arising in the Domestic Relations Court last year, it was announced yesterday in the annual report of the organization. The cases involved a total of 1,588 children, 1,231 boys and 357 girls.

Friends of James J. Dooling, Tammany leader, expressed confidence yesterday that there would be no change in the leadership, at least for the present. Mr. Dooling, It was said, will have talks with more members of the executive committee today and tomorrow and may be at Tammany Hall later in the week.

Thirty thousand fans jammed their way into Ebbets Field yesterday, saw the Dodgers' little threegame winning streak shattered by Dizzy Dean and the Cardinals, and went away with less dissatisfaction than usually is displayed over a Brooklyn defeat.

For too long a time too little has been heard of that incorporated hope, the National Republican Builders. It is a happiness to know that here in New York they have been silently perfecting the reconstruction of the Republican ruins.

An early attempt by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to seek a peace conference between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization was forecast here today by David Dubinsky, president of the garment union.
The Department of Health revealed today the fact that for the first time in the State's history, a month had passed without the reporting of a single death from typhoid fever.

The Gourmet Society, that organization of persons who like to eat good food in an appropriate and careful manner, acquired a new member yesterday who began his dinner with a drink of whisky, smoked a cigar and a pipe during the meal, and ended by proclaiming that the greatest American dishes were terrapin and planked shad.

Deep-seated critical feeling toward the Duke of Windsor among the British upper classes is voiced in polite but unmistakable terms today by two prominent Sunday newspapers that speak for that section of opinion, The Observer and the Sunday Times.
Union employes ratified tonight an agreement in which the Packard Motor Car Company recognized the United Automobile Workers as the sole bargaining agent for its hourly rate employes.

Following is the text as transcribed here of a discussion by the Archbishop of Canterbury of the forthcoming coronation which was broadcast yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company:

Construction of the $70,000,000 vehicular tunnel from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to Staten Island is urged as a means of aiding real estate in the Borough of Richmond, in a letter addressed to Governor Lehman by Bennett E. Siegelstein, attorney for the Victory Development Company.

Prominent musicians and music lovers of New York and Long Island will be. the guests of Thomas P. de Graffenried tonight at a musical to be given with the collaboration of the Hammond Organ Club at his residence.
Destroyers searched for the plane and bodies of two navy aviators today as the United States fleet, its "Battle of the Hawaiian Islands" completed, sailed into Pearl Harbor.

Harry S. New, former Postmaster General, died here at 10:30 o'clock tonight in Johns Hopkins Hospital. The 79-year-old former Cabinet member, credited with starting the air mail, entered the hospital a week ago.

Dr. and Mrs. Seymour St. John Boughton of Glen Ridge have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Elizabeth Boughton, to Ralph. W. Searing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Searing of Glen Ridge.

At a special meeting called to make final arrangements for the hunts racing season in and around New York, the board of stewards of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association granted licenses to twelve amateur riders, seventeen jockeys and twenty-two trainers. The dates for steeplechase events for both the Summer and Fall meetings at Aqueduct were ratified.
The Interior Department respectfully declined today to help a young Midwestern woman get a sweetheart.

Columbia's unexpected victory over Yale on Wednesday and C. C. N. Y.'s equally unexpected triumph over New York University on Friday were outstanding during the week in metropolitan college baseball circles.

Dr. Edward G. Nugent, for nearly forty years a staff member of the Rochester General Hospital, died today of a heart attack, at the age of 76. Born at Waterloo, Dr. Nugent was graduated from Hobart College in 1893, and four years later received his medical degree at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.
Miss Anna Hill Johnstone of this city was married to Curville Jones Robinson of New York yesterday in the garden of Alan Hame, the home of the bride's parents,

Democracy began when Jesus taught men to respect themselves, said the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams in his morning sermon yesterday at the Epworth Methodist Episcopal Church, 150th Street and Twelfth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens.

A total of 129 athletic awards, including six managers' certificates, has been received by undergraduates at the University of Pennsylvania for participation in six indoor sports, Russell Callow, chairman of the awards committee, announced today.

Princeton yachtsmen excelled in four races on Lake Carnegie today to score a 95-82 victory over the Vassar Yacht Club in a week-end dinghy regatta which opened yesterday. Commodore Bob Robie of the Nassau Club, with Frank Bell as crew, annexed individual honors, sailing to three first places today.

When MARY LYON was founding Mount Holyoke College TENNYSON was writing his "medley" entitled "The Princess," first published in the year before MARY LYON'S death, after her twelve years of pioneering struggle.

In the now official Warner property "Swing Your Lady," a Broadway comedy of last Winter concerning a feminine wrestler of the Ozarks, the studio will cast Pat'O'Brien, Joan Blondell and Humphrey Bogart.

Erratic action of the grain markets last week resulted in a marked falling off in the volume of business, with wide fluctuations at times, and brought about a general evening-up of trades in all positions throughout the world. Bulges, due largely to short covering, met profit-taking sales in volume that tended to check the upward price movements and brought about sharp price recessions.

The historic Toboggan Handicap, which has been won by some of the greatest sprinters in turf history since its inaugural in 1890, will feature the opening of the Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park today. Twelve of the best sprinters in the East have been named for the sixfurlong test and a field of at least ten is expected to go to the post with Hal Price Headley's Whopper, favorite.

Mother's Day, celebrated yesterday, was discussed in many churches, synagogues and other gatherings of a religious nature throughout the city. Clergymen and laymen spoke of motherhood in present-day life, the Scriptures and in history. Several discussed the responsibilities of motherhood and in some
Toronto swept both ends of a double-header with Syracuse today, winning the first, 5--3, on the Chiefs' errors, and capturing the second, 2 to 1, on five hits. A crowd of 7,000 saw the games.

Hopelessly deadlocked after almost twelve hours' deliberation, a blue-ribbon jury which had heard the case of Louis Luckman, accused of perjury, was dismissed yesterday morning in Brooklyn by Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers.
Assemblyman Hart S. Van Fleet died today at his home, 139 Westfield Avenue East, of a heart attack. He was a Republican representative from Union County.

The fortunes that befall us and the interpretation we give them shape our lives and character, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday in a sermon at Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive. The topic of his sermon was "The Secret of Spiritual Mastery Over Life."

The presence of Christ on board the vessel of our life is a guarantee of safety amid life's storms, the Rev. John Linton, pastor of the New York Gospel Center, 122 West Seventy-second Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

About 500 persons attended a brief funeral service yesterday afternoon at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, for Sam Franko, noted musician, who died on Thursday.

Evans G. Olwell and Eugene F. Flahive have formed the firm of E. G. Olwell Co. at 115 Broadway to transact a- general investment business. C. B. Richard Co. have opened a branch office in Flushing, L. I., under Chandler G. Burrows.

The Richmond National Bank, James J. Munroe, receiver, sold to Karl Angerer for investment the three-story brick store property at 104-21 Jamaica Avenue, between 104th and 105th Streets, Richmond Hill, in Queens. F. J. Magerle, Inc., was the broker.

Leo McCarey's "Make Way for Tomorrow," which sardonically delayed its Criterion premiere until the eve of Mother's Day, has three qualities rarely encountered in the cinema: humanity, honesty and warmth. These precious attributes,

Mrs. Alta Rosalie Lee, about 45 years old, was seriously injured early today when she jumped or fell from the window of a room on the eighth floor of the Hotel Marseilles, at the southwest corner of Broadway and 103d Street, where she had lived for about a year.

France advanced to the third round of European zone Davis Cup competition today, defeating Norway, 3-0, with an easy victory in the doubles. Marcel Bernard and Yvon Petra defeated Fritz Jenssen and Johann Beer, 6-2, 6-2, 6-2, in the deciding match today.

Award of the Franklin Medal in physical science for 1937 to Dr. Robert A. Millikan of the California Institute of Technology and to Dr. P. J. W. Debye of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, Berlin, is announced by the Franklin Institute.

The effects of growing scarcity and rising prices now loom larger in the Japanese news than political struggles or international relations. Many signs indicate that the country is entering an era where economic factors will exercise an increasing influence on events.

The National Foreign Trade Council has sent a telegram to the chairman of the House Committee on Agriculture, urging that the pending sugar quota legislation be amended so as to permit of an increase in the amount of full duty sugar which may be imported from foreign countries other than Cuba and also that the present Cuban quota be not reduced.
Stocks higher in slowest trading for any week since last June; turnover, 4,136,885 shares. United States Government issues higher; other bonds steady ir. quiet trading; transactions, $49,275,000.
A reduction of nearly 500,0C0 acres in the area sown in grain in Canada in 1937 was predicted by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics today. On the basis of reports from correspondents the

The rejection by the Transit Commission of the Seabury-Berle local traction unification plan apparently came as a surprise to many followers of the transit situation. The decision was reflected quickly in the marketwise action of the traction securities, particularly the bonds, which broke sharply in fairly active trading.

Although three out of every four of the 11,000,000 residents in the New York metropolitan area are under 45 years of age, the population trend is steadily toward a rising proportion of persons past 45, according to a report by the Hospital Survey, which will be published this week by the United Hospital Fund.
Sir Stafford Cripps, Laborite member of Parliament, said in a political speech at Stockton today that the coronation was "bunkum and bunting."

With representatives of the Bureau of Internal Revenue listening to the testimony, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, resuming its investigation of the Van Sweringen network of railroads and other properties, delved today into transactions involving $9,250,000 of land trust issues which were carried on the Van Sweringen books as "liabilities" in the years 1927 to 1929, inclusive.

Two golf players who allegedly drove balls which struck their caddy while he was carrying their bags on a fairway of the Sprain Lake Golf Course, Yonkers, were assessed a total of $250 today by a jury sitting before Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief.

A Republican movement to revise the Social Security Act brought the appointment today by the Social Security Board and the Senate Finance Committee of an advisory council of twenty-four to study possible fundamental changes in the law, including proposals to extend its scope to workers not now covered.

Essex won its initial fixture in the county cricket championship today, getting a six-wicket decision over Somerset at Taunton. The match was concluded a day ahead of schedule, Essex making 228 runs for nine wickets, declared, and 102 for four in reply to Somerset's 223 and 106.
An Australian expert in speech defects under whom King George has trained in an effort to overcome his stammer was one of those whom the King rewarded in his coronation honors list today.

Bill Werber smashed a double with the bases filled in the second inning today, Al Dean duplicated the feat in the fourth inning, and when the day's barrage was over Philadelphia had beaten Detroit again, 9 to 5. The Athletics thus remained in a tie for first place with Cleveland.
Puerto Rico has 52,790 farms, totaling 1,913,047 acres valued at $156,278,450, according to a report issued today by the Puerto Rican Reconstruction Administration.

Coronation early birds took their perches tonight along the Mall near Buckingham Palace. Equipped with camp stools and heavy rugs, they were prepared to camp out more than thirty-five hours to witness the departure of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth for their coronation.

New York's taxicab limitation ordinance, passed last March, was declared constitutional and valid by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman in a decision handed down yesterday. The new law enjoins the Police Department from licensing more cabs than there were in operation at the time it became effective, unless a need for more taxis is shown.

The period of carefree leisure is coming to an end for Prince Bernhard. Hollanders generaly would not like to see him become a second Prince Henry of the Netherlands, Queen Wilhelmina's late consort, for whom life became a bore because of his lack of occupation.
A view of January's devastating floods was presented tonight before 2,000 delegates attending the annual. American Red Cross convention.

Disregarding last night's separate agreement with film producers by the Screen Actors Guild, the Federated Motion Picture Crafts announced plans today for a nationwide theatre boycott in their effort to obtain recognition of the union.

Pittsburgh's league-leading Pirates won their seventh game in eight starts today by pounding Lou Fette, who had been the Bees' only undefeated pitcher, for ten hits and a 4-1 triumph. Bill Swift went the route for the victors, kept Boston's eight blows well scattered and did not issue a pass.

Thirty broadcasters, speaking all tongues of the Western World, except Italian, will describe the coronation events Wednesday from early morning until the day closes with the program, "The Empire's Homage."

Latin-American Foreign Offices have not had time to study carefully the United States Neutrality Bill. If private and unofficial conversations in Latin-American diplomatic and authoritative official circles here are to be credited, three general conclusions have been reached.
With only one upset recorded the quarter final round was reached today in the New England intercollegiate tennis tournament on the Williams College courts.

Admissions by the Mayor and Police Chief that utility company representatives may freely canvass or circularize the town whereas private business men and union delegates must be photographed, fingerprinted and delayed seventy-two hours before being given a permit, caused Recorder William P. Leary to reserve decision here today in a test case of this borough's alleged "anti-labor gag ordinance."

The results of the elections of undergraduate officers by the members of Princeton University's seventeen upper-class eating clubs were announced today by Alden M. Wicks, '37, chairman of the Interclub Committee.
An old-time golfing theory was exploded today at the Garden City Country Club, where the Long Island P. G. A. held its opening tournament of the season.

By turning back the Cherry Valley contingent, 4 to 1, over the Pomonok Country Club course in Flushing yesterday, the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club advanced to a tie for first place with North Hempstead in Class A of the Long Island women's interclub team championship tournament.

Jack Massena of Pelham Manor defeated Harold Levine of the Bronx as play began yesterday in the third annual Greater New York junior singles tennis tournament at Central Park. The match was decided at 5-7, 7-5, 10-8.

A new approach to the teaching of arithmetic, based on the students' daily life, is being evolved for the forty-four evening elementary schools of this city, Ignus O. Hornstein, assistant director of evening schools, disclosed yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times. Senator McNaboe is quoted once again as calling the American Student Union an affiliate of the Young Communist League. Perhaps it is foolish even to undertake to answer the Senator.
Thirty-nine athletes and managers have been honored with insignia for basketball during the past Winter, it has been announced by St. John's University.

Unemployment has sunk below the 1,000,000 mark for the first time in ten years. Some 250,000 jobless were put to work in April, making the total unemployment 961,000. This figure is 800,000 below the figure for April, 1936, and some 5,000,000 below the 1932 figure.

A report that Justices Brandeis and Van Devanter will retire at the end of the present court term early in June, and that this will be announced in the next two or three weeks, is being heard with increasing frequency and was widely discussed at the Capitol today. Sources assigned reached into circles close to some of the justices.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Robert Mackey of Cedarhurst, L. I., of the engagement of Mr. Mackey's daughter, Miss Florence Winifred Mackey, to Stephen J. Patterson of Garden City, L. I., son of Mrs. Anna N. Patterson of this city, and the late Stephen J. Patterson.

Miss Dorothy Gilman Clark of this city will be married on June 12 to William O. Thomson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Thomson. The ceremony will be performed in the South Congregational Church by the Rev. Warren S. Archibald, the pastor.

Paul Chabas, who painted the famous picture, "September Morn," in 1912, died today at the age of 68. He had been an invalid for two years, and the only painting in the room where he spent most of the time was his own copy of the picture that made him world famous.

Glimpses into the future of radio, when reception from foreign countries and world-wide telephony may be clear as crystal and quite free from the bugaboo of static and noise as it now afflicts international communication, were presented yesterday at the first technical sessions of the Institute of Radio Engineers silver anniversary convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Alice Breschel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav A. Breschel of Rye, N. Y., to Charles Pollak Regensburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville E. Regensburg of this city.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. and his associates have definitely abandoned the idea of building a new home for the Metropolitan Opera Association in Rockefeller Center, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. Edward F. Shea of Stoneridge, N. Y., has announced the marriage of her sister, Miss Roberta Anne Sullivan of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dan J. Sullivan, to Robert Sherman Hatfield, also of Clinton.

The highest effective voltage ever used for making X-rays is produced by the new million-volt unit recently installed for cancer treatment at the Collis P. Huntington Memorial Hospital of Harvard University, hospital officials stated today in connection with an inspection of the apparatus by the Harvard board of overseers.

King Gustav and the Cabinet today granted permission for the engagement of the junior Prince Carl and Countess Elsa von Rosen. Prince Carl was born in 1911. He is the son of the King's youngest brother, Prince Carl, and is a brother-in-law of King Leopold of the Belgians. The Countess was born in 1904 and has by a former marriage three children, aged 12, 10 and 7.

A new five-year managmeent stock-purchase plan is to be placed before stockholders of the Pan American Airways Corporation at their meeting in Jersey City on May 20. It would replace the system set up in 1932, now about to expire, and would allow fifty officials to buy a total of 30,000 shares of capital stock at $40 a share.

Sir James Blindell, who rose from errand boy to wealth as a shoe dealer and to prominence in the Simonite Wing of the Liberal party, was killed today in an automobile accident near Boston, Lincolnshire. He was 53.

A resolution authorizing the Westchester Electric Railway Company to substitute a bus for the famed "Toonerville trolley," operating between the Pelham Shore Road and the station of the New Haven Railroad, was adopted by the Pelham Manor Board of Trustees tonight.

Gilbert B. Carpenter of the Badminton Club of Westport has been given top ranking in the men's Class A singles on his showing during the 1936-37 season, according to the lists issued by the Metropolitan Badminton Association yesterday.

Paul Kucheruk, 40 years old, of 540 Sixth Street, a window cleaner, fell to his death at 11 A. M. yesterday in sight of hundreds of persons passing along Fifth Avenue between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets.

Edwin and Jewel Bethany Hughes will play the Poulenc Concerto for two pianos this evening at the studio of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Stuart Moore in the interests of the MacDowell Colony at Peterborough, N. H.
Arthur Nosworthy, head of the Eastern Contracting Company and the Nosworthy Contracting Company of New York and Brooklyn, died today at his home here at the age of 66.

The boycott of British news continued in the Italian press today. Only one newspaper contained a London date line, an item of only a couple of lines by a foreign news agency saying that all Italian journalists had left London.

Miss Elizabeth Curtis, a member of the general dance committee for last season's Yorkville Dinner Dances, gave a tea yesterday at her home, 160 East Seventy-second Street, for members of committees for next season's dances.

Semi-military funeral services will be held here tomorrow afternoon for Harry S. New, former Postmaster General and former United States Senator from Indiana, in Central Christian Church, with private burial at Crown Hill Cemetery. The Rev. W. A. Shullenberger, pastor of the church, of which Mr. New was a member, will deliver the funeral sermon.

The French liner Ile de France, arriving today from Havre and Southampton, has among her passengers Alexander Korda, film producer; Sidney R. Kent, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Films; Murray Silverstone, English representative of the United Artists Corporation; Miss M. Ogorman, E.

Two theatre officials and four young women pleaded not guilty yesterday before County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn on indictments resulting from a raid on April 29 directed against "striptease" performances in Brooklyn burlesque theatres.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that five companies had withdrawn requests that data filed under the Securities Exchange Act be held confidential and that confidential treatment had been refused in the case of three other companies.
In fairly active trading, the various issues of stocks and bonds of the New York City traction
At the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the Children's Welfare Federation yesterday afternoon Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, president, reported that the organization "is now in the black."

Examination Application blanks for examination for promotion to the positions of pilot and marine engineer in this department are forwarded this date. Applications shall be properly filled out and forwarded to this office. not folded or rolled, on Wednesday, May 12.

Miss Elizabeth Parmelee White, daughter of Mrs. William Cravath White of this place and the late Judge White, was married to Warren Hastings Miller, son of the Rev. Everard P. Miller of Scarsdale this morning in the chapel of St Luke's Episcopal Church, East Chester.

Standing by their demand for a 7 1/2-hour day, the London bus strikers rejected tonight all appeals for conciliation over the coronation period. The deadlock is now complete with the prospect of sympathetic walkouts by other transport workers.
Marked improvement in traffic conditions compared with a year ago were revealed in the weekly figures made public yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler.

Moritz Neuberger, retired tobacco dealer, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness. He was 64 years old. Inventor with Frederick Griffin of the shade-grown tobacco process, Mr. Neuberger headed the American branch of the German-controlled tobacco jobbing firm of Heinrich Neuberger Co. from 1903 to 1928, when ill-health forced him to retire from business. The firm was founded by his father.
Stating that Ed Wynn and she had been separated for more than five years, Mrs. Hilda Keenan Wynn filed suit here today to divorce the comedian.

Some few cuts were in good demand. Business generally was only fair to slow, however. Lamb and fresh pork cuts were steady to higher; veal cuts were mostly unchanged; other classes were steady to lower. Early trading in kosher meats Indleated beef and lamb prices to be higher and veal steady as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Representative Mitchell of Illinois, the only Negro member of Congress, announced today that he had filed suit for $50,000 damages against the Pullman Company, and the Illinois Central and Rock Island Railroads, for "humiliation and inconvenience" on charges that he had been ejected from a Pullman car while en route to Hot Springs, Ark., on April 21.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday set aside an award of $115,968 granted in the Federal District Court in Brooklyn last year to Tess Gardella on her complaint that the National Broadcasting Company had allowed an imposter to broadcast as "Aunt Jemima," when as a matter of fact she had been using that name for years on stage and air, and was the only one who had a right to use it.
