Unification of this city's rapid transit lines has been a continuing problem for a decade and a half. The first official report on it was made in 1921. That report fell on barren ground and nothing came of it.
Nearly half of the films placed on the German market this year were of foreign origin. The Censor's report for the first four months shows fifty program pictures were released.

Appropriation of $100,000 by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to be used in organizing the Donnelly Garment Company here drew criticism today from former Senator James A. Reed, husband of the company's president.

Most commodity futures were lower in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, cocoa and hide futures were weakest. On the cash markets all the grains, cocoa, cotton, rubber, standard tin and flour declined, but beef, pork, eggs and quicksilver advanced.

City Counsel Joseph J. Weinberger was notified today that his application for membership in Preiskel-Miller Post 47, Jewish War Veterans, of Passaic had been voided. His initiation fee of $3 was returned to him.
An even dozen Americans, none of them an apparent title threat, have entered the British amateur golf championship. The Associated Press reported yesterday.

Five hundred barbers went out on strike in the Brownsville and East New York areas of Brooklyn yesterday in the first of a series of expected walkouts, according to officials of the Journeymen Barbers International Union. The strike is for higher wages.

All married women who have State jobs and whose husbands are gainfully employed will be required to leave the State employ by the start of the next fiscal year, July 1, Governor Robert E. Quinn said today.

Reinterpretation of Jewish cultural values in the light of contemporary social changes was advocated by speakers yesterday at the closing sessions of the two-day conference of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

To celebrate his coronation King George today dipped into his store of royal honors and on "the advice of his Ministers" brought forth probably the largest and most varied list of titles ever bestowed at a single time by a British sovereign.
According to the official formula prepared for the coronation of King George VI, this is the fashion in which the oath will be administered to him by the Archbishop of Canterbury:

Movemnents of livestock on the bChcago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 13,000 including 4,000 directs. Market fully 10c higher than Fridgy'S average; spots up more on lightweights and butchers over 300 pounds: top $10.55; 'bulk good and choice, 200-300 pounds, 10.35-$10.50: 150-190 pounds $9.85-$10.40; bullc good packing sows, s9.65-$9.90; shipners 2.000; estimated holdover 1.500.

Supreme Court Justice Erskine C. Rogers in Brooklyn set June 2 yesterday as the date on which he will determine when the third trial will be held on the indictment charging Louis Luckman with perjuring himself before the special grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case.

Shipments of finished steel products by the United States Steel Corporation in April decreased 70,755 tons to 1,343,644 tons, compared with 1,414,399 tons in March, but increased 363,737 tons, or 37.1 per cent, compared with shipments of 979,907 tons in April, 1936.

Because Rochester is on standard time, Ellsworth Reming of Buffalo was arrested for illegal parking today. But because Buffalo is on daylight saving time, Judge William H. Tompkins let him off with a suspended sentence.

More than 30,000 troops were encamped in London parks tonight after several days of intricate military movements, transferring here for the coronation soldiers representing every regiment in the British Army.
Funeral services for twenty-four victims of the Hindenburg disaster will be held at 8 o'clock this afternoon at the Hamburg-American Line pier, Forty-sixth Street and the. Hudson River.

The executive committee of the Fur Fashion Show and Exposition to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel announced yesterday that because of heavy demand for tickets the fashion show and banquet will be held on two successive evenings, June 2 and 3.
Today will be a day of cinema premieres, the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer filming of Kipling's tale about the Gloucester fishing fleet, "Captains Courageous," being the chief one.

Joseph J. Baker, a lawyer who has long been identified with fair trade activities in the Bar Association, was appointed chairman of the Advisory Council for the Pre-vention of Commercial Fraud yesterday by Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm Store, Brooklyn.

The Countess of Suffolk has come from Tucson, Ariz., to the Pierre. She will sail tomorrow on the Aquitania. Colonel and Mrs. Clarence S. Wadsworth, who have been at the Madison since returning from Palm Beach, have gone to their home in Middletown, Conn.

Haggard but smiling, Henry T. (Dick) Merrill and John S. Lamble, his co-pilot, stepped from their Lockheed Electra plane at Croydon Airport this evening as if their 3,500-mile flight to pick up films of the coronation, which they will fly to America on Wednesday, merely was part of an ordinary day's work.

Westchester County is coming to take on a personality as have many counties or shires in the British Isles. "An acre in Middlesex," said MACAULAY, "is better than a principality in Utopia." "Kent," says one of DICKENS'S characters, "everybody knows. Kent apples, cherries, hops, women."

The Cleveland Baseball Club has taken out $100,000 worth of life insurance on its strike-out star, Bob Feller. The club announced its action today as Feller took off in a private plane for Des Moines, Iowa, whence he was to go to Van Meter, Iowa, to be graduated from high school.

Judge Richard W. Hawkins, who has for years expressed a sympathetic interest in first offenders and a disinclination to house them with hardened criminals, declared in Suffolk County Court here today that there must be better discipline in homes in the country if its youth is to be saved from criminal careers.

If some of Canada's industrial interests, newspapers and politicians have their way the efforts of the American C. I. O. to dominate Canadian labor may be converted into a political issue and become, like the antireciprocity campaign of 1911, a menace to Canadian-American relations.

The cornerstone for the Kips Bay-Yorkville Health and Teaching Center, 411 East Sixty-ninth Street, was laid yesterday. It will be used to train medical students in preventive medicine and public health administration. The Health Department and five medical schools in the city will cooperate in the work.

Henry L. DeForest, president of the Hackensack Water Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting at Weehawken, N. J., yesterday that the company had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commissio- in contemplation of the issuance of $13,600,000 of 3%1/ per cent first mortgage bonds in a refunding program of present longterm 4, 5 and 5% per cent obligations.

A set of fair-trade practice rules for the men's and boys' clothing manufacturing trade will be submitted to the newly organized Men's Clothing Manufacturers Trade Bureau, Inc., at a meeting tonight at the Hotel McAlpin.

Defeating the Quaker Ridge team on the familiar territory of the losers' own course, the Century Country Club Class A combination advanced to the threshold of the women's Westchester interclub golf championship today.

Pounding three Jasper pitchers for a total of twelve hits, the New York Stock Exchange defeated the Manhattan freshman nine, 12 to 7, at Manhattan Field yesterday.' The reversal was the fifth in six starts this season for the Green cubs.

As the result of an easier money market following the orderly application of the increased reserve requirements on May 1, the Treasury obtained a slight reduction today in the average interest rate at which it marketed about $100,000,000 of Treasury bills of 273-day and 128-day maturities.

Sunshine came to London today for a whole morning, changing completely the face of this coronation picture. For all England, even gray-visaged London, is beautiful by act of Providence in Maytime. Lilacs and tulips are abloom in the parks, hawthorn is coming into bud and wherever there is grass or trees there is fresh greenery that makes the whole world new.
Word of the death in London of Charles Henry Pierre was received here today. He was a member of the colony's official coronation delegation to London with Captain Arthur Cipriani. His age was 59.

Attention is again called to a matter in which the parents of children should be concerned, first of all for their children's sake and their own and then for public safety. The figures for the first quarter of 1937 on immunization against diphtheria, as reported by the Health Commissioner, are ominous.

The annual report of the New Jersey Power and Light Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes, amortization and other expenses and charges, of $1,078,465, an increase of $327,381 over the net of $751,084 reported for 1935.
John L. Lewis moved into the transportation field tonight, granting a request of the Transport Workers Union for affiliation with his Committee for Industrial Organization.

Pensioned On his own application: SERGEANT--John H. Feeley, 101st Precinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed Aug. 12, 1903. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN--Eugene J. Leonard, from 10th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in District Attorney's office, New York County, for 6 days.

South Africa's Davis Cup tennis team took a 2-1 lead over New Zealand today by winning the doubles match of their second-round European zone series. H. G. Farquharson and Vernon G. Kirby defeated C. E. Malfroy and E. D. Andrews of New Zealand, 7-5, 6-2, 6-2.

Jamaica, top-rung holder in the Queens P. S. A. L. race, barely defeated the Bryant nine, next-to-lastplace team, 2 to 1, at Bradley Oval, Long Island City, yesterday. A double by Red Diefentohl in the sixth drove in the winning Jamaica run. The victors now have won nine of their ten circuit games. Bryant has won only one out of eight.

The emergency board appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate the dispute between the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks and the International Longshoremen's Association, which threatened to cause a strike of 25,000 railway clerks on railroads in this area, resumed public hearings yesterday at the Bar Building, 34 West Fortyfourth Street, with little indications of progress toward an adjustment.

Characterizing Mayor La Guardia as "a gentleman with a non-partisan psychosis," who compelled his few Republican appointees to retire ostensibly from political activity but permitting his Socialist appointees to continue political activities "ad lib.," Jacob A. Livingston, former Brooklyn Republican leader, declared last night that defeat of the Mayor for the Republican nomination was essential for the preservation of the party in New York City.

The five-atory flat accommodating ten families, at 261 West 130th Street, has been sold by Elsie Weser to the Tenement Reconstruction Corporation, Irving L. Stone, president. Assessed at $21,000; the building is on a plot 25 by 100 feet.

The Brownell bill, which provides for the release of certain covenants and conditions affecting grants of land under water, and which recently became law when the Governor affixed his signature to it, is termed by Paul H. Fairchild,

A meeting of protest against the shilving by President Roosevelt of the Miller-Tydings bill will be held tonight at the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the Allied Retail Federation of New York State, it was announced here yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. William P. Taylor, rector emeritus of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, East Orange, and for many years a leader in movements to obtain employment for aging workers, died here of a heart attack in the Hospital of St. Barnabas this morning. Dr. Taylor, who had been a cardiac patient at the hospital for several months, was in his seventieth year.

Andrew Jackson High School, the new $2,500,000 building for which ground was broken at 114th Avenue and Cross Island Boulevard, St. Albans, on Nov. 18, 1935, was opened yesterday without ceremony, with 2,500 students registered.

The Nashville Banner published a statement today signed by members of the editorial department in which they said that no Newspaper Guild chapter would be organized and that they would retain "the principles of independent men."

Ruling inadmissible testimony or a detective who said Joseph Potter, when dying, had identified a photograph of Michael Piccardo as the man who had shot him, Queens County Judge Thomas Downs ordered a jury yesterday to acquit Piccardo of first-degree murder.

Investigations of the general tax collection situation and the applicability of present internal revenue laws, conducted by Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, in New York City, were productive of such results that studies in other parts of the country will be made, Secretary Morgenthau said today.

The engagement of Miss Marion Dorothy Steel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph George Steel of this city,. to William Frederick Gross Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Gross, also of-this city, has been announced by her parents.

The arrival here of Vincent York, chairman of the board of the Mexican Railway, and members of the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico marks the resumption of 'discussions here on a settlement of Mexico's funded and railroad debt which President Lazaro Cardenas insists must be arranged jointly.

Intercoastal lumber shippers have asked the Federal Maritime Commission to establish a special bureau to deal with the problems of that trade, under the supervision of a man who is acquainted with intercoastal shipping, it was learned yesterday.

The annual report of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $1,711,867 after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.

The combination of improved weather in the South and weak outside markets brought about a decline of $1 a bale in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, with net losses of 15 to 20 points. After a comparatively steady opening, selling pressure followed a break in both Liverpool and Alexandria and July lost 23 points before the list met resistance and recovered a few points in final dealings.

The Duke of Connaught, 87-year-old great uncle of King George VI, will see the coronation procession from his bed. He was carried from a train to a waiting ambulance at Waterloo station upon his arrival from the country today.
Stones from the birthplaces of members of the royal family are enclosed in the base of a monument to be unveiled Wednesday to commemorate the coronation. The stones, donated by S. J.

The Eighth Annual Fontainebleau Alumni Exhibition opened yesterday at the Argent Galleries. Some two-score artists and sculptors are represented by oils, watercolors and sculpture. In the rear gallery architectural projects and photographs of finished architectural work are also on display.

The stock market here opened today the fourday trading week quiet, with a generally dull tendency. Gilt-edge issues were firm, while demand for German bonds furnished the only activity in the foreign group.

John Drayton, who returned to Boston today after a week-end here, plans to spend July and August in Europe with John Roosevelt, son of the President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. They will return here after a tour in eight countries.
The Maritime Commission will advertise soon to charter for a one-year period the five government-owned steamship lines which are now operated by four managing agents.
A certain liveliness is apparent among the chancelleries of Central Europe, resulting largely from the backing or initiative of Italy and Germany.

Fifteen strikers of the Tilo Roofing Company paid $7.45 costs each when arraigned in court this morning. The men were found guilty of trespassing and fined $25 and costs, with the fine suspended. Leo Melanson, arrested at the same time, was fined $5 and costs for breach of the peace.

Six persons, among whom was a woman, were killed, and six others were wounded severely and one slightly in the Croat township of Senj on the Adriatic coast yesterday in a dispute between Croat Nationalists and the police.

Substantial lowering of the Treasury's cash balance has been accomplished in accordance with an agreement worked out with the Federal Reserve Board just before the reserve requirements of the member banks; were increased to prevent possible credit inflation, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.
John Shimkonis of Andover turned in two of the best rounds of his competitive career to capture medal honors in the New England trials for the national P. G. A. championship at Metacomet today.

United States CHAUFFEUR-$1,200 to $1,500 a year. Applications must be on file with the manager, Second United States Civil Service District, Federal Building, Christopher St., New York, N. Y., not later than May 14. Examination to fill vacancies in the Federal Classified Service in New York City and Vicinity.
Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral, Kentucky Derby winner, arrived here today, apparently in excellent shape for the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.
It is pleasant to see the year 1929 coming back into good repute. Every day brings some statement about the highest

A hearing was called today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for May 21 on an application by the Phelps Dodge Corporation for exemption as a holding company under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

Dr. Elmer K. Bolton, chemical director of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., has been elected a director of the American Chemical Society to succeed Dr. Frank C. Whitmore of Pennsylvania State College, who will become president of the society on Jan. 1, 1938.

Eight residential plots in the Randall Manor section of West New Brighton, Staten Island, property of the trustees of Sailors Snug Harbor, have been sold recently, according to a report from Cornelius G. Kolff, Inc.. agent.

Department store sales for April were 4 per cent higher than for the corresponding month a year ago and for the first four months of 1937 exceeded the January-April period of 1936 by 12 per cent, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This was on the basis of 515 stores reporting from 255 leading cities of the United States.
State police were sent-to Perkasie, Bucks County, today by Governor Earle as reports spread that Philadelphia hosiery workers were on their way to picket the plant of the Perkasie Silk Mills, Inc.

Canada, from coast to coast, is blossoming out in patriotic colors and symbolic decorations which, coupled with ceremony and display, will culminate Wednesday night in a burst of pyrotechnics and bonfires that will gird the Continent in a swiftly growing belt of flame.
Two women died in the Dobbs Ferry Hospital today from injuries received when an automobile in which they were riding last night collided with two other cars on the Saw Mill River Parkway here.

Miss Mary S. Francis, retired Episcopal missionary among the Indians of South Dakota, died yesterday at the Home of Incurables. Her age was 90. A native of New York, she started in 1880 to teach Indian girls at St. Mary's Boarding School on the Santee Agency in Nebraska, which then was included in the Missionary District of South Dakota.

The outside interest in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here today was light- with the market declining moderately in sympathy with the weakness in futures in Liverpool and with corn. Owing to the holi.day in Winnipeg and reports of rains over -the week-end in parts of the Winter wheat belt and the. government report due after the close professionals were not disposed to operate freely.

In the presence of Charles A. Davila, Rumanian Minister to Washington, who attended a gathering of some 500 Rumanians and Rumanian-Americans in celebration of Rumania's sixtieth anniversary of independence last night at the Essex House, the Fascist salute was given by a young man while the Rumanian national anthem was played and the audience stood at attention.

The signing of an agreement between the Amalgamated Clothing Workers and the Friedman-Harry Marks Clothing Company of Richmond, Va., one of the five concerns involved in the recent decision of the Supreme Court upholding the Wagner Labor Relations Act, was announced yesterday by Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated.

We who belong to a great nation that has from its beginnings relegated kings and queens to games of checkers and chess can hardly believe in these thrilling pre-coronation days that we haven't followed Alice right through the looking glass.

Edgar Hoover said today that Federal agents had identified Alfred Power, held with Robert Suhay at Kansas City on charges of killing W. W. Baker, special agent, at Topeka, Kan., April 16, as Glen John Applegate of West Toledo, Ohio.

Eugene C. Casey, retired police lieutenant, who was the city's first bicycle patrolman and organizer of the motor-cycle division, died yesterday at his home, 85 Clarkson Avenue, Brooklyn, in his sixty-fifth year.

Undiscouraged by a cold, stiff wind, members of the Australian and American Davis Cup teams went through their first workouts at Forest Hills yesterday in preparation for the final-round tie to be held in the stadium of the West Side Tennis Club May 29, 30 and 31.

The Civil Service Choral Society extended an invitation to prospective members yesterday in announcing the second series of rehearsals at Washington Irving High School, starting at 6 o'clock this evening.

Two of the four favored entrants were eliminated and the top-seeded singles star was extended as play in the twenty-second annual Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis championship tournament began on the courts of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the National City Bank, who was acquitted four years ago of income tax fraud relating to returns he filed for 1929 and 1930, must pay the government $728,709 on his income for the former year, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals held yesterday in a unanimous decision.

The first day's public auction of the art collection and furnishings at Inisfada, the Tudor-Elizabethan country residence at Manhasset, L. I., of the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, now the wife of William J. Babington Macaulay, was attended by more than 2,000 persons.
Various British offices in this city will be closed tomorrow in observance of- Coronation Day, according to an announcement made yesterday by the office of the British Consul General.

The belief that the State is superior to, wiser than, and more benevolent than the individual was branded as a superstition yesterday by John W.Davis, 1924 Democratic candidate for President, in an address at a luncheon of the Municipal Bond Club of New York at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it had approved the application of the Illinois Central Railroad to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for an additional loan of $10,000,000 for the purpose of retiring its 4 1/2 per cent gold notes due on June 1.

Four parcels of realty in the Bronx will be sold by the city at auction in the Hotel Commodore at noon on May 27. The properties and their upset prices are as follows: Northeast corner of 206th Street and the Grand Concourse, 16,477 square feet, $72,500.

An investigation by the Maritime Commission of passenger rates between the United States and Puerto Rico developed a detailed study of the income, passenger and freight carrying and other operation details of the New York and Puerto Rico Steamship Company yesterday at the Federal Building, 45 Broadway.
The House Flood Control Committee approved today a resolution requiring army engineers to- submit to Congress a comprehensive national plan for controlling floods on all major rivers.

Mayor La Guardia launched a scathing attack against the Transit Commission yesterday for its rejection of the $436,000,000 transit unification plan negotiated and sponsored by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. In effect he charged it with "sham," "fraud" and "misrepresentation" and accused it of having "unleashed" its adverse report only after the adjournment of the Legislature and with the permission of "the political bosses."

Crack Scotland Yard detectives started a final check-up tonight of the thousands of holders of seats along the route of the coronation procession. It was admittedly too big a job to inquire into each case, but every ticket agency has been required to furnish the names and addresses of purchasers so as to permit investigation, of those who may be -suspected of intending to create a disturbance.

At their annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church in West Fortyeighth Street, 800 members of the American Federation of Actors chose -regular and honorary officers for the next three years and named eight councilmen to serve for four years.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange went through the formality yesterday of electing a president, a treasurer, ten members of the governing committee, two govearning members and a trustee of the gratuity fund.

Representative Patman of Texas appeared before a House Judiciary subcommittee today to urge its favorable consideration of his bill to outlaw reciprocal trade agreements or contracts in private industry.

Two distinct price trends characterized quiet trading yesterday in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. The persistent strength in United States Government obligations and the main body of underlying corporate issues was overshadowed by the pronounced weakness which developed in many seeondary and convertible bonds.
Mrs. Lawrence Moore of Dobbs Ferry entertained at luncheon yesterday in the garden of the Ambassador for Miss Ruth. Wagner and Miss Challis Walker, who will sail on Friday aboard the Ile de France.

The twenty-four-day Spring meeting of the Westchester Racing Association, which opened this afternoon at Belmont Park, was attended by several hundred members of the society of the north and south shore Summer colonies and also of New York, many of whom returned this morning from Louisville, where they witnessed the running of the Kentucky Derby.

Commander Charles E. Rosendahl, commanding officer of the Naval Air Station here and the outstanding American expert on lighterthan-air craft, testified at the opening of the official investigation today that he was completely mystified by the origin of the fire that destroyed the German dirigible Hindenburg with a loss of thirtyfive lives last Thursday night.

Five students representing Glen Cove High School at Glen Cove, L. I., were declared the winners today of the intellectual competition held at the Nassau Collegiate Centre here Saturday. Students from thirteen Nassau County high schools were examined for two hours on their knowledge of contemporary national and international affairs. Woodmere High School ranked second and Oyster Bay High School took third place.

Everything from bars of chocolate to pocketsize bottles of whisky is being stored up by a million people tonight in preparation for long hours of waiting to see their large or small bit of the coronation pageantry.

Postal officials announced today the advance of 392 fourth class post offices to third class status, effective July 1. A department spokesman said: "It is an almost unprecedented number of promotions, and more accurately than any other index, reflects the return of prosperity to small communities."

The American flying boat to be used for service between New York and Bermuda is now at the Sikorsky plant at Bridgeport. Known as the U. S. A. Bermuda Clipper, she is of the S-42B type, powered with four Hornet engines.

Lawrence Mullen, one of the five gunmen who held up Barney's clothing establishment in lower Seventh Avenue on the night of Jan. 2, was sentenced by General Sessions Judge Freschi yesterday to fifteen years in Sing Sing on his guilty plea. Fred Dunn,

Three youths who were attempting to row a sixteen-foot boat from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to the Atlantic Highlands fishing grounds were rescued from the Narrows, near Fort Hamilton, yesterday afternoon when their craft capsized.

Patrolman James Murray of Emergency Squad 3, captured an escaped pet raccoon today and came out with a badly bitten thumb. The raccoon escaped from the home of Mrs. William E. Blackledge of 286 Barrow Street.
The National Electricity Syndicate will administer Quebec's first experiment in public ownership of hydroelectric utilities, according to a bill- distributed to members of the Legislature today.

Among the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday was one for 32,000 square feet in the Lincoln Building, 60 East Fortysecond Street, taken by the Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York, which will move its main office from 33 West Forty-second Street.

Big Ray Volpi blazed his high fast ball past Bob Kemelhor in the final frame with the bases loaded and two out to give the Manhattan College nine a 2-0 triumph over Brooklyn College at Manhattan Beach yesterday in one of the best games of the metropolitan intercollegiate campaign this season. It was Manhattan's eighth victory in ten starts.
Several leases of large space in the insurance district to firms in the underwriting and allied lines were reported yesterday by Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc.

The miraculous escape of tiny Werner Franz, 12-year-old cabin boy on the Hindenburg, was accidentally revealed here today when Commander Charles E. Rosendahl took officials of the investigating board to the wreckage.
Considerable rioting occurred in the city of Veracruz tonight when members of the crew of the Spanish steamship Motormar were on shore leave.

The forSnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for April 30 showed that the gold reserve ratio to notes in circulation was 134.08 per cent on April 30, against 135.27 per cent, on April 15.

Ancil Foster Haines, vice president and general manager of the Transpacific American Mail Line, died yesterday at the age of 65. He had been ill since June. He was born in Champaign County, Ohio, and was graduated from Ohio Northern University.

Miss Barbara Root, daughter of Albert Keyes Root, was married to Walter Squires Hollister, son of Mrs. Richard D. Freeman of South Orange, N. J., and the late William Hollister, yesterday morning at the home of the bride's father, 277 Park Avenue.

Emphasizing that the credit of New York City is second only to that of the Federal Government, Lazard Freres Co., Inc., will issue today a detailed analysis in simplified form of the financial condition of the city, which is believed to be the first of its kind ever made.
The American Federation of Labor proposed today that President Roosevelt appoint a commission to devise methods of controlling prices.

The entire world is threatened with a rising death rate from physical strain brought about by the sun spot cycle, Dr. William F. Petersen of the University of Illinois College of Medicine declared today.

Many peeresses who will attend the coronation tomorrow are worrying over how to keep their heavy coronets in place during the long ceremonies in Westminster Abbey, the Dowager Marchioness of Reading said last night in a broadcast from London, heard here over a National Broadcasting Company network.
Announcement has been made by Mrs. Mary Bowne of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Aldage Bowne, to Homer van Beuren Joy of Morristown and Broadmoor, Colorado Springs.

The long service to Judaism of Dr..Stephen S. Wise and Federal Judge Julian W. Mack was hailed last night at a dinner of the merchandising council of the American Jewish Congress at the Hotel Astor. More than 1,000 persons were present.

One of the few elections that the New York Republicans are able to carry is that of the chairman of their State committee. They seem to give more zeal, attention and bad temper to this transaction than to any other.
A customs guard rummaging through holds of the Danish freighter Anna Maersk at Pier 18, Brooklyn, yesterday uncovered 1,200 ounces of prepared smoking opium hidden under piles of dunnage.
Harvard University alumni from all parts of the nation will come here Saturday and Sunday for the fortieth anniversary meeting of the Associated Harvard Clubs.

All WPA workers employed In private hospitals and other institutions not supported by tax funds are to be transferred to other projects, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator here, announced last night.

For the second time this year weekly failures exceeded those for the corresponding week last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. For the week ended May 6, the number of defaults was 177 compared with 183 the week before and with 171 for the corresponding week in 1936.

The Senators scored three runs in the ninth inning today to keep Rookie Julio Bonetti of the Browns from a shutout, but lost to the Browns, 6 to 3. For eight innings Bonetti allowed two hits, but he weakened in the final frame and the Senators' tallies came on three hits, one a double by Jonathan Stone, a walk and Al Simmons's fly.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that payment of $11.375 on each $1,000 bond is being made on State of Maranhao (Brazil) external secured sinking fund 7 per cent gold bonds due in 1958, on surrender of the May 1, 1937, coupon.

Mrs. Raymond Platt of this city and Norwalk, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jeanne Comstock Platt, to Clifford Arthur Roche, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Roche of this city.

Senator Steiwer, keynoter at the 1936 Republican convention, offered a constitutional amendment today providing that candidates for President and Vice President be selected through primaries in the States.

Automobile output continued to gain last week when a sharp decline was seasonal, and the adjusted index spurteC to 132.5, its highest point since the week ended July 27, 1929. It was 118.6 (revised) for the previous week and 114.1 for the week ended May 8, 1936.
The Deapartment of Agriculture announced c today that this year's harvest of Winter wheat, as indicated by coneditions on May 1, would be 654,295000 bushels. A month ago 656,019,000 were indicated.

The Three D's Farm's Gin Daisy, a gray daughter of Royal Ford-Gin Rickey, qualified handsomely .for her engagement in Saturday's renewal of the Kentucky Oaks when she beat a fine field of 3-year-old fillies in today's Colleens' Purse at Churchill Downs.

Mike Belloise of the Bronx, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as the world's featherweight champion, made it two in a row over Johnny Cabello, Puerto Rican boxer, in the main bout at the St. Nicholas arena last night.
The Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath was awarded to Sir Hubert Gough, wartime commander of the Fifth Army in France, in the King's honors list today.

Professor Davide Supino, economist and a native of this city, died here today at the age of 86. Professor Supine held the Chair of Commercial Law at Pisa University, a post to which he was appointed at the age of 27.

A baseball millennium arrived at Ebbets Field yesterday. While 5,920 Flatbush fans watched with unbelieving eyes, Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers played nine innings of errorless ball, performed the unusual feat behind Van Lingle Mungo, and trounced Onkel Franz Frisch's Gas House Gang, the Cardinals, 8--2. Incidentally, the Flatbush boys moved into fifth place.

Registering three tallies in the first period and another pair in the second, the Blue riders, led by the seven-goal Terence Preece, defeated the veteran Ivor Balding's Red poloists, 7 to 5, at Preece Field today.

More than 50,000 building service employes in 3,000 apartment, loft and office buildings in Manhattan received wage increases and vacations with pay in an arbitration award announced yesterday by former Justice Frank C. Laughlin, acting as arbitrator under the existing agreement between the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations and the Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union.

Citizens in fifteen cities in New Jersey will go to the polls tomorrow to cast their ballots for candidates seeking election as City. Commissioners. The polls will open at 8 A. M. and close at 9 P. M. (daylight-saving time) in each of the cities.
An unpartitioned, integrated power development" for the Bonneville Dam was urged by Secretary Ickes today before the House Rivers and Harbors Committee.
After four days of aimless manoeuvring, Joe McCarthy's Yankee clipper finally squared away to windward today and provided at once an eye-filling spectacle.

DiScoveries which push back the earliest history of civilization an estimated 500 years and show the painted pottery peoples of ancient Mesopotamia to have been as advanced in some respects culturally as European civilization of the Middle Ages, more than 5,000 years later, were reported today at the Universitv of Pennsylvania Museum.

The coronation of George VI will be broadcast internanationally tomorrow beginning at 5 A. M., Eastern daylightsaving time. The New York stations in the globe-girdling circuit will be: WEAF, WOR, WJZ, WABC, WINS and WNYC, The radio time table. for the event based on New York time follows with the London time in parentheses:

The William J. Gaynor Junior High. School, described by Arthur S. Tuttle, State WPA Director, as the only one of its kind in the world, was dedicated yesterday morning. It is the first unit of the nearly finished $12,000,000 Williamsburg housing project.
State Referee Isaac Wolfe recommended to the Superior Court today that a divorce be granted to Mrs. Lucille Cameron Roberts Engs from Samuel F. Engs 2d of Darien on charges of cruelty.

Madame Lucie, 47-year-old Paris seamstress, has taken steps to get an injunction against the coronation of King George VI on the ground she is the eldest child of the late Duke of Clarence by a secret marriage with an unnamed sister of the former German Kaiser.

Bucky Walters limited the Reds to four hits today as the Phillies ended a five-game losing streak by pounding out a 10-to-3 victory. The Reds bunched two of their four hits with two errors to tally two runs in the ninth. Their other blows were Lee Grissom's single in the third and Goodman's double in the sixth.
Dr. Harry Yandell Benedict, president of the University of Texas, died unexpectedly here today. He fell in a street adjoining the university campus as he started to step into an automobile.

Willie Mosconi and Erwin Rudolph broke even in the opening play of their twelve block pocket billiard match at the Strand Academy yesterday. Rudolph won 12570, in fifteen innings, then lost, 125-59, in five frames.
Declaring that a situation similar to that preceding the Russo-Japanese War existed, the Japanese Navy urged all Japan today to rise 'again to the defense of the empire if challenged.

In the last two days there have been a number of political developments. President Getulio Vargas has returned to Rio de Janeiro to be near the political arena after again proving that he is Brazil's strong man.

The 1929 income tax return of Pierre S. du Pont, placed in evidence in the old Postoffice Building here yesterday, revealed that he realized capital gains of more than $35,000,000 by selling stocks in the boom market several months before it crashed.
President Roosevolt has been seconded by Secretary Hull for the Nobel Peace Prize. The Secretary said today that he had "definitely and unequivocally eliminated himself by that action."

In a report critical of the activities of managements, protective committees, bankers and lawyers in reorganization proceedings, the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today to Congress adoption of legislation intended to bring about greater "democratization" by curbing and controlling powers of those interests which, it contended, have occupied the dominant position.

The Hellenic Orthodox Church of this city, home of the only Greek congregation in Monroe County, was swept by a fire which caused damage estimated at $20,000 last night. Flames were leaping through the roof before the fire was discovered a few minutes after 10 o'clock.

Funeral services will be held at noon tomorrow for George Ashbridge Rhoads, 76-year-old senior member of J. E. Rhoads Sons, and civic leader, who died Saturday night in Delaware Hospital of a heart ailment. Services will take place at Wilmington Friends Meeting House. Burial will be private.

President Roosevelt was heading up the Texas coast today on the last day at sea of his fishing vacation. He will land here tomorrow and go to Fort Worth, where he will spend Wednesday with his second son, Elliott, who lives on a ranch near there.
Ranger, which is to be christened and launched tomorrow, is not to be the streak of shining silver luster that was planned.
Alix is showing her customary beautiful collection. Drapery continues to be its main theme, but it is less extreme in many of the daytime models.

The income of a $250,000 trust fund and pay increases totaling nearly $35,000 were given today to 375 men and women by the Elliott Addressing Machine Company of Cambridge when the employes threatened to strike and thus ruin a record of fifty-five years of perfect relationship between employer and employe.

A story of the pulpwood magazines will be told by Harold Brain?? Hersey, veteran editor, in 'Pulpwood Editor," which Stokes rill publish on June 3. The pulps lave been the rough cradle of many vell-known writers, and the origin of some large publishing fortunes ?? have been little written of.

Mayor La Guardia and Alfred E. Smith were among eight former presidents of the Board of Aldermen who were entertained at dinner last night in the Hotel Pierre by Aldermanic President William F. Brunner.

No joint meeting of the Pittsburgh Association of Purchasing Agents and the Pittsburgh chapter of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel was held in Pittsburgh in mid-April, as stated incorrectly in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 17.

LOLLING back in a deep chair, Karl Johann Grimm, the black-haired, swarthy-complexioned Keeper of the Cubs, hooked his thumbs under his suspenders and said: "Who me? Aber, nicht! I'm all through as a player. Ja, wohl! Oh, I go up there and take a couple of swings once in a while in practice. Then I stagger off to a quiet spot, sit down and wait for things to settle back in place again."

The Senate considered its unanimous consent calendar, received a bill to establish a mandatory "cashand-carry" neutrality policy and legislative recommendations of the Securities and Exchange Commission, heard Senator Nye urge an investigation of espionage activities and adjourned at 2:26 P. M. until noon tomorrow.
The Indians won their fifth straight game today behind Earl Whitehill and Joe Heving, topping the Red Sox, 6-5, in eleven innings. The victory kept Cleveland in a firstplace tie with the Athletics.

Station W of the New York Post Office moved to its new quarters at 127-135 West Eighty-third Street yesterday morning and opened its windows to the public at the regular business hour. A few hours later the new brick structure, which is ninth in the program of providing seventeen new postal station buildings in the city, was dedicated by Postmaster Albert Goldman.

Sale of the Belmont Theatre, on to an irregular plot 56.8'by 100.5 feet at 121-125 West Forty-eighth Street, featured the foreclosure sales yesterday in the Vesey Street auction rooms. The property was sold on a bid of $100,000 to the Bank for Savings in the City of New York

Police Commissioner Valentine in dedicating the new Floyd Horton Youth Center, at 12 West 108th Street last night held out as an example to the youth of the neighborhood the record of the police hero for whom the center is named.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities on May 5 shows decreases for the week of $213,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, $167,000,000 in balances with domestic banks,

Tage P. Sylvan, who retired in 1934 as a vice president of the New York Telephone Company and then served for two years as president of the Franklin Society for HomeBuilding and Savings, New York, died here today at his home, 99 Central Avenue, after a brief illness of heart disease. He was born in Chicago sixty-four years ago.

The State of California has invited bankers to submit bids on June 24 for a new issue of $3,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds. The bonds will mature serially from Feb. 1, 1939, through 1950. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who is to sail aboard the liner Conte di Savoia on Saturday for his first visit abroad, denied yesterday that his trip was undertaken at the bebest of the Vatican.

Central Maine Power CompanyFor 1936: Net income $1,650,315 after interest, depreciation, taxes and other expenses and charges, which, after preferred dividend charges, was equal to $2.82 a common share, compared with a net of $1,305,750, or 7 cents a share, in 1935.

Major George L. Berry, president of the International Pressmen and Assistants Union, coordinator for Industrial Cooperation and president of Labor's Non-Partisan League, was sworn in today as junior Senator from Tennessee a few minutes after the Senate met at noon.

Its serious financial problems eased by the public's increasing interest in concerts last season and the improvement in business, the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, sponsor of the country's oldest symphony orchestra, has decided to expand its program for the coming season, it was announced at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon at Steinway Hall.

Frequent thefts of coronation decorations from house and street standards were disclosed by the police today at the trial of a man accused of stealing a wooden shield and five flags valued at [Pound]1 from the South London Building.

The Harry Vardon Memorial Cup, named in honor of the late British golfer, will be awarded each year to the professional player making the best record in tournaments conducted each year by the Professional Golfers' Association of America, it was announced yesterday.

The motorman of a Queensbound Independent subway train stepped out of his cab several times last night to shoo away a lost white Spitz dog that insisted on trotting along the subway tracks from the Forty-second Street station toward Queens.

New pioneering journeys into the interior of the human brain, which bring back an entirely new picture of the manner in which six quadrillion living dynamos play in unison the symphony of life and thought, mind and matter, were described here today before the opening sessions of the ninety-third annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

General Sessions Judge Donnellan in sentencing Ira Fox, an antique dealer, to an indeterminate penitentiary term yesterday for criminally receiving $1,178 in Currier Ives prints which had been stolen from an art gallery last Winter, remarked:

Mrs. Charlotte Small Babcock, for many years active in musical activities at Carnegie Hall, New York, died here last night at the home of her sister, Mrs. Simeon H. Rollinson, widow of a former Mayor of West Orange.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Cave of Paducah, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Tyler Cave, to Lyndon Arnold Smith Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashley Fly Wilson of Montclair, N. J.

A world peace prize for Rosika Schwimmer, pacifist and social worker, who will celebrate her sixtieth birthday next September, will be created, it was announced yesterday by Lola Maverick Lloyd, chairman of an international committee for the award, at the Smith College Club, 34 East Fiftieth Street.

Steel operations in the United States are scheduled at 91.2 per cent of capacity this week, as compared with 91.0 per cent last week, a gain of .2 point and .2 per cent, the American Iron Steel Institute reports.

James Brady, 9 years old, who won prominence last Summer when President Roosevelt sent him a new pair of shoes, confessed today, according to the police, that he pushed James S. Tighe Jr., 7, to his death in the Schuylkill River here yesterday because "he was a sissy."
The Rev. Peter Francis Egan, pastor of the St. Francis de Sales Catholic Church, died today in St. Mary's Hospital, Passaic, after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

Delegates to the International Ladies Garment Workers Union convention who favor closer affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization will lead ?? fight to have the convention pledge itself to make a final and clearcut decision on the inter-union issue, it was indicated this evening after a preliminary caucus of the group. Another meeting will be held tomorrow.
Notifications putting minimumi resale prices in. effect under the Feld-Crawford fair-trade law were received here yesterday by local stores on a variety of cosmetics and on one liquor brand.

Representatives of nine Southern States tonight appointed three subcommittees to seek from the Interstate Commerce Commission revision of Southern freight rates. They voted also to raise $100,000 for the campaign.

Irving Sacks, 55 years old, described by Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson as the "wealthiest garnishee racketeer in the country," was found guilty by Justices Bayes, Flood and Curran in Special Sessions late yesterday afternoon on charges growing out of the recent investigation of the garnishee racket affecting policemen, firemen and other city employes.

Tallying a run in the seventh inning to even the score, Fordham's freshman baseball team maintained its undefeated record by holding the St. John's University cub nine to a 4-4 tie in a loosely played contest at Fordham Field yesterday.

The Montreal Royals were outhit by the Baltimore Orioles today, but bunched three of their blows in the sixth inning for the runs that gave them a 2-1 triumph over the International League tailenders.

Stocks weakened and closed lower in quiet trading, United States Steel again below par; turnover, 779,630 shares. United States Government bonds. higher, convertible and traction issues lower; transactions, $7,518,000.

A merger of the Lawyers Title Corporation and the New York Title Insurance Company was proposed again yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, in a petition filed with Supreme Coyrt Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

Following is the text of Mayor La Guardia's radio address yesterday in reply to the Transit Commission's report: The Transit Commission has finally been unleashed by the political bosses and has been permitted to make its alleged "report" after the Legislature has been adjourned.

Leaders of John L. Lewis's steel organizing campaign were following a policy of watchful waiting tonight in face of a union vote to strike Wednesday at the Aliquippa (Pa.) and Pittsburgh works of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation unless the company signs a union contract.

James W. Gerard, special United States envoy to the coronation, was a guest at tonight's state banquet at. Buckingham Palace wearing ceremonial knee breeches for the first time at a state function. He was seated in a place of honor at King George's own table.

Factory workers in four German provinces will receive a regular medical inspection and must in future carry a "health pass" under a plan to be carried out by the German Labor Front with the idea of preserving and increasing productive capacity.

Jake Powell, outfielder of the Yankees, who had been ill here with a mild case of appendicitis, was discharged today from Providence Hospital. He will go to New York to consult with the New York team physician regarding an operation advised by Dr. William Keane, team physician of the Tigers.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn handed down a decision yesterday ordering the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 175 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, to pay $31,504, with interest from 1933, to Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, as rehabilitator of the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company, 26 Court Street Broonnklvn.

John Valentine Dittemore, former director of the Christian Science Church, who brought to a climax a bitter controversy with the other directors by leading an opposition movement n 1924, died yesterday afternoon in the faith of the "mother church."

Tonight's new proceedings go by the name of "Orchids Preferred," which will sing and dance at the Imperial under the sponsorship of Charles H. Abramson. The book and lyrics are Fred Herendeen's, the music Dave Stamper's, and among the principal performers are Eddie Foy Jr., Benay Venuta,

Thousands of toys, brooms, mops and articles of wearing apparel made by blind workers were put on sale yesterday afternoon after a luncheon at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, to open the twenty-third annual-"week for the blind."

The two new viscounts created yesterday by King George VI on the eve of his coronation acknowledge long years of service to the empire by two men of widely differing characters and aims. After many years in the storm and stress of politics, both automatically become members of the House of Lords, to continue their service as elder statesmen of Great Britain.
Former President Carlos Ibafiez returned today from Argentina after an exile of nearly six years and thousands of his friends and supporters welcomed him at Los Cerrillos Airport.

Manhattan's freshman crew will row in the 150-pound cub race to be held at Princeton Saturday in connection with the varsity lightweight test for the Joe Wright Challenge Cup, Coach Allen Walz announced yesterday.

BRONSON ALCOTT, you may or may not remember, was a Transcendentalist pundit and reformer who died in 1888 after a long career of debt, fancy thinking and plain living. Some of his contemporaries in Concord and elsewhere held him almost in awe and regarded him as one of the great men of the time.

Forging down the center of the Widener chute as steadily as a vessel under way, Preeminent, from Kentucky, won the $4,675 Toboggan Handicap yesterday as Belmont Park opened with a society-sprinkled throng of 10,000 in attendance. The victory was another score by young Duval Headley, trainer of his uncle's string which includes the mighty sprinter, Whopper.
Former Kaiser Wilhelm sent a message of sympathy to the Zeppelin works today, saying he was deeply grieved by the loss of the Hindenburg but that the airship building must be continued.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Leslie Morris, pastor emeritus of the Morningside Presbyterian Church and secretary of the home missions committee of the Southern Presbyterian General Assembly for thirty years before his retirement, died tonight. Dr. Morris was born in Abbeville, S. C., 82 years ago.
One of the measures slaughtered in the Assembly in the last day of the legislative session was the Joseph bill which would have authorized the creation of mortgage banks in New York State.

The coronation ceremony in West minster Abbey tomorrow will begir at 6:15 A. M. New York time. This review of the proceedings is printed today for the benefit of those who may wish to listen to the broad casts, which will be carried by lead ing American chains.

The refinery and tank farm property of the Warner Quinlan Company at Linden, N. J., is worth $853,191, John Fedor, real estate broker, testified yesterday in reorganization proceedings for that company conducted before John E. Joyce, referee.

The church has its back to the wall today, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, told 750 women representing twentythree different Protestant denominations at a "May luncheon" yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

George C. .Long, for several years vice president of the Phoenix Insurance Company, Hartford, was elected this afternoon president of the company, to succeed Edward C. Milligan, who died ten days ago at Philadelphia.
About 100 persons attended a private showing of the Children's Science Fair at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday as the guests of the American Institute, sponsors of the fair.
Ralph DePalma tried out the pacemaking car for this year's 500-mile race today to see how it compared with the speedsters he used to drive. He pulled up well pleased.
The warring syndicates and labor organizations in Catalonia have just aired their differences in a tragic manner. They have now apparently seen a new light and order again prevails.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana will launch its Summer advertising campaign for Red Crown gasoline on May 18, when full-page color copy appears in a number of large newspapers and smaller space in the company's list of nearly 1,600 daily and weekly newspapers.

Operations in the first quarter of the Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $3,471,629, after deductions for depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges. After dividend requirements- on the 6 per cent preferred stock the profit is equivalent 'to 40 cents each on 6,563,377 no-par shares of common stock.

Nominees for 3. P. Morgan Co. are credited with holdings of Erie Railroad stock second in amount only to those held by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway in the report for 1936 of the Erie to the Interstate Commerce Commission, made public yesterday.
Jimmy (Ripper) Collins turned golfer momentarily yesterday and, with a perfect pitch shot into the stands, gave the Cubs a victory over the Giants before a gathering of 5,125.

Declaring that no outside person or group had the right to interfere with the "contractual relationship between tenants and landlord," Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan yesterday granted the application of the 2,802 Olinville Avenue Corporation to restrain the Tenants Protective League and its members from interfering with property rights. The league was ordered to post a $250 bond.

Erickson Norman Nichols, retired member of the New York Stock Exchange who served with the Rough Riders in the war with Spain, died here suddenly today in the United Hospital of an intestinal hemorrhage. He, was born in New York seventy-one years ago.

Wilhelm Henie, father of Sonja Henie, screen actress and former world champion skater, died at a hospital here yesterday of a blood clot on the lung. At his bedside were his wife and daughter. Mr. Henie, a native of Norway, recently had filed his first citizenship papers here.

There will be so many vacant chairs when the University of Goettingen celebrates its bicentenary on June 30 that the absentees will be more conspicuous than those present. Regrets are rolling in not only from the universities of the English-speaking world but of Holland and other free countries.
Assemblyman Maurice Whitney, Rensselaer Republican, urged today that Governor Lehman summon a special session to enact "satisfactory" milkcontrol legislation.

The courts of the country should be left "free and untrammeled" to perform their constitutional duty, Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division said in an address last night at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

The Italian press gives prominence to a speech delivered by Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, Viceroy of Ethiopia, at Addis Ababa on the first anniversary of the Italian Empire in which he emphasized the difficulties with which Italians are confronted .there,

Last night's "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera House, the second of the Spring season, employed substantially the same cast as the first, with the exception of the two leading feminine roles. Lucy Monroe, a native New Yorker, was introduced to Metropolitan patrons in the part of Musetta; Hilda Burke sang Mimi.
Freddie Steele, middleweight champion, will risk his title for the third time tomorrow night when he clashes with Frankie Battaglia of Minneapolis in a fifteen-round bout in Civic Auditorium.
The Duke of Windsor's fiancee has a assumed her maiden name of Wallis Warfield, following legal action in London, her spokesman, Herman L. Rogers of New York, announced tonight.
King Zog of Albania has accepted an invitation to visit Italy as the guest of King Victor Emmanuel and is expected here before the end of the year.
Three lots in the Chappaqua Farms development at Chappaqua, Westchester County, have been sold to G. L. Werly, C. A. Wheeler and H. C. Hopkins, all of Long Island.

Plans filed yesterday by architects for new buildings included specifications for a three-story library building costing $200,000 for Manhattan College on Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, opposite 242d Street, the Bronx.
Otis Steel Company first mortgage sinking fund 43A per cent Series A bonds due in 1962 have been admitted to the list of the New York Stock Exchange.
Production of a new electric bulb, giving 10 per cent more light than the present lamp without using any more current, was reported today.

The May meeting of the New York State Safe Deposit Association will be held tomorrow in the Pennsylvania Hotel. Dinner at 6:15 P. M. will be followed by an open forum. The Chase National Bank has been appointed transfer agent for voting trust certificates of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company: common stock.

Improved retail trade last week found immediate reflection in the wholesale markets here yesterday. Summer merchandise was in stronger demand, both from buyers personally in the market and in the heavier mail received. The call for Summer dresses picked up, indicating that somewhat of a turn for the better may be developing in this industry.

Glenn L. Martin, who startled the world a quarter of a century ago with the first airplane flight over the open ocean, repeated his trip today. But this time, instead of the rickety contraption he flew in the original flight, a plane held together by hairpins and silk thread, he was pilot of another craft of his own design, the giant China Clipper, probably one of the most famous seaplanes in the world.

Hussey Hoeh, Inc., brokers, reported the following sales in Brooklyn: One-family houses at 4,122 Foster Avenue, for the Fulton Savings Bank, to Joseph G. Fallert; 3,623 Avenue P for Prosper Homes, Inc.,
A murder charge was brought today against Frank White, deputy sheriff, and charges of. shooting with intent to kill against White and two other deputies.

Sales of 11,573 cars and trucks by the Studebaker Corporation in April set an eight-year record, it was disclosed here yesterday. Paul G. Hoffman, president of the company, said a substantial part of the increased business was due to truck sales.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 9 in an article representing an interview with Professor Otto Stern of the Carnegie Institute of Technology on how hydrogen gas has been observed in the laboratory to explode spontaneously under certain conditions without the presence of any spark, it was incorrectly stated that Professor Stern had been connected with the Zeppelin Works.

Reports that counterfeit social security account cards were being presented as a means of identification by persons cashing checks prompted the Social Security Board yesterday to warn that such cards were to be used only for purposes of the social security program.

An award of $70,000 in a damage suit was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lewis. L. Fawcett in Brooklyn to Mrs. Pauline Frank, 43 years old, of 531 Dumont Avenue, Brooklyn, and her husband, Samuel.

Senator Gerald P. Nye charged in the Senate today that a group of Spanish "nationalists" in this country illegally to supply information to the General Franco forces were undermining the American Neutrality Law.

Heavy fighting continued today along almost the entire Basque "iron ring"--the last line of fortifications upon which Bilbao's defenders count to hold General Emilio Mola's Insurgent army outside the Basque capital.

A first-hand inspection of the waters of the Big Beaverkill has given Bill Newsom cause for rejoicing. It may be said that this veteran trout angler possesses a critical eye together with sound judgment, and his friends know his appraisals are accurate. It was therefore that the interviewer attempted to listen carefully to the informer's experience over the past week-end.

The alimony sit-down strike of Mrs. Genevieve Johnson ended late today when Chief of Police Orval Barr removed her from her father-inlaw's front lawn on a warrant charging her with creating a nuisance and obstructing traffic.

The New York University freshman nine blanked the N. Y. U. School of Education team, 15--0, at Ohio Field yesterday. Murray Wallberg and Harold Auer shared the pitching assignment for-the firstyear men and each gave only two hits, Wallberg going four of the seven frames. The victors punched across nine runs in the sixth. The score by innings:

Trainer R. A. Coward had to call for a volunteer to ride Reelon, a 59-to-1 shot, in the fifth and feature race at Narragansett Park today, before he could send the horse to the post to win by a length and pay $120.40, $34 and $13.10.

The Greater New York Safety Council announced yesterday the appointment of-a committee to select the winners of an essay contest on "A Practical Safety Program to Be Carried Out by an Employer for the Elimination of Home Accidents."
Aroused by what Broadway considers "the most dangerous threat of stage censorship ever passed in New York State," the component forces of the legitimate theatre are uniting to combat it.
The A. W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Trust disclosed today the acquisition of seven works of art for the collection of masterpieces which Andrew W. Mellon has presented to the nation.

Four Democratic Senators assailed President Roosevelt's court plan at a mass meeting here tonight a few hours after two of the national officers of The Defenders, sponsors of the gathering, had been arrested on charges of violating Pennsylvania's State Solicitation Act.
A daily report of all events transpiring in connection with each registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 hereafter will be released by the Securities and Exichange Commission.

Closed shop agreements with foursteamship companies were announced yesterday by the American Radio Telegraphists Association, an affiliate of the C. I. . Wage increases and shorter hours are features of the agreement. Negotia-: tions with other steamship companies are in progress, the union announced.
Following is the text of the summary of a letter written by Ambassador Dodd to Senators Glass, Bulkley and others, as published here today:

Several deals involving industrial and residential property in scattered sections of Long Island were reI ported yesterday. In Long Island City the two-story industrial building, on a plot 150 by 200 feet, running through Fortyfourth Street to Forty-fourth Avenue, was sold to the 21-30 Fortyfourth Avenue Corporation, K. L. Grennan, president.

Mrs. Martha Holden Hooper, long a leader in Brooklyn women's club and religious circles and Prominent in the fight for votes for women, died yesterday at her home, 96 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, after an eight-year illness. Her age was 87.

The Rev. Adalbert Malusecki, for fortythree years rector of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, which, with its 7,000 members, is one of the largest parishes in Pennsylvania, died here this evening, aged 76 years.
An appeal for support of the administration's trade policies was made to the Memphis Cotton Carnival today by Secretary Hull -in an address broadcast by the National Broadcasting Company.

If present labor legislation is permitted to continue unchecked our present capitalist, social and political system is in danger of imminent collapse, George E. Sokolsky, author and publicist, warned the opening session of the thirty-second annual convention of the Lithographers National Association, Inc., at the Greenbrier here today.

The Senate debated government economy, discussed the conference report on the second deficiency bill, received two compromise plans for the Court Bill, received the Vandenberg bill to transfer the administration of relief to the States,

A detailed Treasury exploration of the market transactions of Pierre S. du Pont, in an attempt to collect $781,794 additional income tax for 1929, was characterized yesterday by his attorney, James S. Y. Ivins, as a "fishing expedition."

A fiveyear program of improvements -to and expansion of its properties calling for expenditures aggregating $40,855,500 was revealed today by the Phelps Dodge Corporation in a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $20,285,000 of convertible debentures due on June 15, 1952, and an undetermined number of shares of $25par value capital stock to be reserved for conversion 'of the debentures.

Having demonstrated, to their own satisfaction at least, that they can snap a losing streak most any time they seriously get around to concentrating on the matter, our wavering Yankees promptly went through the motions of starting a new one today as they blew their series final to the White Sox, 7 to 2.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated May 8. CAPTAIN Workman, R. D., Chaplain Corps, staff of the commander of Battle Force, to Bureau of Navigation, Washington, D. C.

The Board of Education has approved the following transfers of teachers and others in various branches of the school system: ASSISTANT TO PRINCIPAL-IN-CHARGE -Annie Sutherland, 403 Manhattan, to 110 Manhattan.

Gold medals for "distinguished services to humanity" were awarded to three men and a woman last night at a dinner marking the twenty-fifth anniversary of the National Institute of Social Sciences at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The winners were Dr. Wesley Clair Mitchell, Professor ot Economics at Columbia University;

Three of the children of the late Queen Victoria, a son and two daughters, have lived to see the Queen's greatgrandson ride to his coronation as ruler over an empire which took form during her reign. The Duke of Connaught, Victoria's youngest son, will sit today in the upper window of St. James's Palace surrounded by the children of Sir Alexander Hardinge,

Although the stock market did exhibit a better tone yesterday than on the day before, this was due to a slackening of selling pressure rather than to a better demand. Trading was cautious and the market appeared to drift aimlessly throughout the day. The closing was irregular. The turnover on the Stock Exchange amounted to 746,000 shares, against 779,000 on Monday.

William E. Dodd, Ambassador to Germany, stated in a letter printed today in The Richmond Times-Dispatch that he had been informed that a man who "owns near a billion dollars" was ready to support "and of course control" an American dictatorship.

Seventy million pounds of perishable food arrive in the city every working day by railroad, truck and boat, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of the Department of Public Markets, reported yesterday.

Addressing the cadet corps of the Texas Agricultural and Mechanical College in a pause today on his way here, President Roosevelt advocated a strong army and navy "for defense and not for aggression," and added a hope that other nations would in the future spend "less for war and more for the arts of peace."

A declining birth rate, which threatens the Jewish people with a stationary population within the next four or five decades, and a steady diminution of its once tremendous commercial class constitute a "crisis" unparalleled in Jewish history since the time of the First Exile, according to-Dr. Salo Wittmayer Baron, Professor of Jewish History at Columbia University.

For a brief time yesterday a large part of the spectators at Belmont Park thought they were witnessing a dead heat as Louie Strubeis Rust and Thomas Somerville's Treford came down to the finish line apparently on even terms at the end of the mile and a sixteenth featured Raceland Handicap.

The first public gathering in the virtually completed nave of the Cathedral of St. john the Divine, a gathering of some 5,000 persons, listened yesterday afternoon and evening to a performance by Albert Stoessel,

Miss Nedine Marble, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. William E. Marble of Deerfield Drive, will be married to Ernest Francis Cowles, son of Russell A. Cowles of New York and the late Mrs. Cowles, at Christ Episcopal Church here on June 5.

Starting times for the annual metropolitan open golf championship were announced yesterday, redealing that seventy-five players will seek the crown in the three-day tournament which will start at the Forest Hill Field Club in Bloomfield, N. J., tomorrow morning.

Mr. THOMAS E. DEWEY, who knows more of rackets than most men, took occasion yesterday, in one of his few public addresses, to describe the problem created by racketeering in this city and to offer certain suggestions for the solution of that problem.
Governor Hermengildo Villanueva, Provincial Governor of Oriental Negroes, Philippine Islands, with jurisdiction over 500,000 people, was in Los Angeles with his family today for a vacation.

Harvard beat Brown today, 7-6, in the first game of their series but did not get its winning run until the ninth inning. With the Bruins leading 5-0 in the fourth, the Crimson made a fine rally, scoring four times. In the ninth inning, with the score 6-6, Al Lupien started the winning drive with a safe bunt and Captain Bilodeau sacrificed.

Considerable attention to school textbooks in France and Germany is being manifested here. Thus far there has been little about which to complain since German and French school books have been scrupulously fair, according to the Tageblatt.

The latest marvel of the radio vacuum tube makers' art, a highpower transmitting bulb scarcely larger than a mountain pen, was displayed yesterday at the Institute of Radio Engineers' silver anniversary convention at the. Hotel Pennsylvania.
The Securitics and Exchange Commission issued today a summary of six registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933 in its program to make available such information daily.

Henry Dazian, theatrical costumer, for two generations, who died at his Winter home in Miami, Fla., on May 4 at the age of 83,. left most of his estate for charitable and scientific purposes. His will, filed for probate in Surrogates' Court yesterday, did not disclose the value of the estate.
Beginning tomorrow, fishing permits will be issued to surf anglers for use along the Rockaway beachfront.

WASHINGTON CALLING, by Marquis Childs. (Morrow, $2.50.) A political drama and love story by the author of "Sweden: The Middle Way." THE UNITED STATES IN WORLD AFFAIRS IN 1936, by Whitney H. Shepardson in collaboration with William O. Seroggs. (Harper, $3.) History in the making.

The National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reported yesterday that total shipments of all types of hosiery in March, 1937, reached a new all-time high point at 12,554,643 dozen pairs, in spite of strike conditions in part of the industry.

Mr. JACOB LIVINGSTON, a Republican of antique type and justly famous in the better or at least fatter days of his party, is no longer chief of the Kings County organization, but he has not lost his art of leadership.

Detectives from the Attorney General's office are seeking Mrs. Ida F. Craven, president of the HolmesWestern Consolidated Mines, Inc., 730 Fifth Avenue, for questioning in connection with the sale of stock of that company, Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the bureau of securities, announced yesterday.

Maurice Evans, the English actor who is currently appearing in the title role of "King Richard II" at the St. James Theatre, received yesterday the Delia Austrian Medal of the Drama League of New York for the most distinguished performance of the theatrical season of 1936-37.

In one of the closest finishes of the day, C. Trentanelli's Jane Vito aCcounted for her second purse of the meeting in the Pleasure Ridge, a four-and-one-half-furlong dash for juveniles, at Churchill Downs today.

A claim against $7,400 in cash sequestrated by Paul Coulcher a few days before he went on trial as an extortioner in the restaurant racket was filed with Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday by Local 16 of the Waiters Union of which Coulcher was formerly secretary and treasurer.
Long-silent church bells rang out today as worshipers crowded into the stately cathedral here, closed for three years but reopened on orders from Governor Roman Yocupicio.

A plan to provide privately the benefits of social security for those not covered by the Federal act of 1935 has been evolved by Gerard Swope, chairman of the board of General Electric, it was revealed yesterday. It already has been put into practice among his domestic servants on his estate at Ossining, N.Y.

G. V. Thomas has been elected a director of the Cream of Wheat Corporation. Charles E. Adams, president of the Air Reduction Company, has been elected a trustee of the Bank of New York and Trust Company.

Crane Co. of Dalton, Mass., today obtained a contract from the Treasury to furnish an estimated 1,743,236 pounds of distinctive paper on which will be printed the government's paper money for the next fiscal year. The contract price was 41 cents a pound. Last year the price was 37 cents a pound.

The Viennese Roof of the St. Regis was opened for the season last night with a gala entertainment. Net proceeds from the many dinner and supper parties will be donated to the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Vincent Astor is acting president.

Expenses per dollar of sales by wholesale merchants and industrial distributors whose sales were under $50,000 were exactly twice those of the group whose sales were more than $1,000,000 in 1935, according to a report issued today by the Census Bureau.

Mrs. Stephen H. Philbin gave a garden tea yesterday at her home, 174 East Seventieth Street, in behalf of the New York Eye and Ear Hospital. Each guest had been requested to bring packages of useful articles suitable for resale later at the Bargain Box, a permanent thrift shop maintained at Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street for the benefit of various charitable organizations.

Competition for the P. S. A. L. individual fencing championship reached the final round last night as six contestants qualified on the Washington Irving High School strips. The final will be held tomorrow night at the same place.
A World War veteran of 61 and-.-a football star half his age have been chosen as opposing candidates for the Minneapolis Mayoralty, to be decided at the election June 14.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Hartman Tobacco Company has been called for May 27 in Hartford, Conn., to vote on a plan to eliminate dividend arrears on the preferred stock aggregating $682,825.
South Africa advanced to the third round of European zone Davis Cup tennis competition today when Vernon Kirby scored the clinching victory in the series with New Zealand.
