Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., are offering an issue of $110,000 Saratoga Springs, N. Y., 1.90 per cent bonds due serially from May 1, 1938 to 1944, at prices to yield 0.80 to 1.85 per cent, according to maturity. The bonds were issued for public works and water purposes.

A program of sixty feature motion pictures for the 1937-38 season will be announced this morning to the Warner Brothers and affiliates convention at the Waldorf-Astoria by Jack L. Warner, vice president in charge of production.

Mayor La Guardia and Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater, announced jointly yesterday the appointment of seven clergymen as chaplains in city hospitals. The assignments were announced at a meeting in City Hall of the examining board recently named by the Mayor to recommend appointment of chaplains to fill vacancies in various branches of the city service.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP).--The Reds blasted three of the Phils hurlers for sixteen hits and a 12-to-3 victory today. Ival Goodman, with a home run and double, led the Reds' attack, batting in three runs.

What is said to be the first commercial shipment of American whisky to Scotland in the seventeen years since prohibition went into effect in the United States will start from here Friday on the Tuscania of the Anchor Line for Glasgow.

Twenty-nine senior members of New York University's varsity basketball, track and baseball teams were honored with special awards last night at the annual N; Y. U. A. A. dinner for the Violet's Winter and Spring sport squads at the New York Athletic Club.

Enhanced by all of the traditional trimmings of trees and colorful shrubs in full bloom, the sixth annual Atlantic City Horse Show opened tonight in the Auditorium. With a big influx of visitors to the famed Jersey resort due to the balmy weather, the show benefited and there was an .attendance of about 5.000.

George W. Curtiss, special agent for the New York zone of the Pennsylvania Railroad, will discuss methods for moving traffic densities before the New York chapter of the Railway and Locomotive Historical Society in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, at 7:30 P. M., Friday.

J. Stanley Brown, personnel director of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, was elected president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the annual meeting of the chapter last night.

Both Chancellor Adolf Hitler and the new British Ambassador, Sir Neville Meyrick Henderson, emphasized in a formal exchange of greetings today the "kindred character" of the British and German peoples.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman, said today that the Maritime Commission would concentrate on the construction of new and faster ships for operation in foreign commerce and use its available funds to start this program.

Pounding relief Pitcher Jack Campbell to cover in the seventh inning, the Toronto Maple Leafs scored four runs to come from behind for the second time as they handed the Syracuse Chiefs an 8-7 setback today. Bobby Porter's fourth hit of the game, with the bases full, was the big blow of the frame.

An issue of $4,260,000 of Missouri Pacific Railroad 3 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates, Series BB, maturing serially on June 1, 1938 to 1952, was awarded yesterday to Freeman Co. on a bid of 100.1556. Salomon Bros. Hutzler bid 100.077 and Brown Harriman Co., Inc., par.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was a visitor yesterday at the exhibit of models, plans and other features of the New York World's Fair of 1939 that are on display in the Empire State Building. The President's wife, saying that she always had been interested in models, spent much of her time inspecting the various exhibits of how the fair will appear by day and night.

The House refused today to accept Presi- bill, dent Roosevelt's recommendation to make the Civilian Conservation Corps permanent, voting 224 to 34 to continue. the agency on an emeragency basis for two.years.

The coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth is being broadcast today, having started at 5 A. M., Eastern daylight-saving time, by what is believed to be the most extensive international hookup ever assembled for a single event. The broadcasters estimate that the world-wide audience in tune may total at least 300,000,000 persons. They have no yardstick by.

Londoners, who usually depend on buses, were making the best job they could tonight in reaching the coronation route in overcrowded subways and trams with the official assurance that these vehicles would still be running tomorrow.

The Maritime Commission ended yesterday an investigation of complaints by Puerto Rican interests that passenger rates on ships opereating between the United States and Puerto Rico were unduly high and the- service unsatisfactory.
Dean and Mrs. Christian Gauss of Joseph Henry House have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hildegarde Gauss, to Douglas B. Steimle of New York.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Melchorre Mauro-Cottone of this city and New London, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Aurora Mauro-Cottone, to Donald Begg, son of Mrs. Joseph R. Begg of this city and Dover Plains, N. Y., and the late Mr. Begg.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Myron J. Brown of 162 East Eightieth Street and Martha's Vineyard, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Maitland Brown, to Frederick Tilney Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Tilney of 907 Fifth, Avenue and Oyster Bay, L. I.

Charles E. Bockus, Dr. Hyman A. Osserman, in 975 Park Ave.; Edith E. Williams, Mrs. Edith Deacon Martin, in 411 E 53d St; Edward H. Robbins, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Julia Stone Gay, in 163 E 81st St; C. Peabody Mohun, Ralph W. Shafor, through Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc.,

Young Charley Mayo Jr., holder of the Long Island amateur championship who seems to be a storm center in golf these days-an amateur in his own district but of doubtful status in the eyes of the M. G. A. and U. S. G. A.-today showed his heels to the field in the first of the Long Island Association one-day amateur events.
The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway has ordered twenty-two omnibuses at a cost of $300,000 from the American Car and Foundry Motors Corporation.

Four new directors were elected today at the annual meeting of Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company stockholders. Those chosen were Louis M. Atherton of Boston, William Church Osborn and Philip J. Roosevelt of New York and Lawrence Howe of Chicago.

The fine old home which has been known for years as the Martin house at 37 Howard Avenue, in the Grymes Hill section of Staten Island, back of St. George, has been sold by the Cornelius G. Kolff, Inc., realty firm to a client for occupancy.
The Browns Jumped on Pete Appleton and Sid Cohen for three runs in the eighth inning after tying the score in the seventh and defeated the Senators today, 7 to 5.

Members of the Junior League will give a dinner dance tomorrow night at their clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. An entertainment program will be contributed by several of the players who had leading rples in the recent production of the Junior League "Follies."

Mrs. Priscilla Baldwin Preston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin of this city and Mount Kisco, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Cleveland Cobb, son of Mrs. Henry Ives Cobb and the late Mr. Cobb, at the home of her brother-in-law and twin sister, Mr. and Mrs. James P. Warburg, at 50 East Seventy-seventh Street. The Rev. Dr: Minot Simons,

After the abdication of Edward VIII, Queen Elizabeth shared the popular acclaim that greeted her husband's accession to the throne. Her marriage in 1923 to George, then the Duke of York, was hailed as a true love match.

A total of $298,133 from 6,005 contributors has been received thus far in the annual Citizens Appeal for the Salvation Army here, it was announced yesterday at a report luncheon attended by more than fifty division chairmen representing trades and industries at the Wall Street Club, 40 Wall Street. A goal of $600,000 has been set.

Lehigh turned back a highly favored Princeton nine, 2-1, on University Field today for its fifth victory of the campaign. With Bob Riddle, sophomore right-hander, scattering the visitors' five singles, the Engineers scored their first marker in the third without a hit and sent Lou Pennauchi around the bases with the winning tally in the sixth on a hit, an error and two stolen bases.

AARONS-Harry S., on May 10, beloved husband of Nettie, loving father of Hortense Hoffman, brother of Martin grandfather of Robert and Jane Hoffman. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St., Amsterdam Ave., Thursday, May 13, at 10 A. M.

Law enforcement has broken down in New York City as the result of "a labyrinth of procedure and overlapping and conflicting jurisdictions, which would almost seem to have been specially designed for the comfort of criminals," Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, charged yesterday.

A large number of city officials, FHA representatives and civic and realty executives will attend a preview of the North American Homes Exposition tonight in Madison Square Garden. The show will be opened to the public tomorrow evening.

Cornell's football squad wound up Spring practice today by losing to Bucknell, 6 to 0, in a practice game witnessed by 6,000. A 54-yard pass play, Bill Jones to Bill Lane, with Lane racing 48 yards to the Cornell one-yard line, set the stage for the touchdown, scored by George Kiick on a plunge at center.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Melchorre Mauro-Cottone of this city and New London, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Aurora Mauro-Cottone, to Donald Begg, son of Mrs. Joseph R. Begg of this city and Dover Plains, N. Y., and the late Mr. Begg.

The statement of the New York Air Brake Company for the first quarter of this year, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $412,692 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges, but before Federal surtax on undistributed earnings.

Two gunmen invaded the Cleveland Democratic Club at 1,140 Eastern Parkway, just east of Utica Avenue, Brooklyn, at 10:15 o'clock last night, held up about forty members meeting in the basement, stole between $300 and $400 and esscaped presumably in a waiting automobile.

IN WESTMINSTER ABBEY, 9 A. M., Wednesday, May 12.--For more than two hours I have sat in my place in the lofty temporary gallery in the Abbey, to which a few chosen press representatives have been admitted, with an unforgettable scene taking form below.
A general rise in the foreign exchanges yesterday gave apparent evidence of an accelerated movement of foreign funds- out of this country and toward Europe, particularly Holland.

Price movements of commodity futures developed irregularity yesterday in active trading. Coffee, copper, tin, cottonseed oil and cocoa futeres declined, and rubber and hide futures advanced. On the cash markets rubber was higher, but all the grains, tins, cotton and flour declined.
Minimum retail prices on a total of forty books were made effective yesterday under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act by William Morrow Co., publishers, 386 Fourth Avenue.

Thomas Morris, a 16-year-old victim of infantile paralysis in whose case President Roosevelt has taken an interest, showed the President today how he has progressed.' The boy, then in a wheel chair, talked with the President here eleven months ago.

A resolution which "deplored delay" in consideration and enactment of the Miller-Tydings bill was approved in principal by a meeting of various trade associations at the Hotel Astor last night and referred to a committee empowered to determine the form that the protest should take.
Walking along Victoria Embankment yesterday I took a look at the decorations in Whitehall, which are perhaps the most beautiful in the city.

Resuming its investigation tomorrow morning into the cause of the destruction of the airship Hindenburg, the Department of Commerce board of inquiry plans to hear extensive testimony from members of the ground crew, most of whom were directly under the ship when the flames started.

Colonel Walter McI. Wolfe, Baltimore civil engineer prominent in reserve army activities here for many years, died today of a heart attack at the University Club. Colonel Wolfe, who was 49 years old, was vice president of the Northeastern Construction Company.

United States MACHINIST, 84c an Hour. Ordnance Department at Large, War Department, Watertown Arsenal, Watertown, Mass.Applications must be on file with the Secretary, Board of Civil Service Examiners, U. S. Arsenal, Watertown, Mass., not later than June 1.
Steel ingot production was unchanged last week in face of a rising seasonal trend, and the adjusted index eased to 121.2 from 121.3. It was 91.2 for the week ended May 9, 1936.
Alfonso da Costa, wartime Premier of Portugal and former President of the League of Nations Assembly, died today in Paris, where he had lived in exile since 1927.

Marshal Mikhail Tukhachevsky, the youngest of the Soviet's five field marshals, brilliant Red Army strategist and organizer and Vice Commissar of Defense, was radically demoted in a startling Red Army shakeup laconically announced without comment today.

A committee representing labor on several major fronts has decided to seek a nation-wide boycott against Maine's recreational resources and industrial products in retaliation for the stand taken by the court in the Lewiston-Auburn shoe strike and the imprisonment of Powers Hapgood, Sidney Grant, a Boston lawyer, and five other union leaders.

Benjamin C. Betner Co., Inc., paper bags, in Building Loan Building, 441 Lexington Ave; Eldorado Chemical Co., in 521 5th Ave; The Western Union Telegraph Co., in Vanderbilt-'Concourse Building, 52 Vanderbilt Ave; Cushman Wakefield, Inc., broker.
Frank W. Bradsby, secretarytreasurer of Hillerich Bradsby Company, manufacturers of baseball bats (Louisville Slugger) and golf clubs, died last night after an illness of two weeks. His age was 59.

Markets Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. has barred the sale of hot dogs from pushcarts and stands in all open-air markets under his jurisdiction, it was disclosed yesterday when an action was started in Supreme Court to have the order set aside as an "arbitrary, capricious abuse of discretion."

Metro's "Captains Courageous," which had its premiere at the Astor last night and will be shown henceforth on a two-a-day basis, is another of those grand jobs of moviemaking we have come to expect of Hollywood's most prodigal studio.

Dr. Miguel Mariano Gomez, ousted President of Cuba, asked the Supreme Court today to restore him to office. Dr. Gomez was impeached and removed from office last Dec. 23 in a fight over a sugar tax to obtain funds for army-controlled schools.

A compromise agreement which averts the threatened extension of the strike of gasoline service station employes was reached yesterday at a conference in the Hotel New Yorker between representatives of the Gasoline Station Attendants Union and the Intercity and Petroleum Dealers Associations.

Mrs. George W. Wilkins of Justa Farm, Huntingdon Valley, gave a tea this afternoon for those who will act as models in the fashion show of the June Fete to be given on June 5 at Lindenhurst for the benefit of the Abingdon Memorial Hospital.

Administration leaders in the Senate are prepared, it is understood, to ask President Roosevelt on his return to the capital to accept some compromise on his court reorganization plan that will enable the bill to leave the Senate Judiciary Committee without an adverse report.

More than 100 mothers and children, mobilizing suddenly, staged a sit-down strike yesterday afternoon and for four hours prevented a Park Department crew from closing a playground in Forty-fifth Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

Italy is celebrating the anniversary of the conquest of Ethiopia. It is a suitable time to survey the condition of affairs one year after that event. When Mussolini first announced his purpose to invade Ethiopia, two schools of opinion developed here.
After amending the La Rue chainstore bill to include theatres, the Pennsylvania Legislature is expected to pass the bill and send it to Governor George H. Earle, who, it is believed, will sign it.

The birth rate for the city continted to rise last week and the infant mortality rate, for the second successive week, registered a new low for the year, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday in his health survey for the week ended last Saturday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Dixon, daughter of John E. Dixon of East Orange, to John Goebel Watson, son of John S. Watson of Easton, Md. The announcement was made yesterday- at a luncheon in Miss Dixon's honor given by her cousin, Mrs. Walter A. Bingham of Orange.

Brig. Gen. Amos W. W. Woodcook announced "reluctantly" today that he had resigned as president of St. John's College, effective June 30. The former prohibition enforcement chief said he was severing his connection with the college partly because its board of visitors and governors refused to make St. John's a coeducational institution.
In committee and on the floor the House, ordinarily a loyal follower, broke away from the administration leash today and pressed on in two steps of its own toward balancing the Federal budget.

One hundred thousand WPA workers in this city will have to be dropped by June 80 if the Federal relief appropriation is cut to $1,000,000,000, Aubrey W. Williams, Deputy Works Progress Administrator and executive director of the National Youth Administration, warned yesterday.

The Indians dropped out of their firstplace tie with the Athletics today as Boston landed on three Cleveland pitchers for eleven hits and an 11-to-4 victory. It was the first setback for the Indians in six games.
The Commerce Department said today gold imports into the United States in April totaled $215,824,506, compared with $154,370,956 in March and $28,106,110 in April, 1936.
Two more arrivals augmented the personnel of the Australian and American Davis Cup camps yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

Sixto Escobar, world bantamweight champion, will get back into action tonight when he opposes Mickey Jerome of Greenpoint in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome. Although Escobar's title will not be at stake, since Jerome will weigh more than the class limit of 118 pounds, a hard fight looms, and Promoter Mike Jacobs expects a large crowd to witness proceedings.

A hurry-up code message from the secretary of Ellis H. Parker Sr. to Paul H. Wendel just six days before Governor Hoffman granted a thirty-day reprieve to Bruno Richard Hauptmann provided some lively moments in the Parker conspiracy trial today.

During the time The New York Woman published advertisements of its own stock at a price of $1.621/2 from January to April the stock could have been purchased for less over the counter, it was brought out yesterday in the examination of Arthur E. Bysshe,

Trial Results Captain William W. McAllister, Engine 69. Charges: Violation of Section 114, Par. 5, R. R., 1926 (two specificationsgiving expression to indecent, profane and boisterous language). Specification 1, not guilty, complaint dismissed. Specification 2, not guilty, complaint dismissed.

The Tennessee House of Representatives tabled and killed today a bill to permit local option on liquor. The vote was 52 to 42. Opponents argued that revenue from liquor, one-third of which was to go for old-age pensions, would be "blood money."
The flow of grain traffic on the Great Lakes, usually from west to east, reversed itself today. The steamer Harry Yates loaded 275,000 bushels- of Argentine corn for -shipment to Chicago.

The marriage of Miss Florence Anna de Haas, daughter of Mrs. Jacob de Haas of 50 Morningside Drive and the late Mr. de Haas, a Zionist leader, historian and journalist, to Lewis N. Dembitz, son of Mrs. A. Lincoln Dembitz of Washington and the late Mr. Dembitz took place on Monday night at the home of the bride's mother.

Making his first start in nearly a year, the Dixiana's Good Catch, a 3-year-old son of Supremeus, added another victory to Trainer Clyde Van Dusen's rapidly mounting score at Narragansett Park today when he won the Chelsea Purse at six furlongs.

The Columbia University tennis team accounted for its sixth victory in seven starts by vanquishing City College, 8-1, on the South Field courts yesterday. Morton Hellman turned in the only triumph for the Lavender, beating Jim Wall in two overtime sets.

Miss Ernestine Dublon, 23 years old, an unemployed dietitian, leaped to her death at 10:20 o'clock last night from the roof of the twentytwo-story Hotel Windermere at West End Avenue and Ninety-second Street to an extension roof over the second floor.

Paul B. Scarff, secretary of S. H. Kress Co., said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that the growth of chain-store legislation was the most serious fact tor confronting the company, but that he felt that the tide had turned.

Guthrie McClintic, theatrical producer, returned on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday after a visit to Ireland where he studied scenic background for the play "Blind Man's Buff," which he expects to produce in New York in the Fall.

Scoring in five of six periods, Lawrenceville School's undefeated polo team routed the Princeton. yearlings, 8-1, today to clinch the annual Spring series with the Tiger cubs. Last week the Laurentians scored a 13-3 victory over the freshmen.

Tenements and converted dwellings figured in several Manhattan deals announced by brokers yesterday. Among the properties changing hands was the six-story apartment house at 504 West 131st Street, which was sold by the Greenwald Company, brokers, for the Protestant Episcopal Church to Irving M. Karpf, operator.
Lowell Thomas, author, lecturer and radio commentator, was yesterday elected president of the vertising Club of New York, sucfeeding H. B. LeQuatte, head of the agency of that name. Lee J.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, beginning today an investigation of the facts underlying the acquirement of control of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad by the Van Sweringen System, charged that the Interstate Commerce Commission was ignored in the initial negotiations and that $8,000,000 was paid for stock that in less than two years dwindled to a market value of approximately $180,000.

Charges of intimidation of workers and violation of the Wagner act were filed yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board against the Horn Hardart Company, operators of forty-four restaurants and stores in this city, by three unions affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

So we have the five-cent fare back with us as a political issue, and a Mayor may be elected to stand between the people and the Traction Crowd, and life in New York is by no means as unrecognizable as some people say.

Despite the criticism of Europeans that people of this country are lacking in culture, Americans. do have an appreciation of fine arts and music that needs, however, to be developed, the Rev. James M. Gillis, editor of The Catholic World, told the Lions Club of New York yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor.

The great pageant which London witnesses today is the coronation of a King, but it is also the reunion of an Empire. Here, as on no other occasion, and by no other act, are symbolized the ties which bind together the British family of nations.

It seems there was a show called "Abie's Irish Rose," which opened hopefully back in the May of 1922, ran fire and a half years and then took an earned vacation. That has now come to an end, and this evening Anne Nichols again will sponsor a production of "Abie."

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,489,200 barrels, compared with 3,497,450 in the preceding week, a drop of 8,250, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Steer beef continued sluggish. Veal moved only fair to slow, and other classes were in fair demand. Steer cuts were weak to lower, lamb carcasses and fresh pork slightly stronger; other classes steady to weak. Early trading ;n kosher meats indicated beef prices to be steady to slightly stronger, veal and lamb steady to weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The New York Madrigal Society Women's Chorus, Marguerite Potter, director, will be heard in concert tonight at the Town Hall, assisted by Kathryn Tenney, soprano; Alcinda Midjo, violinist, and Waldemar B. Hille, pianist.

Mrs. Ellen Hansell Allderdice, widow of Taylor Allderdice, Pittsburgh industrialist and philanthropist, and the first national women's tennis champion, died today in West Penn Hospital, surviving her son, Lawrence, only four days. She was 68 years old.

The rights to more than 100 plays and musical shows, including many old hits, were sold at auction yesterday in the Federal Building to a group composed of Irving Berlin, Jerome Kern, Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Otto Harbach.
The Bank of England prepared for the rush of coronation business today with the purchase of [Pound]4,999,886 worth of gold bullion against which to issue new pound notes.

The coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth will be celebrated in New York City today by divine services, balls, dinners and less formal gatherings that will be attended by distinguished members of the city's British colony and many prominent Americans.

The world's production of gold in the first quarter of this year is estimated at 8,924,000 ounces by the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. This compares with 9,096,000 ounces in the final quarter of 1936.

1st Lt. Joseph Bandes, Med. -Res., 1,027 Walton Ave., New York, unassigned, is ordered to active duty May 12, at Fort Monmouth, N. J. Lt. Bandes will rank from May 12, 1937. He will be relieved from active duty May 25.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 10: COLONELS Truesdell, E., Inf., Ft. Humphreys, D. C., to 16th Inf., Ft. Jay, N. Y., about July 1. Brabson, F. W., Inf., General Staff Corps, Washington, D. C., relieved from detail as a member of the General Staff Corps and assigned to the 18th Inf., Ft. Hamilton, N. Y., Sept. 7.

Plans which may result in the formation of a national association for the popular-price dress industry will be discussed on the evening of the close of the fair-trade-practice conference called by the Federal Trade Commission, it was said here yesterday by Louis Rubin,
When a production carries an orchestra in evening clothes and a hurdy-gurdy of lyrics and tunes it is customary to write at least three paragraphs in honor of the expense.

A working example of national control of one of the worst diseases prevalent in the United Statessyphilis-was presented yesterday to more than 200 leaders in public health work by Dr. Thorvald Madsen of Copenhagen, president of the League of Nations Health Committee at Geneva. He described the system used in Denmark's successful fight against the disease.

Pax Films, Inc., which was set up early this month with the idea of "dubbing" into English four noteworthy foreign motion pictures anntially, yesterday purchased the American rights to the French film "Meyerling."

The opening on Saturday of the low-level bridge, connecting Randalls and Wards Islands in. the East River, was announced yesterday by the Triborough Bridge Authority, which had the span built at a cost' of $530,000.

Guests at last night's State dinner at Buckingham Palace brought away from it the distinct impression of a great personality tactfully steering without attempting to dominate the royal course in this its difficult initial period.

William B. Warner, general manager and president of the McCall Corporation, last year received $125,852 for his services to that organization, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. To Francis Hutter, secretary and manager of the pattern department, was paid $40,769,

The National City Bank has reported that definitive bonds of the $50,000,000 of New York 3 per cent corporate stock issue, dated Jan. 1, 1937, and maturing on Jan. 1, 1977, will be ready for delivery on and after May 17 at the office of the City Controller, Room 380, Municipal Building, New York.

Plans to eliminate unethical business practices in the clothing industry were pushed last night at the Hotel McAlpin at a meeting of the newly organized Men's Clothing Manufacturers Trade Bureau, Inc. Headquarters of the organization, it was announced, have been established at 160 Fifth Avenue.

Senator Glass, commenting today on the letter from--Ambassador Dodd, dealing with the Supreme Court, said: "I received a copy of a long essay from Ambassador Dodd two or three months ago, but it seemed to me. to.have.-no 'relevanoy whatsoever to the question of packing the Supreme Court now before Congress.

Miss Dorothea Darlington entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Mrs. Gurnee Hinman Barrett, Mrs. Frederick A. H. Anger, Mrs. James Fearon Brown, Mrs. Gilbert S. B. Darlington, Mrs. James Lincoln Ashley, Mrs. Seward Erdman, Mrs. Sherman D. Wakefield, Mrs. Elliott C. B. Darlington, Mrs. Emerson Whithorne, Mrs. Walter Bayne Johnston,

MANHATTAN ALEXANDER, JOEL (May 4). Estate, more than $50,000. To Edith R. S. Alexander, widow, executrix, 1,085 Park Av., household, personal effects and income from residue, with power of appointment.

The refusal of Philip De Ronde of New York to disclose the final disposition of $250,000 which he received for negotiating the sale of a subway system in Buenos Aires may result in a test of the Securities and Exchange Commission's power to compel testimony under the Public Utility Act.

Emphatically denying that he had taken any unnecessary risks, Henry T. (Dick) Merrill obviously was annoyed today at reports published here that J. M. Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, contemplated the is. suance of an order to ban the New York-to-Paris air race and other "freak" flights.

Alexander Korda, London film producer, arrived here yesterday on the French liner Ile de France to attend a meeting of the board of United Artists in Hollywood. He said he would spend a few days in New York and then go to California by air.

The State Department has been informed by the Irish Free State that the appointment of John Cudahy of Milwaukee as Minister in Dublin is acceptable. His appointment is expected to be sent soon to the Senate by President Roosevelt.

W. E. Huton Co. and other respondents charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with having manipulated the stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation, will begin their defense at 2 P. M. here today. The hearings will be held in the regional offices of the SEC at 120 Broadway.

The first annual twilight games of the Sixty-ninth Regiment A. A.,. to be held tonight at Lewisohn Stadium, have attracted some of the leading stars of. the country. Champions, record holders and near-champions are entered in the competitions, carded to start at 1 P. M.

A new six-story hospital building is planned by St. Clare's Hospital for erection on the vacant plot alongside the present home of the institution, which is located at 415 West Fifty-first Street, Manhattan.

Heim is featuring full-length Fall sports coats, with straight box fronts and loosely flared swagger backs that curve out slightly below the shoulder blades. Such coats are frequently trimmed with fur bands.
A few minutes before midnight in London, Robert W. Bingham, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, broadcast last night over the N. B. C. network a Coronation Day message to America.

National animosities, industrial discord, mob violence and other social ills were traced today by Professor C. Macfie Campbell, Harvard psychiatrist, directly to the tensions and frustrations in the lives of individuals in a society in which the individual is constantly forced to make ever greater sacrifices of his individualty.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 12.--About the time this is read at early American breakfast tables the great ceremony of crowning George VI as King and Emperor will be drawing to a close in Westminster Abbey.

An abrupt decline of 6 cents a bushel in May corn was a feature of the trading In grain futures on the Board of Trade here, today. General liquidation was underway in the May deliveries of all grains, which depressed the distant futures.

More than 400 Brooklyn, Manhattan and Bronx lawyers gathered at the Hotel Biltmore last night at a dinner marking the beginning of a drive among the attorneys of these boroughs to raise $450,000 in behalf of 116 philanthropies to which the Federation for the Support of Jewish Charities in New York City contributes.

Representatives of several New York real estate organizations opposed the Wagner Housing Bill at a hearing today before the Senate Labor Committee. They urged that lowcost housing be left to private enterprise, subsidized by public funds, with a limit on profits.

Worcestershire defeated Derbyshire by three wickets in a first-class county cricket fixture concluded today at Worcester, while rain stopped play at Lord's, leaving Northamptonshire with a victory on first innings over Middlesex.

Headed by Stewart Mackay, a new group has purchased control of the magazine Commerce and Finance from Barnard Powers, who has decided to devote his time to other interests. The next issue will be sponsored by the new owners.

The Cunard White Star liner Aquitania will sail today for Cherbourg and Southampton. Among her passengers will be Francine Larrimore, actress; Simon Elwes and Mrs. Conrad Berens, two passengers who had booked on the Hindenburg: Conde Nast,

Daniel E. Reagan, retired coal mine operator and manufacturer, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 76 years old. Mr. Reagan formerly was president of the Hocking Valley Products Company of Columbus, Ohio.

Richard M. Simpson, Republican nominee, defeated Lowell Alexander, Democrat, in a special election in the Eighteenth Congressional District today to fill a vacancy in the House caused by the death of Representative Benjamin K. Focht, Republican.

Maxie Berger, popular Bronx lightweight, gained an eight-round verdict over Orville Drouillard, Windsor, Ontario, in the feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 10,000 watched the fast contest.

Most of us have learned from sad experience that the man of science who turns long enough away from his tools and texts to address the general public is usually eager to discuss something of which he knows no more (and frequently less) than the next man.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee tackled Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel company, today in its drive to organize the industry, but emerged empty-handed from a two-hour meeting with J. A. Voss, Republic's industrial relations director.
The Securities and Exchange Commission today issued a stop order
After a day of sightseeing at Williamsburg, Jamestown and Yorktown, Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman of New York arrived here late today to stay at

The Athletics took undisputed possession of first place in the American League today, beating Detroit, 4 to 1; behind the four-hit pitching of George Caster. The Cleveland Indians, who had been tied with the Mackmen, lost to the Red Sox and dropped to second.

The stock markets were very dull and generally depressed today. Gilt-edge securities moved downward, while in foreign loans German bonds encountered offerings and Japanese and South American bonds eased. International stocks fell sharply, with United States Steel and International Nickel dropping.
George W. Belford, who achieved prominence as an originator of vaudeville and circus acrobatic acts during the last twentyfive years, died late last night at his home here at the age of 71.

The Russian Student Fund, which for fifteen years has been instrumental in aiding hundreds of young Russians to complete their education in American universities, was the beneficiary of a Russian Easter part$ last night in the garden of the Ambassador given by the Russian Alumni and Student Association.

The volume of bankers' acceptances and of commercial paper outstanding declined moderately in April, but at the end of the month showed gains over a year ago, according to data published yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The crown jewels were sped to Westminster Abbey today behind the drawn shades of a motor car and under a heavy guard of police. The imperial crown, the Queen's crown and the other regalia were taken to the abbey from the crown jewelers, where they had been overhauled.

Realty officials from seven States and the District of Columbia began gathering in New York yesterday for the Central Atlantic regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, to be held in the Hotel Biltmore.

Even during the height of the coronation celebrations there is considerable speculation and in certain quarters even uneasiness over the guest list that the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield-to which the brideto-be has now changed her name by court permission-are preparing for their-wedding.

Right up to the last moment bargaining is still being done by ticket agencies in the most expensive private stands near Westminster Abbey and elsewhere in favorite places along the route of the coronation procession today.

Burton Tucker, 31 years old, was ordered acquitted yesterday by Judge Morris Koenig in General Sessions on the third day of his trial on a charge that he had abandoned his 59-year-old wife and three small children last July and left them destitute.

A sit-down strike of seamen on four ships of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Company was ended late- yesterday afternoon by the signing of an agreement by representatives of the company with the newly formed National Maritime Union, American Radio Telegraphists Association and Marine Engineers Beneficial Association.

Passenger revenues of the New York Central Railroad continue to show gratifying increases over last year's levels, F. E. Williamson, president, said in remarks accompanying the company's quarterly statement issued yesterday. Coach rates were reduced to 2 cents and Pullman rates to 3 cents a mile by order of the Interstate Commerce Commission last June.

The Committee Act of 1937 designed to extend the jurisdiction of the Securities and Exchange Commission over practices of protective committees in business reorganizations was introduced in the House today by Representative Lea, chairman of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

The champion athlete whose name is emblazoned across the sports pages was held up yesterday by speakers at the annual convention of Boys Clubs of America at the Hotel Commodore as the chief factor in inspiring the under-privileged youth with a sense of sportsmanship necessary to carry him through life despite his unfortunate start.

William Cattell, a retired actor who was well known in the traveling companies of fifty years ago, died here last night at the age of 80. He had been retired for ten years, and lived at 164 Washington Street. His wife, Evelyn Knapp, actress, died five years ago.

The election of William F. Halsey 3d, '38, of Long Beach, Calif., to the presidency of Princeton University's Intracollegiate Athletic Association, campus organization in charge of intermural athletics, was announced today by retiring President Thaddeus T. Hutcheson, '37, of Houston, Texas.

General Emilio Mola reported tonight the central columns of his army driving toward Bilbao had taken the Biscargi range of mountains by assault and had reached positions less than six miles from the beleaguered Basque capital.

A bridegroom who applied for an annulment when he lost the $25-aweek job allegedly provided by his father-in-law as an inducement to marriage drew a sharp rebuke from Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins yesterday. In denying the application, the justice characterized it as an insolent, impious effrontery, lacking any basis in law or morals.

The New York Central Railroad Company announced yesterday that $58,198,400 out of its $59,911,000 of ten-year 6 per cent convertible secured bonds dated May 10, 1934, had been converted into capital stock at the rate of $40 a share up to the close of business on Monday.

A "state of mourning" banning the celebration of the coronation by order of the Arab High Committee was decreed today as a protest against the new immigration schedule permitting 770 Jews, to enter Palestine during the four months ending July 31.

Dan O'Mahoney of Ireland, former champion of the world, threw Wally Dusek of Omaha in the feature wrestling bout at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. A crowd of 1,500 saw O'Mahoney pin his foe with a body hold in 32 minutes and 41 seconds. The weights were 230 for the winner and 220 for Dusek.

The annual meeting and election of officers of the Municipal Bond Club of New York will be held on June 2 at the Bankers Club, E. F. Dunstan, president, announced yesterday. The nominating committee, headed by Myron G. Darby of Darby Co., Inc., has named the following slate:
The plant of the J. G. Brill Company, manufacturers of trolley cars, buses and special railroad cars, was closed today by a strike of 1,700 employes.
The handlers of Pompoon, J. H. Louchheim's big, rangy colt, predicted today the forty-seventh renewal of the Preakness Saturday at Pimlieo will be an outstanding contest.

Introducing the first division Dodgers! After spotting the Cardinals a 7-2 lead in the first three frames at Ebbets Field yesterday the Grimes boys rushed five runs across in the fifth, won the free-hitting affair, 9-7, captured the series, two games to one, and reached fourth place in the National League.

Frank J. R. Mitchell of 195 Claremont Avenue, a former Chicago lawyer, who was president of the Banco Nationale of Santo Domingo from 1911 to 1915, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital after a four-month illness. He was born in Paris, Ill., sixty-five years ago.

William E. Dodd, the United States Ambassador, confirmed here today his. writing of a letter to Senator Robert J. Bulkley, Democrat, of Ohio, warning against the danger of a Fascist dictatorship in the United States which he said an' American billionaire was -ready to support "and of course control."

President Roosevelt, who likes to take a bagful of good books along with him on his fishing tripp, will have a large library to choose from on future expeditions, it was announced yesterday at the closingday sessions of the annual convention of the Americn Booksellers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Mrs. Louise Wharff Rogers, presiden of The Adco, Inc., has been elected president of the Advertising Women of New York, it was announced yesterday.

The Louisiana Arkansas Railway expended $895,642 in the purchase of senior obligations of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway in 1936, the former's report to the Interstate Commerce Commission for last year disclosed yesterday.
The British High Court reached an important decision today that ultimately may alter the character of the British Government's recognition of the Italian Government in Ethiopia.

Mrs. Adolphus Andrews, wife of Rear Admiral Andrews, and Miss Frances Andrews have come from Washington to the St. Regis. Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Fayant have arrived at the Barclay from Miami Beach and will leave for France early in June.

Movements in the Chicago livestock markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows: HOGS Receipts 15,000, including 4,000 direct. Early market steady with Monday's average, later undertone weak to 10 lower; bulk good and choice 200-300 pounds, $10.30$10.50; top, $10.55; comparable 150-190 pounds, $9.85-$10.35 mostly; bulk good 350-550 pounds, packing sows, $9.60-$9.80; choice strongweight pigs up to $9.75.

Doubtless the bill that Senator VANDENBERG and Representative BACON have introduced to revise the Federal relief system has no bright prospect of immediate passage. Its sponsorship is Republican, and if there is going to be any credit for reforming relief the Democratic majority in Congress will want that credit itself.
Mrs. Andrew Melville Reid, a native of France but one of Maryland's leaders in the national organization of Gold Star Mothers, died at her home here today in her eighty-first year.

Yesterday's purchase of [Pound]4,999,886 gold by the Bank of England was the first large purchase by that institution since last December, when the bank acquired [Pound]65,000,000 in the week ended on Dec. 16 and at the same time reduced its fiduciary issue by f60,000,000.

Mrs. Helen Budd Gibby of 170 Roseville Avenue, a member of the first graduating class of the Trenton State Normal School, in 1858, and believed to be the oldest normal school graduate in the country, died yesterday at the age of 98. She was born near Chatham, N. J.
The American republics, with England, France, the Scandinavian peoples and the Czechs, are "the only protectors of the democratic

Imperial Oil, Ltd., has notified the New York Curb Exchange that a record of shareholders will be taken May 14 for distribution of a semi-annual dividend of 25 cents a share and a special dividend of 37 1/2 cents a share, payable in Canadian funds June 1.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that consent decrees had been entered in four cases in the District court for the District of Montana permanently enjoining violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Securities Act of 1933.

The Lucius N. Littauer Foundation, Inc., has granted $100,000 to the permanent endowment of the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science, which is housed in the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the school.

To those in humblest vocations and circumstances, as well as to those who are destined to wear crowns and to be hailed by multitudes, the message of Dr. FOSDICK in his sermon of last Sunday should be inspiriting. He tells the secret of happiness for both alike. The fact is, he says, that happiness is amazingly independent of outward experience. Some of the most miserable,

With the annual election of Actors Equity Association a little more than a fortnight away, the "opposition ticket" of council nominees yesterday announced their platform. They did so in a letter being mailed out to all Equity members.
The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, an operating unit of the Associated Gas and Electric system,

The coronation today has resulted in the greatest number of tie-ups in some form or other by advertisers with an important public event in the history of advertising, according to survey here yesterday.

Dirge-like music echoed through the flag-draped Hamburg-American pier at West Forty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon as representatives of Germany, Sweden and the United States paid their last tribute to the dead of the Zeppelin Hindenburg.

Spirited bidding marked the second day's public auction of the art collection and furnishings at Inisfada, the country mansion of the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, now Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, at Manhasset, L. I.

Caroline Ticknor, author and editor, died at her home in Jamaica Plain today after a year's illness. Born in Boston, the daughter of Benjamin H. and Caroline Cushman Ticknor, she wrote her first book in 1896, and two years later became an editor of the International Library of Famous Literature. One of her last works was "May Alcott," in 1928.

The marriage of Miss Mary Alice McGuirk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward McGuirk of Bellport, L. I., to Arthur Reid Kenedy, son of Arthur Kenedy of 64 East Seventy-eighth Street and the late Mrs. Kenedy, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Under gray skies heavy with the threat of rain, the coronation cavalcade of King George VI moved off toward Westminster Abbey this morning. Troops lined the route, forming pr two walls of color and flashing at steel between which the golden state coach of the King and Queen would roll to the Abbey later in the morning.
Jersey City Pitcher Ben Cantwell won his fourth straight victory today as his mates bunched ten hits off Bob (King Kong) Kline and beat the Bisons, 6 to 5.

Hospitals throughout the State and nation will be open to visitors today for the twelfth annual observance of "National Hospital Day" on the birthday of Florence Nightingale. Calling attention to the work of 600 hospitals, sanatoria and related institutions in the State, Governor Lehman urged "every citizen of New York" to visit a hospital to see demonstrations and exhibitions of medical care.

The players of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association had a difficult time of it over the North Shore Country Club course in their weekly one-day tournament today. Even Miss Grace Amory and Mrs. Allan Rosenberg, who tied for the low gross honors, were highly dissatisfied with their winning 88s.

The Fordham University netmen won their sixth match in succession, defeating St. Francis College, 7-2, on the victor's courts yesterday. Victor Del Guercio and Ray Walsh of the Maroon remained unbeaten in fourteen doubles matches over a period of two seasons when they beat Michael Cafarella and Vincent Kenny.

Walter L. Johnson of Shearson, Hammill Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1918 and a governor since 1919, was elected vice president of that body yesterday by the governing committee. He succeeds E. H. H. Simmons. former president, who intimated to the committee that he did not wish to retain the post that he had held two years.

After a slightly lower opening stocks closed irregular in dull trading; turnover, 746,944 shares. United States Government bonds irregularly lower, domestic and foreign issues irregular; transactions, $9,158,600.

Senator Bulkley said today that Ambassador Dodd had written him from Berlin warning of the "dangers" of an American dictatorship "because he mistakenly thought I was wavering in my support of the President's court plan."

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve held her annual reception in honor of the seniors of Barnard College yesterday afternoon in Barnard Hall. Miss Amy Schaeffer, president of the senior class, and Miss Martha Reed, president of the undergraduate association, assisted on the receiving line.

King George VI gave a personal pledge "to carry on my father's work for the welfare of our great empire" in a moving ceremony today in which the Prime Ministers of five dominions presented "loyal addresses" to him at Buckingham Palace ceremonies.

Showers in the Southwest for the second successive day, with generally fair weather facilitating planting operations elsewhere in the cotton belt, had a depressing effect on the cotton market here yesterday.

The third executive officer and fourth member of the board of trustees of Westminster Theological Seminary to resign within a few weeks in a controversy over doctrine and other matters submitted his resignation at a meeting of the board today, a few hours before the annual commencement exercises.

With apologies from Mayor S. Davis Wilson and expressions of regret from State officials, Owen Wister, honorary State chairman, and two national officers of the Defenders, Inc., were freed by Magistrate Atkinson Costello today of charges of violating the State Solicitations Act.

Plans have been completed by Miss Agnes Forshew Schlegel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Schiegel Jr. of Scarsdale, N. Y., for her marriage to Herbert S. Gardner Jr., son of Herbert S. Gardner, also of Scarsdale, and the late Mrs. Gardner, which will take place June 10 in the Church of St. James the Less, Scarsdale. The Rev.

Frank J. Waller, who won many bicycle races in this country forty years ago, died yesterday at Grasslands Hospital, Eastview. He was 77 years old and lived in Mamaroneck. As a youth he came to this country from Germany and entered sixday bicycle races at a time when only individual cyclists appeared in the contests.

The Whitney Museum of American Art, 10 West Eighth Street. opened yesterday an exhibition of paintings selected from the permanent collection. It follows the oneman show of drawings and sculpture by Gaston Lachaise, and is scheduled to continue until June 1.

A rent strike which has been conducted in two Bronx apartment houses by more than fifty tenants since April 15 was ended yesterday when the tenants paid their rents plus court costs. The houses affected are at 2,802 Olinville Avenue and 2,758 Holland Avenue.

John Christensen, president of the Danish Brotherhood of America, died of a heart attack while dressing in his cabin aboard the liner Pilsudski as it arrived in London from the United States today, Mr. Christensen, who was 67 years old and a resident of Cincinnati, was accompanied by his wife and daughter.

Duane St, 178, 24.11x127.5; Eugene A. Donohue et al, trustee Eliz K. Lorillard, to Pacific Egg Producers Cooperative, Inc, 178 Duane St ($41.50). Platt St, 14-20, 83.11x83.1x59.1x90.10; United States Trust Co. to Rhelando Corp, 95 Maiden Lane ($280).

The Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations issued a statement yesterday from its office, 12 East Forty-first Street, saying that the award of wage increases and vacations with pay to building service employes in Manhattan "will sooner or later be reflected in higher rentals."
News that a child played a bone flute 6,000 years ago shared the front page yesterday with the English Coronation, the encirclement of Bilbao, the Hindenburg inquiry and the New York transit fight.

Mrs. Betty Randolph Sweinhart, a former Follies girl, now-approaching 50, was indicted yesterday by the New York County grand jury on an extortion charge made by Louis Bamberger, former member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Bamberger Brothers, which went out of business in 1933.

Trailing, 2-0, going into the seventh inning, Fordham's baseball team rallied to score three runs and added two more in the eighth to gain a 5-2 victory over St. John's at the Maroon field yesterday. It was the seventh triumph in ten games for the Rams and stretched the losing streak of the Redmen to five straight.

A Compromise Railroad Retirement Bill, designed to carry out provisions of a recent voluntary agreement between management and employes and end a dispute of several years' standing, was introduced today in the Senate by Senator Wagner of New York and in the House by Representative Crosser of Ohio.

Salvatore Ossido, 26 - year - old Brooklyn barber, was sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison during the week of June 21 for criminally assaulting and killing 9-year-old Einer Sporrer, German-born parochial school girl, in the back room of his barber shop on March 19.

Tentative plans for a $3,000,000 automobile trailer camp on the 300acre site of the proposed Bronx airport at the Boston Post Road and the Hutchinson River Parkway, to accommodate visiting motorists during the 1939 New York World's Fair, were announced yesterday byJames J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx.

Peoples Light and Power Company of New York and a group of voting trustees for this company's Class A common stock have registered under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
During the past two days representatives and friends of twelve Christian colleges have been studying in New York their common task-the advancement of Christian higher education in China.

Under pressure from selling agents, the Textile Exporters Association of the United States of America is considering asking that a flat 60 per cent preferential given American cotton goods by Cua when the reciprocal treaty between the two countries comes up for renewal in September.
Charles Blaser, 74-year-old gardener at Paramount Studios and oldest employee in point of service, died here today at California Lutheran Hospital. Born in Berne,
White St; 8-10, 5-story loft and store building. 40x93.2 irregular; Bankers Trust Co, trustee, against Frank Herwig; due, $37,989; taxes, , $496; to plaintiff for $21.000.

The plan of Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of State Insurance, for merging the Lawyers Title Corporation and the New York Title Insurance Company was attacked yesterday by stockholders and creditors of the two existing groups at a hearing before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.
Lieutenant Joseph William Campbell lost his life when a navy plane with six others aboard cracked up this morning in a forced landing in the Caribbean, 130 miles from the fleet air base at Coco Solo.

Notwithstanding the comparison with brisk Easter trade in 1936 and the decline in the stock market, chain stores sales last month made a "reasonably good showing," according to the analysis issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.
While great crowds thronged Buckingham Palace tonight and all London seemed on the move, King George and Queen Elizabeth retired early to rest in preparation for the taxing ceremonies tomorrow.

Daniel Paul Higgins, architect and president of the Catholic Youth Association of the Archdiocese of New York, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as a member of the Board of Education. Mr. Higgins, a nominal Democrat, succeeds Mrs. Margaret McAleenan, whose term expired a week ago.

George M. Naylor, president of the Fairbanks Company, has informed stockholders that on June 1 the company will reduce its funded debt by the payment of $79,000 of Series G and H 6 per cent notes, leaving $358,861 of debt outstanding.
A 68-yearold American woman was one of the first in. line for the long, chilly wait for a glimpse of the coronation procession tomorrow. She was Miss Elizabeth Dunbar of Philadelphia.

Harry Balsamo, hard-hitting Harlem middleweight, stopped Jackie Aldare of Greenpoint in 2:55 of the opening session of a scheduled 10round feature bout before 3,000 persons at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
The austere Senate Finance Committee puzzled today over whether it ought to approve an impost on the likes nesses of Greta Garbo, Ginger Rogers and other actresses who send photographs to fans.

Middleweight Champion Freddie Steele of Tacoma "showed his critics" tonight by knocking out Frank Battaglia of Minneapolis, the challenger, in the third session of a scheduled fifteen-round title fight in the Civic Auditorium.

Thomas Grisdale, breeder and exhibitor of many prize winning bulldogs, died hero on Sunday after a long illness. He was 73 years old. Mr. Grisdale bred and exhibited Prince of Wales, champion in 19261927, the first American-bred English bulldog to win a title in England. Prince of Wales won first ribbons at the Crystal Palace, Cruft's and Olympia.

Vincent J. Murphy, an independent candidate and secretary-treasurer of the New Jersey Federation of Labor, was elected to the Newark City Conimission yesterday, and Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein was returned to office.

Close to 1,000,000 Londoners and visitors from all parts of King George's realm were massed in the streets at dawn today, waiting patiently for the coronation procession to begin. The whole six-mile route was so thickly lined with spectators that in many places there was no room on the sidewalks for any one who came after 5 A. M.

Wilson Co. Edward B. Smith Co. and Glore, Forgan Co. will offer today $6,500,000 of Wilson Co., Inc., 333 per cent debentures due on April 1, 1947. The debentures will be priced at 101 and accrued interest.

A resolution to permit women to become members of the Protestant Episcopal Board of Missions was defeated here today at the sixty-third annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Newark in Trinity Cathedral.
The House Appropriations Committee completed action today upon the regular government supply bills by reporting favorably the Interior Department appropriation measure, carrying $115,871,264.
In August, 1929, the Graf Zeppelin made a successful trip around the world, and during a mooring interval at Lakehurst Dr. Eckener paid a visit to President Hoover.

Foreign merchandising and advertising methods are based on a more fundamental approach than are the "insipid methods of selling we pursue here," Arthur Good-' friend of the L. S. Goldsmith advertising agency, told the Export Managers Club of New York, Inc..

The newspaper Diario Vasco said today that Prince Gaetan of Bourbon- Parma had been seriously wounded while fighting with the Spanish Insurgents. The Prince, who is 31 years old, is the youngest brother of former Empress Zita of Austria, mother of Archduke Otto, claimant of the throne.

The King whom Britain crowns today is unspectacular, respectable and, above all else, a traditionalist. He who emerged from the tumult of the abdication of Edward VIII has passed sedate years of devotion to his family and the empire.

Governor J. A. Flores da Cunha of Rio Grande do Sul, in a manifesto issued yesterday at Porto Alegre, the State capital, endorses former Governor Armando Salles de Oliveira 'of Sao Paulo as a candidate for Brazil's Presidency.

Barnet Jacobs, organizer of Local 4, New York Joint Board of the International Journeymen Barbers Union, announced yesterday that his local had effected a settlement with the employers of 400 barbers in the Brownsville and East New York sections of Brooklyn and that the men would return to work today.

Lowell Thomas was elected president of the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue, yesterday, to succeed H. B. LeQuatte. Lee J. Eastman, head of the Packard Motor Car Company of New York, was elected vice president and Ralph Trier, president of the New York Theatre Program Corporation, treasurer.

The high importance of the work of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime In New York has caused me to break a rule against the making of public addresses to which I have adhered for more than a year.

The empire that remains an empire only because of a common loyalty to the King will pledge allegiance to George VI tomorrow as it did to his father twenty-six years ago. But there have been momentous changes.

Five mural paintings by Stefan Hirsch in the auditorium of the Lenox Hill House, 331 East Seventieth Street, were exhibited yesterday for the first time at a tea in honor of Mr. Hirsch. On the east wall of the auditorium are panels depleting "Recreation" and "The Desire to Build."

Union labor opened an appeal to movie audiences last night to support it in the Hollywood strike of technicians by picketing every film theatre in Times Square. The pickets marched, with placards, back and forth in front of the theatres during the peak of the movie rush, between 8 and 9 P. M., and then quickly disappeared.

Luncheon meeting of the New York Board of Trade, Hotel Astor, noon. Address by George S. Messersmith. Luncheon meeting of the Kiwants Club of New York City, Hotel Mc. Alpin, 12:30 P. M. "Old Revelations and New," Rabbi Morton M. Berman.

Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., said yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commission that a reduction of approximately $625,000 in annual interest and preferred dividend requirements of the New York Steam Corporation would ensue if the present plans for refunding and exchanging preferred stocks were consummated.

More than 1,000 little girls, especially excused from school, danced around twenty-four Maypoles yesterday afternoon in the Sheep Meadow in Central Park. The Maypole dance was the climax of the thirtieth annual park fete of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League.
Callover-of odds for the Derby tonight showed Le Ksar, winner of the 2,000 Guineas, still favorite at 11 to 2 for the June 2 classic for 3-year-olds.

Meadow Brook members' polo speeded up a bit today, with seventeen players getting together in two closely contested matches. On the club's No. 4 field, two teams captained by members of the United States four in the Cup of the America series against Argentina last Fall. battled to a 9-to-9 deadlock, while at Mitchel Field the Blues won from a White combination, 6 to 5.

Barnard School's nine gained the uptown division title in the Metropolitan A. A. of Private Schools-by halting Fieldston, 16-5, on the loser's field yesterday. Ed Beckmann's homer with two on in the 1 third featured.

The Transit Commission disclaimed yesterday official responsibility for the $843,000,000 price suggested by John J. Curtin, its special counsel, as the proper one to pay in a unification deal with the B. M. T. and 1. R. T. and by so doing indicated that it had no intention of accepting Mayor La Guardia's challenge to work out a unification plan along those lines before the Fall Mayoralty campaign.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, May 11.--As a sort of Coronation Eve counter-diversion, debate on President Eamon de Valera's proposed new Constitution opened in the Dail Eireann this evening. Republican extremists, however, put on a show of their own in Dublin tonight which made the Dail proceedings seem tame.

New York University's tennis team defeated Long Island University, 8--1, on the Fleet Hollow courts, for their fifth triumph in eight matches yesterday. Charles Masterson, No. 1 star for the Blackbirds, was the only victor for the losers.

Mrs. Mathilda Kohn Brand, a former dress manufacturer here and the widow of Henry L. Brand, Confederate veteran, died on Monday at her home, 160-15 Seventh Avenue, Beechhurst, Queens, after a two-month illness. Her husband, a retired jeweler, died on Nov. 20 at the age of 99. Mrs. Brand was 89 years old.

If the institutions of freedom are to be preserved, citizens of the United States "must uphold and maintain these institutions and must oppose with their whole strength any measure or proposal which leads away from democracy toward personal government and absolute executive power," Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday afternoon.

Business failures declined in the retail division in the week ended May 6 in comparison with the previous week and with the same week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:

The Lafayette National Bank of Brooklyn, as successor trustee under the last will of Henry Grube, has sold the four-story brick apartment at 703-7 Hopkinson Avenue, Brooklyn, to an investing client of Edward Breslow.
During a ten-minute cessation of the clangor of naval ship building, Ranger, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new America's Cup yacht, was launched this afternoon at the Bath Iron Works.
The cellar-dwelling Baltimore Orioles dropped their second straight game to Montreal today, 8-7, as the Royals hit fourth place for the first time this season.

Atley Donald hurled his fourth consecutive victory today as the Newark Bears evened their series with the Red Wings by a 4-1 victory. Donald held the Bladesmen to six scattered hits and fanned eight batsmen.

MANHATTAN ARCHER, ELIZABETH (Sept. 27, 1936). Gross assets, $19,825; net, $19,014. To Annie Roberts, sister, $4,368; David Archer, nephew; Helen Collins, niece, $5,238 each; James J. Archer and Thomas Archer, nephews, $1,092 each; William D. Roberts, nephew, $1,540; one other bequest. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $14,473. John P. Gerling, attorney, 87-14 Grand St.. Elmhurst, L. I.

Stockholders of the Los Angeles Gas and Electric Corporation and of the Southern California Gas Company, representing substantially more than two-thirds of all classes of outstanding stock, today approved a merger agreement which combines the properties of both under the name of the Southern California Gas - Company. Combined assets will total $151.000.000.

In 1932 and 1933, New Jersey's tax authorities more than doubled the valuation of the property of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company in this State that they had placed on it in 1926 although revenues and payrolls de creased about one-half, it was testified today in the United States District Court here by George J. Ray, vice president and general manager of the company.

Mrs. Sarah A. Connolly, member of a family identified with the early history of this city, died early this morning at her home after a brief illness. Born here seventy-five years ago, she was the daughter of Charles I. and Elizabeth Brown Holder.

Plans for the operation of Harvard's new Graduate School of Public Administration, determined as a result of a series of conferences held this Spring between public officials and members of the school's faculty, were made public at Harvard tonight with the announcement that John H. Williams, Professor of Political Economy at Harvard and vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has been appointed dean of the new school, effective in September.

Theatre audiences were asked last night to urge Governor Lehman to veto the Dunnigan bill, recently passed at Albany, which would empower the Commissioner of Licenses to revoke the permit for any house showing a play he deemed objectionable.
Chancellori Adolf Hitler issued orders today that neither the Graf Zeppelin nor the LP-130 now nearing completion make transatlantic flights until the helium-hydrogen issue has been settled.

Eugene Douglas, 18, today led striking pickets around his father's plant, the New England Paper Tube Company, because, he said, his fellow-workers agreed he should have a $3-a-week pay rise. In the idle factory the lad's father, Henry Douglas, said the youthful picket leader had been slated to inherit the plant.
Food prices are not rising in proportion to the general price increase in this country, according to the American Institute of Food Distribution.

Melvin Schwartzman, 15-year-old Poly Prep tennis captain, and Ralph Dawson of Trinity advanced to the final in the twenty-second annual championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

The daily average sales of variety stores were about 8 per cent less in dollar volume in April than in the corresponding month of 1936, the Commerce Department disclosed today. Compared with March these sales fell off about 9.5 per cent.

Eugene Black, chairman of the Board of Tax Appeals, appointed three members today to act with the Internal Revenue Bureau regarding methods of reducing the number of pending cases of tax litigation, which run into thousands and involve about $500,000,000.

Bond prices continued mixed in slightly increased trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Total sales amounted to $9,158,600 against $7,518,000 on Monday. There was a sharp increase in the demand for United States Government issues which had a turnover of $2,167,600 in contrast to $538,000 on the proceeding day.
The Giants did an impressive job of battering the Cubs as a team yesterday before 6,973 fans at the Polo Grounds and then started after Charley Grimm's clan man for man.

Mayor and Mrs. La Guardia left early this morning by train for Los Angeles, where the Mayor will attend a regional meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors, which he heads. The meetings will start Saturday. The Mayor plans to return to New York in about two weeks.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized listing of $26,560,000 Ohio Edison Company first mortgage 3. per cent bonds due in 1972; 60,147 shares of Caterpillar Tractor Company 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value; voting trust certificates for 66,454 additional shares of Sperry Corporation common stock, $1 par value, and 75,344 additional shares of Interstate Department Stores, Inc., common stock, no par value.

The story of the defense of the Toledo Alcazar in 1936 is told in "The Siege of Alcazar," by Major Geoffrey McNeill-Moss, which Alfred A. Knopf will publish in early July. It is a detailed day-by-day account of what went on in the ancient Moorish fortress during the seventy days of the defense.

Oil explorations, which had been advancing rapidly in accordance with the government's plans, have now been set back considerably on account of lack of funds, it is admitted by the chief of the Department of Mines and Petroleum.

Deliveries for the first four months of 1937 through the nine Eastern pipe lines formerly comprising the Standard Oil group amounted to 37,291,280 barrels, a daily average of 310,760, compared with 30,687,689, a daily average of 253,617, in the corresponding period last year.

It is not unusual for wives to shop for their husbands, so the clerk at Thom McAn's Delancey Street store thought nothing of it when Mrs. Helen Stein of 53 Siegel Street, Brooklyn, walked in last Friday and ordered a pair of size eight men's shoes.

After sixty-eight years of exclusive masculinity, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York voted last night at its annual meeting at 42 West Forty-fourth Street to open its august portals to women. The removal of the bars was accomplished not by constitutional amendment, which requires a twothirds vote, but by a resolution of interpretation, requiring a mere majority.

The warmly disputed contest in Manville, Somerset County, between Mayor Joseph Onka, Republican, and the Borough Council, Democratic,. over the selection of the council's president was decided here today in favor of the Mayor by Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker.

The crowds outside Buckingham Palace this afternoon saw a kestrel fly from St. James Park and circle over Constitution Hill toward the palace and settle on the crown above the royal arms on the pediment over the palace's main doorway.

Pierre S. du Pont, retired chairman of the group of industries connected with the name of du Pont, chuckled here yesterday when he saw the cabled report that Ambassador Dodd had heard in Berlin of an American billionaire who was ready to support an American dictatorship.
After several days of slack trading, activity in Bronx properties again was reported by brokers yesterday. Apartment house sales featured the day's deals.

Compromise between the warring factions in Spain and an adjustment of differences, possibly by outside intervention, is perhaps the only way to insure peace, according to E. Allison Peers, Professor of Spanish at the University of Liverpool, who arrived yesterday on the Aquitania.

The Bees made only one threat today when Cy Blanton, the Pirates' screwball flinger, hurled the National League pace-setters to a 3-0 shutout, registering for the visitors a clean sweep of the three-game series.

A caucus of delegates claiming to represent 85 per cent of those attending the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union convention was held today, after which it was announced they were in concurrence with David Dubinsky, the union president, who predicted several days ago the garment workers would take the initiative in seeking to bring about peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

THE Cardinals have gone but the melody lingers on-if you could call it melody Just before Onkel Franz Frisch bundled his merry men off for Philadelphia, this observer ran into an impromptu rehearsal of that artistic group known as Pepper Martin's Marvelous Musical Mississippi Mudcats. For sound effects, an impromptu rehearsal of the Marvelous Musical Mudcats is akin to spontaneous combustion in the rocket department of a fireworks plant.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, and Lady Lindsay entertained more than 1,000 guests this afternoon in the gardens of the embassy to celebrate the coronation of King George and Queen Elizabeth.

Macombs Rd. 1,505 (11-2873); Morton Estates, Inc. to Macombs Equities, Inc, 332 E 149th St: 5 per cent; $39,475. Mosholu Pkwy No, 29 E (12-3328a): Vypad Realty Corp to Sterling National Bank Trust Co: one year, 6 per cent; building load; $60,000.

Speakers at the annual convention of the New York State Bankers Association, to be held at sea on board the liner Washington over the Memorial Day week-end, will include William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks;
Stocks closed irregularly. lower in second lowest trading of year; turnover, 674,076 shares. United States Government issues lower, corporate and foreign bonds irregular; transactions, $7,821,100.

Thomas Elsmore, former head of the American branch of the Liverpool, England, importing firm of Robert Crooks Co., and later, until his retirement in 1931, with the Bennett Bay Importing Company, New York, died today at his home here. He was born in

Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Grace have returned from the South and are at the Waldorf-Astoria before going to The Crossroads, their country home in Old Westbury. Mrs. Fenton B. Turck will give a luncheon today in the Savoy Room of the Savoy-Plaza.
Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, has been re-elected a member of the Business Advisory Council, Secretary Roper announced at his press conference today. Kermit Roosevelt,

Every word of-the historic ritual in the coronation of King 'George VI in Westminster Abbey and his address to the empire flashed around the earth by radio and was clearly heard .by a multitude of listeners throughout the United States and Canada.

Plans for $5,386,565 .in new industrial construction in the State outside of this city were submitted to the State Department of Labor in April, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday. This is the largest total

There is silence again in Westminster Abbey as the later hours of a lingering Spring afternoon slip by; the thousands of feet that stirred there today have gone their ways; the air that was rent by thousands of voices is still.

The VicarGeneral of the Ermland diocese, Father Kreth, was sentenced to twelve years in the penitentiary and ten additional years of police supervision with the loss of all civil rights today by a court in Braunsberg, East Prussia. He was convicted of gross immorality.

Assuming command when ready, Phil Reilly's Come to Taw, a disappointing preparation for the Kentucky Derby, today dashed to an easy victory over a fast band of 3-year-olds in the Harrods Creek purse at Churchill Downs.

Harrison S. Martin, former first assistant secretary of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in his home at 495 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of fourteen months. He was 74 years old. He had been connected with the Exchange for twenty-seven years.

The Kelvinator Corporation and the Ross Roy Service, Inc., both of Detroit, were charged by the Federal Trade Commission in a complaint filed today with unfair competition through cooperating to disparage the products of Kelvinator's competitors. The complaint

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Eugenia Micou, daughter of Mrs. Morgan Turringtine Micou of University, Va., and the late Dr. Micou, to Anthony Burnham Boynton, son of Commander Harold Walter Boynton, U.S.N. (retired), and Mrs. Boynton of Honolulu, formerly of Scarsdale, N. Y.
For the fourth time a Gloucester County grand jury refused today to indict Edward Hubbard, 28 years old, of Monroeville for the shotgun slaying of his sister's suitor.
