A sentence of twenty-five to thirty years in State's Prison was imposed today on Stephen Bahun, 45 years old, an iron worker, by Judge Robert V. Kinkead in the Court of Oyer and Terminer after Bahun had pleaded non vult to a charge of murder in the second degree.

Bidding mounted considerably at the third day's auction yesterday of art objects and furnishings of Inisfada, the palatial country residence of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, at Manhasset, L. I.

Catholics in numerous towns of six Mexican States have petitioned the Seeretary of the Interior to permit the reopening of churches in their locilities, the pro-Catholic newspaper Ultimas Noticias reports today.

Plans for altering a property in the Chelsea section were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the three-story and basement dwelling at 346 West Twentysecond Street by Stewart Chaplin, who has occupied part of the building since he bought it in 1912.

Announcement was made yesterday by Sidney Hillman, chairman of the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, C. I. O. affiliate, that the union has signed a contract with the Beaunit Mills, manufacturers of rayon knit cloth, for its three plants at Cohoes and Fort Plain, N. Y., and Beverly, N. J.

S. D. Mahan has been appointed made pu general advertising manager of the Lanzit, Westinghouse Electric and Manu- Samue facturing Company, G. H. Bucher, for the executive vice president, announced comprise yesterday. Formerly manager of citation.
Leo Francis Curley, son of former Governor Curley, tonight resigned as a student in the Harvard Law School because of a "slur" he said was made upon his father in a classroom.

Edwin Goodman, president of Bergdorf-Goodman, was elected to the board of directors of the Fifth Avenue Association at a directors' meeting yesterday, succeeding the late Walter Stabler; and Leo S. DePinna, president of DePinna, was named to succeedd the late Arthur Williams. William Warner Hoppin,

The Protestant church in Germany is ready to compromise with the State, but nobody knows what the Nazi government is going to require, according to Dr. Julius Richter, former professor at the University of Berlin, who spoke yesterday on the crisis in the German church at the Spring meeting of the American section of the Universal Christian Council at the Hotel George Washington.

Mrs. Anna Frances Thomas Welles, widow of Francis R. Welles, European manager and vice president of the Western Electric Company, died yesterday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. J. E. Briggs, in Paris, according to word received here. She was 75 years old.

Rather than appear to be taking. sides in the Spanish conflict, Walter Hampden. has reconsidered his promise, to play the leading role in the pageant to be presented May 19 at Madison Square Garden by the American Committee for Spanish Relief.

Suggestions that the controversy raging around President Roosevelt's program for judiciary reorganization might be settled within a few weeks and that it would involve the retirement of some of the present members of the Supreme Court were revived in some circles here today.

Offering will be made today of an issue of $2,000,000 of fifteen-year 5 1/2 per cent debentures, with non-detachable stbck-purchase warrants, and 175,000 shares of common stock of $1 par value of the National Container Corporation. The debentures,

Led by Jim Herbert, New York University's freshman track team turned back the Columbia cubs, 622/3 to 531/3, yesterday at Baker Field. Herbert won the 220-yard dash and quarter-mile in addition to placing second in the low hurdles. For Columbia, Murray Oguss

Gross assets, $103,949; net, $91,882. To Sarah Bronstein and Branna Brilliant, sister, $1,000 each; Rachel Busch, widow, life estate in residue; twelve minor bequests. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $65,187. Feltenstein Rosenstein, attorneys, 305 Broadway.
The Bisons beat Jersey City, 5-1 and 11-2, today, scoring six runs in the last inning of the second game, which was called in the fifth when rain fell.

Miss Ann R. Foster, daughter of Mrs. Barrows Porter of 521 Park Avenue and the late Herbert I. Foster, has completed the plans for her marriage to Thomas LeBoutillier 3d, son of Mrs. Thomas LeBoutillier 2d of Westbury, L. I., and the late Mr. LeBoutillier, on the afternoon of May 27 in the Church of the Resurrection.

The marriage of Miss Ruth D. Voltter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Voltter of 1 West Eightyfirst Street, to Marvin Silberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Silberman of Hartford, Conn., took place last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre.

The engagement of $7,815,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of this amount, $7,552,000 was taken in England on Tuesday, while $263,000 was engaged in India yesterday.
Additional registration statements under the Securities Act of 1933 were made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. They are:

Tributes to King George VI and predictions that his reign would lead to a strengthening of the bonds between Great Britain and the United States were expressed last night at a coronation dinner sponscored by the English-Speaking Union at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Senecaville Dam, a link in the Muskingum Valley floodcontrol program forming Ohio's third largest inland body of water, will be dedicated tomorrow.

LIEUTENANT COLONELS Taylor, V. V., Adjutant General's Dept., 3 days' leave, May 13. Philloon, W. C. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, 8 days' leave, May 14. Patton, G. S. (Cay.), General Staff Corps. 1 month and 15 days' leave, June 23. Williams, C. F., Engrs., 1 month and 15 days' leave, June 15.
Some 400 employes of the Milton Bradley Company, manufacturers of school supplies and games, staged a demonstration strike today which was prolonged far beyond the intended fifteen-minute period.

Trading was slow on most of the major cuts. of steer beef and prices were steady to sharply lower. Veal moved only fair to slow at steady to weak prices. Lamb and fresh pork were in fair demand. Lamb prices were higher and pork steady to stronger. The kosher markets opened steady on practically all classes as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Samuel L. Buck, vice president and director of the Taylor-Wharton Iron and Steel Company here, died at a hospital in Somerville yesterday of pneumonia. He was 64 years old.

More than 100 Dickinson College students, or almost one-fifth of the student body, who have acted, sung or lectured from many rostra in the East, were invited today to attend the recognition reception of the Deputation Committee which they have served.

The prosecution rested yesterday in the General Sessions first-degree murder trial of Joseph Berger, 29 years old, and Gabriel Klar, 34, in the fatal stabbing of Frank Cicero, 33, a Stamford (Conn.) truckman, at a testimonial dinner in the Manhattan Opera House in West Thirtyfourth Street on the night of last Jan. 17. Judge Freschi then

A thirty-five-foot motor cruiser, which had been drifting five hours with one member of its two-man crew dead, was towed here about 9 o'clock last night by the Coast Guard. The skipper of the craft, on its way from City Island, New York, to Parris Island, S. C., was Charles Siebert, 50 years old, of 167 Sands Street, Brooklyn.
The Great Western Sugar Company has contracted for 14 per cent less beet-sugar acreage this year than in 1936, W. L. Petrikin, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting today. The reduction

A strike by 1,200 attendants in 500 gasoline stations in Manhattan and the Bronx, first threatened last Saturday, was averted last night when the workers and employers agreed on a compromise of the Gasline Station Attendants Union's demands.

Two home runs availed the Bees little today as they dropped their sixth consecutive game, losing to the Cubs, 6-2. Charley Root, veteran right-hander, held Boston to five hits, including circuit drives by Gene Moore and Tony Cuccinello, while gaining his first 1937 triumph.

Sixto Escobar, holder of the world bantamweight championship, knocked out Nickey Jerome of Greenpoint in the second round of the scheduled ten-round feature bout at the New York Hippodrome last night.

Sir Henry Birchenough, one of the foremost experts on politico-economic subjects in the world, died today at the age of 84. He was a member of the advisory committee of the Board of Trade, president of the BritishSouth Africa Company and had served on many important commissions.
The Royal Canadian Mounted Police rode on horses in Windsor, Ont., today as its residents and thousands of visitling Detroiters took part in elaborate coronation celebration ceremonies.
Stockholders of the Bridgeport City Trust Company adopted today a recommendation of the board

Justice James P. Hill, presiding justice of the Appellate Division, Third Department, told the Albany County Bar Association last night that"when President Roosevelt attacked the Supreme Court, he did a disservice to his country."

A bill re-creating the office of 'counselor for the State Department was passed today by the House and sent to the White House.

Charles G. Bond, who announced recently that he would seek the Republican nomination for Mayor, denounced Mayor La Guardia last night as "an opportunist eager seize an issue". because of the Mayor's attack on the Transit Commission after its refusal to accept the Seabury-Berle transit unification plan. Mr. Bond addressed the

Golf followers in the metropolitan area will get their first glimpse of: the newest sensation to come down the golf pike tomorrow as Sam Snead,, sensational young White Sulphur Springs star tees off in the metropolitan open championship over the Forest Hill Field Club course.

Charges of violation of the National Labor Relations Act were served yesterday by the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board upon the ConsolidatedEdison Company and six subsidiaries following complaint filed with the board by the United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate.

" Moving-up Day" fighting between freshmen and sophomores, an Alfred University tradition, is slated for oblivion. Aroused by a toll of property damage and injuries to students in recent years, the Student Senate has announced a plan for orderly activities which will be tried out tomorrow for the first time.
Stockholders of the Federal Mining and Smelting Company approved yesterday the retirement of 11,442 shares of preferred stock, of which 6,442 shares are held by the company.

Captain Paul H. Schaefer, retired Arctic explorer, who had also been an artist and lecturer, died today at St. Agnes Hospital here. Captain Schaefer, of 14?? Colden Avenue, suffered a heart attack last Summer and had since been in poor health. His age war 59.

Hamilton Carhartt, founder of the overall manufacturing firm bearing his name, died today of injuries suffered Monday in an automobile collision which earlier took the life of his wife, Mrs. Annette Welling Carhartt. Double funeral services will be held tomorrow.

Charges that paper box manufacturers are "an open and notorious combination acting in conspiracy to maintain a closed market and to fix uniform prices" on the containers used in the women's apparel industry were renewed in a letter sent to the State Attorney General's office by the National Dress Manufacturers Association, and made public yesterday by Mortimer Lanzit, executive director.

Striking employes of the Publicker Commercial Alcohol Company and its affiliate, the Continental Distilling Company, chose tonight a coalition of Committee for Industrial Organization and American Federation of Labor unions to represent them in collective bargaining.

A team of forty-seven athletes yesterday was nominated by Yale for the sixty-first annual track and field championships of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A., which will celebrate their return to New York at Randalls Island Stadium on May 28 and 29.

One would be hard put to it to defend the recent performances in the burlesque theatres of- this city. They were undisguisedly pornographic in aim, often filthy, and devoid of any trace of art. PAUL MOSS,

The Episcopal Diocese of New York voted to take "no action" on the question of the proposed enlargement of the Supreme Court at the closing session of its 154th con-vention yesterday in the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The convention opened Tuesday morning.

The Census Bureau reported today that cottonseed crushed in the ninemonth period, Aug. 1 to April 30, totaled 4,279,306 tons, compared with 3,669,931 in the corresponding period a year ago. Cottonseed on

With the conclusion this afternoon of the protracted hearings of the Federal Trade Commission into an alleged conspiracy of rayon manufacturers to fix prices, it appeared that all but three of the ten companies named by the commission in the original complaint failed to oppose the adverse findings of the trial examiner.

Distribution to home relief families of 2,056,989 articles of clothing made by seamstresses on WPA sewing projects was reported yesterday by Miss Charlotte E. Carr, executive director of the Emergency Relief Bureau.

Frederick C. Weigel, 47 years old, of Port Jervis, a past commander of the Orange County American Legion, was killed today in an automobile accident near Montgomery. Three other occupants of the car, all of Port Jervis, were injured. Thomas R. Scales,

High-salaried movie stars, whose Screen Actors Guild recently reached a separate peace with film producers, are contributing "substantial financial support" to striking studio craftsmen, a union-leader said today.

Mrs. D. Buchanan Merryman of Washington, aunt of Mrs. Wallis Warfield, sailed yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt for Havre, presumably to attend the wedding of her niece to the Duke of Windsor.

Steel production continues at a high rate, but most consumers find their present stocks or commitments ample for their early requirements and, consequently, the volume of new business still is shrinking moderately, Iron Age says this week. Consumption, it adds,
In the greatest team fielding exhibition seen here in many years, Dartmouth won its sixth straight Eastern Intercollegiate League baseball game today by turning back Yale, 3-1.

The plan of reorganization of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation has been amended to provide for an offer to unsecured creditors of one share of new preferred and one share of new common stock for each $100 of claims, instead of three-quarters of a preferred share and one and one-half common shares, as provided in the original plan.

One hundred and forty-two playgrounds -in the city became the battlefield yesterday for confused conflict between Mayor La Guardia, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, WPA Administrator, and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine on the one side, and Park Commissioner Robert Moses on the other.

Edithton Beach the "millionaires' playground," which Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick started to build on the shore of Lake Michigan in Southern Wisconsin, has been gold for $187,000 at a Sheriff's foreclosure auction in Kenosha.

Two little Princesses saw their father crowned King today, but their reactions were very different. Eleven-year-old Princess Elizabeth sat primly in her seat in the royal box, her attention fastened on the dramatic spectacle before her.

Dairymen of Dutchess, Putnam, northern Westchester and Fairfield counties will meet here Monday night to take action on bills passed by the Legislature affecting the milk industry. They will instruct their delegates what position to take at public hearings to be held by Governor Lehman.

Social security account number th cards are the property of the employes to whom they are issued and are not to be retained by employers, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, warned yesterday, after complaints had been received That some employers refused to turn over account cards to their workers.

The influence of the coronation was in evidence yesterday at the annual park the of the Queens Public School Athletic League Kings Park, Jamaica, Queens. The traditional Maypole festivities and the dances were marked with a coronation touch.

A patriotically zealous patrolman, whose name has not been revealed, noticed last Tuesday that the Union Jack, unaccompanied by an American flag, was being displayed in front of the New York office of- The London Daily Telegraph at 55 East Fifty-fifth Street, in anticipation of the coronation of King George VI.

Carefree Beale Street came to life tonight, just as "that evening sun" went down. Some of the hottest "blue" notes ever sounded blared a challenge to trucking, shuffling feet as the king and queen of the cotton makers' jubilee strutted down the avenue.

Estate, less than. $1,000. To Carrie Milhardt, daughter,. executrix, 311 E. 90th St., due: one other bequest. DIETER, PAUL W. (April 5). Estate, less than $5,000. To Myrtle Adams Dieter, widow, executrix, 24 5th Ave.

Investigation of the rates and practices of the New York Telephone Company in service "to and through hotels" was ordered today by the Public Service Commission. An initial hearing will be held here on May 26.

Reports regarding the Brazilian political situation emanating from foreign countries and sent by unauthorized agents apparently do not present a true picture of the situation because they are founded mostly on hearsay.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area increased 12 per cent for the week ended May 8, in comparison with the same week a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the preceding week the gain was 10 per cent.

Never before in the history of man have so many persons heard one and the same voice at the same time - as " listened in" to the voice of King GEORGE VI yesterday. The Shippers Conference of Greater New York, at its monthly meeting, reiterated yesterday its opposition to Federal regulation of water transportation, but expressed its preference for the Maritime Commission as the regulatory body if Federal regulation of ship lines is legalized.
Dr. Thomas Milton Rivers was named yesterday by the board of scientific directors of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research as director of the department of the hospital of the institute.

Princeton and Rutgers divided the honors today in an informal regatta over the Henley distance course on Carnegie Lake. Princeton won two of the races held and Rutgers the other, with Manhattan last in each.

The Student Council of Amherst College has elected Richard M. Howland, Street, '38, of Manhasset, L. I., president. The new vice president is Harry F. Jones Jr., '38, of Riverton, N. J., and John F. McGrath, '38, of New York City, and Homer H. Clark, '39, of Garden City, L. I., were elected treasurer and recording secretary respectively.

At 10:34 o'clock this morning on schedule to the very second, the "all ready" signal was hoisted on the steps of the Victoria Monument and the coronation procession of George VI, monarch of one-fourth of the earth, moved off to the flourishes of Sousa's "Stars and,Stripes Forever."

Three men entered a crowded elevator in the building -at 49 West Thirty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon, cowed the passengers and took a payroll of $1,262 from a young woman. Forcing the passengers to leave the caro?? the ninth floor, they ordered the operator to bring them down to the second floor, where they got out and made their way downstairs and out of the building unnoticed.

Rebecca Henig, a stockholder, filed yesterday in the Supreme Court a motion for a temporary injunction to restrain the Manhattan Finance Corporation, a real estate and mortgage concern at 44 East Fifty-third Street, from submitting to stockholders on May 17 a plan of recapitalization.

A petition asking that an election be held among editorial employes of The United Press Association within the continental limits of the United States to select a collective bargaining agent was filed yesterday afternoon by the American Newspaper Guild with Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel T. Hubbard Jr. of 755 Park Avenue and Kennebunkport, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Hustace Hubbard, to Daniel Ellis Woodhull Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ellis Woodhull of 950 Park Avenue and Kennebunkport.

The so-called Rough House Reds descended on Ebbets Field yesterday for their first engagement with the Dodgers since their wars inFlorida, but their truculence was not apparent and their descent was punctuated by something very like a dull thud.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing at its offices in New York on May 24 in connection with a registration statement filed-under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Austin Silver Mining Company, Austin, Nev., of which Charles H. Sabin Jr. is president. The statement, covering 225,000 shares of $1 par capital stock became effective as of March 22.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Dominick of Greenwich of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine B. ?? Dominick, to Alexander G. Walcott, son of former United States Senator Frederic C. Walcott and the late Mrs. Walcott of Norfolk, Conn.
The ceremony which I-have just witnessed cannot easily be described. It is never easy to describe something. which is a mixture of pageantry, symbolism, tradition, solemnity and religion.

Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, in 'the fourth of a series of lectures on "The Future of the Republican Party," at the New School for Social Research, charged last night that groups seeking to supplant our present individualistic economy with a collectivist society were bent on destroying the Constitution because it stood between them and their objective.

Operations of the Holly Sugar Corporation and subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on March 31 resulted in a consolidated net profit of $2,881,670 after all charges, adjustments, reserves and Federal taxes, according to the annual report issued yesterday.
Well represented among the visiting dignitaries in Westminster Abbey were the lesser breeds within the law. The contingent from

Films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private schools. Marian Anderson gave her final song recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night to a packed house of admirers of her art. The contralto was welcomed with the perfervid sort of enthusiasm such as befalls a singer only when at the top of the wave of public favor.

LONDON, May 12.--The most representative military spectacle the British Empire could muster escorted King George today through six miles of London streets to signalize his coronation, while more than 1,000,000 Londoners and visitors from all countries looked on and cheered even in the last hour, when a cloudburst fell from the skies.
In a setting of medieval splendor such as seemed scarcely to belong to this day and age George VI was crowned King and Emperor in Westminster Abbey today.

The National Sculpture Society has awarded the Lindsay Morris Memorial Prize of $300 to Erwin Springweiler of New York. The award was made in connection with the opening of a special exhibition of small sculpture in relief, on view in the gallery of the Architectural League until May 22.
About 6,000 persons attended the British Empire Coronation Ball, Sponsored by forty British and American societies, last night in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue.
The wolf is gone from Max Dermer's door. Dermer had been keeping the ani- M mal there for eight years as an advertisement for a fur business and the place is not the same without him.

A jury had been chosen and Assistant District Attorney Neary was making his opening address in General Sessions yesterday' in the forgery trial of Frederick B. MacLaren, ex-convict and suspected safe robber, when the prisoner pleaded guilty.

Holidays in Winnipeg and Liverpool resulted in a light speculative trade in wheat futures in the domestic markets today, with prices declining moderately early on the Board of Trade here on scattered local selling and a continuation of liquidation by holders of May contracts.

A Strike by twenty-five men in the Fisher Body Corporation's Plant No. 2 forced the closing of that factory and the Chevrolet Motor Company's final assembly plant today, but, after a four-hour conference of union leaders and the management, the employes agreed to return to work tomorrow, pending further negotiations.

The drive in Congress for budget-balancing economies slowed down measurably today when administration forces began exerting pressure to restore the $1,500,000,000 relief appropriation, reduced to $1,000,000,000 by a House subcommittee yesterday, and the Senate overrode all economy arguments to authorize a new TVA dam, which would cost eventually $112,000,000.

The importance of creating health programs for children and of counteracting "potentially dangerous" parental relationships was stressed yesterday by speakers at the thirtyfirst annual convention of Boys Clubs of America, now in session at the Hotel Commodore, before 300 delegates from every- State.

A special meeting of stockholders of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., has been called for June 11 in Troy, N. Y., to consider a proposal to subdivide each share of common stock into. three shares of the same class. and to change the stated value of the common stock from $19.45 to $6.50 share.

A scene from the motion-picture film taken in Westminster Abbey in which Queen Mary is shown in a close-up drying her eyes during a period of emotion at the coronation service was cut out tonight by order of the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Duke of Norfolk, the Earl Marshal.

Wider use of the X-ray machine in tests to detect tuberculosis and a more intensified drive to increase the number of persons who submit to examinations for the disease were urged yesterday by speakers at the annual conference of the State Committee on Tuberculosis and Public Health of the State Charities Aid Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Major Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the board of the Radio Corporation of America and former Chief of Service of Supply of the American Expeditionary Forces, received in absentia tonight the Medal of Merit of the Army Ordnance Association.

When the Agricultural Department estimated in December the largest acreage on record planted to Winter wheat, there was still the possibility of destruction by an unfavorable Winter, such as reduced the planted acreage of 1935 nearly 30 per cent from the first estimate. The past Winter season has

Abandonment of airships and deflation of its three "blimps" have been ordered.by the War Department, and in the future all army lighter-thanair activity will be devoted exclusively to experiments with balloons, which will be used, if at all, as "eyes" to direct infantry and artillery fire.

The Roman Catholic population of the United States and its possessions was increased by 436,081 persons in 1936, making a grand total of 20,959,134, according to The Official Catholic Directory for 1937, published here yesterday by P. J. Kenedy Sons, book publishers.
The 4,500 bus and trolley operators and shop employes of Public Service Coordinated Transport today asked Thomas N. McCarter, president of Public Service Corporation, for a wage increase.

The Fidelity Liquidating Trust through Joseph P. Day, sales agent, sold properties in New Jersey as follows: House at 879 Prince Street, Teaneck, to Alexander P. Kueller, through Quinn Brothers, co-brokers; dwelling at 117 Fulton Street,

Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stewart 3d of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of Mr. Stewart's daughter, Miss Anne Thomas Stewart, to T. Wilkinson Satterthwaite Jr., son of Mrs. Weeks Satterthwaite of 29 East Eighty-third Street and of T. Wilkinson Satterthwaite.

The State Senate passed the bill today for a graduated tax of $1 to $500 each on chain stores and chain theatres in Pennsylvania. The vote was 33 to 14 on the measure which had the support of the Earle Administration.
Although it opened strong, the Bourse today was influenced by the fact that London's Stock Exchange was closed, so little business was done and prices ended somewhat irregular.

Search for a city manager for Cincinnati appeared near a conclusion, at least temporarily, tonight, with prospect that the City Council would appoint City Solicitor John D. Ellis to succeed Clarence A. Dvkstra.

Al Friedlander, prominent in motion picture distributions in Manhattan and sponsor of the film "Goona-Goona" in 1982, among other independentally produced successes, died yesterday of a heart attack in the office of a former associate, Harry H. Thomas, in Radio Center. His age was 46.

At the annual meeting of shareholders of the Discount Corporation of New York, held at noon yesterday at the company's offices, 58 Pine Street, Herbert N. Repp; vice president and secretary of the corporation, was elected to the board of directors. Mr. Repp, who has

Installment buying has taken shops hold in Cuba with the return of customers prosperity to that country and credit is being used to acquire electrical refrigerators, vacuum clean- * ers, washing machines and a vari-ety of other major household appliances, electrical manufacturers reported here yesterday. Records of payment, they added, have been highly satisfactory.

A rally in the closing innings and an excellent bit of relief hurling by Ed Boell enabled New York University's freshman baseball team to turn back the Manhattan cub nine, 3 to 2, at Manhattan Field yesterday. The Violets tallied two runs in the fifth to tie the score and made their winning marker in the sixth.
Electric power production declined more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index receded to 106.5 from 107.4. It was 100.4 for the week ended May 9, 1936.

Edward Lawford, 24 years old, a real estate broker, of the Hotel Gladstone, 114 East Fifty-second Street, was booked on charges of felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law at 9:30 o'clock last night at the East Sixty-seventh Street police station in connection with the shooting early yesterday of Martene W. (Bill) Corum, 46, sports columnist for the New York Evening Journal.
Pictures of the British coronation were flashed by radio across the Atlantic in an almost unending stream during the height of the festivities yesterday, according to RCA Communications, New York.

Miss Grace Amory accounted for another. one-day tournament as she negotiated her home course at the Women's National Golf and Tennis' Club in 80 today to lead the Long Island Association's weekly field.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 12 (Canadian Press)--Three men, two of them constables of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, rode over a cliff to their deaths early today. Their car plunged over a 100-foot cliff, into the chilly waters of the Ottawa River and, in its course, ploughed through rocks, trees and shrubbery. Of the six in the car, three are suffering from shock, chill and bruises.

Company commanders shall forward a report on Friday, May 14, containing report on Friday. May 14, containing the names of four firemen of their companies who are best qualified to be assigned as company building inspectors. The list shall include the group and/or the platoon number to which they are assigned and also their vacation period.

James W. Shull, former president judge of the Perry County Court and Deputy Attorney General in the Fisher and second Pinchot administrations, died at his home here today after a week's illness. He was 81 years old.
The General Telephone Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net gain of 2,831 telephones in service in April, as compared with a gain of 1,932 instruments in April, 1936.

The trend to eliminate price competition through State laws which would ban advertising by various services is steadily growing, A. T. Falk, director of research of the Advertising Federation of America, said here yesterday. Current
Forty thousand English children cheered longest and loudest for the triumphal homeward procession of their newly crowned sovereigns.

CAPTAIN Webb, D. C., Civil Engineer Corps, de tached from Bureau of Yards and Docks Washington, D. C., on June 30; to home, relieved from all active duty. COMMANDERS Dyer, R. A., Jr., the Gold Star, to Naval Operations, Washington, D. C. Miles, A. C., Washington, D. C., to Naval Air Station, San Diego, Calif.

Drew swamped the Wagner nine, 10 to 5, today for its eighth victory of the season. In its last six games Drew has scored 86 runs. Swede Backstrom held Wagner to three scattered hits and fanned eleven. Six errors helped Wagner in tallying its runs.

Hardly had the news of the Hindenburg's frightful end reached him when Dr. LUDWIG DUERR, director of the Zeppelin plant at Friederichshafen, called the workmen together to inform them that they had in a psychological sense been thrown back to 1908, a fateful year, when Count ZEPPELIN'S plans seemed to have been hopelessly dashed by a catastrophe which had befallen one of his ships at near-by Echterdingen. Only the faith of the German

Barricading themselves in the Salvation Army Hospital, ninety men and fifty women started a "holy revolution" today aimed at overthrowing what they termed foreign domination of the organization in Japan.
A warning against speculation by banks in lowgrade bonds and a proposal for a uniform banking code for State banks were voiced here today by

Following are the addresses of homage to King George from chiefs of state in the British Commonwealth of Nations and colonies in the-British Empire, as transcribed yesterday afternoon by the National, Columbia and Mutual networks:

Although a further slight decline yesterday carried prices on the Cotton Exchange into new low ground for the movement, the market developed resistance at the lower levels and a recovery left the list with net gains of 4 to 7 points.

The firm of Wood, Stephens Wood, Inc., has been formed to conduct a general securities business at 40 Exchange Place. Officers are: John A. Wood, president; Lee H. Wood, vice president and treasurer; Dwight C. Stephens, secretary.

AARONS--Harry S., on May 10, beloved husband of Nettie, loving father of Hortense Hoffman, brother of. Martin, grandfather of Robert and Jane Hoffman. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St., Amsterdam Ave., Thursday, May 13, at 10 A. M.
In the festooned Polo Grounds yesterday, to the strains of "The Star-Spangled Banner," the Giants raised their pennant, a flaming-red banner which proclaimed them "Champions, National League, 1936."

Intensive detective work led early today to the arrest of Irving Barr, 20 years old, of 1,55i Park Place, Brooklyn, a sign painter and handy man in a Bronx department store, on a homicide charge and the clearing up of the mysterious killing of a night watchman in the store.

The Cathedral College baseball team topped the Stevens Tech nine by a 7-4 score at Castle Point Field today. Ed Conway starred on the mound for Cathedral by fanning eleven batters and ending abruptly several Stevens rallies. Al Frio of the
President ROOSEVELT will return .to Washington tomorrow to find Congress displaying more real interest in the problem of a balanced budget than it has shown at any time in recent years.

Harry Z. Levick, 60 years old, an examiner for the State Banking and Insurance Department, died early tonight after a quarrel with his son, Ira R. Levick, 29 years old, in the basement of their home at 611 Woodlawn Avenue. The son,

Transfer of the regular New York Curb Exchange membership of Richard P. Combs to Thomas J. Flanagan of Colvin Co. has been approved. William de Young Kay of Kay, Byfield Co.; William C. Franklin of Biggs, Mohrman Co.; John K. Starkweather of Starkweather Co., and Leo V. Belden of Belden Co. have been elected to associate membership on the Curb Exchange.
Virtually every city, village and hamlet in the British Isles joined this capital and the empire in acclaiming King George VI today.

Dr. Samuel Alexander Kinnier Wilson, neurologist, died today after an operation. Dr. Wilson, who had received high honors from British universities and medical societies, and from professional groups on the Continent and in the United States, was born in New Jersey, U. S. A., a son of the late Rev. J. Kinnier Wilson of County Monaghan, Ireland.

Out in front all the way, Glenn Cunningham, representing the New York Curb Exchange A. A., triumphed in the three-quarter-mile invitation run, billed as the principal feature of the Sixty-ninth Regiment A. A. twilight track and field meet at Lewisohn Stadium last night.

Frederick J. Lisman of 160 West Fifty-ninth Street, investment banker and expert on railroad affairs, filed a plea in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court. He reported liabilities of about $4,000,000, virtually all contingent on an unfinished lawsuit, and assets of undetermined value, also of a contingent nature.

About five hundred students of Brooklyn College met in the Church of the Pilgrims yesterday to commemorate the seventh birthday of the college since it separated from City College and Hunter College. Next September five new buildings in Flatbush will be opened and all college functions will be held there.

The Tudor pretender to the throne of England, "King Anthony I," was slightly ill today, but not as the result of the coronation of his rival, King George VI. The former Californian said he had had too much rhubharb and cream.

Arriving on the North German Lloyd liner Europa today are Dr. Hans Dieckhoff, who will succeed Dr. Hans Luther as German Ambassador, with Mrs. Dieckhoff; Mary Ellis, actress; Mr. and Mrs. A. Reaburn, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lalumier, Stephen Clausen, Dr. George Hasler, Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Pools, Mrs. F. B. Carpenter and Mr. and Mrs. C. O. Swanson.

Movement of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 11,000. including 3,500 direct. Market strong to 10c higher than Tuesday's best time; top, $10.60; bulk good and choice 200-300 pound.

A half-length victory at the end of a mile was scored at Belmont yesterday by the filly Albania, which now races for William H. Berri. Albania was one of three fillies to triumph on a day when outsiders upset four favorites at distances from a sprint to a mile, which was as long as any event during the afternoon.

Sharp criticism f Ambassador Dodd and demands for his recall from Germany were expressed today by some Senators opposed to the President's court bill, who interpreted Mr. Dodd's recent letter to some of their colleagues as an effort to frighten members into voting for court reorganization by representing fascism as the only alternative.

The Accident Board of the Bureau of Air Commerce held today that pilot errors were the probable causes of two air liner crashes close to Newhall Pass near Los Angeles last Winter in which seventeen persons met death.
Directors of Lane Bryant, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock. This is the first payment since 1932.

A number of firms in the furniture, housefurnishing and interior decorating businesses were reported yesterday by brokers as principals in the contracts closed for commercial space. Leases were taken in sections from the financial district to the upper part of Manhattan.
As the stadium echoed to the rattle of fifty-two base hits, the Royals and Baltimore today divided a doubleheader before 14,000 Coronation Day fans.
Two deaths and 9,583 Injuries were ascribed to the coronation celebration in a report made public tonight by the St. John Ambulance Brigade, which organized the task of overseeing the great crowds.

A series of garden visits will be conducted today and tomorrow in the Washington Square district as a benefit for the Judson Health Center, which is situated at 237 Thompson Street, just south of the Washington Arch. The places to be exhibited are distinctive for their intimacy and charm and several are well known to New Yorkers.

Miss Belle Bingley Anderson, for thirty-seven years a member of the faculty of the Masters School for Girls, first as a teacher of history, later as academic dean, died here Monday at her home on Hillside Road. She was graduated from Vassar in 1896.
President Roosevelt-sent to Congress today a message recommending a broad approach to legislation for flood control, soil erosion prevention and water conservation.

Assertions that moral standards were disintegrating through stupidity and supineness and that the older gent eration, by dropping its standards, was. responsible, were made by Rabbi Louis Wolsey of Rodeph Shalom Synagogue, speaking at the opening session today of the State Federation of Pennsylvania Women.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, declared today before the International Ladies Garment Workers Union convention that the rank and file of American labor had lost confidence in the American Federation of Labor and that neither they nor he wished to make peace with the federation.

LONDON, May 12.--With the cheers of London crowds still ringing in his ears, King George gave his personal thanks tonight to his peoples throughout the empire and promised to serve them faithfully in the years ahead.
Queens was the leading center of new construction yesterday when plans were filed for numerous small dwellings. One project in Bayside will cost $225,000.

Two of five defendants were found guilty by a jury in Federal Court last night of defrauding the government in connection with WPA contracts on the Henry Hudson Parkway. The jury disagreed as to the three other defendants.

May Yohe, actress famous in the Nineties and former owner of the "unlucky" Hope diamond, took an assumed name in Portland, Ore., so that public knowledge of the birth of a baby might not interfere with her stage career, it was declared yesterday in a deposition introduced before Referee Jeremiah F. Connor, 80 Maiden Lane.
Members of the Board of Trade today approved changes in rules governing trading in cotton on the Exchange, effective on the March, 1938, contracts, trading in which probably will be started tomorrow.

A wide variety of exhibits relating to the home, ranging from a typical slum flat to a palatial home including gardens and all modern comforts, will be placed on public view for ten days beginning this morning as part of the North American Homes Exposition at Madison Square Garden.
Gutzon Borglum, noted sculptor, maintained today that creation of the Mount Rushmore Memorial was not a "road contractor's job" nor one that can be measured by "the engineer's rule and compass."

The Emancipator III, a racing speed boat owned by S. Mortimer Auerbach, Atlantic City sportsman, foundered today in the upper inlet here while making a trial run. The craft was being driven by its owner at a speed of about fifty miles an hour when it struck what Coast Guards described as a "whirling riptide" and dived to the bottom.

Exceedingly cordial editorials on the coronation appear in all the Japanese newspapers. The Ahahi is reminded of "the greatness of the British Empire and the friendship it enjoys among nations," the Nichi Nichi says that "the whole world rejoices with the British people," and the Yomiuri rejoices that "despite the disappearance of many European thrones the British royal house stands glorious as ever."

Two-day conference of the Hendrik Hudson Regional Committee of the Girl Scouts begins at the Hotel Pennsylvania this morning at 9 o'clock and continues tomorrow. Speakers: Mrs. Herbert Hoover, Mrs. Frederick Edey, Commissioner Paul Moss, Dr. William H.S. Demarest.
While awaiting the arrival of the King and Queen at West-minister Abbey today, the peer's pages, many of whom had awakened at dawn, began to show the strain.

Madison Ave, 929, 4-story tenement and stores, 20x80; Guaranty Trust Co. of New York against Sara Backer; due, $83,577; taxes, , $5,300; to plaintiff for $80,000. 28th St, 129 W, 2-story loft and store building, 25x98.9; Northern Trust Co. against Alvidor Realties, Inc.; due, $30,248; taxes, , $3,363; to Plaintiff for $5,000.
TOLEDO, Spain, May 12.--Heavy government attacks against Insurgent-held Toledo developed today into a mass offensive in which, Insurgents said, the attackers suffered "unprecedented slaughter."

The total output of metals produced or to be produced by the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation to June 30 already has been sold, E. H. Clark, president, told stockholders yesterday. He said that earnings for the first quarter were satisfactory despite the higher operating costs.
The White Sox took advantage of Buck Newsom's wildness today to take a big early lead and down the Senators, 13 to 5, in the first game of the series. It was their fourth victory in five games.

Secretary Wallace said today that the weather was helping President Roosevelt's attempt to alter the Supreme Court. His argument was that good weather might result in large crops, and that farmers fearedprices would slump. The farmers,

Prayers were offered at a coronation service yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, for King George VI and Queen Elizabeth "and for their realm and empire that it may stand among the nations of the world in loyalty to God's kingdom of righteousness, justice and peace."
Richard M. Simpson, Republican, was elected to Congress from the Eighteenth Pennsylvania District yesterday to succeed the late Representative Benjamin' K. Focht, Republican.

Eagle Ave, 673, 3-story frame tenement, 19.6x99.5; Frances S. Quinn against August Eckenwalder; due, $6,151; taxes, , $1,383;- to plaintiff for $2,000. By JOSEPH P. DAY Honeywell Ave, 2,026, 2-story frame dwelling, 22x111.6; Home Owners Loan Corp. against Rose H. Bergen; due, $5,404;

S. C. Stampleman, president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, received $60,000 from that company in 1935, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission just made public through the New York Stock Exchange.

Fifteen-hundred-dollar bets on football games dominated the hearing yetserday in the Securities and Exchange Commission action on the charge that W. E. Hutton Co. and other respondents manipulated the stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation. David W. Peck and

Coronation observances engaged the residents of Bermuda today, starting with a service in the cathedral at 10 A. M. At noon Governor Sir Reginald Hildyard inspected a ceremonial parade of Sherwood Foresters together with a detachment of the Royal Navy and the Royal Marines.
A mystery murder that soothed the nerves of residents in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, rather than made them rush to locksmiths for extra. protection, came to light at 4 P. M. yesterday.

-Dixi Maid won the Senator William H. Smathers Challenge Trophy for three-gaited saddle horses, one of the features of the third session of the seventh annual Atlantic City horse show tonight in the great arena of the Auditorium.

Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, member of the Board of Education, has been elected as one of three new members of the board of trustees of the Catholic Summer School of America, Cliff Haven, N. Y., it was announced yesterday at the Board of Education office.

About 1,800 employes of the J. G. Brill Company remained on strike today while they awaited word from New York as to whether their demands had been met by the American Car and Foundry Company, the parent organization. Two hundred sitdowners remained in the plant.

Harry Fichter, this community's 30-year-old Townsend plan experiment "pensioner," spent the last of his $200 "pension" here today, twelve days after having received it from the Bergenfield Townsend Club.

Explaining its refusal to sign a contract with the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, the Republic Steel Corportion sent a letter today to its 55,000 employes declaring its opposition to the closed shop and asserting that such a compact with the union would mean that independent employes would be coerced into joining it.

A cast of 1,000 children of the Oyster Bay Elementary and High School took part tonight in a pageant entitled "Man Changes His Environment" on the terrace and lawn of the high school building before an audience of 2,000.

Commercial relations between France and Poland were put on a new basis today when a commercial treaty between the two countries was initialed here, replacing the treaty denounced by Poland a year ago.
Lay and clerical delegates, assembled for the annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Rochester, voted decisively today to maintain the church's policy in the remarriage of divorced persons.

Mrs. Mary Ellen Welply, wife of Patrolman Joseph Welply of the Richmond Hill station, died yesterday in the Rockaway Beach Hospital of a bullet wound accidentally inflicted by her husband last Thursday.

Father Divine denied ownership and control of all the "heavens" and "extension heavens," where he is worshiped as God by thousands of Negro and some white followers, in an affidavit filed yesterday in Supreme Court.

The marriage of Miss Annette Davies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Davies, to Raymond Francis MonmonIer, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Carroll Monmonier, took place this evening in the rectory of St. Willianl's Catholic Church. The Rev. Charles Carroll Kerr officiated. There was a reception at the Rolling Road Golf Club.

George Bernard Shaw boycotted the coronation of his sovereign, King George VI, today, announcing that "nature has made me proof against the illusions and idolatries which such ceremonies are intended to create."

The Davis Cup teams of Australia and the United States went through another workout at Forest Hills yesterday in preparation for their match there May 29, 30 and 31. Owing to the disagreeable weather, with a strong wind blowing. Manager Clifford Sproule called a halt to the Australians' practice early. The Americans kept at

The market for long-term government bonds is already beginning to reflect the uncertainty in trading circles over the amount and type of Treasury borrowing to be done next month. That the government will

Darwin P. Kingsley Jr. of the University Club was re-elected president of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday at the organization's final meeting of the season at the Lunch Club, 63 Wall Street.

Charges that the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway, a Van Sweringen-controlled property, had submitted in 1932 a false statement made under oath and signed by the president of the C. E. I., to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in order to pay a note of $700,000 allegedly held by the Midland Bank of Cleveland, were made matters of record this afternoon before the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce. The evidence disclosed
The Daughters of the British Empire gave a luncheon attended by 500 persons yesterday at the Ritz Carlton Hotel, in connection with the coronation observances held here. Mrs. John Hugh Nolan,

A large group of jurors from the trades and industries has awarded prizes for the best work achieved during the year by students at the New York School of Applied Design for Women, 160 Lexington Avenue.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Davison of Top o'Hill, Ridgewood, N. J., have announced the engagement of the eldest of their five daughters, Miss Edwina de Baun Davison, to Ernest Hambley Gill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Gill of Dover, N. J.

After ten years of resentful retirement "Abie's Irish Rose" has returned to Broadway. It was performed again at the Little last evening with some of the old players in the cast and before an audience that leaped ravenously at every racial gag in the script.

The City Industrial' Relations Board passed on to the Federal courts yesterday the task of supervising the collective bargaining referendum to be held on Saturday among the 15,000 employes of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company. The court agreed to act at

Athletes won many of the principal offices and also figured prominently on the list of students tapped for the Pen and Sword Socity, senior honorary organization, at Manhattan Colloge's Moving-Up Day exercises on the campus yesterday.

A $25,000 damage suit for injuries received when a tombstone allegedly toppled on the plaintiff in the Washington Cemetery in Brooklyn has been started in Supreme Court in Brooklyn, it was revealed yesterday. Justice Albert Conway directed Harry Burack of 1,745 Ocean Avenue to present a bill of particulars to defense counsel.

Lamp buyers of local department stores have formed a new group, with Howard Sable, buyer for Gimbel Brothers, named chairman, it was learned here yesterday. Buyers representing about ten local stores have affiliated with the group, which will hold another meeting next Tuesday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr. Sable said
The Alton, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, was the first railroad to report for April. The statement, issued yesterday and showing improvement in gross and net receipts, follows:

A new television "projector gun," which enlarges images a few inches in size to eight by ten feet, or 2,600 times the original size, on a large screen was demonstrated here yesterday afternoon to more than 1,200 radio experts from many countries at the final session of the silver anniversary convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

Percy N. Furber, chairman of the Trans-Lux Daylight Picture Screen Corporation, said at. the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that consolidated net earnings for the first quarter of 1937, after all charges and taxes, were about $92,850, as against $72,386 in the 1936 period.

The number of strangers in trouble who travel to New York appears to be increasing, and with the coming of the world's fair the demands of travelers for assistance probably will constitute an "emergency burden taxing all facilities of social welfare agencies, according to the annual report of the Travelers Aid Society, made public last night at the annual meeting at 144 East Forty-fourth Street.
The trial for the life of a seventyfoot Carolina poplar tree was transferred yesterday from the Flatbush magistrate's court by Magistrate John D. Mason to the Court of Special Sessions.

Cadet Donald W. Thackeray of Wakefield, R. I., is the first winner of the trophy given by Captain Thomas J. Sands to the West Point fencer whose loyalty, sportsmanship and competitive effectiveness have been outstanding during the year.

Miss Anna Lodge Minot, daughter of Mrs. Presley Morgan Taylor of this city and Grafton Winthrop Minot of Paris, was married today to Henry Canby Biddle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Canby Biddle of Green Garden, Wayne. The ceremony was

Evidence from recent delicate surgical operations, in which large areas of the brain were removed without loss of mental capacity, were presented here today as furnishing strong proof that the seat of human intelligence is not located in the frontal lobes of the brain's cortex, as is universally believed, but in a small area in the central portion of the left side of the brain in right-handed persons.

Mrs. Francis Oakey entertained with a luncheon yesterday at Chatham Walk for Mrs. Oswald Jimenis, Mrs. Beeckman J. Delatour, Mrs. F. Patrick Cummings, Mrs. Rollins Browne, Mrs. Russell L. Bradford, Mrs. Lawrence Clarke and Mrs. Edgar Snow.

MARQUIS W. CHILDS has written a slight but bright book-of-the-moment. Washington under the New Deal is the setting, a thoroughly cynical lobbyist is the main character, and despite all the good intentions of sincere and intelligent men, the lobbyist wins.

The Salem Lyceum a Cappella Choir, a musical unit of the Salem Methodist Episcopal Church of this city, will be heard in recital at the church this evening. The ninth annual concert of the choir of the Bushwick Presbyterian Church of Peace in Brooklyn will be held tonight in the church auditorium. Gloria Perkins,

Juan Buelna, president of 7,000 small-scale, Mexicali Valley farmers, announced today the terms of an .agreement reached by his group with the government as the farmers prepared mass 'evacuation of the sit-down camp they :have maintained in Palacio Park in protest against agrairian encroachment.
The market for bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange reflected a further slackening in the trading pace as well as continued apathy on the part of traders generally. Values, as a result,

Louis Franklin Swift, formerly president and chairman of Swift Co., one of the "big five" of packers, died this morning after an illness of several weeks. He was 75 years old. Funeral services will be held at 8:30 P. M. tomorrow in the Lake Forest Presbyterian Church.

Although the salt water angler is gradually assuming a place in the limelight these days, the State of New Jersey reminds license holders that the season for pike and pickerel opens in that State next Thursday.

Although the routes that 'the United States and Great Britain will travel will not be "altogether parallel," the representatives of "the two really democratic governments that continue to exist" must remember that these two nations "are exceedingly interdependent," Federal Judge John C. Knox, senior judge of the Southern District of New York, declared yesterday.

Playing its only home game of the season and the last on the schedule, the Lehigh lacrosse team defeated Lafayette today, 6 to 5. The victory made up for a 16-6 defeat Lehigh suffered at the hands of the Leopards a week ago at Easton.

Factory employment in the State registered but a slight gain of 0.2 per cent from the middle of March to the middle of April, and payrolls increased 1.2 per cent during that period, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner, reported today.

Final approval was given yesterday to three WPA Art Project murals by the Municipal Art Commission, which also passed preliminary approval of two other mural works produced by artists of the mural division of the WPA Federal Art Project.

A large subscription is reported for the card party in behalf of -the Little Sisters of the Assumption, which will take place tomorrow night at the Commodore under the auspices of Friends of the Little Sisters of the Assumption. A musical program by members of the Glee Club of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick will be offered.

On his own application. PATROLMAN--Email H--Lundberg, 5th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum, Appointed Oct. 26, 1911. Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN--Peter E. Sweeney, from 13th Precinct to 18th Division, designated as third grade detective.

A man identified by the police as William Sloup of Williston, Park, L. I., was burned to death shortly before 1 A. M. today when his automobile was in collision with a Long Island Railroad passenger train on Franklin Avenue, between Fifth and Sixth Streets.

With President Roosevelt and Governor Lehman adding their tributes to the hospitals of the nation, and about 50,000 visitors thronging to institutions in this city, National Hospital Day was observed throughout the country yesterday. Teas and receptions were

A world in which market conditions are rapidly improving and colelection and exchange problems gradually disappearing was sketched in reports submitted yesterday by exPort credit executives attending a monthly discussion of foreign credits held in the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.

From all parts of the far-flung British Empire there poured into London tonight dispatches describing coronation celebrations. The only-exceptions to the note of rejoicing were offered in Palestine, whose Arabs had boycotted the coronation, and the Irish Free State.

Thousands of union steel workers picketed the giant plants of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation tonight in the first major steel strike since John L. Lewis began his drive to organize the nation's millmen into one big union.

Those who are Searching patriotically for signs of real "revolt" against the President by Congress, because they believe that will best serve the nation's interest, should keep their hats out of the air until he has been back in Washington a few days from his expedition in search of Gulf of-Mexico tarpon. Senator Bilbo of Mississippi said today that students at Millsaps College have been misled into joining an organization of communistic origin and demanded investigation of all Mississippi student organizations.

Thomas Orr, who was Minister of Finance in the South African Government from 1917 to 1920, died today. He was 80 years old. Born in Loughgall, Ireland, Mr. Orr entered the British civil service in 1875, being appointed to the Exchequer and Audit Department.

The International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries, excluding the International HydroElectric System and its subsidiaries, reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1937 a net profit of $1,746,577 after all deductions.

Dublin today was probably the only city in the .British Commonwealth that took no public part in the Coronation Day celebrations. The Free State's official attitude ,toward the ceremony, as President Eamon de Valera announced recently in the Dail, "was one of detadhment and protest while Ireland is partitioned."

President Roosevelt ended his vacation in Texas today and headed northward. His special train left here at 6:27 o'clock tonight and is due in Washington early Friday morning, going by way of St. Louis.

A. G. Becker Co., Inc.; Edgar Ricker Co. and Loewi Co. will offer today at $100 a share 15,000 shares of Nunn-Bush Shoe Company 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock with warrants for the purchase. for each share of preferred stock of two shares of common stock. The offering is subject

A pageant of the coronation in London with Negroes playing. the roles of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth was presented at Rockland Palace in Harlem last night to the accompaniment of swing music. More than 5,000 Negroes, many of them from the West Indies and formerly of British citizenship, attended the celebration.

Mrs. Linda Giorni, former concert singer, died at the age of 76 yesterday at her home in Los Angeles, after an illness of several weeks, according to word received here. She was the widow of Carlo Giorni, Italian landscape painter.

Running the base paths with speed and daring, Columbia defeated Princeton by 5 to 4 yesterday at Baker Field in an Eastern. Intercollegiate League baseball contest. It was the Lions' second triumph this season over the Tigers.

William H. Gallagher's colt, Rudie, made a show of his field in the Providence Handicap, a mile and one-sixteenth for 3-year-olds, at Narraganset Park. today, and scored by four lengths in 1:461-5 despite the top weight of 120 pounds. Trailing him over the

The Senate approved the conference report on the Second Deficiency Bill carrying funds for a dam at Gilbertsville, Ky., received a Federal committee report on the bill to make a permanent CCC, received a committee report on the Agriculture Appropriation Bill, received President Roosevelt's flood control recommendations and adjourned at 3:02 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

Dr. Samuel Guy Inman, secretary of the Committee on Cooperation in Latin America, representing the foreign mission boards of twenty-nine denominations, last night described the present outlook for religion in Mexico as "most encouraging."

With commodity markets throughout the British Dominions observing the coronation ceremonies, trading on the local exchanges yesterday was on a reduced scale and price movements were generally irregular. On the cash market rye,

The New York Madrigal Society Women's Chorus, Marguerite Potter founder and director, was heard in concert last night at the Town Hall by an audience of good size and friendly disposition. The concert

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are May 11 unless specified: At Hankow: Augusta, Isabel. Pearl Harbor Yard to Mare Island Yard: Neches, Tern, Vireo Asheville, at Swatow, May 12. Cormorant, Washington Yard to Lower Potomac, May 12.
The television broadcast of scenes of the coronation procession-pioneering in outdoor "pick-ups"-proved highly successful today, considering the experimental phase of this art.

Officials of the State of North Carolina awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by Lazard Freres Co., Inc., a new issue of $3,019,000 of permanent improvement and State office building bonds. The syndicate paid a price

Barney Ross, holder of the world's welterweight championship, may be shorn Of his crown if he fails to live up to his agreement to meet Ceferino Garcia of Los Angeles in a title bout, the New York State Athletic Commission intimated at its regular meeting yesterday.

State, county and municipal leaders attended the funeral services this afternoon for Assemblyman Hart S. Van Fleet, who died at his home here Sunday, at the First Methodist Episcopal Church. Mr. Van Fleet was a Republican leader in this section for many years.

Secretary Roper, in discussing today the Hindenburg disaster, expressed the opinion that some plan would be worked out by which this country would make its exclusive helium reserves available "for world commercial needs."

A badly scared State motor vehicle inspector who has been acting as a sort of under-cover investigator for Governor Harold G. Hoffman for the last seven years floundered through testimony today that depicted Mr. Hoffman and Ellis H. Parker Sr. as privately undertaking a quiet investigation of their own into the Lindbergh kidnapping as early as March, 1932.

A sharpened branch of a tree, thrown by a boy at play, caused the death today from lockjaw of Rosemary Hargraves, 5 years old. Detectives arrested a 13-year-old boy who is alleged to have thrown the improvised spear. The girl was playing

Captain Kent C. Mead, who served as a special training camp instructor during the World War, and who, for four years, was an instructor of the Seventh Regiment of New York National Guard, died at Stamford Hospital last night after a brief illness.

More than 5,000 persons, including Samuel D. Riddle, owner of War Admiral, winner of the Kentucky Derby; saw C. Mahlon Kline's Arbitration II come through to a thrilling victory in the Corinthian Plate Steeplechase, feature event of the Rose Tree Hunt Club's opening meet near here today.

The complexities of the RobinsonPatman act, their effect upon commercial practice, advertising policy, accounting systems and the general economic structure were studied in detail at a seminar on the subject under the auspices of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association at its auditorium at 42 West Forty-fourth Street last night.

Repeal of the Ives Teachers' Oath Law, a Republican-sponsored measure passed by the Legislature several years ago, was asked last night by the New York Young Republican Club. The club made the demand in adopting a proposed platform to be submitted to the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs at its annual convention in Syracuse tomorrow.

For his volume, "Poems, 19111936," John Hall Wheelock has received the annual award of the New England Poetry Society for the "most distinguished contribution to poetry in the past year." The award will be presented to Mr. Wheelock at the annual dinner of the society in Boston on May 27, Scribner's, his publishers, announce.
Every motion picture now must be passed by two: boards of censors before exhibition in Ecuador, and now the government is creating a third board, according to reports in the local press.

Stillman Witt Eells, a foreign service officer of the United States for nineteen years and formerly a manufacturer here of fireproof wood, died yesterday at his home, 260 Riverside Drive, after a long illness. Mr. Eells retired in 1935, in which year he completed his service as United States Consul at Valencia, Spain. His age was 64.

Staging a rally in the ninth inning, the Manhattan College baseball team beat St. John's University, 6 to 5, in their second meeting of the season yesterday at Dexter Park. St. John's won the first game, 10 to 5.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Kings County, commenting on Mayor La Guardia's proposal to consolidate-the city's five county District Attorneys' offices into one city-wide department for criminal prosecution, declared yesterday that "the time has arrived when I am convinced that Brooklyn would be better off as an independent municipality, with its own elected officials, from Mayor down."

To Dr. James L. Howe, dean of the school of Applied Science and head of the department of chemistry at Washington and Lee University has been awarded the Herty medal, symbolic of outstanding work in southern chemistry.

Modern art and decorative effects such as have been utilized by many new hotels and large apartment buildings will be rejected in favor of conservative old English townhouse styles for the thirty-sevenstory Hampshire House, now being completed on Central Park South after having stood vacant and unfinished for several years.

The steel workers' organizing committee today demanded, and officials of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company invited, an investigation by the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee of preparations made at the steel plant for a possible shutdown.

Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel of New York City, in a brief filed today in the Supreme Court, defended the validity of the special 3 per cent tax imposed by the city on the gross income of utilities for the purpose of unemployment relief.

A plan for reorganization of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., which has been in receivership since 1932, has been , presented by Wood, Gundy Co. to R. S. McPherson, liquidator of the company. F. H.
King Christian today approved the engagement of his niece, the 27-yearold Princess Feodora, oldest daughter of Prince Harald, to Prince Christian of Schaumburg-Lippe.
The Philadelphia Enquirer will print the following editorial tomorrow morning, under the heading "Debunking the Helium Controversy":

A total of $276,200 has been raised so far by the Special Gifts Committee of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, which is directing the 1937 Catholic Charities appeal, John A. Coleman, chairman of the Special Gifts Committee, reported yesterday at a meeting at the Empire State Club.

The United States "might well accept" preferential trade agreements with the nations of Southeastern Europe to improve economic conditions in that area and buttress world peace, George S. Messersmith, -American Minister to Austria, said yesterday in an address before the New -York Board of Trade at the Astor Hotel.

George S. Konop Jr. of 35-16 eventy-ninth Street, Jackson Heights, who listed his occupation as supervising engineer in the WPA, Division of Parks, with offices at 37 Wost Sixty-fifth Street, Manhattan, yesterday filed in Brooklyn Federal court a voluntary petition in bankruptcy listing liabilities of $2,291,786 and no assets.
Secretary Roper announced today the election of Kermit Roosevelt, president of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, to the Commerce Department's Business Advisory Council. Other additions ratified

A bill to limit the power of the Federal courts to set aside rate schedules for common carriers established by State or Federal authority was introducd in the Senate today by Senator Minton of Indiana.
Interest in yesterday's City Commission election here centered today on the probable line-up of the new commission, in view of the fact that it will include two new members.
A bill which Representative Don McLeod said would infringe "upon the sacred rights of every dog to one bite" bore the disapproval today of the Florida House.

Gray-haired veterans whose future is behind them and lithelimbed youngsters whose future is very much ahead of them united at the New York Athletic Club last night where almost 900 athletes of the past and present assembled for an evening of camaraderie and the sixth annual all-sports. dinner.
The suggestion that wives who stay at home to look after the household should receive a definite salary for their work was advanced last night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President.

Dr. Stephen Fielding Bayne, New York educator, told the forty-third annual convention of the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs in Haddon Hall here today that greater educational opportunities should be provided for the "slow" child to keep his mind in the proper track, because when he became an adult "his vote counts as much as ours."

Melvin Schwartzman captured the singles tennis championship of the Athletic Association of Private Schools yesterday as the twentysecond annual tournament was completed at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. The Poly Prep

A warning that Harvard and Massachusetts Institute of Technology students are just as liable to arrest as any one else if they violate the law was given today by Judge Arthur P. Stone in the East Cambridge District Court as he fined three students for participation in recent undergraduate riots.

The completion of her college education made possible through funds solicited by members of the New York City Police Department, Miss Helen Garvey, 20-year-old New York University senior, expressed "deep thanks" yesterday to those "who will make my graduation next month a reality."
In scenes that had to be witnessed to be believed, staid old London danced, drank, shouted and flirted its celebration of the coronation until the early hours this morning.

A new theory of the cause of the explosion and fire which destroyed the German dirigible Hindenburg with a loss of thirty-five lives here last Thursday night was developed today when the official investigating board inquired into the possibility a propeller had flown off one of the engines and plowed through the hull of the ship with terrific force.
Donald Comer of Birmingham, Ala., president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association, said today that Southern cotton mills were consuming more cotton than ever before.

TORONTO, May 12 (AP).--A seventh-inning rally that produced seven runs gave Syracuse an even break in a Coronation Day doubleheader today. The Chiefs came from behind to capture the second game, 8-5, after dropping the opener, 8-0.

A promise that the pace in the mile and three-sixteenths - Preakness will be a blistering one has reduced the probable field for the historic $50,000 added stakes to be run Saturday at Pimlico to a select group of nine.

Bill Wiener, who pitched Brooklyn College to a 7-6 victory over City College in seven innings at Manhattan Beach last Friday, repeated his winning feat at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday, 2-1, again in a seveninning game.

The Hamburg-American liner Hamburg sailed shortly after last midnight, carrying back to Germany the bodies of twenty-five victims of the Hindenburg disastertwenty-one members of the crew and four passengers.

Dr. Miller McClintock of the Audit Traffic Bureau gave today the thirty-second annual convention of the Lithographers Naitional Association a preview of the national window display study, to be released publicly in about a month. The study has been

Harry Silver, 42 years old, of Tappan, N. Y., a field secretary for the Salvation Army, was arrested today in White Plains on a warrant issued in City Court here and brought to Yonkers to await trial on a charge of grand larceny.

With Joe -Dooley hurling his fourth straight league shutout, Jamaica defeated Far Rockaway, 4 to 0, yesterday at Jamaica Stadium in a Queens division P. S. A. L. game. It marked the tenth triumph in eleven starts for the league-leading nine. Dooley struck out eighteen batters.

The engagement of Miss Sarah Ruth Merritt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Merritt of Piedmont, S. C., to Dr. Edward B. Astwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. M. Astwood of Hamilton, Bermuda, was announced here today.

The Right Rev. Paul Matthews of Princeton announced here today that he would retire in October as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, a position he has held twenty-two years. He will be succeeded by the Right Rev. Wallace J. Gardner of Trenton, now Bishop Coadjutor.

Shipments through the New York State Barge Canal thus far this year are 121,896 tons ahead of the similar period a year ago, it was revealed today by Harvey O. Schermerhorn, State Commissioner of Canals and Waterways.

Advisers of Henry T. (Dick) Merrill announced last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where they have established headquarters, that he had postponed his return flight from England to the United States until tomorrow afternoon or early evening.
Althogh he had been- invited to attend the coronation as a personal guest of King George, J. P. Morgan was not Present at the ceremony in West minster Abbey today.

A united front of all believers in God against the Spanish Leftists, who, he declared, "would destroy religion in Spain," was urged here last night by the Rev. Laurence K. Patterson, Jesuit writer and educator.
The six-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 542 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold subject to a first mortgage of $161,000 to a syndicate represented by Morris A. Crausman, attorney.
A new "deadline" of June 1 for settlement of the Tammany leadership question was reported yesterday to have been agreed upon by influential members of the Tammany executive committee.

Surrogate William J. Shells will be asked to approve $17,500 settlement of the unction suit brought against the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures Corporation'to prevent the showing: of "The Great Ziegfeld" until a share of the profits had been turned over to the producer's estate.

Americans should not think of citizenship as ending at the frontiers of their country, but should be prepared in their minds to be citizens of the world, Colonel Julius Ochs Adler, vice president and general manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared today in an address at Tennessee Wesleyan College.

Chief Internal Revenue agents from all districts of the country were warned by Secretary Morgenthau today that the Federal Government, in order to balance the budget, must collect all income due from taxpayers.

Settlement of all major demands of the gasoline station attendants' union was announced last night by Walter Burk, president of the union, after a conference with representatives of the Inter-City Gasoline Dealers Association and the Petroleum Dealers Association at a meeting held at the Concourse Plaza, 161st Street and Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

The engagement of Miss Mary Hayward Cowles of Washington to Willard Reed Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Reed of Cambridge, Mass., has been announced. The wedding will take place on Oct. 16 in Washington.

The Reds today bought a veteran first baseman and returned Chick Hafey to the active list. Vice President Warren C. Giles announced in New York the purchase, in a straight cash deal, of Baxter Jordan, for six years first baseman of the Bees.
