A call to the pastorate was extended tonight to the Rev. Dr. Edward Weeks Cross, minister of the Union Congregational Church of Richmond Hill, Queens, by the First Congregational Church of this city, which is celebrating its tercentenary this month. Dr. Cross will

The Metropolitan Golf Association will conform with the ruling of the United States Golf Association in the case of Charles H. Mayo Jr., holder of the Long Island amateur golf championship, it was announced yesterday. The U. S. G. A.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1937 a net profit of $11,714,957 after expenses, income and franchise taxes, depreciation and depletion and-provision for the retirement system. This was equivalent

Walter Damrosch's third opera, "The Man Without a Country," the libretto by Arthur Guiterman, freely after Edward Everett Hale's story of the same name, was performed for the first time on any stage last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. Dr. Damrosch conducted

The preliminary annual report of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated balance of income, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, of $2,656,111, comparing with $308,813 in 1935.

Paragraph 2, special order 30, May 3, 1937, is revoked. First Lt. Alphonse F. Pagano, Med-Res., 213 Van Brunt St., Brooklyn, N.Y., unassigned, is assigned to the 77th Division and attached for training to the 302d Medical Regiment.

Mayor La Guardia was urged to run for renomination in a resolution adopted last night at a meeting of the United Citizens Association of Bay Ridge, a Fusion organization, in Imatra Hall, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. The gathering also

Starting next Jan. 1, when construction work on the extension of the Columbia University School of Medicine at Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street is expected to be completed, the school will enlarge its advanced program of graduate medicine studies, Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, dean of the school, announced yesterday.
The Metropolitan Opera House was filled to capacity last night and there were rows of standees for the world premiere of Dr. Walter Damrosch's opera, "The Man Without a Country."

There were two crowns for George VI in today's ceremony. St. Edward's Crown-the Crown of England-the central symbol of the Abbey ritual, flashes with jewels that are now considered priceless. It had to be fitted

The Rev. George C. Koenig, pastor of St. Paul's Lutheran Church, Crotona Avenue and 178th Street, the Bronx, has been elected president of Concordia Lutheran Theological Institute in Bronxville, N. Y. His selection by the trustees was announced yesterday.

Climbing "the dizzy heights of Phi Beta Kappa ranks" is by no means a sure indication of "learning how to use your own head" in later life, Dean Irving H. Berg of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science told members of the honorary fraternity at induction ceremonies yesterday at the Washington Square College.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City yesterday announced the election of James C. Auchincloss as chairman of its board of directors, and Bernard Lichtenberg as vice chairman of the board. These are new offices

Mrs. Julia Gardiner Dunn, wife of Gano Dunn, president of the J. G. White Engineering Corporation, died yesterday at her home, 550 Park Avenue, after a long illness. She was a member of the Colony Club and the National Society of Colonial Dames.

The Cardinals defeated the Phillies, 15-3, today, routing three hurlers with twenty hits, including three home runs, two triples and six doubles. Ducky Medwick and Pepper Martin led the assault with four blows each. Medwick hit two home runs,

Brentwood Hall, the six-story apartment at 48-06 Forty-fifth Street, Sunnyside, Queens, has been sold by Compton Holding, Inc., which built the house seven years ago, to David S. Meister. There are apartments for eightytwo families in the building, which stands on a base 150 by 100 feet.

Important changes among the members of the standing committees of the New York Stock Exchange for the coming year were announced yesterday following a meeting of the governing committee. Chairmen of the various

The Treasury subpoenaed the stock ledgers of Pierre S. du Pont for 1929 and 1930 and put them in evidence here yesterday at the income tax proceeding now in its second week at the Old Postoffice Building.

Robert Gair Company, Inc., $3 cumulative preferred stock, $10 par value, and common stock, $1 par value, have been listed on the New York Stock Exchange, including 186,408 shares of the first issue and 575,000 shares of the second.

Nickolas Zapantis, Greek flier of Richmond, said today that he and his flying partner, Samuel J. Capanis of Montgomery, Ala., had received assurance of financial aid from the Greek-American Order of Ahepa for a proposed 5,200-mile non-stop flight from the United States to Athens. The flight,
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial "At Last a Candidate".does not correctly state the positions which I have taken in connection with this campaign.
Sunday afternoon will see "The Eternal Road" closing, per schedule, at the Manhattan Opera House. But to that announcement the management hastened yesterday to add another. If certain matters can be

Albert Lebrun, Premier Lon Blum, United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt, several members of the French Cabinet and almost all other members of the diplomatic corps in Paris attended divine service at the British Embassy church this morning in honor of the coronation of King George and Queen Elizabeth.

Jake Powell, Yankee outfielder, who was rushed home from Detroit when stricken ill, yesterday underwent an operation for appendicitis at St. Elizabeth's Hospital. The operation was performed by Dr. Robert E. Walsh. It was said later at the hospital that the player was resting comfortably.
Newark unloosed an extra-base hit barrage to defeat the Red Wings, 12 to 5, today. The victory was the Bears' fourth in five starts against Rochester this season.

Dock Commissioner McKenzie said yesterday that he would have no difficulty in finding tenants for the new Piers 32 and 45, North River, which are nearly completed. The ship lines which were to have occupied them have found other quarters in the last three years and probably will not move.

Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers return to the Music Hall's screen this morning in "Shall We Dance." The score is by Ira and George Gershwin and the RKO supporting company includes Edward Everett Horton, Eric Blore, Jerome Cowan, Ketti Gallian and Harriet Hoctor.
A proper' gift for one's country cousin in Latvia, the Latvian Minister of Agriculture has suggested, is a package of fertilizer, according to the Department of Commerce.
Virginio Gayda, editor of the Giornale D'Italia, pronounces today a bitter philippic against Senator William.E. Borah for the remarks he made in the United States Senate about fascism.
Scoring six runs in its last two trips to the plate, Phillips Andover Academy's team gained a 10-5 decision over the Harvard freshman nine today.
The cost of today's coronation pageantry runs into tens of millions of dollars-in government and private funds. It ranks as the most expensive one-day show in the history of modern society.

Unable to agree on election of a Bishop Coadjutor after clergy and laymen were deadlocked through a daylong conflict, weary delegates to the convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Central New York forced adjournment tonight.

Close to 50,000 people crowded the great square before the Peace Tower on Parliament Hill today to pay tribute to the monarch who a few hours earlier had been crowned in London as George VI, King-Emperor of Great Britain and the Dominions.

Philippine imports in 1936 increased substantially for the first time since 1930, totaling approximately $101,126,174; compared with $85,523,849 in 1935, according to a report from American Trade Commissioner J. Bartlett Richards, Manila, made public today by the Department of Commerce.
While King George VI was crowned in London, the man for whose own coronation as Edward VIII the date May 12 riginally had been set was on alien soil knitting a blue pullover for the "woman I love."

Full occupancy is reported by Wilbur D. Gray and Kellogg Eddy, Associates, for the following apartment buildings: 38 Sutton Pl, 34 Beekman Pl, 360 E 50th St, 311 E 9th St, 327 E 75th St. 330-2 E 74th St. 430 E 58th St. 403 E 58th St, 305 E 44th St, 971 1st Ave and 134 E 47th St.

St. Marks P1, 26, s s, 26X120; A. Lillian Anderson to Gloria Stroll, 1,280 Sheridan Ave; mtg $35,000. Same property; Gloria Stroll to 26 Marks Place Realty Corp, 8 W 40th St; mtg $35,000 0th St., 374-378 E. s s, 75X92.3; Harry A. Lehrman to S. Berler, 721 Walton Ave; 1-6 interest; $1.

William M. Affelder, controller and a vice president of the Thompson-Starrett Company, builders, 444 Madison Avenue, New York, died here last night at his home, 30 Cottage Avenue, in his fifty-ninth year.

With completion today of presentation of evidence in behalf of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, one of five railroad companies suing in the United States District Court here for a permanent injunction to restrain New Jersey from collecting taxes for a three-year period in excess of an amount the plaintiffs deem fair, Judge Phillip Forman began taking testimony for the Erie. The other litigants
-Johnny Hopp's single to right scored Frank Myers from second base with the run that gave the Red Wings a 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in ten innings today.

Secretary Harold L. Ickes said at his press conference today that he favored making available helium for the commercial use of foreign countries, provided it can be produced here in sufficient quantities and on the condition that the fort eign government did not use it for war purposes.

Mrs. Emmet F. Whalen of Westchester Bills won the low-gross prize in the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association tournament over the Wee Burn course this-morning with a score of 88. In a field of sixty-two starters, Mrs. Whalen was the only one to break 90, and thirty of the starters failed to return cards.

Facing one of the most intensive election campaigns in the history of the Actors Equity Association, Frank Gillmore, president of that organization since 1928, yesterday admitted that he would have a birthday today. It's his seventieth.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated:
A severe break in cocoa futures in extremely active trading featured the commodity markets yesterday. Other commodities also lost ground in moderate activity.

Ciro Terranova, who is reputed to have made a fortune during his reign as "artichoke king" in New York City, is "broke" and must borrow money to live, according to the transcript of an examination filed today in connection with a suit to collect a judgment against him.

William Woodward's Perifox, dark-horse candidate for the Epsom Derby June 2, today won the Payne Stakes over one and a half miles, the Derby distance. He defeated S. Tattersall's Elgar by two lengths at Newmarket.

The Flushing High nine scored its ninth victory in twelve Queens P. S. A. L. starts and tightened its grasp on the runner-up position by downing Grover Cleveland, 7-6, at Flushing Memorial Field yesterday. Warren Giel of Cleveland hit a homer in the second with three men on the bases.

Henry Bascomb Warriner, who was connected with Dunne Co. of 20 Pine Street, securities dealers, died Wednesday morning while visiting relatives in Jetersville, Va. Mr. Warriner lived at the Willard Hotel, West End Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.
A simple funeral service was held ist night for John Valentine Dittemore, former senior director of the Christian Science Church, in the Universal Funeral Chapel, 597 Lexington Avenue.

Sufficient opposition developed to the proposed recapitalization plan of the Nashua Manufacturing Company at a special meeting held in Nashua, N. H., yesterday, to indicate that the -program to liquidate $45.50 a share in preferred dividend arrears could not be carried through along the lines recommended by the directors.

Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, went to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday in his fight to establish the right of his government to confiscate the 9,000ton Spanish freighter Navemar, as an emergency measure in time of war, in territorial waters of this country.

Alexander J. Brady, assistant controller of the Erie Railroad, was a witness in the Federal District Court here today in the trial before Judge Phillip Forman of the suit of that company and four other carriers for a permanent injunction restraining the State of New Jersey from collecting allegedly excessive taxes for 1934, 1935 and 1936.

A gift of $53,000 to be used as the nucleus for a fund to erect a new men's gymnasium at Bucknell University was acknowledged to day by Arnaud C. Marts, acting president, speaking in chapel exercises. ng in chapel exercises.

Boulevard Court, the four-story apartment on the southeast corner of Eighty-third Street and Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Queens, has been purchased by Norman-Lila Estates, Inc., from the Queensboro Corporation, which constructed the building.

Colonel Cecil H. Meares, world traveler and explorer, died in a hospital here last night after a brief illness. He was a member of the British Antarctic Expedition which explored the South Polar regions in 1910 under command of Captain R. F. Scott.

Miss Peggy Larimer, daughter of Mrs. William Gray Larimer of 405 Park Avenue, formerly of Pittsburgh, and the late Mr. Larimer, has chosen June 3 for her marriage to Thomas F. C. Frost, son of Mrs. Thomas F. C. Frost of London and the late Mr. Frost.

Last week William E. Borah warned the Senate and-the country-speaking, contrary to custom, from manuscript to make his warning more impressive-that advocates of fascism are moving subtly and incessantly to transform to their favored mold the government of the United States.

Domestic corporation bonds sufrered the sharpest reaction in many weeks yesterday on the New York stock Exchange. The downward trend, which had been in evidence to some extent of late, was given added impetus by the sharp break in stock values that was reflected quickly in the prices of the more sensitive and convertible bonds.

Approximately 5,000 persons are expected to attend the dedication and opening by Postmaster General Farley at 11 A. M. tomorrow of the Bronx's new main postoffice. Officially called the Bronx Central Annex Postoffice, the new structure is at 552-82 Grand Concourse, between 149th and 150th Streets.
Adam Markowski's single to right field in the ninth inning, driving in two runs, gave Syracuse an 8-7 victory today over the University of Rochester.

Mrs. Cornelius Tiers will give a tea this afternoon at her home, 26 East Ninety-second Street, for members of the junior committee who will act as ushers at the concert to be given by the choir of the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola Monday night at the Plaza for the joint benefit of the choir fund of the church and the Liturgical Arts Socity.

The Metropolitan Controllers Association will meet next Wednesday to discuss a report on the balance sheet manual of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The report will be submitted by Julius L. Freed, chairman.

A strike of the unlicensed personnel of the Eastern Steamship Lines, which was called yesterday afternoon by the International Seamen's Union, was ended late last night after a series of conferences by officials of both groups.
Ernest Booth, 39-year-old bank robber and author, who is in Folsom Prison under a sentence of twenty-five years, received a parole today from the State Board of Prison Terms and Paroles.

" La Traviata" will be given by the Hippodrome Opera Company tonight at the Hippodrome. Tomorrow night, a double bill consisting of "Cavalleria Rusticapa" and "Pagliacci" is scheduled, and Sunday night, "Carmen" will be presented.

A total of 131,052,131 lines of advertising was carried by newspapers of fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, during April, an increase of 7.5 per cent over the 121,886,991 lines for the like month of last year. For the four-month period since Jan. 1, the gain was 8.3 per cent.
The Merchants Association decided yesterday to ask Governor Lehman to veto the bill legalizing dog racing in this State passed at the recent session of the Legislature.

Phil Cavarretta drove a twelfth-inning double with the bases filled that clinched the Cubs' 8-6 victory over the Bees today. Cavarretta, who replaced Joe Marty in center field in the tenth when the veteran Guy Bush took over the Boston pitching, came to bat in the twelfth after George Stainback and Stanley Hack singled and Gabby Hartnett was passed.

Anton Gronningsater, in 49 E 96th St, through Byrne Bowman, Inc; Houghton Company, broker. George G. Bradley, in 131 E 66th St; Elizabeth T. Brady, in 115 E 90th St; Mrs. Charles A. Fowler, through Rossbach, Lewis Leeds, in 71 Park Ave; Robert C. Leatherbee, through G. Vitagliano, in 131 E. 55th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc. broker.

Seventy-one relatives, friends and employs received bequests in the will of Mrs. Adolph S. Ochs, widow of the former publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, which was filed for probate today in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court. A nominal valuation, "in excess of $10,000," was placed on the estate.

For the second time in three years,the Flowing Gold Challenge Cup, the leading trophy for threegaited saddle horses on tonight's program of the Atlantic City horse show, was captured by the bay mare, Society Barrymore, one of the stars of the stable of Miss Frances M. Dodge of Rochester, Minn.
The Cardinals again defeated the Phillies, 5 to 4 today, scoring the winning run in the seventh on Hugh Mulcahy's wild throw. The Phils had made three tallies in the sixth to tie the score.

ders taken in April by the Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiary companies, including the Midvale Company, were announced today as $3,378,434, compared with $3,642,330 for April, 1936. The total for March was $6,019,215.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Representative Rayburn, the majority leader, interrupted House debate on the Interior Department's 1938 Supply Bill today to defend the chamber against newspaper criticism that this "has been a sit-down Congress."

Frederick Bernard Wernli, superintendent of the twelve-story, 100family apartment house at 440 Riverside Drive, who received last month an annual award of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association for clean sidewalks, told yesterday the secret of his success. He summed it up in two words:

The Committee of Banking Institutions on Taxation at its nineteenth annual meeting yesterday elected Edward J. O'Connor of the Guaranty Trust Company as chairman. Others elected were Frank Bosworth of the Empire Trust Company, vice chairman; Thomas L. Pryor of the Brooklyn Trust Company, secretary; Anthony Quaremba, Daniel Deckert, Stephen Jenkinson and Donald Barnes, as members of the executive committee.

Estate, less than $10,000. To the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, $200; Thomas J. Brennan, son, 220 Boscobel PI., Bronx; Sarah Brennan Brady, daughter, executrix, 556 W. 170th St., and William J. Brennan, son, executor, 556 W. 170th St., one-third residue each.

Through a highly significant 6-to-4 victory over the Reds the Dodgers yesterday stretched their winning streak to four games, something they last accomplished two seasons ago, and thus bade a fond farewell to their Ebbets Field admirers.

Charges that the Federal Communications Commission is fostering a monopoly of trans-ocean radio telegraph communication in favor of the Radio Corporation of America were made today by the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, Inc., in a notice of appeal from a recent commission ruling denying its application for license to establish pointto-point service with Oslo.

The annual meeting of stockholders of the Mission Corporation, an investment company with large holdings of Tide Water Associated Oil Company stock, recessed here late today until 10 o'clock tonight, Pacific time. The delay was owing to many hours spent in counting the proxies of stockholders.

Stocks of refined copper in the United States, exclusive of consumers' stocks at plants or warehouses, amounted to 99,576 tons at the end of April, compared with 121,448 at the close of March, a drop of 21,872 tons, according to the Copper Institute.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows:

A flautist, pianist, violinist and vocalist were announced today as the winners of the recent audition for the selection of young soloists to appear with the Philadelphia Orchestra at next season's youth concerts.
Union automobile workers at the Fisher Body plant of General Motors walked out of the factory today, after a two-hour sit-down, causing a cessation of production and making 7,000 employes idle.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Alba Iregui, daughter of Mrs. Mary L. Iregul of this city, to the Rev. Luther Waddington King, son of the Rev. and Mrs. W. Luther King of Mathews County, Va. Miss Iregui, whose family is of old Spanish origin, was graduated from the Albany Bible School.

Despite a decline from the previous week, when-bank clearings inCuded first-of-the month settlements, the turnover for the week ending on Wednesday was 3.4 per cent above the amount for the corresponding week of 1936. The volume for the twenty-two principal. cities throughout the nation, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.,

Many of the inequalities under which' women in business and the professions have labored are being eliminated. But the tempo of this emancipation has been so slow that most women are still severely handicapped as compared with men in similar occupations.

Tile memberships of lion M. Kelley and John Witter in the New York Stock Exchange were trans-. ferred yesterday to William P. T. Preston of G. M.-P. Murphy Co. and Harold W. Scott of Dean Witter Co., respectively.

Robert E. Jensen and Philip L. Glass were appointed yesterday assistant cashiers of the Public National Bank and Trust Company. The special meeting of stockholders of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation to act on a plan of reorganization has again been adjourned, this time to May 18.
180th St (11-3128), n s, 108 ft e of Daly Ave, 100x152; also 181st St, s s, 170 ft w of Vyse Ave, 13x114; Sadigur Mason Forman Realty Corp to N. Y. Life Insurance Co, 51 Madison Ave, extends mtgs.

A theory that the Republican party, while having no real hope of success in 1940, might get somewhere in 1944 if it submits itself to the iron discipline of an old-style political boss of the Mark Hanna or Matt Quay type is advanced by Charles Michelson in the American Magazine.
The six Yale senior societies chose their quotas of fifteen members each today from the class of 1938 at the annual Tap Day exercises' in Bradford Court.

A reduction of $28,000,000 in brokers' loans was reported for the week ended on Wednesday in the condition statement of member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, issued yesterday. The weekly statement showed a slowing down in the liquidation by the banks of their holdings of government securities,
Joe Kuhel hammered out three triples today to equal a modern major league record and pace the Senators to a 10to-2 Victory over the White Sox.

The State of Kentucky has invited tenders, which will be considered on June 2, for a new issue of $2,100,000 of bridge revenue project No. 12 bonds, to be dated June 1, 1937, and maturing on July 1, 1947. Proceeds from the sale of these bonds will be used to purchase the Covington-Cincinnati bridge from the Covington Cincinnati Elevated Railroad and Transport and Bridge Company.

Counsel for W. E. Hutton Co. labored yesterday to demonstrate that the firm itself, regardless of what its partners and employes might have done, had, engaged in no conspiracy to manipulate the stock of the Atlas Tack Corporation, as charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Twelve girls from New York and vicinity were among the forty-nine students of the Penn Hall Junior College of Chambersburg, Pa., who received awards tonight at the schooI's annual athletic association dinner. The entire student body is spending three weeks here at the Flanders Hotel.

All options to purchase stock in the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation were cleared up on April 30, when George A. Ball and Joseph B. Graham bought 50,000 shares each at $3 a share, the company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Payment was made on last Monday, when the shares were delivered.

One armed man was shot dead, a second was apparently badly wounded, and a detective was slashed over one eye in a battle between two detectives and at least three other men at 177th Street and Walton Avenue, the Bronx, at 8:30 o'clock last night.

The Transport Workers Union put the City Industrial Relations Board "on the spot" yesterday with a demand that it act immediately to fix a date for and agree to supervise a referendum election at which the 4,500 employes of the Third Avenue Railway Company
Feeling the time at hand when he should do something drastic, Manager Joe McCarthy gave his Yankees a grand shaking up today and the result was almost magical.

Milton Speiser, head of the law firm of Speiser Speiser, credited with having the largest accident practice in the courts of the..country, argued his own appeal in the Appellate Division yesterday on his recent conviction in Special Sessions of tampering with witnesses in a Supreme Court suit last June, in which he appeared for the plaintiff.

Mexico, which raised the general tariff an average of 25 per cent in the middle of January, chiefly affecting the United States, has placed a heavy new income tax on companies of the United States through their salesmen here that is expected by local American business circles greatly to reduce their trade with Mexico.

Henry Sears, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry F. Sears of Boston and Beverly, and Mrs. Mary P. Smithers of Greenwich, Conn., today filed marriage intentions at the City Clerk's office. Mr. Sears is the brother of Mrs. Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., wife of the United States Senator.

John K. Starkweather was elected yesterday to membership in the New York Stock Exchange. Announcement was made thereafter of the formation of the firm of Starkweather Co. to succeed the business of Starkweather Co., Incorporated.. The new firm -will have associate membership in the New York Curb Exchange as well as membership in the New York Stock Exchange.

Plans for barbers' strikes that will affect shops in Manhattan as far north as Fifty-ninth Street and also the entire Bronx, were discussed last night at meetings of three locals of the Journeymen Barbers' International Union.

Four William Bayard Cutting fellowships, carrying annual stipends ranging from $1,000 to $2,000 for study abroad, were announced yesterday at Columbia University. The recipients for the coming year are Pierre Francois CornellDechert of Harrisonburg, Va., greatgrandson of the founder of Cornell University, who will study medieval literature at the University of Florence;

Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation, said today that State officials were slightly over-optimistic when they estimated that alcoholic beverage tax collections would reach $13,000,000 for the fiscal year.
Mrs. Clara Guthrie d'Arcis, pacifist leader and business woman, died here last night after a long illness that followed an operation she underwent in New York last March.

Lord Melchett, British industrialist and chairman of the Council of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, who arrived from South America yesterday, appealed to Jewish bankers and leaders in other fields for greater assistance in the resettlement movement in Palestine.
Pre-publication surveys in London newspapers of coming books rarely devote much space to books imported from America, but Damon Runyon's forthcoming book of stories is an exception.

Civilization will go "completely bankrupt" unless world trade channels are cleared for a "freer flow of international goods," the Bankers Association for Foreign Trade was told here today by its president, W. F. Gephart, vice president of the First National Bank, St. Louis.

Trends in distribution, fair trade laws, buying groups, brokerage payments and the relationship of producers with consumer organizations are among the subjects scheduled for discussion at the midyear meeting of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Homestead, Hot Springs, Va. on May 31 and June 1. The question of employer and employee relationship will also be taken up by the manufacturers.

Webster Ave., 2,777 (12-3279); Fred M. Edwards to Kurt Peter, 163 E. 179th St. Story Ave. (11-3660), n. w. cor. of Cross Ave., 100x100; Max Hochman to Rosalie N. Friedman, 417 Beach 69th St., Arverne, N. Y.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $50,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $940,000,000, according to the weekly report of the System, published yesterday. The System's portfolio of government securities was unchanged at $2,526,290,000, following the negligible rise of $50,000 reported in the preceding week.

Harold Mantin, James Madison High School player, led the way into the quarter-finals of the Greater New York junior tennis championship by defeating Jack Geller, 9-7, 6-0, in a third-round match on the Central Park courts yesterday.

The vast realm of GENGHIS KHAN, which stretched from the Pacific to the border of what is now Europe, was breaking up in his lifetime, though he was unaware of the process because days and weeks separated him from his Governors.
A hard-riding Monmouth County Country Club polo team evened matters with the Princeton varsity today by scoring a 5-3 victory over the Tigers in a contest limited to four chukkers by rain.
The American Federation of Labor today started a counter-offensive against organizing efforts of John L. Lewis in the textile industry in the South.

Robert S. Hillyer, Associate Professor of English, has been named Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Harvard University, effective in September. He will take the chair which has been vacant for almost nine years, since the retirement in 1928 of Professor Charles T. Copeland.
The racing legions, shifting their interest from Churchill Downs to historic Pimlico, saw little today but the offspring of the great Man o' War in Saturday's renewal of the $50,000 added Preakness.
New proposals to end the two-weeks' strike of the Federation of Motion Picture Crafts were submitted to the executive board of the federation tonight.

Johannes Wiegel, German antiNazi seaman who had been ordered deported to Germany for illegal entry into the United States, was sent to Baltimore yesterday under immigration guard and will be permitted to depart voluntarily, it was announced yesterday by the American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born.

King George and Queen Elizabeth drove out among their people today through districts that royalty rarely penetrates. Perhaps they had in mind the exclusive character of yesterday's ceremonies in Westminster Abbey, which the motion pictures will reveal to everybody, but in which the plain people had no part even as onlookers.

Friends of Robert F. Wagner Jr., son of United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, have suggested him for the Democratic nomination for Assemblyman in the Sixteenth Manhattan district to succeed William Schwartz, the incumbent, it was learned yesterday.

George L. Berry, appointed last week as Senator from Tennessee, was made defendant today in a suit filed in the Federal court by the Tennessee Valley Authority to condemn mineral rights on land in the Norris Reservoir area which the Senator and others own.

Londoners flocking to newsreel theatres today to view the first movies ever taken of coronation ceremonies within Westminster Abbey were disappointed- to find that although the procession and scenes along the route were shown at length the Abbey ceremonies were limited only to the briefest shots of the actual crowning.

Several witnesses testified yesterday at the opening of the trial before Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz of four men charged with aiding and abetting Robert J. Suhay and Alfred Power in robbing the Northern Westchester Bank at Katonah, N. Y., last March 12. Suhay and Power, accused of being the actual robbers, are being held in Topeka, Kan., for the murder of W. W. Baker, a Federal agent.
George W. Field, the president of the G. W. Field Company, Inc., lumber merchants, died at the Somerset Hospital in Somerville last night of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 66.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling: Gold coin and bullion...increased [Pound]4,915,000 Reserve in bank'g dept.,
Four new courses will be offered at Smith College for the year of 1937-38. They will be in the departments of Latin, German and botany and will supplement the present curriculum.
The Rev. William T. Brady, rector of the Catholic Church of the Holy Cross, Mount Airy, died in St. Joseph's Hospital yesterday in his sixty-fourth year.

The cost of Germany's present economic policy of blockade-proof autarchy was brought home to the German people today when the government announced that in order to finance the production of artificial rubber it had slapped a 100 per cent tax on the importation of natural rubberheretofore duty-free-which automatically doubles its price in GermanY.

The wedding of Miss Treva Wampler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Wampler of Miami, Fla., formerly of Greenwich, and Edward J. Lucke Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Lucke of Milbrook, Greenwich, will take place on May 122 in the rectory of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Greenwich, with the Rev. James Q. Dolan, the pastor, officiating.

President Roosevelt's intentions to raise social standards by Federal action on many fronts, social, agricultural and industrial, have not changed since he outlined them in the "We have just begun to fight" speech at Madison Square Garden, New York, in the last campaign, he said today.

The In terstate Commerce Commission this afternoon announced approval of sales of $2,000,000 of Detroit, To ledo Ironton Railroad 2 3/4 per cent equipment trust certificates and $6,490,000 of Northern Pacific Railway 2 3/4s to a syndicate composed of Salomon Brothers Hutz, ler, Dick Merle Smith and Stroud Co., Inc.
A fourrun uprising in the fourth inning today gave the Syracuse Chiefs a 6-4 victory over the Royals and sent them into a tie with Montreal for fourth place.
Bennett Ellison, partner in the firm of Hoey Ellison, insurance underwriters, died yesterday in his home at 320 East Seventy-second Street after a long illness. He was 49 years old.
Wednesday the representatives of the dominions and colonies of the British Commonwealth of Nations were important figures in the most splendid and best-advertised parade the world has ever seen.

Ordnance experts and Army officers today inspected a 155 mm. gun mounted on a carriage supported by ten pneumatic tires, which can be towed at a speed of fifty-five miles an hour, quickly put into position and can send a ninety-five-pound projectile a distance of 26,000 yards, about fifteen miles.
A further slight decline in the general level of wholesale prices occurred in the week ended on May 8, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

A conference of Republican and Democratic legislative leaders, called for today in an effort to reach an agreement on a program that would permit of adjournment next week, ended almost as soon as it began when the Democrats walked out after the Republicans refused to support an item in the supplemental Appropriations Bill making $35,000 available for the Assembly investigation of Wildwood's fiscal affairs.

From Washington, where it now is, the "Follies" goes to Baltimore next week, spends May 24 and 25 in Richmond, and winds up a generally successful tour on May 26 at Hershey, Pa., scene of recent labor troubles. ...

American Museum of Natural History, 10:30 A. M. "The Indians and the Dutch in New Amsterdam," Almeda Johnson. Luncheon of the Associated Business Papers, Hotel Commodore, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Edward Aherns, Roger Wensley, Aaron Brown, T. E. Alcorn.

Chartered bank deposits were reduced to $194,179,766 on May 12 from $197,023,063 on May 5, according to today's weekly statement of the Bank of Canada. Dominion Government deposits showed a small decrease from $22,040,909 to $21,795,110.
A bigger share of the average dollar spent for food is going to the farmer, government economists said today, because prices of farm products are rising.

Two petty officers of the navy who were in the ground crew last Thursday night testified at the official investigation today that something was wrong with the Hindenburg's rudders when it sailed over the air station preparatory to landing.

The largest gains in the export trade of the United States in March were in exports to Asia, which increased from $32,570,000 in March, 1936, to $52,972,000, according to the monthly study of exports and imports made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Reveling in the chance of a generation to gratify simultaneously their readers' patriotism and love of pageantry, the London morning newspapers today gave more space to the coronation than even the funeral of George V, which set a modern peacetime record, had received.
Ditcators were pictured here today by James G. McDonald of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff as having passed the peak of their power and prestige.

A special student committee settled down last night to an all-night session of ballot-counting as the contest for the four chief Hunter College student offices drew to a close. The counters expected to complete their tally early this morning.

The New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants has elected Morris C. Troper president. Mr. Troper is a partner in the firm of Loeb Troper and for some years has served on various committees of the society.

Leon Armstrong of Max Udell Sons Co. was named chairman of the board of governors of the clothing and furnishings division of the Credit Clearing House at an organization meeting at the Hotel New Yorker last night. He outlined his concept of the program that should be carried out, laying stress upon the confusing trends recently developed.

Mr. NORRIS'S one-house Legislature, called the Senate, has been having its first trial. Opinion in Nebraska is said to be generally favorable. A correspondent of The Des Moines Register was struck by the order and quiet of the proceedings.
Italy, flushed with the pride of empire, is consolidating her gains in Ethiopia and strengthening her position in the Central and Eastern Mediterranean and in the Red Sea.
With their meager reserves almost exhausted the American refugees here. have sent an urgent plea to the United States Embassy in Valencia for a shipment of foodstuffs, it was learned today.
The National Union for Collective Bargaining for Democratic Workers reared its head today and served notice that from now on patronage dispensers would have to deal with the men who hustle the votes.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the System as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.
Germany is constructing great new fortifications along the Baltic coast, it was disclosed tonight, to speed completion of a vast network of defenses at every border.
George N. Harris, secretary-treasurer of the Federal Laid Bank of Spring field, Mass., for the last ten years and prominent in financial and political affairs here, died today at the age of 82.

Directors of Chesapeake Corporation, Alleghany Corporation subsidiary which controls the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, today elected C. L. Bradley to its presidency, succeeding the late O. P. Van Sweringen.

Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson refused yesterday to grant a preliminary injunction to Richard W. Fitch, suing as next-of-kin to the-late Clyde Fitch, playwright, in his suit charging that the musical, "My Maryland," was a plagiarism of Fitch's play, "Barbara Frietchie."

Carl Levi, a district manager for Loew's theatre circuit in New York City, who began his career with the company thirty years ago as a doorman, died early yesterday morning in Mount Sinai Hospital following an operation for an intestinal disorder.

John Burt Holmes of 1,349 Lexington Avenue has announced the marriage of his sister, Mrs. Helen Burt Holmes Streit, widow of Samuel F. Streit, to Alfred D. Bell of this city and East Hampton, which took place on Wednesday in Baltimore. The Rev. J. Franklin Hass, pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church of Baltimore, performed the ceremony.

The Real Estate Club of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York will hold a luncheon Thursday, May 27, at the Hotel Commodore, at which Norman R. Lemke, head of the mortgage loan office of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, will be the main speaker. Emil Leitner is chairman of the club.
A recurrence usual class of a heart ailment from which he had suffered about a year ago prevented J. P. Morgan from attending the coronation ceremonies, as he had intended, it was revealed today.
THE SUPREME COURT AND THE NATIONAL WILL, by Dean Alfange. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50.) Winner of the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Award.

Harmon Elliott, president and principal owner of the Elliott Addressing Machine Company, announced yesterday a $250,000 trust fund for his workers, payments from which will be contingent upon profits. The establishment of the fund was coupled with wage increases totaling more than $30,000 a year, effective today.

Irving Barr, 20 years old, a painter, of 1,551 Park Place, Brooklyn, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate H. Stanley Renaud in Bronx Homicide Court charged with killing Joseph Gieger, a nightwatchman, while committing robbery early Wednesday morning. He was held without bail for a hearing Tuesday.

Payments to life insurance policyholders and beneficiaries in the United States and Canada in 1936 amounted to $2,829,300,138, according to figures made public yesterday by The National Underwriter, weekly insurance newspaper. Of the total, 62 per cent went to living policyholders and the remainder to beneficiaries. In 1935 payments amounted to $2,908,653,202.

The Association of American Railroads reported yesterday that Class I carrier estimated operating revenues for April at $288,446,093, compared with $260,681,994 in the same month of 1936, an increase of 10.7 per cent.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended May 1 totaled 303,249,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

Reade St, 168, n s, 20.10x43.6x7.10x381; also West St; 391, e s, 28.3x28.10; to Weehawken St; Louis A. Ames to Phebe Palmer, 622 West End Ave; one-half interest ($10). Moylan P1, 29-41; Mortgage Commission Realty Corp., trustee, to Edw. J. Chapman, 4,720 Delafield Ave, as trustee.

Miss Ceora Jennings Hufnagel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hufnagel of this city, whose marriage to Walter Ware Slocum of Ardmore, Pa., will take place tomorrow in the Second Congregational Church here, was entertained at luncheon today by Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Croft of Greenwich.

' Four stockholders of the Home Insurance Company brought suit yesterday in Supreme Court to set aside a series of transactions which, it is alleged, caused the company and its stockholders to lose $3,000,000. The transactions all took place about Sept. 10, 1935.

Par won the featured Homs Claiming Stakes at Belmont yesterday, but most of the thrills came in the Delhi Handicap, wherein Zostera and Wise Prince finished in a dead heat. Zostera was a 151 shot, and Wise Prince the 3-to-2 favorite, with the result that players got busy with their pencils to find out if they had any profit when there were two winners in one race.

Heavier shipments of gold from London to this market were resumed yesterday as the British Equalization Fund apparently suspended its purchases of bullion and the price' of gold once more dropped to levels insuring a large profit on imports to the United States. Engagements of $9,064,000 of gold abroad were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, of which $8,844,000 was taken in London and $220,000 in India.

With Joe Mulligan turning in a six-hit performance, the Maple Leafs pounded out an 11-2 victory today over the Jersey City Giants and extended their league lead over the idle Buffalo Bisons and Newark Bears.

Robert S. Page of Norfolk, Va., was installed as president of the Southern Supply and Machinery Distributers Associtation, Inc., in connection with a triple convention held here. Other officers of the association are Jack B. Dale, Dallas, first vice president; Edward F. Strauss, New Orleans, second vice president, and Alvin M. Smith, Richmond, Va., secretary-treasurer.

The city was startled this morning by repercussions of a terrific explosion in Stephens Green. When a squad of police rushed to the beautiful floral park in the center of the city they found the fine equestrian statue of George II, which occupied a high pedestal in the grounds, blown to pieces by a mine.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange resumed the downward movement yesterday and sold at' new low levels under a decline of $1 a bale to end with losses of 13 to 19 points.

The change in inventory practices of the International Paper and Power Company this year resulted in net profits for the first quarter $620,000 lower than would have been reported under the method used in former years.

Houses on the upper East Side changed hands in deals announced yesterday. A member of the New York Stock Exchange purchased for occupancy from Estelle T. Hyams the fivestory American basement dwelling at 122 East Seventy-third Street.
Stocks, reacted and closed weak with widest declines of year; turnover, 1,773,350 shares. United States Government. and corporate bonds lower, foreign is sues Irregular; transactions, $10 186,500.

Two Army players advanced to the semi-finals of the New York State intercollegiate tennis tournament today. Rollins of Army, who was unseeded, defeated Abrams, N. Y. U., 6-3, 6-2, in the first round, and J. Schmidt of C. C. N. Y., 6-0, 6-1, in the second.

With the exception of the match at Swansea between Glamorgan and Sussex, first class cricket matches started May 12 were rained out today. With no play possible for the first two days at Bradford; the Yorkshire-Cambridge University contest was abandoned.

Use of 5,000 watts at communication division terminals of airlines was authorized today by the Federal Communications Commission in anticipation of the use of larger planes, making longer flights in the near future. Ground stations are now limited to 1.000 watts.

The Duke of Windsor, friends said tonight, has appealed to Queen Mary to aid his fight to obtain the British Government's consent to representation of the royal family at his marriage to Mrs. Wallis Warfield.
Viscount Hinchingbrooke, who arrived on the Aquitania, is at the Pierre. Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt have returned from the South.

Edward Lawford, 24 years old, a real estate broker, of the Gladstone Hotel in East Fifty-second Sreet, pleaded not guilty in the Felony Court yesterday to alleged felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law in the shooting of Martene W. (Bill) Corum, sports columnist, early Wednesday morning. Mr.
The personnel of the American Davis Cup squad will be completed. at Forest Hills today with the arrival of three players from California.

Solomon Hanfling of 1,619 Fortyseventh Street, Brooklyn, died on Wednesday of a heart attack at Forty-sixth Street and Sixteenth Avenue, Brooklyn. He was' 64 years old. He had been in the wholesale flower basket business for fortyfive years, being the founder of S. Hanfling Co. of 130 West Twentyeighth Street, Manhattan.

One of the developments in the steel situation that appears particularly to have impressed the financial district is that the Jones and Laughlin Company has been the first to encounter labor difficulties. The assumption previously had been that this company, among the principal independents, was the least inclined to be "hard-boiled," and the names of several others were put forward as ready for an entirely intransigeant attitude toward the C. I. O.

Miss Mildred Hockstader, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Hockstader of 784 Park Avenue and Sarosca Farm, Purchase, N. Y., was married to David A. Moscovitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Moscovitz of Somerville, N. J., yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building. They were unattended.

Archibald B. Gwathmey Jr., a partner in E. A. Pierce Co., 40 Wall Street, New York Stock Exchange and commodity brokers, died yesterday at his home, 4 East Seventy-second Street, after a brief illness.

The Rev. James H. Urie was installed last evening by the Presbytery of New York as pastor of the Beck Memorial Presbyterian Church, 980 East 180th Street, the Bronx. For the last nine years he has been .assistant pastor at the Fort Washington Collegiate. Reformed Church, East 181st Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Mrs. Eleanor Gerouard Baskerville, widow of Patrick J. Baskerville, to John Primrose of Dongan Hills, S. I., formerly of Picton, Nova Scotia, which took place on April 29 in the rectory of St. Theresa's Church, Ottawa, Ont. The Rev. Alphonse O'Neill performed the ceremony, after which the couple left to return to this city.
The Czechoslovak House of Deputies was thrown into tumult this afternoon when a man suddenly arose in the spectators' gallery and fired a pistol at the Ministerial bench.

The government commission appointed in Poland to control prices now has control over wheat, bread, clothing, shoes, oil, coal, iron and bricks, according to a report from Assistant American Trade Commissioner Coldwell S. Johnston at Warsaw made public today by the Deapartment of Commerce.

The market for low-priced American-built automobiles "looks very promising in Mediterranean countries," according to Ward Canaday, chairman of the board of the WillysOverland Motor Car Company, who arrived yesterday on the liner Conte di Savoia.

Spokesmen for the press, radio, and movies acclaimed the American Red Cross today as a guide for impartial public service. Tributes were paid at the final session of the organization's convention by Frank B. Noyes, president of The Associated Press;

The war in Spain and the "whirlwind" which the church is reaping there were described as results of a militaristic spirit which is sweeping the world in a report adopted yesterday by nearly 300 pastors attending the eighty-ninth annual session of the New York East Methodist Episcopal Conference.

A plan of government purchase of all domestically produced cotton for resale to textile manufacturers at fixed prices with the American market protected from foreign competition and textile exports subsidized by the Federal Government was proposed by Senator Bankhead of Alabama today before the annual meeting of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association.

Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMEN--William J. Reckert, 8th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 23, 1917. Christopher J. Mills, 30th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Dec. 24, 1912. Transfer's and Assignments SERGEANT Thomas J. Feeney, from Emergency Service Division to 18th Division. PATROLMAN Francis T. Purdue, from 14th Precinct to Telegraph Bureau.

The proposal of the Municipal Assembly's committee on low cost housing to rehabilitate old-law tenements with ERB funds, providing homes for some 2,000,000 persons, was approved with reservations yesterday by the savings banks of the city at a conference with the committee at City Hall.
All officers of the Percy William Home at East Islip, L. I., were re elected at the annual meeting held last Tuesday.
The Senate displayed no interest today in the identity of the "billionaire" who, Ambassador Dodd says, is ready to establish a Fascist dictatorship in the United States.

The final tea dance in a series under the auspices of the Town Hall Club will take place tomorrow at the clubhouse, 123 West Fortythird Street. Miss Emily Ann Wellman and Robert Hoppock head the committee in charge of the arrangements.

Lord Ashfield, chairman of the London Transport Board, suggested a means of avoiding a repetition of the long wait experienced yesterday by guests at Westminster Abbey, who were delayed by the traffic jam in getting into their limousines.

It isn't often that a golfer who has been lauded to the skies as Sammy Snead has since he broke into the limelight last Winter lives up to his reputation the way the youthful exmountaineer from West Virginia did here today.

Acting Mayor William F. Brunner will meet this afternoon at City Hall a delegation of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish clergymen who will urge approval of the resolution of Alderman Joseph T. Sharkey calling upon the Board of Aldermen to return to their old custom of opening their sessions with prayer.

1st Lt. Alexander Friedman, Med.-Res., now on active duty with CCC Co. 256, Camp SP-8 (N. Y.), Peekskill, N. Y., and additional duty with CCC Co. 2218V, Camp SP-52 (N. Y.), Peekskill, N. Y., will proceed to Governors Island, N. Y., for temporary duty, and upon completion of that duty will return to his proper station.

The stock markets reopened quietly today, and while business in most sections was small, there was a continuance of the firmness shown on Tuesday. Gilt-edge issues improved, but among foreign loans German bonds were one of the few firm exceptions in a weak list. International shares were lower following the dullness in Wall Street, and United States Steel and International Nickel declined.

The New York Curb Exchange's committee on business conduct issued yesterday rules on "daylight trading" similar to those promulgated by the New York Stock Exchange last month. The new rules will be effective on next Monday.

Forging ahead faster in relative production gains than any other division of the General Motors Corporation, the Pbntiac division will manufacture 235,000 cars of the current model if there is no further interruption due to labor difficulties, H. J; KIingler, general manager, told dealers of the Eastern region at a luncheon meeting

The batting average of the Public Works Administration in fighting the injunction proceedings brought by private power interests to tie up public power projects is about 1.000 per cent, Secretary Ickes said today in answer to a question at his press conference.

William Breitenbach, Democratic leader of the Thirteenth Assembly District and former Assemblyman of that district, died at 10:30 o'clock last night at Hamilton Hospital, 145 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, after an operation for appendicitis. Mr.
The three Scandinavian kings will meet here tomorrow when King Haakon of Norway and King Gustaf of Sweden will arrive for King Christian's silver Jubilee celebration Saturday.

Millinery syndicates and the large buying organizations were considering yesterday the eight proposals presented by the Millinery Stabilination Commission, designed to improve conditions in the industry. It was indicated that another conference between these organizations and representatives of the commission will be held next week following the initial meeting here on Wednesday at the Hotel Astor.

Officers were elected yesterday by the New York City Colony of the National Association of New England Women, meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Miss Alice V. Butterfield, who was elected president a year ago, was chosen for another year, as was Mrs. Hoyt A. Moore, second vice president.

Captain Max Pruss, commander of the Hindenburg, who has been in a critical condition at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center as a result of injuries and burns received in the disaster, is now belived to be out of danger, it was said yesterday at the hospital.

Three sailors were known to be dead, four were missing and more than a score were injured following an explosion on the starboard waterline of the British destroyer Hunter today off the Southern Spanish Coast when, Spanish sources said, the vessel either struck a mine or was torpedoed.

There appears on another page or this morning's TIMES an address by former President HERBERT HOOVER, every word of which every reader should read. It has to do with "the business of boys," though he does not exclude their sisters, "for whom our sentiment is even more tender." His' depiction of the boy is likely -to have a place in American literature.
Benjamin Taylor Van Alen, 87 years old, who was a member of the old Bergen Reformed Church here for seventy years, died this morning at his home.
Yesterday's reports of commercial leasing indicated a preference for locations in midtown, and included a number of stores to be used by retailers in various lines of business. The list follows:

The engagement of Miss Marie Brooke Heck to James Tileston Baldwin, son of Mrs. James Clarke Tileston Baldwin of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Mr. Baldwin, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Callendine Heck of Glen Head, L. I.

Lee B. Coshland and Lewis D. Gilbert of New York, who are known as minority stockholders to many companies, urged a Senate committee today to approve legislation to protect small investors from "abuses" by "arbitrary"' managements of big corporations.
America's two ten-goal poloists performed on winning sides today in a six-period match and a round-robin, involving Meadow Brook members.

Beginning tomorrow night, most of the 2,400 stores of the Eastern division of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company will close at 8 o'clock in pursuance of the policy of a shorter work week for employes, A. P. officials said yesterday.

Public offering will be made today by means of a prospectus by Hanson Hanson of 88,000 shares of common stock of the Vacuum Concrete Corporation at $2.12 1/2 a share. The company was formed in March, 1936, to exploit its patented process for vacuum treatment of concrete through license agreements on a royalty basis and rentals of equipment.

Captain Otto Liedert, 45, master of the freighter Wiegand, which ran aground in clear weather on a coral reef marked by a lighthouse, put a pistol bullet through his head today after thirty-six hours of vain attempts to refloat his ship.
The Rev. John L. Mahony, first assistant of St. Stanislaus Kostka Parish, Maspeth, L. I., died unexpectedly in his room in a downtown hotel today.

NOT in a spirit of criticism, but just as a mat ter of mild wonder, Manager Pie Traynor of the league-leading Pirates was asked whether or not the Pittsburgh scouts made a special effort to dig up ball players with fancy first names.

Arthur Garfield Hays, counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union, here by invitation of a local cornmittee, arrived by airplane from New York tonight to join in the investigation of the street battle at Ponce on March 21 between the police and Nationalists, whom the authorities had ordered not to parade. In this disturbance nineteen persons were killed and two-score were injured.

A remarkable purge occurred today in Finland's Social Democratic Labor party in an effort to rid the party-which has five members of the Cabinet-of members who have communistic tendencies and who have carried out intrigues against the moderate Labor policy.

The administration reasserted control over the budget balancing drive, at least for the time being, today when, under its influence, the House Appropriations Committee overrode economy demands and recommended $1,500,000,000 for work relief for the fiscal year 1938, as recommended by President Roosevelt.
The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee recommended today that the Connally "Hot Oil" Act, expiring on June 16, be extended for two years.

Mrs. Robert Grier Monroe of this city and Glen Head, L. I., has announced the marriage of her sister, Mrs. Adine du M. Bernard Gostenhofer, widow of Charles Edward Gostenhofer, to Hampton Sproulls Sealy of Summit, N. J., which took place on May 3 in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. A. M. Ready.

A graphic story of horror resulting from the abuse by Baltimore lawyers of habeas corpus proceedings in obtaining the release of feeble-minded men and women, which let loose on society a Pandora's box of ills, was recounted today before the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association by Dr. Leo Kanner of the Johns Hopkins Medical School.
More than 300 scientists paid homage here today to the memory of Daniel Garrison Brinton, anthropologist, on the 100th anniversary of his birth.

A breakfast rally in the Astor Hotel on Monday-morning at which 1,500 members of the Life Underwriters Association of New York City will be greeted by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, will open the fifth annual Life Insurance Week here.

John Henry Lewis, light-heavyweight champion, will meet Patsy Perroni of Cleveland in a ten-round over-the-weight battle at Madison Square Garden tonight. This may be Lewis's last appearance here as king of the light-heavies.

Weakness in the security and commodity markets dominated the action of grains on the Board of Trade here today, and while there was scattered liquidation by holders of May wheat contracts, net losses were not severe, the spot month being off 7/8 cent a bushel, while the new crop months declined 1/2 to % cent.

Funeral services for Birger Brinck, "flying reporter" and aviation and yachting editor of the Stockholm Tidningen, who was killed in the burning of the Hindenburg, were held yesterday afternoon at the Swedish Evangelical Lutheran Church of Gustavus Adolphus, 151 East Twenty-second Street.

Miss Margery Eafner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Hafner of Malba, Queens, was married last night at the home of her parents to Joseph J. Corn Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Corn of New York, by the Rev. Dr. John Haynes Holmes.

Awards for engineering construction in the week ended yesterday reached the total of $62,701,000, an increase of 105 .per cent over the same week of 1936 and making it the second highest weekly total so far this year, according to The Engineering News-Record. The total for the corresponding week of last year was $30,151,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent statement by Senator Nye that a group of Spanish Nationalists in this country are undermining the American Neutrality Law would seem to be a rather belated recognition of a situation that has made our neutrality legislation an object of ridicule for the past nine months.

Inland Steel Company rights, when issued, have been admitted to dealing on the New York Stock Exchange. Pfeiffer Brewing Company rights have been suspended from dealings. Kresge Foundation ten-year 3 1/2 per cent collateral trust notes due in 1947 have been admitted to the list.

John E. Fitzgerald, general manager and assistant treasurer of the Turner Tanning Machinery Company of Peabody, Mass., died yesterday afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Hospital after a short illness. Mr. Fitzgerald, who was 65 years old, lived at 7 Perkins Street, Peabody.

M. J. Strawbridge, Philadelphia sportsman, watched Argonaut, his ancient gray gelding, annex the ninth running of the Billy Barton Steeplechase, a grueling test of three miles for hunters holding certificates from the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association, today at Pimlico.

Two groups of city gardens were opened to the public yesterday afternoon, one group under the auspices of the Judson Health Center at 237 Thompson Street and the other under that of the School Nature League. Visitors found some gardens on roof tops and others in back yards.

County Judge Gerald Nolan. of Westchester County went out of his way today to assure Novio Santoro, 24 years old, a Yonkers caddy, who was convicted April 2 of first-degree murder, that he would not be sentenced to death in the electric chair.
The pageantry was medieval, but the note sounded by King GEORGE in his radio address had a distinct American ring.

The London Economist, remarking on the recent scare of European markets over a prospective lowering of its price for gold by the United States, agrees with other competent observers in pronouncing such separate action wholly improbable.

James J. Dooling, ailing leader of Tammany, at his desk in Tammany Hall yesterday for the first time in nearly ten months, reiterated that he had no intention of resigning. He also announced that he was ready to meet all comers and that he had a candidate for Mayor in mind.

The North American Homes Exposition, a display of homes and home furnishings which occupies part of the lower floor of Madison Square Garden, opened to the public at 8 o'clock last night. Several hundred persons attended.

New life insurance production in April increased 12.3 per cent over the same month of 1936, according to a report to the Department of Commerce by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents which was made public yesterday.

A plan for reorganizing the Roxy Theatres Corporation was recommended yesterday for approval to Federal Judge William Bondy by Addison S. Pratt, special master, in substantially the amended form agreed upon by creditors a week ago. Mr. Pratt, however, urged that creditors of the equity receivership be paid in full instead of 50 per cent.
Dr. Robert Hyland, surgeon for the Cardinals, said Paul Dean, the team's ailing pitcher, was sufficiently recovered from an operation on his right shoulder to leave the hospital today.

With certain reservations, the Hepburn administration has approved a tentative basis of agreement between the Ontario Government and the Hydro Electric Power Commission and the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Premier Mitchell Hepburn announced today after a conference with T. Stewart Lyon, chairman of the commission.
A formula was devised today for a probable settlement of the strike affecting 25,000 employes of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation here tomorrow.

In a tenderly phrased address on the boy and his problems, former President Herbert Clark Hoover last night urged that a fund of $15,000,000 be raised to expand the work of the Boys Clubs of America, Inc., of which he recently was elected chairman.

A conference of possibly vital importance to Anglo-American relations will begin tomorrow when the free nations of the British Commonwealth will begin another of their periodic family consultations within the historic walls of St. James's Palace.

Mrs. Herbert Hoover, president of the Girl Scouts, opened the Hendrik Hudson regional conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday morning with a plea to the delegates to consider the needs of the individual girl as the most important objective of their organization plans. More than 1,000 council members and leaders from New York and. New Jersey attended.

Announcement of plans for the Eastern Polo League's second season were made by officials last night, with .a total of fourteen teams entered and the possibility of more being added before the close of entries on May 22.

Ernest L. Stedman, 35, of Poughkeepsie, was killed and two persons riding with him were severely injured in an automobile collision near here today. State Police Corporal John Dwyer said Mr. Stedman's car crashed with that of Herbert Scism, 61, of Greenport, then hit a tree. Mr. Scism was unhurt.

The trustees of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company received compensation aggregating $43,000 in 1936, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Of this amount J. M. Kurn drew $25,000, and John G. Lonsdale, as co-trustee, $18000.
New films opening today are "Talk of the Devil" at the-Roxy, with Ricardo Cortez and Sally 'Eilers in the lead roles, and the Teutonic "Die Grobe Adele" at the Eighty-sixth Street Garden Theatre.

A lamplighter in Colonial costume made the rounds of Independence Square tonight, touching off his charges to put Philadelphia citizens in a proper frame of mind to begin the Summer-long observance tomorrow of the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Constitution.
The estate of Max Horwitz on North Street, Greenwich, Conn., consisting of a main residence, several outbuildings and ten acres, was purchased by Braemar, Inc., through George Howe, broker.

The battle of the city's playgrounds went on merrily yesterday. The 142 play areas throughout the city that were closed Wednesday afternoon by Park Commissioner Robert Moses were open throughout the day guarded by the police, with WPA play directors on the job.

The report of the North American Light and Power Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $1,115,644, which amount is exclusive of deficiencies of certain subsidiaries arising from excess of preferred dividends accumulated but not declared. This compares with a net of $1,116,068 in the twelve months ended March 31. 1936.
QUITE possibly, you won't agree that the novel, as an art form, is now in a pitiable state. You may very much doubt that E. M. Forster is the only "considerable" contemporary writer of fiction.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn was called upon today to produce in the Parker conspiracy trial tomorrow morning a letter which the defense hopes will discredit the testimony of a Sing Sing convict that Ellis H. Parker Jr. persuaded him to participate in the kidnapping and torture of Paul H. Wendel in February, 1936.

Professor E. Allison Peers of Liverpool University, speaking yesterday at the Hotel Vanderbilt at a meeting of the American Committee for Spanish Relief, said the great majority of the Spanish people are "faithful to the traditions of their ancestors" and definitely are not Leftist in sympathy.

Appointment of a committee of fifteen which, will memorialize President Roosevelt in the interest of obtaining action at this session of Congress on the Miller-Tydings bill, and which will also collect data to prove that the various State Fair Trade Acts have "not raised prices to the consumer," was announced yesterday by W. A. Hollingsworth, president of the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America and chairman of the committee.

The Providence College baseball team remained undefeated in seven straight games by defeating Villanova today, 4 to 1. Villanova had won eight straight before today's game. A triple by Garbark, Villanova catcher, in the eighth robbed the Friars of a shut-out.
Walter E. Hallett, vice president and.trustee of the Bank for Savings in the City of New York, died at his home here today after an illness of eight weeks. He.was 72 years old.

An event noteworthy in The annaus of opera in New York transpired on Wednesday night when WALTER DAMROSCH, at the age of 75, conducted the premiere of his third opera, "The Man Without a Country." The audience that assembled included all ranks of music lovers in the city, and filled -to its capacity the Metropolitan Opera House.
Walter Lawrence Carlin, who was with the Radio Corporation of America in New York, died at St. Francis Hospital here today at the age of 32.

Under the auspices of the Horticultural Society of New York, the annual Tulip Show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society will open at 2 o'clock this afternoon in the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

The Treasury suffered a setback here yesterday in its current attempt to prove there was an understanding between Pierre S. du Pont and John J. Raskob, each to sell stock to the other totaling $29,000,000 and to repurchase their original holdings, after establishing "fictitious" market losses of $7,496,170 for income tax purposes in 1929.

The books of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation disclose the fact that, as of April 30 this year, five of the principal railway systems included within the Van Sweringen network were in debt to the corporation in the sum of $56,164,928. Since the loans were made, the original total being $56,896,450, there has been returned to the RFC by the borrowing' lines only $731,522.

Six Hunter College girls proved their culinary prowess at a cakebaking contest yesterday afternoon in the Home Economics room of the 2 Park Avenue center of the college. Gladys Olian of 1,915 Hennessy Place, the Bronx, a 19-yearold senior, won first prize with a chocolate cream cake.

In a one-hour speech on foreign affairs Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Foreign Minister, gave the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon a birdseye view of Italy's present situation in the international field.

Scoring eleven runs in the fourth inning today on a combination of hard hitting, bases on balls and misplays, the Naval Academy won from Western Maryland, 16 to 8. Singles by Powell, McFarland, Sbisa, Eliot, a second hit by McFarland and Ingram's triple, with three passed and two errors, accounted for the fruitful inning.

Edgar T. Appleby won the twentieth annual Poggenburg Memorial 18.2 balkline, billiard tournament by defeating Howard Bergman in a play-off match, 300 to 100, in eighteen innings, at Lawler's Manhattan Academy last night. Appleby, playing for 300, had a high run of 47, while Bergman, at the 175 mark, made a cluster of 22.

The Rev. and Mrs. Arthur Howe Bradford of Providence have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Price Bradford, to Thomas Mason Page, son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert W. Page of Scarsdale.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated May 12: COLONELS Cocheu, G. W. (C. A. C.), General Staff Corps, eight days' leave, May 19. Hunt, C. A. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, 16 days' leave, May 15, with permission to visit foreign countries.

The possibility that soil conservation funds which are being paid out in gratuities having no connection with supposed services rendered in return, was raised in the Senate today by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan during the debate on the Agriculture Department Appropriation Bill.

Here and there.. .. Although fishing guides at Peconic Bay do not as yet like to divulge what their actual bookings are, nevertheless there is no denying that all hands expect one of the biggest gatherings in several years to fish for weakfish on Sunday.

Private collectors and spectators filled the great hall at Inisfada yesterday, for the fourth day's auction of furnishings and objects of art collected by Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, for her country mansion at Manhasset, L. I.

During the week ended May 12 member bank reserve balances increased $61,000,000. Additions to memberbank reserves arose from an increase of $44,000,000 in gold stock and decreases of $21,000,000 in money in circulation and $49,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $43,000,000 in Treasury cash and $9,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and a decrease of $2,000,000 in Treasury currency.

A funeral service was held yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Saviour, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn, for Mrs. Martha Holden' Hooper, who died Tuesday at her home, 96 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, at the age of 87.

Francis Wilson, actor and first president of Actors Equity Association, left a net estate of about $98,000, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. He died Oct. 7, 1935, at the age of 81. At the time of his death he was a resident of Clearwater. Fla.

Raymond Leslie Buell of New York, president of the Foreign Policy Association, told. the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs in Haddon Hall, here, today that this nation is drifting into an alliance with France and Great Britain from

Voicing approval of the advice given them by school authorities and public officials, seventy-five foreignborn "students," the majority about 50 years old, received their diplomas yesterday at the annual exercises of the day classes for adults in English and citizenship at Carnegie Hall.

Mr. and Mrs. William Tingue Quimby entertained with a dinner yesterday in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for her sister, Miss Florence Meachem Hyde, and Henry John Wynkoop 3d, whose marriage will take place tomorrow in Christ Church, Greenwich, Conn.

Trade regulations promulgated by the executive committee of the Textile Converters Association of America, Inc., designed to stabilize conditions in the industry, were forwarded yesterday to members of the converting and manufacturing divisions and other interests for their consideration.

Young Republicans from all parts of the State began arriving here tonight for conferences preliminary to the opening tomorrow of a two-day convention of the State.Association of Young Republican Clubs.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, drawing near the end of its twenty-third convention here, went on record today in favor of President Roosevelt's proposal to reform the United States Supreme Court and also in favor of the ChildLabor Amendment.

The urgent need for American Jews to support financially the Joint Distribution Committee and Ort so that these organizations can continue relief and reconstruction work among the Jews in Eastern Europe was .stressed last night by Lord Marley.

Following by less than twenty-four hours the signing of a contract by Major J. Henry Stump for a survey for a municipal electric lighting and power plant, E. H. Werner, vice president of the Metropolitan Edison Company, an affiliate of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, announced today plans to spend $3,000,000 for an annex to the company's plant here.

Mr. and Mrs. George Gifford Symes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Foster Symes, to Donald Francis Lange of Northport, L. I. The wedding will take place in June in New York.
The National Broadcasting Company will broadcast a special program from 3:30 to 4 P. M. tomorrow in honor of the silver jubilee of King Christian X of Denmark and Iceland.
Two flats in Hackensack and dwellings in West Orange and Newark were sold by Leslie Blau, Inc., as broker, for the Paramount Building and Loan Association of Newark.

Mrs. Samuel J. Creegan of Glen Cove gave a luncheon yesterday. at her home, at which she announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Elwyna Van Alen, daughter of T. Elwyn Van Alen of Mineola, to Gordon Sauerbrun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Sauerbrun of Jamaica, N. Y.
Georges Bonnet, the French Ambassador, portrayed his country today as one which, like the United States, is strongly attached to the cause of democracy and peace.
