Ira Levick, 39 years old, formerly a patient at the Camden County Sanitarium for Mental Cases, was held without bail for the grand jury when arraigned today before Police Recorder Walter Van Istendal on a charge of murdering his father, Henry Levick, 60, during a scuffle last night in the basement of their home at 611 Woodlawn Avenue here.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday that title companies may not recoup interest advanced to group certificate holders from funds received under rent assignments or special agreements while any of the property covered by the underlying mortgages in the Series was in default on taxes and assessments.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today summaries of the following additional registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933:

Sterling Products, Inc., has acquired for a price of about $7,300,000 all of the assets, properties, trade marks and business of the American Ferment Company, the Drew Pharmacal Company and the Cellasin Company, all of Buffalo, N. Y.

The consonated Edison Company of New York, Inc., purchased 80,498 additional shares of New York Steam Corporation common stock from minority interests between April 16 and May 10 at a cost of $2,952,456, according to a report filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission. The average price of the shares thus obtained was $32.21, the company stated.
An 8-year-old defendant who recently was challenged to a game of marbles by Judge P. S. Cunniff in c District Court today emerged with e all the marbles after a session with t the jurist.

After detectives had patiently watched the activities of an alleged hold-up gang for almost eight weeks, they rounded up, between noon and midnight Wednesday, three men and two women in an apartment at 1,555 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, the police disclosed yesterday.

British authorities warned Spanish civil war refugees in Gibraltar today that they might have to leave this city. An official statement said the refugees were "causing serious overcrowding to the detriment of British subjects, who are unable to find accommodations."

Charles Green, in 217 Asbury Ave. Westbury, L. L; Terence Preece, in 244 Grand St; James Kenny, in 171 Castle Ave; Dr. Malcolm Meistreil in 419 Winthrop St; Patrick Rattigan, in 145 Butler St; J. Bremner Proctor. in 292 Asbury Ave; Captain Victor Feuerherd, in 410 Winthrop St; William Cabrey, in 61 Old Country Rd; Harland W. Meistrell. broker.

Leaving for Plymouth and Havre today the French liner Ile de France will have among her passengers Norman Armour, United States Minister to Canada, with Mrs. Armour; Arthur Samuels, editor and playwright, and Mrs. Samuels; James Thurber, artist and writer; Pierre Brissaud, French artist, with Mrs. Brissaud; Charles Durand-Ruel, New York and Paris art dealer; Lester Stoeffen, tennis star, and Arthur Brentano Sr., president of Brentano's.
Edward E. Bartlett Jr. has been elected chairman of the arbitration committee of the New York Stock Exchange, succeeding Peter J. Maloney, who has retired from the governing committee.

The Department of Prints and Drawings of the Brooklyn Museum opens today. an exhibition of work by Jean Francois Millet. It will continue through June 27. All the prints to be shown are from the collections of Mrs. Henry Harper Benedict and Mr. and Mrs. George W. Davison.
Reports have reached Paris from competent observers who recently visited Nationalist (Insurgent] Spain that dissension among General Francisco Franco's troops is being put down with an iron hand.

WASHINGTON, May 13.-Debts charged off by banks in accordance with orders of examiners of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation may be deducted from Federal income taxes, Morrison Shafroth, chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Bureau, ruled today.

Georgetown's unbeaten baseball team won its tenth game of the season yesterday with a 9-1 triumph over New York University at Ohio Field. The visitors gave one of the best collegiate performances of the year in gaining the victory.

Mervin E. Anderson, a Fairbanks bus driver, won the world's queerest contest-the Far North's annual ice break-up guessing. When the ice started moving out last night in the Tanana River here at 10:04 P. M.

George Gill, recruit right-hander making his first major league start, pitched the Tigers' initial shut-out of the season, beating the Red Sox today, 4 to 0, with a five-hit performance It was Detroit's first victory in five games.

The Senate passed the Agriculture Department Appropriation Bill, received the Copeland bill for an appropriation for. the development of airplane engines, received the Nye resolution asking the State Department to request Ambassador Dodd to name the "billionaire" behind a Fascist movement in the United States and recessed at 3:12 P. M. until noon Monday.

David Schenker, counsel for the Securities and Exchange. Commission, declared today that an investment trust lost $4,425,000 in connection with financing of the Empire State Building, New York's 1,248-foot skyscraper.

The Duke of Windsor was reported here today to be interested in the purchase of the Cove Neck estate of William B. Leeds, where as Prince of Wales he was entertained by the late Rodman Wanamaker on a visit to this country in 1924.
The Bilbao-bound northern Insurgent army rolled ahead over a fifteen-mile battlefront today and pushed to within five miles of the beseiged Basque capital at some points. Planes blasted the way.
Thomas James Wise, bibliographer, collector and editor, who formed the famous Ashley Library at Hampstead, died today at the age of 77.
Senator Copeland complained today that farmers had mistaken the Capitol dome for a nursing bottle. At hearings on soil conservation measures to help the farmers, he asked:

The National Supply Company of Delaware and subsidiaries, including Spang, Chalfant Co., Inc., reported yesterday for the first three months of this year a net profit, based on book inventories, of $2,644,750 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes, guaranteed dividends on National-Superior Company preferred stock, provision for quarterly dividends on the cumulative preferred stock of Spang, Chalfant and other charges. No provision was made for Federal surtax on undistributed income.

Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers landed at the Music Hall yesterday and by mid-afternoon the heroic usher corps had the situation fairly well in hand. "Shall We Dance," which asks so rhetorical a question it does not even bother to add the interrogation point, is one of the best things: the screen's premiere dance team has done, a zestful,
Playland, the Westchester County amusement park here, will be opened for the tenth Summer season Saturday and will remain open daily until late September.

Bringing total cash borrowing through the medium of Treasury bills to $250,000,000 in the last five weeks, Secretary Morgenthau today announced that $100,000,000 in that type of security, including $50,000,000 for new money and the remainder to refund a maturing issue, would be issued under date of May 19.

The security and commodity markets fell hard yesterday. The stock market had its widest decline in more than a year, with leading issues 'down 1 to more than 6 points. The volume of trading on the Stock Exchange reached 1,773,000 shares, the heaviest in, two weeks. The bond market weakened in increased trading. Selling pressure was felt in virtually all the commodity markets.
Mrs. Harriet Louise Mills Stevenson, widow of W. W. Stevenson, the controller of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, died today at her home, 110 Midland Avenue, here.

In an effort to reduce residential building costs and thus make the idea of owning a home more attractiv8 to families in all parts of the country, the directors of the National Association of Real Estate Boards approved yesterday a plan for the formation of a "Home Builders Guild."

Sydney G. McAllister, president of the International Harvester Corporation, said at the annual meeting of stockholders held in Hoboken, N. J., yesterday that domestic and foreign billings for the- six months ended April 30, first half of the company's fiscal year, were 30 per cent greater than in the corresponding period of last year.

The American Theatre Council's convention will open shortly after noon on May 24 at the Hotel Astor with an address of welcome by Helen Hayes and five-minute speeches by Frank Gillmore, president of Equity; Sidney Howard, president of the Dramatists Guild; Marcus Heiman, president of the League of New York Theatres, and James J. Brennan, president of Theatrical Protective Union Local 1.

A plea of unconstitutionality against the recent Presidential decree requiring commercial firms to employ 50 per cent women and providing that merchants employ only women for the sale of articles of feminine use was presented to the Supreme Court today.

Lumber production was higher last week, when a seasonal decline was called for, and the adjusted index advanced to 86.8 from 86.0. It was 81.8 for the week ended May 9, 1936. Both shipments and orders were lower than those for the previous week, according to reports wired especially to THE NEW YORK TIMES from regional associations.

Just as the sun was setting over the Irish Sea Henry T. Merrill and John S. Lambie took off from Southport Sands Airfield at 9:13 this evening [4:13 P. M. in New York] on the return lap of the first commercial round-trip Atlantic crossing by a heavier-than-air craft.

Against a background of tall trees and shrubs growing with jungle luxuriance and the thunderous roar of lions mingled with the soft made strains of the Blue Danube waltz played by a concert orchestra, the annual garden party of the New York Zoological Society was held yesterday at the Zoological Park the Bronx.

With sports subjects as the theme, the work of American artists was on display yesterday in the first exhibition under the auspices of the Institute of American Sporting Art, Inc. at the Squibb Building.

A total of 7,767,311 volumes of the Bible or parts of the Bible was distributed during 1936 by the American Bible Society, it was disclosed at the 121st annual meeting of the organization yesterday afternoon in the new Bible House, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street.
The April 15 preliminary New York farm price index of 117 is the highest April index since 1930, when it was 142, the State Agriculture Department said today.

Dr. Hugo Eckener and other members of the special committee appointed by Germany to investigate the crash of the Hindenburg arrived last night on the liner Europa. They went immediately to Lakehurst, N. J., where they will examine the wreckage of the fallen craft and consult with the boards of inquiry.

More than thirty important French paintings are being lent by American collectors and museums to the retrospective exhibition of French art in Paris arranged in connection with the International Exposition, to be opened on May 25.

Dick Shikat, former world heavyweight wrestling champion, again conquered Frank Sexton of California in the main bout at the Hippodrome last night. He tossed his rival with a double arm lock and a back heave in 43:31. Shikat weighed 227 pounds and Sexton 232. A crowd of 1,500 saw the contest.
After much discussion and differences among themselves, Paris hairdressers struck today for a five-day week and a 20 per cent increase in wages.

Valentine Bliss, native of Cranfield, England, and a leader in the silk manufacturing industry in Pennsylvania and New Jersey for more than a half century, died today at his home here following an illness of two weeks.

Whitsunday or Pentecost will be commemorated tomorrow. In some churches annual Family Day will be celebrated. A number' of churches will hold post-coronation services with British patriotic organizations being present. Many pastors in their sermons will draw lessons from the coronation.

Twenty-nine Americans arrested April 3 and later convicted of attempting to enter Spain to fight government armies, were released today. They were ordered to leave France within eight days but not by way of the Spanish frontier.

The Rev. Elbert Clay Hoag, Methodist minister for fifty-five years, died Thursday night in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, of injuries suffered earlier in the day when he slipped and fell in a subway station in Brooklyn. He was 86 years old.

President Roosevelt returned to Washington today and promptly made it plain that he intended to push forward toward the objectives outlined in his Madison Square Garden speech last October and fight for his plan for judiciary reform regardless of the present appearance of defeat of the proposal.

Paul Shields of New York, a broker, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he had lost $2,000,000 in Chain Store Stocks, Inc. He testified at the commission's general investigation to determine whether legislation is needed to regulate such trusts.

Sales of an estate in Harrison and of a large business property in New Rochelle were reported from Westchester County yesterday. John J. Reynolds sold for Bernard A. Stock, Albert W. Lockyer and Elwood W. Cromwell, trustees, the property known as the Ferguson Market at 562-68 Main Street, running through to Centre Street,

Price movements of commodity futures were irregular in lessened activity on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, silk, cocoa and copper futures advanced, while hide, coffee, sugar, lead and zinc futures declined.

The German National People's [Nationalist] party was dissolved here tonight by the unanimous vote of its sixty-five delegates. The step was taken, it was explained, in order to secure German unity in Danzig and do away with fraternal strife.

A. J. Hotard of New Orleans and Robert Morgan of Detroit, a pair of stable owners with faith in their horses, invoked an Illinois Racing Commission rule today for the first time on record to run off a dead heat at the Aurora track-with Hotard and the daily double players the winners.

Two Sears, Roebuck salesmen placed identifying hands yesterday on the shoulder of Leonard Haberman in Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz's court room and testified he had purchased a shotgun which the government contends was used in the robbery of the Northern Westchester Bank at Katonah, N. Y., on March 12.

At 7 o'clock on any fine morning a tall officer in the undress uniform of the Danish Guard rides out alone through-the side door of the Amalienborg, the royal palace in the heart of Copenhagen. He appears so punctually that you might set your watch by his coming; in fact many Danes do.
Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan, in an address here yesterday, placed the property rights of employers and "the worker's property rights in his job" on a basis of equality and mutual respect.

Maurice Evans's performance in "King Richard II" by William Shakespeare was praised yesterday afternoon by Daniel Frohman, veteran theatrical producer, as an outstanding example of his contention that "there's always a theatre on Broadway for a good play."

If the Young Republicans of New York were less successful than active last year, that was no fault of theirs; and no person of good-will will look unkindly on their annual convention which began at Syracuse yesterday.

Death Announced Retired Fireman John J. O'Connor, formerly a member of H. L. 109, died May 12. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 1,944 Ford St., Brooklyn, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, May 15. The deputy chief of the 12th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 8 amounted to 767,481 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,942 cars, or 1.9 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 98,615 cars, or 14.7 per cent,

With a favorable gale-like wind sweeping across Legion Field, track stats of a dozen colleges went through qualifying paces to-day for the finals of the fifth annual Southerastern Conference track carnival.
The Ecuadoran Legation here gave out a statement today foreshadowing the collapse of the boundary negotiations with Peru at Washington.

Notices posted today at the plant of the Singer Manufacturing Company here announced a 10 per cent increase in pay for all piece workers and day workers on an hourly basis, effective the week ending June 5. The increase will be the second given voluntarily by the company in four months. In January a 5 per cent increase was put into effect.

LEO XIII, by Rene Fulop-Miller, translated by Conrad Bonacina. (Longmans, Green, $2.50.) This is a study of the ideas, the philosophy, that Pope Leo XIII brought to the papacy and that were behind his concept of a divinely ordered society.

Miss Ann Rossiter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winton Goodrich Rossiter of this place, was married to Andrew Jefferson Berry Jr., son of Mrs. James Thornwell Bargan Jr. of Scarsdale and the late Andrew Jefferson Berry, tonight in the Reformed Church here. The Rev. Dr.

Delaware Power and Light Company--Year to March 31: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, $1,350,296, compared with revised net of $1,225,305 in year to March 31, 1936. For three months to March 31, net income was $387,034, compared with revised net of $342,147 in first quarter of 1936.

Evidence of an improved real estate market in nearly all parts of the country, the need for the construction of more homes to keep t pace with the rising demand and the desirability of cooperative effort to combat rising residential costs were emphasized yesterday at the opening sessions of the Central Atlantic regional conference of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Continuing his attacks on Mayor La Guardia, Jacob A. Livingston, former Brooklyn Republican leader, declared last night that if the Republican party named its own candidate for Mayor this year the party could win the post at City Hall.

Men and women returned from hopeless insanity by insulin, which is saving millions from death by sugar, are bringing back with them the first geographiess of the mind," giving man the first inklings of what goes on in the intricate "labyrinths of psyche,"
Clem Loughlin, manager of the Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League for the last three years, announced his retirement from the game today after twenty years as a player and manager.

During the past seven years, when conditions at home have demanded all the support that private philanthropy could afford, the American colleges in the Near East have refrained from asking for help except from a limited circle of intimate friends.

The Hunter College student body registered approval of its "progressive party" when it ele ted for the chief offices in the student selfgovernment seven- nominees running on the same platform, it was announced yesterday.

A move to test the legality of a ruling by the Federal Bureau of Roads penalizing the State $558,006 because it diverted $7,917,000 from the highway fund for relief was made today by the Joint Appropriations Committee of the New Jersey Legislature.

Representative B. E. Quinn, veteran of the Legislature, was charged with murder today after the fatal. shooting.of Herman- Hicks, 41, a.Houston civil engineer, in an early morning hotel room altercation.
Weakness in the grains and textiles sent The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices lower for the fifth consecutive week. The index declined to 142.2

Lord Astor's Cash Book won the Newmarket Stakes, important Derby trial today, defeating the Earl of Derby's Fair Copy by two lengths. Major J. S. Courtauld's Solfo was third in the field of nine 3-year-olds.
The weakfish season is here at last. The curtain will rise tomorrow on one of the most interesting fishing periods in the metropolitan area.

The marriage of Miss Frances Wharton Poor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wharton Poor of 40 Mitchell Avenue, Flushing, Queens, to Barry Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sevellon Brown of Providence, took place yesterday afternoon in St. George's Episcopal Church in Flushing.

Harold S. Vanderbilt's Class J sloop Ranger, with which he hopes to defend the America's Cup, left Bath today for Newport, R. I., in tow of Vanderbilt's yacht Vara. Ranger was launched here last Tuesday. She will be given her first test under canvas Monday.

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board, and Eugene G. Grace, president, received $180,000 each from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation last year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Quincy Brent and C. Austin Buck, directors, received $90.000 each.

A memorial service in which all veteran organizations have been invited to participate will be held tomorrow it Holy Cross Catholic Church, Forty-second Street west of Eighth Avenue. The service, under the Allied Veterans Memorial Service Committee, will be attended by about 2,500 veterans.

Residential construction started last month in the thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains amounted to $108,204,400, a gain of 20 per cent over the March figure of $90,167,600 and an increase of 61 per cent over the total of $67,151,000 reported in the same area during April, 1936, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation.
Three Skidmore College graduates, returning to their campus for May Day exercises, were injured tonight when their car was in collision with another on the Albany Post Road near here.
With C. V. (Sonny) Whitney leading the attack with three tallies, the White poloists outscored a Red combination, 11 to 7, at Preece Field today. Terrence Preece-led the losers with four markers.

One speaker told the California Bankers Association in convention here today that the nation's budget must be balanced if inflation is to be checked and another warned "only the most farsighted and earnest efforts can possibly avert disaster."

Far Rockaway High School's nine topped John Adams High, 5-4, at Far Rockaway yesterday and tightened its hold on third position in the Queens division P. S. A. L. race. Many other league contests on yesterday's schedule were postponed on account of rain.

The annual tulip show of the Nassau County Horticultural Society was opened to the public yesterday afternoon in the Ameridan Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West. Although other flowers were exhibited, the tulips of many types and varieties, presenting a mass of color, dominated the show.

A mural depicting Governor Clinton "marrying" the waters of Lake Erie with the waves of New York Bay, painted many years ago for De Witt Clinton High School, was made the subject of a copyright suit in Federal. court yesterday.

A lawyer and his former business partner won leniency in General Sessions yesterday because they had aided Bernard C. Botein, Assistant District Attorney, in charge of the Accident Fraud Bureau, in uncovering an old fake accident indemnity claim. Judge Owen W.

German women must get along without hightopped leather boots. The Leather Import Control Bureau has issued an ordinance prohibiting their manufacture for the domestic market in order to save foreign exchange.

Ralph E. McEldowney, a leader in banking and brokerage circles here since 1918, died today of a heart ailment at Bridgeport Hospital, where he had been a patient for several weeks. He was 53 years old.

The Federal Trade Commission, continuing the government's new drive against monopolistic tendencies in industry, today filed. complaints against five companies manufacturing concrete pipe and other concrete products on the Eastern seaboard, charging a conspiracy to fix prices.

The marriage of Miss Betty Bainbridge Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Taylor Ryan of this place, to Donald Gardner Wallace, son of Mrs. Lester Wallace of Glen Ridge, N. J., and the late Mr. Wallace, took place tonight in St. Peter's Church, Essex Fells, N. J.
Detroit's Tigers, .world champions in 1935, loaded the bases in the ninth today with none out, but could not score and the - up-and-down St.- Louis Browns won, 6 to 5.

To Sports Editor of The New York Tmers: After reading John Kieran's column THE TIES entitled "The Man Who Knew John L.," I want to say that the man who knew John L. was right. Jeffries, too, would have walked in and murdered the so-called greats of today.

Joseph Berger, 29 years old, one of two men on trial in General Sessions on a first-degree murder indictment in the stabbing of Frank Cicero, 33, a Stamford (Conn.) boss truckman, before 700 men and women at a testimonial dinner in the Manhattan Opera House on the night of Jan. 27, took the witness stand in his own defense yesterday.

A program of capital expenditures made, and to be made, involving about $12,600,000, was disclosed in a registration statement filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company of Cincinnati covering $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 31/2 per cent series, due in 1967.
Miss Doris Borden,. daughter of General and Mrs. Howard S. Borden, of Old Oaks, River Road, Rumson, was married this afternoon to William Boardman Leonard, son of Mrs. William B. Leonard of Rumson.

The stock markets generally were dull today, the sharp break in Wall Street prices adversely affecting all sections. Gilt-edge issues were firm, but among the foreign loans German bonds failed to maintain yesterday's gains. International stocks were weak and United States Steel and International Nickel slumped.
Louis Delaunay, one of France's great Moliere actors, died today at St. Raphael on the French Riviera after a long illness.

Miss Myrtle Margaret Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Jones of 421 Mountain Avenue, was married to Roy Peter Staack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Staack of Elizabeth, tonight in the chapel of the Presbyterian Church.

Major Gen. William N. Haskell, commander of the New York National Guard, has resigned from the executive directorate of the American Committee for Spanish Relief, now engaged in a drive for funds, it was learned yesterday.
Gene Tunney made his first golfing ace today, and his feat so thrilled the former heavyweight boxing champion that he celebrated by buying a case of champagne for his threesome's Negro caddies.
New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street, 10 A. M. Conference on Education for Peace. Speakers: Oswald Garrison Villard, Dr. Henry Neumann, Algernon D. Black.
Methods used to bring transport planes to safe landings at airports in Europe when weather conditions obscure the ground were demonstrated at Indianapolis Municipal Airport today.

A retail liquor price war involving whiskies protected under FeldCrawford law price maintenance contracts, developed in the downtown section of the city yesterday and was still in progress at closing time last night.

Establishment of an arbitration council "free from political affiliations or prejudice" to handle major industrial problems was proposed yesterday to the American Cotton Manufacturers Association at its Washington convention by George P. Ray, vice president and general sales manager of Riverside and Dan River Cotton Mills.
Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Verner Reed have come from their Winter home in Hobe Sound, Fla., to the Pierre. Later they will go to Denbigh Farms, their place at Greenwich, Conn.
Charles Homer Haskins, Professor Emeritus of History at Harvard University, and an internationally known scholar, died here today. He was 67 years old.
Major Gen. John Lincoln Clem, "Drummer Boy of Chickamauga," who fought in the Civil War when he was only 10 years old, died last night at the age of 86.

Advertising agencies and trade papers were urged yesterday to unite in interpreting the facts of American business to the public by Allen Brown of the Bakelite Company, chairman of the board of the Asociation of National Advertisers. He spoke at a luncheon of the Dotted-Line Club of the Associated Business Papers, at the Hotel Commodore.

Mrs. Henry W. Peabody, author, Christian worker and for twelve years chairman of the. Women's National Committee on Law Enforcement, will make her report as chairman of the national campaign committee for the. Union Christian Colleges of India at the annual meeting of their board of trustees, which consists of American women, at the Hotel Roosevelt next Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.

A mysterious German train that caused many rumors reached Innsbruck at 9 o'clock this morning. The station was party closed by the police, who admitted only .German citizens presenting passports. Some 200 Germans saw the train, consisting of two sleeping cars and three other coaches, arrive with its windows closed and blinds drawn.

The steamship Acadia, which is operated bythe Eastern Steamship Lines between New York and Norfolk, was held at her Hudson River pier last night for lack of an engine room and deck staff, while pickets from the National Maritime Union marched in West Street, adjacent to the pier.
The State Banking Department announced today its approval of a change of location of the Consumers Cooperative Credit Union of Brooklyn from 209 Lott Avenue to 229 Sackman Street, Brooklyn.

Sam Snead, the -sensational young West Virginia golfer, today shot one of the finest rounds of his entire career only to have it wasted by a deluge of rain which rendered the Forest Hill Field Club course unplayable.

Despite the visit of James J. Dooling to Tammany Hall Thursday and his announcement of his intention to remain as leader, members of the Tammany executive committee were skeptical yesterday of his ability to continue.

Dr. L. B. Sharp, executive director of Life Camps, speaking at the morning session of the Hendrik Hudson regional conference of. Girl Scouts at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, expressed the hope that the movement would stimulate other groups to work for the welfare of girls.

Moscow on the radio dial put a number of former members of the German Communist party behind prison bars for terms of from two to six years today. The court then warned all radio fans in Germany to tune their sets carefully away from the Moscow number.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The market for wool has been very quiet. Prices are tending downward, although somewhat irregularly.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $19,383,605, to be represented by 117 municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $10,708,500 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $32,138,023.

Father Divine, Negro cult leader, and three of his "angels" were exonerated yesterday by Magistrate McGee in the Felony Court after a hearing on charges growing out of the stabbing of Harry Green, a white Hoboken building contractor, in the Divine "main heaven" in West 115th Street on April 20.

A new youth center established by the Juvenile Aid Bureau of the Police Department was opened yesterday afternoon at 953 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, by Byrnes MacDonald, Deputy Police Commissioner, and named Thomas Wynn Youth Center.

The Mead Corporation has notified holders of stock purchase warrants, issued under an agreement dated May 1, 1930, that in accordance with the terms of the agreement, an adjustment has been made in the purchase price and other conditions by the Ctiy Bank Farmers Trust Company, as trustee.

Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association, sent a telegram yesterday to Governor Lehman, asking for a public hearing on the Doyle-Neustein bill to establish a State Labor Relations Board and making other provisions similar to the Federal Wagner in Labor Relations Act.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously dismissed yesterday a suit for $367,250 brought by Kenneth S. Guiterman against Frank E. Taplin, former president, chairman of the board and principal stockholder of the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railroad, and against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and A. J. County,one of its vice presidents.

The Tennessee Valley Authority received from the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today a "go ahead" signal for continuance of the federal Government's large electric power program in six Southern States.

The groundwork was laid yesterday for requests by the non-profit hospitals of New York to the Department of Hospitals for greater contributions by the city for the care they give to the indigent sick and injured.

Several million American school children, in thousands of schools throughout the country, sat today simultaneously in special assemblies in four separate time zones to hear the first National School Assembly program arranged by the United States Offices of Education.

The New York State intercollegiate tennis tournament, with entries from Fordham, Colgate, C. C. N. Y., New York University and Army, was forced to the Army indoor courts today because or a heavy rain.

The United Press Association, a news gathering agency, and the American Newspaper Guild agreed yesterday to have the National Labor Relations Board conduct a nation-wide poll of the association's editorial employes to determine whether they wished to be represented by the guild in collective bargaining.

Heavy fire was exchanged tonight by two sections of the Insurgents besieged in University City, it is reported by General Jose Miaja, commander of the defense of Madrid. He said it appeared there was a revolt within the Insurgent ranks.

Sheriff Paul F. Johnson of Rockford, Ill., arrived here by plane today with a warrant charging Lester Brockelhurst, 23 years old, of that city, with the murder of Albin J. Theander, 45-year-old tailor of Stillman Valley, Ill.

The first commercial round-trip plane flight over the North Atlantic and the fastest two-way trip ever made ended at 4:35 o'clock yesterday afternoon when Henry T. (Dick) Merrill, with his co-pilot, John S. Lambie Jr., landed the Daily Express at Floyd Bennett Field.

In London a few weeks ago a representative of one of the British dominions, discussing with the writer the Imperial Conference which opened yesterday, predicted that its momentous and highly controversial business would be to define the- attitude and obligations of the States of the Commonwealth toward Great Britain in the event of war.
Short covering was largely responsible for a sharp upturn in the grain markets today, and disclosed a lack of the aggressive selling which has been in evidence of late.

Rutgers, nine-time champion, qualified seventeen men in the twentyi fifth annual Middle Atlantic States Collegiate -Athletic Association track and field meet preliminaries today to lead Haverford, which saw twelve of its stars advance.
The twelve-room stucco dwelling, situated on a one-acre plot, at 34 Heathcote Road, Scarsdale, Westchester, has been sold by the Empire City Savings Bank to a client of Edward Livingston Montgomery.

Strikes affecting 32,000 employes of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and the Pittsburgh Steel Corporation were settled here today on the basis of recognition of the Steel Workers Organzation Committee for its members.

We print on this page today an important and unusually interesting letter from STUART A. RICE, chairman of the Central Statistical Board, regarding the question of an unemployment census. Dr. RICE points to the inherent difficulties of counting the "unemployed" at any time, and argues that,

Henry T. (Dick) Merrill has had 12,000 hours in the air and has been described by Captain Eddie Rickenbacker, general manager of Eastern Air Lines, as the "best commercial pilot" in the United'States. Others also have praised his skill and judg ment.

Ford Motor Company officials took the offensive today against the proposed unionization drive on its employes scheduled for next week by the United Automobile Workers Union and mapped a counter-attack on "outsiders" seeking to establish "job monopoly."

The Merrill-Lambie flight is the fastest round-trip Atlantic crossing ever made and also is the first commercial round-trip crossing by a heavier-than-air craft. The only other round-trip crossing by plane was the experimental flight that Merrill and Harry Richman, Broadway entertainer, made in September, 1936.

The engagement of $5,395,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $3,190,000 in England and $2,205,000 in Canada, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The price of gold bullion in London was advanced 21/2d an ounce to 140s 8d, which was equal to a cost per ounce for gold shipped here, including interest at the discount rate, of about $34.964, compared with $34.9596 on Thursday.

The United Stockyards Corporation, a $12,000,000 holding and management company, announced today acquisition for $3,383,483 of all the stock holdings of the General Stockyards Corporation, giving the United definite majority control of four yards at St. Paul, Sioux City, Fort Worth and Toronto.

At the request of the Citizens Committee of Ponce for the Defense of Civil Liberties, an investigating committee headed by Arthur Garfield Hays of New York, counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, set out for Ponce this afternoon to sift not only the killings there in the Palm Sunday clash between the police and -Nationalists but the broader question of civil rights in Puerto Rico.

Flood waters, rising an inch an hour, spread fresh damage through Fairbanks tonight and covered three-fourths of the town few inches to several feet. Believing that the ice-choked Tanana and Chena rivers might go even higher, many persons evacuated their homes and took refuge in hotels, public buildings or prirate residences in dry areas.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia will sail for Mediterranean ports today with several notables among her 1,400 passengers. Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will sail with Mrs. Smith for a vacation in Europe.

With a stamping of feet, hostingg and hats thrown into the air,the International Ladies Garment Workers Union gave its unqualified endorsement tonight to the Committee for Industrial Organization, headed by John L. Lewis,

Members of the Sixty-second Coast Artillery Corps stationed at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens, yesterday received a bronze plaque from Major Gen. Frank L. McCoy of the general staff of the United States army.

The Pirates, fresh from a successful Eastern campaign, drove Dizzy Dean to the showers today and crushed the Cardinals, 14 to 4. The victory gave Pittsburgh a three-and-a-half game lead over its closest rivals in the National League, the Cards.

Harvard scored its second victory of the Eastern Intercollegiate League season over Cornell today by a 5-to-1 count, mainly because of the Ithacans' errors. The game was called with two out in Harvard's half of the sixth inning, when rain spoiled all chances of continuing. The winners gained second place in the league race by the victory.

Miss Constance Klee, daughter of Mrs. C. Fred Klee of 115 Henry Street, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Klee, was married to Clarence Richard Foulkes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hughes Foulkes of Bangor, Pa., last night in the First Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn Heights.

Dr. Hugo Eckener and the rest of the German investigating commission joined the Department of Commerce board of inquiry as advisers and observers today, the fourth day of hearings into the Hindenburg disaster a week ago last night, when thirty-five persons lost their lives.

Mrs. Wallis Warfield, when she marries the Duke of Windsor, automatically will become a royal highness under the law of Britain. This fact was made clear here today in response to inquiries based on reports that the Duke had been endeavoring to get the government to take special action to give her this status.

The marble sculptures of Franz H. Rubitschung of 442 East Fiftysixth Street and the oil paintings of Abbie Smith, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. were selected yesterday by a fiveman jury as the best works in a group of more than 150 art objects exhibited in University Hall by Columbia University art classes.
Splitting even in the final two singles matches, Sweden eliminated Greece, 3-2, in the second round of European zone Davis Cup tennis competition today.

Hal Price Headley's Whopper, one of the best sprinters in the country at the present time, will probably go to the post favorite for the forty-fourth running of the Metropolitan Handicap, which tops the first week-end card at Belmont Park today.

The Town Hall Club is holding its final one-picture exhibition of the season, the work now on view being a very large canvas by Chardin (a monumental still-life, "Dog and Duck") lent by the Wildenstein Galleries.

The Transport Workers Union sent a telegram to the City Industrial Relations Board yesterday urging it to reveal by noon today its attitude toward the recent request of the Third A`enue Railway Company that the board fix a date for and supervise a collective-bargaining referendum among the 4,500 employes on its street-car and bus lines.

Miss Doris E. Oakley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Oakley of Woodside Avenue, Westport, and William R. Wright Jr., son of Mrs. W. R. Wright and the late Colonel Wright of New York, were married tonight in Holy Trinity Church here.

The marriage of Miss Florence Anne Breeding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William -Penn Breeding of Orange, N. J., to James Edwin Barton, son of Mrs. James E. Barton of Coatesville, Pa., took place yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The great ballroom of Buckingham Palace provided the background tonight for the last glittering event of coronation week, when King George and Queen Elizabeth presided from magnificently draped thrones over the first court ball of their reign.

Keeping safe hold of a lead established in the previous three interclub tournaments of the Westchester section of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, the Century Country Club Class A team today won -the right to represent its division in the annual intersectional event against the leading clubs of Long Island and New Jersey.

Henry Gray Hershfield, former New Jersey Assemblyman from Passaic County and Republican maJority leader' of the Assembly in 1920, was found dead in bed this morning at his home, 111 Wanaque Avenue. Death was due to a heart attack. He was 61 years old.
Defeating Glamorgan by 181 runs at Swansea today, Sussex pulled out in front of Welsh County and Gloucestershire to take the lead in thr county cricket championship race.

The cruiser Raleigh, flagship of the United States temporary European squadron, evacuated 155 refugees from Alicante, Spain, today and will land them at Marseille, France, the State Department was informed.

The wave of consumer buying this week pushed retail distribution upward on the way to its Spring crest, which is expected to be reached early in June, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

George Nunez, 30 years old, a counterman in a Harlem restaurant, was found dead in bed at 5:30 P. M. yesterday in the bedroom of his tworoom apartment at 27 West 113th Street. He had been stabbed in the temple and abdomen and also struck with a milk bottle.

Miss Ashlyn Lowe Cannon, daughter of Mrs. William Valerie Andrews of Miami, Fla., and the late Ross Cannon of Concord, N. C., was married to Eben Draper of Hopedale, Mass., this evening in the First Presbyterian Church here.
Two newspaper sensations during the past few days have caused much comment in Paris, because they amount in reality to political events of considerable magnitude.

The stock market recovered yesterday part of the heavy losses of Thursday, bonds steadied and commodities rallied moderately. As has been the custom lately when share prices have rallied after severe declines, the volume of trading has diminished.

A decline in the prices of farm products contributed to a further easing in the general level of wholesale prices during the week ended on May 1, The Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index of the bureau, based on the 1926 average, fell to 87.4 from 87.5 the preceding week, and compared with 79.1 a year before.

Although Japan is moving toward greater control of the country's economic structure the present government is less inclined. than its predecessor to interfere with private enterprise. Coordination and guidance. rather than .State control is the keynote of its policies.
Members of society in the Oranges and vicinity will be attracted to the Orange Lawn Tennis Club tomorrow for its fourth annual dog show.

Miss Mary Miller Saylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Saylor of Huntington and New York, and Robert Charles Muhlhausen, son of William C. Muhlhausen of Brooklyn, were married this evening in the First Presbyterian Church here.

Revival of the plan to use a part of the fund of over $100,000,000 obtained under Section 32 of the Agricultural Adjustment Act to provide an "export tolerance" for cotton goods, was attempted yesterday in a series of conferences with administration officials by Samuel C. Lamport, chairman of the tolerance committee of the Textile Export Association.

A demand for dwellings in scattered sections of Manhattan was indicated in deals reported yesterday. The five-story house with elevator at 49 East Seventy-second Street, formerly the home of Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, was sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company to the Forty-nine East Seventy-second Street Corporation, Arthur Greiner, president.

One of the things made positive tonight after the President's conferences with Congressional leaders and his Cabinet during the day was that Mr. Roosevelt would stand by his guns on the Federal judiciary proposal.

Dean Alfange, winner of the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Prize for his volume . "The Supreme Court and the National Will," received his prize check of $2,500 last night at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Astor. He gave it away immediately.

Extending France's hospitality to American tourists who will visit the Paris Exposition this Summer, Premier Leon Blum, in a broadcast over the networks of the National Broadcasting Company, said last night that France and the United States, "our two great democracies," were now closer together than they ever had been.

For some strange reason (could it have been financial?) Ricardo Cortez and Sally Eilers went all the way to England to make "Talk of the Devil," which the Roxy tossed back to them, and to us, yesterday. Speaking patriotically.

John A. Lyons, assistant chief police inspector in charge of the detective division, announced yesterday afternoon that three detectives of the safe and loft squad had been transferred to other police all duties, one with a reduction in pay, while two others had been promoted.

Longer human life, a larger measure of vigorous health, increased happiness and a revitalized society containing fewer misfits and incompetents and a greater number of superior men and women are some of the benefits likely to come from the application of eugenics,
The Union Savings Bank of Patchogue, L. I., has sold the twostory brick and stucco building, standing on a plot 65 by 170 feet, at 1,118 Dickens Avenue, Far Rockaway, Queens, to Anita Berg.

Two gunmen posing as process servers gained entrance to the room of Miss Loretto Shea, a retired actress, in the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza, 101 West Fifty-eighth Street, and robbed her of jewelry valued at $7,000 on Wednesday night, it became known yesterday.

Forecasts of a decline in general business are unwarranted, Leonard P. Ayrej, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, declares in the current issue of its business bulletin. The developments of the last two months, he says, again have demonstrated that the action of the security markets is a more potent influence in shaping business sentiment than all the figures of production and profits.

There is now in the hands of Governor LEHMAN, awaiting his decision, a bill which proposes to incorporate the principles of the Wagner Labor Relations Act into the laws of New York State. The full text of this bill is published in THE TIMES today.

It is the duty of each citizen to back the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, not only for his own safety, but for the future-of our nation, Harry F. Guggenheim, the president, declared last night in a talk broadcast by Station WJZ.
Lutherans of the suburb of Dahlem learned today they will hear no Whitsunday sermon from their fighting pastor, the Rev. Martin Niemoeller.

Miss Courtenay Baylor Illg, daughter of Mrs. William B. Illg of this place, and Lieutenant William Brewer Keese, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin H. Keese of Millburn, N. J., were married here this evening in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

Dr. Hans Heinrich Dieckhoff, the new paper's German Ambassador, arrived this afternoon from New York with Mrs. Dieckhoff and went to a hotel, where he will remain until he takes up his residence in the embassy.

The idea of banking as a business opportunity is pass, safety of investment is more important than large dividend returns, according to Ben Johnson of Washington, special assistant to the board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Fern Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Williams of Camden, N. Y., to Ralph E. Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Phillips of Aurora, Mo., took place here yesterday afternoon in Duncan Phyfe Room of International House.

Lawerence Tibbett won an excellent reception tonight in his London operatic debut at Covent Garden, singing as Scarpia in "Tosca." The audience gave him a series of enthusiastic curtain calls in the second act and he won equal applause with Gina Cigna and Martinelli, who sang the other, leading roles.

A proposal to seek modification or repeal of the capital gains section of the Federal Income Tax Law was approved by the board of directors of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York at a meeting a,t the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

Deaf to the advice of their higher officials, London busmen decided tonight to continue their strike for a seven-anda-half-hour day. The voting by garages was 46 to 4 and by membership 17,459 to 1,776.
Glenn Cunningham, the Kansas flash, staged one of his spectacular stretch runs tonight to defeat a field of stars in a one-mile run at the annual 'Cotton Carnival invitational track meet.

The five-story apartment house containing thirty suites at 8,015 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, was sold by the Brooklyn Savings Bank to a client of Hy. D. Agar, Inc., broker. It was held at $125,000 and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $85,000.

Bond values continued yesterday to drift irregularly to slightly lower levels in another day of uninspired trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Although prices of the higher grade corporate issues held within a narrow trading range, the improvement shown in the stock market was not, to any noticeable extent, reflected in the market for fixed-interest-bearing securities.

A suit for $8,000,000 was filed here today in the Cook County Superior Court against the City National Bank and Trust Company, the Central Republic Trust Company, its receiver, Charles M. Albers, and General Charles G. Dawes, Winnett W. McIlvaine and other stockholders of Central Republic Trust were the plaintiffs.
Governor Lehman will-give, early consideration to the Doyle-Neustein bill to create a "little Wagner act" for New York State, it was indicated today upon return of the Governor to the capital.

The finals for junior church choirs will be held at 2:30 P. M. today in the Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, the Music Education League has announced. All choirs that participated in the preliminaries in the chapel are eligible to sing in the finals.

Some of Commissioner MOSES' coups d'etat seem to be unnecessary, but on more than one occasion they have been useful. This is true of his recent action in closing one hundred and forty-two playgrounds because of a lack of play-directors for them.

Concluding its investigation of the acquisition and operation of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad, now in bankruptcy, by the Van Sweringen interests, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce today produced evidence which, in the committee's opinion,

The estate of James V. Colwell sold to Maran Maran, operators, a plot 50 by 100 feet on Walton Avenue, 125 feet north of the northwest corner of 183d Street, the Bronx. The sale, the first of the property since 1916, was made through Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc.

Kickbacks by salesmen of liquors will be ended on Monday, Sol Cilento, executive vice president of the Wholesale Licensed Alcoholic Beverage Salesmen's Union, told 700 members of the union at a meeting in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, last night.

Until yesterday's rain curtailed activity, department store trade locally was well maintained, scoring gains of 10 per cent or more over the same period last year. Clearance offerings of Spring goods met good response from customers, while initial buying of Summer merchandise was also noted.

District Attorney William C. Dodge announced yesterday his belief that the fatal stabbing of Municipal Court Justice John F. O'Neil last April.21 at Sixth Avenue and Twelfth Street, less than a block from the jurist's 'home, would go down in police annals as "an unsolved mystery ".

Miss Betty Bainbridge Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph T. Ryan of 61 Overlook Road, Caldwell, and Donald Gardner Wallace, son of Mrs. Lester Wallace of 115 Ridgewood Avenue, Glen Ridge, were married tonight at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Essex Fells.

Finnish archaeologists and geographers under the leadership of Professor Vaeinoe Tanner of Helsingfors University set out today on an expedition to Labrador to establish conclusive evidence that the American polar region in an earlier age was connected with Northern Europe.

Brilliant action, glittering harness and the flash of jewels from the boxes combined to make a splendid picture tonight, while seven superb heavy harness horses competed for the $1,000 Chalfonte-Haddon Hall championship stake, one of the leading events of the fourth day of the Atlantic City Horse Show.

Leaders of the striking Federated Motion Picture Crafts unexpectedly rejected a moral peace proposal be from film producers today, and dedared that every actor who passed through studio picket lines would be classed as a "strikebreaker."

After an early decline, prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied $1 a bale yesterday to end 7 points higher to 2 points lower. Selling pressure lifted after an accumulation of overnight orders had been executed and, in sympathy with the recovery in outside markets, the list steadied under professional short covering.

Miss Jean Haddow Hibberd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hayward A. Hibberd of Maplewood, was married this afternoon to Edward Remington Nichols Douglass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Payson Stone Douglass of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

The Arkansas-Missouri Power Corporation of Blytheville, Ark., has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Public Utility Act. The registrant has recently been organized under an order of the Federal District Court for the Northern District of Illinois in proceedings for reorganization of the Arkansas-Missouri Power Company.

The haphazard, inconsequential proceedings at last night's performance of "Carmen" at the Metropolitan Opera House were redeemed by Bruna Castagna, whose singing of the title role imparted to the presentation what vocal glamour it possessed.

Police of the Missing Persons Bureau sent out an eight-State alarm yesterday afternoon for Donaid Cummings Thorpe, 25-year-old graduate student at Columbia University, who has been missing from his residence at 420 West 121st Street since last Saturday afternoon.

British naval authorities tonight tentatively accepted the explanation that a floating mine had caused the explosion that badly damaged the destroyer Hunter off Spain's southern coast yesterday, while two British inquiries continued efforts to fix responsibility.

In a report to Congress dealing with defaults on foreign bonds, the Securities and Exchange Commission endorsed today the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., which was formed in 1933 under government auspices, and of which J. Reuben Clark.

Verdi's "La Traviata" was presented by the Hippodrome Opera Company at the Hippodrome last night before an appreciative audience. In the name part appeared Annunciata Garrotto, long a favorite with patrons of this enterprise. Lawrence Power sang Alfredo's music and the dependable Claudio Frizerio was the Germont.

Miss Ceora Jennings Hufnagel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Bernhard Hufnagel of Dingletown Road, Greenwich, was married to Walter Ware Slocum of Ardmore, Pa., in the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich, this afternoon.
No matter how much they try, London theatre-goers cannot take easily to Ferene Molnar, Hungarian dramatist, whose "The Good Fairy" was staged at the Royalty Theatre tonight.

The efforts of Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, to center in his department the authority for regulating electric signs, amusements and trailer camps in the Queens area contiguous to Flushing Meadow Park, the site for the 1939 New York World's Fair,

The Treasury was barred yesterday from an exploration of stock sales by Mrs. John J. Roskob to Pierre S. du Pont to establish tax losses for Mrs. Raskob in 1931. Richard L. Disney of the Board of Tax Appeal, who is hearing the case at the old Postoffice Building, ruled that the government here was concerned only with the transactions

The sugar section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration issued today its preliminary statement of the deliveries of sugar for consumption by refiners, beet sugar companies and importers of direct-consumption sugar in April, based on telegraphic reports of the companies.
J. Calvin Moss, former member of the Virginia House of Delegates and for forty years district manager of the Union Central Life Insurance Company, died today at his home here. He was 72 years old.

The recent petition sent to President Arturo Alessandri by Jaime Larrain, chairman of the National Confederation of Commerce and Industry, in which he recommends that payment of the foreign debt be suspended, has caused a sensation in business circles here, where arguments for and against suspension are debated in public statements.

Hector Bolitho, whose "King Edward VIII: An Intimate Biography," has just been published, is rapidly completing the manuscript of his biography of King George VI. Lippincott plans to publish it in mid-July.
The Transamerica Corporation's directors approved plans today to alter basically the entire outlook and structure of the world's greatest bank-holding company. The plans include:
Thirteen resounding notes tapped out on the Liberty Bell by Mayor S. Davis Wilson opened today Philadelphia's four-month celebration of the sesqui-centennial of the Constitution.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey reported yesterday for 1936 an increase of more than 50 per cent in consolidated net income to $97,774,583 after all charges and taxes, including taxes of $1,406,296 on undistributed profits.

The Federal Music Project chamber orchestra was heard last night at the WPA Theatre of Music in a concert of its weekly series. Before an audience reduced in numbers by the disagreeable weather, Joseph Littau, staff conductor of the National Broadcasting Company, directed a program.

Reorganization of the shipping methods of Marshall Field Co. has followed the moving of all converted goods warehousing from Chicago to a new location at 249255 West Seventeenth Street, New York, the company announced yesterday.

Although rain necessitated the postponement of platoon and squad drill competitions at New York University's nineteenth annual field day of the Reserve Officers Training Corps yesterday, more than 900 members of the corps were re viewed by. Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase as they paraded at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus.

Simon Podberesky, Stuyvesant High School fencing star, captured the Public School Athletic League championship last night at the Washington Irving High School Auditorium before a large crowd that included Dr. A. K. Aldinger and Johnny McHugh, director of health education and field secretary, respectively, of the P. S. A. L.

In an effort to check speculation and rising prices, the Polish Government has ordered the dissolution of ten cartels, including those formed within the electrical, gas mantel, brick, gypsum, lime, and oil industries.
Robert E. Henry of Greenville, S. C., was elected president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association today at the closing session of the organization's annual meeting here.

Workmen have been sifting debris of the township incinerator at Garden City Park for several days in a search for four pieces of jewelry discarded accidentally by Mrs. Edith King, wife of Dennis King, the actor.
Dudley C. Hasbrouck, dean of volunteer Fire Department officials of Westchester County, died here at his home, 314 Nelson Avenue, late last night of a heart attack. He was 85 years old.
Former United States Treasurer John Burke died in a hospital here today after an operation to relieve a pulmonary congestion. He was 71 years old.
A night of glory for Ambassador Joachim von Ribbentrop, who has not been particularly successful or happy until now in his mission to the Court of St. James, came last night.

A request to veto the Moran bill, passed by the last session of the Legislature, has been forwarded to Governor Lehman by the Merchants Association of New.. York. Under the bill, it would be unlawful for any unlicensed person to engage in business as a builder in New York City after July.

Philip J. Roosevelt, acting as chairman of a protective committee for shareholders of nine subsidiaries of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company controlled by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey, has sent a letter to the shareholders recommending

General Wilhelm Roeder, Minister of War, declared in Parliament today that the Hungarian Government would insist on obtaining equality of armament as an absolute necessity. In rearming, he said, Hungary does not wish to endanger Central or Eastern Europe, but wants only to be in a position to act as an independent, free nation.
President Roosevelt returned from his fishing trip and conferred with leaders of the Senate and House on pending legislation.

Mr. and Mrs. John Knox Cowperthwaite of Far Hills, N. J., gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Nancy Noyes and Alfred Faris King Jr., whose marriage will take place on June 11 in Montclair, N. J. The bride-elect is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes of this city and Montclair.

The often-postponed case where in Fritz Kuhn, national leader of the pro-Nazi German-American League, was charged with failing to file a certificate regarding the sale and distribution of German newspapers and pamphlets by his organization, was dismissed yesterday afternoon by Magistrate An- Dr. thony F. Burke in Yorkville Court.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has discontinued proceedings against Dart Co. in connection with alleged manipulative activities in stock of the Lakey Foundry and Machine Company on the Detroit Stock Exchange.
Miss Lucy Agnes Hayes, Republican co-leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District in Brooklyn from 1919 to 1936, died Thursday at her home, 130 Milton Street, Brooklyn.

The curtain will ring down tomorrow afternoon on one-of the costliest theatrical adventures of all time, "The Eternal Road." Directed by Max Reinhardt and staged at a cost of abut $500,000, it will have played only 152 performances at Thirty-fourth Street's Manhattan Opera House.
Owen Daly, head of Owen Daly Co., investment bankers, and a member of the Baltimore Stock Exchange since 1884, died at his home here last night.

Member trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange was 22.33 per cent of the total volume in the week ended on April 17, compared. with 22.41 per cent in the previous week, according to the weekly analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Miss Florence Ruperti, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justus Ruperti of this city, Cedarhurst, L. I., and Clearwater, Fla., and a descendant of Mathias Nicoll, early Mayor of New York, was married to Allan Gerdau, son of Mrs. Otto Gerdau of 983 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Gerdau, yesterday afternoon in St. James Church by the Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, the rector.

Fifteen thousand employes of Waterbury's three major brass manufacturing companies will receive wage increases of 5 cents an hour, according to announcements made today by the American Brass Company, the Chase Brass and Copper Company and the Scovill Manufacturing Company.

New bond financing this week dwindled to $17,400,000 and was restricted largely to two major classifications of loans. This compares with a total of $83,964,000 in new bonds placed last week, and with $26,386,000 marketed during this week a year ago.
Mexico refused today to apologize to Italy and Germany- for statues portraying Mussolini and Hitler in grotesque forms on floats in the workers' May Day celebration here.
GERARD SWOPE, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, has initiated a pension plan for his own domestic employes. Such employes are not covered by the Social Security Act.

The plant and equipment of the Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company at 80-08 Forty-fifth Avenue, Elmhurst, L. I., were sold for $240,000 at a trustee's auction sale yesterday by order of the United States District Court in Massachusetts in connection with reorganization proceedings.

T was while the Pirates were in town that the subject came up. Some of the Pittsburghers were sitting around, talking of how odd it was that the great Yankee team, apparently a standout in big league circles, had gone into a tailspin on tour, losing four of the first six games on a road trip.

Post-war Vienna during the inflation of 1922 provides the background for "Episode," today's new arrival at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Paula Wessely, Karl Ludwig Diehl and Otto Tressler enact the screen play which was written and directed by Walter Reisch.

Rosie, a four-ton, 70-year-old elephant, who three years ago was a featured player in the Ringling, Barnum and Bailey circus, but since that time has been on relief and attached to a Works Progress Administration circus in Brooklyn,

Bob Feller, baseball's storybook pitcher, received his high school diploma tonight. The eighteen-year-old "little papoose" of the Cleveland Indians was given his diploma by Clarence Dunn, white-haired banker and president of the school board, as cameras clicked and radio announcers described the ceremonies on a coast-to-coast network.

Miss Edith Eyre Schippers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Schippers of this place, was married here tonight in All Saints Church to Paul Philladelphia Huffard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul P. Huffard of Plandome.

The education of our democracy in its foreign, no less than in its domestic, affairs is essential to the perpetuation of our free institutions. Success in the avoidance of war and the gradual rebuilding of the institutions of peace,
Miss Priscilla Alden Dennett became the bride of John Wallace Goodrich Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Goodrich of Boston and Manchester, this afternoon in Emmanuel Church.

The symphonic band and the men's glee club of the department of music education of New York University were presented in joint concert last night at the Town Hall. The concert, attended by a large and demonstrative audience, was given for the benefit of the Lowell Mason Scholarship Fund.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposal to take a census of unemployment has become the "houn' dawg" of the New Deal. Few public issues have been so persistently "kicked around, " and few have been more consistently misunderstood by advocates and opponents alike.

In Sao Paulo tomorrow the Constitutionalista party will launch the Presidential candidacy of Armando Salles de Oliviera. Mr. Salles will be backed by the elements opposing the policies of the present Federal administration.

There has been considerable moaning at the bar in most of the local night spots for the past ten days or two weeks over an appreciable decline in business which was suddenly and inexplicably felt. Some of the more philosophical proprietors have set it down to the troubled state of the Stock Exchange, some to the cautious covering-up which swiftly followed the recent burlesque ban.

The Trio farm, consisting of 167 acres, fronting on the FreeholdTinton Falls Road, at Scobeyville, near Red Bank and Long Branch, N. J., has been sold to John J. Conklin. There are 115 acres of tillable ground and about fifty acres of woodland in the tract, and the Colonial residence, built more than 100 years ago, contains twelve rooms.

An important part of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's investment in securities of the Mexican Telephone and Telegraph Company was transferred to the L. M. Ericsson Telephone Company, Ltd., in 1936 and certain telephone property and investments in Argentina were acquired, the annual report of International for 1936 reveals.

Following the arrest of a man in Bronx Park early this morning on charges of kidnapping and crimfinally assaulting a 21-year-old girl the police expressed the belief that he was one of a trio responsible for many similar cases in the park in the last two months. According to the police, three men would approach a couple in the park, and posing as policemen, drive off the girl's escort and assault her.

The question whether income bonds are to play an important part in the many railroad reorganizations now pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission was brought into the open through a brief filed yesterday with the commission by a group of fiduciary institutions which holds bonds of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway.

Representatives of the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club of Glen Head retained their laurels as the women's Long Island Class A interclub team competition was concluded yesterday at the Queens Valley Golf Club course in Forest Hills.

Gloom descended on utility circles yesterday following the decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals in Covington, Ky., which voided the Southeastern power companies' injunction restraining the Tennessee Valley Authority from erecting transmission power lines and distribution systems for the sale of TVA power.

To amend the labor law, in relation to establishing a labor relations board to promote equality of bargaining power between employer and employee and to diminish the causes of industrial disputes by encouraging collective bargaining, and making an appropriation to the department of labor

Wiliam H. Knox, president of the William H. Knox Company, importers and exporters of 24 State Street, died yesterday afternoon. in Broad Street Hospital of injuries. received two hours earlier when he was struck by two automobiles at Whitehall and Bridge' Streets.

With the arrival in port yesterday of the American Scantic Line freighter City of Fairbury, officials of the line announced they had contracted with the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Company to spend nearly $1,000,000 to renovate the seven freight ships which it operates between New York and Baltic ports.

A strike at twenty-nine of St. Louis's leading hotels was called for tomorrow morning at a meeting of American Federation of Labor Employes tonight. William Brandt, secretary of the Central Trades and Labor

The Westchester League of Women Voters, in annual convention at the Hotel Gramatan, here, today, voted to organize a school for women jurors. The services of judges and court clerks will be enlisted and mock trials will be held to acquaint women with jury duties

District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan announced yesterday that his office has found an "unusual moral condition" involving students in Brooklyn's public high schools which "warrants an immediate and intensive investigation."
Some 200 employes of the Federal Art Project, WPA, staged a second sit-in strike yesterday afternoon at the project headquarters, 235 East Forty-second Street.

The emergency board appointed by President Roosevelt to investigate a dispute between the Southern Pacific Railroad and four railroad brotherhoods reported today that the labor organizations owed it to their members to settle their "interorganization disputes" without threatening interruption of interstate commerce.

Shortly before the United States liner American Banker sailed for London yesterday afternoon a medal was presented by the lines to Captain Alfred M. Moore, her master, for heroism at sea. Captain William H. Lee, marine superintendent, made the presentation on the deck of the ship.
One hundred and fifty Salvation Army men and women, barricaded in the organization's hospital, refused all appeals today for settlement of their "holy revolution."
Francis A. Chapman, publisher of The Providence County Times, long a prominent figure in newspaper and political circles in this State, died at his home here tonight.

Judge R. M. Gibson of Federal District Court issued a temporary injunction today blocking the government's anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America. Judge Gibson's order restrained Attorney General Cummings from continuing the suit filed against the Aluminum Company in the Southern District of New York.

MINNIE HITE MOODY'S "Death Is a Little Man," a novel of Negro life in Atlanta published last year, was an unusually charming piece of work, noteworthy for its characters and atmosphere and for some of the most amusing Negro dialogue written since Joel Chandler Harris.
Miss Minnie Byrd, daughter of the late Colonel William Byrd, lawyer and Confederate officer, died yesterday of a stroke at her home here. She was 70 years old.

A steadily rising demand for American products in export markets has brought with it a variety of serious problems for exporters, says Stanley E. Hollis, executive vice president of the American Foreign Credit Underwriters Corporation, writing in the issue of the corporation's Exporters' Digest, to be released May 20.

More than 250 persons attended a testimonial dinner last night to Dr. William H. Kilpatrick, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, given by the Student Philosophy Club of Teachers College at the Men's Faculty Club, 117th Street and Morningside Drive.

Murray Bleefeld, twice confessed kidnapper, told an "inside" story here today as to how Ellis H. Parker Sr. is supposed to have made his first connection with the Brooklyn gang which has admitted doing the "strong arm" work in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case.

A series of transactions that four minority stockholders allege caused the Home Insurance Company a $3,000,000 loss actually resulted in a $6,000,000 profit for the company, Abraham Kaplan, the company's attorney, informed Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy yesterday. The minority stockholders are suing to set aside the transactions.
It is comforting to learns from the annual convention of the American Psychiatrist Association in

Philadelphia at New York (2)Walters and LaMaster vs. Schumacher and Fitzsimmons or Castleman. Brooklyn at Boston-Mungo vs. Fette. Chicago at Cincinnati-Parmelee or Shoun vs. Davis. St. Louis at Pittsburgh-Harrell vs. Swift.

The emergency board set up by President Roosevelt to avert a threatened strike of 25,000 railway workers in the New York area announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached definitely eliminating the strike.

Under gray, muggy skies that poured down a steady rain, the old Schuylkill River swarmed with oarsmen this afternoon as college and club crews put the finishing touches to their preparations for tomorrow's American Henley regatta.

Peace was restored to the city's playgrounds early last night when the Board of Estimate unanimously voted the necessary funds to hire regular civil service employes to replace WPA workers in 142 playgrounds throughout the city and in park and parkway maintenance posts.

The Macbeth Gallery of this city paid $7,700 for a painting by Frederic Remington at the fifth day's auction yesterday of objects of art and furnishings at Inisfada, residence at Manhasset, L. I., of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady.
Anti-Jewish rioting at Brzesc Litewsk [BrestLitovsk] yesterday continued early today, following the death of a policeman who had been stabbed by a Jewish butcher, Ajzyk Czerdowski.

Unrehearsed drama and suspense that holds listeners at their radio sets crept into broadcasting yesterday when flashes told that the transatlantic fliers, Henry T. Merrill and John S. Lambie, were groping in the rain and fog of the New York. area .in search. of a hole through which to drop to safety.

The twoyear fight of J. Paul Getty for a dominant position in the Tide Water Associated Oil Company appeared successful today when Getty interests succeeded in electing all but one director of the Mission Corporation.

Three officers To date of the German general staff in full uniform were interested spectators today when the Soviet Embassy displayed motion pictures of the Red Army in action during the recent manoeuvres near Minsk, the military center nearest the German border.

Arthur Malcolm Thomas of 1 Mendham, N. J., and Boston has announced the marriage of his daughter, Miss Bliss Thomas, to David Tattersail Fairchild, son of Colonel and Mrs. David Sturges Fairchild of this city, which took place on May 6 in Elkton, Md.

The New York Telephone Company filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission an application for authority to issue $25,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent refunding bonds, Series B, to be secured by a refunding mortgage to the Bankers Trust Company. The bonds, dated July 1, 1937, will mature in thirty years.

Joseph Breen, president of the Breen Contracting Corporation, who was convicted last Wednesday of defrauding the government of $35,000 in connection with WPA contracts on the Henry Hudson Parkway, received a prison sentence of a year and a- day and was fined $5,000 yesterday by Federal Judge Mandelbaum.

In a cloud of generalities, through which one could discern the particular hopes and anxieties of each dominion, the Imperial Conference opened today with an hour and-a half of speechmaking in Queen Anne's Room of St. James's Palace.

A special service in tribute to C. J. Lucas, Moderator of the United Church of South India, will be held under the auspices of a Committee of the Reformed Classes in the New York area tomorrow at 4 P. M. in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue. Mr.
Government reports credited domestic cotton mills today with maintaining their peak consumption pace through April by utilization of 718,947 bales.
A Federal court ruling tonight temporarily cleared the way for Jimmy Braddock, heavyweight boxing champion, to meet Joe Louis in an expected near-million-dollar bout in Chicago June 22.

Mars Shield, Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's Milky Way Farm entry, was a favorite today to capture the sixtythird running of the Kentucky Oaks tomorrow at Churchill Downs.
