The brown filly by Diavolo-Escutcheon was established as the favorite to take the $5,000 added "derby of the fillies" on the basis of her winning performance in the Texas Derby.

For the first time in the history of corporate practice in the United States, the International Paper and Power Company has forwarded proxies to its stockholders, to be voted at the annual meeting called in Boston for June 23, permitting the stockholders to vote either "yes" or "no" on the plan of recapitalization proposed by the company.

Miss Beatrice Vernam Behr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Behr of this place, was married here this afternoon to Donald Bogart Kipp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben E. Kipp of Passaic, in St. Peter's Church by the Rev. David K. Montgomery.
Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag granted yesterday an injunction restraining The World's Fair News, a magazine, from continuing to use the name.
The Japanese fliers, Masaki Iinuma and -Kenji Tsukagoshi, hopped off today at 8:10 in their monoplane Kamikaze [Divine Wind] for a return flight to Tokyo.

Magistrate Anna B. Kross of New York City told the New Jersey Federation of Women's Clubs today that the prevention of crime was a woman's business. She addressed the closing session of the forty-third annual convention at Haddon Hall here.

A new form for registration on Exchanges under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 has been adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission for issuers engaged directly or through subsidiaries primarily in the-business of owning securities of banks for the purpose or with the effect of exercising control.

Legal steps toward final liquidation of the interest of the estate of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad in the New York, Westchester Boston electric line, into which previous New Haven managements had poured more than $25,000,000 in a vain effort to make

In the comparative quiet of Madison Square Garden last night John Henry Lewis of Phoenix, Ariz., the world light-heavyweight champion, continued his campaign against heavyweight fighters, but without adding any particular glory to his reputation.

Coming out flatly for communism, Harry Bridges of San Francisco, Pacific Coast president of the International Longshoremen's Association, told the University of Washington Lunch eon Club this afternoon that the time is coming when there will be no employing class in the United States.

Young Republicans, at the annual meeting of the Association of New York State Republican Clubs, which convened here this afternoon, manifested a marked disposition to work in closer harmony with the State organization of their party than ever before.

Again drawing the No. 1 post position, from which he won the Kentucky Derby last week, Samuel D. Riddle's War Admiral will go to the post tomorrow at Pimlico for the renewal of Maryland's: bestknown horse race, the $50,000 added Preakness.

Like schoolboys throwing spitballs when teacher steps out of the room, members of the House cut up today when Speaker Bankhead and Representative Rayburn of Texas, the Democratic leader, went to the White House to talk over the legislative situation.
The downpour of yesterday washed out the first game of series between the Giants and the Phillies at the Polo Grounds. It was decided to play two contests today, the first starting at 1:30 P. M.

With the outcome depending on the final event, the Amherst track team defeated Williams, 71 1/2 to 63 1/2, in a pouring rain on Pratt Field today to throw the Little Three championship into a three-way tie.
Dr. Malcolm M. Crawford, chief coroner of Toronto since 1926 and supervising coroner for Ontario for the last six years, died at his home today at the age of 57.

It is not often that police attending the daily morning lineup at police headquarters show any emotion as criminals who have been arrested the night before pass in review on the brilliantly lighted platform for routine questioning.

Encouraged by President Roosevelt's expression in favor of stabilizing farm prices "at reasonable levels," farm organization leaders, acting with Federal commodity experts, were completing today a legislative draft of a comprehensive agricultural adjustment program.

Liberal trade policies are the cure for the world's deficiencies in economic health and sanity, Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, said here today in an address to the Bankers Association for Foreign Trade. "Economic nationalism must be resisted," he declared. "Trade barriers must be reduced; discriminatory practices must cease."

With the return to work of some 32,000 strikers in the Jones Laughlin Steel Company and Pittsburgh Steel Corporation plants as a result of settlements made in these shortlived strikes, attention in steel circles is now focused on the union's threat to call strikes in plants of other independent steel companies.

Lieutenant Claus Hinkelbein, a young German airplane pilot, who was a passenger on the last voyage of the dirigible Hindenburg, testified at today's hearing before the Department of Commerce investigating board. He said he was unable to throw any light on the cause of the fire that destroyed the airship.
Women executives in the government were guests of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt at a White House garden party this afternoon.

A range of about 2,500 rug patterns, exclusive of plain and figured types, are being offered by manufacturers of American-loomed floor coverings, according to the report of style and color trends for this Spring, just issued by the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers for its members and its Style Trend Council.

The last day of the auction of furnishings and objects of art at Inisfada, the country mansion of Mrs. William J. Babington Macaulay, the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady, at Manhasset, L. I., realized $253,840.

The modern stenographer or secretary, if a woman and one who wishes to advance in the business world, must have a broader cultural background and must exercise more restraint in the use of cosmetics, cigarettes and cocktails, according to William D. Camp, presdent of the Executive Service Corporation.

THE destruction of the German dirigible Hindenburg was to philatelists a poignant reminder of numerous stamps which reflect the development of Zeppelin construction and flights from the days of pioneering in gliding to the present era of transoceanic crossings by the lighterthan-air type of craft.
Margherita Rouse Conklin, who was taken in a wheel chair to her wedding with Comedian Chester Conklin three years ago, died last night at the age of 45.

Departmental charges that he violated police regulations by granting an interview to a newspaper reporter "on police business" without official permission were served yesterday on former Detective Stephen di Rosa, who was attached to the staff of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey until the restaurant racket trial.

Members of the Women's Board of the Church Charity Foundation of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will hold their Spring festival on May 27 at the Home for the Aged, 452 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn.

Barnard Academy's nine captured the all-league baseball championship of the Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools by conquering Staten Island Academy in a play-off yesterday at Woodmere, L. I., 3-1. Junior O'Keefe's double sent in two runs in the fourth.

Mayor Manvel Whittemore and the ScarsdaleVillage Trustees are convinced that a Village Hall costing about $400,000 should be erected. They are in a quandary, however, as to just where it should be situated.

Two firemen were fatally injured early today when a Kingston fire truck was struck by a passengers train in a blinding rainstorm. They were Peter A. Carey, 42, and Preston Dewitt, 32. Harold Minckle, the driver, suffered shock, lacerations and possible fractures. A fourth fireman escaped injury:

A fouracre plot on the Military Academy reservation at West Point was approved by Secretary Woodring today as the site for the Treasury's proposed silver depository. Buildings will be constructed to house the government's huge accumulation of silver but, because of the lesser value of the metal, no such extensive underground system will be built as at Fort Knox, Ky., for the gold stocks.
SUFFICIENTLY contrasting are the several displays of sculpture that opened last week, composed of work by Hilda Kristina Lascari, A. N. A., Antonio Salemme, Robert Bros and Sybil Kennedy.

Fire which destroyed two groundfloor shops in the Elk Hotel, 203 West Fifty-third Street, just off Broadway last night, spread to the second floor of the building, seriously damaging three rooms and forcing half a dozen guests to flee down the fire-escapes.

Limiting the Owls to five hits and striking out ten batters, Johnny Morris, veteran right-hander, hurled the City College baseball team to a 9-2 victory over Temple University at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday.

Work on the Paris exhibition is being pushed forward with far more vigor and good-will now than at any time since the original plans were laid and there is every. reason to hope that at least the main exhibits will be ready by Monday, May 24, when it is due to be inaugurated.

Miss Elizabeth Miller Rochester, daughter of Mrs. Frederick J. Elder of this place and John C. Rochester of New York and Brookhaven, L. I., was married to Albert Robert Erda of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gustave Erda, in Christ's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. A. Kenneth Ackerman performed, the ceremony.

A letter from Governor Lehman to Harry F. Guggenhein, president of the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime, Inc., expressing the opinion that the militant support of an enlightened public opinion was necessary for the sound administration of the laws was made public yesterday by Mr. Guggenheim.

Forging ahead in the final event, Haverford College's track and field team scored 35 9-10 points to capture the twenty-fifth annual Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic Association championship on Gettysburg College's Nixon Field today.

Economic, social and educational problems will be the chief topics of discussion at the seventeenth annual convention of the New Jersey League of Women Voters at the Hotel Monterey, Asbury Park, opening Wednesday. The meetings will continue through Friday.

Mrs. James M. Roche has been reelected chairman of the Senior Guild of Colony House, Inc. Other officers elected are Mrs. Charles C. Meytrott, Mrs. George H. Gartlan, Mrs. John R. Garnaus, Mrs. Platt Willets, Mrs. Gordon L. Edwards and Mrs. Edward C. Elford.

The tide of civil war was running against the Spanish Insurgents last March. The Loyalists had won smashing victories on the Guadalajara and Cordoba fronts; their defense of Madrid was impenetrable; their Russianmade planes were supreme in the air, and serious mutinies were said to be smoldering behind Generalissimo Franco's lines.

The report to date of the Women's United States Lacrosse Association is both discouraging and promising. The established sectional teams of the association have had smaller and less enthusiastic practice and preliminary matches than in the past.

Allowing only four scattered hits, Howard Schade pitched Upsala College to a victory over Savage today, 7-1. Led by the heavy hitting of Jim Buckley and Pat Tortorella, Upsala did most of its scoring in the sixth inning.

Harry Teoli, a dynamite expert, placed nine charges of dynamite in holes in the base of the 180-foot stack at a paper mill and set them off today. The base was shattered by the blast, the top toppled to the ground, but a 100-foot section dropped intact from the middle to the foundation.
Harvard's varsity and junior varsity eight-oared crews continued their rudder-showing ways against Cornell, Syracuse and Massachusetts Institute of Technology on the Charles River basin late today.

DISTINCTION: For the most distinguished theatrical performance of the 1937-38 theatrical season Maurice Evans, star of "King Richard II" last week received the Delia Austrian Medal of the Drama League of New York.
All public schools in Brooklyn and Queens will be closed on Anniversary Day, June 10, according to an announcement made by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

The growth of the spoils system in public office constitutes a major menace to American government, the National Civil Service Reform League declared yesterday as a result of a study of the administrative personnel of national, State and county government.

The great ceremonial in London is illuminated in elaborate color and shining gold on the page of history. There emerges the British throne, now regarded with friendly feeling by most nations as a symbol of liberty and peace.

Arthur Garfield Hays of New York, counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, who is heading an investigation of the causes of the Palm Sunday clash between Nationalists and police in Ponce, will be permitted to visit the Ponce district jail to take the testimony of Lorenzo Pinero, secretary of the Nationalist party, who is being held with nine other Nationalists on a charge of murdering two policemen in the Ponce affair.

The growth of the life insurance business in the United States closely parallels the history and progress of the nation itself. Transferred to this country by the early settlers, the first fraternal insurance society on record was founded in 1759.
Bob Feller rejoined the Indians today, happy over his graduation from high school but a little irritated by reports that his strikeout right arm was more than just sore.

Ben Cantwell, veteran right-hander, turned in his fifth successive victory of the season in the second game of today's International League double-header as Jersey City gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a double setback to knock them out of first place. The scores of both games were 6-4.

MANY a salt-water fisherman has had this day marked on his calendar for weeks, for like his cousin, the trout angler, who annually awaits the opening day with ceremonious attention, he : grows somewhat impatient for the weakfish season to start at Peconic Bay.

A committee of members of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association is being formed to supervise details for a benefit entertainment serving to open the Skyline Terrace of the Hotel Madison on June 15 for the Summer season. The party will begin at 5 P. M. with an outdoor fashion show and will continue through dinner and supper.

Ramsay Potts, the University of North Carolina's tennis wizard, won the Southern Conference singles title for the second consecutive year on the Country Club of Virginia courts today. He defeated a team-mate, Eddie Fuller, 8-6, 6-3, 10-8.

When Dick Merrill, whose first name is really Henry, landed his Lockheed Electra at Floyd-Bennett airfield Friday afternoon he had completed the first commercial round trip over the North Atlantic made by an airplane.

As new construction, alterations in existing buildings and expansion of business reflect the return of prosperity in the Fifth Avenue section, real estate in the area continues to hold a place of growing importance by pouring into the city's coffers an annual tax yield of more than $35,000,000.

World cotton exports in the first eight months of this season were the largest in three years, the Deapartment of Agriculture reported today. The United States supplied a relatively smaller share while British India, Egypt and South American countries increased their proportions.

The Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, nine scored a run on a walk, a sacrifice and an error in the final frame to break-a 2-2 deadlock and beat Brooklyn College, 3-2, in a seven-inning contest at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

Word of the death of Mrs. Jonthan E. Shoemaker, retired missionary of the Central China Mission of the Presbyterian Church, U. S. A., was received here yesterday by the Board of Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church, 156 Fifth Avenue.
Mrs. Fred K. Truslow Jr. has charge of arrangements for the final luncheon of the Junior Service League of Summit, to be held Wednesday at Canoe Brook Country Club.

The Yale third and fourth varsity eights led the recently organized Dartmouth first crew by six and three lengths, respectively, in a race on the Housatonic today. Because of the strong current, the course was shortened and no times were taken.
The annual senior ball of Trinity College was held last night at the Hartford Club. L. Barton Wilson 3d of Baltimore was chairman of the committee on arrangements.
Ballot, the oldest thoroughbred sire in America, died this afternoon at E. Gay Drake's Mineola Farm on the Bryan Station Pike near here. Foaled April 18, 1904, Ballot was 33 years old.
The navy disclosed today that it had wa begun to create a vast reservoir of fighting aviators who will be available for service in event of war.

Strike crises which will affect four major independent steel companies and 105,000 employes within ten days loomed today as the result of a meeting of seventy steel lodge officials and sub-regional directors of the Steel Workers Organization Committee.

THE Sycamore family is all right Thirty-five years ago, Grandpa Vanderhof decided one day simply to quit working and devote his life to attending college commencements. Pa Sycamore makes fireworks in the cellar, assisted by Mr. De Pinna who came with the ice one day and just stayed on.

Miss Mary Frances Snowber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Francis Snowber of Far Rockaway, Queens, was married to Carl Herbert Gruning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Gruning, also of Far Rockaway, yesterday morning in the Church of St. Mary Star of the Sea by Mgr. John J. H. Robinson.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Adams Critchett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Hamilton Critchett of Douglaston Manor, Queens, to Russell Lanson Boyer Jr., son of Russell Lanson Boyer of Freeport and the late Mrs. Boyer, took place last night in the Community Church, Douglaston.
Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Rolfe of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hilda, to Robert, M. Kugler, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kugler Jr. of Springfield, Mass.

Ratification of a plan to reunite the three branches of the Methodist Church, after almost a century of division, was voted yesterday by a joint lay-ministerial session of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.
The University of Pennsylvania freshman baseball team, reaching two pitchers for a total of fourteen hits, scored a 12-7 victory at the expense of the Princeton Cubs today on the Brokaw diamond.
The annual Spring dance of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel will be held on Friday night, May 21, in Preston Hall, it was announced today by Miss Anne Powers, the chairman.
PEOPLE who once were content to munch on hard rolls and butter to satisfy their hunger while they waited for dinner to be served now demand hors d'oeuvre.
The bombing of a building in Warsaw and rioting in Grabow, Lodz Province, today marked the spread of anti-Semitic disorders in Poland in spite of nation-wide police precautions.
Mrs. Harry Talman Moore has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Helen Gray Moore, to Thomas Duncombe Hall Barns, son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Barns.

Continental Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries-Twelve months to March 31: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, $4,470,341, which, after preferred dividend requirements, was equal to $14.69 a common share, comparing with a net of $3,626,750, or $10.75 a common share, in the preceding twelve months.

MANY city dwellers pace the trails of parks and open country these days intent upon getting as close as possible to nature. These hikers and campers find health and pleas ure, but some get too close to nature and contract ivy or Sumac poisoning.

At a time when European diplomacy is playing with the court tries of Central Europe, it is especially significant that the United States Government appears ready to waive its repugnance to special trade concessions and its insistence on most-favored-nation treatment in so far as such concessions will aid those nations to better their collective economic status.

SANTA FE, N. M. A WESTCHESTER (N. Y.) car gave us the horn in broth erly greeting as we slid out of Las Cruces and headed for Santa Fe and the Indian country. No two cars from the same State pass one another out here without the salute.

While its armies held the Insurgents back, the Valencia government allowed itself the democratic luxury of a Ministerial crisis today. Premier Francisco Largo Caballero presented his resignation to President Manuel Azana this morning and at 2 o'clock this afternoon was charged by the President with the formation of a new government.
Voicing optimism but unable to conceal his disappointment over the negative results of his three-year mission here in an effort to help better Soviet-Japanese relations, Konstantin K. Yureneff,

Relief in St. Louis has been a mess ever since it was thrust on the city by the depression, but instead of getting better as the years roll around, it becomes worse. Right now the situation is in its sorriest muddle.

One of the big problems facing President Roosevelt-aside from affairs of state-is what to do with the gifts he receives. Whether he is on vacation or at the White House the public sends and gives him all kinds of things. Presidents, of course, have always received tokens of affection from their fellowcountrymen, but none has ever been as popular with the gift-givers as Mr. Roosevelt.

William Van Hoogstraten, conductor, and Felix Robert Mendelssohn, 'cellist, have been appointed to the Department of Music in the New York University School of Education Summer School, it was announced yesterday by Deen John W. Withers.

AT the other end of the wire was Owen Davis, not long ago returned from Hollywood and working very hard--working just now on "Yippi." "A big show," he called it, and "a long job," for this is no soft romance of song and dance but a musical satire on East versus West--kind of a follow-up, he said, to "Whoopee."

The annual report of the United Light and Railways Company for 1936, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $5,645,628, compared with $4,019,068 in 1935, an increase of $1,626,559.

Greece, oldest of democracies, is realizing to an increasing degree what it means to be under a dictatorship. A people traditionally individualistic, accustomed to thousands of years of thinking for themselves, now find their thoughts controlled by their government.

C. A. Waldron, president of the Maine Federation of Labor, said today that the American Federation of Labor would not join in a proposed boycott of Maine because of its "harsh" treatment of C. I. O. leaders in the Lewiston-Auburn shoe strike.

Payments to living life insurance policy holders from 1929 through 1936 totaled $13,328,000,000, the Life Agency Officers Association announced yesterday. Payments to beneficiaries, including death and double indemnity claims, amounted to $7.230.000.000 in the same period.

Those who plan to loll on a beach on Decoration Day and on Summer week-ends and holidays thereafter should be interested in the numerous store displays of conveniences for mitigating certain aspects of life on the sands.

Latest archaeological discoveries in the long-lost city of Monte Alban in Southwestern Mexico have led to a growing belief that these excavations may be of greater importance in revealing America's past than was the finding of the historic tomb of Tutankh-Amen in disclosing the degree of Egypt's ancient culture.

Faced with new problems arising from changes in the pattern of urban growth, in home design and construction methods, mortgage financing and building costs, realty experts outlined plans yesterday for a series of national surveys to enable them to meet the needs of the future in these fields.

A group of railroad fans who make a hobby of taking "last rides" on railway lines will come here tomorrow for a trip on the Niagara Falls-Buffalo high-speed electric line, which may soon go out of existence.

THE British civil service is by no means such a leisurely occupation nowadays as it was when Edmund Gosse and Austin Dobson were officials of the Board of Trade and W. M. Rossetti of the Inland Revenue Department.

Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky last night postponed sentence upon Frank Carone, convicted of disorderly conduct in a relief demonstation, until May 25. He did so after reading a probation report which showed that Carone had been sent to Auburn prison in 1934 for one to two years following a relief riot in Utica, N. Y.

A pointed invitation to the old reigning house of Hohenzollern to give up its vast estates for the benefit of the peasants of the Third Reich is contained in an article published in the Landpost, the National Socialist party's food publication.

ASHLEY DUKES'S Mercury Theatre, which first produced Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral" and Auden and Isherwood's "Ascent of F. 6," has now brought to London "In Theatre Street," a translation from the French of H. R. Lenormand's "Crepuscule au Theatre,"

A committee of prominent persons and approximately twenty clubs and patriotic societies are sponsoring the second performance of Walter Damrosch's new American opera, "The Man Without a Country," which will be given tomorrow night at the Metropolitan Opera House to assist the National Institute of Immigrant Welfare.

Alone among the world's newspapers the Italian press almost totally ignored Britain's coronation. The Italian correspondents had left London a few days before on orders of their government, which at the same time barred from Italy all British newspapers except three that are regarded as friendly.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va.--Where past Presidents of the United States once stepped, White Sulphur Springs guests will tread today when the President's Cottage and Old White Museum will be opened for the season.
STROUDSBURG, Pa.-The season is well under way in the Poconos, with all the golf courses open and the Summer programs announced. Summer camps are being put in readiness for the season.

A home run by Al Simmons broke a tie in the eighth inning today and gave the Senators a 5-to-4 triumph over the Red Sox. The game was a see-saw battle for seven innings between Pitchers Buck Newsom and Lefty Grove. Newsom allowed eight hits before he was lifted for a pinch hitter. Pete Appleton hurled the last two innings and got credit for the victory.
Workmen have put finishing touches on an eight-foot owl which is to be erected at a road intersection near here as a highway warning sign and a memorial.

Miss Louise Miller Tyler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Tyler of 5 Prospect Place, formerly of Bronxville, N. Y., was married to James Doudge Tate, also of this city, yesterday morning in the Tudor Towers by the Rev. Dr. John Gass, rector of the Church of the Incarnation.

Miss Eunice Poulson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Poulson of Upper Montclair, N. J., has completed plans for her marriage to Stanley Morton Parsil, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Roy Parsil of Short Hills, N. J., which will take place the afternoon of June 12 in the First Congregational Church of Montclair.
BATAVIA, Java.-The Volksrad, the native Assembly of Java, recently passed, by unanimous vote, a petition to Queen Wilhelmina to grant dominion status to Netherlands East Indies within ten years.

Shrouded in mystery are the doings here of Joseph A. C. Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations. He attended the ceremony in Westminster Abbey Wednesday, then disappeared from public view, his name not appearing on any hotel register.

Emmett Dewane, 55, a farmer living near here, fought a duel nearly to the death with a tractor on his farm. He was hurled under the machine when it struck a rut in the field. The plow wheel passed over him, fracturing his skull and crushing him about the shoulders, while the plowshare ripped gash in a leg.

MARGERY and Luke, the two lovers of this book, are people of the soil. But Luke has been brought up on a family farm in Durwich, Me., has gone through life accepting and loving it, has become a carpenter proud of his work, glad to be the one young man who does not flee his little village.

Dr. Roy J. Deferrari, dean of the Graduate School and Summer School of the Catholic University of America, Washington, D. C., will deliver the baccalaureate address at the twenty-fifth annual Degree Day ceremonies to be held at the College of Mount St. Vincent on June 1, it was announced yesterday.

At least one attractive American girl is pursuing knowledge vigorously, literally as well as figuratively, in the Swiss Alps. Miss M. Elizabeth Maxfield, traveling fellow of Radcliffe, who is preparing a handbook on the revival of the Raeto-Romansh language in the southeastern part of Switzerland, is using skis for transportation to collect her material, as well as for recreation.
In a driving finish Mars Shield, the favored filly from the Milky Way Farms, captured- the sixty-third running of the $5,000 added Kentucky Oaks at Churchill Downs today.

Big Ray Volpi and his Manhattan team-mates evened the score for the season with New York University yesterday as they trounced the, Violet nine, 12-2, at Ohio Field before a crowd of about 1,500 persons which included a. gathering of Violet alumni celebrating their annual reunion.

The Detroit and Canada Tunnel Corporation applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to acquire the ferry business of the Detroit and Windsor Ferry Company, its principal competitor, for $150,000 cash and $750,000 in 5 per cent first-mortgage bonds maturing in 1966.
The engagement has been announced of Miss Elizabeth Charlotte Muller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Roy Muller, to William Rudolph Kanne, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Kanne.

Mrs. Thomas Walker Page of the Shoreham has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Rose Walker Page, to John B. Wilson, son of Mrs. Andrew T. Wilson of Boston and the late Mr. Wilson.

SPRING brings out the walking enthusiasts, and many of them are discovering walks within the shadows of the city's skyscrapers that are "both thrilling and educational" (as the Coney Island barkers will soon be saying).
Noble and Greenough's first fouroared crew defeated Exeter by four feet in a three-quarter mile race on the Charles today. However, the Exeter seconds, after leading all the way won from the Noble

Three of the rebellious anarchists who have controlled the Spanish town of Puigcerda, near the French border, almost since the outbreak of the civil war were killed today in street fighting with Communists who tried to-seize authority.

With the arrival here last week of Francisco Medina, Chilean civil engineer, W. R. Grace Co. and the Grace Line started a policy of industrial scholarships which has long been the dream of D. Stewart Iglehart, president of both companies.

Statesmen of Central Europe and those of other countries seeking to control its policies are looking to London, full of hope or anxiety. Austrian and Czechoslovak newspaper editorials emphasize that Britain's mission today is as conciliator between rival Continental groups, and call attention to the importance of the simultaneous visits in London of Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia and Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt of Austria.

General Federation representatives who will participate in the convention of the Connecticut Federation of Women's Clubs at Waterbury, Wednesday and Thursday of this week, include Mrs. Edward Hammett of Sheboygan, Wis., chairman of safety, and Mrs. William Dick Sporborg of Port Chester, N. Y., chairman of legislation.

Charles F. O'Mara of Yonkers, N. Y., has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Eileen Zita O'Mara, to George Vincent Murphy of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Murphy of Scranton, Pa., formerly of East Orange, N. J.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization is a long-way off, many months at least and possibly years.

PEIPING.--Japanese plans for "economic cooperation" between Japan and China-plans that include the exploitation of natural resources, the extension of established lines of communication and the inauguration of new communication systems' throughout North China-point with ever-increasing clarity to the establishment of a special Japanese "sphere of influence" in this region.

Mr. and Mrs. L. Briant Hedden of this place will celebrate their sixty-sixth wedding anniversary at a reception at their home tomorrow afternoon. Mrs. Hedden, who before her marriage was Miss Agnes Arthur, is 84 years old and her husband 89.

Thousands of persons, including notables in society and racing circles from New York, Philadelphia, Washington and others cities, enthusiastically paid homage to the Queen of the Preakness, Miss Anne Preston McAdoo, granddaughter of Senator William Gibbs McAdoo, when she was crowned by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the Preakness committee, at, the ball in the Fifth Regiment Armory tonight, which climaxed Preakness Day at Old Pimlico.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

THE film technicians' strike which has occupied Hollywood these last two weeks was brought to Broadway Tuesday night when an army of pickets, variously estimated at between 100 and 300, paraded with banners and placards in fron of Manhattan's first-run houses. The effectiveness of the demonstration was dubious, according to reports.

The series of garden days under the auspices of the School .Nature League, begun last week, will be continued on Wednesday with the exhibition of several backyard gar dens of city residences. The places on view will be those of Mrs. Carl Forsch, 184East Sixty-fourth Street;

The plans announced last week by the Swedish Government for monetary measures to check a possible inflation, including; if necessary, an upward revaluation of the currency, attracted interest in Wall Street banking circles as a portent of the changing trend in world monetary affairs.

Private financial institutions entering the field of low-priced home financing will have excellent opportunities to obtain a large volumeof sound mortgages, declares Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald.

One of the orphans of the storm of economy which is beating about the dome of the Capitol these days will be the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, unless President Roosevelt assumes a putative and protective paternity over it, which he has thus far declined to do.
The Ministry of Marine tonight announced the discovery of a mine "of German manufacture" off the port of Almeria, near the spot where the British destroyer Hunter was disabled Thursday.

HONGKONG.--Without the publicity that has attended the work upon the great British naval base at Singapore, the island of Hongkong has also seen a great strengthening of defense works and now ranks as a second Gibraltar.

TORONTO. PLANS are underway to air-map the islands which make up Canada's Eastern Arctic. Preliminary work was started last Summer when Geodetic Surveyors C. H. Ney and Joseph Courtright established ground points at various ports of call on the annual cruise of the Nascopie, supply ship to the far North.

LONG queues of dilatory motorists Fisting the license bureaus in the five boroughs of this city and, to a lesser extent, those of other cities in the State for last-minute drivers' licenses, are to be conspicuous by their absence this year. Commissioner Charles A. Harnett, head of the Motor Vehicle Bureau, believes that the new law, an amendment to Section 20 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law,

A special meeting of the holders of preferred and common stocks of the Certain-teed Products - Corporation was adjourned on Friday until May 28 due to lack of a quorum. The-Marine Midland Trust Company is registrar for the $1-par common stock of Air Associates, Inc.

The Arab hunger strikers in Acre prison and the Arab High Committee won a victory today when the government announced that 100 of the 150 prisoners would be released today and that others would be freed in a few days.

"Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" were presented last night by the Hippodrome Opera Company before a good-sized and enthusiastic audience. In the second work the part of Silvio was sung by George Ira Everett, American baritone, who thus made his first appearance with the company.

The government of the Virgin Islands is jubilant over the establishment of J. W. Wuppermann Angostura Bitters, Inc., here. This is the first definite step during the twenty years of American occupancy by which the islands have appreached self-sufficiency. The corportion is expected to pay $50,000 a year in taxes, which, with local revenues, will approximate the Federal grant.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Richardson German of Maplewood, N. J., who are passing the week-end at Northampton, Mass., gave a dinner there last night at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Richardson German, to E. Harris Harbison of Princeton, N. J., eldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Warner Harbison of Sewickley, Pa.

ELIZABETH RETHBERG of the Metropolitan Opera Company, now appearing in several of the country's important music festivals, will return to the Salzburg Festival this Summer in the role of Donna Anna in "Don Giovanni," an opera in which she hitherto has always sung Donna Elvira.

The annual alumnae luncheon Tuesday at the Pierre will inaugurate the Commencement Week program of the Semple School. Baroness Bernadino Galluppi, president of the alumnae, will preside with Mrs. T. Darrington Semple, principal and founder of the school.

Dave Hennen Morris, United States Ambassador to Belgium, returned on the United States liner Manhattan yesterday on leave. He is accompanied by his wife. Mrs. Morris is recovering from an attack of bronchial pneumonia and her physician in Belgium advised her to return here.

THE memory of a fine old tale dearly loved in childhood has been shaped by an artist into a retelling that is buoyant and vivid, into pictures that sparkle with gayety and humor, resulting in the sheer enchantment of "Seven Simeons."

Lord Marley, deputy speaker of the House of Lords, will discuss "Overseas Today" on the afternoon program of the all-day session of the 'Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, to be held on Wednesday at 10:15 A. M., in the Community House, Congregation EmanuEl, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. A forum on "Safeguarding Marriage and the Family," at which Dr. Ira S. Wile and Dr. Sidney E. Goldstein will speak, is to follow.

Americans have been eating about the same quantity of food for the last ten years, notwithstanding the great reduction in incomes between 1931 and 1935. But after an analysis of dietary records kept by different types of families, Dr. Hazel K. Stiebeling of the Bureau of Home Economics points out that the kinds of food eaten by families at different income levels are very different.

BERTRAND RUSSETL is a celebrity. A scientist of solid reputation and an enthusiast over modern ideas of matrimony and education, he has been wrapped, late in life, within the robes of a peer. Yet he continues to be interesting.
To the physical ills of Lynwood (Schoolboy) Rowe was added today the mental distress of discovering his pay has been discontinued until he is in conedition to pitch.

HONDURAS stamps, announced in these columns on May 2, have been received. They are large and colorful and commemorate the lengthening of the term of President Carias to 1943. A portrait of the President appears in the upper left-hand corner while below is a view of the General Carias Bridge.

The marriage will take place in Tokyo on June 15 of Henry Ashley Clarke of the British Diplomatic Service, elder son of Dr. and Mrs. H. H. R. Clarke of Kent, and Miss Virginia Bell, younger daughter of the late Edward Bell of New York, who was former Charge d'Affaires of the United States Legation in Peking, and of Mrs. James Dodds, wife of the Counselor of the British Embassy at Tokyo.

Smith College offers to its students a theatre workshop course, which is experimentation in play production, under the direction of Samuel A. Eliot of the Department of English. Students make a study of the theory of directing actors and of the modern tendencies in staging, and get practice in organizing a stage production.

Miss Jeanne DeLand Bachrach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Fabian Bachrach of this place, was married here tonight to Frederick Paige Kimball, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Kimball of Dedham and North Falmouth, in the First Unitarian Church by the Rev. Herbert Hitchen.
Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Lyons of Staten. Island have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Violet Lyons, to W. John Villaume, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Villaume of Summit N. J.

By the passage of beneficial legislation during its closing days the New York Legislature did much to make up for its earlier negative record, George H. Hallett Jr., secretary of the Citizens Union, declared yesterday in an appraisal of the session ended a week ago.

The writer is best known as coauthor with his wife, Helen Merrill Lynd, of "Middletown" and, lately, "Middletown in Transition," outstanding studies of a typical American city. Professor Lynd is a member of the department of sociology of the Graduate Faculty of Political Science of Columbia University.

LONDON. -- London's famous squares-Cavendish, Berkeley, Dorset, Belgrave and Russell, to name a few of the better known-seem likely to succumb soon to the growth of British democracy. Sir Thomas Inskip in a recent speech suggested that the railings which surround the squares should be removed.

In a meet that was marked by exceptionally fine performances right down the line Columbia vanquished Manhattan, 81 to 54, in their dual track and field engagement at Baker Field yesterday and forthwith boosted its hopes for an I. C. A. A. A. A. crown a fortnight hence.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wadsworth Ruediger of this city of the engagement of their daughter. Miss Paisley Ruediger, to Henry Breuer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Layton Breuer, also off Montclair.

Election of officers and the reception of three new member clubs will be important items on the program of the sixty-second annual convention of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Friday. Mrs. Webster F. Williams of Hollis, Queens, is the nominee for president to succeed Mrs. Charles W. Mulford of Bay Shore.

This little town on Lake Constance that was going to conquer the air for Germany has had its worst defeat in a history filled with vicissitudes. Before the Hindenburg disaster the fame of the engineers and craftsmen here who build Zeppelins stood high.

Winning both places in the finals of both the singles and doubles in the New York State intercollegiate tennis tournament, in progress here on the cadet courts, Army's tennis team has taken the team championship as well as the individual titles and leads in the race for the Challenge Cup offered to the team that first scores 100 points.

Finishing with- a whirlwind sprint, Johnny Drebinger, 17-year-old sensation from South Side High School, Rockville Centre, won the mile event in the sixteenth annual interscholastic invitation track meet held at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today. The time was 4:40.6, despite the so?? track.
Vital statistics just published for 1936 show French births and marriages decreased, while divorces increased. However, child mortality as well as the general death rate decreased considerably.

A BOOK that is salt with the tang of the sea; a book through the pages of which the spindrift blows, is 'The Masts of Gloucester," by Raymond McFarland. This is not the first sea narrative which Mr. McFarland has done.

The marriage of Miss Elenore Schmidt, daughter of Mrs. Lewis Schmidt of East Orange, to David Courter Dally, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore E. Dally of Maplewood, took place this afternoon in St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church, Irvington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. M. R. L. Hirsch, the pastor.

The government confiscated today the last issue of the Catholic weekly Sturm Ueber Oesterreich, which has close connections with Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg, as a result of an article entitled "Lakehurst Propaganda."
Greenwich Academy annexed the principal awards in the annual junior riding meet sponsored by the Greenwich Riding Association at the outdoor ring of the Round Hill Club Stables today.

As a port that carries on an immense trade with Japan, sending raw cotton from the San Joaquin Valley and a wide variety of manufactured goods in return for Japan's raw silk cargoes, San Francisco laid itself out this week to give the Japanese Economic Mission a royal welcome.

Assurances were given yesterday by President James E. Finegan of the Municipal Civil Service Commission that sufficient civil service playground directors will be available tomorrow to man all 142 playgrounds which were taken over by the police a few days ago when the Park Department closed them by order of Commissioner Robert Moses.

Annual Communion Breakfast of Vera Cruz Council No. 647, Knights of Columbus. Hotel Astor, 9:30 A. M. Speakers: The Rev. Edwin Scully, the Rev. Peter Duffee, Commissioner Joseph M. Foley, Joseph Lamb, James E. Farrell.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended May 12, aggregated $8,628,000,000, or 13 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 9 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

J. Wray .Cleveland, who was a vice president of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company from 1922 until his retirement in 1933, died yesterday at his residence, 995 Fifth Avenue, after an illness of four years. His age was 77.
Beginning tomorrow a reproduction of a low-cost house, for which plans were developed by the Federal Housing Administration, will be on display in Bloomingdale's for one month.

Enunciating such words as "megalocephalic," "tergiversation" and "agoraphobia" with evident ease, a team of women speech experts defeated a team of men yesterday in what is believed to be the first educational "pronunciation bee" held in this city.

Continuation of the 2- per cent retail sales tax by New York City until July 1, 1938, was assured today when Governor Lehman signed the bill of Senator John L. Buckley. Proceeds from the tax are used by the city to finance relief.

The passage by the State Legislature of two measures sponsored by the New York Insurance Department and amending the State Insurance Law is expected to broaden the investment demand by insurance companies, especially those writing life policies.
Following the lead established by Ontario and Quebec, mining companies in British Columbia, third-ranking gold Province in the Dominion, will prospect by air on a large scale in the coming Summer.

TELEVISION has progressed so far in London that the British Broadcasting Corporation now releases the week's programs a week-in advance as a supplement to Radio Times, the official broadcast- program journal of the organization.

According to an air mail report from Managua, Nicaragua, fifty Conservatives were arrested at the order of President Anastasio Somosa two days ago for celebrating the birthday of former President Emiliano Chamorro. Each celebrant was fined twelve cordobas on a charge of vagrancy.
The body of Captain Ernst A. Lehmann, technical adviser on the zeppelin Hindenburg, was taken back to Germany last night aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

Coming up apparently from nowhere in the final dash to the wire, the Wheatley Stable's Snark won the forty-fourth running of the $5,000 added Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday and defeated one of the best fields of milers seen in the East thus far this year.

FROM earlier recordings the casual listener could hardly appreciate the amount of material Berlioz borrowed from his unsuccessful opera, "Benvenuto Cellini," or the masterly means by which he concentrated it into the Roman Carnival overture.

New Jersey's famed Raritan River, of whose banks Rutgers students have been singing fond college tunes, is coming into its own again. There was a time when Florida-bound yachtsmen invariably crossed the State of New Jersey via the Delaware and Raritan Canal which had its eastern terminus at New Brunswick.

"So he's going to fly the ocean alone, is he?" Veteran pilots and aviation men were saying that, sometimes with a laugh, frequently with an expression of unbelief, and always with. the added word that it couldn't be done.

Harvard's track and field team upset all calculations today when it beat Dartmouth, 70 to 65, in the annual dual meet held in the Stadium. Although the Indians won eight first places to Harvard's seven, Coach Mikola's athletes reaped a harvest of eight second places which netted 24 points, while Dartmouth furnished only six runnersup for 18 points.

The American Peoples School, a residential center for young men and women who work during the day and study in the evening, celebrated its third anniversary with a dinner last night at the school, 67 Stevenson Place, the Bronx.

Despite McCone's strike-out pitching, the Swarthmore College nine was defeated by Haverford, 7--4, today on the Swarthmore diamond. Taking the lead in the first, Haverford pulled out of danger by scoring four more in the seventh after Swarthmore had tied the count with a six-inning attack netting three runs.

Louise Bourbon is showing small, shallow-crowned tricornes of white felt with the outside part of the turned - up brim faced with black lace and held on the head at the back with black lace bands. She trims sports hats with applications of embroidered wool tapestry.
Six teams have moved away to good starts in the three sections of the Wall Street Soft Ball League. Among the "Bulls," the Continental Bank and Asiel Co. have won two games each.
Miss Jane Thomson died at her home here this afternoon after a long illness. She was 72 years old. Miss Thomson was born in it Morayshire, Scotland, but had lived in Greenwich for forty-five years.

ARMSTRONG-Effle J., suddenly, May 14, 1937, at 2,350 Davidson Ave., daughter of the late Robert M. and Elizabeth (nee Porter), sister of Bert Armstrong. Funeral from Walter B. Cooke's, Inc., Funeral Home, 1 West 190th St., Monday, 10:45 A. M. Services St. James Episcopal Church 11 A. M. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

THE tumult is over, the shouting has died, the town is resigned to its routine unhappiness. A week ago it appeared that the glamour children would press the coronation for first place in the headlines, that many of the world's most highly publicized personalities would be members of picket lines carrying banners charging that genius (the producer) was being unfair to art (the actor).

Students at Massachusetts State College have petitioned the trustees for the immediate institution of the Bachelor of Arts degree here. In an article appearing in the Collegian it was revealed that the petition had been sent to the trustees by the student senate and the Women's Student Government Association.

With the Howard clothing chain starting last week to test a tenpayment plan in Pittsburgh, the trend to installment selling in the men's wear field is rapidly broadening and may in time blanket practically every important unit in the field, according to comment here yesterday.
Fornation of the Comstock Canning Corporation, incorporated for $500,000, has been announced here. Its capital stock consists of 50,000 common shares of a par value of $10 a share.
Italy will have nearly 110 submarines in the water by the end of the year and she is planning to increase her air force to a total of 4,100 first-line combat planes by 1941, it has been learned here.

Nicholas Soyer, inventor of "paper bag cookery," which created a world-wide furor twenty-five years ago, died today at the age of 74. At the time of his invention he was chef at Glamis Castle, home of Queen Elizabeth, who rode her white pony into his kitchen to see the medals and prizes awarded to him.

Amateur astronomers discover new stars and amateur camera men win prizes for excellence in photography, so it is not surprising that navy and Zeppelin officials have asked snapshot hobbyists for any pictures they may have of the Hindenburg burning.

Fordham's varsity track and field team conquered City College, 87 to 38, at the Lewisohn Stadium yesterday in their annual dual meet. The Rams dominated the running events, capturing all the firsts and sweeping all three places in the 440-yard run, and a feat they duplicated in the discus throw.

The marriage of Miss Etta Marie Brandt, daughter of Robert Jackson Brandt of 87 Woodruff Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mrs. Brandt, to Howard Duncan MacDougall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan MacDougall of Brooklyn and St. Albans, Queens, took place last night in the chapel of St. Paul's Church, Flatbush.

Mrs. Ella Jessup Baker of the class of '65 and Mrs. Grace Haldane Higginson of the class of '72, the oldest living alumnae of the Gardner School, will be guests of honor at the card party and luncheon to be held Friday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, under the auspices of the school alumnae association.

Banishment of the proverbial tin soldier and the living-room carpet battlefield and the substitution of toy postmen and other peaceful workers of society was suggested yesterday for children to aid in their development into citizens who will demand permanent peace and resist all war propaganda.

Members of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom from many cities of this country and Canada will be among the guests at a Canadian-American dinner here next Saturday under the auspices of the Buffalo Division of the league, of which Miss Marion Pickard Dana is chairman.

John V. Cockcroft, Northern Westchester representative of the National Real Estate Clearing House, has purchased the Kathryn Lewis property in Dobbs Ferry, through Miss Ada F. White of Dobbs Ferry as broker.

THE tenement at 56-58 East 122d Street has just undergone a complete modernization from the plans by J. M. Berlinger. The previous lack of up-to-date facilities made this building a liability to the owner, the Seamen's Bank for Savings. The bank decided that only an extensive alteration would bring the desired improvement in income.
The South Kent four-oared shells won two races from the Pomfret crews on Hatch Pond today. Though both Pomfret boats showed good blade work, South Kent had much more power and won easily.
REGULAR daily program service for listeners in Europe and the British Isles has been opened by the Columbia Broadcasting System's new 40-kilowatt short-wave transmitter, W2XE, at Wayne, N. J.

War Admiral's head stretching first past the winning post decided the fortyeighth Preakness before 40,000 wildly excited observers at Pimlico today. The son of Man o' War was driven out to the last ounce to save the prize from Pompoon, the colt that finished so badly beaten off behind him in the Kentucky Derby a week ago.

San Sebastian's casino, closed since the day General Miguel Primo de Rivera became dictator of Spain, will open for gambling next week and roulette with a double zero will be played to help General Francisco Franco pay for some of his war bill, according to a Rebel official who arrived in Paris today.

The Graduate School of Bryn Mawr College has announced plans for the third departmental rotating research project, to be carried on in 1937-38, when the departments of Greek and Latin will devote their attention to special work in the field of ancient religion.
An agreement today ended the strike of 950 employes of the Continental Distilling Company and the Publicker Commercial Alcohol Company, which began three weeks ago.
The first labor agreement in the history of the scrap iron industry was reached yesterday by the New York chapter of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel and the Waste Material Sorters.
Louis Frankel, president of the Rochester Iron and Metal Company and vice president of Frankel Brothers Co., Inc., died today in Strong Memorial Hospital of pneumonia. His age was 73.

FEWER weeks in-the cinema have been more encouraging than the one through which we have just passed. We will not say it has restored our faith in the screen, for we never really have lost it, but it has bolstered a flagging interest and it has demonstrated, in three specific cases,

The engagement of $3,921,000 gold in Great Britain for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought the total of gold engagements for the week to $32,984,000, of which $23,987,000 was taken in England, $5,200,000 in Japan and $3,797,000 in India.
Thirty-five Federal agents, led by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, arrested twenty-four men and women tonight in a series of vice raids here. .

The Kent first crew defeated the Belmont Hill firsts by three lengths in 4:33 today. Kent held the lead all the way and finished strong. The Kent seconds defeated the Kent sixth form crew by two lengths. Because of a swift current, the course record was broken by all three Kent crews.

MEXICO, D. F. A MAN in a black felt hat with a four inch straight brim, a baggy felt gray suit and a flowing, stringy black tie, a man who looks like a kindly old-fashioned Southern Congressman. is a familiar figure in Mexico City.

Congress is being tempted again. This time the temptation has nothing to do with political patronage or opportunism, with the sinister plans of lobbyists or with any alluring stratagems from the White House.

Professor Christianna Smith of the Department of Zoology at Mount Holyoke College has been awarded grants from the Division of Medical Sciences of the National Research Council and the Elizabeth Thompson Science Fund for research during the next academic year.

Edward F. Creagh of Hornell was elected editor this week of the Alfred University student newspaper, Fiat Lux. Co-business managers elected were Miss Eleanor Wisniski of Campbell and Bernard Spiro of Flushing.

Bill Coughlin's Lafayette nine defeated Lehigh, 8-3, on Fisher Field before 3,000 today. It was the eighth victory in a row for the Maroon. Lafayette reached two hurlers for thirteen safeties to score its victory after trailing by two runs.

Evidence that foreign shipping lines are strengthening their positions in the Pacific trade was found this week in San Francisco in the numerous announcements by Japanese, French, British and other steamship companies of fleet expansion and new tonnage.

Mount Holyoke College undergraduates put thoughts of the recent centenary celebrations behind them this week and turned their attention to the round of social and Intercollegiate activities which must be crowded into the college calendar before semester examinations begin at the end of the month.
The low-level bridge connecting Randalls and Wards Islands, in the East River, was opened to the public yesterday morning. The span was built by the Triborough Bridge Authority at a cost of $530,000.

BERKOWITZ--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Berkowitz of 215 West 98th St. announce the confirmation of their daughter, Blanche, Sunday, May 16, at Temple Israel. BLOOM--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bloom, 200 West 86th, announce the confirmation of their daughter, Flora Bernice, at Temple Rodeph Sholom, May 16, 1937.

At every window in Copenhagen tonight the blind is up, curtains are drawn back and a light burns. Throughout Denmark it is the same. This is the people's final tribute to King Christian X on his silver jubilee.

Criticism of the attitude of some bankers and realty interests on the slum and slum rental problems is voiced by the housing committee of the League of Mothers' Clubs in a report on a survey the committee made of 1,092 tenement families.

Before an audience of 4,000 the annual May Day festivities of Skidmore College were held in convention Hall today, the rain preventing exercises on the green. Presiding over the fete were Miss Clara Groves, '38, of St. Joseph, Mo., and her court.

William Hard, executive assistant to John D. M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, replying to Ambassador Dodd's warning against Fascist usurpation of power here, denied yesterday that the accusation applied to any Republican and countered with the statement that there had never been "a Republican who pined and panted for dictatorship in the White House."

Public and private enterprise in the housing field are shown side by side in the North American Homes Exposition at Madison Square Garden, points out Evans Clark, director of the Twentieth Century Fund and economic adviser to the New York City Housing Authority.
More than fifty drivers are scheduled to compete in a series of auto races to be held this afternoon over the speedway at Langhorne, Pa. Six events will be run.
Armed struggles between merchants, landowners and large renters and the peasants among whom the government is dividing large estates are threatened in various parts of Mexico.

Docks and piers on the inland waterways hereabout are commencing to fill up as visiting boatmen arrive for fishing and sailing. The first porgies and kingfish have put in their appearance and there have been several excellent catches.
HARD times have come to the Soay islanders of Scotland. They are seventy in number and live on the little isle off the coast of larger Skye, Inner Hebrides.

Because of the combined effect of the corporate surplus tax, the heavy increase in installment buying and the rise in retail prices, store owners and controllers are currently faced with the problem of obtaining increased capital and a number of retail establishments have completed or are considering public financing.
Guy N. Irving, former prison guard, today was convicted of negligence in permitting Joseph Bruno to escape from his custody on Dec. 18, 1936. The jury recommended "extreme mercy."

Frank L. Price, oldtime jockey and trainer of running horses, died today at his home here, at the age of 67. He started his career as a jockey at Monmouth Park, retiring in 1904 after riding eight years at Arlington race track in Chicago.

Springfield's historic First Congregational Church, which was organized in 1637 by William Pynchon, founder of the city, and his little band of followers, began its tercentenary celebration today with an exhibition of historic relics.
By CATHERINE MACKENZIE Pratt Institute in Brooklyn celebrates its fiftieth anniversary this week. This is an anniversary for locational education as well as for a single school.

Miss Muriel Grace Warne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cecil Warne of this city, was married to Ernest Wilburton Fields, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Nathaniel Fields of Kingsport, Tenn., at noon today in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church here.

In the vastly accelerated social service movement in the United States women are the real "wheel horses," according to the evidence adduced from a perusal of plans for the National Conference of Social Work which takes place at Indianapolis this month.
IT might seem absurd that our States, whose boundaries are mainly artificial lines over which we scoot nowadays with little thought, should be considered to have distinct individualities.

Mrs. Sarah Barrows Bubendey, daughter of Ira Barrows of 860 Park Avenue and the late Mrs. Cecilia Fitler Barrows, was married to Dr. Hugh Miller of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon in the Lapman Memorial Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary. The Rev.

Continued substantial improve ment in the conduct of the city's Law Department under the third year of the Fusion administration was described to Mayor La Guardia in the annual report of the department for 1936, sent yesterday to the Mayor by Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel.

Princeton University's varsity lacrosse team moved another step toward the Eastern intercollegiate championship. today on Poe Field by defeating Yale, 12-4. It was the fifth consecutive victory for the Tigers.

EIGHT of New York's college clubs have a bridge league and play a series of matches against one another every year. Their 1936-37 season called for three separate competitions, the last of which ended last week. The Yale Club made a clean sweep. J.
KINGSTON, N. Y. --The Catskill Mountain region and all of Ulster County will join in the sesquicentennial celebration to be held in Woodstock village and township from May 30 to June 5.

COHEN, ALBERT (Oct. 4, 1936). Gross assets, $5,962; net, $5,451. To wife, Rebecca Cohen, sons, Samuel A. and Meyer Cohen, one-third of residuary estate each. Chief assets, real estate, cash and mortgages, $5,962. Meyer Cohen, attorney, 369 Stone Ave.

WHILE most centers reported retail trade gains last week, sales results again took on a spotty appearance. Weather conditions were blamed but it was also noted that the public seems to have struck a period of hesitation.

THIS nicely printed volume of poems is the first issue of the Verona Press. The volume is pleasing to the eye, but the poetry is often highly artificial. Mr. Johnston has skill in verse forms, but he tries desperately to be original in language and in syntax.

The Stevens Tech baseball team defeated Rensselaer Ploy, 10-3, at Castle Point, today in a game marked by the hard hitting of Frio, Verdee and Chirko of Stevens. Chirko held the Engineers to eight hits. gineers to eight hits.

The amended charter for Federal savings and loan associations, recently approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has been adopted by 786 Federal associations throughout the country, it was announced by the board today.

Student interest in social studies at Brown University has shown a marked increase during the last five years, with registration gains of more than 100 per cent in some courses. The gains are found in the Deapartments of Economics, History and Social and Political Science.

Edward H. Saxton, president and treasurer of the Leominster Shell Goods Company and treasurer and founder of the E. H. Saxton Company, wholesale jewelry firm of Boston, died this afternoon at his home. He was 73 years old.

Danes of New York yesterday Joined with Danes all over the United States in celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the reign of King Christian X of Denmark and Iceland. An impressive service commemorating the quarter century reign of the monarch of the world's oldest kingdom was conducted at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

CASTING aside ten years of tradition that banned recordings from WEAF-WJZ, the National Broadcasting Company showmen,. greatly moved by the dramatic disk made by two Chicago radio men' of their impressions at the scene of the dirigible Hindenburg disaster, put the recording on the air in a recent ten-minute broadcast.
The Frederic Duclos Barstow Memorial Science Building at the Pawling School, was formally dedicated this afternoon in the presence of more than 700 students, alumni and parents.
Boston College struck back at Fordham yesterday for an earlier defeat this season but waited until the eighth inning of a close baseball game to do it.

Miss Catherine Fischer Carlton of Atlanta and Albert P. Craig Jr. of Scarsdale, N. Y., were married here late this afternoon, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. L. C. Fischer, the bride's uncle and aunt. Dr. M. Ashby Jones of Atlanta officiated.

ROME--High Fascist officials are considering stern measures to check the increasing disregard of the Fascist salute by- party members. The upraised arm with which zealous Fascists greeted each other during the first years of the regime is no longer seen as often as before.

An improved market for real estate in Pittsburgh, Pa., was reported by the large delegation attending the Central Atlantic regional convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, which closed here yesterday.
Twelve seniors who 'have distinguished themselves in their studies in the last three and three-quarter years at St. Peter's College have been placed on the honor list, it was announced this week.
In a stirring finish that brought victory by split seconds, a lightweight varsity crew from M. I. T. wrote rowing history on Lake Carnegie today by winning the Joseph Wright Challenge trophy.

Some of Princeton University's most prominent alumni are among those which will assemble here next month for major reunion celebrations preceding Princeton's 190th commencement exercises on June 22, a survey of preliminary reunion plans revealed today.
ROME--There is no doubt that competition between Italy and Great Britain for supremacy in the Mediterranean is now keener than ever, notwithstanding the gentlemen's agreement concluded last January.

Six graduating seniors at Hunter College have been awarded amethyst "H" pins by the Student SelfGovernment Association, it was announced byJanet Mears, president of the organization. Only seniors are eligible for the award, which is given for continuous service throughout the college course, outstanding service in one field and good service in a second.

The wandering youths of Amerioa, boys and girls who aimlessly roamed the country a few years ago, are now back home and at work or in school, Colonel Hulda Smith of Chicago, commander of the Northwest area of the Volunteers of America, reported today at the organization's annual national council.

Home developments - of- many types are assured -in the near future throughout the northern section of Hudson County, N.J., when the facilities of the Midtown Tunnel under construction beneath the Hudson River between Manhattan and New Jersey are available, predicts Leslie King,

Festive flower booths will be set up on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral on Tuesday in observance of "Outdoor Cleanliness Day," which has been arranged by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association in cooperation with the Sanitation Department to bring to the attention of the public the laws for street and sidewalk cleanliness.

Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge, president of the Young Women's Christian Association of New York, will give a luncheon for members ofthat organization's board of directors tomorrow at her home, Greyston, in Riverdale, after the May meeting of the board. The afternoon session of the directorate will be followed by a tea at the Riverdale home of Mrs. George A. Wyeth.

Of tropical aspect, with high-colored foliage in bronze and red shades, with ornamental clusters of fruits, there is no tall annual that equals the castor-oil plant or ricinus, for massing in backgrounds or for lawn specimens.

Displaying an effective three-quarter attack in the second half, Princeton University's varsity fifteen turned back the New York Rugby Club, 13-8, today. In a preliminary engagement the Nassau Jayvees and the Nek York Jayvees battled to a 3-3 deadlock.

THE average American on vacation prefers to travel by auto mobile and to stop at a hotel; his trip lasts about three weeks and he selects his travel objectives as he goes. He chooses good roads rather than great scenery; he has a distinct predilection for visiting old haunts and, by and large, he prefers comfort and safety to speed.

Leaders in the public school system pointed yesterday to the picture of the Americanization process they saw at work in the careers of the six young junior high school finalists in THE TIMES essay contest on the Constitution.

The Jamaica Hilltopper, undergraduate publication of Jamaica High School, won the sixth annual metropolitan press contest conducted by the Fourth Estate Club of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East.

RICHARD STRAUSS'S "Salome, "with Erica Darbo in the title role and Alexander Smallens conducting, and the solo appearance of Lily Pons will be attractions of the first ten days of the twentieth anniversary season of the Lewisohn Stadium concerts, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman, has announced.

Mrs. W. Gustav Triest was elected president at a recent meeting of the directors of the Prosperity Shop which maintains a permanent thrift shop at 1,279 Third Avenue for the benefit of various philanthropic organizations.

Yesterday afternoon's performance of "Mignon" at the Metropolitan was the most satisfying heard at that house in many a moon. This fact could be attributed largely to the presence in the cast of Jennie Tourel, who made her debut in the title role.
Mr. and Mrs. G. Rushton Howell of Wayne have announced the engagement- of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Mary Howell, to David Andrew Gordon Mutch, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Andrew Mutch of Wynnewood.
Dr. Hans H. Dieckhoff, the new German Ambassador, who arrived yesterday to take up his duties, paid an official call today on Secretary Hull.

ABOUT the middle of May, ten years ago, a few men were standing on Roosevelt Field in Long Island, waiting for something to happen. Almost anything would do, for they had been haunting the field for weeks and were bored. A big three-motored airplane, built to fly the Atlantic, was overdue from the factory.

FEAR of the sound of one's own voice breaking on sacred objects in a museum belongs seemingly to the present and not to a past generation. At the current show in the Museum of the City of New York, "Old New York Dines and Wines," authoritative older voices rise one above the other, extolling succulent tables of memory.

CATALONIA has again claimed the attention of those who have had their eyes trained on Loyalist Ma drid and Insurgent Burgos. There has been fighting in the streets of Barcelona, capital of the northeastern provinces of Spain that comprise autonomous Catalonia; anarchists have challenged the government; the casualties have been heavy.

Arthur Knapp, a member or the afterguard of the America's Cup candidate Ranger and long a power in the Interclub class became the first to win a race in the new International One-Design class today as a three-race series opened for the James D. Sparkman Trophy. The tests are being conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Attired in buff and blue Colonial uniforms, wigs and tri-cornered hats, thirteen mounted policemen, representing the thirteen original States, galloped north, south and west today to deliver to Governors of those States invitations

Following the recent announcement that a large apartment house is about to be constructed in Teaneck, Bergen County, N. J., another similar operation in the immediate neighborhood was announced yesterday by Robert Cadieu, architect of Cliffside Park, who is preparing plans for a three-story edifice to contain 101 suites which will occupy a four-acre tract in Englewood.

THE report of the 80,000 Federal- Music Project performances and the 57,000,000 persons in the United States who have heard "living music" in a series of remarkably rich and varied programs, since October of 1935, is eloquent of more than mere figures.

John P. Feeney of Dorchester, noted criminal lawyer of this city, former Mayor of Woburn and close friend of former Governor James M. Curley, died here early today at the Beth Israel Hospital of bronchial pneumonia in his sixty-fifth year.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Mitchell Barry, daughter of James Beamer Barry of this place and the late Mrs. Barry, to Stephen Hawes Bacon, son of Mrs. John F. Bacor of Tarrytown, took place this after noon at Christ Church here. The rev. Harold F. Hohly officiated.

LONDON. THE old Ludwig Canal in Bavaria has come back into the news after a long absence. Like a gigantic stairway, it crosses the beautiful Franconian Jura, one of the main watersheds of Europe, in a series of-more than 100 locks in 110 miles of length. At its northern end it connects with the Main,

THE Paris International Exposition of 1937 will be the first of its kind to devote a very considerable place in its calendar -to musical events. A committee of which Albert Roussel is the president has organized a wide diversity of musical events.

Hints of what is yet to come among Summer fruits and vegetables are appearing in the specialty markets of the city. Green-skinned watermelons, glowing red cherries, red-black African grapes, mangoes, peaches, nectarines, huckleberries, and even corn-on-the-cob, are available in limited amounts throughout the city.

Guests lugged their own baggage, made their own beds, and with apparent good nature put up with other limited services today in eight leading St. Louis hotels affected by a strike of union chambermaids, bellboys, cooks and other employes.

Since the Agricultural Adjustment Act-of 1933 was passed in the -midst of a grave ?? crisis not a single Congressional session has ended without enactment of some major piece of farm relief legislation.

More than 200 Amherst College undergraduates and their guests, most of them students from girls' colleges, last night thronged the new Alumni Gymnasium for the Junior Promenade, climax of the college social season.
ARTHUR FARWELL, head of theory in the Music Department, Michigan State College, East Lansing, Mich., is issuing his compositions there in hand-drawn, hand-printed editions.
C. I. O. affiliates, with about 10,000 members, were under suspensin today from the Los Angeles Central Labor Council, under orders of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harold Mortimer Kennard of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Jackson Kennard, to A. Gardiner Layng, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Montague Layng of Montclair.

Major Gen. George E. Leach, who was four times Mayor of Minneapolis before his defeat in 1929, made a spectacular return to city politics this week by winning the nomination for Mayor with almost as many votes as his two principal opponents together.

GUAYAQUIL.-Ecuador's colony of so-called Communists, exiled by President Paez to the Galapagos Islands, has not found life enchanting in the famous "enchanted isles," according to Saul T. Mora, newspaper man, who is the first of the exiles to return to the mainland.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today a rising trend in all major classes of crime in metropolitan areas.

Alfred E. Smith sailed on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia yesterday with Mrs. Smith and a party of friends for his first crossing of the Atlantic. Now in his sixtyfourth year, the former Governor has never been abroad and on only one occasion has he been out of the United States.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Sisto of this city of the engagement of Mr. Sisto's daughter, Miss Catherine Sinclair Sisto, to Ernest John Miller, son of Gordon MacKensie Miller of Montreal.

DETROIT. IN decentralizing its operations, General Motors is moving many of its manufacturing activities to the East. This fact has become more apparent the past two weeks with the announcement of extensive plans for expansion of parts and accessories divisions in New York State. Obviously the East will benefit by increased employment and larger automotive payrolls.
