Hospital librarians are being trained scientifically to select reading material suitable for individual patients, in the first collegiate course of its kind, now offered at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis.

Continuous operation of the city's light, power and gas system, uninterrupted by strikes or lockouts, is guaranteed in the new collective bargaining agreement between the Consolidated Edison Company and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers; Dan W. Tracy, international president of the A. F. of L. affiliate, disclosed yesterday.

Opening the 1937 cricket season on the grounds of the Crescent Athletic Club today, Haverford College suffered defeat at the hands of the Crescent players, champions of the New York and. Metropolitan District C Cricket Association, by a margin of 46 runs.

The War Deapartment released the following orders today dated May 14: COLONEL Jones, W. F., F.A., 12th F.A., Fort Sam Houston, Texas, to duty with Civilian Conservation Corps, Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

The marriage of Miss Anne Bailey Milne, daughter of Mrs. James S. Milne of 80 Westminster Road, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Milne, to Arthur H. Fandrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Fandrey of Brooklyn and Port Jefferson, L. I., took place yesterday afternoon in St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

American golfers who play over the Mid-Ocean course at Tucker's Town often gaze across the blue waters of Castle Harbor to Nonsuch Island, where the Bermuda Government is conducting a novel experiment in the training of delinquent boys.

The Alvena Cobanks estate of sixteen acres and an early American house in the Long Ridge district of Danbury, Conn., has been sold to Walter Tittle, portrait painter. William E. Hawkins Jr. negotiated the deal.

Following elections which attracted wide attention in the student body, campus publications at the University of Pennsylvania have an- were nounced the organization of new editorial and business boards for the next academic year.

To her already enormous foreign political refugee population France just now is adding several hundreds--sometimes several thousands--of Spanish children and old people every day. Ever since Europe became divided into "isms" instead of nationalities, these refugees have been pouring in steadily, unceasingly.

One of the large industrial deals of the present year in New Jersey has just been closed by the taking of title by the Spotswood Realty Corporation of the plant and equipment formerly known as the American Salpa Plant, at Spotswood, in the New Brunswick industrial area.

THE third and last volume of the enormous correspondence between Tchaikovsky and his wealthy patroness, Nadejda von Meck, has just come out in Moscow, and now we have firsthand documents on the whole story of their strange relationship, of which we see now another and an amusing side of it.

Many fine estates in Hartford and Farmington are to be opened to public view Tuesday and Wednesday for the benefit of the Hartford Art School. The Art Society of Hartford sponsors the event as in previous years.

The administration's new anti-trust drive, reversing the policy toward business which prevailed during the NRA period, has delayed and obscured-but by no means killedthe New Deal's plans for reviving the price control and fair trade practice features of NRA.

Under a perfectly timed ride by Jockey L. Guymon, Orinoco, running for Mrs. Sam Orr of New Orleans, won the Rockford Handicap at one mile and seven yards before a crowd of more than 12,000 spectators at Aurora today.

Three hundred and twenty-three Columbia College seniors, in academic robes, will gather in Van Amringe Quadrangle for Class Day exercises at 4 o'clock in the afternoon of May 31. Sitting in the shadows of the memorial erected to the memory of J. Howard Van Amringe, a former dean of the college,

Felix M. Warburg will speak at a dinner at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, tomorrow night to mark the new partnership in the fundraising campaign of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.

Realty transactions reported yesterday included sales of tenement houses in Harlem. Syndicates were active in the trading. The Empire City Savings Bank sold the five-story flat, on a lot 25 by 100.11 feet, at 271 West 118th Street through the RosenbergMurray Company, broker.

Harvard's varsity tennis team registered a 5-to-4 victory over Columbia University on Divinity courts, Cambridge, today. Captain Jim Fuld, Dick Dorson and Hubert Hauck were singles winners for Harvard while Hauck and Lowman and Bolton and Gordon scored at doubles.

Lawrence Management, Inc., Westchester realty firm, is expanding its operations to include appraisals and mortgage servicing. Arthur R. Storm, Inc., has moved to larger offices at 1,432-34 Queen Anne Road, Teaneck, N. J. Peter Forrest will discuss realty brokerage laws at a meeting of the 23d St. Association on Wednesday In the Hotel Gramercy Park. Harry Nystad has been elected treasurer of the association to succeed the late Henry Voorhis.

For the third straight year Cornell defeated. Pennsylvania in their annual track meet today on Franklin Field, 83-52. Hill School lost to the Penn freshmen, 68-58, in a meet held in conjunction with the varsity.

Japan is at the crossroads between constitutional government and government by committee and the military. The Throne, the people and big business indubitably wish an unalloyed representative government, but the Hayashi Cabinet and. the army want a purely bureaucratic regime or committee government similar to the Shogunate era.
As a part of practical preparation for living, Bradford Junior College is holding a series of lectures and conferences, bringing to the college visitors of note.
The Northern Indiana Amish, a sect of thrifty farm folk who eschew modern inventions and teach their children to stay with the land, are nettled by Ruth Lininger Dobson's novel "Straw in the Wind."
Miss Helen Radey Woolford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Whitefield Woolford of Haverford, was married this afternoon to Alfred Duff Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Garfield Lewis of Pittsburgh.

Combining sixteen timely hits with seven stolen bases, Columbia defeated Cornell, 12 to 3, yesterday in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League contest at Baker Field. It was the fourth league conquest of the season for the Lions and the game was the Blue's final home appearance of the campaign.

At midnight tomorrow the entry list will be closed finally for the eleventh annual bench show of the Morris and Essex Kennel Club, to be given Saturday, May 29, at Giralda Farms in Madison, N. J, No exceptions will be made and any entry received after that hour will be returned.

This year's proceedings of the American Eugenics Society made it clearer than ever that the scientists among the advocates of human betterment have given up the innocent Victorian belief in heredity as the sole agency that must be controlled if we are not to be swamped by the socially unfit.

AIMING to be ready for the coronation broadcast, engineers of the British Broadcasting Corporation completed, their task of installing new high power empire transmitters at Daventry to increase the signal strength in foreign lands.

Ostend brown gelding owned by Mrs. Frank M. Gould of New York, defeated eight other horses to lift the Gloucester FOK Hunters Plate and Langston Cup in the feature event of the Rose Tree Hunt Club meet today before a big crowd.

The subway fare was plunged last week into politics-which is nothing new for New York. In almost every Mayoralty campaign since the World War it has been an issue, with all concerned proclaiming devotion to the nickel ride while insinuating that the opposition was secretly seeking to undermine it.

Miss Herberta May Alrich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Alrich of 128 Fort Washington Avenue, was married to Lawrence H. Dempewolff, son of Dr. and Mrs. August F. Dempewolff of this city, last night in the Chapel of the Intercession, 155th Street and Broadway, by the vicar, the Rev. Dr. S. Tagart Steele Jr.

Emphasis in the Department of Motion Pictures of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs has been shifted from the presentation of week-end family programs and the arrangement of frequent junior matinees to a closer tie-up of the films with the reading of good books. In this connection Mrs.

Girls at Goucher College have gone in for some unique hobbies. One Phi Beta Kappa has been experimenting with red-blooded snails. From two small specimens a fine group of these pedigreed snails has come into existence.

Society should be responsible for "the education, welfare and development" of all young people up to the age when they can secure paid work, the American Youth Commission, of which Newton D. Baker is chairman and Owen D. Young vice chairman, stated last week. Under present conditions of unemployment, boys and girls should not be turned adrift at the end of their school days.

Seven runs on two hits, two walks and three errors in the first half of the twelfth inning after one was out enabled the Baltimore Orioles to break a 2-to-2 deadlock with the Rochester Red Wings today and score a 9-to-5 victory when the Rochester pitching and defense cracked wide open.

Contracts for delivery of grain in May developed strength today as the result of short covering based on the belief that scattered liquidation had run its course, but the buying disclosed a lack of aggressive selling.

Board of Trade figures for April are as follows: Total imports, [pound]82,870,000; exports of British products, [pound]43,020,000; re-exports, [pound]7,270,000; total exports, [pound]50,290,000; excess of imports, [pound]32,580,000.

A special "surprise party" is now being arranged by Mrs. Vincent Astor and Miss Elsa Maxwell for Thursday night at the Twenty-One Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street, for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Astor is acting president.

EVER since the "Zwei Herzen im Drei-Viertel Takt" of 1930 there have been recurrences of the Vienna motif, some of them successful, some of them passable, but nearly all concerned with the Vienna of the Hapsburgs, before the war, inflation and a changing political concept had altered matters.

Complaints received at City Hall that several members of the panel of 150 labor dispute arbitrators named by Mayor La Guardia had been solicited for campaign funds resulted in an official warning yesterday to ignore such solicitations. A letter to this effect has been sent to members of the panel by Lester Stone of the Mayor's staff.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Schroth of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorette Elisabeth Schroth, to William Brant Kolb, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kolb of Cynwyd, Pa.

Mrs. ROOSEVELT'S notion that housewives should get regular wages is being carried beyond her original intention. The cartoonists are talking labor unions for wives, minimum wages, maximum hours and old-age pensions.

AT intervals the Whitney Museum of American Art puts on a show made up of material in the permanent collection. These occasions are always gratifying, since it is thus possible for us to renew our acquaintance with work that (space limitations being what they are) can .be made available only in this way.

New England leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organization, aroused by the imprisonment at Lewiston, Me., of six of their organizers and fearful that Judge Harry Manser's Interpretation of the Wagner act may halt their unionizing of industrial workers in that State, are now instigating a national boycott of Maine's vacation resorts this Summer.

During the depression life insurance companies of the United States distributed an average of $9,993,538 a day, or 6.6 per cent of the national daily income of $151,320,627 from 1930 to 1935, inclusive, according to G. L. Hunt, national chairman of Life Insurance Week.

Bucknell faculty members interested in setting up a pension systern at the university have requested the board of trustees to consider a joint contributory plan, beginning in September, which would provide retirement annuities for college employes.

Miss. Alyce Mary Mansfield of Tappan, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs.; Hiram Mansfield of Norfolk, Conn., was married here today to Roswell James Russell of Bryant, Ohio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Russell.

Mrs. Edward . MaoDowe, widow of the compose, will be guest of honor at a tea Wednesday afternoon at the home of Miss Anne Morgan, 3 Sutton Place, whioh will be given in the interests of the- MaoDowell Summer Colony at Peterborough, N. H. The colony for creative artists will open next month for its thirty-second season.

Daylight-saving time begins in Holland next Saturday night, and Europe will then be through shifting its clocks until Autumn. The French changed on April 4, to the confusion of foreigners who had to catch trains to Paris. The Belgians followed suit on April 11.
The nation's mechanical engineers will pay tribute to Henry Ford here next week at the semi-annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
WHAT might be done with art in our subways is discussed in a letter from Doris Kravis, chairman of the public use of art committee, Mural Painters and Sculptors Section, New York, Artists Union.

Boy students of the junior and senior high schools of this community, who have been cutting classes to caddy at near-by golf courses, will no longer have to invent incredible excuses for their absences, according to a plan devised by Paul D. Schreiber, superintendent of schools, and made public today.
Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle spoke last evening at a supper dance in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of a club he founded soon after he became rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The annual card party, fashion show and tea under the auspices of the Democratic Junior League of New York will be held next Saturday in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre for the benefit of the Social Service Bureau maintained by the organization.

The University of Vermont track team today won a heptagonal meet by amassing 38 points in the fifteen events. Trinity placed second with 281-6 points, Connecticut State third with 27; Middlebury, pre-meet favorite, fourth with 26; Tufts fifth with 19, and Colby and Massachusetts State trailed with 16 1/2 and 11 1-3 points, respectively.

PARIS. THE Paris Exposition of 1937, which is to be opened to the public on May 25, has been built along, over and one might say in the winding Seine, right in the middle of modern Paris, and that ancient river is going to be exploited as never before.
At the annual May Day celebration and presentation of the sophomore masque by students at Pembroke College today Miss Mary Emma Dull, '37, of Pittsburgh was crowned May Queen.

An opportunity to aid the maintenance of the Greenwich House Health Center at 27 Barrow Street and at the same time to visit picturesque gardens in Greenwich Village will be provided by the series of garden exhibitions arranged for Wednesday and Thursday afternoons by Mrs. J. G. Phelps Stokes and several other women interested in the work of the health center.

Miss Elizabeth L. Irwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Irwin of 1,275 Clinton Place, has chosen June 18 for her marriage to James C. Kellogg 3d, son of Mrs. James C. Kellogg Jr. of this city and the late Mr. Kellogg. The ceremony will take place in Westminster Presbyterian Church. A reception will follow at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club.

In what witnesses said was a geologist, of hold-up by two Negroes, an uniidentified man, about 35 years old, was shot and fatally wounded at 12:30 o'clock this morning when he tried to resist his assailants in front of 218 St. James Place, near Fulton Street, Brooklyn. The thugs ran about a block to Gates Avenue, darted west on that thoroughfare and disappeared.

Ringing tribute to the "adaptability" and "native efficiency" of the United States fleet during the World War was paid by Admiral Sir Ernle Chatfield, First Sea Lord and professional head of the British Navy.

WASHINGTON. -- Federal land banks now hold, real estate and Sheriffs' certificates to the number of nearly 30,000, W. I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, recently told a House committee.
TELEVISION pictures can now be projected, with the clarity of home-movies, on a wall screen measuring 18 by 24 inches, which is about the size of a newspaper page.
Monty Stratton, towering White Sox righthander, held the Indians to three singles today to register his fourth victory and his second shutout of the season. Chicago won, 6 to 0.

Mrs. Howard Green of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Topping Green, to William G. Daub Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Daub of Red Bank, N. J. The announcement was made at a luncheon given today by Mrs. Green at her home here.

Three Pennsylvania fishermen were drowned today when their eleven-foot boat overturned in Delaware Bay three miles off this point. Charles Wyckoff, 47 years old, of Glenolden, had set out early this morning with his son, Edward, 15, and his son-in-law, Robert Aello, 22.

MR. BETHELL JONES subtitles his life of Catherine of Portugal, queen to the third Stuart King of England, a "romantic biography," and at once the historically minded reader is prepared for the worst. What, another!

Swollen by heavy rain, New England rivers rose today, overflowing their banks in parts of Vermont, New Hampshire and Western Massachusetts. Highways were inundated or damaged by landslides in the Western Massachusetts hill country.

Undertaking to clarify the respective positions of the United States and the Philippines regarding the Commonwealth's foreign relations, High Commissioner Paul V. McNutt has sent a polite but firmly worded note to all the foreign consulates in Manila advising them to send all official communications intended for Commonwealth officials through the High Commissioner's office.

Miss Anna Gisondi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Gisondi of Cos Cob, Greenwich, was married to Arthur La Morte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank La Morte of New York, in St. Catherine's Catholic Church, Riverside, Greenwich, this morning by the Rev. Joseph A. Ganley, the pastor.

Stop and go lights in New York terminals this week-end might have simplified a traffic problem there for hordes of delegates, departing for one or another of the conventions of women's organizations with which the calendar is crowded for the next several days.

Prejudice against women in the profession is being overcome, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College said here today at the tenth Spring meeting of the New Jersey Division, American Association of University Women.

Miss Harriett Gilchrist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce O. Gilchrist of this place, has chosen June 4 as the date for her marriage to Horace Arthur Wadsworth of Greenwich, Conn., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Wadsworth, now in Bound Brook, N. J. The ceremony will take place in the evening in Christ Church, Hackensack, and will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Edgar L. Cook.

Miss Anna C. Dowling of 1,390 Dean Street, Brooklyn, entertained at a luncheon and bridge yesterday at her home for Miss Alice Regina Carroll, whose marriage to Raymond J. Pellman of Cincinnati will take place in the Summer.

Off with his fishing togs, on with his fighting clothes, President Roosevelt late this week stepped into the incipient revolt in Congress-worked up mostly over his court reorganization plan-and outlined a program of legislation for the remainder of the session which may bring the severest test between the White House and Capitol witnessed here in recent years.

Now that the coronation is over, Britain has come to earth with a bump to face the stern realities which had little place in Wednesday's pageantry. From crowns and coronets and fairy-tale coaches it is an abrupt transit to labor unrest and the ever-present dangers of the foreign situation.

A. P. Giannini's suggestion yesterday that the activities of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association might be extended brought vigorous opposition today from those opposed to interstate branch banking. The Transamerica Corporation owns the Bank of America, Mr. Giannini said.

Employers seeking students to take into industry are interested in whether they have initiative, ideas and personality and not in their grades, Professor James F. Norris of Massachusetts Institute of Technology said last night in accepting the medal of the American Institute of Chemists.

Three-fourths of this Alaska town remained under water today as ice jams continued to dam the flooding Tanana and Chena Rivers. Mayor Collins said the city was in no immediate need of outside assistance, but he hoped the flood would arouse action on the longsought Federal flood control project.

A series of special events throughout the country will mark the fifth annual life insurance week program which begins tomorrow, George L. Hunt, chairman of the executive committee -in charge of the observance, announced yesterday.

Today and this week the tulips planted along the walk of Brooklyn Botanic Garden bordering the experimental plot south of the conservatories will be in prime condition. The 100 varieties of lilacs in the plantation west and northwest of the Rose Garden are also in bloom.

China's Foreign Minister, Dr. Wang Chung-hui, will voice China's greetings to America from Shanghai next Wednesday when radiophone service between this country and the United States is formally inaugurated.

OYEZ! Oyez! For the benefit of those fight fans who would like to know what has happened and what may follow in the great heavyweight legal tangle, the following brief submitted by that famous firm of unlicensed solicitors, Rowley, Powley, Gammon Spinach, is herewith exposed to view:
In ancient London last week, amid the medieval pomp and pageantry of a royal coronation, an Empire-Commonwealth forged anew the bonds that hold 500,000,000 people in a common loyalty.

Zinnia linearis is a new and totally "different" zinnia which has recently been introduced by one of the California seedsmen and hybridizers. While it is not one of the novelties that book an all-America award this year, it is, nevertheless, well worth the attention of gardeners everywhere.

A children's book exhibit and conference on children's reading, will be held at the Westchester County Center, here, on Monday and Tuesday, it was announced today. The event is sponsored by the Association for Arts in childhood, with the cooperation of the Westchester County Recreation Commission.

Mrs. Genevieve Johnson's fifteenday sit-down strike for alimony was cited as an act of cruelty in divorce proceedings filed here today by Ralph Johnson. Mrs. Johnson conducted her strike in. a rocking chair in front of the home of her husband's parents in Longmont, twenty miles from here.

FATHER DIVINE is an amazing figure enough, to all reasonable eyes--that undersized and insignificant-looking Negro, called "God" by devout and chanting thousands in this civilized day. But the most amazing thing about the pattern of this strange apotheosis is not the grandiloquent little man who is its center: it is the pattern itself.

With furniture scoring a very sharp increase, twenty-one out of thirty-five sections of local department stores had gains in advertising linage used in April, in comparison with the same month last year, according to the "breakdown" issued yesterday by Media Records.

New tension is arising in North China, according to Japanese sources of information, which charge that an eleven-year-old Japanese boy was so badly beaten by Chinese in Peiping that he was taken to a hospital, where he will have to remain three weeks to recover.

Republican leaders who addressed the closing sessions of the convention of the State Association of Young Republican Clubs here today linked "the future of the Republican party with the impending break-up of the Democratic party over the Supreme Court issue."

FRANCE has announced a stamp to be issued this month to commemorate the tenth anniversary of Charles A. Lindbergh's solo flight across the Atlantic, which took place on May 20, 1927. Colonel Lindbergh is no newcomer to the stamp album, since the universal acclaim with which his feat was greeted was soon reflected in the philatelic world.

President Roosevelt congratulated Henry T. (Dick) Merrill and his co-pilot, John S. Lambie Jr., on their round. trip flight across the Atlantic when they called on him at the White House this noon by his invitation.

Possibilities of increasing the muskrat population in wide areas of marshland in Northern Manitoba to provide productive trapping grounds and a livelihood for Indian trappers are being studied by the Indian Affairs Branch.

Park Avenue is well established as a leading shopping avenue, according to Harold C. Samuels, who points out that the lease recently taken by Camilla Shanahan on the ground floor of the Hotel Ambassador, Park Avenue and Fifty-third Street, completes the leasing of the last hotel corner in that section of the avenue.
A horse show will be -held tomorrow on the grounds of the Washiington Irving Country Club, formerly the Rockwood Hall Country Club here, under the auspices of the Westchester Cancer. Committee. .

A group of thirty-seven students at Barnard College, who are interested in sociology, were represented by two students at an interview with Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve recently on the possibility of enlarging courses and adding professors in the Sociology Department.

ALL the facts discovered by the police concerning the murder of Rufus Ray, a too successful divorce lawyer, are here presented in the form of a file containing the reports of the various detectives assigned to the case, together with photographs. photostats, memoranda, letters, telegrams, ,
Purchases by the railroads from manufacturing enterprises in the first three months of this year exceeded those of any like period since 1930, according to Railway Age.

BESET though he is by certain inherited inconveniences, the chief one being the ready adaptability of his, name to punning and another being his resemblance to Robert Taylor, Director Mark Sandrich is a contented man, and will continue to be as long as he can think up fresh ideas for Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers pictures.

The engagement of Miss Beatrice Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilbert of this city, to Joseph Benjamin Birdsell of Boston, son of Mrs. John Comly Birdsell of South Bend, Ind., and the late Mr. Birdsell, has been announced by her parents.

Bonds called last week for payment prior to maturity were in somewhat smaller volume than in the preceding period, although they represented a well-diversified list. The principal refundings announced consisted of industrial, railroad and foreign issues.
To take effect 12 noon, May 16: LIEUTENANT--Ludolph Bose, Borough Headquarters Squad, Brooklyn-Richmond, at $2,000 per annum. Appointed June 12, 1901.

Jack Sharkey Jr., 127, Union City, N. J., outpointed Joey Fontana, 127, East Side, in the feature sixround bout at the Ridgewood Grove in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the victor drop his rival for a short count in the fifth and gain the verdict.

NADIA BOULANGER, director of the Ecole-Normale of Paris and the American Conservatory at Fontainebleau, France, has been engaged by Radcliffe College as visiting lecturer in music .during the second term of that institution's next academic year.

For a time today it looked as if the bad luck that befell Sam Snead yesterday, when a deluge of rain washed out his record-breaking 65, might cost the White Sulphur Springs sensation the metropolitan open championship. It didn't. At any rate, not at the conclusion of the second round.

The Securities and Exchange Commission revealed today that the Taylor Young Airplane Company of Alliance, Ohio, had offered for registration a proposed issue of 115,000 shares of $1 par common stock, the proceeds to be applied on indebtedness and to add to the plant, machinery and equipment and working capital.

Buying activity in the wholesale market here last week centered on Summer-type merchandise, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers.

Robert R. Bogi won the high-gun honors at the weekly 50-target skeet shoot of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today with a perfect score. In the shoot-off for the handicap prize, which followed, James White was victor.

Machine-gun battles in the MeuseArgonne were never noisier than the Albany waterfront this afternoon as a hundred speed boat drivers, most of them in tiny outboard pancakes, roared up and down the Hudson with their mufflerless motors wide open in preparation for tomorrow morning's tenth annual running of the marathon down to Manhattan.

WITH the second bill of the WPA Federal Dance Theatre, consisting this time of productions by Tamiris and Charles WeidWian, settled at the Bayes Theatre for a run, it beeomes necessary to broach the delicate problem of what kind of critical standards should be used to measure such presentations as these.
The first county-wide rally of the fifty-five Holy Name Societies in Westchester County will be held on June 6 at the County Center here, according to arrangements

About 500 members of the New York Curb Exchange Athletic Association attended the annual outing and dinner today at Karatsonyi's Hotel, Hempstead Harbor. The men arrived in sixteen buses and several private automobiles and devoted the day to outdoor sports, baseball, tug-o-war, running, jumping and pole vaulting.

More than $2,225,000 has been paid by stockholders of the Central Republic Bank and Trust Company to the Reconstruction Finance Corporalion as a result of the double-liaability assessment against them regently upheld by Judge James H. Wilkerson in Federal District court, It was announced today by O. John Rogge and Harold Rosenwald, attorneys for the RFC.

Miss Jane Crawford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Crawford of North Adams, was married here this morning in St. Paul's Cathedral to the Rev. Richard Lief of New York by the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Bishop of Massachusetts.

The Transport Workers Union of America, which recently left the American Federation of Labor to affiliate with the Committee on Industrial Organization, won the exclusive right last night to represent all the 13,500 employes of the Iaterborough Rapid Transit Company in collective bargaining with the management.

The Westfield Y. M. C. A. has solved how to meet the terms of the will of Senator Frederick H. Gillett, who left $300,000 for the maintenance of a new Y. M. C. A. building provided it cost not less than $100,000.

Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, the indomitable cripple who became a great pioneer of the British labor movement and the first Socialist Chancellor of the Exchequer, died of a heart attack this morning at his home in Tilford, Surrey, where he had been living in virtual retirement for several years. He was 72.

Miss Eleanor Hanna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Hanna of this place, was married this afternoon to Robert Strong Adams of Glen Ridge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Adams of Cleveland, at the home of her parents.

ENCOUNTER in April" is a first book of poems by the daughter of George Sarton, distinguished Professor of'History of Science at Harvard. Miss Sarton is a student of the drama, also, and has been associated with Eva La Gallienne in her productions.

Discussion of the development of the residential colleges in Yale University is an important feature of the volume of essays and addresses of President James R. Angell, which has just been published by the Yale University Press.
RETIRED: A young man of 70 closed his desk last week in the Mayor's office in Lincoln, Neb., and walked out a private citizen. "Brother Charley" Bryan's lone Political career

Most commodity futures ruled steady yesterday in subdued activity. Rubber, copper, tin, lead and wool top futures were virtually unchanged, while coffee, hide and cottonseed oil futures advanced. In the cash markets all the grains, lard, tin and cotton gained, but wool tops fell to a new low level at $1.14 a pound.

The Women's Division of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee will give a luncheon on Thursday to Mrs. Felix M. Warburg, honorary chairman of the division, who has just returned from Europe. It will take place at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, Mrs. Leo Sulzberger, chairman of the division, announced.
A survey of the acts of the recent session of the State Legislature shows that many measures of prime interest to real estate men, property owners and mortgage officials failed to win approval.
The Italian Ambassador and Mrs. Fulvio Suvich entertained with a dinner and ball this evening at the Italian Embassy. The dinner was served at small tables.

THERE has been no more scathing portrait of an obnoxious wise guy than Mr. Weidman's hero in some time. His Harry Bogen is a rather insistently heartless young adventurer in the garment trade who proceeds along his triumphant way by a technique of ruthless betrayal.

Climaxing the second annual Spring horse show of the Wall Street Riding Club at the club's tanbark on West Sixty-sixth Street last night, the New York City Police Department's aged bay gelding Speedy triumphed over a big field in the open jumping competition, the featured event.

Undergraduates at williams college and more than 460 guests are participating in the annual Spring house-party festivities being held here this week-end. Girls from twenty-two States and many colleges are here for the dances at the fraternities and the Garfield Club.

Louis Saul Sterling, who was born on the lower East Side of New York and went to London thirty years ago with a phonograph under his arm and $30 in his pocket, has been made a Knight Bachelor of the British Empire by King George VI in the coronation honors list, friends in New York learned yesterday.

The American Federation of Labor and a small section of the Canadian National Labor Union movement have rallied within the last week to the support of Premier Hepburn of Ontario and those important industrial and newspaper interests which have been seeking to keep John L. Lewis and his Committee of Industrial Organization out of Canada.

THE report made last week by Marshall Field, president of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, contains interesting figures that invite speculation and comment. During the twenty-four weeks of the season just completed -the orchestra's ninety-fifth-ninety-one concerts were given in Carnegie Hall, one in Hartford, Conn.

To cement further the bonds of Franco-Yugoslav friendship, Prince Regent Paul of Yugoslavia will officially visit Paris about the middle of next week on his return from London. This. semi-official announcement was made here tonight.

An examination of our Constitution from the viewpoint of democracy will prove an interesting and valuable study. The whole world is talking about democracy. Some say it has failed; others claim otherwise. I believe our country,
Phi Beta Kappa at Williams College will act as a liaison between undergraduates and administration in regard to administrative and curricular matters in the future.

LED by the towering flat canvas pyramids of five America's Cup defender candidates and heralded by booming of min nature brass cannon as yacht club flags and ensigns are broken out to warm breezes, the pleasure-boat fleet of this northern sector is now going into commission.

Georgia's Bulldogs dethroned Louisiana State today as the Southeastern Conference champions in a track and field meet in which six records were broken. The Tigers from Baton Rouge, supreme in the sport since 1931, lost the championship by 12 points, with Auburn taking third place and Kentucky fourth.

President Roosevelt was criticized by Horace D. Taft, brother of former President Taft, for "not a voice lifted against the sit-down strike when a word from him would have stopped the disregard for law which has accompanied the use of the weapon."

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Richardson of St. Paul, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Jenkins Richardson, to Dr. Edward Sumner Brewster, son of Major Sidney- W. Brewster, United States Marine Corps, retired, and Mrs. Brewster of this city.

The striking Federated Motion Pictures Crafts refused tonight offers of a truce which would have returned them to work on Monday. Pat Casey, labor conciliator for the producers, informed federation leaders tonight "the producers have been and are willing to negotiate the matter of a union shop along with other demands."

The recent announcement by the United States Appraiser here that all imports from Gablonz, Czechoslovakia, have become subject to "withheld appraisement," focuses attention on a glaring omission in the bill introduced into the House some days ago covering changes in the administrative provisions of the present Tariff Act, James B. Herzog, vice president of S. Stern, Stiner Co., customs brokers, said yesterday.
AS part of the post-coronation social functions and activities, England is commemorating this Spring the centenary of the death of John Constable, the greatest "natural painter" of English landscape.

Rutgers University seniors, in a poll conducted by The Targum, campus newspaper, published in that paper today, showed majorities for the President's court reorganization plan. Of 146 seniors voting on the reorganization question seventy-seven were in favor of Roosevelt's proposal.
Harold S. Vanderbilt's newly launched America's Cup defense candidate Ranger was towed into this famous port today minus all but about 30 feet of her 165-foot mast made of aluminum alloy.

Life Insurance Week, the fifth national program sponsored by 140 leading companies in the United States, will open tomorrow and continue through Saturday with special programs for each day in 1,000 cities and towns.

Miss Kathleen Kinsella, merchandise manager of Gimbels notions and novelties department, was guest of honor last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria jointly sponsored by the United Palestine Appeal and the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.
The nation's only one-house Legislature completed its first session today with the forty-three members in general agreement that "our work has been good, but not sensational."

Oriental rugs, Chinese furniture and textiles, silver, portrait miniatures, diamond and other preciousstone jewelry and other objects will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., Wednesday, Thursday and Friday afternoons. The sale will comprise property of a Western private collector, of Mrs. P. B. K. Daingerfield and other owners.

Summer courses in housing, community planning and low-rental management will be given from June 14 to July 28 at the New York University School of Architecture and Allied Arts, 1,071 Sixth Avenue. Registration opens June 10. Fees range from $24 for one course to $110 for five courses.

Pitched overboard during a rainstorm, Albert Graham Ober Jr., Baltimore sportsman, was drowned twelve miles off Block Island today. Mr. Ober was on the yacht, the Flying Cloud, bound from Fairhaven to Baltimore. On board were five guests and two crew members.

Mrs. Gussie Block, 30 years old, of 172 Varet Street, Brooklyn, who we arrested Fridayafternoonwhen she attempted to smuggle a piece of heroin-soaked string, three feet in length, to her husband, Peter, prisoner in the Harts Island Penitentiary, was in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday morning charged with violation of the Harrison Drug Act.

The Department of Public Welfare announced yesterday the arrest of three men in a charity racket which has recurred in various parts of the city for many years. The technique is always the same. Business men get phone calls from a "judge" or other alleged public officials-often a real name is used -and are told that the official is interested in a certain philanthropic work and will do favors for those who contribute.

LEGEND relates that thunder, lightning and other upheavals of nature accompanied the births of certain historical personages as portents of their coming greatness. If unusual natal disturbances bear the same relationship to events as to men it augurs well for the impending National Convention of the Legitimate Theatre.

Mr. and Mrs. Calvin L. Roosevelt of this place today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Frances Roosevelt, to G. Frederick Mullen of New Haven. The announcement was made at a party given by the Roosevelts in their home.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Glenn Partridge, daughter of Mrs. Charles Adin Partridge of Noble and the late Mr. Patridge, to Johnson Alcock Webster, son of Mrs. Georgina Webster of Brooklyn, took place here tonight in the Abington Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Roland Bruce Lutz.

Grains of cornstarch injected into some types of cancer in mice have caused the tumors to disappear or show marked regression. Dr. Robert Chambers, Research Professor of Biology at New York University, states in the annual scientific report of the International Cancer Research Foundation, issued today.

In practically all of the popular lake sections in the metropolitan suburban territory preparations have been going forward actively since the first of May to inaugurate the Summer season during the Decoration Day week-end period with more ambitious recreation programs than last year.
Behind Lefty Lee Grissom's two-hit hurling, the Reds won their first game of the season at home today and climbed out of the National League cellar by defeating Chicago, 3 to 2.
TECHNICAL problems on radio allocations, particularly short waves, will be studied when the International Radio Consulting Committee meets in Bucharest May 21 to June 10.

Thirty branches of the New Jersey Society Children of the American Revolution will hold their annual picnic next Saturday. They will meet in the morning to view the Revolutionary period relics on display at McKonkey's Ferry House in Washington Crossing State Park, after which they will go to Sullivan's Grove for a picnic luncheon.
Princeton golfers gained a double victory today and went into a firstplace tie with Georgetown in the Southern division of the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

Henry W. Ruger Jr., 28 years old, won the $15,000 Cape Cod Colonial house given away at the White Plains Better Housing Exposition under the auspices of the White Plains Better Housing Bureau, which closed tonight in the Westchester County Center here.

Sixty New York organizations interested in international commerce are cooperating in the observance of Foreign Trade Week beginning today and continuing through Saturday, it was announced yesterday by James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Munson Butler of this city and Pocasset. Cape Cod, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Elizabeth Butler, to Northrop C. Clarey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Northrop C. Clarey of New Bochelle, N. Y.

Out of the 151 members of the senior class who will receive degrees at Williams College in June, 131 have definitely decided their future occupations, according to a poll recently completed by The Williams Record, undergraduate publocation.

The Warrington, a new $3,646,000 destroyer leader, was launched here today at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company. About 3,000 spectators watched while Miss Katherine Taft Chubb of 605 Weat 112th Street, New York, great-great-granddaughter of Commodore Lewis Warrington,

For a rock -garden of herbs a situation facing south or west is best, because nearly all varieties of herbs enjoy sunlight. Some protection on north and east sides will prevent burning and killing by the cold biting winds of Winter.

The Mrs. Frank Murray estate, consisting of 100 acres of land with house at Croton-on-Hudson, N. Y., has been sold to Frank Rudolti of New 'York City, who plans extensive improvements. J. Vincent Ball negotiated the deal.

WHILE President Roosevelt and the Department of State are emphasizing the "goodneighbor' policy abroad, another branch of the government, the Federal Housing Administration, is stressing "'good neighborhoods" here at home.

Officers and members of the General Nathaniel Woodhull Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution met yesterday at a "white breakfast" in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador in celebration of the thirty-sixth anniversary of the granting of the chapter charter.

Robert S. Sinclair, one of the most widely known business men in Indiana, died here late last night after nearly a year's illness. He was 64 years old. Mr. Sinclair was chairman of the board of directors of the Kingan Co. meat-packing concern. The illness from which he succumbed

Miss Shirley Lowenhaupt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Lowenhaupt of Montclair, was married to Franklin J. Koehler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Koehler, of Montclair, this afternoon in St. Cassian's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Landers, the pastor.
The Dock Department is studying plans to renovate the Hudson River piers between Twenty-third and Forty-second Streets, according to Dock Commissioner John Mackenzie.
Ever since "The Thin Man," Van Dykes are being assiduously collected by people who never even heard of the Flemish master.

Convinced that four or five million of those now unemployed will remain as a residue even if American industry attains the prosperity of 1929, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Works Progress Administrator, predicted in a speech yesterday that poverty in the United States would be wiped out within the next twenty years.

Under threatening skies and a heavy field, Holy Cross annexed its sixth straight baseball triumph by defeating Yale today, 8 to 5. Mo Jubitz had one disastrous inning, the fifth, and the Crusaders took advantage of his slip to register four runs and clinch the game.

Count and Countess Giuseppe Cippico, who had been at the WaldorfAstoria; sailed yesterday on the Conte di Savoia to return to Rome. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Oliver Rea of Pittsburgh are at the Ritz-Carlton.
Manager Burleigh Grimes admitted today, although the game of the Dodgers against the Bees had been called off because of wet grounds, that he was happy over two things.

In an effort to impress upon Congress the "need" for an increased Federal relief appropriation, 700 persons, representing seven organizations of WPA workers, voted yesterday. to call a one-day stoppage of work on all local WPA projects for Thursday, May 27.

Lilacs were first brought to this country by the early New England settlers, and since that time they have been popular everywhere. There is no typical New England garden or dooryard without its lilac bush.
THE story of Don Juan is a theme which not only attracted Moliere, but has become almost an obsession to two generations of modern French playwrights. Rostand tackled it without very much success.

The President of the United States, bronzed and rested after a fortnight's holiday off the Texas coast, returned to Washington-last week, where Congress waited to learn his legislative plans. Awaiting him were many problems, two of them outstanding-government economy and court revision.

Veteran riflemen of the Seventh Regiment, New York National Guard, today won a match from the midshipmen, 2,378 to 2,336, gaining a slight margin at 200 and 300 yards in both classes of fire and 34 points at the 600-yard range. slow fire.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Florence Siegrist, daughter of Mrs. William Siegrist of 1,033 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, and Shorelands, Old Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Siegrist, to Elmer Wadsworth Earl Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer W. Earl of Maplewood, N. J., which will take place on the night of June 23 in the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Alfred Grant Walton will officiate.

As of May 1, a total of 27,051,976 Social Security account numbers had been assigned to applicants for participation in the old-age benefit plan, and about $150,000,000 had been granted to States for aid of the needy aged, needy blind and dependent children, the Social Security Board reported today.

Creating of a high school for superior pupils, based on the theory that bright children need special training, is being planned for New York City, Dr. John L. Tildsley, Associate Superintendent of Schools disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON. THE speed with which America's scenic wonder drive-the 500 mile Blue Ridge Parkway-is carried to completion depends upon how much money Congress appropriates for the work, as Public Works Administration funds for this purpose are now exhausted. All of the $6,000,000 allocated by PWA has been obligated.

To the No. 1 dog n the benches, the oft-victorious and impressive liver-and-white pointer Ch. Nancolleth Marquis, went the top honors in the Orange Kennel Club's fourth annual all-breed dog exhibition held today on the picturesque grounds of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

The marriage of Miss M. Elise Kendall of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ola Kendall of Jacksonville, Fla., to Glenn Balch, son of Mrs. G. O. Balch of Dallas, Texas, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Riverside Church. The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick performed the ceremony.
WHEN travelers wander through the West and Southwest of the United States this Summer by rail, by bus, or by automobile, few among them will not sometime, somewhere, see an Indian.

MISCELLANEOUS aircraft operators flew 523,266 miles perfatal accident and 664,145 miles per passenger fatality in the six months from July to December, 1936, the Bureau of Air Commerce, Department of Commerce, announced last week. Operators in this category, which includes flying services, schools, specialists in photographic flying, crop dusting and the like, and private flyers, suffered 909 accidents during the period, in 51,803,290 miles of flying. Miles flown per accident were 56,989.
The drama and dance departments of the Bennett Junior College will present in the outdoor theatre May 22 the first of five performances of "Iphigenia in Tauris," by Euripides.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Richardson German of Maplewood have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Richardson German, to E. Harris Harbison of Princeton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Warner Harbison of Sewickley, Pa. The announcement was made today in Northampton, Mass., where Miss German is a student at Smith College.

Racing--War Admiral, winner of the Kentucky Derby, captured the Preakness as 40,000 looked on at Pimlico. Pompoon was second, as he was in the Kentucky Derby, and Flying Scot third. The winner paid $2.70, $2.30 and $2.40 across the board.
Announcement of the engagement of Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole, dean of Stoneleigh College, Rye, N. H., to Dr. Henry Gilbert Reynolds of Paducah, Ky., was made in The Boston Transcrint today.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for. operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustments.

Miss Margaret Rosseland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Rosseland of this place, has set June 3 for her marriage to Edgar J. van Dyk, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. H. van Dyk of Detroit. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Butz will perform the ceremony, which will take place in Prospect Presbyterian Church, Maplewood.

Lieut. Commander Charles Reginald Jacobsen, commanding officer of the Thirty-third Fleet Division, New York Naval Militia, United States Naval Reserve, and the training ship Briarcliff at Tomp kinsville, S. I., died Friday night at his residence, 12 Beach Avenue,

IN Defense of Capitalism Against Its Defenders" might be a better title for this book which, judged by the logic and tenor of its argument, is an effective criticism and repudiation of all those reforms that have been advanced and in many instances adopted for the alleged or implied purpose of preserving the present social order.

SOMETIMES-too often, alaswe are misled into thinking that art is essentially a stern, difficult business, a problem to bear upon which one must perforce bring one's gravest, most analytical and -cheerless faculties.

The New York Baled Shavings Company of 44 Whitehall Street, Manhattan, has purchased a tract of land along the Lehigh Valley Railroad near Morris Avenue from Frederick J. Weppler and others, executors of the Weppler estate.

A FORMER mechanic, accustomed for many years to working with his hands, first in a wholesale bicycle shop in Copenhagen, then in the United States in shipbuilding and bicycle plants, stepped quietly the other day into the presidency of General Motors and the leadership of an army of 275,000 men and women.

The newspaper Mercurio's naval expert says that, in view of the naval policy being followed by other South American countries, Chile must delay no longer the purchase of modern cruisers, destroyers and other units to replace war vessels too old to be of practical service in case of armed conflict.

Members of the Battle Pass Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution are holding their anniversary services this morning at the Flatlands Dutch Reformed Church in Brooklyn. During the morning a historic marker placed by the chapter on the grounds of the church will be unveiled.

Franz Lehar will conduct the opening performance of his operetta "Paganini," C. B. Cochran's lavish production which is opening at the Lyceum May 20. There will be a chorus and ballet numbering ninety-seven, and an orchestra of forty-three.

The country estate of Judge J. J. Young in New Castle, Westchester County, consisting of nineteen acres on the Pines Bridge Road, has been sold to Joseph H. Schwattz of New York City. There are two large houses, one of brick and the other of fieldstone; several farm buildings and a swimming pool on the place.

Miss Miriam Helen Gleeson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Gleeson of South Orange, was married this evening to Richard Griffith, son of Mrs. Clarence E. Pyle of Short Hills, at the home of her parents.

NOW is the time when the motorist who likes plenty of open space and no crowds and doesn't mind a few inconveniences does well to take the north road. Let the luxury-loving brethren and sisters go later. The early visitor finds Nature in one of her best moods.

Princeton's varsity crew, rolling along under lightning-fast conditions on the Schuylkill, came home in front in the Childs Cup race today, leaving Penn and Columbia behind in that order. Thus the Orange and Black at last crowned with victory the weeks of fine rowing it has produced this year.

Mrs. A. Simmel Knerr of Fargo, N. D., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Katherine Knerr of 61 West Ninth Street, to Donald Kinney Angell of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Walter Angell of Cortland, N. Y., and the late Mr. Angell.

Austen G. Fox, for many years a leading member of the New York bar, who had been president of the Harvard Club of New York and the Harvard Alumni Association, died in his home here at 7:30 tonight after several months of failing health. He was 87 years old.
TO tell the story of Glenn Curtiss is to tell, in large part, the story of the beginnings of aviation in the United States: what Curtiss did,

The trend of business was irregular last week, with some sections of the country reporting substantial gains in retail and wholesale trade activity, while in other areas there were no indications of improvement over the previous week. Business generally, however, moved at a much faster pace than in the corresponding period, with some sections showing gains in trade as high as 25 per cent over the 1936 figures, with the South reporting the sharpest increases.

With the opening of the Imperial Conference in London on Friday, local foreign traders were predicting yesterday that negotiations between this country and England for a reciprocal trade treaty will be under way by July.

Thirty-seven per cent of the College of New Rochelle seniors, who chose marriage as their ambition in the class poll early this Spring, will enter the teaching profession upon graduation in June, according to a report submitted this week by Miss Irene M. Wightwick, personnel director of the college.

Owing to the increasing demand for homesites the developers of the village of Munsey Park, formerly the Frank A. Munsey estate on the North Shore of Long Island, are subdividing the Munsey golf course, which will provide an additional sixty-seven acres to the residential community.

A scientific check on the efficiency of trout stream improvement work in Connecticut is being undertaken by Dr. George W. Hunter 3d, Assistant Professor of Biology at Wesleyan University, who is collaborating with Lyle Thorpe, aquatic biologist of the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game.
A barrage of homers rocketed the Newark Bears into the International League's first place today as they gained a twin victory over the champion Bisons, 9-5 and 6-3.

To further the use of water-going aircraft a group of enthusiasts in that branch of aviation, who included private owners, pilots, manufacturers and operators, met at a luncheon at the Columbia University Club last week and formed the Seaplane Flying Association.

THE official register of the genus collector with an account of his habitat and tastes has undergone revision for the eighth time. It emerges as "Holden's Private Book Collectors in the United States and Canada With Mention of Their Hobbies."

A remarkable dialogue on United States neutrality laws, and the prospect of their successful application, took place in Boston, May 8, between A. Lawrence Lowell, President Emeritus of Harvard University, and Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War during the World War.

The outdoor Japanese garden of the Ritz-Carlton will be opened for the season on May 25 with a dinner and dance for the benefit of the Judson Health Center. Dancing will take place in the Oval Room adjoining the garden and bridge tables will be set up in the Palm Court. An entertainment program will be, presented at intervals during the evening.
The reign of "the Malaga cripple," Antonio Martin, who established his independent "commune" at Puigcerda, Catalonia's mountain gateway to France, is ended.

An architectural competition is announced by House Garden in its May issue, being open to all registered architects in the United States. Cash prizes to be awarded total $3,000 and the winner in Class I will receive the commission to design the "Ideal House for 1938."
Wild Bill Cummings, a hometown boy with a heavy foot, left broken Speedway records in his wake today as he won the pole position for the 500-mile automobile race here on May 31.

Chauncey B. Griffen reports substantial improvement in realty activity this season in virtually all sections of Westchester County. During the month of April, he reports that his office closed twelve sales and forty-four leases, which was the largest volume for the Griffen organization since 1929.

The University of Pittsburgh administered the first defeat of the season to Army's athletes today when the Panthers breezed home with plenty to spare in seven of the eight track events contested and broke even in the field events, for a total point score of 72 to Army's 54.

FEATURES of the third week of the Metropolitan Opera Spring season include the revival of Henri Rabaud's "Marouf," with Mario Chamlee in the title role, the appearance of four new artists with the company and the first performance of "Lohengrin."

ACCORDING to recent bulletins from Moscow, Alexander Afinogenoff, author of "Fear," and Vladimir Kirshon, author of "Red Rust," have been expelled from the directorate of the playwrights' section of the Union of Soviet Writers.

WHEN Henry Ford declared history to be bunk, I confess that I did not envy the professors who, whether in self-defense or otherwise, and without requiring in advance a bill of particulars, went to Chicago to refute him.

BONNEVILLE,Ore. THE river rumbles and roars. It thrashes against granite wails and gnaws ominously at basalt cliffs. Around jagged rocks it booms like the surf. Miniature geysers of spray are splashed high in the air. Whirlpools form and break, and form again.
Hardly five minutes after she had been sworn in today as Minister to Norway, Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, New York and Washington society woman, received a first lesson in diplomacy.

Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, revealed today in a report that more than 118,500 persons were employed on WPA conservation projects in the continental United States during the last two. weeks of March, with projects under way in every State.
Art for health's sake has relieved the monotony of white walls in the Indianapolis City Hospital with a complete mural setting. It is the only hospital in America containing an art gallery, says Dr.

THE hiker who selects a marsh as the object of his expedition will find much to interest him in Spring. Even that cozy patch of ground at the edge of Van Cortlanidt Park is representatiye of marsh life.

Transit unification plans are born, have their brief day in the sun and pass into limbo. But the five-cent-fare issue goes on forever. That, apparently, is the moral to be drawn from the Transit Commission's rejection last week of the $436,000,000 unification plan sponsored by Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr.
In the past forty-eight hours the political atmosphere became clearer, at least in Northern Brazil. The strained relations

Miss Kate Davison Rice, daughter of Schuyler Neilson Rice of Highland Park, New Brunswick, N. J., and the late Mrs. Rice, has completed plans for her marriage to Roger Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Whitmore Williams of the Hotel White, this city.

One thousand dollars in cash and some jewels, the value of which was not made known, were recovered from a waste paper consignment to the Robert Gair Company here just before the paper was to be beaten into pulp.

Extension of the power of juvenilecourt judges to include punishment of adults who contribute to delinquency or dependency of minors was urged today by the New York State Association of Judges of Children's Courts.

Two card parties for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys have been planned for May 25 and 26 at the headquarters of the organization in Millington, N. J. The occasions will mark the twenty-first anniversary of the founding of farm by Judge Harry V. Osborne, who was then of the Essex County Common Pleas bench and heard children's cases.

ABSORBING: "We talked about our sons and our grandchildren; yes, and our great-grandchildren, for what more important topic is there?"--Mrs. James Roosevelt. ROD SPARED: "Parents today are not strict enough with their children." --Judge Richard W. Hawkins.

THE airship is doomed." This sentence uttered by- some persons with a sort of "I told you so" shake of the head and by others with regret and disappointment finds no echo in the minds of those government servants and their advisers upon whom the future of lighter-than-air in this Country depends.

Every effort is being made by the National Park Service to reproduce at Wakefield, Westmoreland Coun?? Va., the aspect and environment of the country estate of that name where "The Father of His Country" was born.
FOR those in the forties or about to enter the forties this book will afford amusement and subject for thought. In sonnets, here, Mr. Jones comments whimsically, satirically
FEW highly competent professional soldiers like Colonel Spaulding are at the same time the possessors of a ripe and strenuous scholarship which many academicians might envy in vain.

Fifteen graduating seniors at New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East, were chosen for the school's "Hall of Fame," it was announced at the University yesterday.

ARONSON--WEINSTEIN-Mrs. Philip Silber announces engagement of her sister, Anne Weinstein, 220 West 71t St., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. S. Weinstein, to Mr. David Aronson, 201 West 11th St. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Aronson.

Plans to aid the preservation of Gore Place at Waltham, called "one of the half dozen outstanding houses of the United States," will be made by the American Institute of Architects at its sixty-ninth convention in Boston, June 1 to 4, it was announced by Stephen F. Voorhees of New York, president of the institute.
What is expected to be the largest annual convention of the New Jersey Bankers Association since 1929 will be held in the Hotel Traymore here on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

THERE was a time when it might have been foolhardy for insurance companies to foster publicly a Life Insurance Week. The public, envisioning insurance salesmen on a seven-day rampage. might have been tempted to scurry for cover.

Samuel Finkelstein of New York manufacturer of men's clothing president of Sam Finkelstein Co of Virginia, Inc., 212 Fifth Avenue New York, died here early thi morning in the Atlantic City Hos pital of bronchial pneumonia and the effects of a stroke suffered las week.

A new unit in the chain of Schrafft's restaurants will be opened at 462 Fourth Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-first Street, this week. The decorative scheme is Directoire-Regency, with paneled walls of soft Sahara brown, interspersed with gold-framed mirrors with capitals in bronze-green.

New faces will be visible on the dais and new voices audible on the executive staffs of a number of the largest organizations of women in New Jersey this Autumn as the result of the elections that have been in progress there this month.

Temple University is planning five seprate Summer schools, expecting an enrollment of several thousand. The regular university Summer school of six weeks, from June 28 to Aug. 6, will be preceded and followed by shorter, closely integrated sessions, each of about two and a half weeks.

The Navy won a surprising victory over the University of Richmond nine today, 17 to 0. The Navy opened its heavy scoring in the second when sixy runs were tallied on sigles by Ingram, Gibson and McKay, a triple by Anderson and errors by Garber and Lynch.
CHICAGO will be a gay place this Summer as the 100th anniversary of the city is celebrated. It was incorporated in 1837, at which time it was a settlement of log houses inhabited by 4,000 people.

As a gala closing of its twentysecond season, which has been marked by notable achievements, the Woman's City Club will hold its annual meeting and dinner on Tuesday evening in its new headquarters in the International building in. Rockefeller Center.

SEVENTY-FIVE American artists and about half that number from France, Germany and Mexico are represented, for the most part well and typically by recent examples, in the Ninth Biennial International Exhibition of Water-Color Painting at the Brooklyn Museum (till June 12).

While the Governor and the Secretary of State have quarreled over the terms of a proposed auto drivers' license bill the roll of traffic death in Illinois has steadily increased. Reports for the first three months of 1937 show an increase of 162 fatalities over the total for the same period in 1936.

Plans have been completed by Miss Helen V. Briggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Frank Briggs of South Orange, for her marriage to Lawrence A. Spilman, son of Dr. Harold A. Spilman and Mrs. Spilman of Ottumwa, Iowa.

Dr. Paul Romanoff, curator of the Museum of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, advances a new system for studying biblical and post-biblical Palestinian topography which he believes will be of value to archaeologists.
One of the season's best attended yacht launching took place yesterday afternoon at the Dawn Shipyard, Clason Point, when Commodore Daniel F. B. Hickey's 52-foot Diesel cruiser, Danell,

An analysis of figures in the League of Nations monthly bulletin of statistics, out today, shows that 1937 started with an almost universal rise in the cost of living and with deposits in commercial and savings banks in almost all countries at the highest points in a decade.

Where they failed last year by a scant third of a point, Princeton University's track and field forces succeeded today in Palmer Stadium and scored a stunning upset by turning back Yale's recently crowned Heptagonal Games champions, 74-61.

Retailers as well as manufacturing plants will be picketed in any future strikes of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. This action was decided upon as the twenty-third convention closed here today.

Miss Marie Eugenie Thebaud, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Gibert Thebaud, was married this afternoon to Douglass Mabee Compton, son of Major and Mrs. Ranulf Compton of Madison, Conn., at the home of her parents here. The Rev.

PUERTO CEDENO, Venezuela. ALUXURIOUS airplane recently carried a group of tourists, including one American, from Maracay, Venezuela, over the mountains and the Ilanos to the Orinoco River. It was a history-making flight, inaugurating air tours to an unspoiled wilderness and the picturesque cataracts of that famous stream.

RECKONED in terms of numbers and skill in navigation, the burst of May travel by ship and train and airplane from hereabout is modest compared to the visitation of wild birds now flocking into New York's yards and parks.

POLAND, land-locked except for a tiny opening on the Baltic Sea at Gdynia, is busily preparing for its annual Carnival of the Sea, the "Swieto Morza." On rivers and streams and on the Baltic, water-craft are being trimmed

An experiment designed to trace the history and development of cinematic technique, which was carried on by the City College Film and Sprockets Society ended Friday night with the last showing of the society's film revivals.

With Captain Pete Dominick and Ken Schiffer setting the pace, the Yale varsity polo team turned back Princeton, 9-4, on Devereux Field today. The contest marked the Elis' second triumph in three starts this Spring.

Miss Mary Virginia Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Browning Hamilton of this city, has chosen June 26 as the date for her marriage to Douglass G. Adair Jr. of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass G. Adair of Mobile, Ala. The ceremony will take place in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here.
Direct air-mail, passenger and express service between New York and Denver became effective yesterday, M. F. Redfern, district traffic manager of United Air Lines, disclosed.

Colonel George Grant Seaman, U. S. A. (retired), died early today at the age of 50. He had been a patient in Barnes Hospital since May 1. Colonel Seaman served on the general staff at Washington before his retirement to private life

The public hearing which Governor Lehman will hold this week on the Dog.Racing Bill will throw into higher relief than ever the question of betting, which has been a knotty one in this State ever since Charles Evans Hughes, as Governor, wrote into the Constitution a prohibition against bookmaking and pool selling.

Private James W. Wingard, a recruit temporarily attached to, the Quartermaster Corps at Fort Slocum, was injured fatally tonight in a fist fight with another soldier in front of Barracks 85. The victim, about 23 years old, was a resident of Duquesne, Pa.

THE demand for seats at the forthcoming Bach festival at Bethlehem, Pa., May 28 and 29, is announced as unprecedented at the annual event,, nearly all available seats having been sold by the beginning of April. Requests for reservations have come from some 170 cities and towns, representing eighteen States. Visitors from Canada, France and Germany will attend the four sessions.

Back in the friendly atmosphere of the East with an unsatisfactory invasion of the hostile West behind them, the Yankees looked like champions today as they snatched victory from Connie Mack's Athletics before 17,208 at Shibe Park and crept to within half a game of the league leaders.
